author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement: n/a
remarks: A further piece of advice (cf. oath ids 1367-1370 and 1372): don't swear a false oath by the gods; there is no way of hiding from the gods a debt owed. The type of oath alluded to is one denying that the swearer owes a debt to the swearee.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that whereas "the detested Thessalians and stupid Thebans" regarded Philip as their friend, benefactor and saviour, the Athenians viewed him with suspicion, yet maintained the peace because there was nothing that they could do. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

title: Rhodes and Osborne, GHI
if_taken: They will be eligible to be citizens
if_refused: They will not be eligible to be citizens
statement: [That they shall not bring shame upon the sacred weapons nor shall they desert the man beside them, wherever they stand in the line. They shall fight in defence of things sacred and profane and shall not hand the fatherland on lessened, but greater and better both as far as they are able and with all. And they shall be obedient to whoever exercises power reasonably on any occasion and to the laws currently in force and any reasonably put into force in the future. If anyone attempts to destroy these, they shall refuse to allow him both as far as is in their power and in union with all, and they shall honour the ancestral religion]
gods_invoked: Aglaurus; Hestia; Enyo; Enyalios; Ares; AthenaEpithet(s)Areia; Zeus; Thallo; Auxo; Hegemone; Heracles; The boundaries of my fatherland; Wheat; Barley; Vines; Olives; Figs
remarks:
This inscription was set up in the mid-fourth century by Dio, son of Dio, of Acharnae, the priest of Ares and Athena Areia. He describes the oath as "the ancestral oath of the ephebes".  
Lycurgus referred to the oath "which all citizens swear when they are inscribed into the lexiarchikon grammateion and become ephebes" in his speech against Leocrates. This stone also includes a copy of the oath that the Athenians swore at Plataea in 479 (see oath id 338). 
See also oath id 2740, 2741, 2742, 2743, 3417, 3827.

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
statement: n/a
remarks: Here the violation of oaths is mentioned as one of a list of types of betrayal, together with the violation of solemn pledges and of marriage bonds.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Theocrines
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Epichares argues that it is wrong for those who wish to keep their oaths to reject his endeixis. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he will not go to the Thesmophorion unless Euripides swears to help him if he gets into trouble]
 Ἢν λαλῇς δ’, ὅπως τῷ φθέγματι
  γυναικιεῖς εὖ καὶ πιθανῶς.
{ΚΗ.}  Πειράσομαι. 
 {ΕΥ.}  Βάδιζε τοίνυν. 
  {ΚΗ.}  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω οὔκ
remarks: The condition on which this oath is based (i.e. a formal oath) is considered in the next entry (oath id 711). The two entries should be read in conjunction with each other.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That it is no wonder that Hegesandrus will be appearing for the defence]
 καὶ οὐδὲν μὰ Δία θαυμαστόν
remarks:
Aeschines argues that the fact that Hegesandrus has refused to testify indicates that he will be appearing for the defence. 
He swears that it is no wonder that he will be doing so, saying (evidently with sarcasm) that he will come up to the witness stand trusting in his record as an upright man and an enemy of wickedness.  What Aeschines evidently means the jury to understand is that Hegesandrus will testify (falsely) for the defence because he is utterly shameless, as evidenced by his previous affair with Leodamas - later (111) Aeschines will refer to him as having formerly been "Leodamas' wife". 
See also oath id 2558.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
remarks:
Clearchus said that he could not see why the Persian King who had so many advantages would need, if he really wanted to destroy them, to make an oath and give his right hand and forswear himself by the gods and make his pledges false to both Greeks and barbarians. 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Aeschylus
title: Agamemnon
statement:
[That she will be content with present hardship, but that for the future, the daimon of the Pleisthenids should leave her house and wear away another family with murderous deaths]
  ἐγὼ δ’ οὖν
ἐθέλω δαίμονι τῶι Πλεισθενιδᾶν
ὅρκους θεμένη τάδε μὲν στέργειν
δύστλητά περ ὄνθ’, ὃ δὲ λοιπόν, ἰόντ’
ἐκ τῶνδε δόμων ἄλλην γενεὰν
τρίβειν θανάτοις αὐθένταισιν·
remarks: Clytemnestra swears that she will endure present hardships, and invites the daimon of the Pleisthenids (i.e. the family curse) into a compact with her whereby he will leave the house. But it is not in her power to propose such a compact, and indeed the daimon neither makes a compact with her nor leaves the house.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the Spartans will not give all the locations mentioned (the Hedgehog location, the Malian inlet and the Legs of Megara)]
 Τὸ δεῖνα τοίνυν, παράδοθ’ ἡμῖν τουτονὶ
  πρώτιστα τὸν Ἐχινοῦντα καὶ τὸν Μηλιᾶ
  κόλπον τὸν ὄπισθεν καὶ τὰ Μεγαρικὰ σκέλη.  
{ΛΑ.} Οὐ τὼ σιώ, οὐκὶ πάντα γ’, ὦ λισσάνιε.
remarks: These “locations” are being mapped out on the person of Reconciliation (see Sommerstein ad 1168-70 for details), which helps to explain the Spartan refusal to give them up. Swearing by the Dioscuri is typically Spartan, cf. oath id 1216 for cross references.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That men will not die when they're little children (i.e. if the birds rule)]
 Ἢ παιδάρι’ ὄντ’ ἀποθνῄσκειν δεῖ; 
 {ΠΕ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: The idea is that birds will be able to give humans longer lives by giving them some of their own years; the longevity of the crow was proverbial- see further Sommerstein ad 609.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Italian Locrians
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Italian Locrians
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides states that at the time of the outbreak of war in Sicily in 427, the Locrians in Italy allied themselves with Syracuse.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That Paphlagon had done the same thing to him (i.e. cheating people by selling them rotten ox leather that looked thick but susequently stretched]
 Νὴ Δία κἀμὲ τοῦτ’ ἔδρασε ταὐτόν

author: Andocides
title: Against Alcibiades
date: At the time of the speech ca.417-415 (417 to 415)
statement:
[That they would neither exile, nor imprison, nor put to death anybody without trial]
 ὄμνυτε μηδένα μήτ’ ἐξελᾶν μήτε δήσειν μήτε ἀποκτενεῖν ἄκριτον
remarks:
The author of the speech argues that it is just to blame the author of the law concerning ostracism, since he framed it contrary to the oath of the demos and the boule, to neither exile, nor imprison, nor put to death anybody without trial. 
There is no other evidence that the Athenians swore such an oath. 
There was a clause in the oath of the Boule about not imprisoning anyone (Dem. 24.147; see oath ids 1775 and 3492), and it’s a reasonable supposition that the clause also mentioned the penalties of exile and death, which likewise the Boule had no power to inflict.  So it's quite likely that this is what the author is referring to.  But that wouldn't be relevant to ostracism (in which the Boule had no role), so he smuggles in a reference to the Demos as well.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: They will be eligible to be citizens
if_refused: They will not be eligible to be citizens
statement: [That they shall not bring shame upon the sacred weapons nor shall they desert the man beside them, wherever they stand in the line. They shall fight in defence of things sacred and profane and shall not hand the fatherland on lessened, but greater and better both as far as they are able and with all. And they shall be obedient to whoever exercises power reasonably on any occasion and to the laws currently in force and any reasonably put into force in the future. If anyone attempts to destroy these, they shall refuse to allow him both as far as is in their power and in union with all, and they shall honour the ancestral religion]
gods_invoked: Aglaurus; Hestia; Enyo; Enyalios; Ares; Athena; Zeus; Thallo; Auxo; Hegemone; Heracles; The boundaries of my fatherland; Wheat; Barley; Vines; Olives; Figs
remarks:
Demosthenes catalogues various speeches Aeschines made in 348/7, including when he read out "the oath of the ephebes in the precinct of Aglaurus". 
See also oath id 340.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Lycurgus urges the jurors not to listen to those who digress from the point (following the example of trials before the Areopagus where such digressions are forbidden). He says that if they heed his advice, "defendants will receive an impartial hearing, prosecutors will be least able to give false information, and you will be best able to vote in accordance with your oath". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Mantitheus concludes by asking the jurors to decide what they think is most just on the basis of the laws, their oaths, and the admissions Boeotus has made. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
The Corinthian envoy to Sparta argues that the fact that Apollo has encouraged the Spartans to go to war against Athens (see oath id.1548) indicates that he considers that the Athenians have broken the treaty.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That Socrates had said that wrongdoers are wretched and he had been refuted by Polus]
 Καὶ τοὺς ἀδικοῦντας ἀθλίους ἔφην εἶναι ἐγώ, καὶ ἐξηλέγχθην ὑπὸ σοῦ.  {ΠΩΛ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That if "Cleon" threatens him, he will sing another insulting verse about him]
 ἐγὼ δέ γε, 
 ἐὰν ἀπειλῇ, νὴ Δί’ ἑτέραν ᾄσομαι.
remarks: Bdelycleon is pretending to be Cleon here, singing "Harmodius", which Philocleon is supposed to take up.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Androtion
statement:
[That although Androtion has been offensive in his public conduct he has done other things well]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία ταῦτα μὲν τοιοῦτός ἐστιν ἐν οἷς πεπολίτευται, ἄλλα δ’ ἔσθ’ ἃ καλῶς διῴκηκεν.
remarks: Diodorus outlines Androtion's offensive actions in the past, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his argument.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That those who clamoured for a trial to decide whether Euripides or Aeschylus was better at his craft were the criminals]
 ἀλλ’ ὁ δῆμος ἀνεβόα κρίσιν ποεῖν 
  ὁπότερος εἴη τὴν τέχνην σοφώτερος.
  ΞΑ.  Ὁ τῶν πανούργων;
  ΟΙ.  Νὴ Δί’, οὐράνιόν γ’ ὅσον.
remarks: Euripides is supported by the criminals in Hades, Aeschylus by the decent folk (at 783). See Sommerstein ad 738 on the identity of the slave.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Nicostratus
statement:
[That whereas Chariades did none of these things, he did administer Nicostratus' property]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία ἐπειδὴ τούτων οὐδὲν ἐποίησε, τὴν οὐσίαν τοῦ Νικοστράτου διεχείρισεν.
remarks: The speaker hypothesises that someone might object that while Chariades did not administer the customary rites after Nicostratus' death, he did administer Nicostratus' property. In the next sentence, and also later (26), he claims that witnesses have testified (presumably during an earlier speech - the surviving speech is a supplementary one) to the falsity of the imaginary objector's assertion.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That poverty is a charming thing to take pride in]
 τί γὰρ σύ, ἔφη, ὦ Χαρμίδη, ἐπὶ τίνι μέγα φρονεῖς; Ἐγὼ αὖ, ἔφη, ἐπὶ πενίᾳ μέγα φρονῶ. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, ἐπ’ εὐχαρίτῳ γε πράγματι.
remarks: This statement would be ironic in most people’s mouths, but Socrates really means it!

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Aeschines mentions the alliance between Athens and Chalcis (341/0) and the one between Athens and Thebes (339/8) and says that he will refer to both later. 
Several of its provisions are mentioned by Aeschines 3.142-3:  that Athens would help Thebes against any (Boeotian) city that defected from her leadership; that two-thirds of the cost of the war should be paid by Athens, one-third by Thebes; and certain provisions about the naval and military command (behind Aeschines' hostile presentation of these we may perhaps perceive a provision that both the sea and land commands should be shared between the two states, with Athens having the greater say at sea and Thebes on land). 
See also oath id 2514, 2516, 2675, 2704, 2705, 2706, 2717, 2718, 3390, 3876, 3877, 3879, 3881, 3882.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the Inlaw is a rogue]
 Πανοῦργος εἶ νὴ τὴν Ἑκάτην τὴν φωσφόρον.
remarks: The is a response to the Inlaw quoting Euripides' 'Helen' as if he were the title character. Sommerstein notes ad loc.: "this women's oath is also found in Lys. 443, 738 [see oath ids 1176 and 1192]. It is unlikely to be a coincidence that one of the only two known mentions of Hecate Phosphorus in tragedy is in 'Helen' (569)'.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_taken: Their statement will carry greater weight
statement:
[That neither Helen, nor the goods claimed were with them, but were instead in Egypt with King Proteus]
 μὴ μὲν ἔχειν Ἑλένην μηδὲ τὰ ἐπικαλεόμενα χρήματα, ἀλλ’ εἶναι αὐτὰ πάντα ἐν Αἰγύπτῳ
remarks: For the same oath sworn by the Trojans before the Greeks besieged their city see oath id 1287.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
statement:
[That they would release Cleomenes and all the men with him]
 τῇ δὲ τρίτῃ Κλεομένην μὲν καὶ τοὺς μετ’ αὐτοῦ 
πάντας ἀφεῖσαν ὑποσπόνδους
remarks: This truce came about after Cleomenes attempted to take control of Athens, but the council resisted and he and his supporters fled to the Acropolis, where the people besieged them for two days, but made this truce on the third. Cf. Herodotus 5.72 (oath id 1336).

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Same oath as id 316. Here Menelaus agrees that the Greeks and Trojans should take the oath, adding the condition that Priam should come so that he himself will "cut the oath" (this important and formulaic phrase implies that the slaughter of the animal was a crucial element of the oath), since his children are arrogant and untrustworthy.

author: Pindar
title: Paean 6
statement:
[That Neoptolemus would never get home nor reach old age]
 ὤ̣[μο]σε [γὰρ θ]εός, 
γέ[ρον]θ̣’ ὅ̣[τι] Πρίαμον 
π[ρ]ὸς ἑρκεῖον ἤναρε βωμὸν ἐ[π‐
  εν]θορόντα, μή νιν εὔφρον’ ἐς οἶ[κ]ον 
μ̣ήτ’ ἐπὶ γῆρας ἱξέ‐
  μεν βίου·
remarks: Apollo's oath is a response to Neoptolemus' sacrilegious slaughter of Priam at the altar of Zeus during the Trojan war. Pindar proceeds to tell us that Apollo then slew Neoptolemus while he was quarreling over honours in Apollo's sanctuary.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Peloponnesians and Ambraciots were able to withdraw from Oeniadae
statement: [? That they would not molest the Peloponnesians and Ambraciots while they withdrew]
remarks:
Thucydides states that after the withdrawal of the Athenian forces that were helping the Acarnanians and Amphilochians, these made a truce with the Peloponnesian and Ambraciots who had taken refuge at Oeniadae with Salynthius the king of the Agraeans.  
See also oath id 1633.

author: Plato
title: Philebus
statement:
[That a person who is in an intermediate state between pleasure and distress cannot be said to be in a state of either whole distress or whole pleasure]
 Πότερον ἀλγοῦνθ’ ὅλως ἢ χαίροντα; {ΠΡΩ.} Μὰ Δί’
remarks: The “intermediate state”  is one in which a person in pain from (e.g.) hunger or thirst is thinking of the pleasures of eating or drinking that would end that pain, but has not yet actually begun replenishing himself.  Protarchus says that such a person actually has a double grief (physical pain and mental longing).  He is not, therefore, actually denying that the person is “in a state of … whole distress”; he is rejecting that proposition because it understates the truth!  Socrates then argues that Protarchus’ claim is only true when the person has no expectation of being able to satisfy his desire.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That he will not hide behind his shield, but will say what he thinks on behalf of the Spartans]
 Ἀμέλει μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐκ ἐνασπιδώσομαι, 
  λέξω δ’ ὑπὲρ Λακεδαιμονίων ἃ ’μοὶ δοκεῖ.
remarks: The Chorus' response to Dicaeopolis is in dochmiacs, a tragic metre rarely used in comedy. Here it serves to heighten the tension, as noted by Sommerstein ad loc. with further detail.

author: Aristophanes
title: Danaides
statement: unknown
remarks: This oath is unusual in that it is sworn by a sacred object rather than a sacred being. Cf. e.g. Iliad 1.233-246 at oath id 312. The reference to Lynceus in fr. 272 suggests that the play is set in Argos. For another oath by Zeus Herkeios, see oath id 1509.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
remarks: Aeschylus, while accepting that Euripides did not invent the story of Phaedra, continues to argue that it is the duty of the poet to conceal what is evil (and even if, as here, it is already in the public domain, he should avoid giving it further publicity). See further Sommerstein ad 1053-56.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Minor
statement:
[That a deceitful man would tell as many lies about arithmetic calculation as about other things]
  Ὁ ψευδὴς οὖν πότερον περὶ μὲν τἆλλα ψευδής ἐστιν, οὐ μέντοι περὶ ἀριθμόν, οὐδὲ ἀριθμῶν ἂν ψεύσαιτο; {—ΙΠ.} Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία περὶ ἀριθμόν.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus asks the jurors whether they can see any advantage to the polis in a law that overrides the decisions of the courts and requires unsworn people to cancel the judgements of sworn juries. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement:
[That Aphobus acknowledged that Milyas was free and that he testified against Demon]
 τὸν ἄνθρωπον ὡς ὡμολόγησας ἐλεύθερον εἶναι καὶ κατὰ Δήμωνος ἐμαρτύρησας
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that Aphobus initially asked for Milyas to be interrogated regarding 30 minas, but later claimed that he should be interrogated regarding the whole amount. 
Demosthenes knew this, and confronted Aphobus offering to make a deal. According to the deal, Demosthenes would hand over the man who had the copy of the challenge Aphobus made, and swear that Aphobus acknowledged that Milyas was free and that he testified against Demon. After he did so, if Aphobus would swear by his daughter (see oath id 3524) to the contrary, Demosthenes would then give up to Aphobus (after interrogation of the slave) the entire sum Aphobus asked for at the beginning. 
Thus, the payment Aphobus has been forced to make to Demosthenes would be reduced by the amount he claimed Milyas knew about (30 minae), and he would not suffer as a result of false-witnesses. 
However, Aphobus refused the challenge. 
Although it is not made clear here, Demosthenes states at 57 that he swore the oath himself, as did the witnesses. See also oath id 3526, 3528.

title: IC IV
if_taken: He will be believed (unless the pledgee also swears)
statement: [? That he had discharged his debt (and so was entitled to have his pledge returned)]
remarks:
This text concerns disputes over pledged property. If both swear, the pledgee (i.e. the debtor) wins the case. 
See also oath id 1009.

author: Hypereides
title: In defence of Euxenippus
statement:
[That he has not resorted to using supporting speakers]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία αὐτὸς τοιούτωι πράγματι οὐ κέχρησαι.
remarks: Hypereides is introducing an imaginary objection by his opponent, who is supposed to claim (falsely) that he had never made use of supporting speakers, and is then reminded that he did just that when prosecuted by Alexander of Oeum - and that Hypereides was one of them!

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Thebans were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That he would ensure his troops did not molest the Thebans while they collected their dead]
remarks:
Xenophon states that after the battle at Coronea the Thebans sent heralds to Agesilaus asking to be able to bury their dead under a truce. 
See also oath id 1929.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Wealth really is blind]
 Τυφλὸς γὰρ ὄντως ἐστί; 
  {ΧΡ.}  Νὴ τὸν οὐρανόν.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he thinks his father is right in what he has said (that one should refrain from saying what one is not absolutely sure of to avoid being disbelieved in the future) ]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, ὦ πάτερ, καλῶς μοι δοκεῖς λέγειν

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That they think his comedies are good]
 ἐκ τούτου μοι πιστὰ παρ’ ὑμῶν γνώμης ἔσθ’ ὅρκια.
remarks: The oath here is apparently only metaphorical.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That Meidias should not go to prepare entertainment for him]
 Οὔ, μὰ Δί’ <you shan't go to prepare entertainment for me>
remarks:
After Meidias allowed Dercylidas into Skepsis, the latter then demanded that Meidias allow him entry to the city of Gergis. Dercylidas then sacrificed to Athena, and announced that Meidias' bodyguard should lay down their arms since Meidias now had nothing to fear. 
Meidias, not knowing what to do, offered to prepare hopsitality for Dercylidas, who said, "No by Zeus, since it would be shameful for me to entertained by you after having sacrificed, rather than to entertain you".

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
statement: n/a
remarks:
Aeschines states that when Demosthenes is lying he first swears an oath by his shameless eyes. 
See also oath id 651.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Highlights the Informer's indignation at such a suggestion
statement:
[That he has not learned any trade]
 τέχνην τιν’ ἔμαθες;  
  {ΣΥ.}  Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That people say Socrates does not concern himself with the gods but with utterly useless things]
 Οἶσθα οὖν, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, μετεωρότερόν τι τῶν θεῶν; Ἀλλ’ οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ τούτων σε λέγουσιν ἐπιμελεῖσθαι, ἀλλὰ τῶν ἀνωφελεστάτων.

author: Plato
title: Theages
statement:
[That he would go to none other than the horse-masters if he desired to become wise in the art of horsemanship]
 Τί οὖν εἰ τὰ ἱππικὰ ἐτύγχανες ἐπιθυμῶν σοφὸς γενέσθαι; παρὰ τίνας ἂν ἀφικόμενος ᾠήθης δεινὸς ἔσεσθαι ἱππεύς; ἦ παρ’ ἄλλους τινὰς ἢ τοὺς ἱππικούς; {ΘΕ.} Μὰ Δία οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Euripides
title: Melanippe the Wise
statement: unknown
remarks: What is sworn does not survive in the fragments.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
if_taken: Artyphius will feel safe to appear before the king
if_refused: Artyphius will not feel safe to appear before the king
statement: [That his safety in the presence of the king is assured]
remarks: Artyphius is captured by this deceitful oath, broken by the king who is urged on by his wife Parysatis. Artyphius is thrown into the dust as is Arsites, and both are killed, although Darius had been reluctant to kill Arsites his brother. Cf. oath id 3464 for a comparable assurance of safety which is broken, and oath id 3459 for a woman's  influence in making a man break his oaths.

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Megalopolitans
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
In opposition to those who argue that the Megalopolitans should prove that they will be reliable allies for Athens by destroying the stelai recording their alliance with Thebes (assuming for the sake of argument that these stelai actually exist - which the Megalopolitans deny), Demosthenes argues that Athens should simultaneously demand that the Megalopolitans destroy the stelai and that the Spartans maintain the peace, and that if either side rejects the demand made of it, Athens should support the other. 
Demosthenes goes on to argue that if the Megalopolitans still cling to their alliance with the Thebans it will be obvious to all that they prefer the ambition of Thebes to the claims of justice.  
For the formation of the alliance between the Arcadians and Thebes cf. Diodorus 15.62.3.

author: Sappho
title: Fragments
statement:
[That she would always be a virgin hunting on the peaks of mountains]
  Ἄρτεμις δὲ  θέων  ]μέγαν ὄρκον ἀπώμοσε
νὴ τὰν σὰν κεϕά ]λαν· ἄϊ πάρθενος ἔσσομαι 
ἄδμης οἰπό]λ̣ων ὀρέων κορύφα̣ι̣σ’ ἔπι 
θηρεύοισ’... ]
remarks: This fragment (= Alc. 304 L.-P.), like oath ids 409, 1358, 1363, contains a female goddess swearing by Zeus' head, here described as the "mighty oath of the gods". Cf. oath id 160.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Eretria. 
The decree states that the representatives of each polis will swear their "traditional oath". The Athenian boule was to elect ten men (five from the boule and five private citizens) to receive the oaths of the Eretrians. 
For the oath of the Athenians see oath id 300.

title: SEG
if_taken: They could take office in the boule
if_refused: They could not take office in the boule
remarks:
This oath is an addition to the bouleutic oath. Each new bouleutes now also swore: "If someone coins money of silver in the poleis, or uses coins, weights, or measures on than those of Athens, I shall punish him and impose fines on him".  
([ἐὰν τις κόπτηι] νόμισμα ἀργυρίο ἐν [ταῖσι πόλεσιν ἢ χρῆται νομίσμ]α̣τι ἄλλωι τῶι Ἀθηνα[ίων ἢ σταθμοῖς καὶ μέτροις ἄλ]λ̣οις ἢ τοῖς Ἀθηναίων κ[αὶ τιμωρήσομαι καὶ ζημιώσω].) 
This addition to the oath predates that in IG I(3) 1453 from Smyrna (see oath id 278). Presumably the terms recorded here were found to be not sufficiently precise and were soon after altered to the form preserved in the text from Smyrna. 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
When relating the history of the island of Sicily, Thucydides describes how the Phoenicians had many settlements along the coast of the island, but abandoned most of these settlements when the Greeks began crossing to Sicily in large numbers. 
Thucydides observes that the Phoenicians settled together in Motya, Soloeis and Panormus near to where the Elymi (i.e. the Sicanians who were said to be the descendants of the Trojans who escaped from the Achaeans) dwelt. 
Thucydides notes that the Phoenicians chose this location partly because the voyage from Sicily to Carthage is shortest there, and partly because they trusted their alliance with the Elymi.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
impact: No real impact - Euripides continues with the pretence.
statement:
[That anyone taking the Inlaw away will be crying soon, when he gets hit with the torch]
 Κλαύσετ’ ἄρα νὴ τὼ θεὼ 
  ὅστις σ’ ἀπάξει τυπτόμενος τῇ λαμπάδι.
remarks: On swearing by the two goddesses, see oath id 713.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
statement:
That Athenian statesmen like Aristides and Themistocles were worthy advisers and leaders for Athens, and not rogues such as these men i.e. Demosthenes and his co-defendants, who have done nothing nor will do anything of value for the polis, but only look after their own safety and make money from all quarters]
 ἐκεῖνοι ἦσαν, ἐκεῖνοι ὦ Ἀθηναῖοι ἄξιοι σύμβουλοι καὶ ἡγεμόνες ὑμῶν καὶ τοῦ δήμου, μὰ Δί’ οὐ τὰ τοιαῦτα κινάδη, οἳ πεποιήκασιν μὲν οὐδὲν οὐδὲ πράξουσιν ἀγαθὸν ὑπὲρ τῆς πόλεως, τὴν δ’ ἑαυτῶν ἀσφάλειαν τηροῦντες καὶ παντ<αχ>όθεν ἀργυριζόμενοι καὶ πεποιηκότες τὴν πόλιν ἀδοξοτέραν ἑαυτῶν,

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement: n/a
remarks:
Here Socrates explains that concord is deemed the greatest of blessings for cities and that everywhere in Greece, citizens are asked to swear to be of one mind, and everywhere they take this oath. The unanimity (homonoia), says Socrates, is unanimous willingness to obey the laws (not unanimity on the best choruses or aulos-players or poets).  
"Everywhere" must be a vast exaggeration, but we can reasonably take this passage as evidence that such oaths existed in a number of poleis, especially perhaps in those which had experienced a period of civil strife.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Tyrannus
if_broken: May they suffer the worst fate, dying godless and friendless
impact: Seems to convince Oedipus against killing Creon
statement:
[That the Chorus are not seeking Oedipus' death or exile from the land]
 Οι. εὖ νυν ἐπίστω, ταῦθ’ ὅταν ζητῇς, ἐμοὶ
ζητῶν ὄλεθρον ἢ φυγὴν ἐκ τῆσδε γῆς.
Χο. οὐ τὸν πάντων θεῶν θεὸν πρόμον 
῞Αλιον· ἐπεὶ ἄθεος ἄφιλος ὅ τι πύματον
ὀλοίμαν, φρόνησιν εἰ τάνδ’ ἔχω.
remarks: All but one of the oaths referred to in this play (id 1979) have to do with persuading Oedipus against thinking or acting irrationally. The informal oath formula ou + acc. is not common and seems to appear for the most part in Sophoclean lyrics; cf. oath ids 1979, 1980 (cf. also id 240 emended to 'ma'), and id 1978 (iambics).

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of King Croesus ca.560-546 (560 to 546)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: According to Herodotus, Croesus agreed to be friends with the Ionians of the islands (Καὶ οὕτω τοῖσι τὰς νήσους οἰκημένοισι Ἴωσι ξεινίην συνεθήκατο). Presumably this was a sworn alliance.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: The girls begin to make piglike squealing noises
statement:
[That he will take the girls back home if they don't start making pig vocalizations]
  Φώνει δὴ τὺ ταχέως, χοιρίον.  
 Οὐ χρῆσθα; Σιγῇς, ὦ κάκιστ’ ἀπολουμένα; 
 Πάλιν τ’ ἀποισῶ ναὶ τὸν Ἑρμᾶν οἴκαδις.

author: Aristotle
title: Politics
statement:
[That perhaps it is clear that in certain collectivities it can't possibly be true that the many have more intelligence than the few]
 εἰ μὲν οὖν περὶ πάντα δῆμον καὶ περὶ πᾶν πλῆθος ἐνδέχεται ταύτην εἶναι τὴν διαφορὰν τῶν πολλῶν πρὸς τοὺς ὀλίγους σπουδαίους, ἄδηλον, ἴσως δὲ νὴ Δία δῆλον ὅτι περὶ ἐνίων ἀδύνατον
remarks: The concept being discussed here is that the many have more intelligence than the few because there are more of them, and a collective judgement will be better than the judgement of a few regardless of intelligence.  But this may not always be true, and in some cases it most certainly is not.  For example, many animals will not have more intelligence than a few men - and, Aristotle adds, there are some humans who to all intents and purposes are no better than animals.  However, he immediately goes on to say that a blanket rejection of the "wisdom of crowds" principle would be equally unjustified.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That (he thinks) Strepsiades is out of his mind]
  οὐκ εὖ φρονεῖς, μὰ τὸν Δία τὸν Ὀλύμπιον.
remarks: Strepsiades ridicules the invocation of Zeus.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Andocides says to the jurors, "I am reminding you of what happened, men who have sworn great oaths before casting your votes in my case, and invoked the greatest curses on yourselves and your children, (swearing) that you would vote justly in my case. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
statement:
[That the truth they hear from Socrates will not be expressed in elegant language such as his accusers have used]
 ὑμεῖς δέ μου ἀκούσεσθε πᾶσαν τὴν ἀλήθειαν—οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, κεκαλλιεπημένους γε λόγους, ὥσπερ οἱ τούτων

author: Aeschylus
title: Hypsipyle
if_taken: They would be allowed to land
if_refused: They would not be allowed to land
impact: Argonauts have intercourse with the Lemnian women
statement: [That they would have intercourse with the women as soon as they landed]
remarks: This is not, strictly speaking, a fragment of Aeschylus but it is a firm statement about the plot of his Hypsipyle which comes from a scholium on Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica 1.769-773.  In Aeschylus' play, according to this scholium, when the Argonauts were caught in a storm off Lemnos and hoping to come in and land there, the Lemnian women 'came against them in arms' and refused to let them put in unless they swore to have intercourse with the women as soon as they landed.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
impact: Xerxes was forced to give Artaynte the cloak woven for him by his wife
statement:
[That he would give Artaynte whatever she asked]
 δώσεις μοι τὸ ἄν σε αἰτήσω; ὁ δὲ πᾶν μᾶλλον δοκέων κείνην αἰτῆσαι ὑπισχνέετο καὶ ὤμοσε·
remarks:
According to Herodotus, Xerxes' wife Amestris wove and gave to him a great and subtly coloured cloak. 
When Xerxes was wearing this cloak he went to see his lover, Artaynte (the wife of his son Darius) and being pleased with her offered to give her whatever she wanted in return for the favours she had given to him. 
When Artaynte asked  Xerxes "will you give me whatever I ask?", he promised and swore to do so thinking that she would ask for anything except what she did; she asked for the cloak.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Onetor 2
statement:
[That not all Onetor's actions were of that sort]
Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’ ἴσως οὐχὶ πάντ’ αὐτῷ τοιαῦτα πέπρακται,
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that someone will respond in this way to his description of Onetor's conduct.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she would be willing to join Lysistrata if she finds a plan for bringing the war to an end]
 Ἐθέλοιτ’ ἂν οὖν, εἰ μηχανὴν εὕροιμ’ ἐγώ,
  μετ’ ἐμοῦ καταλῦσαι τὸν πόλεμον;
{ΚΛ.}  Νὴ τὼ θεὼ
remarks: On swearing by Demeter and Persephone, see oath id 788.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That a statement that beautiful customs and laws are beautiful because they are pleasant to sight or hearing will not pass unnoticed and uncriticized by the person by whom Socrates would be most ashamed to be caught talking nonsense]
 Ταῦτα δ’ ἴσως, ὦ Σώκρατες, κἂν παραλάθοι τὸν ἄνθρωπον.  {ΣΩ.} Μὰ τὸν κύνα, ὦ Ἱππία, οὐχ ὅν γ’ ἂν ἐγὼ μάλιστα αἰσχυνοίμην ληρῶν καὶ προσποιούμενός τι λέγειν μηδὲν λέγων.
remarks: It turns out that this person is Socrates himself. For other instances of Socrates invoking "the dog", see oath id 2548.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That Timocrates' objective, in proposing that the nomothetai should sit the next day, was not to ensure that some matter relating to the Panathenaea should be properly dealt with (but to ensure that there was no time to study properly, or to organise opposition to, the law he would be proposing)]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχ ἵν’ ὡς κάλλιστα γένοιτό τι τῶν περὶ τὴν ἑορτήν

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
if_taken: They can compete freely for Helen's hand
if_refused: Exclusion from the competition for Helen's hand
statement:
[That they would support whoever became Helen's husband should someone take her from the house, that they would all march against him and sack his city with force of arms, be he Greek or Asiatic]
 ὅρκους συνάψαι δεξιάς τε συμβαλεῖν
  μνηστῆρας ἀλλήλοισι καὶ δι’ ἐμπύρων
  σπονδὰς καθεῖναι κἀπαράσασθαι τάδε· 
  ὅτου γυνὴ γένοιτο Τυνδαρὶς κόρη,
  τούτωι συναμυνεῖν, εἴ τις ἐκ δόμων λαβὼν
  οἴχοιτο τόν τ’ ἔχοντ’ ἀπωθοίη λέχους,
  κἀπιστρατεύσειν καὶ κατασκάψειν πόλιν
  ῞Ελλην’ ὁμοίως βάρβαρόν θ’ ὅπλων μέτα.
remarks: This oath is mentioned several times in the play, cf. oath ids 183, 184, 185.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That no one can show that Aeschylus ever created a female character in love]
 οὐδ’ οἶδ’ οὐδεὶς ἥντιν’ ἐρῶσαν πώποτ’ ἐποίησα γυναῖκα.
  ΕΥ.  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: Euripides here agrees with Aeschylus quite emphatically, implicity defending the validity of portraying female characters consumed by a passionate love. See also Sommerstein ad 1043 and 1044 for more details.

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the Opuntian Locrians
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the Opuntian Locrians
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Isocrates argues that no thanks to the Persian King, but thanks to Conon, and thanks to "the alliance formed at Corinth", the Spartans were defeated at Cnidus. 
See also oath id 2835.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he keeps the gods as his friends in a very simple way]
 πῶς αὐτοὺς θεραπεύων οὕτω φίλους ἔχεις. Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἑρμογένης, καὶ μάλα εὐτελῶς.
remarks: He explains as follows: he sings their praises (which costs nothing), he always gives them back part of what they bestow on him, he avoids profane speech as much as he can, and he never lies when he has invoked them as witnesses (see oath id 2262).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he will not stop]
  Στῆθ’, ἀντιβολῶ σε, στῆθι. 
  {ΒΛ.}  Μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ μὲν οὔ.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
statement: [? That they would not make an attack on each other or the allies of each other]

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he will take care of the tip of his tail (i.e. penis)]
 τὴν κέρκον φυλάττου νυν ἄκραν. 
  {ΚΗ.}  Ἐμοὶ μελήσει νὴ Δία

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
After being pressured by their Argive allies, the Athenians were convinced by Alcibiades to inscribe at the bottom of the Laconian stele that the Spartans had not kept their oaths; they then took a force of Messenian helots to Pylos to ravage Spartan-controlled territory. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Chalcidians in Thrace
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Chalcidians in Thrace
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that immediately after the Eleans became allies of Argos (see oath id 1697), the Chalcidians in Thrace, and the Corinthians (see oath id 1698) also became allies of Argos. 
For other references to this alliance and its impact see oath id 1752. See also oath id 1826.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Acarnania under the auspices of the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
The decree indicates that three or five Athenians were to be chosen to receive the oaths of the new allies (see also oath id 355 and 357). For the oath of the Athenians see oath id 353. For the oath of the existing allies of Athens see oath id 354. 
For other references to the Second Athenian Confederacy see oath id 2974.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Aphrodite
impact: Zeus grants her privileges instead of marriage
statement:
[That she would be a virgin for all time]
 ὤμοσε δὲ μέγαν ὅρκον, ὃ δὴ τετελεσμένος ἐστίν
ἁψαμένη κεφαλῆς πατρὸς Διὸς αἰγιόχοιο 
παρθένος ἔσσεσθαι πάντ’ ἤματα, δῖα θεάων.
remarks: Other deities swear by the head of Zeus. Cf. oath ids 1334, 1358 and also 160.

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker states that the reason a financial penalty was imposed for breaking the law concerning the oaths of reconciliation was that anyone who was audacious enough to rake up old grudges should not only be convicted of perjury, but should also suffer an immediate penalty and not merely await punishment by the gods. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Taurus son of Echetimidas; Athenaeus, son of Pericleidas; Philocharidas; Aeneas son of Ocytus; Euphamidas son of Aristonymus; Damotimus son of Naucrates; Onasimus, son of Megacles; Nicasus, son of Cecalus; Menecrates son of Amphidorus; Amphias son of Eupalidas; Nicostratus; Nicias; Autocles, son of Tolmaeus
swearee: Taurus son of Echetimidas; Athenaeus, son of Pericleidas; Philocharidas; Aeneas son of Ocytus; Euphamidas son of Aristonymus; Damotimus son of Naucrates; Onasimus, son of Megacles; Nicasus, son of Cecalus; Menecrates son of Amphidorus; Amphias son of Eupalidas; Nicostratus; Nicias; Autocles, son of Tolmaeus
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Free access to the oracle at Delphi (the Spartans promised to try to persuade the Boeotians and Phocians about this)
2. Those who had misused the treasures at Delphi were to be sought out
3. Each side should retain what territory it currently possessed (the Athenian garrison at Pylos should keep within the coastal high points Buphras and Tomaeus; the Athenian garrison in Cythera should have no communication with the territory of the Spartan allies; the Athenian garrison in Nisaea and Minoa should not cross the roads leading to the mainland and the Megarians should not cross it either; the Athenians should retain the island [Atalante?] which they took and neither side shall communicate with the other; the Athenians should retain whatever territory they possessed in Troezen in accordance with the agreements which the Troezenians had made with the Athenians)
4. The Spartans and their allies were not permitted to sail in oared ships except along their own coasts, and then only in vessels of less than 500 metra capacity not designed for use in war
5. Deserters should not be received
6. Any disputes should be resolved by arbitration]
remarks:
Thucydides describes here the one year armistice between Athens and Sparta in 423. 
The Athenian swearers were all generals. It seems likely that the Peloponnesians who swore the oath were also power-holders. 
Thucydides also quotes the Athenian decree proposed by Laches which endorsed the armistice. 
For other references to this oath and its impact, see oath id 1677, 1678 and 1680.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
if_refused: Peisetaerus will not reveal his plan
if_kept: The chorus will be judged victorious by all the judges and the audience
if_broken: The chorus will win by just one vote
impact: Peisetaerus disarms and reveals his plan
statement: [That the Chorus will not bite Peisetaerus nor pull at his balls, nor poke him in the eyes ]
remarks: This is a reference to the pact made between the chorus and Peisetaerus at oath id 642.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the chorus-leader is quite right to tell the Athenians to pick up their cloaks to make sure they are not seen by any of the Hermclipper family]
 Εἰ σωφρονεῖτε, θαἰμάτια λήψεσθ’, ὅπως 
  τῶν ἑρμοκοπιδῶν μή τις ὑμᾶς ὄψεται
{ΑΘ. α}  Νὴ τὸν Δί’ εὖ μέντοι λέγεις.
{ΛΑ.}  Ναὶ τὼ σιὼ
remarks: The Athenian and the Spartan both use an oath formula to agree with what the Chorus-leader has said. The Athenian invokes Zeus, the Spartan the Dioscuri (cf. oath id 1216 with cross references). The "Hermclipper family" refers to "those who had been responsible, in 415, for the mutilation of the faces and the phalli of the pillar-images of Hermes in the streets of Athens" (Sommerstein ad 1094).

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
statement: n/a
remarks: Athena, defending Orestes' right to refuse to swear that he did not kill his mother (see oath id 212), asserts that an unjust case ought not to prevail by means of oaths. Cf. oath id 210.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he cannot name any orators currently active who struggle always to say what is best, whether it be welcome or unwelcome to the hearers]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δία οὐκ ἔχω ἔγωγέ σοι εἰπεῖν τῶν γε νῦν ῥητόρων οὐδένα.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
statement:
[That Boeotus and Pamphilus were sons of Mantias]
 ἡ δὲ δεξαμένη, οὐ μόνον τοῦτον, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸν ἀδελφὸν τὸν ἕτερον πρὸς τούτῳ κατωμόσατ’ ἐκ τοῦ πατρὸς εἶναι τοῦ ἐμοῦ.
remarks: Mantitheus states that as a result of this oath (see also oath id 3567, 3568, 3576, 3581), it was necessary for Boeotus and Pamphilus to be enrolled in the phratry. Mantias enrolled Boeotus under that name, but Boeotus later had himself enrolled in the deme register as Mantitheus.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he wil not answer Euthydemus' question until he finds out exactly what the question means]
 Οὐ τοίνυν μὰ Δία ἀποκρινοῦμαι, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, πρότερον πρὶν ἂν πύθωμαι.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: n/a
remarks: In discussing laws for transactions in the market-place of Magnesia, it is stated the person who swears oaths falsely (presumably with the aim of making profit), disregarding the gods, will be the most hateful to the gods. Cf. oath id 2724.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Epigenes is obliged (to screw her)]
 νὴ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην, δεῖ γε μέντοι σ’·
remarks: According to the new rules, the young man must first "screw" an old or ugly woman before he can "screw" his young girlfriend. The old woman will now read him out this new law; cf. oath id 840.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That she did not look at Cyrus]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἐκεῖνον ἐθεώμην
remarks: This statement is given in response to Tigranes asking his wife if she found Cyrus handsome. She continues to respond to questions in an appropriate manner- cf oath id 2374.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_broken: May he never speak in public again
impact: Provokes the Sausage-seller to swear a counter-oath
statement:
[That the Sausage-seller and his allies will not surpass him in shamelessness]
Οὔτοί μ’ ὑπερβαλεῖσθ’ ἀναιδείᾳ μὰ τὸν Ποσειδῶ, 
ἢ μήποτ’ Ἀγοραίου Διὸς σπλάγχνοισι παραγενοίμην.
remarks: See also the Sausage-seller's counter-oath at id 995.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement:
[That wherever the law is master over the rulers, and the rulers are slaves to the law, there, salvation will come about, and all the blessings which the gods bestow on states]
 ἐν ᾗ δὲ ἂν δεσπότης τῶν ἀρχόντων, οἱ δὲ ἄρχοντες δοῦλοι τοῦ νόμου, σωτηρίαν καὶ πάντα ὅσα θεοὶ πόλεσιν ἔδοσαν ἀγαθὰ γιγνόμενα καθορῶ. {ΚΛ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὦ ξένε·

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement: n/a
remarks: After having his suggested oath rejected by Socrates on the grounds that the school doesn't give gods any recognition (nomisma), Strepsiades has misunderstood Socrates' reply as meaning "we do not regard gods as coins (nomismata)" and therefore deduces that coins and not gods are invoked when taking an oath (on the confusion in meaning see Sommerstein ad loc.). Here Strepsiades asks what coins are required for oath-taking according to the beliefs of the school. On the reference to Byzantium, see Sommerstein ad 248.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: n/a
remarks: Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes pretended that he had heard the news about the death of Philip not from Charidemos, but from Zeus and Athena, the deities by whose names he perjures himself by day, and who then converse with him at night.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Argives and Corinthians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Argives and the Corinthians while they collected their dead]

author: Xenophon
title: Lacedaemonian Politeia (except ch.14)
date: During the experience of Xenophon (399 to 355)
statement:
[That while the kings abide by their oaths, they will keep the kingship unshaken]
 ἐμπεδορκοῦντος ἐκείνου ἀστυφέλικτον τὴν βασιλείαν παρέξειν
remarks:
Xenophon states that every month the Spartan kings and Ephors exchange oaths. 
The kings swear to rule according to the laws of the polis, and the Ephors swear on behalf of the polis that while the kings abide by their oaths they will keep the kingship unshaken. Presumably the ephors were swearing that they would preserve the kingship of the particular king with whom they were exchanging oaths rather than the institution of kingship. 
For the corresponding oath sworn by the kings see oath id 2235; and cf. Plato's Laws- oath id 2679.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he does not think he can have a great sense of his own worth if he has no sense at all yet]
 Οὐδ’ ἄρα μεγαλόφρων εἶ, εἴπερ ἄφρων ἔτι.  Μὰ Δία, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὔ μοι δοκεῖ.
remarks: Lysis is, of course, being led up the garden path by Socrates, since both Socrates and the reader know very well that very many people (including just about every adult that Socrates ever talks to) pride themselves on all sorts of things about which they know nothing.

title: IvO
reference: 23, frag a, line 5; frag b, line 6
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The editor of IvO identified the script as West-Greek and the dialect as Doric. Roehl tentatively suggested that it might have come from Laconia, but that was rejected by the editor of IvO.  
However, the ending -essi, while typically Aeolic, is also found in some north-western dialects, alongside -ois [sic] - and Elean is among them.  And, crucially, the appearance of ζὲ for δὲ is characteristic of early Elean and with one exception is apparently not found in any truly Doric dialect of the Peloponnese.  It follows that the dialect of this inscription is Elean (no later than 550). 
This very fragmentary text contains two references to the taking of oaths. In frag a, line 5, there is a reference to "the oath ceremonies" (τὰ hό[ρκια]), and in frag b, line 5 the text has been restored to read [τ]οῖς εὐhορκεό[ντεσσι], and line 6 has been restored to read τῶι ζὲ hόρ[κωι],  or τοῖζε hορ[ίοις]. Exactly what the benefits for keeping these oaths were cannot be determined with the evidence we have.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Androtion
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus warns the jurors that if they accept Androtion's plea every future boule will find excuses not to build ships. But if they do as the law says, and what is necessary because of their oath - i.e. the reject the appeals of the defendant - then every boule will deliver ships to them. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Symposium
date: When Diotima had delayed the plague for 10 years (440)
statement:
[That he wouldn't dare to say that any of the gods are not beautiful or prosperous] 
 ἢ τολμήσαις ἄν τινα μὴ φάναι καλόν τε καὶ εὐδαίμονα θεῶν εἶναι;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’, ἔφην.
remarks: If 440 is the imaginary date for Socrates’ meeting with Diotima, then Socrates is right on the cusp of “adolescence” and “maturity”, since he was born in 470/69; and he is, of course, very much the pupil in this dialogue.  Cf. especially 201d5 (“she taught me erotics”) with Dover’s note (p.137:  “a slyly humorous reminder of another kind of erotikos logos, in which a smirking youth tells his friends about the accomplishments of a hetaira”).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus tells the jurors that Olympiodorus won the case easily, but refused to split the proceeds, "even though he has given his oath and made an agreement with me that in very truth we should take equal shares" (see oath id 3623). He reminds the jurors that the document concerning the agreement is still in the hands of Androcleides who has testified before them.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That there is indeed another bird approaching]
  Ἕτερος ὄρνις οὑτοσί.  
 {ΕΥ.}  Νὴ Δί’ ἕτερος δῆτα
remarks: Cf. oath id 637.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes alleges that as soon as the peace was concluded, and before Diopeithes had been campaigning in the Chersonese, Philip occupied Serrium and Doriscus, and expelled the Athenian garrison from Serreion Teichos and the Sacred Mount. 
Demosthenes asks what these actions meant, for Philip had sworn to observe the peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That what Praxagora said was a good idea (i.e. to hand over the running of the city to the women)]
  {Γυ. α}  εὖ γ’ εὖ γε νὴ Δί’, εὖ γε.

author: Sophocles
title: Trachiniae
impact: Heracles marches against the land of Eurytus
statement:
[That he would make a slave of the man [Eurytus] who had made him a slave- along with his wife and children] 
 χοὔτως ἐδήχθη τοῦτο τοὔνειδος λαβὼν
ὥσθ’ ὅρκον αὑτῷ προσβαλὼν διώμοσεν, 
ἦ μὴν τὸν ἀγχιστῆρα τοῦδε τοῦ πάθους
ξὺν παιδὶ καὶ γυναικὶ δουλώσειν ἔτι.
remarks: This alleged oath is reported in a narrative by Lichas which is partly true and partly false. Later (354ff.) it will be revealed by another witness that Lichas had himself said previously that the real reason for Heracles' campaign against Oechalia was he had fallen in love with Eurytus' daughter Iole.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1a
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
statement:
[That he will give counsel in accordance with the laws]
 καὶ τὸν βουλευτικὸν ὅρκον ὀμόσας, ἐν ᾧ ἦν κατὰ τοὺς νόμους βουλεύσειν
remarks:
This passage in Xenophon refers to the trial, before the ekklesia, of the generals from the sea-battle at Arginusae who were charged with abandoning the bodies of the dead Athenians there. Socrates, who was the foreman (epistates) of the prytaneis who presided over the ekklesia, was the only one who opposed putting to the vote the illegal motion to condemn Thrasyllus and Erasinides and their colleagues to death as a single group, by a single vote. Acting in this way, against popular demand, and further incurring threats from powerful people, Socrates, Xenophon says, felt bound to honour his bouleutic oath rather than to humour the people's unjust request. Xenophon also discusses this trial in his Hellenica, see oath ids 2004 and 2005.  
For further information on the bouleutic oath, see also remarks on Aristotle's Ath. Pol 22 (oath id 1775).

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
Euxitheus, the defendant, observes that the prosecutor and witnesses are not under oath, and argues that the witnesses should only be allowed to give evidence after taking the preliminary oath (διωμοσία) with their hands on the sacrificial victims. 
It is not true that the prosecutor is "not under oath", since he must have sworn to the truth of his charge in an antomosia.  It is, however, true that he is not under the specially solemn oath that a normal homicide prosecutor would have had to take; cf. oath id 2470.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That those who are afraid when there is nothing to fear are even less courageous than those who are fearless through ignorance]
 Τί δὲ οἱ καὶ τὰ μὴ δεινὰ δεδοικότες; Ἔτι γε νὴ Δί’  ἧττον, ἔφη.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2163.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Adeimantus refers to sunomosiai ("clubs of members who have been sworn in") as part of the way people try to escape the notice of the gods and contrive to overreach with impunity.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That gaining peace after they were losing the war, together with the destruction of their enemies the Phocians and the demolition of their walls and cities, is not all the Thebans have gained from the Peace of Philocrates]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’,

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the same party at Argos which had brought about the peace treaty with Sparta then brought about the renunciation of the alliance with the Mantineans, Eleans and Athenians. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
impact: Provokes Philoctetes into aiming his bow at Odysseus
statement:
[That he, in the name of the Atreidae and the whole army, forbids Neoptolemus from handing Philoctetes back the bow]
 Οδ. ἐγὼ δ’ ἀπαυδῶ γ’, ὡς θεοὶ ξυνίστορες,
ὑπέρ τ’ ᾿Ατρειδῶν τοῦ τε σύμπαντος στρατοῦ.
remarks: Odysseus' oath is true in that he does forbid the action, but his order is ignored.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker cites a clause of the peace that "it shall be the business of the delegates at the Congress and those responsible for public safety to see that in states that are parties to the peace there shall be no executions and banishments contrary to the laws established in those states, no confiscation of property, no partition of lands, no cancellation of debts, and no emancipation of slaves for the purposes of revolution. 
He then argues that those who advocate abiding by the peace are not only failing to prevent any of these evils, but are joining in promoting them. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Pindar
title: Pythian 4
impact: Encourages Jason to leave for his quest
consequences_of_breach: Pelias' murder is contrived by Medea
statement:
[That Pelias will hand over the kingship to Jason if he willingly accomplishes the task of retrieving the golden fleece] 
 τοῦτον ἄεθλον ἑκὼν τέλεσον· καί τοι μοναρχεῖν 
καὶ βασιλευέμεν ὄμνυμι προήσειν. καρτερός
ὅρκος ἄμμιν μάρτυς ἔστω
  Ζεὺς ὁ γενέθλιος ἀμφοτέροις.’
remarks: Pindar ends his retelling of the myth before the return of Jason, and so the issue of Pelias breaking his oath is not addressed, although Pindar does refer to Medea as "the slayer of Pelias" at 251.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Chremylus is not trying to make a pass at her]
  Πειρᾷ μὲν οὖν ἴσως σε καὶ τῶν τιτθίων
  ἐφάπτεταί σου λανθάνειν δοκῶν ἐμέ.
{ΓΡ.}  Μὰ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην, οὐκ ἐμοῦ γ’, ὦ βδελυρὲ σύ.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 1069, swearing by Aphrodite does not indicate, as some have suggested, that the Old Woman is pretending to be young again- see Ecc. 980-981, 999-1000 and 1008 (oath ids 836, 838 and 839) where it is used by a woman who has no need to conceal her age. It is rather an indication of sexual desire.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That to be a qualified supervisor, a man must not only care that the job should be done well, but must also know what must be done, when, and how]
 Ὅταν <δὲ> παραστήσῃς τινί, ἔφην ἐγώ, τοῦτο καὶ πάνυ ἰσχυρῶς, ὅτι δεῖ ἐπιμελεῖσθαι ὧν ἂν σὺ βούλῃ, ἦ ἱκανὸς ἤδη ἔσται ὁ τοιοῦτος ἐπιτροπεύειν, ἤ τι καὶ ἄλλο προσμαθητέον αὐτῷ ἔσται, εἰ μέλλει ἐπίτροπος ἱκανὸς ἔσεσθαι; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος, ἔτι μέντοι λοιπὸν αὐτῷ ἐστι γνῶναι ὅ τι τε ποιητέον καὶ ὁπότε καὶ ὅπως

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
Xenophon states that when King Pausanias marched on the Piraeus, he was accompanied by all the allies except the Corinthians and Boeotians who said that they would not be keeping their oaths if they made a military expedition against the Athenians when they were not doing anything against the treaty. 
Xenophon argues that this was not their real objection. Rather, they feared that the Spartans wanted to make Athenian territory their own reliable dependency. 
For other references to this peace treaty see oath id 1893.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
impact: Provokes the Sausage-seller to rival this claim
statement:
[That he still has a chest full of oracles]
  Καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἔτι γέ μοὐστὶ κιβωτὸς πλέα.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Bouleutai; Chabrias of Aexone; Chares of Angele; Iphicrates of Rhamnous; Execestides; Alcimachus of Anagyrous; Diocles of Alopece
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Carystus. 
The text indicates that the strategoi present in Athens will swear. The name of Chabrias was erased which might suggest that he was not in Athens when the oath was sworn.  
For the corresponding oath of the Carystians see oath id 455.  
See also Dem. 8.74; Diodorus 16.7.2.

author: Eubulus
title: Mylothris
statement:
[That he was really Vinegar (and not Wine)]
 εἶθ’ ὑπώμνυτο
ὁ μὲν οἶνος ὄξος αὑτὸν εἶναι γνήσιον
remarks: Presumably during some official proceedings, Wine swears a hupomosia that he is not who he is seemingly in an attempt not to be drunk. Cf. Vinegar's similar statement at oath id 1462.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That if the Scythian archer touches her even with the tip of his finger, she will make him howl, though he is a public servant]
  Εἰ τἄρα νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν τὴν χεῖρά μοι 
ἄκραν προσοίσει, δημόσιος ὢν κλαύσεται.

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That things seem to be something like Socrates has explained (i.e. that true opinion only becomes knowledge when it is tethered and becomes stable)]
 Νὴ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔοικεν τοιούτῳ τινί.

author: Euripides
title: Supplices
if_broken: The Argive land should be wretchedly destroyed
statement: [That Argives will never bring force of arms against Athens, and if others do, Argos will impede them with her spear]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 140.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Thucydides alleges that Athenians and the Peloponnesians both broke the so-called Thirty Years' Peace treaty. 
For other references to this treaty see oath id 1439, 1525, 1527, 1529, 1530, 1531, 1532, 1533, 1535, 1537, 1538, 1539, 1540, 1547, 1548, 1549, 1550, 1551, 1557, 1558, 1564, 1578, 1579, 1580, 1795, 1894, 2384, 2632, 3731.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds the jurors that Aphobus is prosecuting for false witness, and that they have sworn to give their vote concerning this. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he cannot decide (between the two poets)]
 Νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν σωτῆρα, δυσκρίτως γ’ ἔχω·
remarks: The invocation of Zeus the Saviour is appropriate when Dionysus has said he is choosing a poet "so that the city may be saved" (1419; cf. also 1436, 1501).

author: Hypereides
title: In defence of Lycophron
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Hypereides refers to the Heliastic oath, which he warns the jurors, "orders you to listen equally to the prosecution and defence". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That a foreman without loyalty is useless]
 ἄνευ γὰρ εὐνοίας τί ὄφελος καὶ ὁποίας τινὸς οὖν ἐπιτρόπου ἐπιστήμης γίγνεται; Οὐδὲν μὰ Δί’

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Epigenes will buy the old woman a tiara if it's a wax one]
 ἦ μὴν ἔτ’ ὠνήσει σὺ καὶ στεφάνην ἐμοί. 
 {Επ.}  νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἤνπερ ᾖ γέ που τῶν κηρίνων.
remarks: Sommerstein translates stephane as "tiara" and explains ad 1034: "either the old woman is thinking of the stephane regularly worn by a bride on her wedding day… or she is hoping, as a hetaira might, to receive one as an expensive present from a grateful lover".

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he once had a haggis explode on him]
  νὴ Δί’ ἐγὼ γοῦν ἀτεχνῶς ἔπαθον τουτί ποτε Διασίοισιν.
  ὀπτῶν γαστέρα τοῖς συγγένεσιν κᾆτ’ οὐκ ἔσχων ἀμελήσας,
  ἡ δ’ ἄρ’ ἐφυσᾶτ’, εἶτ’ ἐξαίφνης διαλακήσασα πρὸς αὐτὼ
  τὠφθαλμώ μου προσετίλησεν καὶ κατέκαυσεν τὸ πρόσωπον.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
statement:
[That he would rather fight Megabates off once again than that everything he sees should turn into gold]
 μάχεσθαί γε μέντοι πάλιν τὴν αὐτὴν μάχην ὄμνυμι πάντας θεοὺς ἦ μὴν μᾶλλον βούλεσθαι ἢ πάντα μοι ὅσα ὁρῶ χρυσᾶ γενέσθαι.
remarks:
According to Xenophon, Agesilaus loved Megabates the son of Spithridates, yet when Megabates tried to kiss Agesilaus (as Persians do to those they honour), he resisted. 
Megabates felt slighted, and ceased to try to kiss Agesilaus. 
When Agesilaus approached one of Megabates' companions to ask whether he could persuade Megabates to show him honour once again, the companion asked whether Agesilaus would kiss Megabates if he yielded. Agesilaus responds, "No, by the Twin gods, not if I were to become the fairest, strongest and swiftest man" (see oath id 2307). 
Agesilaus then goes on to swear by all the gods that he would rather fight the same battle over again than that everything I see should turn into gold. 
Roughly, Agesilaus says, "I wouldn't kiss him for all the tea in China; but I'd sooner have the chance to fight him off again, like I did before, than have all the gold in Peru!" i.e. in other words: "I fancy him rotten, but I don't kiss boys in public."

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
if_taken: The treaty and alliance would be formalised
if_refused: There would not be a treaty or alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Andocides cites the peace treaty between Athens and Syracuse as an example of how the Athenians traditionally make war for the sake of others when it is possible for them to make peace for their own sake. 
He states that when the Syracusans came with a request, desiring friendship instead of disagreement, and to make peace instead of war, pointing out how much stronger would be an alliance with themselves rather than that with the Egestans and Catanians if we were willing to make one, we again chose war instead of peace, to go to Sicily for the Egestans and Catanians, instead of staying at home with the Syracusans as allies. 
"It is generally accepted that Andocides has invented this embassy" (Edwards ad loc.)

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement: n/a
remarks:
Xenophon observes that when Cyrus the younger was sent down to be satrap of Lydia, Greater Phrygia and Cappadocia and commander of all the troops in the plain of Castolus, he was trusted. 
He notes that if anyone had been an enemy, when Cyrus made a treaty with him, he trusted that he would suffer no harm in violation of that treaty. 
Xenophon observes that the cities in Asia Minor chose Cyrus over Tissaphernes because they trusted him. 
See also oath id 2075.

author: Demosthenes
title: On Halonnesus
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Hegesippus states that Philip's ambassadors agreed to an amendment to the peace treaty to include a clause that each side should retain what belonged to it. He complains that Philip is claiming that he never agreed to this point, and that the ambassadors never raised it. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: There would not be any alliance(s)
remarks:
The exact oath statement is unknown. 
The Plataean speaker argues that the Thebans are going to claim that the Plataeans have taken the side of Sparta, and that by destroying Plataea they have benefited the whole alliance i.e. the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
See also oath id 2974.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
if_taken: They can give a valid verdict
if_refused: Their verdict will be a nullity
statement: [? That they would give a just verdict]
remarks: Apollodorus states that the laws state that arbitrators should give their decision under oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Inspires Dionysus to suggest a costume exchange
statement:
[That he was not afraid of Aeacus' threats]
  Σὺ δ’ οὐκ ἔδεισας τὸν ψόφον τῶν ῥημάτων
  καὶ τὰς ἀπειλάς; 
ΞΑ.  Οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐδ’ ἐφρόντισα.

author: Pherecydes Ath.
title: Fr. 79a
impact: Eleans did not take part in the Isthmian games
statement:
[That they would not take part in the Isthmian games]
 Ἠλείοις ἀπώμοτον εἶναι τὰ Ἴσθμια ἀγωνίζεσθαι
remarks: This passage dealing with the Moliones refers to the Eleans being under oath not to take part in the Isthmia because the Corinthians had failed to punish Heracles for murdering the Moliones on their way to the games.
