Presumably the story was that the Eleans voted to impose an oath on all Elean citizens that they would not take part in the Isthmian Games.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That the young man is making the right decision]
 Νοῦν ἄρ’ ἕξεις νὴ Δία.

author: Demosthenes
title: Exordia
statement:
[That he bears X (a politician who has made a great name by his anti-Theban speeches) no ill will, but wishes that his plan had been a good one]
 οὔτε γὰρ τούτῳ κακόνους εἰμὶ μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς ὑμῖν τ’ ἀγαθὸν βούλομαι ἄν γενέσθαι
remarks: The exordium as a whole shows that Demosthenes is arguing that it is no good (as Kipling would put it) killing Thebans with your mouth if you don’t make the necessary preparations for actually fighting them.

author: Lysias
title: Against Alcibiades 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker argues that if those who speak on behalf of Alcibiades can prove that he has been on service in the infantry, or that he had undergone scrutiny to serve in the cavalry, he should be acquitted. But if they demand that Alcibiades be let off as a favour to themselves, then they are encouraging the jurors to break their oath and disobey the laws. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Epistle 2
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes writes that it was not constitutional for the sworn jurors to assent to whatever the boule decided i.e. that he should be convicted. What Demosthenes is complaining about is that the jurors accepted (not a decree but) an accusation by the boule when it was made without any of the evidence being made public. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That Autolycus, the man speaking for the Areopagites, is a man who has lived an honourable life with dignity and in a manner worthy of that body]
 ἦν μὲν ὁ τὸν λόγον λέγων ἐκ τῶν Ἀρεοπαγιτῶν Αὐτόλυκος, καλῶς νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω καὶ σεμνῶς καὶ ἀξίως ἐκείνου τοῦ συνεδρίου βεβιωκώς·
remarks: Timarchus had proposed a motion that the Areopagus should appear before the demos regarding houses of the Pnyx. Autolycus was chosen to speak on behalf of the Areopagus.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the same things are not only both beautiful and ugly but also both good and bad]
 Λέγεις σύ, ἔφη, καλά τε καὶ αἰσχρὰ τὰ αὐτὰ εἶναι; Καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἔγωγ’, ἔφη, ἀγαθά τε καὶ κακά·
remarks: The argument is that the same thing can be good for one things but bad for another; cf. oath id 2097.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he knows which things are good and which things are evil]
 Οὐκοῦν, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, τὰ μὲν ἀγαθὰ καὶ τὰ κακὰ ὁποῖά ἐστι πάντως που γιγνώσκεις; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη
remarks: Euthydemus is at present quite sure that this is true (he would consider himself "worse than a slave" if he did not have this knowledge), but it will not take Socrates very long to demonstrate, by his usual methods, that Euthydemus actually knows nothing.

author: Plato (com.)
title: Summachia
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: The title of Plato's play (Summachia) suggests that an alliance was sworn at some point in the play, or that reference was made to an alliance (which by nature contains an oath). However, there are no further references in the fragments.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Cephallenia. 
Cf. Xenophon, Hellenica 6.2.38. This oath and alliance are presumably a follow-up alliance to that in oath id 353-357.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Draws attention to the figure hiding under the donkey
statement:
[That the donkey is carrying someone underneath it]
 ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δία φέρει 
  κάτω γε τουτονί τιν’ ὑποδεδυκότα.
remarks: Philocleon is hiding under the donkey trying to escape. When discovered he responds with an informal oath; see oath id 1067.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That they would allow the Spartan troops to leave in safety with their arms]
 ἀσφάλειαν μετὰ τῶν ὅπλων  .
remarks: Xenophon states that the Spartan garrison in the Cadmea agreed to leave provided they were allowed to withdraw with their arms. The Thebans swore the oaths and let them go on these terms.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he wants Peace to accept their sacrifice]
  Δέξαι δῆτ’, ὦ πολυτιμήτη, 
  νὴ Δία
remarks: This oath emphasises an imperative.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the city will be a happy place (i.e. with the women in charge)]
 νὴ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην μακαρία γ’ ἄρ’ ἡ πόλις 
  ἔσται τὸ λοιπόν.
remarks: The statement is true at least from the Swearer's perspective, and as Sommerstein notes ad 558, "with this feminine oath [cf. 189-191- oath id 791] Praxagora abruptly throws off all disguise and pretence [cf. 553- oath id 813], and reveals herself as the leader of a new régime with a radical, and distinctively feminine programme".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Thucydides states that three hundred Samians were persuaded by Peisander and his Athenian accomplices to conspire against the Samian demos. 
They began by combining with Charminus, the Athenian commander, and some other Athenians on Samos, to assassinate the ostracized Athenian demagogue Hyperbolus, as a pledge of their loyalty to the oligarchic cause, but this alerted their opponents to what was being plotted, and when a coup was attempted it was easily put down.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
if_taken: He will be part of a conspiracy
if_refused: He will not be part of a conspiracy
statement: [That he will be party to the conspiracy]
remarks: Bdelycleon here responds to the chorus' suggestion that he is a conspirator. See remarks on ids 1087 and 1079; cf. oath id 1107.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
if_taken: The terms will of the agreement will be valid
if_refused: The terms will not be valid
statement:
[That if Odysseus does not return, Eumaeus can kill him, but if Odysseus does return, he will receive a tunic and a mantle, and be sent on his way to Doulichion] 
ἀλλ’ ἄγε νῦν ῥήτρην ποιησόμεθ’· αὐτὰρ ὄπισθεν
μάρτυροι ἀμφοτέροισι θεοί, τοὶ Ὄλυμπον ἔχουσιν. 
εἰ μέν κεν νοστήσῃ ἄναξ τεὸς ἐς τόδε δῶμα,
ἕσσας με χλαῖνάν τε χιτῶνά τε εἵματα πέμψαι
Δουλίχιόνδ’ ἰέναι, ὅθι μοι φίλον ἔπλετο θυμῷ· 
εἰ δέ κε μὴ ἔλθῃσιν ἄναξ τεὸς ὡς ἀγορεύω, 
δμῶας ἐπισσεύας βαλέειν μεγάλης κατὰ πέτρης, 
ὄφρα καὶ ἄλλος πτωχὸς ἀλεύεται ἠπεροπεύειν.”
remarks: The Cretan proposes an agreement between himself and Eumaeus as follows: if Odysseus returns, the Cretan will be rewarded; but if Odysseus does not return, the Cretan will be killed. The Cretan calls the gods to witness his statement but the agreement is not made since Eumaeus rejects it. Eumaeus is forced to reject the oath because if, as he expects, Odysseus does not return, he will have to choose between a violation of the oath and a violation of the laws of hospitality, with divine punishment a certainty either way. From Odysseus' point of view, of course, that makes the oath a very handy device for testing Eumaeus. This oath is made with reference to the previous oath sworn by the Cretan at oath id 542 (also referred to in the immediately preceding lines at oath id 545), in which he swore that Odysseus would come home.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians were able to collect their dead amounting to 330 men and all their generals
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides relates, that when the Athenians were defeated by the Bottiaeans and Chalicidians, they fled to Potidaea, and collected the bodies of their dead under a truce.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
statement:
[That Medea will not let any of her enemies rejoice at vexing her heart (because, one way or another, she will kill them)]
  ἢν μέν τις ἡμῖν πύργος ἀσφαλὴς φανῆι,
  δόλωι μέτειμι τόνδε καὶ σιγῆι φόνον·
  ἢ δ’ ἐξελαύνηι ξυμφορά μ’ ἀμήχανος,
  αὐτὴ ξίφος λαβοῦσα, κεἰ μέλλω θανεῖν, 
  κτενῶ σφε, τόλμης δ’ εἶμι πρὸς τὸ καρτερόν.
  οὐ γὰρ μὰ τὴν δέσποιναν ἣν ἐγὼ σέβω 
  μάλιστα πάντων καὶ ξυνεργὸν εἱλόμην,
  ῾Εκάτην, μυχοῖς ναίουσαν ἑστίας ἐμῆς,
  χαίρων τις αὐτῶν τοὐμὸν ἀλγυνεῖ κέαρ.
gods_invoked: HecateEpithet(s)dwelling in the innermost part of the hearth
remarks: Mastronarde (2002) ad 397 remarks: 'Hecate was worshipped outdoors, in streets, and at crossroads, so Medea's statement that the goddess dwells within her house, virtually in displacement of Hestia, conveys both an exotic transgression of the norm and a special personal intimacy'.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Emphasises the strength of Philocleon's punch
statement:
[That Philocleon has ‘learned Olympia thoroughly’, i.e. knows all about Olympic fight-sports and fighters]
  νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἐξέμαθές γε τὴν Ὀλυμπίαν.
remarks: Bdelycleon's statement here follows on from his being knocked to the ground by his father.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That the expanse in front of Dionysus is the lake Heracles mentioned]
 Τοῦτο; λίμνη.
ΔΙ.  νὴ Δία 
  αὕτη ’στὶν ἣν ἔφραζε, καὶ πλοῖόν γ’ ὁρῶ

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
statement:
[That he could not tell the jurors how ready Conon's supporters are to do anything at all]
 ἡ δ’ ἀπ’ αὐτῶν ἑτοιμότης οὐδ’ ἂν εἰπεῖν μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς δυναίμην ὅση καὶ οἵα πρὸς τὸ ποιεῖν ὁτιοῦν ὑπάρχει
remarks: This is a graphic way of saying that their lawlessness and violence are almost beyond belief.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That he does not even know what he himself is saying]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐδ’ αὐτὸς οἶδ’ὅτι λέγω
remarks: This confession of aporia is almost exactly the same oath statement as oath id 2960.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
impact: Gives a finality to the decision
statement:
[That Peisetaerus is giving him good advice]
 Νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον εὖ γέ μοι δοκεῖς λέγειν
remarks: The advice referred to is that the young man should go as a soldier to Thrace where he can satisfy his belligerent spirit.

author: Plato
title: Letter VII
if_taken: The community would be governed fairly
if_refused: The community would not be governed fairly
statement:
[That (in drawing up laws) they will give no advantage either to conquerors or conquered, but equal rights in common to the whole city]
 μεταπεμψαμένους δὲ ὀμόσαντας δεῖσθαι καὶ κελεύειν θεῖναι νόμους, μήτε νικήσασιν μήτε νικηθεῖσιν νέμειν πλέον, τὸ δὲ ἴσον καὶ κοινὸν πάσῃ τῇ πόλει.
remarks: Plato’s advice as to how a city should reconstitute itself after a period of civil strife is here expressed in general terms (though he clearly does think it is what Dion’s friends should do, if they get the chance). The advice is as follows: The current rulers, whoever they are, should invite about fifty elders of high character from all over Greece to come and make laws for them, laws which should not discriminate between the winning and losing factions in the civil conflict.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would abide by the agreement which they made with the citizens of Halieis]
 ὄμ[οσαν δ’] αὐτοῖς Ἀ[θεναίον hε βολὲ καὶ hοι σ]τ̣ρατεγοὶ ἐμμε[νε̃ν ἐ]ν ταῖς χσυνθ[έ]κ̣[αις hὰς χσυνέθεντ]ο πρὸς hαλιᾶς hοι ἐπὶ] τὰ χσυγκε[ίμενα·]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Halieis. 
The Athenians swore to abide by the agreement that had made with the people of Halieis.  
For the corresponding oaths of the citizens and envoys of Halieis see oath id 227-228.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That one cannot hunt down a friend like a hare by swift pursuit, nor like birds by cunning nor like enemies by force]
 Τί οὖν; ἔφη, ὃν ἂν ἡμῖν τε δοκῇ καὶ οἱ θεοὶ μὴ ἐναντιῶνται, ἔχεις εἰπεῖν ὅπως οὗτος θηρατέος; Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ κατὰ πόδας, ὥσπερ ὁ λαγῶς, οὐδ’ ἀπάτῃ, ὥσπερ αἱ ὄρνιθες, οὐδὲ βίᾳ, ὥσπερ οἱ ἐχθροί·

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides states that deliberation about the terms of a peace (i.e. the peace that he has just been negotiating) should be cautious, but once one has sworn oaths and made agreements one should abide by them. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the kind of excellence that makes good statesmen and rulers is the finest excellence and greatest skill]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, τῆς καλλίστης ἀρετῆς καὶ μεγίστης ἐφίεσαι τέχνης·
remarks: For a similar oath statement cf. oath id 2085.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines states that while he personally is on trial, the greater part of the accusation has been directed against Philocrates, Phrynion and the other members of the embassy, Philip and the peace [of Philocrates], and the policies of Eubulus. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Argives believed that because Sparta had made an alliance with Boeotia the Spartans had persuaded the Boeotians to accede to the treaty with Athens. 
The Argives thus feared that their whole confederacy (see oath id 233) would go over to the Spartans. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Philistus
title: Sicelica
statement: [? That they would not attack Demosthenes' forces if he surrendered]
remarks: Philistus (cited by Pausanias 1.29.12) claims that Demosthenes made a truce with the Syracusans for his soldiers and excluded himself from the agreement, and then attempted to commit suicide, whereas Nicias voluntarily submitted to the surrender.

author: Lysias
title: Against Eratosthenes
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal, maintain secrecy, and overthrow the democracy]
remarks:
Lysias describes how Theramenes - in his defence speech before the council - reproached the exiles (because it was through him that they had returned), and those who had shared in the government (i.e. the Thirty) because he had provided them with many indications of his loyalty and he had received oaths from them in return. 
See also oath id 2823.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he is delighted to have learnt that (i.e. that because of the funnel Euripides describes, he is not to see or hear)]
 Διὰ τὴν χοάνην οὖν μήτ’ ἀκούω μήθ’ ὁρῶ; 
  Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἥδομαί γε τουτὶ προσμαθών.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Hermes
statement:
[That he will never pay compensation for the ruthless theft]
 μέγαν δ’ ἐπιδώσομαι ὅρκον· 
οὐ μὰ τάδ’ ἀθανάτων εὐκόσμητα προθύραια.
καί ποτ’ ἐγὼ τούτῳ τίσω ποτὶ νηλέα φωρὴν
gods_invoked: Finely adorned porches of the gods
remarks: Hermes again shows his tricksy use of oaths. His oath statement is true, but it does not prove that he hasn't stolen the cattle (cf. 379-380 and also oath id 1358).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That Aeschines' career subsequent to being a secretary and errand-boy to minor officials was fully worthy of his earlier career]
 οὐ κατῄσχυνας μὰ Δί’ οὐδὲν τῶν προϋπηργμένων τῷ μετὰ ταῦτα βίῳ
remarks:
Demosthenes has alleged that Aeschines did the work of a servant at his father's school and assisting his mother in her mystery-cult rituals. 
He then goes on to describe how Aeschines served as an under-secretary to one or more magistracies, and then went on to play the role of the third actor for a troupe of inferior actors.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he had never been told by anyone before how Peace disappeared]
  Ταῦτα τοίνυν μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω ’γὼ ’πεπύσμην οὐδενός
remarks: Trygaeus' statement is a reaction to Hermes' account of the origins of the war recounted at 605ff.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Spartans were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Spartans while they collected their dead]
remarks: Xenophon indicates that the Corcyraeans set up a trophy and gave back the dead under a truce.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That it was not a mouse that made a bit of earth fall on his head]
  πόθεν ποτ’ ἐμπέπτωκέ μοι τὸ βωλίον;
 {Βδ.}  ἴσως ἄνωθεν μῦς ἐνέβαλέ σοί ποθεν. 
 {Ξα.}  μῦς; οὐ μὰ Δί’

author: Homer
title: Iliad
impact: Hera and Athena do not help Poseidon save Aeneas
statement:
[That they will not intervene on behalf on the Trojans even if Troy is sacked]
 ἤτοι μὲν γὰρ νῶϊ πολέας ὠμόσσαμεν ὅρκους 
πᾶσι μετ’ ἀθανάτοισιν ἐγὼ καὶ Παλλὰς Ἀθήνη 
μή ποτ’ ἐπὶ Τρώεσσιν ἀλεξήσειν κακὸν ἦμαρ,
[μηδ’ ὁπότ’ ἂν Τροίη μαλερῷ πυρὶ πᾶσα δάηται
καιομένη, καίωσι δ’ ἀρήϊοι υἷες Ἀχαιῶν].
remarks: Here Hera makes reference to "oaths" that she and Athena have taken, but the occasion or occasions are left vague and are never mentioned elsewhere.

author: Alexis
title: Pythagorizousa
statement:
[That it is the custom of the Pythagoreans to sacrifice the finest beast available]
  δ’ ἑστίασις ἰσχάδες καὶ στέμφυλα 
καὶ τυρὸς ἔσται· ταῦτα γὰρ θύειν νόμος
τοῖς Πυθαγορείοις. {Β.}  νὴ Δί’, ἱερεῖον μὲν οὖν 
ὁποῖον ἂν κάλλιστον, ὦ βέλτιστ’, ἔχῃς.
remarks: Evidently the second speaker (i) is pretty confident that the first speaker has no first-hand knowledge of Pythagorean beliefs and practices and (ii) wants to make damn sure (s)he has a decent dinner!

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
statement:
[That, if he says what he really thinks, he would be ashamed to show himself as a sophist to his fellow Greeks]
  Σὺ δέ, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, πρὸς θεῶν, οὐκ ἂν αἰσχύνοιο εἰς τοὺς Ἕλληνας σαυτὸν σοφιστὴν παρέχων;  Νὴ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, εἴπερ γε ἃ διανοοῦμαι χρὴ λέγειν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Philocleon has not bought a meal (he just has three crabs)]
 μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐδέν γ’ ἄλλο πλήν τρεῖς καρκίνους.
remarks: Xanthias is responding here to Philocleon's informal oath (see oath id 1134) and disagreeing with Phil.'s statement. Presumably the point of the contradiction is that no one would have a meal consisting only of crab (or even of crab, bread, and wine).

title: IG I(3)
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Delphic Amphictony
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Delphic Amphictony
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks:
This inscription records an agreement between Athens and the Delphic Amphictiony. 
The oath has not survived on the stone.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement:
[That he is not bringing the suit against Boeotus out of love of litigation]
 Οὐδεμιᾷ φιλοπραγμοσύνῃ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ὦ ἄνδρες δικασταί, τὴν δίκην ταύτην ἔλαχον Βοιωτῷ,

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest the Potidaeans once they evacuated the city]
remarks:
According to Thucydides the Potidaeans capitulated to the Athenians on the following terms:  
1. the Potidaeans, their children and their wives and mercenary troops were to leave the city. 
2. Each was allowed to take one garment (two in the case of women) and a fixed sum of money for the journey. 
Thucydides states that they went to Chalcidice or wherever they were able to go.

title: SEG
statement:
[The statement is unknown]
[- - -]ραι καὶ Κλειταγόρη φιλέται[ροι]
[νὴ τ]ὸν Δία καὶ τὴν Δήμητρα
remarks:
Graffito on a fragment of the foot of an Athenian cup. 
The statement is very fragmentary. All that can be said for certain is that the text appears to be an oath sworn by Zeus and Demeter. 
Cleitagore is presumably a hetaira (and so almost by definition). So too, no doubt, was the other person of whose name we have only the last three letters. It is possible that the first line is a toast to these two ladies, and the second line confirmation thereof. 
An alternate restoration for line 1 suggested by Oikonomides was included in SEG 36.114. It reads:  
[- - - κό̣]ραι καὶ Κλειταγόρη Φιλέτα ἡ̣ [- -] 
[- - - νὴ τ]ὸν Δία καὶ τὴν Δήμητρα. 
This restoration is not convincing on epigraphical grounds. 
Oikonomides' suggestion that the oath by Demeter shows the speaker to be female is nonsense. See A.H. Sommerstein in De Martino & Sommerstein ed. Lo spettacolo delle voci [Bari 1995] ii 66-67, who argues that in Aristophanes and Menander, with one exception [Men. Epitr. 955, νὴ τὴν φίλην Δήμητρα], only men swear by Demeter [26 times]; women swear by Demeter and Kore.)

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Thurians as allies, observing that they were fighting due to stasis. 
See also oath id 1844.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
swearer: Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?) and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that the city is the object of slander due to the policies of Demosthenes in connection with the present crisis i.e. the aftermath of Sparta's war with Macedon. He argues that if the Athenians crown Demosthenes they will seem to be in sympathy with those who violate the common peace. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see also oath id 479.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the country-folk were right to rumble in dissent at the idea that women should take over the running of the city]
 οἱ δ’ ἐκ τῶν ἀγρῶν 
  ἀνεβορβόρυξαν. {Βλ.} νοῦν γὰρ εἶχον, νὴ Δία.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That as a child, he used to strike with his dagger everything he could without getting caught]
 καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία ἔπαιόν γε τῇ μαχαίρᾳ πᾶν ὅ τι δυναίμην λανθάνειν

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the river flows right through the middle of Babylon and it is more than two stadia in width]
 Ὁ δὲ ποταμός, ἔφη, οὗτος οὐ διὰ μέσης τῆς πόλεως ῥεῖ πλάτος ἔχων πλέον ἢ ἐπὶ δύο στάδια; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Γωβρύας
remarks: Gobryas and Chrysantas are surprised by Cyrus' suggestion of overcoming Babylon by starving its inhabitants, seeing that the Euphrates flows straight through. Cyrus then explains that he intends to divert the course of the river.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would not attack each other, and that each party should keep its own territory]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Corinthians sent envoys to Thebes to see if a peace could be negotiated. When the Thebans agreed, the Corinthians requested that they might conclude peace with those who desired peace and leave the war to those who wished to continue fighting. 
When the Thebans gave their consent to this as well, the Corinthians asked permission from the Spartans to make peace with Thebes. The Spartans advised them to make peace and gave permission to their other allies to make peace with Thebes as well. They refused to make peace themselves while Messenia was independent. 
The Thebans tried to force the Corinthians to make an alliance with them (see oath id 2038), but the Corinthians refused. 
Xenophon observes that after the peace was concluded the Argives, having sworn to make peace on terms that each party should keep its own territory, and fearing that the Phliasian exiles occupying Tricaranum - in Phliasian territory - would therefore have to evacuate it, took over the place and maintained a garrison there, claiming it was their own territory (even though not long before they had been treating it as enemy soil and ravaging the land), and refused a Phliasian demand for arbitration.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the reason for which they are venturing this great venture (i.e. to get into the Assembly) is to see if they can take over the running of the city and do some good]
 τούτου γέ τοι, νὴ τὴν ἐπιοῦσαν ἡμέραν, 
 τόλμημα τολμῶμεν τοσοῦτον οὕνεκα, 
 ἤν πως παραλαβεῖν τῆς πόλεως τὰ πράγματα
 δυνώμεθ’ ὥστ’ ἀγαθόν τι πρᾶξαι τὴν πόλιν.
remarks: Praxagora swears (literally) "by the approaching day". Sommerstein ad 105 notes that this is "an unusual oath (though Hes. 'Thg.' 124 does make Day a goddess, daughter of Night) designed to stress the importance of the coming day for the women and for Athens and probably to suggest that it will mark a new dawn in the City's fortunes".  Day is one of several Hesiodic divinities who are rarely if ever heard of again, e.g. (to restrict ourselves to children and grandchildren of Night) Deception, Hunger, Pains, Battles, Lies, and Disputes.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that if the Athenians raise a military force and keep a close eye on their expenditure they can compel Philip to keep the peace, or fight him on equal terms. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks:
Callistratus tells the jurors that after he and Olympiodorus had induced Moschion to hand over some 600 drachmas out of 1000 which he admitted having stolen from Comon's estate, Olympiodorus later tortured Moschion on his own, found that he had stolen a further 70 minas (7000 drachmas) from the estate, extracted the money from him, and kept it for himself, even though he had sworn to make all enquiries and do everything in concert with Callistratus (see oath id 3623). 
Callistratus states that initially he did not press for his share of the money, thinking that Olympiodorus would act in accordance with their oaths, but when he did ask Olympiodorus about the money, he kept delaying and putting him off. Eventually other claimants to the estate appeared, and Olympiodorus said that Callistratus would have to wait until the suits were settled.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
statement:
[That a man of noble and gentle character who had once loved might refuse to accept their vilification of Eros]
 εἰ γὰρ ἀκούων τις τύχοι ἡμῶν γεννάδας καὶ πρᾷος τὸ ἦθος, ἑτέρου δὲ τοιούτου ἐρῶν ἢ καὶ πρότερόν ποτε ἐρασθείς, λεγόντων ὡς διὰ σμικρὰ μεγάλας ἔχθρας οἱ ἐρασταὶ ἀναιροῦνται καὶ ἔχουσι πρὸς τὰ παιδικὰ φθονερῶς τε καὶ βλαβερῶς, πῶς οὐκ ἂν οἴει αὐτὸν ἡγεῖσθαι ἀκούειν ἐν ναύταις που τεθραμμένων καὶ οὐδένα ἐλεύθερον ἔρωτα ἑωρακότων, πολλοῦ δ’ ἂν δεῖν  ἡμῖν ὁμολογεῖν ἃ ψέγομεν τὸν Ἔρωτα;  {ΦΑΙ.} Ἴσως νὴ Δί’, ὦ Σώκρατες.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes points out the importance that Solon attached to giving the speakers a fair hearing: he says that Solon thought that his laws needed to have their validity reinforced, not just by the fact of being written down, but also by making the jurors swear. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Coloneus
statement: [That Theseus will give Oedipus sanctuary]
remarks: Oedipus says that he will not ask Theseus to take an oath, to which Theseus replies that "you would get no more <by an oath> than by my word", i.e. that his simple promise will be kept no less faithfully than an oath would.  Cf. oath id 284.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes imagines that Aeschines will make his defence speech as if he were on trial about the peace itself. Demosthenes tells the jurors that Aeschines will not do so because he wishes to render an account more actions than he has been accused of, but because he realises his own conduct is bad, and that a defence of the peace, if nothing else, at least sounds well-intentioned. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That no desire is stronger than the hope of becoming a better man by associating with another]
 Ἔστιν οὖν τις μείζων ἐπιθυμία ἢ ὅταν τίς τῳ συνὼν οἴηται δι’ ἐκεῖνον ἔσεσθαι ἀμείνων ἀνήρ; {ΕΡΜ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐδ’ ὁπωστιοῦν, ὦ Σώκρατες.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Navy-Boards
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the Athenians that rather than actually starting a war against the Persian King, they should be content to let him know that they would have done so long ago but for the fact that lies and perjury are as disgraceful in the eyes of Greeks as they are honourable in the eyes of the King. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That Simonides, when he says that it is just to render each man his due, does not mean that a deposit should be given back to a man who is not in his right mind, and therefore, Simonides must mean something else]
 Ἄλλο δή τι ἢ τὸ τοιοῦτον, ὡς ἔοικεν, λέγει Σιμωνίδης τὸ τὰ ὀφειλόμενα δίκαιον εἶναι ἀποδιδόναι.  Ἄλλο μέντοι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη·

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
When Xenophon addresses the lochagoi of Proxenus the Boeotian he observes that "as long as the treaty lasted I never ceased commiserating ourselves and congratulating the King and his followers. For I saw plainly what a great amount of fine land they possessed, what an abundance of provisions, what quantities of servants, cattle, gold, and apparel.  
But whenever I took thought of the situation of our own soldiers, I saw that we had no share in these good things, except we bought them, I knew there were but few of us who still had money wherewith to buy, and I knew that our oaths restrained us from getting provisions in any other way than by purchase. Hence, with these considerations in mind, I used sometimes to fear the truce more than I now fear war." 
Xenophon goes on to say that he is no longer afraid because the Persians have violated their oaths (see oath id 2098). 
See also oath id 2105.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That when someone acquires a new possession, pleasure always keeps him wide awake]
 Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σάκας, οὐδέ γε τῶν λαμβανόντων τι νυστάζοντα οὐδένα ἂν  ἴδοις ὑφ’ ἡδονῆς.
remarks: The Sacian is disagreeing with Pheraulas who claims that only loss of possessions causes sleeplessness.

author: Eupolis
title: Taxiarchoi
statement: unknown
remarks: This passage is too fragmentary to reconstruct the oath statement.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Fuels the quarrel between the two poets
statement:
[That he is ready to bite and be bitten (metaphorically in the trial) before Aeschylus]
 ΕΥ. Ἕτοιμός εἰμ’ ἔγωγε, κοὐκ ἀναδύομαι,  
  δάκνειν, δάκνεσθαι πρότερος, εἰ τούτῳ δοκεῖ,
  τἄπη, τὰ μέλη, τὰ νεῦρα τῆς τραγῳδίας,
  καὶ νὴ Δία τὸν Πηλέα γε καὶ τὸν Αἴολον 
  καὶ τὸν Μελέαγρον κἄτι μάλα τὸν Τήλεφον.
remarks: Sommerstein ad 861 remarks that Euripides speaks of the coming contest as if it were a cock-fight.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he was told the same thing by a man from Crapton]
  Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ καὶ πρὸς ἐμὲ τοῦτ’ εἶπ’ ἀνὴρ Κόπρειος.
remarks: What he has been told is that Paphlagon had deliberately sold silphium stalks cheaply so that people would buy them and eat them and fart in court (and thus kill Demos with a foul smell). On the pun "Crapton" for the deme Kopros ("dung" in Greek), see Sommerstein ad 899.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That those who sleep too much are also (like drunkards) unable to show the proper concern about things for which they are responsible]
 Οἱ οὖν τούτου ἀκρατεῖς μόνοι, ἐγὼ ἔφην, ἀδύνατοί εἰσιν ἐπιμελεῖσθαι ἢ καὶ 
ἄλλοι τινές; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος, καὶ οἵ γε τοῦ ὕπνου·

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Highlights the Old Woman's desire for the young man
statement:
[That if he pledges to her that the young man will come to her, she will carry the pots]
  Ἀλλ’ εἴ γε μέντοι νὴ Δί’ ἐγγυᾷ σύ μοι 
  ἥξειν ἐκεῖνον ὡς ἔμ’, οἴσω τὰς χύτρας.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement: [That he has deposited all the property that he had into the central store]
remarks: Here, Blepyrus suggests a hypothetical false oath that could be taken by those who do not want to deposit their wealth into this new central store created by the women.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That the (Persian) king must be concerned that the parks in which he himself spends time be furnished in the finest manner possible with trees and all the other fine things that the eath produces]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κριτόβουλος, ἀνάγκη τοίνυν, ὦ Σώκρατες, 
ἔνθα γε διατρίβει αὐτός, καὶ ὅπως ὡς κάλλιστα κατεσκευασμένοι ἔσονται οἱ παράδεισοι ἐπιμελεῖσθαι δένδρεσι καὶ τοῖς  ἄλλοις ἅπασι καλοῖς ὅσα ἡ γῆ φύει.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he is not going to worry about the "oil-flask" joke (which Dionysus says is about to blow up into a [metaphorical] storm)]
 Τὸ ληκύθιον γὰρ τοῦτο πνευσεῖται πολύ.
ΕΥ. Οὐδ’ ἂν μὰ τὴν Δήμητρα φροντίσαιμί γε·
remarks: Euripides believes in the truth of the oath he swears, but, as it will turn out, the "oil-flask" joke is going to cause him some trouble. For further details concerning the joke, see Sommerstein ad 1198-1247.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
After they had fought against the Athenians at Corcyra the Corinthians sent a messenger to the Athenians and accused them of having broken the treaty. 
Thucydides indicates that the Corinthian messenger was not carrying the herald's wand to avoid giving the impression that they were at a state of war.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That it is difficult for women to sleep alone without a penis]
 Χαλεπὰ μὲν ναὶ τὼ σιὼ
  γυναῖκας ὑπνῶν ἐστ’ ἄνευ ψωλᾶς μόνας.
remarks: Swearing by the Dioscuri is typically Spartan practice; cf. oath id 1216 with cross references for other invocations of the Dioscuri in this play.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
The text indicates that if a stranger helped a divorced woman carry off property that rightfully belonged to her ex-husband he is to pay ten staters, plus double the value of whatever the judge swears he helped carry off. 
According to R. Parker, in The Cambridge Companion to Ancient Greek law, (Cambridge 2005), pp72-3, this passage indicates that "Swearing and judging are not, therefore, two processes but one. The judge does not swear to judge justly and then opine that the third party joined in removing goods worth, as it might be, three staters; he swears that the third party removed goods worth three staters. If he has been misled by false testimony, the religious guilt is none the less his". 
For other references to the oath sworn by the judge at Gortyn see oath id 980, 982, 1003, 1086, 1088, 1094, 1095, 1113, 1136, 1137, 1138, 1142.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he is not being ironical]
 Εἰρωνεύῃ, ὦ Σώκρατες.  {ΣΩ.} Μὰ τὸν Ζῆθον, ὦ Καλλίκλεις
remarks: Socrates invokes Zethus as the very person in whose name Callicles has just - he claims - spoken ironically against him. Zethus was not a god but a hero (oaths by heroes exist, but are not very common).

author: Euripides
title: Medea
if_taken: Aegeus will be helped with his childlessness
if_refused: Aegeus will not be helped in his childlessness
if_broken: Aegeus will suffer the fate of those who offend the gods
impact: Medea can proceed with her revenge plan
statement:
[That Aegeus will never expel Medea from his land, and neither will he give Medea up of his own free will, as long as he is living, if some enemy wishes to take her away]
 τούτοις δ’ ὁρκίοισι μὲν ζυγεὶς 
  ἄγουσιν οὐ μεθεῖ’ ἂν ἐκ γαίας ἐμέ·
  λόγοις δὲ συμβὰς καὶ θεῶν ἀνώμοτος
  φίλος γένοι’ ἂν κἀπικηρυκεύμασιν
  τάχ’ ἂν πίθοιο· τἀμὰ μὲν γὰρ ἀσθενῆ, 
  τοῖς δ’ ὄλβος ἐστὶ καὶ δόμος τυραννικός. 
Αι. πολλὴν ἔδειξας ἐν λόγοις προμηθίαν·
  ἀλλ’, εἰ δοκεῖ σοι, δρᾶν τάδ’ οὐκ ἀφίσταμαι.
  ἐμοί τε γὰρ τάδ’ ἐστὶν ἀσφαλέστερα,
  σκῆψίν τιν’ ἐχθροῖς σοῖς ἔχοντα δεικνύναι,
  τὸ σόν τ’ ἄραρε μᾶλλον. ἐξηγοῦ θεούς.  
Μη. ὄμνυ πέδον Γῆς πατέρα θ’ ῞Ηλιον πατρὸς
  τοὐμοῦ θεῶν τε συντιθεὶς ἅπαν γένος.
Αι. τί χρῆμα δράσειν ἢ τί μὴ δράσειν; λέγε.
Μη. μήτ’ αὐτὸς ἐκ γῆς σῆς ἔμ’ ἐκβαλεῖν ποτε,
  μήτ’ ἄλλος ἤν τις τῶν ἐμῶν ἐχθρῶν ἄγειν 
  χρήιζηι μεθήσειν ζῶν ἑκουσίωι τρόπωι.
Αι. ὄμνυμι Γαῖαν φῶς τε λαμπρὸν ῾Ηλίου
  θεούς τε πάντας ἐμμενεῖν ἅ σου κλύω.
Μη. ἀρκεῖ· τί δ’ ὅρκωι τῶιδε μὴ ’μμένων πάθοις;
Αι. ἃ τοῖσι δυσσεβοῦσι γίγνεται βροτῶν.
gods_invoked: Gaia; HeliosEpithet(s)Medea's grandfather, shining; All the gods
remarks: This oath guarantees Medea a safe haven to which she can escape after perpetrating her crimes. On the relationship between oath and supplication, see remarks on oath id 2690.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: King Perdiccas became hostile to Athens
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides indicates that King Perdiccas of Macedon became hostile to the Athenians after they made this alliance with his brother Philip and Derdas of Elimea, who were making common cause against him. 
For other references to the various alliances between Athens and Perdiccas see oath id 256.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 2
statement:
[That Mantias dishonoured Boeotus and Pamphilus in order to show favour to Mantitheus and his mother]
ὅτι νὴ Δία, ὡς οὗτοι φήσουσιν, ἐμοὶ χαριζόμενος καὶ τῇ ἐμῇ μητρὶ τούτους ἠτίμαζεν.
remarks: Mantitheus asks why, if his mother had not been a lawfully espoused wife and had brought no dowry, yet Plangon had done so, Mantias acknowledged him and raised him, instead of Boeotus and Pamphilus. He imagines that "these men" will respond in this way to his question.

title: IvO
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This is an alliance between the Eleans and the "Erwaoioi".  The text literally reads συνμαχία rather than συμμαχία.  
Meiggs and Lewis #17 commented on the absence of an explicit oath in this treaty.  
Dubois (in SEG 35.378) suggested that the treaty involved not Heraea in Arcadia, but rather Eua in the Thyreatis.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he cannot see a way to make sense of their arguments]
 Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐ πάνυ εὐπορῶ ἔγωγε.
remarks: Socrates admits the same. Cf. oath id 3083.

author: Aristotle
title: Metaphysics
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Aristotle refers to the view held by "some people" that the very ancient thinkers who "first formulated ideas about the gods" regarded water as the primary substance (as Thales did later).  Those whom Aristotle is citing regarded Thales’ theory as just a formalization of traditional beliefs, beliefs evidenced by what the poets say about the oath of the gods being sworn by the water of Styx. Their argument was that what is most ancient is most revered; the oath (or Oath) is what is most revered; water was believed to be the gods' oath-object; therefore water must have been believed to be the most ancient thing in the universe.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement:
[That the laws of old and the principles of those who drew them up in the beginning are an honour to the polis]
 ἐγκώμιον γὰρ νὴ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν εἰσι τῆς πόλεως οἱ παλαιοὶ νόμοι καὶ τὰ ἔθη τῶν ἐξ ἀρχῆς ταῦτα κατασκευασάντων.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That those under kappa who go to the Cornmarket Colonnade are not to eat greedily]
 τοὺς δ’ ἐκ τοῦ κάππ’ ἐς τὴν στοιὰν χωρεῖν τὴν ἀλφιτόπωλιν.
 {Βλ.}  ἵνα κάπτωσιν; {Πρ.} μὰ Δί’
remarks: Sommerstein translates "Eta" rather than "kappa" in order to keep the pun: they are not going to the Cornmarket to "eta up the corn". See Sommerstein ad 686-7 for further details.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That his father has learnt discretion through his defeat at the hands of Cyrus]
 Ποίαν δ’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, καὶ σὺ τοῦ πατρὸς ἧτταν λέγων οὕτως ἰσχυρίζει σεσωφρονίσθαι αὐτόν; Ἧι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, σύνοιδεν ἑαυτῷ ἐλευθερίας μὲν ἐπιθυμήσας,δοῦλος δ’ ὡς οὐδεπώποτε γενόμενος, ἃ δὲ ᾠήθη χρῆναι λαθεῖν ἢ φθάσαι ἢ ἀποβιάσασθαι, οὐδὲν τούτων ἱκανὸς γενόμενος διαπράξασθαι. σὲ δὲ οἶδεν, ἃ μὲν ἐβουλήθης ἐξαπατῆσαι αὐτόν, οὕτως ἐξαπατήσαντα ὥσπερ ἄν τις τυφλοὺς καὶ κωφοὺς καὶ μηδ’ ὁτιοῦν φρονοῦντας ἐξαπατήσειεν· ἃ δὲ ᾠήθης λαθεῖν χρῆναι, οὕτω σὲ οἶδε λαθόντα ὥστε ἃ ἐνόμιζεν ἑαυτῷ ἐχυρὰ χωρία ἀποκεῖσθαι, σὺ εἰρκτὰς ταῦτα ἔλαθες προκατασκευάσας· τάχει δὲ τοσοῦτον περιεγένου αὐτοῦ ὥστε πρόσωθεν ἔφθασας ἐλθὼν σὺν πολλῷ στόλῳ πρὶν τοῦτον τὴν παρ’ ἑαυτῷ δύναμιν ἁθροίσασθαι.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
impact: Emphasises his desire to speak first
statement:
[That he should be allowed to speak first]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία.
remarks: Paphlagon here responds to the Sausage-seller's oath with a counter-oath. The Sausage-seller will in turn respond by invoking Poseidon, an oath which supersedes Paphlagon's in strength. See oath ids 987, 988, 990.

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: Their attempts to prevent disregard for duty will be proven
if_refused: Their attempts to prevent disregard for duty will not be proven
impact: Intended impact- it is made clear that the person in question could not be reformed
statement:
[That they were truly unable to reform X (person)]
 εἰσιοῦσαι δ’ εἰς τὰς οἰκίας τῶν νέων αἱ γυναῖκες, τὰ μὲν νουθετοῦσαι, τὰ δὲ καὶ ἀπειλοῦσαι, παυόντων αὐτοὺς τῆς ἁμαρτίας καὶ ἀμαθίας· ἐὰν δ’ ἀδυνατῶσι, πρὸς τοὺς νομοφύλακας ἰοῦσαι φραζόντων, οἱ δ’ εἰργόντων. ἂν δὲ καὶ ἐκεῖνοί πως ἀδυνατήσωσι, πρὸς τὸ δημόσιον ἀποφηνάντων, ἀναγράψαντές τε καὶ ὀμόσαντες ἦ μὴν ἀδυνατεῖν  τὸν καὶ τὸν βελτίω ποιεῖν.
remarks: This passage refers to a generic oath, not a specific one. It is required in cases where couples are failing in their procreative duties. Female inspectors visit the houses and try to prevent the couples from mistakes and folly. If they fail, they report to the law-guardians who themselves attempt the same thing. If they also are unable to influence whichever party of the couple is failing in their duties, they must inform the state-council and post up in writing this sworn statement. The unreformed party then has recourse to a trial, and if s/he loses, penalties are inflicted- in particular disqualification from attending various feasts and celebrations.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That the manliest way to die is not the way Themistocles died]
 Πῶς δῆτα, πῶς γένοιτ’ ἂν ἀνδρικώτατα;
  Βέλτιστον ἡμῖν αἷμα ταύρειον πιεῖν·
  ὁ Θεμιστοκλέους γὰρ θάνατος αἱρετώτερος. 
  {ΔΗ. }  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: As Sommerstein remarks ad 84: "there was a popular legend, alluded to [here]… that [Themistocles] committed suicide by drinking bull's blood in order to avoid fulfilling a promise he had made to the [Persian] King that he would help subject Greece to Persian rule".

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he will do his best to gather willing recruits for Cyrus' campaign, so as to make the sight of himself as great a pleasure to Cyrus as the sight of Cyrus now is to him]
 καὶ ὁ Κῦρος εἶπεν· Οὐκοῦν καὶ ἄλλους, ἔφη, προθύμως ἐξάξεις; ἐπομόσας οὖν ἐκεῖνος Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, ἔστε γ’ ἂν ποιήσω καὶ σὲ ἐμὲ ἡδέως θεᾶσθαι
remarks: This is a good example to highlight the fact that an informal oath, most commonly an invocation of Zeus as we have here, was nevertheless regarded as a an act of swearing, qualified here by the narrator's explanation "he swore". The man in question is the same man who had pretended to be one of Cyrus' kinsmen earlier on in the Cyropaedia and chased after him in order to get a kiss- see oath ids 2318-2320.

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
statement:
[That Silenus has not seen the wine, but smells it]
 Οδ. εἶδες γὰρ αὐτήν; Σι. οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ὀσφραίνομαι.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Athenian general Thrasybulus of Steiria was operating near the Hellespont with a fleet of 40 triremes. 
Thrasybulus reconciled Amedocus the king of the Odrysians with Seuthes, and then made them friends and allies of the Athenians. 
See also oath id 302 for the oaths sworn at Athens.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Phaenippus
if_taken: He will be able to proceed with the antidosis
if_refused: He will not be able to proceed with the antidosis
statement: [That he will give a true and honest inventory of his property, except that in the silver mines, all of which the laws have made exempt from taxes]
remarks:
The speaker addresses Phaenippus, and tells him that he will prove that his statement is false, and that he has come before the jurors as a perjured man. 
The speaker then describes how Phaenippus opened the seals of the buildings and carried away grain and wine from within, sold thirty minas of timber, and fabricated debts. 
See also oath id 3594

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks:
This inscription records an agreement between Lygdamis (the tyrant) and the Halicarnassians and the Salmakitians. 
Part of the agreement was to make the law referred to in oath id 1048 and 1049.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Xanthias explains why Dionysus is a fine master
statement:
[That Xanthias' master is a fine gentleman]
  Νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν σωτῆρα, γεννάδας ἀνὴρ 
  ὁ δεσπότης σου.
remarks: See Sommerstein ad 738 on the identity of the slave.

author: Antiphanes
title: Misoponeros
statement:
[That the Scythians do not have nurses and tutors]
 μὰ Δί' οὐχὶ τίτθας εἰσάγουσι βασκάνους,
καὶ παιδαγωγοὺς αὖθις
remarks: This short fragment contains four informal oaths. See oath ids 1400-1403. Clearly the speaker wishes his statements to be emphatic and taken seriously.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
 ἦ μὴν πορεύσεσθαι ὡς διὰ φιλίας ἀσινῶς σῖτα καὶ ποτὰ λαμβάνοντας ὁπόταν μὴ ἀγορὰν παρέχωμεν, ἐὰν δὲ παρέχωμεν ἀγοράν, ὠνουμένους ἕξειν τὰ ἐπιτήδεια.
remarks:
Three days after Tissaphernes spoke with the Greeks he returned with a message from the King that they would be spared. 
Tissaphernes and the brother of the King's wife swore that they would lead the Greeks back home and provide them with supplies (see oath id 2098). 
The Greeks on their part were to swear that they would proceed as they would through a friendly country and take no food from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market. 
After the oaths were exchanged Tissaphernes returned to the King, having said that he would return fully equipped to take the Greeks back home and return to his own satrapy. 
For other references to this oath see oath id 2108, 2111, 2168, 2172, 3854, 3855, 3856, 3857.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That he does not know if he can beat around the bush all day and avoid saying outright that Timarchus has been a prostitute]
 μὰ τὸν Διόνυσον οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅπως δυνήσομαι περιπλέκειν ὅλην τὴν ἡμέραν
remarks: Aeschines argues that if Timarchus has been earning his living with his body in the home of Misgolas and another, then it will be clear that he has not only been a kept lover, but also a prostitute.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
if_taken: He can take office in the boule
if_refused: He cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
Theomnestus observes that Apollodorus, as a member of the boule, had sworn to give the best counsel to the Athenian demos. 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
if_taken: They will be allowed to judge
if_refused: They will not be allowed to judge
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aristotle states that dikastai swear "That they would use their best judgement" (ἐὰν δὲ ὁ γεγραμμένος ᾖ πρὸς τὸ πρᾶγμα, τό τε “γνώμῃ τῇ ἀρίστῃ” λεκτέον ὅτι οὐ τοῦ παρὰ τὸν νόμον ἕνεκα δικάζειν ἐστίν, ἀλλ’ ἵνα, ἐὰν ἀγνοήσῃ τί λέγει ὁ νόμος, μὴ ἐπιορκῇ). 
This is a reference to part of the dikasts' oath (cf. Eumenides 674-5 and remarks on oath id 214). 
 We are told that this oath does not justify a dikast in deciding contrary to the law but is intended to relieve him from the charge of perjury.  
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Lysias
title: Against Andocides
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker argues that Andocides had nothing to do with the agreement between the men from Piraeus and the men from the asty. 
He goes on to say that the oaths took place not for the sake of one man, but for the sake of all the Athenians. 
This is a typically far-fetched attempt to exclude Andocides from the benefits of the amnesty:  the agreements, the speaker claims, were between the two sides in the civil war, and therefore cannot be invoked by Andocides who was on neither side.  A different but cognate line is taken in the Agoratus case (13.89-90; see oath id 2829), where it is argued that the amnesty doesn’t apply to that case because the prosecutor and the defendant were on the same side in the civil war. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Thucydides
title: History
impact: Sparta and Argos remained at peace for thirty years
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
3. Neither side was to make an alliance with an enemy of the other]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that the thirty years' peace between Sparta and Argos was about to expire, and that the Argives were unwilling to make another treaty (σπένδεσθαι ) unless the territory of Cynuria was restored to them. 
Thucydides provides us with no other details about the treaty. 
See also oath id 1687, 1691, 1712.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
remarks:
Demosthenes has a decree which he proposed read to the jurors. This decree stipulated that ambassadors should be sent to Philip - wherever they should ascertain that Philip might be - without delay to exchange the oaths with him.  
Demosthenes alleges that these ambassadors waited in Macedonia for three months until Philip returned from conquering Thrace, and complains that they could have saved the Thracians had they found Philip and made him swear the oaths before he captured Thrace.  
Demothenes argues that Philip would not have harmed Thrace with the Athenian envoys present, or else they would not have received his oath, and the peace would not have been concluded.  
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Archilochus
title: Fragments
consequences_of_breach: Archilochus' poetic invective against Lycambes and his family
statement: [That he would abide by the terms of their agreement]
remarks: This is a reference to Lycambes as oath-breaker. Ancient testimonia, doubtless relying on Archilochus’ own text, claim that Archilochus had been engaged to marry Lycambes' daughter Neoboule, and that Lycambes then broke off the engagement. This provoked Archilochus' invective against him and his family which allegedly provoked their suicide. Brown (p.69) comments that "Lycambes is revealed as an oath breaker and thus a menace to society… However personal the insult, Archilochus treats his feud with Lycambes as a matter of public concern". For Salt and Table as oath objects, cf. the use of the Table of Xenia in the Odyssey at oath ids 542, 545, 556, 561.

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
statement: n/a
remarks: This refers to the debauched band of Philip's companions said to number not more than 800. Among many vices they were wont to commit perjury and cheating in the most august place.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
impact: Emphasises the seriousness of the statement
statement:
[That he is not joking (when he says he wants to be introduced to the man who has taught Alcibiades to distinguish the just from the unjust)]
 Σκώπτεις, ὦ Σώκρατες.  {ΣΩ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Φίλιον τὸν ἐμόν τε καὶ σόν, ὃν ἐγὼ ἥκιστ’ ἂν ἐπιορκήσαιμι·
remarks: Socrates swears "by the God of the Friendship between you and me” and qualifies this with the phrase "by whom I would least perjure myself" to emphasise the seriousness of his informal oath.

author: Antiphanes
title: Boutalion
statement:
[That the swearer and her company very much enjoyed the fish that was brought to them]
 ἦλθεν φέρων ποτ’ ἰχθυοπώλης μαινίδας
καὶ τριγλίδας, καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἤρεσεν σφόδρα
ἡμῖν ἅπασιν.
remarks: The swearer is a free hetaira.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That they will have to peel Procne like an egg in order to kiss her]
 Ἀλλ’ ὥσπερ ᾠὸν νὴ Δί’ ἀπολέψαντα χρὴ 
 ἀπὸ τῆς κεφαλῆς τὸ λέμμα κᾆθ’ οὕτω φιλεῖν.
remarks: Euelpides is intercepted by Tereus before he can put his plan into effect, but the oath statement is nonetheless true. E. does not swear that he will kiss Procne, he merely swears as to how he would have to go about it.

author: Plato
title: Critias
if_taken: They will prove themselves worthy rulers
if_refused: They will not be worthy to rule
if_broken: Grievous curses will be called down on the disobedient
impact: They will rule according to the laws
statement:
[That they will give judgement according to the laws inscribed on the column, punish any who had theretofore or would thereafter transgress the laws, that they would trangress none of the laws wittingly, neither giving nor obeying commandment except according to the laws of their father]
 ὅτ’ οὖν κατὰ τοὺς αὑτῶν νόμους θύσαντες καθαγίζοιεν πάντα τοῦ ταύρου τὰ μέλη, κρατῆρα κεράσαντες ὑπὲρ ἑκάστου θρόμβον ἐνέβαλλον αἵματος, τὸ δ’ ἄλλ’ εἰς τὸ πῦρ ἔφερον, περικαθήραντες τὴν στήλην· μετὰ δὲ τοῦτο χρυσαῖς φιάλαις ἐκ τοῦ κρατῆρος ἀρυτόμενοι, κατὰ τοῦ πυρὸς σπένδοντες ἐπώμνυσαν δικάσειν τε κατὰ τοὺς ἐν τῇ στήλῃ νόμους καὶ κολάσειν εἴ τίς τι πρότερον παραβεβηκὼς εἴη, τό τε αὖ μετὰ τοῦτο μηδὲν τῶν γραμμάτων ἑκόντες παραβήσεσθαι, μηδὲ ἄρξειν μηδὲ ἄρχοντι πείσεσθαι πλὴν κατὰ τοὺς τοῦ πατρὸς ἐπιτάττοντι 
νόμους. ταῦτα ἐπευξάμενος ἕκαστος αὐτῶν αὑτῷ καὶ τῷ ἀφ’ αὑτοῦ γένει, πιὼν καὶ ἀναθεὶς τὴν φιάλην εἰς τὸ ἱερὸν τοῦ θεοῦ, περὶ τὸ δεῖπνον καὶ τἀναγκαῖα διατρίψας, ἐπειδὴ γίγνοιτο σκότος καὶ τὸ πῦρ ἐψυγμένον τὸ περὶ τὰ θύματα εἴη, πάντες οὕτως ἐνδύντες ὅτι καλλίστην κυανῆν στολήν, ἐπὶ τὰ τῶν ὁρκωμοσίων καύματα χαμαὶ καθίζοντες, νύκτωρ,  πᾶν τὸ περὶ τὸ ἱερὸν ἀποσβεννύντες πῦρ, ἐδικάζοντό τε καὶ ἐδίκαζον εἴ τίς τι παραβαίνειν αὐτῶν αἰτιῷτό τινα·
remarks: This oath is accompanied by many rituals and sanctifying features. The ceremony is conducted in the sanctuary of Poseidon in the centre of the island. After a chosen bull has been slaughtered and its blood allowed to run on the column inscribed with the laws and oath (see oath id 3200), a libation of wine mixed with one blood clot for each man is poured over the sacrificial fire in golden cups. Once each has sworn the oath for himself and his future descendants, he drinks and dedicates the cup in the god's sanctuary, and then turns his attention to the banquet. When darkness falls and the sacrificial fire has died down, all don dark blue robes, seat themselves by the embers of their oath sacrifice, on the ground, extinguishing all the fire in the sanctuary and thus give and receive judgement.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
statement:
[That they will prevent the Furies from pursuing Orestes]
 Κλ. ὕπνος πόνος τε κύριοι συνωμόται
δεινῆς δρακαίνης ἐξεκήραναν μένος.
remarks: Clytemnestra here personifies Sleep and Toil in the powerful image of them having sworn a pact to thwart the vengeance sought by her Furies.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
Xenophon states that by 365 the Eleans were again allies of Sparta. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Wealth is in his house]
 Πλοῦτος παρὰ σοί; 
  {ΧΡ.}  Νὴ τοὺς θεούς.
remarks: Blepsidemus is still not quite convinced, and Chremylus invokes a specific deity to prove the truth of his statement at oath id 875.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That if prizes were offered for the tribe (etc.) that performed each public duty best, there would be much more despatch in starting for the appointed place, and greater promptness in the paying of war taxes whenever occasion required]
 καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία ὁρμῷντό γ’ ἂν θᾶττον ὅποι δέοι, τιμῆς ὀρεγόμενοι, καὶ χρήματα θᾶττον <ἂν> εἰσφέροιεν, ὁπότε τούτου καιρὸς εἴη,

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Egestans as allies. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 87 and 298.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: In this very fragmentary text about an agreement between Athens and Chalcis, there is a brief reference to [τ]οὺς ὅρκο[υς]. A reference to the allies suggests that this decree can be dated to the time of the Second Athenian League.

author: Anonymus Tragicus
title: Fragment 188b
statement: unknown
remarks: This is a reference to someone who has trampled on their oaths. Cf. oath ids 1338 and 1381.

author: Euripides
title: Phoenissae
impact: Prompts Creon to let Antigone leave as she wishes
statement:
[That her marriage night will make her one of the Danaids (i.e. she will murder her husband if forced to marry)]
 Αν. νὺξ ἆρ’ ἐκείνη Δαναΐδων μ’ ἕξει μίαν. 
Κρ. εἶδες τὸ τόλμημ’ οἷον ἐξωνείδισεν;
Αν. ἴστω σίδηρος ὅρκιόν τέ μοι ξίφος.
remarks: Antigone's oath is conditional on her being forced to marry. Creon decides against this and so Antigone's oath does not need to be fulfilled.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
if_refused: Peace treaty will not be formalised
statement: [That he would not injure Clearchus and the Greeks]
remarks: Ctesias reports here that after Clearchus and his generals had been seized and sent to the king in chains, contrary to solemn oaths, Clearchus asked for a comb and proceeded to comb his hair. As a measure of gratitude to Ctesias for providing the comb, he gave him a seal ring. See also oath id 2111 for details of the oath broken by Tissaphernes.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
According to the text in all other cases other than those inscribed above the judges shall decide under oath (ὀμνὺς). 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Ephippus
title: Kirke
statement:
[That the swearer wants to drink wine which is no more than 42% water- three parts water to four parts wine (whereas normal dilution would be 70-75%)]
 οἶνον πίοις ἂν ἀσφαλέστερον πολὺ 
ὑδαρῆ. {Β.} μὰ τὴν γῆν, ἀλλὰ τρία καὶ τέτταρα. 
{Α.} οὕτως ἄκρατον, εἰπέ μοι, πίει; {Β.} τί φής;

author: Aeschylus
title: Septem Contra Thebas
swearer: Polynices; Amphiaraus; Parthenopaeus; Hippomedon; Capaneus; Eteoclus; Tydeus
if_taken: Their dedication to the campaign is proven
if_refused: Their dedication to the campaign is not proven
statement:
[That they will either raze the city of the Cadmeans to the ground, sacking it by force, or that they will die and mix their blood with the earth]
  ἄνδρες γὰρ ἑπτά, θούριοι λοχαγέται,
ταυροσφαγοῦντες ἐς μελάνδετον σάκος,
καὶ θιγγάνοντες χερσὶ ταυρείου φόνου,
῎Αρην ᾿Ενυὼ καὶ φιλαίματον Φόβον 
ὡρκωμότησαν, ἢ πόλει κατασκαφὰς
θέντες λαπάξειν ἄστυ Καδμείων βίαι,
ἢ γῆν θανόντες τήνδε φυράσειν φόνωι·
remarks: The Seven swear either of two things, to annihilate the city or to die (cf. oath id 293). So death here will not be a consequence of breaking the oath, it is part of the oath itself. Compare the comic treatment of a "slaughter" over a shield in Aristophanes' Lysistrata (see oath id 1164), and note also the description of oath rituals among the Scythians by Herodotus (see oath id 1327). Oath sacrifices are performed over a shield also at oath id 2078. The oath statement of the Seven is similar to that of the Spartans attacking Messene, see oath id 3599.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The text records the alliance between Athens and Cetriporis of Thrace, Lyppeus of Paeonia and Grabus of Illyria. 
See also oath id 459, 460, 461.

author: Plato
title: Ion
statement:
[That he has never seen a man with skill to judge only one specific sculptor but not others]
 ἐν ἀνδριαντοποιίᾳ ἤδη τιν’ εἶδες ὅστις περὶ μὲν Δαιδάλου τοῦ Μητίονος ἢ Ἐπειοῦ τοῦ Πανοπέως ἢ Θεοδώρου τοῦ Σαμίου ἢ ἄλλου τινὸς ἀνδριαντοποιοῦ ἑνὸς πέρι δεινός ἐστιν ἐξηγεῖσθαι ἃ εὖ πεποίηκεν, ἐν δὲ τοῖς τῶν ἄλλων ἀνδριαντοποιῶν ἔργοις ἀπορεῖ τε καὶ νυστάζει, οὐκ ἔχων ὅτι εἴπῃ; {—ΙΩΝ.} Οὐ μὰτὸν Δία, οὐδὲ τοῦτον ἑώρακα.

title: IC IV
if_taken: He can exact double the cost
if_refused: He cannot exact double the cost
statement: [? That the cost of the cleansing was a certain amount]
remarks: The text indicates that if the person responsible for carrying out the cleansing does not do so the judge can exact double the cost after swearing an oath (αἰ δέ κα μὲ καθαίρει ἆι ἔγρατται, αὐτὸν καθα[ίρεν κ’ ὄτι κ’ ἀν]αισιμόσει [ὀ]μόσαντα διπλεῖ πρ̣[άδ]δεθαι).

author: Plato
title: Apologia
if_taken: He will be allowed to proceed with charges
if_refused: He will not be allowed to proceed with charges
statement: [That Socrates believes in divinities]
remarks: Meletus, asked whether Socrates believes in no gods at all or in gods other than those of the city, has unwisely picked the former alternative; it is then easy for Socrates to demonstrate that this is inconsistent with the assertion in Meletus’ sworn indictment that Socrates believes in daimonia, since the existence of daimonia implies the existence of daimones, and daimones are either gods or the children of gods. Cf. oath ids 2777 and 2780.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that Dercylidas sent to the cities of Aeolis and requested that they free themselves, admit him inside their walls, and become his allies. 
Those in Neandria, Ilium and Cocylium obeyed. The citizens of Cebren also later complied.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he will not knead any more dung-cakes]
  καὶ τρῖβ’ <ἔθ’> ἑτέρας.
  {ΟΙ. Βʹ}  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω ’γὼ μὲν οὔ·

author: Anonymus Oxyrhynchicus
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Megarians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That the they would not molest the Megarians and the Spartans while they collected their dead]
remarks:
The text indicates that the Athenians pursued the Megarians up the road leading to the city and killed many men. Afterwards, they gave up the dead under a truce. 
For details of the battle see Diodorus 13.65.1-2.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes rejects Philip's claims in a letter that he prevented the Athenian ambassadors from travelling to the allied cities to receive the oaths for the peace because he wanted them to negotiate an agreement between the Halians and the Pharsalians. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: On the Scrutiny of Euandros
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
The speaker asks the bouleutai to consider whether they have "sworn to install a magistrate who has not passed the scrutiny, or, after holding the scrutiny, to crown the man who is worthy of office". 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: ca.546 after Cyrus conquered Lydia (546 to 544)
statement: n/a
remarks:
According to Herodotus, Cyrus said of the Greeks to a Spartan envoy, "I have never yet feared men who have a place set apart in the middle of their city, where once assembled they deceive each other swearing oaths". 
The manuscript reads ὀμοῦντες. Rosén emends this to read ὁμιλοῦντες, whereas previous editions have been emended to read ὀμνύντες. Because of the exceptional circumstances it has been decided to follow the previous editions rather than the designated text of Rosén.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: Unity among Persians and fairness in Persian rule would be assured
if_refused: Unity among Persians and fairness in Persian rule would not be assured
impact: Unity among the Persians is formalised
statement: [That if anyone attacks Persia or attempts to break Persian laws, he will come to assist Persia with all his might]
remarks: Here, Xenophon explains how Cyrus and the Persians accepted the proposals of Cambyses for swearing a pact (see oath ids 2500 and 2501) and states that that the Persians and their king continue to act in accordance with this agreement.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the seed of those in their prime is not likely to be the same as that of those who have not yet reached their prime or have passed it]
 ἢ δοκεῖ σοι ὅμοια τὰ σπέρματα εἶναι τὰ τῶν ἀκμαζόντων τοῖς τῶν μήπω ἀκμαζόντων ἢ τῶν παρηκμακότων; Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ εἰκὸς ὅμοια εἶναι.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the enemy would trust him if he were to allege he were fleeing from Cyrus]
 Εἰ τοίνυν, ἔφη, προσποιησάμενος ἐμὲ φεύγειν ἐθέλοις εἰς τοὺς πολεμίους ἐλθεῖν, οἴομαι ἄν σε πιστευθῆναι ὑπὸ τῶν πολεμίων. Ἔγωγε ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἀράσπας

author: Aristotle
title: Unidentified Work
statement: n/a
remarks: This fragment gives an explanation for the concept that the gods swear by the Styx. First, we are told that her daughter Nike helped the gods in their struggle against the giants, and in exchange for her good deed, Zeus ordered the gods to swear their oaths by Nike's mother Styx. This is taken from Hes. Thg. 383-403 (oath id 1291). An alternative, philosophical, explanation is that water is the mother of all things, and the poets call the river Styx the mother of the gods.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would defend each other in the event of their being wronged by their enemies, but that the Camarinaeans would receive the Athenians only if they put in with a single ship, unless they themselves sent for more]
remarks:
Thucydides states that after the envoys from Syracuse and Athens put to the Camarinaeans their arguments as to why they should support them in the war, the Camarinaeans resolved to help neither the Athenians nor the Syracusans, as they were allies of both parties, and it seemed consistent with their oaths to aid neither. 
For other references to the alliance between Athens and Camarina see oath id 1789. 
For the alliance between Syracuse and Camarina see oath id 1774, 1788, and 1790.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes warns the Athenians that they have been deceived in accepting the peace. He reminds them of the fate of Phocis, Thermopylae, Thrace, Doriscus, Serrium and Cersobleptes. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leochares
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that he will have the clerk read the depositions and the law regarding inheritance, for they are the essential points in the case and the matters upon which they will cast their vote under oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Statesman
statement:
[That his previous statement showed a mistake in his calculation, as Socrates has pointed out]
 Εὖ γε νὴ τὸν ἡμέτερον θεόν, ὦ Σώκρατες, τὸν Ἄμμωνα, καὶ δικαίως, καὶ πάνυ μὲν οὖν μνημονικῶς ἐπέπληξάς μοι τὸ περὶ τοὺς λογισμοὺς ἁμάρτημα.
remarks: The alleged mistake is that Theodorus seems to have assumed that the statesman, the philosopher and the sophist are of equal value. It is not surprising that Theodorus should invoke Ammon, being from Libya, though this is consciously referred to by the explanation 'our god'.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Astyphilus
if_taken: He can proceed with his case
if_refused: He cannot proceed with his case
statement: [That the facts in his written statement were true]
remarks: The speaker calls upon the jurors to decide after considering his declarations under oath (the antomosia which stated that the deceased did not adopt a son, did not bequeath his property, and left no will.).

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the Boeotian woman's "mint shoots" are very neatly plucked out]
 Καὶ νὴ Δία 
 κομψότατα τὴν βληχώ γε παρατετιλμένη.
remarks: The "mint shoots" refer to pubic hair.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
Diodorus tells the jurors that he has been informed that Timocrates will cite as a precedent the statute which contains the words "Nor will I imprison any Athenian citizen who offers three sureties taxed in the same class as himself, except any person found guilty of conspiring to betray the city or to overthrow the democracy, or any tax-farmer or his surety or collector being in default". He argues that this statute is intended to protect those who are still untried, not those who have stood trial. He goes on to argue that Solon wished to deprive the boule of the authority to imprison, and thus included this formula in the bouleutic oath - but not the judicial oath. 
See also oath id 1775.

title: IG I(3)
swearer: Socrates; Democleides; Phormion; Ch[- - -]; Pericles; Glaucon; Callistratus; Xenophon; Tlepolemus
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That they would act and speak and deliberate rightly towards the Samian demos to the best of their ability in accordance with the agreement made between themselves and the Samian magistrates]
 [δρ]άσο καὶ ἐρο̃ καὶ [βολεύσο καλὸν το̃ι δέμοι το̃ι] Σαμίον hό τι ἂν [δύνομαι καὶ ἐπιμελέσομαι Σα]μίον κατὰ hὰ [hομολόγεσαν hοι στρατεγοὶ hοι] Ἀθεναίον [καὶ hοι ἄρχοντες hοι Σαμίον·]
remarks:
This inscription records a treaty between Athens and Samos. 
The oath was sworn by the Athenian strategoi.
