For the corresponding oath taken by the Samians see oath id 158.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Apaturius
if_refused: It will not be resolved and Apaturius will forfeit his deposit
statement: [? That his version of the facts was true]
remarks:
The speaker claims, that after Parmenon began proceedings against Apaturius for assault, he proposed an oath for Apaturius to take about some of the charges. Apaturius agreed to it, and deposited a sum of money which he would forfeit if he did not swear the oath.  
The speaker claims that Apaturius did not present himself to swear the oath because he was aware that many people would know that he had perjured himself, so "in order to escape the oath" (ὡς δὲ δίκῃ λύσων τὸν ὅρκον) he initiated a counter prosecution.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That it seemed to them that their army was at Orestheum marching against the strangers]
 δὴ δοκέειν εἶναι ἐν Ὀρεσθείῳ στίχοντας ἐπὶ τοὺς ξείνους·
remarks:
After Pausanias' army left Sparta, envoys from their allies came and warned that the Athenians would make peace with Persia because the Spartans had abandoned their allies. 
The ephors responded "on oath" (ἐφ’ ὅρκου), that as far as they knew their army was at Orestheum marching against the strangers. 
The envoys did not understand this and asked the ephors for the meaning of their oath, and according to Herodotus, thereby learned the whole truth.

title: IG II(2)
date: Third quarter of the 4th century (349 to 325)
if_taken: He can act as a scrutineer (euthynos)
statement:
[That they would avoid acting unjustly, not themselves, nor through anyone else on their behalf, nor with their knowledge, or by any other manner or means. And if anyone seemed to be in the wrong they would condemn him at the scrutiny and punish him as the offence seemed to them to deserve]
 [- - - - οὔτ’ αὐτὸς ἐγὼ] οὔτ[ε] ἄ[λ]λος ἐμοὶ οὐ[δὲ ἄ]λλ̣ε̣(ι) εἰδότος ἐ̣μο[ῦ μηχανῆι ἢ τ]έ[χνη]ι οὐδεμιᾶι· κ̣α̣ὶ ἐὰν μ[ο]ι [δ]οκεῖ ἀδικεῖν κα[τευθ]υν[ῶ] α[ὐτ]οῦ [καὶ τιμήσ]ω οὗ [ἂ]ν μ[ο]ι [δ]οκεῖ ἄξιον εἶναι τὸ ἀδί[κ]ημα· [νὴ τ]ὸ[ν] Δ[ία ν]ὴ τὸ[ν] Ἀπόλλω νὴ τὴ[ν Δ]ήμ<η>τρα, εὐορ<κ>οῦντι μ[έν] <μ>οι πολ[λ]ὰ κα[ὶ ἀγα]θά, εἰ δ’ ἐπιορκο[ί]ην τἀναντία·
linguistic: nh thn, nh ton, omnu, ork
remarks:
The beginning of the oath of the scrutineers is lost. 
This entry follows the text in Rhodes and Osborne, GHI, 63. Kirchner identified the deme as Myrrhinous. Rhodes and Osborne suggest Hagnous.  
For the oath of the reckoner see oath id 535. For the oath of the advocates see oath id 536. See also oath id 538.  
The text indicates that the demarch will oversee the ballot for those participating in the scrutiny and will exact their oaths.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
statement:
[That Meletus' statement, that all the jury members are able to educate and improve the young, is good news]
 Πῶς λέγεις, ὦ Μέλητε; οἵδε τοὺς νέους παιδεύειν οἷοί τέ εἰσι καὶ βελτίους ποιοῦσιν; Μάλιστα. Πότερον ἅπαντες, ἢ οἱ μὲν αὐτῶν, οἱ δ’ οὔ; Ἅπαντες.  Εὖ γε νὴ τὴν Ἥραν λέγεις
remarks: Swearing by Hera is typical of Socrates- see oath id 1870 with cross references.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That it would also be worth examining how some farmers say that they are being ruined by farming and are without resources while others have a generous supply of all they need from farming]
 Ἂν δὲ καὶ παραπλησίους γεωργίας 
γεωργοῦντας, τοὺς μὲν ἀπολωλέναι φάσκοντας ὑπὸ γεωργίας
καὶ ἀποροῦντας, τοὺς δὲ ἀφθόνως καὶ καλῶς πάντα ἔχον- 
τας ὅσων δέονται ἀπὸ τῆς γεωργίας; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he is indeed educating Callias while flattering him]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη
remarks: Cf. oath id 2281.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Wealth has even more power than that which has already been mentioned]
 Ἐγὼ τοσαῦτα δυνατός εἰμ’ εἷς ὢν ποεῖν; 
 {ΧΡ.} Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία τούτων γε πολλῷ πλείονα·

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That most of the spectators are "wide-arsed", i.e. habitually submit, or formerly submitted, to buggery]
 πολὺ πλείονας, νὴ τοὺς θεούς,
  τοὺς εὐρυπρώκτους.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he remembers his father speaking of the qualities of a good ruler]
 τὸ δέ, τούτου μεγάλου ἔργου ὄντος, οὕτως ἐπίστασθαι ἀνθρώπων ἄλλων προστατεύειν ὅπως ἕξουσι πάντα τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἔκπλεω καὶ ὅπως ἔσονται πάντες οἵους δεῖ,  τοῦτο θαυμαστὸν δήπου ἡμῖν τότε ἐφαίνετο εἶναι. Ναὶ μὰ Δι’, ἔφη, ὦ πάτερ, μέμνημαι καὶ τοῦτό σου λέγοντος·

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
swearer: Kosmos; Damioi; The twenty of the polis
statement: [? That they would not allow anyone who had held the office of kosmos in the last ten years to serve as kosmos again]
remarks: The text states that no man who has held the office of kosmos in the last ten years may hold office again. It then indicates that "the swearers shall be the kosmos, and the damioi and the twenty of the polis" (ὀμόται δὲ κόσμος κοἰ δάμοι κοἰ ἴκατι οἱ τᾶς πόλ̣[ιο]ς)

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The King should allow the Greeks to be autonomous;
2. The Spartans should leave the country and remove their harmosts.
Presumably both parties swore to maintain the status quo pending negotiations]
remarks:
Xenophon states that when Tissaphernes proposed a truce Dercylidas agreed on the condition that the King should allow the Greeks to be autonomous. Tissaphernes agreed, but insisted that the Spartans should leave the country and remove their harmosts from the Greek cities. 
The truce was to last until the proposals were reported back to Sparta by Dercylidas and to the King by Tissaphernes.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That they should adopt the view that happiness awaits the unblemished soul at death]
 οὕτω φῶμεν, ὦ Κέβης, ἢ ἄλλως; Οὕτω νὴ Δία, ἔφη ὁ Κέβης.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
impact: Clytemnestra is grateful for Achilles' support
statement: [That he will never lie or deceive anyone] ψευδῆ λέγων δὲ καὶ μάτην ἐγκερτομῶν, θάνοιμι
remarks: This serves to reinforce Achilles' previous sworn promise not to allow Iphigeneia to be sacrificed (see oath id 188).

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he will lay the Sausage-seller flat]
  Ἐγώ σε νὴ τὸν Ἡρακλέα παραστορῶ.
remarks: Paphlagon makes this statement as he exits- the statement is one of frustration, and not one of actual intent.

author: Isaeus
title: On Behalf of Euphiletus
statement:
[That Euphiletus is his brother, by the same father]
 ἦ μὴν Εὐφίλητον τουτονὶ ἀδελφὸν εἶναι ἐμαυτοῦ ὁμοπάτριον.
remarks:
The speaker (Euphiletus' half-brother) states that he, his father Hegesippus, and Euphiletus' mother are all willing to swear that Euphiletus is legitimate (see also oath id 3184, 3185).  
The speaker goes on to stress that the jurors would be justified in regarding their oaths as more worthy of credence than the statements of their opponents, because whereas they are willing to swear oaths concerning Euphiletus, their opponents are repeating statements which they heard from Euphiletus' enemies or are uttering their own lies.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Fuels the argument between Aeschylus and Euripides
statement:
[That the genesis of the play explained by the character which appeared first in Euripides' dramas was better than the genesis of Euripides- see remarks]
 Εἶτ’ οὐκ ἐλήρουν ὅ τι τύχοιμ’ οὐδ’ ἐμπεσὼν ἔφυρον,
ἀλλ’ οὑξιὼν πρώτιστα μέν μοι τὸ γένος εἶπ’ ἂν εὐθὺς 
τοῦ δράματος.
ΔΙ.  Κρεῖττον γὰρ ἦν σοι νὴ Δί’ ἢ τὸ σαυτοῦ.
remarks: The clumsy paraphrase of the oath statement is intended to reflect the jibe that Aeschylus makes at Euripides' parentage, namely the fact that his mother was allegedly a vegetable seller. See further Sommerstein ad 947 and 840.

author: Theopompus
title: Medos
if_refused: There would not be any alliance(s)
remarks:
This is a reference to the Second Athenian League proposed by Callistratus. Its purpose was to protect the allies against oppression from Sparta. Athens also took measures to allay fears that a second Athenian league might be converted into a second Athenian empire. Namely, the allies had the right of absolute veto on any Athenian proposal of which they did not approve. Also, the settlement of Athenians in allied lands was no longer permitted. See further Diodorus Siculus 15.28. 
See also oath id 2974.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That what Hippias claims to have discovered is a very good thing indeed]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφη, μέγα λέγεις ἀγαθὸν ηὑρηκέναι
remarks: Hippias has just claimed to be able to say something on the matter of Justice which neither Socrates nor anyone else will be able to contradict.  (We never learn what it is!)  Swearing by Hera is typical of Socrates; see oath id 1870 with cross references.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
The prosecutor argues that Demosthenes will try to mislead the Athenians and tell them that he made the Thebans their allies. 
See also oath id 2670.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of Amasis ca.570-525 (570 to 525)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Herodotus notes that Amasis made an alliance with the Cyrenians, and later married Ladice, said by some to be the daughter of Battus.

author: Lysias
title: On overthrowing democracy
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that they ought to regard as the best democrats those who want to be united, and who thus keep to the oaths and agreements, believing that this will be the most satisfactory safeguard for the city. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Nicias addressed the Athenian assembly to speak against the Sicilian expedition, warning the Athenians that although they think the treaty affords them security, if they suffer a defeat in Sicily, their enemies will be quick to attack them. 
Nicias observes that the treaty will continue to exist in name provided they keep quiet, and warns the Athenians that many of the most powerful states have not accepted the agreement. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that it is not right to reckon up what the Athenians could reasonably expect to possess after making the peace as an exchange for what "these men" (i.e. Aeschines and Philocrates) sold. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Alcaeus
title: Fragments
date: Before Myrsilus came to power (612 to 608)
if_broken: May an Erinys pursue the man
statement:
[That they would never (abandon?) any of their comrades, but either die at the hands of men who came against them or kill them and rescue the people from their oaths]
 τὸν Υ̓́ρραον δὲ πα[ῖδ]α πεδελθέ̣τ̣ω̣ 
κήνων Ἐ[ρίννυ]ς ὤς ποτ’ ἀπώμνυμεν 
τόμοντες ἄ..[  ´̣.]ν̣.. 
μηδάμα μηδ’ ἔνα τὼν ἐταίρων 
ἀλλ’ ἢ θάνοντες γᾶν ἐπιέμμενοι 
κείσεσθ’ ὐπ’ ἄνδρων οἲ τότ’ ἐπικ.´̣η̣ν
ἤπειτα κακκτάνοντες αὔτοις 
δᾶμον ὐπὲξ ἀχέων ῤύεσθαι. 
κήνων ὀ φύσγων οὐ διελέξατο
πρὸς θῦμον ἀλλὰ βραϊδίως πόσιν 
ἔ]μβαις ἐπ’ ὀρκίοισι δάπτει 
τὰν πόλιν ἄμμι δέ̣δ̣[.]..[.].ί.αις
remarks: Alcaeus here refers to Pittacus (son of Hyrrhas) "trampling the oaths of his fellow Lesbians" in joining the tyrant Myrsilus and sharing power with him. Myrsilus had come to power after the overthrow of Melanchrus, which we are told happened in the 42nd Olympiad (612-608). Alcaeus calls for an avenging curse to pursue Pittacus, but in fact, Pittacus would be chosen as dictator in 590 when Myrsilus died, and ruled till 580. For the trampling of oaths, cf. oath ids 1381 and 1512.

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Megalopolitans
statement:
[That it is monstrous to choose as allies the men whose ranks they faced at Mantinea (i.e. the Arcadians), and to help them against those with whom they shared the dangers of battle (i.e. the Spartans)]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία ταῦτα μὲν οὕτω δεῖν ἔχειν φήσομεν, δεινὸν δ’ εἰ, πρὸς οὓς παρεταττόμεθ’ ἐν Μαντινείᾳ, τούτους συμμάχους αἱρησόμεθα, εἶτα βοηθήσομεν τούτοις ἐναντία ἐκείνοις μεθ’ ὧν τότ’ ἐκινδυνεύομεν.
remarks: Demosthenes replies to this objection, "I quite agree, provided that the other side [meaning here Sparta] is prepared to act justly".

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he couldn't say whether those who claim that everything is in change would say that everything is changing in both the possible ways - alteration and locomotion - or that some things are changing in both ways and others only in one of them] 
 Τοῦτο τοίνυν οὕτω διελόμενοι διαλεγώμεθα ἤδη τοῖς τὰ πάντα φάσκουσιν κινεῖσθαι καὶ ἐρωτῶμεν· Πότερον πᾶν φατε ἀμφοτέρως κινεῖσθαι, φερόμενόν τε καὶ ἀλλοιούμενον, ἢ τὸ μέν τι ἀμφοτέρως, τὸ δ’ ἑτέρως; {ΘΕΟ.} Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ ἔγωγε οὐκ ἔχω εἰπεῖν·
remarks: He goes on to say that he thinks they would probably say 'in both ways'.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leochares
statement:
[That he put Leochares' name instead of his own on the diamarturia because he had the youth adopted as son to Archiades]
 ὅτι νὴ Δί’, ἂν εἴποι, τοῦτον [γὰρ] εἰσπεποίηκα υἱὸν τῷ Ἀρχιάδῃ.
remarks: The speaker asks why Leostratus put the name of his son on the diamarturia instead of his own when the older facts should have been confirmed by the older man, and imagines that Leochares will respond in this way.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: The Theban and Dicaeopolis meet on amicable terms
statement:
[That Dicaeopolis has done the Theban a favour]
 Νεὶ τὸν Ἰόλαν ἐπεχαρίττω γ’, ὦ ξένε·
remarks: The Theban swears by Iolaus as the nephew of Heracles. See also oath id 616.  The "favour" that Dicaeopolis has done for the Theban is to drive away the pipers who had come from Thebes with him; it appears likely (see Olson on 862-3) that we are to take this statement of thanks as sincere, and that the merchant's apparent invitation to the pipers to play a tune (863) is a thinly disguised insult to them.

author: Demosthenes
title: On Halonnesus
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Hegesippus refers to a proposed Athenian amendment to the peace - namely that all the Greeks who were not parties to the peace should remain free and independent, and that the signatories should unite to defend them if attacked - and accuses Philip of robbing the Thessalians and Epirotes of their independence (see oath id 3824) even though he has stated in his letter that he accepts the amendment and considers it to be just. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearee: Hermocrates, son of Hermon; Heracleides, son of Lysimachus; Sicanus son of Execestus
if_taken: The generals would (hopefully) be assured of the support of the Syracusans
statement:
[That they would allow the generals to command according to their judgement ]
 ὀμόσαι αὐτοῖς τὸ ὅρκιον ἦ μὴν ἐάσειν ἄρχειν ὅπῃ ἂν ἐπίστωνται·
remarks:
Thucydides states that after the Syracusans were defeated by the Athenians, Hermocrates son of Hermon advised them to reduce the number of generals from the existing fifteen, give them full powers, and swear an oath that they would allow them to command according to their wisdom. 
The Syracusans voted everything that he advised and elected three generals: Hermocrates himself, Heracleides son of Lysimachus and Sicanus son of Execestus.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Lycomedes persuaded the Ten Thousand to negotiate an alliance with the Athenians. Lycomedes himself led the Arcadian delegation. 
The Athenians were initially divided on the issue because they were also allies of the Spartans who were at war with the Arcadians. But when they learned that the alliance would not disadvantage the Spartans they accepted the alliance with the Arcadians. Xenophon makes it clear that the alliance did not disadvantage Sparta, because to refuse the alliance would have driven the Arcadians into the arms of Thebes (7.4.2). 
When Lycomedes left Athens he had the misfortune to land near a spot where Arcadian exiles happened to be and was killed. 
For this alliance see also oath id 2036.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Cilicians; King of Assyria; Lycaonians; Arabians; Phoenicians; Ionians; Aeolians; Most Greeks in Asia
swearee: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Cilicians; King of Assyria; Lycaonians; Arabians; Phoenicians; Ionians; Aeolians; Most Greeks in Asia
statement: [That they would fight together in attacking the Medes and Persians]
remarks: Apparently the allies were convinced of the need for the alliance by the Assyrian king's suggestions that the Medes and the Persians, who had intermarried, and were powerful nations, would be likely to make war on each of the other nations and subjugate them. Those who were unconvinced by such arguments were apparently bribed to join the alliance.  Cf. oath ids 2326, 2385 and 2389. The allies subsequently begin to desert- see oath id 2387.   In book 6, the Indian spies report to Cyrus that Croesus has been made leader and general over all the allied kings. They also report that Thracian swordsmen had been hired and 120,000 armed Egyptians were sailing to join them (see oath id 2449). Indians were listed amongst the original allies (see oath id references above) but are not mentioned here for obvious reasons, and the Carians are also absent, though Lycaonians, Arabians, Phoenicians, Ionians, Aeolians and almost all the Greek colonists in Asia have now seemingly joined the alliance. Also, in book 6, the Assyrian king, whose father had originally proposed the alliance has fled and left his troops under the king of Babylon. The Hyrcanians, subjects of Assyria, had previously deserted- see oath id 2387. Now, Cyrus reminds his troops how Croesus fled rather than standing by his allies, when he saw the Syrians (i.e. the Assyrians) defeated (cf. oath id 2387).

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement: [That he would rule according to the established nomoi; and that he would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
remarks: The Athenian here blames the kings of Argos, Messene and Sparta for ultimately bringing ruin on themselves because they were not in agreement about their oath (see oath ids 2678-83).

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
impact: Emphasises the truth of the statement
statement:
[That he did not bash on the old woman's door]
  {Γρ. α}  καὶ τὴν θύραν γ’ ἤραττες. {Επ.} ἀποθάνοιμ’ ἄρα.
remarks: This is a conditional self-curse, implying an oath.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
if_taken: They would be allowed to judge
if_refused: They would not be allowed to judge
impact: Fair choice of new deme members
statement: [That they would judge fairly]
remarks: This is an oath which the deme members swear when scrutinizing the age and legitimacy of young men for registration as new members of the deme. The members should decide whether the men who present themselves are of the age prescribed by law (18) and whether they are free men and born as prescribed by the laws. 42.2.3-4 records that deme members are punished if the young men are found to be under 18.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That Euthydemus should show him that he already has the knowledge he seeks]
 Ἐπίδειξον τοίνυν με νὴ Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ, ἔχοντα

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that an alliance was made between Athens and Argos, and at the same time both made an alliance with Thessaly on the same terms and confirmed by the same oaths. 
See also oath id 1555 and 1566.

author: Euripides
title: Andromache
statement: [That they will join with Orestes in plotting the death of Neoptolemus]
remarks: Since this is in effect a conspiracy, it is likely that Orestes is to be imagined as swearing to the Delphians as well as they to him, but this is not actually stated.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That there are no railings present (in their mock court)]
  μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ πάρεστιν.

author: Alexis
title: Olynthioi
date: After the destruction of Olythus (348)? (347 to 322)
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a general reflection on the unreliability of oaths, and on the superiority of facts to oaths. In other words, if evidence available to you proves that X is false, then people can swear it’s true till they’re blue in the face and you still ought not to believe them. Arnott ad loc. notes that characters in later comedy are often advised to avoid oaths or place no trust in them. Cf. oath ids 1408, 1433, 1446.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_refused: Antilochus will not get the prize
statement:
[That he did not cheat in the chariot race]
 — Ἀντίλοχ’ εἰ δ’ ἄγε δεῦρο διοτρεφές, ἣ θέμις ἐστί, 
στὰς ἵππων προπάροιθε καὶ ἅρματος, αὐτὰρ ἱμάσθλην
χερσὶν ἔχε ῥαδινήν, ᾗ περ τὸ πρόσθεν ἔλαυνες, 
ἵππων ἁψάμενος γαιήοχον ἐννοσίγαιον
ὄμνυθι μὴ μὲν ἑκὼν τὸ ἐμὸν δόλῳ ἅρμα πεδῆσαι.
remarks: This is the same oath referred to at id 421. It is refused by Antilochus who concedes and offers full restitution to Menelaus, suggesting that he had, in fact, cheated (though not giving up his claim to be rightfully entitled to the prize). Menelaus accepts his offer of restitution.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Pseudartabas is made to repeat what he has said more clearly

title: IC II
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: All that can be determined is that an oath with an explicit curse was sworn.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 2
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
statement: [That Boeotus and Pamphilus were sons of Mantias]
remarks: Mantitheus argues that if someone were to come forward and indict Boeotus for usurping the rights of citizens, alleging that Mantias had denied on oath that Boeotus was his son (see oath id 3580), Boeotus would not be able to rely on anything other than the fact that his father had been forced to admit that Boeotus was his son because of Plangon's oath and the decision of the arbitrator (see also oath id 3562).

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
impact: This is an emphatic acceptance of Ischomachus' point
statement:
[That he believes Ischomachus' view that all men naturally love those things which they think will benefit them]
 Νὴ Δία, ἐγὼ δέ γέ σοι, ἔφην, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, ἐπομόσας λέγω ἦ μὴν πιστεύειν σοι φύσει [νομίζειν] φιλεῖν ταῦτα πάντας ἀφ’ ὧν ἂν ὠφελεῖσθαι νομίζωσιν.
remarks: This is a unique example (so far) of an informal oath qualified by a verb of swearing. Strictly speaking, Socrates is swearing that he is swearing!

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
Andocides says that he has heard people saying that because of the last peace (404) the Thirty were established, many Athenians died drinking hemlock and others fled into exile. He also observes that the Spartans made them demolish walls, surrender their fleet and recall exiles. 
Andocides contrasts this truce with the proposed peace which will allow them to build walls, maintain as many warships as they wish and keep Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros, while not compelling them to receive back their exiles. 
See also oath id 1893.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Pheidippides will not eat anything of his] 
  οὐκ ἄρα μὰ τὴν Δήμητρα τῶν γ’ ἐμῶν ἔδει

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he wants Demosthenes to tell him (who the man is with the extraordinary profession)]
 Εἴπω;  {ΝΙ.}  Νὴ Δία.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that Philip demanded that his allies the Byzantines assist him against Athens, and that when they refused, saying that they had not made their alliance with him under those terms, he besieged them. 
It is clear that this alliance did not include a clause that Philip and the Byzantines were to have the same friends and enemies. 
See also oath id 3263.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Greeks in Thrace
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Greeks in Thrace
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The Corinthians argued that it would not be right for them to join the treaty with Athens because they would be betraying their allies in Thrace. The Corinthians claimed that had given oaths to these allies "in private" (ἰδίᾳ) i.e. they were acting independently from the Spartans, when they revolted along with Potidaea and then other oaths later. 
The Corinthians maintained that they could not join the treaty because of the clause which stated that they were bound to obey "unless it was objectionable to the gods or the heroes" because they would be violating their oaths to the Greeks in Thrace which would be inherently objectionable to the gods and heroes.  
Thucydides states, "these things they said concerning their oaths of old (τῶν παλαιῶν ὅρκων)".

author: Lysias
title: Against Simon
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [? That he knew well that the defendant had wounded with the intent to kill]
remarks:
The defendant argues, "Since he [Simon] cares nothing for the oaths he has sworn, I will try to inform you concerning the lies he has told". 
See also oath id 2808.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
if_taken: They will be able to testify
if_refused: They will not be able to testify
statement: [That Euxitheus' mother Nicarete was an Athenian]
remarks:
Euxitheus calls Damostratus and Apollodorus to testify that his mother was an Athenian. 
He then says that he will call other (closer) relatives to testify. He names Timocrates, his maternal uncle and Timocrates' son Euxitheus, and adds that Euxitheus had three sons. He then calls "those of them who are still in Athens". It is not stated that these additional witnesses swore before testfiying, but there is not reason why they should not have done so, and they were probably required by law to do so.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Aristogeiton
statement:
[That the defendant is himself a man of sober character, coming from a good family, that he has done the Athenians many noble services in private and public life and that therefore the dikastai would be justified in sparing him]
 Ἀλλ’ αὐτὸς ὁ κρινόμενος νὴ Δία μέτριος τὸν τρόπον, καὶ προγόνων χρηστῶν, καὶ πόλλ’ ὑμᾶς καὶ ἰδίᾳ καὶ δημοσίᾳ καλὰ εἰργασμένος, ὥστε διὰ τ⌈α⌉ῦτ’ ἄξιόν ἐστιν αὐτοῦ φείσασθαι;
remarks: The prosecutor hypothesises that someone might object that Aristogeiton is a man of sober character, coming from a good family, that he has done you many noble services in private and public life and that therefore you are justified in sparing him.  From all we know of Aristogeiton's reputation (from this speech and Demosthenes 25 and 26) it is very unlikely that such an assertion would be made, and the speaker at once proceeds to demonstrate its absurdity.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the best way to make men eager is not to be forthcoming]
 Εἰ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, πρῶτον μὲν τοῖς κεκορεσμένοις μήτε προσφέροις μήτε ὑπομιμνῄσκοις, ἕως ἂν τῆς πλησμονῆς παυσάμενοι πάλιν δέωνται, ἔπειτα τοὺς δεομένους ὑπομιμνῄσκοις ὡς κοσμιωτάτῃ τε ὁμιλίᾳ καὶ τῷ μὴ φαίνεσθαι βουλομένη χαρίζεσθαι καὶ διαφεύγουσα, ἕως ἂν ὡς μάλιστα δεηθῶσι·

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
remarks: Andocides is considering, and rejecting, a series of justifications that might be offered for continuing the war.  This one is the last and most improbable, since, as he immediately goes on to say, Athens, at least in his opinion, does not have the wherewithal to achieve the suggested aim, and in any case would be likely to suffer for it afterwards at Persian hands.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: When Lamprocles was a young man (405 to 399)
statement:
[That the state looks into the failure of individuals to honour their parents' graves when examining candidates for office]
 καὶ νὴ Δία ἐάν τις τῶν γονέων τελευτησάντων τοὺς τάφους μὴ κοσμῇ, καὶ τοῦτο ἐξετάζει ἡ πόλις ἐν ταῖς τῶν ἀρχόντων δοκιμασίαις.
remarks: Cf. remarks on oath id 2054.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 1
statement:
[That they are not at peace, but at war with Philip]
 μὰ Δί’ οὐχ ἡμεῖς γ’,’ εἴποιτ’ ἄν, ‘ἀλλὰ Φιλίππῳ πολεμοῦμεν.
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the Athenians that if someone asked them whether they were at peace they would reply that they were not, but at war with Philip. 
He then goes on to criticise the Athenian generals.

author: Ananius
title: Fragment
statement:
[That the swearer loves the swearee by far the most of all people]
 καὶ σὲ πολλὸν ἀνθρώπων
ἐγὼ φιλέω μάλιστα, ναὶ μὰ τὴν κράμβην.
remarks: Swearing by "Cabbage" is clearly a comic oath, but cf. Hipponax fr. 104.47-49 where someone entreats a seven-leafed cabbage "which he used to offer in a pot to Pandora at the Thargelia" (trans. Gerber). For invocation of the cabbage as Eideshort see also oath ids 1438, 1470, 1483.  Compare also oath id 1382 "by the Poppy Leaf" and oath id 1468 “ by the Almond Tree”.

author: Isocrates
title: Antidosis
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Isocrates argues that even though the Athenians swear each year to hear impartially both the prosecutors and the defendants, they depart so far from this in practice that they listen to all that the prosecutor has to say but sometimes don't even listen to the voice of the defendant. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [? That his version of events is true]
remarks: Apollodorus asks the jurors whether they can imagine that Archebiades would perjure himself (see oath id 3646) in order that the money might go to Cephisiades, a metic, might get the money, or to Phormion who, according to Callippus, erased something from the deposit ledger.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement:
[That they will vote for all the decrees awarding the honours conferred on Charidemus to all their benefactors]
 ψηφιούμεθα νὴ Δία.
remarks: Euthycles asks whether they should vote for decrees conferring the honours for Charidemus to all their benefactors, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his question.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and that they would respect the division of Cotys' former kingdom and not attempt to change the settlement by force, and that the Athenians would receive back their possessions ]
remarks:
This decree records a treaty between Athens and the Thracian kings Berisades, Amadocus and Cersebleptes.  
See also oath id 2576, 2661, 3272, 3432, 3454, 3455.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she does recognise the man (he is her husband Cinesias)]
 Γιγνώσκει τις ὑμῶν; 
  {ΜΥ.}  Νὴ Δία  
  ἔγωγε· κἄστιν οὑμὸς ἀνὴρ Κινησίας.

author: Plato
title: Hipparchus
statement:
[That he doesn't consider as profit a banquet after which one gets ill, even if the banquet had been enjoyable and one had not incurred any expense by it]
 Ἆρα καὶ τὰ τοιάδε λέγεις, ἐάν τις ἑστιαθείς, μηδὲν ἀναλώσας ἀλλ’ εὐωχηθείς, νόσον κτήσηται;  {ΕΤ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he thinks Critobulus has kissed Cleinias (and that this has inflamed his passion)]
 καίτοι νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ὦ ἄνδρες, δοκεῖ μοί γ’, ἔφη, ὡς ἐν ἡμῖν αὐτοῖς εἰρῆσθαι, οὗτος καὶ πεφιληκέναι τὸν Κλεινίαν·

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Xenophon records the names of the Spartan ephors holding office at the end of the war, and observes that Aenesias had taken office during the fifteenth year after the thirty years' peace was made after the capture of Euboea. 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That a painter who painted the ideal of a beautiful man would be no less good a painter should he not be able to prove that it is possible for the subject of his painting to exist]
 Οἴει ἂν οὖν ἧττόν τι ἀγαθὸν ζωγράφον εἶναι ὃς ἂν γράψας παράδειγμα οἷον ἂν εἴη ὁ κάλλιστος ἄνθρωπος καὶ πάντα εἰς τὸ γράμμα ἱκανῶς ἀποδοὺς μὴ ἔχῃ ἀποδεῖξαι ὡς καὶ δυνατὸν γενέσθαι τοιοῦτον ἄνδρα;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’, ἔφη.
remarks: This is an analogy for the vailidity of their discussion of the ideal state.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That ordinary clouds don't look like women]  
 εἴξασιν δ’ οὖν ἐρίοισιν πεπταμένοισιν,
  κοὐχὶ γυναιξίν, μὰ Δί’

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, when King Cotys (Otys) disobeyed a command of the Great King he feared that he would be seized, fined or put to death, and trusting in a truce he had made with Agesilaus (see oath id 2305), he came into Agesilaus' camp, made an alliance, and chose to take the field with him, bringing a thousand horse and two thousand light horse. 
See also oath id 1920.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Athenogenes
statement:
[That she was speaking out of goodwill for the speaker and telling him the whole truth]
ἦ μὴν με]τ’ εὐνοίας τῆς ἐμῆς λέγειν καὶ ἐπὶ πάση̣]ς ἀληθείας,
remarks:
The speaker states that when he told his mistress Antigone (a hetaira) that Athenogenes had been rude to him and unwilling to come to an agreement, she said that Athenogenes was always like that, and told him not to worry. He tells the jurors that her manner could not have been more sincere, and that she swore the greatest oaths to show that she was speaking out of goodwill for him and truthfully. 
He goes on to say that he took Antigone at her word, but that she was cheating him from start to finish.

author: Isocrates
title: Concerning the team of horses
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
The speaker - Alcibiades the younger - reminds the jurors that his father caused the most powerful cities in the Peloponnese to revolt from the Spartans and brought them into alliance with Athens. 
This must be a reference to the alliance between Athens, Argos, Mantinea and Elis ca.420 (see also oath id 251).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That he thinks the cases of the other debtors to the state are not the same as that of Aristogeiton, nor anything like it, but quite different]
 οὐ μέντοι μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς τούτῳ γ’ ὑπάρχειν ὁμοίους οἴομαι τούτους, οὐδὲ πολλοῦ δεῖ, ἀλλὰ καὶ τοὐναντίον.
remarks: The speaker states that Aristogeiton says that there are many men in debt to the state, and all of them are in the same case as himself. This oath is his response to Aristogeiton's claim.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Athenians came to defence of the Corcyraeans in their dispute with Corinth
statement:
[That they would defend each other should anyone attack Corcyra or Athens or the allies of either]
 ἐπιμαχίαν δ’ ἐποιήσαντο τῇ ἀλλήλων βοηθεῖν, ἐάν τις ἐπὶ Κέρκυραν ἴῃ ἢ Ἀθήνας ἢ τοὺς τούτων ξυμμάχους
remarks:
According to Thucydides, the Athenians decided to make a defensive alliance rather than an offensive and defensive alliance to ensure that they were not breaking the Thirty Years' Peace. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1534, 1587 and 1647.

author: Magnes
title: Pytakides
statement:
[That s/he had never been a <insert something discreditable>]
 εἰπέ μοι, νυνδὴ μὲν ὤμνυς μὴ γεγονέναι, νῦν δὲ φῄς.
remarks: Presumably the person is not purported to have sworn that they had "never been born" which is what the line would mean if it were not elliptical.  Prima facie the oath is false, since the swearer has apparently just contradicted it; but perhaps the contradiction is explicable (e.g. by some piece of comic casuistry), or perhaps the verb of swearing is being used in the “Sophoclean” sense. The speaker may have caught his interlocutor in a sophistic language-trap, as Euthydemus and his brother repeatedly do in Plato's dialogue of that name, and induced him to make two statements that can be twisted into seeming to contradict each other.

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That he has never had anything to do with any of the sophists, nor would he allow of any of his family to associate with them]
 Οὐδὲ μὰ Δία ἔγωγε συγγέγονα πώποτε αὐτῶν οὐδενί, οὐδ’ ἂν ἄλλον ἐάσαιμι τῶν ἐμῶν οὐδένα.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That (if they charge at the women) they will learn that there are four whole companies of fully armed fighting women inside the Acropolis]
 Νὴ τὼ θεὼ γνώσεσθ’ ἄρα 
 ὅτι καὶ παρ’ ἡμῖν εἰσι τέτταρες λόχοι
 μαχίμων γυναικῶν ἔνδον ἐξωπλισμένων.
remarks: For swearing by Demeter and Persephone, see remarks on id 788.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
impact: the Macronians helped the Greeks cut down trees to build a bridge
statement:
[That they would not harm each other]
 ὅτι οὐ κακῶς γε ποιήσοντες
remarks:
When the Greeks were met by a force of Macronians in battle array they asked who they were. 
The Macronians responded by identifying themselves, and asking why the Greeks were coming against their land. 
The Greeks responded that they had not come to do them any harm whatsover, and that they had been at war with the King and were on their way back to Greece. 
The Macronians asked whether they would give pledges to this effect and the Greeks replied that they were ready to give and receive pledges. 
Thereupon the Macronians gave the Greeks a barbarian spear and the Greeks gave them a Greek spear, for the Macronians declared that these were pledges. Both sides called upon the gods to witness.

author: Isocrates
title: Aegineticus
statement:
[That they would vote in accordance with the laws]
 ὑμῶν δὲ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ὀμωμοκότων ψηφιεῖσθαι
remarks: The speaker asks the jurors from what illegal act his opponents would abstain when they are attempting to persuade the jurors to declare his father's will invalid even though the laws have been read and the jurors have sworn to vote in accordance with them.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That Aeschines would not have told the logistai not to call Demosthenes to account for the second embassy if he had anything true to say in accusation of Demosthenes]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἀπηγόρευε καλεῖν.
remarks: Demosthenes claims that Aeschines told the logistai not to call Demosthenes to undergo the euthynai for the second embassy to Philip because he did not want to undergo the scrutiny himself. Demosthenes argues that this is proof that Aeschines is guilty. Demosthenes claims that if Aeschines had anything true to say about him he would have made a speech of accusation at that time, and certainly would not have been telling the logistai not to call him.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would be loyal to Athens, and be just and guileless in their dealings with them]
remarks: This Athenian decree honouring the demos of Samos promises that the Samians shall be autonomous and that they shall act in all respects in accordance with the oaths and treaties agreed by the Athenians and the Samians. This is clearly a reference to an earlier alliance between Athens and Samos.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he is not afraid of Bdelycleon]
 ἐγὼ δ’
  ἀπολοίμην εἰ σὲ δέδοικα.
remarks: Cf. oath id 1093.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That it will really do him good if he twists his neck]
  Περίαγε τὸν τράχηλον.  
  {ΕΠ.}  Νὴ Δία 
  ἀπολαύσομαί τί γ’, εἰ διαστραφήσομαι
remarks: Ironical exclamation.

author: Ergias
title: FGrH # 513
if_taken: Terms to end the siege would be formalised
if_refused: Terms to end the siege would not be formalised
impact: Phalanthus and his men leave the city to Iphicles
statement:
[That Phalanthus and his men could take out of the city anything that they had in the belly and that Iphicles would provide them with boats]
 Ὡς δὲ καὶ τοὺς ἰχθῦς εἶδεν, ὑπέλαβε  
τὴν χώραν οὐκ ἔτι αὐτῶν εἶναι, καὶ ἐπεκηρυκεύσατο 
πρὸς τὸν Ἴφικλον, ὑπόσπονδος ὑπεξελθεῖν ἀξιῶν μετὰ
τῶν σὺν αὑτῷ. Συγκαταθεμένου δὲ τοῦ Ἰφίκλου, ἐπι-  
τεχνᾶται ὁ Φάλανθος τοιόνδε τι. Καταβαλὼν ἱερεῖα 
καὶ τὰς κοιλίας ἐκκαθάρας, ἐν ταύταις ἐπειρᾶτο ἐξάγειν  
χρυσίον καὶ ἀργύριον. Αἰσθόμενος δὲ ὁ Ἴφικλος διε-
κώλυσε. Προσφέροντός τε τοῦ Φαλάνθου τὸν ὅρκον, ὃν
ὤμοσεν, ἐάσειν ἐξάγεσθαι ὅ τι κατὰ γαστρὸς αἴρωνται,
ἀντισοφίζεται, πλοῖα αὐτοῖς διδοὺς, ἵνα ἀποκομισθῶσι, 
παραλύσας τὰ πηδάλια καὶ τὰς κώπας καὶ τὰ ἱστία, 
ὀμόσαι φήσας πλοῖα παρέξειν, ἄλλο δὲ οὐδέν.
remarks: Both Phalanthus and Iphicles technically keep their oaths, but each manages to bend the meaning of his oath. Phalanthus and his men try to smuggle gold and silver out of the city in the bellies of their animals, while Iphicles provides boats but no oars, sails or rudders. In fact, Iphicles had tricked Phalanthus into surrendering the city. There was an oracle that the city would hold until ravens became white and fish appeared in mixing bowls but Iphicles got a reliable servant to put fish into the mixing bowls and paint ravens with gypsum.

author: Pindar
title: Olympian 7
impact: Rhodes becomes the island of Helios
statement:
[That Rhodes would belong to Helios]
 ἐκέλευσεν δ’ αὐτίκα χρυσάμπυκα μὲν Λάχεσιν 
χεῖρας ἀντεῖναι, θεῶν δ’ ὅρκον μέγαν 
μὴ παρφάμεν,
ἀλλὰ Κρόνου σὺν παιδὶ νεῦσαι, 
  φαεννὸν ἐς αἰθέρα μιν πεμφθεῖσαν ἑᾷ κεφαλᾷ  
ἐξοπίσω γέρας ἔσσε‐
  σθαι.
remarks: Here we are told how Lachesis (the goddess of apportionment) is instructed not to break "the great oath of the gods" (i.e. swearing by the Styx) but to agree with Zeus that the island of Rhodes should be allotted to Helios.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker argues that Alexander has violated the clause in the agreement stipulating that "all parties to the peace may sail the seas, and that none may hinder them or force a ship of any of them to come to a harbour, and that anyone who violates this shall be treated as an enemy by all the parties to the peace" by forcing Athenian grain ships coming from the Black Sea to put in at Tenedos. 
He argues that such a stupid and gross violation of the oaths almost cost Alexander the right to command at sea when the Athenians voted to launch a fleet and thereby forced him to end his interference with the traffic. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_broken: May Odysseus lose his head and never again be called the father of Telemachus
statement:
[That if he finds Thersites playing the fool once more, he will take him and strip him naked and send him back howling to the ships]
 ἀλλ’ ἔκ τοι ἐρέω, τὸ δὲ καὶ τετελεσμένον ἔσται·
εἴ κ’ ἔτι σ’ ἀφραίνοντα κιχήσομαι ὥς νύ περ ὧδε,
μηκέτ’ ἔπειτ’ ᾿Οδυσῆϊ κάρη ὤμοισιν ἐπείη,
μηδ’ ἔτι Τηλεμάχοιο πατὴρ κεκλημένος εἴην, 
εἰ μὴ ἐγώ σε λαβὼν ἀπὸ μὲν φίλα εἵματα δύσω,
χλαῖνάν τ’ ἠδὲ χιτῶνα, τά τ’ αἰδῶ ἀμφικαλύπτει, 
αὐτὸν δὲ κλαίοντα θοὰς ἐπὶ νῆας ἀφήσω 
πεπλήγων ἀγορῆθεν ἀεικέσσι πληγῇσιν.
remarks: Odysseus is not forced to fulfill his oath because the threat is enough to stop Thersites' abuses. Cf. oath id 339 for a similar self-curse as oath.

author: Thucydides
title: History
date: 431-400 i.e. the period that Thucydides describes (431 to 400)
swearee: The other members of the sworn band
if_taken: He could be part of a sworn band
if_refused: He could not be part of a sworn band
statement: [? That he would fight while he was alive, and would not regard being alive as more important than being free; that he would not leave his taxiarch or his enomotarch, whether he was alive or dead, and that he would bury the dead among his fellow-fighters, and that he would leave no-one unburied]
remarks:
Thucydides describes the Spartan chain of command, whereby the king gives orders to the polemarchs, the polemarchs to the lochagoi, the lochagoi to the pentekosteres, the pentekosteres to the enomotarchs, and the enomotarchs to the enomotiai i.e. the "sworn bands" that each Spartan joined as an adolescent. 
Thucydides states that at the battle at Mantinea each Spartan enomotia was deployed to a depth of four men. What Thucydides seems to be saying is that while the depth of the phalanx was at the discretion of the lochos commander, the normal depth was eight; if so, an enomotia would normally have 32 men, a pentekostus (despite its name) 128, and a lochos 512. 
See also oath id 1272.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that he told the ambassadors to set sail for the Hellespont as quickly as possible, and not to abandon any of these places and allow Philip to occupy them. 
Demosthenes claims that he did so because he thought that Athens would gain one of two advantages. Either, once they had administered the oaths to Philip in accordance with the decree he would return what he had taken from Athens, or, if he did not return them, the Athenian ambassadors would report his failure to do so back to Athens at once. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Answer to Philip's Letter
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the Athenians that they should expect that the gods will be their mightiest allies and supporters since Philip has perfidiously broken the peace, violating his promises and oaths. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

title: LSAM
statement: [? That they did present gifts to the priestess of Artemis, or did make sacrifices]
remarks: The text indicates that those accused of not making presentations of gifts to the priestess of Artemis or making sacrifices are either to "deny the crime under oath in the boule" (εἰὰμ μὴ ἐξομόσει ἐν τῆι βουλῆι), or to owe a fine to the exactors of punishment, who are to punish him.

author: Plato
title: Republic
impact: Emphasises the importance of the inquiry
statement:
[That they must not abandon the inquiry into managing the education of the guardians, even if it should prove rather long]
 Μὰ Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, ὦ φίλε Ἀδείμαντε, οὐκ ἄρα ἀφετέον, οὐδ’ εἰ μακροτέρα τυγχάνει οὖσα.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
After Clearchus and most of the other Greek generals had been executed by the Persians, Ariaeus addressed the Greeks and told them that "Clearchus, inasmuch as he was shown to be perjuring himself and violating the truce has received his deserts and is dead". 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2105.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he does excel more in kindness than in generalship (because he enjoys deeds of kindness much more than deeds of generalship]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος·
remarks: Cyrus here agrees with Gobryas' previous statement- see oath id 2491.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That if the demos protests and says that it is not right for a grown-up son (the tyrant) to be supported by his father, but the reverse, the demos will then learn to its cost what it is and what a creature it has begotten (i.e. he thinks that the tyrant will use force against his father, who,  in this passage, is the demos itself)] 
 Γνώσεταί γε, νὴ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, τότ’ ἤδη ὁ δῆμος οἷος οἷον θρέμμα γεννῶν ἠσπάζετό τε καὶ ηὖξεν, καὶ ὅτι ἀσθενέστερος ὢν ἰσχυροτέρους ἐξελαύνει.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other's territory]
remarks:
Polydamas of Pharsalus, the proxenos to Sparta, travelled to Sparta to appeal for their assistance against Jason of Pherae. 
He reported that Jason had concluded a truce with Pharsalus, and then told Polydamas of his military strength.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
impact: Seuthes curses the man who did not pay the Greeks and agrees to pay the money
statement:
[That even if Seuthes had offered to pay what was due to him, he would not have accepted it unless the soldiers were also at the same time to recover what was due to them]
 ὄμνυμι δέ σοι μηδὲ ἀποδιδόντος δέξασθαι ἄν, εἰ μὴ καὶ οἱ στρατιῶται ἔμελλον τὰ ἑαυτῶν συναπολαμβάνειν.
remarks: This passage raises a question of general interest about oaths whose veracity can never be confirmed or refuted.  It is an oath - and a "formal" oath at that - about what Xenophon would have done in a hypothetical situation that never actually existed.  It is thus a particularly pure case of a statement for which the oath provides the sole possible means of confirmation.  There are, of course, many situations in which there is in practice no way to confirm or to refute a sworn statement; there are not so many in which, as here, confirmation or refutation are logically impossible (and will be until there are truly reliable lie-detectors).  A modern parallel is the question nearly always asked of the main prosecution witness in a fraud trial, "Would you have paid him the money if you had not believed that he was being truthful/honest about.. ?".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Sparta at the start of the war in 431 as all of the Peloponnesians within the Isthmus except for Argos and Achaea (Pellene was the only Achaean city allied to Sparta), Megara, the Locrians (the Opuntian and Epicnemidian), the Boeotians, Phocians, the Ambraciots, the Leucadians and Anactorians. 
The first official meeting of the so-called Peloponnesian League took place ca.504 after the abortive invasion of Attica. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Aristarchus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The speaker states that "when peace came" at the end of the Corinthian War he had difficulties with the public treasury "(a euphemistic way of saying that he was deprived for a time of his citizen rights for being in debt to the state)". 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
if_taken: The judgement would be set aside
if_refused: He will be confirmed as guilty
statement: [That his absence had been unavoidable]
remarks: Demosthenes states that after Straton of Phalerum decided the case against Meidias, he applied to have Straton's judgement set aside, but then failed to attend at the proper time to take the oath that his absence from the arbitration had been unavoidable. Thus, Meidias was reported to have not taken the oath, and Straton's judgement against him automatically became final and binding.

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
statement:
[That he believes that 'to become' and 'to be' are different]
 ταὐτόν σοι δοκεῖ εἶναι τὸ γενέσθαι καὶ τὸ εἶναι, ἢ ἄλλο;  Ἄλλο νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Πρόδικος.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Phormion
if_taken: He can give a valid verdict
if_refused: His verdict will be a nullity
statement: [? That he would give a true verdict]
remarks: The speaker states that when his dispute with Phormion was brought before Theodotus for arbitration, Theodotus did not want to convict Phormion because they were connected to each other, but was reluctant to dismiss the case for fear of committing perjury i.e. by breaking his oath to give a true verdict.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he'd be better off renouncing his father altogether rather than battling with all these troubles day after day]
 νὴ Δί’ ἦ μοι κρεῖττον ἐκστῆναι τὸ παράπαν τοῦ πατρὸς 
  μᾶλλον ἢ κακοῖς τοσούτοις ναυμαχεῖν ὁσημέραι.
remarks: Like Bdelycleon's statement at id 1071, this is surely an exaggeration based on his frustrations at his present situation. As Sommerstein remarks ad 478: "in theory a son could [renounce his father] by having himself adopted by another (childless) man, who then took over all paternal rights in relation to him. For an only son to take this step, however, would certainly incur strong social disapproval as a dereliction of the son's duty to maintain his father in old age; and we know of no case in which an only son of a living father allowed himself to be adopted.... Yet Bdelycleon is so exasperated by the trials of his long struggle to cure Philocleon of his addiction to jury service that he wonders if this shocking action might not be the lesser evil".

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a metaphorical oath. There is no actual statement. The placing of a boundary stone is said to make Zeus a witness, and the boundary stone itself is "enorkos", i.e. "it has an oath in it". Anyone who moves the boundary stone is as one who has committed perjury. Zeus Homophylos is witness for those of the city, Zeus Xenios for foreigners on the frontier. The fury of the gods is said to bring deadly wars. He that obeys the law will not suffer evils, but whoever despises the law will be liable to a double penalty- both from the gods and from the law. Under the law, whoever has moved a boundary stone can be brought to court, and if found guilty the court will decide on an appropriate penalty.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes again complains that Aeschines and Philocrates had the clause "also to Philip's descendants" added to the peace treaty. Demosthenes argues that this clause has deprived the next generation of Athenians of their hopes for the future. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the lawsuits will be about lots of things]
 τοῦ γὰρ τάλαν οὕνεκ’ ἔσονται; 
 {Βλ.}  πολλῶν οὕνεκα, νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω·
remarks: Blepyrus believes his statement to be true, but Praxagora will prove all his arguments to be false in the context of this new society in which lawsuits will not be necessary. Cf. oath id 820.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he will repay what was being lent to him]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἀποδώσειν γ’ ἐπώμνυς τοὺς θεούς
remarks: It is not clear whether the oath was volunteered or exacted.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
consequences_of_breach: The Armenian king is hunted down
statement: [That they would fight alongside each other]
remarks: In a speech to his men, Cyrus relates how the Armenian king, formerly an ally and subject of Cyaxares, has now deserted his alliance on seeing the enemy approaching. Cyrus therefore instructs his men to hunt down the Armenian king as if hunting an animal.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That they will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, they shall help with all their strength]
remarks:
Xenophon indicates that when stasis broke out in Tegea the Mantineans intervened in support of a faction that wanted to unite all the Arcadians. After they slaughtered many of their opponents, some 800 of these fled to Sparta. 
The Spartans decided that, in accordance with their oaths i.e. the common peace of 371, they ought to avenge those slain and aid those who had been banished. 
Thus, the Spartans decided to make an expedition against the Mantineans on the grounds that they had violated their oaths by proceeding in arms against the Tegeates.  
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That the Innkeeper has not yet mentioned all the salted fish]
 Τὸ πολὺ τάριχος οὐκ εἴρηκά πω.
  Πλ. Μὰ Δί’ οὐδὲ τὸν τυρόν γε τὸν χλωρόν
remarks: See also oath ids 398 and 400.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades II
statement:
[That a man who is an expert in some particular speciality will fall far short of being a wise man]
 Δοκεῖ οὖν σοι ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι τὸν περὶ τούτων τι ἐπιστήμονα ὄντα ἄρα καὶ ἄνδρα φρόνιμον εἶναι, ἢ πολλοῦ φήσομεν ἐνδεῖν;  {ΑΛ.} Πολλοῦ μέντοι νὴ Δία.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds that jurors that he brought about the alliance with the Euboeans (see oath id 2669), as well as the Thebans (oath id 3390)  and the Achaeans, Corinthians, Megarans, Leucadians and Corcyraeans (see oath id 3392). 
See also oath id 2669.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That the poet has escaped the iciness he refers to (in his poetry) now that he has that little tunic]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἀλλ’ ἤδη πέφευγας ταυταγὶ 
 τὰ κρυερὰ τονδὶ τὸν χιτωνίσκον λαβών.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Cinesias believes that Myrrhine loves him
statement:
[That the ground will not do for them (to have sex on)]
  Ἀρκεῖ χαμαὶ νῷν. 
{ΜΥ.}  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω
remarks: Sommerstein notes ad loc. that swearing by Apollo "is normally a men's oath, but [that it is] used by a woman at Frogs 508 in a sentence of the same structure as this".

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Corinth began to think about returning to the Peloponnesian League
statement:
[That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
 ἐμμενῶ τῇ ξυμμαχίᾳ κατὰ τὰ ξυγκείμενα δικαίως καὶ ἀβλαβῶς καὶ ἀδόλως, καὶ οὐ παραβήσομαι τέχνῃ οὐδὲ μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ.
remarks:
This inscription records the so-called Argive alliance.  
The text indicates that each city will swear the oath that is most binding in their land. The Athenians were to swear on behalf of their allies, whereas the Argives, Mantineans, Eleans, and their allies were to swear individually by state. 
It is stipulated that for the renewal of the oath the Athenians will travel to Elis, Mantinea, and Argos, thirty days before the Olympic games, and the Argives, Eleans and Mantineans will travel to Athens ten days before the Great Panathenaea. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id  251.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
impact: Aeschines used this oath in his defence speech
statement:
[That he shared the city's pleasure at sending men of this quality on the embassy, men whose speaking skill and honesty were a credit to the polis]
 συγχαίρειν τῇ πόλει, ὅτι τοιούτους ἄνδρας ἐπὶ τὴν πρεσβείαν ἐξέπεμψεν, οἳ καὶ τοῖς λόγοις καὶ τῇ πίστει ἦσαν ἄξιοι τῆς πόλεως.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That what is unlike the fine can be fine because a fine wrestler is unlike a fine runner, and a shield fine for defence is completely unlike a javelin fine for swift and powerful throwing]
 Πῶς οὖν, ἔφη, τὸ τῷ καλῷ ἀνόμοιον καλὸν ἂν εἴη; Ὅτι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ἔστι μὲν τῷ καλῷ πρὸς δρόμον ἀνθρώπῳ ἄλλος ἀνόμοιος καλὸς πρὸς πάλην, ἔστι δὲ ἀσπὶς καλὴ πρὸς τὸ προβάλλεσθαι ὡς ἔνι ἀνομοιοτάτη τῷ ἀκοντίῳ, καλῷ πρὸς  τὸ σφόδρα τε καὶ ταχὺ φέρεσθαι.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That Mica will not lay a finger on him]
 Οὔ τοι μὰ Δία σύ γ’ ἅψει.
remarks: As it happens, the scene is interrupted by the character of Cleisthenes before the two can come to blows.

author: Thucydides
title: History
impact: Sparta and Argos remained at peace for a short time
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1.The peace would last for fifty years
2. At any time (unless there was pestilence or war) either party might challenge the other to decide by battle their claims to the district of Thyrea just as they had done before i.e. at the so-called Battle of the Champions. Pursuit by the victors across the borders of either Argos or Sparta was forbidden]
remarks:
Thucydides describes how envoys from Argos and the Spartans came to an agreement about a peace treaty. 
The Spartans agreed to this in writing, but requested that the envoys returned to Argos to present the treaty to the Argive people. If they were satisfied, the envoys should return to Sparta at the time of the Hyacinthia to take the oaths.

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest Adrastus while he collected the dead]
remarks: Isocrates observes that when Adrastus failed to obtain a truce from the Thebans for collecting the dead, he travelled to Athens as a suppliant and convinced Theseus and the Athenians to successfully intercede on his behalf.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callicles
if_taken: Their statements will carry more weight
statement:
[That Callicles threw rubble on the road, and narrowed the road by bringing the wall forward]
 ἵνα δ’ εἰδῆθ’ ὅτι καὶ τὸν χλῆδον εἰς τὴν ὁδὸν ἐκβεβλήκασιν, καὶ τὴν αἱμασιὰν προαγαγόντες στενοτέραν τὴν ὁδὸν πεποιήκασιν,
remarks:
The speaker reminds the jurors that he and his mother were willing to swear the customary oath (see also oath id 3682), and argues that this is the strongest proof he could offer given that they are under oath (see oath id 3683). 
He then has the clerk read his challenge (proklesis) to the jurors for a second time.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
if_taken: The Nurse will divulge her secret
if_refused: The Nurse will not divulge her secret
impact: Hippolytus is bound against his will and will later be unable to clear his name
statement: [That he will not reveal what he has been told]
remarks: Frogs 101-102 is a clumsy paraphrase of Euripides' Hippolytus 611-612, where Hippolytus says that his tongue has sworn, but his heart is not under oath; see oath id 125. See also Frogs 1471 (oath id 514) and Thesmophoriazusae 275-276 (oath id 711).

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
swearer: Leaders of the Samian colonists; Hippocrates
swearee: Leaders of the Samian colonists; Hippocrates
statement:
[That he would betray the Zanclaeans if the Samians agreed to give him half of the movable goods and slaves from the city of Zancle and all that was in the countryside]
 πάντων τῶν ἐπίπλων καὶ ἀνδραπόδων τὰ ἡμίσεα μεταλαβεῖν τῶν ἐν τῇ πόλι, τὰ δ’ ἐπὶ τῶν ἀγρῶν πάντα Ἱπποκράτεα λαγχάνειν
remarks:
According to Herodotus the Zanclaeans appealed to Hippocrates for assistance against the Samians who were allied to Anaxilaus the tyrant of Rhegium. 
Hippocrates made an agreement with the Samians and betrayed the Zanclaeans.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[Τhat he does not think for a moment that Meidias' silent supporters get any benefit by supporting him]
 οὓς μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐδὲν ὠφελεῖσθαι νομίζω παρὰ τούτου
remarks: The reference is to supporters of Meidias who do not make speeches themselves in the courts or the ecclesia, but merely nod ostentatiously to demonstrate their approval of what Meidias says. MacDowell ad loc. notes that Demosthenes here "skilfully kills two birds with one stone:  Meidias' supporters are corrupt and hope to be rewarded by him, and Meidias is too mean to pay them."

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: The defeated man will have his corpse returned to his people
if_refused: There are no rules for the treatment of the defeated man's corpse
statement:
[That they would not defile the defeated man's body but to return the corpse after the armour has been stripped]
  ἀλλ’ ἄγε δεῦρο θεοὺς ἐπιδώμεθα· τοὶ γὰρ ἄριστοι
μάρτυροι ἔσσονται καὶ ἐπίσκοποι ἁρμονιάων· 
οὐ γὰρ ἐγώ σ’ ἔκπαγλον ἀεικιῶ, αἴ κεν ἐμοὶ Ζεὺς 
δώῃ καμμονίην, σὴν δὲ ψυχὴν ἀφέλωμαι· 
ἀλλ’ ἐπεὶ ἄρ κέ σε συλήσω κλυτὰ τεύχε’ Ἀχιλλεῦ
νεκρὸν Ἀχαιοῖσιν δώσω πάλιν· ὣς δὲ σὺ ῥέζειν. 
  Τὸν δ’ ἄρ’ ὑπόδρα ἰδὼν προσέφη πόδας ὠκὺς Ἀχιλλεύς·  
Ἕκτορ μή μοι ἄλαστε συνημοσύνας ἀγόρευε· 
ὡς οὐκ ἔστι λέουσι καὶ ἀνδράσιν ὅρκια πιστά, 
οὐδὲ λύκοι τε καὶ ἄρνες ὁμόφρονα θυμὸν ἔχουσιν,
ἀλλὰ κακὰ φρονέουσι διαμπερὲς ἀλλήλοισιν,
ὣς οὐκ ἔστ’ ἐμὲ καὶ σὲ φιλήμεναι, οὐδέ τι νῶϊν
ὅρκια ἔσσονται, πρίν γ’ ἢ ἕτερόν γε πεσόντα
αἵματος ἆσαι Ἄρηα ταλαύρινον πολεμιστήν.
remarks: Hector proposes that they swear to one another that whoever wins the contest will not defile the other's body but give it back for burial. Hector promises to do so within this proposal but Achilles refuses to take an oath, saying that there can be no oaths between lions and men, nor can wolves and lambs come into agreement. So, according to Achilles, there can be no oaths between between himself and Hector. Cf. also oath id 342.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Dicaeogenes
if_taken: He can proceed with his case
if_refused: He cannot proceed with his case
statement: [That the facts in his written statement were true]
remarks:
Menexenus (III) begins his case against Leochares by announcing that since Dicaeogenes (III) is not fulfilling his part of the agreement they made regarding the estate of Dicaeogenes (II), "we" (i.e. Menexenus and his cousins) are bringing an action against Leochares, his surety, in accordance with his antomosia, which he asks to be read out to the jury. 
Menexenus then repeats that the details in the antomosia are true. 
It would make no sense for Menexenus to ask for the antomosia to be read out unless it contained some specific statements – probably (at least) the statements that the agreement was made between Menexenus and Dicaeogenes (it was an agreement to hand over two-thirds of the disputed estate) and that Leochares went surety for it.  
See also oath id 3042.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Athens at the outbreak of the war in 431 as: 
Chios, Lesbos, Plataea (allied since 519), the Messenians in Naupactus (allied since ca.461), Corcyra (allied since 434/3), Zacynthus, some cities in Caria, the Dorians adjacent to Caria, Ionia, the Hellespont, the coast of Thrace and the Cyclades except Melos and Thera (each of these poleis presumably became allies at the same time as Chios and Lesbos). 
Thucydides also states that "most of the Acarnanians" were allied to Athens. 
See also oath id. 1569 and 1842. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see oath id 1778.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That righteousness is the least debatable type of nobility]
 Εἰ καλοκἀγαθία ἐστὶν ἡ δικαιοσύνη. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἀντισθένης, ἥ γε ἀναμφιλογωτάτη·

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That if the just and good man conquers the evil and unjust man in point of pleasure to such a great extent, he will surpass him to an inconceivable extent in decency and beauty of life and in virtue]
 Οὐκοῦν εἰ τοσοῦτον ἡδονῇ νικᾷ ὁ ἀγαθός τε καὶ δίκαιος τὸν κακόν τε καὶ ἄδικον, ἀμηχάνῳ δὴ ὅσῳ πλείονι νικήσει εὐσχημοσύνῃ τε βίου καὶ κάλλει καὶ ἀρετῇ;  Ἀμηχάνῳ μέντοι νὴ Δία, ἔφη.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Thebans were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Thebans while they were collecting their dead]
remarks: Xenophon states that when the Corinthians repelled the Theban assault upon their walls they dragged the bodies of the Theban dead to the wall and erected a trophy, after giving back the bodies under a truce.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the man just mentioned does not, by any means, try to get the largest share of hard work]
 ἄλλος δ’ ἐπήρετο αὐτόν· Ἦ καὶ τῶν πόνων; Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ μὲν δή·
remarks: Cf. oath id 2344.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he is happy for Pheidippides to keep horses, even a team of four, rather than assault him]
 ἵππευε τοίνυν νὴ Δί’, ὡς ἔμοιγε κρεῖττόν ἐστιν
 ἵππων τρέφειν τέθριππον ἢ τυπτόμενον ἐπιτριβῆναι.
remarks: The circumstances for keeping the oath do not arise.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes sarcastically observes that the jurors ought to acquit Aeschines to avoid committing perjury (by breaking their oath to give a just verdict) if all of his promises have been fulfilled in consequence of the peace, and they made peace happily knowing that their allies would be ruined, Thebes strengthened, and Philip would seize Thrace, and would set up bases on Euboea. 
He goes on to argue that if Aeschines made promises contrary to these outcomes of the peace, e.g. that Philip was a friend of Athens, that he would put a stop to the insolence of Thebes, and that Philip would hand over Euboea and Oropus, the jurors should condemn Aeschines in order to avoid committing perjury and incurring the curse (see oath id 3806). 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: n/a
remarks: Aeschines exhorts the jurors, "When, perjurer that he [Demosthenes] is, he falls back on the trust that oaths inspire, remind him that a man who perjures himself repeatedly, yet always demands to be trusted because of his oaths, must rely on one of two things - either new gods or a new audience - neither of which he has".

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Bdelycleon is afraid of him]
  νὴ τὴν Δήμητρα, δέδοικας.
remarks: Philocleon clearly believes his statement to be true.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
For another reference to the alliance between Athens and Acarnania see also oath id. 1586 and 1842. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see oath id 1778.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Pantaenetus
statement:
[That he would have wanted to persuade Pantaenetus' slaves to sit down in the grindery (and beg for transfer to a different owner)in order to get possession of them]
 ἵνα νὴ Δί’ αὐτοὺς κτήσωμαι
remarks: Nicobulus asks why he would have wanted to the slaves to sit down, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his question.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That the money in dispute is owed to (or not owed by) the deceased's estate]
remarks: The text indicates that an action must be brought for the debt within a year (sc. or else not at all).  The judge is to give judgement according to the testimony.  The persons required to testify (sc. on behalf of the deceased) are his heirs, except that in the case of a judgement debt the judge and the mnemon must testify too.  If they do testify, then "[the judge] shall judge, having sworn, himself and the witnesses, that they win the simple amount"; in other words, the witnesses must swear that the money in dispute is owed to (or is not owed by) the deceased's estate, and then the judge, having sworn the usual judicial oath, will decide in their favour.  Nothing is said about oaths on the other side, but presumably they must have had an opportunity to swear too; however, the witnesses for the estate are evidently to be treated as horkioteroi.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he sees that the majority of people are laughable in their competence at sport, business, public speaking and generalship]
 ἐν ἑκάστῃ τούτων τοὺς πολλοὺς πρὸς ἕκαστον τὸ ἔργον οὐ καταγελάστους ὁρᾷς; {ΚΡ.} Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δία

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That he would not bathe or take food until he had brought Hector's head to the grave of Patroclus]
 μηδὲν τούτων πράξειν, πρὶν ἂν τὴν τοῦ Ἕκτορος κεφαλὴν ἐπὶ τὸν τοῦ Πατρόκλου τάφον ἐνέγκῃ.
