remarks: The reference is apparently to Iliad 23.38-47 (see oath id 420), but that passage says nothing about bringing Hector's head (for which see 18.334-5, where there is no oath; cf. also 23.19-23).  Aeschines is referring to the passage from memory and importing material into it from elsewhere.

title: IG I(3)
statement: [That they do not have the means or health to perform their duties]
remarks:
The regulations concerning the epistatai of Eleusis stipulate that those elected as epistatai cannot decline their office by an oath i.e. that one has not the means or health to perform their duties. 
 The texts reads as follows: [ἐχ]σομοσίαν δὲ μὲ ῏εν[α]ι·

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That he does not want a blanket (he wants a fuck)]
 Ἀλλὰ σισύραν οὐκ ἔχεις.  
{ΚΙ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐδὲ δέομαί γ’, ἀλλὰ βινεῖν βούλομαι

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
impact: Gives a sense of urgency to the situation
statement:
[That they have no business standing about]
  Οὐ τἄρα μὰ Δί’ ἡμῖν ἔτ’ ἔργον ἑστάναι.
remarks: Peisetaerus is responding here to the news that more than ten thousand settlers will be arriving in Nephelokokkugia.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That there was nothing between him and Philip]
μηδὲν εἶναι σοὶ καὶ Φιλίππῳ πρᾶγμα
remarks:
Demosthenes asks whether Aeschines thinks that the jurors are so overcome by sleep and forgetfulness that they will not remember all the times during the war when he cursed and swore that there was nothing between him and Philip. 
See also oath id 3388.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the other Lesbians; Representatives; Representatives of the other Peloponnesians
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the other Lesbians; Representatives; Representatives of the other Peloponnesians
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Peloponnesians resolved to send a force to the Isthmus to invade Attica
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides states that after the Mytilenaean envoys made their case the Spartans and their allies accepted their proposals and received the Lesbians as their allies.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That by his law he recruits many metics for liturgies]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’ εἰς τὰς τῶν μετοίκων λῃτουργίας εἰσποιεῖ πολλούς.
remarks:
Demosthenes imagines that Leptines will object that by his law he recruits many metics for liturgies. 
See also oath id 3375.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That they would abide by the law and not rob and plunder each other]
 ἵνα δωσίδικοι εἶεν καὶ μὴ ἀλλήλους φέροιέν τε καὶ ἄγοιεν
remarks: Herodotus states that Artaphrenes compelled the Ionians to make an agreement among themselves that they would abide by the law and not rob and plunder each other.

author: Sophocles
title: Ichneutai
statement:
[That the footprints of the cattle are pointing the wrong way]
 παλινστραφῆ τοι να̣ὶ̣ μὰ Δ̣ί̣α̣ τὰ̣ β̣ή̣μ̣α̣τ̣α̣
εἰς τοὔμπαλιν δέδορκεν·
remarks: When he stole Apollo's cattle, Hermes dragged them backwards and walked backwards himself, to confuse any pursuers (Homeric Hymn to Hermes 76-78).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Theocrines
statement:
[That Theocrines and those like him punish wrongdoers]
 τοὺς ἀδικοῦντας νὴ Δί’ οὗτοι κολάζουσιν,
remarks: The speaker asks how Theocrines could be useful to the state, and imagines that someone will respond in this way.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The Plataean speaker asks the Athenians to remember that they undertook their most recent war (378-4) not to secure the freedom of themselves and their allies (for they already enjoyed their freedom), but on behalf of all those who were being deprived of their autonomy in violation of the oaths and agreements i.e. the King's Peace. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That he will make sure he does not claim credit for the peace]
 ‘νὴ Δί’, ἢ ἀδικήσω γ’,’ ἔφην.
remarks:
Demosthenes reports to the jurors that he asked the Athenians in the ecclesia to neither praise him for the peace, nor criticise him if it went wrong. He states that Aeschines then interrupted him, telling him not to disown the peace, but to make sure that he did not take credit for it if it worked well for Athens. Demosthenes states that he responded to Aeschines with this oath. 
Philocrates then stood up and observed that it was no wonder that he and Demosthenes did not agree, because Demosthenes drank water whereas he drank wine.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Argives hoped that the Boeotians could become allies as the Corinthians, Eleans and Mantineans had done. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

title: IG XII Supplement
if_taken: The young man can be introduced to the phratry
if_refused: He cannot be introduced to the phratry
statement: [? That the young man was the son of the man reputed to be his father]
remarks:
The statement sworn by the mother is not clearly specified. Presumably she swore to verify the identity of the father. 
For the oath sworn by the father see oath id 728.  
For the oath sworn by the witnesses see oath id 729.  
For oaths sworn when an elder brother or an uncle introduced a young man to the phratry see oath id 731 and 732.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he does not believe that the truth about rhythm could be discovered in a brief discourse]
 διελέσθαι γὰρ οὐ σμικροῦ λόγου. ἢ σὺ οἴει;  Μὰ Δί’, οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he never thought he would hear Socrates say that good housekeepers would make good generals]
 καὶ ὁ Νικομαχίδης, Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐκ ἄν ποτε ᾤμην ἐγὼ σοῦ ἀκοῦσαι ὡς οἱ ἀγαθοὶ οἰκονόμοι ἀγαθοὶ στρατηγοὶ ἂν εἶεν.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is clear that someone who doesn't stick to what he says doesn't know what he thought he knew]
 Τί δὲ δή, ὃς ἂν βουλόμενος τἀληθῆ λέγειν μηδέποτε τὰ αὐτὰ περὶ τῶν αὐτῶν λέγῃ, ἀλλ’ ὁδόν τε φράζων τὴν αὐτὴν τοτὲ μὲν πρὸς ἕω, τοτὲ δὲ πρὸς ἑσπέραν φράζῃ, καὶ λογισμὸν ἀποφαινόμενος τὸν αὐτὸν τοτὲ μὲν πλείω, τοτὲ δ’ ἐλάττω ἀποφαίνηται, τί σοι δοκεῖ ὁ τοιοῦτος; Δῆλος νὴ Δί’ εἶναι ὅτι ἃ ᾤετο εἰδέναι οὐκ οἶδεν.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The King's country in Asia is to remain his possession and to be governed as he pleases
2. The Spartans and their allies shall not go against the country of the King, nor the King against the Spartans and their allies.
3. If any of the Spartans and their allies go against the King's territory, the Spartans and their allies shall stop them, and if any of the King's subjects go against the Spartans and their allies the King shall stop them
4. Tissaphernes shall pay for the ships now present until the arrival of the King's ships. After these arrive, the Spartans can then pay for their own ships if they wish. If not, Tissaphernes will provide money, but the Spartans will repay the money at the end of the war
5. When the King's ships arrive, the ships of the Spartans and their allies and those of the King shall wage war together, according to what seems best to Tissaphernes and the Spartans and their allies. If they wish to end the war with the Athenians, they will do so jointly.]
remarks:
Pharnabazus observes to Agesilaus and the other Spartans present that he became their ally at the time when they were at war with Athens. 
Pharnabazus lists several examples of assistance he has rendered to the Spartans, including: 
1. Providing money for their fleet; 
2. Fighting alongside them on land and driving their enemies to the sea. 
He contrasts his behaviour with the of Tissaphernes, accusing him of double-dealing. 
See Thucydides 8.57.2-59.1 (oath id 1818) for this oath. Thucydides names Tissaphernes as the principal Persian involved in the negotiations.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
As part of his defence, Aeschines recounts how he spoke briefly to Philip about the oaths they had gone to receive, and about the other matters they had been instructed to raise. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That the Helots could leave unmolested]
 τῷ δ’ αὐτῷ χρόνῳ καὶ Λακεδαιμόνιοι τοὺς εἰς τὸ Κορυφάσιον τῶν Εἱλώτων ἀφεστῶτας ἐκ Μαλέας ὑποσπόνδους ἀφῆκαν
remarks: Xenophon states that the Spartans allowed the Helots who had fled from Malea to Coryphasium (Pylos) to leave unmolested under a truce.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [That if Agesilaus arranged a truce to last until the return of the messengers whom he would send to the King, he would do his utmost to obtain autonomy for the Greek cities in Asia]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, when Tissaphernes sent envoys to Agesilaus threatening war unless he withdrew from Asia, Agesilaus, with a beaming face, told the envoys to inform Tissaphernes that he was grateful to him for his perjury, by which he had gained the hostility of the gods for himself and made them allies of the Greeks. 
See also oath id 1916-7 and 2255-6.

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates argues that not even the present peace, nor the autonomy which is inscribed in the agreements, but does not exist in the real political world, is preferable to the rule of Athens. 
He goes on to argue that the absence of the Athenian fleet leaves the sea vulnerable to piracy, and that more cities have been captured in war than before the Greeks made the peace. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the women have no right to save him (if he doesn't ask for it)]
 Νὴ τὴν Δήμητρ’ ἄδικόν γε.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
swearer: Artapanus; Megabyzus; Artapanus' 3 sons; Other conspirators
swearee: Artapanus; Megabyzus; Artapanus' 3 sons; Other conspirators
if_taken: Their conspiracy would be made safe
if_refused: Their conspiracy would not be made safe
statement:
[That they would be allies against Artaxerxes (I)]
 καὶ ὅρκοις ἀλλήλους ἀσφαλίζονται
remarks: Cf. oath id 3447.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That the Spartans can not stand Hippias’s discourses on arithmetic (or language, or music, he then adds)]
 Πολλοῦ ἄρα δέουσιν περί γε λογισμῶν ἀνέχεσθαί σου ἐπιδεικνυμένου. {—ΙΠ.} Πολλοῦ μέντοι νὴ Δία.

author: Anonymus Comicus
title: Fragments
statement:
[That the robbers are good men]
 νὴ τὴν] Δήμητρ’, ἀγαθουϲ.[
remarks: The passage relates to the robbing of a house. It seems likely that the oath statement which begins by refering to "good men" is an ironic statement concerning the robbers.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That Aristogeiton does not extort money from politicians]
 οὐχὶ μὰ Δία τοὺς λέγοντας
remarks: The speaker alleges that Aristogeiton extorts money from the demos by threatening prosecution, but that he does not get money from politicians because they know how to throw mud back at him.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
if_taken: They will be eligible to be a citizen
if_refused: They will not be eligible to be citizens
statement: [That they shall not bring shame upon the sacred weapons nor shall they desert the man beside them, wherever they stand in the line. They shall fight in defence of things sacred and profane and shall not hand the fatherland on lessened, but greater and better both as far as they are able and with all. And they shall be obedient to whoever exercises power reasonably on any occasion and to the laws currently in force and any reasonably put into force in the future. If anyone attempts to destroy these, they shall refuse to allow him both as far as is in their power and in union with all, and they shall honour the ancestral religion]
gods_invoked: Aglaurus; Hestia; Enyo; Enyalios; Ares; Athena; Zeus; Thallo; Auxo; Hegemone; Heracles; The boundaries of my fatherland; Wheat; Barley; Vines; Olives; Figs
remarks:
Lycurgus has the clerk read the ephebic oath to the jurors, and then describes it as "a fine and solemn oath". 
See also oath id 340.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Wealth has more power than Zeus]
 Ἐγὼ γὰρ ἀποδείξω σε τοῦ Διὸς πολὺ
  μεῖζον δυνάμενον.
  {ΠΛ.}  Ἐμὲ σύ;  {ΧΡ.} Νὴ τὸν οὐρανόν.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he perceived that the company's drink had been poisoned because he saw Astyages and his guests unsteady both in mind and in body]
  Καὶ πῶς δὴ σὺ τοῦτο, ἔφη, ὦ παῖ, κατέγνως; Ὅτι νὴ Δί’ ὑμᾶς ἑώρων καὶ ταῖς γνώμαις καὶ τοῖς σώμασι σφαλλομένους.
remarks: Cf. oath ids 2311-2315.

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a general reference to oaths made as a result of challenges in legal cases. Advice is given on how to tackle such evidence by directing attention to the weakest part of the opponent's case. Oaths are mentioned together with “witnesses” and “tortures” (i.e. torture-challenges).  These are three of the five kinds of “artless proofs” (atekhnoi pisteis) listed by Aristotle in Rhetoric  (the others are laws and contracts)- see oath id 1728.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
statement:
[That Socrates had defined love very clearly at the beginning of his speech]
 ἀλλ’ εἰπὲ καὶ τόδε—ἐγὼ γάρ τοι διὰ τὸ ἐνθουσιαστικὸν οὐ πάνυ μέμνημαι—εἰ ὡρισάμην ἔρωτα ἀρχόμενος τοῦ λόγου.  {ΦΑΙ.} Νὴ Δία ἀμηχάνως γε ὡς σφόδρα.
remarks: The definition was given, at great length, in 237d-238c.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
if_taken: They will be allowed to judge
if_refused: They will not be allowed to judge
statement: [That they will judge the choruses fairly]
remarks: The Ecclesiazusae was probably produced at the City Dionysia rather than the Lenaea. See Sommerstein p.7 with n.33. See also oath ids 1427, 2382, 3396, 3402.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That she will not allow the installation of storage-pits for water in taverns]
 νῦν δ’ οὐκ ἐάσω, κατά γε τὴν ἐμὴν μίαν, 
  ἐν τοῖς καπηλείοισι λάκκους ἐμποιεῖν 
  ὕδατος. ἐμοὶ μὲν οὐ δοκεῖ, μὰ τὼ θεώ. 
 {Πρ.}  μὰ τὼ θεώ; τάλαινα, ποῦ τὸν νοῦν ἔχεις;
 {Γυ. α} τί δ’ ἔστιν; οὐ γὰρ δὴ πιεῖν γ’ ᾔτησά σε.
 {Πρ.} μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ ἀνὴρ ὢν τὼ θεὼ κατώμοσας,
  καίτοι τά γ’ ἄλλ’ εἰποῦσα δεξιώτατα.
remarks: The fact that the woman swears by the two goddesses (Demeter and Persephone), although she is pretending to be a man, gives her away as this is a woman's oath (cf. oath id 713 with cross references). Praxagora emphatically (and also using an oath, see oath id 789) takes issue with this invocation and explains why it was not appropriate. The woman will later respond with an oath invoking Apollo (see oath id 790).

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[That he has not seen a better wood-cutter than himself]
καὶ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ εἶδον ἐμαυτο̃ ἀμείνω ὑλοτόμον
remarks: This is a grave stone for a certain Mannes Ὀρύμαιος. Ὀρύμαιος appears to be an otherwise unattested ethnic.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that while the Athenian envoys were idle in Pella, Philip was busy capturing Doriscus, Thrace, the region of the forts and Hieron Oros, all during conditions of peace and truce. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That men such as Lycon who no longer train in the gymnasium should smell like gentlemen]
 ἡμᾶς δὲ τοὺς μηκέτι γυμναζομένους τίνος ὄζειν δεήσει; Καλοκἀγαθίας νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2192.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That organising the procession does not make him a great man (as he is carrying tunics for the officers)]
 οἱ δὲ ἡγεμόνες ἐπεὶ ἴδοιεν αὐτόν, ἔλεγον· Μέγας δὴ σύγε, ὦ Φεραύλα, ὁπότε γε καὶ ἡμῖν τάξεις ἃ ἂν δέῃ ποιεῖν. Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Φεραύλας, οὐ μόνον γε, ὡς ἔοικεν, ἀλλὰ καὶ συσκευοφορήσω· νῦν γοῦν φέρω τώδε δύο κασᾶ, τὸν μὲν σοί, τὸν δὲ ἄλλῳ·

title: IEphesos
date: End of the sixth century (525 to 500)
statement: The statement is unknown, but most likely was the normal form of exomosia - that the witness did not know that the statement he was being asked to make was true.
remarks:
The text indicates that in order for a witness to claim exemption from testifying, an oath is to be sworn to Zeus, before the judges, with a boar offered to Zeus. The boar is to be provided by the plaintiff/prosecutor.  
The text reads as follows: ἐγμαρτυρῆσαι ⋮ ἐπὶ τοῖς δικάζοσιν ⋮ ὀμνύντα ⋮ κάπρωι ⋮ τὸ Ζῆνα ⋮ ἐγμαρτυρε̃ν ⋮ τὸν δὲ κάπρον ⋮ παρεχέν ⋮  ΄ο̃ ἂν τὸ πρῆχ[μα ἔηι·] 
Presumably this law was devised as a protection against the sort of ploy we see, for example, in Aeschines 1.45-50 and 67-69 – calling a witness whom you know to be hostile, in order to gain rhetorical advantage from his refusal to testify; at Ephesus, at this time, you could do this if you wanted to, but it would cost you a pig!  There would normally be no other reason why anyone would want to call a witness if he wasn't confident the witness would give the evidence he desired.

author: Demosthenes
title: On Organisation
statement:
[That their ancestors did not set up bronze statues of Themistocles and Miltiades (but rewarded them as men no superior to themselves)]
 μὰ Δί’ οὐ χαλκοῦς ἵστασαν, ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐδὲν αὑτῶν κρείττους ὄντας, οὕτως ἐτίμων.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives of the Chalcidians in Thrace; Envoys; Envoys
swearee: Representatives of the Chalcidians in Thrace; Envoys; Envoys
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Chalcidians began to fight against the Athenians
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Argives and Spartans sent envoys to Thrace and renewed their ancient oaths with the Chalcidians, and swore new ones. 
See also oath id 1699 and 1826.

title: SEG
statement:
[That it is a swallow (and therefore spring)]
 νὲ τὸν hερακλέα
remarks:
This vase-painting was first published by Guarducci, EG 3, pp467-8. 
Three figures are watching a swallow. The figure on the left (a beardless youth)  points to the swallow and says "Look, a swallow" (ἰδοῦ, χελιδόν). The figure in the middle (a bearded man) points to the swallow, saying, "By Heracles" (νὲ τὸν hερακλέα). The  figure on the right (a young boy), with open hand states, "There it is" (hαυτεί).  The painter himself writes, "It is spring already" (ἔαρ ἔδε).

author: Hesiod
title: Works and Days
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a reference to the birth of Horkos (Oath). His birth (on the fifth day) is used to explain how "all fifth days are harsh". His birth from Eris (Strife) was attended by the Erinyes (Furies) and he was born as a bane on those who take false oaths. See also oath id 1289. This is clear evidence that oaths were thought of as curses.

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
if_taken: They will be allowed to judge
if_refused: They will not be allowed to judge
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
This is a reference to the dikasts' oath, which included the clause stated here - "That they will judge according to the laws" (ὀμόσαντες κατὰ τοὺς νόμους τοὺς κειμένους τὴν ψῆφον οἴσειν). Cf. also oath ids 1610, 1613, 1614 (referring to the duty of the judges to listen to all sides of the argument). 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Isocrates
title: Archidamus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
  ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Archidamus tells the Spartans that the Thebans have acted contrary to their oaths and agreements (i.e. the King's Peace) in razing both Thespiae and Plataea to the ground. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the woman had not asked for any drink]
  τί δ’ ἔστιν; οὐ γὰρ δὴ πιεῖν γ’ ᾔτησά σε. 
 {Πρ.}  μὰ Δί’
remarks: For context, see oath ids 788 and 790.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the scroll she produces (which contains a decree) will make Epigenes do what she wants]
  κοὐκ ἂν πιθοίμην οὐδέποτ’. {Γρ. α} ἀλλά, νὴ Δία,
  ἀναγκάσει τουτί σε.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That during the three months the ambassadors were in Pella they administered the oaths to the allies, or carried out their other duties]
  Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’ ἐν τούτῳ τῷ χρόνῳ τοὺς ὅρκους ἔλαβον παρὰ τῶν συμμάχων, ἢ τἄλλ’ ἃ προσῆκεν ἐποίησαν.
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that someone will make this objection to his claims that the ambassadors were idle in Pella. He responds that the ambassadors drew one thousand drachmas in travel expenses, yet did not administer the oath to a single city, either on the way there or on the way back.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he cannot relate the conversation between Socrates and Theaetetus from memory]
 ἔχοις ἂν διηγήσασθαι; {ΕΥ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, οὔκουν οὕτω γε ἀπὸ στόματος·

author: Sophocles
title: Trachiniae
impact: Confuses Deianeira as to who is telling the truth
statement:
[That he will tell the truth]
 Δη. ἦ καὶ τὸ πιστὸν τῆς ἀληθείας νεμεῖς;
Λι. ἴστω μέγας Ζεύς, ὧν γ’ ἂν ἐξειδὼς κυρῶ.
remarks: Lichas lies here in spite of his oath, though it could perhaps just about be argued that he doesn't actually break his oath. When asked who the girl is, he says he "cannot say" rather than he "doesn't know". This is at least highly misleading, however. We may also note that Lichas, who swears here (falsely) by Zeus, is ultimately killed by the son of Zeus at the altar of Zeus. Compare the oath he is reported to have sworn at id 274, where he tells the truth concerning the girl's identity.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Callias is providing perfect hospitality]
 Νὴ Δί’, ὦ Καλλία, τελέως ἡμᾶς ἑστιᾷς

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the Sacian had not hit one of those present]
 ἀναβλέψας δὲ ὁ Σάκας ἐρωτᾷ τίνος ἔτυχεν. Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐδενὸς τῶν παρόντων.
remarks: The Sacian had hit Pheraulas with a clod of earth. Pheraulas had ridden on as if nothing had happened and was therefore no longer "present"; cf. oath id 2846.

author: Demosthenes
title: On Organisation
statement:
[That there are other words, false and harmful to the state that have slipped into their speech, such as 'in the dikasteria lies your salvation', and 'it is the vote that must save the state']
 καὶ νὴ Δί’, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, ἕτεροί γε λόγοι παρερρυήκασι πρὸς ὑμᾶς ψευδεῖς, καὶ πολλὰ τὴν πολιτείαν βλάπτοντες, οἷον ἐν τοῖς δικαστηρίοις ὑμῖν ἐστιν ἡ σωτηρία, καὶ δεῖ τῇ ψήφῳ τὴν πολιτείαν ὑμᾶς φυλάττειν.
remarks: Demosthenes goes on to argue that it is only military strength and success that can enable the Athenians to vote in the dikasteria or exercise any of their other freedoms.

title: IErythrae
reference: 10, fragment a, lines 9-11; fragment b, lines 6-9
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The inscription refers to an occasion when there was a political amnesty.  Both fragments of the text indicate that "the names of those swearing the oaths are to be inscribed on the public noticeboard".  
Fragment b was found in Chios. Presumably some of those involved in the amnesty were returning to Erythrae from exile in Chios.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
date: After 594/3 whenever an archon took office (594 to 322)
if_taken: They will be permitted into office
if_refused: They will not be permitted into office
if_broken: They will dedicate a golden statue
statement:
[That they will abide by their oaths as in the time of Acastus]
 τεκμήριον δ’ ἐπιφέρουσιν, ὅτι οἱ ἐννέα ἄρχοντες ὀμνύουσιν ὥσπερ  ἐπὶ Ἀκάστου τὰ ὅρκια ποιήσειν
remarks: The oaths referred to here are those stating that the archons will observe the laws, as established by Solon (594/3). Acastus was believed to have been the first Archon. Cf. also ids 1758, 1811 and  2745.

title: IG I(3)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: This stone is the republication of the homicide laws of Dracon from 621/0. The letters ΟΜΝΥ̣ are preserved on line 43 of the stone, which suggests that there was a reference to an oath here. Stroud suggested that the word may have been ὀμνύ̣[μενος], but the nature of the oath cannot be determined.

author: Hesiod
title: Shield
if_broken: He would suffer the wrath of the gods
impact: He is bound to lead an expedition against the Taphians and Teleboans.
statement:
[That he would not enter his wife's bed until he had avenged the murder of his wife's brothers and burned down the villages of the Taphians and Teleboans]
 ἔνθ’ ὅ γε δώματ’ ἔναιε σὺν αἰδοίῃ παρακοίτι 
νόσφιν ἄτερ φιλότητος ἐφιμέρου, οὐδέ οἱ ἦεν 
πρὶν λεχέων ἐπιβῆναι ἐυσφύρου Ἠλεκτρυώνης
πρίν γε φόνον τείσαιτο κασιγνήτων μεγαθύμων
ἧς ἀλόχου, μαλερῷ δὲ καταφλέξαι πυρὶ κώμας
ἀνδρῶν ἡρώων Ταφίων ἰδὲ Τηλεβοάων.
τὼς γάρ οἱ διέκειτο, θεοὶ δ’ ἐπὶ μάρτυροι ἦσαν·
τῶν ὅ γ’ ὀπίζετο μῆνιν, ἐπείγετο δ’ ὅττι τάχιστα 
ἐκτελέσαι μέγα ἔργον, ὅ οἱ Διόθεν θέμις ἦεν.
remarks: Amphitryon invokes a number of unspecified gods, one of whom is Zeus. He fulfills his oath forthwith.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Thebans were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That his troops would not molest the Thebans while they collected their dead]
remarks:
Xenophon states that after the battle at Coronea the Thebans sent heralds to Agesilaus asking to be able to bury their dead under a truce. Agesilaus consented and then went to Delphi to offer Apollo a tithe of the spoils. 
See also oath id 2298.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [? That he would not take any warlike action against the Athenians provided they kept their promise that they would leave the Calchedonians alone if the latter paid their dues]
remarks:
Alcibiades, Thrasyllus and some of the other generals led the Athenians in an assault upon Calchedon. The Spartan harmost Hippocrates sallied out and tried to effect a junction with Pharnabazus who was commanding a great force of infantry and cavalry outside the walls. When Hippocrates was slain in the fighting, the soldiers with him fled back to the city, and Pharnabazus withdrew to his camp at Heracleium in the Calchedonian territory. 
Alcibiades then sailed to the Hellespont and the Chersonese to collect money, and the rest of the generals made an agreement with Pharnabazus, that if they should spare Calchedon, Pharnabazus should give the Athenians twenty talents and conduct Athenian envoys to the King. 
They also received an oath from Pharnabazus that the Calchedonians should pay to the Athenians the same tribute they usually paid, and give up the money that they owed in arrears. 
See also oath id 1885 and 1887.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That he would observe the truce guilelessly, allowing three months for the transaction]
 σπονδὰς ἄξειν ἀδόλως, ὁρισάμενος τῆς πράξεως τρεῖς μῆνας.
remarks:
According to Xenophon, Tissaphernes approached Agesilaus regarding a truce and swore that he would do his best to convince the King to guarantee the autonomy of the Greeks in Asia if Agesilaus agreed to halt hostilities (see oath id 2255). 
Agesilaus swore to abide by the truce for three months. 
Xenophon states that whereas Tissaphernes broke his oath at once, Agesilaus continued to keep the truce even though he was aware that Tissaphernes had broken his oath. 
Thus, by showing Tissaphernes to be a perjurer Agesilaus made him distrusted everywhere, and by proving himself to be true to his oaths and his agreements, Agesilaus encouraged all - both Greeks and barbarians - to make an agreement with him whenever he wished. 
Xenophon also describes this oath exchange in the Hellenica (see oath id 1916-7).

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates criticises the King's Peace, arguing that it is the King who dictates the destiny of the Greeks, who dictates what each must do, and who all but sets up governors in their cities. He argues that the King decided the war, directed the terms of the peace and presides over the affairs of the Greeks. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the first thing he wishes to learn from the women is what their object was in shutting off the Acropolis with bolts]
  Καὶ μὴν αὐτῶν τοῦτ’ ἐπιθυμῶ νὴ τὸν Δία πρῶτα πυθέσθαι, 
 ὅ τι βουλόμεναι τὴν πόλιν ἡμῶν ἀπεκλείσατε τοῖσι μοχλοῖσιν.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
swearer: Artapanus; Megabyzus; Artapanus' 3 sons; Other conspirators
swearee: Artapanus; Megabyzus; Artapanus' 3 sons; Other conspirators
if_taken: Their conspiracy would be made safe
if_refused: Their conspiracy would not be made safe
statement: [That they would be allies against Artaxerxes (I)]
remarks: It is made clear here that Artapanus and Megabyzus were not alone in the conspiracy against Artaxerxes I. After Artapanus' death, a fight breaks out between the conspirators and the other Persians. Artapanus' three sons are killed and Megabyzus in injured in the fight. Cf. oath id 3446.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That it was not in Sparta that he made the most money (although he visited the city often)] 
 τόδε δέ μοι εἰπέ, σὺ αὐτὸς πόθεν πλεῖστον ἀργύριον ἠργάσω τῶν πόλεων εἰς ἃς ἀφικνῇ; ἢ δῆλον ὅτι ἐκ Λακεδαίμονος, οἷπερ καὶ πλειστάκις ἀφῖξαι; {ΙΠ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That they would follow Cleomenes in whatever enterprise he led]
 προσάγων σφι ᾗ μὲν ἕψεσθαί σφεας αὐτῷ τῇ ἂν ἐξηγέηται
remarks:
This oath was proposed, but never taken because Cleomenes was arrested. Herodotus observes that Cleomenes wanted to make the Arcadians swear by the waters of the Styx, "besides other oaths" (ἄλλους τε ὅρκους).  
For the "other oaths" see oath id 1499.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That Aristogeiton is the watchdog of the demos]
 κύων νὴ Δία, φασί τινες, τοῦ δήμου
remarks:
The speaker asserts that the friends of Arsitogeiton will respond in this way. 
Evidently Aristogeiton, like Cleon, enjoyed being called (or calling himself) the People's watchdog.

author: Euripides
title: Phoenissae
if_taken: Polynices will be able to enter the city unharmed
if_refused: Polynices will not be allowed into the city
impact: Polynices can enter the city unharmed
statement: [That they would abide by the terms of the truce]
remarks: The servant makes reference here to having brought truce terms to Antigone's brother (Polynices). This surely refers to the terms under which Polynices can come into the city, i.e. each brother agrees not to harm the other during the embassy.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
if_taken: They will be eligible to be a citizen
if_refused: They will not be eligible to be citizens
statement: [That they shall not bring shame upon the sacred weapons nor shall they desert the man beside them, wherever they stand in the line. They shall fight in defence of things sacred and profane and shall not hand the fatherland on lessened, but greater and better both as far as they are able and with all. And they shall be obedient to whoever exercises power reasonably on any occasion and to the laws currently in force and any reasonably put into force in the future. If anyone attempts to destroy these, they shall refuse to allow him both as far as is in their power and in union with all, and they shall honour the ancestral religion]
gods_invoked: Aglaurus; Hestia; Enyo; Enyalios; Ares; Athena; Zeus; Thallo; Auxo; Hegemone; Heracles; The boundaries of my fatherland; Wheat; Barley; Vines; Olives; Figs
remarks:
Lycurgus argues that the oath is the force that holds democracy together. He cites three oaths: the oath sworn by the archon, the oath sworn by the judge i.e. the Heliastic oath, and the oath of the private citizen i.e. the ephebic oath (see oath id 2744 and 2745). He says that each of these men gives this pledge, and rightly. 
See also oath id 340.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Wealth is the cause of people sacrificing to Zeus]
  Θύουσι δ’ αὐτῷ διὰ τίν’; Οὐ διὰ τουτονί; 
  {ΚΑ.}  Καὶ νὴ Δί’
remarks: The idea here is that wealth is a prerequisite for making sacrifices to Zeus. On the double use of the term "wealth" as both a prerequisite and an object, see Sommerstein ad 130-197.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the singer sang most excellently]
 οὐκ ἀκροώμενοι δὲ τοῦ ᾄδοντος ὠμνύετε ἄριστα ᾄδειν·
remarks: The oath is allegedly made through a drunken haze during which, Cyrus claims, Astyages and his guests could not even hear the singer, so the oath is not strictly true, but it is not an outright lie either- Astyages and his guests, in their drunken state, seem to believe that the singer is excellent. This is very similar to  Ar. Lys. 1238, see oath id 1236.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines responds to Demosthenes' allegation that he had delivered a speech regarding the proposed peace, in the presence of ambassadors from other Greek poleis, who had been invited with the intention of getting them to join the Athenians in war against Philip or to share in the peace, whichever course was thought more advantageous. 
Eubulus had sent embassies in 348 to encourage the Greeks to join Athens against Philip. 
Aeschines challenges Demosthenes to call the members of these embassies to give evidence about this. He says (with obvious confidence) that if they testify that they had returned and were not still abroad at the time when the polis was concluding the peace, or if evidence can be produced that they reported back to the boule, he is ready to leave the platform and propose the death penalty for himself. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Alexis
title: Orchestris
statement:
[That there will be as much wine as they want]
 ἀλλὰ μήν, νὴ τὼ θεώ,
ἔσται γ’ ὅσον ἂν βουλώμεθ’
remarks: The oath by Demeter and Persephone is particular to women; cf. oath id 788.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That he does not want Myrrhine to put scent on him]
  Βούλει μυρίσω σε;
{ΚΙ.}  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω μή μέ γε.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes urges the jurors to hold fast to what they think is just and to remember it until they vote so that they may cast their votes true to their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That men must now not sacrifice to Zeus but to the birds]
 Ὄρνιθες ἀνθρώποισι νῦν εἰσιν θεοί,
  οἷς θυτέον αὐτοῖς, ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ οὐ τῷ Διί.
remarks: There is great irony, and indeed self-contradiction, here. Having just proclaimed that the birds are now men's gods, Peisetaerus invokes Zeus in an informal oath to confirm the fact that men should no longer sacrifice to Zeus. P. nevertheless continues invoking Zeus in informal oaths for the duration of the play (the next occurence after this passage is at oath id 675), though he does also once swear "by the kestrels" (see oath id 676), who would now count as the new gods.  There is a related paradox at line 1614 (see oath id 690).

author: Philoxenus of Leucas
title: The Banquet
date: The Banquet is "new" in a comedy by Plato (391) (395 to 391)
statement:
[That a huge portion of cooked tunny was served which had been carved right to the belly]
 ναὶ μὰ θεοὺς 
  ὑπερμέγεθές τι θέμος  
  θύννου μόλεν ὀπτὸν ἐκεῖθεν 
θερμὸν ὅθεν γλυφις 
  τετμημένον εὐθὺς ἐπ’ αὐτὰς  
τὰς ὑπογαστρίδας

author: Empedocles
title: fr. 115 D-K
if_taken: The decree will become an enforceable divine law
if_refused: The decree will not become an enforceable divine law
impact: Gods will be punished for crimes including perjury
statement: [That they will abide by what will inevitably happen, i.e. that they will uphold a decree which ordains that whenever any god commits murder or perjury, he will inevitably, automatically, be punished in various ways (see remarks)]
remarks: If a god breaks this oath he will then be guilty of perjury. Punishments listed for murderers and perjurers include: wandering apart from the gods for thirty thousand seasons among mortals on their painful paths, being pursued by the strength of the air and the sea, and being spat out by the sea on the ground in the rays of the bright sun and the violent swirl of the wind, hated by all.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Theocrines
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker urges the jurors to asks Theocrines whether he thinks it right that men who have sworn to judge according to the laws should make a decision contrary to the laws. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades II
statement:
[That a state which consisted of experts in various specialities, each trying to apply his specialized knowledge to the running of the state, but none having any knowledge of what was good for the state or for himself, would be full of turmoil and lawlessness]
 Φαίης γε ἂν οἶμαι ὁπόταν ὁρῴης ἕνα ἕκαστον αὐτῶν φιλοτιμούμενόν τε καὶ νέμοντα τὸ πλεῖστον τῆς πολιτείας  τούτῳ μέρος,  ἵν’ αὐτὸς αὑτοῦ τυγχάνει κράτιστος ὤν· λέγω δὲ τὸ κατ’ αὐτὴν τὴν τέχνην βέλτιστον γιγνόμενον· τοῦ δὲ τῇ πόλει τε καὶ αὐτὸν αὑτῷ βελτίστου ὄντος τὰ πολλὰ διημαρτηκότα, ἅτε οἶμαι ἄνευ νοῦ δόξῃ πεπιστευκότα.  οὕτως δὲ τούτων ἐχόντων, ἆρα οὐκ ἂν ὀρθῶς λέγοιμεν φάντες πολλῆς ταραχῆς τε καὶ ἀνομίας μεστὴν εἶναι τὴν τοιαύτην πολιτείαν;  {ΑΛ.} Ὀρθῶς μέντοι νὴ Δία.

author: Sophocles
title: Colchides
statement: see remarks
remarks: Here, one character (Medea?) asks another if he (Jason?- a male in any case) swears to do a favour in return. This could possibly be a reference to the oath between Jason and Medea, where he apparently swore to marry her in return for her help in obtaining the golden fleece (which Medea makes much of in Euripides' play- see oath id 111 with cross references).

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides refers to various complaints by the Athenians and the Spartans regarding the treaty e.g. 
1. the Spartans had failed to make their allies in Thrace, the Boeotians or the Corinthians accept the treaty 
2. the Athenians did not hand over Pylos 
3. the Spartans did not hand over Amphipolis or Panactum or Athenian prisoners that were in the hands of the Boeotians 
Thucydides also observes that after the change of ephors at the start of the year 421/0 the Spartans began to wish to annul the treaty. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That the letters from Philip call on the Athenians not merely to come and fight the Phocians, but to come at once]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἤδη γε·
remarks: Demosthenes has these letters read to the jurors.

title: IG XII Supplement
swearer: The elder brother of the young man
if_taken: He can introduce his brother to the phratry
if_refused: he cannot introduce his brother to the phratry
statement:
[That the young man was the son of the same father as himself]
 ὁ δὲ ἐσάγωγ [καὶ ὀμνύτω ὁμοπ]άτριον
remarks:
For the oath sworn by the father (if he was still alive) see oath id 728.  
For the oath sworn by the witnesses see oath id 729.  
For the oath sworn by the mother see oath id 730.  
For oath sworn when an uncle introduced a young man to the phratry see oath id 732.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
date: During the regency of Ptolemy of Alorus 367-365 (367 to 365)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Aeschines states that when he spoke to Philip he told him about how Ptolemy of Alorus continually worked against Athens in the interest of Amphipolis, and how when Athens was in controversy with Thebes, Ptolemy made an alliance with the Thebans.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That managing a chorus is a very different thing from managing an army]
 Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Νικομαχίδης, ἀλλ’ οὐδὲν ὅμοιόν ἐστι χοροῦ τε καὶ στρατεύματος προεστάναι.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That straightforward dealings are not always what is required, even with friends]
 Λέγεις, ἔφη, σὺ οὐδὲ πρὸς τοὺς φίλους ἅπαντα δεῖν ἁπλοίζεσθαι; Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτα, ἔφη·

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement:
[Τhat he made no allegation against Aristarchus before the boule]
 μηδὲν κατ’ αὐτοῦ πρὸς τὴν βουλὴν εἰρηκέναι φαῦλον
remarks:
Demosthenes has already accused Meidias of committing perjury and then calls witnesses to verify his claims. 
See also oath id 3409.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
statement:
[That they will not hide anything away but distribute everything] 
Τρωσὶν δ’ αὖ μετόπισθε γερούσιον ὅρκον ἕλωμαι 
μή τι κατακρύψειν, ἀλλ’ ἄνδιχα πάντα δάσεσθαι
remarks: This oath is never taken. Hector briefly considers surrender and complete restitution to the Achaeans, of which this oath would have been a part. He almost at once rejects the idea as impracticable, since Achilles would never accept it, and he goes to meet Achilles in single combat.

author: Plato
title: Theages
statement:
[That what he is going to tell Socrates is hard to believe]
 Ἐγώ σοι ἐρῶ,” ἔφη, “ὦ Σώκρατες, ἄπιστον μὲν νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ἀληθὲς δέ
remarks: This Aristeides is the grandson of the Athenian statesman during the Persian wars. He goes on to explain how he has realised that simply being in Socrates' company, or even in the same house, is what caused his argumentation skills to improve. The whole thing is rather mystical!

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Athenians came to defence of the Corcyraeans in their dispute with Corinth
statement:
[That they would defend each other should anyone attack Corcyra or Athens or the allies of either]
 ἐπιμαχίαν δ’ ἐποιήσαντο τῇ ἀλλήλων βοηθεῖν, ἐάν τις ἐπὶ Κέρκυραν ἴῃ ἢ Ἀθήνας ἢ τοὺς τούτων ξυμμάχους
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Athens at the outbreak of the war in 431 as: 
Chios, Lesbos, Plataea (allied since 519), the Messenians in Naupactus (allied since ca.461), the Acarnanians (allied since 431), Corcyra (allied since 434/3), Zacynthus, some cities in Caria, the Dorians adjacent to Caria, Ionia, the Hellespont, the coast of Thrace and the Cyclades except Melos and Thera (each of these poleis presumably became allies at the same time as Chios and Lesbos). 
See also oath id 1528.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That some of the men were afraid]
 ἦσαν δὲ νὴ Δία καὶ ἡμῶν οἳ ἔδεισαν
remarks: Xenophon is recounitng his own speech to his men when he described what happened when they were attacked by a crowd of men with stones in their hands shouting "strike! strike! throw! throw!". He observes that the Cerasuntians were terrified and fled to their ships. He also notes (with an oath) that some of the Greeks were afraid.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That the kind of man whose chief concern is bettering himself will certainly take part in politics in his own city (i.e. the ideal city whose establishment they have described), but perhaps not in the city of his birth]
 Ἀλλὰ μὴν καὶ τιμάς γε, εἰς ταὐτὸν ἀποβλέπων, τῶν μὲν μεθέξει καὶ γεύσεται ἑκών, ἃς ἂν ἡγῆται ἀμείνω αὑτὸν ποιήσειν, ἃς δ’ ἂν λύσειν τὴν ὑπάρχουσαν ἕξιν, φεύξεται ἰδίᾳ καὶ δημοσίᾳ. Οὐκ ἄρα, ἔφη, τά γε πολιτικὰ ἐθελήσει πράττειν, ἐάνπερ τούτου κήδηται. Νὴ τὸν κύνα, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, ἔν γε τῇ ἑαυτοῦ πόλει καὶ μάλα, οὐ μέντοι ἴσως ἔν γε τῇ πατρίδι, ἐὰν μὴ θεία τις συμβῇ τύχη.
remarks: Swearing "by the dog" is common only to the character of Socrates (see oath id 2548 with cross references), who is notorious for questioning the nature of the gods.  Other characters occasionally use this oath formula- see oath id 1058 from Aristophanes' Wasps.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That they will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, they shall help with all their strength]
remarks:
Cleiteles the Corinthian envoy to Athens in 370 tells the Athenians that the Corinthians have done nothing wrong since peace was made, yet the Thebans have invaded their land, cut down their trees, burned houses, seized property and cattle.  
Cleiteles reminds that Athenians that they had taken care to make the Corinthians swear the oaths, and warns them that they will be violating their own oaths if they do not aid the Corinthians. 
Xenophon states that the Athenians shouted their approval and said that Cleiteles had spoken justly. 
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That they have a messmate who always does his best to get more than his share]
 Ἀλλ’ ἐγώ, ἔφη, ἄνδρα οἶδα καὶ τοῦ δήμου ὃς συνερεῖ ὥστε μὴ εἰκῇ οὕτως ἰσομοιρίαν εἶναι. ἄλλος δ’ ἀντήρετο τοῦτον τίνα λέγοι. ὁ δ’ ἀπεκρίνατο· Ἔστι νὴ Δί’ ἀνὴρ ἡμῖν σύσκηνος, ὃς ἐν παντὶ μαστεύει πλέον ἔχειν.
remarks: The speaker humorously “confesses” a moment later that his statement was false; of course it was only “false” because he had taken it for granted that he would be understood as referring to good things only. See also oath id 2345.

author: Carcinus
title: Medea
statement: That Medea has not killed her children, but has sent them to safety, entrusting them to her nurse
remarks: This oath appears in a Louvre papyrus (Antiq. Égypt. inv. E 10534) first published by A. Bélis, CRAI (2004) fasc. 3.1305-29 and re-edited by M.L. West, ZPE 161 (2007) 1-10.  Bélis identified the passage as coming from Carcinus' Medea, in which, according to Aristotle (Rhetoric 1400b8ff), Medea, exactly as here, is accused of killing her children after they had disappeared, having "made a mistake in sending them away".  In the fragment, Jason demands of Medea, who denies killing her children, that she produce them alive.  Medea, who evidently cannot do so, instead makes the sworn statement above; the name of the god(dess) she invoked is lost, but the first few letters of an epithet are uncertainly read as Skuthik- (Scythian).  The next to speak, probably Creon, ignores the oath entirely; Medea, he says, admits to having killed Glauce (Creon's daughter and Jason's new bride), she has surely killed her children too, and he gives Jason permission to put her to death.  It is quite possible that the children have in fact, by this point, already perished at other hands, but if so this is not yet known to any of those on stage.  The fragment is in iambic trimeters, but Medea's lines (and only hers) have musical notation; West argues that the papyrus is not part of a complete text of the play, but an excerpt arranged for "concert" performance by a virtuoso singer.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes sarcastically remarks to the jurors, that if all of Aeschines' promises have been fulfilled in consequence of the peace, and they made peace happily knowing that their allies would be ruined, Thebes strengthened, and Philip would seize Thrace, and would set up bases on Euboea, they ought to acquit Aeschines to avoid committing perjury (by breaking their oath to give a just verdict). 
Demosthenes goes on to argue that if Aeschines made promises contrary to these outcomes of the peace, e.g. that Philip was a friend of Athens, that he would put a stop to the insolence of Thebes, and that Philip would hand over Euboea and Oropus, then the jurors should not take the curse and perjury home with them for the sake of the bribes Aeschines took (see also oath id 3807). 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement:
[That of all the things he hears Demosthenes will say, the one he is about to tell the jurors enrages him the most]
 Καὶ νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς τοὺς Ὀλυμπίους, ὧν ἐγὼ πυνθάνομαι Δημοσθένην λέξειν, ἐφ’ ᾧ νυνὶ μέλλω λέγειν ἀγανακτῶ μάλιστα.
remarks: Aeschines is outraged that Demosthenes intends to compare his (Aeschines') talents to the Sirens.  (No such comparison appears in Demosthenes' defence speech as we have it.)

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Emphasises his agreement to Philocleon's statement
statement:
[That Philocleon would indeed enjoy eating a "nice little lawsuit, stewed in a casserole" (more than the he would like to eat skate or eel)]
 ἀλλ’ ἥδιον ἂν  
δικίδιον σμικρὸν φάγοιμ’ ἂν ἐν λοπάδι πεπνιγμένον. 
 {Βδ.}  νὴ Δί’

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Pantaenetus
statement:
[That Nicobulus' slave cheated him out of four talents]
 ὑπὸ τοῦ οἰκέτου νὴ Δία τοῦ ἐμοῦ
remarks: Nicobulus calculates (with some irony) that Pantaenetus has been cheated out of four talents, and asks who did this to him. He imagines that Pantaenetus will respond in this way.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Perdiccas joined forces with the Athenians against the Chalcidians
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides describes here how Perdiccas made another alliance with Athens. Perdiccas would go on to break this alliance (just as he had done with previously alliances with Athens). 
For other alliances between Athens and Perdiccas see oath id 256.  
See also oath id. 1545 and 1751.

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
statement:
[That he had only found out the previous evening that Protagoras is visiting Athens]
 σὺ δὲ ἄρτι πέπυσαι;” “Νὴ τοὺς θεούς,” ἔφη, “ἑσπέρας γε.”

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
According to the text, if someone owing money leaves property to an heiress, she is (through the intervention of male relatives) to mortgage the property or sell it to the value of the debt. Penalties for anyone who buys, or takes in mortgage, the property of an heiress under any other circumstances are then stipulated. If the defendant in cases arising from the illegal mortgage or sale of an heiress' property maintains that the property does not rightfully belong to the heiress, the judge shall decide under oath (ὀμνὺς). 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
  ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The Plataean speaker argues that the Thebans are going to claim that the Plataeans have taken the side of Sparta, and that by destroying Plataea they have benefited the whole alliance i.e. the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy, but says the Athenians should help them because in his opinion no accusation against the Plataeans should have greater validity than "the oaths and agreements" i.e. the terms of the King's Peace. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the other Dorians of Sicily
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Spartans became involved in the war in Sicily
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
Thucydides states that all the Dorian cities in Sicily except Camarina had joined the Spartan alliance at the outbreak of the war. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Xanthias is delighted (because his master is in trouble)
statement:
[That this man is the villain who came into the inn once and ate up sixteen of their loaves]
 ῾Ο πανοῦργος οὑτοσί,  
  ὃς εἰς τὸ πανδοκεῖον εἰσελθών ποτε 
  ἑκκαίδεκ’ ἄρτους κατέφαγ’ ἡμῶν— 
 ΠΛΑΘΑΝΗ  
  Νὴ Δία
remarks: The women believe that Dionysus is, in fact, Heracles because of his costume. They believe the oath to be true, although technically it is not. See Sommerstein ad 549-578 on the status of the two women.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he has seen plenty of strange things but never yet has he seen a raven in a piper's muzzle]
 Τουτὶ μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ πολλὰ δὴ καὶ δείν’ ἰδὼν 
  οὔπω κόρακ’ εἶδον ἐμπεφορβειωμένον.
remarks: The "raven-piper" is probably, as Dunbar suggests, a supernumerary performer who brought up the rear of the sacrificial procession (the piper's regular place in such processions), wearing a raven costume and mask with phorbeiā and pipes, and miming the action of piping. This is the revised view of Sommerstein in addendum ad 858 in his edition of Wealth (p. 295).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds that jurors that he brought about the alliance with the Thebans (see oath id 2670),  as well as the Euboeans (oath id 3391), and the Achaeans, Corinthians, Megarans, Leucadians and Corcyraeans (see oath id 3392). 
See also oath id 2670.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Inflames Cinesias with even more desire for his wife
statement:
[That he does need a mattress]
 Μή μοί γε. 
{ΜΥ.}  Νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be friends and allies to the Athenians faithfully and guilelessly; would consider their friends and enemies to be the same as those of the Athenians; would not aid the enemies of the Athenians in any way; and would not bear malice on account of the past.]
 φίλοι ἐσόμε[θα Ἀθεναίοις καὶ χσύμ]μαχοι πιστο̃[ς] κα[ὶ] ἀδόλος καὶ τ[ὸς αὐ]τὸ[ς φίλος καὶ ἐχθ]ρὸς νομιο̃με[ν] hόσπερ ἂν Ἀθενα[ῖοι], καὶ ο[ὐκ ὀφελέσο τὸ]ς ἐχθρὸς τὸς Ἀθεναίον οὔτε χρ[έμα]σ̣ιν h[απλο̃ς οὔτε δυ]νάμει οὐδεμιᾶι, οὐδὲ μνεσικ[ακέσο] το̣̃ν [παροιχομέν]ον ἕνεκα·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and poleis in the Bottiae. 
This entry takes into account textual changes suggested in Agora 16.16.  
Five Athenians were elected to receive the oath of the Bottiaeans. The names of three Bottiaean poleis are extant: Calindoea, Tripoae and Cemacae. 
For the corresponding oath of that Athenians see oath id 231.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he will not pursue the deserters]
 ἀλλὰ μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐκ ἔγωγε αὐτοὺς διώξω,
remarks:
When Xenias and Pasion desert Cyrus, he tells the Greeks that he will not pursue them even though he could. 
He adds that he will not have any man say about him that he uses a man so long as he is with him and then when he wants to leave seizes him, maltreats him and despoils him of his possessions. 
Xenophon observes that when the Greeks heard the magnanimity of Cyrus they continued on their way with greater satisfaction and eagerness.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That if Mica lays a hand on him, he will make her shit out the sesame-cake she has eaten]
 Πρόσθιγε μόνον, κἀγώ σε νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν— 
  {ΜΙ.}  Τί δράσεις; 
  {ΚΗ.}  τὸν σησαμοῦνθ’ ὃν κατέφαγες, τοῦτον χεσεῖν ποήσω.
remarks: As it happens, the scene is interrupted by the character of Cleisthenes before the two can come to blows.

author: Thucydides
title: History
impact: Sparta and Argos remained at peace for thirty years
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
3. Neither side was to make an alliance with an enemy of the other]
remarks:
Thucydides observed that the Argives hoped that if their treaty with the Spartans did not continue they might become allies of Athens. 
See also oath id 1683.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Heracles explains various routes to Hades

author: Plato
title: Hipparchus
statement:
[That he doesn't think that someone who takes up farming could think to make gain from planting a plant he knew was worthless]
 ἆρ’ ἔστιν ὅντινα οἴει γεωργικὸν ἄνδρα γιγνόμενον, καὶ γιγνώσκοντα ὅτι οὐδενὸς ἄξιον φυτεύει τὸ φυτόν, οἴεσθαι ἀπὸ τούτου κερδαίνειν; {ΕΤ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.
remarks: It is clear that, whether or not this work is by Plato, it was at any rate written before the invention of the Common Agricultural Policy.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement:
[That his mother serving as wet-nurse to Cleinias brought no advantage to him in his present peril, since the work as wet-nurse is a source of slander against them]
 τῷ μὲν εἰς ἔμ’ ἥκοντι κινδύνῳ νῦν μὰ τὸν Δι’ οὐχὶ συμφέρον πρᾶγμα ποιήσασα (ἀπὸ γὰρ ταύτης τῆς τιτθείας ἅπασ’ ἡ περὶ ἡμᾶς γέγονεν βλασφημία),

author: Bacchylides
title: Pasiphae (?)
impact: Daedalus will not reveal the secret to Minos
statement: [That he would keep the secret of Pasiphae's sickness]
remarks: This passage refers to Pasiphae telling Daedalus of her illness (i.e. her lust for the bull), and making him swear an oath. We must presume that the oath sought by Pasiphae is one of secrecy, like that sought by the Nurse from Hippolytus in Euripides' eponymous play (see remarks on oath id 125), although there Hippolytus is effectively tricked by swearing secrecy before being told what the secret is.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That the tyrant son would rate his girl- or boyfriend above his parents, and would strike the latter and make them into servants of the former]
 Ἀλλ’, ὦ Ἀδείμαντε, πρὸς Διός, ἕνεκα νεωστὶ φίλης καὶ οὐκ ἀναγκαίας ἑταίρας γεγονυίας τὴν πάλαι φίλην καὶ ἀναγκαίαν μητέρα, ἢ ἕνεκα ὡραίου νεωστὶ φίλου γεγονότος οὐκ ἀναγκαίου τὸν ἄωρόν τε καὶ ἀναγκαῖον πρεσβύτην πατέρα καὶ τῶν φίλων ἀρχαιότατον δοκεῖ ἄν σοι ὁ τοιοῦτος πληγαῖς τε δοῦναι καὶ καταδουλώσασθαι ἂν αὐτοὺς ὑπ’ ἐκείνοις, εἰ εἰς τὴν αὐτὴν οἰκίαν ἀγάγοιτο; Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would not remember past grievances]
remarks:
When Agesilaus arrived at Thespiae he found that the citizens were involved in a factional dispute. The supporters of Sparta wanted to put to death their opponents, including a certain Menon. 
Agesilaus did not allow this, but reconciled them and compelled them to give oaths to one another. 
Agesilaus then left Boeotia and led his army home.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he would not have enough money to pay his travelling expenses on the way home unless he should sell his horse and what he had about his person]
 ἦ μὴν ἔσεσθαι μηδὲ ἐφόδιον ἱκανὸν οἴκαδε ἀπιόντι, εἰ μὴ ἀπόδοιτο τὸν ἵππον καὶ ἃ ἀμφ’ αὑτὸν εἶχεν.
remarks:
Cleagoras who painted the murals at the Lyceum and Eucleides the Phliasian seer met Xenophon at Lampsacus. 
Eucleides congratulated Xenophon on his safe return, and asked him how much gold he had got. When Xenophon swore that he would have to sell his horse and his possessions in order to bear the cost of returning home, Eucleides did not believe him. 
When the Lampsacenes sent gifts of hospitality to Xenophon and he was sacrificing to Apollo, he gave Eucleides a place beside him. When Eucleides saw the vitals of the victims he said that he believed that Xenophon had no money.

author: Andron
title: Fragment 10 EGM
impact: Licymnios is no longer afraid to let his son go with Heracles on the expedition against Troy
statement:
[That Heracles would bring Licymnios' son Argeios home]
 Λικύμνιον δέ φασι τὸν 
πατέρα Ἀργείου, φοβούμενον ὅτι καὶ τὸν πρότερον
αὐτοῦ υἱὸν ὀνόματι Οἰωνὸν ἀποστείλας εἰς Λακεδαίμονα
μεθ’ Ἡρακλέους ἀπέβαλεν, οὐ βούλεσθαι προΐεσθαι
τοῦτον, ἕως Ἡρακλῆς ὤμοσεν ἀπάξειν πάλιν αὐτόν.
Τότε οὖν συμπεσούσης τῷ Ἀργείῳ τῆς τοῦ βίου τε- 
λευτῆς, διαπορηθεὶς ὁ Ἡρακλῆς πῶς ἂν ἐπιτελέσοι
τὸν ὅρκον, ἔκαυσεν αὐτὸν, καὶ πρῶτόν φασι τοῦτον 
τοιαύτης ἐπιμελείας τυχεῖν.
remarks: Argeios dies during the first sack of Troy but Heracles keeps his oath by burning Argeios' body and bringing it home to Licymnios as ashes. This is given as the reason behind cremation in Greek society.

author: Plato
title: Charmides
statement:
[That he does not know whether he possesses the quality of sophrosyne (since neither, he nor Critias, nor Socrates have been able to figure out what it really is)]
 Καὶ ὁ Χαρμίδης, Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἦ δ’ ὅς, ἔγωγε, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐκ οἶδα οὔτ’ εἰ ἔχω οὔτ’ εἰ μὴ ἔχω

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That they should pity Meidias] 
 ἐλεῆσαι νὴ Δία
remarks: Demosthenes asks the jurors what other defence is left for Meidias. He imagines that someone might respond that pity is left.

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
statement:
[That it is opportune that Prodicus happens to be present at their discussion]
 Νὴ τὸν Δία, εἰς καιρόν γε παρατετύχηκεν ἡμῖν ἐν τοῖς λόγοις Πρόδικος ὅδε.
remarks: Prodicus is being held up by Socrates as an expert on Simonides, being a fellow Cean, in his attempt to rebut Protagoras' arguments about the meaning of some of the poet's lines.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Phormion
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that it would be outrageous if they were to dismiss the case after swearing to vote in accordance with the laws, when the laws authorise trials before the Thesmothetae for contracts made at Athens. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he wouldn't have escaped from the wasps so easily if they'd been drinking in Philocles' melodies]
 ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ οὐ ῥᾳδίως οὕτως ἂν αὐτοὺς διέφυγες, 
  εἴπερ ἔτυχον τῶν μελῶν τῶν Φιλοκλέους βεβρωκότες.
remarks: Sommerstein explains line 462 as follows: Philocles…, son of Philopeithes and nephew of Aeschylus, was a tragic dramatist, who on one occasion won first prize ahead of Sophocles' Oedipus Tyrannus. He was proud of his art and his family…, but was frequently ridiculed as an ugly man with a pointy head… whose poetry and music were "bitter" and unpleasant…, whence he was nicknamed "Gall"… and "Son of Briny"… Hence Philocleon is saying that if his fellow-jurors had nurtured themsleves on the acid melodies of Philocles instead of the sweet ones of Phrynicus (220) they would have become "sharper" and more penetrative, and been harder to defeat".

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement:
[That it is true that the Greeks assert the falsehood that the Sun and Moon and some other stars never travel along the same path, but are called "planets" (i.e. wanderers)]
 Ὦ ἀγαθοί, καταψευδόμεθα νῦν ὡς ἔπος εἰπεῖν Ἕλληνες πάντες μεγάλων θεῶν, Ἡλίου τε ἅμα καὶ Σελήνης.  {ΚΛ.} Τὸ ποῖον δὴ ψεῦδος;  {ΑΘ.} Φαμὲν αὐτὰ οὐδέποτε τὴν αὐτὴν ὁδὸν ἰέναι, καὶ ἄλλ’ ἄττα ἄστρα μετὰ τούτων, ἐπονομάζοντες πλανητὰ αὐτά.{ΚΛ.} Νὴ τὸν Δία, ὦ ξένε, ἀληθὲς τοῦτο λέγεις·
remarks: The Athenian makes no attempt to explain his assertion – which to many readers will have seemed extraordinary – that the sun, moon and planets “travel each on its own path – one path, not many – always in a circle” (822a). Plato is alluding to the theory of planetary motion devised in his time by Eudoxus, the first of a long series of attempts to show that there were regular patterns of circular motion underlying the apparently irregular movements of these bodies in the sky.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes addresses Eubulus and blames him for the peace. He claims that when Philocrates made the proposal for peace, Eubulus told the Athenians that they must either contribute money and convert the theoric fund into a military fund, or vote for Philocrates' proposal, which was supported by Aeschines. Demosthenes claims that as a result of Eubulus' speech, the peace that was made was disgraceful instead of fair. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Lysicrates' nose will hold itself as high as that of the most handsome men]
 Λυσικράτους ἄρα νυνὶ ῥὶς ἴσα τοῖσι καλοῖσι φρονήσει;  
 {Γε.}  νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω
remarks: This is with reference to the notion that women will now only be allowed to sleep with handsome men once they have taken care of the ugly and short.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That when he swore, his son didn't yet know "unjust argument"]
  μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ γάρ πω τότ’ ἐξηπίστατο
  Φειδιππίδης μοι τὸν ἀκατάβλητον λόγον.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Cyrus should not provide them with a double feast, at least not in one day, unless he can porived them with double stomachs]
 ἐπεὶ οὖν πάντα διπλᾶ ποιεῖτε, διπλῆν ὑμῖν δίκαιον καὶ τὴν εὐωχίαν παρέχειν. Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ ταξίαρχος, μήτοι γ’ ἐν μιᾷ ἡμέρᾳ, εἰ μὴ καὶ διπλᾶς ἡμῖν τὰς γαστέρας παρέξεις.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That they will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, they shall help with all their strength]
remarks:
Xenophon indicates that when stasis broke out in Tegea the Mantineans intervened in support of a faction that wanted to unite all the Arcadians. After they slaughtered many of their opponents, some 800 of these fled to Sparta. 
The Spartans decided that, in accordance with their oaths i.e. the common peace of 371, they ought to avenge those slain and aid those who had been banished. 
Thus, the Spartans decided to make an expedition against the Mantineans on the grounds that they had violated their oaths by proceeding in arms against the Tegeates.  
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
remarks:
Xenophon indicates that the Greeks were approached by Tiribazus, the satrap of Armenia, who offered to conclude a treaty with them. His terms were immediately accepted by the Greek generals. 
The Greeks marched on and Tiribazus followed them. 
When the Greeks captured a Persian who informed them that Tiribazus intended to march ahead and capture a mountain pass where he could attack them, they mounted an assault on Tiribazus' camp and put his men to flight.  
After capturing Tiribazus' tent and possessions the Greeks continued their march.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [?That they would protect the Samians, and be just and guileless in their dealings with them]
remarks: This Athenian decree honouring the demos of Samos promises that the Samians shall be autonomous and that they shall act in all respects in accordance with the oaths and treaties agreed by the Athenians and the Samians. This is clearly a reference to an earlier alliance between Athens and Samos.

author: Isocrates
title: Concerning the team of horses
statement: [That the facts pleaded in their written statement were true]
remarks:
The defendant - Alcibiades the younger - argues that his opponents are spending more time slandering his father than they are in informing the jurors about their sworn charges (antomosia). 
This passage refers not just to the present prosecution but to a whole series of charges that have been brought against the speaker, not all of which involve alleged thefts.  In the present case there can have been no allegation "that the defendant had stolen", since the alleged theft had been committed by his father when he himself was a small child; rather, the prosecutor is suing him for the value of the property of which he alleges he was wrongly deprived.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That it is not surprising that Aeschines is going to argue that Demosthenes did all the same things as he himself did]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ εἰκότως γε.
remarks: It is not surprising, according to Demosthenes, because criminals "always" use any argument, however implausible, that may give them a chance of avoiding punishment.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement: [That what they are saying is true]
remarks: The chorus here sing that if Bdelycleon defeats Philocleon in the debate, old men will be mocked as "the husks of affidavits". Sommerstein has this translation which he explains as follows: "i.e. worthless rubbish from the lawcourts. The word translated "affidavit" is antomosia, a sworn statement by a litigant of the facts on which he based his claim or defence". The antomosia was an oath which the plaintiff/prosecutor and the defendant both had to take, at the preliminary hearing of their case, to the truth of the written statements of their claim and defence, respectively.  If either party refused to take the oath, he would lose his case by default; if he took the oath, he could continue with his case. Cf. also oath id 1111.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he has never heard a cleverer idea]
 μὰ γῆν, μὰ παγίδας, μὰ νεφέλας, μὰ δίκτυα,  
 μὴ ’γὼ νόημα κομψότερον ἤκουσά πω·
remarks: The idea in question is to create a bird city in the sky. Tereus here invokes four powers in his informal oath, only the first of which, Earth, is a divine being.  Sommerstein ad 194 notes that the line "is probably a parody of a metrical oath ("By Earth, by springs, by rivers, by streams"), for which see oath ids 1410 and 1445. Here the springs, rivers and streams are replaced by "objects of which birds stand in awe and terror" (Kakridis)". Cf. oath id 1510.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
if_refused: They would not be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
When King Archidamus learned that the Plataeans were going to remain loyal to Athens he made the following appeal to the gods: "gods and heroes who hold the Plataean land, be witnesses that we did no wrong in the beginning, nor until these men (the Plataeans) had first abandoned the oath we swore together did we come against this land.." 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1501.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
