statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker asks whether his opponents who are insisting that the Athenians should abide by the peace and their oaths believe that the clauses of the treaty against Athens should be in force, but are opposed to those clauses which are for Athens' protection. He asks whether they will confirm whatever is against Athens in the oaths and favourable to their opponents, yet think it proper to continually oppose anything which is advantageous to Athens.  
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Pindar
title: Olympian 11
statement:
[That the victorious boy will have future success]
See also remarks.
εἰ δὲ σὺν πόνῳ τις εὖ πράσσοι, μελιγάρυες ὕμνοι
ὑστέρων ἀρχὰ λόγων  
τέλλεται καὶ πιστὸν ὅρκιον μεγάλαις ἀρεταῖς·
remarks: This is a metaphorical oath. What is being said in effect is that victory odes for Hagesidamus' first success are equivalent to a sworn pledge of future success. See also oath id 1320 and cf. id 23. Pindar swears in his authorial persona at ids 1312, 1313, 1317, 1319, 1321.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Here one of the Achaeans or Trojans expresses the wish for them to be true to their oath of truce (see oath id 318).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes refers to the time when the peace was concluded and Philip's ambassadors had received the oaths and departed. He explicitly calls the peace "the one of Philocrates", and "the one that this man (i.e. Aeschines) supported". 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Argives were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Argives while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that after their victory at Mantinea the Spartans set up a trophy in front of the dead of the enemy, stripped the slain, took up their own dead, and then withdrew to Tegea where they buried them, and gave up the dead of the enemy under a truce.

title: IG XII 8
work_date: late fifth or early fourth century
date: Late fifth or early fourth century (410 to 390)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 43.1235.  
The text indicates that the inhabitants of Neapolis in Thrace who have Thasian ancestry will henceforth be considered Thasian. When they come of age they shall swear an oath (of allegiance) according to the law.

author: Demosthenes
title: Answer to Philip's Letter
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the Athenians that it must be clear to them that Philip never really concluded a peace with them, but only postponed the war. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he doesn't think the young men of their ideal state should be told the stories of the poets which would tend to encourage the young to believe that a god or a hero would be doing nothing out of the ordinary if he committed the worst imaginable crimes, or if he inflicted punishment, however severe, on his father for some wrongdoing]
 Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὐδὲ αὐτῷ μοι δοκεῖ ἐπιτήδεια εἶναι λέγειν.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Greeks]
 ὀμόσαντες ἡμῖν τοὺς αὐτοὺς φίλους καὶ ἐχθροὺς νομιεῖν
remarks:
After Ariaeus announced to the Greeks that Clearchus had been executed for violating the truce, Cleanor the Orchomenian responded, "Ariaeus, you most base of men, and all you others who were friends of Cyrus, are you not ashamed before the gods and men, that after giving us your oaths to have the same friends and enemies, you have betrayed us, joining with Tissaphernes that most godless and villainous man, you have destroyed the men to whom you swore and also betrayed the rest of us and have come against us with our enemies?". 
Ariaeus responded that it had been shown that Clearchus had been plotting against Tissaphernes and the other Persians. 
See also oath id 2177, 3852, 3853.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he would be offended, not if Hystaspas asked him a question, but if he had a question he wanted to ask and did not ask it]
  Ἆρ’ ἄν, ἔφη, ὦ Κῦρε, ἀχθεσθείης μοι, εἴ σε ἐροίμην ὃ βούλομαί σου πυθέσθαι; Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη, τοὐναντίον τούτου ἀχθοίμην ἄν σοι, εἰ αἰσθοίμην σιωπῶντα ἃ βούλοιο ἐρέσθαι.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement:
[That Charidemus did some harm, but only in self-defence]
 νὴ Δί’, ἀμυνόμενος γὰρ ὑπὲρ τοῦ 
μὴ παθεῖν ἐποίει τι κακόν
remarks: Euthycles describes the former hostilities between Athens and Charidemus, and argues that no one could claim that Charidemus only harmed Athens in self-defence.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the man Lysistrata has spotted is indeed by the shrine of Chloe]
 Ποῦ δ’ ἐστίν, ὅστις ἐστί;  
{ΛΥ.}  Παρὰ τὸ τῆς Χλόης. 
{ΚΑ.} Ὢ νὴ Δί’ ἐστὶ δῆτα. Τίς κἀστίν ποτε;
remarks: Sommerstein notes ad 835: "Demeter Chloe (the goddess of green things…) had a sanctuary close under the Acropolis, a little way south of the Propylaea (and hence to the left of an observer looking out)".

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Lysicrates of Oenoe; Antimachus; Thrason of Erchia
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be a friend and ally to Cetriporis, and would wage the war with Cetriporis against Philip without deceit and with all their strength as far as possible, and would not put an end in advance to the war against Philip without the consent of Cetriporis and his brothers; and they would join with Cetriporis and his brothers in subduing the other places that Philip holds, and they would join in taking Crenides with Cetriporis and his brothers, and they would give back - - -]
[ὀμνύω Δία καὶ Γῆν] καὶ Ἥλιον καὶ Ποσει[δ]ῶ καὶ Ἀθηνᾶν καὶ [Ἄρην, φίλος ἔσομαι] Κετριπόρι καὶ τοῖς ἀδελφοῖς τοῖς Κ[ετριπόριος καὶ σ]ύμμαχος, καὶ πολεμή[σ]ω μετὰ Κετριπόρ[ιος τὸν πόλεμον τ]ὸν πρὸς Φίλιππον ἀδόλως παντὶ σθένε[ι κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν, κ]αὶ οὐ προκαταλύσομαι τὸν πόλεμον ἄν[ευ Κετριπόριος κ]αὶ τῶν ἀδελφῶν τὸν πρὸς Φίλιππον, κ[αὶ τἆλλα χωρία ἃ κατ]έχε[ι] Φίλιππος συνκα[τ]α[σ]τρέψομαι μ[ετὰ Κετριπόριος κ]αὶ τῶν ἀδελφῶν, καὶ Κρηνίδ[α]ς συνε[ξ]αι[ρήσω μετὰ Κετριπ]ό[ρ]ιος κα[ὶ τ]ῶν [ἀδ]ελφῶν, καὶ ἀποδώσω τὰ [- - - - ]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares
remarks:
The text records the alliance between Athens and Cetriporis of Thrace, Lyppeus of Paeonia and Grabus of Illyria.  
Only the oath to Cetriporis has survived. The text indicates that three Athenian presbeis were appointed, presumably to travel to Thrace to make the oath to Cetriporis.  
See also oath id 460, 461 and 462.

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
swearer: Envoys; Representative of the Persian King
swearee: Envoys; Representative of the Persian King
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Isocrates criticises the Athenians and the Spartans of his own time, by contrasting the fact that the Spartans and the Athenians have been sending ambassadors to the Persian King, courting his friendship and alliance, with the fact that this had not happened in the time of Darius and Xerxes. 
See also Demosthenes 12.6-7, where Philip writes to the Athenians complaining that they have sent envoys to the King of Persia urging him to declare war on Philip and to negotiate a defensive alliance. See oath id 3289.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he does boast as though he were handsomer than Socrates]
 ὡς γὰρ καὶ ἐμοῦ καλλίων ὢν ταῦτα κομπάζεις. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κριτόβουλος
remarks: As Critobulus goes on to say, to be no handsomer than Socrates he would have to be uglier than any Silenus in a satyr-drama!

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: n/a
remarks: When Critias addressed the boule to denounce Theramenes, he observed that "men make peace and become trustworthy again to enemies, but no one ever makes peace with or trusts for the future a man caught as a traitor".

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That the plundering of corpses and the refusal to permit their burial must be dismissed from the ideal state]
 Ἐατέον ἄρα τὰς νεκροσυλίας καὶ τὰς τῶν ἀναιρέσεων διακωλύσεις;  Ἐατέον μέντοι, ἔφη, νὴ Δία.
remarks: The context strongly suggests that these prohibitions apply only when the enemy is Greek.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That (he assumes) Strepsiades didn't know the Clouds nourish sophists] 
 οὐ γὰρ μὰ Δί’ οἶσθ’ ὁτιὴ πλείστους αὗται βόσκουσι σοφιστάς
remarks: The swearer doesn't believe in Zeus!

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks: According to Xenophon, when King Cotys (Otys) disobeyed a command of the Great King he feared that he would be seized, fined or put to death, and trusting in a truce he had made with Agesilaus, and then made an alliance with him (see oath id 1920 and 2304).

author: Hypereides
title: Against Demosthenes
statement:
[That neither laws nor decrees apply to Demosthenes]
 Ἀλλ’ ἐγώ, ὦ [ἄνδρες] δικα̣σ̣τ̣α̣ί̣, [ὅπερ καὶ] πρὸς τοὺ̣[ς παρακαθη]μένους̣ [ἀρτίως ἔ]λ[ε̣γο̣ν̣, θαυ[μάζω] τουτὶ τὸ πρᾶ[γμα· εἰ δ̣]ὴ̣ νὴ Δία κατὰ [Δημ]οσθένους μό[νου τ]ῶ̣ν ἐν τῆι πόλει [μήτε ο̣]ἱ νόμοι ἰσχύου[σιν οἱ] κελεύον̣τ̣ε̣ς̣ κύ[ρια εἶν]αι ὅσα ἄν τις [αὐτ]ὸς κ̣αθ’ αὑτοῦ διάθηται, μήτε τὰ ψηφίσματα τοῦ δήμου, καθ’ ἃ ὑμεῖς μὲν ὀμωμόκατε τὴν ψ[ῆ]φον οἴσειν, ἔγραψεν δὲ αὐτὰ οὐδεὶς τῶν ἐχθρῶν τῶν Δημοσθένους, ἀλλ’ αὐτὸς οὗτος, ἐ̣ψη[φ]ί̣σ̣ατ̣ο δὲ ὁ δῆμ̣ος [το]ύτου κελεύο[ντ]ο̣ς.
remarks: Hypereides observes that the jurors have sworn to observe these very laws and decrees (see oath id 2756), and they were proposed not by Demosthenes' enemies, but by Demosthenes himself, almost as if he had sought to destroy himself.

author: Isocrates
title: Concerning the team of horses
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
The speaker - Alcibiades the younger - reminds the jurors that his father caused the most powerful cities in the Peloponnese to revolt from the Spartans and brought them into alliance with Athens. 
This must be a reference to the alliance between Athens, Argos, Mantinea and Elis ca.420 (see also oath id 251).

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, the Athenians decided to make a defensive alliance rather than an offensive and defensive alliance to ensure that they were not breaking the Thirty Years' Peace.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That the only help left for Aristogeiton is that which comes to all defendants from the natural temper of the jurors: pity, pardon and benevolence]
 ἃ κοινὰ νὴ Δία πᾶσιν ὑπάρχει τοῖς ἀγωνιζομένοις παρὰ τῆς τῶν ἄλλων ὑμῶν φύσεως, καὶ οὐδεὶς αὐτὸς ἑαυτῷ ταῦτα φέρει τῶν κρινομένων, ἀλλ’ ὑμῶν ἕκαστος ἔχων οἴκοθεν ἔρχεται, ἔλεον, συγγνώμην, φιλανθρωπίαν.

author: Epicharmus
title: Ga kai Thalassa
statement: unknown
remarks: This is an affirmative oath. Swearing by cabbages and other plants is not uncommon in comic oaths- cf. oath ids 1380, 1382, 1438, 1468, 1470.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That women do have plenty of spirit (lit. "bile") in them if there's a wine-shop nearby]
 ἢ γυναιξὶν οὐκ οἴει
  χολὴν ἐνεῖναι; 
{ΠΡ.} Νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω καὶ μάλα  
  πολλήν γ’, ἐάνπερ πλησίον κάπηλος ᾖ.
remarks: Sommerstein explains the phrase"if there's a wine-shop nearby" as follows: "i.e. only when well primed with drink are women likely to display the "manlike" quality of anger".

author: Plato
title: Meno
impact: Emphasises the silliness of the suggestion
statement:
[That it seems unreasonable and indeed foolish to send someone wishing to learn the art of flute-playing to those who don't teach the art]
 οὐ πολλή σοι δοκεῖ ἀλογία εἶναι;  {ΑΝ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία ἔμοιγε, καὶ ἀμαθία γε πρός.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes again criticises Philip for besieging his erstwhile allies the Byzantines, and asks what act could be more shameful. 
See also oath id 3263.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
The Spartans sent envoys to the Corinthians to dissuade them from making an alliance with Argos. The envoys warned the Corinthians that they would be violating the terms of their oaths, and that they were already doing wrong in not accepting the treaty with Athens inasmuch as it had been declared that whatsoever the majority of the allies decreed should be binding, unless the gods or heroes should forbid it. 
The Corinthians countered that they could not join the treaty because they would be betraying their allies in Thrace (see oath id 1695). 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Lysias
title: Against Simon
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had not wounded with the intent to kill]
remarks: The defendant tells the jurors that he was attacked by Simon, and summons witnesses to testify that on the spot where Simon says a fight occurred nobody on either side had his head broken or received any other injury. These witnesses would have sworn the diomosia prior to giving evidence, as was necessary in trials held bvefore the Areopagus Council.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement: [That Euxitheus' father Thucritus was an Athenian and related to them]
remarks: Euxitheus tells the jurors that he would suffer most pitiably of all people if they were to vote that he is an alien after all these relatives have testified and sworn that they are related to him.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Aristogeiton
statement:
[That the jurors must not think that Aristogeiton will improve if he is acquitted now]
 οὐ γὰρ δὴ μὰ τὸν Ἡρακλέα βελτίω γενήσεσθ’ αὐτὸν προσδοκᾶτε συγγνώμης νυνὶ τυγχάνοντα παρ’ ὑμῶν,

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That she does not use any of the contrivances listed by Socrates to 'net' lovers]
 Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ἡ Θεοδότη, ἐγὼ τούτων οὐδὲν μηχανῶμαι.
remarks: There seems to be a certain disingenuousness about all of Theodote's answers. Are we really to suppose that this hetaira was completely ignorant of "man-hunting" techniques until Socrates turned up?

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides observes that the Athenians will be making common peace for all the Greeks, and giving them all power to share in all its benefits.  
Andocides also observes that when the Spartans began the war they ruled on land and sea, and will be left by the peace with neither of these. 
This argument is more nonsense from Andocides; the Spartans will be as powerful on land after the proposed peace as they were before the war - if not more so, since Boeotia will be split up, and Argos and Corinth separated and forbidden to unite.  Cf. 2408, where Andocides' point is that if Athens fights on she will have to fight without the Thebans (he was wrong about that). 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That a monetary value can be placed on friends]
 σκοποῦμαι δὴ τοῦτο, ἔφη, εἰ ἄρα, ὥσπερ τῶν οἰκετῶν, οὕτω καὶ τῶν φίλων εἰσὶν ἀξίαι. Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἀντισθένης·

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 1
statement:
[That Philip is not dead, but he is ill]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἀσθενεῖ.
remarks: We are invited to listen to street gossip as people discuss news and rumour: Imaginary Athenian B tells Imaginary Athenian A that no, Philip isn’t dead, just ill. Demosthenes then warns the Athenians that even if something were to happen to Philip they will raise up another Philip through their inaction.

author: Hipponax
title: Fragment
statement: [That he would be a loyal friend]
remarks: In this fragment, Hipponax curses his former friend extensively, who has treated him unjustly and "trampled his oaths". Cf. oath ids 1338 and 1512.

author: Isocrates
title: Antidosis
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Isocrates states that he does not wonder that men spend more time in denouncing those who attempt to deceive the jury than upon their own defence, nor that they claim calumny (diabole) is our greatest bane. He asks what could achieve more mischief than calumny, when it causes liars to be looked upon with respect, innocent men to regarded as guilty, and jurors to break their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [? That his version of events is true]
remarks:
Apollodorus asks the jurors whether his own witness - Archebiades - is so shameless as to give testimony against Callippus, a fellow deme member, and a man active in public life, and to say that Apollodorus is telling the truth and that Callippus is lying, knowing that if Callippus wants to denounce him for giving false evidence or simply administer an oath to him, he will be compelled to take whatever pledge Callippus orders him to take. 
This seems to mean that if Callippus sues Archebiades for giving false evidence, he will be able, if he wishes, to challenge Archebiades to swear that his evidence was in fact true.  Would Archebiades, Apollodorus asks, want to run the risk of being forced to commit perjury as a result of such a challenge?  In reality, of course, he wouldn’t need to run that risk, because he could always refuse the challenge (or haggle over its terms).

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement: [That they would rule according to the established nomoi; and that they would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
remarks: The Athenian here blames the kings of Argos, Messene and Sparta for ultimately bringing ruin on themselves because they were not in agreement about their oath (see oath ids 2679-83).

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Epigenes will howl if he screws the young girl (before screwing her)]
  οἰμώζων ἄρα, νὴ Δία, σποδήσεις.
remarks: According to the new rules, the young man must first "screw" an old or ugly woman before he can "screw" his young girlfriend.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
date: Post 335 (the reform of the ephebate) (355 to 322)
impact: Three men are chosen as candidates
statement: [That they will choose representatives fairly]
remarks: After the registration of the new deme members (see oath id 1800), their fathers meet by tribes and choose on oath three members of the tribe over forty whom they consider best suited to take charge of the ephebes.  From the thirty candidates so chosen the Assembly then elects ten, one from each tribe, as sophronistai of the ephebes; they also elect, from outside the list of thirty, a kosmetes as president of the board.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he does not believe that it is possible for any of the things which exist not to be what it is]
 ἆρ’ οὖν δοκεῖς οἷόν τέ τι τῶν ὄντων τοῦτο ὃ τυγχάνει ὄν, αὐτὸ τοῦτο μὴ εἶναι;  Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Athenians; Spartans; The other Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: Athenians; Spartans; The other Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that after the Spartans rejected their assistance against the Helot revolt in Messenia the Athenians gave up the alliance they had made with the Spartans against the Persians, and became allies of their enemies the Argives. 
For the alliance of the Greeks against the Persians see also oath id 1501. 
Cf. de Ste Croix, The Origins of the Peloponnesian War, Appendix XXXII.

author: Euripides
title: Supplices
statement:
[That their entreaties of the gods were no help to them]
 ἄγ’, ὦ γεραιαί, στείχετε, γλαυκὴν χλόην
  αὐτοῦ λιποῦσαι φυλλάδος καταστεφῆ,
  θεούς τε καὶ γῆν τήν τε πυρφόρον θεὰν 
  Δήμητρα θέμεναι μάρτυρ’ ἡλίου τε φῶς
  ὡς οὐδὲν ἡμῖν ἤρκεσαν λιταὶ θεῶν.
gods_invoked: The gods; Gaia; DemeterEpithet(s)torch-bearing goddess; Helios' light
remarks: This oath is proposed to the chorus as advice but not actually taken up, since Adrastus immediately afterwards adopts the alternative plan of an intensified supplication of Theseus.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he wishes never again to be on a jury that finds Cleon guilty of embezzlement]
 “σπεῦδ’, ὦ ψυχή—”. ποῦ μοι ψυχή; “πάρες, ὦ σκιερά—”. 
μὰ τὸν Ἡρακλέα μή νυν ἔτ’ ἐγὼ ’ν τοῖσι δικασταῖς 
 κλέπτοντα Κλέωνα λάβοιμι.
remarks: Sommerstein comments as follows: "Philocleon had prayed (525) that if he lost the debate with his son and then broke his vow to kill himself, he might be deprived for ever of the delights of judging. Now, having failed to fulfill his vow, he reiterates this "curse" upon himself. That he imagines himself convicting Cleon does not necessarily mean that he now consciously believes Cleon to be a thief; in the later trial-scene (893-1002) he is still Cleon's devoted supporter. Rather, Philocleon is blurting out, as he did at 592 and the chorus at 342 and 418, a fact which he knows in his heart to be true but which contradicts the pro-Cleon political stance he continues to maintain".

author: Alexis
title: Homoia
statement:
[That he is not fond of good dinners (since he prefers desserts)]
  οὐδὲ φιλόδειπνός εἰμι μὰ τὸν Ἀσκληπιόν
remarks: The speaker is "most likely to be a parasite or…slave" (Arnott ad loc.). Arnott notes that swearing by Asclepius is a "standard male oath in later comedy" but this is our only example before 322.

title: IG II(2)
swearee: Representatives of the poleis in Ceos
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
[That they would not harbour grudges for what is past against any of the Ceans, nor would they kill or make an exile any of the Ceans who abide by the oaths and this agreement, but they would bring them into the alliance like the other allies. But if any one commits an act of revolution in Ceos contrary to the oaths and the agreement, they would not allow him by any craft or contrivance as far as possible. If any one does not wish to live in Ceos, they would allow him to live wherever he wishes in the allied cities and enjoy his own property. To this they would be steadfast in their oath, by Zeus, by Athena, by Poseidon, by Demeter: to him who keeps the oath there shall be many good things, but to him who breaks the oath, ill] 
 ὀ μνησικακήσω [τῶ]ν πα[ρ]εληλυθότων πρὸ[ς] Κείος οὐδ[ε]νὸς οὐδὲ ἀποκτενῶ Κ[είων] ὀ[δ]ένα, οὐδὲ φυγάδα ποήσω τῶν ἐμμενόντων τοῖς ὅρκο[ις καὶ τ]αῖς συνθήκαις ταῖσδε, εἰς δὲ τὴν συμμαχίαν εἰσά[ξω καθάπ]ερ τὸς ἄλλος συμμάχος. ἐὰν δέ τι[ς] νεωτερίζηι τι [ἐν Κείωι παρ]ὰ τὸς ὅρκος καὶ τὰς συνθήκας, οὐκ ἐπιτρέψω οὔτε τέχνηι οὔ]τε μηχανῆι ὀδεμιᾶι εἰς τὸ δυνατόν. εἰ δέ τις [μή βούλεται οἰ]κεῖν ἐγ Κέωι, ἐάσω αὐτὸν ὅπο ἂν βόληται τῶ[ν συμμαχίδων πόλ]εων οἰκο̃ντα τὰ ἑαυτο̃ καρπο̃σθαι. ταῦτα [ἐμπεδορκήσω νὴ τὸν] Δία, νὴ τὴν Ἀθηνάαν, νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ, νὴ [τὴν Δήμητρα· εὐορκο̃ντι] μὲν πόλλ’ ἀγαθά εἶναι, ἐπιορκο̃ν[τι δὲ κακά.]
linguistic: nh thn, nh ton, ork, wmos
remarks:
This is a new agreement between Athens and the Ceans after some citizens from Iulis violated the previous agreement.  
For the corresponding oath of the Ceans see oath id 424.  
For the oath of the reinstated Ceans see oath id 427.  
For the earlier agreement see oath id 431, 443.  
See also oath id 520, 521.

title: SGDI
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: This document is one of two lease documents published by a group known as the Klytidai (perhaps a tribe) from Chios. The text indicates that one of the parties involved in a dispute over a lease may offer an oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Leads Dicaeopolis to respond that the Ambassadors are making fools of the Greeks
statement:
[That the Persian king served the Greek ambassadors a bird three times the size of Cleonymus; the bird was called a "fooler"]
  Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δί’ ὄρνιν τριπλάσιον Κλεωνύμου
 παρέθηκεν ἡμῖν· ὄνομα δ’ ἦν αὐτῷ φέναξ.
remarks: Cleonymus was repeatedly satirized by Aristophanes as an obese glutton, and also (though not before 423) for having run away from battle, see Sommerstein ad loc.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 2
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement:
[That Boeotus was not his son]
οὐκ ἔφη τοῦτον υἱὸν αὑτοῦ εἶναι
remarks:
Mantitheus imagines what would happen if someone came forward and indicted Boeotus for usurping the rights of citizens, alleging that Mantias had denied on oath that Boeotus was his son. 
Mantitheus argues that if this happened Boeotus would not be able to rely on anything other than the fact that his father had been forced to admit that Boeotus was his son because of Plangon's oath (see oath id 3562) and the decision of the arbitrator.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That his father would sell the plots of land he cultivated if he could get a good price]
 Πότερα δέ, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, ὁπόσους ἐξειργάσατο χώρους ὁ πατὴρ πάντας ἐκέκτητο ἢ καὶ ἀπεδίδοτο, εἰ πολὺ ἀργύριον εὑρίσκοι; Καὶ ἀπεδίδοτο νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος·

title: IC IV
swearer: The owner of the dead animal
statement: [? That the death or injury of the animal was caused by his opponent]
remarks: The text states that if an animal is dead, or it is not able to be moved, the owner who has suffered loss shall summon his opponent in the presence of two witnesses, within five days, to show him the dead animal. If the owner has brought the dead animal to the defendant or summoned the defendant to see the dead animal, his oath regarding the death of the animal is to be believed. (αἰ δέ κα τετνάκηι ἢ μὴ νυνατὸν ἦι [[η]] ἐπιδίεθθαι, καλῆν ἀντὶ μαιτύρ̣ον δυο̃ν ἐν ταῖς πέντε ἆι δείκσει ὀπῆ κ’ ἦι, κ’ ὀρκιότερον ἤμην αὐτὸν καὶ τὸνς μαίτυρανς αἰ ἐπεδίετο ἢ ἐπήλευσε ἢ ἐκάλη δεικσίον).

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he will not become a student] 
  τούτων γενοῦ μοι, σχασάμενος τὴν ἱππικήν.
{Φε.}οὐκ ἂν μὰ τὸν Διόνυσον εἰ δοίης γέ μοι
  τοὺς Φασιανοὺς οὓς τρέφει Λεωγόρας.
remarks: Contradicts the oath he swore at 90-91, also invoking Dionysus.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
statement: n/a
remarks:
Andocides states that those who complain that because of the last peace the Thirty were established, many Athenians were put to death by being made to drink hemlock, and others fled into exile, are in error, because a peace and a truce are very different things. 
He argues that a peace (eirene) is made by agreement between men on equal terms, and a truce (spondai) is dictated by the victors after winning the war. This distinction has no support whatever in the ordinary usage of the terms, though the point that there is a great difference between a dictated and a negotiated peace is sound enough.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That Socrates will not hear Hippias' discovery until he has declared his own opinion on the nature of Justice]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἀκούσῃ, πρίν γ’ ἂν αὐτὸς ἀποφήνῃ, ὅ τι νομίζεις τὸ δίκαιον εἶναι.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The prosecutor argues that the Athenian jurors did not allow the services Timotheus the son of Conon rendered to the state to outweigh their oaths, and that the jurors should not disregard their oaths in the present case against Demosthenes. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Hesiod
title: Theogony
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a further reference to the gods swearing their great oath by the river Styx. Cf. oath ids 1291 and 1295.

author: Lysias
title: Against Pancleon
if_refused: He could not bring the suit
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The speaker tells the jurors that at the pretrial oath (antomosia) in the dike that Aristodicus initiated against Pancleon, when he was claiming that dikai involving him should not be brought before the court of the Polemarch [on the ground that he was a Plataean and therefore eligible for Athenian citizenship], he was the object of a diamarturia that stated that he was not a Plataean.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes imagines that Aeschines will object that Athens has three hundred triremes and equipment and money for them because of the peace. 
He responds that Philip has also become more prosperous, and more formidable because of the peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would be not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not make an armed attack on one another]
remarks:
This truce was probably of no defined duration and could be terminated by either side on ten days' notice (to run from the date on which the declaration of termination was received by the other side). 
Nicias observes that many of their enemies are kept in restraint by a "ten-day" truce. 
For other references to this truce see oath id 1701.

author: Alcaeus
title: Fragments
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment refers to someone breaking an oath. It is possible that this is another reference to the oath broken by Pittacus, which is the only oath mentioned elsewhere in Alcaeus (see remarks on oath ids 1338 and 1340), but the text is just too fragmentary to tell.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he could not say through what part of the body the mind perceives things such as existence and non-existence, except that he doesn't think there is a special bodily organ (for the perception of mathematical or logical properties) analogous to, say, the eye (which perceives optical properties) or the ear (which perceives acoustic properties)]
 ἡ δὲ δὴ διὰ τίνος δύναμις τό τ’ ἐπὶ πᾶσι κοινὸν καὶ τὸ ἐπὶ τούτοις δηλοῖ σοι, ᾧ τὸ “ἔστιν”ἐπονομάζεις καὶ τὸ “οὐκ ἔστι” καὶ ἃ νυνδὴ ἠρωτῶμεν περὶ αὐτῶν; τούτοις πᾶσι ποῖα ἀποδώσεις ὄργανα δι’ ὧν αἰσθάνεται ἡμῶν τὸ αἰσθανόμενον ἕκαστα;  {ΘΕΑΙ.} Οὐσίαν λέγεις καὶ τὸ μὴ εἶναι, καὶ ὁμοιότητα καὶ ἀνομοιότητα, καὶ τὸ ταὐτόν τε καὶ [τὸ] ἕτερον, ἔτι δὲ ἕν τε καὶ τὸν ἄλλον ἀριθμὸν περὶ αὐτῶν. δῆλον δὲ ὅτι καὶ ἄρτιόν τε καὶ περιττὸν ἐρωτᾷς, καὶ τἆλλα ὅσα τούτοις ἕπεται, διὰ τίνος ποτὲ τῶν τοῦ σώματος τῇ ψυχῇ αἰσθανόμεθα. {ΣΩ.} Ὑπέρευ, ὦ Θεαίτητε, ἀκολουθεῖς, καὶ ἔστιν ἃ ἐρωτῶ αὐτὰ ταῦτα. {ΘΕΑΙ.} Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔγωγε οὐκ ἂν ἔχοιμι εἰπεῖν, πλήν γ’ ὅτι μοι δοκεῖ τὴν ἀρχὴν οὐδ’ εἶναι τοιοῦτον οὐδὲν τούτοις ὄργανον ἴδιον ὥσπερ ἐκείνοις

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Macartatus
if_taken: They can assess the qualifications of new members
if_refused: They cannot assess the qualifications of new members
statement: [That they would accept as members of the phratry only legitimate sons of members of the phratry]
remarks: Sositheus tells the jurors that when he introduced his son Eubulides to the members of Hagnias' phratry, Macartatus did not challenge the introduction in the proper ritual way, but instead expected the phratry-members would rule that he was not legitimate in violation of their oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That he will take away an informer and pack him up like a piece of pottery]
 Ἐγᾦδα τοίνυν· συκοφάντην ἔξαγε,
  ὥσπερ κέραμον ἐνδησάμενος. 
 {ΘΗ.}  Νεὶ τὼ σιώ
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 905, the invocation of the "twin gods" coming from Theban lips suggests Amphion and Zethus who built the walls of Thebes (rather than Castor and Pollux, the twin gods of Spartans).

author: Demosthenes
title: On Halonnesus
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Hegesippus claims that although peace had been made the Athenians have still not received the benefits promised to them by Philip before it was made. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
if_taken: They would be allowed into the Peloponnesian League
if_refused: They would not be allowed into the Peloponnesian League
impact: The Eleusinians paid tribute to the league in the same way as the rest of the Athenians
statement: [To have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and to follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks: The oath statement is not specified, but see oath id 1595 for further information.

author: Aristotle
title: Aporemata Homerica
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Helios; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Here Aristotle once again brings up the oath of Iliad 3 and 4 (cf. oath ids 1999 and 2002). He discusses the issue of Helios being "All-seeing and All-hearing" as he is invoked by Agamemnon in this oath. The question is: if the Sun sees and hears everything, why does Odysseus have to tell him that the men have stolen his cattle in the Odyssey. The following solutions are offered: the Sun sees everything but not at the same time; Lampetia who gave the information is his vision; or that it was appropriate for Agamemnon to say as he does, when formulating the oath in the duel episode, “Sun who seest all and hearest all”, and also appropriate for Odysseus to speak as he does to his companions; for the Sun does not, after all, see the things in Hades. This again is a very poor argument, since the event reported to Helios by Lampetia occurred on earth, not in Hades!  A better answer, which appears not to have occurred to Aristotle (or even to Aristarchus, a century and a half later), would have been that from the fact that a messenger reports an event to you, it does not necessarily follow that but for the report you wouldn’t have known about the event; and/or that Lampetia’s report gives Helios an additional cause for complaining to Zeus – namely that his daughter (cf. Odyssey 12.131-6) is distressed.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: None- no report of the proposed alliance being accepted
statement: [That they would fight with each other against the Medes and the Persians]
remarks: Croesus, after compelling almost all the Greeks in Asia Minor to fight with him and the allies against the Medes and the Persians, even goes so far as to send envoys to Sparta to try to negotiate an alliance with them. Compare Herodotus 1.69ff.  According to Hdt. the alliance was made, and Croesus instructed the Spartans to send a force to Sardis by a specified date for a campaign against the Persians (1.77).  But before the appointed day came, Sardis itself was under siege, and Croesus sent a second, urgent request (1.82).  The Spartans took immediate steps to comply, but when they had already finished their preparations news arrived that Sardis had been captured and Croesus taken prisoner (1.83).  In Xenophon, where the story is being told from Cyrus’ point of view, it is not surprising that nothing is said about whether the alliance was actually made or not, since in any case it had no effect on the course of the war. On the other hand, Xen. might be only too pleased to avoid having to present his hero and his beloved Sparta as enemies even in name.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the Corinthian woman is of a noble line]
  Χαἵα ναὶ τὼ σιώ, 
  Κορινθία δ’ αὖ.
remarks: Cf. oath id 1216 with cross references for other invocations of the Dioscuri in this play.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Astyphilus
statement: [That he is telling the truth i.e. that the will was deposited with him]
remarks:
The speaker states that Hierocles has made a bargain with Cleon to divide up Astyphilus' property, and will demand to be believed on the ground that he is speaking the truth. 
The speaker goes on to say that he believes that Hierocles would be pleased to swear to it if someone were to propose an oath to him.

author: Euripides
title: Helena
impact: Menelaus is satisfied that no other man shall have his wife
statement:
[That if their plan fails and Menelaus is killed, she will never accept another husband (i.e. Theoclymenus) but will kill herself with the same sword]
 Ελ. ἀλλ’ ἁγνὸν ὅρκον σὸν κάρα κατώμοσα ... 
Με. τί φήις; θανεῖσθαι; κοὔποτ’ ἀλλάξεις λέχη;
Ελ. ταὐτῶι ξίφει γε· κείσομαι δὲ σοῦ πέλας.
Με. ἐπὶ τοῖσδε τοίνυν δεξιᾶς ἐμῆς θίγε.
Ελ. ψαύω, θανόντος σοῦ τόδ’ ἐκλείψειν φάος.
remarks: As with the previous oath in this play (348), this oath is also conditional. It states what is to happen should Helen fail to persuade Theonoe to help them escape. In fact Theonoe will be persuaded and the fulfillment of the oath will not be required. See id 162 for Menelaus' reciprocal oath. It is noteworthy that Helen swears by Menelaus' head. Divinities swear by Zeus' head (cf. oath ids 409, 1334, 1358, 1363), but this is the only example of an oath by a mortal's head.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
Diodorus tells the jurors that the phrase "I will not imprison any Athenian citizen" is a phrase in the "written oath" taken by the bouleutai to prevent rhetores in the boule caballing to imprison any citizen. 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
impact: Echemus, King of Tegea, slew Hyllus in battle
statement:
[That if Hyllus should defeat the Peloponnesian champion, the Heraclidae should return to the land of the their fathers, but if he were defeated, the Heraclidae should go back and lead their army away and not seek to return for one hundred years]
 ἢν μὲν Ὕλλος νικήσῃ τὸν Πελοποννησίων ἡγεμόνα, κατιέναι Ἡρακλείδας ἐπὶ τὰ πατρώια, ἢν δὲ νικηθῇ, τὰ ἔμπαλιν Ἡρακλείδας ἀπαλλάσσεσθαι καὶ ἀπάγειν τὴν στρατιὴν ἑκατόν τε ἐτέων μὴ ζητῆσαι κάτοδον ἐς Πελοπόννησον
remarks: According to Herodotus, when a dispute arose between the Tegeates and the Athenians regarding who should hold the opposite wing to that held by the Spartans, the Tegeates cited this precedent to justify their claim to hold the wing.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Zenothemis
statement:
[That he will tell the truth]
 καὶ πάντας ὑμῖν ὄμνυμι τοὺς θεοὺς ἦ μὴν ἐρεῖν τἀληθῆ
remarks:
Demon claims that Zenothemis will blame Demosthenes for the prosecution and say that he is relying on the fact that Demosthenes being an orator and a well-known man makes his case more plausible.  
Demon admits that Demosthenes is his kinsman, but swears that he will tell the jurors the truth - namely that when he asked Demosthenes to help him, Demosthenes agreed to do so because it would be disgraceful to refuse, but warned him that since he began to speak on public affairs he has never intervened in a private case. The text breaks off at this point, but D.M. MacDowell, Demosthenes Speeches 27-38 (Austin 2004), p94 n28, suggests that "Demosthenes may have gone on to suggest that calling on a leading orator to oppose an insignificant foreigner might appear oppressive and prejudice the jury against Demon".

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: Penelope doesn't know that Telemachus is leaving and therefore does not try to stop him
statement:
[That she will not tell Penelope that Telemachus is leaving for eleven or twelve days or until she misses him] 
 ἀλλ’ ὄμοσον μὴ μητρὶ φίλῃ τάδε μυθήσασθαι, 
πρίν γ’ ὅτ’ ἂν ἑνδεκάτη τε δυωδεκάτη τε γένηται, 
ἢ αὐτὴν ποθέσαι καὶ ἀφορμηθέντος ἀκοῦσαι,  
ὡς ἂν μὴ κλαίουσα κατὰ χρόα καλὸν ἰάπτῃ.” 
  ὣς ἄρ’ ἔφη, γρηῢς δὲ θεῶν μέγαν ὅρκον ἀπώμνυ. 
αὐτὰρ ἐπεί ῥ’ ὄμοσέν τε τελεύτησέν τε τὸν ὅρκον, 
αὐτίκ’ ἔπειτά οἱ οἶνον ἐν ἀμφιφορεῦσιν ἄφυσσεν,
ἐν δέ οἱ ἄλφιτα χεῦεν ἐϋρραφέεσσι δοροῖσι·
remarks: When Penelope realizes that Telemachus has gone, Eurycleia reveals to her that she had taken this oath. See oath id 533. It is interesting to note that Odysseus, when discovered by Eurycleia in book 19, does not request any oath of silence from her.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
impact: Emphasises the conviction of his statement
statement:
[That Socrates does not acknowledge that the sun and moon are gods]
 οὐδὲ ἥλιον οὐδὲ σελήνην ἄρα νομίζω θεοὺς εἶναι, ὥσπερ οἱ ἄλλοι ἄνθρωποι;  Μὰ Δί’, ὦ ἄνδρες δικασταί
remarks: Meletus supports his statement by saying that Socrates calls the sun a stone and says that the moon is made of earth.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That the fact that in some households slaves are chained but nonetheless run away repeatedly while in others they are unchained and want to stay and work is a fact about household management that is worth examining]
 Τί οὖν, ἄν σοι, ἔφη, καὶ οἰκέτας αὖ ἐπιδεικνύω ἔνθα μὲν 
πάντας ὡς εἰπεῖν δεδεμένους, καὶ τούτους θαμινὰ ἀποδιδρά- 
σκοντας, ἔνθα δὲ λελυμένους καὶ ἐθέλοντάς τε ἐργάζεσθαι 
καὶ παραμένειν, οὐ καὶ τοῦτό σοι δόξω ἀξιοθέατον τῆς
οἰκονομίας ἔργον ἐπιδεικνύναι; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κριτόβουλος, καὶ σφόδρα γε

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That people always say that wealth is the most cowardly thing]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἀλλὰ καὶ λέγουσι πάντες ὡς 
  δειλότατόν ἐσθ’ ὁ πλοῦτος.
remarks: This is a reference to the proverb that rich men were cowards; see further Sommerstein ad 203.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Callias will always win the approval of the people]
 Οὐκοῦν σύ με, ὦ Σώκρατες, μαστροπεύσεις πρὸς τὴν πόλιν, ὅπως πράττω τὰ πολιτικὰ καὶ ἀεὶ ἀρεστὸς ὦ αὐτῇ; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ἂν ὁρῶσί γέ σε μὴ τῷ δοκεῖν ἀλλὰ τῷ ὄντι ἀρετῆς ἐπιμελούμενον.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Hyperbolos has gained much by crime - but not a knife!]
  Ὑπέρβολος δ’ οὑκ τῶν λύχνων πλεῖν ἢ τάλαντα πολλὰ 
 εἴληφε διὰ πονηρίαν, ἀλλ’ οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐ μάχαιραν
remarks: The Worse Argument is ridiculing his opponent's claim that virtue (sophrosyne) can be shown to be beneficial to its possessor because Peleus, thanks to his virtue, had been given a knife by the gods when in peril from wild beasts.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he does not know how much Cyaxares has in the way of funds]
 Τί δέ, ἔφη, οἶσθα ὁπόσα αὐτῷ ἔστι; Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, οὐ μὲν δή.
remarks: Cambyses is trying to make the point that Cyrus is trusting in Cyaxares' funds without any knowledge of circumstances.

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that if anyone in the colonies plotting against Thasos reveals the plot  he will receive a reward of 200 staters, "and there is to be no sworn denunciation against him".

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by the alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Spartans were at war with the Eleans in 399 because they had made an alliance with the Athenians, Argives and Mantineans. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251. 
Xenophon observes that the Spartans were also at war with Elis because they had been barred from both the equestrian and athletic events at the Olympic games.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That they believe in the existence of absolute equality as an entity distinct from the equality of any two particular objects]
  φαμέν πού τι εἶναι ἴσον, οὐ ξύλον λέγω ξύλῳ οὐδὲ λίθον λίθῳ οὐδ’ ἄλλο τῶν τοιούτων οὐδέν, ἀλλὰ παρὰ ταῦτα πάντα ἕτερόν τι, αὐτὸ τὸ ἴσον· φῶμέν τι εἶναι ἢ μηδέν; Φῶμεν μέντοι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σιμμίας, θαυμαστῶς γε.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
statement: [That Diondas' friends are in agreement with his activities] ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία  οἱ οἰκεῖοι  ὁμογνώμονες  αὐτῷ εἰσὶν  οἷς πράττει
remarks: Hypereides has asked the jury whether Diondas' accusations have ever been taken seriously in the past, and has pointed out that, on the contrary, he has regularly been shown up in court as a sykophant.  He now imagines an objector drawing attention to the views of Diondas' friends; he replies that at least one of them (not named) says openly that he is opposed to Diondas' activities and that Diondas will not listen to his advice.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he should not be put to death for having given equal speaking parts to women, slaves, etc.]
 ἀλλ’ ἔλεγεν ἡ γυνή τέ μοι χὠ δοῦλος οὐδὲν ἧττον, 
χὠ δεσπότης χἠ παρθένος χἠ γραῦς ἄν.  
ΑΙ.  Εἶτα δῆτα 
οὐκ ἀποθανεῖν σε ταῦτ’ ἐχρῆν τολμῶντα;
ΕΥ.  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω·
remarks: Aeschylus speaks here as a champion of traditional values, though he himself had very significant speaking parts for female characters, see Sommerstein ad 951.

author: Plato
title: Ion
statement:
[That Homer deals with the typical subjects of poetry in a better way than other poets]
 Ὅμηρος δὲ ἄμεινον;  {ΙΩΝ.} Ἄμεινον μέντοι νὴ Δία.

author: Theophilus
title: Boiotia
statement:
[That not even Autocles would have used his right hand so elegantly (in mixing a cup of wine?)]
τετρακότυλον δὲ κύλικα κεραμεᾶν τινα
τῶν Θηρικλείων, πῶς δοκεῖς; κεραννύει 
καλῶς, ἀφρῷ ζέουσαν· οὐδ’ ἂν Αὐτοκλῆς
οὕτως μὰ τὴν γῆν εὐρύθμως τῇ δεξιᾷ 
ἄρας ἐνώμα.
remarks: Autocles is no doubt the man mentioned in Timocles fr. 19 as “a lover of the aulos”, i.e. of symposia.

author: Anonymus Oxyrhynchicus
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Mysians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That he would not order the Spartans to molest the Mysians while they collected their dead]
remarks:
After their ambush failed, the Mysians sent heralds to Agesilaus and collected their dead under a truce. 
See also oath id 3311.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes claims, that after the embassy had returned from Philip's court, Aeschines addressed the ecclesia and reported that he heard some of the Euboeans saying, "We're well aware, ambassadors, of the terms on which you've made the peace with Philip, and we know that you've given Amphipolis to him, while Philip will hand over Euboea to you". 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: On overthrowing democracy
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker again urges the jurors to abide by their "oaths and agreements" i.e. the oaths of reconciliation. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That they would never return to Phocaea before the lump of iron should appear again]
 ὤμοσαν μὴ πρὶν ἐς Φώκαιαν ἥξειν πρὶν ἢ τὸν μύδρον τοῦτον ἀναφανῆναι
remarks:
Herodotus states that the Phocaeans resolved to leave their homeland and never return. They threw a lump of iron in the sea, and swore that they would never return to Phocaea until the lump should appear again.  
Herodotus observes that as they were preparing to sail away, more than half of the citizens were taken with a longing and sorrow for their homeland, and sailed back to Phocaea, thus breaking their oaths (ψευδόρκιοι δὲ γενόμενοι).  
Herodotus also notes that those who kept their oaths (Οἳ δὲ αὐτῶν τὸ ὅρκιον ἐφύλασσον) sailed away.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement: n/a
remarks: In the context of the decline of moral standards after the death of Cyrus, Xenophon here explains that in early times, Persian kings and their officers were true to their oaths and pledges, even when dealing with the worst offenders. A contrast is drawn with Rheomithres who violated great oaths- see oath id 2504.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is improbable that the seed of those who are not in their prime will be of good quality]
 Τὰ τῶν μὴ ἀκμαζόντων ἄρα οὐ σπουδαῖα; Οὐκ εἰκὸς μὰ Δί’, ἔφη.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That even if they have shelter for themselves in the winter, they will have none for their horses or their attendants or for the mass of their troops]
 προσέρχεται μὲν γὰρ δήπου χειμών, στέγαι δὲ εἰ καὶ ἡμῖν αὐτοῖς εἰσιν, ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ οὐχ ἵπποις οὐδὲ θεράπουσιν οὐδὲ τῷ δήμῳ τῶν στρατιωτῶν, ὧν ἄνευ ἡμεῖς οὐκ ἂν δυναίμεθα στρατεύεσθαι·

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
Xenophon names the Eleans, their dependencies (the Triphylians, Acrorians and Lasionians), and their former dependencies (the Marganians, Letrinians and Amphidolians) as allies of Sparta at the battle of Nemea in 394. 
See also oath id 1915.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would defend each other in the event of their being wronged by their enemies, but that the Camarinaeans would receive the Athenians only if they put in with a single ship, unless they themselves sent for more]
remarks:
Hermocrates of Syracuse tells the Camarinaeans that they made their alliance with Athens "in the event of your enemies attacking you, and you were to aid the Athenians only when they were wronged by others, and not when they are wronging their neighbours as they are now". 
For other references to this alliance and its impact see oath id 1774, 1788, 1789 and 1791.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes opens his speech by observing that many speeches are made in the ecclesia about the wrongs Philip has committed since the conclusion of peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leochares
statement:
[That Leostratus had the right to drive them from the estate of Archiades because he was the father of Leocrates]
 ὅτι νὴ Δία πατὴρ ἦν τοῦ τετελευτηκότος.
remarks: The speaker asks what right Leostratus had to drive them from the estate of Archiades, and imagines that someone will respond in this way.

author: Plato
title: Parmenides
statement:
[That he does not think it will be easy to determine how other things are going to partake of the forms, if they can partake of them neither in part nor as wholes]
 Τίνα οὖν τρόπον, εἰπεῖν, ὦ Σώκρατες, τῶν εἰδῶν σοι τὰ ἄλλα μεταλήψεται, μήτε κατὰ μέρη μήτε κατὰ ὅλα μεταλαμβάνειν δυνάμενα; Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, φάναι, οὔ μοι δοκεῖ εὔκολον εἶναι τὸ τοιοῦτον οὐδαμῶς διορίσασθαι.

author: Xenophon
title: Poroi
statement: [? That they would recognise the autonomy of their former allies]
remarks:
Xenophon writes, "if you think that the burdens imposed during the war just now (i.e. the Social War) make it impossible for you to contribute anything at all, then keep down the cost of administration during the next year to the amount that taxes yielded before the peace (i.e. the peace at the end of the Social War)". 
The exact details of the peace treaty are uncertain. Diodorus 16.22 indicates that the Athenians were forced to make peace after the Persian King threatened to wage war on the Athenians with three hundred warships. He notes that the Athenians had little difficulty concluding a peace because their former allies also desired peace.  
Most modern scholars argue that the Athenians swore to recognise the autonomy of their former allies (see Dem. 15.26).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement: [That Wealth is in his house]
remarks: See also oath id 874.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Athenians; Representatives of some of the Etruscans; Representatives
swearee: Athenians; Representatives of some of the Etruscans; Representatives
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes some Tyrrhenians i.e. Etruscans as allies.

title: SEG
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 32.65. The linguistic marker is entirely restored. These sumbolai between Athens and an unknown Cretan state are on terms similar to those from an earlier agreement between Athens and Cnossus.

author: Anonymus Tragicus
title: Fragment 333a
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a reference to 'swift-moving oaths', presumably Oath gods catching up with a perjurer. Compare the 'swift-running Erinys' at A. Septem 791.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That he thinks that it will not escape the notice of the jurors that Timocrates is introducing laws that contradict every statute and even a statute of his own]
 ὃ μὰ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν οὐδ’ ὑμᾶς οἴομαι λανθάνειν

author: Euripides
title: Phoenissae
swearee: Hippomedon; Tydeus; Parthenopaeus; Adrastus; Amphiaraus; Capaneus; People of Cadmus
if_taken: The lives of the soldiers will be spared
if_refused: The lives of the soldiers will not be spared
impact: Duel to the death between Eteocles and Polyneices
statement:
[That they will decide the battle by single combat, with the winner to be sole possessor of Oedipus' wealth and power, thus sparing the lives of their soldiers]
 ῏Ω γῆς ῾Ελλάδος στρατηλάται, 
  Δαναῶν ἀριστῆς, οἵπερ ἤλθετ’ ἐνθάδε,
  Κάδμου τε λαός, μήτε Πολυνείκους χάριν
  ψυχὰς ἀπεμπολᾶτε μήθ’ ἡμῶν ὕπερ.
  ἐγὼ γὰρ αὐτὸς τόνδε κίνδυνον μεθεὶς
  μόνος συνάψω συγγόνωι τὠμῶι μάχην· 
  κἂν μὲν κτάνω τόνδ’, οἶκον οἰκήσω μόνος,
  ἡσσώμενος δὲ τῶιδε παραδώσω μόνωι·
  ὑμεῖς δ’ ἀγῶν’ ἀφέντες, ᾿Αργεῖοι, χθόνα
  νίσεσθε, βίοτον μὴ λιπόντες ἐνθάδε·
  Σπαρτῶν τε λαὸς ἅλις ὃς κεῖται νεκρός. 
  τοσαῦτ’ ἔλεξε. σὸς δὲ Πολυνείκης γόνος 
  ἐκ τάξεων ὤρουσε κἀπήινει λόγους.
  πάντες δ’ ἐπερρόθησαν ᾿Αργεῖοι τάδε
  Κάδμου τε λαὸς ὡς δίκαι’ ἡγούμενοι.ἐπὶ τοῖσδε δ’ ἐσπείσαντο κἀν μεταιχμίοις 
  ὅρκους συνῆψαν ἐμμενεῖν στρατηλάται.
remarks: Compare the truce oath of Iliad 3.245-301 (see oath id 318), where Menelaus and Paris are to decide the war by single combat.

title: IC IV
if_taken: She will be able to keep the disputed property
if_refused: She will not be able to keep the disputed property
statement: [? That she had not taken property that belonged to her ex-husband]
remarks: The text indicates that in cases where the judge decrees that a divorced woman is to swear an oath of denial she must do so within 20 days. These oaths of denial were required if a woman denied that she had taken property that belonged to her ex-husband. See also oath id 1114.

author: Aeschylus
title: Septem Contra Thebas
statement:
[That he will sack the the city of the Cadmeans in defiance of Zeus]
 ὄμνυσι δ’ αἰχμὴν ἣν ἔχει, μᾶλλον θεοῦ
σέβειν πεποιθὼς ὀμμάτων θ’ ὑπέρτερον, 
ἦ μὴν λαπάξειν ἄστυ Καδμείων βίαι
Διός·
remarks: No person of sound mind could seriously believe in the validity of an oath sworn in defiance of the gods' will. Note also the error of valuing the spear above Zeus, and compare the oath in Euripides 'Supplices' sworn by Capaneus at id 139. It seems that Aeschylus is playing on the fact that an inanimate Eideshort (like Achilles' sceptre) can fill exactly the same syntactic role in the formulation of an oath that a god can.

author: Dionysius
title: Thesmophoros
statement:
[That Simias has gratified the swearer very much by his words]
 σφόδρα μοι κεχάρισαι, Σιμία, νὴ τοὺς θεούς,
ταυτὶ προείπας·
remarks: The rest of the fragment makes it fairly evident that Simias wants to learn to be a cook, and the speaker’s first few lines make most sense if Simias has said that cookery seems to him to be a very difficult art to master.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The text records the alliance between Athens and the Neapolitans in Thrace. 
The relief of this inscription shows Athena clasping the hand of another goddess.  
Line 9 refers to the things which the envoys from the Neapolitans have reported to the Athenians.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That the way the plot was being carpentered had not escaped his notice]
  Ταυτὶ μὰ τὴν Δήμητρά μ’ οὐκ ἐλάνθανεν 
  τεκταινόμενα τὰ πράγματ’

author: Plato
title: Apologia
statement:
[That Socrates does not acknowledge the existence of any gods at all]
 οὐδένα νομίζω θεὸν εἶναι; Οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία οὐδ’ ὁπωστιοῦν.
remarks: Meletus certainly believes his statement to be true.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that Dercylidas sent to the cities of Aeolis and requested that they free themselves, admit him inside their walls, and become his allies. 
Those in Neandria, Ilium and Cocylium obeyed. The citizens of Cebren also later complied.

title: CID I
statement:
[That they would - - - - - not delete the things written except according to orders from the hieromnemones - - - - - and not ever receive gifts from trials]
 [- - - - - τῶγ γεγραμμενένων μὴ ἀπογραψ[ε̃]ν ἄλ̣λ̣[ο] ἢ̣ κατὰ τοὶ ἱερομνάμ̣[ο]ν̣ες κε[λευσέοντι - - - - -] κ̣[α]τ̣ὰν δ[ί]κ̣αν μηδὲ δῶρα δεξε̣ῖ̣σ̣θαι μηδέπο̣κ̣α̣· οὕτω̣ς ὑπίσχ[ο]μα̣[ι ποὶ το̃ Ἀπόλλωνος το̃ Πυθίο καὶ τᾶς Λα]το̣̃ς καὶ τᾶς Ἀρτάμιτος καὶ εὐ̣[ορ]κέοντι μέμ μ[ο]ι πολλὰ καὶ ἀγαθά̣, [αἰ δ’ ἐφιορκέοιμι - - - - - · το̃ς δὲ ἱερομνάμονας ὁρκιξέω καὶ τ̣ὸς κ̣άρυκ̣ας τὸν αὐτὸν ὅρκον [- - - - -]
remarks:
This text was previously published as IG II(2) 1126. 
The statement of the secretary(?) is very fragmentary. 
 For the oath sworn by the hieronmenon see oath id 928.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That if she really is adored by Socrates and his companions, then she ought to be grateful to them for looking on her beauty]
 ἐκ δὲ τούτων εἰκὸς ἡμᾶς μὲν θεραπεύειν, ταύτην δὲ θεραπεύεσθαι. καὶ ἡ Θεοδότη, Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, εἰ τοίνυν ταῦθ’ οὕτως ἔχει, ἐμὲ ἂν δέοι ὑμῖν τῆς θέας χάριν ἔχειν.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
if_taken: He will not have to give evidence
if_refused: He will have to give evidence
statement: [? That he did not know that Timarchus had left his father's house to live a dissolute life with him]
remarks:
Aeschines states that he will summon Misgolas to testify to the truth i.e. that Timarchus left his father's house to live a dissolute life with him. He alleges that Misgolas will answer the summons, but resort to the most shameless course - to deny the truth under oath as a favour to Timarchus (i.e. the exomosia when called to give evidence). 
Aeschines says that his denial will be for nothing, for he will provide other witnesses.  (These witnesses, however, can probably say no more than that Timarchus lived in Misgolas' house, not what was the nature of the relationship between them.)

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
statement: n/a
remarks: Here oaths are referred to in a list as one of the five kinds of "artless" proof in forensic oratory. This is a reference to oath challenges. For detailed discussion of this use of oaths, see oath id 1730.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and household
statement: [? That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
Theomnestus states that Stephanus swore that Apollodorus had killed a runaway slave with his own hand, thus affirming matters which had never taken place, and which he had never seen or heard from any human being. 
Theomnestus goes on to state that Stephanus was proved to have committed perjury and brought forward a false accusation. Stephanus secured only a few votes, and left the court a perjured man with the reputation of a scoundrel.

author: Lysias
title: Against Andocides
swearer: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker states that the greatest criminal (apart from Andocides) was Batrachus, who became an informer under the Thirty, "and even though the agreements and oaths applied to him just as to those from Eleusis, he was afraid of you - whom he wronged - and went to live in another city". The "agreements and oaths" referred to here are those of the reconciliation in 403/2. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that when Cleon was campaigning in the north he sent envoys to Perdiccas requesting him to come with an army "in accordance with the terms of the alliance". 
Thucydides had earlier described how Perdiccas sent a herald to the Athenian generals and made an agreement with them, but it is not until this reference that Thucydides actually states that an alliance was made.  
For other references to alliances between Athens and Perdiccas see oath id 256.  
See also oath id 1545 and 1751.

author: Archilochus
title: Fragments
statement: unknown
remarks: This reference to someone who was swearing an oath was written in the margin of a fragment which is now lost. It is either a gloss or a variant of the original text.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that after Philip had sworn to the peace, his fellow ambassadors were bribed by Philip to postpone their departure from Macedon until his preparations for the campaign against Phocis were well advanced. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

title: Rhodes and Osborne, GHI
swearee: Other members of the sworn band
if_taken: He could be part of a sworn band
if_refused: He could not be part of a sworn band
statement: [? That he would fight while he was alive, and would not regard being alive as more important than being free; that he would not leave his taxiarch or his enomotarch, whether he was alive or dead, and that he would bury the dead among his fellow-fighters, and that he would leave no-one unburied]
remarks:
The oath sworn before the battle at Plataea includes a promise that the hoplites would not desert the enomotarch (the commander of the Spartan unit known as a 'sworn band'). 
See also oath id 1272.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That he will not stand up and advise the Athenians when they are deliberating about how to spell]
 Πότερον οὖν, ὅταν περὶ γραμμάτων Ἀθηναῖοι βουλεύωνται, πῶς ἂν ὀρθῶς γράφοιεν, τότε ἀναστήσῃ αὐτοῖς συμβουλεύσων;  {ΑΛ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he earnestly requests that Tereus comply with the chorus's wishes]
 τὴν δ’ ἡδυμελῆ ξύμφωνον ἀηδόνα Μούσαις 
 κατάλειφ’ ἡμῖν δεῦρ’ ἐκβιβάσας, ἵνα παίσωμεν μετ’ ἐκείνης. 
{ΠΕ.} Ὢ τοῦτο μέντοι νὴ Δί’ αὐτοῖσιν πιθοῦ
remarks: "Do what they ask" is equivalent to "I request that you do what they ask", and this is the "statement" of the oath here.

author: Antiphanes
title: Kleophanes
impact: Emphasises the insult to the sophists
statement:
[That the sophists are thin, feeble and starving]  
 τὸν σπουδαῖον ἀκολουθεῖν ἐρεῖς
ἐν τῷ Λυκείῳ μετὰ σοφιστῶν, νὴ Δία, 
λεπτῶν, ἀσίτων, συκίνων
remarks: The speaker is probably an old man, the addressee a young man.

author: Plato
title: Critias
if_taken: They will prove themselves worthy rulers
if_refused: They will be unworthy to rule
if_broken: Grievous curses will be called down on the disobedient
impact: They will rule according to the laws
statement: [That they will give judgement according to the laws inscribed on the column, punish any who had theretofore or would thereafter transgress the laws, and that they would transgress none of the laws wittingly, neither giving nor obeying commandment except according to the laws of their father]
remarks: The inscribed 'oath' referred to here mentions only the curses, not the actual promise made, with the oath itself apparently presented as the curse for oath-breakers, an interesting reminder of the oath's primal function as a curse. The implication is that the laws and oath/curse inscribed on the column represent the oath which was originally sworn by the earliest kings (cf. 119c) and is reportedly taken by the new kings at alternate intervals of four and five years (119d), here paraphrased in the oath statement. See further oath id 3201. No god is specified, but the presence of the god Poseidon as sanctifying witness is assured by swearing in his sanctuary.

author: Aeschylus
title: Choephoroi
statement:
[That he pursued his mother's death justly]
 ὡς ἴδηι πατήρ,
οὐχ οὑμός, ἀλλ’ ὁ πάντ’ ἐποπτεύων τάδε 
῞Ηλιος, ἄναγνα μητρὸς ἔργα τῆς ἐμῆς,
ὡς ἂν παρῆι μοι μάρτυς ἐν δίκηι ποτὲ
ὡς τόνδ’ ἐγὼ μετῆλθον ἐνδίκως φόνον
τὸν μητρός· Αἰγίσθου γὰρ οὐ λέγω μόρον·
ἔχει γὰρ αἰσχυντῆρος, ὡς νόμος, δίκην.
remarks: The final play of the trilogy will show that Orestes' murder of his mother was not the simple righteous act he claims here. However, it is clear that he sincerely believes it to be justified, as does Apollo.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack the Spartans while they collected their dead]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Spartans were defeated fighting the Arcadians on the road that leads to Cromnus. 
After they retreated from the field of battle some of the older Arcadians proposed a truce. 
The Spartans collected their dead and the Arcadians set up a trophy.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of their alliance]
remarks: The deal is: if the Hyrcanians make good their promise to prove that the Assyrian army is within striking distance (by bringing back some hostages), Cyrus will honour them as friends on an equal footing with the Persians and Medians. Cyrus later makes a point of honouring his oaths to the Hyrcanians- see oath id 2412.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That by 'the better' and 'the superior' he very much means 'the wiser']
 οὐκ ἐρεῖς, τοὺς βελτίους καὶ κρείττους πότερον τοὺς φρονιμωτέρους λέγεις ἢ ἄλλους τινάς;  {ΚΑΛ.} Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δία τούτους λέγω, καὶ σφόδρα γε.

title: IC IV
if_taken: She will be able to keep the disputed property
if_refused: She will not be able to keep the disputed property
statement: [That she had not taken property that did not rightfully belong to her]
remarks: The text indicates that if the woman denies that she has taken property that belongs to her ex-husband, the judge shall decree that she swear an oath of denial. If her ex-husband takes back anything from her after she has sworn her oath of denial, he is to return the property and pay her five staters. For another oath relating to this judicial procedure see oath id 1115. An amendment to this procedure is made in Col XI, lines 46-50. See oath id 1143.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
statement:
[That Medea will not leave her children for her enemies to treat shamefully]  
 μὰ τοὺς παρ’ ῞Αιδηι νερτέρους ἀλάστορας,
  οὔτοι ποτ’ ἔσται τοῦθ’ ὅπως ἐχθροῖς ἐγὼ 
  παῖδας παρήσω τοὺς ἐμοὺς καθυβρίσαι.
gods_invoked: Nether Spirits of VengeanceEpithet(s)who dwell in Hades
remarks: This passage, if genuine, marks the final moment of decision in Medea's plan to kill her children.  It may well, however, not be genuine:  see M.D. Reeve, CQ 22 (1972) 51-61 (accepting Bergk's deletion of 1056-80; Diggle concurs) and D. Kovacs, CQ 36 (1986) 343-352 (deleting 1056-64 only).  The passage is, however, still recorded here, since if not by Euripides it is likely to have been written for a fourth-century production.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 2
statement:
[That Boeotus is a man who loves peace and hates litigation]
 νὴ Δί’, ἀπράγμων γάρ τις ἴσως ἐστὶν ἄνθρωπος καὶ οὐ φιλόδικος.
remarks: Mantitheus wonders why Boeotus has meekly accepted the decision of the arbitrator in his suit against Mantitheus, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his comments.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that Perdiccas "had been an ally and friend" of Athens. 
The (disputed) date for this alliance is provided by N.G.L. Hammond and G.T. Griffith, History of Macedonia, Vol II, p122. 
Perdiccas would later break this agreement. For other references to the various alliances between Athens and Perdiccas see oath id 256.  
See also oath id 1545 and 1751.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he does not know the meaning of the last question he himself put]
 Πῶς, ἦ δ’ ὅς, λέγεις;  Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, οὐκ οἶδα
remarks: Cf. oath id 3082.

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: This is a treaty between Sybaris and the Serdaioi.  The text literally reads σύνμαχοι rather than σύμμαχοι.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks: Thucydides states that Peisander visited all the "clubs" (τάς ξυνωμοσίας, lit. "sworn conspiracies") which existed in the city "for the courts and offices" (i.e. for mutual support among their members in elections and lawsuits), and urged them to join together and take common counsel to overthrow the democracy.  This implies that previously, while doubtless hostile to democracy in theory (as the "Old Oligarch" is, or as Alcibiades professed to be at Sparta, Thuc. 6.89), they had not envisaged taking any practical initiative to destroy it.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Emphasises the importance of the issue
statement:
[That they must not in the least pass over discussion of the true nature of virtue]
Ἥκιστα, νὴ τὸν ξένιον, ὦ ξένε, θεόν, ἐατέον που τὸ τοιοῦτον, ἐπεὶ δοκεῖς ἡμῖν ὀρθότατα λέγειν

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he will not let Paphlagon speak before him]
 Οὐκ αὖ μ’ ἐάσεις; 
  {ΑΛ.}  Μὰ Δία.
remarks: See also oath ids 987, 989, 990.

author: Andocides
title: Against Alcibiades
date: At the time of the speech ca.417-415 (417 to 415)
statement: n/a
remarks: [Andocides] says to the Athenians, "it is typical of Alcibiades to think nothing of laws or oaths himself, and to attempt to teach you to offend against them, and to cause the banishment and death of others unmercifully, but himself to beg and cry piteously".

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: They will not be allowed to choose the judges
if_refused: They will not be allowed to choose the judges
statement:
[That the judges they choose will be the men (one from each group of leaders) whom they deem most likely to decide law suits in the best and holiest way]
 πάσας δὴ τὰς ἀρχάς, ὁπόσαι τε κατ’ ἐνιαυτὸν καὶ ὁπόσαι πλείω χρόνον ἄρχουσιν, ἐπειδὰν μέλλῃ νέος ἐνιαυτὸς μετὰ θερινὰς τροπὰς τῷ ἐπιόντι μηνὶ γίγνεσθαι, ταύτης τῆς ἡμέρας τῇ πρόσθεν πάντας χρὴ τοὺς ἄρχοντας συνελθεῖν εἰς ἓν ἱερὸν καὶ τὸν θεὸν ὀμόσαντας οἷον ἀπάρξασθαι πάσης ἀρχῆς ἕνα δικαστήν, ὃς ἂν ἐν ἀρχῇ ἑκάστῃ ἄριστός τε εἶναι δόξῃ καὶ ἄριστ’ ἂν καὶ ὁσιώτατα τὰς δίκας τοῖς πολίταις αὐτῷ τὸν ἐπιόντα ἐνιαυτὸν φαίνηται διακρίνειν.
remarks: This refers to a generic oath, not a specific one.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
swearee: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
statement: [That they would fight together in attacking the Medes and Persians]
remarks: Apparently the allies were convinced of the need for the alliance by the Assyrian king's suggestions that the Medes and the Persians, who had intermarried, and were powerful nations, would be likely to make war on each of the other nations and subjugate them. Those who were unconvinced by such arguments were apparently bribed to join the alliance. The Hycarnians had not been mentioned as original swearers of the alliance, presumably because they are Assyrian subjects in any case. After the death of the Assyrian King and the panic among the Assyrians and the allies who were now deserting, the Hyrcanians, who had been placed at the rear, a position engineered to protect the Assyrians, but not themselves, decide to court the Persians and seize the opportunity to revolt. They offer to be Cyrus' allies and guides. Cf. oath ids 2326, 2381, 2385 and 2389.

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
statement:
[That Silenus has not dreamt this (i.e. the labours he has had because of Dionysus)]
 φέρ’ ἴδω, τοῦτ’ ἰδὼν ὄναρ λέγω;  οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἐπεὶ καὶ σκῦλ’ ἔδειξα Βακχίωι.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That it was fated that the sheep-monger should fall before a leather-monger]
 Τὸν προβατοπώλην ἦν ἄρ’ ἀπολέσθαι χρεὼν 
  ὑπὸ βυρσοπώλου; 
  {ΔΗ. }  Νὴ Δί’.
remarks: The leather-monger referred to is Paphlagon, but the oracle being read out here also suggests his fall (140).

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Cytherans departed and Pharnabazus placed a garrison on the island
statement: [? That they would not molest the Cytherans as they left the island]
remarks:
Xenophon states that when Pharnabazus besieged the island of Cythera, the people there abandoned their walls out of fear that their city would be captured by storm. 
Pharnabazus allowed the Cytherans to depart to Laconia under a truce and then placed a garrison on the island.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Phaenippus
if_taken: He will be able to proceed with the antidosis
if_refused: He will not be able to proceed with the antidosis
statement:
[That he will give a true and honest inventory of his property, except that in the silver mines, all of which the laws have made exempt from taxes]
 ἀποφαίνω τὴν οὐσίαν τὴν ἐμαυτοῦ ὀρθῶς καὶ δικαίως, πλὴν τῶν ἐν τοῖς ἔργοις τοῖς ἀργυρείοις, ὅσα οἱ νόμοι ἀτελῆ πεποιήκασι
remarks: The speaker states that Phaenippus has brought a counter-charge against him, alleging that he is not rendering a just inventory of his property on the grounds that he is not declaring his mining leases. The speaker cites the law regarding this (which stipulates that mining leases are exempt), and observes - with heavy irony - that Phaenippus is complaining about the fact that he is swearing according to the law.

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
if_kept: An abundance of good things to him and his descendants
