if_broken: He shall melt away and dissolve, as will his descendants and property
statement:
[The sworn statement of colonists: Resolved by the assembly. Since Apollo spontaneously told Battus and the Therans to colonise Cyrene, it has been decided by the Therans to send Battus off to Libya, as Archagetes and as King, with the Therans to sail as his hetairoi. On equal and fair terms they shall sail according to family (?), with one son to be conscripted [- - -] adults and from the other Therans those who are free-born [- - -] shall sail. If they establish the settlement, kinsmen who sail later to Libya shall be entitled to citizenship and offices and shall be allotted portions of the land which has no owner. But if they do not successfully establish the settlement and the Therans are incapable of giving it assistance, and they are pressed by hardship for five years, from that land shall they depart, without fear, to Thera, to their own property, and they shall be citizens. Any man who, if the city send him, refuses to sail, will be liable to the death-penalty and his property shall be confiscated. The man harbouring him or concealing him, whether he be a father (aiding his) son, or a brother his brother, is to suffer the same penalty as the man who refuses to sail. On these conditions a sworn agreement was made by those who stayed there and by those who sailed to found the colony, and they invoked curses against those transgressors who would not abide by it, whether they were those settling in Libya or those who remained. They made waxen images and burnt them, calling down the following curse, everyone having assembled together, men, women, boys, girls: 'The person who does not abide by this sworn agreement but transgresses it shall melt away and dissolve like the images - himself, his descendants and his property; but those who abide by the sworn agreement - those sailing to Libya and those staying in Thera - shall have an abundance of good things, both themselves and their descendants']
 ὅρκιον τῶν οἰκιστήρων· [ἔ]δοξε τᾶι ἐκκλησίαι· ἐπεὶ Ἀπόλλων αὐτομάτιξεν Β[άτ]τωι καὶ Θηραίοις ἀποι[κίξαι] Κυράναν, ὁριστὸν δοκεῖ Θη[ραίο]ις ἀποπέμπεν ἐς τὰν [Λιβ]ύαν Βάττομ μὲν ἀρχαγέτα[ν τ]ε καὶ βασιλῆα, ἑταίρους δὲ τοὺς Θηραίους πλέν· ἐπὶ τᾶι ἴσα[ι κ]αὶ τᾶι ὁμοίαι πλ̣έν κατὰ τὸν ο̣ἶκον, υἱὸν δὲ ἕνα καταλ[έ]γεσθαί ΤΟΣ̣Δ̣ΕΕΛ̣Ο̣ - - - - κ̣α̣ὶ̣ τοὺς ἡβῶντας καὶ τῶν [ἄλλ]ων Θηραίων ἐλευθέρος - - - πλέν. αἰ μὲν δέ κα κατέχ[ων]τι τὰν οἰκισίαν οἱ ἄποικοι, τῶν οἰκείων τὸγ καταπλέον[τα] ὕστερον εἰς Λ̣ιβύ̣αν καὶ πολιτήιας καὶ τιμᾶμ πεδέχ[εν] καὶ γᾶς τᾶς ἀδεσπότω ἀπολαγχάν̣ε̣ν. αἰ μὲν δέ κα μὴ κατ[έχ]ωντι τὰν οἰκισίαν μηδὲ οἱ Θηραῖοί μ̣ιν δυνῶνται ἐπικου̣[ρέ]ν, ἀλλὰ ἀνάγκαι ἀχθῶντι ἔτη ἐπὶ πέντε, ἐκ τᾶς γᾶς ἀτίμ[εν] ἀδιέως Θήρανδε ἐπὶ τὰ αὐτῶγ χρήματα καὶ ἦμεμ πολιάτας· ὁ δέ κα μὴ λῆι πλέν ἀποστελλοίσας τᾶς πόλιος, θανά[σι]μος τένται καὶ τὰ χρήματα ἔστω αὐτοῦ δαμόσια. ὁ δὲ ἀποδεκόμενος ἢ ἀδήιζων ἢ πατὴρ υἱὸν ἢ ἀδελφεὸς ἀδελφεὸν παισεῖται ἅπερ ὁ μὴ λέων πλέν. ἐπὶ τούτοις ὅρκια ἐποιήσατο οἵ τε αὐτεῖ μένοντες καὶ οἱ πλέοντες οἰκίξοντες καὶ ἀρὰς ἐποιήσαντο τὸς ταῦτα παρβεῶντας καὶ μὴ ἐμμένοντας ἢ τῶν ἐλ Λιβύαι οἰκεόντων ἢ τῶν αὐτεῖ μενόντων. κηρίνος πλάσσαντες κολοσὸς κατέκαιον ἐπαρεώμενοι πάντες συνενθόντες καὶ ἄνδρες καὶ γυναῖκες καὶ παῖδες καὶ παιδίσκαι· τὸμ μὴ ἐμμένοντα τούτοις τοῖς ὁρκίοις ἀλλὰ παρβεῶντα καταλείβεσθαί νιν καὶ καταρρὲν ὥσπερ τὸς κολοσός, καὶ αὐτὸν καὶ γόνον καὶ χρήματα, τοῖς δὲ ἐμμένοισιν τούτοις τοῖς ὁρκίοις καὶ τοῖς πλέοισι ἐλ Λιβύαν κ[αὶ] τ[οῖς μέ]νοισι ἐν Θήραι ἦμεν πολλὰ καὶ ἀγαθὰ καὶ αὐ[τοῖς καὶ γό]νοις.
remarks:
This inscription records the oath sworn by Battus and all the Therans sent to colonise Cyrene. The oath was sworn once they had assembled together all the men, women, boys and girls. 
This document from the fourth century indicates that all the Therans living in Cyrene were to renew the oath in order to acquire Theran citizenship.  
See oath id 1052.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he can't tell which of the two is the god]
  ΑΙ. Οὔ τοι μὰ τὴν Δήμητρα δύναμαι ’γὼ μαθεῖν  ὁπότερος ὑμῶν ἐστι θεός.

author: Antiphanes
title: Misoponeros
statement: unknown
remarks: This follows on from the informal oath at id 1400 with reference to foster-mothers.  A lacuna in Athenaeus’ text leaves it unclear what is being said about foster-mothers, but the context suggests very strongly that what is being said about them is that they are even worse than nurses and tutors!    The sequence develops as follows:  There is no worse evil than nurses and tutors … except for foster-mothers, who excel everyone in villainy … except begging priests, who are the filthiest race on earth … except fishmongers, who are the worst of all … except money-changers … . There are four informal oaths in this short fragment.  See oath ids 1400-1403.

author: Eupolis
title: Prospaltioi
statement: unknown
remarks: This passage is too fragmentary to reconstruct the oath statement.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would be an ally of the Athenians and the allies, and would not defect from the Athenians and the allies themselves, nor would they allow another as far as possible. They would make all private and public lawsuits against Athenians subject to appeal in accordance with the agreement, as many as are for more than one hundred drachmas. If anyone dares to wrong those of the Ceans who have returned, or the Athenians or any of the allies, contrary to the oaths and the agreement, they would not allow him by any craft or contrivance, but would go in support with all their strength as far as possible]
remarks:
This inscription refers to an alliance between Athens and the poleis on Ceos. 
The exact statement is unknown. However, it must have been similar to the new agreement sworn by the Ceans in 363/2 (see oath id 424). 
The text of the decree makes it clear that several Iulietans had been convicted of violating their oaths and were condemned to death. They subsequently returned to Ceos and overturned the stelai on which the agreement and the names of those who had violated the oath were written. They went on to attack the so-called friends of the Athenians whom the Athenian demos had reinstalled at Iulis, executing some, condemning others to death, and confiscating the property of other including Satyrides, Timoxenus and Miltiades, all in violation of the oath and agreement. These latter three victims were attacked because they had spoken against a certain Antipater when the Athenian boule had condemned him to death for killing Aeson the Athenian proxenos. The penalty for their crimes was exile from Ceos and Athens and the confiscation of their property. The citizens of Carthaea on Ceos were praised for abiding by their oaths.  
See also oath id 422, 424, 427, 520, 521.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That Paphlagon has never given him any sole from his stock for his shoes]
 σκύτη τοσαῦτα πωλῶν 
  ἔδωκας ἤδη τουτῳὶ κάττυμα παρὰ σεαυτοῦ
  ταῖς ἐμβάσιν φάσκων φιλεῖν;  
 {ΔΗ.}  Οὐ δῆτα μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That those in love with making a profit are not (unlike those who are in love with a person) incapable of being trained to concern themselves with work on the farm (if they are shown that this is profitable)]
 Τί δέ, ἔφην ἐγώ, οἵτινες αὖ ἐρωτικῶς ἔχουσι τοῦ κερδαίνειν, ἦ καὶ οὗτοι ἀδύνατοί εἰσιν εἰς ἐπιμέλειαν τῶν κατ’ ἀγρὸν ἔργων παιδεύεσθαι; Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος, οὐδαμῶς γε, ἀλλὰ καὶ πάνυ εὐάγωγοί εἰσιν εἰς τὴν τούτων ἐπιμέλειαν·

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That people will not sacrifice any more to the other gods (because of Wealth)]
  Μὰ Δί’, οὐδέ γε θύσει·

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he will not let Wealth go]
 Ἄφετόν με νῦν· ἴστον γὰρ ἤδη τἀπ’ ἐμοῦ. 
  {ΧΡ.} Μὰ Δί’,
remarks: Cf. remarks on oath id 853.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That he is not asking Critobulus to break in colts]
 Πωλοδαμνεῖν 
με κελεύεις, ὦ Σώκρατες; Οὐ μὰ Δί’
remarks: Socrates has said that since Critobulus “is forced to deal with horses”, he ought to take some steps to acquire some specialized knowledge of them – and Critobulus misunderstands him to mean that Socrates is suggesting he become a professional horsebreaker (n.b. no trade for a gentleman).

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he is not going to attack every word and expression of Euripides' work individually, but, with the help of the gods, will destroy all his prologues with an oil-flask]
 Καὶ μὴν μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ κατ’ ἔπος γέ σου κνίσω
  τὸ ῥῆμ’ ἕκαστον, ἀλλὰ σὺν τοῖσιν θεοῖς 
 ἀπὸ ληκυθίου σου τοὺς προλόγους διαφθερῶ.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
After the Corinthians accused the Athenians of breaking the treaty (see oath id 1532) they countered that they were not because they had come to the aid of the Corcyraeans who were their allies. 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That they would follow Cleomenes in whatever enterprise he led]
 προσάγων σφι ᾗ μὲν ἕψεσθαί σφεας αὐτῷ τῇ ἂν ἐξηγέηται
remarks:
Cleomenes also tried to make the Arcadians swear by the waters of the Styx.  
See oath id 1495.

author: Euripides
title: Ion
impact: The truth of Ion's parentage is forcefully reasserted
statement:
[That Ion's father is no mortal, but Apollo]
 Κρ. μὰ τὴν παρασπίζουσαν ἅρμασίν ποτε
  Νίκην ᾿Αθάναν Ζηνὶ γηγενεῖς ἔπι,
  οὐκ ἔστιν οὐδείς σοι πατὴρ θνητῶν, τέκνον, 
  ἀλλ’ ὅσπερ ἐξέθρεψε Λοξίας ἄναξ.
remarks: Cf. oath id 155, which also asserts the truth of Ion's parentage.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That abstaining from sex would indeed make peace more likely to happen]
  {ΚΛ.} Εἰ δ’ ὡς μάλιστ’ ἀπεχοίμεθ’ οὗ σὺ δὴ λέγεις, — 
  ὃ μὴ γένοιτο, —μᾶλλον ἂν διὰ τουτογὶ
  γένοιτ’ ἂν εἰρήνη;
 {ΛΥ.}  Πολύ γε νὴ τὼ θεώ.
remarks: On swearing by Persephone and Demeter, see oath id 788.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: He will gain the trust of the Carians
if_refused: He will not gain the trust of the Carians
statement: [That he will enter the walls of the Carians without treachery and for the advantage of those who receive him]
remarks: This is the same oath as id 2464. Here Adusius reminds the Carians of his oath which was 'for the advantage of those who receive him' and urges them to be at peace.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon comments on the military activities of the Athenians in 366 with regard to their alliances with Sparta and the Arcadians. He notes that the Athenians were obliged to send cavalry to aid the Arcadians in case anyone took the field against Arcadia, but that they did not set foot in Laconia for the purpose of war. 
See also oath id 2001.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the Athenians were robbed in making the peace with Philip. He claims that Philip deceived them with regard to Phocis, Thermopylae, Thrace, Doriscus, Serrium and Cersobleptes. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That men drink in the Assembly]
 {Πρ.}  ἰδού γε σοὶ πίνουσι. {Γυ. β} νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν
remarks: Men did not drink in the Assembly (and Praxagora knows it, see her contemptuous retort, 136 init.), but it is evident that the speaker sincerely believes they do; she offers comically persuasive arguments - they adopt crazy policies, ergo they must be drunk; they utter long prayers [before the proceedings begin], therefore there must be libations too (cf. oath id 786); they revile each other, etc.  So this oath is not true, but the speaker is not lying either.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus tells the jurors that when other claimants to the estate of Comon launched suits, he and Olympiodorus took counsel together as they had sworn to do (see oath id 3623), to determine the best way to deal with the other claimants.

author: Isocrates
title: Archidamus
swearee: Ancestors of Archidamus i.e. the Kings
statement:
[That, as long as the kings kept their oath, they would never attack the monarchy nor allow others to do so; and that they would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
 βασιλεῖαι τρεῖς βασιλευομέναις πόλεσιν τριτταῖς ὤμοσαν ἀλλήλαις ἑκάτεραι, κατὰ νόμους οὓς ἔθεντο τοῦ τε ἄρχειν καὶ ἄρχεσθαι κοινούς, οἱ μὲν μὴ βιαιοτέραν τὴν ἀρχὴν ποιήσεσθαι προϊόντος τοῦ χρόνου καὶ γένους, οἱ δέ, ταῦτα ἐμπεδούντων τῶν ἀρχόντων, μήτε αὐτοὶ τὰς βασιλείας ποτὲ καταλύσειν μήτ’ ἐπιτρέψειν ἐπιχειροῦσιν ἑτέροις, βοηθήσειν δὲ βασιλῆς τε βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις καὶ δήμοις, καὶ δῆμοι δήμοις καὶ βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις.
remarks:
Archidamus tells the men of Sparta that until the present day they have remained faithful to the agreements and oaths made with his forefathers. 
See also oath id 2679.

author: Antiphon (soph.)
title: fr. 44a (Pendrick)
statement: n/a
remarks: Here various instances of things called 'hostile to nature' are considered, meaning that they represent more suffering and less pleasure than is possible. One such instance is specified as those who tender an oath to others (the assumption must be that the opponent will be able to swear it) but do not swear one themselves. Such a person would be putting himself at a considerable disadvantage to his opponent. See also Aristotle's discussion of oath-challenge tactics in court (oath id 1730).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes denounces Aeschines for supporting Philocrates, whom he describes as "the man who made the proposal for payment", and claims that after Aeschines was elected to administer the oaths, he neglected all the instructions of the demos, destroyed the allies, and told more and bigger lies than anyone before or since. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
impact: Emphasises the difficulty of the inquiry
statement:
[That he thinks it is no easy thing to discover why Hestia was so named]
 Τί οὖν ἄν τις φαίη διανοούμενον τὸν ὀνομάσαντα Ἑστίαν ὀνομάσαι; {ΕΡΜ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία οὐδὲ τοῦτο οἶμαι ῥᾴδιον εἶναι.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Coloneus
impact: Provokes the Chorus to inquire further
statement:
[That he endured the worst things willingly but not by choice]
 Οι. ἤνεγκον κακότατ’, ὦ ξένοι, ἤνεγκον ἑκὼν μέν, θεὸς ἴστω· 
τούτων δ’ αὐθαίρετον οὐδέν.
remarks: The meaning of this paradoxical statement appears to be that Oedipus willingly endured the horror of being the husband of his mother and the killer of his father (i.e. he did not commit suicide on discovering the truth - cf. OT 1367ff.) but he did not commit either of these crimes by choice (because in each case, as he says at 525-6 and 548, he did not know that the other person was his parent).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Navy-Boards
statement:
[That he does not want or expect the Persian King to get the impression that the Greeks are in distress, alarm or confusion (but only that they are not willing to break a treaty to which they have sworn)]
 μὴ μὰ Δί’ ὡς ἀποροῦσιν ἢ φοβοῦνται ἢ θορυβοῦνται πάντες {οἱ Ἕλληνες καὶ Ἀθηναῖοι}, πολλοῦ γε καὶ δεῖ·
remarks:
Demosthenes urges the Athenians not to send a summons to the Greeks which they will not obey and not to declare a war they cannot wage. 
See also oath id 3299.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The prosecutor alleges that Demosthenes has claimed as his own sons who had never been born (or who had not been born to him), in violation of the laws which govern oaths in court. 
This presumably refers to the common practice (see e.g. oath id 3674) of a speaker in court reinforcing an assertion by calling down destruction on his children if he was not telling the truth.  Demosthenes' daughter, apparently his only legitimate child, had died in 336, but Athenaeus (13.592e-f) states that Demosthenes had illegitimate children by a courtesan.  Probably therefore Demosthenes has at some time sworn on the heads of these illegitimate children, and the speaker is either (i) arbitrarily taking "children" in Demosthenes' oath to mean "legitimate children" or (ii) insinuating that Demosthenes is not these children's actual father.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
remarks:
When Xenophon addresses the lochagoi of Proxenus the Boeotian, after mentioning that he used to be envy the Persians and fear the truce they had made with them, Xenophon goes on to say, "But seeing that their own act has put an end to the truce, the end has likewise come, in my opinion, both of their arrogance and of our embarrassment. For now all these good things are offered as prizes for whichever of the two parties shall prove to be the braver men; and the judges of the contest are the gods, who, in all likelihood, will be on our side. For our enemies have sworn falsely by them, while we, with abundant possessions before our eyes, have steadfastly kept our hands therefrom because of our oaths by the gods; hence we, I think, can go into the contest with far greater confidence than can our enemies.  
Besides, we have bodies more capable than theirs of bearing cold and heat and toil, and we likewise, by the blessing of the gods, have better souls; and these men are more liable than we to be wounded and killed, if the gods again, as on that former day, grant us victory." 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: Emphasises that the Sacian agrees with Pheraulas
statement:
[That anyone who gets intense pleasure from having much wealth will also find himself having to spend a lot and therefore get intense pain]
 ὅστις οὖν ἰσχυρῶς χρήμασιν ἥδεται, εὖ ἴσθι τοῦτον καὶ δαπανῶντα ἰσχυρῶς  ἀνιᾶσθαι. <Ναὶ> μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σάκας
remarks: The Sacian replies that he doesn’t find spending painful, quite the reverse.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That the Spartans who were suffering on account of the war deserved it]
 Νὴ Δί’, ὦ μέλ’, ἐν δίκῃ γε δῆτ’
remarks: On the fluctuating identity of the Chorus in this play, see Sommerstein (ed) xviii-xix.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would not attack each other's territory]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Athenians felt threatened by the growing power of Thebes and weakened by the continous raids from Aegina and sent envoys to Sparta who concluded a peace. 
See also oath id 2957.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he would be better off keeping guard on Scione than on his father]
 νὴ Δί’ ἦ μοι κρεῖττον ἦν 
 τηρεῖν Σκιώνην ἀντὶ τούτου τοῦ πατρός.
remarks: The statement is surely a bit hyperbolical – Bdel. can't seriously prefer camp life in a Thracian winter (with the risk of death from enemy sallies or camp epidemics) to being at home in Athens – though doubtless accurately reflecting his feelings at this moment. On the historical relations between Athens and Scione, see Sommerstein ad 210.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The Athenians claim that the Spartans have violated their oath by campaigning against the other Greeks. This is clearly a reference to the so-called King's Peace. 
For the other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Alexis
title: Tokisths or Katapseudomenos
statement:
[That he is happy, not because he will eat well at the wedding, but because he will burst <through overeating> – which is the way he would wish to die)]
 εὐδαίμων ἐγώ, μὰ τὸν Δία
τὸν Ὀλύμπιον καὶ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν οὐχ ὅτι 
ἐν τοῖς γάμοισιν, ἄνδρες, εὐωχήσομαι,
ἀλλ’ ὅτι διαρραγήσομ’
remarks: It is likely that the parasite refers to the particular wedding which is to be celebrated in (probably at the end of) this play.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he has bought his meal (since a second crab-dancer has appeared)]
  νὴ Δί’ ὠψώνηκ’ ἄρα.

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
statement:
[That he can no longer say in what subject the sophist is an expert and can make others expert]
 τί δή ἐστιν τοῦτο περὶ οὗ αὐτός τε ἐπιστήμων ἐστὶν ὁ σοφιστὴς καὶ τὸν μαθητὴν ποιεῖ;  Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκέτι ἔχω σοι λέγειν.

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
statement:
[That the Chorus saw Silenus (in the process of) selling the goods to the strangers]
 ἔγωγε τοῖς ξένοις τὰ χρήματα 
  περνάντα σ’ εἶδον· εἰ δ’ ἐγὼ ψευδῆ λέγω,
  ἀπόλοιθ’ ὁ πατήρ μου·
remarks: The satyrs' oath is true since they use the present participle, indicating that they saw the sale taking place. They do not claim to have seen the sale completed. See also oath ids 98 and 99.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the affair at Plataea violated the peace treaty, and both sides began to prepare for war.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

title: IG II(2)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
Line 6 reads [- - ἐὰν δὲ μ]ὴ ὀμόσηι τὸν ὅρκον - - ]. Immediately following this is a break in the stone and the words καὶ ἀποδ̣[έκται - -]. This implies that the apodektai and another group of officials swore the oath.  
Both Koehler and Kirchner suggested a date during the Lycurgan period ca.338-326.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Metapontians as allies, observing that they were fighting due to stasis. 
See also oath id 1827.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Aeschines compares the alliance between Athens and Thebes in 339/8 with Darius III sending money to Athens after Alexander invaded Asia Minor. He argues that just as Darius' fear and the crisis brought his gold to Athens, the Thebans' fear of Philip and the looming crisis brought about the Athenian-Theban alliance (so that Demosthenes deserves no credit for it). 
See also oath id 2670.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Euaeon's speech was good]
 νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον χρηστά γ’.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he is not kissed by Sambaulas because the latter is not fond of toil]
 Κἄπειτα τοιοῦτον ὄντα οὐ φιλεῖς αὐτὸν ὥσπερ τοὺς συγγενεῖς; καὶ ὁ αἰσχρὸς ἐκεῖνος πρὸς τοῦτο ἔφη· Μὰ Δία· οὐ γὰρ φιλόπονός ἐστιν·
remarks: “If Sambaulas tried to kiss me,” says the ugly man, “it would be all the exercise he’d ever need” [because of the man’s enormous bushy beard, cf. 2.2.28].

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
statement:
[That Conon's supporters are not the sort of people who will give false testimony]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’ οὐκ εἰσὶ τοιοῦτοι.
remarks: Ariston argues that all of Conon's supporters attend the same symposia and are likely to give false testimony. He imagines that someone will respond in this way.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That he cannot tell Socrates of any other Athenian apart from Pericles' two sons and from Alcibiades' own brother Cleinias (none of whom, as Alcibiades has himself pointed out, were any great advertisement for Pericles’ educational abilities) who is held to have been made wiser through being in company with Pericles]
 Ἀλλὰ τῶν ἄλλων Ἀθηναίων ἢ τῶν ξένων δοῦλον ἢ ἐλεύθερον εἰπὲ ὅστις αἰτίαν ἔχει διὰ τὴν Περικλέους συνουσίαν σοφώτερος γεγονέναι, ὥσπερ ἐγὼ ἔχω σοι εἰπεῖν διὰ τὴν Ζήνωνος Πυθόδωρον τὸν Ἰσολόχου καὶ Καλλίαν τὸν Καλλιάδου, ὧν ἑκάτερος Ζήνωνι ἑκατὸν μνᾶς τελέσας σοφός τε καὶ ἐλλόγιμος γέγονεν.  {ΑΛ.} Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔχω.
remarks: Cf. Protagoras 319e-320b.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he has profited by coming to Nephelokokkugia]
  Ἀπέλαυσα τἄρα νὴ Δί’ ἐλθὼν ἐνθαδί,
  εἴπερ γέ μοι καὶ τὸν πατέρα βοσκητέον
remarks: This is a sarcastic exclamation- the oath statement is not meant to be taken literally. The young man is here responding to the news that he will be expected to look after his father if he settles in Nephelokokkugia, news which leaves him disappointed.

author: Plato
title: Letter VI
if_taken: A bond of friendship will be created between them
if_refused: There will be no bond of friendship
statement:
[That they would be loyal to each other]  
 μήπω συγγεγονότι, καὶ τέχνῃ δι’ ἐμπειρίας εἰληφέναι. τί οὖν δὴ λέγω; σοὶ μέν, Ἑρμεία, πεπειραμένος Ἐράστου καὶ Κορίσκου πλέονα ἢ σύ, φημὶ καὶ μηνύω καὶ μαρτυρῶ μὴ ῥᾳδίως εὑρήσειν σε ἀξιοπιστότερα ἤθη τούτων τῶν γειτόνων· ἔχεσθαι δὴ παντὶ συμβουλεύω δικαίῳ τρόπῳ τούτων τῶν ἀνδρῶν, μὴ πάρεργον ἡγουμένῳ. Κορίσκῳ δὲ καὶ Ἐράστῳ πάλιν Ἑρμείου ἀντέχεσθαι σύμβουλός εἰμι καὶ πειρᾶσθαι ταῖς ἀνθέξεσιν ἀλλήλων εἰς μίαν ἀφικέσθαι φιλίας συμπλοκήν. ἂν δέ τις ὑμῶν ἄρα ταύτην πῃ λύειν δοκῇ—τὸ γὰρ ἀνθρώπινον οὐ παντάπασιν βέβαιον—δεῦρο παρ’ ἐμὲ καὶ τοὺς ἐμοὺς πέμπετε μομφῆς κατήγορον ἐπιστολήν· οἶμαι γὰρ δίκῃ τε καὶ αἰδοῖ τοὺς παρ’ ἡμῶν ἐντεῦθεν ἐλθόντας λόγους, εἰ μή τι τὸ λυθὲν μέγα τύχοι γενόμενον, ἐπῳδῆς ἡστινοσοῦν μᾶλλον ἂν συμφῦσαι καὶ συνδῆσαι πάλιν εἰς τὴν προϋπάρχουσαν φιλότητά τε καὶ κοινωνίαν, ἣν ἂν μὲν φιλοσοφῶμεν ἅπαντες ἡμεῖς τε καὶ ὑμεῖς, ὅσον ἂν δυνώμεθα καὶ ἑκάστῳ παρείκῃ, κύρια τὰ νῦν κεχρησμῳδημένα ἔσται. τὸ δὲ ἂν μὴ δρῶμεν ταῦτα οὐκ ἐρῶ· φήμην γὰρ ἀγαθὴν μαντεύομαι, καὶ φημὶ δὴ ταῦθ’ ἡμᾶς πάντ’ ἀγαθὰ ποιήσειν, ἂν θεὸς ἐθέλῃ.  Ταύτην τὴν ἐπιστολὴν πάντας ὑμᾶς τρεῖς ὄντας ἀναγνῶναι χρή, μάλιστα μὲν ἁθρόους, εἰ δὲ μή, κατὰ δύο, κοινῇ κατὰ δύναμιν ὡς οἷόν τ’ ἐστὶν πλειστάκις, καὶ χρῆσθαι συνθήκῃ καὶ νόμῳ κυρίῳ, ὅ ἐστιν δίκαιον, ἐπομνύντας σπουδῇ τε ἅμα μὴ ἀμούσῳ καὶ τῇ τῆς σπουδῆς ἀδελφῇ παιδιᾷ, καὶ τὸν τῶν πάντων θεὸν ἡγεμόνα τῶν τε ὄντων καὶ τῶν μελλόντων, τοῦ τε ἡγεμόνος καὶ αἰτίου πατέρα κύριον ἐπομνύντας, ὅν, ἂν ὄντως φιλοσοφῶμεν, εἰσόμεθα πάντες σαφῶς εἰς δύναμιν ἀνθρώπων εὐδαιμόνων.
remarks: The purpose of this letter is to urge the tyrant of Atarneus to cultivate friendly relations with his neighbours from Scepsis by swearing loyalty to each other in earnestness and playfulness (323d) and by reading the letter together as many times as possible. If someone is suspected of breaking the agreement, the parties are urged by Plato to write to him for judicious advice (323c).

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be allies and friends of the Athenians and to be ready to hand over their harbours to the Athenians and to be ready to assist the Athenians to the best of their ability and to abide by their agreements with the Athenians faithfully and guilelessly]
 [χσύμμαχο]ι ἐσόμεθα Ἀθεναί[οις καὶ φίλοι ἐπιτέδειοι καὶ παρέ]χσομεν Ἀθεναίοι[ς ναύσταθμον καὶ προθύμος ὀφελέσ]ομεν Ἀθεναίοις κα[τὰ τὸ δυνατὸν ἐμ παντὶ καιρο̃ι καὶ ἐ]μμενο̃μεν ταῖς χσ[υνθέκαις πιστο̃ς καὶ ἀδόλος Ἀθεναί]οις·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Halieis. 
The citizens of Halieis swore their oath of loyalty to Athens and their action was reported to the Athenians under oath by presbeis (see oath id 227). 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 229.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That Themistocles did not make the city love him by incantations (but by protecting her)]
 Θεμιστοκλῆς δὲ πῶς ἐποίησε τὴν πόλιν φιλεῖν αὑτόν; Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἐπᾴδων, ἀλλὰ περιάψας τι ἀγαθὸν αὐτῇ.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
statement: n/a
remarks: Andocides observes that if the Athenians must make war they long for peace, but if someone makes a peace they calculate the benefits of war.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he does not wish to be a rhapsode]
 Ἀλλὰ μὴ ῥαψῳδός; ἔφη· καὶ γὰρ τὰ Ὁμήρου σέ φασιν ἔπη πάντα κεκτῆσθαι. Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’, ἔφη·
remarks: Cf. oath id 2123.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines claims that Demosthenes has dared to ask men who have sworn to give both litigants an equal hearing (τῶν ἀντιδίκων ὁμοίως ἀμφοτέρων ἀκούσεσθαι), not to listen to the party at most risk i.e. himself. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Cleidemus
title: Protogonia
statement:
[That they would not start hostilties]
 ὀμόσαντας μηδέποτε πολέμου κατάρξειν
remarks: Cleidemus (cited by Plutarch, Theseus. 19) claims that Theseus made a treaty with Ariadne, recovered the young Athenians, and established friendship between the Athenians and the Cretans, swearing that they would not start hostilities.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
Thucydides describes how the Thebans refused to give up Panactum unless the Spartans "made a separate alliance with them as they had done with Athens" (ξυμμαχίαν ἰδίαν ποιήσωνται ὥσπερ Ἀθηναίοις), and how the Spartans acquiesced. 
For other references to this alliance and its impact see oath id 1715, 1718-1720, 2013, 2022, 2297, 3014.

author: Lysias
title: Concerning the Olive Stump
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that that the defendant had not removed an olive tree or olive stump]
remarks:
The defendant claims that there was never an olive tree or stump on the land in question. He claims that upon acquiring the land in question in 404/3 he let it out for two years to Callistratus who did not take over any olive tree or stump, and then the land was worked by Demetrius for one year, and then Proteas, who worked the land for three years. 
He then summons (sworn) witnesses to verify his claims.  The witnesses are on oath because the trial was held before the Areopagus Council.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That if the jurors were to consider matters in light of the truth they would find that the men who are to blame for what has happened (i.e. the loss of the war to Philip etc) are men in the several cities who resemble Aeschines, not himself]
 καίτοι νὴ τὸν Ἡρακλέα καὶ πάντας θεούς, εἴ γ’ ἐπ’ ἀληθείας δέοι σκοπεῖσθαι, τὸ καταψεύδεσθαι καὶ δι’ ἔχθραν τι λέγειν ἀνελόντας ἐκ μέσου, τίνες ὡς ἀληθῶς εἰσὶν οἷς ἂν εἰκότως καὶ δικαίως τὴν τῶν γεγενημένων αἰτίαν ἐπὶ τὴν κεφαλὴν ἀναθεῖεν ἅπαντες, τοὺς ὁμοίους τούτῳ παρ’ ἑκάστῃ τῶν πόλεων εὕροιτ’ ἄν, οὐ τοὺς ἐμοί·
remarks: Demosthenes goes on to blame Daochus, Cineas and Thrasydaeus for betraying the Thessalians, Cercidas, Hieronymus and Eucampidas the Arcadians, Myrtis, Teledamus and Mnaseas the Argives, Euxitheus, Cleotimus and Aristaechmus the Eleans, Neon and Thrasylochus the Messenians, Aristarchus and Epichares the Sicyonians, Deinarchus and Demaratus the Corinthians, Ptoeodorus, Helixus and Perilas the Megarians, Timolas, Theogeiton and Anemoetas the Thebans, and Hipparchus, Cleitarchus and Sosistratus the Euboeans.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Hermes
impact: None- Apollo does not believe him
statement:
[That he himself is not responsible (for the theft of the cattle) and that he hasn't seen anyone else stealing the cattle]
εἰ δὲ θέλεις πατρὸς κεφαλὴν μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμοῦμαι·
μὴ μὲν ἐγὼ μήτ’ αὐτὸς ὑπίσχομαι αἴτιος εἶναι, 
μήτε τιν’ ἄλλον ὄπωπα βοῶν κλοπὸν ὑμετεράων
remarks: This oath reference exemplifies Hermes' notoriety as a trickster. He volunteers to swear an oath and invokes the power of his father's head (cf. oath ids 1334, 1363 and also 160). But he doesn't actually swear anything. He merely PROMISES (ὑπίσχομαι); cf. also oath id 1361 where he promises rather than swearing. Apollo is not fooled by Hermes' deceptive words (cf. oath id 1359).

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he sees the door- he thinks!]
 {ΕΥ.}  Ὁρᾷς τὸ θύριον τοῦτο;
  {ΚΗ.}  Νὴ τὸν Ἡρακλέα  
  οἶμαί γε.
remarks: The Inlaw's uncertainty as to whether he sees the door may be due to his earlier (mis-?)understanding of Euripides' scientific/sophistic language as meaning that he (Inlaw) is not supposed to see anything at all (8-20; cf. oath id 696).

author: Sophilus
title: Phularchos or Philarchos
statement:
[That he is already getting frisky (with the prospect of gluttonous eating)]
 γαστρισμὸς ἔσται δαψιλής· τὰ προοίμια 
ὁρῶ  .  .  .  .  .  χορτασθήσομαι. 
νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον, ἄνδρες, ἤδη στρηνιῶ.
remarks: The fact that the swearer address the audience suggests that he is male himself.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would give assistance to the demos of Athens in full strength, to the best of their ability, if anyone comes for the purpose of making war either by land or sea, against the land of the Athenians, in accordance with the demands of the Athenians. Concerning war and peace they would act in accordance with whatever the Athenians and the majority of the allies resolve, and in other respects they would act in accordance with the resolutions of the Athenians and the allies. That this is true they swear by Zeus and Apollo and Demeter]
 [βοηθήσω Ἀθ]ηναίων τῶι  [δ]ήμωι παντὶ σθέν[ει κατὰ τὸ δυν]ατόν, αἴ κά τις ἐ[πίηι ἐπὶ πολέμωι ἤ κατὰ γ]ῆν κατὰ γῆν ἤ κατὰ θάλατταν ἐ[πὶ τὴγ χώραν τὴγ Ἀθην]αίων καθ’ ὅτι κ’ ἐπαγ[γέ]λλω[ντι Ἀθηναῖ]οι, καὶ περὶ πολέμ[ο]υ κ[αὶ εἰρ]ή[νης πράξω καθ’ ὅ τ]ι κ[α] Ἀ[θ]ηναίο[ι]ς κ[α]ὶ [τῶι] π[λήθει τῶν συμμάχ]ων δ[ο]κῆι κ[αὶ τἆ]λλα ποι[ήσω κατὰ τὰ δόγματα] τὰ Ἀθηνα[ί]ων κα[ὶ τῶ]ν [συμμάχων· ἀληθῆ δὲ ταῦ]τα να[ὶ τ]ὸν Δία [κα]ὶ [τὸν Ἀπόλλωνα καὶ τὰν Δά]ματ[ρα]· εὐορκ[έο]ν[τι μέμ μοι εἴη πολλὰ καὶ  ἀγαθ]ά, εἰ δὲ μή, [τἀναντία].
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Corcyra. 
This oath and alliance are presumably a follow-up alliance to that in oath id 353-357. For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 401.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he is nobody]
 τίς εἶ ποτ’, ὦ ’νθρωπ’, ἐτεόν;
 {Φι.}  Οὖτις, νὴ Δία.
remarks: Clearly Philcoleon is not "nobody". He is giving the same lie as Odysseus had given to Polyphemus (though not under oath) when the latter had asked for his name (Odyssey 9. 424-463), but here Phil. is reinforcing it with an informal oath.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Xenophon observes that after the Spartans had sworn that they would leave the Greek states independent, and then seized the Theban acropolis they were punished by the men they had wronged. 
For the other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he doesn't want Peace to do what adulterous wives do]
 καὶ μὴ ποίει γ’ ἅπερ αἱ 
  μοιχευόμεναι δρῶσι γυναῖκες. 
  Καὶ γὰρ ἐκεῖναι παρακλίνασαι 
  τῆς αὐλείας παρακύπτουσιν· 
  κἄν τις προσέχῃ τὸν νοῦν αὐταῖς
  ἀναχωροῦσιν· 
  κᾆτ’ ἢν ἀπίῃ, παρακύπτουσιν. 
  Τούτων σὺ πόει μηδὲν ἔθ’ ἡμῖν.
  {ΤΡ.}  Μὰ Δί’

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the city has not been handed over to the women for them to weave]
 ὑμῖν δέ φασι παραδεδόσθαι τὴν πόλιν.  {Πρ.}  τί δρᾶν; ὑφαίνειν; {Βλ.} οὐ μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ ἄρχειν.
remarks: Sommerstein ad 556 remarks: "since one cannot "weave" a city-state, we are probably meant to suppose that Praxagora is pretending to have misheard thn polin "the City" as e.g. ton peplon "the robe".".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There will be a threat of force
statement:
[That they would in truth maintain a democracy and live in harmony, and prosecute zealously the war against the Peloponnesians, and be enemies of the Four Hundred, and not make overtures to them]
 ἦ μὴν δημοκρατήσεσθαί τε καὶ ὁμονοήσειν καὶ τὸν πρὸς Πελοποννησίους πόλεμον προθύμως διοίσειν καὶ τοῖς τετρακοσίοις πολέμιοί τε ἔσεσθαι καὶ οὐδὲν ἐπικηρυκεύσεσθαι
remarks:
Thucydides states that when the Athenians at Samos had learned that the Four Hundred had seized control, Thrasybulus and Thrasyllus (being openly in favour of changing the government at Samos to a democracy) bound all the Athenian soldiers and the Samians of military age by the most solemn oaths that they would maintain a democracy, and live in harmony, continue to fight against the Peloponnesians, and be enemies of the Four Hundred. 
Thucydides states that they focused in particular on "the oligarchs". 
After this the Athenians deposed the generals and trierarchs they suspected of being oligarchs.

title: IG II(2)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: This text is very fragmentary. Little can be deduced from what is extant.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
The exact statement is unknown. The text indicates that "the judge is to decide upon swearing" (τὸν δικαστὰν ὀμνύντα κρίνεν). 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides indicates that the Athenian general Asopius was defeated when he landed his forces near Leucas. The Athenians departed after collecting their dead from the Leucadians under a truce.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
statement: n/a
remarks: The Chorus here make a general reflection on the fact that the enchanting force of oaths has vanished, but this is prompted specifically by Jason's betrayal of his oath, previously mentioned- see oath ids 114 and 115.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Emphasises the truth of the statement
statement:
[That the woman standing beside Philocleon is Dardanis]
  νὴ τὸν Δί’, αὕτη πού ’στί σοί γ’ ἡ Δαρδανίς.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Andocides states that the Athenians rejected an offer of an alliance with Syracuse (see oath id 2426) in favour of their existing alliances with Egesta and Catana.  
Andocides states that instead of choosing peace with the Syracusans they chose to go to Sicily for the Egestans and Catanians, losing many Athenians and allies, the best before the rest, and throwing away many ships and much money in the process. 
See also oath id 87, 298 and 1841.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: The Persians will attack the Greeks
statement: [? That his army would remain where it was]
remarks:
After the battle of Cunaxa, King Artaxerxes sent Phalinus to negotiate with the Greeks regarding a truce. 
Phalinus tells Clearchus the Greek commander that Artaxerxes has said that if the Greeks remain where they are there will be a truce. If they advance or retire, there will be war. 
When asked for his answer, Clearchus responds that his view is the same as that of the King. 
When asked to clarify, Clearchus replies, "if we remain a truce, if we retire or advance, war". 
Phalinus again asks Clearchus whether he should report a truce or war, and Clearchus again makes the same reply, but does not indicate what he wishes to do. The truce proposed here is referred to also by Ctesias (see oath id 3477).

author: Demosthenes
title: On Halonnesus
swearer: Philip of Macedon; The Athenians in Potidaea
swearee: Philip of Macedon; The Athenians in Potidaea
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Hegesippus argues that the Athenians settled at Potidaea were robbed of their territory by Philip, even though they were allies, and Philip had sworn to all the inhabitants of the city.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he was brave to stand up and wipe himself]
  ἐγὼ δ’ ἀνέστην καὶ προσέτ’ ἀπεψησάμην.
ΞΑ.  ᾿Ανδρεῖά γ’, ὦ Πόσειδον. 
ΔΙ.  Οἶμαι νὴ Δία.
remarks: Dionysus clearly believes his own statement, thereby taking seriously what Xanthias had intended as an entirely sarcastic compliment.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: There would not be any alliance(s)
remarks:
The speaker refers to "the alliance" i.e. the so-called 'Second Athenian Confederacy' or 'Second Athenian Sea League'. For the foundation of this League see also Diod. 15.28.3. 
See also oath id 334, 335, 353, 354, 355, 356, 357, 1441, 2975, 3638, 3862.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement:
[That he did not have adequate provision for his old age]
 μὴ εἶναι αὑτῷ ἐφόδια τῷ γήρᾳ ἱκανά
remarks:
Apollodorus complains that Timotheus recently swore that he did not have adequate provision for his old age, despite possessing a large estate. 
Again, no witnesses are called to provide evidence that Timotheus swore this oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Peisetaerus will hear a sample of his compositions]
 σὺ δὲ κλύων εἴσει τάχα. 
  {ΠΕ.}  Οὐ δῆτ’ ἔγωγε. 
  {ΚΙ.}  Νὴ τὸν Ἡρακλέα σύ γε.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That some of those who obtained immunity did not deserve it]
 ὅτι νὴ Δί’ ἦσάν τινες τῶν εὑρημένων ἀνάξιοι.
remarks: Demosthenes imagines what might happen if Leucon, King of Bosporus (an honorary Athenian citizen) is informed that he is no longer immune from performing liturgies. He imagines that Leucon will write to the Athenians asking why his immunity has been taken away, and that one of the orators will have to draft a response from the demos.

author: Demosthenes
title: Exordia
statement:
[That he does not think that there are any people in the whole world who would listen so complacently when reminded of their real faults as the Athenians do when they are reviled for faults that are not theirs]
 ἐγὼ γὰρ μὰ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν οὐδένας ἂν τῶν ἄλλων ἀνθρώπων οὕτως ἡδέως οἶμαι τὰ προσόνθ’ αὑτοῖς ἀκοῦσαι νουθετουμένους, ὡς ὑμεῖς τὰ μὴ προσήκοντα κακῶς ἀκούοντες.
remarks: Demosthenes is commenting on the apparently calm reception given to the allegedly mendacious accusations made against Athens by an embassy that has come from a foreign power.

author: Lysias
title: Against Alcibiades 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that they ought to condemn Alcibiades as one whom they have judged to be a hereditary enemy of the city, and to set neither pity nor forgiveness, nor favour above the established laws and the oaths that they have sworn. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Epistle 4
statement:
[That the Athenians are faring better than the Spartans, the Persians, the Cappadocians, Syrians and Indians, but worse than the Thessalians, Argives and Arcadians who had the fortune to be in alliance with Philip]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία τούτων μὲν ἄμεινον ὑμᾶς πράττειν ἅπαντες ὁμολογήσουσι, Θετταλῶν δὲ καὶ Ἀργείων καὶ Ἀρκάδων χεῖρον, ἤ τινων ἄλλων οἷς ἐν συμμαχίᾳ συνέβη γενέσθαι Φιλίππῳ.
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that someone will respond in this way to his letter.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement: [? That they would decide justly whether each deme member was entitled to remain on the deme register]
remarks:
Aeschines observes that the same argument always works with juries: "Gentlemen of the jury, the demesmen with their vote rejected this man on oath, though nobody in the world accused him or bore witness against him; they voted on the basis of their knowledge". 
This refers to a particular occasion - the revision of the deme registers in 346/5.  The oath of the demesmen is mentioned in Dem. 57.8-9; it was taken at the revision meeting of the deme, and presumably it included an undertaking to decide every case fairly, etc., much as in the dicastic oath.  Euxitheus, the speaker, complains that his enemies deleted from this oath the phrases, which of course formed part of the dicastic oath, about voting "in accordance with the most just opinion, and not from favour or enmity" (Dem. 57.63); but he does not say that by doing so they were breaking the law, and it may well be that the oath prescribed by decree for the demesmen on this occasion was shorter and simpler than that prescribed for jurors - in other words, that the phrases mentioned were deleted from the oath, not by Eubulides and his cronies at deme level, but by the Assembly when it set up the review procedure. 
Incidentally, Dem. 57.44 and 53 seem to show that when a man was struck off the deme register and afterwards appealed to a dicastic court, any witnesses he brought forward had to confirm their testimony by oath.  The logic of this, presumably, is that the demesmen's decision was made on oath and should not be overturned on the basis of statements not made on oath.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
 ὑμῖν τὴν χώραν καὶ ἀδόλως ἀπάξειν εἰς τὴν Ἑλλάδα ἀγορὰν παρέχοντας· ὅπου δ’ ἂν μὴ ᾖ πρίασθαι, λαμβάνειν ὑμᾶς ἐκ  τῆς χώρας ἐάσομεν τὰ ἐπιτήδεια.
remarks:
Three days after Tissaphernes spoke with the Greeks he returned with a message from the King that they would be spared. 
Tissaphernes and the brother of the King's wife swore that they would lead the Greeks back home and provide them with supplies. 
The Greeks on their part were to swear that they would proceed as they would through a friendly country and take no food from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market (see oath id 2105). 
After the oaths were exchanged Tissaphernes returned to the King, having said that he would return fully equipped to take the Greeks back home and return to his own satrapy. 
For other references to this oath see oath id 2109, 2114, 2171, 2173, 2174, 2176, 2178, 2179, 2181, 2184.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he did not pay much attention to the Delphi inscription "Know Thyself" because he felt he knew himself already]
 Πότερον οὖν οὐδέν σοι τοῦ γράμματος ἐμέλησεν ἢ προσέσχες τε καὶ ἐπεχείρησας σαυτὸν ἐπισκοπεῖν ὅστις εἴης; Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτα, ἔφη· καὶ γὰρ δὴ πάνυ τοῦτό γε ᾤμην εἰδέναι· σχολῇ γὰρ ἂν ἄλλο τι ᾔδειν,  εἴ γε μηδ’ ἐμαυτὸν ἐγίγνωσκον.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2131.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That her hair has gone white very quickly]
 πολιὰ γεγένησαι ταχύ γε, νὴ τὸν οὐρανόν.
remarks: Sommerstein ad loc. remarks: "We are evidently to suppose either that he had actually hitherto been blinded to her physical decay by his desire and need for her money, or that, for the same reason, he pretended not to notice".

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That a foreman must not only be able to make the men under his rule obey but also be able to keep his hands off his master's property and not steal]
 Ὅταν δέ, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, ἔφην ἐγώ, καὶ ἄρχειν ἤδη ἱκανός σοι γένηται ὥστε πειθομένους παρέχεσθαι, ἦ ἀποτετελεσμένον τοῦτον ἡγῇ ἐπίτροπον, ἢ ἔτι τινὸς προσδεῖται ὁ ταῦτα ἔχων ἃ σὺ εἴρηκας; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος, τοῦ γε ἀπέχεσθαι τῶν δεσποσύνων καὶ μὴ κλέπτειν.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
Xenophon states that when King Pausanias marched on the Piraeus, he was accompanied by all the allies except the Corinthians and Boeotians who said that they would not be keeping their oaths if they made a military expedition against the Athenians when they were not doing anything against the treaty. 
For other references to this peace treaty see oath id 1893.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he is doing what Demos wants him to (i.e. bringing out his oracles so that they can be heard)]
 Καὶ μὴν ἔνεγκ’ αὐτοὺς ἰών, ἵν’ οὑτοσὶ 
  αὐτῶν ἀκούσῃ. 
  {ΑΛ.}  Πάνυ γε.  
  {ΔΗ.}  Καὶ σύ νυν φέρε.  
  {ΠΑ.}  Ἰδού.
  {ΑΛ.}  Ἰδοὺ νὴ τὸν Δί’

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between  Athens and Carystus. 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 454.  
See also Dem. 8.74; Diodorus 16.7.2.

author: Eubulus
title: Lakones or Leda
statement:
[That they had heard that when the cook made a mistake at the swearee's house, the piper was beaten]
  ἀλλ’ ἠκούσαμεν 
καὶ τοῦτο, νὴ τὴν Ἑστίαν, οἴκοι ποθ’ ὡς 
ὅσ’ ἂν ὁ μάγειρος ἐξαμάρτῃ, τύπτεται, 
ὥς φασιν, αὑλητὴς παρ’ ὑμῖν.
remarks: The piper, like the cook/butcher/slaughterer, was part of the personnel normally required for a sacrifice.  This seems to have been a proverbial expression, cf. Philyllius fr. 9; Sommerstein adapts: “Don’t shoot the pianist just because you’re angry with the chef”.

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That when those who claim to be teachers of a subject are generally thought to be bad at that subject themselves, and those who are good at it aren’t sure whether it can be taught, he can’t say that either group can really be called teachers]
 τοὺς οὖν οὕτω τεταραγμένους περὶ ὁτουοῦν φαίης ἂν σὺ κυρίως διδασκάλους εἶναι;  {ΜΕΝ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Emphasises the statement and reinforces Lysistrata's oath at id 1174
statement:
[That if the archer so much as lays a hand on Lysistrata, he will get such a beating that he will shit all over the place]
  Εἰ τἄρα νὴ τὴν Πάνδροσον ταύτῃ μόνον 
 τὴν χεῖρ’ ἐπιβαλεῖς, ἐπιχεσεῖ πατούμενος.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 439, Pandrosus "was one of the daughters of the mythical Athenian king Cecrops…; she had a precinct on the Acropolis close to the temple of Athena Polias".

author: Euripides
title: Supplices
if_broken: The Argive land should be wretchedly destroyed
statement:
[That Argives will never bring force of arms against Athens, and if others do, Argos will impede them with her spear]  
  πρῶτον λάβ’ ὅρκον. τόνδε δ’ ὀμνύναι χρεὼν
  ῎Αδραστον· οὗτος κύριος, τύραννος ὤν,
  πάσης ὑπὲρ γῆς Δαναϊδῶν ὁρκωμοτεῖν. 
  ὁ δ’ ὅρκος ἔσται μήποτ’ ᾿Αργείους χθόνα
  ἐς τήνδ’ ἐποίσειν πολέμιον παντευχίαν
  ἄλλων τ’ ἰόντων ἐμποδὼν θήσειν δόρυ.
  ἢν δ’ ὅρκον ἐκλιπόντες ἔλθωσιν πόλιν,
  κακῶς ὀλέσθαι πρόστρεπ’ ᾿Αργείων χθόνα. 
  ἐν ὧι δὲ τέμνειν σφάγια χρή σ’ ἄκουέ μου.
  ἔστιν τρίπους σοι χαλκόπους ἔσω δόμων,
  ὃν ᾿Ιλίου ποτ’ ἐξαναστήσας βάθρα
σπουδὴν ἐπ’ ἄλλην ῾Ηρακλῆς ὁρμώμενος
  στῆσαί σ’ ἐφεῖτο Πυθικὴν πρὸς ἐσχάραν. 
  ἐν τῶιδε λαιμοὺς τρεῖς τριῶν μήλων τεμὼν
  ἔγγραψον ὅρκους τρίποδος ἐν κοίλωι κύτει
  κἄπειτα σώιζειν θεῶι δὸς ὧι Δελφῶν μέλει,
  μνημεῖά θ’ ὅρκων μαρτύρημά θ’ ῾Ελλάδι.
remarks: The oath is a presciption for the future and must be taken outside dramatic time. Adrastus takes the oath on behalf of his people. This oath is particularly rich in sanctifying features. Apart from those listed in the statement (going to Delphi, using Heracles' tripod, sacrificing three sheep, inscribing the oath on the tripod), it is also stated that the sacrifical knife should be buried in the earth near the place where the Seven are to be cremated, and should be brought out and displayed to the Argives to inspire them with fear, should they ever come against Athens. The oath is true in that the Argives had indeed never attacked Athens, but in the Archidamian war they had remained neutral and had done nothing to help Athens against the Spartans and Thebans.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes concludes by imploring the jurors to remember the laws and the oaths they swore. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
The Corcyraean envoys to Athens refer to the Athenian peace treaty with the Spartans and argue that the Athenians will not be breaking the treaty if they make a separate alliance with Corcyra. 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

title: SEG
proposed_by: Philocomus, son of Phanthides, of Eleusis
if_taken: They will act as guarantors of the rent money
if_refused: They cannot act as guarantors of the rent money
statement:
[That the rent money would be paid prior to the sacrifice]
 ἐγγυητά[ς] τ[ε] καταστησάτω ὁ μισθωσάμενος δύο ἄνδρας [ὀμουμέν]ους ᾖ μὴν ἀποδώσειν τὴν μίσθωσιν πᾶσαν ἐν τῶι  χρό[νω]ι τῶι  εἰρημένωι·
remarks: This deme decree from Eleusis indicates that in order to raise money for the sacrifices to Heracles-in-Acris stone quarries would be leased to the highest bidder. Two men were to be appointed to provide surety that the rent money would be paid prior to the sacrifice.

author: Hypereides
title: In defence of Lycophron
statement:
[That she would not have sex with anyone else]
 ὅτι συνομωμο[κ̣υῖα εἰ]η πρὸς ἐμέ,
remarks:
Lycophron has been charged with committing adultery with the daughter of Dioxippus, the wife of Charippus. Charippus has alleged that the daughter of Dioxippus sworn herself to Lycophron, and Lycophron was overheard urging her to abide by this oath. 
Lycophron asks the jurors if they believe that Charippus was so obtuse as to be prepared to marry the girl if she had sworn an oath to him (Lycophron) and if he had been overheard urging her to abide by that oath.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he tries to train his foremen himself]
 αὐτὸς παιδεύεις τοὺς ἐπιτρόπους; Αὐτὸς νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, πειρῶμαι παιδεύειν

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the girl has done him a favour by helping him escape from the old woman]
  νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν σωτῆρα, κεχάρισαί γέ μοι, 
  ὦ γλυκύτατον, τὴν γραῦν ἀπαλλάξασά μου.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 838 for context.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he has had stomach upsets at the Panathenaia]
 ἤδη ζωμοῦ Παναθηναίοις ἐμπλησθεὶς εἶτ’ ἐταράχθης
  τὴν γαστέρα καὶ κλόνος ἐξαίφνης αὐτὴν διεκορκορύγησεν;
 {Στ.}  νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
impact: Emphasises the realism of the performance
statement:
[That the boy and girl performers were in love with each other]
 ὥστε μὴ μόνον τὸν Διόνυσον ἀλλὰ καὶ τοὺς παρόντας ἅπαντας συνομόσαι ἂν ἦ μὴν τὸν παῖδα καὶ τὴν παῖδα ὑπ’ ἀλλήλων φιλεῖσθαι.
remarks: Cf. oath ids 2285 and 2286.  It is here stated that the spectators "would have joined in swearing" that the two young people were in love (sc. if they had been asked whether this was so).

author: Plato
title: Symposium
date: When Diotima had delayed the plague for 10 years (440)
statement:
[That he agrees that what people love is the good and nothing else]
 ὡς οὐδέν γε ἄλλο ἐστὶν οὗ ἐρῶσιν ἅνθρωποι ἢ τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ. ἢ σοὶ δοκοῦσιν;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔμοιγε, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus tells the jurors whenever anyone asks Olympiodorus why he refuses to pay him when he swore to share everything equally (see oath id 3623) he asserts that Callistratus has broken the agreement and treated him outrageously, and states that Callistratus has been speaking and acting in opposition to him all along.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That the bird is a francolin]
 Ἐκεινοσὶ δὲ νὴ Δί’ ἀτταγᾶς.
remarks: Many editors give lines 297-8 to Tereus, addressing both Peisetaerus and Euelpides.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the man he sees is indeed Blepyrus]
  νὴ τὸν Δί’ αὐτὸς δῆτ’ ἐκεῖνος.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes asserts that when Philip lays his hands on Megara, sets up tyrannies in Euboea, makes his way into Thrace, hatches plots in the Peloponnese, and does all this with armed force, he is breaking the peace. 
He ironically suggests that Philip is breaking the peace unless the Athenians consider that Philip's men with siege engines are keeping peace until they bring them to bear on the walls. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Isocrates
title: To Nicocles
statement: n/a
remarks: Isocrates urges Nicocles, the son of Euagoras the King of Cypriot Salamis, to demonstrate that he values truth so highly that his word will be trusted more than the oaths of other men.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: They would be unable to take up office
statement:
[That they would protect the funds of the deme Scambonidae and submit their accounts to the auditor for scrutiny]
 : καὶ τὰ κοιν[ὰ] τὰ Σκαμβονιδο̃ν σοο̃ : καὶ ἀποδόσο :  παρὰ τὸν εὔθυνον : τὸ καθε̃κον :
remarks: This oath is part of the laws of the deme Scambonidae found in the Theseion.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: Representatives; Pharsalian representatives; Crannonian representatives; Scotussian representatives; Larissan representatives
swearee: Representatives; Pharsalian representatives; Crannonian representatives; Scotussian representatives; Larissan representatives
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Larissans, Crannonians, Scotussians and Pharsalians were allies of the Boeotians and molested Agesilaus when he returned from Asia in 394. 
See also oath id 2258.

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
Euxitheus, the defendant, argues that he ought to be being tried in a homicide court rather than a Heliastic court, and that the prosecutor should have sworn the preliminary oath (διωμοσία). He describes the diomosia as "the most solemn and binding oath known", and argues that the prosecutor should have taken this oath "under pain of causing yourself and your kin and your house to perish, that you would accuse me only in connexion with the murder itself, to the effect that I committed it". 
It is striking that Eux. says only that in a dike phonou his prosecutor would have had to swear with special solemnity that he would speak strictly to the point - not that he’d have had to swear with special solemnity that Eux. was guilty.  Presumably he doesn't want to risk reminding the jury that in the preliminary proceedings to this trial the prosecutor had sworn (though not with special solemnity) that Eux. was guilty!

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That when he tried to think out a defence speech to present to the jury, his divine voice opposed him]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ τὸν Δία, φάναι αὐτόν, ὦ Ἑρμόγενες, ἤδη μου ἐπιχειροῦντος φροντίσαι τῆς πρὸς τοὺς δικαστὰς ἀπολογίας ἠναντιώθη τὸ δαιμόνιον.
remarks: Compare oath id 2288 for an almost identical statement.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That it would not be at all strange if it were easier for the farmer to provide food for four rather than dividing his time between providing himself with food, shelter, clothing and shoes, since some men are naturally apt for certain tasks]
  Καὶ ὁ Ἀδείμαντος ἔφη· Ἀλλ’ ἴσως, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὕτω ῥᾷον ἢ ’κείνως. 
  Οὐδέν, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, μὰ Δία ἄτοπον. ἐννοῶ γὰρ καὶ αὐτὸς εἰπόντος σοῦ, ὅτι πρῶτον μὲν ἡμῶν φύεται ἕκαστος οὐ πάνυ ὅμοιος ἑκάστῳ, ἀλλὰ διαφέρων τὴν φύσιν, ἄλλος ἐπ’ ἄλλου ἔργου πράξει.
remarks: The farmer will presumably be providing food for four families (his own, the builder's, the weaver's and the shoemaker's), not just four individuals.

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
statement:
[That Philoctetes is not being tricked a second time]
Φι. πῶς εἶπας; ἆρα δεύτερον δολούμεθα;
Νε. ἀπώμοσ’ ἁγνὸν Ζηνὸς ὑψίστου σέβας.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That he has never been driven to admit that there is no such thing as a bad man]
 ἐς τόδε ἤδη ἐξηνέχθης, ὥστε μὴ πάνυ σοι δοκεῖν εἶναί τινα ἄνθρωπον πονηρόν;  {ΕΡΜ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία

author: Thucydides
title: History
remarks:
Thucydides states that after the Spartans and Argives made their alliance they voted not to receive heralds or embassies from Athens unless they evacuated their forts and withdrew from the Peloponnese, and not to make peace or carry on war with anyone except together. 
Presumably the clause "would share in the treaty and alliance" indicates that the other cities in the Peloponnese  would have the same rights and obligations under the treaty as the Spartans and Argives - if they chose to join the treaty. 
The Spartans and Argives also decided to send envoys to the Greeks in Thrace and to Perdiccas of Macedon.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes says that if it were really true that Philip is now powerful enough to intimidate the jurors into ignoring their oath and justice in order to gratify him, this would be a terrible indictment against Aeschines who has made him so. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Pindar
title: Nemean 7
statement:
[That Pindar has not stepped up to the line and sent his tongue speeding like a bronze-cheeked javelin, which releases the strong neck from wrestling without sweat before the body falls under the blazing sun]
 Εὐξένιδα πάτραθε Σώγενες, ἀπομνύω  
μὴ τέρμα προβαὶς ἄκονθ’ ὥτε χαλκοπάραον ὄρσαι 
θοὰν γλῶσσαν, ὃς ἐξέπεμψεν παλαισμάτων 
αὐχένα καὶ σθένος ἀδίαν‐
  τον, αἴθωνι πρὶν ἁλίῳ γυῖον ἐμπεσεῖν.
remarks: The oath statement, which is taken from Race's translation is quite opaque in meaning. Race suggests the following interpretation: "The pentathlon could be won with enough victories in earlier events such as the javelin throw, thereby obviating the deciding wrestling match in the heat of the day. The implication is that Pindar will spare no effort in praising the victor". For Pindar swearing as authorial persona cf. oath ids 1312, 1313, 1315, 1317, 1321.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker repeats his argument that the Athenians should believe those who say that they should abide by the agreement, unless when they insist on  abiding by their oaths they interpret them as not forbidding any act of injustice, or that no one will notice a change from democracy to tyranny or the overthrowing of a constitution. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he gave Socrates good advice when he bade him practise rhetoric which preserves one's life in the law courts]
 ἢ οἴει δεῖν τοῦτο παρασκευάζεσθαι ἄνθρωπον, ὡς πλεῖστον χρόνον ζῆν, καὶ μελετᾶν τὰς τέχνας ταύτας αἳ ἡμᾶς ἀεὶ ἐκ τῶν  κινδύνων σῴζουσιν, ὥσπερ καὶ ἣν σὺ κελεύεις ἐμὲ μελετᾶν τὴν ῥητορικὴν τὴν ἐν τοῖς δικαστηρίοις διασῴζουσαν;  {ΚΑΛ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία ὀρθῶς γέ σοι συμβουλεύων.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement:
[That the members of the tribe will call upon Mantitheus and Boeotus for duties in the same way as they nominate other people]
 οἴσουσι νὴ Δί’ οἱ φυλέται τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον ὅνπερ καὶ τοὺς ἄλλους.
remarks: Mantitheus asks how he will be distinguished from Boeotus when the state commands them to perform any duty i.e. liturgies. He imagines that someone will respond in this way, and argues that no one will be able to distinguish between them if they are both Mantitheus, son of Mantitheus of Thoricus.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That Socrates will always know everything if Euthydemus wishes it]
 καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία, ἔφη, αὐτὸς ἀεὶ ἐπιστήσῃ καὶ ἅπαντα, ἂν ἐγὼ βούλωμαι.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 3097.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: n/a
remarks: The Athenian discusses here two different types of people, both atheist. The first type will be full of outspoken talk about gods, sacrifices and oaths, and by ridiculing others may well make converts like himself, if he is not punished.  The other type holds the same opinions but has a reputation for virtue; he is full of guile and deceit.  This type produces many seers and men active in all kinds of wizardry, and sometimes also tyrants, demagogues and generals, and men who use private initiation rites to make conspiracies, and the wily characters who are called sophists [lit. the wiles of those who are called sophists].  In speaking of the first type, Plato probably has in mind, more than anyone else, Diagoras of Melos; of the second type, Protagoras and other sophists, but also men like Alcibiades (n.b. “demagogues and generals … who use private initiation rites to make conspiracies”).

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That she will not let Epigenes go]
  μὰ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην, ἥ μ’ ἔλαχε κληρουμένη, 
  μὴ ’γώ σ’ ἀφήσω.
remarks: In fact, the old woman holds onto Epigenes until 1041, where, as Sommerstein has in his stage direction, the old woman loosens her grip on Epigenes, shocked at the Girl's suggestion that she would be more like the boy's mother than his wife.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he and the Sausage-seller will shove a peg in Paphlagon's mouth as butchers do]
 Καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἐμβαλόντες αὐ-  
  τῷ πάτταλον μαγειρικῶς 
  εἰς τὸ στόμ’
remarks: Sommerstein comments on "as butchers do" (376): "when examining pigs before slaughter for signs of tapeworm, such as cysts on the under surface of the tongue".

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he thinks the king's wrong-doing was human]
 καὶ ὁ Κῦρος εἶπεν· Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη, ὦ Ἀρμένιε, ἀνθρώπινά μοι δοκεῖς ἁμαρτεῖν·
remarks: The wrong-doing in question was the fact that the Armenian king had put to death a man whom his son had particularly admired. The reason for the sentence was that the king was jealous because he thought his son held the man in greater regard than he held his own father. As the man did before his death, Cyrus urges Tigranes to forgive his father. The comparison between 'the man' and Socrates is quite apparent. The 'man' is accused of corrupting the young, and tells Tigranes that he believes that when men do wrong from ignorance, they do so against their will.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: n/a
remarks: The Athenian here remarks that the worst stage in the degeneration of society is when people no longer care about oaths or pledges or gods, when men are like the Titans who are said to have reverted to their original state, dragging out a wretched existence with no respite from evils. This is very like Hesiod Works and Days 180-201 (see oath ids 1298 and 1299).

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
if_taken: Admission to the school will be granted
statement:
[That he will pay any fee asked] 
 μισθὸν δ’ ὅντιν’ ἂν 
  πράττῃ μ’, ὀμοῦμαί σοι καταθήσειν τοὺς θεούς.
{Σω.}  ποίους θεοὺς ὀμεῖ σύ; πρῶτον γὰρ θεοὶ
  ἡμῖν νόμισμ’ οὐκ ἔστι.
remarks: The oath Strepsiades offers is rejected because the school doesn't recognize gods (meaning the traditional gods).

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
remarks:
Aeschines states that after Philip had destroyed the cities of Phocis and strengthened the position of Thebes, the ambassadors who had negotiated the peace were under the gravest accusation. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That the qualities of an inspiring leader (in any field) cannot be learned by seeing them or hearing about them once. It requires not only “education” but “the right kind of nature” plus a divine gift]
 οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία τοῦτό γε ἔτι ἐγὼ λέγω ἰδόντα μαθεῖν εἶναι, οὐδ’ ἅπαξ ἀκούσαντα, ἀλλὰ καὶ παιδείας δεῖν φημι ... καὶ φύσεως ἀγαθῆς ... καὶ τὸ μέγιστον θεῖον γενέσθαι

author: Xenophon
title: Lacedaemonian Politeia ch.14
date: At the time Xenophon was writing ch.14. i.e. 362/1 (362)
statement:
[That he cannot say with any confidence that the laws of Lycurgus still remain unchanged to this day]
 Εἰ δέ τίς με ἔροιτο εἰ καὶ νῦν ἔτι μοι δοκοῦσιν οἱ Λυκούργου νόμοι ἀκίνητοι διαμένειν, τοῦτο μὰ Δία οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θρασέως εἴποιμι.
remarks: Xenophon observes, "if someone were to ask whether I think that the laws of Lycurgus still remain unchanged to this day, this I could not say, by Zeus, with any confidence".

title: IvO
if_taken: They will be eligible to act as jurors
if_refused: They will pay of fine of 5 mnas per day
statement: [? That they would vote according to the laws]
remarks:
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 30.406.  
This inscription was found at Olympia and outlines the arrangement of the affairs of the settlement of Scillus by the Eleans.  
The rhetra outlines the appointment of two officials (the damiorgoi) Nicarchidas and Pleistaenus and their duties, one of which is to oversee the prosecution of anyone who causes stasis. The damiorgoi were to put them on trial, and choose men (presumably to act as jurors). Before taking office these men would swear an oath by the god of Olympus i.e. Zeus Olympios. If they refused to swear the oath, they would pay a fine of 5 mnas each day for sacrifices to Zeus Olympios. The text of lines 9-12 is as follows: ὀμόσαντες πο<τ> τὸν θεὸν τὸν Ὀλύν[πιον· αἰ δέ τις μὲ ὀμόσαιτο, πέντε μνᾶ]ς κ’ ἀποτίνοι τᾶς ἀμέρας κατ(τ)θυτὰς τοῖ Δὶ Ὀλυ[νπίοι·].

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he has not wronged his father or his mother]
 μῶν μή τι ἠδίκηκας τὸν πατέρα ἢ τὴν μητέρα; Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε, ἔφη.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Androtion
statement:
[That they will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, they shall help with all their strength]
 Ἐμμενῶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ἃς βασιλεὺς κατέπεμψε καὶ τοῖς ψηφίσμασι τοῖς Ἀθηναίων καὶ τῶν συμμάχων. ἐὰν δέ τις στρατεύῃ ἐπί τινα πόλιν τῶν ὀμοσασῶν τόνδε τὸν ὅρκον, βοηθήσω παντὶ σθένει
remarks:
Diodorus reminds the Athenians that they obtained a peace on their own terms because of the strength of their fleet. 
This is a very misleading statement; though, in respect of this and other passages, one could say that the King's Peace looked very much better to Athenians in retrospect than it did at the time. 
For other references to the common peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the gown has a nice smell of willy]
  Νὴ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην, ἡδύ γ’ ὄζει ποσθίου.
remarks: The smell comes from the fact that, although it is a woman's gown, Agathon is the one who wears it. Swearing by Aphrodite is nearly always a woman's oath (cf. oath id 791), and it is noteworthy here that the Inlaw invokes the goddess as he is putting on women's clothes.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
