According to Thucydides, after the Spartans managed to send a force of hoplites to bolster Epidaurus against the forthcoming Argive attack in the following summer, the Argives sent envoys to Athens to complain that the Athenians had permitted the Spartans to go past their territory by sea (i.e. to sail past Aegina), which they claimed was a violation of the clause in their treaty that they would not allow enemies to pass through their territory. 
The Argives added that they would feel aggrieved unless they should bring the Messenians and helots to Pylos to annoy the Spartans. 
As a result of this Alcibiades convinced the Athenians to inscribe at the bottom of the peace-treaty stele that the Spartans had not kept their oaths (i.e. for the Peace of Nicias) and to take a force of Messenian helots to Pylos to ravage Spartan-controlled territory. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Cephallenia under the auspices of the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
The decree indicates that three or five Athenians were to be chosen to receive the oaths of the new allies (see also oath id 355 and 356). For the oath of the Athenians see oath id 353. For the oath of the existing allies of Athens see oath id 354. 
For other references to the Second Athenian Confederacy see oath id 2974.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that immediately after the Eleans became allies of Argos (see oath id 1697), the Corinthians and the Chalcidians in Thrace (see oath id 1699) also became allies of Argos. 
For other references to this alliance and its impact see oath id 1700 and 1726.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Hermes
impact: Apollo cannot reveal what he knows to Hermes
statement:
[That none of the gods but Apollo shall know the complex design of Zeus]
 αὐτὰρ ἐγώ γε 
πιστωθεὶς κατένευσα καὶ ὤμοσα καρτερὸν ὅρκον
μή τινα νόσφιν ἐμεῖο θεῶν αἰειγενετάων 
ἄλλον γ’ εἴσεσθαι Ζηνὸς πυκινόφρονα βουλήν.
remarks: The oath is described as "powerful" (καρτερὸν).

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker refers to the oaths of reconciliation, citing the law proposed by Archinus which stipulated that if anyone should commence a lawsuit in violation of the oaths of the amnesty, the defendant should be able to enter a plea of exception (paragraphe), the magistrate should submit this question to the tribunal, the defendant should speak first, and the loser should pay a penalty of one-sixth of the sum at stake. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Aeneas son of Ocytus; Amphias son of Eupalidas; Athenaeus, son of Pericleidas; Autocles, son of Tolmaeus; Damotimus son of Naucrates; Euphamidas son of Aristonymus; Menecrates son of Amphidorus; Nicasus, son of Cecalus; Nicias; Nicostratus; Onasimus, son of Megacles; Philocharidas; Taurus son of Echetimidas
swearee: Aeneas son of Ocytus; Amphias son of Eupalidas; Athenaeus, son of Pericleidas; Autocles, son of Tolmaeus; Damotimus son of Naucrates; Euphamidas son of Aristonymus; Menecrates son of Amphidorus; Nicasus, son of Cecalus; Nicias; Nicostratus; Onasimus, son of Megacles; Philocharidas; Taurus son of Echetimidas
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Free access to the oracle at Delphi (the Spartans promised to try to persuade the Boeotians and Phocians about this)
2. Those who had misused the treasures at Delphi were to be sought out
3. Each side should retain what territory it currently possessed (the Athenian garrison at Pylos should keep within the coastal high points Buphras and Tomaeus; the Athenian garrison in Cythera should have no communication with the territory of the Spartan allies; the Athenian garrison in Nisaea and Minoa should not cross the roads leading to the mainland and the Megarians should not cross it either; the Athenians should retain the island [Atalante?] which they took and neither side shall communicate with the other; the Athenians should retain whatever territory they possessed in Troezen in accordance with the agreements which the Troezenians had made with the Athenians)
4. The Spartans and their allies were not permitted to sail in oared ships except along their own coasts, and then only in vessels of less than 500 metra capacity not designed for use in war 
5. Deserters should not be received
6. Any disputes should be resolved by arbitration]
remarks:
When the city of Scione revolted from Athens, the Athenians and the Spartans were in dispute over whether the city had revolted before or after the one-year armistice had been made. 
For other references to this oath and its impact, see oath id 1676.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
if_refused: Peisetaerus will not reveal his plan
if_kept: The chorus will be judged victorious by all the judges and the audience
if_broken: The chorus will win by just one vote
impact: Peisetaerus disarms and reveals his plan
statement:
[That the Chorus will not bite Peisetaerus nor pull at his balls, nor poke him in the eyes ]
 ἥνπερ ὁ πίθηκος τῇ γυναικὶ διέθετο, 
 ὁ μαχαιροποιός, μήτε δάκνειν τούτους ἐμὲ
 μήτ’ ὀρχίπεδ’ ἕλκειν μήτ’ ὀρύττειν—
{ΕΥ.}  Οὔ τί που 
  τόνδ’;
 {ΠΙ.}  Οὐδαμῶς. Οὔκ, ἀλλὰ τὠφθαλμὼ λέγω. 
{ΧΟ.}  Διατίθεμαι ’γώ.
 {ΠΙ.}  Κατόμοσόν νυν ταῦτά μοι. 
 {ΧΟ.}  Ὄμνυμ’ ἐπὶ τούτοις, πᾶσι νικᾶν τοῖς κριταῖς  
  καὶ τοῖς θεαταῖς πᾶσιν, —
{ΠΙ.}  Ἔσται ταυταγί.  
{ΧΟ.} εἰ δὲ παραβαίην, ἑνὶ κριτῇ νικᾶν μόνον.
remarks: In the terms and conditions of this oath, the Chorus-leader is clearly referring to the competitive nature of comic performances in Athens. Note that the rewards and penalties specified are designed to make it impossible for the play not to be victorious - the worst penalty for breaking the oath will be to win by just one vote. The plan which Peisetaerus will reveal is for the creation of a bird city in the sky, endorsed by Tereus at 194-195; cf. oath id 635.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Emphasises the desire for a settlement
statement:
[That Lysistrata should be summoned as the only person who can make a settlement between them]
  Τί οὐ καλοῦμεν δῆτα τὴν Λυσιστράτην, 
  ἥπερ διαλλάξειεν ἡμᾶς ἂν μόνη; 
  {ΛΑ.}  Ναὶ τὼ σιώ
remarks: Swearing by the Dioscuri is typically Spartan. Cf. oath id 1216 with cross references.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
if_refused: Orestes' testimony will not be believed
statement: [That Orestes did not kill his mother]
remarks: Sommerstein ad loc. explains: 'At the opening of an Athenian homicide trial, the accuser had to make oath that the defendant had committed the homicide, the defendant (normally) that he had not… If either party refused to swear, he automatically lost the case. Here Orestes clearly cannot swear that he did not kill his mother; the Erinyes claim that this automatically proves him guilty and punishable, without there being any room for argument…about compulsion or justification'.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Pheidippides will not be allowed to live there (sc. if he refuses to become a student)
 οὔτοι μὰ τὴν Ὁμίχλην ἔτ’ ἐνταυθοῖ μενεῖς
remarks: Circumstances for keeping oath do not arise.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
statement: [?That they will scrutinise the laws honestly in accordance with the best interests of the Athenian people]
remarks:
Andocides cites the decree of Teisamenus which states that "the laws being handed over are to be examined by the boule and the five hundred nomothetai elected by the demesmen, after they have taken the oath". 
This is a special panel of nomothetai elected directly by the demesmen, as opposed to the regular nomothetai appointed by lot from those who have already taken the heliastic oath (if indeed these already existed in 403). 
We do not know what oath this special panel took, but it is unlikely to have been the heliastic oath, since they were elected as scrutineers of legislation, not as judges.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
if_taken: They would have been allowed to proceed with charges
if_refused: They would not have been allowed to proceed with charges
statement:
[That Socrates commits injustice and is meddlesome, investigating things beneath the earth and in the heavens, and that he makes the weaker argument the stronger and teaches these things to others]
 ὥσπερ οὖν κατηγόρων τὴν ἀντωμοσίαν δεῖ ἀναγνῶναι αὐτῶν· “Σωκράτης ἀδικεῖ καὶ περιεργάζεται ζητῶν τά τε ὑπὸ γῆς καὶ οὐράνια καὶ τὸν ἥττω λόγον κρείττω ποιῶν καὶ ἄλλους ταὐτὰ ταῦτα διδάσκων.”
remarks: Unlike oath id 2777, this is not an antomosia sworn by Socrates’ actual prosecutors; it is what those who have long slandered him (Aristophanes and many anonymous others) would have sworn if they had ever tried to prosecute him.

title: IC IV
statement: [That he was innocent]
remarks:
Evidently both parties were challenged to swear to the truth of their respective contentions; whoever refused to swear ipso facto lost the case; and if both swore, the man was deemed guilty.   
This would not, of course, mean, as it usually does now, that he was claiming the woman had consented; he would be claiming either [i] that intercourse had not taken place at all or [ii] that it wasn't him, guv. 
See also oath id 1096.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Onetor 2
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [That the dowry was worth 80 minae]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that Onetor would have sworn a false oath about his relationship with Aphobus had he been required to swear one. 
He states that Onetor had said that the dowry was 80 minas, and wonders what would have happened if he had been allowed to recover it on condition that he swore that this was true. Demosthenes asks how Onetor could deny that he would have sworn then since he is offering to swear an oath now. Demosthenes argues that this means that Onetor is proving that he would have committed perjury, for he now says that the sum he gave as a dowry was not 80 minas, but a talent (i.e. 60 minas). According to Demosthenes, there is no reason to believe that Onetor is perjuring himself in one statement rather than the other, and asks what opinion one should have of a man such as Onetor who so readily convicts himself of perjury.

author: Anonymus Tragicus
title: Fragment 71
statement: unknown
remarks: Someone here invokes Zeus Herkeios with the same formula as oath id 1267.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Indicates that Aeschylus is now winning this argument
statement:
[That a man who is an exile both returns and remigrates]
  φεύγων δ’ ἀνὴρ ἥκει τε καὶ κατέρχεται.
  ΔΙ.  Εὖ νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω
remarks: Aeschylus here rebuts Euripides' statement which had originally convinced Dionysus, who responded with an informal oath at id 494. The fact that Dionysus swears by Apollo here, as opposed to the more frequently invoked deity Zeus (called on in oath id 494), emphasizes Dionysus' turnabout in opinion. Swearing by Apollo is more emphatic in comedy than swearing by Zeus. But see also oath id 505, where Euripides trumps Aeschylus and Dionysus swears by Hermes.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That he does like the statement they have come to: 'beauty is not good nor good beauty']
 Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Ἱππία·
remarks: See oath id 3161 for context.

title: ICS
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: All that can be determined from this document in Cypriot syllabary is that an oath was sworn. This text is unusual in that it seems to read μὰ ναὶ instead of ναί μα.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
if_taken: They can compete freely for Helen's hand
if_refused: Exclusion from the competition for Helen's hand
statement: [That they would support whoever became Helen's husband should someone take her from the house, that they would all march against him and sack his city with force of arms, be he Greek or Asiatic]
remarks: Cf. oath ids 182, 184, 185.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus tells the jurors that if two litigants cited two inconsistent laws to claim their vote they would not be able to give judgement in favour of both, nor would they be able to vote for either without breaking their oath, because this would mean contravening the opposite law which is equally valid. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of [cities?] from Thrace?; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of other Greek states
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace (?) and neither break the agreement with Philip (?) nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?) neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, from any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?) and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?) as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon...]
 [ὀμνύω (?) Δία, Γῆν, Ἥλιον, Ποσ]ειδῶ, Ἀ̣[θηνᾶν, Ἄρη, θεοὺς πάντας καὶ πάσα]ς̣ ἐμμενῶ [ἐν τῆι εἰρήνηι· (?) καὶ οὔτε τὰς σ]υνθήκας τὰ̣[ς πρὸς Φίλιππον καταλύσω, (?)· οὔτ]ε ὅπλα̣ ἐπ̣οί[σω ἐπὶ πημονῆι ἐπ’ οὐθένα τῶν] ἐ̣μ̣μ̣ενόντων ἐν τ[οῖς ὅρκοις (?) οὔτε κατὰ γῆν] οὔτε κατὰ θάλασ[σαν· οὐδὲ πόλιν οὐδὲ φρο]ύ̣ριον καταλήψομ[αι οὐδὲ λιμένα ἐπὶ πολέ]μωι οὐθενὸς τῶν τ[ῆς εἰρήνης κοινωνούντ]ων τέχνηι οὐδεμι[ᾶι οὐδὲ μηχανῆι· οὐδὲ τ]ὴ̣ν βασιλείαν [τ]ὴν Φ[ίλιππου καὶ τῶν ἐκγόν]ων καταλύσω, ὀδὲ τὰ[ς πολιτείας τὰς οὔσας] παρ’ ἑκάστοις ὅτε τ[οὺς ὅρκους τοὺς περὶ τῆ]ς εἰρήνης ὤμνυον· [οὐδ’ αὐτὸς οὐθὲν ὑπενα]ν̣τίον ταῖσδε ταῖς [συνθήκαις ποήσω οὐδ’ ἄλ]λ̣ωι ἐπιτρέψω εἰς [δύναμιν. ἂν δέ τις ποῆι τι] παράσπονδον πε[ρὶ τὰς συνθήκας, βοηθήσω] καθότι ἂν παραγ[γέλωσιν οἱ ἀδικούμενοι (?)], καὶ πολεμήσω τῶ[ι τὴν κοινὴν εἰρήνην (?) παρ]αβαίνοντι καθότι [ἂν δοκῆι τῶι  κοινῶι συνεδ]ρ̣ίωι καὶ  ὁ ἡγεμ̣ὼ[ν παραγγέλληι, καὶ  οὐκ ἐγκ]α̣ταλείψω το̣[..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The text of the "League of Corinth" treaty followed here is Rhodes and Osborne, GHI, 76. The text of this inscription is very fragmentary and subject to debate. 
There are two fragments: 
Fragment A includes the actual oath; 
Fragment B is a (fragmentary) list of the poleis included in the peace. 
See also oath id 2719, 2757, 3316, 3317, 3318, 3319, 3320, 3321, 3322, 3324, 3325, 3326, 3327, 3328, 3329, 3330, 3389, 3721.

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and they wouldl lead them back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they did not furnish them with a market they would allow them to take provisions from the country]
remarks:
Isocrates argues that the Persians found themselves so inferior to the Ten Thousand that the King did not scruple to arrest the captains of the Greeks in violation of the truce, hoping by this lawless act to throw their army into confusion, and preferring to offend against the gods rather than openly fight the Greeks. 
See also oath id 2098.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That the best thing for Wealth is for him to stay in the temple of Asclepius]
 κατακλίνειν αὐτὸν εἰς Ἀσκληπιοῦ
  κράτιστόν ἐστι. 
  {ΒΛ.}  Πολὺ μὲν οὖν, νὴ τοὺς θεούς.
remarks: This is because there are no doctors in Athens- see remarks on oath id 789.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Callias should not envy Antisthenes' wealth (because Niceratus is about to ask Antisthenes for a loan)]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Νικήρατος, μὴ ζήλου
remarks: The “loan” for which Niceratus is going to ask Antisthenes is that of the ability to be satisfied with what he has.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines asks the jurors whether it is right for those who have not been wronged but are wronging the city to punish those who supported the peace, while the jurors themselves, who benefit from the peace desert the men who served the public so well. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the lifetime of Herodotus ca.484 to ca.415 (484 to 415)
statement: n/a
remarks:
Herodotus observes that the Thracian basileis (unlike the rest of the Thracians) worshipped Hermes above all gods and swore oaths only by him. They did so partly because they claimed Hermes as their ancestor. 
Herodotus states that the rest of the Thracians worshipped only Ares, Dionysus and Artemis.

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Megalopolitans
statement:
[That he has not been prompted by private friendship or personal enmity for either side i.e. the Spartans or the Megalopolitans (but has said what he considers best for the Athenians)]
 Ἐγὼ μὲν οὖν, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὔτε φιλῶν οὐδετέρους οὔτε μισῶν ἰδίᾳ εἴρηκα, ἀλλ’ ἃ νομίζω συμφέρειν ὑμῖν·

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Eretria. 
The decree states that the representatives of each polis will swear their "traditional oath". 
For the oath of the Eretrians see oath id 301.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That as allies they would be forever guileless and reliable to each other]
remarks:
Thucydides notes that the Athenians invaded Sicily in 415 on the pretext that they were succouring their old allies.  
The Egestans are said to have appealed strongly for Athenian assistance and reminded the Athenians of their alliance with the Leontines "in the time of Laches" and the former war because they had got themselves into a war with the neighbouring Selinuntians who were bringing in the Syracusans as allies and pressing them hard on land and at sea. 
This alliance is presumably a renewal of the alliance from 433 preserved in IG I(3) 54 (see oath id 166-7) and mentioned by Thucydides (see oath id 1662). 
For other references to the alliances between Athens and Leontini see oath id 1766 and 1770.

title: IG I(3)
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They can not take office in the boule
remarks:
Lines 26-34 are thought to be part of the bouleutic oath. Rhodes, The Athenian Boule, (Oxford 1972), pp 195-6 discusses these lines in detail. He notes that "we seem to be in the middle of an oath, with the verb ἐπιψηφίζω in the frist person singular and οὐ for negative. But from line 29 onwards we have verbs in the infinitive and μή to indicate negation: there are references to the boule of the five hundred and the bouleuterium, and perhaps to the sum of 500 drachmae". 
These lines have been restored as follows: 
[- - - οὐκ ἐπιφς]εφιω̃ ἐμ [β]ολ̣ε̃ι: οὔ[τ]’ ἐ̣[ν ἐ]κ̣[κλεσίαι] α[- - - - -] 
[- - - ἐὰν δὲ ἐπιφς]εφίζο τ[..]μ̣ος[…]ο̣[- - - - - - - - -] 
[- - - μέτε δεμ]οσίον μέτε [ἰδ]ίον [- - - - - - - - - - - -] 
[- - - - - - -] βολεύεν [τ]ὸ[ς] πεντακ[οσί]ο[ς - - - - -] 
[- - - - - - πε]ν̣τ̣ακοσι[..] δραχ̣μ̣[- - - - - - - - - - - - -] 
[- - - μέχρι πεντακοσί]ον δρ[α]χμ[ο̃ν], πλέον δὲ μ̣ὲ ᾽ε̣̃ν̣αι ἐ̣π̣[ιβαλλεν - -] 
[- - - - - - -]ον ἐν το̃ι βολευτερίοι τὲν βο[λὲν - - - - - - -] 
[- - - - - - - -]ν : 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That she is not Proteus' daughter Theonoe]
  Αὕτη Θεονόη Πρωτέως. 
  {ΚΡ.}  Μὰ τὼ θεώ
remarks: This passage is part of the extended parody of Euripides' 'Helen'. See also oath ids 747 and 748. On swearing by the two goddesses see oath id 713.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
statement: [? That the evidence he gave was true]
remarks:
The prosecutor claims that Demosthenes is liable to all the curses known to the city, having broken the oaths he took on the Areopagus, in the names of the Semnai Theai and the other gods by whom it is customary to swear, and making himself accursed at every sitting of the Assembly. 
The prosecutor goes on to argue that if there is any power to exact a just punishment from perjurers and criminals (which he naturally argues there is) then Demosthenes shall pay.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he doesn't think his opinion is contrary to what Socrates has said about Justice (that lawful and just are the same thing)]
 καὶ ὁ Ἱππίας, Ἀλλὰ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὔ μοι δοκῶ τἀναντία γιγνώσκειν οἷς εἴρηκας περὶ  τοῦ δικαίου.

author: Sophocles
title: Antigone
statement:
[That he would not keep his peace if he saw destruction threatening his citizens nor would he count as a friend someone who was an enemy of the land]
 ἐγὼ γάρ, ἴστω Ζεὺς ὁ πάνθ’ ὁρῶν ἀεί,
οὔτ’ ἂν σιωπήσαιμι τὴν ἄτην ὁρῶν  
στείχουσαν ἀστοῖς ἀντὶ τῆς σωτηρίας,
οὔτ’ ἂν φίλον ποτ’ ἄνδρα δυσμενῆ χθονὸς
θείμην ἐμαυτῷ

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That they would abide by such laws as Solon should make for ten years]
 ὁρκίοισι γὰρ μεγάλοισι κατείχοντο δέκα ἔτεα χρήσεσθαι νόμοισι τοὺς ἄν σφι Σόλων θῆται
remarks:
Herodotus describes how Solon changed the laws of Athens and compelled the Athenians to swear to abide by the new laws for ten years. 
Presumably Solon enacted these laws when he served as archon in 594/3. 
Herodotus notes that Solon left Athens so that the Athenians could not compel him to change the laws himself.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
remarks: On the pun "porker", see also oath ids 611-615 and 617.  There is another pun too:  Dicaeopolis' question merely means "are they weaned?", but in the Megarian's reply "without" means "without the permission of".

author: Aristotle
title: Politics
statement:
[That it is just for the poor, if they are the majority in a city, to seize and redistribute the wealth of the rich because that was the decision of the rightful rulers, and the decision of the rightful rulers is [apparently by definition] just. See also remarks]
 ἂν οἱ πένητες διὰ τὸ
πλείους εἶναι διανέμωνται τὰ τῶν πλουσίων, τοῦτ’ οὐκ ἄδικόν 
ἐστιν; “ἔδοξε γὰρ νὴ Δία τῷ κυρίῳ δικαίως.”
remarks:
Aristotle is not making this statement in his own person; the speaking voice here is that of a hypothetical defender of the thesis that the majority have the right to rule; in other words, we have here the familiar use of νὴ Δία to introduce an imaginary objector’s words. The argument (1281a14-21) runs thus, if one puts it, so to speak, into Socratic form: 
 
	Aristotle:  Is it just for the poor, if they are the majority in a city, to seize and redistribute the wealth of the rich? 
	Majoritarian:  Yes (by Zeus), because that was the decision of the rightful rulers, and the decision of the rightful rulers is [apparently by definition] just. 
	Aristotle:  Is justice a virtue? 
	Majoritarian:  Of course. 
	Aristotle:  Can virtue ever ruin its possessor? 
	Majoritarian:  No. 
	Aristotle:  Do you think the city is likely to survive as a cohesive community, if the wealth of the rich is seized in this way? 
	Majoritarian:  Quite likely not. 
	Aristotle:  And will its destruction be the ruin of rich and poor alike? 
	Majoritarian:  I suppose so. 
	Aristotle:  But in that case, according to your own statement, the poor, in causing their own ruin, cannot have been acting justly? 
 
The Statement, taken literally, seems to assume what has to be proved (viz. that the action is just), but this is probably merely due to Aristotle's compressed style.  The chapter proceeds to consider various other possible answers to the question “who has the right to rule?”, and by the end of it we have found that any ruling authority (whether the many, the few, the one, or even the law) may commit unjust acts.  It must follow (though, typically, Aristotle’s text does not spell this out) that the proposition “The decision of the rightful rulers is just” is false; in other words, that no person, group or institution can be said to have the right to rule (to be kyrion, in Aristotle’s terminology) if by that is meant the right to enforce their will, whatever it may be, on the community as a whole.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Apollodorus
if_taken: They could take part in the proceedings
if_refused: They could not take part in the proceedings
statement: [That they would register only people who were of full age, whose fathers were members of the deme, and whose mothers were citizens]
remarks: The speaker Thrasyllus claims that the demesmen took the oath over the sacrificial victims and registered his name as a member of the deme in accordance with Apollodorus' orders. He stresses that they did so in spite of his opponents' claims that Apollodorus had not adopted him as his son.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Aphrodite struck Euripides down]
 ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ σοί τοι καὶ τοῖς σοῖσιν πολλὴ πολλοῦ ’πικαθῆτο, 
ὥστε γε καὐτόν σε κατ’ οὖν ἔβαλεν. 
ΔΙ.  Νὴ τὸν Δία τοῦτό γέ τοι δή
remarks: The statement alludes to the alleged scandal of Cephisophon seducing Euripides' wife. See further Sommerstein ad 944 and 1046, and his article in Leeds International Classical Studies (electronic) 3.1 (2003/4) (http://www.leeds.ac.uk/classics/lics).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That Androtion was a good manager of his sister]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία τὴν ἀδελφὴν καλῶς διῴκηκεν
remarks: Diodorus imagines that someone will object in this way to his description of Androtion's relations with his family. He goes on to allege that Androtion, far from treating his sister properly, gave her in marriage to a foreigner.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
if_broken: Destruction of Demosthenes and his sister
statement:
[That Demosthenes' father had set Milyas free when he was about to die and that he was regarded by the family as free]
 τὸν ἄνθρωπον τοῦτον ἀφεῖναι τὸν πατέρ’ ἡνίκ’ ἐτελεύτα, καὶ νομίζεσθαι παρ’ ἡμῖν τοῦτον ἐλεύθερον·
remarks: Demosthenes tells the jurors that he was willing to hand over his female slaves to testify under torture that his father had freed Milyas on his death-bed, and that his mother (Cleobule) was willing to call himself and his sister to her (her only children), and pledge by them that Milyas was set free by his father when he was dying and was regarded in their family as free. He argues that none of the jurors would suppose that she would have been willing to swear this "by us" unless she was certain that what she would be swearing was true.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That although the Persians are insatiable of blood, she will give them their fill of it]
 ἥλιον ἐπόμνυμί τοι τὸν ασσαγετέων δεσπότην, ἦ μέν σε ἐγὼ καὶ ἄπληστον ἐόντα αἵματος κορέσω.
remarks:
According to Herodotus, Queen Tomyris sends a herald to Cyrus requesting that he return her son to her and depart unpunished from the country of the Massagetae. She argues that it is enough that Cyrus has slain a third of the Massagetae. Her message ends with an oath that if Cyrus does not do as she requests she will give him his fill of blood. 
When Cyrus refuses to comply, Tomyris gathers together her forces and attacks Cyrus. The Persian army is defeated, and Cyrus is slain. Tomyris fills a skin with human blood, and put Cyrus' head into the skin with the words, "as I threatened, so I will do, and give you your fill of blood".

author: Hypereides
title: In defence of Euxenippus
statement:
[That Euxenippus has no right to be supported by anyone]
 Εὐξενίππῳ δ’ ὅτι ἰδιώτης ἐστὶ καὶ πρεσβύτερος οὐδὲ τοὺς φίλους καὶ τοὺς οἰκείους ἐξέσται βοηθεῖν, εἰ δὲ μή, διαβληθήσονται ὑπὸ σοῦ; νὴ Δία·
remarks: Hypereides asks rhetorically whether Euxenippus is to not even have the right of help from his friends and family without their being slandered by Polyeuctus, and puts into his mouth the reply "That's right, by Zeus, because what he has done is appalling and deserves to be punished by death".

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That there are no identifiable doctors in Athens]
  Τίς δῆτ’ ἰατρός ἐστι νῦν ἐν τῇ πόλει;
  Οὔτε γὰρ ὁ μισθὸς οὐδέν ἐστ’ οὔθ’ ἡ τέχνη.
  {ΒΛ.}  Σκοπῶμεν. 
  {ΧΡ.}  Ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἔστιν.  
  {ΒΛ.}  Οὐδ’ ἐμοὶ δοκεῖ. 
  {ΧΡ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: Sommerstein ad 408 comments: "It is not to be supposed that Athens was devoid of medical practitioners…; the reference is to public physicians, outstanding members of the profession who were employed by the states, at very high salaries… to give free treatment to all citizens".

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
According to Xenophon, when Sparta's enemies sent embassies desiring peace, Agesilaus would not grant them peace (i.e. the King's Peace) until Corinth and Thebes agreed to restore to their homes the citizens who had been exiled on account of their sympathy with the Spartans. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That if his troops were well prepared he thinks it would be wise to engage the enemy as quickly as possible if he expected to gain some advantage by it]
  Ὁπότε δέ, ὦ πάτερ, σοι ἤδη ἔχοιεν μὲν τὰ ἐπιτήδεια οἱ στρατιῶται, ὑγιαίνοιεν δέ, πονεῖν δὲ δύναιντο, τὰς δὲ πολεμικὰς τέχνας ἠσκηκότες εἶεν, φιλοτίμως δ’ ἔχοιεν πρὸς τὸ ἀγαθοὶ φαίνεσθαι, τὸ δὲ πείθεσθαι αὐτοῖς ἥδιον εἴη τοῦ ἀπειθεῖν, οὐκ ἂν τηνικαῦτα σωφρονεῖν ἄν τίς σοι δοκοίη διαγωνίζεσθαι βουλόμενος πρὸς τοὺς πολεμίους ὡς τάχιστα; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, εἰ μέλλοι γε πλέον ἕξειν·

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he thought that the Athenians were clever and that the original version of Clouds was his best comedy]
 ὦ θεώμενοι, κατερῶ πρὸς ὑμᾶς ἐλευθέρως
  τἀληθῆ, νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον τὸν ἐκθρέψαντά με.
  οὕτω νικήσαιμί τ’ ἐγὼ καὶ νομιζοίμην σοφὸς 
  ὡς ὑμᾶς ἡγούμενος εἶναι θεατὰς δεξιοὺς
  καὶ ταύτην σοφώτατ’ ἔχειν τῶν ἐμῶν κωμῳδιῶν
  πρώτους ἠξίωσ’ ἀναγεῦσ’ ὑμᾶς, ἣ παρέσχε μοι
  ἔργον πλεῖστον·
remarks: The swearees never heard the oath (the revised play was not produced).

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: they remained at peace through the winter
statement: [? That they would not attack the other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that Dercylidas offered Pharnabazus a truce in order that he might avoid being a burden to his allies by wintering in their territory. 
Dercylidas then wintered in Bithynian Thrace and plundered the land.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
statement: [That Phalaecus and his men would be allowed to depart in safety wherever they pleased if the Phocians agreed to demolish their city walls]
remarks:
Aeschines claims that after Phalaecus made terms with Philip and departed, he (Aeschines) pleaded for the lives of those Phocians who had not been guilty of sacrilege. 
See also oath id 2624.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That objects which are dissimilar can nevertheless be called beautiful if they are well made for their respective functions]
 Καὶ πῶς, ἔφη, οἷόν τε ταῦτα μηδὲν ὅμοια ὄντα ἀλλήλοις πάντα καλὰ εἶναι; Ἂν νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, πρὸς τὰ ἔργα ὧν ἕνεκα ἕκαστα κτώμεθα εὖ εἰργασμένα ᾖ ἢ εὖ πεφυκότα πρὸς ἃ ἂν δεώμεθα, καὶ ταῦτ’, ἔφη ὁ Κριτόβουλος, καλά.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That they are not there for his good since they will be dining at his expense]
  Ἀπὸ τῶν ἐμῶν γὰρ ναὶ μὰ Δία δειπνήσετον.
remarks: The Informer is responding here to Carion's informal oath at 888-889- see oath id 895.

author: Plato
title: Theages
statement:
[That he would not know to whom he might send a son who refused to be taught from those skilled in the art he wished to learn]
 ἔχοις ἂν αὐτῷ ὅτι χρῷο καὶ ὅποι πέμποις ἄλλοσε μὴ ἐθέλοντα παρὰ τούτων μανθάνειν;  {ΘΕ.} Μὰ Δία οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That he would not attack Charidemus as he withdrew]
remarks:
Euthycles states that Charidemus crossed from Asia to the Chersonese without Athenian authority, "because of the truce". 
See also oath id 3465.

author: Euripides
title: Polyidos
statement: n/a
remarks: <Polyidos> tells Minos (?) he ought to suppose the gods are merciful if someone wishes to escape death or some other misery by using an oath.

author: Hesiod
title: Theogony
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a reference to Horkos (Oath), the child of Eris (Strife), who is said to do more damage to men than any other, when anyone willingly swears a false oath. West remarks ad loc.: "An oath is by origin a curse which a man lays upon himself, to take effect if what he declares is false. The god Horkos is the personification of this curse; that is why he is attended by the Erinyes in Op. 803". See also remarks on oath id 1302.

title: IG IX, 1(2)
statement:
[That they would not deliberately distance themselves from the Opuntians with any pretext or device of their own free will]
 ἔνορϞον τοῖς ἐπιϜοίϞοις ἐν Ναύπακτον… μὲ 'ποστᾶμεν… ἀ<π' Ὀ>ποντίον τέκναι καὶ μαχανᾶι… μεδὲ μιᾶι… ϜεϞόντας;
remarks:
Thirty years earlier at the time of the foundation of the Locrian colony at Naupactus the new colonists swore an oath of allegiance to Opus. It was stipulated that the oath could be repeated if they desired in thirty years time. The oath would be administered by one hundred men of the Naupactians to the Opuntians, and 100 men of the Opuntians to the Naupactians.  
For the oath sworn by the Opuntians see oath id 749. For the earlier oath see oath id 716.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Catanaeans voted to make an alliance with the Athenians, and asked them to bring the rest of their army from Rhegium.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: This oath is recounted in detail at oath id 318. Here Paris suggests the oath to Hector who then proposes it to Menelaus (3.73 = 3.94, cf. oath id 317). The oath is true in that peace is made, but the oath is subsequently broken by the Trojan ally Pandarus through the intervention of Athena (see also oath ids 322-326). Aristotle discusses both the oath and the manner in which it is broken in Aporematon Homericon (see oath ids 1999, 2000, 2002). In Plato's Republic, the passage is rejected as unsuitable material for the members of the ideal state because it presents the gods as instigating the violation of the oaths (see oath id 2540).

author: Pindar
title: Paean 6
statement: unknown
remarks: This is a reference to the god's oath by Styx. The text is too fragmentary to reveal anything further.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement: n/a
remarks:
Thucydides observes that when stasis afflicted the Greek world there was no promise that could be depended upon, and no oath frightening enough to reconcile men. 
At this point Thucydides is referring in particular to Corcyra. For the oath of reconciliation between the oligarchs and the democrats at Corcyra see oath id 1630.  
For another discussion of oaths in the time of stasis see oath id 1635.

author: Plato
title: Philebus
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Protarchus discusses the nature of pleasure and concludes that it is completely destitute of reason which is supported by the fact that, among other things, even perjury committed by a person in love is forgiven by the gods. The lover's oath was proverbially worthless. Cf. oath ids 2921, 2925, and 1307 and compare also oath id 363. It is interesting that Protarchus doesn’t actually answer Socrates’ question, which was not “How closely is pleasure akin to reason?” but “Which is more closely akin to truth – pleasure or reason?”  But this is to be regarded merely as a casual looseness of expression by Protarchus and/or Plato, since what he does say clearly implies that, in his view, whereas reason is “either identical with truth, or else resembles it more closely than anything else does”, pleasure has no necessary connection with truth at all.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: No impact (seems to be an aside)
statement:
[That Euripides doesn't yet know what trouble he brings on himself]
 Οὔτοι μὰ Δί’ οἶσθ’ οἷ’ αὐτὸς ἐργάζει κακά.
remarks: Sommerstein ad loc. interprets as follows: "Euripides cannot be aware what a tiresome bore he is in his plays, otherwise he would not dare to complain when tiresomely pestered himself".  Olson tentatively prefers to understand the statement as meaning that Euripides' plays "promote vicious behaviour and do incalculable damage to the city", comparing  Frogs 1008-12, 1043-98.

author: Aristophanes
title: Georgoi
statement:
[That he will not cheat]
εἴ γ’ ἐγκιλικίσαιμ’, ἐξολοίμην, φαθὶ λέγων

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
if_taken: The child could be admitted to the phratry
if_refused: The child could not be admitted to the phratry
if_broken: Utter destruction of both himself and his family
statement: [That he did not have, nor had he ever had any son other than Hipponicus, whose mother was Glaucon's daughter]
remarks: When describing how Callias introduced the boy to his genos (see oath id 2363), Andocides stresses that this was the same boy that Callias had previously disowned under oath (see oath id 2362).

title: IC IV
if_taken: If believed he can keep the land
statement:
[That the land in question is the property of the pledgee and not that of the pledger]
 ὀμνύμε[ν δὲ ε῏] μὰν τούτο μέν ἐστι ἀβλοπίαι δικαίος πρὶν μολέθ[θαι τὰν] δίκαν, ο῏ δ’ ἐνεκύρακσαν μὲ ἔμεν· νικε̃ν δ’ ὄτερά κ’ οἰ π̣[λίες ὀ]μόσοντι.
remarks:
The text indicates that during disputes over pledged property, the person to whom property was pledged should summon the pledger in order to mark off the land (i.e. measure it), and if the one summoned does not appear the pledgee should mark off the property himself, and warn the pledger to appear in the agora in four days time before two witnesses. They are to swear that the land in question is the property of the pledgee and not that of the pledger. 
Whoever has the most witnesses to swear on his behalf is to win the case. 
For the oath of the pledgers see oath id 986. 
For an almost identical text see oath id 994.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that if Philip accepted the Phocians as allies of Athens and swore oaths to them (see oath id 3823), he would have violated his oaths to the Thessalians (see oath id 3825) and the Thebans. 
Demosthenes claims that Philip swore "to assist the Thebans in taking control of Boeotia". This is presumably rhetorical exaggeration. Cf. MacDowell ad loc.
See also oath id 3878, 3880, 3883.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: n/a
remarks: Because those who are willing to commit perjury are at an advantage in legal trials, oaths are banned from the proceedings, not only at the opening of the trial (see oath id 2728), but at any point during it:  except in suits between foreigners, no one is to be allowed to use an oath to bolster the credibility of a statement.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Spartans decided that the treaty had been broken and consulted the oracle at Delphi to see what to do. 
The god replied told them they would win the war and that he would help them whether invoked or not.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 2
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
statement: [That if Mantias should propose an oath regarding the paternity of Boeotus, she would refuse it, and that, when this had been done, all relations between them would be at an end]
remarks:
Mantitheus bemoans the fact that Plangon deceived his father into acknowledging Boeotus and Pamphilus as his sons, because it has robbed him of two thirds of his inheritance, and driven him from his family home.  
For the details of Plangon's perjury see oath id 3561.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he will not put the cloak on]
 οὐκ ἀναβαλεῖ;
 {Φι.}  μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’.
remarks: Philocleon clearly means what he says at the time, but subsequently gives in to his son, and dons the cloak at 1155.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he ardently desires to ask Socrates whether he was joking or not]
 Ἐμοὶ μὲν δοκεῖ, ὦ Καλλίκλεις, ὑπερφυῶς σπουδάζειν· οὐδὲν μέντοι οἷον τὸ αὐτὸν ἐρωτᾶν.  {ΚΑΛ.} Νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς ἀλλ’ ἐπιθυμῶ.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Androtion
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus tells the jurors that they have to decide what value they put on their constitution, the laws and their oath. He 
warns them that if they acquit Androtion everyone will conclude that they prefer the sum of money that Androtion has brought in by collecting unpaid taxes to the laws and to keeping their oaths. 
Diodorus then asks them to remember their oath, and to reflect that the indictment concerns not the collection of taxes, but the sovereignty of the laws. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Euripides was not stoned for taking hold of Aeschylus' tragedy throne]
  κἄπειτ’ ἐπαρθεὶς ἀντελάβετο τοῦ θρόνου,
  ἵν’ Αἰσχύλος καθῆστο.
ΞΑ.  Κοὐκ ἐβάλλετο;  
  ΟΙ.  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: The idea here is that Euripides is mad (see Sommerstein ad 778). See Sommerstein ad 738 on the identity of the slave.

author: Isaeus
title: Fragmentary Oration 3
statement:
[That if his opponent were honest he would be producing witnesses and examining the accounts in detail, not doing what he is doing now, viz. relying on slanderous arguments]
 μὴ μὰ Δία ταῦτα ποιεῖν

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That he would help Athens and with so great an army that the Athenians would say "What a swarm of locusts is coming"]
  καὶ τὸν πατέρ’ ἠντεβόλει βοηθεῖν τῇ πάτρᾳ· 
  ὁ δ’ ὤμοσε σπένδων βοηθήσειν ἔχων 
  στρατιὰν τοσαύτην ὥστ’ Ἀθηναίους ἐρεῖν· 
  «Ὅσον τὸ χρῆμα παρνόπων προσέρχεται».
remarks: This oath is reported by Theorus and its fulfillment is made clear by the presence of the Thracian soldiers on stage, though they are ridiculed by Dicaeopolis. In fact Dicaeopolis responds to the report with an oath in the form of a self-curse, swearing that he does not believe a word of what Theorus says (except for the locusts); see oath id 594.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he is not proud of being victorious]
 Οὗτός γε μήν, ἔφη τις, δῆλον ὅτι ἐπὶ τῷ νικηφόρος εἶναι. καὶ ὁ Αὐτόλυκος ἀνερυθριάσας εἶπε· Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.
remarks: This is apparently the first time anyone has induced Autolycus to say anything at all during the evening!  A moment later, when asked what he does take pride in, he sweetly replies “My father”, and leans back in his father’s lap.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest the Thebans as they departed the island]
remarks:
Aeschines reminds the jurors that the Athenians repelled a Theban invasion of Euboea at Tamynae and sent them back to the mainland under a truce. 
See also oath id 3414, 3425.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes describes how Philip was seizing Euboea to use as a base against Athens, making an attempt on Megara, seizing Oreus, razing Porthmus, bringing the Hellespont under his control, besieging Byzantium, destroying some Greek cities and restoring exiles to others, and asks the jurors whether or not Philip was violating the peace when he did so. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a general reference suggesting that men's judicial oaths can no longer be trusted. Cf. oath id 1300.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_refused: War will continue as it is
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: This oath is recounted in detail at id 318. Here Hector blames Zeus for the Troajns having broken the truce.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Theocrines
statement:
[That Demosthenes was unable to attend due to illness]
 ὡς νοσοῦντα
remarks: Epichares tells the jurors that when Theocrines once launched a graphe paranomon against Demosthenes, the latter sent someone to swear that he was unable to attend the trial due to illness. Epichares argues that this is an example of how despicable Theocrines is, since Demosthenes was going around abusing Aeschines, and Theocrines could have sworn the counter-hypomosia, but did not (see also oath id 3720).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that Alcibiades led a force to the Peloponnese to assist the Argives and their allies in settling matters "concerning the alliance" (περὶ τὴν ξυμμαχίαν). 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
if_taken: The Inlaw will put on a woman's voice
if_refused: The Inlaw will not put on a woman's voice
impact: The Inlaw finally goes off to infiltrate the Thesmophoria
statement:
[That he will save the Inlaw by hook or by crook if he finds himself in trouble]
 Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω οὔκ, ἤν γε μὴ 
  ὀμόσῃς ἐμοί— 
{ΕΥ.}  Τί χρῆμα;  
 {ΚΗ.}  συσσώσειν ἐμὲ  
  πάσαις τέχναις, ἤν μοί τι περιπίπτῃ κακόν. 
{ΕΥ.}  Ὄμνυμι τοίνυν αἰθέρ’, οἴκησιν Διός. 
{ΚΗ.}  Τί μᾶλλον ἢ τὴν Ἱπποκράτους ξυνοικίαν;
 {ΕΥ.}  Ὄμνυμι τοίνυν πάντας ἄρδην τοὺς θεούς. 
{ΚΗ.} Μέμνησο τοίνυν ταῦθ’, ὅτι ἡ φρὴν ὤμοσεν, 
  ἡ γλῶττα δ’ οὐκ ὀμώμοκ’, οὐδ’ ὥρκωσ’ ἐγώ.
remarks: Euripides' initial oath by Aither (a quotation from his own play Melanippe the Wise - see oath id 194) is rejected by the Inlaw, who evidently does not regard Aither as a real god, and Euripides substitutes a more conventional oath by "all the gods".  Being a comedy, of course, the Inlaw does get into trouble and Euripides upholds his oath by coming to his aid. In lines 275-276, the Inlaw reminds Euripides that his "heart" has sworn and not his "tongue". This, of course, is a reference to the famous line 612 from Euripides' Hippolytus, where the title character is bound by an oath of silence- see oath id 125; cf. also oath ids 376 and 514.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
if_taken: He will not have to give evidence
if_refused: He will have to give evidence
statement: [? That he did not know that he had consorted with Timarchus]
remarks:
Aeschines states that he will summon Hegesandrus to testify that he had consorted with Timarchus. But he says that he is perfectly aware that Hegesandrus will deny it under oath, and thereby perjure himself. 
The deposition is read out, and Hegesandrus denies it under oath (i.e. the exomosia when summoned to give evidence). 
Aeschines then says, "I was not unaware that Hegesandrus would show no respect for the oath, O men of Athens, I warned you in advance". 
See also oath id 2559.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
Clearchus rejected suggestions that they should leave immediately on the grounds that it would seem as if they were going away with hostile intent and acting in violation of the treaty. 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2105.

author: Aeschylus
title: Agamemnon
statement:
[That no expectation treads for her in the palace of Fear as long as Aegisthus lights the fire of her hearth]
  καὶ τήνδ’ ἀκούεις ὁρκίων ἐμῶν θέμιν·
μὰ τὴν τέλειον τῆς ἐμῆς παιδὸς Δίκην,
῎Ατην ᾿Ερινύν θ’, αἷσι τόνδ’ ἔσφαξ’ ἐγώ,
οὔ μοι φόβου μέλαθρον ἐλπὶς ἐμπατεῖ
ἕως ἂν αἴθηι πῦρ ἐφ’ ἑστίας ἐμῆς 
αἴγισθος, ὡς τὸ πρόσθεν εὖ φρονῶν ἐμοί·
remarks: Clytemnestra may believe the oath she swears at this point in the trilogy, but Fear will gnaw away at her in the second play, even while Aegisthus is still alive.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That he wants to "get among the muck good and early"]
  Ἐγὼν δὲ κοπραγωγῆν γα πρῲ ναὶ τὼ σιώ.
remarks: This is a reference to anal copulation, see Sommerstein ad loc.; swearing by the Dioscuri is typically Spartan, cf. oath id 1216 with cross references.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Demeter will not want to share out her wheat to the hungry]
 κἄπειτ’ αὐτοῖς ἡ Δημήτηρ πυροὺς πεινῶσι μετρείτω. 
 {ΕΥ.}  Οὐκ ἐθελήσει μὰ Δί’
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 581, the idea is that Demeter will withhold the food "in the manner of politicians who make promises of free or cheap distribution of corn to the public which they fulfill only in part or not at all". Euelpides' statement reflects the view, frequently adopted in comedy and as old as Hesiod, that the gods are fundamentally hostile to humanity.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Rhegians allied themselves with the Leontines because they were kin.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That he will never surrender his goods]
 ἐγὼ καταθήσω τἀμά; κακοδαίμων ἄρα 
  ἀνὴρ ἔσομαι καὶ νοῦν ὀλίγον κεκτημένος. 
  μὰ τὸν Ποσειδῶ γ’ οὐδέποτ’,

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The King shall possess what territory he currently holds as well as that held by his forefathers
2. The Spartans and the Persians will stop the Athenians from gaining any revenue from these lands
3. The Spartans and Persians will fight together against the Athenians and not stop unless both agree
4. Any subjects revolting from Persia will be enemies of Sparta and any subjects revolting from Sparta will be enemies of Persia]
remarks:
Thucydides states that when there was a meeting between Tissaphernes and the Peloponnesian forces in 412/11 at Cnidus, one of the Spartans, a certain Lichas, objected to the two treaties between Persia and Sparta on the grounds that they would allow King Darius to claim the Aegean islands, Thessaly, Locris and Boeotia as his possessions. Lichas urged them to make a better treaty. Tissaphernes was offended and left in a rage. 
For references to the three agreements between the Spartans and the Persians see oath id 1806.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement: [That he would rule according to the established nomoi; and that he would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
remarks: The Athenian here reaches the conclusion that the lawgivers in the time of Cresphontes and Temenus were not fully expert in the art of legislation, since otherwise they would hardly have deemed it sufficient to moderate by means of oaths a youthful soul endowed with power such as might develop into a tyranny. Cf. oath ids 2678-86.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
if_taken: The Nurse will divulge her secret
if_refused: The Nurse will not divulge her secret
impact: Hippolytus is bound against his will and will later be unable to clear his name
statement: [That he will not reveal what he has been told]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 125.

title: IC IV
reference: 72, Col II, line 54 - Col III, line 1
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
According to the text, if a husband and wife divorce, she is receive her own property, half the produce of her own property, half of what she has woven, and an additional five staters if her husband is the cause of the divorce. But if he should declare that he is not the cause, the judge shall decide the case under oath (τὸν δικαστὰν ὀμνύντα κρίνεν). 
See also oath id 1115.

title: IPArk
statement:
[That they would be guileless in the synoecism with the Euaemnians with regard to the agreement, by Zeus Ares, by Athena Areia, by Enyalios Ares. That they would never drive away the Euaemnians, not by Zeus Ares, not by Athena Areia, not by Enyalios Ares]
 ἀψευ̣δήων ἂν τὰν συϜο[ι]κίαν τοῖς Εὐαιμν[ί]οις πὸς τὰς συνθέ[σ]ις, νεὶ τὸν Δία τὸν Ἄ̣[ρ]ηα, νεὶ τὰν Ἀθάναν̣ τ̣ὰν Ἄρηαν, νεὶ τὸν Ἰν̣[υ]άλιον τὸν Ἄρηα· οὐ̣δ’ ἂν ἐξελαύνοια τ̣ὸς Εὐαιμνίος οὔποτ̣ε, οὐ τὸν Δία τὸν Ἄ̣[ρ]η̣α, οὐ τὰν Ἀθάναν [τ]ὰν Ἄρηαν, οὐ τὸν Ἰνυ̣άλιον τὸν Ἄρηα· κ̣εὐορ̣[κέντι] μὲν [τ]ἀγαθά, [ἐ]πιορκέντ[ι] δὲ ἐξολέσθαι κα<ὐ>τὸν καὶ γένος.
linguistic: nei tan, nei ton, ork, wmos
gods_invoked: Zeus Ares; Athena Areia; Enyalios Ares
remarks:
This text refers to the synoecism of Orchomenos and Euaemon. 
The text was originally published as IG V, 2 343.  
For the corresponding oath of the representatives of Euaemon see oath id 575.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus

[That they are in danger of leaving out the greatest good from their discussion (i.e. good fortune)]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία κινδυνεύομέν γε τὸ μέγιστον τῶν ἀγαθῶν παραλιπεῖν.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That they would leave the whole of Boeotia if they received back their prisoners]
 καὶ τὴν Βοιωτίαν ἐξέλιπον Ἀθηναῖοι πᾶσαν, σπονδὰς ποιησάμενοι  ἐφ’ ᾧ τοὺς ἄνδρας κομιοῦνται
remarks: Thucydides states that after losing the battle at Coronea the Athenians made a treaty to leave the whole of Boeotia if they received back their prisoners. He indicates that as a result of this agreement the whole of Boeotia became autonomous.

author: Aristophanes

title: Frogs

 ἀλλὰ τὰς λαγόνας σπόδει. 
  ΑΙ.  Μὰ τὸν Δί’

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That he should prefer to go without food for himself for two days than to have his men go without for one day]
 ἐγὼ δὲ νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς καὶ δεξαίμην ἂν αὐτὸς μᾶλλον δύο ἡμέρας ἄσιτος ἢ ὑμᾶς μίαν γενέσθαι·
remarks: When Teleutias was sent out to be admiral of the Spartan fleet he warned the sailors that he had no extra money to pay them, but promised to reward them if they fought well. It was then that he swore that he would rather go without food himself for two days than see them go hungry for just one.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he will make the boy howl for singing of cries of pain]
 κλαύσει νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον
  οἰμωγὰς ᾄδων
remarks: The oath does not need to be fulfilled because the boy starts to sing of things which please Trygaeus.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: There will be peace between the Armenians and Chaldaeans
statement:
[That they will be friends,  be free from one another, have the right of intermarriage and mutual tillage and pasturage in each other's territories, and have a defensive alliance in case any one should injure either party]
 Ὡς δ’ ἤκουσαν ταῦτα ἀμφότεροι, ἐπῄνεσαν καὶ ἔλεγον ὅτι οὕτως ἂν μόνως ἡ εἰρήνη βεβαία γένοιτο. καὶ ἐπὶ τούτοις ἔδοσαν καὶ ἔλαβον πάντες τὰ πιστά, καὶ ἐλευθέρους μὲν ἀμφοτέρους ἀπ’ ἀλλήλων εἶναι συνετίθεντο, ἐπιγαμίας δ’ εἶναι καὶ ἐπεργασίας καὶ ἐπινομίας, καὶ ἐπιμαχίαν δὲ κοινήν, εἴ τις ἀδικοίη ὁποτέρους.
remarks: Cyrus also agrees to leave a garrison on the heights between both countries to ensure that the terms of the peace treaty are enforced. In the passage referred to in this entry, the peace treaty is ratified. Cf. also oath ids 2376 and 2377.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance

remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Halicyae. 
The actual oath has not survived on the stone. Both formulae are restored. This entry takes into account textual changes noted in SEG 48.55.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
if_taken: They will be able to judge
statement: [? That they would decide justly whether he was entitled to be entered on the deme register]
remarks: Euxitheus states that when he was entered on the deme register and all the other deme members, upon swearing, cast their votes concerning him as the law prescribes, Euboulides neither denounced him, nor cast his vote against him. Rather, they all voted that he was a member of the deme.

author: Lysias
title: On the murder of Eratosthenes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that Euphiletus had not killed unlawfully]
remarks: Euphiletus reports describes the killing of Eratosthenes to the jurors. He then summons his witnesses to support his story. These witnesses would have sworn the diomosia prior to giving evidence, as was necessary in a dike phonou.

author: Empedocles
title: fr. 30 D-K
statement: n/a
remarks: This fragment of Empedocles is discussed by Aristotle. It refers to the appointment by 'great Strife' of members of the Sphere in turn, and these are bound by a 'broad oath'. For Aristotle's treatment of this passage, see oath id 1822. Cf. M. Garani in Sommerstein and Fletcher ed. Horkos (Exeter, 2007) 189-202.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Spartans sent Ischagoras, Menas and Philocharidas as envoys to Thrace and ordered Clearidas (their governor) to give up Amphipolis to the Athenians, and the rest of the allies to accept the treaty as it related to each. 
But they were unwilling to do so because they felt that the terms were unfavourable to them, so Clearidas returned to Sparta to see whether the agreement could be changed. When he found that they were bound (by oath) he returned to Amphipolis with orders to return the city if he could or at least remove all the Peloponnesians from the city. 
The envoys of the allies at Sparta would not accept the treaty unless one that was more fair could be made, so the Spartans went ahead and made an alliance with the Athenians on their own. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he makes his breastplates to fit]
 οὐ γὰρ δὴ ἴσους γε πάντας οὐδὲ ὁμοίους οἶμαί σε ποιεῖν, εἴ γε ἁρμόττοντας ποιεῖς. Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ποιῶ·

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That the law is right to forbid those who have mistreated their parents from speaking in the Assembly]
 νὴ Δία καλῶς γε, ὡς ἔγωγέ φημι.
remarks:
Aeschines observes that the lawgiver i.e. Solon excludes from speaking before the people anyone who beats his father or mother, or fails to support them and provide a home for them, and swears, "and rightly, by Zeus, I myself say". 
He goes on to argue that anyone who does not honour those from his own household cannot be trusted to treat the city as he ought.

swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of both parties

Xenophon observes that after the battle of Mantinea both parties set up a trophy and both gave up the dead under a truce.

καὶ Θεολύτη μάλ’ εὐπρόσωπος καὶ καλή,  
ὑπέφαιν’ ἐσομένη δ’ Ὤκιμον λαμπρὰ πάνυ

title: Fragment 566

remarks: Like oath id 871, the statement here expresses Chremylus' opinion.

author: Xenophon
title: Apology
statement: [That the testimony they give is true]
remarks: After his trial, Socrates is here reported to have accused the witnesses in the trial against him to have committed perjury after having been instructed to bear false witness against him. This is very odd, because in trials before ordinary juries witnesses were not on oath.  A witness might very well, however, when giving evidence orally in court (as witnesses did until 378), reinforce any of his statements by an oath; and quite likely some of the prosecution witnesses against Socrates did so (as the prosecutor Meletus does when Socrates cross-questions him in section 20 [oath id 2290]).  Such oaths would be volunteered, and there would be no consequences "if taken" or "if refused".

author: Plato
title: Apologia
swearee: Jury who voted for the death penalty
statement:
[That revenge will come upon those who have condemned him to death, and the punishment  will be far worse than their killing of him]
 φημὶ γάρ, ὦ ἄνδρες οἳ ἐμὲ ἀπεκτόνατε, τιμωρίαν ὑμῖν ἥξειν εὐθὺς μετὰ τὸν ἐμὸν θάνατον πολὺ χαλεπωτέραν νὴ Δία ἢ οἵαν ἐμὲ ἀπεκτόνατε·
remarks: Socrates is not here addressing the whole jury, but only those who had voted for the death penalty.  He addresses them from 38c7 to 39d10, after which the rest of his speech is directed to those who had voted the other way.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That they must not be persuaded]
 Νὴ Δί’, οὐχὶ πειστέον
remarks: See remarks on oath id 936.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: The Thirty and their followers; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The Thirty and their followers; The rest of the Athenians
statement:
[That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
 καὶ ὀμόσαντες ὅρκους ἦ μὴν μὴ μνησικακήσειν
remarks:
When the Athenians learned that the men in Eleusis were hiring mercenaries they made an expedition against them with the entire army. 
They killed the generals of the men in Eleusis when they came for a conference, and persuaded the others to reconcile by sending their friends and relatives to them. 
They swore not to remember wrongs, and still today (i.e. the time of writing) live together as a community and the demos abide by their oaths. 
See also oath id 1796.

 Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὡς ἔγωγ’ οἶμαι,

title: IC IV

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement: [?That Persians should act in each other's interests and in the interests of the Persian empire]
remarks: If this chapter is genuine, it must have been written later than 367 (see below).  That does not necessarily entail that the whole work was written that late; this chapter, which ruins the ending of the work, must (if it is by Xenophon) be what one might call a "grumbling appendix" rather like chapter 14 of the Lakedaimonion Politeia. Here Xenophon remarks on the decline of morals in Persia after Cyrus' death, giving the example of the satrap Rheomithres who betrays his wife and children and the children of his friends, leaving them as hostages with the king of Egypt. He apparently assisted the satrap Ariobarzanes (who is also mentioned in this passage) in revolting against Artaxerxes II in 367 B.C. Ariobarzanes sent Rheomithres to Tachos, king of Egypt, for help. Rheomithres received troops and money through which he was able to make peace with the king of Persia, and has no concern for the hostages he left in Egypt. Xenophon complains that he has broken 'the greatest oaths', but it is not clear exactly what the oaths were. Perhaps they were the generic oaths sworn by Persians and their king since those of Cyrus and his subjects (see oath ids 2500 and 2501). Betrayal of fellow Persians would certainly count as a violation of this oath.  Alternatively he may be referring to oaths exchanged between Rheomithres and Ariobarzanes themselves as part of their conspiracy.  Xenophon further complains that men capable of such actions seem only to have the highest honours heaped on them.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That all the instances of ("natural" rather than "legal") penalties mentioned by Socrates do seem to suggest the work of the gods]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔφη, θεοῖς ταῦτα πάντα ἔοικε·

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: Whilst Herodotus was in Scythia ca.465-444 (?) (465 to 444)
statement:
[That every year each member of the tribe of the Neuri is turned into a wolf and after remaining so for a few days returns to his former shape]
 Λέγονται γὰρ ὑπὸ Σκυθέων καὶ Ἑλλήνων τῶν ἐν τῇ Σκυθικῇ κατοικημένων ὡς ἔτεος ἑκάστου ἅπαξ τῶν Νευρῶν ἕκαστος λύκος γίνεται ἡμέρας ὀλίγας καὶ αὖτις ὀπίσω ἐς τὠυτὸ κατίσταται
remarks: Herodotus writes that Greeks in Scythia told him that every year each member of the tribe of the Neuri is turned into a wolf and after remaining so for a few days returns to his former shape. He notes that those who say these things do not persuade him, but they say it nevertheless and swear oaths that it is true.

author: Anonymus Oxyrhynchicus
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: Tissaphernes' men were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That he would not order the Spartans to molest Tissaphernes' men while they collected their dead]
remarks:
The text indicates that after Agesilaus defeated Tissaphernes in battle, he waited three days before leading his forces into Phrygia. 
During this time he returned the dead to the enemy under a truce, set up a trophy, and ravaged the countryside.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This alliance must have been concluded immediately after Cyrus conquered Lydia, since Herodotus maintains that Cyrus made a sworn agreement with Miletus on the same terms as the Milesians had with the Lydians. 
Herodotus refers to this alliance three times to explain why the Milesians did not fight against the Persians. 
For the other references see oath id 1280 and 1281.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
statement:
[That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
 καὶ τοὺς ὅρκους ὤμοσεν τοῖς Ἴωσιν ὥστε τὸν αὐτὸν ἐχθρὸν εἶναι καὶ φίλον
remarks:
The author states that Aristides administered oaths to the Ionians two years after the battle of Salamis, in the archonship of Timosthenes (478/7). Their oaths were ratified by letting lumps of iron sink to the bottom of the sea. 
The author goes on to state that the Athenians would later treat their allies too masterfully, except Chios, Lesbos and Samos. 
The exact statement of the oath for the so-called Delian League is unknown. The author of the Ath.Pol. indicates here that they swore oaths "to have the same enemies and friends". Herodotus indicates that after Mycale the Greeks swore "to remain loyal and not desert". IG I(3)15 indicates that the Erythraeans later swore to "not desert the Athenian masses nor the allies of the Athenians". 
Plutarch, Aristides 25, states that Aristides took the oath on behalf of the Athenians, and later urged the Athenians to put the perjury of breaking their oaths on his head, and to use that to their advantage. 
See also oath ids 1520, 1554, 1562, 1563, 1569, 1584, 1586, 1588, 1638, 1639, 1828, 1829, 1831, 1832, 1834, 1890, 2023, 2025, 3622.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes says that he knew Aeschines was lying when he said that Philip would punish the Thebans and that the Phocians would not suffer, because when Philip was about to swear the oaths concerning the peace, "these men" (i.e. Aeschines and Philocrates), declared that the Phocians were excluded from the agreement, whereas it would have been reasonable for them to keep quiet if the Phocians were going to be safe (cf. 174). 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: Against Philon
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
The speaker states that he has sworn "to give the best advice to the city..and to expose anyone who has been appointed by lot whom we know is unsuitable to serve in the boule" (ἐγὼ δὲ ὀμόσας εἰσῆλθον εἰς τὸ βουλευτήριον τὰ βέλτιστα βουλεύσειν τῇ πόλει, ἔνεστί τε ἐν τῷ ὅρκῳ ἀποφανεῖν εἴ τίς τινα οἶδε τῶν λαχόντων ἀνεπιτήδειον ὄντα βουλεύει), and and tells the other bouleutai that he is going to deliver the accusation against Philon in accordance with the oath. 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That it is the duty of the Athenians not to break up the force under Diopeithes in the Chersonese, but to provide an additional force to assist him]
 Ταῦτα τοίνυν ἅπαντας εἰδότας καὶ λογιζομένους χρή, οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχ ἣν Διοπείθης πειρᾶται τῇ πόλει δύναμιν παρασκευάζειν, ταύτην βασκαίνειν καὶ διαλῦσαι πειρᾶσθαι, ἀλλ’ἑτέραν αὐτοὺς προσπαρασκευάζειν καὶ συνευποροῦντας ἐκείνῳ χρημάτων καὶ τἄλλ’ οἰκείως συναγωνιζομένους.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Athenians sent thirty ships around the Peloponnese with orders to put in at the Argolid and summon the Argive hoplites to the ships "in accordance with the alliance". 
At 7.26.1 Thucydides describes how the Athenian admiral Charicles collected the soldiers and sailed against Laconia. 
For other references to this alliance see  oath id 1756 and 1835. See also oath id 255.

author: Sophocles
title: Antigone
statement: n/a
remarks: The Chorus here discuss the civic excellence of the man who interweaves the laws of the land with the sworn justice of the gods (i.e. who obeys the law and keeps his oaths, cf. A.L. Brown [Warminster, 1987] ad loc.).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Spudias
if_taken: They can give a valid verdict
if_refused: Their verdict will be a nullity
statement: [? That they would give a true verdict]
remarks: The speaker warns the jurors not to think that men who know all the facts about the case, and who now are giving testimony at their own risk - i.e. the arbitrators - would have formed a different conclusion when they had been put under oath.

author: Isocrates
title: For Demonicus
statement: n/a
remarks:
Isocrates advises Demonicus, the son of his Cypriot friend Hipponicus, not to swear an oath to get money, not even when he intends to swear a true oath; for some people will suspect him of perjury, and others (or perhaps the rest, i.e. everyone else) of greed. 
This appears to be an unrealistic counsel of perfection, since if Demonicus literally obeyed it, anyone would be able to defraud him with impunity.  However, the passage makes an interesting, and earlier, parallel to the oath-reduction programme in Plato's Laws, and one that should strengthen our suspicion that among fourth-century intellectuals there was a feeling that the currency of oaths was getting badly devalued.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: The farmers will be unaffected by the war
if_refused: The farmers will not be unaffected by the war
statement:
[That there should be peace for those who were working, war for those who were bearing arms]
καὶ ἐγένοντο συνθῆκαι τοῖς μὲν ἐργαζομένοις εἰρήνην εἶναι, τοῖς δ’ ὁπλοφόροις πόλεμον.
remarks: There is no explicit mention of oaths here, but an agreement made between enemies on restrictions of war suggests ratification with oaths.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Socrates seems to be a truly noble man]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ὦ Σώκρατες, καλός γε κἀγαθὸς δοκεῖς μοι ἄνθρωπος εἶναι.
remarks: Swearing by Hera is unusual. Only Socrates does it repeatedly. Both Callias and Hermogenes swear by Hera in this dialogue (see oath ids 2256 and 2281 with cross references for Socrates' oaths by Hera). Callias and Hermogenes are from the same deme as Socrates, which may explain their use of this oath. The reference books, such as LGPN, give Lycon’s deme as Thorikos.  This is known from schol. Pl. Apol. 23e, which refers, of course, to the Lycon who was one of Socrates’ accusers.  The present passage, with its praise of Socrates, seems to prove conclusively that the accuser and the father of Autolycus were two different people; the only thing they are known to have in common is that they were apparently both accused in comedy of being foreigners (Eupolis fr. 61, Metagenes fr. 10).  Another argument against identifying them is that if Autolycus was born in the late 440s, his father would have had to be at least as old as Socrates, in which case it would be surprising to find him in 399 as the third man in a prosecution team of three.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he is always reluctant to enter someone else's house]
  Ἀλλ’ ἄχθομαι μὲν εἰσιὼν νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς 
  εἰς οἰκίαν ἑκάστοτ’ ἀλλοτρίαν πάνυ·

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That the rulers mentioned by Socrates are not invisible]
 καὶ τίνες δὴ οὗτοί εἰσιν,  ἔφη ὁ Κριτόβουλος, οἳ ἀφανεῖς ὄντες ἄρχουσιν αὐτῶν; Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ
Σωκράτης, οὐκ ἀφανεῖς εἰσιν, ἀλλὰ καὶ πάνυ φανεροί
