remarks: The "rulers" mentioned by Socrates turn out to be the vices in men’s characters.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus tells the jurors that they must not allow anyone to think that they have disregarded the oaths they have sworn and gratified an unjust passion. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be allies to the Athenians forever, without guile and without injury]
 [σύνμαχοι ἐσόμ]εθα [Ἀθεναίοις ἀίδιοι] ἀδό[λος καὶ ἀβλαβο̃ς·]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Leontini. 
The swearers were envoys from Leontini.  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 166. Cf. oath id 3205.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That Ismenia comes as a representative of Boeotia]
 Πρέσβειρά τοι ναὶ τὼ σιὼ Βοιωτία
  ἵκει ποθ’ ὑμέ.
remarks: On the twin gods, see remarks on 1151; cf. oath id 1216 with cross references for other invocations of the Dioscuri in this play.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
statement: [That she is not devising ill for Odysseus]
remarks: This oath is related by Odysseus in his narrative to Alcinous. It is reported as proposed by Odysseus and sworn by Circe at oath id 539, and is here referred to as having been originally suggested to Odysseus by Hermes. Cf. also oath id 540.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement: [? That they will fight together against Xerxes]
remarks:
Demaratus warns Xerxes that he should capture the island of Cythera to draw the Greeks away from the Isthmus. 
He claims that at the Isthmus, upon all the Peloponnesians swearing oaths together against Xerxes, he will face tougher battles than the one at Thermopylae. 
It is unclear whether Demaratus says to Xerxes that "the Peloponnesians will all swear together against you" or that "all the Peloponnesians have sworn together against you" (πάντων Πελοποννησίων συνομοσάντων ἐπὶ σοί)

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That with his wizardry he can make Demos expand and contract at his pleasure]
  Καὶ νὴ Δί’ ὑπό γε δεξιότητος τῆς ἐμῆς
  δύναμαι ποεῖν τὸν δῆμον εὐρὺν καὶ στενόν.
remarks: Sommerstein comments ad 720 that this is presumably a proverbial expression (but not otherwise attested) meaning "I can do what I like with him."

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
if_broken: Phthia will never be named and Sipylos, the stay of barbarians, will be great
statement:
[That Agamemnon will not touch Clytemnestra's daughter, not even lay a finger on her dress]
 μὰ τὸν δι’ ὑγρῶν κυμάτων τεθραμμένον
  Νηρέα, φυτουργὸν Θέτιδος ἥ μ’ ἐγείνατο,
  οὐχ ἅψεται σῆς θυγατρὸς ᾿Αγαμέμνων ἄναξ, 
  οὐδ’ εἰς ἄκραν χεῖρ’, ὥστε προσβαλεῖν πέπλοις·
  ἢ Σίπυλος ἔσται πολύς, ἔρεισμα βαρβάρων,
  ὅθεν πεφύκασ’ οἱ στρατηλάται γένος,
  Φθίας δὲ τοὔνομ’ οὐδαμοῦ κεκλήσεται.
gods_invoked: NereusEpithet(s)reared by the waves, father of Thetis
remarks: Achilles is, in effect released from this oath by Iphigenia's decision to die voluntarily. See also Achilles' subsequent oath at id 189 and the oath at id 3885.

author: Xenarchus
title: Porphyra
statement: unknown
remarks: In this fragment someone swears by Dionysus, but the oath statement does not survive.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Hagnias
statement: [That his allegations were true]
remarks:
Theopompus argues that his opponent (the son of his brother Stratocles) ought to be able to answer immediately as to the degree of his relationship to Hagnias, and moreover to swear to it, and produce witnesses so that the jurors might attach greater credence to what he says. 
Apparently, says Theopompus, his opponent believes that the jurors will believe him despite the fact that he has given no answers, produced no witnesses, sworn no oath and quoted no law.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That the long compound words favoured by Aeschylus are difficult to understand]
  ΕΥ.  ἀλλ’ ἢ Σκαμάνδρους ἢ τάφρους ἢ ’π’ ἀσπίδων ἐπόντας
γρυπαιέτους χαλκηλάτους καὶ ῥήμαθ’ ἱππόκρημνα,
ἃ ξυμβαλεῖν οὐ ῥᾴδι’ ἦν. 
ΔΙ.  Νὴ τοὺς θεούς

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
Xenophon observes that in 399 all the allies including the Athenians (but excepting the Corinthians and Boeotians) took part with King Agis in the campaign against Elis. 
For other references to the treaty between Athens and Sparta see oath id 1893.

title: FD III: 1
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: All that can be determined is that if someone denied liability he was to do so under oath.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That it does seem strange to him that it is impious for a person to end his own life even if it would be for his benefit to do so]
 θαυμαστὸν ἴσως σοι φαίνεται εἰ τούτοις τοῖς ἀνθρώποις μὴ ὅσιον αὐτοὺς ἑαυτοὺς εὖ ποιεῖν, ἀλλὰ ἄλλον δεῖ περιμένειν εὐεργέτην. Καὶ ὁ Κέβης ἠρέμα ἐπιγελάσας, Ἴττω Ζεύς, ἔφη, τῇ αὑτοῦ φωνῇ εἰπών.
remarks: This is a unique example of concsious reference to dialect in Plato (leaving aside various remarks in Cratylus where language itself is the subject of discussion). Attention is drawn to the fact that Cebes uses an oath formula from his own Boeotian dialect- 'ittw' for attic 'istw'.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Hypereides points out that the existing situation in 339 was that Thebes was at peace and in alliance with Philip, while Athens was at war with him.
See also oath id 3826.

author: Lysias
title: On the property of Aristophanes
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker asks the jurors to listen to his speech until the end, and to deliver the verdict that is best for them and most in keeping with their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes has decrees proposed by Diophantus and Callisthenes (calling for the evacuation of the countryside and the holding of the sacrifices to Heracles within the city wall) read to the jurors, and argues that these were not the consequences the Athenians were expecting when they made the peace and alliance with Philip, and when they were persuaded to add the words "also to his descendants" to the agreement. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would support each other in war]
remarks: Herodotus states that Cambyses ordered his fleet to sail against Carthage, but the Phoenicians would not agree to this, arguing that they were bound by great oaths and they could not righteously fight against their own sons (ὁρκίοισί τε γὰρ μεγάλοισι ἐνδεδέσθαι καὶ οὐκ ἂν ποιέειν ὅσια ἐπὶ τοὺς παῖδας τοὺς ἑωυτῶν στρατευόμενοι). Presumably these oaths were sworn at the time of the foundation of the colony and renewed annually.

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Liberty of the Rhodians
statement: n/a
remarks: Demosthenes criticises the Athenians because, whereas in the case of allied states they believe the most loyal are those who have sworn to regard Athens' friends and enemies as their own, nevertheless when it comes to Athenian politicians they trust men who have thrown in their lot with the enemies of the state.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he knows that the first need of men which the gods have provided is light]
 Ἀλλ’ οἶσθά γ’, ἔφη, ὅτι πρῶτον μὲν φωτὸς 
δεόμεθα, ὃ ἡμῖν οἱ θεοὶ παρέχουσι; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
statement: n/a
remarks:
The defendant asks the jurors, "What court would they [the prosecutors] hesitate to invade with their lies? What oaths would they not dare to break?". He goes on to add that the prosecutors know that the jurors are the most conscientious and most fair in Greece, yet the come before the jurors intent on deceiving them. See also oath id 2513. 
This line of thought is a repetition of section 49 (see oath id 2510).

author: Aristotle
title: Lakedaimonion Politeia
proposed_by: Apollo's Pythian oracle (male, n/a, unknown, unknown)
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: The Spartans, at war with Amyclae, are advised to take the Aegeids as allies, and presume that this means Athens (as descendants of Aegeus). The Spartans journey to Athens and stop at Thebes on the way where they encounter the Theban Aegeid phratry and it becomes clear to them that the Thebans are the ones with whom an alliance should be made.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: Abradatas prays that he may be a worthy husband for his wife
statement:
[That she would rather die with her husband should he prove himself a noble man than to live disgraced with him disgraced]
 ὅμως δὲ οὕτως ἔχουσα πρὸς σὲ ὥσπερ σὺ οἶσθα, ἐπομνύω σοι τὴν ἐμὴν καὶ σὴν φιλίαν ἦ μὴν ἐγὼ βούλεσθαι ἂν μετὰ σοῦ ἀνδρὸς ἀγαθοῦ γενομένου κοινῇ γῆν ἐπιέσασθαι μᾶλλον ἢ ζῆν μετ’ αἰσχυνομένου αἰσχυνομένη·

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he doesn't think anyone, mad or sane, would persuade himself into saying that it was a necessary truth that “horse” and “ox”, or that “one” and “two”, were the same thing]
 Ἄλλον δέ τινα οἴει ὑγιαίνοντα ἢ μαινόμενον τολμῆσαι σπουδῇ πρὸς ἑαυτὸν εἰπεῖν ἀναπείθοντα αὑτὸν ὡς ἀνάγκη τὸν βοῦν ἵππον εἶναι ἢ τὰ δύο ἕν;  {ΘΕΑΙ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
statement:
[That he is not willingly bringing the suit against Olympiodorus]
 οὔτ’ αὖ μὰ τὸν Δία τὸν μέγιστον ἑκών,

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
swearer: Men chosen to draw up register of 5000
if_taken: They will be allowed to choose register
if_refused: They will not be allowed to choose register
statement: [That they will choose the 5000 fairly]
remarks: We are told here that ten men over forty were chosen from each tribe for the purpose of drawing up a register of 5000 suitable Athenians to whom the control of the state should be entrusted. The oath statement is not specified, but presumably the oath was to ensure a fair selection. This is all part of a largely fictive reconstruction of the events of 411, including (as its next event) an entirely mythical meeting of the Five Thousand (who did not even exist at this time); the author of the Ath.Pol. himself, however, clearly believed the account to be historical. See also oath id 2843.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That the mercenaries are acting terribly in ravaging the shores of the Hellespont, and that Diopeithes is wrong in detaining the merchant-ships, and that the Athenians must not condone it]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία, ταῦτα μὲν ἐξελέγχονται, δεινὰ ποιοῦσι δ’ οἱ ξένοι περικόπτοντες τὰ ἐν Ἑλλησπόντῳ, καὶ Διοπείθης ἀδικεῖ κατάγων τὰ πλοῖα, καὶ δεῖ μὴ ἐπιτρέπειν αὐτῷ.
remarks: Demosthenes is imagining how someone might object to his arguments.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides indicates that the Thessalians sent a cavalry contingent to assist the Athenians at the battle of Tanagra (458/7), but that they deserted to the Spartans during the battle. 
See also oath id 1553 and 1566.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
statement: [That Boeotus and Pamphilus were sons of Mantias]
remarks: Mantitheus complains that Boeotus has launched two or three lawsuits against him for money, and argues that if Plangon has sworn truly (see oath id 3562), it proves that Boeotus is a malicious sykophantes, for if Boeotus and Pamphilus were legitimate sons of Mantias, and Mantias had been maintaining two households, there would be no money left for Boeotus to pursue.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he cannot explain what is made by the art of kingship (in the sense in which the art of medicine produces health and the art of agriculture produces food)]
 Τί δὲ ἡ βασιλικὴ πάντων ἄρχουσα ὧν ἄρχει; τί ἀπεργάζεται; ἴσως οὐ πάνυ γ’ εὐπορεῖς.  {ΚΡ.} Μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
statement: n/a
remarks: Here, the poet narrates Odysseus' genealogy and how he got the scar discovered by Eurycleia. During this narrative, Autolykos (Odysseus' grandfather) is mentioned as being skilled above all men in thievery and the art of the oath. Clearly, the implication is that oaths, if skillfully formulated, can be exploited for deceptive purposes. This passage is discussed by Socrates in Plato's Republic, see oath id 2524.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Gives extra validity to the accusation
statement:
[That it is obvious that Labes stuffed himself with the cheese in the dark]
 κἀνέπλητ’ ἐν τῷ σκότῳ.
 {Φι.}  νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἀλλὰ δῆλός ἐστ’·
remarks: Labes represents Laches, the Hound represents Cleon, and the accusation represents a charge of embezzlement against Laches when in command in Sicily in 427-424.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That Callicles should cheerfully let anyone strike him with a humiliating blow (since he will not suffer if he is truly an honourable man)]
 καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία σύ γε θαρρῶν πατάξαι τὴν  ἄτιμον ταύτην πληγήν
remarks: The "humiliating blow" is a smack in the face (486c2-3).

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
if_broken: That Hippolytus will die unfamed and nameless, and that neither sea nor land will accept his body when he dies
statement: [That Hippolytus never touched Theseus' wife, nor would he have wished to, nor further would the idea have even occured to him]
remarks: Same oath as id 129

title: IC IV
if_refused: Their property will be disposed of as in the case of someone refusing to judge
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that disputes over land borders the judge and the mnemon are to deal with the case within 15 days. If the plaintiff claims that 15 days have elapsed the judge and the mnemon are to be considered "horkioteroi" (i.e. their oaths will be believed) if they swear that they have done something regarding the case. If they do not swear their property will be disposed of "as in the case of someone refusing to judge". (αἰ πονίοι πεντεκαίδεκ’ ἀμέρανς ἀμπεληεύθεν ὀ ἄρκον τᾶς δίκας, ὀρκιότερον ἤμην τὸν δικαστὰν καὶ τὸμ μνάμονα. αἰ δέ κα μὲ ὀμόσοντι κελομένο, κατὰ τὰ αὐτὰ πράδεθαι το̃ μὲ ὀμόσαντος ἆιπερ αἴ κα μὴ λῆι δικάκσαι).

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That things would not be good for them if the Chaldaeans were in possession of the heights]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἀρμένιος, οὐκ ἂν ἡμῖν αὖ καλῶς ἔχοι, εἰ οὗτοι παραλήψονται πάλιν τὰ ἄκρα ἄλλως τε  καὶ τετειχισμένα.
remarks: The Chaldaeans feel the same (see oath id 2378), and Cyrus decides to leave a Persian garrison on the heights to ensure that the peace is enforced.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
statement:
[That, as long as the king kept his oath, they would never attack the monarchy nor allow others to do so;  and that they would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
 βασιλεῖαι τρεῖς βασιλευομέναις πόλεσιν τριτταῖς ὤμοσαν ἀλλήλαις ἑκάτεραι, κατὰ νόμους οὓς ἔθεντο τοῦ τε ἄρχειν καὶ ἄρχεσθαι κοινούς, οἱ μὲν μὴ βιαιοτέραν τὴν ἀρχὴν ποιήσεσθαι προϊόντος τοῦ χρόνου καὶ γένους, οἱ δέ, ταῦτα ἐμπεδούντων τῶν ἀρχόντων, μήτε αὐτοὶ τὰς βασιλείας ποτὲ καταλύσειν μήτ’ ἐπιτρέψειν ἐπιχειροῦσιν ἑτέροις, βοηθήσειν δὲ βασιλῆς τε βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις καὶ δήμοις, καὶ δῆμοι δήμοις καὶ βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις.
remarks: The discussion concerns the time in which Temenus was King of Argos, Cresphontes was king of Messene and Procles and Eurysthenes were kings of Sparta, when the area was first divided into the three states of Argos, Sparta and Messene. The king swears a reciprocal oath- see oath id 2682. The kings and people of Sparta and Argos do the same- see oath ids 2678-81. The kings do not break their oath, but they subsequently disagree about it- see oath ids 2684-6.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a remark on the terrible fact of knowing that in a society where oaths are sworn almost half the citizens are perjurers (of the kind who are likely to swear falsely in court- see oath id 2728), although they have no scruples about associating with each other at common meals and other public and private gatherings. The point of “they have no scruples about associating with one another …” is that anyone who took oaths seriously would not, for his own safety’s sake, want to be under the same roof, aboard the same ship, etc., as a perjurer.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The King shall possess what territory he currently holds as well as that held by his forefathers
2. The Spartans and the Persians will stop the Athenians from gaining any revenue from these lands
3. The Spartans and Persians will fight together against the Athenians and not stop unless both agree
4. Any subjects revolting from Persia will be enemies of Sparta and any subjects revolting from Sparta will be enemies of Persia]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the agreement was concluded through Tissaphernes the Persian satrap and Chalcideus the Spartan admiral. 
The Spartan soon found this agreement unsatisfactory and made two subsequent agreements with the Persians.  
For references to all the agreements between the Spartans and the Persians see oath id 1807, 1810, 1812, 1815 and 1818.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the young man requires (or wants- see remarks) something from her]
  οὐ σοῦ γ’, ὦλεθρε,
 δεόμενος οὐδέν. {Γρ. α} νὴ Δί’, ὦ φθίνυλλα σύ
remarks: According to the new rules, the young man must first "screw" an old or ugly woman before he can "screw" his young girlfriend. δεόμενος could be interpreted as meaning either "requires" or "wants". It is true to say that Epigenes, if he is to obey both the law and his own desires, will need to sleep with the old woman; and it is not too big a stretch, either, to say that he will want to – but only in the sense in which one “wants” to, say, pay a parking fee (as the unavoidable but unwelcome cost of being allowed to go into, or in some cases out of, the car park) and may even be impatient to be allowed to pay it.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Egesta. 
The actual oath has not survived on the stone. The oath was to be sworn in the presence of the so-called horkotai ("oath commissioners") from Athens.  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 298. See also oath id 1841.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: Emphasises the difficulty of finding those who have left without guides
statement:
[That Cyrus found those they were looking for thanks to the guidance of the Hyrcanian defectors from the Assyrian alliance]
 Πῶς δὲ Κῦρος, ἔφη, καὶ οἱ σὺν αὐτῷ ἐφ’ οὓς ἐπορεύοντο; Ὅτι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ἀκούω ἀφεστηκότας τῶν πολεμίων Ὑρκανίους τινὰς καὶ ἐλθόντας δεῦρο οἴχεσθαι ἡγουμένους αὐτῷ.
remarks: Cyaxares wakes up from a drunken night and is furious to find that Cyrus and the rest of the Median troops, apart from his fellow-revellers, have left.  He orders them to be fetched back, Cyrus if he is willing but the Medes in any case.  The cavalry sent to carry out these orders are at a loss for some time, and though they eventually find some guides, they do not reach Cyrus' camp until about midnight the next night.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Pheidippides will comply with his father's request]  
 λέγε δή, τί κελεύεις; 
 {Στ.} καί τι πείσει; 
 {Φε.} πείσομαι, νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον.
remarks: Pheidippides will directly contradict this statement eighteen lines later; see oath id 4.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he denounces Paphlagon]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία κἄγωγε τοῦτον
remarks: The charge on which he denounces Paphlagon is "for running into the Prytaneum with an empty stomach and then running out again with a full one"; Sommerstein ad 281 comments on the implication of this charge that Cleon/ Paphlagon was taking advantage of a right to which he was not really entitled. See Sommerstein ad loc. for further details.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he knows how to put the ostrakon on top of the clay]
 ἢ τὸ ὄστρακον ἀγνοεῖς, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, πῶς ἂν ἐπὶ τοῦ πηλοῦ ἄνω καταθείης; Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ, οὐδὲν ὧν εἶπας, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, ἀγνοῶ
remarks: The context is the planting of olive trees. As Pomeroy notes ad loc., the ostrakon (or 'shard') "placed on top of the poultice of clay described in the preceding paragraph prevents water from leaking in and causing the wood to rot."

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he loves Xanthias]
 ΔΙ.  Κάκιστ’ ἀπολοίμην, Ξανθίαν εἰ μὴ φιλῶ.
remarks: Dionysus uses an oath here in an attempt to convince Xanthias to swap places with him, now that the situation has turned to his disadvantage.  Xanthias is not impressed, and agrees to the exchange only after Dionysus has sworn never to take the gear back (oath id 426).

author: Antiphanes
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: unknown
remarks: These are apparently the words of Demosthenes, though it is not clear whether he is the speaker in the play. This is exactly the same line as oath id 1445.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Phaenippus
statement:
[That he gave strict orders to Phaenippus' ass-drivers and made them stop carrying off timber from the farm]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ἀπειπὼν καὶ κωλύσας τοὺς ὀνηλάτας μὴ ἐξάγειν τὴν ὕλην ἐκ τῆς ἐσχατιᾶς

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That if two orators made proposals, one to build long ships, the other to spend the money on state pay, the state-pay man would depart an easy winner over the trireme man]
 Καὶ νὴ Δί’ εἴ γε δύο λεγοίτην ῥήτορε, 
  ὁ μὲν ποεῖσθαι ναῦς μακράς, ὁ δ’ ἕτερος αὖ 
  καταμισθοφορῆσαι τοῦθ’, ὁ τὸν μισθὸν λέγων 
  τὸν τὰς τριήρεις παραδραμὼν ἂν ᾤχετο.
remarks: On possible allusions in this passage see Sommerstein ad 1350-3.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That it will not profit the members of the ideal state to hear the poets' stories of the gods' capabilities for lust and deceit]
 οὐδὲ Ἄρεώς τε καὶ Ἀφροδίτης ὑπὸ Ἡφαίστου δεσμὸν δι’ ἕτερα τοιαῦτα. Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὔ μοι φαίνεται ἐπιτήδειον.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he will become Theodote's partner in the pursuit of friends only if she can persuade him to]
 καὶ ἡ Θεοδότη, Τί οὖν οὐ σύ μοι, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἐγένου συνθηρατὴς τῶν φίλων; Ἐάν γε νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, πείθῃς με σύ.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides observes that the Peloponnesians (other than the Spartans) were angered by the clause in the treaty which stated that it would be consistent with their oaths to make changes that seemed good to Athens and Sparta, i.e. without any need to consult their allies.  They suspected that the Spartans were planning to combine with the Athenians in order to "enslave" the lesser Peloponnesian states, and were eager to bolster their security by allying themselves with Argos. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That the Athenians ought to revive past grievances against those wanting help and to look for excuses to abandon everything]
 μνησικακεῖν νὴ Δία πρὸς τοὺς βουλομένους σῴζεσθαι, καὶ προφάσεις ζητεῖν δι’ ἃς ἅπαντα προησόμεθα.
remarks: Demosthenes asks what advice he should have given the city, and sarcastically answers himself "Why, of course - to rake over the past, and to look for excuses to enable us to lose everything!"  Then, serious again, he says that if he had done anything of that sort he would deservedly have been put to death.

author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement: n/a
remarks: This is another piece of advice for the good man to flee "oaths that destroy men". This could mean that the good man should avoid swearing oaths that ruin other people (cf. oath id 1372), or that for his own safety he should be careful about trusting the oaths of others (cf. oath id 1368).

author: Lysias
title: Against the members of a Sunousia
statement:
[That he does not see what harm it will do him if he ceases to associate with the members of the group]
 ἐπεί τοι μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅ τι ζημιωθήσομαι μὴ ξυνὼν ὑμῖν·
remarks: The speaker says that he is willingly withdrawing from the group because he cannot see what benefits he receives from being a member.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement: [That Euxitheus' mother Nicarete was an Athenian]
remarks: Euxitheus tells the jurors that he would suffer most pitiably of all people if they were to vote that he is an alien after all these relatives have testified and sworn that they are related to him.

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
impact: Provokes Hippolytus' rage which causes Phaedra to believe he will ignore his oath. This in turn leads to her planning his destruction.
statement: [That Hippolytus will not reveal what he has been told]
remarks: This is a reference to Hippolytus' oath in the eponymous Euripidean play, and to lines 611-612 where he exclaims that his tongue has sworn but his mind is not under oath (see further oath id 125). Here Aristotle refers to this passage and to the fact that Euripides had been accused of impiety by Hygiaenon because of this verse.

author: Demosthenes
title: Olynthiac 2
statement: n/a
remarks: When attacking Philip's actions, Demosthenes observes that to call a man a perjurer and faithless without drawing attention to his actions might justly be termed abuse; but to provide a comprehensive proof of the charge by describing his conduct in detail fortunately requires only a short speech.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
if_taken: They will be permitted to act as judges
if_refused: They will not be permitted to act as judges
impact: Case will be judged by both Athena and her people
statement: [That they will judge according to the laws]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 214.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
statement:
[That he will not lie to the jurors, but tell them what he heard from his father]
 καὶ μὰ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω καὶ τὴν Δήμητρα, οὐ ψεύσομαι πρὸς ὑμᾶς, ὦ ἄνδρες δικασταί, ἀλλ’ ἃ τοῦ πατρὸς ἤκουον, διηγήσομαι ὑμῖν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he rolled on the ground when he saw a kite]
 Νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον, ἐγὼ γοῦν
 ἐκυλινδούμην ἰκτῖνον ἰδών·
remarks: The oath reinforces Peisetaerus' previous statements concerning the original kingship of the kite. As Sommerstein notes ad 501, Greeks paid homage to this bird because its arrival, which preceded that of the swallow, heralded the coming of spring.

author: Alcaeus (com.)
title: Pasiphae
statement:
[That someone has paltry domestic utensils]
 καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δί’ ἄλλα σκευάρι’ οἰκητήρια

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he has not seen the woman whom he is asking Araspas to look after]
 Ἑώρακας δ’, ἔφη, ὦ Κῦρε, τὴν γυναῖκα, ἥν με 
κελεύεις φυλάττειν; Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That he doesn't see his mind's designers]
  Μὰ Δί’ οὐ γὰρ ὁρῶ τοὺς κυρίους, ὥσπερ τῶν ἐνθάδε γιγνομένων τοὺς δημιουργούς.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians as they left the city]
remarks:
Xenophon states that when Lysander sailed against Byzantium and Calchedon the inhabitants of both cities admitted him and allowed the Athenians to withdraw under a truce. 
See also oath id 1891.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That the reason he has a passion for the boy Daοlochus is that he desires to get from him not what he may have easily, but that which a tyrant should be the last to receive]
 Ὅτι μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σιμωνίδη, οὐ τοῦ ἑτοίμου παρ’ αὐτοῦ δοκοῦντος εἶναι τυχεῖν τούτου μάλιστα ἐπιθυμῶ, ἀλλὰ τοῦ ἥκιστα τυράννῳ προσήκοντος κατεργάσασθαι.
remarks:
Simonides asks Hiero to explain his passion for the boy Dailochus (surnamed "the fairest"), given that he has just denied that love for boys springs up in a tyrant's heart. 
What Hiero is saying is that yes, of course, he wants sexual gratification from Dailochus, but only if it is given freely - and being a tyrant, he will never in fact be able to know whether a surrender has been free or coerced.   
(1.38 is a nice note on "faking it".)

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
swearer: Thessalians; Boeotians; Dorians; Ionians; Perrhaebians; Magnesians; Dolopians; Locrians; Oetaeans; Phthians; Malians; Phocians
swearee: Thessalians; Boeotians; Dorians; Ionians; Perrhaebians; Magnesians; Dolopians; Locrians; Oetaeans; Phthians; Malians; Phocians
if_taken: They would be part of the koinon
if_refused: They would not be part of the koinon
statement:
[That they would not destroy any Amphictyonic polis or to bar access to flowing water in war or peace, and to take the field against anyone who broke his oath and destroy his city; and if anyone were to rob the god's property or connive in or advise any action against the contents of the temple, they would punish him with hand and foot and voice and all their power]
 μηδεμίαν πόλιν τῶν Ἀμφικτυονίδων ἀνάστατον ποιήσειν, μηδ’ ὑδάτων ναματιαίων εἴρξειν μήτ’ ἐν πολέμῳ μήτ’ ἐν εἰρήνῃ, ἐὰν δέ τις ταῦτα παραβῇ, στρατεύσειν ἐπὶ τοῦτον καὶ τὰς πόλεις ἀναστήσειν, καὶ ἐάν τις ἢ συλᾷ τὰ τοῦ θεοῦ, ἢ συνειδῇ τι, ἢ βουλεύσῃ τι κατὰ τῶν ἱερῶν, τιμωρήσειν καὶ χειρὶ καὶ ποδὶ καὶ φωνῇ καὶ πάσῃ δυνάμει·
remarks:
Aeschines refers to the first synod of the Amphictyons, and states that he informed Philip about this oath, and told him that it seemed unjust to let the Boeotian cities lie in ruins. 
He states that he listed the twelve peoples who shared responsibility for the temple (stressing that the Thebans were not the only Boeotians included), and showed that each - both great and small - had an equal vote.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he has never seen a trench for plants dug more than three feet wide (nor even more than two feet wide)]
 Τί δέ, τὸ πλάτος ἤδη τινὰ τριπόδου πλέον εἶδες; Οὐδὲ μὰ Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ, διπόδου

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will come right back after just spreading "them" on the bed]
 Ἀλλ’ ἥξω ταχέως νὴ τὼ θεὼ 
 ὅσον διαπετάσασ’ ἐπὶ τῆς κλίνης μόνον.
remarks: As Sommerstein comments ad 732: "does she mean [spreading] the fleeces, or her legs?". It is intentionally unclear; compare also the next oath at id 1192. For swearing by Demeter and Persephone, see remarks on id 788.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That he would surrender the son of Iphiades to the Athenians]
remarks:
Euthycles asks for the agreement between Charidemus and Athenodorus to be read to the jurors. He then tells the jurors that Charidemus swore the oath they have heard, but as soon as he saw that Athenodorus' forces had been disbanded, and that Chabrias had come with only one trireme, he did not surrender the son of Iphiades, nor did he fulfil any of his other sworn promises. Euthycles complains that Charidemus repudiated the agreement, and drew up another one which did not refer to the surrender of Iphiades' son, even though he had previously sworn to give him up. 
I suppose this must mean that Charidemus forged this new version of the agreement, and claimed that the earlier one wasn’t genuine?

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates argues that if he does not continue his argument he will give the impression that the peace will leave Athens as a disadvantage, for whereas the Thebans are allowed to retain possession of Thespiae, Plataea, and the other cities (i.e. Orchomenus and Oropus) which they have seized contrary to their oaths, the Athenians will be withdrawing from the territory which they hold, under no compulsion. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That Aristogeiton has a brother who is present and who brought a previous action]
 πλὴν ἔστι νὴ Δία, ἔστιν ἀδελφός τις οὗτος αὐτῷ, ὁ παρὼν καὶ τὴν καλὴν δίκην λαχών
remarks: The "previous action" is that mentioned in sections 55 and 58 of the speech; the brother prosecuted Aristogeiton for having sold their half-sister into slavery abroad.

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That, perhaps, if virtue is knowledge then it can be taught]
 καὶ δῆλον, ὦ Σώκρατες, κατὰ τὴν ὑπόθεσιν, εἴπερ ἐπιστήμη ἐστὶν ἀρετή, ὅτι διδακτόν ἐστιν.  {ΣΩ.} Ἴσως νὴ Δία·
remarks: Socrates is being cautious here and continues to suggest that they should not bind themselves to this principle. His diffidence about whether virtue is knowledge must to some extent be tongue-in-cheek.  It is based on the difficulty of finding anyone who can actually teach it (89d-e).  Neither Plato, nor the Platonic Socrates, believes that virtue can be taught in the way one teaches medicine or shoemaking.  For them, the way to learn virtue is the same way in which the slave has just learned (a bit of) geometry.

author: Epicharmus
title: Kyklops
statement:
[That something is much more hollow than a mortar]  
 ναὶ τὸν Ποτιδᾶν, κοιλότερος ὁλμοῦ πολύ
remarks: Given the title of the play 'Cyclops' it is not surprising to see an invocation of Poseidon, since the Cyclops Polyphemus is his son. Cf. oath id 99. The  “something” which is more hollow (i.e. has a bigger cavity) than a mortar probably refers to a big drinking-cup and the speaker is probably the Cyclops.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he did not know the Clouds were divine]  
  ταύτας μέντοι σὺ θεὰς οὔσας οὐκ ᾔδεις οὐδ’ ἐνόμιζες; 
 {Στ.}  μὰ Δί’,

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks: Xenophon states that Agesilaus induced the Acarnanians, Aetolians and [Amphilochian] Argives to enter into friendship with the Achaeans (see also oath id 1951) and alliance with himself (see oath id 1950 and 2302).

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement:
[That the only logical explanation why anyone should be willing to help a man who did the city as much harm as Leocrates did is that his supporters have interests at variance with those of their country]
 ἡγοῦμαι δ’ ἔγωγε οὐδένα {ἂν} οὕτω μεγάλα τὴν πόλιν εὐεργετηκέναι, ὥστ’ ἐξαίρετον ἀξιοῦν λαμβάνειν <ἂν> χάριν τὴν κατὰ τῶν προδιδόντων τιμωρίαν, οὐδ’ οὕτως ἀνόητον ὥστε φιλοτιμεῖσθαι μὲν πρὸς τὴν πόλιν, τούτῳ δὲ βοηθεῖν ὃς αὐτοῦ πρώτου τὰς φιλοτιμίας ἠφάνισεν·  εἰ μὴ νὴ Δία μὴ ταὐτὰ τῇ πατρίδι καὶ τούτοις ἐστὶ συμφέροντα.
remarks: Lycurgus states that he does not believe that anyone could have done sufficient services for the city to be able to get a traitor acquitted, nor that anyone who has ambitions to help the city would be so unthinking as to help a traitor like Leocrates. The only other possibility is that Leocrates' supporters are acting in their own interests and against their country's.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
 ἐμμενῶ τῇ ξυμμαχίᾳ κατὰ τὰ ξυγκείμενα δικαίως καὶ ἀβλαβῶς καὶ ἀδόλως, καὶ οὐ παραβήσομαι τέχνῃ οὐδὲ μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ.
remarks:
Thucydides refers here to the so-called Argive alliance. He indicates that each city will swear the oath that is most binding in their land. The Athenians were to swear on behalf of their allies, whereas the Argives, Mantineans, Eleans, and their allies were to swear individually by state. 
It is stipulated that for the renewal of the oath the Athenians will travel to Elis, Mantinea, and Argos, thirty days before the Olympic games, and the Argives, Eleans and Mantineans will travel to Athens ten days before the Great Panathenaea. 
Thucydides states that the Corinthians did not join (literally 'join in swearing') this offensive and defensive alliance, but were content with their first alliance with Argos (see oath id 1698) which was defensive only. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Blepyrus is her blessed and thrice-happy master]
 ὦ δέσποτ’, ὦ μακάριε καὶ τρισόλβιε. 
 {Βλ.}  ἐγώ; {Θε.} σὺ μέντοι, νὴ Δί’

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That he is not shitting any more]
  οὗτος, τί ποιεῖς; οὔτι που χέζεις; {Βλ.} ἐγώ;
  οὐ δῆτ’ ἔτι γε μὰ τὸν Δί’

author: Aristophanes
title: Heroes
statement:
[That the hero in question is not Argive (nor even Greek)]
{Α.} οὐκ ἠγόρευον; οὗτός ἐστ’ οὐκ Ἀργόλας.
{Β.} μὰ Δί’ οὐδέ γ’ Ἕλλην, ὅσον ἔμοιγε φαίνεται.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That it is perhaps the case that, as with other crafts, the legislator can be good or bad]
 Ἴσως ἄρα νὴ Δί’ ἔσται, ὥσπερ ἐν ταῖς ἄλλαις τέχναις, καὶ νομοθέτης ὁ μὲν ἀγαθός, ὁ δὲ κακός

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: He would not have to serve as ambassador
if_refused: He would have to serve as ambassador
impact: Demosthenes did not serve as ambassador
statement: ? That he was unwell and could not serve as an ambassador]
remarks: To add further weight to his sworn statement that he would not have gone as an ambassador to Philip if it had not been for his wish to rescue the prisoners of war, he reminds the jurors that he twice took the exomosia when he was elected for the third embassy to Philip (see also oath id 3765).

title: IG I(3)
swearer: Hannibal, son of Gisgo; Himilco, son of Hanno
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would be true to their alliance with Athens]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Carthage. 
Although this restoration seems to have been accepted by most scholars, in his translation of the text Fornara claimed, "the restoration of this inscription is almost purely hypothetical". For the names of the swearers see Diodorus 13.80.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
statement:
[That he believes Phaedrus has learnt Lysias' speech by heart unless it was very long]
 ἐγὼ οἶμαι, νὴ τὸν κύνα, ἐξεπιστάμενος τὸν λόγον, εἰ μὴ πάνυ τι ἦν μακρός
remarks: Swearing by the "dog" is a typical expression of the Socrates. Cf. oath id 2548 with cross references.

author: Alcidamas
title: Odysseus: Against Palamedes for Treachery
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a discussion of Palamedes' inventions including weights and measures which, it is argued, provide opportunities for the unscrupulous to commit perjury. For oaths in the context of Palamedes, cf. oath id 1602.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
impact: Leads Tereus to an alternative suggestion
statement:
[That he would not settle in Lepreus because of Melanthius]
 Τί οὐ τὸν Ἠλεῖον Λέπρεον οἰκίζετον 
  ἐλθόνθ’;  
  {ΠΕ.}  Ὁτιὴ νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς ὅσ’ οὐκ ἰδὼν 
  βδελύττομαι τὸν Λέπρεον ἀπὸ Μελανθίου.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 151: "the point of the joke is that Melanthius suffered from an unsightly skin-disease" (lepra - not necessarily what we would now call leprosy), and Peisetaerus, knowing Melanthius and therefore knowing what lepra is like, does not wish to live in a place with so ill-omened a name as Lepreus.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife; Greek generals; Greek lochagoi
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
[That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
When the Persians began to burn their own territory in order to deny the Greeks the opportunity to find provisions, Xenophon observed to his men, "Do you not see that the Persians admit the country is now ours? For while they stipulated when they made the treaty that there should be no burning of the King's territory, now they are doing that very thing themselves, as though the land were another's". 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he is glad he asked Cyrus the question (as to why Cyrus had given a more honourable place to Chrysantas than to him)]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ὦ Κῦρε, ἥδομαί γε ταῦτά σε ἐρωτήσας.
remarks: The reason he is glad is that he will now try to emulate Chrysantas. Swearing by Hera is typical of Socrates, but it also occasionally attested in other speakers, some apparently from the same deme as Socrates, but some apparently just displaying Socrates' influence on Xenophon's own speech and composition, as here. See oath id 1870 with cross references.

author: Pindar
title: Olympian 2
statement:
[That no city within a century had produced a man more beneficent to his friends in spirit and more generous of hand than Theron]
 αὐδάσομαι ἐνόρκιον λόγον ἀλαθεῖ νόῳ, 
τεκεῖν μή τιν’ ἑκατόν γε ἐτέων πόλιν 
  φίλοις ἄνδρα μᾶλλον 
εὐεργέταν πραπίσιν ἀφθονέστερόν τε χέρα
Θήρωνος.
remarks: This oath comes in a victory ode for Theron of Akragas, winner in the chariot race of 476 BC. The translation in the oath statement is taken from W. Race. Pindar also swears in his authorial persona at ids 1313, 1315, 1317, 1319, 1321.

author: Demosthenes
title: Answer to Philip's Letter
statement:
[That some of the orators are in Philip's pay]
 καὶ νὴ Δία πρὸς τούτοις τῶν παρ’ ἡμῖν ῥητόρων τινές,

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That she has a beard with her]
 ἔχετε δὲ τοὺς πώγωνας, οὓς εἴρητ’ ἔχειν
  πάσαισιν ὑμῖν, ὁπότε συλλεγοίμεθα; 
 {Γυ. α}  νὴ τὴν Ἑκάτην, καλόν γ’ ἔγωγε τουτονί.
remarks: This is referring to the false beards with which the women will diguise themselves to get into the assembly. Swearing by Hecate, as Sommerstein notes, is regularly a women's oath (cf. oath ids 747, 846, 890), though it could also be used by men (see oath id 908).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
When the Athenians, Mantineans and Eleans and later the Argives made an expedition against Orchomenos in Arcadia, the Orchomenians capitulated on condition that: 
1. they should be received as allies 
2. they should give hostages to the Mantineans 
3. they should deliver up the men that the Spartans had deposited with them. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Plato
title: Charmides
statement:
[That what he says is correct]
 Νῦν ὀρθῶς λέγεις, ἦ δ’ ὅς.  Νὴ Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ.
remarks: Socrates has just told Charmides that what matters is not who it was that offered the definition of sophrosyne, but whether it is correct.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Sparta at the start of the war in 431 as all of the Peloponnesians within the Isthmus except for Argos and Achaea (Pellene was the only Achaean city allied to Sparta), Megara, the Locrians (the Opuntian and Epicnemidian), the Boeotians, Phocians, the Ambraciots, the Leucadians and Anactorians. 
Presumably the Ambraciots, Leucadians and Anactorians joined the Peloponnesian League between 446 and 431. The former date is uncertain. de Ste Croix, Origins of the Peloponnesian War, p124, considers these states off too little consequence to hypothesise a date for their entrey into the Peloponnesian League. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That by mentioning men who have fallen into misfortune he has no wish to reproach anyone]
 οὐ γὰρ ὀνειδίσαι μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐδενὶ δυσχερὲς οὐδὲν βουλόμενος τοῦτο ποιήσω,
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that by mentioning some men who have come to grief he intends to show them that the Athenians eschew violence and insolence like that perpetrated by Meidias. He reminds the jurors about two chorus directors - Sannion and Aristides - who have not been prevented from doing their jobs despite the fact that they could be legally removed. He argues that the Athenians have such respect for their office that they will not touch them. 
He contrasts this with the behaviour of Meidias who dared to punch him in the face while he was serving as choregus.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
impact: Zeus believes Hera and sends a threat to Poseidon through Iris
statement:
[That it is not by her will that Poseidon is afflicting the Trojans]
 ἴστω νῦν τόδε Γαῖα καὶ Οὐρανὸς εὐρὺς ὕπερθε 
καὶ τὸ κατειβόμενον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, ὅς τε μέγιστος 
ὅρκος δεινότατός τε πέλει μακάρεσσι θεοῖσι,
σή θ’ ἱερὴ κεφαλὴ καὶ νωΐτερον λέχος αὐτῶν
κουρίδιον, τὸ μὲν οὐκ ἂν ἐγώ ποτε μὰψ ὀμόσαιμι· 
μὴ δι’ ἐμὴν ἰότητα Ποσειδάων ἐνοσίχθων 
πημαίνει Τρῶάς τε καὶ Ἕκτορα, τοῖσι δ’ ἀρήγει, 
ἀλλά που αὐτὸν θυμὸς ἐποτρύνει καὶ ἀνώγει,
τειρομένους δ’ ἐπὶ νηυσὶν ἰδὼν ἐλέησεν Ἀχαιούς.
αὐτάρ τοι καὶ κείνῳ ἐγὼ παραμυθησαίμην 
τῇ ἴμεν ᾗ κεν δὴ σὺ κελαινεφὲς ἡγεμονεύῃς.
gods_invoked: Gaia; OuranosEpithet(s)wide; Water of Styx; Zeus' headEpithet(s)sacred; Marriage bed of Zeus and Hera
remarks: This oath is volunteered by Hera in repsonse to a threat of violence by Zeus. Cf. oath ids 1334, 1358 and 1363 for divinities swearing by Zeus' head; cf. also oath id 160. Demosthenes Against Boeotus quotes part of the description here where the oath is said to be "the greatest and most awful" power among all mankind. He is highlighting the severity of swearing a false oath (in this case by Plangon) by quoting the Iliadic phrase which calls the water of the Styx "the greatest and most awful oath among the blessed gods". See oath id 3577.  Hera is saying here that it is not by her will that Poseidon is harming the Trojans and helping the Achaeans; rather, she supposes [!] he must have taken it into his own head to do so.  In fact, Poseidon would not have taken any action had he not been told by Sleep that it was safe to do so (14.354-360); and though Sleep was not acting on Hera's explicit orders, he knew very well that this, or something like it, was what Hera wanted – she was not going to all the trouble of putting Zeus to sleep, and making (and swearing to- see oath id 350) an extravagant promise to a minor god, just for fun – so that what Poseidon did was the predictable, intended and desired result of what Hera did and said.  All the same, there was enough of a break in the chain of causation to keep the oath formally true.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That, though it is bad that an oligarchic state gives privileges to the wealthy regardless of their abilities, it is no less bad that such a state is bound to be in reality two mutually hostile communities, the rich and the poor]
 Ἓν μὲν δὴ τοῦτο τοσοῦτον ὀλιγαρχία ἂν ἔχοι ἁμάρτημα. Φαίνεται. Τί δέ; τόδε ἆρά τι τούτου ἔλαττον; Τὸ ποῖον; Τὸ μὴ μίαν ἀλλὰ δύο ἀνάγκῃ εἶναι τὴν τοιαύτην πόλιν, τὴν μὲν πενήτων, τὴν δὲ πλουσίων, οἰκοῦντας ἐν τῷ αὐτῷ, ἀεὶ ἐπιβουλεύοντας ἀλλήλοις. Οὐδὲν μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ἔλαττον.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he turned back after he had set out from home, not because he had heard that the men were doing well, but because he heard that they were suffering, so he returned to do what he could to help]
 ἀπετραπόμην μέν γε ἤδη οἴκαδε ὡρμημένος, οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία οὔτοι πυνθανόμενος ὑμᾶς εὖ πράττειν, ἀλλὰ μᾶλλον ἀκούων ἐν ἀπόροις εἶναι ὡς ὠφελήσων εἴ τι δυναίμην.
remarks:
Some of the soldiers denounce Xenophon before the Spartans, saying that they would have joined the Spartans earlier, had not Xenophon convinced them to do otherwise and led them to Thrace. 
This oath is part of Xenophon's defence of his actions.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that it was a combination of fear and the need for an alliance that brought the Athenian demos to seek an alliance with Thebes - not Demosthenes. 
See also oath id 2670.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that to the present day no one has ever prevailed over them, the laws, or the oaths.  
This presumably means (to the extent that it means anything) that no Athenian jury has ever given a verdict contrary to law or justice as a result of the influence of a prominent politician.   MacDowell, with remarkable mildness, says that Demosthenes "probably underestimates the influence of politicians in the courts". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Sophocles
title: Electra
statement:
[That they, if they do not pay their dues, will not go long without suffering]
 ἀλλ’ οὐ τὰν Διὸς ἀστραπὰν
καὶ τὰν οὐρανίαν Θέμιν
δαρὸν οὐκ ἀπόνητοι.
remarks: March rightly points out that the implicit subject of this very elliptical sentence is not so much “those who do not pay their dues” as “we, if we do not pay our dues” (cf. telou=men). The informal oath formula οὐ + acc., current in Doric and Arcadian (cf. oath ids 575, 576, 1217, 1219, 1230, 2214, 2307), was not used in Attic, and in tragedy it is found only in Sophocles (see oath ids 244, 1978, 1979) and mostly, as here, in lyric.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he does not owe the creditor any money]  
 καὶ ταῦτ’ ἐθελήσεις ἀπομόσαι μοι τοὺς θεοὺς
  ἵν’ ἂν κελεύσω ’γώ σε;
 {Στ.}  τοὺς ποίους θεούς;
 {Χρ.}  τὸν Δία, τὸν Ἑρμῆν, τὸν Ποσειδῶ.
remarks: Str. is willing to swear, but clearly regards oaths as meaningless.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
swearer: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
statement:
[That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
καὶ οὐ μνησικακήσω τῶν πολιτῶν οὐδενὶ πλὴν τῶν τριάκοντα <καὶ τῶν δέκα> καὶ τῶν ἕνδεκα· οὐδὲ τούτων ὃς ἂν ἐθέλῃ εὐθύνας διδόναι τῆς ἀρχῆς ἧς ἦρξεν
remarks:
Andocides cites the oaths of reconciliation as well as the oath of the bouleutai (see oath id 2356) and the Heliastic oath (see oath id 2357) as evidence that the Athenians should not remember past grievances with regard to his own case. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he doesn't want Myrtia to summon him to appear before the commissioners of the market for damaging her stock]
 προσκαλοῦμαί σ’, ὅστις εἶ,
  πρὸς τοὺς ἀγορανόμους βλάβης τῶν φορτίων, 
  κλητῆρ’ ἔχουσα Χαιρεφῶντα τουτονί. 
 {Φι.}  μὰ Δί’

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
impact: Emphasises the silliness of the argument
statement:
[That, following the argument, they must now admit that if a man is overcome by some force to commit evil although he knows it is evil, this force will have to be labelled 'good' (since they have established that 'pleasure' is really 'good')]
 θέμενοι δὴ οὕτω λέγωμεν ὅτι Γιγνώσκων ὁ ἄνθρωπος τὰ κακὰ ὅτι κακά ἐστιν, ὅμως αὐτὰ ποιεῖ. ἐὰν οὖν τις ἡμᾶς ἔρηται, “Διὰ τί;” Ἡττώμενος, φήσομεν· “Ὑπὸ τοῦ;” ἐκεῖνος ἐρήσεται ἡμᾶς· ἡμῖν δὲ ὑπὸ μὲν ἡδονῆς οὐκέτι ἔξεστιν εἰπεῖν—ἄλλο γὰρ ὄνομα μετείληφεν ἀντὶ τῆς ἡδονῆς τὸ ἀγαθόν—ἐκείνῳ δὴ ἀποκρινώμεθα καὶ λέγωμεν ὅτι Ἡττώμενος  “Ὑπὸ τίνος;” φήσει. Τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ, φήσομεν νὴ Δία.

title: Pouilloux, Recherches
statement:
[That they will judge fairly and justly]
 δικάζειν δὲ αὐτοὺς ὀμνύντας [κατὰ τοὺς νόμους ὡς ἰσότ]α̣τα καὶ δικαιότατα·

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
The Plataeans allege that the Thebans have attacked their city in a time of peace (ἐν σπονδαῖς). For the Theban response see oath id. 1580. 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Lacritus
statement:
[That justice concerning mercantile contracts should be obtained before the Basileus]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία παρὰ τῷ βασιλεῖ.
remarks: Androcles asks where else should justice concerning mercantile contracts be obtained, and imagines that someone will suggest the Eleven, the Archon, the Basileus, the Polemarch or the Generals in response. This oath is one of these responses. The suggestion is absurd, since commercial cases fell far outside the Basileus' sphere of responsibility.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That excessive care for the body is an impediment to the good life (for rich and poor alike)]
 Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, σχεδόν γέ τι πάντων μάλιστα ἥ γε περαιτέρω γυμναστικῆς ἡ περιττὴ αὕτη ἐπιμέλεια τοῦ σώματος·

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that his prokatalepsis will enable them to vote justly and in accordance with their oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That  they are not having a civil conflict]
 Μῶν στασιάζετε;  
{ΠΕ.}  Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
remarks:
According to Thucydides, when the Spartan envoys returned to Pylos the Spartans demanded the return of their ships according to the agreement. 
The Athenians accused them of having made a raid against the fort "in violation of the truce" (παράσπονδον) and of other acts that Thucydides claims are not worth mentioning. 
As a result the truce ended and war resumed. 
See also oath id 1649.

author: Sophocles
title: Ajax
if_taken: He can compete freely for Helen's hand
if_refused: Exclusion from competition for Helen's hand
statement: [That he would support Helen's successful suitor should the latter be robbed of his wife]
remarks: This is the same oath referred to repeatedly in Euripides' 'Iphigenia in Aulis', see oath id 182 with cross references. There are some grounds for suspecting interpolation here, though. See Garvie ad loc..

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will not come down to him]
  Μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ μὲν αὐτόσ’ οὔ.
remarks: Myrrhine keeps her word until she is persuaded to come down by the cries of her baby.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
if_taken: He could introduce his son to the genos
if_refused: He could not introduce his son to the genos
statement: [That he believed the boy to be his own son, by an Athenian woman, betrothed to him according to the law]
remarks: Apollodorus repeats his claim that Phrastor refused to swear when challenged and chose to avoid committing perjury, and married another woman, of Athenian birth, in accordance with the law (see also oath id 3727).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Athenians were angry that the Spartans had made a separate alliance with the Boeotians. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1708.

title: Rhodes and Osborne, GHI
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Others as ordered by the Chalcidians
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be an ally in accordance with what has been agreed]
 συμμαχήσω κατ̣[ὰ τὰ ὡμολογημένα.]
remarks:
This alliance between Philip II and the cities of Chalcidice is said to have included a special clause stipulating that neither party could negotiate a separate alliance with Athens. 
The text indicates that both parties should swear "without guile and without craft".  
For the corresponding oaths of Chalcidians see oath id 719, 3864.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That the Athenians should allow Chabrias' son to be robbed of the immunity which his father justly received and bequeathed to him]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία τὸν παῖδα τὸν Χαβρίου περιίδωμεν ἀφαιρεθέντα τὴν ἀτέλειαν, ἣν ὁ πατὴρ αὐτῷ δικαίως παρ’ὑμῶν λαβὼν κατέλιπεν.
remarks:
Leptines, of course, would not have used the words that Demosthenes here puts into his mouth; in fact he wouldn’t have mentioned the son of Chabrias at all.  In other words, Demosthenes is once again being sarcastic or ironical. "What would be a good new law to make? - Ah, yes, of course:  deprive the son of Chabrias of the immunity his father was awarded!"   
Demosthenes is speaking in support of Chabrias' son Ctesippus.

author: Timocreon
title: Fragment
work_date: After Themistocles was exiled from Greece
date: After Themistocles had gone to Persia (465 to 460)
impact: Accusations and charges of Medism leading to ostracism
statement: [That he would abide by his agreement with the Persians]
remarks: Here Timocreon claims that he is not the only one who swears solemn oaths with the Persians. Clearly, the person implied here is Themistocles, who had apparently voted against Timocreon on a previous charge of Medism, and was himself (at the end of the 470s) accused of medism by the Spartans, who wanted to get him arrested (or expelled) because he was stirring up hostility against them in the Peloponnese.  He then fled, first to Corcyra, then to Molossia, then to Macedonia, and finally to Ephesus from where he made contact with the new Persian king Artaxerxes (465). Cf. oath id 1347.

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Isocrates argues that even though the Athenians and Spartans are allied to each other, they are more hostile to each other than to those with whom they are openly at war. 
See also oath id 2030. 
It should be noted that Demosthenes 16 (For the Megalopolitans), in 353, suggests the alliance was by then dead; if it was alive, one would have expected that Dem. would surely have had to argue that the proposed alliance with Megalopolis was quite consistent with the existing alliance with Sparta.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callicles
if_taken: Their statements will carry more weight
statement:
[That Callicles threw rubble on the road, and narrowed the road by bringing the wall forward]
 ἵνα δ’ εἰδῆθ’ ὅτι καὶ τὸν χλῆδον εἰς τὴν ὁδὸν ἐκβεβλήκασιν, καὶ τὴν αἱμασιὰν προαγαγόντες στενοτέραν τὴν ὁδὸν πεποιήκασιν,
remarks: The speaker states that he offered Callicles' mother the chance to swear to her son's versions of the facts (see oath id 3697), and declared that he was ready to summon his own mother to swear to his version (see also oath id 3684).

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
remarks: The donkey, of course, is carrying Xanthias' load because it is carrying Xanthias himself, but Xanthias' point is that he himself is still burdened down, and so his oath is not untrue.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is not possible to know democracy without knowing the demos]
 Δοκεῖ οὖν σοι δυνατὸν εἶναι δημοκρατίαν εἰδέναι μὴ εἰδότα δῆμον; Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔμοιγε.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines warns the jurors that they have sworn to give their verdict on the exact charge brought by the prosecution (ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν ψηφιεῖσθαι ὧν ἂν ἡ δίωξις ᾖ). 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the area of the silver mines is allegedly unhealthy]
 Καὶ γὰρ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, λέγεται βαρὺ τὸ χωρίον εἶναι
remarks: Socrates advises Glaucon that he can use this as his excuse for not having visited them. See remarks on oath id 2085 for context and cf. other entries for 3.6.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That his answer to the Ten Thousand would be speedy]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ τὼ σιώ, ἔφη, ταχύ τοι ὑμῖν ἀποκρινοῦμαι.
gods_invoked: The twin gods i.e. Castor and Pollux
remarks: When the Greeks implored Cleander not to put to death the man arrested by Dexippus, or Agasias who had rescued him (see oath id 2205), and also to take leadership of them if he wished, Cleander replied that he would hand the men back to them and lead them back to Greece if the gods allowed it.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Tyrannus
impact: Highlights the chorus' false sense of security
statement:
[That, if the chorus is a seer and has wise judgement, Cithaeron will be honoured at the next full moon as mother and nurse and birth-place of Oedipus, with dancing]
 εἴπερ ἐγὼ μάντις εἰ-
μι καὶ κατὰ γνώμαν ἴδρις,
οὐ τὸν Ὄλυμπον ἀπείρων,
ὦ Κιθαιρών, οὐκ ἔσῃ τὰν αὔριον
πανσέληνον μὴ οὐ σέ γε τὸν πατριώταν Οἰδίπου 
καὶ τροφὸν καὶ ματέρ’ αὔξειν,
καὶ χορεύεσθαι
remarks: The oath is never fulfilled because the chorus is neither a seer nor wise in judgement. The informal oath formula οὐ + acc., current in Doric and Arcadian (cf. oath ids 575, 576, 1217, 1219, 1230, 2214, 2307), was not used in Attic, and in tragedy it is found only in Sophocles (see oath ids 244, 1978, 1980) and mostly, as here, in lyric.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines urges the jurors to respect their fellow citizens and to remember the oath they swore and the laws. He says that he is sure their verdict will be just, faithful to their oath, and beneficial to them and the whole polis. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
if_taken: They will be eligible to be citizens
if_refused: They will not be eligible to be citizens
statement: [That they shall not bring shame upon the sacred weapons nor shall they desert the man beside them, wherever they stand in the line. They shall fight in defence of things sacred and profane and shall not hand the fatherland on lessened, but greater and better both as far as they are able and with all. And they shall be obedient to whoever exercises power reasonably on any occasion and to the laws currently in force and any reasonably put into force in the future. If anyone attempts to destroy these, they shall refuse to allow him both as far as is in their power and in union with all, and they shall honour the ancestral religion]
gods_invoked: Aglaurus; Hestia; Enyo; Enyalios; Ares; Athena; Zeus; Thallo; Auxo; Hegemone; Heracles; The boundaries of my fatherland; Wheat; Barley; Vines; Olives; Figs
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds the jurors that they have sworn to obey the laws (τοῖς νόμοις πείσεσθαι). The phraseology used here fits the ephebic oath much better than the dicastic oath; if Demosthenes had been referring to the latter, he would have written κατὰ τοὺς νόμους ψηφιεῖσθαι. 
For other references to the ephebic oath see oath id 340.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
The Thebans respond to the allegation by the Plataeans that they attacked them in a time of peace (see oath id 1579). 
The Thebans claim that they were attempting to put an end to Plataea's alliance with an outsider i.e. Athens (see oath id 1561). 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Dicaeogenes
statement:
[That they would declare what they regarded as true from the statements]
 ἀποφήνασθαι ἃ ἐγίγνωσκον ἀληθέστατα ἐκ τῶν λεγομένων
remarks:
Menexenus states that after the arbitrators had deliberated, the arbitrators he had chosen (Diotimus and Melanopus) expressed their readiness to declare what they regarded as the truth, with or without an oath. 
However, the arbitrators chosen by his opponents (Diopeithes and Demaratus) refused. Menexenus points out that Diopeithes was his personal enemy and Demaratus was the brother of the Mnesiptolemus appointed along with Leochares to act as surety that Dicaeogenes (III) returned the property to the sisters of Dicaeogenes (II). 
Diopeithes and Demaratus, we are presumably meant to infer, saw as clearly as their colleagues what the truth of the matter was, but were unwilling to declare it because to do so would harm their friends.  
See also oath id 3046.

author: Demosthenes
title: For Phormion
statement:
[That Phormion deserves to be acquitted]
 ἄξιον ὄντα νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ θεοὺς ἅπαντας

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
The text indicates that after someone in possession of a disputed slave has been defeated in court he is to hand over the slave within five days. If he does not do so the judge is to give judgement that the successful party in the case is entitled to 50 staters plus one stater each day that the man is not handed over if it is a free man, or 10 staters plus 1 drachma per day if it is a slave. At the end of the year the 'three-fold fines' are to be exacted. "As to the time (i.e. the number of days that have elapsed since the slave/free man has not been handed over), the judge shall decide under oath" (το̃ δὲ τὸν δικαστὰν ὀμνύντα κρίνεν). 
For another oath relating to this part of the judicial procedure see oath id 1094. 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That the man who was finding fault with philosophy was not an orator in the slightest]
 Ἥκιστα νὴ τὸν Δία ῥήτωρ

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That announcing contests and prizes is not the same as announcing shares of rewards for army service]
 Καὶ τί δεῖ, ἔφη ὁ Χρυσάντας, ἐμβαλεῖν λόγον περὶ τούτου, ἀλλ’ οὐχὶ προειπεῖν ὅτι οὕτω ποιήσεις; οὐ καὶ τοὺς ἀγῶνας οὕτω προεῖπας καὶ τὰ ἆθλα; Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, οὐχ ὅμοια ταῦτα ἐκείνοις·
remarks: Cyrus thinks sharing booty is a different thing from proclaiming competition prizes because he thinks booty belongs by right to the whole army.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Pheidippides has been taught to argue against justice]
  ἐδιδαξάμην μέντοι σε νὴ Δί’, ὦ μέλε,
  τοῖσιν δικαίοις ἀντιλέγειν

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
remarks:
When all the envoys who had come to Thebes to hear the King's letter refused to swear the oath, the Thebans sent envoys to the other Greeks and directed them to swear that they would act in accordance with the King's letter. 
However, when they arrived at their first destination, Corinth, the Corinthians refused saying that they had no desire for oaths shared with the King. 
Xenophon observes that all the other cities followed the Corinthians, and this Theban attempt to gain hegemony came to an end. 
See also oath id 1995.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That the text of the decree outlawing Arthmius of Zeleia has been set up in any old place]
 νὴ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ὅπως ἔτυχεν ταῦτα τὰ γράμμαθ’ ἕστηκεν.
remarks:
Demosthenes has the clerk read to the jurors the decree declaring Arthmius of Zeleia an enemy of Athens because he was sent by the Persian king to bribe the Greeks. He says that it was set up by their ancestors because they were concerned that no other person in the world would harm the Greeks for money. 
Demosthenes imagines that someone will respond in this way to his argument. He counters this imaginary objection by pointing out that the decree has been set up "on the right-hand side of the great bronze Athena" (the Promachos) on the Acropolis.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement:
[That he understands that Demosthenes proposes to ask him why he denounces Demosthenes' policy as a whole, but did not prevent any specific actions or indict them, but has brought the indictment after an interval in which he has not engaged much in political life]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ὡς ἐγὼ πυνθάνομαι, μέλλει με ἀνερωτᾶν διὰ τί τὸ μὲν κεφάλαιον αὐτοῦ τῆς πολιτείας ψέγω, τὰ δὲ καθ’ἕκαστον οὐκ ἐκώλυον οὐδ’ ἐγραφόμην, ἀλλὰ διαλείπων καὶ πρὸς πολιτείαν οὐ πυκνὰ προσιὼν ἀπήνεγκα τὴν γραφήν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Blepyrus should do as Chremes suggests in order to be able to have lunch and screw at the same time]
 σὺ δέ γε νὴ Δία 
  δρᾶ ταῦθ’, ἵν’ ἀριστᾷς τε καὶ κινῇς ἅμα.
remarks: The implicit stage direction is that Chremes raises his long comic phallus to his lips, as Sommerstein suggests. See Sommerstein ad 470 for further details.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That he is a herald and has come from Sparta to arrange a settlement]
 Κᾶρυξ ἐγών, ὦ κυρσάνιε, ναὶ τὼ σιὼ 
ἔμολον ἀπὸ Σπάρτας περὶ τᾶν διαλλαγᾶν.
remarks: Swearing by Castor and Pollux is typical for Spartans, cf. oath ids 1151, 1152, 1155, 1162, 206, 1218, 1226, 1227, 1230, 1231, 1232 in this play.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
if_taken: Furies will be honoured by Athenians with sacrifices before childbirth and marriage
statement: [That they will renounce their anger against Athena and Athens]
remarks: The text at 1044 is corrupt, but the line may be treating the agreement between Athena and the Erinyes as a sworn compact. See further Sommerstein ad loc..

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Prior to the destruction of Plataea, the Athenians and Plataeans assisted each other when they were threatened
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides observes, "such was the fate of Plataea in the ninety third year after they became allies of Athens". 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1561.

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
statement: [That the facts pleaded in the litigant's written statement or claim of defence were true]
remarks: The speaker tells the jurors that they should aid not those who try to show that they are the most miserable of men, but those whose statements concerning the facts to which they have sworn in their antomosiai are manifestly the most just.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Encourages Dionysus and Xanthias to move on
remarks: See also oath id 388.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he does not know by what route the gods should fly, but he knows it's not the one that Iris used]
 Ποίᾳ γὰρ ἄλλῃ χρὴ πέτεσθαι τοὺς θεούς; 
 {ΠΕ.} Οὐκ οἶδα μὰ Δί’ ἔγωγε· τῇδε μὲν γὰρ οὔ.
remarks: Sommerstein notes that at 1220, Peisetaerus repeats the oath sworn by Iris at 1210 word for word (see oath id 671).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That he believes that Dinias has been a valuable servant to the polis]
 ἐγὼ δ’, εἰ πολλοῦ τῇ πόλει Δεινίας ἄξιον αὑτὸν παρέσχηκεν, ὡς ἔμοιγε δοκεῖ νὴ τοὺς θεούς,
remarks: Dinias, together with several other distinguished political figures, had been chosen to speak in support of the new law.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That spiritedness is clearly different from reason since children are full of spiritedness as soon as they are born, but come to reason late, if at all]
 καὶ γὰρ ἐν τοῖς παιδίοις τοῦτό γ’ ἄν τις ἴδοι, ὅτι θυμοῦ μὲν εὐθὺς γενόμενα μεστά ἐστι, λογισμοῦ δ’ ἔνιοι μὲν ἔμοιγε δοκοῦσιν οὐδέποτε μεταλαμβάνειν, οἱ δὲ πολλοὶ ὀψέ ποτε.  Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, καλῶς γε εἶπες.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That there is no finer ambition for a man than to become leader of the city]
