 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, καλὸν γάρ, εἴπερ τι καὶ ἄλλο τῶν ἐν ἀνθρώποις.
remarks: Here Socrates engages a young and ambitious Glaucon in conversation at the request of his brother Plato and uncle Charmides. Apparently Glaucon's desperate attempts to become leader of the city (before he was twenty!) were making him the object of ridicule. Socrates succeeded in bringing a halt to Glaucon's attempts. For a similar oath statement cf. oath id 2125.

author: Sophocles
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: unknown
gods_invoked: Dioscuri; EurotasEpithet(s)third; Argive gods; Spartan gods
remarks: Because "nh" does not occur in tragedy, this fragment is most likely to come from a satyr drama. Here Sophocles uses the unusual "Lapersa" to mean the Dioscuri. The swearer is presumably either Argive or Spartan.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Theocrines
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker reminds the jurors that they have sworn to vote according to justice. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
statement: [? That they would not attack each other's territory]
remarks:
The Plataean speaker tells the Athenians that they were so superior to the Spartans in war that the Spartans, even though they held most of the other Greeks in servitude, were glad to see the conclusion of peace with Athens. 
See also oath id 1972.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of King Ariston ca. 545-530 (545 to 530)
impact: Ariston perceived that the gods were involved
statement:
[That Ariston himself had given her the garlands she was wearing]
 Ἐγὼ δὲ ἐφάμην ἐκεῖνον· ὁ δὲ οὐκ ὑπεδέκετο· ἐγὼ δὲ κατωμνύμην
remarks:
Ariston's wife claimed that on the third night after Ariston brought her to his home a phantom appeared in his image and lay with her and placed garlands upon her. 
Ariston entered later and asked who had given her the garlands. She said that he had given them to her, and when he denied this she swore an oath to confirm that he had given the garland to her. 
The seers determined that the garlands had come from the precinct of the hero Astrabacus which was established at the courtyard doors. 
Ariston's wife thus claimed that either the hero or Ariston was the father of Demaratus.

title: IG XII 2
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This inscription refers to the return of exiles to Mytilene as ordered by Alexander the Great.   
The text is fragmentary, but we can determine that 20 arbiters were to be elected by the demos to facilitate the reconciliation at Mytilene. 10 men were to be chosen from the returning exiles and 10 from those who had remained in the city. These arbiters were to decide what to do with the money set aside for the implementation and "the oath which the citizens are to swear" (καὶ περὶ ὄρκω [τὸγ κε ἀπομόσσοισι οἱ] πόλιται·). This was presumably a new oath of allegiance.  
The arbiters were then to put their proposals before the people, who would then deliberate.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides states that after the treaty was made Clearidas brought back the troops which Brasidas had taken to Thrace. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the Opuntian Locrians
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the Opuntian Locrians
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Isocrates refers to "the alliance" formed against the Spartans when they were denying the Greeks their independence, and asks, "What cities of repute did we not call upon to join the alliance?" (See oath id 2019). 
Isocrates goes on to describe the labours of the Athenians, and claims that they did not cease waging war and facing perils by land and sea until the Spartans were willing to enter into "the treaty guaranteeing independence" i.e. the King's Peace. 
See also oath id 2835.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and household (?)
statement: [? That he has not killed]
remarks: Euthycles states that the rules for the oath of the defendant are the same as for the prosecutor (see oath id 3439), except for the fact that he is free to withdraw after making his first speech.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That they should give full citizen rights to everyone in Athens and also to citizens of the states of the empire]
 καὶ νὴ Δία τάς γε πόλεις, ὁπόσαι τῆς γῆς τῆσδ’ εἰσὶν ἄποικοι, 
 διαγιγνώσκειν ὅτι ταῦθ’ ἡμῖν ὥσπερ τὰ κατάγματα κεῖται
 χωρὶς ἕκαστον· κᾆτ’ ἀπὸ τούτων πάντων τὸ κάταγμα λαβόντας 
 δεῦρο ξυνάγειν καὶ ξυναθροίζειν εἰς ἕν, κἄπειτα ποῆσαι 
 τολύπην μεγάλην κᾆτ’ ἐκ ταύτης τῷ δήμῳ χλαῖναν ὑφῆναι.
remarks: The statement is expressed by Lysistrata using the metaphor of wool and weaving. Sommerstein remarks ad 582 that the colonies referred to must be the Ionic-speaking states of Asia Minor and the Aegean.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between  Athens, Arcadia, Achaea, Elis and Phlius. 
See also oath id 446.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
statement:
[That all the jurors who had cast their vote for him had voted for truth and justice, and that he had spoken no lie]
 τἀληθῆ καὶ τὰ δίκαια ἐψηφίσθαι τῶν δικαστῶν ὅσοι τὴν ψῆφον ἤνεγκαν αὐτῷ, καὶ ψεῦδος μηδὲν εἰρηκέναι, εἰ δὲ μή, ἐξώλη αὐτὸν εἶναι ἐπαρᾶσθαι καὶ τὴν οἰκίαν τὴν αὑτοῦ,
remarks:
Aeschines states that surely their ancestors were right to prescribe this oath for the party who obtained the verdict in homicide trials in the Palladium. Although Aeschines only mentions the Palladium, it is generally assumed that his statement applies to other special homicide courts. 
Aeschines adds that the victors also prayed for many blessings for the jurors.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That a ruler who has become popular will have need for a bodyguard]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία, εἶπεν ὁ Σιμωνίδης, δεήσεται μὲν οὖν.
remarks: Simonides is responding to Hiero's question, "Do you say that once a ruler becomes popular he will have no need for a bodyguard?".  Simonides says that a bodyguard will still be needed because "some people are like horses, becoming more unmanageable the better their needs are satisfied".

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That they would not wage war on the Calchedonians until the envoys should return from the King]
 δὲ μὴ πολεμεῖν Καλχηδονίοις, ἕως ἂν οἱ παρὰ βασιλέως πρέσβεις ἔλθωσιν
remarks:
According to Xenophon, the Athenian generals made an agreement with Pharnabazus, that if they should spare Calchedon, Pharnabazus should give the Athenians twenty talents and conduct Athenian envoys to the King. 
They also received an oath from Pharnabazus that the Calchedonians should pay to the Athenians the same tribute they usually paid, and give up the money that they owed in arrears. 
The generals themselves then swore that they would not wage war on the Calchedonians until the envoys should return from the King. Xenophon observes that Alcibiades was not present at this exchange of oaths, but was in the neighbourhood of Selymbria. 
For the oath of Pharnabazus see oath id 1883 and 1885. See also oath id 1886.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
Book 4 begins with a summary of the previous book. Xenophon mentions the treaty between the Greeks and the Persians, and the warfare after Tissaphernes broke the truce i.e. the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians. 
See also oath id 2105.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Lycurgus argues that the oath is the force that holds democracy together. He cites three oaths: the oath sworn by archons, the oath sworn by judges i.e. the Heliastic oath, and the oath of the private citizens i.e. the ephebic oath. He says that each of these men gives this pledge, and rightly. 
See also oath id 2743 and 2745. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That his father (Cambyses I) does not get drunk when he drinks]
 Ὁ δὲ σὸς πατήρ, ὦ παῖ, πίνων οὐ μεθύσκεται; Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη.

author: Anonymus Comicus
title: Fragments
statement: unknown
remarks: The text is too fragmentary to identify the oath statement.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That he has recently gained much credit in Sparta by setting forth in detail the honourable practices to which a young man ought to devote himself]
  Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ὦ Σώκρατες, περί γε ἐπιτηδευμάτων καλῶν καὶ ἔναγχος αὐτόθι ηὐδοκίμησα διεξιὼν ἃ χρὴ τὸν νέον ἐπιτηδεύειν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Emphasises each woman's desire to drink wine first
statement:
[That Myrrhine will not be allowed to swear first unless she draws the first lot]
  Ἐᾶτε πρώτην μ’, ὦ γυναῖκες, ὀμνύναι. 
{ΛΥ.} Μὰ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην οὔκ, ἐάν γε μὴ λάχῃς.
remarks: Again, this oath is taken during the long oath sequence of oath id 1164.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That he does not think it would be pious to acquit Aristogeiton]
 νομίζω δὲ μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐδ’ ὅσιον·

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, the Megarians complained that they were excluded from harbours throughout the Athenian empire, "contrary to the treaty" (παρὰ τὰς σπονδάς). 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he caught Socrates dancing early in the morning]
 ἢ οὐκ ἴστε ὅτι ἔναγχος ἕωθεν Χαρμίδης οὑτοσὶ κατέλαβέ με ὀρχούμενον; Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Χαρμίδης·
remarks: Socrates has taken up dancing, he says, because he has noticed that it provides good exercise for the whole body at once.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That the oxen (which had been seized by the Boeotians) had kept Dercetes well supplied with manure]
  {ΓΕ.} Καὶ ταῦτα μέντοι νὴ Δί’ ὥπερ μ’ ἐτρεφέτην
  ἐν πᾶσι βολίτοις.
remarks: The phrase "well supplied with manure", more literally "in all cowdung" (ἐν πᾶσι βολίτοις) is a surprising comic substitute for a phrase such as "in all good things" (ἐν πᾶσιν ἀγαθοῖς) as noted by both Sommerstein and Olson ad loc.

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
statement:
[That he will not testify for the addressee]
 μαρτύρησόν μοι, ὦ Καλλίκλεις· μὰ τοὺς 
θεοὺς οὔκουν ἔγωγε· κωλύοντος γὰρ ἐμοῦ ταῦτα ἔπραξεν οὗτο&sigmaf .  καὶ διὰ τούτου ἐν ἀποφάσει ψευδομαρτυρήσας ψευδομαρτυρίου δίκην οὐχ ὑφεξε&iota
remarks:
Sommerstein offers the following interpretation of this passage:  X calls Callicles to the stand and asks him to testify, and (by prior collusive arrangement, of course) he says "No, I won’t, because I tried to stop this man [X’s opponent] doing this [what X has accused him of]."  The italicized statement is (we are to understand) false, but because it has been made, not as part of a witness statement, but in the process of refusing to make a witness statement (en apophasei), Callicles is not liable to be sued for giving false testimony since he has not given any testimony at all!!  Of course he had no business making a statement like that to the jury if he wasn’t actually a witness; but he couldn’t help it slipping out … .  In Athens, at the time when Anaximenes was writing, X would have had to prepare a written statement of evidence for Callicles to confirm, and if Callicles refused to confirm it, he would have had to swear that he did not know the statement to be true; but there would of course be no difficulty in composing a statement about which the (non-)witness could truthfully take such an oath.  To take a concrete (if slightly different – and purely imaginary) example: 
 
X falsely accuses Y of beating his wife. 
X prepares a witness statement for Z:  “Y beats his wife regularly.” 
Z, called to the stand, says “No, I can’t testify to that; actually Y has stopped beating her.” 
Z swears that he does not know the prepared statement to be true. 
 
X has thus got Z to tell the jury, falsely, that Y has in the past beaten his wife (and is thus guilty as charged) without either committing perjury or giving false testimony.

author: Sophocles
title: Trachiniae
statement:
[That he was bringing Iole to be the wife of Heracles]
 οὐκ ἐπώμοτος λέγων
δάμαρτ’ ἔφασκες ῾Ηρακλεῖ ταύτην ἄγειν;
remarks: Lichas has been as close as anyone gets in Sophocles to lying under oath at oath id 273. Here the Messenger recalls a statement previously sworn by Lichas to prove that he is lying.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes calls for the clerk to read  to the jurors the decree requiring the ambassadors to administer the oaths, the letter from Philip, Philocrates' original motion, and the one passed by the demos. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That discovering the nature of knowledge is one of the hardest things]
 Ἀλλὰ τὴν ἐπιστήμην, ὥσπερ νυνδὴ ἐγὼ ἔλεγον, σμικρόν τι οἴει εἶναι ἐξευρεῖν καὶ οὐ τῶν πάντῃ ἄκρων;  {ΘΕΑΙ.} Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἔγωγε καὶ μάλα γε τῶν ἀκροτάτων.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That they will abide by the terms of the agreement] 
See also remarks.
remarks: The peace treaty referred to here by the Chorus was originally proposed by Amphitheos at 51-52, envisaged as being between the Athenians and the Spartans. Dicaeopolis subsequently undertakes to make a thirty-year peace treaty with the Spartans alone (see oath id 596). Although a real peace treaty necessarily entails the swearing of an oath, Dicaeopolis never actually swears one in the context of this treaty. However, we must bear in mind that this is a comic treaty of a fantastical nature, exemplified by the fact that it is characterized by physical smells and flavours. But, we should also note that, at oath id 600, the Acharnians assume that the Spartans have sworn the treaty and that their oaths cannot be trusted. This treaty is referred to multiple times throughout the play.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The Athenians attacked Perdiccas, charging him with having exchanged oaths with (ξυνωμοσίαν) the Argives and Spartans i.e. having broken his alliance with them (see oath id 256). 
Perdiccas thus came to be considered an enemy by the Athenians. 
See also oath id 1751. 
According to Thucydides 7.9, Perdiccas and the Athenians made a joint attack on Amphipolis in the summer of 414.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: Aeschines will not have to serve as ambassador
if_refused: Aeschines will have to serve as ambassador
statement: [? That Aeschines was unwell and could not serve as an ambassador]
remarks: Demosthenes states that the matter of the exomosia sworn on Aeschines' behalf is in the public records in the Metroon (see oath id 3766).

title: IG XII 9
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that the demarch should make unknown individuals swear an oath, and if he does not make them swear or take a pledge from those not swearing, he shall pay a fine of fifty drachmas.

author: Philip of Macedon
title: Letter to the Athenians
statement:
[That the Athenians have broken the peace, and/or that he will settle the issue]
 ὡς δὲ προϋπαρχόντων καὶ διὰ τὴν ἐμὴν εὐλάβειαν μᾶλλον ἤδη τοῖς πράγμασιν ἐπιτιθεμένων καὶ καθ’ ὅσον ἂν δύνησθε κακοποιούντων ὑμῶν, ἀμυνοῦμαι μετὰ τοῦ δικαίου, καὶ μάρτυρας τοὺς θεοὺς ποιησάμενος διαλήψομαι περὶ τῶν καθ’ ὑμᾶς.
remarks: It is not clear exactly which statement Philip is calling the gods to witness.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the peace was brought about not through his own actions but by Aeschines and the other ambassadors accepting bribes from Philip. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Thebes and Mytilene. 
The text indicates that the oath was to be sworn by "seventeen citizens from the polis". It is not clear which polis is meant here.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
remarks:
Xenophon addressed the Greeks and said, "Cleanor has spoken of the perjury and faithlessness of the barbarians, and this is understood, I imagine, by the rest of you". 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement:
[That he was not responsible for the death, neither by his own act nor by instigation]
 ἐγὼ δὲ  μὴ ἀποκτεῖναι, μήτε χειρὶ ἐργασάμενος μὴτε βουλεύσας.
remarks:
The defendant tells the jurors that they have to use the evidence to decide which of the two sworn statements - that of the prosecution or his own - is more truthful and faithful to the oath. He then calls witnesses to verify his statement. 
See also oath id for the oath of the prosecution 2483 and oath id 2481 for the oaths of the witnesses.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he does not merely think, but knows, that true rulers hold office and rule willingly]
 σὺ δὲ τοὺς ἄρχοντας ἐν ταῖς πόλεσιν, τοὺς ὡς ἀληθῶς ἄρχοντας, ἑκόντας οἴει ἄρχειν; Μὰ Δί’ οὔκ, ἔφη, ἀλλ’ εὖ οἶδα.
remarks: There is no doubt that Thrasymachus sincerely believes this statement, but Socrates will later show (especially in books VI and VII) that it is untrue.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
impact: War between the Athenians and the Spartans (temporarily) ceased
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides refers to the peace treaty between Athens and Sparta, and commences describing the events that followed. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement:
[That even if one of those (in the house) is sleeping well wrapped up, the merry-making of the speaker and his band of revellers will be eagerly welcomed]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, εἴ τις τῶνδε καὶ ἐγκεκαλυμμένος εὕδει, 
  ἡμέτερον κῶμον δέξεται ἁρπαλέως

title: IG IX, 1(2)
statement:
[That they would not deliberately distance themselves from the Opountians with any pretext or device of their own free will]
 ἔνορϞον τοῖς ἐπιϜοίϞοις ἐν Ναύπακτον… μὲ ’ποστᾶμεν… ἀ<π’ Ὀ>ποντίον τέκναι καὶ μαχανᾶι… μεδὲ μιᾶι… ϜεϞόντας;
remarks: This oath was sworn at the establishment of a colony of Opuntian Locrians at Naupactus.  The text indicates that the oath of allegiance to Opus could be repeated if they desired in thirty years time. The oath would be administered by one hundred men of the Naupactians to the Opuntians, and 100 men of the Opuntians to the Naupactians.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides observes that after the Athenians made an alliance with Argos the treaty between Athens and Sparta was not renounced by either party. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That 'Telamon' was the right song to sing]
 Νυνὶ δ’ ἅπαντ’ ἤρεσκεν· ὥστ’ εἰ μέν γέ τις
  ᾄδοι Τελαμῶνος, Κλειταγόρας ᾄδειν δέον, 
  ἐπῃνέσαμεν ἂν καὶ πρὸς ἐπιωρκήσαμεν.
remarks: The First Athenian refers to a potential oath here sworn falsely during the drunken meeting in the Acropolis (off-stage). It is impossible to know whether such an oath was actually sworn, or whether this is just a "Sophoclean" usage (where a character treats an unsworn statement as an oath- see oath id 236 with cross references). The sentence also seems to be cut short by the return of the slaves (see Sommerstein ad 1238). Telamon was a warlike song whereas Cleitagora began with a reference to “peace and prosperity”, so that a less generous-minded Athenian (like the ambassadors referred to in 1231-5) might have seen the choice of song as evidence that the Spartans were really as hawkish as ever. For a similar situation, cf. Xen. Cyr. I.iii.10.12 in oath id 2313.

author: Aeschylus
title: Agamemnon
statement:
[That Orestes' dead father, as he lies supine, will bring him back]
 ὀμώμοται γὰρ ὅρκος ἐκ θεῶν μέγας,
ἄξειν νιν ὑπτίασμα κειμένου πατρός.
remarks: For the gods swearing a 'great oath', cf. oath id 1511.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives of the Locrians of Oeniadae
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would support the Acarnanians]
remarks: Thucydides states that Demosthenes found upon his arrival at Naupactus that Oeniadae had been forced by the rest of the Acarnanians to join "the Athenian alliance" (τὴν Ἀθηναίων ξυμμαχίαν).

author: Isocrates
title: To Philip
statement: n/a
remarks: Isocrates argues that since great reversals occur, and the Greeks care nothing about former enmities, or oaths, or about anything else except what they believe to be expedient, Philip will be able to reconcile the Greeks and convince them to fight against the Persians.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Eros too flies on golden wings]
 Αὐτίκα Νίκη πέτεται πτερύγοιν χρυσαῖν καὶ νὴ Δί’ Ἔρως γε·
remarks: Cf. oath id 652.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Mantitheus related how Boeotus swore the hypomosia in the name of Boeotus (see oath id 3571), and asks "when a man has thus given judgement against himself that he is properly Boeotus, what verdict can he ask of sworn jurors?". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he is not giving Dionysodorus verbal abuse]
 Σὺ μέν, ἔφη ὁ Διονυσόδωρος, λοιδορῇ, ὦ Κτήσιππε, λοιδορῇ.  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε, ἦ δ’ ὅς, ὦ Διονυσόδωρε

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That Polus cannot say that to possess great power is only to do what seems best to one (since he has already said that great power was a good for its possessor)]
 οὐδὲν γὰρ ποιεῖν ὧν βούλονται ὡς ἔπος εἰπεῖν, ποιεῖν μέντοι ὅτι ἂν αὐτοῖς δόξῃ βέλτιστον εἶναι.  {ΠΩΛ.} Οὐκοῦν τοῦτο ἔστιν τὸ μέγα δύνασθαι;  {ΣΩ.} Οὔχ, ὥς γέ φησιν Πῶλος.  {ΠΩΛ.} Ἐγὼ οὔ φημι; φημὶ μὲν οὖν ἔγωγε. {ΣΩ.} Μὰ τὸν—οὐ σύ γε, ἐπεὶ τὸ μέγα δύνασθαι ἔφης ἀγαθὸν εἶναι τῷ δυναμένῳ.
remarks: Socrates' point has been that it is not good for a man if a man does what he wrongly thinks is best for him.This is an unusual oath in that Socrates interrupts himself before he invokes a deity. So we have the oath formula but no sanctifying deity.  For the interrupted oath, cf. Ar. Frogs 1374 (oath id 509).

title: IC IV
swearer: The person who received the slave as a pledge
if_taken: He will be believed and he will not have to pay for the slave
if_refused: He will have to pay the simple value
statement:
[That neither he himself is responsible for the disappearance of the slave, nor he jointly with someone else, nor did he know about the disappearance]
 αἰ δέ κ’ ἀπόληται ὀ κατακείμενος, δικακσάτο ὀμόσαι τὸν καταθέμενον μήτ’ αὐτὸν αἴτιον ἔμην μήτε σὺν ἄλλοι, μήτ’ ἄλλοι Ϝισάμην.
remarks: The text indicates that if the person who accepted the pledge does not give the oath "as it is written" or does not prove his claim, he shall pay the simple amount.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
if_taken: The boy could be admitted to the genos
if_refused: He could not be admitted to the genos
statement:
[That the boy was truly lawfully begotten by himself, born of Chrysilla]
 ἦ μὴν τὸν παῖδα ἑαυτοῦ εἶναι γνήσιον, ἐκ Χρυσίλλης γεγονότα·
remarks:
Andocides states that Callias changed his mind about his son by Chrysilla and introduced the boy to his genos, the Ceryces. 
Callicles spoke against this, but the Ceryces voted according to the law by which they abide i.e. that the father who swears he is introducing a son who is truly he is own may introduce him. 
Andocides stresses that when Callias swore that the boy was his son, it was the same boy he had previously disowned under oath (see oath id 2363).

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Aeschines states that when he was a delegate to the Amphictyones, an Amphissan saw him and called out to the rest of the Greeks that the Athenians should be banned from the temple under the curse because of their alliance with the Phocians proposed by Hegesippus known as 'top-knot' (Crobylus). 
According to Diod. 16.27.1, the Athenians, Spartans and some others made an alliance with the Phocians, and "undertook to support them".

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: The embassy will depart from Athens
statement: [? That he would guarantee safe conduct for the Athenian ambassadors]
remarks: Demosthenes claims that after the Athenians sent a herald to make a truce with Philip their ambassadors, starting later, travelled so swiftly that they caught up with the herald at Larisa. He argues that they made such speed, despite the dangers involved, because it was in Philip's interests for peace to be made as quickly as possible - insinuating that these Athenian representatives (with the exception of Demosthenes himself) were in reality working on Philip's behalf

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: He will be allowed to preside and judge
if_refused: He will not be allowed to preside and judge
impact: Gymnastic or horse-racing competition judged fairly
statement: [That he will judge fairly and according to the laws]
remarks: Other types of judge are also to swear oaths- trial judges, those voting for new public officials, judges of music contests (see oath ids 2730, 2731, 2732) as well as anyone else who does not bring any gain to himself by committing perjury.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That he really is going to bring his possessions (to give to the state)]
  ὄντως γὰρ οἴσεις; {Γε.} ναὶ μὰ Δία
remarks: See remarks on oath id 827.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That those to whom he gives money do not pay him it back]
 Ἦ καί σοι, ἔφη, ἀποδιδόασιν ὅ τι ἂν λάβωσι; Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ μὲν δή

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Envoys sent to Sparta from Acanthus and Apollonia warned the Spartans that they had heard that the Olynthians had voted to send envoys to Athens and Thebes to conclude an alliance. 
See also oath id 1960 and 1961.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Desired impact is for their words to be believed
statement:
[That what they say is true]
 δεύτερος δὲ ὁ μέχρι τριάκοντα ἐτῶν, τόν τε Παιᾶνα ἐπικαλούμενος μάρτυρα τῶν λεγομένων ἀληθείας πέρι
remarks: Clinias and the Athenian have decided that three choruses should entertain the children of the Magnesians with stories of noble deeds, and tell them that the best life as declared by the gods is the most just as well as the most pleasant. The second chorus should invoke Apollo the Healer as witness to the truth of what they say.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement:
[That the five tribunals are worthless and unfairly constituted]
 νὴ Δία, ἴσως εἴποι τις ἄν, ἀλλὰ ταῦτα μὲν οὐδενός ἐστ’ ἄξια οὐδὲ δικαίως εὑρημένα
remarks: Euthycles states that the proceedings he has named - the laws which order the contending parties at homicide trials to summon one another, to tender evidence, to take oaths - are in practice at all five tribunals (at the Areopagus, the Palladium, the Delphinium, in the Piraeus and in the prytaneion, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his comment.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Plato
title: Laches
statement:
[That Nicias denies that wisdom and courage (andreia) are separate things]
 χωρὶς δήπου σοφία ἐστὶν ἀνδρείας  {ΣΩ.} Οὔκουν φησί γε Νικίας.  {ΛΑ.} Οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That Phalaecus and his men would be allowed to depart in safety wherever they pleased if the Phocians agreed to demolish their city walls]
remarks:
Demosthenes states that the truce between Philip and the Phocians was made between the 21st and 23rd of the month of Skirophorion. He argues that they made the peace after hearing Aeschines' promises that Philip would spare them, but by the 27th of the month Dercylus arrived from Chalcis and reported that Philip had put the Phocians' fate in the hands of the Thebans.  
Demosthenes calculates that this decision was reported some four days after the truce was made. He stresses that none of their cities were captured or taken by storm, and argues that the Phocians were ruined because they made the truce, and that they only made the truce because they thought that Philip would preserve them. 
See also oath id 2624.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would defend each other in the event of the being wronged by their enemies, but that the Camarinaeans would receive the Athenians only if they put in with a single ship, unless they themselves sent for more]
 τὰ ὅρκια εἶναι μιᾷ νηὶ καταπλεόντων Ἀθηναίων δέχεσθαι
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Camarinaeans refused to receive the Athenians in 415, arguing that the terms of their oath were to receive the Athenians only if they put in with a single ship, unless they themselves sent for more. 
The date of this alliance can be deduced from 6.75.3 where Thucydides refers to the alliance between Athens and Camarina "in the time of Laches". See also oath id 1788, 1789, 1790 and 1791.

title: IG XII 5
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That they would deliberate as well as they were able concerning the Histiaeans]
 καὶ περὶ Ἱστιαιέωμ β̣[ουλεύσειν <ἀγαθὸν> ὅ, τι ἂν] δύνωνται.
remarks:
This oath is attached to a treaty between Ceos and Histiaea.   
For the corresponding oath of the Histiaeans, see oath id 742.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker argues that it is wrong for the Athenians to be indignant when their own autonomy is compromised but to ignore violations of the sworn agreement which they made when they occur somewhere else. 
He goes on to argue that it is wrong for certain speakers to urge them to abide by the peace, but allow those who broke the peace to act as they please.  
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Pindar
title: Paean 22
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment refers to someone swearing, but there is no further information to be deduced.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: Calchas will speak freely to Achilles
if_refused: Calchas will not speak freely to Achilles
statement:
[That Achilles will protect Calchas against Agamemnon as long as he is alive]
 τοὶ γὰρ ἐγὼν ἐρέω· σὺ δὲ σύνθεο καί μοι ὄμοσσον 
ἦ μέν μοι πρόφρων ἔπεσιν καὶ χερσὶν ἀρήξειν·
ἦ γὰρ ὀΐομαι ἄνδρα χολωσέμεν, ὃς μέγα πάντων 
᾿Αργείων κρατέει καί οἱ πείθονται ᾿Αχαιοί·
κρείσσων γὰρ βασιλεὺς ὅτε χώσεται ἀνδρὶ χέρηϊ·
εἴ περ γάρ τε χόλον γε καὶ αὐτῆμαρ καταπέψῃ, 
ἀλλά τε καὶ μετόπισθεν ἔχει κότον, ὄφρα τελέσσῃ, 
ἐν στήθεσσιν ἑοῖσι· σὺ δὲ φράσαι εἴ με σαώσεις. 
Τὸν δ’ ἀπαμειβόμενος προσέφη πόδας ὠκὺς ᾿Αχιλλεύς· 
θαρσήσας μάλα εἰπὲ θεοπρόπιον ὅ τι οἶσθα· 
οὐ μὰ γὰρ ᾿Απόλλωνα Διῒ φίλον, ᾧ τε σὺ Κάλχαν
εὐχόμενος Δαναοῖσι θεοπροπίας ἀναφαίνεις,
οὔ τις ἐμεῦ ζῶντος καὶ ἐπὶ χθονὶ δερκομένοιο
σοὶ κοίλῃς παρὰ νηυσὶ βαρείας χεῖρας ἐποίσει 
συμπάντων Δαναῶν, οὐδ’ ἢν ᾿Αγαμέμνονα εἴπῃς, 
ὃς νῦν πολλὸν ἄριστος ᾿Αχαιῶν εὔχεται εἶναι.
remarks: This oath is proposed presumably because Calchas fears the consequences of speaking freely if he does not have a guarantee of protection. It also highlights Achilles' power struggle with Agamemnon.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That piety is a most excellent thing]
 Εἰπέ μοι, ἔφη, ὦ Εὐθύδημε, ποῖόν τι νομίζεις εὐσέβειαν εἶναι; καὶ ὅς, Κάλλιστον νὴ Δί’, ἔφη.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks: The defendant states that he will prove that his accusers are the most reckless perjurers and the most impious men.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That he will never ask Euripides for anything again, except just one thing: some wild chervil]
 κάκιστ’ ἀπολοίμην, εἴ τί σ’ αἰτήσαιμ’ ἔτι, 
πλὴν ἓν μόνον, τουτὶ μόνον, τουτὶ μόνον, 
σκάνδικά μοι δὸς μητρόθεν δεδεγμένος.
remarks: Dicaeopolis is alluding to the alleged occupation of Euripides' mother as a seller of wild vegetables.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Both parties continued to fight against the Peloponnesians
statement:
[That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Athenians, and they would defend each other]
 ὥστε τοὺς αὐτοὺς ἐχθροὺς καὶ φίλους νομίζειν
remarks: For the earlier defensive alliance between Athens and Corcyra see oath id 1833.

author: Aristophanes
title: Unidentified Drama
date: Reference to Agathon gives more precise range (415 to 400)
statement:
[That it is as much like a real dildo as the moon is like the sun]
 κα[ὶ μ]ὴν λέγεταί γ’ ὥϲ ἐϲθ[’ ὅμοιον ποϲθίωι
ἀλη[θ]ινῶι κ[αὶ τ]οῦτο. {A.} νὴ Δ[ί’ 
ὥϲπερ [ϲ]ελήνη γ’ ἡλίωι·
remarks: The feminine plural participles in lines 12 and 17 of the fragment suggest that the swearer and swearee are both female.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Hypereides says that when the Athenians (together with the Thebans) marched west from Thebes in 339, Philip left Boeotia without having achieved any of his aims, and the Athenians and Thebans, returning to Thebes, quickly formalized their alliance.  He adds that the jury will perceive the importance of making the alliance at that time, because otherwise Athens would have been left to face Philip alone and on Attic soil.
See also oath id 2670.

author: Hypereides
title: In defence of Euxenippus
statement:
[That Polyeuctus has the ability to be a capable politician]
 καὶ νὴ Δία καὶ δύνασαι
remarks: Hypereides says, "Once you had chosen to be a politician - and by Zeus you are capable - you were under an obligation not to prosecute private individuals, or make them victims of youthful insolence".

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Cyrus' question about the best way to gain an advantage over the enemy is not an easy or simple one to answer]
 Πλέον δ’ ἔχειν, ὦ πάτερ, πολεμίων πῶς ἄν τις δύναιτο μάλιστα; Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκέτι τοῦτο φαῦλον, ὦ παῖ, οὐδ’ ἁπλοῦν ἔργον ἐρωτᾷς·

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he knows what "kata daktulon" means]
  κατὰ δάκτυλον; νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἀλλ’ οἶδ’.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the women should not be there now (since they should have arrived long ago)]
 Ἆρ’ οὐ παρεῖναι τὰς γυναῖκας δῆτ’ ἐχρῆν;
{ΚΛ.}Οὐ γὰρ μὰ Δί’ ἀλλὰ πετομένας ἥκειν πάλαι.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Hagnias
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker, Theopompus, states that his opponent believes that the jurors ought to believe him despite the fact that he has given no answers, produced no witnesses, sworn no oath, quoted no law, and the fact that the jurors have sworn to vote according to the laws. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of various Greek poleis
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of various Greek poleis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that when the dispute arose between Chalcis and Eretria all the rest of the Greeks took sides in alliance with one side or the other (see also oath id 3835).  
For the involvement of Miletus and Samos in the Lelantine war see Herodotus 5.99 (oath id 1522 and 1523).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes observes that since Aphobus refused to take the oath that he had not acknowledged that Milyas was free and that he had not testified against Demon (see oath id 3524) it cannot be right for jurors who have taken oaths to believe him and convict the witnesses. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Theages
statement:
[That he does not know what Euripides would reply if asked in which sort of subjects the wise have their wisdom]
 Ἐπειδὴ δὲ εἶπε—  σοφοὶ τύραννοι τῶν σοφῶν συνουσίᾳ, ἡμῶν ἐρωτώντων· “Τῶν τί σοφῶν λέγεις, ὦ Εὐριπίδη;” τί ἂν φαίη; ποῖα ἂν εἶναι ταῦτα; {ΘΕ.} Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ οἶδ’ ἔγωγε.
remarks: The discussion is based on an alleged quotation from Euripides which reads "Tyrants are wise by being in company with wise men". The fragment has been attributed to Sophocles' 'Locrian Ajax' but the line also seems to have been attributed to Euripides by Aristophanes (fr. 323), by Antisthenes the Socratic, and indeed by Plato elsewhere (Rep. 568a-b).  They can’t all have been wrong, and the scholiast on Ar. Thesm. 21 (to whom we owe most of this information – including the attribution to Sophocles) is very probably right to suppose that the same line was used by both poets (cf. Soph. fr. 695 ~ Eur. Ba. 193), as is also the view of a scholiast on the Republic passage.  The line is Sophocles fr. 14; cf. Kannicht's Euripides fr. 888b.

author: Euripides
title: Bellerophon
statement: n/a
remarks: <Bellerophon>states that tyrants break oaths to sack cities.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
if_refused: Their safety would not be assured
statement: [That they would give up their arms and cease resistance against Persian rule]
remarks: The reciprocal oath of Megabyzus to Inarus and the Athenians is ultimately broken, though not through any fault of his own. See oath id 3459.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: This inscription refers to an alliance between Athens and Messene, renewed at this time.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
When countering the charge that he was responsible for the destruction of the Phocians, Aeschines claims that "it became clear that the Thessalians and Philip were going to take the field not long before the peace was concluded". 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he is dedicating his shoes to the god as well (as his cloak)]
 Καὶ ταῦτ’ ἀναθήσων ἔφερες οὖν; 
  {ΔΙ.}  Νὴ τὸν Δία.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That if someone could make people attractive to the whole polis, he would satisfy the requirements of the ideal procurer]
 Εἰ δέ τις καὶ ὅλῃ τῇ πόλει ἀρέσκοντας δύναιτο ἀποδεικνύναι, οὐχ οὗτος παντελῶς ἂν ἤδη ἀγαθὸς μαστροπὸς εἴη; Σαφῶς γε νὴ Δία, πάντες εἶπον.

author: Euripides
title: Andromache
impact: Encourages the audience to believe her statement
statement:
[That she did not share Neoptolemus' bed willingly]
 Ζεὺς τάδ’ εἰδείη μέγας,
  ὡς οὐχ ἑκοῦσα τῶιδ’ ἐκοινώθην λέχει.
remarks: This oath is not marked by the usual marker of third person imperative with the invocation of a god. Here we have a third person optative.

author: Hesiod
title: Works and Days
if_kept: The swearer will have no favour
statement: n/a
remarks: Here, Hesiod describes a time when we are told that there will be no favour for the righteous and the good man who keeps his oath; see also oath id 1299.

title: IG XII 9
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Histiaea and Eretria. 
The text indicates that the oaths should be renewed each Olympiad. The text clearly stipulates that the current archai and all future archai will swear the oath. The text also indicates a penalty of ten talents for whichever party transgresses the alliance (a tithe from which will go to the shrine of Apollo).  
For the oath of the Eretrians see oath id 755.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: Between 585 and the lifetime of Herodotus (585 to 415)
remarks:
When describing the alliance between the Lydian king Alyattes and the Median king Cyaxares, Herodotus indicates that "these ethne" make oaths as the Greeks do, but also cut the skin of their arms and lick each other's blood. It is unclear whether Herodotus is referring to the Lydians or Medes (or even the Cilicians and Babylonians since these are described as having organised the reconciliation between the two warring parties).  
For the oath in question see oath id 1276.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Tyrannus
if_broken: May he not be blessed but die accursed
impact: Prompts Jocasta to plead with Oedipus to be reasonable
statement: [That he has not been plotting against Oedipus]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 241.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he doesn't think that a person has knowledge of something when they believe that one and the same thing is a part sometimes of one thing, sometimes of a different thing, or when they believe that now one now another thing is part of one and the same thing]
 Πότερον ἡγούμενος ἐπιστήμονα εἶναι ὁντινοῦν ὁτουοῦν, ὅταν τὸ αὐτὸ τοτὲ μὲν τοῦ αὐτοῦ δοκῇ αὐτῷ εἶναι, τοτὲ δὲ ἑτέρου, ἢ καὶ ὅταν τοῦ αὐτοῦ τοτὲ μὲν ἕτερον, τοτὲ δὲ ἕτερον δοξάζῃ;  {ΘΕΑΙ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.
remarks: Socrates’ point is that a belief which is not consistently held cannot amount to knowledge.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
The Theban envoy argues that the Plataeans have betrayed the Greeks with whom they had sworn oaths against the Persians, and argues that they ought to have betrayed the Athenians because they would have been betraying only one state. 
This argument assumes that the Plataeans had no way to remain faithful both to the Athenian alliance and to the anti-Persian oath; this would be true, if at all, only if the latter had committed the participants to fight for the liberty of Greece against all enemies, not just against the Persians - for which there is no evidence, and which the Thebans themselves never venture to assert. 
For other references to the anti-Persian alliance see oath id 1501.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That the "porker" belongs to a human being]
  Ἀλλ’ ἔστιν ἀνθρώπου γε. 
 {ΜΕ.}  Ναὶ τὸν Διοκλέα, 
  ἐμά γα.
remarks: Dicaeopolis thinks he is referring to the girl's genitals, but the Megarian takes up the statement as meaning that the pig belongs to him. On the double meaning of "porker", see remarks on oath id 611.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That it does not please him at all to say that beauty is not good and good is not beauty]
  Ἀρέσκει οὖν ἡμῖν καὶ ἐθέλοιμεν ἂν λέγειν ὡς τὸ καλὸν οὐκ ἀγαθὸν οὐδὲ τὸ ἀγαθὸν καλόν;  {ΙΠ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, οὐ πάνυ μοι ἀρέσκει.
remarks: See oath id 3161 for context.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that they must keep watch and look forward to ensure that they do not disgrace the goddess Dike (from whom each of those chosen to judge is named), because the sacred trust they have received  from the laws, the politeia and the fatherland to guard all that is good and just in the city is embodied in an oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That (he thinks) his last suggestion made sense]
  οὐδὲν λέγεις.
 {Στ.}  νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς ἔγωγ’
remarks: Strepsiades' last suggestion (when asked how to avert disaster in a lawsuit, with an unwinnable case and no witnesses) had been to hang himself; he justifies this by the argument that "nobody's going to bring a case to court against me when I'm dead".

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
swearer: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
Having discussed the decrees and laws which (he claims) make it illegal to prosecute him now for what he is alleged to have done in 415 [not that that's actually what he is being prosecuted for!], he now turns to the oaths that Athenians swore "after the reconciliation" i.e. in 403/2 - one for the whole people, one for the Council, and one for the jurors. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Plato
title: Euthyphro
statement:
[That he does not think that care will harm the object cared for]
 ἢ ἐπὶ βλάβῃ οἴει τοῦ θεραπευομένου τὴν θεραπείαν εἶναι; {ΕΥΘ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks: Xenophon refers here to the so-called Argive alliance of ca. 420 (see also oath id 251). Describing events of 399 he states that the Spartan declaration of war against Elis in that year was partly due to long-standing resentment of the alliance they had made with the Athenians, Argives and Mantineans - even though this alliance had long lapsed, and Athenians actually took part in the Elean war as Allies of Sparta (3.2.25). The Spartans' more immediate grievances concerned the Eleans' actions in debarring them from the Games at Olympia in 400, and preventing King Agis from making a sacrifice there to Zeus.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he does not wish to hide anything]
  Ἀλλ’ οὐδὲν ἀποκρύψας ἐρῶ μὰ τοὺς θεούς.

author: Xenophon
title: Apology
statement:
[That he has tried twice to consider his defence but his divine voice opposed him]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δία, φάναι αὐτόν, καὶ δὶς ἤδη ἐπιχειρήσαντός μου σκοπεῖν περὶ τῆς ἀπολογίας ἐναντιοῦταί μοι τὸ δαιμόνιον.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2165 for an almost identical oath statement.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he does himself sleep with the boy all night and every night]
 Οὐδ’ αὐτὸς ἄρ’, ἔφη, συγκαθεύδεις αὐτῷ; Νὴ
Δί’ ὅλας γε καὶ πάσας τὰς νύκτας.
remarks: See oath id 2268 for Socrates' response.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he is not calling Asclepius a boorish sort of god]
Λέγεις ἄγροικον ἄρα σύ γ’ εἶναι τὸν θεόν; 
  {ΚΑ.}  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’
remarks: Carion proceeds to commit a more serious blasphemy by calling the god a shit-eater.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he doesn't think that people who are skilled in musical theory are skilled in dialectic, except for a very few]
 Τοῦ προοιμίου, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, ἢ τίνος λέγεις; ἢ οὐκ ἴσμεν ὅτι πάντα ταῦτα προοίμιά ἐστιν αὐτοῦ τοῦ νόμου ὃν δεῖ μαθεῖν; οὐ γάρ που δοκοῦσί γέ σοι οἱ ταῦτα δεινοὶ διαλεκτικοὶ εἶναι. Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, εἰ μὴ μάλα γέ τινες ὀλίγοι ὧν ἐγὼ
ἐντετύχηκα.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That he understands how to humiliate those of his friends who wish to appear greater than him]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, τούς γε βουλομένους ἐμοῦ μείζους φαίνεσθαι·
remarks:
Xenophon relates how after the thirty Spartiates with Agesilaus denounced Lysander for behaving more pompously than royalty, Agesilaus dismissed all those Ephesians with petitions who were introduced by Lysander. 
Lysander went to Agesilaus and said, "it seems that you understand how to humiliate your friends." Agesilaus responded, "yes, by Zeus, I do, at any rate those who wish to appear greater than I".

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That the Athenians will serve as councillors and jurors without the payments]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’ ἀμισθεὶ ταῦτα ποιήσομεν
remarks: Diodorus asks Timocrates what the Athenians are going to do for the first eight prytanies if they are unable to pay their councillors because of Timocrates’ law (see oath id 3475). He asks if the Athenians are never to meet and deliberate? If so, shall they still be living under democracy? Shall there be no sessions of the courts, civil or criminal? If so, what security will there be for complainants? Shall councillors not attend at their office to transact their legal business? If so, what remains but complete disorganization? He imagines that Timocrates will respond in this way to his question.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
if_taken: They can compete freely for Helen's hand
if_refused: Exclusion from the competition for Helen's hand
statement: [That they would support whoever became Helen's husband should someone take her from the house, that they would all march against him and sack his city with force of arms, be he Greek or Asiatic]
remarks: Cf. oath ids 182, 183, 185.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Menecles
if_refused: They could not render their decision
statement:
[That they would decide what was to the common good of those in dispute]
 τὰ συμφέροντα γνώσεσθαι
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that he submitted his dispute with Menecles' brother for arbitration in order to prevent people from perceiving him as setting the two brothers against each other. 
After swearing to decide what was in their common interests, the arbitrators gave as their verdict that his party should give up what his opponent claimed and hand it over as a free gift, and then made both parties swear to behave in a proper manner towards one another (see oath id 3027).

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
if_taken: Allowed to compete for Helen's hand
if_refused: Exclusion from competition for Helen's hand
statement: [That they would support whoever became Helen's husband should someone take her from the house, that they would all march against him and sack his city with force of arms, be he Greek or Asiatic]
remarks: Aristotle illustrates the distinction between "commonplace" and "specific" facts by the case of Achilles.  Commonplace facts about him include the fact that (like many others) he was one of the demigods or that he took part in the Trojan expedition; examples of specific facts, unique to Achilles, are that he killed Hector, or that he took part in the Trojan war although he was not under constraint of oath. Traditionally Achilles had arrived late at Sparta and was not counted amongst Helen's suitors (cf. Hesiod fr. 204.87-93, our earliest source for the story that Achilles arrived late). On this oath, see further, e.g. oath ids 182-4, 1308.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
if_taken: He could introduce his son to the phratry
statement:
[That he knew Euxitheus was an Athenian, born of an Athenian woman betrothed to him]
 ἀστὸν ἐξ ἀστῆς ἐγγυη τῆς αὑτῷ γεγενημένον εἰδώς,
remarks: Euxitheus tells the jurors that his father swore the customary oath and introduced him to the phratry members, and that this has been presented in testimony.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That Euripides will be getting what he deserves]
 Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ καὶ δίκαιά γ’ ἂν πάθοις.
remarks: The Inlaw is referring to the plot that the women have hatched against Euripides because he allegedly slanders them in his tragedies.

author: Anonymus Lesbius
title: Fragment
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment refers to a "great oath" but no further details are known.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That he is afraid that in describing Aeschines to the jury in proper terms he may be thought to have chosen topics that are inappropriate for himself]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ θεοὺς ὀκνῶ μὴ περὶ σοῦ τὰ προσήκοντα λέγων αὐτὸς οὐ προσήκοντας ἐμαυτῷ δόξω προῃρῆσθαι λόγους.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: Hypnos will help Hera beguile Zeus by putting him to sleep
impact: Hypnos makes Zeus sleep after Hera and Zeus sleep together
statement:
[That she will give Hypnos Pasithea] 
  ῝Ως φάτο, χήρατο δ’ ῞Υπνος, ἀμειβόμενος δὲ προσηύδα·  
ἄγρει νῦν μοι ὄμοσσον ἀάατον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ,
χειρὶ δὲ τῇ ἑτέρῃ μὲν ἕλε χθόνα πουλυβότειραν,
τῇ δ’ ἑτέρῃ ἅλα μαρμαρέην, ἵνα νῶϊν ἅπαντες 
μάρτυροι ὦσ’ οἳ ἔνερθε θεοὶ Κρόνον ἀμφὶς ἐόντες,
ἦ μὲν ἐμοὶ δώσειν Χαρίτων μίαν ὁπλοτεράων 
Πασιθέην, ἧς τ’ αὐτὸς ἐέλδομαι ἤματα πάντα.
  ῝Ως ἔφατ’, οὐδ’ ἀπίθησε θεὰ λευκώλενος ῞Ηρη,
ὄμνυε δ’ ὡς ἐκέλευε, θεοὺς δ’ ὀνόμηνεν ἅπαντας
τοὺς ὑποταρταρίους οἳ Τιτῆνες καλέονται.
αὐτὰρ ἐπεί ῥ’ ὄμοσέν τε τελεύτησέν τε τὸν ὅρκον,  
τὼ βήτην Λήμνου τε καὶ ῎Ιμβρου ἄστυ λιπόντε 
ἠέρα ἑσσαμένω ῥίμφα πρήσσοντε κέλευθον.
remarks: Once Zeus is asleep, Hypnos stirs Poseidon to defend the Danaans. The oath proposed by Hypnos here is in fact a challenge to formalize Hera's previous promise of the same, cf. Hector's oath to Dolon oath id 349.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That his attendant carried his bedding and the rest of his baggage]
 Φέρων νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, τά τε στρώματα καὶ τἆλλα σκεύη.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Philocles
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The prosecutor (again) argues that the Athenian jurors did not allow the services Timotheus the son of Conon rendered to the state to outweigh their oaths, and that the jurors should not do so presently. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That they are not going to have dinner]
 {ΕΥ.}  Δειπνήσειν μέλλομεν; Ἢ τί; 
  {ΠΙ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: Peisetaerus has called for water to wash his hands before commencing his speech, and Euelpides confuses this with the regular washing of hands before a meal.  Peisetaerus' emphatic response reflects his excitement about revealing his plan (of creating a bird city in the sky; cf. also oath id 635).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That any citizen of Amphipolis or resident Athenian, if he chose, might remain there, retaining possession of his property with fair and equal rights; but anyone who was not inclined to stay could leave within five days and take his property with him]
 Ἀμφιπολιτῶν καὶ Ἀθηναίων τῶν ἐνόντων τὸν μὲν βουλόμενον ἐπὶ τοῖς ἑαυτοῦ τῆς ἴσης καὶ ὁμοίας μετέχοντα μένειν, τὸν δὲ μὴ ἐθέλοντα ἀπιέναι τὰ ἑαυτοῦ ἐκφερόμενον πέντε ἡμερῶν
remarks:
Thucydides states that Brasidas made a truce on the terms that any citizen of Amphipolis or resident Athenian could leave within five days and take his property with him. 
See also oath id 1671.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
statement: n/a
remarks: Athena talks of the witnesses as 'the sworn supporters' of each side's case, but Sommerstein ad loc. reads ὀρϑώματα for ὁρκώματα since 'in the actual trial Orestes and the Erinyes take no oaths before presenting their arguments, nor Apollo before giving evidence and ὁρκώματα is likely to be a corruption due to the mention of oaths in 483 and 489'.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
if_taken: Their wives will have sex with them
if_refused: Their wives will refuse to have sex with them
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: The herald here refers to the Spartan women's demand that the men make formal peace before they will consent to have sex with them again. The men will later agree to this treaty- see oath id 1234 and cf. ids 1238 and 1239.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: see remarks
remarks: This is a law for the market-sellers of Magnesia forbidding them to swear oaths in order to promote their wares to customers. Anyone who disobeys these rules can be beaten with impunity by any citizen present over the age of thirty. Indeed if someone neglects to punish a seller who swears in contravention of this law, that man is himself liable to reprobation for betraying the laws. Cf. oath ids 2723 and 2724 for other laws relating to oaths in the market-place.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
 ἐμμενῶ τῇ ξυμμαχίᾳ κατὰ τὰ ξυγκείμενα δικαίως καὶ ἀβλαβῶς καὶ ἀδόλως, καὶ οὐ παραβήσομαι τέχνῃ οὐδὲ μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ.
remarks:
This inscription records the so-called Argive alliance. See Thucydides 5.47.1-12 for full details.  
The text indicates that each city will swear the oath that is most binding in their land. The Athenians were to swear on behalf of their allies, whereas the Argives, Mantineans, Eleans, and their allies were to swear individually by state. 
It is stipulated that for the renewal of the oath the Athenians will travel to Elis, Mantinea, and Argos, thirty days before the Olympic games, and the Argives, Eleans and Mantineans will travel to Athens ten days before the Great Panathenaea. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the mountains on the border with Chaldaea are not unoccupied]
 Νῦν δὲ ταῦτα τὰ ὄρη ἔρημά ἐστιν; Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη
remarks: Tigranes explains that the Chaldaeans have left lookouts posted on the heights and will come rapidly in force when the approach of an enemy is reported.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he thinks he will surpass Paphlagon in shamelessness]
 Ἔγωγε, νὴ τοὺς κονδύλους, οὓς πολλὰ δὴ ’πὶ πολλοῖς
  ἠνεσχόμην ἐκ παιδίου, μαχαιρίδων τε πληγάς,
  ὑπερβαλεῖσθαί σ’ οἴομαι τούτοισιν
remarks: The Sausage-seller swears by "the fists whose blows he has borne many on many a time from a child up" and by "the slashes of butcher's knives". Presumably he makes a parody of the oath formula by invoking these "shameless" acts as entities in an attempt to suggest that he is more shameless than Paphlagon.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he does not consider the art of swimming something to be particularly revered]
 ἦ καὶ ἡ τοῦ νεῖν ἐπιστήμη σεμνή τίς σοι δοκεῖ εἶναι;  {ΚΑΛ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔμοιγε.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Establishes a false sense of agreement
statement:
[That the cheese-grater said it grated out what it received to the troops]
  εἰ μὴ κατέκνησας τοῖς στρατιώταις ἅλαβες.
  φησὶ κατακνῆσαι. 
 {Φι.}  νὴ Δί’, ἀλλὰ ψεύδεται.
remarks: Philocleon then qualifies his statement by asserting that the cheese-grater is lying.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement:
[That they will add the designation 'son of Plangon' if the are entering the name of Boeotus and the name of Mantitheus' mother when entering his name]
 προσπαραγράψουσι νὴ Δία τὸν ἐκ Πλαγγόνος, ἂν σὲ ἐγγράφωσιν, ἂν δ’ ἐμέ, τῆς ἐμῆς μητρὸς τοὔνομα.
remarks: Mantitheus is asking how they will be able to distinguish between himself and Boeotus if they are both called Mantitheus, son of Mantias, of Thoricus, and imagines (with heavy irony) that someone might reply in this way.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That they would restore the Theban captives if the Thebans withdrew from their territory]
 ἀναχωρησάντων δὲ πάλιν ἐκ τῆς γῆς ἀποδώσειν αὐτοῖς τοὺς ἄνδρας
remarks:
The Thebans withdrew from the city after making this agreement. 
After they withdrew, the Plataeans slew the captives. 
The Thebans claimed that the Plataeans had promised to restore the captives and confirmed their promise by oath. 
The Plataeans claimed that they promised to restore the men if they should come to an agreement after preliminary negotiation and denied that they had sworn oaths.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he would not be willing to give the title of 'good poet' to a man who injured himself by his poetry]
 καίτοι οἶμαι ἐγὼ ἄνδρα ποιήσει βλάπτοντα ἑαυτὸν οὐκ ἄν σε ἐθέλειν ὁμολογῆσαι ὡς ἀγαθός ποτ’ ἐστὶν ποιητής, βλαβερὸς ὢν ἑαυτῷ. Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἔφη·

title: SEG
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That if anyone attacked Sicyon or Messene (or overthrew the demos in these poleis?) they would help with all their strength on land and sea]
remarks:
This inscription records and alliance between Pisa, Sicyon and Messene. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 49.466. For the corresponding oaths of the Sicyonians and Messenians see oath id 581.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That he does not know why Eubulus wishes to attack him]
 ὡς ἔγωγε μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐκ οἶδ’ ἀνθ’ ὅτου
remarks: These words are directly addressed to Eubulus.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he has never come there before and that he has never stolen so much as a hair's worth of Aeacus' property]
  Καὶ μὴν νὴ Δία, 
 εἰ πώποτ’ ἦλθον δεῦρ’, ἐθέλω τεθνηκέναι, 
  ἢ ’κλεψα τῶν σῶν ἄξιόν τι καὶ τριχός.
remarks: Xanthias has been accused of theft because he has been mistaken for Heracles who stole Cerberus from Hades.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
remarks:
Aeschines argues that an investigation of the facts will show that Demosthenes moved more motions concerning the peace and alliance than Philocrates. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Niceratus wants to go home smelling of onions so that his wife will believe that no one would even have dreamt of kissing him]
 Ὦ ἄνδρες, ὁ Νικήρατος κρομμύων ὄζων ἐπιθυμεῖ οἴκαδε ἐλθεῖν, ἵν’ ἡ γυνὴ αὐτοῦ πιστεύῃ μηδὲ διανοηθῆναι μηδένα ἂν φιλῆσαι αὐτόν. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης
remarks: The statement is a joke at Niceratus' expense. He has just been displaying his knowledge of Homer, including the reference to onions as good for having with drink, and has asked for someone to bring him an onion for the others to enjoy it.

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks: Euxitheus argues that because it is very easy to give false evidence against a man on a capital charge, the jurors should acquit him, and at a proper homicide trial the prosecution (and their witnesses) will take the customary preliminary oath before accusing him.

author: Plato
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he won't be quiet]
 Οὐκ εὐφημήσεις; φάναι τὸν Σωκράτη.  Μὰ τὸν Ποσειδῶ, εἰπεῖν τὸν Ἀλκιβιάδην
remarks: An oath by Poseidon may be appropriate to Alcibiades because of his well-known connection with chariot racing.  He must recently have bought the team of horses which helped him to pull off his extraordinary success (1st, 2nd, 4th) in the Olympics of 416, a few months after the party is supposed to have taken place; the memory of this was kept fresh in the early fourth century by the lawsuit for which Isocrates 16 was written.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Evergus and Mnesibulus
statement: [That he was unable to attend]
remarks: The speaker states that when he entered a suit against Theophemus for having assaulted him in the performance of public duty, Theophemus' countersuit against him came up before the jurors first because he did not enter a special plea or a hypomosia for delay. He states that he did not do so because these measures had once been a disadvantage to him in a former suit.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
statement:
[That he fears the Athenians will be forced to gradually yield to Philip as Olynthus, Eretria and Oreus were forced to do because they felt their suffering was inevitable]
  ὃ νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω δέδοικ’ ἐγὼ μὴ πάθηθ’ ὑμεῖς, ἐπειδὰν εἰδῆτ’ ἐκλογιζόμενοι μηδὲν ἔθ’ ὑμῖν ἐνόν.
remarks: Demosthenes states that the people of Olynthus, Eretria and Oreus gradually yielded to Philip because they thought their suffering was inevitable, and then swears that he fears the Athenians will have the same experience when they count their chances and discover that there is nothing left for them to do.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That he didn't ask his wife to tell him where his cloak was]
  εἶτ’ οὐδὲ τὴν γυναῖκ’ ἐκέλευσάς σοι φράσαι;
 {Βλ.}  μὰ τὸν Δί’
remarks: See remarks on oath id 796.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That he does not really understand what Socrates is saying]
 οἶμαι γάρ σε νῦν οὐ μανθάνειν. Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἔφη ὁ Κέβης, οὐ σφόδρα.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes imagines that Aeschines might argue that convicting the peace-ambassadors will lead to hostility with Philip. Demosthenes states that if this is true, he cannot think of a more serious charge to bring against Aeschines. He asks that if the man who paid money to obtain the peace (i.e. Philip) has become so formidable that the jurors will now ignore their oath and justice and only consider how to gratify Philip, what punishment would be appropriate for the man responsible for this (i.e. Aeschines)? 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
impact: Emphasises the similarity between Neoptolemus and his father
statement:
[That they were seeing the dead Achilles alive once again] 
 ὀμνύντες βλέπειν τὸν οὐκέτ’ ὄντα ζῶντ’ ᾿Αχιλλέα πάλιν.
remarks: The Greeks' oath is not technically true, but clearly it is meant to imply the striking likeness that Neoptolemus bears to his father.

author: Philip of Macedon
title: Letter to the Athenians
swearer: Envoys; Representatives of the Persian King
swearee: Envoys; Representatives of the Persian King
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Philip accuses the Athenians of negotiating with the Persian King for a defensive alliance. 
See also oath id 3001.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
statement: n/a
remarks: The speaker argues that it is not surprising that those in the pay of the Macedonian king are so insolent that they insist the Athenians should abide by oaths which have already been broken, for it is impossible that men who have sold themselves to oppose their country's interests to care about laws and oaths.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That courage is useful for the greatest purposes]
 Χρήσιμον ἄρα οὐ πρὸς τὰ ἐλάχιστα νομίζεις τὴν ἀνδρείαν; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, πρὸς τὰ μέγιστα μὲν οὖν.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he has more than enough property to match the fortune of Gobryas' daughter]
 Ἦ καὶ ἔστι σοι, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, οὐσία ἀξία τῶν τῆς παιδός; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, πολλαπλασίων μὲν οὖν χρημάτων

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
