statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The prosecutor states that Demosthenes made an agreement with the demos and proposed "the decree against himself" (i.e. the decree providing for the Areopagus Council to identify and name the persons who had received money from Harpalus), to be kept in the Metroon. He argues that it would be impious for the jurors to invalidate this agreement, or to give a vote which does not conform with the actions of the gods themselves, after they have sworn by the gods themselves. He cites as evidence two mythical cases (the trials of Ares and of Orestes) in which Poseidon and the Semnai Theai, respectively, accepted judgements against them given by the Areopagus Council. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.  It of course bound the juror to vote in accordance with law and justice, not with the actions of any particular god (otherwise e.g. they would never have been able to convict an adulterer!); in any case the gods with whose behaviour they are being urged to conform (Poseidon and the Semnai Theai) are not the same gods by whom they swore the Heliastic oath (Zeus, Apollo and Demeter).

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That the Sausage-seller has fraudulently seized Paphlagon's property]
 Οἴμοι τάλας, ἀδίκως γε τἄμ’ ὑφήρπασας. 
  {ΑΛ.}  Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ

author: Eubulus
title: Unidentified Drama
statement:
[That he has drunk <very well>]
 πέπωκ’ ἐγὼ μὰ <τὸν> Δία τὸν
Μενδαῖον.
remarks: Sicon is a name normally given to cooks. The epithet "Mendaios" is an invention based on the name of the wine.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Agelaus the archon; Polemarchs; Hipparchs; Hippeis; Hieromnemones; Other officials who hold office
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would go in support with all their strength as far as possible if anyone went against the polis of Athens for war or overthrew the Athenian demos]
 βο[η]θ[ήσ]ω παντὶ σθένει κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν, ἐὰν τις ἴ[ηι] ἐπὶ τὴν πόλιν τὴν Ἀθ[ην]αίων ἐπὶ πολέμωι ἢ τὸν δῆμον καταλύει τὸν Ἀθηνα[ίων]·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Thessaly.  
The text indicates that each party will swear their "lawful oath".  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 451.  
For the oath of the Thessalian envoys in Athens see oath id 453.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That a smaller amount of seed should be scattered into weaker soil because Socrates thought less work should be assigned to the weaker]
 Λέγεις σύ, ἔφην ἐγώ, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, τῇ ἀσθενεστέρᾳ γῇ μεῖον δεῖν τὸ σπέρμα ἐμβαλεῖν; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, καὶ σύ γε συνομολογεῖς, λέγων ὅτι νομίζεις τοῖς ἀσθενεστέροις πᾶσι  μείω προστάττειν πράγματα.
remarks: Ischomachus is reminding Socrates of what he had said a little earlier (17.9).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That until now, her boyfriend used to come to her door every day]
  Καὶ μὴν πρὸ τοῦ γ’ ὁσημέραι, νὴ τὼ θεώ, 
  ἐπὶ τὴν θύραν ἐβάδιζεν ἀεὶ τὴν ἐμήν.
remarks: Swearing by the Two Goddesses (Demeter and Persephone) is exlusively a woman's oath; cf. remarks on  Ecc. 153-159, oath id 788.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That she will not let Epigenes go]
  ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἀφήσω μὰ Δία σ’.
remarks: At this moment, Epigenes is the subject of a tug-of-war between the Second Old Woman and the Third; cf. also oath id 838 for the First Old Woman who wouldn't let go.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he will gladly explain his routine activities to Socrates]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος, καὶ πάνυ ἡδέως σοι, ὦ Σώκρατες, διηγήσομαι ἃ ἐγὼ ποιῶν διατελῶ

author: Epicharmus
title: Pyrra kai Promatheus
statement: unknown
remarks: In view of takh’ … k’ (equivalent to Attic takh’ an) it seems very much as though the speaker is saying that the person referred to would have denied a certain proposition on oath (sc. had he been asked to do so?);  cf. oath id 1496, which likewise deals with a hypothetical oath.

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[? That they would guarantee a certain privilege  to the Eretrians if they obeyed the Athenians]
 [- - - - - - - - - ταῦτα δὲ ἐμπεδώσω Ἐρετρι]εῦσιν̣ [πει]θ̣[ομένοις τῶι δήμωι τῶι Ἀθηναίω]ν·
remarks:
This inscription records the regulations imposed on Eretria by Athens. 
The text of the oath sworn by the Athenians is almost wholly restored and contains none of the lingusitic formulae.  
For the corresponding oath of the Eretrians see oath id 146.

title: SEG
statement:
[That they would not conspire to revolt, cause a revolution  or revolt, and would not prosecute anyone or confiscate property or arrest or put to death anyone unless he has been condemned by the law of the polis by more than [200?] in Teos, and by more than 500 in Abdera. They would not set up any aisymnetes; with many [- - -]]
 οὐ̣ βολεύσ̣ω : οὐδὲ π̣οιήσω : οὐδὲ λυ[ή]σ̣ω : ο[ὐ]δ̣ὲ̣ διώξω : ο[ὐ]δ̣ὲ [χρ]ήμ[α]τα̣ : δημιώσ[ω : οὐ]δὲ δήσω. οὐδὲ κατ̣[ακ]τε[ν]έω : ἂμ̣ μ̣ὴ̣ σ[ὺ]ν [- - -]ΙΣΙΝ : ἐν̣ Τέωι [ἢ] π̣λέο̣σ[ι]ν [κ]α̣ὶ ἂμ̣ μ̣ὴ̣ ὐ̣π[ὸ] πόλεω[ς] : ν[ό]μο : καταλαφθέν[τ]α̣ : ἐν δὲ Ἀβδή[ρ]οισιν : [σ]ὺμ πε̣ντακο̣[σ]ίοισιν : ἢ πλ[έο]σιν αἰσυμνήτην : οὐ στήσω̣ [ο]ὔτε· σὺμ πολλοῖσιν - - -

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Aetolia.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Herodotus indicates that during the Lelantine war the Milesians came to the assistance of the Eretrians, while the Samians assisted Chalcis (see oath id 1523).  
For Thucydides on the alliances at the time of the Lelantine war see oath id 1518.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
statement:
[That poleis devise many means for defence and safety, namely palisades, walls, trenches and things like these]
 ἔστι τοίνυν νὴ Δί’,’ ἔφην ἐγώ, ‘παντοδαπὰ εὑρημένα ταῖς πόλεσιν πρὸς φυλακὴν καὶ σωτηρίαν, οἷον χαρακώματα καὶ τείχη καὶ τάφροι καὶ τἄλλ’ ὅσα τοιαῦτα.
remarks:
Demosthenes is relating to the Athenians a conversation he had with the Messenians and the Argives. 
This passage is an interesting example of a paradox at the heart of the 'imaginary objector' oath and other rhetorical usages of a similar kind.  Demosthenes' actual point is that walls, trenches, etc., are not all that important; the real protection of a democratic state is something quite different, namely mistrust (especially of tyrants).  In other words, the oath actually devalues the statement to which it is attached.  This is not, I think, because oaths were coming to have little value.  Rather, the ploy is to affirm the truth of a statement, and by that very affirmation to cast doubt on its importance, as English does with "To be sure" and "It is true that" and German with zwar.

author: Sophocles
title: Electra
statement:
[That Chrysothemis is not mocking when she says that Orestes has returned]
 Χρ. πάρεστ’ ᾿Ορέστης ἡμίν, ἴσθι τοῦτ’ ἐμοῦ
κλύουσ’, ἐναργῶς, ὥσπερ εἰσορᾷς ἐμέ.
Ηλ. ἀλλ’ ἦ μέμηνας, ὦ τάλαινα, κἀπὶ τοῖς
σαυτῆς κακοῖσι κἀπὶ τοῖς ἐμοῖς γελᾷς; 
Χρ. μὰ τὴν πατρῴαν ἑστίαν, ἀλλ’ οὐχ ὕβρει
λέγω τάδ’, ἀλλ’ ἐκεῖνον ὡς παρόντα νῷν.
remarks: Electra has just heard the detailed report of Orestes' (fictitious) death, and so refuses to believe her sister's oath.

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
The speaker asks how it can be right to trust Callimachus when he speaks on his own behalf when he has been shown to have committed perjury when speaking on behalf of his brother-in-law. 
See also oath id 2972.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [? That Timotheus owes him 44 minas, 38 drachmas and 2 obols]
remarks:
Apollodorus challenges Timotheus to accept his oath as decisive evidence. 
See also oath id 3663.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Empusa is gone]
 ῞Ημπουσα φρούδη.
  ΔΙ.  Κατόμοσον. 
  ΞΑ.  Νὴ τὸν Δία. 
  ΔΙ.  Καὖθις κατόμοσον. 
  ΞΑ.  Νὴ Δί’. 
  ΔΙ.  ῎Ομοσον. 
  ΞΑ.  Νὴ Δία.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 391.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he would like to take his pay and leave without being bothered]
 Βούλει δῆτα τὸν μισθὸν λαβὼν  
  μὴ πράγματ’ ἔχειν ἀλλ’ ἀπιέναι; 
  {ΕΠ.}  Νὴ τοὺς θεούς.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides asks what value Corinth will be to the Athenians if the Boeotians are making peace with the Spartans. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That he invites others to help in recovering a servant who has run away by announcing a reward]
 Εἰπέ μοι, ἔφη, ὦ Διόδωρε, ἄν τίς σοι τῶν οἰκετῶν ἀποδρᾷ, ἐπιμελῇ, ὅπως ἀνασώσῃ; Καὶ ἄλλους γε νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, παρακαλῶ, σῶστρα τούτου ἀνακηρύττων.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That the men accused of bribery at the instance of Demophilus, and punished with death, were guilty of far less serious crimes than Timarchus]
 πολὺ νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω ἔλαττον ἁμάρτημα ἡμαρτηκότες τουτουὶ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου.
remarks:
Aeschines asks rhetorically, whether some individuals alleged by Demophilus to have been involved in bribery (in the assembly and the lawcourts) were acquitted. 
He answers his own question with an oath by Heracles (see oath id 2564), and then goes on to swear that their crime was less serious than that perpetrated by Timarchus.  His argument is that they had been tempted to commit the crime by old age and poverty (whereas Timarchus had merely succumbed to his own lustfulness), so presumably they were convicted of taking, not offering, bribes.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That bodily conditions which lead sometimes to benefit and sometimes to harm are not any more good than they are evil]
 Ταῦτα οὖν, ἔφη, ποτὲ μὲν ὠφελοῦντα, ποτὲ δὲ βλάπτοντα, μᾶλλον ἀγαθὰ ἢ κακά ἐστιν; Οὐδὲν μὰ Δία φαίνεται κατά γε τοῦτον τὸν λόγον

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of King Ariston ca. 545-530 (545 to 530)
statement:
[That Demaratus was not his son]
ἀπώμοσε, φὰς οὐκ ἑωυτοῦ μιν εἶναι
remarks:
Leotychides brought the ephors who had heard Ariston make this oath to testify as witnesses.  
For the original reference to this oath see oath id 1348.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds the Athenians that they provided assistance to Corinthian exiles after the Peace of Antalcidas (i.e. the King's Peace) was concluded. 
For the other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he has the most splendid Cocryraean wings (in his basket)]
 Καὶ μὴν ἔστι μοι νὴ τὸν Δία 
  κάλλιστα Κορκυραῖα τοιαυτὶ πτερά.
remarks: The "wings" turn out to be a double-thonged whip.

author: Lysias
title: Against Agoratus
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal, maintain secrecy, and resist attempts to overthrow the democracy]
remarks: The speaker tells the jurors that in 404, when the Council had been corrupted and was keen for oligarchy, a certain Theocritus (an intimate of Agoratus) entered the Council and informed them that there was a conspiracy opposed to oligarchy. He declined to provide names, "as he was bound by the same oaths as them". At section 13 the speaker names the generals Strombichides and Dionysodorus as the leaders of the movement in favour of democracy.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Spartans sent envoys to Athens to explain that the alliance with Boeotia was not intended to injure Athens. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1708.

author: Demosthenes
title: Epistle 4
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes imagines that someone will respond to his letter by arguing that the Athenians are worse off than the Thessalians, Argives and Arcadians (see oath id 3725) who had the fortune to be in alliance with Philip.  
See also oath id 2951.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That Trygaeus and the slave are not going to eat all the offals by themselves]
 Οὔτοι μὰ τὴν Γῆν ταῦτα κατέδεσθον μόνω
remarks: Hierocles tries to fulfill his oath by attempting to snatch some of the offals away for himself but is stopped by Trygaeus who beats him.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would abide by terms of the compact:
1. They were to have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans;
2. They were to follow the Spartans wherever they led and to fight by their side]
 καὶ ὀμόσαντες ταῦτα ἐμμενεῖν οὕτως
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Olynthians were compelled to send by the Spartan siege to sue for peace. 
After swearing to abide by the agreement the envoys returned home. 
See also oath id 1967.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: [---]cles of Erchia; Demochares of Paeania; Other unknown representatives of Athens
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Amyntas III, King of Macedon. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in Tod, GHI II, 129. Cf. SEG 21.236. The two Athenians named in this entry are the two hipparchs. Their names are listed at the base of the stone in a list of names that includes Amyntas and Alexander of Macedon (in larger letters and presumably a later addition).  
The decree also praises the Athenian envoys to Amyntas and the envoys from Amyntas, Ptolemy, Antenor and [---]son.  
For the oath sworn by Amyntas and Alexander see oath id 404.

author: Pherecrates
title: Tyrannis
statement:
[That the women have only had one drink]
  κὠμνύουσι μὴ ’κπιεῖν ἀλλ’ ἢ μίαν
remarks: The swearers are women who have seized control of the state. The point is that the potters (who are, of course, all women now) have been making such enormous drinking-vessels for women’s use (see lines 4-7) that “one drink” is the equivalent of more than a thousand standard measures (line 10).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That the old man's name is Philocleon]
 ἔστιν δ’ ὄνομα τῷ μὲν γέροντι Φιλοκλέων, 
  ναὶ μὰ Δία
remarks: Sommerstein comments ad 134 that Xanthias swears here in response to audience laughter on hearing the old man's name, literally "Cleon-lover".

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Lacritus
statement:
[That he does not think that conceited people who think themselves clever should covet other people's property and deprive them of it, relying on making a speech]
 οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία οἶμαί γε δεῖν  ἀνθρώπους καταφρονοῦντας καὶ οἰομένους δεινοὺς εἶναι ἐφίεσθαι τῶν ἀλλοτρίων, οὐδὲ ἀφαιρεῖσθαι, τῷ λόγῳ πιστεύοντας·

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Peloponnesians received back their dead and wrecked ships
statement: [? That they would not molest the Peloponnesians while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides relates how the Peloponnesians made a truce with the Athenians when they were defeated off Naupactus.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
statement: [That she is not devising ill for Odysseus]
remarks: Same oath as  ids 537, 539. Here, Circe reminds Odysseus of her oath because she thinks he is afraid of eating her food.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he has never enjoyed a debate as much as the present one, although he has heard many]
 Νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ὦ Χαιρεφῶν, καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ αὐτὸς πολλοῖς ἤδη λόγοις παραγενόμενος οὐκ οἶδ’ εἰ πώποτε ἥσθην οὕτως ὥσπερ νυνί·

title: IC IV
statement: [That they had brought the child to the husband, and that he rejected it]
remarks:
According to the text, if a wife who is divorced gives birth to a child the relatives are to bring the child to her ex-husband in the presence of witnesses. If the man rejects his child, the child will be in the mother's power either to rear or expose. The text indicates that the relatives and witnesses are to be believed (horkioteroi) if they swear that the child was brought to the man. 
See also oath id 3868. 
For the regulation concerning children of serfs see oath id 1127.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
[That they would do as much good as they could for the Athenian people and the colony, in act, word and counsel; that they would not rebel against the Athenians in word or deed, neither of their own volition nor by persuasion; and that they would not subvert the democracy at Colophon, either from within or in emigration]
 [δράσο καὶ ἐ]ρο̃ καὶ βολεύσο [ὅ τι ἂν δύνομαι καλὸν καὶ ἀγαθὸν πε]ρὶ τὸν δε̃μον τ[ὸν Ἀθεναίον καὶ περὶ τὲν ἀποικία]ν καὶ οὐκ ἀποστ̣[έσομαι το̃ δε̃μο το̃ Ἀθεναίον οὔτε λ]όγοι οὔτ᾿ ἔργ[οι οὔτ᾿ αὐτὸς ἐγὸ οὔτ᾿ ἄλλοι πείσομαι κ]αὶ δεμο[κρατίαν οὐ καταλύσο Κολοφο̃νι οὔτ᾿ α]ὐ̣τὸς ἐγὸ οὔτ᾿ ἄ[λλοι πείσομαι οὔτ᾿ ἐς ἀλλεν ἀφιστά]μενος πόλιν ο[ὔτ᾿ αὐτόθι στασιάζον, κατὰ δὲ τὸν ὅρκ]ον ἀλεθε̃ [τ]αῦτ[α ἐμπεδόσο ἀδόλος καὶ ἀβλαβο̃ς νὲ τὸν Δ]ία καὶ τὸν Ἀπό[λλο καὶ τὲν Δέμετρα, καὶ εἰ μὲν ταῦτα] παραβ<α>ίνοιμ[ι ἐξόλες εἴεν καὶ αὐτὸς ἐγὸ καὶ τὸ γέ]νος τὸ ἐμὸν [ἐς τὸν ἅπαντα χρόνον, εὐορκο̃ντι δὲ εἴε]μοι πο[λ]λὰ καὶ [ἀγαθά - - -]
remarks:
This inscription records an agreement between Athens and the oikistai on Colophon. 
The oath was to be inscribed on a stele on the acropolis at the expense of the Colophonians. Another stele was to be set up by the colonists at Colophon.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he had a fall from his chariot]
  ἵππους γ’ ἐλαύνων ἐξέπεσον νὴ τοὺς θεούς.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
swearer: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
Andocides warns the jurors that if they convict him they will be affecting also the other citizens with whom they were reconciled and swore oaths (i.e. the oath of reconciliation in 403/2), and those who were restored from exile, as well as those who were re-enfranchised. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement:
[That he thinks it is not right to mention this monster - i.e. Demosthenes - on the same day as Themistocles, the men who fought at Marathon and Salamis, and the men of Phyle]
 ἀλλ’ ἔγωγε μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς τοὺς Ὀλυμπίους οὐδ’ ἐν ταῖς αὐταῖς ἡμέραις ἄξιον ἡγοῦμαι μεμνῆσθαι τοῦ θηρίου τούτου κἀκείνων τῶν ἀνδρῶν.
remarks:
Aeschines refers to the actions of Themistocles during the Persian wars, the victors at Marathon and Salamis, and the men of Phyle, and swears that he does not think it is right to mention Demosthenes on the same day as these heroes. 
Later the same day Demosthenes was to swear a memorable oath "by those who braved danger on behalf of your ancestors at Marathon, and those who stood in line at Plataea, and those who fought the sea-battles at Salamis and Artemisium, and many other brave men who lie in the public tombs" (18.208); the following few sentences (18.209) show that he had this passage of Aeschines' speech in mind.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Chalcidians in Thrace
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Chalcidians in Thrace
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Argives and Spartans sent envoys to Thrace in 418/7 who renewed their ancient oaths with the Chalcidians, and then made new ones. 
For other references to this old alliance and its impact see oath id 1699. For a reference to the new alliance in 418/7 see oath id 1752.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
impact: Blepyrus believes that Praxagora is oblivious
statement:
[That she doesn't know what was decided at the Assembly]
 {Βλ.}  οὐδ’ ἄρα τὰ δόξαντ’ οἶσθα; {Πρ.} μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ μὲν οὔ.
remarks: Praxagora lies here to conceal her infiltration of the Assembly; cf. also the informal oaths at ids 799 and 801, which are of dubious veracity.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: During civil strife when people fled to Peiraeus (404 to 403)
statement:
[That he is aware that all those people listed by Socrates make a good living by manufacturing and selling various commodities]
 Εἶτ’ οὐκ οἶσθα ὅτι ἀφ’ ἑνὸς μὲν τούτων, ἀλφιτοποιίας, Ναυσικύδης οὐ μόνον ἑαυτόν τε καὶ τοὺς οἰκέτας τρέφει, ἀλλὰ πρὸς τούτοις καὶ ὗς πολλὰς καὶ βοῦς, καὶ περιποιεῖται τοσαῦτα ὥστε καὶ τῇ πόλει πολλάκις λειτουργεῖν, ἀπὸ δὲ ἀρτοποιίας Κύρηβος τήν τε οἰκίαν πᾶσαν διατρέφει καὶ ζῇ δαψιλῶς, Δημέας δ’ ὁ Κολλυτεὺς ἀπὸ χλαμυδουργίας, Μένων δ’ ἀπὸ χλανιδοποιίας, Μεγαρέων δ’ οἱ πλεῖστοι ἀπὸ ἐξωμιδοποιίας διατρέφονται; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη
remarks: The context is that Aristarchus is struggling to feed his dependants; cf. oath ids 2064 and 2065.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he doubts whether he would have had a son more kind to him than Cyrus has been, had he had children]
 οὐ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ὦ Κῦρε, εἰ ἦν οἷος ἔφυν ἐξ ἀρχῆς καὶ ἐπαιδοποιησάμην, οὐκ οἶδ’ ἂν εἰ ἐκτησάμην παῖδα τοιοῦτον περὶ ἐμέ·
remarks: The name of the land is never specified. It is the land of Gadatas and borders on Assyria. The statement gains in poignancy because Gadatas is a eunuch.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Convinces Dionysus that Charon is going to Hades
statement:
[That Charon is really going to hell (lit. the ravens), at least for Dionysus]
  ἐς κόρακας 
ΔΙ.  ὄντως;
ΧΑ.  Ναὶ μὰ Δία σοῦ γ’ οὕνεκα.
remarks: Charon means that (regardless of what his plans might have been otherwise) he will be very pleased to ensure that Dionysus ends up in a bad place!

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement:
[That he did suffer suffer at Conon's hands the insults of which he accuses him, that he was dealt those blows, and that his lip was split so badly that it needed to be stitched, and that he is suing him because he has been the victim of hybris]
 ὀμνύω τοὺς θεοὺς καὶ τὰς θεὰς ἅπαντας καὶ πάσας ὑμῶν ἕνεκ’, ὦ ἄνδρες δικασταί, καὶ τῶν περιεστηκότων, ἦ μὴν παθὼν ὑπὸ Κόνωνος ταῦθ’ ὧν δικάζομαι, καὶ λαβὼν πληγάς, καὶ τὸ χεῖλος διακοπεὶς οὕτως ὥστε καὶ ῥαφῆναι, καὶ ὑβρισθεὶς τὴν δίκην διώκειν.
remarks:
Ariston has his challenge (proklesis) read to the jurors, and states that he was willing to swear to it then, and that he is willing to do so in court. 
After swearing he stresses that he is not perjuring himself, "not even if Conon explodes with indignation". 
He goes on to argue that he has not only explained his claims, but added a (sworn) pledge to them. 
(NB he isn’t actually bringing a charge of hybris, only of aikeia, but he claims throughout the speech that Conon could, on the facts, have been validly charged with hybris.)

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That it seems impossible to recognise that belongings of Alcibiades are his without knowing Alcibiades]
 Ἀδύνατον γὰρ ἴσως σοι φαίνεται μὴ γιγνώσκοντα Ἀλκιβιάδην τὰ Ἀλκιβιάδου γιγνώσκειν ὅτι Ἀλκιβιάδου ἐστίν.  {ΑΛ.} Ἀδύνατον μέντοι νὴ Δία.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes begins his speech by remarking that whenever he hears the Athenians discuss Philip's violations of the Peace of Philocrates he observes that their speeches are manifestly inspired by justice and generosity, and that those who denounce Philip are saying exactly the right thing. 
He goes on to lament that while everyone is saying the right thing, nobody ever seems to get round to doing the right things. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Apollodorus recalls the time when the Spartans attacked Plataea in violation of the peace of 446/5, and reminds the jurors that King Archidamus told the Plataeans that they would be spared if they should break off their alliance with Athens, but the Plataeans refused, saying that they would do nothing without the Athenians. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1561.

author: Lysias
title: Against Theomnestus 1
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
To further criticise Theomnestus' defence tactic (see oath id 2818), the speaker cites a law which reads: "Having forsworn Apollo, let him give security. If he flees the course of justice, let him flee". 
He then argues that "the word 'forswearing' is swearing, and for 'flee' we now say run away". 
This refers to a particular type of situation, even though we don’t know what that situation was, except that it rather sounds as though the subject of the infinitives is a defendant in some type of case or other.  We have chosen to render the key verb as "forswear" which has undergone a somewhat similar semantic development in English: today it refers to perjury or to a sworn renunciation of something, but in Middle English it could sometimes be used as merely a transitive counterpart of "swear"; the OED quotes from the Cursor Mundi (I modernize the spelling):  "The land of Jude he has forborne, / For there they have his death forsworn" (i.e. have sworn to kill him).

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Peisetaerus' idea is good]
 Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ ταῦτά γέ τοι καλῶς λέγεις.
remarks: Poseidon here responds to Peisetaerus' suggestion of an alliance between the gods and the birds in an attempt to curb perjury (on which see oath id 689). Poseidon shows himself up as stupid by swearing by himself.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that he was justly acquitted when indictments, audits and eisangelias were brought against him after Chaeronea, and that his acquittal was a credit to the jurors who swore the oath and gave their verdict in accordance with it. 
Demosthenes goes on to argue that it was fitting for Ctesiphon to describe his stewardship as honest and free of corruption because it had been confirmed so by the "sworn jurors" who acquitted him. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
if_taken: They will be able to judge
if_refused: They will not be able to judge
statement: [That they would decide justly whether each deme member was entitled to remain on the deme register]
remarks: Euxitheus complains that Euboulides wasted time making speeches and introducing decrees, so that when the deme members were sworn in for the diapsephisis it was already late in the day.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is not because of any wish to be a doctor that his collection of books is beneficial to him] 
 Τί δὲ δὴ βουλόμενος ἀγαθὸς γενέσθαι, ἔφη, ὦ Εὐθύδημε, συλλέγεις τὰ γράμματα; ἐπεὶ δὲ διεσιώπησεν ὁ Εὐθύδημος σκοπῶν ὅ τι ἀποκρίναιτο, πάλιν ὁ Σωκράτης, Ἆρα μὴ ἰατρός; ἔφη· πολλὰ γὰρ καὶ ἰατρῶν ἐστι συγγράμματα. καὶ ὁ Εὐθύδημος, Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἔγωγε.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2124.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
statement: n/a
remarks:
The defendant asks, "What accusation would they [the defendants] hesitate to bring, what court would they hesitate to mislead, what oaths would they not break after taking thirty mnas as they have from the Poristai, the Poleitai, the Practores and the clerks attached to them to bring me to court? And after swearing these oaths, all because during my prytany I learned of their scandalous malpractices, brought them before the boule, and showed that an inquiry should be instituted". 
See also oath id 2510, 2512 and 2513).

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That one can only make one's enemies contribute to the city's wealth if one is stronger than they]
 Ἀλλ’, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔφη ὁ Γλαύκων, δυνατόν ἐστι καὶ ἀπὸ πολεμίων τὴν πόλιν πλουτίζειν. Νὴ Δία σφόδρα γ’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, ἐάν τις αὐτῶν κρείττων ᾖ· ἥττων δὲ ὢν καὶ τὰ ὄντα προσαποβάλοι ἄν.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 2085 for context and cf. other entries for 3.6.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he will not buy his son dried figs (instead of knucklebones)]
 ἀλλ’ ἰσχάδας, ὦ παπία· ἥδιον γάρ— 
 {Χο.}  οὐκ ἂν
  μὰ Δί’
remarks: See also remarks on oath id 1075 for context.

author: Pherecrates
title: Korianno
statement:
[That the oil is sticky]
 γλίσχρον γέ μοὐστὶ τὸ σίαλον νὴ τὼ θεώ.
remarks: The speaker is probably the hetaira Korianno, since respectable women did not go to the public baths. Swearing by Demeter and Persephone is a specifically female oath; see remarks on oath id 788.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The text refers to the fact that the Mytileneans have been abiding by the oaths that they have sworn, as opposed to the Spartans who have violated them. This is clearly a reference to the so-called King's Peace. 
For the other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: Representatives; Envoys; Envoys of the allies of Athens; Envoys
swearee: Representatives; Envoys; Envoys of the allies of Athens; Envoys
remarks:
Xenophon observes that the Athenians withdrew their garrisons and sent after Iphicrates and his ships and compelled him to give back everything which he had captured after the time when the oaths were taken at Sparta. 
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That the Moon and the Sun are plotting to betray Greece to the barbarians because barbarians sacrifice to them and Greeks don't]
  Ἡ γὰρ Σελήνη χὠ πανοῦργος Ἥλιος 
  ὑμῖν ἐπιβουλεύοντε πολὺν ἤδη χρόνον
  τοῖς βαρβάροισι προδίδοτον τὴν Ἑλλάδα.
  {ΕΡ.}  Ἵνα δὴ τί τοῦτο δρᾶτον;
  {ΤΡ.}  Ὁτιὴ νὴ Δία 
  ἡμεῖς μὲν ὑμῖν θύομεν

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the "man" speaking in the Assembly (i.e. Praxagora in disguise) said that most of the people here were informers]
 καὶ νὴ Δία 
  τωνδὶ τὸ πλῆθος.
remarks: "Most of the people here" refers to the men of the assembly, who, in turn, are also the members of the audience which are now being indicated by Chremes.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Plataens as allies. 
For other references to the alliance between Athens and Plataea see oath id 1561.

title: IG I(3)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This inscription records an agreement between Athens and Miletus. 
The oath statement is not extant. 
The oath was to be sworn in the presence of the so-called "five".

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Philocleon's dancing was not good]
 οὐκ εὖ; 
 {Ξα.}  μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: None: Penelope does not believe him
statement:
[That Odysseus is already in the land of his fathers, either sitting still or advancing, and is learning of all the evil actions and himself devising evil for the suitors]
 ἴστω νῦν Ζεὺς πρῶτα θεῶν ξενίη τε τράπεζα 
ἱστίη τ’ Ὀδυσῆος ἀμύμονος, ἣν ἀφικάνω, 
ὡς ἦ τοι Ὀδυσεὺς ἤδη ἐν πατρίδι γαίῃ, 
ἥμενος ἢ ἕρπων, τάδε πευθόμενος κακὰ ἔργα, 
ἔστιν, ἀτὰρ μνηστῆρσι κακὸν πάντεσσι φυτεύει
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)first of the gods; Table of xenia; Hearth of blameless Odysseus
remarks: It is interesting to note that this was not how Theoclymenos read the portent originally at 15.530-534, where he simply proclaims that Telemachus and his family will have lordly power forever. Perhaps the present statement is not offered as an interpretation of the omen; rather, this is a separate prophecy, and the omen is merely referred to as being consistent with it (n.b. oi(=on).  It is also worth noting that when Th. interpreted the omen in book 15, he was reacting to Telemachus’ pessimistic apprehensions about Eurymachus soon being Penelope’s husband and Odysseus’ successor unless Zeus were to “bring about an evil day for him before his marriage” (15.520-4); so that his interpretation implied, even if it did not state, that Zeus would do just that.

title: IC IV
swearer: The serf who captured the defendant; The serf's master; One other witness
statement:
[That he took him in adultery, and not by subterfuge]
 μοικίοντ’ ἐλέν, δολόσθαι δὲ μέ
remarks: For examples where men of different status swore this oath see oath id 1097 and 1098.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides states that Naxos was the first allied city to be enslaved in violation of the established rule. 
Presumably Naxos became an ally of Athens after the victory over the Persians. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That she brought things with which she could do some carding while the Assembly was filling up]
  ταυτί γέ τοι νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἐφερόμην, ἵνα
  πληρουμένης ξαίνοιμι τῆς ἐκκλησίας.
remarks: This passage, and the next informal oath reveal the Second Woman's stupidity. Clearly the carding will give her away when she is disguised as a man. See also remarks on oath id 783.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the Athenians disregarded Serrium and Doriscus after the peace was made. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he does not think the Protagorean theory of measure applies any less to gods than to men]
 ἢ ἧττόν τι οἴει τὸ Πρωταγόρειον μέτρον εἰς θεοὺς ἢ εἰς ἀνθρώπους λέγεσθαι;  {ΘΕΑΙ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε·
remarks: The theory referred to is Protagoras' famous doctrine (now known as cognitive relativism) that "the measure of all things is a man", or, as it is elsewhere put, "what seems true for a person is true for that person" (161c).  Socrates has already pointed out (161d-162a) that this doctrine is self-stultifying - for if my beliefs, whatever they are, are as true for me as yours are for you, what right has Protagoras to claim that his doctrines are truer than anyone else's? - and he now adds that the doctrine also implies that Theaetetus is as wise as the gods, since, again, his beliefs are as true for him as (say) Athena's are for her.

title: IG I(3)
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
This oath is an addition to the bouleutic oath. Each new bouleutes now also swore: "If someone coins money of silver in the poleis and does not use Athenian coins or weights or measures, but uses foreign coins and weights and measures, I shall impeach him according to the former decree proposed by Clearchus" (ἐὰν τις κόπτηι νόμισ[μα] ἀργυρίο ἐν τῆσι πό[λεσι] καὶ μὴ χρῆται νομ[ίσμασιν τοῖς] Ἀθη[να]ίων ἢ σταθμοῖς ἢ μέτ[ροις ἀλλὰ ξενικοῖς νομίσμασι]ν καὶ σταθμοῖς καὶ [μ]έτροις, [ἐσαγγελλέσθω ἐς] τ[ὴν βολὴν κατὰ τὸ πρότε]ρον ψήφισμα ὅ Κλέαρχ[ος εἶπεν]) 
This addition to the bouleutic oath seems to be an enhancement of an earlier clause added to the oath (see oath id 3759). 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 28.2. 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Various parties later accuse each other of breaking this peace.  
For the other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Socrates discusses the mature man in love who gives oaths to his young beloved in an attempt to keep him happy. Cf. oath id 2933 and oath ids 363 and 1307 for the proverbial untrustworthiness of a lover's oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That the crow is croaking something different from before]
  Οὐ ταὐτὰ κρώζει μὰ Δία νῦν τε καὶ τότε.

author: Antiphon
title: On the Revolution
statement:
The statement is unknown.  
(start of new column) ξοις ἐδόκει μὰ | τοὺ]ς θεοὺς τοὺς | Ὀλυ]μπίους οὐ| .. ε]ἴ γε ὀρθῶς
remarks:
In this very fragmentary passage it is quite unclear what statement is being sworn to, but most likely the speaker is denying that certain persons, at some time in the past (at the time of the coup of 411?), held a certain opinion.  Gagarin, very reasonably, does not print this fragment, his view being that its "restoration..is mere guesswork" (p.248). 
It should be mentioned that the gaps are likely to be quite small, since the lines of the papyrus are mostly only 8-13 letters long.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
When Lycomedes, one of the Arcadian envoys, refused to swear to abide by the terms sent down by the Persian King (see oath id 1995-6) and said that it was not proper for the congress to be held at Thebes, but rather at the seat of war wherever that might be, the Thebans became angry with him and said that he was destroying the alliance. 
Lycomedes was so angered by this that he and the other Arcadian envoys refused to occupy a seat and departed from Thebes.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement: n/a
remarks: In the context of a discussion which has turned to suggesting that the just man is a kind of thief, Socrates makes reference to Homer's description of Autolycus as being gifted beyond all men in thievery and in the art of the oath (used for deceptive purposes)- cf. oath id 560.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
remarks:
After Xenophon advocated preparing for war, a certain Apollonides, one of Proxenus' lochagoi, opposed him, saying that Xenophon was speaking nonsense in suggesting that they could gain safety by any means other than by winning the King's consent. 
Xenophon interrupted him, reminding him and others that when the Greeks had refused the King's order to disarm, they had forced him to negotiate a treaty, but when, relying on that treaty, the Greek leaders went unarmed to a conference (as Apollonides is now advising should be done again), they were arrested and were now undergoing torture.  He recommended that Apollonides, who had shown himself unworthy of the name of Greek, should be stripped of his rank and made to serve as a porter.  Apollonides was driven out of the camp, and his former colleagues then called a meeting of officers from the whole army and invited Xenophon to address them. 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Antisthenes
title: fr. 187 (Giannantoni)
statement:
[That Homer did not make the character of wise Nestor treacherous and duplicitous]
 οὐδὲ τὸν Νέστορα, τὸν σοφόν, οὐ μὰ Δία δόλιον καὶ παλίμβολον τὸ ἦθος
remarks: This statement is reportedly made during a discussion of portrayal of character in Homer where Antisthenes argues that Odysseus is more blamed than praised by the poet in comparison to other characters.

author: Hesiod
title: Catalogue of Women
if_taken: They will be considered as a suitor
if_refused: They will not be considered as a suitor
statement:
[That none of them would attempt to make Helen his wife without Tyndareus' consent, and they each would attack anyone who attempted to do so]
 πάν]τ̣α̣ς̣ δὲ μ̣νηστῆρ̣[ας] ἀπ̣[ήι]τ̣ε̣ε̣ν̣ ὅ̣ρκι̣α̣ π̣ιστά̣, 
ὀ]μ̣ν̣ύμεναί τ’ ἐκέλευσ̣[ε] και̣ [..]π̣.. ἀρ̣ά̣ασθαι 
σπονδῆι, μή τιν’ ἔτ’ ἄ̣λ̣λον̣ [ἄ]νε̣υ̣ ἕ̣θεν ἄλλα π̣έ̣ν̣ε̣σ̣θ̣α̣ι̣ 
ἀμφὶ γάμωι κούρης εὐ[ω]λ[ένο]υ̣· ὃ̣ς̣ δ̣έ̣ κ̣ε̣ν ἀνδρῶν̣ 
αὐτὸς ἕλοιτο βίηι, νέμεσίν τ’ ἀπ[ο]θ̣ε̣ῖ̣το καὶ αἰδῶ, 
τὸν μέτα πά̣ν̣τας ἄνωγεν ἀολλέας ὁρμηθῆνα̣[ι 
ποινὴν τεισομένους.
remarks: Most of the suitors remain true to their oath, but Odysseus attempts to wriggle out of the second clause of the oath by pretending to be mad. Ultimately however, the suitors join forces to attack Paris, the man who took Helen as wife without Tyndareus' consent.

title: IG II(2)
statement:
[That they were witnessing that the candidate being introduced was the legitimate son of the man introducing him by a wedded wife]
 μαρτυρῶ ὃν εἰσάγει ἑαυτῶι ὑὸν ῏εναι το̃τον γνήσιον ἐγ γαμετῆς· ἀληθῆ ταῦτα νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν Φράτριον· εὐορκο̃<ν>τι μέν μοι πολλὰ καὶ ἀγαθὰ ῏εν[[αι, εἰ δ’]] ἐπιορκοίην, τἀναντία.
remarks: The witnesses swear their oath and give evidence whilst holding the altar to Zeus Phratrios.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: He will not have to serve as ambassador
if_refused: He will have to serve as ambassador
impact: Demosthenes did not go on the embassy
statement: [? That he could not serve as an ambassador]
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that when he was elected to be an ambassador to Philip for the third time, he immediately took the exomosia. 
See also oath id 3770.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
date: After 594/3 whenever an archon took office (594 to 322)
if_taken: They will be permitted into office
if_refused: They will not be permitted into office
if_broken: They will dedicate a golden statue
statement: [That they will exercise their office justly and in accordance with the laws, and not  take bribes on account of their office (if they do, they will dedicate a golden statue)]
remarks: This is a passing reference to the oath of the archons. Cf. also ids 1753 and 1811.

author: Lysias
title: For Polystratus
if_taken: They can join the Syracusan army
if_refused: They cannot join the Syracusan army
statement: [? That they would obey the orders of their officers and the Syracusan people]
remarks:
The speaker is trying to prove his loyalty to Athens and tells the jurors that when he was serving in Catana, a Syracusan arrived with an oath (i.e. to recruit Catanians for the Syracusan army).  
According to the speaker, the Syracusan was ready to make people swear the oath, and was going individually to each person present. The speaker spoke against him, and went to a certain Tydeus and explained the situation to him. (Tydeus - later a general; he perished in or after the battle of Aegospotami, cf. Xen. Hell. 2.1.16, 26 -  was probably a son of the famous Lamachus; see CQ 28 (1978) 383.) 
The speaker does not say whether his initiative succeeded in stopping the recruitment drive, and his silence strongly suggests that it did not.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That the Athenians should try all the generals separately, according to the decree of Cannonus, and if they see fit, his kinsman the younger Pericles first of all]
 κατὰ τοῦτο τὸ ψήφισμα κελεύω κρίνεσθαι τοὺς στρατηγοὺς καὶ νὴ Δία, ἂν ὑμῖν γε δοκῇ, πρῶτον Περικλέα τὸν ἐμοὶ προσήκοντα·
remarks: Euryptolemus addressed the assembly to criticise the proposal of the boule to try the generals who served at Arginusae by a single vote. Instead he advocated trying them separately, according to the decree of Cannonus.

title: CID I
work_date: late fifth or early fourth century
date: Late fifth or early fourth century (424 to 350)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text indicates that if the rules regarding service as tagos were broken the damiourgoi and all the other Labyadai were to exact a fine, but if anyone disputes the fine, "he is to swear the customary oath" (ἐξομόσας τὸν νό[μιμ]ον hόρκον λελύσθω). 
For the oath sworn by the tagoi when taking up office see oath id 916.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That it was not Spithridates that asked him to suggest that Otys should marry Spithridates' daughter]
 Μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη ὁ Ἀγησίλαος, ἐκεῖνος μὲν ἐμέ γε οὐκ ἐκέλευσε ταῦτα λέγειν·
remarks:
When Agesilaus suggested that Otys should marry his son to Spithridates' daughter, Otys asked whether the marriage proposal was acceptable to Spithridates. 
Agesilaus responded, "by the gods, it was not he that asked me to say this". 
Agesilaus had already suggested the marriage to Spithridates who expressed his willingness but doubted that Otys would agree. Spithridates had not empowered Agesilaus to make the offer on his behalf, nor had he forbidden it - he merely expressed doubt that it could happen. When Otys asked Agesilaus whether Spithridates was in favour of the match, Agesilaus said that Spithridates did not tell him to suggest the marriage, but that he was always delighted to think of ideas that would benefit his friends - in other words, it's my idea, not his, but I've reason to believe he'll have no objection. Otys then suggested that Agesilaus should find out whether Spithridates was in favour. Agesilaus then sent Herippidas to see Spithridates and the marriage was agreed.

title: Athenian Agora
swearer: Diopeithes, son of Phasyrcides, of Sunium; Philoneos, son of Ameinonicus, of Sunium; Chalcideus, son of Andromenes, of Sunium; Chariades, son of Charicles, of Sunium; Theophanes, son of Zophanes, of Sunium; Hegias, son of Hegesias, of Sunium; Ameinias, son of Philinos, of Sunium
statement: [? That they would abide by the decisions of the arbitrators]
remarks:
The text records the arbitration of a dispute within the genos of the Salaminioi between the men of the deme Sunium and the so-called Seven Tribes. 
For the corresponding oath of the men of the Seven Tribes see oath id 445.

author: Eupolis
title: Demoi
statement:
[That the swearer will cause him to sit howling]
 (ΣΥ.) καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία κλάοντα καθέϲω ϲ’ [.]....[.
remarks: Aristeides has come up from the dead.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That Paphlagon is not really thinking about how Demos can rule Arcadia]
  Οὐχ ἵνα γ’ ἄρξῃ μὰ Δί’ Ἀρκαδίας προνοούμενος
remarks: According to the Sausage-seller, Paphlagon is not really rejecting embassies offering treaties in order that Demos can rule over all the Greeks (including Arcadia). Rather, the Sausage-seller argues, Paphlagon is thinking about how he can rob and take bribes from the allied states, and how the people can be prevented by the mists of war from perceiving his crimes.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Athenians came to defence of the Corcyraeans in their dispute with Corinth
statement:
[That they would defend each other should anyone attack Corcyra or Athens or the allies of either]
 ἐπιμαχίαν δ’ ἐποιήσαντο τῇ ἀλλήλων βοηθεῖν, ἐάν τις ἐπὶ Κέρκυραν ἴῃ ἢ Ἀθήνας ἢ τοὺς τούτων ξυμμάχους
remarks:
The Athenian envoys tell the Peloponnesians that they have come to assist the Corcyraeans because they are their allies. 
For other reference to this alliance see oath id 1528.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That Aristogeiton's name will be erased from the list of public debtors and replaced by Ariston's]
 ἐξαλειφθήσεται νὴ Δία, ὁ δ’ ἀντεγγραφήσεται·
remarks: The speaker asks what will happen in Aristogeiton convicts Ariston of entering his name on the list of public debtors with malicious intent, and imagines that someone will respond in this way.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
swearer: Lampito; Calonice; Myrrhine; All women present; Lysistrata
swearee: Lampito; Calonice; Myrrhine; All women present; Lysistrata
if_taken: The sex strike will be ensured; peace will be enabled
if_refused: The sex strike will not be ensured; war will continue
if_kept: May she drink from the wine-cup
if_broken: May the wine-cup be filled with water
impact: The sex strike is ensured and peace is enabled
statement:
[That no man whatever, neither lover nor husband shall come near her with his cock up, and that she will pass her life at home, pure and chaste in make-up and saffron gown so that her husband may be greatly inflamed with desire for her, and that she will never yield herself to her husband of her own free will. And if he should force her against her will, she will submit grudgingly and not thrust back. She will not raise her Persian slippers ceilingwards. She will not stand in the lioness-on-a-cheesegrater position]
  Τί δῆτα ταῦτ’ οὐχ ὡς τάχιστα, Λαμπιτοῖ,
  ξυνωμόσαμεν, ὅπως ἂν ἀρρήκτως ἔχῃ; 
{ΛΑ.}  Πάρφαινε μὰν τὸν ὅρκον, ὡς ὀμιόμεθα. 
{ΛΥ.}  Καλῶς λέγεις. Ποῦ ’σθ’ ἡ Σκύθαινα; Ποῖ βλέπεις;
  Θὲς εἰς τὸ πρόσθεν ὑπτίαν τὴν ἀσπίδα, 
  καί μοι δότω τὰ τόμιά τις.
{ΚΛ.}  Λυσιστράτη,  
  τίν’ ὅρκον ὁρκώσεις ποθ’ ἡμᾶς;
{ΛΥ.}  Ὅντινα;  
  εἰς ἀσπίδ’, ὥσπερ, φασίν, Αἰσχύλος ποτέ, 
  μηλοσφαγούσας.
{ΚΛ.}  Μὴ σύ γ’, ὦ Λυσιστράτη,  
  εἰς ἀσπίδ’ ὀμόσῃς μηδὲν εἰρήνης πέρι. 
{ΛΥ.}  Τίς ἂν οὖν γένοιτ’ ἂν ὅρκος; Ἢ λευκόν ποθεν
  ἵππον λαβοῦσαι τόμιον ἐντεμώμεθα;  {ΚΛ.}  Ποῖ λευκὸν ἵππον;
{ΛΥ.}  Ἀλλὰ πῶς ὀμούμεθα 
  ἡμεῖς; 
{ΚΛ.}  Ἐγώ σοι νὴ Δί’, ἢν βούλῃ, φράσω.  
  Θεῖσαι μέλαιναν κύλικα μεγάλην ὑπτίαν, 
  μηλοσφαγοῦσαι Θάσιον οἴνου σταμνίον
  ὀμόσωμεν εἰς τὴν κύλικα μὴ ’πιχεῖν ὕδωρ.
{ΛΑ.}  Φεῦ δᾶ, τὸν ὅρκον ἄφατον ὡς ἐπαινίω. 
{ΛΥ.}  Φερέτω κύλικά τις ἔνδοθεν καὶ σταμνίον. 
{ΚΛ.}  Ὦ φίλταται γυναῖκες, ὁ κεραμὼν ὅσος. 
  Ταύτην μὲν ἄν τις εὐθὺς ἡσθείη λαβών.
{ΛΥ.}  Καταθεῖσα ταύτην προσλαβοῦ μοι τοῦ κάπρου.
  Δέσποινα Πειθοῖ καὶ κύλιξ φιλοτησία,
  τὰ σφάγια δέξαι ταῖς γυναιξὶν εὐμενής.
{ΚΛ.}  Εὔχρων γε θαἶμα κἀποπυτίζει καλῶς.  
{ΛΑ.}  Καὶ μὰν ποτόδδει γ’ ἁδὺ ναὶ τὸν Κάστορα.
{ΚΛ.}  Ἐᾶτε πρώτην μ’, ὦ γυναῖκες, ὀμνύναι. 
{ΛΥ.}  Μὰ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην οὔκ, ἐάν γε μὴ λάχῃς. 
  Λάζυσθε πᾶσαι τῆς κύλικος, ὦ Λαμπιτοῖ·
  λεγέτω δ’ ὑπὲρ ὑμῶν μί’ ἅπερ ἂν κἀγὼ λέγω· 
  ὑμεῖς δ’ ἐπομεῖσθε ταῦτα κἀμπεδώσετε. 
  Οὐκ ἔστιν οὐδεὶς οὔτε μοιχὸς οὔτ’ ἀνήρ— 
{ΚΛ.}  Οὐκ ἔστιν οὐδεὶς οὔτε μοιχὸς οὔτ’ ἀνήρ—
{ΛΥ.}  ὅστις πρὸς ἐμὲ πρόσεισιν ἐστυκώς. Λέγε. 
{ΚΛ.}  ὅστις πρὸς ἐμὲ πρόσεισιν ἐστυκώς. Παπαῖ, 
  ὑπολύεταί μου τὰ γόνατ’, ὦ Λυσιστράτη.
{ΛΥ.}  Οἴκοι δ’ ἀταυρώτη διάξω τὸν βίον— 
{ΚΛ.}  Οἴκοι δ’ ἀταυρώτη διάξω τὸν βίον— 
 {ΛΥ.}  κροκωτοφοροῦσα καὶ κεκαλλωπισμένη—  {ΚΛ.}  κροκωτοφοροῦσα καὶ κεκαλλωπισμένη—  
{ΛΥ.}  ὅπως ἂν ἁνὴρ ἐπιτυφῇ μάλιστά μου· —
{ΚΛ.}  ὅπως ἂν ἁνὴρ ἐπιτυφῇ μάλιστά μου· —
{ΛΥ.}  κοὐδέποθ’ ἑκοῦσα τἀνδρὶ τὠμῷ πείσομαι.
{ΚΛ.}  κοὐδέποθ’ ἑκοῦσα τἀνδρὶ τὠμῷ πείσομαι.
{ΛΥ.}  Ἐὰν δέ μ’ ἄκουσαν βιάζηται βίᾳ— 
{ΚΛ.}  ἐὰν δέ μ’ ἄκουσαν βιάζηται βίᾳ— 
{ΛΥ.}  κακῶς παρέξω κοὐχὶ προσκινήσομαι.
{ΚΛ.}  κακῶς παρέξω κοὐχὶ προσκινήσομαι.
{ΛΥ.}  Οὐ πρὸς τὸν ὄροφον ἀνατενῶ τὼ Περσικά. 
{ΚΛ.}  Οὐ πρὸς τὸν ὄροφον ἀνατενῶ τὼ Περσικά. 
{ΛΥ.}  Οὐ στήσομαι λέαιν’ ἐπὶ τυροκνήστιδος.  
{ΚΛ.}  Οὐ στήσομαι λέαιν’ ἐπὶ τυροκνήστιδος.
{ΛΥ.}  Ταῦτ’ ἐμπεδοῦσα μὲν πίοιμ’ ἐντευθενί— 
{ΚΛ.}  Ταῦτ’ ἐμπεδοῦσα μὲν πίοιμ’ ἐντευθενί— 
{ΛΥ.}  εἰ δὲ παραβαίην, ὕδατος ἐμπλῇθ’ ἡ κύλιξ. 
{ΚΛ.}  εἰ δὲ παραβαίην, ὕδατος ἐμπλῇθ’ ἡ κύλιξ.
{ΛΥ.}  Συνεπόμνυθ’ ὑμεῖς ταῦτα πᾶσαι;
 {ΠΑΣΑΙ}  Νὴ Δία. 
{ΛΥ.}  Φέρ’ ἐγὼ καθαγίσω τήνδε.
linguistic: nh, omei, omiom, omnu, omos, omoum, ork, wmos
remarks: Lysistrata calls upon Peitho and the Cup of Amity to receive their oath-sacrifice. The women collectively invoke Zeus when they swear agreement at 237. As Sommerstein notes ad 203, the Cup of Amity was "a cup by the sharing of which two or more persons pledge friendship to one another". The "if kept" and "if broken" terms and conditions of the oath reflect the characteristic stereotype of women liking their wine neat (see further Sommerstein ad 197). It is noteworthy that the cup of wine used in the oath ritual is brought on by a Scythian; cf. Herodotus 4.70 (id 1327) for details of Scythian oath rituals. Note also the similar sanctifying features of slaughter and blood caught in a shield in A. Seven Against Thebes, see oath id 198.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That he admires Hippias for seeming well disposed and helping him as much as he is able (to understand the nature of beauty) ]
 καὶ νὴ τὴν Ἥραν ἄγαμαί σου ὅτι μοι δοκεῖς εὐνοϊκῶς, καθ’ ὅσον οἷός τ’ εἶ, βοηθεῖν·
remarks: This seems to be the only Platonic dialogue in which Socrates swears by Hera twice – in addressing a person whom, far from admiring (as is usually the case in invocations of Hera), he intellectually despises, but who is far too vain to be aware of this! For informal oaths by Hera, see oath id 1870 with references.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia in Tauris
if_refused: Pylades will not deliver Iphigenia's letter
if_broken: May Iphigenia never set foot in Argos as long as she lives
statement:
[That she will let Pylades go safely out of the barbarian land]
 Ορ. ἦ κἀντιδώσεις τῶιδε τοὺς αὐτοὺς λόγους;
Ιφ. τί χρῆμα δράσειν ἢ τί μὴ δράσειν; λέγε. 
Ορ. ἐκ γῆς ἀφήσειν μὴ θανόντα βαρβάρου. 
Ιφ. δίκαιον εἶπας· πῶς γὰρ ἀγγείλειεν ἄν; 
Ορ. ἦ καὶ τύραννος ταῦτα συγχωρήσεται; 
Ιφ. ναί· 
  πείσω σφε, καὐτὴ ναὸς ἐσβήσω σκάφος.
Ορ. ὄμνυ· σὺ δ’ ἔξαρχ’ ὅρκον ὅστις εὐσεβής. 
Ιφ. δώσω, λέγειν χρή, τήνδε τοῖσι σοῖς φίλοις.
Πυ. τοῖς σοῖς φίλοισι γράμματ’ ἀποδώσω τάδε. 
Ιφ. κἀγὼ σὲ σώσω κυανέας ἔξω πέτρας.
Πυ. τίν’ οὖν ἐπόμνυς τοισίδ’ ὅρκιον θεῶν;
Ιφ. ῎Αρτεμιν, ἐν ἧσπερ δώμασιν τιμὰς ἔχω.
Πυ. ἐγὼ δ’ ἄνακτά γ’ οὐρανοῦ, σεμνὸν Δία.
Ιφ. εἰ δ’ ἐκλιπὼν τὸν ὅρκον ἀδικοίης ἐμέ; 
Πυ. ἄνοστος εἴην· τί δὲ σύ, μὴ σώσασά με;
Ιφ. μήποτε κατ’ ῎Αργος ζῶσ’ ἴχνος θείην ποδός.
remarks: See also Pylades' oath, id 149.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That although he had always wanted to approach Cyrus, he had been too ashamed]
 Προσελθεῖν γάρ σοι, ἔφη, ἀεὶ βουλόμενος 
ναὶ μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς ᾐσχυνόμην.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2319.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That caring for sick slaves will be a most gratifying task if those she cares for prove to be more thankful and loyal than before]
  ἴσως ἀχαριστότερον δόξει εἶναι, ὅτι, ὃς ἂν κάμνῃ τῶν οἰκετῶν, τούτων σοι ἐπιμελητέον πάντων ὅπως θεραπεύηται. Νὴ Δί’ ἔφη ἡ γυνή, ἐπιχαριτώτατον μὲν οὖν, ἂν μέλλωσί γε οἱ καλῶς θεραπευθέντες χάριν εἴσεσθαι καὶ εὐνούστεροι ἢ πρόσθεν ἔσεσθαι

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement: [That they would kill, by word and deed and vote and their own hand, if they could, anyone who overthrows the democracy at Athens and anyone who holds any office in the future after democracy has been overthrown, and anyone who sets himself up to be tyrant or helps set up a tyrant. And if anyone else kills the man, they would consider him pure in the eyes of both gods and spirits, because he has killed an enemy of the Athenians, and they would sell all the property of the dead man and give half to the killer, and would not hold any back. And if anyone dies in killing or attempting to kill any such man, they would care for both him and his children, just as for Harmodius and Aristogeiton and their descendants. And they declare null and void all oaths that have been sworn at Athens or in the camp or anywhere else against the people of Athens]
remarks:
Lycurgus refers here to the so-called oath of Demophantus. He claims that the Athenians swore that if anyone found a person aspiring to tyranny, or attempting to betray the city, or overthrew the democracy, he would be guiltless if he killed him (ἐάν τις τυραννίδι ἐπιτιθῆται ἢ τὴν πόλιν προδιδῷ ἢ τὸν δῆμον καταλύῃ, τὸν αἰσθανόμενον καθαρὸν εἶναι ἀποκτείναντα). He states that the oath was sworn after the overthrow of the Thirty, although the decree cited by Andocides states that the oath itself was taken after the overthrow of the Four Hundred in 410/09. 
See also oath id 2358.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Wealth will never be happy again]
 Οὔ τοι μὰ τὴν Δήμητρα χαιρήσεις ἔτι.
remarks: The oath/curse has no effect on Wealth, but Chremylus is unaware of his identity at this point, assuming that he is just a blind old man.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Chians and the other allies of Sparta assembled at Ephesus in 406 to consult regarding the war. 
They resolved to send envoys to Sparta to request that Lysander be made commander of the fleet. 
See also oath id 1804.

title: CID I
reference: 9, Face A, ll 1-18; Face B, ll 26-34; Face C, ll 3-6
work_date: late fifth or early fourth century
date: Late fifth or early fourth century (424 to 350)
statement:
[That he would serve as tagos justly, according to the laws of the polis and the Labyadai, regarding the offerings and sacrificial victims and of cakes; He would exact money and publish accounts justly for the Labyadai and would not steal nor do any harm by any means or device to the property of the Labyadai, and he would make the tagoi for the next year swear the oath according to as it is written: I promise by Zeus Patroios. If I keep my oath may good things (happen to me) and if I break my oath may evil (happen to me)- evil instead of good]
 τα̣γ̣ε̣[υ]σέω δι[κ]α[ίως κ]α[τ]ὰ τοὺν ν̣όμους [τ]ᾶς [π]ό[λι]ος καὶ το[ὺ]ς τῶν Λαβυαδ[ᾶν] πὲρ τῶν ἀ[π]ελ[λ]αίων καὶ [τᾶ]ν δαρατᾶν̣· κ̣α̣ὶ̣ τ̣ὰ̣ χρήμ[α]τ[α] συμπραξέ[ω] κ[ἀ]ποδειξέω [δι]καίως τοῖς̣ Λα̣β̣υ̣άδαις [κ]ωὔτε κλεψέω οὔτε βλα[ψ]έ[ω ο]ὔ̣τε τέχνηι οὔτε μαχα̣νᾶ̣[ι] τ̣ῶν τῶλ Λαβυαδᾶ̣ν̣ χρημ̣[άτ]ων καὶ τὸς ταγοὺ[ς ἐπ]αξ̣έ̣ω̣ τὸν hόρκον τοὺς ἐ[ν ν]έω[τ]α κὰτ τὰ γεγρ̣αμμέν̣α̣. hόρκ̣ος· hυπίσχομα̣ι̣ ποὶ τοῦ Δ[ι]ὸς τοῦ Πατ̣ρώιου· εὐορκέον̣τι μέμ μοι ἀ̣γα̣θὰ̣ εἴη, αἰ [δ’] ἐ̣φιορκέοιμ[ι, κ]α̣κῶν (?) τ̣ὰ κ[α]κὰ ἀντὶ τῶν ἀγ[α]θῶν.
remarks: The text also indicates that anyone who serves as tagos without swearing the oath is to pay a fine of fifty drachmas. For the oath sworn by a tagos who disputed being  prosecuted for violating these rules see oath id 917.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That Spithridates' daughter could be sent for by sea at once if Agesilaus wished]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ὄτυς, κατὰ θάλατταν ἤδη ἂν πέμποιτο, εἰ σὺ βούλοιο
remarks:
When Agesilaus suggested that Spithridates should give his daughter to Otys to marry his son, he cautioned that they could not fetch the girl by land before spring. 
Otys replied, "But by Zeus she could be sent for by sea at once if you [i.e. Agesilaus] wish."

title: Athenian Agora
swearer: Thrasycles, son of Thrason, of Boutadae; Stratophon, son of Straton, of Agryle; Melittius, son of Execestides, of Boutadae; Aristarchus, son of Democles, of Boutadae; Arceon, son of Eumelides, of Acharnae; Chaerestratus, son of Pancleides, of Epicephisia; Demon, son of Demaretus, of Agryle
statement: [? That they would abide by the decisions of the arbitrators]
remarks:
The text records the arbitration of a dispute within the genos of the Salaminioi between the men of the deme Sunium and the so-called Seven Tribes.  
For the corresponding oath of the men of Sunium see oath id 444.

author: Eupolis
title: Baptai
statement:
[That what the adressee is suffering is in fact just]
 πολλοῦ μὲν οὖν δίκαια ναὶ μὰ τὰς κράμβας
remarks: This is a response to the informal oath in the preceding line (id 1469). Each swearer believes his/her own statement to be true. On swearing by cabbages, see remarks on id 1438.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he loves and cherishes Demos]
 Κἄγωγ’, ὦ Δῆμ’, εἰ μή σε φιλῶ καὶ μὴ στέργω, κατατμηθεὶς 
  ἑψοίμην ἐν περικομματίοις· κεἰ μὴ τούτοισι πέποιθας,  
  ἐπὶ ταυτησὶ κατακνησθείην ἐν μυττωτῷ μετὰ τυροῦ 
  καὶ τῇ κρεάγρᾳ τῶν ὀρχιπέδων ἑλκοίμην εἰς Κεραμεικόν.
remarks: There are a whole list of self-curses contained in this oath. If his statement is not true, the Sausage-seller curses himself first of all "to be cut up and boiled with mincemeat". If Demos doesn't believe that, then he further curses himself as follows: "may I on this table be grated with cheese into savoury mash, and may I be dragged by the balls on my own meathook to Cerameicus". The extended list of self-curses is presumably intended to cap that of Paphlagon (at id 1019) to which the Sausage-seller seems to be responding.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That Aristogeiton has goodwill toward the Athenians because they condemned him in endeixis trials and twice put him and his brother into prison]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’ ὅτι τὰς ἐνδείξεις αὐτοῦ κατεψηφίσασθε, καὶ δὶς εἰς τὸ δεσμωτήριον κατέθεσθε καὶ αὐτὸν καὶ τὸν ἀδελφόν, διὰ ταῦθ’ ὑμῖν εὔνους ἐστίν
remarks: The speaker suggests ironically that someone will respond in this way.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the first gounds for war against Athens which the Corinthians had was the fact the Athenians had fought against them in a time of truce.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That Hippias’ answer is an attractive one that will win him much credit – that is, attractive to, and likely to win credit with, the hoi polloi.]
 Καλῶς γε, ὦ Ἱππία, νὴ τὸν κύνα καὶ εὐδόξως ἀπεκρίνω.
remarks: This statement is very highly ironic, or perhaps ambiguous, since the answer Hippias has given to Socrates’ question is actually an utterly hopeless one! For other instances of Socrates invoking "the dog" see oath id 2548 with cross references.

title: ICS
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
if_broken: Breaking the oath is stated to be impious
statement:
[That the land given to the sons of Onasikypros would belong to them and their descendants forever while they remained within the boundaries of Idalion]
 τάς κε ζᾶ(?)ς τάσδε κὰς τὸς κάπος τόσδε οἱ Ὀνασικύπρων παῖδες κὰς τῶ(ν) παίδων οἱ παῖδες ἕξο(ν)σι αἰϜεὶ, ο(ἳ) ἰ(ν) τ(ῶι) οἱρῶνι τῶι  ἘδαλιῆϜι ἴω(ν)σι.
remarks:
This inscription records an agreement between King Stasikypros, the people of Idalion and Onasilos the doctor and his brothers. 
The land given to the sons of Onasikypros was a reward for medical services rendered to the people of Idalion when the city was besieged by the Persians and the people of Citium.

title: IG I(3)
swearer: Those (men) who have attained puberty; Envoys
statement:
[That they would not rebel against the Athenian demos by word or deed, in any way whatever, either by their own volition or by the persuasion of another. If anyone did rebel they would denounce him to the Athenians. They would pay the tribute to the Athenians which they would persuade them to assess, and as an ally they would be the best and truest possible, and they would assist the Athenian demos and defend them if anyone injures the Athenian demos, and they would obey the Athenian demos]
 οὐκ ἀπο[σ]τέσομαι ἀπὸ το̃ [δ]έμο το̃ Ἀθεναίον οὔτε τέ[χ]νει οὔτε μεχανε̃ι οὐδεμιᾶι οὐδ’ ἔπει οὐδὲ ἔργοι οὐδὲ το̃ι ἀφισταμένοι πείσομαι, καὶ ἐὰν ἀφιστε̃ι τις κατερο̃ Ἀθεναίοισι, καὶ τὸν φόρον hυποτελο̃ Ἀθεναίοισι, hὸν ἂν πείθο Ἀθεναίος, καὶ χσύμμαχος ἔσομαι hοῖος ἂν δύνομαι ἄριστος καὶ δικαιότατος καὶ το̃ι δέμοι το̃ι Ἀθεναίον βοεθέσο καὶ ἀμυνο̃, ἐὰν τις ἀδικε̃ι τὸν δε̃μον τὸν Ἀθεναίον, καὶ πείσομαι το̃ι δέμοι το̃ι Ἀθεναίον.
remarks:
This inscription records the regulations imposed on Chalcis by Athens. 
The tithe consecrated from the confiscated property was to go to Zeus Olympios. 
The swearing of the oath at Chalcis was to be overseen by Athenian presbeis and the "horkotai". Lines 45ff refer to the election of five Athenians as horkotai.  
The oath is described in lines 40ff as being exchanged just as it was with the Eretrians (see oath id 146 and 147).  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 148. The decree and oaths were to be inscribed on marble stelai at the expense of the Chalcidians. The Athenian copy was placed on the acropolis, and the Chalcidian copy in the temple of Zeus Eleutherios.  
The decree ends with the word hόρκος as if the text of the oath would be inscribed there, but it was not done so, presumably because it has already been incorporated into the body of the decree. 
See also oath id 3861.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he had not forgotten something he wished to say]
 καὶ τὸν Κῦρον ἰδόντα, Ἀλλ’ ἦ, φάναι, ἐπελάθου τι ὧν ἐβούλου εἰπεῖν; Μὰ Δία, φάναι
remarks: The truth is that, after convincing Cyrus that he is a relation in order to obtain the kiss that is customary among Persians greeting relatives, Artabazus is pursuing Cyrus in the hopes of getting another kiss after a time of separation- cf. oath id 2320 and also oath id 2499.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That his wife should try to act to the best of her ability using the capabilities she has received from the gods and do what custom encourages to benefit the oikos]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ, ἅ τε οἱ θεοὶ ἔφυσάν σε δύνασθαι καὶ ὁ νόμος συνεπαινεῖ, ταῦτα πειρῶ  ὡς βέλτιστα ποιεῖν.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement: [That they would kill, by word and deed and vote and their own hand, if they could, anyone who overthrows the democracy at Athens and anyone who holds any office in the future after democracy has been overthrown, and anyone who sets himself up to be tyrant or helps set up a tyrant. And if anyone else kills the man, they would consider him pure in the eyes of both gods and spirits, because he has killed an enemy of the Athenians, and they would sell all the property of the dead man and give half to the killer, and would not hold any back. And if anyone dies in killing or attempting to kill any such man, they would care for both him and his children, just as for Harmodius and Aristogeiton and their descendants. And they declare null and void all oaths that have been sworn at Athens or in the camp or anywhere else against the people of Athens]
remarks:
Lycurgus refers here to the so-called oath of Demophantus. He states that the Athenians erected a stele and then swore the oath together. 
In order to make the oath relevant to Leocrates, Lycurgus has to import ideas into it which are not to be found in its text (known from Andocides, On the Mysteries 97-98 = oath id 2358).  He replaces all its aorist subjunctives (appropriate to completed actions) by present subjunctives (appropriate to actions in progress or even in preparation); he says explicitly, and falsely, that the Athenians swore to kill (not only anyone who actually e.g. overthrew the democracy but also) anyone who was contemplating doing so; and even so, since Leocrates was not being accused of attempting to overthrow democracy or establish tyranny, he has to assert, again falsely, that the oath covers anyone who "is in the process of betraying [present tense again!] his country", an expression not found in the oath itself.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Convinces Wealth to reveal his identity
statement:
[That Chremylus and Carion will let the blind man go, if he wants, if he tells them who he is]
 Ἀλλ’ ἢν πύθησθέ μ’ ὅστις εἴμ’, εὖ οἶδ’ ὅτι
  κακόν τί μ’ ἐργάσεσθε κοὐκ ἀφήσετον.
{ΧΡ.}  Νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς ἡμεῖς γ’, ἐὰν βούλῃ γε σύ.
remarks: As Sommerstein remarks ad 74: "Chremylus, while [swearing] not to detain the blind man by force, thus reserves the right to detain him by persuasion if he can".

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the Athenians to remember that Philip is at war with them and has broken the peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That she intends to be carding while the Assembly is filling up]
  {Πρ.} πληρουμένης τάλαινα; {Γυ. β} νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad loc.: "Praxagora's point [with which she challenges the Second Woman here], which she does not need to spell out, is that women, when carding (in the home), often sat with one foot up on a stool and with their clothes raised above the knee….It would be foolish of any woman wishing to pass as a man to adopt a posture like this at any time". See also oath id 782.

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[That they would deliberate as best they could for the Erythraean demos and the Athenians and their allies, and they would not rebel against the Athenians or their allies, either on their own initiative nor persuaded by anyone else, nor would they receive back any exiles; of those who fled to the Medes, without the permission of the Athenians and the demos, they would not banish those who remain in Erythrae without the permission of the Athenians and the demos; if any Erythraean kills another Erythraean he shall be put to death if he is judged guilty; if banishment is the sentence he shall be exiled from the Athenian alliance and his property shall be confiscated; if someone is caught betraying the city to tyrants he shall be put to death, both he and his children unless they report him to the demos; his children shall receive half his property and the rest shall be confiscated..]
β̣ολεύσο hος ἂν [δύ]νο[μ]α̣[ι] ἂρ̣ι̣στ[α καὶ] δ[ι]κα[ιότα]τα Ἐρυθραίον το̃ι πλέθει καὶ Ἀθεναίον καὶ το̃ν [χσυ]νμά[χ]ον [κ]αὶ οὐκ [ἀποσ]τέσομαι Ἀθεναίον το̃ π[λ]έθος οὐδὲ [το̃ν] χσυνμάχον το̃ν Ἀθεναίον οὔτ’ αὐτὸς ἐγὸ ο[ὔ]τ’ ἄ[λ]λοι̣ π̣ε[ί]σομ̣[αι οὐ]δ̣’ - - - οὔτ’ αὐτὸς ἐγὸ οὔτ’ ἄλλο[ι π]εί[σομαι - - -] το̃ν φ̣[υγάδ]ον [κατ]αδέχσομαι οὐδ[ὲ] hένα οὔτ’ - - - - - [ἄλλο]ι πείσο̣[μ]α[ι το̃ν ἐς Μέδος φ̣ε[υ]γ̣ό[ντο]ν ἄνευ τε̣̃[ς] β̣ο[λε̃ς τε̃ς Ἀθε]ναίον καὶ το̃ [δ]έ̣μο [ο]ὐδὲ το̃ν μενόντον ἐχσελο̃ [ἄ]ν[ευ] τε̣̃ς β̣[ολε̃ς τ̣ε̃ς Ἀθεναίον καὶ [το̃] δ̣έμ̣ο· ἐὰν δέ τ[ι]ς ἀποκτέ̣νει̣ [Ἐρυθραῖ]ος hέτερον Ἐρυ̣θ̣ρ̣[αῖ]ον, τεθ[ν]άτ̣ο ἐὰν [γν]οσθε̃ι - - - [γν]οσθε̃ι̣ φ̣ευ̣γέτο ḥάπ̣ασ[αν] τὲ[ν] Ἀθεναίον χσθνμαχί[..καὶ τ]ὰ χρέματα δεμόσ[ια ἔσ]το Ἐρυθραίον· ἐὰν δέ [τ]ις - - - - το<ῖ>ς τυράννοις - - - - Ἐρυθραί<ο>ν καὶ  - - - τεθνάτο - - - παῖδε[ς] ḥοι ἐχς ἐκ̣έν[ο - - - hοι] πα̣ῖδες [h]οι ἐχς [ἐ]κέν[ο - - - Ἐρυθραίο[ν] καὶ - - - Ἀθεναίον - - - τὰ δὲ χρέ̣ματα - - - κατα<θ>έντας - - - [π]αῖδες - - - εσθο κα<τὰ> ταῦτα καὶ - - - [τὸν δ]ε̃μ̣ον τὸν Ἀθεναίον - - -
remarks:
This very fragmentary inscription records the regulations imposed on Erythrae by Athens. 
Previous editors e.g. Meritt in ATL 2, D10, have been more "adventurous" with their restorations.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he suspects that Socrates is right]
 Καὶ ἐγώ, νὴ τὸν Δία, ὑποπτεύω
remarks: Socrates has pointed out that if they agree that perception and knowledge are the same thing, they must also agree that that a man who has acquired knowledge by visual perception forgets it when he shuts his eyes. Theaetetus objects, but is cornered by the argument.

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
statement: [That they would be loyal to each other]
remarks: Theopompus mentions vaguely that some provisions were made under the alliance relating to the territory of the Pisidians and of Aspendos.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
statement: n/a
remarks: Socrates follows up his discussion of lover's oaths (see oath id 2932 ) to consider the progression of the lover who learns wisdom and temperance, thus becoming a new man disinclined to fulfill his former oaths for fear of reverting to his former character, much to the disappointment of the young beloved. This is a lesson not to yield to a lover inevitably devoid of reason. Cf. oath ids 2921 and 2925.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That the master is sleeping after eating some myrtle-berries and gnats]
 Ἀλλ’ ἀρτίως νὴ τὸν Δία
εὕδει καταφαγὼν μύρτα καὶ σέρφους τινάς.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Croesus and his forces are drawing their wings a long way from their centre - and also from Cyrus's own]
 Πάνυ γε, ἔφη ὁ Χρυσάντας, καὶ θαυμάζω γε· πολὺ γάρ μοι δοκοῦσιν ἀποσπᾶν τὰ κέρατα ἀπὸ τῆς ἑαυτῶν φάλαγγος. Ναὶ μὰ Δι’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, καὶ ἀπό γε τῆς ἡμετέρας.
remarks: Croesus has planned to encircle the Persians by outflanking them, but Cyrus has already received this information from his spies and is acting on it.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that this alliance between Athens and Sparta was made on terms of full equality, with each party leading for periods of five days on land and sea. 
After the alliance was formalised, both parties became involved in warfare in the Peloponnese against the Thebans. 
See also oath id 2948.

author: Plato
title: Republic
impact: Emphasises his disagreement with Socrates' statement
statement:
[That he does not mean that to him, Homer and Simonides, justice is a kind of stealing so long as it is for the benefit of friends and the harm of enemies]
 ἔοικεν οὖν ἡ δικαιοσύνη καὶ κατὰ σὲ καὶ καθ’ Ὅμηρον καὶ κατὰ Σιμωνίδην κλεπτική τις εἶναι, ἐπ’ ὠφελίᾳ μέντοι τῶν φίλων καὶ ἐπὶ βλάβῃ τῶν ἐχθρῶν. οὐχ οὕτως ἔλεγες;  Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, ἀλλ’ οὐκέτι οἶδα ἔγωγε ὅτι ἔλεγον·
remarks: Poor Polemarchus no longer knows what he means after his discussion with Socrates has been twisted in knots. For further context, cf. oath ids 2522 and 2524.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would be allies to the Persians and would not betray them]
remarks:
After the Greeks elected new leaders, Cheirisophus the Spartan addressed the Greek mercenaries saying that their present situation was particularly painful because they had been robbed of their generals and been betrayed by Ariaeus and his men, "who were formerly allies". 
See also oath id 2078.

author: Stesichorus
title: Fragment
if_taken: They will be considered as a suitor
if_refused: They will not be considered as a suitor
statement: [That none of them would attempt to make Helen his wife without Tyndareus' consent, and they each would attack anyone who attempted to do so]
remarks: A scholion on Iliad 2.339 shows that the oath of Helen's suitors featured in a work by Stesichorus, though nothing more can be ascertained. The oath statement quoted here is drawn from the Hesiodic reference to the suitor's oath (id 1308).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That it violates right, justice and political decency to try to deny the accused access to the people and a hearing, especially out of malice or envy]
 οὔτε μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς ὀρθῶς ἔχον οὔτε πολιτικὸν οὔτε δίκαιόν ἐστιν, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι·

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
