swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the Athenians made peace with Philip because of the generals i.e. because of their incompetence. He repeats his claim that Aeschines is not on trial for the peace itself, but that the peace has been discredited because of Aeschines' actions. He asks the jurors who would have objected to the peace if they hadn't been tricked by Aeschines and none of the allies had been destroyed. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: Against Pancleon
statement:
[That his case could not properly be brought before the court of the Polemarch]
 ἀμφισβητῶν μὴ πρὸς τὸν πολέμαρχον εἶναί
remarks:
The speaker states that when Pancleon swore (in his antomosia) that he should not be brought to trial before the Polemarch on the ground that he was a Plataean, and therefore eligible for Athenian citizenship, he was the object of a diamarturia that stated that he was not a Plataean. 
It should be noted that it is not entirely clear whether Pancleon was a slave owned by Nicomedes, or a Plataean; he has been classified as a slave above because it is the speaker's concern to present him as one. 
See also oath id 2846.

title: IG II(2)
if_taken: They can take up office as synegoroi
if_refused: They cannot take up office as synegoroi
statement:
[That they would perform their duties most justly and not allow anyone who was not eligible to be a member of the phratry to enter the phratry]
 συνηγορήσεν τὰ δικαιότατα καὶ ὀκ ἐάσεν ὀδένα μὴ ὄντα φράτερα φρατρίζεν
remarks: Five synegoroi were elected to decide appeals concerning eligibility to join the phratry. Their oaths were to be administered by the phratriarch and the priest of the phratry. It seems likely that they swore oaths by Zeus Phratrios, but the text does not explicitly state that this was the case.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he will not guide his old father any longer (if he persists in his refusal to buy him dried figs)]
  μὰ Δί’ οὔ τἄρα προπέμψω σε τὸ λοιπόν.

author: Pherecrates
title: Krapataloi
if_taken: They will be allowed to judge
if_refused: They will not be allowed to judge
statement: [That they will judge the choruses fairly]
remarks: This is a reference to the judges' oath. The chorus leader appeals to their oath to judge fairly. Cf. oath id 1247 with cross references.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_broken: May the gods give him many griefs, such as they give to perjurers
statement:
[That he did not sleep with Briseis]
 ὀμνυέτω δέ τοι ὅρκον ἐν Ἀργείοσιν ἀναστὰς
μή ποτε τῆς εὐνῆς ἐπιβήμεναι ἠδὲ μιγῆναι·
καὶ δὲ σοὶ αὐτῷ θυμὸς ἐνὶ φρεσὶν ἵλαος ἔστω. 
αὐτὰρ ἔπειτά σε δαιτὶ ἐνὶ κλισίῃς ἀρεσάσθω
πιείρῃ, ἵνα μή τι δίκης ἐπιδευὲς ἔχῃσθα.  
Ἀτρεΐδη σὺ δ’ ἔπειτα δικαιότερος καὶ ἐπ’ ἄλλῳ 
ἔσσεαι. οὐ μὲν γάρ τι νεμεσσητὸν βασιλῆα 
ἄνδρ’ ἀπαρέσσασθαι ὅτε τις πρότερος χαλεπήνῃ.
Τὸν δ’ αὖτε προσέειπεν ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν Ἀγαμέμνων·
χαίρω σεῦ Λαερτιάδη τὸν μῦθον ἀκούσας·
ἐν μοίρῃ γὰρ πάντα διίκεο καὶ κατέλεξας.
ταῦτα δ’ ἐγὼν ἐθέλω ὀμόσαι, κέλεται δέ με θυμός,
οὐδ’ ἐπιορκήσω πρὸς δαίμονος. αὐτὰρ Ἀχιλλεὺς
μιμνέτω αὖθι τέως περ, ἐπειγόμενός περ Ἄρηος· 
μίμνετε δ’ ἄλλοι πάντες ἀολλέες, ὄφρά κε δῶρα  
ἐκ κλισίης ἔλθῃσι καὶ ὅρκια πιστὰ τάμωμεν.
σοὶ δ’ αὐτῷ τόδ’ ἐγὼν ἐπιτέλλομαι ἠδὲ κελεύω· 
κρινάμενος κούρητας ἀριστῆας Παναχαιῶν
δῶρα ἐμῆς παρὰ νηὸς ἐνεικέμεν, ὅσσ’ Ἀχιλῆϊ 
χθιζὸν ὑπέστημεν δώσειν, ἀγέμεν τε γυναῖκας.  
Ταλθύβιος δέ μοι ὦκα κατὰ στρατὸν εὐρὺν Ἀχαιῶν
κάπρον ἑτοιμασάτω ταμέειν Διί τ’ Ἠελίῳ τε.
Τὸν δ’ ἀπαμειβόμενος προσέφη πόδας ὠκὺς Ἀχιλλεύς· 
Ἀτρεΐδη κύδιστε ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν Ἀγάμεμνον 
ἄλλοτέ περ καὶ μᾶλλον ὀφέλλετε ταῦτα πένεσθαι,  
ὁππότε τις μεταπαυσωλὴ πολέμοιο γένηται
καὶ μένος οὐ τόσον ᾖσιν ἐνὶ στήθεσσιν ἐμοῖσιν. 
νῦν δ’ οἳ μὲν κέαται δεδαϊγμένοι, οὓς ἐδάμασσεν
Ἕκτωρ Πριαμίδης, ὅτε οἱ Ζεὺς κῦδος ἔδωκεν, 
ὑμεῖς δ’ ἐς βρωτὺν ὀτρύνετον· ἦ τ’ ἂν ἔγωγε 
νῦν μὲν ἀνώγοιμι πτολεμίζειν υἷας Ἀχαιῶν
νήστιας ἀκμήνους, ἅμα δ’ ἠελίῳ καταδύντι 
τεύξεσθαι μέγα δόρπον, ἐπὴν τεισαίμεθα λώβην.
πρὶν δ’ οὔ πως ἂν ἔμοιγε φίλον κατὰ λαιμὸν ἰείη 
οὐ πόσις οὐδὲ βρῶσις ἑταίρου τεθνηῶτος 
ὅς μοι ἐνὶ κλισίῃ δεδαϊγμένος ὀξέϊ χαλκῷ
κεῖται ἀνὰ πρόθυρον τετραμμένος, ἀμφὶ δ’ ἑταῖροι 
μύρονται· τό μοι οὔ τι μετὰ φρεσὶ ταῦτα μέμηλεν,
ἀλλὰ φόνος τε καὶ αἷμα καὶ ἀργαλέος στόνος ἀνδρῶν.
Τὸν δ’ ἀπαμειβόμενος προσέφη πολύμητις Ὀδυσσεύς· 
ὦ Ἀχιλεῦ Πηλῆος υἱὲ μέγα φέρτατ’ Ἀχαιῶν,
κρείσσων εἰς ἐμέθεν καὶ φέρτερος οὐκ ὀλίγον περ
ἔγχει, ἐγὼ δέ κε σεῖο νοήματί γε προβαλοίμην 
πολλόν, ἐπεὶ πρότερος γενόμην καὶ πλείονα οἶδα.
τώ τοι ἐπιτλήτω κραδίη μύθοισιν ἐμοῖσιν. 
αἶψά τε φυλόπιδος πέλεται κόρος ἀνθρώποισιν,
ἧς τε πλείστην μὲν καλάμην χθονὶ χαλκὸς ἔχευεν,
ἄμητος δ’ ὀλίγιστος, ἐπὴν κλίνῃσι τάλαντα
Ζεύς, ὅς τ’ ἀνθρώπων ταμίης πολέμοιο τέτυκται. 
γαστέρι δ’ οὔ πως ἔστι νέκυν πενθῆσαι Ἀχαιούς· 
λίην γὰρ πολλοὶ καὶ ἐπήτριμοι ἤματα πάντα
πίπτουσιν· πότε κέν τις ἀναπνεύσειε πόνοιο; 
ἀλλὰ χρὴ τὸν μὲν καταθάπτειν ὅς κε θάνῃσι 
νηλέα θυμὸν ἔχοντας ἐπ’ ἤματι δακρύσαντας·
ὅσσοι δ’ ἂν πολέμοιο περὶ στυγεροῖο λίπωνται
μεμνῆσθαι πόσιος καὶ ἐδητύος, ὄφρ’ ἔτι μᾶλλον 
ἀνδράσι δυσμενέεσσι μαχώμεθα νωλεμὲς αἰεὶ
ἑσσάμενοι χροῒ χαλκὸν ἀτειρέα. μηδέ τις ἄλλην 
λαῶν ὀτρυντὺν ποτιδέγμενος ἰσχαναάσθω·
ἧδε γὰρ ὀτρυντὺς κακὸν ἔσσεται ὅς κε λίπηται  
νηυσὶν ἐπ’ Ἀργείων· ἀλλ’ ἀθρόοι ὁρμηθέντες
Τρωσὶν ἐφ’ ἱπποδάμοισιν ἐγείρομεν ὀξὺν Ἄρηα.
  Ἦ, καὶ Νέστορος υἷας ὀπάσσατο κυδαλίμοιο
Φυλεΐδην τε Μέγητα Θόαντά τε Μηριόνην τε
καὶ Κρειοντιάδην Λυκομήδεα καὶ Μελάνιππον· 
βὰν δ’ ἴμεν ἐς κλισίην Ἀγαμέμνονος Ἀτρεΐδαο.
αὐτίκ’ ἔπειθ’ ἅμα μῦθος ἔην, τετέλεστο δὲ ἔργον· 
ἑπτὰ μὲν ἐκ κλισίης τρίποδας φέρον, οὕς οἱ ὑπέστη,
αἴθωνας δὲ λέβητας ἐείκοσι, δώδεκα δ’ ἵππους·
ἐκ δ’ ἄγον αἶψα γυναῖκας ἀμύμονα ἔργ' εἰδυίας 
ἕπτ’, ἀτὰρ ὀγδοάτην Βρισηΐδα καλλιπάρῃον.
χρυσοῦ δὲ στήσας Ὀδυσεὺς δέκα πάντα τάλαντα
ἦρχ’, ἅμα δ’ ἄλλοι δῶρα φέρον κούρητες Ἀχαιῶν. 
καὶ τὰ μὲν ἐν μέσσῃ ἀγορῇ θέσαν, ἂν δ’ Ἀγαμέμνων 
ἵστατο· Ταλθύβιος δὲ θεῷ ἐναλίγκιος αὐδὴν 
κάπρον ἔχων ἐν χερσὶ παρίστατο ποιμένι λαῶν.
Ἀτρεΐδης δὲ ἐρυσσάμενος χείρεσσι μάχαιραν, 
ἥ οἱ πὰρ ξίφεος μέγα κουλεὸν αἰὲν ἄωρτο, 
κάπρου ἀπὸ τρίχας ἀρξάμενος Διὶ χεῖρας ἀνασχὼν 
ηὔχετο· τοὶ δ’ ἄρα πάντες ἐπ’ αὐτόφιν εἵατο σιγῇ 
Ἀργεῖοι κατὰ μοῖραν ἀκούοντες βασιλῆος. 
εὐξάμενος δ’ ἄρα εἶπεν ἰδὼν εἰς οὐρανὸν εὐρύν· 
ἴστω νῦν Ζεὺς πρῶτα θεῶν ὕπατος καὶ ἄριστος 
Γῆ τε καὶ Ἠέλιος καὶ Ἐρινύες, αἵ θ’ ὑπὸ γαῖαν
ἀνθρώπους τείνυνται, ὅτις κ’ ἐπίορκον ὀμόσσῃ, 
μὴ μὲν ἐγὼ κούρῃ Βρισηΐδι χεῖρ’ ἐπένεικα, 
οὔτ’ εὐνῆς πρόφασιν κεχρημένος οὔτέ τε' ἄλλου. 
ἀλλ’ ἔμεν’ ἀπροτίμαστος ἐνὶ κλισίῃσιν ἐμῇσιν. 
εἰ δέ τι τῶνδ’ ἐπίορκον ἐμοὶ θεοὶ ἄλγεα δοῖεν
πολλὰ μάλ’, ὅσσα διδοῦσιν ὅτίς σφ’ ἀλίτηται ὀμόσσας. 
 Ἦ, καὶ ἀπὸ στόμαχον κάπρου τάμε νηλέϊ χαλκῷ.
τὸν μὲν Ταλθύβιος πολιῆς ἁλὸς ἐς μέγα λαῖτμα
ῥῖψ’ ἐπιδινήσας βόσιν ἰχθύσιν·
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)most noble, loftiest of the gods; Gaia; Helios; ErinyesEpithet(s)nether avengers
remarks: Odysseus here calls for Agamemnon to take the oath that he first volunteered at oath id 347.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: Representatives; Envoys; Envoys of the allies of Athens; Envoys
swearee: Representatives; Envoys; Envoys of the allies of Athens; Envoys
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Athenians sent envoys to Sparta to negotiate a peace agreement and sent envoys to the Thebans to encourage them to join with them in sending envoys to Sparta. 
The Spartans agreed to the terms suggested by the Athenians, and swore on behalf of themselves and their allies. 
The Athenians and their allies swore separately. 
The Thebans signed their names amongst those cities which had sworn, but on the following day their envoys demanded that the writing be changed to read that "the Boeotians" had sworn rather than "the Thebans". 
Agesilaus replied that he would change no part of what they had sworn to and signed in the first place, but said that he would strike out their names if they did not wish to be included in the treaty. 
Xenophon observes that after this agreement had been made the Athenians hoped that the Thebans might be decimated, while the Thebans went home utterly despondent. 
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That the Sun and the Moon have been stealing some of the days and nibbling at the year's cycle because they want to take over the cults of the Olympian gods for themselves]
 Ταῦτ’ ἄρα πάλαι τῶν ἡμερῶν παρεκλέπτετον 
  καὶ τοῦ κύκλου παρέτρωγον ὑφ’ ἁρματωλίας.  
  {ΤΡ.}  Ναὶ μὰ Δία
remarks: See also oath id 940 for further context.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the "man" speaking in the Assembly (i.e. Praxagora in disguise) said that "you" were an informer]
 καὶ νὴ Δία 
  καὶ συκοφάντην.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 435, Chremes means "you as a typical male" but Blepyrus understands "you as an individual". Cf. also oath id 805.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [?That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks: Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Cephallenians as allies, observing that they were autonomous but compelled to come because of Athens' mastery of the sea; the alliance had been made in 431 when an Athenian fleet of 100 ships came to the island and "won it over without fighting" (Thuc. 2.30.2).

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
statement:
[That the wine pourer is not unfair]
 Κυ. οἱνοχόος ἄδικος. 
  Σι. <οὐ> μὰ δί’, ἀλλ’ οἷνος  γλυκύς.
remarks: Seaford (1984) ad loc. remarks: 'L has rasura before μὰ (the Byzantines thought that μά is long...). As a supplement editors prefer Hermann's οὐ; but there is much to be said for ναί (Aldina): it is more comic that Sil. should agree with Pol., but then introduce a more powerful consideration'.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Foreshadows the revelry which is about to be related
statement:
[That some god has created an unmanageable situation in the house]
  νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον, ἄπορά γ’ ἡμῖν πράγματα 
δαίμων τις εἰσκεκύκληκεν εἰς τὴν οἰκίαν.
remarks: Xanthias proceeds to describe what has been going on at 1476-80.

title: IC IV
swearer: The apetairos who captured the defendant; Two others
statement:
[That he took him in adultery, and not by subterfuge]
 μοικίοντ’ ἐλέν, δολόσθαι δὲ μέ
remarks: For examples where men of different status swore this oath see oath id 1097 and 1099.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
if_taken: A fair contest will be ensured
if_refused: The contest may not be fair
impact: The Cretan (i.e. Odysseus) feels safe in taking on Iros one on one.
statement:
[That none of them will side with Iros and strike Odysseus down]
 ἀλλ’ ἄγε νῦν μοι πάντες ὀμόσσατε καρτερὸν ὅρκον,
μή τις ἐπ’ Ἴρῳ ἦρα φέρων ἐμὲ χειρὶ βαρείῃ 
πλήξῃ ἀτασθάλλων, τούτῳ δέ με ἶφι δαμάσσῃ.”
  ὣς ἔφαθ’, οἱ δ’ ἄρα πάντες ἐπώμνυον, ὡς ἐκέλευεν. 
[αὐτὰρ ἐπεί ῥ’ ὄμοσάν τε τελεύτησάν τε τὸν ὅρκον,]
τοῖς δ’ αὖτις μετέειφ’ ἱερὴ ἲς Τηλεμάχοιο·

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Athenians attacked Potidaea in 432 because they had been an ally and were now in revolt. 
Presumably Potidaea became an ally of Athens after the victory over the Persians.  
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: During civil strife when people fled to Peiraeus (404 to 403)
statement:
[That Socrates' advice is so good that he will now go to borrow capital to make a start in business]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη ὁ Ἀρίσταρχος, οὕτω μοι δοκεῖς καλῶς λέγειν, ὦ Σώκρατες, ὥστε πρόσθεν μὲν οὐ προσιέμην δανείσασθαι, εἰδὼς ὅτι ἀναλώσας ὃ ἂν λάβω οὐχ ἕξω ἀποδοῦναι, νῦν δέ μοι δοκῶ εἰς ἔργων ἀφορμὴν ὑπομενεῖν αὐτὸ ποιῆσαι.
remarks: Socrates has just given Aristarchus advice on how to make a good living for himself and his female relations. Cf. oath ids 2064-2066 for context.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he has not suffered his present condition (i.e. of being a eunuch) through any unjust or base speech or deed on his part]
 καὶ ταῦτα, ἔφη, ὦ Κῦρε, ὄμνυμί σοι θεούς, οἳ καὶ ὁρῶσι πάντα  καὶ ἀκούουσι πάντα, οὔτε ἄδικον οὔτε αἰσχρὸν οὐδὲν οὔτε εἰπὼν οὔτε ποιήσας ἔπαθον.
remarks: The story of how Gadatas was castrated by the current Assyrian king was told at 5.2.28. The king has since claimed that Gadatas had made advances to one of the royal concubines, but others have alleged (and Gadatas here in effect swears it to be true) that the king was merely jealous because this concubine had praised Gadatas' good looks and said that his future wife would be a lucky woman.  The name of the land is never specified. It is the land of Gadatas and borders on Assyria.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
statement: n/a
remarks: Ariston argues that the man who actively avoids making oaths - even honest oaths - and who would never dream of swearing an oath on his children's heads, (except in circumstances where it is sanctioned by custom ), is more to be believed than a man who swears by his children, even going through fire.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That he does not require any clearer proof (than their recent discussion) that the soul is man]
  Ἔτι οὖν τι σαφέστερον δεῖ ἀποδειχθῆναί σοι ὅτι ἡ ψυχή ἐστιν ἄνθρωπος;  {ΑΛ.} Μὰ Δία

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That a boat is to be seen]
 αὕτη ’στὶν ἣν ἔφραζε, καὶ πλοῖόν γ’ ὁρῶ. 
ΞΑ.  Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ κἄστι γ’ ὁ Χάρων οὑτοσί

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Peace
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes warns the Athenians that if anyone proposes the Athens makes an alliance with another state it must be done without detriment to the existing peace i.e. the Peace of Philocrates. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes begins his speech by telling the jurors not to treat any personal favour or individual man as more important than justice or the oath they have each sworn. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Lysias
title: Against Theomnestus 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker appeals to the jurors to vindicate him and his father, and to remember the laws and the oaths they have sworn. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That it was a happy honour to the statesman Cephalus that he had never been indicted for moving an illegal decree]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ εὔδαιμόν γε.
remarks: Demosthenes comments that Aeschines has said that it was a fine achievement of Cephalus of Collytus to have never been indicted. Demosthenes agrees that Cephalus' record is creditable (καλόν), and adds that it entitles Cephalus to be called truly happy.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he has remembered something else]
 Καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἕτερόν γ’ ἐστὶν οὗ ’μνήσθην ἐγώ.
remarks: What Peisetaerus has remembered is that he wants the maiden Princess to be given to him as his wife.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
if_taken: They will be able to testify
if_refused: They will not be able to testify
statement:
[That Euxitheus' father Thucritus was an Athenian and related to them]
 διομνυμένων <Ἀθηναῖον> εἶναι καὶ συγγενῆ τὸν ἐμὸν πατέρ’αὑτοῖς·
remarks:
Euxitheus tells the jurors that they have heard from his father's relatives (three of his father's cousins, and the son of one), who testify that he was an Athenian and related to them. 
He argues that none of them would lie, standing alongside those who would know that he was lying, calling down curses upon himself. 
This is one of the rare cases in which witnesses swear in a non-homicide case; probably this was a special requirement imposed in cases like this arising out of the deme register revisions of 345.  It is likely, therefore, that they would not have been allowed to give evidence without swearing.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he admires Euthydemus for valuing the treasures of wisdom more than silver and gold]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, ἄγαμαί γέ σου, διότι οὐκ ἀργυρίου καὶ χρυσίου προείλου θησαυροὺς κεκτῆσθαι μᾶλλον ἢ σοφίας·
remarks: Swearing by Hera is typical of Socrates; see oath id 1870 with cross references.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Heralds of King Artaxerxes II; Clearchus
swearee: Heralds of King Artaxerxes II; Clearchus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
After the truce was concluded, Tissaphernes came to address the Greeks to ask why they had taken the field against the King. 
Clearchus responded that they had not gathered to fight against the King, and that they had taken the field because they were obliged to defend Cyrus because he had done them favours in the past. 
Clearchus then says that since Cyrus is dead, they are no longer fighting against the King for his realm and have no wish to harm his territory or the King himself, but will defend themselves if attacked. 
Clearchus adds that if anyone does them a service they will not be outdone in doing a service to him. 
Tissaphernes responds that he will carry this message to the King and bring back his reply, stating that the truce will continue until he returns. He also proposes to set up a market so that the Greeks can gather provisions. 
See also oath id 2084.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he will pass both his hands at once through the "oarports" (i.e. arm-holes) of the cuirass]
  Τῃδί, διεὶς τὴν χεῖρα διὰ τῆς θαλαμίας 
  καὶ τῇδ’. 
  {ΚἍ.}  Ἅμ’ ἀμφοῖν δῆτ’; 
  {ΤΡ.}  Ἔγωγε νὴ Δία

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Phliasian envoys were able to go to Sparta
statement: [? That he would allow the Phliasian envoys safe conduct to Sparta]
remarks:
When Agesilaus marched against Phlius, they appealed to him to allow their envoys safe conduct to Sparta in order to treat with the Spartan authorities. 
Agesilaus was angry at the implication that he did not hold authority, but gave safe conduct to the embassy.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Amyntas, son of Arrhidaeus; Alexander, son of Amyntas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Amyntas III, King of Macedon. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in Tod, GHI II, 129. Cf. SEG 21.236.  
The decree indicates that an uncertain number of Athenians will accept the oaths from Amyntas and his son Alexander. The decree also praises the Athenian envoys to Amyntas and the envoys from Amyntas, Ptolemy, Antenor and [---]son.  
For the oath sworn by the Athenians see oath id 405.

author: Pherecrates
title: Cheiron
statement:
[That some things or people (plural subject of the sentence) resemble side-dishes in being named after their seasonings]  
 νὴ τὸν Δί’ ὥσπερ αἱ παροψίδες 
τὴν αἰτίαν ἔχουσ’ ἀπὸ τῶν ἡδυσμάτων,
οὓς ὁ καλέτας ἀξιοῖ τοῦ μηδενός.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That the smoke (i.e. Philocleon) comes from figwood, the most stinging kind of smoke]
 καπνὸς ἔγωγ’ ἐξέρχομαι. 
 {Βδ.} καπνός; φέρ’ ἴδω, ξύλου τίνος σύ; 
 {Φι.}  συκίνου. 
 {Βδ.} νὴ τὸν Δί’, ὅσπερ γ’ ἐστὶ δριμύτατος καπνῶν.
remarks: As Sommerstein comments ad 145, "there is an implied pun on sukophantes "informer, malicious accuser" whose literal meaning was "revealer of figs"".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Peloponnesians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Peloponnesians while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Spartan admiral Cnemus made a truce with the Stratians.

author: Demosthenes
title: For Phormion
statement:
[That however he looks at it he cannot see any reason for the jury to believe Apollodorus and convict Phormion]
 Ἀλλ’ ἔγωγε μὰ τὸν Δία καὶ θεοὺς πανταχῇ σκοπῶν οὐδὲν ὁρῶ, δι’ ὅ τι ἂν σοὶ πεισθέντες τουδὶ καταψηφίσαιντο.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
if_taken: Odysseus will allow his men to beach on the island
if_refused: The men will not be allowed to beach on Thrinacia
statement:
[That they will not slaughter any sheep or oxen they come upon on the island]
  ἀλλ’ ἄγε νῦν μοι πάντες ὀμόσσατε καρτερὸν ὅρκον·
εἴ κέ τιν’ ἠὲ βοῶν ἀγέλην ἢ πῶϋ μέγ’ οἰῶν
εὕρωμεν, μή πού τις ἀτασθαλίῃσι κακῇσιν  
ἢ βοῦν ἠέ τι μῆλον ἀποκτάνῃ· ἀλλὰ ἕκηλοι 
ἐσθίετε βρώμην, τὴν ἀθανάτη πόρε Κίρκη.’
  ὣς ἐφάμην, οἱ δ’ αὐτίκ’ ἀπώμνυον ὡς ἐκέλευον.
αὐτὰρ ἐπεί ῥ’ ὄμοσάν τε τελεύτησάν τε τὸν ὅρκον, 
στήσαμεν ἐν λιμένι γλαφυρῷ εὐεργέα νῆα 
ἄγχ’ ὕδατος γλυκεροῖο καὶ ἐξαπέβησαν ἑταῖροι
νηός, ἔπειτα δὲ δόρπον ἐπισταμένως τετύκοντο.
remarks: Eurylochus urges the men to break this oath at 12.340-351 because they have exhausted their food supply. They follow his suggestions and break it at 12.353-365. The punishment for these actions is brought about by Zeus, after a threat from Helios. Zeus causes a shipwreck in which all the men drown, except Odysseus, who is washed up on Ogygie. This is all related in Odysseus' narrative to Alcinous.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Philocleon will not escape without punishment for knocking over her loaves]
 οὔτοι μὰ τὼ θεὼ καταπροίξει Μυρτίας 
  τῆς Ἀγκυλίωνος θυγατέρος καὶ Σωστράτης 
  οὕτω διαφθείρας ἐμοῦ τὰ φορτία.
remarks: Swearing by the the two goddesses was exclusively a woman's oath (cf. remarks on oath id 788).

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That, as things stand, they will require no small discussion to settle matters satisfactorily]
 ταῦτα οὖν ὅπῃ ποτὲ ἔχει, μὰ τὸν κύνα, ὦ Γοργία, οὐκ ὀλίγης συνουσίας ἐστὶν ὥστε ἱκανῶς διασκέψασθαι.
remarks: Swearing by "the dog" is typical of Socrates' character. See oath id 2548 for references.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
impact: Medea comes to Greece with Jason
consequences_of_breach: Causes Medea's fury and revenge plan
statement: [That he would be faithful to Medea]
remarks: The Nurse here reports Medea's outburst concerning Jason's perjured oath. The oath is referred to several times in the play- see oath ids 113, 118 and 122.  It is not clear whether the oath was volunteered by Jason or proposed by Medea, but cf. oath id 361. Most scholars agree that Jason should be thought of as a perjurer in this play, but against this view see A. Allan's contribution in A. Sommerstein and J. Fletcher (eds) 'Horkos' (Exeter, 2006).

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he will sue if Strepsiades doesn't pay]
 σὺ δὲ νὴ τὸν Ἑρμῆν προσκεκλήσεσθαί γ’ ἐμοί,
  εἰ μὴ ’ποδώσεις τἀργύριον.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
statement:
[That they would kill, by word and deed and vote and their own hand, if they could, anyone who overthrows the democracy at Athens and anyone who holds any office in the future after democracy has been overthrown, and anyone who sets himself up to be tyrant or helps set up a tyrant. And if anyone else kills the man, they would consider him pure in the eyes of both gods and spirits, because he has killed an enemy of the Athenians, and they would sell all the property of the dead man and give half to the killer, and would not hold any back. And if anyone dies in killing or attempting to kill any such man, they would care for both him and his children, just as for Harmodius and Aristogeiton and their descendants. And they declare null and void all oaths that have been sworn at Athens or in the camp or anywhere else against the people of Athens]
κτενῶ καὶ λόγῳ καὶ ἔργῳ καὶ ψήφῳ καὶ τῇ ἐμαυτοῦ χειρί, ἂν δυνατὸς ὦ, ὃς ἂν καταλύσῃ τὴν δημοκρατίαν τὴν Ἀθήνησι. καὶ ἐάν τις ἄρξῃ τιν’ ἀρχὴν καταλελυμένης τῆς δημοκρατίας τὸ λοιπόν, καὶ ἐάν τις τυραννεῖν ἐπαναστῇ ἢ τὸν τύραννον συγκαταστήσῃ. Καὶ ἐάν τις ἄλλος ἀποκτείνῃ, ὅσιον αὐτὸν νομιῶ εἶναι καὶ πρὸς θεῶν καὶ δαιμόνων, ὡς πολέμιον κτείναντα τὸν Ἀθηναίων, καὶ τὰ κτήματα τοῦ ἀποθανόντος πάντα ἀποδόμενος ἀποδώσω τὰ ἡμίσεα τῷ ἀποκτείναντι, καὶ οὐκ ἀποστερήσω οὐδέν.  Ἐὰν δέ τις κτείνων τινὰ τούτων ἀποθάνῃ ἢ ἐπιχειρῶν, εὖ ποιήσω αὐτόν τε καὶ τοὺς παῖδας τοὺς ἐκείνου καθάπερ Ἁρμόδιόν τε καὶ Ἀριστογείτονα καὶ τοὺς ἀπογόνους αὐτῶν. δὲ ὅρκοι ὀμώμονται Ἀθήνησιν ἢ ἐν τῷ στρατοπέδῳ ἢ ἄλλοθί που ἐναντίοι τῷ δήμῳ τῷ Ἀθηναίων, λύω καὶ ἀφίημι.
remarks:
Andocides cites the decree proposed by Demophantos in 410/409. The decree stipulated that all Athenians were to swear over unblemished sacrifices to kill any man who overthrows the democracy at Athens or holds office after democracy has been overthrown (See also oath id 2748, 2749, 2750). 
The decree states that the oath was to be taken before the Dionysia, in the customary manner. 
Andocides argues that this law has now become invalid - otherwise Epichares, one of his prosecutors, having served on the boule under the Thirty, could have been killed with impunity - along with all laws older than the archonship of Eucleides (403/2) which have not been promulgated as part of the revised law-code. 
See also oath id 3383.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement:
[That the wife of Demosthenes (senior) was rich and brought him a large dowry in gold]
 καὶ γαμεῖ γυναῖκα πλουσίαν μὲν νὴ Δία καὶ χρυσίον ἐπιφερομένην πολύ

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Metapontians supported Athens in the war against Syracuse
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that Metapontum was an ally of Athens in 413, but provides no details about when this alliance was formalised.  
See also oath id 1837.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That an Assembly has taken place]
  ἀτὰρ γεγένηται; {Βλ.} ναὶ μὰ Δί’.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
statement:
[That Philip was forced to yield against his better judgement, finding himself hemmed in between the Thessalian cavalry and the Theban hoplites]
 Ἀλλ’ ἐβιάσθη νὴ Δία (ταῦτα γάρ ἐσθ’ ὑπόλοιπον) καὶ παρὰ γνώμην, τῶν Θετταλῶν ἱππέων καὶ τῶν Θηβαίων ὁπλιτῶν ἐν μέσῳ ληφθείς, συνεχώρησε ταῦτα.
remarks: Demosthenes is imagining how someone might defend Philip for favouring Thebes over Athens.

author: Sophocles
title: Electra
statement:
[That Electra will not escape punishment for her insolence when Aegisthus returns]
 ἀλλ’ οὐ μὰ τὴν δέσποιναν ῎Αρτεμιν θράσους
τοῦδ’ οὐκ ἀλύξεις, εὖτ’ ἂν Αἴγισθος μόλῃ.
remarks: Clytemnestra believes in the truth of her statement. However, as events unfold with the return of Orestes, Electra does not suffer at the hands of Aegisthus.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
remarks: See remarks on oath id 391.

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
The speaker claims that Callimachus perjured himself when he appeared as a witness on behalf of his brother-in-law. 
When a certain Cratinus was involved in a dispute with Callimachus' brother-in-law over a farm, they hid away a female slave, accused Cratinus of murder and prosecuted him in the Palladium. 
When the brother-in-law had made the accusation and Callimachus had testified under oath that the woman was dead, Cratinus and his friends (who were aware of what Callimachus' brother-in-law had done) went to the house where the slave woman had been hidden, seized her by force, and presented her to the court alive. 
The speaker notes that the seven hundred jurors unanimously voted against Callimachus' brother-in-law, even though fourteen witnesses had given the same evidence as Callimachus. 
See also oath id 2973.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
if_taken: He will not have to testify
statement: [That he did not know that the facts, to which he had been called to testify, were true]
remarks:
Apollodorus states that he has entered a suit against Antiphanes because he did not testify or take the exomosia according to the law. We know from §19 that Antiphanes did not appear in court when summoned (he kept refusing to let Apollodorus submit his evidence to the arbitrator, always promising he’d testify on the day; when the day came, he didn’t turn up, even when Apollodorus went to his home to summon him; and the arbitrator, after waiting all day, gave a verdict against Apollodorus.) 
Apollodorus demands that Antiphanes gets up and swears whether he loaned Timotheus 1000 drachmas in Calaureia, and whether Philip received that sum from Pasion. 
Apollodorus presumably wants Antiphanes to do what he wouldn’t do before the arbitrator – either confirm that the money was indeed lent to Timotheus and that it originally belonged to Pasion, or deny it under oath.  (There would surely be no need for an oath – certainly Apollodorus would have no interest in demanding one – if Antiphanes was willing to confirm these propositions.)  And since at the end of §20 Apollodorus passes straight on to other matters, and never mentions Ant. again except briefly in passing at §48, we may safely take it that all this rigmarole about calling Antiphanes as a witness and demanding that he go up to the stand is just play-acting and that Apollodorus knows perfectly well that Antiphanes is not in court at all.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Meton had better be off]
  Ὑπάγοιμι τἄρ’ ἄν.
  {ΠΙ.} Νὴ Δί’, ὡς οὐκ οἶδ’ ἂν εἰ  
  φθαίης ἄν·

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Andocides states that the Athenians made an alliance with the Boeotians in 395 because they thought they could defend themselves against the whole world with the power of the Boeotians joined with them. 
He contrasts this situation with the position in 392/1 when they are deliberating whether they should continue the war with the Spartans without the Boeotians who are (according to Andocides) making peace with the Spartans. 
See also oath id 2419.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That he will not tell Hermogenes to go to Diodorus' house]
 καὶ ὁ Διόδωρος, Ἀλλὰ καλῶς γε, ἔφη, λέγεις, ὦ Σώκρατες, καὶ κέλευσον ἐλθεῖν ὡς ἐμὲ τὸν Ἑρμογένην. Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἔγωγε·
remarks: Socrates has advised Diodorus to help Hermogenes and thinks that Diodorus should himself call on Hermogenes.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That the men accused of bribery at the instance of Demophilus were not acquitted]
 μὰ τὸν Ἡρακλέα,
remarks:
Aeschines asks rhetorically, whether some individuals alleged by Demophilus to have been involved in bribery (in the assembly and the lawcourts) were acquitted. 
He answers his own question with this oath, and then goes on to swear that their crime was less serious than that perpetrated by Timarchus. 
See also oath id 2565.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That health causes evil, and sickness good, when a military (or maritime) disaster occurs, because those who were absent ill survive while the healthy fight (or sail) and perish]
 Πότε δ’ ἄν, ἔφη, τὸ μὲν ὑγιαίνειν
κακοῦ αἴτιον γένοιτο, τὸ δὲ νοσεῖν ἀγαθοῦ; Ὅταν νὴ Δί’,
ἔφη, στρατείας τε αἰσχρᾶς καὶ ναυτιλίας βλαβερᾶς καὶ ἄλλων πολλῶν τοιούτων οἱ μὲν διὰ ῥώμην μετασχόντες ἀπόλωνται, 
οἱ δὲ δι’ ἀσθένειαν ἀπολειφθέντες σωθῶσιν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Peisetaerus cannot see any of the gods behind Prometheus]
 Τῶν θεῶν ὁρᾷς τινα  
  ἐμοῦ κατόπιν ἐνταῦθα; 
 {ΠΕ.}  Μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ μὲν οὔ.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That some of those who received immunity from liturgies did not deserve it]
 νὴ Δί’ ἀνάξιοι γάρ τινες τῶν εὑρημένων ταῦτ’ ἦσαν·
remarks:
Demosthenes again imagines that Leptines will swear that some of those who received immunity from liturgies did not deserve it.  
See also oath id 3368.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of King Ariston ca. 545-530 (545 to 530)
impact: Many years later Demaratus lost his throne because he was believed to be illegitimate
statement:
[That Demaratus could not be his son]
 οὐκ ἂν ἐμὸς εἴη
remarks:
Ariston's wife gave birth less than ten months after their marriage. 
Ariston was with the ephors at the time and was heard to say that the boy (Demaratus) could not be his son. 
For the consequences of this oath see oath id 1349 and 1351.

author: Lysias
title: Against Agoratus
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
At section 17, the speaker describes the proposal for peace being put to the demos. At section 34 he describes the Athenians complying with the terms of the peace. 
See also oath id 1893.

author: Demosthenes
title: Epistle 4
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that someone will respond to his letter by arguing that the Athenians are worse off than the Thessalians, Argives and Arcadians who had the fortune to be in alliance with Philip.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
Thucydides states that when Alcibiades sent a message to the Argives urging them to come to Athens along with the Mantineans and Eleans to make an alliance the Argives realised that the alliance between Sparta and Boeotia had not been made with the consent of the Athenians. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1708.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he'll either be made very happy today by his lovers, or else he's going to play hard to get]
 Ἀλλ’ ἢ μεγάλως εὐδαιμονήσω τήμερον
  ὑπὸ τῶν ἐραστῶν, νὴ Δί’, ἢ ’γὼ θρύψομαι.
remarks: Sommerstein ad 1162-3 explains the statement as follows: "[he] will not show [himself] willing to yield to either "suitor" unless one of them thoroughly cossets [him]".

author: Eubulus
title: Chrysilla
statement:
[That X (never in the end identified)  is a good woman]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία χρηστὴ τίς ἦν μέντοι, τίς;
remarks: This is a failed oath. There is no proposition which can be true or false since the speaker, having mentioned Penelope and Alcestis, fails to find another good woman to name.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would go in support with all their strength as far as possible if anyone went against the polis of Athens for war or overthrew the Athenian demos]
 βο[η]θ[ήσ]ω παντὶ σθένει κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν, ἐὰν τις ἴ[ηι] ἐπὶ τὴν πόλιν τὴν Ἀθ[ην]αίων ἐπὶ πολέμωι ἢ τὸν δῆμον καταλύει τὸν Ἀθηνα[ίων]·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Thessaly. 
The text indicates that each party will swear their "lawful oath".  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 451.  
For the oath of the rest of the Thessalians see oath id 452.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That if weeds spring up and choke the grain, they should cut the weeds]
 Τί γάρ, ἔφη, ἂν ὕλη πνίγῃ συνεξορμῶσα τῷ σίτῳ καὶ διαρπάζουσα τοῦ σίτου τὴν τροφὴν ὥσπερ οἱ κηφῆνες διαρπάζουσιν ἄχρηστοι ὄντες τῶν μελιττῶν
ἃ ἂν ἐκεῖναι ἐργασάμεναι τροφὴν καταθῶνται; Ἐκκόπτειν ἂν νὴ Δία [τὴν τροφὴν] δέοι τὴν ὕλην, ἔφην ἐγώ

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That her boyfriend didn't ask her for a lot]
  Οὐ πολλὰ τοίνυν, μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω
remarks: This is another sarcastic statement with an informal oath (cf. also oath ids 873 and 884). The old woman has just finished listing all the many things her boyfriend would ask her for, all while claiming that this was not a lot.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Epigenes should not go to the Second Old Woman, but come to her instead]
 {Γρ. β}  σιγῇ βάδιζε δεῦρο. {Γρ. γ} μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ ὡς ἐμέ.
remarks: The two old women are fighting over Epigenes at this point. This oath is interesting inasmuch as the oath seems to reinforce a command, not a statement.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That Ischomachus shows that his wife has a masculine intelligence]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφην, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, ἀνδρικήν γε ἐπιδεικνύεις τὴν διάνοιαν τῆς γυναικός.
remarks: There’s a difference between having “masculine intelligence”, i.e. being as intelligent as a man, and having “a masculine intelligence”, i.e. being intelligent in the same kinds of ways as a man.  Pomeroy, rightly, takes Socrates here to mean the latter. She notes ad loc.: "Ischomachus reminds Socrates that, despite the masculinity of his wife's mind, she continues to obey her husband". For Socrates invoking Hera in an informal oath cf. oath ids 1872, 2102, 2106, 2122, 2144, 2268, 2778, 2896, 2929, 3116, 3157, 3159.

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[That they would not rebel against the Athenians by word or deed in any way whatever, neither by their own volition nor by persuasion, and if anyone did rebel they would denounce him to the Athenians, and they would pay as tribute whatever sum they could persuade the Athenians to prescribe]
 οὐκ ἀποσ̣[τήσομαι ἀπὸ το̃ δήμο τ]ο̃ Ἀθηναίων οὔτε τέ[χνηι οὔτε μηχανῆι οὐδε]μ̣ιᾶι οὐδ᾿ ἔπει οὐδὲ [ἔργωι οὐδὲ τῶι ἀφισταμέν]ωι πείσομαι, καὶ ἐὰ̣[ν ἀφιστῆι τις κατερῶ Ἀθ]η̣[να]ίοις, καὶ τὸν φ̣ό̣[ρον ὑποτελῶ τοῖς Ἀθηναίοις ὃ]ν̣ [ἂν] πείθω [Ἀθηναίος - - - - - - - - - -]
remarks:
This inscription records the regulations imposed on Eretria by Athens. 
The oath was to be sworn in the presence of the horkotai ("oath-commissioners") from Athens. The generals were to ensure that everyone swore the oath. For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 147. See also the oath sworn by the Chalcidians, which is described as the same as this oath (oath id 148).

author: Epicharmus
title: Pyrra kai Promatheus
statement: unknown
remarks: The text is too fragmentary to reveal the oath statement.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the men deserve having water thrown over them]
 Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ τὸν ἁλυκὸν δίκαιά γε.
remarks: The magistrate's argument is that the men are to blame for assisting their wives in their wickedness and teaching them licentiousness. Sommerstein notes ad loc. that "the Briny" is "probably not an actual cult-title of Poseidon but a comic substitute for e.g. Halimedon "ruler of the seas"… The epithet adds emphasis to the oath".

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That if they (i.e. Cleophon and the Revenue Board and Myrmex and Nicomachus and Archenomus) don't come quickly, Pluto will tattoo them, out them in fetters and send them down below the earth with all haste, along with Adeimantus son of Leucolophus]
 κἂν μὴ ταχέως 
  ἥκωσιν, ἐγὼ νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω 
 στίξας αὐτοὺς καὶ ξυμποδίσας 
 μετ’ Ἀδειμάντου τοῦ Λευκολόφου  
 κατὰ γῆς ταχέως ἀποπέμψω.
remarks: See Sommerstein ad loc. on the various figures mentioned here. As regards Pluto's statement, Sommerstein notes ad 1510-4 that "Pluto himself resides under the ground and therefore cannot literally send anyone there but only take them. He is, however, being made to image himself as a rich man who owns slaves at several sites, and is ordering that certain badly-behaved slaves should be tattooed…, put in fetters…, and sent from a more comfortable site (e.g. a town house) to a harsher (e.g. mill or mine work)".

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Herodotus indicates that during the Lelantine war the Samians came to the assistance of Chalcis, while the Milesians assisted Eretria (see oath id 1522).  
For Thucydides on the alliances at the time of the Lelantine war see oath id 1518.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1a
impact: Emphasises the truth of his statement
statement:
[That Socrates taught his companions to view the established laws with contempt, saying that it was foolish to appoint public officials by lot (for no other job is awarded by lot, nor would mistakes made in such jobs have such disastrous consequences)]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία, ὁ κατήγορος ἔφη, ὑπερορᾶν ἐποίει τῶν καθεστώτων νόμων τοὺς συνόντας, λέγων ὡς μῶρον εἴη τοὺς μὲν τῆς πόλεως ἄρχοντας ἀπὸ κυάμου καθιστάναι, κυβερνήτῃ δὲ μηδένα θέλειν χρῆσθαι κυαμευτῷ μηδὲ τέκτονι μηδ’αὐλητῇ μηδ’ ἐπ’ ἄλλα τοιαῦτα, ἃ πολλῷ ἐλάττονας βλάβας ἁμαρτανόμενα ποιεῖ τῶν περὶ τὴν πόλιν ἁμαρτανομένων·
remarks: The accuser clearly believes in the truth of his statement, but Xenophon's purpose here is, of course, to defend Socrates, which he proceeds to do in what follows - though without ever actually denying that Socrates said what the accuser alleges he said!  This is our first example of the common oratorical use of Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία to introduce a point supposed to be made by an opponent.  In this case the point is one the opponent really has made; more often it is hypothetical (“But someone may say …”).

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks: Euxitheus, the defendant, argues that his case can only be judged correctly if the customary preliminary oath has been sworn, and only if he is allowed to confine his defence to the question before the court.

author: Plato
title: Symposium
statement: n/a
remarks: Pausanias here discusses how it is popularly believed that the lover is the one person who will be pardoned by the gods for breaking his oath, for the lover's oath is invalid (cf. oath id 1307). The concept of the irrational behaviour of lovers being sanctioned by law is also discussed. So complete indulgence is accorded to the lover both by gods and by men. Pausanias speculates that this can be accounted for if it is remembered that the moral value of the act is not what one might call a constant. It is the pursuit of love for an immoral purpose that is punshed by law. Cf. oath id 2921 and 2932.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Evergus and Mnesibulus
statement: [That he was unable to attend]
remarks: The speaker tells the jurors that when he entered a suit against Theophemus for having assaulted him in the performance of public duty, Theophemus launched a countersuit against him, and entered a special plea and a hypomosia for postponing the case against himself.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Blepyrus has experienced the same thing as the neighbour (i.e. their wives have disappeared)]
  νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ ταὐτὰ τοίνυν ἄντικρυς 
  ἐμοὶ πέπονθας·
remarks: See remarks on oath id 796.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
statement:
[That they ought to have done this and not that]
 νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἔδει γὰρ τὸ καὶ τὸ ποιῆσαι καὶ τὸ μὴ ποιῆσαι.
remarks: Demosthenes says that it will be a disgrace to lose to Philip and then say afterwards, "By Zeus, we ought to have done this and not that".

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
if_taken: They can compete freely for Helen's hand
if_refused: Exclusion from competition for Helen's hand
statement: [That they would join forces with Helen's husband to retrieve her should she be abducted]
remarks: Odysseus explains to Neoptolemus that only he can credibly persuade Philoctetes that he has abandoned the Trojan expedition because he is not bound by oath to support Helen's husband, although the oath doesn't seem terribly relevant to Odysseus' argument. Presumably what he's really trying to say is that N. had nothing to do with the original abandonment of Philoctetes - or even just that Ph. won't recognize him and therefore won't know he is an enemy.

author: Lysias
title: Against Philon
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
remarks: The speaker asks his fellow bouleutai to consider which oaths Philon would respect when he has already betrayed the ancestral gods with his actions.  He is clearly thinking of the bouleutic oath - Philon is undergoing his dokimasia for membership of the boule - just as his subsequent references to giving good advice and keeping secrets allude to aspects of a bouleutes' duties.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
After stressing that all the Athenians find fault with the consequences of the peace, Demosthenes reminds the jurors that they have come into the dikasterion to judge euthynai, having sworn an oath on behalf of the polis. He asks them whether it would not be a disgrace if they let off "the man responsible for the trouble". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Philip of Macedon
title: Letter to the Athenians
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Philip accuses the Athenians of capturing cities in the Pagasaean Gulf which are allied to him. 
See also oath id 2951.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker complains that those in the pay of the Macedonian king are so insolent that they insist the Athenians should abide by oaths which have already been broken, as if Alexander's power allows  him to commit perjury. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That those who do not fear dangers because they don't recognise them as dangers are not courageous since (if one were to take a diffrerent view) many madmen and cowards would count as brave]
 Οἱ ἄρα μὴ φοβούμενοι τὰ τοιαῦτα διὰ τὸ μὴ εἰδέναι τί ἐστιν οὐκ ἀνδρεῖοί εἰσι; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, πολλοὶ γὰρ ἂν οὕτω γε τῶν τε μαινομένων καὶ τῶν δειλῶν ἀνδρεῖοι εἶεν.
remarks: Here an affirmative oath-expression is used to emphasize a negative statement. Our analysis must therefore be that Socrates has asked Euthydemus whether he agrees that persons of this kind are not courageous, and Euthydemus replies that yes, he does agree.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Cyrus has given him a cup which is not of the same gold as the gift which he gave Chrysantas (see remarks)]
 καὶ ὁ Ἀρτάβαζος εἶπε· Μὰ Δί’,  ἔφη, ὦ Κῦρε, οὐχ ὁμοίου γε χρυσοῦ ἐμοί τε τὸ ἔκπωμα δέδωκας καὶ Χρυσάντᾳ τὸ δῶρον.
remarks: Artabazus makes this statement just after Cyrus has kissed Chrysantas. Artabazus, who is in love with Cyrus and has previously obtained kisses from Cyrus through his dubious machinations (cf. oath ids 2318-2320, 2386), here expresses his jealousy through the metaphor of gifts.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement: n/a
remarks: In a discussion of the rewards which poets allege the gods bestow on just men, it is mentioned that some poets say that the pious oath-keeper will leave behind him children’s children and a continuing line of descendants beyond.  Plato appears to have blended recollections of the Hesiod Works and Days 282-5 (see oath id 1301), and of Tyrtaeus fr. 12.30; the latter is not about the pious but about the brave.

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: He will be allowed to proceed with selling his wares in the market-place
if_refused: He will not be allowed to proceed with selling his wares in the market-place
statement: [That his wares are the genuine article]
remarks: Further to discussions of violation of laws governing business transactions in the market-place of Magnesia, is stated that any market-seller who is challenged to so so must swear to the authenticity of his wares in the presence of the agoranomoi (supervisors of the market-place). They are, however, forbidden to swear oaths to this effect to customers- see oath id 2725.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
 ἐμμενῶ τῇ ξυμμαχίᾳ κατὰ τὰ ξυγκείμενα δικαίως καὶ ἀβλαβῶς καὶ ἀδόλως, καὶ οὐ παραβήσομαι τέχνῃ οὐδὲ μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ.
remarks:
This inscription records the so-called Argive alliance. See Thucydides 5.47.1-12 for full details.  
The text indicates that each city will swear the oath that is most binding in their land. The Athenians were to swear on behalf of their allies, whereas the Argives, Mantineans, Eleans, and their allies were to swear individually by state. 
It is stipulated that for the renewal of the oath the Athenians will travel to Elis, Mantinea, and Argos, thirty days before the Olympic games, and the Argives, Eleans and Mantineans will travel to Athens ten days before the Great Panathenaea. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

title: IC IV
if_taken: If believed he can keep the land
statement:
[That the land in question is the property of the pledgee and not that of the pledger]
 ὀμνύμεν δὲ ε῏ μὰν τούτο μ[έν ἐστι ἀβλοπίαι δικαίος πρὶν] μ̣ολέθαι τ[ὰν δίκαν, ο῏ δ’ ἐνεκύρακσαν μὲ ἔμεν - - -]
remarks:
The text indicates that during disputes over pledged property, the person to whom property was pledged should summon the pledger in order to mark off the land (i.e. measure it), and if the one summoned does not appear the pledgee should mark off the property himself, and warn the pledger to appear in the agora in four days time before two witnesses. They are to swear that the land in question is the property of the pledgee and not that of the pledger. 
For the oath of the pledger see oath id 996. For an almost identical text see oath id 984 and 986.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That she was looking (not at Cyrus) but at the man who said he would sell his soul rather than see her enslaved (i.e. Tigranes)]
 Ἀλλὰ τίνα μήν; ἔφη ὁ Τιγράνης. Τὸν εἰπόντα νὴ Δία ὡς τῆς αὑτοῦ ψυχῆς ἂν πρίαιτο ὥστε μή με δουλεύειν.
remarks: Tigranes is evidently pleased by his wife's responses. Cf. oath id 2373.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Labes is not a conspirator]
 καὶ ξυνωμότης.
 {Βδ.}  μὰ Δί’
remarks: On the suggestion of Labes being a conspirator, see also remarks at id 1107.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That the principle that to ingratiate oneself with one’s beloved one must make oneself as much like him/her/them as possible applies just as much to Callicles’ passion for Demos, son of Pyrilampes, as it does to his passion for the demos of Athens  (Callicles is in love with both of them, 481d4-5, as Socrates is with Alcibiades and philosophy)]
 οὐ γὰρ μιμητὴν δεῖ εἶναι ἀλλ’ αὐτοφυῶς ὅμοιον τούτοις, εἰ μέλλεις τι γνήσιον ἀπεργάζεσθαι εἰς φιλίαν τῷ Ἀθηναίων δήμῳ καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία τῷ Πυριλάμπους γε πρός.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, after the Thebans attacked Plataea in 431, the Plataeans sent a herald out to the Thebans saying that "they had done an impious thing in trying to seize their city in time of peace" (λέγοντες ὅτι οὔτε τὰ πεποιημένα ὅσια δράσειαν ἐν σπονδαῖς σφῶν πειράσαντες καταλαβεῖν τὴν πόλιν).  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement:
[That perhaps Boeotus is clever]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἴσως ἔστιν.
remarks: There is a play on two senses of δεινός, or perhaps rather on two ways of understanding it.  Boeotus wants to be thought highly intelligent; Mantitheus replies "yes, you can certainly say he’s clever, I imagine" - meaning that he has "the purely technical expertise of the sycophant" (Carey & Reid, Demosthenes: Selected Private Speeches, p178).

title: SEG
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That if anyone attacked Arcadia or overthrew the demos, they would help with all their strength]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Arcadia, Pisa and Acrorea. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 49.466. For the corresponding oath of the Arcadians see oath id 580.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he knows very well what language Hippothales uses towards his favourite]
  Νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη ὁ Κτήσιππος, πάνυ γε

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That Meidias' supporting speakers are not coming to his aid to do him a favour]
 οὐχ οὕτω τούτῳ χαρίσασθαι μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς βουλόμενοι
remarks: Demosthenes argues that those supporting Meidias are doing so not out of a desire to do him a favour, but in order to harm Demosthenes, because Eubulus wrongly regards him as an enemy.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
if_broken: May he perish most wretchedly, and his wife and children too, and Archedemus
impact: Xanthias accepts and dons Heracles' gear
statement: [That he will never take back Heracles' gear from Xanthias]
remarks: Xanthias here accepts the oath volunteered by Dionysus at id 426 (see remarks there).

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and that they would respect the division of Cotys' former kingdom and not attempt to change the settlement by force, and that the Athenians would receive back their possessions ]
remarks:
Aeschines accuses Demosthenes of betraying Cersobleptes, a friend and ally of the polis, to Philip. 
For the decree announcing the alliance between Athens and Cersobleptes (and Berisades and Amadocus of Thrace) see oath id 458.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Critobulus is handsome]
 Εἰ μὲν τοίνυν μὴ καλός εἰμι, ὡς οἴομαι, ὑμεῖς ἂν δικαίως ἀπάτης δίκην ὑπέχοιτε· οὐδενὸς γὰρ ὁρκίζοντος ἀεὶ ὀμνύοντες καλόν μέ φατε εἶναι. κἀγὼ μέντοι πιστεύω.
remarks: Critobulus here claims that he takes pride in his handsomeness, and he believes that he is handsome because, although no one asks them for an oath, those present are always swearing that he is handsome.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement: [That Euxitheus' father Thucritus was an Athenian and related to them]
remarks: Euxitheus argues that he has shown that he is entitled to citizenship by having his kinsmen give testimony under oath, and showing that they have always been his kinsmen from the beginning.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
The Corinthians seem to have rejoined the Peloponnesian League in the winter of 419/8, for Thucydides includes them in a list of the allies of Sparta. 
The Corinthians were still part of the Argive alliance in 420/19 because Thucydides (5.55) mentions that they attended a conference of Argos' allies at Mantinea that year. They are not mentioned again until the military campaign in 418/7. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he doesn't envy Euripides his upbringing]
  Μὰ τὸν Δί’, οὐ ζηλῶ σε τῆς παιδεύσεως.
remarks: Euripides has just said that at Agathon's age he himself was like Agathon is now (i.e. effeminate).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement: [That the outcome of the vote was incorrect]
remarks: Demosthenes asks how much money the leading taxpayers would have given to have him refrain from proposing his law regarding the trierarchy, or failing that to have someone lodge an objection to the law under oath.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Hermes
statement:
[That he did not drive the cows home, nor cross the threshold]
 ὡς οὐκ οἴκαδ’ ἔλασσα βόας, ὣς ὄλβιος εἴην, 
οὐδ’ ὑπὲρ οὐδὸν ἔβην·
remarks: The oath statement is technically true (a cave has no threshold), but it does not mean that Hermes didn't steal the cattle, and neither does Hermes' subsequent oath at id 1359.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the alliance]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Chalcis. 
The text states that "the city will swear to the Chalcidians". 
The terms of the alliance were that: Chalcis would be free, autonomous, ungarrisoned. Chalcis would pay no tribute, and would not receive a governor from the Athenians. The Athenians and Chalcidians would defend each other as far as they were able. 
For the corresponding oath of the Chalcidians see oath id 352.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he had not carried a load on the long journey which he claims wore him out]
 Ἄλλου δὲ λέγοντος ὡς παρετάθη μακρὰν ὁδὸν πορευθείς, ἤρετο αὐτὸν εἰ καὶ φορτίον ἔφερε, Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’, ἔφη

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That (through their discussion) they have purged their city, which was luxurious a short while earlier]
  Καὶ νὴ τὸν κύνα, εἶπον, λελήθαμέν γε διακαθαίροντες πάλιν ἣν ἄρτι τρυφᾶν ἔφαμεν πόλιν.
remarks: Swearing "by the dog" is common only to the character of Socrates (cf. oath ids 2645, 2651, 2776, 2859, 2874, 2928, 3054, 3081, 3119, 3121, 3126, 3158). Other characters occasionally use this oath formula- see oath id 1058 from Aristophanes' Wasps.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
impact: Intensifies the anticipation of the revelation
statement:
[That he is bursting to tell the chorus his plan]
 Καὶ μὴν ὀργῶ νὴ τὸν Δία
remarks: The plan which Peisetaerus will reveal is for the creation a bird city in the sky, endorsed by Tereus at 194-195; cf. oath id 635.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That any citizen of Amphipolis or resident Athenian, if he chose, might remain there, retaining possession of his property with fair and equal rights; but anyone who was not inclined to stay could leave within five days and take his property with him]
 Ἀμφιπολιτῶν καὶ Ἀθηναίων τῶν ἐνόντων τὸν μὲν βουλόμενον ἐπὶ τοῖς ἑαυτοῦ τῆς ἴσης καὶ ὁμοίας μετέχοντα μένειν, τὸν δὲ μὴ ἐθέλοντα ἀπιέναι τὰ ἑαυτοῦ ἐκφερόμενον πέντε ἡμερῶν
remarks:
Thucydides states that he (in his capacity as an Athenian general) arranged matters at Eion to receive those who chose to come from the upper town according to the terms of the truce. 
See also oath id 1670.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
if_taken: They will be permitted to act as judges
if_refused: They will not be permitted to act as judges
impact: Case will be judged by both Athena and her people
statement: [That they will judge according to the laws]
remarks: Sommerstein ad loc. summarizes what was probably sworn (based on the oaths of ordinary dikasts): 'to vote according to the laws or, where the laws gave no guidance, according to the most just opinion…, to take no bribes…, and (probably) not to be moved by gratitude or hostility'. This oath is referred to several times during the course of the play- cf. oath ids 216, 218, 219, 221.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
swearer: Calonice; Lampito; Myrrhine; All women present; Lysistrata
swearee: Calonice; Lampito; Myrrhine; All women present; Lysistrata
if_taken: The sex strike will be ensured; peace will be enabled
if_refused: The sex strike will not be ensured; war will continue
if_kept: May she drink from the wine-cup
if_broken: May the wine-cup be filled with water
impact: The sex strike is ensured and peace is enabled
statement: [That no man whatever, neither lover nor husband shall come near her with his cock up, and that she will pass her life at home, pure and chaste in make-up and saffron gown so that her husband may be greatly inflamed with desire for her, and that she will never yield herself to her husband of her own free will. And if he should force her against her will, she will submit grudgingly and not thrust back. She will not raise her Persian slippers ceilingwards. She will not stand in the lioness-on-a-cheesegrater position]
remarks: Cinesias here refers to the conspiratorial oath sworn by the women at id 1164. See remarks there for further information.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
statement:
[That Aphobus had not been convicted because he admitted Milyas to be a free]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχ ὅτι τὸν Μιλύαν ὡμολόγησεν εἶναι ἐλεύθερον
remarks: Demosthenes argues that Aphobus had been convicted not because he admitted Milyas to be a freedman, but because of his mismanagement of Demosthenes' inheritance.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That, after their discussion, he does not think it possible that beauty is good or vice versa]
 ἢ δοκεῖ σοι οἷόν τε εἶναι ἐκ τῶν προειρημένων; {—ΙΠ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, οὔ μοι φαίνεται.
remarks: See oath id 3161 for context.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That he does not think one could name qualities more discreditable to the spirit of debate than boldness, screaming, false charges, intimidation and shamelessness]
 νομίζω δὲ μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐδ’ ἂν αἰσχίω

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Strepsiades' idea is clever]
  σοφῶς γε νὴ τὰς Χάριτας.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Andocides flatters the jurors, saying "I think that you are anyway prepared to make a just decision, and it was because I trusted in you that I stayed to face trial, seeing that in both private and public cases you reckon this the most important thing, that you vote according to your oaths, and it is this alone which holds the city together". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Euthyphro
statement:
[That he is not prepared to say that when he does a pious action, he makes some deity better]
 καὶ σὺ τοῦτο συγχωρήσαις ἄν, ὡς ἐπειδάν τι ὅσιον ποιῇς, βελτίω τινὰ τῶν θεῶν ἀπεργάζῃ; {ΕΥΘ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[That they would not rebel against the Athenian demos by word or deed, in any way whatever, either by their own volition or by the persuasion of another. If anyone did rebel they would denounce him to the Athenians. They would pay the tribute to the Athenians which they would persuade them to assess, and as an ally they would be the best and truest possible, and they would assist the Athenian demos and defend them if anyone injures the Athenian demos, and they would obey the Athenian demos]
 οὐκ ἀπο[σ]τέσομαι ἀπὸ το̃ [δ]έμο το̃ Ἀθεναίον οὔτε τέ[χ]νει οὔτε μεχανε̃ι οὐδεμιᾶι οὐδ’ ἔπει οὐδὲ ἔργοι οὐδὲ το̃ι ἀφισταμένοι πείσομαι, καὶ ἐὰν ἀφιστε̃ι τις κατερο̃ Ἀθεναίοισι, καὶ τὸν φόρον hυποτελο̃ Ἀθεναίοισι, hὸν ἂν πείθο Ἀθεναίος, καὶ χσύμμαχος ἔσομαι hοῖος ἂν δύνομαι ἄριστος καὶ δικαιότατος καὶ το̃ι δέμοι το̃ι Ἀθεναίον βοεθέσο καὶ ἀμυνο̃, ἐὰν τις ἀδικε̃ι τὸν δε̃μον τὸν Ἀθεναίον, καὶ πείσομαι το̃ι δέμοι το̃ι Ἀθεναίον.
remarks:
This inscription records the regulations imposed on Chalcis by the Athenians. 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 148.  
See also oath id 150.

author: Xenophon
title: Apology
statement:
[That he would never want to suffer the potential difficulties of old age]
 μὰ Δί’, εἰπεῖν αὐτόν, ὦ Ἑρμόγενες, ἐγὼ ταῦτα οὐδὲ προθυμήσομαι

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Chremylus' wealth would be dirty if he had stolen it from the god (i.e. Apollo)]
  Πῶς οὐδὲν ὑγιές;
  {ΒΛ.}  Εἴ τι κεκλοφὼς νὴ Δία  
  ἐκεῖθεν ἥκεις ἀργύριον ἢ χρυσίον
  παρὰ τοῦ θεοῦ
remarks: Cf. Chremylus' response at oath id 870.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That the god didn't notice his fart]
 Οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐδ’ ἐφρόντισεν.
remarks: The god in question is Asclepius.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he believes the boy will be completely corrupted if he is persuaded to sleep with someone]
 Ἀλλ’ οὔτοι, ἔφη, ἀποκτεῖναι βούλονται, ἀλλὰ πεῖσαι αὐτὸν συγκαθεύδειν αὐτοῖς. Σὺ δ’, ὡς ἔοικας, εἰ τοῦτο γένοιτο, νομίζεις ἂν διαφθαρῆναι αὐτόν; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, παντάπασί γε.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That the experts in harmony labour uselessly to measure audible musical intervals]
 ἢ οὐκ οἶσθ’ ὅτι καὶ περὶ ἁρμονίας ἕτερον τοιοῦτον ποιοῦσι; τὰς γὰρ ἀκουομένας αὖ συμφωνίας καὶ φθόγγους ἀλλήλοις ἀναμετροῦντες ἀνήνυτα, ὥσπερ οἱ ἀστρονόμοι, πονοῦσιν. Νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest the Spartans while they collected their dead if they agreed to leave Boeotia afterwards]
remarks:
After Lysander's army was defeated at the battle at Haliartus, the Thebans told the second Spartan army led by King Pausanias that they would not give up the dead except on condition that the Spartans should leave their country.  
Pausanias welcomed this and left Boeotia after collecting the dead. 
Pausanias was prosecuted when he returned home for not reaching Haliartus on the same day as Lysander and for making a truce to collect the dead rather than trying to recover them by battle.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
statement: n/a
remarks: Agamemnon states with reference to the oath taken by Helen's suitors (see oath ids 182, 183, 184) that the gods are aware when oaths are taken wrongfully or under compulsion.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
statement: [That they would not attack each other]
remarks: The truce is proposed by Artaxerxes but refused by the Greeks. See oath id 2077 for further details and oath id 2084 for details of the truce finally made in Babylon.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Menecles
swearer: The speaker and his party; Menecles' brother and his party
swearee: The speaker and his party; Menecles' brother and his party
statement:
[That they would behave properly to one another, both in words and in deeds as far as lay within their power]
 εὖ ποιεῖν ἀλλήλους καὶ λόγῳ καὶ ἔργῳ
remarks:
The speaker states that the arbitrators decided that his party should give up what his opponent claimed and hand it over as a free gift, and then ordered both parties to swear at the altar of Aphrodite to behave in a proper manner towards one another. 
See also oath id 3026, 3029, 3031, 3032, 3034.

title: IG II(2)
swearee: Cephalus of Collytus; [-----] of Alopece; Aesimus; [-----] of Phrearrhi; Democlides
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That if anyone goes against the Athenians they would go in support as far as possible]
 ἐάν τις ἴη̣ι ἐπ’ Ἀθηναίος β̣οηθε̃[ν Χ]ίος παντὶ σθέ[νε]ι κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Chios. 
Five Athenians were elected to travel to Chios to witness the oath of the Chians. The terms of the alliance indicate that the Athenians and Chians would come to the aid of each other to the best of their ability if they were attacked by a third party. These oaths were stated to have been in addition to and not in violation of those sworn in the King's Peace (see oath id 328) which is described as a peace and oath and agreement.  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 305.

author: Sappho
title: Fragments
statement:
[That she no longer gets pleasure from living]
 ο]ὐ μὰ γὰρ μάκαιραν̣ [ἔγωγ’
ο]ὐδὲν ἄδομ’ ἔπερθα γᾶ[ς  ἔοισα

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That Perseus (i.e. Euripides) will not fuck Andromeda (i.e. the Inlaw) from behind]
 ἐξόπιστο πρώκτισον. 
  {ΕΥ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: Euripides is speaking within the dramatic fiction he and the Inlaw have created, in which they are playing Perseus and Andromeda respectively; the Archer, on the other hand, does not understand drama, so that to him the Inlaw is simply an old man and the erotic interest of "Perseus" in him is somewhat puzzling.

author: Hesiod
title: Works and Days
statement:
[That his twisted accusations attacking the good man are true]
 βλάψει δ’ ὁ κακὸς τὸν ἀρείονα φῶτα 
μύθοισι σκολιοῖς ἐνέπων, ἐπὶ δ’ ὅρκον ὀμεῖται.
remarks: This is a hypothetical oath. Cf. oath id 1298 where the just man's oath will gain no appreciation.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
In 422/1 the representatives of the Spartans and the Athenians swore, "I will abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly" 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. free access to common sanctuaries
2. the independence of Delphi
3. peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. it was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. the Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. the Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to  their homelands
9. the fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
After they had made a treaty and alliance with the Spartans, the Argives sent envoys to Athens bidding them evacuate the fortress they had built at Epidaurus. 
Demosthenes removed the men from the fortress, and afterwards the Athenians "renewed the treaty with the Epidaurians". This treaty must be the Peace of Nicias, which had been broken because the Athenians and the Epidaurians had been fighting against other (see 5.75.6). 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Herodotus indicates that the Lydians and the Medes were at war with each other, and were reconciled after a solar eclipse by Syennesis of Cilicia and Labynetus (presumably Nebuchadnezzar) the Babylonian. These men brought it about that there should be a sworn agreement (τὸ ὅρκιον) between the Lydian king Alyattes and the Median king Cyaxares, and an exchange of marriages between them whereby Alyattes gave his daughter to Astyages the son of Cyaxares.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Tyrannus
if_broken: May he not be blessed but die accursed
statement: [That he has not been plotting against Oedipus]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 241. This time the Chorus try to convince Oedipus to calm his rage against Creon on account of the latter's oath.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he has not forgotten that when he and his school-fellows first began learning to read and to write, they thought that now one letter now another was part of the same syllable, and put the same letter sometimes into the proper syllable, sometimes into another]
 Ἆρα λέγεις τῆς αὐτῆς συλλαβῆς τοτὲ μὲν ἕτερον, τοτὲ δὲ ἕτερον ἡγουμένους γράμμα, καὶ τὸ αὐτὸ τοτὲ μὲν εἰς τὴν προσήκουσαν, τοτὲ δὲ εἰς ἄλλην τιθέντας συλλαβήν;  {ΣΩ.} Ταῦτα λέγω. {ΘΕΑΙ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐ τοίνυν ἀμνημονῶ

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: Hippias will go to the conference
if_refused: Hippias will not go to the conference
statement:
[That if his proposals were unsatisfactory to Hippias, he would restore him to the fortress safe and sound]
 ἢν μηδὲν ἀρέσκον λέγῃ, πάλιν αὐτὸν καταστήσειν ἐς τὸ τεῖχος σῶν καὶ ὑγιᾶ
remarks:
According to Thucydides, when stasis broke out in Notium the port of Colophon, one party fortified their part of the city and called in mercenaries (Arcadian and barbarian) and the other party escaped and called in Paches the Athenian general to assist them. 
Paches summoned Hippias the commander of the Arcadian mercenaries to a conference, on condition that if his proposals were unsatisfactory he would restore him to the fortress safe and sound. 
When Hippias came to him, Paches kept him under guard but unfettered, while making a surprise assault on the fortress. 
After Paches captured the fortress he put to death all the Arcadian and barbarian mercenaries, and then took Hippias into the fortress as he had agreed (ἐσπείσατο) and as soon as Hippias was inside Paches seized him and shot him down.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That he would like to hear the "porkers" grunt"]
 Ἦ λῇς ἀκοῦσαι φθεγγομένας; 
  {ΔΙ.}  Νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς 
  ἔγωγε.
remarks: See also remarks on oath ids 611 and 612.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Hypereides says he would be pleased to hear from his accuser whether or not it was thought at the time that the Athenian-Theban alliance was advantageous for Athens and Greece.
See also oath id 2670.

author: Hypereides
title: In defence of Euxenippus
statement: [That he was unable to attend]
remarks: Hypereides states that a charge of attempting to overthrow democracy is too serious a matter to allow an oath of postponement (the hypomosia) to be taken.  He is insisting on the value of the eisangelia procedure as a safeguard of the constitution, but arguing that it has no application to a case like that of Euxenippus.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Cyrus and his companions were taught to be honest when they were young so that they would learn to behave honestly towards their friends and fellow-citizens, not towards enemies]
 Πῶς μήν, ἔφη, παῖδας ὄντας ἡμᾶς καὶ ἐφήβους τἀναντία τούτων ἐδιδάσκετε; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, καὶ νῦν πρὸς τοὺς φίλους τε καὶ πολίτας·
remarks: Dishonesty is necessary to overcome an enemy, explains Cambyses. In what follows, he explains that Cyrus had, in fact, been taught the arts of deception as a young boy (e.g. in hunting) although the boy had not recognised them as such. Cf. oath id 2336.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he has never seen a man so rustic and clueless, so stupid and forgetful]
  μὰ τὴν Ἀναπνοήν, μὰ τὸ Χάος, μὰ τὸν Ἀέρα,
  οὐκ εἶδον οὕτως ἄνδρ’ ἄγροικον οὐδαμοῦ
  οὐδ’ ἄπορον οὐδὲ σκαιὸν οὐδ’ ἐπιλήσμονα

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Apollodorus
statement:
[That Apollodorus would have done better if he had chosen a child from the family of one of his friends, adopted him, and given him his property] 
Εἰ νὴ Δία παιδίον ἐποιήσατο λαβὼν παρά του τῶν φίλων ὄντων, καὶ τούτῳ τὴν οὐσίαν ἔδωκεν;
remarks: The speaker imagines that someone might object that Apollodorus would have been better off if he had adopted a child of one of his friends, and then asks the jurors how Apollodorus could have done better than to adopt him, the son of his half-sister.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the women who are approaching come from Anagyrus]
 πόθεν εἰσίν;
 {ΛΥ.}  Ἀναγυρουντόθεν.  
 {ΚΛ.}  Νὴ τὸν Δία·
