remarks: Calonice and Lysistrata reach this conclusion based on the allegation that the women in question exude a foul smell; this is a play on the homonym for the name of the deme which designated the malodorous shrub bean-trefoil. See further Sommerstein ad 67-68.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That when Aeschylus was alive, the crew of the Paralus only knew how to call out for their barley-cake and say "yoho" (i.e. to their crewmates)]
 Καίτοι τότε γ’, ἡνίκ’ ἐγὼ ’ζων,
οὐκ ἠπίσταντ’ ἀλλ’ ἢ μᾶζαν καλέσαι καὶ «Ῥυππαπαῖ» εἰπεῖν.
  ΔΙ.  Νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω
remarks: The statement refers to Aeschylus' claim that Euripides has taught the crew of the fast state trireme Paralus to "talk back to their officers" - possibly alluding to the occasion in 411 when they were ordered to take representatives of the Four Hundred to Sparta for peace negotiations and instead handed them over to the Argives to be imprisoned.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [That he had not acknowledged that Milyas was free and that he had not testified against Demon]
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that Aphobus refused this oath in front of many witnesses. 
See also oath id 3523, 3525, 3527, 3529.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
if_refused: They would not be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
Thucydides refers to the alliance of the Greeks against the Persians, but names only the Athenians and the Spartans out of all the poleis that fought against the Persians. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1501.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
if_taken: Megabyzus may be persuaded to see the king
if_refused: Megabyzus may not be persuaded to see the king
statement: [That the king does not desire to harm him]
remarks: These ambassadors have come to petition Megabyzus after a fall-out between him and Menostates, son of Artarios, brother of Artaxerxes. Menostates had attacked Megabyzus and been decisively defeated, and Artarios had subsequently sought to make peace with Megabyzus at the court of the king (Artaxerxes). After Megabyzus receives these oaths from the ambassadors, the king sends word that he forgives Megabyzus. Later, however, he becomes enraged when Megabyzus shoots a lion before he has a chance to shoot it himself, and cuts off Megabyzus' head forthwith.

author: Euripides
title: Erechtheus
swearer: Sisters of sacrificed daughter of Erectheus
statement: [That they would die together]
remarks: The content of the oaths sworn between the sisters is not stated in the surviving fragments, but there is evidence in other sources, notably [Apollodorus] 3.15.4, that in some accounts they swore to die together. In the play Athena gives instructions for the sisters to be buried. This shows that the oath referred to is the oath that the sisters would die together.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Strategos #1; Alcias of Chytroi (strategos #2); Hipposthenes of Minthous (strategos 3#); Xenotimus (strategos #4); Clearchus (strategos #5); Phileas of Zarex (strategos #6); A[---] the hipparch; Hippeis; Eparagon of Amarynthus (taxiarch #1); Demarchus of Hermae (taxiarch #2); Epasippus (taxiarch #3); Democrates (taxiarch #4); S[---] of Styra (taxiarch #5); Bouleutai
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would abide by the alliance and arrangement with the Athenian demos and the allies, justly and guilelessly; and if someone went against the land of the Athenians or overthrew the Athenian demos, they would help with all their strength as they were able]
 ἐμμενῶ τῆι συμ[μαχίαι καὶ συντάξει πρὸς τὸν δῆμ]ον τὸν Ἀθηναίων [καὶ τοὺς συμμάχους δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως· καὶ ἐὰν τ[ις ἴηι ἐπὶ τὴν χώραν τὴν Ἀθηναίω]ν ἢ τοὺς συμμάχο[υς τοὺς Ἀθηναίων ἢ καταλύηι τὸν] δῆμον τὸν Ἀθηνα[ίων, βοηθήσω παντὶ σθένει κατὰ τ]ὸ δυνατόν·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Eretria. 
The text indicates that each city would swear its lawful oath. Fragment b indicates that the Eretrian oath was sworn by the strategoi, hipparch, hippeis, taxiarchs and bouleutai, who are listed in that order. The Athenians elected five men to receive the oaths of the Eretrians.  
It is interesting that the agreement should stipulate that the oath should be sworn at Eretria by persons occupying pretty much the same positions as those who normally swore such oaths at Athens - including all the cavalrymen. 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 471.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
statement:
[That it seems to him that his opponent has only one concern, to enhance his reputation during the course of his speech]
 Ἀλλ’ ἔμοιγε νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς οὑτοσὶ δοκεῖ τοῦτο μόνον λογίζεσθαι ὅπως μεταξὺ λέγων εὐδοκιμήσει·
remarks: What Aeschines is saying is that Demosthenes is only concerned to be well regarded while he is speaking; if a short time afterwards he's exposed as the biggest villain in Greece, he couldn't care less about that!

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That the imbeciles who give him a livelihood by coming to view his marionettes are his source of pride]
 Ἐπὶ νὴ Δία τοῖς ἄφροσιν. οὗτοι γὰρ τὰ ἐμὰ νευρόσπαστα θεώμενοι τρέφουσί με.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Emphasises her pleasure at the news
statement:
[That she wants to garland him with a string of oven-baked loaves in honour of his good tidings]
  Νὴ τὴν Ἑκάτην, κἀγὼ δ’ ἀναδῆσαι βούλομαι 
  εὐαγγέλιά σε κριβανιτῶν ὁρμαθῷ
remarks: The news in question is that no one will ever be short of bread. On oaths by Hecate see oath id 777.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
Aristotle here refers to the introduction of the bouleutic oath which he ascribes to the archonship of Hermocreon. For the content of the oath at different times, see Rhodes 'The Athenian Boule' pp. 190-9, arguing that the oath was not aimed at restricting the powers of the boule (against e.g. Clochι and Larsen). He states (p. 192): "a deliberate reduction of its powers is conceivable only in such circumstances as we find in 410, and highly unlikely ninety years before that date". The bouleutai had a new obligation imposed in 410/09 to sit in their allotted seats. Rhodes again (p. 193): "If the essence of the bouleutic oath was a declaration of allegiance to the constitution and an undertaking to work for the good of the city, the particular clauses concerned with the actual powers of the boule could come and go without invalidating the claim that 'the same oath' was being sworn". 
See also oath id 278, 2021, 2356, 2851, 2857, 2858, 3492, 3493, 3713, 3714, 3758, 3759.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that Aeschines' most serious offence was making the city's disgrace perpetual by adding the phrase 'also to his [Philip's] descendants' to the peace treaty. He argues that the fact that they did so when drafting a peace treaty with a mortal man who had been made powerful by just a few successes was offensive to living Athenians and posterity. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the Inlaw will regret his outrage against them and the impious words he has spoken]
 Ἀλλ’ οὐ μὰ τὼ θεὼ τάχ’ οὐ 
  χαίρων ἴσως ἐνυβριεῖς 
  λόγους τε λέξεις ἀνοσίους.
remarks: As it turns out, the girl, whom the Inlaw proposes to slaughter, is in reality a wineskin disguised; the "mother", Mica, knows this, but the chorus, we may presume, do not. The Inlaw's "godless deeds" are thus not impious as they first seem. He has, however, already committed a grave sacrilege, and we shall soon learn that, even while this scene has been going on, the Council has sentenced him to death (though he will eventually escape with Euripides' help). On swearing by the 'two goddesses', see remarks on oath id 713.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Persians entered the city believing that they were safe
consequences_of_breach: Otanes slew all the Samians who fought against him
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
Herodotus states that when Otanes (one of the so-called 'Seven' who overthrew the Magi) led a Persian force to Samos to install Syloson the brother of Polycrates in power on Samos, Maendrius the tyrant and nephew of Syloson offered to leave the island under a truce (ὑπόσπονδοί). Otanes agreed to this, and upon the treaty being made (σπεισαμένου) the Persians entered the city. 
After this, Charilaus the brother of Maendrius persuaded him to breach the agreement. Maenadrius left the city as agreed, but once he had done so Charilaus led a force against the Persians who were taken unaware, "believing a full agreement had been made" (δοκέοντάς τε δὴ πάντα συμβεβάναι). 
After seeing the great harm done to the Persians, Otanes ignored the orders given to him by Darius to deliver the island unharmed to Syloson and commanded his soldiers to kill all the Samian men and boys they captured.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker argues that Alexander has broken the terms of the peace by restoring the sons of Philiades as tyrants at Messene. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Aeschylus
title: Unidentified drama
statement: n/a
remarks: This single line from an Aeschylean play expresses the view that it is not oaths that give credibility to men, but men that give it to oaths, i.e. that an oath only merits belief if it is sworn by a person who merits belief.  (Logically, this should imply that oaths are useless; but it may be e.g. an explanation by character A of why he is content with the word, or handclasp, of character B and is not requiring an oath even on a very important matter, and the speaker may be less interested in the logical implications of what he is saying than in its value as a compliment to B.)

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is not possible for a man to know even a fraction of all things]
 Ἆρ’ οὖν δοκεῖ σοι ἀνθρώπῳ δυνατὸν εἶναι τὰ ὄντα πάντα ἐπίστασθαι; Οὐδὲμὰ Δί’ ἔμοιγε πολλοστὸν μέρος αὐτῶν.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks: The defendant states that if he proved nothing except for the fact that the prosecutors attacked him when they were paid to do so, but frequented his society when they were not, the jurors would have heard enough to think them the worst perjurers and most impious of men.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Enrages the leader of the first semichorus
statement:
[That everything that Dicaeopolis has said was just and not one bit of it a lie]
 Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ, καὶ λέγει γ’ ἅπερ λέγει 
  δίκαια πάντα κοὐδὲν αὐτῶν ψεύδεται.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would live together in peace (and to make an offensive and defensive alliance with Athens)]
 τοὺς δ’ ἄλλους οἰκεῖν σπονδὰς πρὸς ἀλλήλους ποιησαμένους καὶ πρὸς Ἀθηναίους, ὥστε τοὺς αὐτοὺς ἐχθροὺς καὶ φίλους νομίζειν
remarks:
When stasis broke out at Corcyra, Nicostratus son of Diitrephes, the Athenian general, persuaded both factions to bring to trial the twelve men thought to have started the trouble (these promptly fled) and to make a treaty with each other to live together. 
After this they were also to extend their alliance with Athens to an offensive as well as a defensive alliance.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Argos. 
The text refers to an oath: [hόρκ]ον, but is too fragmentary to be properly understood. 
See also oath id 1756, 1797 and 1835.

author: Aristophanes
title: Unidentified Drama
date: Reference to Agathon gives more precise range (415 to 400)
statement: unknown
remarks: The text is too fragmentary to reveal the statement, but there are feminine plural participles in lines 12 and 17 of the fragment, suggesting that the swearer and swearee are both female.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Mantitheus tells the jurors, that in cases which are not covered by the laws, they have sworn "to decide what they consider to be most just". Mantitheus argues that even if there were no law concerning his case they would still be bound to vote in his favour. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he does not know any phrase which has a soul]
 Οἶσθα οὖν τι, ἔφη, ῥῆμα ψυχὴν ἔχον;  Μὰ Δία οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he cannot know whether Archelaus of Macedon is happy without having met him]
 συγγενόμενος ἂν γνοίης, ἄλλως δὲ αὐτόθεν οὐ γιγνώσκεις ὅτι εὐδαιμονεῖ;  {ΣΩ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτα.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
if_taken: The child could be admitted to the phratry
if_refused: The child could not be admitted to the phratry
if_broken: Utter destruction of both himself and his family
impact: The child was denied admission to the phratry
statement:
[That he did not have, nor had he ever had any son other than Hipponicus, whose mother was Glaucon's daughter]
 ἦ μὴν μὴ εἶναί <οἱ> υἱὸν ἄλλον μηδὲ γενέσθαι πώποτε, εἰ μὴ Ἱππόνικον ἐκ τῆς Γλαύκωνος θυγατρός· ἢ ἐξώλη εἶναι καὶ αὐτὸν καὶ τὴν οἰκίαν,
remarks:
Callias denied that the child of his wife's mother (he was married to the daughter of Ischomachus) was his son. 
Andocides reports that Callias called for destruction to fall upon himself and his family if he was not telling the truth, and adds, "as it will". 
Callias later changed his mind and introduced the boy to his phratry.  
See oath id 2363 and 2364.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
The text indicates that if a defendant accused of illegally selling a slave claims that the sale did not happen on his instructions, "the judge shall decide upon swearing an oath, if no witness testifies" (τὸν δικαστὰν ὀμνύντα κρίνεν, αἰ μὲ ἀποπονίοι μαίτυρς). 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: [That they would not neither work the land themselves, nor allow anyone else, but would aid the god and the consecrated land with hand and foot <and voice> and every means]
remarks:
Aeschines describes how he reacted when an Amphissan denounced the Athenians for impiety because of their alliance with the Phocians when he was a delegate to the the Amphictyones when the council was deciding the fate of Amphissa. 
Aeschines states that he ordered Apollo's oracle, the ancestors' oath and the curse to be read out, and declared to the other delegates, "Personally, for the sake of the Athenian demos, my life, my children, and my household, in keeping with the oath, I intend to help the god and the sacred land with hand and foot and voice, and every means I can, and I release our city from impiety against the gods". 
The 'strong curse' which accompanied the oath was as follows: "If anyone should violate this, city, individual or race, let them be cursed by Apollo, Artemis, Leto and Athena Pronaia. Their land should produce no crops, their wives bear children not like the parents, but monsters, their livestock not produce natural offspring; they should be defeated in war, lawsuits and debates, and they themselves, their households and their race should perish utterly; and they shall never offer pure sacrifice to Apollo, Artemis, Leto and Athena Pronaia, and may the gods not accept their offerings. 
Aeschines then urged the delegates to make their decision, and stressed that those who had actually committed the impiety (i.e. the Amphissans) should be punished. 
See also oath id 2696.

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: He will be allowed to judge
if_refused: He will be allowed to judge
statement: [That he will judge fairly and according to the laws]
remarks: Other types of judge are also to swear oaths- trial judges, those voting for new public officials, judges of physical contests (see oath ids 2730, 2731, 2733) as well as anyone else who does not bring any gain to himself by committing perjury.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That they should only take (and not give)]
 ἀλλὰ λαμβάνειν  
  ἡμᾶς μόνον δεῖ;  {Αν.}  νὴ Δία·
remarks: For a defence of this reading, see Sommerstein ad 778-9.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That those to whom he gives money do not give him back thanks either instead of silver]
 Τί δέ, ἀντὶ τοῦ ἀργυρίου χάριτας; Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐδὲ τοῦτο

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That he would not attack the Mantineans if they agreed to tear down their walls and to live apart in villages]
remarks: Xenophon states that when King Pausanias invaded their territory the Mantineans agreed to tear down their walls. Pausanias said that he would not make peace unless they also agreed to live apart in villages. The Mantineans agreed to this also.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: The king has the formal support of his men
statement:
[That they would come to aid if anyone tried to destroy their kingdoms]
 Καὶ πάντες δὴ τούτοις ὤμοσαν οἱ τότε βοηθήσειν, ἐάν τις τὴν βασιλείαν αὐτῶν διαφθείρῃ.
remarks: The discussion concerns the time in which Temenus was King of Argos, Cresphontes was king of Messene and Procles and Eurysthenes were kings of Sparta, when the area was first divided into the three states of Argos, Sparta and Messene.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [? That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks: Euthycles complains that the decree of Aristocrates authorises prosecutions without these oaths if anyone kills Charidemus.

author: Plato
title: Laches
statement:
[That it is true that Nicias has often heard him say 'Every man is good in that in which he is wise and bad in that in which he is unwise]
 Πολλάκις ἀκήκοά σου λέγοντος ὅτι ταῦτα ἀγαθὸς ἕκαστος ἡμῶν ἅπερ σοφός, ἃ δὲ ἀμαθής, ταῦτα δὲ κακός. {ΣΩ.} Ἀληθῆ μέντοι νὴ Δία λέγεις, ὦ Νικία.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Theorus explains that Sitalces has sent some Thracian soldiers
statement:
[That he does not believe a word of what Theorus has said, apart from the reference to locusts]
 Κάκιστ’ ἀπολοίμην, εἴ τι τούτων πείθομαι
  ὧν εἶπας ἐνταυθοῖ σὺ πλὴν τῶν παρνόπων.
remarks: See also the oath sworn by Sitalces, to which Dicaeopolis is responding, at oath id 592.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides states that he will describe the breaking of the treaty between Athens and Sparta. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_broken: May the gods give him many griefs, such as they give to perjurers
statement: [That he did not sleep with Briseis]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)most noble, loftiest of gods; Gaia; Helios; ErinyesEpithet(s)nether avengers
remarks: The oath is here first volunteered by Agamemnon who is speaking to Nestor. The oath itself finally takes place at oath id 412.

author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement: n/a
remarks: Another piece of advice (cf. oath ids 1367-1370). The poet is warning his reader not to conspire to murder a tyrant. The point is probably:  if you assist a tyrant, he’ll double-cross you; if you conspire against him, one of your confederates will double-cross you (for, as other poems in the collection – and also Alcaeus – indicate, the oath of the political conspirator was almost as suspect as that of the lover).

title: IG IX, 1(2)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This inscription records the procedures for the trials of those attempting to overturn the agreement concerning the Locrian colony at Naupactus. 
The jurors were to swear their oath prior to casting their votes into the urn. The oath is described as "the customary oath".

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[That they would abide by the agreement and treaty, justly and guilelessly]
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to  their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Nicias proposed sending an embassy to Sparta to urge them to restore Panactum to them intact and to give up the alliance with the Boeotians unless they should accede to the treaty. 
The Spartans did not give up their alliance with the Boeotians, but the oaths were renewed at the request of Nicias. 
Thucydides states that Nicias made this request because he was afraid of how the Athenians would respond, because he was seen as the instigator of the treaty. When Nicias returned home the Athenians were enraged by the refusal of the Spartans to break their alliance with Boeotia and immediately made an alliance with Argos. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias see oath id 1681, 1684, 1685, 1688, 1689, 1693, 1702, 1703, 1704, 1709, 1716, 1717, 1721, 1723, 1733, 1763, 1768, 1794.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Draws attention to the Spartans entering
statement:
[That the Spartans are coming out of the Acropolis]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’· ὡς ἤδη γε χωροῦσ’ ἔνδοθεν.

author: Aeschylus
title: Agamemnon
impact: The chorus believe that Cassandra is a true prophet
statement: [That the Chorus do not know the ancient wrongdoings of the house]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 201.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: Brasidas will be more easily able to persuade the Thracians to revolt
if_refused: Brasidas will find it more difficult to persuade the Thracians to revolt
statement:
[That whoever Brasidas should win as allies should be autonomous]
 ἦ μὴν οὓς ἂν ἔγωγε προσαγάγωμαι ξυμμάχους ἔσεσθαι αὐτονόμους
remarks:
Brasidas tells the Acanthians that he has come not to cause harm, but to liberate the Greeks, having bound the Spartan magistrates (τὰ τέλη) by the most solemn oaths "that whoever he should win as allies should be autonomous".   
After this Brasidas states that the Spartans deliberate carefully over matters, which could not give the Acanthians better security "aside from their oaths". 
See also oath id 1668.

author: Isocrates
title: To Philip
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Isocrates states that after the battle of Leuctra when the Thebans and the Peloponnesians were trying to devastate Sparta, the Athenians alone formed an alliance with the Spartans and helped save them from destruction. 
See also oath id 2030.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Hermes is a god who flies and wears wings]
 Καὶ νὴ Δί’ ὅ γ’ Ἑρμῆς  
 πέτεται θεὸς ὢν πτέρυγάς τε φορεῖ
remarks: Cf. oath id 653.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he will dance (if the Syracusan teaches him)]
 καὶ ἐγὼ μέν, ἔφη, 
πάνυ ἂν ἡδέως, ὦ Συρακόσιε, μάθοιμι τὰ σχήματα παρὰ σοῦ. καὶ ὅς, Τί οὖν χρήσῃ αὐτοῖς; ἔφη. Ὀρχήσομαι νὴ Δία.
remarks: The boy is a pais, so he may be no more than a child (i.e. under 18); he might, on the other hand, be slightly older and a slave (also pais).

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
if_taken: They will be allowed to judge
if_refused: They will not be allowed to judge
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Anaximenes refers to the Heliastic oath, and states that the judges swore that they would judge according to the laws: κατὰ τοὺς νόμους κρινεῖν ὀμωμοκότας (see also oath id 1613). 
See also oath id 1614 (where Anaximenes refers to the duty of the juror to listen to all sides of the argument). 
For the full details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes refers to the time when the Athenians first sent an embassy to Philip to negotiate a peace treaty. He argues that on this occasion they travelled swiftly despite the dangers involved because it was in Philip's interests for peace to be made as quickly as possible. Later, however, when they had orders to travel swiftly and it was safe to do so, they did not because it was in Philip's interests for the longest possible time to elapse before the administering of the oaths. The implication is that, on both embassies, Aeschines and his colleagues were acting in the interests of Philip and against those of Athens. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he would not claim it as a certainty that every colour appears to a dog or any other creature such as it appears to him]
 σὺ διισχυρίσαιο ἂν ὡς οἷον σοὶ φαίνεται ἕκαστον χρῶμα, τοιοῦτον καὶ κυνὶ καὶ ὁτῳοῦν ζῴῳ; {ΘΕΑΙ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Sophocles
title: Trachiniae
if_taken: Hyllus will not provoke his father's curse
if_refused: Hyllus will provoke his father's curse
impact: Heracles is granted his dying wishes
statement:
[That he will set his father on his funeral pyre, and marry Iole]
 Ηρ. ἔμβαλλε χεῖρα δεξιὰν πρώτιστά μοι.
Υλ. ὡς πρὸς τί πίστιν τήνδ’ ἄγαν ἐπιστρέφεις;
Ηρ. οὐ θᾶσσον οἴσεις μηδ’ ἀπιστήσεις ἐμοί;
Υλ. ἰδού, προτείνω, κοὐδὲν ἀντειρήσεται.
Ηρ. ὄμνυ Διός νυν τοῦ με φύσαντος κάρα. 
Υλ. ἦ μὴν τί δράσειν; καὶ τόδ’ ἐξειπεῖν σε δεῖ. 
Ηρ. ἦ μὴν ἐμοὶ τὸ λεχθὲν ἔργον ἐκτελεῖν.
Υλ. ὄμνυμ’ ἔγωγε, Ζῆν’ ἔχων ἐπώμοτον.
Ηρ. εἰ δ’ ἐκτὸς ἔλθοις, πημονὰς εὔχου λαβεῖν.
Υλ. οὐ μὴ λάβω· δράσω γάρ· εὔχομαι δ’ ὅμως. 
Ηρ. οἶσθ’ οὖν τὸν Οἴτης Ζηνὸς ὑψίστου πάγον;
Υλ. οἶδ’, ὡς θυτήρ γε πολλὰ δὴ σταθεὶς ἄνω.
Ηρ. ἐνταῦθά νυν χρὴ τοὐμὸν ἐξάραντά σε
σῶμ’ αὐτόχειρα καὶ ξὺν οἷς χρῄζεις φίλων,
πολλὴν μὲν ὕλην τῆς βαθυρρίζου δρυὸς 
κείραντα, πολλὸν δ’ ἄρσεν’ ἐκτεμόνθ’ ὁμοῦ
ἄγριον ἔλαιον, σῶμα τοὐμὸν ἐμβαλεῖν, 
καὶ πευκίνης λαβόντα λαμπάδος σέλας
πρῆσαι. γόου δὲ μηδὲν εἰσίδω δάκρυ,
ἀλλ’ ἀστένακτος κἀδάκρυτος, εἴπερ εἶ 
τοῦδ’ ἀνδρός, ἔρξον· εἰ δὲ μή, μενῶ σ’ ἐγὼ
καὶ νέρθεν ὢν ἀραῖος εἰσαεὶ βαρύς.
Υλ. οἴμοι, πάτερ, τί εἶπας; οἷά μ’ εἴργασαι.
Ηρ. ὁποῖα δραστέ’ ἐστίν· εἰ δὲ μή, πατρὸς
ἄλλου γενοῦ του μηδ’ ἐμὸς κληθῇς ἔτι. 
Υλ. οἴμοι μάλ’ αὖθις, οἷά μ’ ἐκκαλῇ, πάτερ,
φονέα γενέσθαι καὶ παλαμναῖον σέθεν.
Ηρ. οὐ δῆτ’ ἔγωγ’, ἀλλ’ ὧν ἔχω παιώνιον
καὶ μοῦνον ἰατῆρα τῶν ἐμῶν κακῶν.
Υλ. καὶ πῶς ὑπαίθων σῶμ’ ἂν ἰῴμην τὸ σόν; 
Ηρ. ἀλλ’ εἰ φοβῇ πρὸς τοῦτο, τἄλλα γ’ ἔργασαι.
Υλ. φορᾶς γέ τοι φθόνησις οὐ γενήσεται.
Ηρ. ἦ καὶ πυρᾶς πλήρωμα τῆς εἰρημένης;
Υλ. ὅσον γ’ ἂν αὐτὸς μὴ ποτιψαύων χεροῖν· 
τὰ δ’ ἄλλα πράξω κοὐ καμῇ τοὐμὸν μέρος.
Ηρ. ἀλλ’ ἀρκέσει καὶ ταῦτα· πρόσνειμαι δέ μοι
χάριν βραχεῖαν πρὸς μακροῖς ἄλλοις διδούς. 
Υλ. εἰ καὶ μακρὰ κάρτ’ ἐστίν, ἐργασθήσεται.
Ηρ. τὴν Εὐρυτείαν οἶσθα δῆτα παρθένον;
Υλ. ᾿Ιόλην ἔλεξας, ὥς γ’ ἐπεικάζειν ἐμέ.
Ηρ. ἔγνως. τοσοῦτον δή σ’ ἐπισκήπτω, τέκνον·
ταύτην, ἐμοῦ θανόντος, εἴπερ εὐσεβεῖν
βούλῃ, πατρῴων ὁρκίων μεμνημένος,
προσθοῦ δάμαρτα, μηδ’ ἀπιστήσῃς πατρί·
μηδ’ ἄλλος ἀνδρῶν τοῖς ἐμοῖς πλευροῖς ὁμοῦ 
κλιθεῖσαν αὐτὴν ἀντὶ σοῦ λάβῃ ποτέ,
ἀλλ’ αὐτός, ὦ παῖ, τοῦτο κήδευσον λέχος.
πείθου· τὸ γάρ τοι μεγάλα πιστεύσαντ’ ἐμοὶ
σμικροῖς ἀπιστεῖν τὴν πάρος συγχεῖ χάριν.
Υλ. οἴμοι. τὸ μὲν νοσοῦντι θυμοῦσθαι κακόν,
τὸ δ’ ὧδ’ ὁρᾶν φρονοῦντα τίς ποτ’ ἂν φέροι;
Ηρ. ὡς ἐργασείων οὐδὲν ὧν λέγω θροεῖς.
Υλ. τίς γάρ ποθ’, ἥ μοι μητρὶ μὲν θανεῖν μόνη
μεταίτιος, σοὶ δ’ αὖθις ὡς ἔχεις ἔχειν,
τίς ταῦτ’ ἄν, ὅστις μὴ ’ξ ἀλαστόρων νοσοῖ,
ἕλοιτο; κρεῖσσον κἀμέ γ’, ὦ πάτερ, θανεῖν
ἢ τοῖσιν ἐχθίστοισι συνναίειν ὁμοῦ.
Ηρ. ἁνὴρ ὅδ’ ὡς ἔοικεν οὐ νεμεῖν ἐμοὶ
φθίνοντι μοῖραν· ἀλλά τοι θεῶν ἀρὰ
μενεῖ σ’ ἀπιστήσαντα τοῖς ἐμοῖς λόγοις. 
Υλ. οἴμοι, τάχ’, ὡς ἔοικας, ὡς νοσεῖς φανεῖς.
Ηρ. σὺ γάρ μ’ ἀπ’ εὐνασθέντος ἐκκινεῖς κακοῦ.
Υλ. δείλαιος, ὡς ἐς πολλὰ τἀπορεῖν ἔχω.
Ηρ. οὐ γὰρ δικαιοῖς τοῦ φυτεύσαντος κλύειν.
Υλ. ἀλλ’ ἐκδιδαχθῶ δῆτα δυσσεβεῖν, πάτερ;
Ηρ. οὐ δυσσέβεια, τοὐμὸν εἰ τέρψεις κέαρ.
Υλ. πράσσειν ἄνωγας οὖν με πανδίκως τάδε;
Ηρ. ἔγωγε· τούτων μάρτυρας καλῶ θεούς.
Υλ. τοιγὰρ ποήσω, κοὐκ ἀπώσομαι, τὸ σὸν
θεοῖσι δεικνὺς ἔργον. οὐ γὰρ ἄν ποτε 
κακὸς φανείην σοί γε πιστεύσας, πάτερ.
remarks: During this long oath-taking sequence, Heracles must persuade his son to do such things as are abhorrent to him. For this reason he asks Hyllus to swear by Zeus before divulging what it is he wants his son to swear to. Actually, Heracles asks Hyllus to swear by Zeus' head (1185) but Hyllus simply invokes Zeus as witness (1188). In so doing, Heracles acts more like a god than a mortal, since elswhere in Greek poetry only deities invoke the head of Zeus as oath object; cf.  oath ids 409, 1334, 1358, 1363. Of course, Heracles will become a god after the end of the play, but he does not yet know this. See also Heracles' oath at id 277.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That he has yearned for the Athenian market as if for a mother]
  Ἐπόθουν τυ ναὶ τὸν Φίλιον ᾇπερ ματέρα.
remarks: The Megarian invokes 'Philios' i.e. 'the god of friendship' which is a title of Zeus. Sommerstein comments ad loc.: "Its use here implies that the speaker is greeting the Athenian market like an old friend he has not seen for a long time".

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: Aeschines will not have to serve as ambassador
if_refused: Aeschines will have to serve as ambassador
statement: [? That Aeschines was unwell and could not serve as an ambassador]
remarks: Demosthenes complains, that when Dercylus reported that the Phocians had been destroyed, Aeschines went as an unelected ambassador to Philip, without considering the illness for which he took the exomosia, nor that another man had been appointed in his place (see oath id 3766).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The Athenians charged Perdiccas with having made an alliance with Argos and Sparta, and also charged him with having been false to his alliance with them. They argued that the expedition led by Nicias against the Chalcidians in Thrace and Amphipolis had failed because of his defection. Thus, Perdiccas was regarded as an enemy by the Athenians. 
For other references to alliances between Athens and Perdiccas see oath id 256.

author: Philip of Macedon
title: Letter to the Athenians
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Phillip argues that the Athenians acknowledged that he had acted correctly concerning Amphipolis by making peace with him while he was occupying the city and by subsequently making an alliance with him. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

title: IG XII 5
if_taken: They will not have to pay a fine
if_refused: They shall pay a fine of 100 drachmas to the demos and 50 to whoever denounces him
statement:
[That they do not hold any flocks which they have not declared]
 ὁμόσα[ι δὲ καὶ ἄλλ]ο μὴ νεμεν
remarks:
The text indicates that the hieropoioi are to announce to those possessing flocks that they are to burn sacrifices for all the flocks they hold, and if they do not hold flocks, to swear that they do not hold any flocks which they have not declared (this means one must interpret νέμεν as a present rather than a future infinitive). 
Whoever does not swear within an uncertain number of days will owe 100 drachmas to the demos and up to half of that sum to whoever denounces him. 
We may reasonably suppose that there was an official list of flock-holders somewhere; that anyone who swore that he was not (or no longer) a flock-holder was removed from the list; and that the list was policed by unfriendly neighbours who could be relied on to inform the authorities if anyone not on the list was illicitly keeping sheep.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
remarks:
Demosthenes states that he wishes to address the charges laid against him concerning the peace treaty and the embassy to Philip. He argues that Aeschines has ascribed to him what was done by Aeschines himself and Philocrates. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Hesiod
title: Catalogue of Women
statement: unknown
remarks: Zeus (as restored by Merkelbach and West) is called to witness here, but the text is too fragmentary to reveal the content of the oath statement.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Chalcidians in Thrace
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Chalcidians in Thrace
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: This inscription records an alliance between Athens and the Chalcidians in western Thrace.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
The Greeks swore that they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase 
 ἦ μὴν πορεύσεσθαι ὡς διὰ φιλίας ἀσινῶς σῖτα καὶ ποτὰ λαμβάνοντας ὁπόταν μὴ ἀγορὰν παρέχωμεν, ἐὰν δὲ παρέχωμεν ἀγοράν, ὠνουμένους ἕξειν τὰ ἐπιτήδεια. ]
remarks:
When addressing the Greeks, Xenophon says, "I was saying that we have many fair hopes of deliverance. For in the first place we are standing true to the oaths we swore in the name of the gods, while our enemies have perjured themselves, and in violation of their oaths have broken the truce". 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
The defendant tells the jurors that they have to use the evidence to decide which of the two sworn statements - that of the prosecution or his own - is more truthful and faithful to the oath. He then calls witnesses to verify his statement. 
See also oath id 2482 for the oath of the defendant and oath id 2481 for the oaths of the witnesses.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
statement:
[That the jurors ought not to share in Demosthenes' venality and ill fortune any longer, nor place their hopes of safety on him, nor think that without him they will have no brave men or wise advisers]
 μὴ μὰ Δία τὸν πλείω χρόνον τῆς Δημοσθένους δωροδοκίας καὶ ἀτυχίας κοινωνεῖν, μηδ’ ἐν τούτῳ τὰς ἐλπίδας τῆς σωτηρίας ἔχειν, μηδ’ οἴεσθαι ἀπορήσειν ἀνδρῶν ἀγαθῶν καὶ συμβούλων σπουδαίων,

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates claims that the Athenians did not cease waging war and facing perils by land and sea until the Spartans were willing to enter into "the treaty guaranteeing independence" i.e. the King's Peace. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
impact: Alliance formalised and sucessful campaigns launched against Babylon, Armenia and other nations of Asia
statement: [That they will fight with each other]
remarks: There is no way of telling which Assyrian king " Ninus" refers to, hence the designation of mythical time. Ninus is the Greek name for an imaginary king of a real empire – a name doubtless derived from that of its capital city, Nineveh.  In Hdt. 2.150 he (or maybe another king of the same name) is the father of Sardanapallus.  No real Assyrian king bore the name Ninus or anything like it.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between  Athens, Arcadia, Achaea, Elis and Phlius. 
See also oath id 446.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she once saw a long-haired chap, a cavalry officer, on horseback, buying porridge from an old woman and throwing it into his brass hat]
 Νὴ Δί’ ἐγὼ γοῦν ἄνδρα κομήτην φυλαρχοῦντ’ εἶδον ἐφ’ ἵππου  
  εἰς τὸν χαλκοῦν ἐμβαλλόμενον πῖλον λέκιθον παρὰ γραός·
remarks: This is reported as an instance of a ridiculous spectacle (a man shopping in full armour).

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines tells the jurors, "I acknowledge that I advised the people to come to terms with Philip and to make the peace, which you [Demosthenes], now consider shameful". 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That tyrants are not more loved than ordinary men because they are more often forced to engage in actions that make men hated]
 Ὅτι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σιμωνίδη, καὶ ἐξ ὧν ἀπεχθάνονται ἄνθρωποι, ἡμᾶς πολὺ πλείω τῶν ἰδιωτῶν ἀνάγκη ἐστὶ πραγματεύεσθαι.
remarks:
Hiero is responding to Simonides' observation that high rank itself is a most striking embellishment to the person which casts a shadow over anything repulsive in him and highlights his best features. Because of this, Simonides argues, services rendered by rulers are rewarded with greater gratitude, and that, "When you have the power to give more, it is natural that you should be more deeply loved than private citizens". 
Simonides has asked, literally, "How can it not be the case that a tyrant, who can confer such great benefits and gifts on his subjects, will be more loved than an ordinary man can be?"  And Hiero replies "Because, by Zeus, we also have to do many more of the things that cause a man to be hated."  Hence the statement is "That a tyrant, despite the benefits and gifts he can confer on his subjects, will not be greatly loved, because he will also be forced to do many things that make him hated."

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That the Calchedonians should pay the Athenians the same tribute they usually paid, and pay off the money that they owed in arrears]
 καὶ ὅρκους ἔδοσαν καὶ ἔλαβον παρὰ Φαρναβάζου ὑποτελεῖν τὸν φόρον Καλχηδονίους Ἀθηναίοις ὅσονπερ εἰώθεσαν καὶ τὰ ὀφειλόμενα χρήματα ἀποδοῦναι, Ἀθηναίους δὲ μὴ πολεμεῖν Καλχηδονίοις, ἕως ἂν οἱ παρὰ βασιλέως πρέσβεις ἔλθωσιν.
remarks:
Xenophon states that Pharnabazus thought that Alcibiades should also give his oath (as the other Athenian generals had done), and waited at Calchedon for Alcibiades to return from Selymbria. 
When Alcibiades did come, he refused to swear until Pharnabazus should swear his oath to him. Pharnabazus did so at Calchedon to his representatives Euryptolemus and Diotimus.  Alcibiades then swore his oath at Chrysopolis to the representatives of Pharnabazus: Mitrobates and Arnapes. 
Xenophon observes that both parties not only gave the official oath but also personal pledges. In spite of this, Pharnabazus later arranged Alcibiades' murder (Diod. 14.11; Plut. Alcibiades 39.1-8). 
See also oath id 1883 and 1887.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
When addressing the Greeks, Xenophon says, "I was saying that we have many fair hopes of deliverance. For in the first place we are standing true to the oaths we swore in the name of the gods, while our enemies have perjured themselves, and in violation of their oaths have broken the truce" i.e. the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians. 
See also oath id 2105.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
if_broken: They will dedicate a golden statue
statement: [That they will act in office justly and according to the laws, and not take gifts for performing their official duties, and if they do take any gift, they will dedicate a golden (life-size) statue (at Delphi)]
remarks:
Lycurgus argues that the oath is the force that holds democracy together. He cites three oaths: the oath sworn by archons, the oath sworn by judges i.e. the Heliastic oath, and the oath of the private citizens i.e. the ephebic oath. He says that each of these men gives this pledge, and rightly. 
According to Arist. Ath.Pol. 55.5, the archons " go to the stone on which the severed parts (of sacrificial victims) are, the same stone on which the arbitrators swear when they give their decisions and witnesses when they swear an oath to excuse them from testifying; and they go up on to it and swear to act in office justly and according to the laws, and not to take gifts for performing their official duties, and if they do take any gift, to dedicate a golden (life-size) statue (at Delphi: Plut. Sol. 25.3).  Having sworn, they go from there to the Acropolis and take the same oath again there, and after that they enter office."   
The stone was in front of the Stoa Basileios  
See also oath id 2743 and 2744.  
For the oath of the archon see oath id 1753.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he is antipathetic towards Astyages' cup-bearer Sacas because Sacas often keeps him from seeing his grandfather]
 Ἀλλὰ τί ποτε σύ, ὦ παῖ, τῷ Σάκᾳ οὕτω πολεμεῖς; τὸν δὲ Κῦρον εἰπεῖν· Ὅτι νὴ Δία, φάναι, μισῶ αὐτόν· πολλάκις γάρ με πρὸς τὸν πάππον ἐπιθυμοῦντα προσδραμεῖν οὗτος ὁ μιαρώτατος ἀποκωλύει.

author: Anonymus Comicus
title: Fragments
statement:
[That the second thing Apollo gave to Cronus was not a loan of money or goods, but an oracle that he would be deposed from his kingship by his son]
 ἑτέραν ἔχρησε[ν οὐκέτι] δρα[χ]μῶ[ν ἀ]ξ[ίαν, 
οὐ σκευάρια, μὰ τὸν Δί’, οὐδὲ χρήματα,
ἐκ τῆς βασιλείας δ’ ἐκπεσεῖν ὑπὸ π[αιδίου
remarks: The son who will overthrow Kronos is, of course, Zeus who is invoked here. Rhea is swearing by Zeus, although she probably hasn't given birth to him yet. If Zeus hasn’t been born yet, his son Apollo is even more definitely incapable of current existence!! The oath-statement depends crucially on a pun on the ambiguity of the verb xra/w (both “lend” and “give an oracular response”).  Apollo e)/xrhse Cronus a drachma, and never got his money back; which made him so angry that he e)/xrhse again – not this time money or goods, but (here the sense changes from “lent” to “prophesied”) that Cronus would be deposed by his son.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Emphasises the determination of the women
statement:
[That there is no threat or fire or anything strong enough that the men can bring against the women to open the gates, except on their conditions]
  Οὐ γὰρ τοσαύτας οὔτ’ ἀπειλὰς οὔτε πῦρ 
  ἥξουσ’ ἔχοντες ὥστ’ ἀνοῖξαι τὰς πύλας 
  ταύτας, ἐὰν μὴ ’φ’ οἷσιν ἡμεῖς εἴπομεν.
{ΚΛ.}  Μὰ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην οὐδέποτέ γ’·

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That Hippias has been lucky that the Spartans are not interested in hearing a recital of a list of Athenian archons from Solon on]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ὦ Ἱππία, ηὐτύχηκάς γε ὅτι Λακεδαιμόνιοι οὐ χαίρουσιν ἄν τις αὐτοῖς ἀπὸ Σόλωνος τοὺς ἄρχοντας τοὺς ἡμετέρους καταλέγῃ·
remarks: Socrates' comment comes as a response to Hippias' remarks on how the Spartans are only interested in ancient lore, with the result that he has had to become an expert in the subject.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
gods_invoked: The gods by whom oaths are sworn
remarks:
The Athenian envoy to Sparta urges the Spartans not to violate the treaty or to transgress their oaths, but to let their differences be settled by arbitration. 
He goes on to warn the Spartans that if they refuse the Athenians will invoke as witnesses the gods by whom oaths are sworn and endeavour to make reprisals against those who begin the war.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That Aristogeiton has been a useful servant to the state and the Athenians must overlook all his crimes and save him]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία ταῦτα μὲν οὕτως ἔχειν ὁμολογήσετε, χρήσιμον δ’ ἄνθρωπον
τῇ πόλει κρίνειν, ὥστε πάντα ταῦτα παριδόντας δεῖν αὐτὸν σῴζειν

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That he has not come with a spear hidden in his clothes]
 Κἄπειτα δόρυ δῆθ’ ὑπὸ μάλης ἥκεις ἔχων;  
 {ΚΗ.}  Οὐ τὸν Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωνγα.
remarks: The herald does not have a spear but an erect phallus hidden beneath his clothes, which he tries to conceal (cf. oath ids 1218 and 1219).

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
if_kept: The Argive people will be treated kindly
if_broken: Despair and ill omens will be brought to the Argives, so that they repent
statement:
[That no helmsman of his land will come to bring war against Athens, and that, even from the grave, he will bar the road with impossible disasters for those who break the oath, but will be kind to those who keep it]
 ἐγὼ δὲ χώραι τῆιδε καὶ τῶι σῶι στρατῶι
τὸ λοιπὸν εἰς ἅπαντα πλειστήρη χρόνον
ὁρκωμοτήσας νῦν ἄπειμι πρὸς δόμους,
μή τοί τιν’ ἄνδρα δεῦρο πρυμνήτην χθονὸς 
ἐλθόντ’ ἐποίσειν εὖ κεκασμένον δόρυ.
αὐτοὶ γὰρ ἡμεῖς ὄντες ἐν τάφοις τότε 
τοῖς τἀμὰ παρβαίνουσι νῦν ὁρκώματα
ἀμηχάνοισι πράξομεν δυσπραξίαις,
ὁδοὺς ἀθύμους καὶ παρόρνιθας πόρους 
τιθέντες, ὡς αὐτοῖσι μεταμέληι πόνος·
ὀρθουμένων δὲ καὶ πόλιν τὴν Παλλάδος
τιμῶσιν ἀεὶ τήνδε συμμάχωι δορὶ
αὐτοῖς ἂν ἡμεῖς εἶμεν εὐμενέστεροι.
remarks: This alliance had been volunteered at oath ids 211 and 220.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Dionysus makes reference to the perjurers that Heracles had referred to as lying in the "mud and ever-flowing dung"; cf. oath id 378.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Athenians assisted the Corcyraean democrats during the ensuing internal factional dispute
statement:
[That they would defend each other should anyone attack Corcyra or Athens or the allies of either]
 ἐπιμαχίαν δ’ ἐποιήσαντο τῇ ἀλλήλων βοηθεῖν, ἐάν τις ἐπὶ Κέρκυραν ἴῃ ἢ Ἀθήνας ἢ τοὺς τούτων ξυμμάχους
remarks:
Thucydides states that in 427 the Corcyraeans voted to continue their (defensive) alliance with the Athenians, but also to renew their former friendship with the Peloponnesians. 
Not long afterwards stasis ensued. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1528.

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that they are bound by two oaths - the oath they swore before serving as jurors (see oath id 2967) and the oath they swore when the made the agreement for the Amnesty.  
He goes on to argue that it is not fitting that they should give their votes based upon favour or a feeling of fairness, nor anything else apart from the oaths they took when they agreed to the Amnesty. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds that jurors that they have sworn to give their votes according to the laws of Athens (ὀμωμοκότες κατὰ τοὺς νόμους δικάσειν) - not those Thebes or Sparta, or their earliest ancestors - i.e. those under which immunites were granted to the men whom Leptines is now trying to rob with his law. He reminds them that where there are no laws to guide them, they must decide according to their best judgement. 
Demosthenes goes on to urge the jurors to observe their oaths  by allowing the Athenians to honour their benefactors. 
The "best judgement" clause is discussed by D.C. Mirhady in Sommerstein & Fletcher ed. Horkos (Exeter, 2007) 48-59, though we do not agree with all his conclusions.  Demosthenes.’s argument based on this clause is a good one:  the jurors are entitled, and even bound, to reject a law if they consider it unjust.  Not so good is the argument based on the "vote according to the laws" clause:  if, as in this case, new law N is designed, in whole or in part, to repeal old law V, one cannot say that the jurors are bound by their oath to uphold V and therefore to reject N - unless, of course, one is arguing that no existing law should ever be changed, and that is certainly not something that Demosthenes believed. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That no one has stuck her with anything]
  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔμοιγ’ ἐπέβαλεν οὐδείς, ὦ μέλε.
remarks: Iris refers to the entry-pass which Peisetaerus had asked her about. On the sexual innuendo in this passage which prompts Iris' indignant response here, see Sommerstein ad 1212-6.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement: n/a
remarks: It is agreed here between Socrates and Glaucon that a man whose birth and breeding are in harmony with the ideal state would not be faithless either in the keeping of his oaths or in other agreements.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Heralds of King Artaxerxes II; Clearchus
swearee: Heralds of King Artaxerxes II; Clearchus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
The exact oath statement is unknown.  It is likely, though not completely certain, that the Persians also swore that they would lead the Greeks to a place where they could get provisions; the wily and cautious Clearchus would be likely to insist on that. 
According to Xenophon, the Persian King was terrified of the approach of the Greeks and sent heralds to negotiate a truce. 
Clearchus responded (because the Greeks had no provisions), "Report to him that we must have a battle first; for we have not had breakfast, and no one should dare speak to the Greeks about a truce unless he provides them with a breakfast". 
The heralds left, and returned quickly with a report that the King thought what they said seemed reasonable, and that they had brought guides with them who could lead the Greeks to a place where they could get provisions if a truce should be concluded. 
Clearchus asked whether he was making a truce merely with the men who were coming and going, or whether the truce would bind others as well. 
The heralds replied, "every one of them until your message is carried to the King". 
Clearchus then took counsel, and it was thought best to conclude a truce quickly so that they could get provisions without being molested. 
Clearchus, however, delayed telling the heralds in order to make them afraid, but then concluded the truce after it seemed the proper time had come. 
After the truce was concluded the heralds led the Greeks to where they could get provisions. 
Xenophon observes that Clearchus, although he had made the truce, kept his army in line of battle on the march, and commanded the rearguard himself. 
See also oath id 2088.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Euxitheus tells the jurors that they will be abiding by their oaths if they vote in his favour. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The Plataean speaker asks how the Athenians can avoid the charge of acting with inconsistency if they do not prevent the Thebans from violating their oaths and treaties, yet pretend that they are making war on the Spartans for the same reason. 
He goes on to argue that it would be an outrage if they were determined to stand by those who had been constant allies of the Spartans, yet were to allow the Plataeans - their allies for the longest time, and subservient to the Spartans only in the last war - to become the most miserable of men. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Sophocles
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment is the single word ὡρκωμότηκεν. Someone swore an oath, but unfortunately, there is nothing further which can be deduced from this fragment.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That (s)he is taking a long time pissing because (s)he is having difficulty passing water]
 Πολύν γε χρόνον οὐρεῖς σύ. 
  {ΚΗ.}  Νὴ Δί’, ὦ μέλε, 
  στραγγουριῶ γάρ·

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
impact: War between the Athenians and the Spartans (temporarily) ceased
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides observes that the Peace of Nicias was formalised at around the same time as the ten-day truce between Athens and Boeotia (see oath id 1701 and 1769). 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Sophocles
title: Antigone
impact: Creon's punishments lead Haemon to take his own life
statement:
[That Haemon will not continue to insult him with impunity]
 ἀλλ’ οὐ, τόνδ’ Ὄλυμπον, ἴσθ’ ὅτι,
χαίρων ἔτι ψόγοισι δεννάσεις ἐμέ.
remarks: The informal oath formula οὐ + acc., current in Doric and Arcadian (cf. oath ids 575, 576, 1217, 1219, 1230, 2214, 2307), was not used in Attic, and in tragedy it is found only in Sophocles (see oath ids 244, 1979, 1980) and mostly in lyric (this is the only instance in spoken iambics).  The linguistic abnormality may be designed to mark the extremity of Creon's anger; his next words are to order that Antigone be brought out of the palace and put to death before her fiancé's eyes, an order which is not carried out only because Haemon immediately storms off, declaring (erroneously) that his father will never set eyes on him again.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines reminds the jurors that they have sworn to vote according to the laws ( κατὰ τοὺς νόμους ψηφιεῖσθαι). 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds the jurors that they must guard the laws and their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Prior to the destruction of Plataea, the Athenians and Plataeans assisted each other when they were threatened
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The Thebans claim that they have attacked Plataea to aid wealthy Plataeans who desired to end the alliance between Plataea and the "outsider" i.e. Athens. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1561.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Dicaeogenes
statement:
[That they would declare what they thought to be just]
 ἀποφανεῖσθαι ἃ δίκαια ἡγοῦνται εἶναι
remarks:
Menexenus states that the arbitrators said that if they could effect a compromise without putting themselves under an oath they would do so, but if not they would take an oath to declare what they thought to be just. 
See also oath id 3047.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Pantaenetus
statement:
[That after getting his money back and doing Pantaenetus no wrong whatever, he thought that Pantaenetus would never prosecute him]
 κομισάμενος δὲ τἀμαυτοῦ καὶ τοῦτον οὐδ’ ὁτιοῦν ἀδικῶν, μὰ τοὺς θεούς, οὐδ’ ἂν εἴ τι γένοιτο, ᾠήθην ἂν δίκην μοι λαχεῖν ποτὲ τουτονί.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
The text indicates that if there is contention over the status or ownership of a slave the judge is to give judgement according to the witness if a witness testifies, but "he is to decide on oath" (τὸν δικαστὰν ὀμνύντα κρίνεν)  if they testify for both or for neither. 
For another oath related to this judicial process see oath id 1095. 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That the man who was finding fault with philosophy is said to have knowledge of oratory (although he is not an orator)]
 ἀλλ’ ἐπαΐειν αὐτόν φασι περὶ τοῦ πράγματος νὴ τὸν Δία
remarks: Cf. oath id 3102.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Hystaspas is foolish if he thinks he'll be able to make Aglaitadas laugh]
 Καὶ οἴει γε, ὦ Ὑστάσπα, γέλωτα περιποιεῖν ἐξ ἐμοῦ; καὶ ὁ ταξίαρχος εἶπε· Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἀνόητος ἄρ’ ἐστίν·

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Strepsiades would deserve a beating (if he insults Euripides again)]
  ἀλλ’ αὖθις αὖ τυπτήσομαι.
 {Φε.}  νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἐν δίκῃ γ’ ἄν.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be allies and follow wherever the Thebans led the way]
 ἦ μὴν συμμάχους ἔσεσθαι καὶ ἀκολουθήσειν ὅποι ἂν Θηβαῖοι ἡγῶνται
remarks:
Xenophon indicates that Epaminondas received pledges from the Achaeans that they would be allies and follow wherever the Thebans led them. 
After this Epaminondas returned home to Thebes.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That the disease needs serious attention, because, spreading, it has reached Athens]
 ταῦτα νὴ τὴν Δήμητρα, εἰ δεῖ μὴ ληρεῖν, εὐλαβείας οὐ μικρᾶς δεῖται, ὡς βαδίζον γε κύκλῳ καὶ δεῦρ’ ἐλήλυθεν, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, τὸ νόσημα τοῦτο.
remarks: The "disease" to which Demosthenes refers is the desire to curry favour with Philip.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement:
That one thing at least none of the jurors will worry about is that Demosthenes, great-hearted man and outstanding warrior, if he fails to win the prize for valour, will go home and kill himself]
 οὐ γὰρ δὴ μὰ τὸν Ἡρακλέα τοῦτό γε ὑμῶν οὐδεὶς φοβήσεται, μὴ Δημοσθένης, ἀνὴρ μεγαλόψυχος καὶ τὰ πολεμικὰ διαφέρων, ἀποτυχὼν τῶν ἀριστείων ἐπανελθὼν οἴκαδε ἑαυτὸν διαχρήσηται·
remarks: Aeschines - who has repeatedly accused Demosthenes of cowardice, for allegedly running away at the battle of Chaeronea - is being sarcastic here when he calls him a "great-hearted man and outstanding warrior" and implicitly compares him with Ajax!

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Blepyrus does not have to get up groaning at daybreak any longer]
  οὐδὲ στένειν τὸν ὄρθρον ἔτι πρᾶγμ’ ἆρά μοι; 
 {Χρ.}  μὰ Δί’
remarks: This is because the women are now in charge.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he agrees that it is difficult to find a truly unified community anywhere in the world]
 οὕτω γὰρ μεγάλην πόλιν μίαν οὐ ῥᾳδίως οὔτε ἐν Ἕλλησιν οὔτε ἐν βαρβάροις εὑρήσεις, δοκούσας δὲ πολλὰς καὶ πολλαπλασίας τῆς τηλικαύτης. ἢ ἄλλως οἴει;  Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he did not expect this nuisance, that the poet would have found out about the city so quickly]
 Τουτὶ μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ τὸ κακὸν οὐδέποτ’ ἤλπισα,
 οὕτω ταχέως τοῦτον πεπύσθαι τὴν πόλιν.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement: [That they would judge the choruses fairly]
remarks:
Demosthenes includes the fact that Meidias "stood beside the judges while they were taking their oath" among the many crimes committed by Meidias. 
What Demosthenes says here will not make much sense to the jury unless they are already familiar with the story at which he is hinting and which he will refer to a little less obscurely later (3402).  Even there, the story is not spelt out; but the author of the second Hypothesis writes:  "As Demosthenes says..while the judges were swearing that they would give victory to the best singer [sic], Meidias kept nudging them and saying 'except Demosthenes', until Demosthenes shouted out and exposed him."  It is not clear whether the commentator has inferred all this from the text of the speech, or whether he has some other source (e.g. a lost speech of another orator). 
For further details see also oath id 3402. 
For other references to the judges' oath see oath id 1247.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement: n/a
remarks:
The Spartan envoys offering terms of peace to the Athenians observed that a permanent reconciliation is not likely to be secured when one party gains mastery in war and then takes revenge on the enemy "using its advantage to force the swearing of unequal oaths". 
Hornblower, A Commentary on Thucydides, Vol. II, p171, observes that this speech "conforms to the rules laid down in the Rhetoric to Alexander 1425a36ff. for the appropriate way to ask for a peace when the war is not going your way".

author: Sophocles
title: Ajax
statement: n/a
remarks: Ajax discusses the oath as an example of the power of time to reveal what is hidden. Some scholars have seen this as an echo of Archilochus fr. 122.1 (see oath id 1377). Garvie ad loc. explains 'Ajax is thinking of oaths in general, not a specific oath sworn by himself to the sons of Atreus or to Tyndareus' (cf. oath id 235).

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she is not concerned about her wool being pulled to pieces by the hens]
  Ὀλίγον μέλει σοι τῆς κρόκης φορουμένης 
  ὑπὸ τῶν ἀλεκτρυόνων;
{ΜΥ.}  Ἔμοιγε νὴ Δία.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[That they would not inhabit the disctrict of Panactum, and that both parties should pasture flocks there in common]
 μηδετέρους οἰκεῖν τὸ χωρίον, ἀλλὰ κοινῇ νέμειν
remarks: Thucydides states that when the Thebans destroyed the fort at Panactum they justified their actions on the pretext that in earlier times, when there had been a dispute about Panactum, oaths had been taken that neither the Boeotians nor the Athenians should inhabit the district, but that both should graze the land in common.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
statement: [That they are pure, chaste, and without taint from things that are impure, including intercourse with men. That they celebrate the Feast of the Wine God and the Bacchic rite honouring the god in accordance with the ancestral rule and at the appointed times]
remarks: Apollodorus states that when Phano was betrothed to Theogenes of Cothocidae, the archon basileus, she administered the oath to the Venerable Priestesses (Gerarai) who preside over the sacrifices.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
impact: The women are appalled at the suggestion
statement:
[That "we" (i.e. the women) commit such evil deeds (as Euripides accuses them of)]
 Ταῦτ’ οὐ ποιοῦμεν τὰ κακά; Νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν
  ἡμεῖς γε.
remarks: The complexity of this oath lies in the fact that the Inlaw is only pretending to be a woman, so the "we" of the oath, really means "you". In keeping with his disguise, the Inlaw swears by Artemis.

author: Bacchylides
title: Love Songs
statement: [? That he would be loyal to his mistress]
remarks: This is a fragmentary reference to a perjurer (also deceiver and slanderer) "running away to [his] dear wife". This suggests that the oath he has broken may have been one of loyalty to a mistress.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes observes that the Athenians understand the beauty of Solon's directions for legislating. He notes that the first stage takes place in the courts, before men under oath. 
Most of the jurors’ oath, when one comes to think of it, was not actually relevant to their role as nomothetai, though some clauses appear to have been added (e.g. that they would not vote for a tyranny, an oligarchy, a cancellation of debts or a redistribution of land) that did have relevance to it (see Demosthenes 24.149-151), as did the "perfectly honest opinion" clause mentioned in oath id 3380.  It is striking, by the way, that Demosthenes explicitly attributes the nomothesia procedure to Solon, at a time when there were many men alive (some of them probably on the jury) who still remembered the time when no such procedure existed! 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Heracles is afraid of Dionysus, afraid he might be mad]
 ΔΙ. ῾Ως σφόδρα μ’ ἔδεισε. 
ΞΑ.  Νὴ Δία, μὴ μαίνοιό γε.
remarks: Xanthias agrees with Dionysus that Heracles is afraid. The rest of his statement is an aside to the audience.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callicles
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker states that he is prepared to swear the customary oath (see oath id 3682) and argues that this is the best course of action considering that the jurors have also sworn an oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That they will include sources of difficulties for mankind in their concept of happiness if they include beauty, strength, wealth, good repute, and the like]
 πῶς γὰρ ἄν τις ἄνευ τούτων εὐδαιμονοίη; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, προσθήσομεν ἄρα, ἐξ ὧν πολλὰ καὶ χαλεπὰ συμβαίνει τοῖς ἀνθρώποις·
remarks: This is a response to oath id 2137.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That he had not taken a bribe and would not]
 μὴ λαβεῖν δῶρα μηδὲ λήψεσθαι
remarks:
Aeschines claims that Timarchus once asserted that Philotades of Cydathenaeum - a citizen - was a former slave of his, and persuaded the demesmen to disfranchise him. Aeschines claims that Timarchus took charge of the prosecution in court, and after taking the sacrificial victims in his hand, swore by the gods of oaths that he had not taken a bribe and would not, calling down destruction on himself. 
Aeschines claims that it was later proved that Timarchus received 20 minas from Leuconides, Philotades' brother-in-law, money which he soon spent on Philoxene the courtesan. Aeschines states that Timarchus thus abandoned the case and broke his oath. 
The "gods of oaths" (horkioi theoi) are Zeus, Apollo and Demeter. 
Fisher ad loc. assumes that the oath was taken at the deme meeting (in Cydathenaeum, a city deme) at which Philotades was struck off; but to judge by Dem. 57, these meetings were attended, and the oaths sworn, only by members of the deme, and Timarchus did not belong to the deme of Cydathenaeum but to that of Sphettus (cf. Aeschines 1.104 – his paternal uncle).  As can be seen from Dem. 57, however, court witnesses were also, exceptionally, required to give their testimony on oath in appeals against deme decisions during this review of the citizen registers (see oath ids 3699, 3701-7, 3709-11).  It is not clear from Dem. 57 alone whether these oaths were taken at the trial itself or at a preliminary hearing.  Now Timarchus evidently did not testify at the trial, with the result that the case against Philotades collapsed.
