It must follow, I think, that the witnesses' oaths in such cases were taken at a preliminary hearing, and that Timarchus duly swore one and submitted a deposition but then did not turn up at the trial to confirm it.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That, as leader, he will do away with all garrisons]
  Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Γλαύκων, ἁπάσας μὲν οὖν ἔγωγε, ἕνεκά γε τοῦ οὕτως αὐτὰς φυλάττεσθαι ὥστε κλέπτεσθαι τὰ ἐκ τῆς χώρας.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 2085 for context and cf. other entries for 3.6.

author: Plato
title: Charmides
impact: Socrates is bound by oath to cure the soul in the first instance
statement:
[That he would not let anyone, however rich or noble or fair, persuade him to cure the body independently of the soul]
 καί μοι πάνυ σφόδρα ἐνετέλλετο μήτε πλούσιον οὕτω μηδένα εἶναι μήτε γενναῖον μήτε καλόν, ὃς ἐμὲ πείσει ἄλλως ποιεῖν. ἐγὼ οὖν—ὀμώμοκα γὰρ αὐτῷ

author: Asclepiades
title: FGrH #12
if_taken: Good relations between Amphiaraus and Adrastus would be ensured
if_refused: Good relations between Amphiaraus and Adrastus would not be ensured
impact: Ultimately leads to Amphiaraus' part in the expedition against Thebes
statement:
[That any differences between himself and Adrastus would be arbitrated by Eriphyle (wife of Amphiaraus and sister of Adrastus)]
 Ἀμφιάραος ὁ Ἰο-
κλέους 
γήμας Ἐριφύλην
τὴν Ταλάου καὶ διενεχθεὶς ὑπέρ τινων πρὸς Ἄδραστον,
καὶ πάλιν διαλυθεὶς ὁρκούμενος ὡμολόγησεν ὑπὲρ ὧν
ἂν διαφέρωνται πρὸς ἀλλήλους αὐτός τε καὶ Ἄδραστος
ἐπιτρέψειν Ἐριφύλην κρίνειν καὶ πείθεσθαι αὐτῇ.
remarks: Although Amphiaraus knew that the expedition against Thebes was doomed, and was unwilling to take part, he was bound to go by this oath. Eriphyle, who had been bribed by Polyneices with the necklace of Harmonia, decided that Amphiaraus should go, and he was forced to comply with her wishes.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that since it is clear that Meidias committed the acts of which he accuses him, and since they were committed with insolence, they should now turn to the laws, because they have sworn to judge according to them. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Dionysius of Syracuse. It is not entirely certain whether the alliance was made between Athens and Dionysius I or II. If it was the former, he was almost certainly aged over sixty; if the latter, he was probably not yet thirty years of age. 
The stone is too fragmentary to determine the identity of the different officials who swore the oath along with Dionysius. Lines 37-8 indicate that each party shall swear their own "lawful oath". 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 407.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That Adeimantus will discover that  in most men of the kind who esteem property above all, when there is an opportunity to spend the money of others, their appetites become drone-like]
 Καὶ νὴ Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, ὦ φίλε, τοῖς πολλοῖς γε αὐτῶν ἐνευρήσεις, ὅταν δέῃ τἀλλότρια ἀναλίσκειν, τὰς τοῦ κηφῆνος συγγενεῖς ἐνούσας ἐπιθυμίας.
remarks: “drone-like” apparently means “parasitic and criminal”, to judge by 554b8-c1.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he has not even received what Seuthes promised to him for his own services]
 ὀμνύω γὰρ ὑμῖν θεοὺς ἅπαντας καὶ πάσας μηδ’ ἃ ἐμοὶ ἰδίᾳ ὑπέσχετο Σεύθης ἔχειν·
remarks:
Xenophon swears this oath when defending himself against the allegation that he had received what belongs to the soldiers. 
He goes on to say that Seuthes is present, and knows well whether Xenophon is swearing falsely.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes dares to say that the Thebans made their alliance with Athens because of his speeches, rather than because of the danger they were in or Athens' reputation. 
See also oath id 2670.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the peace was made because Philip's ambassadors and "these men" (i.e. Aeschines and Philocrates) convinced the Athenians to agree to a peace that excluded the Phocians by promising that Philip would give them what they wanted after the peace was made. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Spartans were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Spartans while they collected their dead]
remarks:
Xenophon states that after the battle of Leuctra, some of the Spartans thought the disaster was unendurable and said that they ought to prevent the enemy from setting up a trophy and to try to recover the dead by fighting rather than by a truce. 
The polemarchs felt that too many of the Spartans had fallen and the allies did not have the heart to fight, so they sent a herald to ask for a truce. 
The Thebans then set up a trophy and gave back the bodies under a truce.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement: [That Strepsiades will not get away with treating him like this]
remarks: Strepsiades here mocks the First Creditor's oath saying that swearing by Zeus and the gods is terribly amusing to those who know better (i.e. know that they do not exist). Cf. oath id 1245.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
Andocides states that when the peace was made with the Spartans, and the Athenians demolished the walls and recalled the exiles, and the Thirty were established, and afterwards Phyle was seized and then Mounychia, the Athenians experienced troubles which he prefers not to recall. 
For other references to the peace treaty and alliance between Athens and the Spartans and their allies see also oath id 1893.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
impact: Emphasises Polus' eager support of his teacher Gorgias
statement:
[That Chaerephon is free to make trial of Gorgias’ ability as a question-answerer]
  Πάρεστι τούτου πεῖραν, ὦ Χαιρεφῶν, λαμβάνειν.  {ΠΩΛ.} Νὴ Δία·

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he would think the bitch sensible if she went and got some wheat somewhere in exchange for her evil tongue]
 εἰ νὴ Δί’ ἀντὶ τῆς κακῆς γλώττης ποθὲν 
  πυροὺς πρίαιο, σωφρονεῖν ἄν μοι δοκεῖς
remarks: This reported oath is entirely fictitious. As Sommerstein notes ad 1401-5: "Philocleon had been advised (1259) to appease his victims by narrating "something funny of Aesop". He misunderstands this, and instead of telling a fable by Aesop he tells a tale of his own invention about Aesop, in which the characters of Aesop and the bitch are transparent disguises for himself and Myrtia".

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That it is fearsome indeed if they are going to have to fight]
  τοῦτο μέντοι δεινὸν ἤδη, νὴ Δί’, εἰ μαχούμεθα.
remarks: Xanthias is responding to the Chorus (now seemingly transformed into wasps) who seem ready to attack Bdelycleon over his treatment of his father.

author: Demosthenes
title: For Phormion
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker states that Apollodorus is asking the jurors to set his malicious accusation above the laws in accordance with which they have sworn to judge. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
The Plataeans argue that they are not the first to break the peace.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Aristophanes
title: Dramata or Niobos
statement:
[That s/he does not have the least desire for a plate of boiled fish]
 οὐδὲν μὰ Δί’ ἐρῶ λοπάδος ἑψητῶν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the Assembly finished at first light]
  {Βλ.}  ἤδη λέλυται γάρ; {Χρ.} νὴ Δί’ ὄρθριον μὲν οὖν.
remarks: The statement is of dubious veracity, and is clearly, at least, an exaggeration of the truth since the Assembly was to begin at sunrise. Cf. also oath ids 801 and 813.

author: Sophocles
title: Antigone
statement: [That the guard would never come back to the palace of Creon, whether or not the criminal was found]
remarks: The guard here treats the statement he made at 327-329 as a sworn oath which he has broken, although it was not in fact an oath at all. This seems to be a particular feature of Sophocles. Cf. oath ids 236, 270, 285, 289, 292.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
if_taken: They would prove their determination to recover Thyrea
if_refused: They would not prove their determination to recover Thyrea
impact: Argives are subject to a self-imposed curse
statement: [That no Argive should grow his hair long, and none of their women should wear gold jewellery, until they recovered Thyrea]
remarks: The reference is to an event mentioned by Herodotus 1.82.7. The Argives had lost Thyrea to the Spartans as a result of the "Battle of the Champions" and "from that time cut their hair, whereas they had previously been required to grow it long, and made a law and a curse that no Argive should grow his hair long, and none of their women should wear gold jewellery, until they recovered Thyrea".  Hdt. places these events in the time of Croesus, apparently not long before the fall of Sardis; c. 550-546.  The Argives never did recover Thyrea, but they did try to get Thyrea (also called Cynuria) back by negotiation in 421 and 420 as the price of renewing their peace treaty with Sparta, but the Spartans wouldn't hear of it (Thuc. 5.14.4, 5.41.2).  They invaded the territory in 414 and took much booty (Thuc. 6.95.1), with which they made a major dedication at Delphi (Paus. 10.9.12); perhaps they reckoned then that on this occasion they'd held the area long enough to discharge their vow. Cf. oath id 3599 where the Spartans manage to keep their oath but still send men back to Sparta after having sworn an oath not to return home again until they had either destroyed Messene or were all killed.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes criticises Aeschines and Philocrates for excluding the Phocians, the Halians and Cersobleptes from the treaty, contrary to the decree passed by the demos. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
statement:
[That the tree they are making for is a delightful resting place]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, καλή γε ἡ καταγωγή
remarks: Informal oaths by Hera are particular to Socrates and a few others. See oath id 1870 with cross references.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
statement: [That they would protect Plataea should anyone attack]
remarks:
The Plataeans entreated the Spartans in the name of the common gods of the Hellenes, and appealed to the oaths sworn by their (the Spartans') fathers, supplicated them by the tombs of their fathers, and appealed to dead to save them from falling into the hands of the Thebans. 
For other references to this oath see oath id 1598.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Peisetaerus' criticsm is correct]
  Νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον εὖ γε μωμᾷ ταυταγί.
remarks: Peisetaerus' criticism is that the current behaviour of birds wins them no respect.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
date: Up to the time of Xenophon (538 to 401)
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
Xenophon observes that the mountains east of the Tigris in Armenia are the country of the Carduchians. These were a warlike tribe not subject to the King, and on one occasion a royal army of one hundred thousand men had invaded their country, and not a single man had returned. 
Xenophon notes that despite this, they sometimes made a treaty with the satrap in the plain, and when this happened some of the people in the plain had dealings with the Carduchians, and some of the Carduchians had dealings with the people in the plain.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Gobryas should tell the truth]
 Οὐκοῦν, ἔφη ὁ Γωβρύας, κἀγὼ τἀληθῆ λέγω; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος
remarks: This is an emphatic example of the stereotype that Persians abhor deception and lies and value the truth most highly.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_refused: War will continue as it is
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Idomeneus reaffirms his promise to Agamemnon to fight, especially now that he says the Trojans have destroyed  their oaths and have been the first to break the truce. This is the same oath as id 318.

author: Pindar
title: Olympian 6
statement:
[That the victor (Hagesias of Syracuse) is also both a good seer and fighter]
 ἑπτὰ δ’ ἔπειτα πυρᾶν νε‐ 
  κροῖς τελεσθέντων Ταλαϊονίδας
εἶπεν ἐν Θήβαισι τοιοῦτόν τι ἔπος· 
  ‘Ποθέω στρατιᾶς ὀφθαλμὸν ἐμᾶς 
ἀμφότερον μάντιν τ’ ἀγαθὸν καὶ
  δουρὶ μάρνασθαι.’ τὸ καί 
ἀνδρὶ κώμου δεσπότᾳ πάρεστι Συρακοσίῳ. 
οὔτε δύσηρις ἐὼν οὔτ’ ὦν φιλόνικος ἄγαν,
καὶ μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμόσσαις τοῦτό γέ οἱ σαφέως 
μαρτυρήσω· μελίφθογγοι δ’ ἐπιτρέψοντι Μοῖσαι.
remarks: Pindar also swears in his authorial persona at ids 1312, 1315, 1317, 1319, 1321.

title: IG XII 2
date: 336 and after (during the reign of Alexander) (336 to 324)
statement:
[That they would perform their advocacy for the city as best they could..]
 οἴτινε[ς ὀ]μόσαντες Ἀπόλ[λων]α Λύκειον ὄ[μ]α σ̣[υναγ]ορήσοισι [τᾶ πόλι ὄππω]ς κε δύνα[νται - - -]
remarks:
The trials of the former tyrants of Eresus - Eurysilaus and Agonippus - were ordered by Alexander the Great.   
This inscription refers to the trial of Eurysilaus.   
The statement is not intact. 
For the oath sworn at the trial of Agonippus see oath id 778. For the oath sworn at the trial of the descendants of the first tyrants of Eresus see oath id 780.

author: Demosthenes
title: Answer to Philip's Letter
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes states that Philip has used the peace to forestall the Athenians by occupying many fortresses, harbours, and other points of vantage. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would abide by the truce for four months, during which time they would settle their dispute by arbitration]
remarks:
Thucydides states that King Agis was blamed at Sparta for having made the four month truce with the Argives when he had such a good opportunity to subdue Argos.  
When the Spartans learned that Orchomenos had fallen they resolved to raze his house to the ground and fine him ten thousand drachmas. 
Agis begged them not to do this, and promised to wipe out the charges by a brave deed. 
For other references to this truce and its impact see oath id 1741.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
Xenophon notes that the Thebans and Corinthians objected to the treaty and alliance between Athens and Sparta in 404. 
For other references to this peace treaty see oath id 1898, 1899, 1914, 2354, 2390, 2409, 2599, 2825, 2837, 2838, 2839.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That he has not observed that tyrants tend to eat with more gusto than ordinary people - on the contrary, in most people's opinion, they eat with disgust] 
 Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ μὲν οὖν, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἀγλευκέστερον, ὡς πολλοῖς ἂν δόξειεν.
remarks:
Simonides is responding to Hiero's question as to whether he has noticed that tyrants fall to their meals with more zest than private citizens. 
Simonides is saying (i) with an oath, that he has not observed that tyrants tend to eat with more gusto than ordinary people, and (ii) on the basis of common opinion, that they actually, if anything, enjoy their food less.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That the study of geometry will make an immense difference to a student’s ability to learn about warfare and all other subjects]
 καὶ πρὸς πάσας μαθήσεις, ὥστε κάλλιον ἀποδέχεσθαι, ἴσμεν που ὅτι τῷ ὅλῳ καὶ παντὶ διοίσει ἡμμένος τε γεωμετρίας καὶ μή.  Τῷ παντὶ μέντοι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he has never seen a trench for plants dug less than a foot deep (nor even less than a foot and a half deep)]
 ἤδη τινὰ εἶδες τὸ βάθος ἐλάττονα ποδιαίου; Οὐδὲ μὰ Δί’, ἔφην, ἔγωγε τριημιποδίου.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Emphasises the determination of the women
statement:
[That if the men kindle their flame, they will unleash the wild sow within themselves, and will shear the men's fleece (i.e. tear out their white hair) leaving them screaming for help]
 Εἰ νὴ τὼ θεώ με ζωπυ‐  {Ant.}  ρήσεις, λύσω τὴν ἐμαυτῆς
  ὗν ἐγὼ δή, καὶ ποήσω
 τήμερον τοὺς δημότας βωστρεῖν σ’ ἐγὼ πεκτούμενον.
remarks: On swearing by Persephone and Demeter, see remarks on id 788.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus opens his speech by telling the jurors that Timocrates' law undoes their vote which they cast on all matters after swearing. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
statement: [? That they would abide by the peace, on condition that Chios, Cos and Rhodes were able to withdraw from the Second Athenian Confederacy, and the independence of Byzantium was recognised]
remarks:
Isocrates argues that if they make peace with their allies (as their common agreements demand they do), they will enjoy peace, security and the financial rewards that peace offers. 
See also oath id 3007.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That Aristogeiton's numerous and respectable kinsmen will come forward and intercede on his behalf]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία καὶ χωρὶς τούτων συγγενεῖς πολλοὶ καὶ καλοὶ κἀγαθοὶ παραστάντες αὐτὸν ἐξαιτήσονται.
remarks: The speaker is again being ironic.

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That he does not know what length will give the square of eight feet]
 Οὐδ’ ἄρ’ ἀπὸ τῆς τρίποδός πω τὸ ὀκτώπουν χωρίον γίγνεται. {—ΠΑΙ.} Οὐ δῆτα. {—ΣΩ.} Ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ ποίας; πειρῶ ἡμῖν εἰπεῖν ἀκριβῶς· καὶ εἰ μὴ βούλει ἀριθμεῖν, ἀλλὰ δεῖξον ἀπὸ ποίας. {—ΠΑΙ.} Ἀλλὰ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔγωγε οὐκ οἶδα.
remarks: The slave is now “making progress on the path of recollection”, since the removal of false beliefs is an essential preliminary to facilitating his “recollection”of the truth known before birth. Cf. oath id 3141.

author: Epicharmus
title: Kyklops
statement:
[That sausages and leg (of mutton) are delicious]
 χορδαί τε ἁδύ, ναὶ μὰ Δία, χὠ κωλεός

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he can see the Clouds]
  νῦν γέ τοι ἤδη καθορᾷς αὐτάς, εἰ μὴ λημᾷς κολοκύνταις.
 {Στ.}  νὴ Δί’ ἔγωγ’.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
date: During the experience of Xenophon (399 to 360)
statement: n/a
remarks: Xenophon observes that Agesilaus had such reverence for religion that even his enemies considered his oaths and his treaties were more to be relied upon than their friendship with each other.

author: Lycurgus
title: Oration 15
statement: n/a
remarks: Lycurgus states, "we must help our friends and relatives as far as we can, without perjury".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
 ἐμμενῶ τῇ ξυμμαχίᾳ κατὰ τὰ ξυγκείμενα δικαίως καὶ ἀβλαβῶς καὶ ἀδόλως, καὶ οὐ παραβήσομαι τέχνῃ οὐδὲ μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ.
remarks:
Thucydides refers here to the so-called Argive alliance. He indicates that each city will swear the oath that is most binding in their land. The Athenians were to swear on behalf of their allies, whereas the Argives, Mantineans, Eleans, and their allies were to swear individually by state. 
It is stipulated that for the renewal of the oath the Athenians will travel to Elis, Mantinea, and Argos, thirty days before the Olympic games, and the Argives, Eleans and Mantineans will travel to Athens ten days before the Great Panathenaea. 
Thucydides states that the Corinthians did not join (literally 'join in swearing') this offensive and defensive alliance, but were content with their first alliance with Argos (see oath id 1698) which was defensive only. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Blepyrus is the last of all to go for dinner]
 ἐπὶ τὸ δεῖπνον ἔρχομαι.  
 {Θε.}  νὴ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην, πολύ γ’ ἁπάντων ὕστατος.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Aristogeiton
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The prosecutor urges the jurors not to release Aristogeiton and fail to give the verdict demanded by their oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
remarks:
Tissaphernes responds to Clearchus' comments regarding their oaths, "there are so many ways to make war on the Greeks that are not dangerous to us, so why would we choose the one way which is impious in the sight of gods and shameful in the sight of all men?". 
Tissaphernes goes on to say, "it is those who are without ways and means and are bound by necessity (and these are villains in any case) who are willing to accomplish an object by swearing falsely by the gods and being faithless to men. 
Tissaphernes tells Clearchus that the Persians are not so unreasoning or foolish. 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Corinthians sent envoys to Argos to negotiate an alliance (5.27.2), after which the Argives resolved to make an alliance with any of the Greeks except for Athens and Sparta (5.28.1-2). Thucydides observes that the Mantineans and their allies were the first to join the Argives. 
For this system of alliances which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," and later included Athens, see also oath id 251.

author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement: n/a
remarks: This oath reference is contained within advice to trust neither in an oath nor in affection, not even if Zeus himself is invoked to guarantee the pledge; cf. oath id 1369.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That he does not suppose that the jurors will be able to follow the jumbled arguments advanced by Aeschines]
 Τῶν μὲν οὖν λόγων, οὓς οὗτος ἄνω καὶ κάτω διακυκῶν ἔλεγε περὶ τῶν παραγεγραμμένων νόμων, οὔτε μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς ὑμᾶς οἶμαι μανθάνειν οὔτ’ αὐτὸς ἐδυνάμην συνεῖναι τοὺς πολλούς·

author: Lysias
title: For the Soldier
statement:
[That they would call up only those who had not been on campaign]
 ὀμόσαντες μὲν οὖν τοὺς ἀστρατεύτους καταλέξειν
remarks:
The speaker, Polyaenus, claims that he had been called up unfairly for military service, and had objected to the generals who were responsible for the call up without success.  
He claims that the generals broke their oaths to call up only those who had not been on campaign, and have since been persecuting him for having criticized them.

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
statement: [That they would abide by the terms of the peace]
remarks: This is a reference to a peace treaty between Athenians and the Epidaurians and maritime cities, i.e. those of the Argolic Acte (Trozen, Hermione and Halieis).  It is difficult to pin down the date of this peace treaty. It can’t have been during the wars of 371-362, when these states were on the same side as Athens (for Sparta, against Thebes).  There is, however, a reasonable context for it in the 370s, after Chabrias’ naval victory at Naxos (376) when the Athenian fleet became dominant in the western Aegean and many states joined the recently founded Second Athenian League.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement: [That Euxitheus' mother Nicarete was an Athenian]
remarks: Euxitheus tells the clerk to take the deposition of Cleinias and his relatives who know that his mother once served as Cleinias' nurse. He says that their oath requires them to bear witness not to what Euboulides says, but to what they have always known regarding his mother i.e. that she was an Athenian (aste).

author: Demosthenes
title: Olynthiac 1
statement:
[That it is not surprising that Philip is a cruel ruler (because undeserved success engenders folly in unbalanced minds)]
 καὶ μὰ Δί’ οὐδὲν ἄπιστον ἴσως·

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
if_taken: They will be permitted to act as judges
if_refused: They will not be permitted to act as judges
impact: Case will be judged by both Athena and her people
statement: [That they will judge according to the laws]
remarks: Here Apollo asserts that Zeus is stronger than an oath (compare oath id 210). As Sommerstein ad loc. notes, 'the oath referred to here can only be that of the jurors, which Apollo therefore is in effect telling them to disregard- a shocking request, which no one would dream of making in a real Athenian trial and which Athena will not countenance (710)'. See further remarks on oath id 214.

author: Isocrates
title: Euagoras
statement: [? That he would obey the Great King and pay tribute to him]
remarks:
Isocrates remarks that the Great King made peace with Euagoras at a time when the Persians were not accustomed to make peace with their rebellious subjects. He observes that the Great King abandoned custom in leaving the authority of Euagoras undisturbed. 
The peace was agreed on condition that Euagoras was recognised in his position as king of Salamis, and that Euagoras agreed to obey the Great King and pay him tribute.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Polycles
statement:
[That he was without resources in a way that no one who wasn't really keeping track of his affairs would believe ]
 ἀπορῶν δὲ αὐτὸς ὡς μὰ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω οὐδεὶς ἄν μοι πιστεύσειεν, ὅστις μὴ ἀληθῶς παρηκολούθηκε τοῖς ἐμοῖς πράγμασιν.

author: Amipsias
title: Sphendone
statement:
[That none of the rich men are like the addressee in having a well-stocked table and in wanting to gobble up rich food]
 κοὐδείς σοὐστὶν τῶν πλουτούντων, μὰ τὸν Ἥφαιστον, προσόμοιος, 
καλλιτράπεζος καὶ βουλόμενος λιπαρὸν ψωμὸν καταπίνειν
remarks: Swearing by Hephaestus, god of fire, is appropriate in the context of cooking meat.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
impact: Shows the conviction of the birds
statement:
[That the kingship rightly belongs to the birds if they are older than Earth and were born before the gods]
  Οὔκουν δῆτ’ εἰ πρότεροι μὲν γῆς, πρότεροι δὲ θεῶν ἐγένοντο, 
 ὡς πρεσβυτάτων ὄντων αὐτῶν ὀρθῶς ἐσθ’ ἡ βασιλεία; 
 {ΧΟ.}  Νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 646.  Some editors attribute this oath to Euelpides.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That it is all the more undesirable that he should go and see the captured woman if she is as beautiful as Araspas says]
 ἀλλὰ πάντως, ἔφη, καὶ σὺ θέασαι αὐτήν. καὶ ὁ Κῦρος ἔφη· {Ναὶ} Μὰ Δία, πολύ γε ἧττον, εἰ τοιαύτη ἐστὶν οἵαν σὺ λέγεις.
remarks: Cyrus is afraid that he will lapse into wasting his time through gazing at the woman's beauty.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That every free man should pray not to have a man who is slave to his pleasures among his slaves]
 ἐμοὶ μὲν δοκεῖ νὴ τὴν Ἥραν ἐλευθέρῳ μὲν ἀνδρὶ εὐκτὸν εἶναι μὴ τυχεῖν δούλου τοιούτου
remarks: The oath by Hera is unusual and particular to Socrates; cf. oath id 1870 with cross-references.  It normally accompanies an expression of admiration; the present passage is the only one in Plato or Xenophon in which Socrates swears by Hera in any other context.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement:
[That the name Boeotus was given to him by way of derision or insult]
 νὴ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ὕβρει καὶ ἐπηρείᾳ τινὶ τοῦτ’ ἐτέθη σοι.
remarks: Mantitheus tells Boeotus that he should keep the name which Mantias gave him, and imagines that Boeotus will respond in this way.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Corinthians began to hate the Athenians
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Megarians revolted from the Spartans and joined the Athenians in alliance because the Corinthians were pressing them hard in a war over boundaries. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see oath id 1778.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: Philoetius hopes that the oath is true
statement:
[That Odysseus will come home, while Philoetius is still there]
  “βουκόλ’, ἐπεὶ οὔτε κακῷ οὔτ’ ἄφρονι φωτὶ ἔοικας, 
γινώσκω δὲ καὶ αὐτός, ὅ τοι πινυτὴ φρένας ἵκει,
τοὔνεκά τοι ἐρέω καὶ ἐπὶ μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμοῦμαι·
ἴστω νῦν Ζεὺς πρῶτα, θεῶν ὕπατος καὶ ἄριστος,  
ἱστίη τ’ Ὀδυσῆος ἀμύμονος, ἣν ἀφικάνω· 
ἦ σέθεν ἐνθάδ’ ἐόντος ἐλεύσεται οἴκαδ’ Ὀδυσσεύς·
σοῖσιν δ’ ὀφθαλμοῖσιν ἐπόψεαι, αἴ κ’ ἐθέλῃσθα,
κτεινομένους μνηστῆρας, οἳ ἐνθάδε κοιρανέουσι.”
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)first among the gods; Table of xenia; Hearth of blameless Odysseus
remarks: Philoetius had just previously said (217-225) that he was considering emigration.  His response to the oath ("if only the son of Kronos would fulfil this word!", 236)  shows him to be loyal to Odysseus. For similar oath statements, cf. oath ids 542, 545, 559.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That rather than being closer to finding the knowledge they sought, Socrates and Cleinias had apparently found themselves in considerable perplexity]
 Νὴ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, εἰς πολλήν γε ἀπορίαν, ὡς ἔοικεν, ἀφίκεσθε.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he will not be there to prosecute]
 σὺ δὲ κατηγόρει παρών. 
 {Ξα.}  μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Hippolytus asks whether Theseus intends to banish him without trial, without examining his oaths and pledges, and without consulting prophets. Cf. oath id 128.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That they could not work their own farms securely, let alone those of the Armenians, if the Armenians were to have possession of the heights]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφασαν οἱ Χαλδαῖοι, οὐκ ἂν ἡμεῖς ἀσφαλῶς ἐργαζοίμεθα μὴ ὅτι τὴν τούτων, ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἂν τὴν ἡμετέραν, εἰ οὗτοι τὰ ἄκρα ἔχοιεν.
remarks: The Armenians feel the same (see oath id 2379), and Cyrus decides to leave a Persian garrison on the heights to enusre that the peace is enforced.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That the Sausage-seller had other pranks when he was a boy]
  Καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἄλλα γ’ ἐστί μου κόβαλα παιδὸς ὄντος·
remarks: He proceeds to explain one such prank which involved perjury. See oath id 1000.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement:
[That he would rule according to the established nomoi; and that he would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
 βασιλεῖαι τρεῖς βασιλευομέναις πόλεσιν τριτταῖς ὤμοσαν ἀλλήλαις ἑκάτεραι, κατὰ νόμους οὓς ἔθεντο τοῦ τε ἄρχειν καὶ ἄρχεσθαι κοινούς, οἱ μὲν μὴ βιαιοτέραν τὴν ἀρχὴν ποιήσεσθαι προϊόντος τοῦ χρόνου καὶ γένους, οἱ δέ, ταῦτα ἐμπεδούντων τῶν ἀρχόντων, μήτε αὐτοὶ τὰς βασιλείας ποτὲ καταλύσειν μήτ’ ἐπιτρέψειν ἐπιχειροῦσιν ἑτέροις, βοηθήσειν δὲ βασιλῆς τε βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις καὶ δήμοις, καὶ δῆμοι δήμοις καὶ βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις.
remarks: The discussion concerns the time in which Temenus was King of Argos, Cresphontes was king of Messene and Procles and Eurysthenes were kings of Sparta, when the area was first divided into the three states of Argos, Sparta and Messene. The people swear a reciprocal oath- see oath id 2683. The kings and people of Sparta and Argos do the same- see oath ids 2678-81.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: n/a
remarks: It is decided that in Magnesia, since men's belief in the gods is not what it once was (cf. oath id 2727), litigants and defendants will be forbidden from swearing antomosiai and the like at the beginning of a trial. Rather each litigant and each defendant will write down his charges or defence and hand them to the magistrate without an oath. In all cases where a large gain will accrue to him who denies knowledge or swears an exomosia, all the contending parties must be judged by trial without oaths. Any oath which can be taken to gain an advantage for oneself is to be banned also during the trial (see oath id 2734). The prohibitions are instituted because of the high degree of perjury among those who do not hold the gods in respect (see oath id 2729). Only resident aliens are exempt from these prohibitions of oaths, since they are not expected to grow old in Magnesia.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Spartans or their allies should not go against or raise revenue from whatever lands and cities belong to King Darius or belonged to his ancestors.
2. King Darius and his subject shall not go against the territory of the Spartans
3. They shall fight against the Athenians and if they make peace they shall do so together
4. Whatever forces are in the territory of the King shall be paid for by the King
5. If any of the cities that have entered into the agreement with the King go against the territory of the King, the rest shall prevent this; and if any of those who inhabit the King's territory go against the territory of the Spartans or their allies, the King shall strive to prevent this and gave aid to the extent of his power]
remarks:
This is the second agreement between the Spartans and the Persians. A third agreement was made not long after this one. 
For references to all these agreements see oath id 1806.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That he needs some scheme which will allow him to keep his property, but also to take part in the communal meal]
 νὴ τὸν Δία, δεῖ γοῦν μηχανήματός τινος, 
  ὅπως τὰ μὲν ὄντα χρήμαθ’ ἕξω, τοῖσδέ τε 
  τῶν ματτομένων κοινῇ μεθέξω πως ἐγώ.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 872, "he has already thought of, and had to abandon, three plans (to force his way in to the meal 860-4; to snatch food at the door, 865-6; to use the Neighbour's property, instead of his own, to secure admission, 869-871)". In fact, a few moments later, he will think of what he evidently considers to be a good plan (875-6), though we never learn what it is.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That what the sausage-seller has stated is true]
 Νὴ Δί’
remarks: See remarks on oath id 976 for further information and context.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he loves his father]
 εἰπέ μοι, φιλεῖς ἐμέ; 
{Φε.} νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ τουτονὶ τὸν ἵππιον.
remarks: Strepsiades objects to the choice of god invoked, because his son's love of horses (cf. Hippios) has been the source of his troubles.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: Cyrus will help him avenge the death of his son
if_refused: Cyrus will not help him avenge the death of his son
statement: [That if Cyrus helps him avenge his son and lets him keep his castle and province and the power he had before, Gobryas will give Cyrus the castle as his headquarters when he comes and will pay him the tribute of the province. Gobryas, with the forces of his province, will follow Cyrus wherever he may march, and he gives Cyrus his daughter in marriage]
remarks: Gobryas here offers himself to Cyrus as a "slave and ally", since he does not wish to serve the new successor to the Assyrian throne who killed his son. Cyrus accepts and the alliance is formally sworn a little later- see oath id 2398.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That, when planting, he would pack the earth firmly around the plant (rather then just heaping it)]
 ἐπαμήσαιο δ’ ἂν μόνον, ἔφη, τὴν γῆν, ἢ καὶ σάξαις ἂν εὖ μάλα περὶ τὸ φυτόν; Σάττοιμ’ ἄν, ἔφην, νὴ Δί’ ἐγώ.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Citizens of the poleis on Ceos
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
That they would be an ally of the Athenians and the allies, and would not defect from the Athenians and the allies themselves, nor would they allow another as far as possible. They would make all private and public lawsuits against Athenians subject to appeal in accordance with the agreement, as many as are for more than one hundred drachmas. If anyone dares to wrong those of the Ceans who have returned, or the Athenians or any of the allies, contrary to the oaths and the agreement, they would not allow him by any craft or contrivance, but would go in support with all their strength as far as possible. To this they would swear by Zeus, by Athena, by Poseidon, by Demeter. To him who keeps the oath there shall be many good things, but to him who breaks the oath, ill]
[συμμαχήσω Ἀθηναίοις καὶ] τοῖς συμμάχοις, καὶ οὐ[κ ἀποστήσομαι ἀπ’ Ἀθηναίων καὶ τῶ]ν συμμάχων οὔτε αὐτὸς [ἐγὼ οὔτε ἄλλωι πείσομαι ἐς τὸ δυνατ]όν. τὰς δὲ δίκας καὶ τ[ὰς γραφὰς τὰς κατ’ Ἀθηναίων ποιήσομαι] πάσας ἐκκλήτος κ[ατὰ τὰς συνθήκας, ὁπόσαι ἂν ὤσιν ὑπὲρ ἑ]κατὸν δραχμάς. ἐὰ[ν δέ τις τολμᾶι ἀδικε̃ν Κείων τὸς κατελθ]όντας ἢ Ἀθηναίο]ς ἢ τῶν συμμάχων τινὰ παρὰ τοὺς ὅρκους καὶ] τὰς συνθήκας, [οὐκ ἐπιτρέψω οὔτε τέχνηι οὔτε μηχανῆι οὐδ]εμιᾶι, βοηθή[σω δὲ παντὶ σθένει κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν. ταῦτα ἐμπ]εδορκήσω ν[ὴ τὸν Δία, νὴ τὴν Ἀθηνάαν, νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ, νὴ τὴν Δ]ήμητρα· εὐ[ορκο̃ντι μὲν πόλλ’ ἀγαθὰ εἶναι, ἐπιορκο̃ντι δὲ κα]κὰ.
remarks:
This inscription records a new agreement between Athens and the poleis on Ceos. 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians and the allies see oath id 422.  
For the oath of the reinstated Ceans see oath id 427.  
For the earlier agreement see oath id 431, 443.  
See also oath id 520, 521.

author: Archippus
title: Onou Skia
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment is a single word indicating that someone has sworn an oath, but nothing further can be deduced.

author: Ephorus
title: Histories
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a reference to water often being called Achelous (after the river and eponymous god) in sacral language including that of oaths, prayers and sacrifices. See also Dodds on Euripides, Bacchae 625-6.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he is not giving the finger to blabbering adolescents]
  Οὔκουν καταδακτυλικὸς σὺ τοῦ λαλητικοῦ;
  {ΔΗ.}  Μὰ Δί’

author: Lysias
title: On the Property of Nicias' brother
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that his opponent - Poliochus - would like nothing more than to succeed in the case, because he would regard it as a fine demonstration of his power in Athens to make the jurors vote in contradiction of the oaths they have sworn. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes urges the jurors not to forgive Aeschines for the loss of Phocis and Thermopylae if he defends himself by pointing out that they still possess the Chersonese. He argues that when the peace was made and the Chersonese was made safe, the Phocians were preserved for another four months before they were destroyed by Aeschines' mendacity. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Hesiod
title: Theogony
statement: n/a
remarks: Like the references at ids 1291 and 1293, this reference concerns the Styx as "oath" in the sense that she is invoked by gods to guarantee their oaths. In this passage, Hesiod lists the punishments for any god who swears a false oath on the river Styx. For one year, he is laid flat and does not breathe; nor is he allowed come near ambrosia and nectar to eat, but without breath and without voice he lies on a bed and the evil coma covers him. After this year of punishment, the perjuring god is then cut off from all share in the life of the everlasting gods for nine years, and has no part in their counsels or festivals. In the tenth year, he mingles once more in the assemblies of gods on Olympus.

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Liberty of the Rhodians
statement:
[That he would not like to say that he knows what the King will do]
 ἐπεὶ καὶ βασιλέα γε, ὅ τι μὲν ποιήσει μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἂν εἴποιμ’ ἔγωγ’ ὡς οἶδα,
remarks: Demosthenes then goes on to say that it would be to their advantage if they were to know whether the King of Persia is going to claim Rhodes or not.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the movements of the sun are such as to give maximum benefit to mankind]
 Τὸ δὲ τὸν ἥλιον, ἐπειδὰν ἐν χειμῶνι τράπηται, προσιέναι τὰ μὲν ἁδρύνοντα, τὰ δὲ ξηραίνοντα, ὧν καιρὸς διελήλυθε, καὶ ταῦτα διαπραξάμενον μηκέτι ἐγγυτέρω προσιέναι, ἀλλ’  ἀποτρέπεσθαι φυλαττόμενον μή τι ἡμᾶς μᾶλλον τοῦ δέοντος θερμαίνων βλάψῃ, καὶ ὅταν αὖ πάλιν ἀπιὼν γένηται ἔνθα καὶ ἡμῖν δῆλόν ἐστιν ὅτι, εἰ προσωτέρω ἄπεισιν, ἀποπαγησόμεθα ὑπὸ τοῦ ψύχους, πάλιν αὖ τρέπεσθαι καὶ προσχωρεῖν, καὶ ἐνταῦθα τοῦ οὐρανοῦ ἀναστρέφεσθαι ἔνθα ὢν μάλιστ’ἂν ἡμᾶς ὠφελοίη; Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, καὶ ταῦτα παντάπασιν ἔοικεν ἀνθρώπων ἕνεκα γιγνομένοις.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
The defendant asks the jurors, "What court would they [the prosecutors] hesitate to invade with their lies? What oaths would they not dare to break?". He goes on to add that the prosecutors know that the jurors are the most conscientious and most fair in Greece, yet they come before the jurors intent on deceiving them, in spite of the oaths they have sworn i.e. that they knew well that the defendant had killed. See also oath id 2512. 
This line of thought is a repetition of section 49 (see oath id 2510).

author: Aristotle
title: Titel 143,1 Gigon
if_taken: He would be able to escape service in the expedition
if_refused: He would not be able to escape service in the expedition
if_broken: unknown (see remarks for punishment on perjury)
impact: He was relieved of his obligation to serve
statement: [That he was not in a position (could be financially or physically) to take part in the expedition]
remarks: This reference comes from extracts of Politeiai attributed to Heracleides (in this case of the Locrians), which Gigon regards as all derived from Aristotle but to which he gives no fragment numbers. The passage relates to a certain Polemarchus (or perhaps a holder of the office of polemarch) who, at some unspecified time, committed perjury and was able to escape service in the expedition of the Corinthians. He is subsequently plagued by weasels who bite him continually during the night when he tries to sleep, eventually causing him to take his own life.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That she did not break the jewel that was worth most]
 Οὐ δήπου, ὦ γύναι, συγκόψασα τὸν σαυτῆς κόσμον τὰ ὅπλα μοι ἐποιήσω; Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ἡ Πάνθεια οὔκουν τόν γε πλείστου ἄξιον·
remarks: Panthea broke up her jewels to make her husband's armour, but she did not break her most precious jewel- i.e. Abradatas himself.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That not all people think that seven and five make twelve]
 ἢ πάντες λέγουσί τε καὶ οἴονται δώδεκα αὐτὰ εἶναι;  {ΘΕΑΙ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία
remarks: Theaetetus goes on to say that people would be much more likely to make the same kind of mistake when dealing with higher numbers. He assumes that Socrates was really asking about any pair of numbers, not just the particular pair 7+5.  To a modern reader, certainly, the argument would have been much more convincing if instead of 7 and 5 Socrates had specified, for example, 748 and 563 (and, of course, had asked for an instant response, not a calculation).

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would be loyal to each other and fight alongside each other]
remarks: Philip and Amadocus subsequently go to fight another Thracian king, Kersobleptes, as allies.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Thucydides states that after the affair of the Mysteries had come to light the Athenians were in an ugly temper and were suspicious about those who had been blamed for the affair. 
It seemed to the Athenians that the whole thing had been done in a sworn conspiracy aimed at oligarchy or tyranny. By calling it "oligarchic and tyrannical", Thucydides seems to be insinuating that those who believed in it were engaging in some very muddled thinking. 
See also oath id 1771.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That the Byzantines are deluded and stupid beyond measure]
 νὴ Δία, κακοδαιμονῶσι γὰρ ἅνθρωποι καὶ ὑπερβάλλουσιν ἀνοίᾳ.
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that someone might respond in this way to his statement that without Athenian support the Byzantines are doomed.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he thinks the old man (i.e. Wealth) is without a foreskin]
 οἶμαι δὲ νὴ τὸν οὐρανὸν καὶ ψωλὸν αὐτὸν εἶναι.
remarks: The condition of the penis is conjectured evidently because the phallus is not visible. See further Sommerstein ad 267.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
impact: Convinces the spectators of the true love that exists between them
statement:
[That she loves him]
 καὶ γὰρ ἤκουον τοῦ Διονύσου μὲν ἐπερωτῶντος αὐτὴν εἰ φιλεῖ αὐτόν, τῆς δὲ οὕτως ἐπομνυούσης
remarks: This is part of a performance during the Symposium showing Ariadne and Dionysus falling in love. This is apprently so realistic that the spectators would have sworn the couple were in love (even though they are clearly actors). Cf. oath ids 1286 and 1287.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That friends should count as wealth if someone knows how to use them so as to benefit from them]
 οἱ δὲ φίλοι, ἄν 
τις ἐπίστηται αὐτοῖς χρῆσθαι ὥστε ὠφελεῖσθαι ἀπ’ αὐτῶν, 
τί φήσομεν αὐτοὺς εἶναι; Χρήματα νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κριτόβουλος

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be alllies to the Leontinians forever, without guile and without injury]
 [σύ]νμα[χ]οι ἐσόμ[εθα Λεοντ]ίν[οις ἀί]δ̣ιο[ι ἀδόλος κ]αὶ [ἀβλα]βο̃ς·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Leontini. 
The prescript was erased and reinscribed in antiquity. Each line is longer than the original text. The reason for the erasure is unknown. For the corresponding oath of the Leontinians see oath id 167. See also oath id 3205.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
 Ψηφιοῦμαι κατὰ τοὺς νόμους καὶ τὰ ψηφίσματα τοῦ δήμου τοῦ Ἀθηναίων καὶ τῆς βουλῆς τῶν πεντακοσίων. καὶ τύραννον οὐ ψηφιοῦμαι εἶναι οὐδ’ ὀλιγαρχίαν οὐδ’ ἐάν τις καταλύῃ τὸν δῆμον τὸν Ἀθηναίων ἢ λέγῃ ἢ ἐπιψηφίζῃ παρὰ ταῦτα, οὐ πείσομαι οὐδὲ τῶν χρεῶν τῶν ἰδίων ἀποκοπὰς οὐδὲ γῆς ἀναδασμὸν τῆς Ἀθηναίων οὐδ’ οἰκιῶν οὐδὲ τοὺς φεύγοντας κατάξω, οὐδὲ ὧν θάνατος κατέγνωσται, οὐδὲ τοὺς μένοντας ἐξελῶ παρὰ τοὺς νόμους τοὺς κειμένους καὶ τὰ ψηφίσματα τοῦ δήμου τοῦ Ἀθηναίων καὶ τῆς βουλῆς οὔτ’ αὐτὸς ἐγὼ οὔτ’ ἄλλον οὐδένα ἐάσω. οὐδ’ ἀρχὴν καταστήσω ὥστ’ ἄρχειν ὑπεύθυνον ὄντα ἑτέρας ἀρχῆς, καὶ τῶν ἐννέα ἀρχόντων καὶ τοῦ ἱερομνήμονος καὶ ὅσοι μετὰ τῶν ἐννέα ἀρχόντων κυαμεύονται ταύτῃ τῇ ἡμέρᾳ, καὶ κήρυκος καὶ πρεσβείας καὶ συνέδρων οὐδὲ δὶς τὴν αὐτὴν ἀρχὴν τὸν αὐτὸν ἄνδρα, οὐδὲ δύο ἀρχὰς ἄρξαι τὸν αὐτὸν ἐν τῷ αὐτῷ ἐνιαυτῷ. οὐδὲ δῶρα δέξομαι τῆς ἡλιάσεως ἕνεκα οὔτ’ αὐτὸς ἐγὼ οὔτ’ ἄλλος ἐμοὶ οὔτ’ ἄλλη εἰδότος ἐμοῦ, οὔτε τέχνῃ οὔτε μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ. καὶ γέγονα οὐκ ἔλαττον ἢ τριάκοντα ἔτη. καὶ ἀκροάσομαι τοῦ τε κατηγόρου καὶ τοῦ ἀπολογουμένου ὁμοίως ἀμφοῖν, καὶ διαψηφιοῦμαι περὶ αὐτοῦ οὗ ἂν ἡ δίωξις ᾖ.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That Ismenia does indeed represent Boeotia]
  Νὴ Δί’ ὡς Βοιωτία
remarks: Myrrhine is emphatically agreeing with Lampito's previous sworn statement to the same effect (see id 1152). The statement is a joke referring to “Ismenia’s pubic region”, as Sommerstein's commentary puts it, which is compared to the lush plains of Boeotia.

title: IG II(2)
date: Third quarter of the 4th century (349 to 325)
if_taken: He can act as an advocate (synegoros)
if_refused: He cannot act as an advocate (synegoros)
statement:
[That they would advocate what is just for the deme and to vote as seems to them most just]
 συν<η>γορήσειν τῶι  δήμωι τ[ὰ δ]ίκαια καὶ ψ[ηφ]ιεῖσθαι ἃ ἂν μοι δοκεῖ δικαιότατα εἶναι·
remarks:
This entry follows the text in Rhodes and Osborne, GHI, 63. Kirchner identified the deme as Myrrhinous. Rhodes and Osborne suggest Hagnous.  
For the oath of the scrutineer see oath id 531. For the oath of the reckoners see oath id 535. See also oath id 538.  
The text indicates that the demarch will oversee the ballot for those participating in the scrutiny and will exact their oaths.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
impact: Adeimantus and the Corinthians stayed at Artemisium
statement:
[That he would give Adeimantus a greater gift than the King of the Medes would send him for deserting his allies]
 ἐπεί τοι ἐγὼ μέζω δῶρα δώσω ἢ βασιλεὺς ἄν τοι ὁ Μήδων πέμψειε ἀπολιπόντι τοὺς συμμάχους.
remarks:
According to Herodotus, because Adeimantus and the Corinthians were eager to withdraw to the Isthmus, Themistocles bribed him to stay and fight. 
Herodotus observes that Themistocles had scarcely ended his oath before he sent three talents of silver to Adeimantus' ship.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he will clap the Sausage-seller in stocks]
  Ἐν τῷ ξύλῳ δήσω σε νὴ τὸν οὐρανόν.
remarks: Paphlagon made the same threat at 367, but without the added strength of the oath formula.

author: Xenarchus
title: Pentathlos
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a general reflection on the untrustworthiness of a woman's oath and a parody of oath id 363; cf. also ids 1307 and 1433.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
statement:
[That he is grieved if he does not save Iphigenia through battle]
 ἄχθομαι δ’, ἴστω Θέτις,
  εἰ μή σε σώσω Δαναΐδαισι διὰ μάχης 
  ἐλθών.
remarks: Compare Achilles' previous oath at id 188. See also the oath at id 3885.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Ciron
if_taken: He could introduce the children to the phratry
if_refused: He could not introduce the children to the phratry
statement:
[That he was introducing the children of an Athenian mother duly married]
 ὀμόσας κατὰ τοὺς νόμους τοὺς κειμένους ἦ μὴν ἐξ ἀστῆς καὶ ἐγγυητῆς γυναικὸς εἰσάγειν·
remarks: The speaker states that when he and his brother were born their father introduced them to his phratry under oath, and that none of the phratry members objected or disputed the truth of his statements.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a peace treaty or alliance
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Spartans did not compel the Eleans to give up the presidency of the shrine of Zeus Olympios when they ended the war. 
See also oath id 2016.

title: FD III: 1
if_broken: Whoever does not act as a judge after swearing shall pay fifty drachmas
statement:
[That they would judge and give their vote with justice]
 οἵτινες ὁμόσουσι μὲν δικάζει[ν], τὰν δὲ ψᾶφον [φέρειν δικαιότατα.
remarks:
The text indicates that eleven men would be chosen to act as judges, and that they would "swear to judge and to give their vote with justice; and whoever upon swearing does not judge shall pay fifty drachmas". 
Perhaps this oath was designed to prevent judges from absenting themselves from cases that they might find personally or politically embarrassing.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That he is glad that Socrates has reminded him of Aesop's fables (since friends had wanted to find out why Socrates had been composing lyrics by adapting Aesop's fables and the prelude to Apollo)]
  Ὁ οὖν Κέβης ὑπολαβών, Νὴ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔφη, εὖ γ’ ἐποίησας ἀναμνήσας με.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Hypereides says it is unreasonable for Diondas to criticize him because the alliance with Thebes was unequal (Athens having to contribute two-thirds of the war effort in money, horses and troops; compare Aeschines, Against Ctesiphon 142-3), when Athens had supplied 220 out of 360 ships at Salamis, over four-fifths of the fleet at Artemisium, and had fought alone at Marathon (all three of these assertions are exaggerated).
See also oath id 2670.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
statement: n/a
remarks:
Antiphon states that exacting an oath or a pledge is the greatest and strongest compulsion known to free men. 
It is possible that horkois kai pistesin may be a hendiadys, since in context an oath is the only kind of pistis that could be relevant; that explanation could resolve Gagarin's evident bafflement.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the gods do not ordain what is other than just]
 Πότερον οὖν, ὦ Ἱππία, τοὺς θεοὺς ἡγῇ τὰ δίκαια νομοθετεῖν ἢ ἄλλα τῶν δικαίων; Οὐκ ἄλλα μὰ Δί’, ἔφη·

author: Anonymus Oxyrhynchicus
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The text indicates that Agesilaus made a treaty with Gyes in Paphlagonia. This must be the same king called Otys and Cotys by Xenophon. 
It should be mentioned that σπονδάς is a restoration, and not a very convincing one; one would expect συμμαχίαν, but presumably this is too long for the available space. 
See also oath id 1920.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That he would render whatever services Etearchus asked]
 ἐξορκοῖ ἦ μέν οἱ διηκονήσειν ὅ τι ἂν δεηθῇ
remarks:
Herodotus states that Etearchus, the ruler (basileus) of Oaxus in Crete, was a widower with an unmarried daughter named Phronime. When he took a second wife she mistreated Phronime, accused her of lewdness and convinced her husband that the charge was true. 
Etearchus then made friends with a Theran trader named Themison and made him swear an oath to render whatever services he asked. 
When Etearchus ordered Themison to take away Phronime and throw her into the sea Themison was "angry at being tricked in his oath" and renounced his friendship with Etearchus. 
He then took the girl away to sea, and in order to quit himself of his oaths to Etearchus, bound the girl with ropes, lowered her into the sea and then pulled her out again. Themison then sailed back to Thera with the girl. 
The date of these events can be extrapolated from the fact that Phronime was the mother of Battus, who founded the Theran colony at Cyrene ca.635.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement:
[That they would not eat with their husbands, nor call them by name]
 μή κοτε ὁμοσιτῆσα τοῖσι ἀνδράσι μηδὲ οὐνόματι βῶσαι τὸν ἑωυτῆς ἄνδρα
remarks:
Herodotus claims that "the Ionians who emigrated from Athens" did not bring wives to their settlements, but instead married Carian women whose parents they had put to death and that the women swore this oath because the men had married them after killing their fathers, husbands and sons. Herodotus goes on to add that the oath in question took place in Miletus.  
Herodotus does not provide a date for these events, but Eusebius dates the foundation of Miletus and Ephesus by Athens to 1087 B.C.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes has an extract from Philip's letter read to the jurors, and complains that while Philip  - before he got a peace treaty - agreed that he would write down the good things he would do for Athens if he received an alliance, after obtaining both he now says he does not know what favour he can offer Athens. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
if_taken: They will be allowed into office
if_refused: They will not be allowed into office
statement:
[That they will propose what they consider to be best for the city]
  ὀμόσαντες ἦ μὴν συγγράψειν ἃ ἂν ἡγῶνται βέλτιστα εἶναι τῇ πόλει
remarks:
This organisation was established as part of the constitution of the Four Hundred. Gomme, Andrews and Dover comment on this in the context of Thucydides Book VIII, stating (p.213) "an oath would be almost automatic for such an appointment, and the content of the oath could almost be predicted... Aristotle's formulation is close to that of the bouleutic oath ... and may come from the decree".  
For the bouleutic oath, see oath id 1775.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That he is very far from supposing that he knows the cause of (e.g.) one person or one number being bigger than another]
 Πόρρω που, ἔφη, νὴ Δία ἐμὲ εἶναι τοῦ οἴεσθαι περὶ τούτων του τὴν αἰτίαν εἰδέναι

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That it would be madness for the Athenians to send a large and costly fleet to keep watch on one of their own commanders]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐ δαπάναις καὶ τριήρεσιν τοσαύταις ἡμᾶς αὐτοὺς φυλάττειν, ἐπεὶ τοῦτό γ’ ἐστὶν ὑπερβολὴ μανίας·
remarks: Demosthenes observes that if Diopeithes is acting outrageously in detaining merchant-ships in the Hellespont he can be stopped, for there are laws which direct them to bring an eisangelia against offenders. It is absurd, he argues (with an oath), to send another commander to the region, with a large and costly fleet, just to keep watch on him.

title: IG I(3)
swearer: Generals; Trierarchs; Hoplites; Any other Athenians present
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend the Selymbrians, and be just and guileless in their dealings with the Selymbrians]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Selymbria. 
The agreement between the Athenians and the Selymbrians was to be set up in a temple of a god or goddess whose name is lost.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
swearer: The Thirty and their followers; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The Thirty and their followers; The rest of the Athenians
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks: One unnamed citizen is found to have broken the terms of the amnesty and was executed as an example to all at the suggestion of Archinus, after which no one broke the terms of the agreement (see oath id 1799). The terms of the reconciliation are as follows (quoting Rhodes' translation of 39): "Of the Athenians who had remained in the city, those who wished to emigrate might occupy Eleusis, retain their rights as citizens, with full power and authority over themselves, and continue to draw the revenues from their own property. The sanctuary at Eleusis was to be common to both communities, under the care of the Heralds and Eumolpidae in accordance with tradition. No one from Eleusis was to go to the city, and no one from the city was to go to Eleusis, except in each case for the Mysteries. Those at Eleusis were to contribute to the alliance from their revenues in the same way as the rest of the Athenians [see oath id 1786]. If anyone who emigrated took a house at Eleusis, he was to seek agreement with the owner; if they were unable to agree, each should choose three assessors, and the owner should accept whatever price they fixed. Any of the people of Eleusis might join the community if they were approved by the new settlers. Those who wished to emigrate to Eleusis should be entitled to register, in the case of those already in the city of Athens, within ten days of swearing the oaths of reconciliation, and to emigrate within twenty days; in the case of those who were away from Athens, within the same period from their return. No one living at Eleusis should be entitled to hold office in the city, without cancelling his registration and returning to live in the city. Trials for homicide should be held in accordance with tradition in cases where a man had himself performed the act of killing or wounding. Otherwise no one was to recall the past misdeeds of the anyone except the Thirty, the Ten, the Eleven and the governors of the Piraeus, and not even of these if they successfully submitted to an examination. The examination was to take place, for the governors of the Piraeus, among the men of the Piraeus; for those who had held office in the city, among those possessed of a property qualification. Alternatively, those who were not willing to submit to an examination might emigrate. Each side was to repay separately the money that it had borrowed for the war". See also Andocides 1.90-91 (a selective set of quotations) and oath ids 1900-1902, 2322, 2355, 2359, 2360, 2634, 2806, 2807, 2829, 2847, 2848, 2849, 2850, 2855, 2958, 2959, 2966, 2968, 2970, 2971.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Macartatus
swearer: Those making counter-claims to the estate
if_taken: They can proceed with their case
statement: [That the facts in his written statement were true]
remarks: Sositheus states that when the estate was awarded to Phylomache, none of those who made counter-claims to Hagnias' estate ventured to swear the antomosia to verify that he was nearer of kin than her.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Emphasizes the lack of food in Megara
statement:
[That if the girls go back home unsold, they will experience terrible hunger]
 ὡς ναὶ τὸν Ἑρμᾶν, αἴπερ εἱξεῖτ’ οἴκαδις
  ἄπρατα, πειρασεῖσθε τᾶς λιμῶ κακῶς.
remarks: The Megarian has been driven by the shortage and high prices of food at Megara to bring his daughters to Dicaeopolis' market to be sold as slaves.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he has never seen Cyrus avoiding danger or shrinking from the enemy when in battle]
 Τί γάρ, ἔφη, ἐπεὶ οἱ πολέμιοι ἦλθον καὶ διαγωνίζεσθαι ἔδει πρὸς αὐτούς, ἐν τούτῳ κατενόησάς πού με ἢ πόνου ἀποστάντα ἤ τινος  κινδύνου φεισάμενον; Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ μὲν δή.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, in 395 the leading men in Thebes were aware that unless someone began the war the Spartans would not break the treaty with their allies. They resolved to stir up trouble between Sparta's allies, which would then force the Spartans to intervene. 
Accordingly, they persuaded the Opuntian Locrians to levy money from territory which was in dispute between Phocis and Locris, for they thought that if this was done Phocis would invade Locris. This did happen, and the Thebans made a counter invasion of Phocis. When Phocis appealed to Sparta for assistance, war between Sparta and Thebes ensued. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement: [That they would support whoever became Helen's husband should someone take her from the house, and that they would all march against him and sack his city with force of arms, be he Greek or Asiatic]
remarks:
Thucydides argues that the expedition to Troy came about because of the power of Agamemnon compared to the princes of his time, rather than because the suitors were bound by their oaths to Tyndareus. 
For other references to this oath see Euripides, Iphigenia Aulidensis 58-65, 78, 391 and 395 (oath id 182-185) and Sophocles, Philoctetes 72 (oath id 280). See also Isocrates 10.40.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
if_taken: Their statements will carry more weight
statement: [That Aphobus acknowledged that Milyas was free and that he testified against Demon]
remarks: Demosthenes again states that Aphobus did not give a pledge after he and the witnesses had sworn that Aphobus acknowledged that Milyas was free and that he testified against Demon (see also oath id 3523).

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text indicates that the Athenian strategos Chabrias made an agreement with the poleis on Ceos and exhanged oaths with them (lines 13-20). It is also stated that the demos had resolved to ratify this agreement.  
Three envoys were sent from Ceos to swear the oaths before the synedrion. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 39.73.  
For the oath sworn by Chabrias see oath id 521.  
This inscription must be dated to either immediately before or after IG II(2) 111 - see oath id 422.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the matter concerning which Lysistrata has brought the women together is "meaty"]
  καὶ νὴ Δία παχὺ

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Hagnias
statement:
[That the laws do not oblige him to submit to criminal trials in matters about which they (the laws) have instituted private suits nor to run any personal risk over property which he has been awarded by a court verdict]
 Ταῦτα καὶ οἱ νόμοι κελεύουσιν, οὐ μὰ Δία οὐ γραφὰς ἐμὲ φεύγειν περὶ ὧν δίκας ἰδίας εἶναι πεποιήκασιν, οὐδὲ κινδυνεύειν περὶ τοῦ σώματος,

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
if_taken: Clearchus and his men would be persuaded to come to the conference
if_refused: Clearchus and his men might not be persuaded to come to the conference
impact: Clearchus and his men are presuaded to come
statement: [That, if Clearchus came with his generals to Tissaphernes, he would give Clearchus publicly the names of those who told him that Clearchus was plotting against him and his army]
remarks: The reference to the oaths and deceit in this fragment of Ctesias strongly suggests that the oaths were somehow connected to luring Clearchus and his generals to Tissaphernes' conference where they were then killed. The oath statement quoted here is based on an agreement referred to in Xenophon Anabasis 2.5.24-26. In an attempt to quell Clearchus' suspicions, Tissaphernes proposes this agreement. Clearchus then agrees to come to the conference and to reveal the sources from whom he has his reports concerning Tissaphernes. It must be noted, however, that the agreement is not sworn in Xenophon, although Tissaphernes does in any case break a previous oath not to injure Clearchus (see oath id 2111). The deceitful Menon is also mentioned in the Ctesias passage as being involved. Cf. oath id 2166.

author: Euripides
title: Phoenissae
statement:
[That it was not by his choice, but by his opponent's, that he took up the spear against his closest kin]
 θεοὺς δ’ ἐπώμοσ’ ὡς ἀκουσίως 
  τοῖς φιλτάτοις ἑκοῦσιν ἠράμην δόρυ.
remarks: As at various other points in this play (e.g. 72, 476, 630) Polyneices stresses that Eteocles is the aggressor through having broken their agreement to rule each for one year at a time.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That some of the comrades seem ill-mannered in the matter of socializing]
 ἐν μέντοι τῇ συνουσίᾳ δύσκολοι ναὶ μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς ἔνιοι αὐτῶν φαίνονται.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2340.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That (he thinks) there's no point in Strepsiades learning more about gender] 
  ἀτὰρ τί ταῦθ’ ἃ πάντες ἴσμεν μανθάνω;
 {Σω.}  οὐδὲν μὰ Δί’
remarks: The swearer doesn't believe in Zeus!

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That some people have many enemies]
 Οὐκοῦν καὶ ἐχθροὺς
κέκτηνταί τινες; Νὴ Δία καὶ πολλούς γε ἔνιοι

author: Hypereides
title: Epitaphios
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
Hypereides states that Aristophon was known as "Ardettus" because he often committed perjury there. 
One would expect the nickname to refer to what must have been by far the most familiar oath taken at Ardettus (and the only one that we actually know of), namely the heliastic oath.  But since jurors voted secretly, no one could know whether Aristophon had ever broken that (unless he was accused of taking bribes).  Pollux (8.122) speaks of a court (dikasterion) at Ardettus; if he is right, the reference may rather be to Aristophon's activity as a litigant in this court, perhaps on some of the 75 occasions on which he was accused (always unsuccessfully) of moving an illegal decree (Aeschines 3.194).

author: Xenophon
title: Apology
statement: n/a
remarks: After his trial, Socrates claims that it has not been shown that he has sworn oaths by gods other than Zeus, Hera and their company of gods.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he's sure Blepsidemus would treat him like a friend - spend three minas and claim twelve]
 Καὶ μὴν φίλως γ’ ἄν μοι δοκεῖς νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς 
  τρεῖς μνᾶς ἀναλώσας λογίσασθαι δώδεκα.
remarks: The qualifying line 381 makes it very clear that the statement is sarcastic. Cf. oath ids 884 and 900.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Socrates lists the many aspects of life, with which most people concern themselves, which he shunned. This includes "sunomosiai", clubs with sworn in members- cf. oath id 2534.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That they are being deceived]
 «Ἐξαπατώμεθα,
  νὴ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν.
remarks: The context here related by Hermes is a situation in which Athenians had gained some success and the Spartans had come to discuss peace (contrast oath id 935) as at Pylos in 425 (see Sommerstein ad 219 for details). Sommerstein ad 217 explains the reference to being tricked as follows: "when the Spartan embassy of 425 asked to be allowed to negotiate with elected Athenian representatives, rather than having to reply to the Athenian demands in open assembly, Cleon seized this as proof "that they had no honest intentions" (Thuc. 4.22.2)". Cf. also oath id 937 which has the same context.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that Dercylidas sent to the cities of Aeolis and requested that they free themselves, admit him inside their walls, and become his allies. 
Those in Neandria, Ilium and Cocylium obeyed. The citizens of Cebren also later complied.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Pyrrhus
statement:
[That if his opponent was telling the truth the smallness of the dowry would have made him indignant and he would have launched an eisangelia against Endius]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία, εἴ γ’ ἦν ἀληθὲς τὸ πρᾶγμα.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Locris. 
The text indicates that the Athenians wanted to ensure that the Locrians "might swear as quickly as possible and be in the alliance according to the oaths and the agreement". 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 464.

author: Chioinides
title: Ptochoi
statement:
[That neither Gnesippos nor Kleomenes would have sweetened these things in nine strings] 
 ταῦτ’ οὐ μὰ Δία Γνήσιππος οὐδὲ Κλεομένης 
ἐν ἐννέ’ ἂν χορδαῖς κατεγλυκήνατο.
remarks: Presumably the point is that neither of these two musicians could have sweetened the music under discussion, i.e. it’s so insipid that no amount of jazzing-up could make it agreeable.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
date: When the Sausage-seller was a boy (445 to 435)
if_taken: He will be able to conceal his theft
if_refused: He will be charged with theft
impact: He was believed and got away with his crime
statement:
[That he didn't steal meat from the butchers]
 ἐξηπάτων γὰρ τοὺς μαγείρους <ἂν> λέγων τοιαυτί· 
  «Σκέψασθε, παῖδες· οὐχ ὁρᾶθ’; ὥρα νέα, χελιδών.» 
Οἱ δ’ ἔβλεπον, κἀγὼ ’ν τοσούτῳ τῶν κρεῶν ἔκλεπτον.  
{ΔΗ. } Ὦ δεξιώτατον κρέας, σοφῶς γε προὐνοήσω· 
  ὥσπερ ἀκαλήφας ἐσθίων πρὸ χελιδόνων ἔκλεπτες 
 {ΑΛ.} Καὶ ταῦτα δρῶν ἐλάνθανόν <γ’.> Εἰ δ’ οὖν ἴδοι τις αὐτῶν, 
 ἀποκρυπτόμενος εἰς τὼ κοχώνα τοὺς θεοὺς ἀπώμνυν· 
 ὥστ’ εἶπ’ ἀνὴρ τῶν ῥητόρων ἰδών με τοῦτο δρῶντα· 
 «Οὐκ ἔσθ’ ὅπως ὁ παῖς ὅδ’ οὐ τὸν δῆμον ἐπιτροπεύσει.» 
 {ΔΗ. }  Εὖ γε ξυνέβαλεν αὔτ’· ἀτὰρ δῆλόν γ’ ἀφ’ οὗ ξυνέγνω· 
 ὁτιὴ ’πιώρκεις θ’ ἡρπακὼς καὶ κρέας ὁ πρωκτὸς εἶχεν.
remarks: Cf. oath ids 979 and 1038.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
if_taken: He can take office in the boule
if_refused: He cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
The speaker, Theomnestus, refers to when Apollodorus was chosen by lot to serve in the boule, and states that when Apollodorus had passed the scrutiny and sworn the customary oath, there came upon the city the war with Philip in the Chersonese. 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Lysias
title: On the murder of Eratosthenes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that Euphiletus had not killed unlawfully]
remarks: Euphiletus tells the jurors that if he had planned to kill Eratosthenes he would have summoned all his friends to witness the killing, but as he did not know what was going to happen he had with him only a few friends.
