He then summons witnesses who could testify to the truth of what he said 37-42 - probably therefore Sostratus (39) and Harmodius (41).  Neither of these was present when Eratosthenes was killed, but they are still (reasonably enough) prepared to swear that he was not killed unlawfully.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
impact: War between the Athenians and the Spartans (temporarily) ceased
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
linguistic: eirhn, omnu, ork, speis, spend, spond, wmnu, wmos
remarks:
According to the terms of the Peace of Nicias, the Athenians and the Spartans would each swear their most solemn customary oath, and seventeen men would represent each city. Both parties would renew the oath each year. It was stated that it would be consistent with their oath (εὔορκον) for changes to be made to the agreement if both parties agreed. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the breastplate is a fine invention covering the parts of a man's body that need most protection without impeding the hands]
 Πρὸς δὲ Πιστίαν τὸν θωρακοποιὸν εἰσελθών, ἐπιδείξαντος αὐτοῦ τῷ Σωκράτει θώρακας εὖ εἰργασμένους, Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφη, καλόν γε, ὦ Πιστία, τὸ εὕρημα τὸ τὰ μὲν δεόμενα σκέπης τοῦ ἀνθρώπου σκεπάζειν τὸν θώρακα, ταῖς δὲ χερσὶ μὴ κωλύειν χρῆσθαι.
remarks: Swearing by Hera is typical of Socrates; see oath id 1870 with cross references.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Philocles
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The prosecutor argues that Philocles cannot be trusted and has betrayed Athens. He states, "If anyone values silver and gold more than highly than his loyalty to you and has no more regard for an oath or for honour and right than he has for making money, then that man, in so far as he is able, will sell Munichia if he has a buyer; he will signal to the enemy and reveal your secrets, he will betray your army and your fleet". 
The reference to his disregarding of oaths is an allusion to the oath mentioned in section 2. See also oath id 2551.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: Alcibiades' son is mentioned as an 'eromenos' (401)
statement:
[That scorpions, although quite small, inflict excruciating and maddening pain if they fasten on the mouth]
 οὐκ οἶσθ’ ὅτι τὰ φαλάγγια οὐδ’ ἡμιωβελιαῖα τὸ μέγεθος ὄντα προσαψάμενα μόνον τῷ στόματι ταῖς τε ὀδύναις ἐπιτρίβει τοὺς ἀνθρώπους καὶ τοῦ φρονεῖν ἐξίστησι; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ξενοφῶν·
remarks: Xenophon here swears as a character in his own work.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: Emphasises the difficulty of approaching Babylon
statement:
[That it is difficult to march right past the walls of Babylon because the Babylonian forces greatly outnumber those of the Persians]
  Τί οὖν, ἔφη, τοῦτο χαλεπόν; Ὅτι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Γωβρύας, οἶδα ἐξελθοῦσαν ἂν δύναμιν ἐξ αὐτῆς πολλαπλασίαν ἧς σὺ ἔχεις νῦν·

author: Anaxilas
title: Euandria
statement:
[That the speaker does not want the (female) addressee to ‘give’ him/her some object now in her possession, but to ‘give it back’]
 καὶ τὰς παλαίστρας δώσω {Β.}μὰ τὴν γῆν μὴ σύ γε
δῷς, ἀλλ’ ἀπόδος. {A.} καὶ δὴ φέρουσ’ ἐξέρχομαι
remarks: This fragment can be dated fairly closely, to 342-335.  This is because it alludes to the dispute between Athens and Philip II over Halonnesos (cf. [Dem.] 7).  Athens demanded that Philip “return” the island to her; Philip refused to do so (claiming he had not taken the island from Athens but from a band of pirates), but was willing to “give” the island to Athens (ex gratia, as it were).  On the advice of Hegesippus and Demosthenes, the Assembly refused this offer, and Philip kept the island.  The fragment is itself corrupt:  as transmitted, it won’t scan, so we don’t know what it is that is to be given/returned, but it certainly isn’t wrestling-schools; it must, in fact, be something that one can carry in one’s hand (see end of fragment).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Stephanus 1
if_taken: They will not have to testify
statement: [That they did not know that the facts, to which they had been called to testify, were true]
linguistic: omei, omnu, omos, ork, wmos, wrk
remarks:
Apollodorus tells the jurors that he will call witnesses to testify that Stephanus stole his deposition from the box. He says that he does not think they will take the exomosia, but says that if they do he will have the clerk read a proklesis (challenge) by which the jurors will catch the witnesses in their perjury. 
The clerk reads the statement which Stephanus has drafted for these witnesses, and Apollodorus tells the witnesses to give evidence or take the exomosia, which they do. 
Apollodorus then tells the jurors that it was plain they would take the exomosia eagerly, and repeats his claim that he has a proklesis to be read so that they may be convicted of perjury. He then has his proklesis read - that they were present when Apollodorus challenged Stephanus to give up his slave to be put to torture concerning the theft of the document and that Stephanus refused. 
It seems that there must be two sets of witnesses here.  The first set of witnesses are Phormio’s friends, who refuse to testify that they were aware that Stephanus stole the deposition.  The second set are friends of Apollodorus, who bear witness to the fact that he (subsequently) made a challenge in the terms stated.  Apollodorus certainly would not be such a fool as to issue a challenge without having friendly witnesses present.  I note that in the challenge it is stated that "Apollodorus was ready to write a document specifying the terms upon which the torture was to take place":  no wonder that Stephanus refused the challenge, if its terms and conditions were to be unilaterally determined by his opponent!  It is perhaps, too, worth mentioning what according to the witnesses were the words of Stephanus' reply to the challenge:  "If you say I’ve done you any wrong, then sue me if you want to."

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That he knew well he was being wronged]
 Μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἠγνόουν ἔγωγε, ἀλλὰ σαφῶς ἐγίγνωσκον ὅτι ἠδικούμην.
remarks: This refers to times when Alc. as a child had complained of being cheated in a game.

author: Plato
title: Menexenus
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other allies; Representatives
if_taken: They would receive payment from the Persian king
if_refused: They would not receive payment from the Persian king
statement:
[That if the Persian King would pay them money, they would make over to him the Hellenes of Asia Minor]
 φοβηθεὶς δὲ βασιλεὺς τὴν πόλιν, ἐπειδὴ ἑώρα Λακεδαιμονίους τῷ κατὰ θάλατταν πολέμῳ ἀπαγορεύοντας, ἀποστῆναι βουλόμενος ἐξῄτει τοὺς  Ἕλληνας τοὺς ἐν τῇ ἠπείρῳ, οὕσπερ πρότερον Λακεδαιμόνιοι  αὐτῷ ἐξέδοσαν, εἰ μέλλοι συμμαχήσειν ἡμῖν τε καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις συμμάχοις, ἡγούμενος οὐκ ἐθελήσειν, ἵν’ αὐτῷ πρόφασις εἴη τῆς ἀποστάσεως. καὶ τῶν μὲν ἄλλων συμμάχων ἐψεύσθη· ἠθέλησαν γὰρ αὐτῷ ἐκδιδόναι καὶ συνέθεντο καὶ ὤμοσαν Κορίνθιοι καὶ Ἀργεῖοι καὶ Βοιωτοὶ καὶ οἱ ἄλλοι σύμμαχοι, εἰ μέλλοι χρήματα παρέξειν, ἐκδώσειν τοὺς ἐν τῇ ἠπείρῳ Ἕλληνας· μόνοι δὲ ἡμεῖς οὐκ ἐτολμήσαμεν οὔτε ἐκδοῦναι οὔτε ὀμόσαι.
remarks: This is a reference, again during the fictitious funeral speech, to the Sardis-Sparta conferences where peace proposals were put on the table, involving the recognition of the Persian king's control of Asian Greece. The historical accuracy of Socrates' statements is completely unreliable. It is claimed here that all the allies and the Spartans swore to the agreement except Athens, who fought on alone against the barbarians. This is simply not true, but given that the events allegedly reported here would have been recent at the time of writing, it follows that contemporaries would have recognised this as a great manipulation of the truth contrived for the sake of the spoofed funeral speech. Andocides had urged the Athenians to accept the terms of the peace, but the peace was rejected- see oath id 2393.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the cooking-pot is black]
 νὴ Δία μέλαινά γ’·

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
date: After 594/3 whenever an archon took office (594 to 322)
if_taken: They will be permitted into office
if_refused: They will not be permitted into office
if_broken: They will dedicate a golden statue
consequences_of_breach: A golden statue must be dedicated if a bribe is taken
statement:
[That they will exercise their office justly and in accordance with the laws, and not  take bribes on account of their office (if they do, they will dedicate a golden statue)]
 ἀναβάντες δ’ ἐπὶ τοῦτον ὀμνύουσιν δικαίως ἄρξειν καὶ κατὰ τοὺς νόμους, καὶ δῶρα μὴ λήψεσθαι τῆς ἀρχῆς ἕνεκα, κἄν τι λάβωσι ἀνδριάντα ἀναθήσειν χρυσοῦν. ἐντεῦθεν δ’ ὀμόσαντες εἰς ἀκρόπολιν βαδίζουσιν καὶ πάλιν ἐκεῖ ταὐτὰ ὀμνύουσι, καὶ μετὰ ταῦτ’ εἰς τὴν ἀρχὴν εἰσέρχονται.
remarks: The oath is sworn twice, once in the Stoa of the Basileus and once on the Acropolis. See also oath ids 1753 and 1758 for the oath of the archons.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement: [That he would rule according to the established nomoi; and that he would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
remarks: The Athenian here reaches the conclusion that the lawgivers in the time of Cresphontes and Temenus were not fully expert in the art of legislation, since otherwise they would hardly have deemed it sufficient to moderate by means of oaths a youthful soul endowed with power such as might develop into a tyranny. Cf. oath ids 2678-86.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
statement:
[That the Chorus will never bring any of Phaedra's evils to light]
 Χο. ὄμνυμι σεμνὴν ῎Αρτεμιν, Διὸς κόρην,
  μηδὲν κακῶν σῶν ἐς φάος δείξειν ποτέ.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Emphasises the degree of Aristophanes' disappointment
statement:
[That no one ever heard better comic poetry than in the previous year's comedy (Clouds)]
 καίτοι σπένδων πόλλ’ ἐπὶ πολλοῖς ὄμνυσιν τὸν Διόνυσον 
  μὴ πώποτ’ ἀμείνον’ ἔπη τούτων κωμῳδικὰ μηδέν’ ἀκοῦσαι.
remarks: The chorus here report an oath allegedly sworn by Aristophanes, who appropriately invokes Dionysus as the patron god of drama to support his cause, and further gives additional force to his oath through the solemnity of libations. His 'Clouds' performed at the City Dionysia of 423 had been ranked third.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
impact: Emphasises Ctesippus' bewilderment at the question
statement:
[That, unless he is going mad, he does believe it is possible to lie]
 Τί δέ, ἔφη, ὦ Κτήσιππε, ὁ Εὐθύδημος, ἦ δοκεῖ σοι οἷόν τ’ εἶναι ψεύδεσθαι;  Νὴ Δία, ἔφη, εἰ μὴ μαίνομαί γε.

title: IPArk
statement: [That they would be guileless in the synoecism with the Euaemnians with regard to the agreement, by Zeus Ares, by Athena Areia, by Enyalios Ares. That they would never drive away the Euaemnians, not by Zeus Ares, not by Athena Areia, not by Enyalios Ares]
gods_invoked: Zeus Ares; Athena Areia; Enyalios Ares
remarks: The text indicates that in the future the people of the newly synoecised community of Orchomenos will renew their oaths (see oath id 575 and 576), and that the oath ceremonies (τὰ ὅρκια) will now be the same, whereas previously the citizens of the two communities swore different oaths. However, the citizens who were formerly from the city of Euaemon will be able to swear their old oath and will not be compelled to swear the oath of the Orchomenians.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Athenian and various poleis; Spartan and various poleis
swearee: Athenian and various poleis; Spartan and various poleis
statement: [?That they would not make an attack on the other party or their allies]
remarks:
Thucydides indicates that after the Athenians and the Peloponnesians made peace for five years the Athenians did abstain from making war against the Hellenes and made war in Cyprus instead. 
See also oath id 2383.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Amynias' diagnosis of Bdelycleon's father's ailment is not correct]
  Ἀμυνίας μὲν ὁ Προνάπους φήσ’ οὑτοσὶ 
  εἶναι φιλόκυβον αὐτόν. 
 {Σω.}  ἀλλ’ οὐδὲν λέγει, 
  μὰ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἀφ’ αὑτοῦ τὴν νόσον τεκμαίρεται.

author: Ephorus
title: Histories
if_taken: Elis would become sacred to Zeus
if_refused: Elis would not become sacred to Zeus
if_broken: Whoever invaded Elis or failed to defend it would be under a curse
impact: Elis is made sacred to Zeus and prospers in a state of peace
statement:
[That Elis should be sacred to Zeus (and therefore free from invasions, and that they would defend Elis from invasion to the extent of their power)]
συνομολογηθῆναι ῥαιδίως ἐκ πάντων μεθ’ ὅρκου τὴν Ἠλείαν ἱερὰ εἶναι τοῦ Διός, τὸν δ’ ἐπιόντα ἐπὶ τὴν χώραν ταύτην μεθ’ ὅπλων ἐναγῆ εἶναι, ὡς δ’ αὔτως ἐναγῆ καὶ τὸν μὴ ἐπαμύνοντα εἰς δύναμιν.
remarks: The oath is broken by Pheidon the Argive, tenth descendant of Temenus who was king when the oath was made. He claimed the right to celebrate the Olympian games and forcibly invaded Elis and celebrated the games himself, but the Spartans came to their aid in fighting Pheidon off.

author: Antiphanes
title: Plousioi
statement:
[That Diogeiton had persuaded all (the fishermen) to bring (contributions) to his house]
 καὶ Διογείτων νὴ Δία
ἅπαντας ἀναπέπεικεν ὡς αὑτὸν φέρειν
remarks: All the people mentioned in this fragment are great opsophagoi who want to possess as much fish as possible; vide Davidson passim.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Leads Aeacus to believe that Xanthias has divine protection
remarks: This is apparently a degenerate oath. The point that creates the problem is that Xanthias has been hurt.  At oath id 390, Xanthias seems to swear to a statement that he, at most, suspects to be false. Here he seems to be swearing to a statement that he knows to be false.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That it seems to him that it is well worth a man's while to consider what sort of conduct it was that enabled Teleutias to inspire the men he commanded with such a feeling toward himself]
 ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δία τόδε ἄξιόν μοι δοκεῖ εἶναι ἀνδρὶ ἐννοεῖν, τί ποτε ποιῶν ὁ Τελευτίας οὕτω διέθηκε τοὺς ἀρχομένους. τοῦτο γὰρ ἤδη πολλῶν καὶ χρημάτων καὶ κινδύνων ἀξιολογώτατον ἀνδρὸς ἔργον ἐστίν
remarks: Xenophon adds that "to attain to this is indeed the achievement of a true man, more noteworthy than the expenditure of much money and the encountering of many dangers".  He has not yet in fact actually said what it was about Teleutias that won him such affection and admiration from his men, but we will later discover that it was his devotion to their welfare and his willingness to share their hardships (5.1.14-15; cf. oath id 1955).

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
swearee: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
statement: [That they would fight together in attacking the Medes and Persians]
remarks: Apparently the allies were convinced of the need for the alliance by the Assyrian king's suggestions that the Medes and the Persians, who had intermarried, and were powerful nations, would be likely to make war on each of the other nations and subjugate them. Those who were unconvinced by such arguments were apparently bribed to join the alliance. In the passage referred to in this oath entry, the allies flee, seeing the Assyrians themselves panic-stricken by the onslaught of the Persian army. Cf. oath ids 2326, 2385 and 2389. The allies subsequently begin to desert- see oath id 2387.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That it is the First Boy that he is asking whose son he is]
 Τοῦ καί ποτ’ εἶ; 
  {Π. Αʹ}  Ἐγώ; 
  {ΤΡ.}  Σὺ μέντοι νὴ Δί’.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement:
[That he was not responsible for the death, neither by his own act nor by instigation]
 ἐγὼ δὲ  μὴ ἀποκτεῖναι, μήτε χειρὶ ἐργασάμενος μὴτε βουλεύσας.  ]
remarks: The defendant states that many of the bystanders are familiar with the facts (i.e. that he can be refuted in the second prosecution speech), have heard the oath-commissioner (the horkotes), and are giving close attention to his defence. He goes on to say that he would like them to think that he is respecting the oath he swore (i.e. the diomosia), and that if he persuades the dikasts to acquit him, it was by telling the truth.

author: Euripides
title: Supplices
impact: Adrastus expresses gratitude on behalf of Argos
statement:
[That Adrastus and the Argives have been honoured by the Athenians with a great boon]
Ζεὺς δὲ ξυνίστωρ οἵ τ’ ἐν οὐρανῶι θεοὶ
  οἵων ὑφ’ ἡμῶν στείχετ’ ἠξιωμένοι.
remarks: Theseus' point is not "You thoroughly deserve to have something like this done for you, old chap" but "We've treated you as worthy of a very great favour, and don't you forget it or you'll be showing base ingratitude".

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That he does not think that they are right in saying that a name is a vocal imitation of the thing named]
 Μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἐμοί πω δοκεῖ καλῶς λέγεσθαι

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Argives eventually went to war against Sparta
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
After there was a democratic revolution at Argos the demos began to fear the Spartans and began to court "the alliance of the Athenians". 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1797 and 1835. See also oath id 255.

author: Philip of Macedon
title: Letter to the Athenians
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Philip denies that his actions in Cardia breach the peace because he had been an ally of the Cardians before the peace was made. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

title: IErythrae
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
[That they would go to support Hermias and his hetairoi by land and by sea, with all their strength as far as possible, and would accomplish the other things in accordance with the agreement]
 βοηθήσω Ἑρμί[αι καὶ τ]οῖς ἑταίροις καὶ κατὰ γῆν [καὶ κατ]ὰ θάλασσαν παντὶ σθένει κ[ατὰ τὸ δ]υ̣νατόν, καὶ τὰ ἄλλα ἐπιτελ[έω κατὰ τ]α̣ ὡμολογημένα.
remarks:
This oath is attached to an agreement between Erythrae and Hermias, ruler of Atarneus.   
For the corresponding oath sworn by Hermias and his companions see oath id 764.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That if anyone goes against the Athenians they would go in support as far as possible]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Byzantium. 
These five Byzantine presbeis presumably swore the oath to the Athenians.  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 332.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
remarks: Execestides was an Athenian citizen who was accused by his enemies of being descended from non-Greek slaves. See further Sommerstein ad 11 and MacDowell in Sommerstein et al. ed. Tragedy, Comedy and the Polis (Bari 1993) 364-5.

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
if_taken: They will be allowed to judge
if_refused: They will not be allowed to judge
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Anaximenes refers to the Heliastic oath, and states that the judges swore that they would judge according to the laws: τοὺς δὲ δικάζοντας ὑμᾶς ὀμωμοκέναι κατὰ τὸν νόμον κρινεῖν (see also oath id 1610). 
See also oath id 1614 (where Anaximenes refers to the duty of the judge to listen to all sides of the argument). 
For the full details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That Theaetetus has given an excellent answer to Socrates' question]
 Εὖ γε νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ὦ φίλε, καὶ θείως
remarks: Theaetetus has been dextrous in observing the pitfall of answering Socrates' last question in the obvious way. In doing so, he would contradict what he has said previously. Socrates’ praise is tinged with irony, however, since what Theaetetus is really doing is confessing that he has been trapped in a contradiction. Socrates swears here by Hera, an invocation very much associated with the character of Socrates- see oath id 1870 with cross-references.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that Philip did not want his allies to swear to the peace because Aeschines and Philocrates had been unable to have the clause "except the Halians and Phocians" inserted in the agreement, but had been compelled to write "for the Athenians and the allies of the Athenians" instead. Demosthenes argues that if Philip's allies had sworn to the peace they would not have been likely to join Philip's campaign against the Athens' allies Halos and Phocis. Demosthenes also argues that Philip did not want his allies to swear to the peace because he did not want any witnesses to the promises he made to secure the peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[That he would join in strife and woeful war]
 νείκεα συνμείσχ̣ιν̣ (sic) πόλεμόν θ’ ἅμα δακρυόεντα
remarks:
The text of the grave stele reads as follows: "Here a man in love with a boy swore an oath to join in strife and woeful war; I (this tombstone) am sacred to Gnathios of Eroeadae who perished in battle". 
On the other side of the stele it is written in another hand: "Gnathios you are always too hasty" or "Gnathios you always try too hard".

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_taken: They will be part of the conspiracy
if_refused: They will not be part of the conspiracy
statement: [That they will conspire against the people]
remarks: The Paphlagonian here calls for help as he is being assaulted by the conspirators. For details of this conspiracy, see remarks on oath ids 975 and 1004.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he is indeed praising the dancing instructor]
 καὶ ὁ Χαρμίδης εἶπεν·  Ἐπαινοῦντι ἔοικας τὸν ὀρχηστοδιδάσκαλον. Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης·

author: Epicharmus
title: Pyrra kai Promatheus
statement: unknown
remarks: The reference is too fragmentary to reveal the oath statement.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That Hippias' words (concerning the suggestion that no one will confound Socrates any longer on the nature of beauty)are well spoken if they do indeed manage to defeat the adversary]
 Εὖ γε νὴ τὴν Ἥραν λέγεις, ὦ Ἱππία, εἰ χειρωσόμεθα τὸν ἄνδρα.
remarks: On Socrates and a few select others swearing by Hera, see oath id 1870 with cross references.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That it is absurd to think that Aristogeiton would be well-disposed toward the Athenians after they condemned his father to death and sold his mother when she was found guilty of defrauding her emancipator]
 ἀλλ’ ἄτοπον νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ θεοὺς τοῦτό γε

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement: n/a
remarks:
Lycurgus argues that men are often deceived, but no one who has broken his oath can deceive the gods. 
He adds that if the perjurer does not suffer himself, his children and his family will suffer great misfortune.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he had noticed his wife's stimulated interest in her duties as a result of their discussions]
 Ἦ καὶ ἐπέγνως τι, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, ἔφην ἐγώ, ἐκ τούτων αὐτὴν κεκινημένην μᾶλλον πρὸς τὴν ἐπιμέλειαν; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
Book 3 begins with a summary of the previous book. Xenophon notes that the preceding chapter described "all that took place after the death of Cyrus while the Greeks were on the way back with Tissaphernes during the period of the truce" i.e. the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians. 
See also oath id 2105.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he does not know what has become of him to make him feel unable to speak to Astyages about the boys going hunting]
 Τίς οὖν ἂν ἡμῖν Ἀστυάγει μνησθείη; Τίς γὰρ ἄν, ἔφασαν, σοῦ γε ἱκανώτερος πεῖσαι; Ἀλλὰ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἔφη, ἐγὼ μὲν οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅστις ἄνθρωπος γεγένημαι· οὐδὲ γὰρ οἷός τ’ εἰμὶ λέγειν ἔγωγε οὐδ’ ἀναβλέπειν πρὸς τὸν πάππον ἐκ τοῦ ἴσου ἔτι δύναμαι.
remarks: Cyrus does eventually pluck up the courage to broach the subject with his grandfather, but the fear of confronting his grandfather about putting himself (and the other boys) in danger, after he has been warned against this, is clearly genuine. The OCT is printed here, but one set of manuscripts reads  μὰ τὴν Ἥραν for μὰ τὸν Δία. As lectio difficilior, μὰ τὴν Ἥραν must surely be the correct reading. Swearing by Hera is typical of Socrates, but it also occasionally attested in other speakers, some apparently from the same deme as Socrates (cf. Sommerstein, CQ 58 [2008], forthcoming), but some apparently just displaying Socrates' influence on Xenophon's own speech and composition. If this reading is correct, it is a unique example of an invocation of Hera for a negative statement. All other examples read Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν. Cf. oath ids 1870, 1872, 2102, 2106, 2122, 2144, 2268, 2494.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines argues that it serves Demosthenes to confuse the dates of events (in order to accuse him of causing Cersobleptes to lose his kingdom and other alleged crimes), but it serves him to give the events in their proper order, beginning with the journey to receive the oaths from Philip. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

title: CID I
swearer: Five men chosen from the pilgrims
swearee: The boule of those sailing from Andros to Delphi
proposed_by: The boule of those sailing from Andros to Delphi
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The details of this oath are unclear. 
The text indicates that the Andrians sent a large contingent to Delphi - 3 architheoroi, several priests and a boatload of pilgrims, and that the boule is to choose five men from those sailing to Delphi, and to administer an oath (βολὲ δὲ το̃ν πλεόντον ἐς Δελφὸ[ς] hελέσθο πέντ’ ἄνδρας καὶ ὁρκοσάτο).

author: Xenophon
title: Poroi
statement: n/a
remarks:
Xenophon writes, "were it apparent that you were striving to make the shrine at Delphi autonomous as it used to be, not by joining in war, but by sending embassies up and down Greece, I for my part should not be surprised if you found all the Greeks of one mind, bound together by oaths and allies against anyone who attempted to seize the shrine in the event of the Phocians abandoning it". 
The key clause is "in the event of the Phocians abandoning it".  In any realistic world, they were never going to be induced to abandon it except (i) by force or (ii) by a guarantee against collective punishment (which might just have persuaded them to disown, and deliver up, the leaders responsible for seizing the shrine).  In event (i) it would certainly be Thebes, not Athens, that would earn the prestige.  If Xenophon is thinking clearly (which may be doubted), he must be thinking in terms of event (ii), and suggesting that Athens propose the foundation of a new Hellenic League (perhaps a strengthened version of the Amphictyonic League) with its members bound by a clear treaty commitment to keep the peace with each other and to use force against any future violator of Delphi (or, presumably, against anyone who attacked a member of the League).

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That they would not wage war on the Calchedonians until the envoys should return from the King]
μὴ πολεμεῖν Καλχηδονίοις, ἕως ἂν οἱ παρὰ βασιλέως πρέσβεις ἔλθωσιν
remarks:
Xenophon states that Pharnabazus thought that Alcibiades should also give his oath (as the other Athenian generals had done), and waited at Calchedon for Alcibiades to return from Selymbria. 
When Alcibiades did come, he refused to swear until Pharnabazus should swear his oath to him. When Pharnabazus swore his oath to the representatives of Alcibiades, Alcibiades himself swore his oath at Chrysopolis to the representatives of Pharnabazus: Mitrobates and Arnapes. 
Xenophon observes that both parties not only gave the official oath but also personal pledges. 
See also oath id 1883.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Isocrates criticises the Spartans for attacking their own allies and benefactors. 
He claims that although the Chians supported the Spartans more zealously than any of their other allies by means of their fleet, they later drove into exile the foremost of their citizens, and launched their triremes from the docks and made off with their whole navy (See also oath id 1804). 
Isocrates also criticises the Spartans for turning on the Thebans and the Persian king (see oath id 3013 and 3014).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Euthycles states that the jurors have sworn "to judge according to their perfectly honest opinion" (γνώμῃ τῇ δικαιοτάτῃ δικάσειν). 
He argues that if the jurors decide in favour of the defendant in a graphe paranomon because the prosecutors failed to make their case due to collusion or incompetence, their decision will result in the continuation in force of an illegal decree, but is nevertheless in keeping with their oath to judge according to their perfectly honest opinion. He argues that this is so because the view that commends itself to their judgement is guided by the speeches they hear, and if they vote in accordance with that view they vote piously. He goes on to argue that every man who does not vote against his better judgement due to spite or favour or another dishonest motive votes piously. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That at the moment there are men walking around the Agora in armour, among the potters and greengrocers, like Corybantes]
  Νῦν μὲν γὰρ δὴ κἀν ταῖσι χύτραις καὶ τοῖς λαχάνοισιν ὁμοίως 
  περιέρχονται κατὰ τὴν ἀγορὰν ξὺν ὅπλοις ὥσπερ Κορύβαντες.
 {ΠΡ.}  Νὴ Δία· χρὴ γὰρ τοὺς ἀνδρείους.
remarks: The magistrate qualifies his statement by explaining that such behaviour is to be expected from brave men. On the reference to the Corybantes, see Sommerstein ad 558.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
statement: [? That they would not attack each other's territory]
remarks:
The Plataean speaker states that the Athenians voted to exclude the Thebans from the peace treaty of 374. 
See also oath id 1972.

author: Sophocles
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: n/a
remarks: Here a character comments on how a woman flees the bitter pain of childbirth through oaths, but then is "caught in the same net again vanquished by desire". It is a rather odd statement. Sommerstein suggests the following explanation: "a woman in labour swears (as she very well might, in the absence of any effective analgesic measures) that she will never let herself go through this again - which of course, in those days, meant that she was swearing herself to long-term celibacy. But what happens as soon as the memory of the birth fades? Why, she is "vanquished by the presence of desire" (which, being a woman, she of course, in Greek male eyes, can't resist) and gets "caught in the same net again".  Compare oath id 363 on women's oaths.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: He could not bring a prosecution
statement:
[That Demaratus was not the son of Ariston or the rightful king of Sparta]
 ὁ Λευτυχίδης κατόμνυται Δημαρήτῳ, φὰς αὐτὸν οὐκ ἱκνεομένως βασιλεύειν Σπαρτιητέων, οὐκ ἐόντα παῖδα Ἀρίστωνος
remarks:
At the time he swore this oath Leotychides was not yet king. 
In court Leotychides reminded the Spartans that Ariston had been heard to swear that Demaratus was not his son.  
For references to this oath see oath id 1348 and 1349.

title: IG XII 3
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: Koehler commented that the lettering was similar to that of Athenian inscriptions from the Lycurgan period. The text is very fragmentary, and all that can be determined is that this part of the text is outlining what will happen if someone does not swear an oath.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not make an armed attack on one another]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Corinthians asked the Boeotians to secure for them entry into the ten day truce with Athens which that they made not long after the fifty years' treaty. This truce was probably of no defined duration and could be terminated by either side on ten day's notice (to run from the date on which the declaration of termination was received by the other side). 
The Corinthians also asked the Boeotians to renounce the truce if the Athenians refused, and to make no truces in the future without them.  
The Athenians refused to include the Corinthians in the truce on the grounds that there was already a truce with the Corinthians if they were allies of the Spartans. 
The Boeotians did not give up their truce with Athens, which angered the Corinthians. However, Thucydides observes that there was a cessation of hostilities between the Athenians and the Corinthians without an actual truce. 
See also oath id 1769.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he has hot yet had time to concern himself with the expenditure of the city]
 δῆλον γὰρ ὅτι καὶ τούτων τὰς περιττὰς ἀφαιρεῖν διανοῇ. Ἀλλὰ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐδὲ πρὸς ταῦτά πω ἐσχόλασα.
remarks: See oath id 2085 for context and cf. other entries for 3.6.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he does not see how he could not be ashamed if Gadatas gives him more lavish gifts on his departure than he is able to provide reciprocally]
 εἰ δὲ πλείω μοι δοὺς ἀπίοις ἢ λαμβάνοις παρ’ ἐμοῦ, μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅπως ἂν δυναίμην μὴ αἰσχύνεσθαι.
remarks: The name of the land is never specified. It is the land of Gadatas and borders on Assyria.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: In a time when beasts could speak (0)
statement:
[That he does indeed share his master's food]
 τῷ δὲ κυνί, ὃς οὐδὲν τοιοῦτόν σοι παρέχει, μεταδίδως οὗπερ αὐτὸς ἔχεις σίτου. τὸν κύνα οὖν ἀκούσαντα εἰπεῖν· Ναὶ μὰ Δί’·
remarks: Socrates gives Aristarchus advice here illustrated by a fable. Aristarchus has been charged by the women of his household as "eating the bread of idleness". Socrates relates a fable in which a sheep comes to her master and asks why the dog gets to share the master's food when he gives none of what the sheep gives the master (wool, lambs and cheese). The dog overhears and replies that, of course, he shares his master's food for does he not protect the sheep from being eaten by wolves or stolen by thieves? So also Aristarchus should tell his women that he is their watch-dog.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That Glaucon accepts that justice is that quality which creates men and cities in which each component/individual does its/his own job and no other (cf. 443b1-3)]
 Ἔτι τι οὖν ἕτερον ζητεῖς δικαιοσύνην εἶναι ἢ ταύτην τὴν δύναμιν ἣ τοὺς τοιούτους ἄνδρας τε παρέχεται καὶ πόλεις;  Μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
statement:
[That Philip has chosen to favour Thebes over Athens because because he thought their claims were more just]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’, εἴποι τις ἂν ὡς πάντα ταῦτ’ εἰδώς, οὐ πλεονεξίας ἕνεκ’ οὐδ’ ὧν ἐγὼ κατηγορῶ τότε ταῦτ’ ἔπραξεν, ἀλλὰ τῷ δικαιότερα τοὺς Θηβαίους ἢ ὑμᾶς ἀξιοῦν.
remarks: Demosthenes is imagining how someone might defend Philip for favouring Thebes over Athens.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will lie down and not bring him anything]
 κατάκεισο καὶ μή μοι φέρε
  μηδέν.
 {ΜΥ.}  Ποήσω ταῦτα νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν.
remarks: Sommerstein remarks ad 949 "if Cinesias were alert, he might think this an odd moment for Myrrhine to swear by a goddess associated with chastity".

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
if_taken: They will be permitted to act as judges
if_refused: They will not be permitted to act as judges
impact: Case will be judged by both Athena and her people
statement: [That they will judge according to the laws]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 214.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callicles
statement:
[That Callicles should have proven to everyone that there was a watercourse]
 καὶ νὴ Δι’ ἐπιδεῖξαί γέ σ’ ἔδει πᾶσιν ἀνθρώποις χαράδραν οὖσαν,
remarks: The speaker addresses this comment to Callicles.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Prior to the destruction of Plataea, the Athenians and Plataeans assisted each other when they were threatened
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
In this passage the Theban envoys argue that if the Plataeans made their alliance with Athens to defend themselves against Thebes they ought to have only invoked their aid against the Thebans instead of helping them in their aggression against others. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1561.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement: [That they would kill, by word and deed and vote and their own hand, if they could, anyone who overthrows the democracy at Athens and anyone who holds any office in the future after democracy has been overthrown, and anyone who sets himself up to be tyrant or helps set up a tyrant. And if anyone else kills the man, they would consider him pure in the eyes of both gods and spirits, because he has killed an enemy of the Athenians, and they would sell all the property of the dead man and give half to the killer, and would not hold any back. And if anyone dies in killing or attempting to kill any such man, they would care for both him and his children, just as for Harmodius and Aristogeiton and their descendants. And they declare null and void all oaths that have been sworn at Athens or in the camp or anywhere else against the people of Athens]
remarks:
Demosthenes refers here to the so-called oath of Demophantus. 
See also oath id 2358.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That she has no idea through which gate she entered the fortress]
 Κατὰ ποίας πύλας  
  εἰσῆλθες εἰς τὸ τεῖχος, ὦ μιαρωτάτη; 
  {ΙΡ.} Οὐκ οἶδα μὰ Δί’ ἔγωγε, κατὰ ποίας πύλας.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That the sea does not grow bigger as time passes]
 τὴν θάλαττάν ἐσθ’ ὅτι πλείονα
  νυνὶ νομίζεις ἢ πρὸ τοῦ;
 {Χρ.}  μὰ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἴσην.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That although he knows the taxiarch was aiming to entertain with his story, he nevertheless reproaches him greatly (and justly)]
 ὁπότε γε νῦν καὶ αὐτὸς εἰδὼς ὅτι εὐφραίνειν μέν τί σε βουλόμεθα, βλάψαι  δ’ οὐδέν, ὅμως οὕτως ἐν πολλῇ ἀτιμίᾳ ἡμᾶς ἔχεις. Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἀγλαϊτάδας, καὶ δικαίως γε
remarks: In what follows, Aglaitadas argues that weeping is better for self-control than laughing.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That it seems to him that it is time for the Athenians to be seeking some other friend instead of the King]
 Νὴ Δία, ὦ Ἀθηναῖοι, ὥρα γε ὑμῖν, ὡς ἔοικεν, ἄλλον τινὰ φίλον ἀντὶ βασιλέως ζητεῖν
remarks:
Xenophon states that various Greek cities sent envoys to the court of the Persian King to gain his support regarding a peace treaty. 
After the King wrote a document that was favourable to the cause of the Thebans and detrimental to the Athenians and the Spartans, Leon, one of the Athenian envoys, swore to his fellow Athenian representatives, in the presence of the King, that it was time for the Athenians to look for support elsewhere. 
When Leon's oath was translated for the King, he added a further clause to his document, to the effect that "if the Athenians are aware of anything more just than these provisions, let them come to the King and inform him".

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: n/a
remarks: Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes weeps more easily than other men laugh (i.e. he can produce tears at will) and finds perjury the most natural thing in the world.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That Aeschines' aim in prosecuting Timarchus was not to improve the behaviour of the jurors' sons]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχὶ τῶν  ὑμετέρων παίδων,
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that someone will object to his criticism of Aeschines' prosecution of Timarchus by arguing that Timarchus' trial improved the morals of the young men of Athens (see oath id 3802). He responds to this imaginary objection with this oath of his own.

author: Demosthenes
title: For Phormion
statement:
[That he thinks that it is relevant to tell the jurors everything that is evidence of Phormion's character and of his honesty and kindness]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἔγωγ’, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, νομίζω πάνθ’ ὅσα τοῦ τρόπου τοῦ Φορμίωνός ἐστι σημεῖα καὶ τῆς τούτου δικαιοσύνης καὶ φιλανθρωπίας, καὶ ταῦτ’ εἰς τὸ πρᾶγμ’ εἶναι πρὸς ὑμᾶς εἰπεῖν.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
statement:
[That Odysseus' ship was ready and crewed to take him back to his fatherland]
 ὥς μοι Θεσπρωτῶν βασιλεὺς μυθήσατο Φείδων·
ὤμνυε δὲ πρὸς ἔμ’ αὐτόν, ἀποσπένδων ἐνὶ οἴκῳ,
νῆα κατειρύσθαι καὶ ἐπαρτέας ἔμμεν ἑταίρους
remarks: The oath related here by Odysseus in disguise as the Cretan is entirely fictitious. He tells Eumaeus the same story at oath id 544, also in disguise.

title: IC IV
swearer: The citizen who captured the defendant; Four others
statement:
[That he took him in adultery, and not by subterfuge]
 μοικίοντ’ ἐλέν, δολόσθαι δὲ μέ
remarks:
The text indicates that if anyone caught in the act of adultery declares that he has been taken by subterfuge, the captor is to swear an oath that he captured him in adultery and not by subterfuge. In cases involving fifty staters or more i.e. cases involving the seduction of a free woman the captor is to swear along with four witnesses.  
For examples where men of different status swore this oath see oath id 1098 and 1099.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he beats his dog]
 τύπτεις τὸν κύνα τοῦτον;  Καὶ ὁ Κτήσιππος γελάσας, Νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
statement:
[That Silenus is Ganymede]
 Σι. ἐγὼ γὰρ ὁ Διός εἰμι Γανυμήδης, Κύκλωψ;
Κυ. ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ὃν ἁρπάζω γ’ ἐγὼ ’κ τῆς Δαρδάνου.
remarks: The Cyclops' statement is true in the sense that he believes Silenus to be Ganymede through his drunken stupor, but untrue in the sense that Silenus is not in fact Ganymede.

author: Pherecrates
title: Krapataloi
statement:
[That (if the judges don't judge fairly) Pherecrates will tell a much more slanderous story about them (i.e. in a future play)]
 ἢ νὴ τὸν φίλιον
μῦθον εἰς ὑμᾶς ἕτερον 
Φερεκράτης λέξει πολὺ τού- 
του κακηγορίστερον.
remarks: The swearer is the chorus-leader speaking on behalf of (but not in the persona of) the author. Cf. oath id 1427.

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: They will be allowed to judge
if_refused: They will not be allowed to judge
statement: [That they would judge fairly]
remarks: In this discussion of music, it is said that the true judge of music competitions should not yield to mob pressure nor give his verdict carelessly through cowardice and lack of spirit, which would be contrary to the oath he had sworn (the reference is specifically to calling upon the gods). Cf. oath id 2732 for judges' oaths as envisaged in Magnesia.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Athenians captured Astacus and expelled the tyrant Euarchus. 
After they did so "they incorporated the land into the alliance" i.e. they made an alliance with the new regime.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Causes the boy to lament his existence
statement:
[That he does not know whence he and his son will get dinner if the court does not sit today]
 μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε νῷν οἶδ’ 
  ὁπόθεν γε δεῖπνον ἔσται.
remarks: Cf. 303-7; he had been asked how, if there was no court sitting, he would be able to buy lunch for the family, and replies that he doesn’t know where they will get dinner from (i.e. how they’ll be able to afford even one meal in the day, let alone two).

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Dicaeogenes
swearer: Menexenus (III); The cousins of Menexenus; Dicaeogenes; Leochares
swearee: Menexenus (III); The cousins of Menexenus; Dicaeogenes; Leochares
statement:
[That they would abide by the decision of the arbitrators]
 ἐμμενεῖν οἷς οὗτοι γνοῖεν
remarks:
In sections 16-30, Menexenus (III) indicates that Menexenus (II) - the cousin of Menexenus (III) - took Dicaeogenes to court and had the will showing him as sole heir declared invalid. Leochares was subsequently successfully prosecuted for bearing false witness. 
Menexenus agreed to ignore the potential penalty provided that Dicaeogenes (III) agreed to give up two-thirds of the estate of Dicaeogenes (II) to the sisters of Dicaeogenes (II), and Leochares agreed to act as surety. Mnesiptolemus of Plotheia also agreed to act as surety. 
However, according to Menexenus, both Dicaeogenes (III) and Leochares soon denied that the agreement had been made. 
Thus, Menexenus commenced proceedings against Leochares for failing to guarantee the handing over of the property by Dicaeogenes (III). 
When the action against Leochares was coming on, both Leochares and Dicaeogenes (III) met with Menexenus and his cousins and asked them to postpone the action and submit the matter to arbitration. They agreed, and after four arbitrators were chosen they swore to abide by their decision (see oath id 3046, 3047).  
See also oath id 3048.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
impact: The Greeks elected Cheirisophus their leader
statement:
[That when he became aware of their intention to elect him as sole leader, he offered sacrifice to learn whether it was best for them to entrust him to this command and for him to undertake it; and the gods gave him such signs in the sacrifices that even a layman could perceive that he must withhold himself from accepting the sole command]
 ἦ μὴν ἐγώ, ἐπεὶ τὴν ὑμετέραν γνώμην ᾐσθανόμην, ἐθυόμην εἰ βέλτιον εἴη ὑμῖν τε ἐμοὶ ἐπιτρέψαι ταύτην τὴν ἀρχὴν καὶ ἐμοὶ ὑποστῆναι· καί μοι οἱ θεοὶ οὕτως ἐν τοῖς ἱεροῖς ἐσήμηναν ὥστε καὶ ἰδιώτην ἂν γνῶναι ὅτι τῆς μοναρχίας ἀπέχεσθαί με δεῖ.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That injustice will not appear to be a very terrible thing if it is going to be fatal to its possessor, since that would be a release from all troubles]
  Μὰ Δί’, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὐκ ἄρα πάνδεινον φανεῖται ἡ ἀδικία, εἰ θανάσιμον ἔσται τῷ λαμβάνοντι—ἀπαλλαγὴ γὰρ ἂν εἴη κακῶν—

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he has not yet made notes about matters concerning the naval and military strength of Athens and her enemies]
 Ἀλλ’ εἰ γέγραπταί σοι, ἔνεγκε, ἔφη· πάνυ γὰρ ἡδέως ἂν τοῦτο ἀκούσαιμι. Ἀλλὰ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐδὲ  γέγραπταί μοί πω.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 2085 for context and cf. other entries for 3.6 (esp. oath id 2090).

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides refers to those in Athens who wished to annul the treaty and observes that Alcibiades the son of Cleinias was one of these men. 
Thucydides observes that Alcibiades was opposed to the treaty because the Spartans had negotiated it through Nicias rather than himself. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Lysias
title: Against Alcibiades 1
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
The speaker prosecuting Alcibiades reminds the jurors that this is the first case where a citizen has been prosecuted for desertion since the peace was made i.e. the peace in 404. 
See also oath id 1893.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the women must be mad (to listen to the Inlaw's statements)]
  Οὔ τοι μὰ τὴν Ἄγλαυρον, ὦ γυναῖκες, εὖ φρονεῖτε
remarks: See also oath id 721.

author: Timocreon
title: Fragment
work_date: After Themistocles was exiled from Greece
impact: Accusations and charges of Medism leading to exile
statement: [That he would abide by his agreement with the Persians]
remarks: Here Timocreon acknowledges that he has sworn oaths with the Persians, but points the finger at Themistocles for doing the same thing. See further remarks on oath id 1345.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Prometheus has always been a god-hater]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἀεὶ δῆτα θεομισὴς ἔφυς.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad loc, the term θεομισής can mean both "hating the gods" or "hated by the gods". He further remarks: "Prometheus' reply shows that he understands it in the first sense, but Peisetaerus' words would be equally true in the second".

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he cannot stop laughing]
 ΗΡ.  Οὔ τοι μὰ τὴν Δήμητρα δύναμαι μὴ γελᾶν.
remarks: Heracles is laughing at Dionysus' appearance- he is wearing a lion-skin over a saffron robe.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callicles
statement:
[That no one,  whether they lived in the country or in town, would put up with water flowing down the road getting onto his property or house]
 ἔπειτα τίς ἂν ὑμῶν εἴτ’ ἐν ἀγρῷ νὴ Δί’ εἴτ’ἐν ἄστει τὸ διὰ τῆς ὁδοῦ ῥέον ὕδωρ εἰς τὸ χωρίον ἢ τὴν οἰκίαν δέξαιτ’ ἂν [αὑτοῦ];
remarks: The speaker phrases this oath as a rhetorical question.

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following termss:
1. The King's country in Asia is to remain his possession and to be governed as he pleases
2. The Spartans and their allies shall not go against the country of the King, nor the King against the Spartans and their allies.
3. If any of the Spartans and their allies go against the King's territory, the Spartans and their allies shall stop them, and if any of the King's subjects go against the Spartans and their allies the King shall stop them
4. Tissaphernes shall pay for the ships now present until the arrival of the King's ships. After these arrive, the Spartans can then pay for their own ships if they wish. If not, Tissaphernes will provide money, but the Spartans will repay the money at the end of the war
5. When the King's ships arrive, the ships of the Spartans and their allies and those of the King shall wage war together, according to what seems best to Tissaphernes and the Spartans and their allies. If they wish to end the war with the Athenians, they will do so jointly]
remarks:
Isocrates describes how the Spartans were so avid to gain mastery of the sea that they were (a) negotiating a treaty of friendship and alliance with the Persian king, and promising to give over to him all the Greeks of Asia, and (b) promising to liberate Athens' [Asian] allies if they revolted. 
He claims that after they had given these pledges to the allies of Athens and the King, and had conquered Athens in war, they reduced those who they had sworn to set free to a state of slavery worse than that of Helots, and they returned the favour to the King by persuading his brother Cyrus to dispute his throne and sent an army to support Cyrus in his endeavour.  (This is massively misleading:  Cyrus needed no Spartan persuasion to dispute his brother's throne; his brother wsa not the King [Darius II] with whom Sparta had made the alliance, but his successor [Artaxerxes II]; and the Greek army that supported him was neither despatched nor financed by Sparta.) 
See also oath id 1818.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that he cannot think that any of the jurors will give Meidias impunity for insolence in the future by voting under oath for anything except what they consider to be just. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians recovered their two missing bodies
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Athenians invaded Corinthian territory and defeated the Corinthians in battle. They set up a trophy and collected all but two of their dead. 
At this time the Athenians fled fearing that the rest of the Peloponnesians were coming to assist the Corinthians. 
The Athenians crossed over to the adjacent islands and sent a herald who recovered the missing two bodies under a truce (ὑποσπόνδους).

author: Sophocles
title: Electra
if_refused: The tale of Orestes' death may not be believed
statement:
[That Orestes has died in an accident at the Pythian games after being flung from his chariot]
 ἄγγελλε δ’ ὅρκον προστιθείς, ὁθούνεκα
τέθνηκ’ ᾿Ορέστης ἐξ ἀναγκαίας τύχης,
ἄθλοισι Πυθικοῖσιν ἐκ τροχηλάτων 
δίφρων κυλισθείς·
remarks: Orestes tells his Paidagogos to swear an oath to the effect that he has died, but the Paidagogos does not ultimately do so. He does describe the fictitious death of Orestes in extraordinary detail, but he never actually swears that this is true.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will not come back (home) unless the men reach a settlement and stop the war]
 Οὐ βαδιεῖ πάλιν;
{ΜΥ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’, ἢν μὴ διαλλαχθῆτέ γε 
  καὶ τοῦ πολέμου παύσησθε.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
swearer: Representatives of the allies of Athens
if_taken: They will be included in the peace
if_refused: They will not be included in the peace
remarks:
Aeschines calls for Aleximachus, the author of the motion that Cersobleptes' representative should be permitted to join the other allies in giving the oath to Philip, and the men who served with Demosthenes as proedroi to testify that Demosthenes refused to put the motion to the vote.  
He then tells the jurors that they can see that Demosthenes, who just now burst into tears here at mention of Cersobleptes, tried to shut him out of the alliance.  
Aeschines concludes by telling the jurors that after the adjournment of that session of the assembly, Philip's ambassadors proceeded to administer the oaths to Athens' allies in the Strategion. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he marvels at Gorgias' answers (because of their brevity)]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ὦ Γοργία, ἄγαμαί γε τὰς ἀποκρίσεις
remarks: Swearing by Hera is typical of Plato's Socrates (cf. oath id 1870 with cross references), though some others swear by Hera in informal oaths, which Sommerstein (forthcoming in CQ 58 [2008]) has suggested is a dialect feature of the deme Alopeke. Dodds ad loc. points out, correctly, that swearing by Hera is regularly associated with expressions of admiration – it hardly ever occurs in any other context.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: None - Bdelycleon claims he will not let his father go
statement:
[That they will bawl (because of the way Bdelycleon is treating his father)]
 ἀλλὰ μὴ κεκράγατε. 
 {Χο.}  νὴ Δί’

author: Demosthenes
title: For Phormion
statement:
[That he has been treated disgracefully after the state has been given these sums and after he has spent a great deal on liturgies]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία ταῦθ’ ἡ πόλις εἴληφεν, καὶ δεινὰ πέπονθας πολλὰ καταλελῃτουργηκώς.
remarks: The speaker catalogues the wealth of Apollodorus and complains that he does not pay back the money he owes, and imagines that Apollodorus will respond in this way.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes asks rhetorically whether "these men" (i.e. Aeschines and Philocrates) conducted the embassy contrary to their instructions. He asks whether they excluded the Phocians from the treaty when the terms said "for the Athenians and their allies", and asks why they administered the oaths to the allies Philip sent to them, when the decree said "to administer the oaths to the officials in the cities". For the oaths sworn by the allies of Philip see oath id 3782. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Chians as allies, observing that they were autonomous and contributed ships. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
impact: Demosthenes persuaded the Athenians not to make peace
statement:
[That if anyone said we must make peace with Philip he would grab him by the hair and haul him off to prison]
 εἴ τις ἐρεῖ ὡς χρὴ πρὸς Φίλιππον εἰρήνην ποιήσασθαι, ἀπάξειν εἰς τὸ δεσμωτήριον ἐπιλαβόμενος τῶν τριχῶν,
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that when Demosthenes suspected that the Boeotians would make peace with Philip in exchange for money, and feared that he would be left out of the proceedings (and not receive money), he tried to influence the boeotarchs who were in Athens at the time by swearing in the Assembly that he would arrest anyone who spoke in favour of peace. 
Aeschines argues that Demosthenes was imitating the policy of Cleophon "who, we are told, brought the city to ruin during the war against Sparta". 
Aeschines portrays Demosthenes as a perjurer for saying this, and sarcastically suggests that Phidias' statue of Athena was created to serve Demosthenes' profiteering and perjury.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.  And they will not recall grievances, nor let anyone else persuade them to do so, but will vote according to the established laws]
remarks:
Andocides cites the oaths of reconciliation (see oath id 2355) as well as the oath of the bouleutai (see oath id 2356) and the Heliastic oath as evidence that the Athenians should not remember past grievances with regard to his own case. Andocides quotes from the dikasts' oath: "I will not recall grievances nor will I do so at another's bidding, but I will vote according to the established laws". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.  This particular clause is not found in the text of the oath as given there (Dem. 24.149-151); it was evidently added to the oath in 403, and may have been dropped a generation or so later when it was felt to be no longer relevant.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement: n/a
remarks: This is an abstract discussion of an alliance made, in a time of stasis, between an oligarchic or democratic faction and an external state of the same political type. In the circumstances imagined, such an alliance would almost certainly need to be buttressed by oaths.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he is really going to sit on something worth ten minas and shit]
  Ἔπειτ’ ἐπὶ δεκάμνῳ χεσεῖ καθήμενος; 
  {ΤΡ.}  Ἔγωγε νὴ Δί’
remarks: He does not swear that he is going to buy the cuirass, only that he is going to shit in it – and though he does not actually do so, this is because (like Blepyrus at Eccl. 372, see oath id 798) he is interrupted.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he has not received what the other generals have received, not even as much as some of the lochagoi]
 συνεπόμνυμι μηδὲ ἃ οἱ ἄλλοι στρατηγοὶ ἔλαβον εἰληφέναι, μὴ τοίνυν μηδὲ ὅσα τῶν λοχαγῶν ἔνιοι.
remarks: Xenophon continues defending himself against the allegation that he had received what belongs to the soldiers by saying, "to surprise you even more, I swear that I have not even received what the other generals have received, indeed not as much as some of the lochagoi".

author: Plato
title: Charmides
statement:
[That he doesn’t think there is a kind of visual faculty that cannot see or distinguish objects, colours, etc., but can only see itself and other visual faculties, and distinguish what is and is not a visual faculty]
 ἐννόει γὰρ εἴ σοι δοκεῖ ὄψις τις εἶναι, ἣ ὧν μὲν αἱ ἄλλαι ὄψεις εἰσίν, οὐκ ἔστιν τούτων ὄψις, ἑαυτῆς δὲ καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ὄψεων ὄψις ἐστὶν καὶ μὴ ὄψεων ὡσαύτως,  καὶ χρῶμα μὲν ὁρᾷ οὐδὲν ὄψις οὖσα, αὑτὴν δὲ καὶ τὰς ἄλλας ὄψεις· δοκεῖ τίς σοι εἶναι τοιαύτη;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔμοιγε.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Sparta at the start of the war in 431 as all of the Peloponnesians within the Isthmus except for Argos and Achaea (Pellene was the only Achaean city allied to Sparta), Megara, the Locrians (the Opuntian and Epicnemidian), the Boeotians, Phocians, the Ambraciots, the Leucadians and Anactorians. 
de Ste Croix speculates that the Boeotians joined the Peloponnesian League between 446 and 431. They must have done so after the battle of Coronea in 446, but before the outbreak of the war in 431. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement: [That Meidias was unable to attend the arbitration due to illness or absence from Attica]
remarks:
Demosthenes states that when the day of judgement came, and all the legal possibilities were now exhausted - hypomosiai and paragraphai - Straton the arbitrator asked him to postpone the arbitration until the next day. But when Demosthenes did not agree to this, and Meidias did not appear, Straton was forced to decide the case in favour of Demosthenes. 
Straton is classified as mature/old because he was 59 at the beginning of the year and may or may not have turned 60 by the time in question.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_refused: War will continue as it is
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Agamemnon rouses the Argives back into battle, encouraging them by saying that the Trojans have broken their oaths, and listing again the consequences for the oath-breakers: vultures will feed on Trojan flesh, and their wives and children will be shipped to Greece. This is the same oath as id 318.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
impact: Democedes treated Atossa; Atossa provided what Democedes wanted in return
statement:
[That she would give him whatever he asked]
 Ὁ δὲ φὰς ὑγιέα ποιήσειν ἐξορκοῖ μιν ἦ μέν οἱ ἀντυπουργήσειν ἐκείνην τοῦτο τὸ ἂν αὐτῆς δεηθῇ
remarks:
Herodotus states that Atossa needed medical treatment for her breasts which Democedes promised to provide if she swore an oath to give him whatever he asked.  
Democedes promised that he would not ask for anything shameful.  
In accordance with her oath Atossa did as Democedes asked and encouraged Darius to send Democedes as a spy to Greece, which enabled him to escape and return to his homeland.

title: IG XII Supplement
work_date: late fifth or early fourth century
date: Late fifth or early fourth century (424 to 375)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text seems to be a law regarding what happens when the officials known as the karpologoi do not administer an oath ([- - - καρπο]λόγοι μὴ ὁρκώσαντες - - - ). 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 36.792.

author: Philip of Macedon
title: Letter to the Athenians
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Philip criticises the Athenians because their general Callias has captured cities on the Pagasaean gulf even though the Athenians had sworn them to him, and they were allied to him (see also oath id 3288). 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Aristotle quotes Archilochus fr. 122.1 (see oath id 1377) where it is said that nothing can be sworn to be impossible.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he has heard what Gobryas has said]
 καὶ ὁ Κῦρος εἶπεν· Ἤκουσας, ὦ Ὑστάσπα, Γωβρύου τὸ ῥῆμα; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη·

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
The defendant argues that the laws, preliminary oaths (διωμοσίαι), cut-pieces and proclamations and all the other things that are done for homicide trials are very different from the proceedings in other trials, because it is imperative that the facts at issue can be verified because there is so much at stake. 
This passage is almost identical to Antiphon 5.88 (see oath id 2475). The difference between 6.6 and 5.88 is of course that this time we really are in a proper homicide trial!

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1a
statement:
[That, when making laws, the assembly presumes it is right to do good, not evil]
 Πότερον δὲ τἀγαθὰ νομίσαν δεῖν ποιεῖν ἢ τὰ κακά; Τἀγαθὰ νὴ Δία, φάναι, ὦ μειράκιον, τὰ δὲ κακὰ οὔ

author: Aristophanes
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: unknown
remarks: This single word (empedorkein) is a reference to abiding by one's oath (euorkein) but includes a pun on the word "fetters". It may refer either to a specific oath or a be a more general discussion.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
statement:
[That he will speak and draft a motion about which the Athenians can vote if they wish]
 ἐγὼ νὴ Δί’ ἐρῶ, καὶ γράψω δέ, ὥστ’ ἂν βούλησθε χειροτονήσετε.
remarks: Demosthenes goes on to suggest that the Athenians should set aside funds for a large military force.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would obey the Athenians, and be just and guileless in their dealings with them]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Selymbria. 
The agreement between the Athenians and the Selymbrians was to be set up in a temple of a god or goddess whose name is lost.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: They will not have to give evidence
if_refused: They will have to give evidence
statement: [That they did not know that the facts, to which they had been called to testify, were true]
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that he caught Aeschines coming out of Philip's tent at Pherae, and that Aeschines stayed behind with Philip for a day and a night after the other Athenian ambassadors departed. 
He says that he will call the other ambassadors to either testify or to take the exomosia. He says that if they take the exomosia he will prove that they are committing perjury.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That it is perhaps the case that if the primary and secondary elements of language are strung together at random, the results will be bad] 
 μᾶλλον δὲ οὐχ ἡμεῖς, ἀλλὰ λέγων ἐξηνέχθην. συνέθεσαν μὲν γὰρ οὕτως ᾗπερ σύγκειται οἱ παλαιοί· ἡμᾶς δὲ δεῖ, εἴπερ τεχνικῶς ἐπιστησόμεθα σκοπεῖσθαι αὐτὰ πάντα,  οὕτω διελομένους, εἴτε κατὰ τρόπον τά τε πρῶτα ὀνόματα κεῖται καὶ τὰ ὕστερα εἴτε μή, οὕτω θεᾶσθαι· ἄλλως δὲ συνείρειν μὴ φαῦλον ᾖ καὶ οὐ καθ’ ὁδόν, ὦ φίλε Ἑρμόγενες. {ΕΡΜ.} Ἴσως νὴ Δί’, ὦ Σώκρατες.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
swearer: Representatives; Alcetas; Jason of Pherae; Representatives of various poleis
swearee: Representatives; Alcetas; Jason of Pherae; Representatives of various poleis
if_refused: There would not be any alliance(s)
remarks:
Apollodorus refers to Alcetas and Jason as allies of the Athenians, and says that they spoke on behalf of Timotheus at his trial in 373/2. 
Alcetas and his son Neoptolemus are named as allies of Athens at lines 109-110 of IG II(2) 43. The name on the next line was deliberately erased in antiquity. The name of Jason has often been restored in this rasura. Cf. Rhodes and Osborne, Greek Historical Inscriptions 404-323 B.C., (Oxford 2003), p105. 
For other references to the Second Athenian League see oath id 2974.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
remarks: Euelpides explains that he did not let the crow go - rather, it flew away.  This is, in fact, another way of saying the same thing, but Peisetaerus (ironically?) goes along with the pretence that there is a difference.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Xenophon states that when Autophradates was besieging Ariobarzanes, an ally of Sparta, he fled due to fear of Agesilaus who came as an envoy.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That (he's determined) Socrates won't deceive him]
  μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ ψεύσει γέ με·
remarks: Socrates has just said that Strepsiades will become "fine, sieved meal" (i.e. a clever, subtle orator), but he is simultaneously sprinkling wheat- or barley-meal over Strepsiades, and Strepsiades professes to suspect that that is all he is referring to.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, after the Spartans managed to send a force of hoplites to bolster Epidaurus against the forthcoming Argive attack in the following summer, the Argives sent envoys to Athens to complain that the Athenians had permitted the Spartans to go past their territory by sea (i.e. to sail past Aegina), which they claimed was a violation of the clause in their treaty that they would not allow enemies to pass through their territory. 
The Argives added that they would feel aggrieved unless they should bring the Messenians and helots to Pylos to annoy the Spartans. 
As a result of this Alcibiades convinced the Athenians to inscribe at the bottom of the Laconian stele that the Spartans had not kept their oaths (i.e. for the Peace of Nicias) and took a force of Messenian helots to ravage Pylos . 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement: [That they would kill, by word and deed and vote and their own hand, if they could, anyone who overthrows the democracy at Athens and anyone who holds any office in the future after democracy has been overthrown, and anyone who sets himself up to be tyrant or helps set up a tyrant. And if anyone else kills the man, they would consider him pure in the eyes of both gods and spirits, because he has killed an enemy of the Athenians, and they would sell all the property of the dead man and give half to the killer, and would not hold any back. And if anyone dies in killing or attempting to kill any such man, they would care for both him and his children, just as for Harmodius and Aristogeiton and their descendants. And they declare null and void all oaths that have been sworn at Athens or in the camp or anywhere else against the people of Athens]
remarks:
Lycurgus tells the jurors that they have sworn in the decree of Demphantos to "to kill the man who betrays his country, by word, deed, hand or vote". He tells them that he uses the word "you" because they must not think that as heirs to the riches bequeathed by their ancestors they can renounce their share in the oaths and pledges their fathers gave as security to the gods. 
See also oath id 2358.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
