statement:
[That if there is a difficulty about his father Aristogeiton will appeal to the sobriety and respectability of his own life]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία, εἰ ταῦτ’ ἐστὶν αὐτῷ δυσχερῆ τὰ περὶ τὸν πατέρα, εἰς τὸν ἑαυτοῦ βίον καταφεύξεται ὡς σώφρονα καὶ μέτριον.
remarks: The speaker is being ironic.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text indicates that Heracleides of Clazomenae was honoured for having cooperated with Athenian presbeis to the King of Persia and assisting in the conclusion of "the treaty with the King" (τὰσπονδὰς [τὰς πρὸς βασιλέα]). See also oath id 2424. 
It has also been suggested that the treaty was concluded with Seuthes or Medocus of Thrace in the 380s.  
This inscription has also been published as IG II(2) 8.

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That four times is not the same as twice]
 Διπλάσιον οὖν ἐστιν τὸ τετράκις τοσοῦτον; {—ΠΑΙ.} Οὐ μὰ Δία.
remarks: Socrates is attempting to prove that it is possible to recollect truths the soul knew before birth by testing an uneducated slave boy on matters of geometry. Cf. oath id 3142.

author: Epicharmus
title: Odysseus Automolos
statement:
[That the speaker (Odysseus?) was in cahoots with the Achaeans and had committed treason against the pig]
 δέλφακά τε τῶν γειτόνων
τοῖς Ἐλευσινίοις φυλάσσων δαιμονίως ἀπώλεσα,
οὐχ ἑκών· καὶ ταῦτα δή με συμβολατεύειν ἔφα
τοῖς Ἀχαιοῖσιν προδιδόμειν τ’ ὤμνυέ με τὸν δέλφακα.
remarks: The speaker is almost certainly Odysseus.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia in Tauris
if_taken: Iphigenia will enable Pylades to escape
if_refused: Iphigenia will not enable Pylades to escape
statement:
[That he will bring Iphigenia's letter back to Argos]
 Ιφ. ὅρκον δότω μοι τάσδε πορθμεύσειν γραφὰς
  πρὸς ῎Αργος, οἷσι βούλομαι πέμψαι φίλων.
Ορ. ἦ κἀντιδώσεις τῶιδε τοὺς αὐτοὺς λόγους;
Ιφ. τί χρῆμα δράσειν ἢ τί μὴ δράσειν; λέγε.
Ορ. ἐκ γῆς ἀφήσειν μὴ θανόντα βαρβάρου.
Ιφ. δίκαιον εἶπας· πῶς γὰρ ἀγγείλειεν ἄν;
Ορ. ἦ καὶ τύραννος ταῦτα συγχωρήσεται;
Ιφ. ναί·
  πείσω σφε, καὐτὴ ναὸς ἐσβήσω σκάφος. 
Ορ. ὄμνυ· σὺ δ’ ἔξαρχ’ ὅρκον ὅστις εὐσεβής. 
Ιφ. δώσω, λέγειν χρή, τήνδε τοῖσι σοῖς φίλοις.
Πυ. τοῖς σοῖς φίλοισι γράμματ’ ἀποδώσω τάδε. 
Ιφ. κἀγὼ σὲ σώσω κυανέας ἔξω πέτρας.
Πυ. τίν’ οὖν ἐπόμνυς τοισίδ’ ὅρκιον θεῶν;
Ιφ. ῎Αρτεμιν, ἐν ἧσπερ δώμασιν τιμὰς ἔχω.
Πυ. ἐγὼ δ’ ἄνακτά γ’ οὐρανοῦ, σεμνὸν Δία.
Ιφ. εἰ δ’ ἐκλιπὼν τὸν ὅρκον ἀδικοίης ἐμέ; 
Πυ. ἄνοστος εἴην· τί δὲ σύ, μὴ σώσασά με;
Ιφ. μήποτε κατ’ ῎Αργος ζῶσ’ ἴχνος θείην ποδός.
Πυ. ἄκουε δή νυν ὃν παρήλθομεν λόγον.
Ιφ. ἀλλ’ εὐθὺς ἔστω κοινός, ἢν καλῶς ἔχηι.
Πυ. ἐξαίρετόν μοι δὸς τόδ’, ἤν τι ναῦς πάθηι 
  χἠ δέλτος ἐν κλύδωνι χρημάτων μέτα
  ἀφανὴς γένηται, σῶμα δ’ ἐκσώσω μόνον,
  τὸν ὅρκον εἶναι τόνδε μηκέτ’ ἔμπεδον.
remarks: See also Iphigenia's reciprocal oath (id 151).

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the hard thing she has in her belly is not a male child at all (but something hollow and metal)]
  Τί τοῦτ’ ἔχεις τὸ σκληρόν;
{ΓΥ. Γʹ}  Ἄρρεν παιδίον.  
{ΛΥ.} Μὰ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην οὐ σύ γ’ ἀλλ’ ἢ χαλκίον
  ἔχειν τι φαίνει κοῖλον· εἴσομαι δ’ ἐγώ.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would defend each other, and that they would respect the division of Cotys' former kingdom and not attempt to change the settlement by force, and that the Athenians would receive back their possessions ]
 εἶναι μὲν τὴν ἀρχὴν κοινὴν τῆς Θρᾴκης εἰς τρεῖς διῃρημένην, πάντας δ’ ὑμῖν ἀποδοῦναι τὴν χώραν
remarks:
Euthycles states that Athenodorus the Athenian general made an an alliance with Berisades and Amadocus, and compelled Cersobleptes to take part in a sworn agreement with the Athenians and the other Thracian princes that the kingdom of Thrace should be held in common and divided between the three, and that they should all restore to the Athenians their territory i.e. Cardia. 
However, when the Athenians sent only Chabrias with one ship to receive the surrender of Cardia, Charidemus persuaded Cersobleptes to repudiate the agreement, and a new agreement (less favourable to Athens) was drawn up. 
The Athenians later sent ten ambassadors to Cersobleptes who were to force him to renew his oath, or accept the oaths of Berisades and Amadocus, and join them in making war on Cersobleptes. 
According to Euthycles, the ambassadors took so long to get to Thrace that a relief expedition was sent, and a new agreement was made. 
See also oath id 458.

author: Eupolis
title: Baptai
statement:
[That what the swearer is suffering is unholy]
 ἀνόσια πάσχω ταῦτα ναὶ μὰ τὰς Νύμφας.
remarks: Cf. also the response at oath id 1470.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates argues that the Athenians should not only make peace with the Chians, Rhodians and Byzantines in 355, but also with "all men", and not merely accept the terms of the peace drawn up by "certain men" (i.e. Eubulus), but also the terms entered into with the King of Persia (i.e. the so-called King's Peace). 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That Demos' ears used to open up like a parasol and then close again]
  Τὰ δ᾽  ὦτά γ᾽ ἄν σου νὴ Δί’, ἐξεπετάννυτο
  ὥσπερ σκιάδειον καὶ πάλιν ξυνήγετο.
remarks: Sommerstein explains the statement ad 1347-8: "i.e. [he] would only listen to those orators who said what [he] wanted to hear".

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Xenophon states that Lysander attacked Cedriae because it was an ally of Athens. 
Lysander captured the city and enslaved the inhabitants. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That so long as the appetite holds out, the man who dines at the costlier feast has more pleasure than he who is served with a cheaper meal]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σιμωνίδης, ὅσον ἂν χρόνον ἡ ψυχὴ προσίηται, τοῦτον πολὺ μᾶλλον ἥδονται οἱ ταῖς πολυτελεστέραις παρασκευαῖς τρεφόμενοι τῶν τὰ εὐτελέστερα παρατιθεμένων.
remarks: Simonides is responding to Hiero's suggestion that the greater the number of superfluous dishes at a feast, the sooner the diner will feel full and the sooner his feelings of pleasure will abate.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he cannot name any type of life that looks with scorn on political office other than the life of true philosophers]
 Ἔχεις οὖν, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, βίον ἄλλον τινὰ πολιτικῶν ἀρχῶν καταφρονοῦντα ἢ τὸν τῆς ἀληθινῆς φιλοσοφίας; Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: Emphasises his agreement with Araspas' statement
statement:
[That Araspas still goes about his duties and practices horsemanship even though he has seen the beautiful woman]
 ἐγὼ γοῦν, ἔφη, ταύτην ἑωρακὼς καὶ πάνυ καλῆς δοξάσης μοι εἶναι ὅμως καὶ παρὰ σοί εἰμι καὶ ἱππεύω καὶ τἆλλα τὰ ἐμοὶ προσήκοντα ἀποτελῶ. Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος·
remarks: Cf. oath ids 2400 and 2401 for context.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That they should train the future ruler in the habit of conducting urgent business before he satisfies his hunger]
 Τὸ οὖν προαιρεῖσθαι τὸ κατεπεῖγον μᾶλλον πράττειν ἢ τῇ γαστρὶ χαρίζεσθαι πότερον ἂν αὐτῶν ἐθίζοιμεν; Τὸν εἰς τὸ ἄρχειν, ἔφη, νὴ Δία
remarks: The context is the hypothetical training of two youths, one to be fit for ruling, the other to never be disposed to put himself forward.

author: Demosthenes
title: Olynthiac 3
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace]
remarks:
Demosthenes states that the Athenians had "negotiated a peace with the Olynthians that hampered Philip sorely". 
Libanius in his Hypothesis to Olynthiac 1 notes that the Olynthians waited for a time when Philip was abroad to send ambassadors to Athens to negotiate a peace. Hammond, A History of Macedonia, Volume 2, p298, argues that this can be best placed in 352 when Philip was preoccupied in Thessaly.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [That he had not injured Callippus when he gave Cephisiades the money Lycon had deposited with him, after he had promised that he would not pay it out without Callippus' consent]
remarks:
Apollodorus tells the jurors that some of Callippus' friends have been so audacious that they have testifed that Callippus challenged Pasion to swear an oath before Lysitheides the arbitrator, and that Pasion refused to swear. 
Apollodorus calls forward witnesses to testify that these men are lying, and that Callippus did not at any time challenge  Pasion to swear an oath. 
In view of the notorious difficulty of proving a negative, it is perhaps worth mentioning that Apollodorus claims to have witnesses to every meeting that ever took place between Pasion and Callippus.  If believed, this will add considerable credibility to his claim that no oath-challenge was ever made.

author: Isocrates
title: To Philip
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Isocrates states that Philip has drawn the Thessalians into alliance with him by his benefactions. 
Diod. 16.14.2 states that when the Aleuadae fought against the tyrants in Thessaly they gained Philip as an ally, and that Philip entered Thessaly and overthrew the tyrants. Diodorus states that because Philip showed such goodwill to the Thessalians they became not only his allies, but also allies to his son Alexander. 
See also oath id 3259, 3288, 3724, 3825.

author: Choerilus
title: Persica
statement: n/a
remarks: This fragment contains the remark that it is not expedient to swear either justly or unjustly. For advice against taking oaths cf. oath id 1369.

author: Thucydides
title: History
impact: Sparta and Argos remained at peace for thirty years
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
3. Neither side was to make an alliance with an enemy of the other]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that the Argives resolved to send envoys around Greece to negotiate alliances with any of the Greeks except the Spartans and the Athenians, because they thought war with Sparta was imminent due to the fact that the peace treaty was on the point of expiring. 
See also oath id 1683.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That Demosthenes was guilty of misconduct while in office]
 νὴ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἀδίκως ἦρξα.
remarks: Demosthenes has argued that he was awarded a crown for his donations (which were not subject to audit) and not for his conduct in office (which was), and adds that for the latter he has in any case undergone and passed his audit.  To this Aeschines is represented as retorting "Yes, but you committed misconduct in office", to which Demosthenes replies "If so, why didn’t you accuse me at the time?"

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement: [That Euxitheus' father Thucritus was an Athenian and related to them]
remarks: Euxitheus points out that the witnesses who testified on his behalf could inherit his property if he was illegitimate or an alien. He asks why they would have chosen to run the risk of a suit for false witness and to perjure themselves for a small payment, rather than to take everything, risk free, and without calling down destruction upon themselves.

author: Lysias
title: On a wound by premeditation
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had not wounded with the intent to kill]
remarks:
The defendant tells the jurors that his statement is true, and that it could be verified by Philinus and Diocles, but it is not possible for them to testify because they have not taken the diomosia concerning the charge laid against him, as was necessary in trials held before the Areopagus Council. 
Presumably the reason why Philinus and Diocles have not sworn is that they have no personal knowledge of whether or not the defendant had wounded his accuser.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That they are not innovating in preferring Apollo and the instruments of Apollo to Marsyas and his instruments]
 Οὐδέν γε, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, καινὸν ποιοῦμεν, ὦ φίλε, κρίνοντες τὸν Ἀπόλλω καὶ τὰ τοῦ Ἀπόλλωνος ὄργανα πρὸ Μαρσύου τε καὶ τῶν ἐκείνου ὀργάνων.  Μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὔ μοι φαινόμεθα.
remarks: Traditionally, Marsyas, a satyr and inventor of the aulos, had challenged Apollo on his kithara to a competition and lost.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That his servants do not complain when they use the lukewarm water for both drinking and washing]
 Ἆρ’ οὖν, ἔφη, καὶ οἱ οἰκέται σου ἄχθονται πίνοντές τε αὐτὸ καὶ λούμενοι αὐτῷ; Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη·

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
[That they would not harbour any grudges for anything that is past, nor would they kill any of the Ceans - - -]
[οὐ μν]ησικακ[ήσω τῶν παρεληλυθότων ὀδενός, οὐδὲ ἀποκτενῶ Κεί]ων ὀδέ[να - - -]
remarks:
This inscription records a new agreement between Athens and the poleis on Ceos. 
The statement is very fragmentary.  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians and the allies see oath id 422.  
For the oath of the rest of the Ceans see oath id 424.  
For the earlier agreement see oath id 431, 443. See also oath id 520, 521.

author: Alexis
title: Eisoikizomenos
statement:
[That someone dipped the four pigeons, not each into the same perfume, but each into their own]
 ἀλλὰ τέτταρας 
περιστερὰς ἀφῆκεν ἀποβεβαμμένας
εἰς οὐχὶ ταὐτὸν μὰ Δία τὴν αὐτὴν μύρον, 
ἰδίῳ δ’ ἑκάστην.
remarks: The translation of the statement is based on Arnott's interpretation (see further ad 4-5). Arnott remarks ad loc. that the speaker "is identified as a miles gloriosus, possibly (like Meineke) by a comparison with Antiphanes fr. 200, from Stratiotes, which describes a banquet given by the king of Cyprus in Paphos (n.b. pigeons were associated with Aphrodite). Arnott  further comments (ad 5) that "the oath emphasises, although here it is not placed next to, the preceding negative οὐχὶ".

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_taken: There will be peace for thirty years
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: The Peace-terms here are personified in comic fashion in the form of two girls.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That they won't get away with their long-standing conspiracy against the people]
  Οὔτοι μὰ τοὺς δώδεκα θεοὺς χαιρήσετον,
  ὁτιὴ ’πὶ τῷ δήμῳ ξυνόμνυτον πάλαι.
remarks: It should be noted that Paphlagon's character here is a caricature of Cleon. See also oath id 975 on the sworn conspiracy mentioned here.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That not one of those who knows how to ride horses knew before he learned]
 μὰ Δί’ οὐδὲ γὰρ τούτων τῶν ἐπισταμένων νῦν πρὶν μαθεῖν οὐδεὶς ἠπίστατο.
remarks: Cyrus is considering teaching his men to ride in order for the Persians to have a superior cavalry.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he thinks a cutting would take root better if planted sideways under the earth like an L shape [lit. a gamma on its back] (rather than being planted upright)]
 Πότερα δὲ ὅλον τὸ κλῆμα ὀρθὸν τιθεὶς πρὸς τὸν οὐρανὸν βλέπον ἡγῇ μᾶλλον ἂν ῥιζοῦσθαι αὐτὸ ἢ καὶ πλάγιόν τι ὑπὸ τῇ ὑποβεβλημένῃ γῇ θείης ἄν, ὥστε κεῖσθαι ὥσπερ γάμμα ὕπτιον; Οὕτω νὴ Δία·

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
statement:
[That, as long as the king kept his oath, they would never attack the monarchy nor allow others to do so;  and that they would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
 βασιλεῖαι τρεῖς βασιλευομέναις πόλεσιν τριτταῖς ὤμοσαν ἀλλήλαις ἑκάτεραι, κατὰ νόμους οὓς ἔθεντο τοῦ τε ἄρχειν καὶ ἄρχεσθαι κοινούς, οἱ μὲν μὴ βιαιοτέραν τὴν ἀρχὴν ποιήσεσθαι προϊόντος τοῦ χρόνου καὶ γένους, οἱ δέ, ταῦτα ἐμπεδούντων τῶν ἀρχόντων, μήτε αὐτοὶ τὰς βασιλείας ποτὲ καταλύσειν μήτ’ ἐπιτρέψειν ἐπιχειροῦσιν ἑτέροις, βοηθήσειν δὲ βασιλῆς τε βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις καὶ δήμοις, καὶ δῆμοι δήμοις καὶ βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις.
remarks: The discussion concerns the time in which Temenus was King of Argos, Cresphontes was king of Messene and Procles and Eurysthenes were kings of Sparta, when the area was first divided into the three states of Argos, Sparta and Messene. The king swears a reciprocal oath- see oath id 2680. The kings and people of Sparta and Messene do the same- see oath ids 2678-9 and 2682-3. The kings do not break their oath, but they subsequently disagree about it- see oath ids 2684-6.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
 ἐμμενῶ τῇ ξυμμαχίᾳ κατὰ τὰ ξυγκείμενα δικαίως καὶ ἀβλαβῶς καὶ ἀδόλως, καὶ οὐ παραβήσομαι τέχνῃ οὐδὲ μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ.
remarks:
Thucydides refers here to the so-called Argive alliance. He indicates that each city will swear the oath that is most binding in their land. The Athenians were to swear on behalf of their allies, whereas the Argives, Mantineans, Eleans, and their allies were to swear individually by state. 
It is stipulated that for the renewal of the oath the Athenians will travel to Elis, Mantinea, and Argos, thirty days before the Olympic games, and the Argives, Eleans and Mantineans will travel to Athens ten days before the Great Panathenaea. 
Thucydides states that the Corinthians did not join (literally 'join in swearing') this offensive and defensive alliance, but were content with their first alliance with Argos (see oath id 1698) which was defensive only. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Chians and Erythraeans and Tissaphernes the Persian satrap sent envoys to Sparta to try to convince the Spartans to come to Asia. 
The Spartans sent a certain Phrynis, one of the perioeci, to Chios to see whether the Chians had as many ships as they claimed. 
When Phrynis returned the Spartans voted to make an alliance with the Chians and Erythraeans. 
See also oath id 1889, 2993, 3112.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
impact: Emphasises the statement; see also remarks.
statement:
[That he is going to be careful in case the women piss on him]
 ἃς ἐγὼ φυλάξομαι, 
  νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ, μὴ κατουρήσωσί μου.
remarks: Sommerstein comments ad 832, that the Dissident is worried that the women will treat him and all men "with arrogant contempt, in revenge for the way men have so long treated them… The speaker's fears are strikingly belied, before he has said another word, by the Heraldess' announcement inviting all male citizens to feast".

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that the Thirty Years' Peace (αἱ τριακοντούτεις σπονδαὶ) had remained unbroken for 14 years, but was broken in the 15th year when the Thebans attacked Plataea.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: The suitors laugh at Telemachus in a divinely-driven mania
statement:
[That he is not delaying his mother's marriage, but he urges her to marry whomever she wants, and offers them countless gifts]
 “οὐ μὰ Ζῆν’, Ἀγέλαε, καὶ ἄλγεα πατρὸς ἐμοῖο, 
ὅς που τῆλ’ Ἰθάκης ἢ ἔφθιται ἢ ἀλάληται, 
οὔ τι διατρίβω μητρὸς γάμον, ἀλλὰ κελεύω
γήμασθ’ ᾧ κ’ ἐθέλῃ, ποτὶ δ’ ἄσπετα δῶρα δίδωμι·
remarks: This is the only instance in the Odyssey where the oath formula "ma" is used. It is also the only volunteered oath which bears no relation to the homecoming of Odysseus.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he does not believe a youngster like Cleinias came up with the arguments that Socrates has reported (concerning seeking the art which will make them blessed)]
 Τί λέγεις σύ, ὦ Σώκρατες; ἐκεῖνο τὸ μειράκιον τοιαῦτ’ ἐφθέγξατο;  {ΣΩ.} Οὐκ οἴει, ὦ Κρίτων;  {ΚΡ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐ μέντοι
remarks: Cf. oath id 3091 where it is decided that the words must have been spoken by a higher power.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
if_taken: He will be part of a conspiracy
if_refused: He will not be part of a conspiracy
statement: [That he will be party to the conspiracy]
remarks: Here Philocleon accuses Labes of being a conspirator. See remarks on ids 1079, 1087, 1089, 1090 for further information on notions of conpiracies in this play.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
if_taken: The Nurse will divulge her secret
if_refused: The Nurse will not divulge her secret
impact: Hippolytus is bound against his will and will later be unable to clear his name
statement: [That he will not reveal what he has been told]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 125.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: The Greeks who fought at Plataea
swearee: The Greeks who fought at Plataea
statement: [That they would protect Plataea should anyone attack]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Spartans deciding the fate of Plataea determined that the Thebans were right to sugest that they should consider whether they had received any service from the Plataeans when deciding their fate. 
The Spartans argued that they had invited the Plataeans to be neutral according to the treaty of Pausanias after the defeat of the Medes  (the Spartan position was that this treaty required the Plataeans to join in maintaining the freedom of the other Greek states taking part in it, but they would be content for Plataea to remain neutral), and had offered them the same conditions before the blockade. Since this offer had been refused, the Spartans were released from this treaty. 
See also oath id 1598.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Stephanus 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Apollodorus urges the jurors to punish Stephanus in the interest of the laws and the oaths they have sworn. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That Socrates should be so bold as to describe what kind of thing knowing is]
 βούλει τολμήσω εἰπεῖν οἷόν ἐστι τὸ ἐπίστασθαι; φαίνεται γάρ μοι προὔργου τι ἂν γενέσθαι. {ΘΕΑΙ.} Τόλμα τοίνυν νὴ Δία.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Syracusans were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Syracusans while they recovered their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that one day after the Athenians defeated the Syracusans in battle outside the city they gave back the Syracusan dead under a truce (ὑποσπόνδους ).

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: Between 554 and 546 but probably after 550 (554 to 546)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Herodotus states that when Croesus was at war with Cyrus of Persia, he marched away to Sardis, intending to ask for help from the Egyptians "in accordance with the sworn agreement" (κατὰ τὸ ὅρκιον ). Herodotus then adds that Croesus had also made an alliance with Labynetus of Babylon.  
For the alliance between Croesus and Amasis see oath id 1278.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That if his opponents are asserting that so long as Philip keeps his hands off Athens and the Piraeus, he is not doing us any wrong nor waging war against us, it is logical that they are opposed to Athens preparing for war]
 πλὴν εἰ τοῦτο λέγουσι νὴ Δί’, ὡς, ἂν ἀπέχηται τῆς Ἀττικῆς καὶ τοῦ Πειραιῶς Φίλιππος, οὔτ’ ἀδικεῖ τὴν πόλιν οὔτε ποιεῖ πόλεμον.
remarks: "It is imperative," says Dem. in effect, "that we should defend ourselves against the aggressor – unless, indeed, my opponents are asserting that so long as Philip keeps his hands off Athens and the Peiraeus, he is not doing us any wrong nor waging war against us."  The statement is then, roughly:  If Demosthenes’ opponents are asserting that  [as above], it is logical that they are opposed to Athens preparing for war.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, Euryptolemus argued before the assembly that if the Athenians decided to try the Arginusae generals separately they would be trying them in accordance with the law, piously, and according to their oaths i.e. the oath sworn by the dikastai. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Croesus' object in making his line as long as possible is to use the extra length to outflank and surround Cyrus’ army]
 ἐβούλετο γὰρ ὅτι πλεῖστον ὑπερφαλαγγῆσαι τοῦ σοῦ στρατεύματος. Πρὸς τί δή, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, τοῦτο ἐπιθυμῶν; Ὡς ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, τῷ περιττῷ κυκλωσόμενος.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he even knows of tyrants (tyrannoi) who were driven to crime by (what they see as) lack of resources (although they should have had plenty)]
 Καταμεμάθηκας οὖν ὅτι ἐνίοις μὲν πάνυ ὀλίγα ἔχουσιν οὐ μόνον ἀρκεῖ ταῦτα, ἀλλὰ καὶ περιποιοῦνται ἀπ’ αὐτῶν, ἐνίοις δὲ πάνυ πολλὰ οὐχ ἱκανά ἐστι; Καὶ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Εὐθύδημος, ὀρθῶς γάρ με ἀναμιμνῄσκεις, οἶδα καὶ τυράννους τινάς, οἳ δι’ ἔνδειαν  ὥσπερ οἱ ἀπορώτατοι ἀναγκάζονται ἀδικεῖν.
remarks: For similar expositions on a man of poor means having enough and a man of greater means finding himself in need, cf. oath ids 2064-2070.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
The defendant asks, "What accusation would they [the defendants] hesitate to bring, what court would they hesitate to mislead, what oaths would they not break after taking thirty mnas as they have from the Poristai, the Poleitai, the Practores and the clerks attached to them to bring me to court? And after swearing these oaths, all because during my prytany I learned of their scandalous malpractices, brought them before the boule, and showed that an inquiry should be instituted". 
This line of thought is repeated in section 51 (see oath id 2512 and 2513).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes has the document recording the alliance between Athens and Phocis read to the jurors. He says that "friendship, alliance, support" were what the Phocians were expecting from Athens. 
Cf. Diodorus 16.27.5.

author: Lysias
title: For Polystratus
if_taken: He could draw up the register
if_refused: He could not draw up the register
statement: [? That he would ensure a fair selection]
remarks:
Polystratus' son argues that at the time of the oligarchic coup, Polystratus was unwilling to take the oath and to draw up the list of the Five Thousand; however, Polystratus was compelled to do so. When he had taken the oath, after sitting in the council for only eight days, he took ship to Eretria and proved his bravery in the naval battles there. 
See also oath id 1781.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Herodotus states that when Polycrates made himself ruler of all Samos he agreed to be friends with Amasis the king of Egypt. 
Herodotus states at 3.43 that Amasis wrote to Polycrates renouncing his friendship on the grounds that he knew a great disaster would befall Polycrates and he did not wish to have to lament the misfortune of a friend when this happened.

title: IG XII 5
statement:
[That if he sees anyone cutting down timber in excess of what is allowed he will denounce him to the theoroi]
 [ἤ]ν τινα ἴδηι κόπτοντα πὰρ τ[ὰ] ἐκγινόμενα, κατερ[ε̃]ν, πρὸς τ[ὸ]ς θεορός.
remarks: This decree is part of the regulations for the administration of a sacred grove. The law is designed to ensure that no one cuts down more timber than is  allowed.

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Liberty of the Rhodians
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Demosthenes asks why there is no man in Byzantium seeking to dissuade his countrymen from seizing Chalcedon which belongs to the King, or from taking Selymbria, making it tributary to them, and including it in Byzantine territory, contrary to the oaths and agreements which guarantee the autonomy of those cities i.e. the oaths of the King's Peace. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aeschylus
title: Theoroi
statement: unknown
remarks: Since the curse in line 2 is second-person, it cannot have anything to do with the oath mentioned in line 1. The addressee has apparently taken an oath of some sort (it might be an athlete's oath, but we can't tell) and the speaker (Dionysus?) apparently curses him for having done so.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That in very truth and guilelessly he would negotiate the peace]
 ἦ μὴν πράξειν ἀδόλως τὴν εἰρήνην
remarks:
At Ephesus, Tissaphernes sent to Agesilaus and asked him with what intent he had come to Asia Minor. Agesilaus answered, "that the cities in Asia shall be independent, as are those in our part of Greece." Tissaphernes replied, "then if you are willing to make a truce until I can send to the King, I think you could accomplish this object and, if you should so desire, sail back home."  
Agesilaus responded, "indeed I should so desire, if I could but think that I was not being deceived by you."  
Tissaphernes reponded to this, "but it is possible for you to receive a guarantee on this point, that in very truth and guilelessly, if you follow this course, we will do no harm to any part of your domain during the truce."  
After this agreement had been reached, Tissaphernes swore an oath to the representatives who were sent to him, that in very truth and  guilelessly he would negotiate the peace, and they swore in turn on behalf of Agesilaus to Tissaphernes that in very truth, if he did this, Agesilaus would steadfastly observe the truce (see oath id 1917).  
Xenophon observes that Tissaphernes straightway violated the oaths which he had sworn; for instead of keeping peace he sent to the King for a large army in addition to that which he had before. But Agesilaus, though he was aware of this, nevertheless continued to abide by the truce. 
For the consequences of breach see 3.4.25 where Tithraustes says to Agesilaus, "the man who caused these troubles both to you and to us has got his deserts" after the King beheaded Tissaphernes in 395.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That Socrates has not spoken too earnestly – at least, not too earnestly for Glaucon]
 Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὔκουν ὥς γ’ ἐμοὶ ἀκροατῇ.

title: Syll (3)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This decree was probably set up not long after Alexander the Great passed through the area. Nine citizens were elected to act as inspectors to find out whether any public land had been occupied illegally and to impose fines. After the inspection was carried out, eleven citizens were to be elected from among the citizens who did not possess any public land. Eight of the eleven would serve as judges of those accused of owning public land illegally, and the remaining three would serve as advocates.  
The text indicates that "that judges and advocates were to swear by Artemis according to the law" (ὀμόσαι δὲ τοὺς δικαστὰς κ̣αὶ τοὺς συνηγόρους τὴν Ἄρτεμιν κατὰ τὸν νόμον). 
For the oath of the advocates see oath id 924.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That his skin is not the basis of his pride]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἐπὶ τούτῳ μέγα φρονῶ.
remarks: This is a response by the showman to Socrates' joke about him (see oath id 2268).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That his cloak has plenty of holes in it]
 Διὰ τοῦ τριβωνίου·  
  ὀπὰς γὰρ εἶχεν οὐκ ὀλίγας μὰ τὸν Δία.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Hypereides imagines the charges that might have been brought against him and Demosthenes if they had been arrested and put on trial before Philip; one of them is "that we made the Thebans your [the Athenians'] allies".
See also oath id 2670.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That they believe there exists an essence of justice]
 Τί δὲ δὴ τὰ τοιάδε, ὦ Σιμμία; φαμέν τι εἶναι δίκαιον αὐτὸ ἢ οὐδέν; Φαμὲν μέντοι νὴ Δία.

author: Plato
title: Theages
statement:
[That they should consult on which person Theages should be sent to in order to help him become a wise tyrannos]
 ἀλλὰ νῦν—ὁρᾷς; — ἐπειδὴ ἐναντίον ἐμοῦ κατείρηκέ σου, κοινῇ βουλευώμεθα ἐγώ τε καὶ σὺ ἐς τίνος ἂν αὐτὸν πέμποιμεν καὶ διὰ τὴν τίνος συνουσίαν σοφὸς ἂν γένοιτο τύραννος;  {ΔΗ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, βουλευώμεθα δῆτα
remarks: This passage follows a long series of questions by which Socrates has inveigled Theages into a position where, to avoid repudiating previous answers, he has to say that the expertise he desires is expertise in tyranny.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
impact: Provokes the Sausage-seller's retort that he looks forward to seeing Paphlagon out of his proedria
statement:
[That he will destroy the Sausage-seller]
 Ἀπολῶ σε νὴ τὴν προεδρίαν τὴν ἐκ Πύλου
remarks: Paphlagon swears by the proedria (i.e. privileged seating at the theatre and other public spectacles) that Pylos won for him. As Sommerstein notes ad 575, this honour had been conferred on Cleon after the victory of Sphacteria.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That he believes that Androtion became the victim of this arrogant, overbearing temper, not by accident, but by the visitation of the gods so that he and his associates might suffer as they deserved]
 οἶμαι δέ, νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν Ὀλύμπιον, ὦ ἄνδρες δικασταί, οὐκ ἀπὸ ταὐτομάτου τὴν ὕβριν καὶ τὴν ὑπερηφανίαν ἐπελθεῖν Ἀνδροτίωνι, ἀλλ’ ὑπὸ τῆς θεοῦ ἐπι-
πεμφθεῖσαν

author: Timocles
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: unknown
remarks: This is exactly the same fragment as oath id 1410; cf. also oath id 1510. It is quite likely that Demosthenes was himself the speaker in the play, since Timocles' plays seem to have been in important respects more like Old than New Comedy.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Aeschylus has characters in his dramas who for long periods do not utter a sound]
 Πρώτιστα μὲν γὰρ ἕνα τιν’ ἂν καθῖσεν ἐγκαλύψας, 
 Ἀχιλλέα τιν’ ἢ Νιόβην, τὸ πρόσωπον οὐχὶ δεικνύς, 
πρόσχημα τῆς τραγῳδίας, γρύζοντας οὐδὲ τουτί.
 ΔΙ.  Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ δῆθ’.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Ciron
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker asks the jurors to remember the oaths which they have sworn to judge by, and to vote as justice demands. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That as allies they would be trustworthy and just and steadfast and reliable to the Rhegians, and provide aid to them if..]
 [χσύμ]μ̣αχοι ἐσόμεθα πισ]τοὶ δίκαιοι καὶ ἰσ]χuρoὶ καὶ ἀβλαβε̃ς [ἐς ἀίδιον ῾Ρεγίνοις καὶ] ὀφελέσομεν ἐ[άν το δέονται - - - - -]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Rhegium. 
For information concerning the corresponding oath of the Rhegians (which has not been preserved)  see oath id 163.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Didorus argues that Timocrates is trying to establish the right of appeal against a verdict returned under oath, after the argument and the trial. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will not speak immediately (but will wait for the other women to arrive)]
Ἀλλ’ εἴ τι πάνυ δεῖ, ταῖς παρούσαισιν λέγε. 
{ΛΥ.} Μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ ἐπαναμείνωμεν ὀλίγου γ’ εἵνεκα

title: IG II(2)
date: Third quarter of the 4th century (349 to 325)
if_taken: He can act as a reckoner (logistes)
if_refused: He cannot act as a reckoner (logistes)
statement:
[That he would reckon what he (the official being scrutinised) appears to him to have spent]
λογιεῖσθαι ἃ ἂν μοι δοκεῖ ἀν[ηλ]ωκέναι
remarks:
This entry follows the text in Rhodes and Osborne, GHI, 63. Kirchner identified the deme as Myrrhinous. Rhodes and Osborne suggest Hagnous.  
For the oath of the scrutineer see oath id 531. For the oath of the advocates see oath id 536. See also oath id 538.  
The text indicates that the demarch will oversee the ballot for those participating in the scrutiny and will exact their oaths.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
statement:
[That as many as were Greeks and surrendered to the Persians without having been compelled to do so, in good case (i.e. if they win) should be deprived of one tenth of their possessions for the god of Delphi]
 ὅσοι τῷ Πέρσῃ ἔδοσαν σφέας αὐτοὺς Ἕλληνες ἐόντες, μὴ ἀναγκασθέντες, καταστάντων σφι εὖ τῶν πρηγμάτων, τούτους δεκατεῦσαι τῷ ἐν Δελφοῖσι θεῷ
remarks:
Herodotus states that after the Thessalians, Dolopes, Enienes, Perrhaebians, Locrians, Magnesians, Melians, Achaeans of the Phthia, Thebes and all Boeotia except Thespiae and Plataea had all paid tribute to Xerxes, all the Greeks who declared war against the barbarians entered into this sworn agreement. 
The reference to "the god of Delphi" suggests that the oath was sworn by Apollo at Delphi, but Herodotus does not explicitly state this. 
It seems that this oath was proceeded by a sworn alliance against the Persians (see oath id 1501), for this oath is presented as an afterthought:  those who had levied war against the barbarian (aorist participle) swore that all Greeks who had surrendered to the Persians (aorist indicative) without being compelled should be, etc.  In other words, the alliance was one thing, and this oath was a separate oath which happened later.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That the Chorus will be as rich as Midas if they get asses' ears]
  Ὄντως γὰρ ἔστι πλουσίοις ἡμῖν ἅπασιν εἶναι;
  {ΚΑ.}  Νὴ τοὺς θεούς, Μίδαις μὲν οὖν, ἢν ὦτ’ ὄνου λάβητε.
remarks: The Chorus are so enamoured with the idea of being wealthy that they do not react to the insult about asses' ears (which were associated with Midas in art - see Sommerstein ad 287).

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Ariadne is in love with him]
 ὥστε μὴ μόνον τὸν Διόνυσον ἀλλὰ καὶ τοὺς παρόντας ἅπαντας συνομόσαι ἂν ἦ μὴν τὸν παῖδα καὶ τὴν παῖδα ὑπ’ ἀλλήλων φιλεῖσθαι.
remarks: Cf. oath ids 2285 and 2309.  It is not said that the actor playing Dionysus actually swore to this statement, only that he "would have sworn", sc. if he had been asked whether the statement was true.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That what would prevent Socrates from knowing how to manage an estate is the same as would prevent a man from knowing how to play the pipes]
 τί οὖν κωλύει
καὶ σὲ ἐπίστασθαι; Ὅπερ νὴ Δία καὶ αὐλεῖν ἂν κωλύσειεν
ἄνθρωπον ἐπίστασθαι, εἰ μήτε αὐτὸς πώποτε κτήσαιτο αὐλοὺς 
μήτε ἄλλος αὐτῷ παράσχοι ἐν τοῖς αὑτοῦ μανθάνειν·
remarks: Socrates' point is that a person who had never owned a pair of pipes, or even borrowed them for learning purposes, could not be expected to know how to play the instrument, and similarly Socrates does not know how to manage an estate because he has never owned one himself nor has he ever been asked to manage one belonging to someone else.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Cyrus did wrong to accuse Hystaspas of influencing Gadatas]
 καὶ ὁ Κῦρος εἶπεν· Ἀδίκως ἄρα ἐγὼ Ὑστάσπαν τόνδε καταιτιῶμαι. Ἀδίκως μέντοι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ὑστάσπας, ὦ Κῦρε
remarks: See also oath id 2442.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
In a speech encouraging the Athenians to join in the war against Sparta in 395 a Theban envoy to Athens told the Athenians that the Thebans had been good allies to the Spartans. 
See also oath id 1708.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the Athenians that they must fix in their minds the fact that Philip is at war with them and has broken the peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Spartans felt that the Archidamian War was brought about by their their transgression (as opposed to the renewed war of 413 which they felt had been caused by Athens), for two reasons. 
Firstly, because the Thebans had entered Plataea "in a time of truce" (ἐν σπονδαῖς). 
Secondly, because they had not responded to the summons when the Athenians had invited them to arbitrate, even though the former agreements (i.e. the thirty years' peace) stipulated that neither party was to resort to arms to settle a dispute if the other were willing to submit the matter to arbitration. 
The Spartans felt that they deserved their misfortune (εἰκότως δυστυχεῖν) such as the disaster at Pylos because they had broken the agreement. 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That, thanks to Socrates, he has said more about knowledge than he had in him to say]
 Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δί’ ἔγωγε πλείω ἢ ὅσα εἶχον ἐν ἐμαυτῷ διὰ σὲ εἴρηκα.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Macartatus
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Sositheus argues that a conspiracy was formed against Phylomache, and a written agreement was entered into and deposited with Medius (?) of Hagnus by Theopompus, the father of Macartatus, Glaucon and Glaucus (Hagnias' half-brothers), and Eupolemus (one of their friends). 
See also oath id 3604.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker argues that the Athenians will be able to see that the terms of the agreement and the oaths have been violated, and that he will prove this. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This alliance must have been concluded immediately after Cyrus conquered Lydia, since Herodotus maintains that Cyrus made a sworn agreement with Miletus on the same terms as the Milesians had with the Lydians. 
Herodotus refers to this alliance three times to explain why the Milesians did not fight against the Persians.  
For the other references see oath id 1281 and 1282.

author: Lysias
title: On the Scrutiny of Euandros
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker tells the bouleutai that he has heard that Euandros will argue that the dokimasia is not about him alone, but also about those who remained in the city, and that he will remind them about their "oaths and agreements" in the hope that these will gain him the approval of those who remained in the city. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes observes that some Phocians thought that the Athenians regretted having made the peace with Philip, but that it was pointed out to them that the Athenians had voted to extended the peace to Philip's descendants.  
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had or had not killed]
remarks: The defendant suggests that the best chance of deciding a case in accordinace with justice will arise when there are many witnesses  - both free men and slaves - and the free men can be compelled to tell the truth by oaths and pledges, whereas other means (i.e. torture) are used to extract the truth from slaves.  He has challenged his prosecutors to question his witnesses and examine his slaves under torture, and they have refused the challenge.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That those who lack power over themselves are not free (i.e. are ruled by bodily pleasures and thereby unable to do what is best)]
 Παντάπασιν ἄρα σοι δοκοῦσιν οἱ ἀκρατεῖς ἀνελεύθεροι εἶναι; Νὴ τὸν Δί’ εἰκότως.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Pyrrhus
statement:
[That it was a matter of secondary importance about which they obtained the deposition from Pyretides, so that negligence in the affair is not surprising]
 Ἴσως γὰρ ἦν νὴ Δία πάρεργον καὶ φαῦλον, περὶ οὗ τὴν ἐκμαρτυρίαν παρὰ τοῦ Πυρετίδου φασὶ ποιήσασθαι οὗτοι, ὥστε οὐδὲν θαυμαστὸν ὀλιγωρηθῆναι ἦν τὸ πρᾶγμα.
remarks: The speaker is arguing that if Nicodemus was telling the truth he would have summoned all his friends to testify on his behalf instead of merely calling Pyretides, and imagines that someone might object in this way.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Arcephron of Lamptrae (bouleutes 1); [---] of Thria (bouleutes 2); [---] of Hagnous (bouleutes 3); Bouleutes #4; Bouleutes #5; Idiotes #1; Hippocrates of Cerameis (idiotes 2); Idiotes #3; Chaerephon of Cedoe (idiotes 4); Emmenides of Coele (idiotes 5); [---] of Sunium (idiotes 6); Aristides of Oe (idiotes 7); Idiotes #8; Glaucon of Perithoedae (idiotes 9); Phaedrus (idiotes 10)
if_taken: They would be eligible to decide on the new boundary (and place the new boundary markers)
if_refused: They would be ineligible to decide on the new boundary (and place the new boundary markers)
statement:
[That they would not vote according to favour or hostility, but as uprightly and piously as they could]
 ὀ[μόσαντας τὸν νόμιμον ὅρκον ἦ μὴν] μήτε χάριτος ἕνεκα μὴτ’ ἔ[χθρας ψηφιεῖσθαι, ἀλλὰ ὡς δι]καιότατα καὶ εὐσεβέστατα·
remarks:
The text indicates that 15 Athenians (five bouleutai and 10 men from all the Athenians) were elected to decide in the Eleusinion in the city (not at Eleusis) about the dispute between Athens and Megara over the boundaries of the sacred land.  
It is stated that they would swear "the customary oath".

author: Cratinus
title: Cheirones
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a discussion concerning those for whom the greatest oath is sworn by "dog", then "goose", rather than by gods. See further Sosicrates FGrH 461 F3.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
The text indicates that an oath was sworn prior to a decision being made, presumably by a judge [- - ὀμν]ὺς κριν[έτο - -]. 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Socrates points out that were he to try to prevail upon the jury with entreaties to go against their dikastic oath, he would be simultaneously accusing himself of having no religious belief. In fact, he says, this is very far from the truth. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That the Attic boys will get what's coming to them]
 «Ναὶ τὼ σιώ, νῦν ἁττικίων δωσεῖ δίκαν.»
remarks: Swearing by the Twin gods (Castor and Pollux) is a typical Spartan oath. The context here suggested by Hermes is that the Spartans swear such an oath when they gain a small advantage in the war, which Sommerstein ad 213 explains as "e.g. the time of the great plague in Athens in 430, when the Athenians sued unsuccessfully for peace". The penalty that will have to be paid is "presumably for the crime of attempting (as Spartan propaganda put it) to enslave Greece" (Sommerstein ad 214). We are surely to understand this oath as false since the Athenians had not lost the war, and since Spartan oaths could reportedly not be trusted. Cf. Athenian oaths at ids 936 and 937.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
After the reconciliation was formalised, King Pausanias withdrew his army and the men from Piraeus went up to the Acropolis and sacrificed there. 
For other references to the oath of reconciliation see also oath id 1796.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That a man who could take over the management of someone else’s estate and run it profitably would command a very high salary]
 Νὴ Δία καὶ 
πολύν γε μισθόν, ἔφη ὁ Κριτόβουλος, φέροιτ’ ἄν, εἰ δύναιτο
οἶκον παραλαβὼν τελεῖν τε ὅσα δεῖ καὶ περιουσίαν ποιῶν 
αὔξειν τὸν οἶκον.
remarks: Pomeroy notes ad loc: "Considering that the wealthy usually delegated supervision of their estates, it is interesting that Socrates assumes that Critobulus should take personal responsibility for this".

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Hypereides refers to "the stele which the Thebans had set up with Philip", referring (as he makes clear a few lines later, see oath id 3880) to the stele recording their alliance with Philip, made in 353 (with a view to cooperation against the Phocians in the Sacred War) and still in being in 339.
See also oath id 3826.

author: Xenophon
title: Apology
statement:
[That he knows of one group of people that Socrates has influenced badly: those whom Socrates has persuaded to obey him rather than their parents]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Μέλητος, ἐκείνους οἶδα οὓς σὺ πέπεικας σοὶ πείθεσθαι μᾶλλον ἢ τοῖς γειναμένοις.
remarks: Socrates says in Euthyphro (2b) that Meletus is young and unknown (cf. too Pl. Apology 25d, 26e); he might therefore be under thirty, making his name as a prosecutor as budding politicians often did.  (Not that his political career ever actually bloomed.)

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he has not stolen wealth from the god Apollo]
  μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ μὲν οὔ.
remarks: Temple-robbing was a heinous crime. See also Blepsidemus' accusation at oath id 869.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Chalicidians from Thrace; Representatives
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Chalicidians from Thrace; Representatives
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides indicates that as soon as the Potidaeans revolted from Athens they made a sworn agreement together (κοινῇ ξυνομόσαντες) with the Chalcidians from Thrace and the Bottiaeans.

title: SEG
if_taken: They could continue with their claim (or defence)
if_refused: They could not continue with their claim (or defence)
statement: [That the facts in their written statements were true]
remarks: This text was written on a jar which contained the documents relating to a legal case concerning an heiress. The jar contained the diamartyria, the law on abuse of heiresses, challenge of testimony, oaths of litigants (the antomosia ?), and names a certain Antenor as sealing the lid. For the oath sworn during the diamartyria see oath id 524. The restoration of ὅρκοι was rejected by Soritz-Hadler in SEG 36.296 in favour of μαρτυρία(ι) γραφαὶ, but reaffirmed by Boegehold in Athenian Agora XXVIII, pp79-81.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That no one is capable of running with a torch any more due to lack of exercise]
 λαμπάδα δ’ οὐδεὶς οἷός τε φέρειν
  ὑπ’ ἀγυμνασίας ἔτι νυνί. 
  ΔΙ.  Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆθ’
remarks: The reference is to torch-races at festivals like the Panathenaea and Prometheia.  This is another allusion to the fact that young men are now sitting around engaging in discussion rather than exercising. See also oath id 486.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That it would be great if the Peloponnesians no longer existed]
 ἢ μηκέτ’ εἶναι μήτε Πελοποννησίους—
{ΚΛ.}  Βέλτιστα τοίνυν μηκέτ’ εἶναι νὴ Δία.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That it would be terrible if Melanopus were imprisoned now]
 ἀλλὰ Μελάνωπος δεινὸν νὴ Δί’ ἐστὶν εἰ δεθήσεσθαι νῦν ἔμελλεν
remarks: Diodorus imagines that someone will respond in this way. The imaginary speaker appears to be saying this because of the virtues of Melanopus' father Laches.

author: Euripides
title: Phoenissae
statement:
[That he has suffered pitiably and been driven from the land without his rights like a slave]
 τὴν δὲ θρέψασάν με γαῖαν καὶ θεοὺς μαρτύρομαι
  ὡς ἄτιμος οἰκτρὰ πάσχων ἐξελαύνομαι χθονός,
δοῦλος ὣς ἀλλ’ οὐχὶ ταὐτοῦ πατρὸς Οἰδίπου γεγώς
remarks: Compare oath id 172.

author: Anaxilas
title: Neottis
statement:
[That he calls the hetaera he has fallen in love with a smart babe]
  καὶ σὺ νῦν οὐχ ὡς λέγεις 
πόρνης, ἑταίρας δ’ εἰς ἔρωτα τυγχάνεις  
ἐληλυθώς· ἆρ’ ὡς ἀληθῶς ἐστι γοῦν
ἁπλῆ τις; {Β.} ἀστεία μὲν οὖν, νὴ τὸν Δία
remarks: The first speaker seems to be saying that the girl is haplê (“simple”); he means by this “honest, not duplicitous”, but the second speaker takes him to mean “simple-minded” and replies “no, she’s really sophisticated” vel sim.

author: Isocrates
title: To Philip
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Isocrates writes that Philip and Athens anticipated his plan to write about how to bring about an end to the war by making peace before he had completed his discourse. 
He adds that while he was in joyful agreement with the terms of the peace, he at once began to consider the possibilities for Greece as a whole i.e. that the Greeks should put aside their differences and wage war on the Persians. 
See also oath id. 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Stephanus 1
if_taken: He will not have to testify
statement: [That he did not know that the facts, to which he had been called to testify, were true]
remarks: Apollodorus tells the jurors that when he was making a witness swear the exomosia, Stephanus stole his deposition from the box.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: Brasidas will be more easily able to persuade the Thracians to revolt
if_refused: Brasidas will find it more difficult to persuade the Thracians to revolt
statement:
[That whoever Brasidas should win as allies should be autonomous]
 ἦ μὴν οὓς ἂν ἔγωγε προσαγάγωμαι ξυμμάχους ἔσεσθαι αὐτονόμους
remarks:
The Acanthians voted to revolt from Athens, but did not admit Brasidas' army until he pledged to the oaths sworn by the magistrates at Sparta when they sent him, that those who he might win as allies should be autonomous. 
See oath id 1667.

author: Plato
title: Menexenus
statement: [That as allies they would be forever guileless and reliable to each other]
remarks: In this fictional funeral oration, reference is made to alliance between Athens and Leontini through praise of the brave men who died fighting for the liberties of the Leontines, to whom they were bound by oaths. Cf. oath ids 166 and 167.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
if_taken: Their wives will have sex with them
if_refused: Their wives will refuse to have sex with them
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: The Spartan here sings and dances inviting Artemis to join in their peace treaty to keep them united. Cf. oath ids 1220, 1234, 1239.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Thebans were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That he would not molest the Thebans while they were collecting their dead]
remarks:
After slaying the vanguard of Epaminondas' army when he invaded the city of Sparta, Archidamus set up a trophy and gave back the dead under a truce. 
Epaminondas then withdrew to Tegea.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he knows well that Cyrus and his men have more mattresses and couches than he does]
 Ὑμῖν νὴ Δί’ εὖ οἶδ’ ὅτι, ἔφη, καὶ στρώματα πλείω ἐστὶ καὶ κλῖναι

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is much more agreeable to see people whose characteristics seem beautiful and good and lovable than to see people who appear shameful and wicked and hateful]
 Πότερον οὖν, ἔφη, νομίζεις ἥδιον ὁρᾶν τοὺς ἀνθρώπους δι’ ὧν τὰ καλά τε κἀγαθὰ καὶ ἀγαπητὰ ἤθη φαίνεται ἢ δι’ ὧν τὰ αἰσχρά τε καὶ πονηρὰ καὶ μισητά; Πολὺ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, διαφέρει, ὦ Σώκρατες.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Philocles
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The prosecutor argues that Philocles has broken the oath which he swore between the statue of Athena and the table, presumably in one of her temples on the Acropolis. 
We do not know what occasion is being referred to, though Hansen (The Athenian Democracy, 227 and n.30) evidently assumes that these passages refer to the generals’ oath of office.  The nine archons took an oath on the Acropolis (Ath.Pol. 55.5), and it would not be surprising if the generals, who exercised functions that had previously belonged to the polemarch, had to do likewise.   This view is supported by §§9-10 with their focus on offences likely to be committed by a general, especially a general in charge of Munichia and the dockyards. 
See also oath id 2552.

author: Lysias
title: Funeral Oration
swearer: New members of the Piraeus party
swearee: Other members of the Piraeus party
if_taken: They would be members of the sworn party
if_refused: They would not be able to join the sworn party
impact: They fought against the Thirty and their supporters
statement: ? That they would fight together for the overthrow of the Thirty]
remarks:
At this stage of the funeral oration Lysias urges the Athenians to remember the men who fought for the cause of democracy against King Pausanias of Sparta. He states that they had "as allies their oaths and their agreements". 
Todd, Lysias, p38 n.21, argues that the term "'oaths and agreements' at 2.62 is a standard term for the amnesty of 403/2". 
However, the events being commemorated occurred during, not after, the civil war; the men referred to all belonged to - indeed, constituted - the Piraeus party; and they are described as "having for enemies…their own fellow-citizens".  Todd himself, in another of his footnotes, says correctly that the amnesty came after the fighting here spoken of.  The "oaths and agreements" spoken of must therefore be those taken by the democrats among themselves, resolving to fight together for the overthrow of the Thirty.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement: [That Euxitheus' mother Nicarete was an Athenian]
remarks: Euxitheus argues that he has shown that he is entitled to citizenship by having his kinsmen give testimony under oath, and showing that they have always been his kinsmen from the beginning.

title: Rhodes and Osborne, GHI
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would guard what has been established by the Chalcidians; and if anyone went against Amyntas, into his land for war, they would go to support Amyntas..]
 [φυλάξω τὰ συγκεί]μενα Χαλκιδ̣[εῦσι, καὶ ἐάν τις ἴηι ἐπ’ Ἀ]μ̣ύνταν [ἐς τὴν χώραν ἐπὶ πολέμοι βοηθήσω Ἀμ]ύν[ται - - -]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Amyntas III of Macedon and the Chalcidians. 
This text also appears as Syll (3) 135 and Tod, GHI 111.

author: Democritus
title: fr. 259 D-K
statement: n/a
remarks: Democritus, discussing the killing of enemies in war, says it should be done "according to ancestral law, in any manner which law does not forbid; and the things that forbid it are the local religious sanctities of each community, and treaties, and oaths".  In other words, one ought not to kill even an enemy soldier in a sacred place, or contrary to a treaty or truce, or contrary to one's oath.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_broken: May the gods give him many griefs, such as they give to perjurers
statement: [That he did not sleep with Briseis]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)most noble, loftiest of gods; Gaia; Helios; ErinyesEpithet(s)nether avengers
remarks: Odysseus relates Agamemnon's oath proposal in his embassy to Achilles. The oath is actually taken at oath id 412.

author: Thucydides
title: History
impact: Sparta and Argos remained at peace for thirty years
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
3. Neither side was to make an alliance with an enemy of the other]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that the Spartans made an alliance with Athens because the Argives had refused to renew the treaty (ἐπισπένδεσθαι) i.e. the Thirty Years' Peace, when Ampelidas and Lichas went as envoys to Argos. 
See also oath id 1683.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement:
[That they would rule according to the established nomoi; and that they would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
 βασιλεῖαι τρεῖς βασιλευομέναις πόλεσιν τριτταῖς ὤμοσαν ἀλλήλαις ἑκάτεραι, κατὰ νόμους οὓς ἔθεντο τοῦ τε ἄρχειν καὶ ἄρχεσθαι κοινούς, οἱ μὲν μὴ βιαιοτέραν τὴν ἀρχὴν ποιήσεσθαι προϊόντος τοῦ χρόνου καὶ γένους, οἱ δέ, ταῦτα ἐμπεδούντων τῶν ἀρχόντων, μήτε αὐτοὶ τὰς βασιλείας ποτὲ καταλύσειν μήτ’ ἐπιτρέψειν ἐπιχειροῦσιν ἑτέροις, βοηθήσειν δὲ βασιλῆς τε βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις καὶ δήμοις, καὶ δῆμοι δήμοις καὶ βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις.
remarks: The discussion concerns the time in which Temenus was King of Argos, Cresphontes was king of Messene and Procles and Eurysthenes were kings of Sparta, when the area was first divided into the three states of Argos, Sparta and Messene. The people swear a reciprocal oath- see oath id 2679. The kings and people of Argos and Messene do the same- see oath ids 2680-3. Compare alos Xenophon's Lac. Pol. - oath id 2235.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would not attack the territory of each other for thirty years]
remarks:
Xenophon states that in 386 there was common talk that the thirty year's truce concluded after the battle of Mantinea had expired as far as the Mantineans were concerned. 
The Mantineans refused to tear down their walls and the Spartans proclaimed a campagin against them. 
See also oath id 1761.

author: Andocides
title: Against Alcibiades
statement: [That they would judge the choruses fairly]
remarks:
[Andocides] states that when Taureas, a rival choregus, tried to remove a foreigner from Alcibiades' chorus for the boys' dithyramb, Alcibiades struck him. He then states that the judges voted in favour of Alcibiades' chorus, "some in fear, others in complaisance..valuing their oath less than him".   
For the oath sworn by the judges see also oath id 1247.

title: Rhodes and Osborne, GHI
if_broken: He will be a sinner against the Caunian King, Arkesimas, Leto, her descendants and the Nymphs
statement:
[That they would do completely what is inscribed on the stele for these gods and the priest, and not change anything or allow anyone else to do so]
 καὶ ἐποιήσαντο ὅρκους Ξάνθιοι καὶ οἱ περίοικοι ὅσα ἐν τῆι στήληι ἐγγέγραπται ποιήσειν ἐντελῆ τοῖς θεοῖς τούτοις καὶ τῶι  ἱερεῖ, καὶ μὴ μετακινήσειν μηδαμὰ μηδ’ ἄλλωι ἐπιτρέψειν·
gods_invoked: The Caunian King; Arkesimas; Leto; The descendants of Leto; The Nymphs
remarks:
This text is part of a trilingual inscription (Lycian and Greek on the front and Aramaic on the side) which records a resolution by the Xanthians and their perioikoi. 
The Xanthians and their perioikoi swore to do completely what was inscribed on the stele i.e. to establish an altar to the Caunian King and Arkesimas, to appoint Simias the son of Kondorasis as priest (and his descendants for all time), to give Simias ateleia, land, a salary of 1.5 minas, to make new freedmen pay 2 drachmas to the god, and to ensure that the sacrifices are made to the Caunian King and Arkesimas.  
Presumably the Caunian King, Arkesimas, Leto, the descendants of Leto i.e. Apollo and Artemis, and the Nymphs were invoked as part of the oath since it is stated that anyone violates the oath he will be a sinner against them. 
The text indicates that Pixodarus is to have authority.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Antisthenes should acknowledge that he lost his argument with Callias]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, ἀνεχέσθω μέντοι·

title: TAM II, 1-3
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would abide by the agreements guilelessly and innocently]
remarks:
This inscription records an agreement between Mausollus and Phaselis. 
The text indicates that the Phaselites swore to abide by the agreement with Mausolus under the same terms except that they were to remove "the royal oath?"  [ἐμμενεῖν τοῖς ὡμολογ]ημένοις ἐξαιρῶντας τὸ βασι[λικὸν ὅρκιον?]. 
The text followed for this entry is the original text of Wilhelm reproduced by Hornblower, Mausolus, p367, as M10, with emendments by AHS. In lines 6-7 the text of Wilhelm reads: [ἐμμενεῖν τοῖς ὡμολογ]ημένοις ἐξαιρῶντας τὸ βασι[λέως ὅρκιον?]. The text in TAM reads: [ἐμμενεῖν τοῖς ὡμολογ]ημένοις ἐξαιρῶντας τὸ Βασι[λέως Τύχαν].  
For the oath sworn by Mausolus and his wife Artemisia see oath id 1053.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That Miccus is no insignificant man (but a competent sophist)]
 Μὰ Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, οὐ φαῦλός γε ἁνήρ, ἀλλ’ ἱκανὸς σοφιστής.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Phaenippus
statement:
[That there were two threshing floors on Phaenippus' farm, each one nearly a plethron in extent]
 ἦσαν γὰρ νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς καὶ τὰς θεάς, ἄνδρες δικασταί, δύο ἅλως αὐτόθι, μικροῦ πλέθρου ἑκατέρα.

author: Antiphanes
title: Homonymoi
statement:
[That the land does indeed bear figs]
 σῦκα μὲν νὴ τὸν Δία 
πάνυ φέρει.
remarks: The speaker's name (Hipponicus) does not occur elsewhere in comedy as that of a fictitious character so it gives no indication of age category. It can be no accident that this speaker singles out figs from a list of nine Athenian products; there has got to be a secondary meaning.  If this were Old Comedy we would assume at once that he was thinking of sykophants, and the pun was still in use in Middle Comedy (cf. Eubulus fr. 74).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and household
statement: [? That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
Euthycles describes the oath sworn by prosecutors in a homicide trial and reminds the jurors that every man who brings an accusation must swear an oath, calling destruction upon himself, his kin and his household. 
He also observes that whoever swears this oath must not treat it as a normal oath, but as one which no man swears for any other purpose. He notes that the swearer stands over the entrails of a boar, a ram and a bull, and they must have been slaughtered by the necessary officers and on the days appointed so that every requirement of solemnity has been met. 
Euthycles argues that even then the person who has sworn this oath does not gain immediate credence; and if any falsehood is discovered he and his children and his kindred will be marked by his perjury. 
"Does not gain immediate credence" presumably means that he is still expected to prove his case by argument. 
For the oath of the defendant see oath id 3440.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would not harbour grudges for what is past against any of the Ceans, nor would they kill or make an exile any of the Ceans who abide by the oaths and this agreement, but they would bring them into the alliance like the other allies. But if any one commits an act of revolution in Ceos contrary to the oaths and the agreement, they would not allow him by any craft or contrivance as far as possible. If any one does not wish to live in Ceos, they would allow him to live wherever he wishes in the allied cities and enjoy his own property]
remarks:
This inscription refers to an alliance between Athens and the poleis on Ceos. 
The text notes that Chabrias swore on behalf of the Athenians and those Ceans whom the Athenians reinstated. The exact statement is unknown. However, it must have been similar to the new agreement sworn by the board of strategoi in 363/2 (see oath id 422) 
For a full analysis of the text see Rhodes and Osborne, GHI 39.  
See also oath id 422, 424, 427, 520, 521.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
impact: Mention of the Amazon queen and her son Hippolytus provoke Phaedra's distress
statement:
[That if Phaedra dies, she will be betraying her children and they will not share in their father's house]
 εἰ θανῆι, προδοῦσα σοὺς 
  παῖδας, πατρώιων μὴ μεθέξοντας δόμων,
  μὰ τὴν ἄνασσαν ἱππίαν ᾿Αμαζόνα,
  ἣ σοῖς τέκνοισι δεσπότην ἐγείνατο,
  νόθον φρονοῦντα γνήσι’, οἶσθά νιν καλῶς,
  ῾Ιππόλυτον ...
remarks: Barrett (1964) ad loc. remarks that this is 'no real oath at all', but it is formulated as one and is therefore recorded here.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement: [That his claim is true]
remarks: This is a general reference in the parabasis to affidavits (antomosiai) which appear alongside summonses and depositions imagined as part of the nightmare of the victim who sees the sukophantes preparing for a prosecution; cf. Sommerstein ad 1041. The antomosia was an oath which the plaintiff/prosecutor and the defendant both had to take, at the preliminary hearing of their case (before whichever magistrate would be presiding at the eventual trial), to the truth of the written statements of their claim and defence, respectively.  If either party refused to take the oath, he would lose his case by default; if he took the oath, he could continue with his case. Here the context shows that the reference is to prosecutors only. Cf. also id 1250.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That if Dionysodorus is talking, then what he is talking about is true and real]
 σὺ δὲ ὡμολόγηκας τὸ μὴ ὂν μὴ οἷόν τ’ εἶναι μηδένα ποιεῖν— ὥστε κατὰ τὸν σὸν λόγον οὐδεὶς ψευδῆ λέγει, ἀλλ’ εἴπερ λέγει Διονυσόδωρος, τἀληθῆ τε καὶ τὰ ὄντα λέγει. Νὴ Δία, ἔφη ὁ Κτήσιππος, ὦ Εὐθύδημε· ἀλλὰ τὰ ὄντα μὲν τρόπον τινὰ λέγει, οὐ μέντοι ὥς γε ἔχει.
remarks: Ctesippus is happy to make this statement, but he qualifies it by saying that while Dionysodorus might be talking about real things, he is not talking about them as they really are.

title: IvO
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the treaty]
remarks:
The text indicates that "If they (whoever they may be?) should transgress their oath, the decision (as to their penalty?) is to rest with the hiaromaos at Olympia" (αἰ τὸ[ν] ὅρκον παρβαίνοιαν, γνῶμαν τὸρ ἰ[α]ρομάορ τ’ Ὀλυμπίαι). 
Virgilio in SEG 38.364 suggested that the Anaitoi and the Metapioi, who are the parties to this treaty, were small communities of Elis located near Olympia. The hiaromaos was interpreted as a local official associated with the sacred altar to Zeus in the Altis at Olympia.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The rebels left and were settled at Naupactus by the Athenians
statement:
[That they would not attack the Messenians if they left the Peloponnese and agreed to never set foot in it again]
 ἐφ’ ᾧ ἐξίασιν ἐκ Πελοποννήσου ὑπόσπονδοι καὶ μηδέποτε ἐπιβήσονται αὐτῆς·
remarks: The Messenian rebels at Ithome agreed to surrender to the Spartans on condition that they should leave the Peloponnese under a truce and never set foot in it again.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the neighbour is a loser]
 κακοδαίμων ἄρ’  εἶ, 
  νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν σωτῆρα.
remarks: This is with reference to the fact that the Neighbour has announced his intention to bring his possessions to the state as required under the new women's rιgime.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
