statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Spartans or their allies should not go against or raise revenue from whatever lands and cities belong to King Darius or belonged to his ancestors.
2. King Darius and his subjects shall not go against the territory of the Spartans
3. They shall fight against the Athenians and if they make peace they shall do so together
4. Whatever forces are in the territory of the King shall be paid for by the King
5. If any of the cities that have entered into the agreement with the King go against the territory of the King, the rest shall prevent this; and if any of those who inhabit the King's territory go against the territory of the Spartans or their allies, the King shall strive to prevent this and gave aid to the extent of his power]
remarks:
Thucydides states that when there was a meeting between Tissaphernes and the Peloponnesian forces in 412/11 at Cnidus, one of the Spartans, a certain Lichas, objected to the two treaties between Persia and Sparta on the grounds that they would allow King Darius to claim the Aegean islands, Thessaly, Locris and Boeotia as his possessions. Lichas urged them to make a better treaty. Tissaphernes was offended and left in a rage. 
For references to the three agreements between the Spartans and the Persians see also oath id 1806.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement:
[That it would be most unseemly if ever a city's women were so badly reared that they were unable to defend their children as mother-birds do, when the males are absent, but fled instead to fill the shrines and temples in cowardice]
 Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ ξένε, οὐδαμῶς εὔσχημον γίγνοιτ’ ἄν, τοῦ κακοῦ χωρίς, τοῦτο ἐν πόλει ὅπου γίγνοιτο.
remarks: Clinias is responding favourably to an argument by the Athenian in support of his view that girls and women should be given military training.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks: Xenophon refers here to the so-called Argive alliance of ca. 420 (see also oath id 251). Describing events of 399 he states that the Spartan declaration of war against Elis in that year was partly due to long-standing resentment of the alliance they had made with the Athenians, Argives and Mantineans - even though this alliance had long lapsed, and Athenians actually took part in the Elean war as Allies of Sparta (3.2.25). The Spartans' more immediate grievances concerned the Eleans' actions in debarring them from the Games at Olympia in 400, and preventing King Agis from making a sacrifice there to Zeus.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That his father also told him that his duty was to practise self-control]
  ἐμὸν δ’ ἔφησεν ἡ μήτηρ ἔργον εἶναι σωφρονεῖν. Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ, ὦ γύναι, καὶ γὰρ ἐμοὶ ὁ πατήρ.
remarks: Ischomachus' father, then, gave the same advice to him as his wife's mother gave to her.  Ischomachus adds (rather unusually, but then he is a thin disguise for Socrates!) that self-control for a man and a woman means the same thing, which he defines (again rather unusually, no doubt because the whole context is a discussion of household management) as "acting in such a way that one's existing property is in the best possible state and that as much further property as possible is added to it by fair and just means".

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he will not hit Carion while he has a garland on]
 Οὐ γάρ με τυπτήσεις στέφανον ἔχοντά γε.
  {ΧΡΕΜΥΛΟΣ}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 21: "One who wore a sacred garland was himself in a measure sacred… and it was impious to strike him".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Potidaeans were able to collect their dead from the battlefield
statement: [? that they would not molest the Potidaeans while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that after the battle the Athenians set up a trophy and gave up their dead under a truce (ὑποσπόνδους) to the Potidaeans.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Oedipus was not a fortunate man at first]
 ΕΥ. «Ἦν Οἰδίπους τὸ πρῶτον εὐδαίμων ἀνήρ,» 
  ΑΙ.  Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’
remarks: Aeschylus argues that Oedipus was never fortunate (eudaimon), but on the contrary was ill-fated (kakodaimon) from his very birth. Cf. oath id 504.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will tell her what she will swear]
 Ἀλλὰ πῶς ὀμούμεθα 
  ἡμεῖς; 
{ΚΛ.} Ἐγώ σοι νὴ Δί’, ἢν βούλῃ, φράσω.
remarks: This informal oath comes in the long formal oath sequence of oath id 1164.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia in Tauris
impact: Apollo responds with instructions to rid Orestes of his pollution
statement:
[That he would starve himself to death in the temple if Apollo did not save him]
 ἐπώμοσ’ αὐτοῦ βίον ἀπορρήξειν θανών,
  εἰ μή με σώσει Φοῖβος, ὅς μ’ ἀπώλεσεν.
remarks: Orestes' oath is conditional, and Apollo's response means he does not need to fulfill his oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That he is going to go straight to the Commissioners and will show himself to them just as he is]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἀλλὰ τοῖς προβούλοις ἄντικρυς
  ἐμαυτὸν ἐπιδείξω βαδίζων ὡς ἔχω.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records a defensive alliance between  Athens, Arcadia, Achaea, Elis and Phlius. 
For the corresponding oaths of the Peloponnesians see oath id 447, 448, 449 and 450.

author: Eupolis
title: Marikas
statement:
[That someone is afraid of something]
 νὴ Δία δεδοι[κ
remarks: This fragment comes from the body of a scholion, not from the lemma, so it's not certainly by Eupolis.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he'll prove that Paphlagon took a bribe from Mytilene of more than forty minas]
 Καί σ’ ἐπιδείξω
  νὴ τὴν Δήμητρ’, ἢ μὴ ζῴην,
  δωροδοκήσαντ’ ἐκ Μυτιλήνης 
  πλεῖν ἢ μνᾶς τετταράκοντα.
remarks: The charge of taking a bribe from Mytilene is, as Sommerstein remarks ad 834, "precisely the charge that Cleon, in the Assembly debate of 427 on the fate of that city after its unsuccessful rebellion, had himself made against his opponent Diodotus (Thuc. 3. 38. 2)." Here "a charge originally made by Cleon against another is nonsensically turned against Cleon himself". Forty minas is not a large bribe, but Sommerstein suggests ad 835 that "the gravamen of the charge lies not so much in the amount of the bribe as in Cleon's alleged failure to fulfil his side of the alleged bargain; for in two successive debates he had advocated the execution or enslavement of the entire Mytilenean people (Thuc. 3.36-40) and in the end over a thousand men were put to death under a decree proposed by him (Thuc. 3.50.1).

title: IPriene
statement:
[That the accused have damaged the city]
 κατομόσαντα κατὰ τὸν νόμον ὡς βλάπτο[υσι] τὴμ πόλιν
remarks: The text indicates that any Maronite or Prienian who wished could bring suit against the accused "upon confirming by oath, according to the law, that they [the accused] have damaged the city"( εἶναι δὲ τοῖς αἰτίοις δικάσα[σθαι] καὶ τῶι  Μαρωνίτηι καὶ Πριηνέων τῶι  βουλομέ[νωι] κατομόσαντα κατὰ τὸν νόμον ὡς βλάπτο[υσι] τὴμ πόλιν, τὴν δὲ καταδίκην γίνεσθαι τοῦ [Μαρωνί]τεω·)

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, Spithridates told Agesilaus that if he went to Paphlagonia with him he would bring the king of the Paphlagonians to a conference and make him an ally. 
Agesilaus eagerly undertook the journey, and upon his arrival in Paphlagonia, King Otys came and concluded an alliance. 
See also oath id 2304, 3314.

author: Democritus
title: fr. 239 D-K
statement: n/a
remarks: It is said here that base people who swear oaths when in a tight spot (sc. in order to get out of it) don't bother to keep their oath once they have got out of the tight spot.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That the word 'bad' (κακόν) is strange and difficult to interpret]
 Ἄτοπόν τι νὴ Δία ἔμοιγε δοκεῖ καὶ χαλεπὸν συμβαλεῖν.
remarks: Socrates suggests that the word has a foreign origin.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: Aeschines will not have to serve as ambassador
if_refused: Aeschines will have to serve as ambassador
statement: [? That Aeschines was unwell and could not serve as an ambassador]
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that when Aeschines realised that Demosthenes was not going to participate in the embassy to Philip, he also wished to remain in Athens, but to take the exomosia without some reason was a very serious matter and very suspicious. 
He states that Aeschines resolved his problem by giving the excuse that he was unwell, and sent his brother to take the exomosia. He reports that Aeschines' brother (it is uncertain whether it was Aphobetus or Philochares) took the physician Execestus to the boule when he swore the oath. 
See also oath id 3766.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Coloneus
if_kept: Theseus' land will be forever unharmed
impact: Oedipus' children cannot approach his grave
statement:
[That he will not allow anyone to approach Oedipus' grave, nor invoke the sacred tomb where he lies]
 Θη. ὦ παῖδες, ἀπεῖπεν ἐμοὶ κεῖνος 
μήτε πελάζειν ἐς τούσδε τόπους
μήτ’ ἐπιφωνεῖν μηδένα θνητῶν 
θήκην ἱεράν, ἣν κεῖνος ἔχει.
καὶ ταῦτά μ’ ἔφη πράσσοντα κακῶν
χώραν ἕξειν αἰὲν ἄλυπον. 
ταῦτ’ οὖν ἔκλυεν δαίμων ἡμῶν
χὠ πάντ’ ἀίων Διὸς ῞Ορκος.
remarks: By saying that "Horkos, son of Zeus, who hears all things" heard Oedipus' injunctions to him, Theseus implies that Oedipus made him swear to obey those injunctions.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That it is very clear that Thrasymachus has made two statements which contradict each other. (He has said (i) that justice is “nothing but what is advantageous to the stronger” and also (ii) that it is just for the weaker to obey the commands of the stronger; Socrates has now shown that these two propositions will contradict each other whenever the ruling power issues commands that are contrary to its own interest)] 
 Οἴου τοίνυν, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, καὶ τὸ ἀσύμφορα ποιεῖν τοῖς ἄρχουσί τε καὶ κρείττοσι δίκαιον εἶναι ὡμολογῆσθαί σοι, ὅταν οἱ μὲν ἄρχοντες ἄκοντες κακὰ αὑτοῖς προστάττωσιν, τοῖς δὲ δίκαιον εἶναι φῇς ταῦτα ποιεῖν ἃ ἐκεῖνοι προσέταξαν —ἆρα τότε, ὦ σοφώτατε Θρασύμαχε, οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον συμβαίνειν αὐτὸ οὑτωσί, δίκαιον εἶναι ποιεῖν τοὐναντίον ἢ ὃ σὺ λέγεις; τὸ γὰρ τοῦ κρείττονος ἀσύμφορον δήπου προστάττεται τοῖς ἥττοσιν ποιεῖν. Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, ὁ Πολέμαρχος, σαφέστατά γε.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
remarks:
Cleanor the Orchomenian addressed the Greeks and spoke as follows, "Come fellow soldiers, you see the perjury and impiety of the King. You also see the faithlessness of Tissaphernes. It was Tissaphernes who said that he was a neighbour of Greece and that he would do his utmost to save us. It was none other than he who gave us his oaths, giving his right hand, and then he deceived and seized our generals". 
Cleanor goes on to observe that Tissaphernes did not even show reverence to Zeus the god of hospitality, for he invited Clearchus to his own table and then made that very act the means of deceiving and destroying him. 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: Adusius would negotiate peace amongst the Carians
if_refused: Adusius would not negotiate peace amongst the Carians
statement:
[That they would receive Adusius within their walls without treachery to the advantage of Cyrus and the Persians]
 πιστὰ δ’ ἠξίου γενέσθαι, καὶ τοὺς μὲν Κᾶρας ὀμόσαι ἀδόλως τε δέξεσθαι εἰς τὰ τείχη σφᾶς καὶ ἐπ’ ἀγαθῷ τῷ Κύρου καὶ Περσῶν·
remarks: Adusius swears a reciprocal oath. See oath id 2464.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That the boy should certainly fill a large goblet for Philip, and should do so also for the rest of them]
 καὶ ὁ παῖς ἐγχεάτω μοι τὴν μεγάλην φιάλην. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Καλλίας, καὶ ἡμῖν γε, ἐπεὶ καὶ ἡμεῖς διψῶμεν ἐπὶ σοὶ γελῶντες.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
Xenophon explicitly states that the Phliasians remained steadfast in their alliance with the Spartans in 366 despite being hard-pressed by the Argives. 
Xenophon observes that they had become friends of the Spartans when they were at their greatest, but remained loyal after Leuctra despite the revolts of the perioeci and the Helots, and the allies with the exception of a few. 
See also oath id 2034. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and that they would respect the division of Cotys' former kingdom and not attempt to change the settlement by force, and that the Athenians would receive back their possessions ]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the Athenian neglect and abandonment of Serrium and Doriscus ruined Thrace and Cersobleptes who was their ally. 
See also oath id 457.

title: IG XII 2
statement:
[That they would judge this case, so far as concerns things that are found in the laws, in accordance with the laws, and so far as concerns anything else industriously, as well and as justly as possible; and if they condemn they would assess rightly and justly. They would do this by Zeus and Helios]
 [ν]αὶ δικάσσω τὰν [δίκαν ὄ]σσα μὲν ἐν τοῖς [νόμ]οισι ἔνι κὰτ τοὶ[ς νόμο]ις, τὰ δὲ ἄλλα ἐκ̣ [φιλοπ]ονίας ὠς ἄριστα κ[αὶ δ]ικαι<ό>τατα· καὶ τιμά[σ]ω, αἴ κε κατάγνω, ὄρθω[ς] κ̣αὶ δι<καί>ως. οὔτω ποήσω ναὶ μὰ Δία καὶ Ἄιλιον.
remarks: When Alexander issued his order for the return of exiles in 324/3, the grandsons of the first tyrants appealed to Alexander to be reinstated in Eresus and offered to stand trial.  Alexander decided that they should stand trial in Eresus, and they were not allowed to return. This oath is the one to be sworn at their trial.  For the oaths sworn at the previous trials of former tyrants of Eresus, see oath 776 and 778.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: He would not have to serve as ambassador
if_refused: He would have to serve as ambassador
statement: [? That he could not serve as an ambassador]
remarks:
Demosthenes imagines that Aeschines will ask why he joined them on the embassy to receive the oaths from Philip and why he did not take the exomosia. 
He replies to this imagined objection that he went because he had promised to bring ransom money for some Athenian prisoners of war in Philip's custody, and that it would have been dishonourable to take the exomosia and then travel to Pella as a private citizen.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
impact: Socrates feels compelled to give his speech
statement:
[That unless Socrates delivers his speech in the very presence of the plane tree, Phaedrus will never again report any other speech by any other author]
 ὁ δέ μοι λόγος ὅρκος ἔσται. ὄμνυμι γάρ σοι—τίνα μέντοι, τίνα θεῶν; ἢ βού λει τὴν πλάτανον ταυτηνί; —ἦ μήν, ἐάν μοι μὴ εἴπῃς τὸν λόγον ἐναντίον αὐτῆς ταύτης, μηδέποτέ σοι ἕτερον λόγον μηδένα μηδενὸς μήτε ἐπιδείξειν μήτε ἐξαγγελεῖν.
remarks: Phaedrus wonders which of the gods to swear by and eventually decides to invoke the plane tree as witness. If it fails to hear Socrates’ speech, it will know that it must hold Phaedrus to his promise and punish him for any breach of it. Trees, after all, could have indwelling spirits (Dryads or Hamadryads); one tree, to be mentioned later in the Phaedrus (275b), was the first prophet; and the whole location is sacred to the Nymphs (230b). Cf. oath id 2931.

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
swearer: Aristides; Representatives; Representatives of various poleis
swearee: Aristides; Representatives; Representatives of various poleis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks: In spite of the alliance, there were frequent quarrels amongst the allies. For other references to the Delian League see oath id 1778 with cross references. Here Theopompus refers to Athens having adopted a practice of adding 'and for the Chians' to all official prayers for the city's prosperity. We have more direct evidence for this practice in Aristophanes, Birds 879-880. In fact, this Theopompus fragment comes from a scholium on that passage.  Chios had a special position in the Athenian alliance because, after the Lesbian revolt of 428, it was the only member of the League (except for the unimportant Methymna) which did not pay tribute.  See also Thrasymachus fr. 3 D-K.

title: Athenian Agora
date: Second half of the fifth century (449 to 400)
statement:
[The statement is unknown]
  [ν]ὲ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀ[πόλλονα]
[- -]εοι τείσαιτο
καὶ τὸ[ς ἄλλος]
θεό[ς - - -]
[- - -]κ̣ος
remarks:
Graffiti on underside of base fragment of a black-glazed pyxis.  
Lang's text from the editio princeps is very fragmentary. All we can say for certain is that the author swore by Zeus and Apollo and the other gods. Lang writes, "The oath on the first line of (a) may have included one or two other deities; it must have been followed by a wish that a certain person might be avenged or punished". 
Oikonomides suggested an alternate text in SEG 36.135. This version can be considered unreliable on epigraphic grounds. His text reads as follows:  
[- - - ὤμοσ]ε τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀσ̣[κληπιὸν - - -] 
[- - - δίκην, ὦ θ]ε̣οί, τείσαιτο vacat 
καὶ τὸν [αἰ]νετὸ[ν] θεὸ[ν]. Oikonomides translates the text as follows: "he took an oath by Zeus and Asclepius...(I hope), Oh Gods, that he will have to pay for it the right price. And (I trust) the praiseworthy God (will hear me?).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Philocleon will not be allowed to stay there any longer]
  οὔτοι μὰ τὴν Δήμητρ’ ἔτ’ ἐνταυθοῖ μενεῖς
remarks: Bdelycleon proceeds to pick his father up and carry him into the house.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
if_taken: The Phoenician woman would go with them
if_refused: The Phoenician woman would not go with them
statement:
[That they would take the Phoenician woman home safely]
 ‘εἴη κεν καὶ τοῦτ’, εἴ μοι ἐθέλοιτέ γε, ναῦται, 
ὅρκῳ πιστωθῆναι ἀπήμονά μ’ οἴκαδ’ ἀπάξειν.’ 
  ὣς ἔφαθ’, οἱ δ’ ἄρα πάντες ἐπώμνυον, ὡς ἐκέλευεν. 
αὐτὰρ ἐπεί ῥ’ ὄμοσάν τε τελεύτησάν τε τὸν ὅρκον, 
τοῖς δ’ αὖτις μετέειπε γυνὴ καὶ ἀμείβετο μύθῳ·
remarks: As a result of the oath being taken, the Phoenician woman feels safe in sailing with the men. It also prompts her to offer gold and Eumaeus as possible ransom. The sailors do not fulfill their oath, but this is due to the divine intervention of Artemis killing the woman on the voyage.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Prior to the destruction of Plataea, the Athenians and Plataeans assisted each other when they were threatened
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides here refers to the long tradition of friendship and alliance that existed between Athens and Plataea. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1577, 1581, 1585, 1642, 1644, 1646, 1830, 1843, 3732.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That most men dishonestly keep borrowed property]
 ἡμῶν δὲ τοὺς πολλοὺς ἔφασκε τοῦτο δρᾶν.  
 {Βλ.}  νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ μαρτύρων γ’ ἐναντίον.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [?That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks: Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Zacynthians as allies, observing that they were autonomous but compelled to come because of Athens' mastery of the sea.  Athens had sent a diplomatic mission to Zacynthus and neighbouring states in 431 (Thuc. 2.7.3, where these states are contrasted with Athens' existing allies), and the mention of Zacynthus in the list of Athenian allies directly before the first Peloponnesian invasion of Attica (2.9.4) shows that at Zacynthus this initiative was successful.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
date: 411-362 i.e. the time that Xenophon is describing (411 to 362)
swearee: Other members of the sworn band
if_taken: He could be part of a sworn band
statement: [? That he would fight while he was alive, and would not regard being alive as more important than being free; that he would not leave his taxiarch or his enomotarch, whether he was alive or dead, and that he would bury the dead among his fellow-fighters, and that he would leave no-one unburied]
remarks:
Xenophon observes that at the battle of Leuctra in 371, King Cleombrotus led the three enomotiai (i.e. the "sworn bands" that each Spartan joined as an adolescent) abreast, so that the phalanx was not more than twelve men deep. 
See also oath id 1272.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That every man who assists zealously with the ropes (to haul up Peace) may never take up a shield again]
  χὤστις προθύμως ξυλλάβοι τῶν σχοινίων, 
  τοῦτον τὸν ἄνδρα μὴ λαβεῖν ποτ’ ἀσπίδα.
  {ΤΡ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: This oath is unusual in that it confirms a prayer. The oath formula here is particularly weak.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: Seuthes was able to move into the so-called 'Delta' to attack his enemies there
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks: Xenophon states that Seuthes' enemies in the mountains besought him to grant them a truce, agreeing to do anything, and urging him to receive their pledges. Xenophon personally encouraged Seuthes to accept their surrender on condition that they would give up hostages.

author: Plato
title: Charmides
statement:
[That he knows Charmides]
 Οἶδα μέντοι νὴ Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Gives added weight to the threat
statement:
[That if the Chorus-leader tells the boys off again using his fists, that they will extinguish the lamps and go off home on their own]
 εἰ νὴ Δί’ αὖθις κονδύλοις νουθετήσεθ’ ἡμᾶς, 
ἀποσβέσαντες τοὺς λύχνους ἄπιμεν οἴκαδ’ αὐτοί.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That it was very pardonable that some people who were perfectly happy to talk to Meidias should regret the supposed dropping of the prosecution against him]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ αὐτοῖς πολλὴ συγγνώμη
remarks: Demosthenes has observed that at the time when Meidias was going around alleging that Demosthenes had dropped the case, some of those who are perfectly happy to talk to Meidias were sorry to hear it. He then swears that this attitude of theirs was very pardonable, because Meidias is unbearable.

author: Pherecrates
title: Automoloi
statement:
[That it was distressing to listen to someone singing badly]
 νὴ τὴν Δήμητρ’, ἀνιαρὸν ἄρ’ ἦν τὸ κακῶς ᾄδοντος ἀκούειν·

author: Homer
title: Iliad
impact: Ate is physically banished from heaven, with the result that she vexes humans on earth
statement:
[That Ate shall never return to Olympus or the starry heavens] 
 αὐτίκα δ’ εἷλ’ Ἄτην κεφαλῆς λιπαροπλοκάμοιο
χωόμενος φρεσὶν ᾗσι, καὶ ὤμοσε καρτερὸν ὅρκον
μή ποτ’ ἐς Οὔλυμπόν τε καὶ οὐρανὸν ἀστερόεντα
αὖτις ἐλεύσεσθαι Ἄτην, ἣ πάντας ἀᾶται.
ὣς εἰπὼν ἔρριψεν ἀπ’ οὐρανοῦ ἀστερόεντος  
χειρὶ περιστρέψας· τάχα δ’ ἵκετο ἔργ’ ἀνθρώπων.
τὴν αἰεὶ στενάχεσχ’ ὅθ’ ἑὸν φίλον υἱὸν ὁρῷτο
ἔργον ἀεικὲς ἔχοντα ὑπ’ Εὐρυσθῆος ἀέθλων.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 410.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he has a large collection of writings by wise men]
 Εἰπέ μοι, ἔφη, ὦ Εὐθύδημε, τῷ ὄντι, ὥσπερ ἐγὼ ἀκούω, πολλὰ γράμματα συνῆχας τῶν λεγομένων σοφῶν ἀνδρῶν γεγονέναι; καὶ ὁ Εὐθύδημος, Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες·

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes will elicit loud and hostile heckling from the jurors by dragging in his speeches and criticising the peace that was brought about through the actions of himself and Philocrates in order to prevent him from defending himself. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: Against Eratosthenes
statement:
[That he would rescue Lysias]
 με σώσειν
remarks:
Lysias states that when he was handed over to Peison (one of the Thirty) he asked if Peison would rescue him for a price. When Peison agreed to a price of one talent of silver, Lysias made him swear an oath to rescue him although he "knew well that he had no regard for gods or men".  
Lysias claims that Peison swore the oath, calling down destruction upon himself and his children if he did not rescue Lysias upon receiving the talent. 
When Lysias opened his money chest to pay Peison, the latter took its entire contents - in all more than five talents in cash, plus four silver cups. 
When they left Lysias's house, they were met by Melobius and Mnesitheides (other members of the Thirty) who ordered Peison to go to the house of Lysias' brother Polemarchus, and Lysias to accompany them to the house of Damnippus (another member of the Thirty). Peison told Lysias that he would meet him at Damnippus' house, but Lysias managed to escape unaided.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
statement:
[That they are pure, chaste, and without taint from things that are impure, including intercourse with men. That they celebrate the Feast of the Wine God and the Bacchic rite honouring the god in accordance with the ancestral rule and at the appointed times]
 Ἁγιστεύω καὶ εἰμὶ καθαρὰ καὶ ἁγνὴ ἀπό <τε> τῶν ἄλλων τῶν οὐ καθαρευόντων καὶ ἀπ’ ἀνδρὸς συνουσίας, καὶ τὰ θεοίνια καὶ τὰ ἰοβάκχεια γεραρῶ τῷ Διονύσῳ κατὰ τὰ πάτρια καὶ ἐν τοῖς καθήκουσι χρόνοις.
remarks:
Apollodorus calls the sacred herald who waits upon the wife of the archon basileus when she administers the oath to the Venerable Priestesses (Gerarai) as they carry their baskets in front of the altar before they have contact with the rituals. He does so in order that the jurors might hear the oath and its wording (so far as this is permissible) and understand how holy and ancient the rites are. 
After the oath has been read, Apollodorus reminds the jurors that they have heard the oath and the accepted rites handed down from their ancestors, and how Phano performed the rites and administered the oath to the Gerarai.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That (s)he has been at the Thesmophorion every year]
 Ἀνῆλθες ἤδη δεῦρο πρότερον; 
 {ΚΗ.}  Νὴ Δία  
  ὁσέτη γε.
remarks: The Inlaw lies under oath here in an attempt to maintain his cover. We note that  Νὴ Δία is the weakest form of oath.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That the Athenians cannot have been wrong when they took upon themselves the peril of war for the freedom and salvation of all]
 ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἔστιν, οὐκ ἔστιν ὅπως ἡμάρτετ’, ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, τὸν ὑπὲρ τῆς ἁπάντων ἐλευθερίας καὶ σωτηρίας κίνδυνον ἀράμενοι, μὰ τοὺς Μαραθῶνι προκινδυνεύσαντας τῶν προγόνων, καὶ τοὺς ἐν Πλαταιαῖς παραταξαμένους, καὶ τοὺς ἐν Σαλαμῖνι ναυμαχήσαντας καὶ τοὺς ἐπ’ Ἀρτεμισίῳ, καὶ πολλοὺς ἑτέρους τοὺς ἐν τοῖς δημοσίοις μνήμασιν κειμένους ἀγαθοὺς ἄνδρας, οὓς ἅπαντας ὁμοίως ἡ πόλις τῆς αὐτῆς ἀξιώσασα τιμῆς ἔθαψεν, Αἰσχίνη, οὐχὶ τοὺς κατορθώσαντας αὐτῶν οὐδὲ τοὺς κρατήσαντας μόνους. δικαίως·
gods_invoked: The Athenians' ancestors who faced danger at Marathon; Those who stood in the battle-line at Plataea; Those who fought at Salamis and Artemisium; Those who lie in the public tombs
remarks: Demosthenes is swearing by those who fought at Marathon, Plataea, Salamis and Artemisium and all who fell in all of Athens’ other wars, whether the battles they fought in were won or lost. Although the war-dead are never explicitly spoken of as heroes in any text of the classical period, "there is no form of cultic honour customarily granted to heroes that [they] did not receive" (R. Parker, Athenian Religion: A History [Oxford, 1996] 136); it is thus logical, though unique, that they here also receive the heroic/divine honour of being made witnesses to an oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Heracles is a bastard]
 Ἐγὼ νόθος; Τί λέγεις;
  {ΠΕ.}  Σὺ μέντοι νὴ Δία
remarks: Peisetaerus argues that Heracles is a bastard because he is the son of a "foreign" (presumably meaning non-divine) woman. As Sommerstein notes ad 1652, "throughout this dialogue it is assumed that the laws of Athens apply to the gods; and at Athens, since Pericles' citizenship law of 451/0, it had been impossible for a citizen and a non-citizen to be legally married, and the children of such a couple were necessarily illegitimate".

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Encourages Xanthias to say something funny
statement:
[That he is giving Xanthias permission to say something at which the spectators will laugh]
  ΞΑΝΘΙΑΣ  
  Εἴπω τι τῶν εἰωθότων, ὦ δέσποτα,
  ἐφ’ οἷς ἀεὶ γελῶσιν οἱ θεώμενοι; 
  ΔΙΟΝΥΣΟΣ 
  Νὴ τὸν Δί’

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The Plataean speaker sums up by again arguing that the Athenians should decide in favour of Plataea if they have recalled his words regarding their oaths and agreements, as well as his words regarding the devotion of the Plataeans toward them, and the hostility of the Thebans. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that they are bound by two oaths - the oath they swore before serving as jurors and the oath they swore when the made the agreement for the Amnesty.  
He goes on to argue that it is not fitting that they should give their votes based upon favour or a feeling of fairness, nor anything else apart from the oaths they took when they agreed to the Amnesty. 
See also oath id 2968 and 1796. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: Their alliance and treaty would be formalised
if_refused: There would be no alliance and treaty
remarks: Thucydides states that on the terms of this agreement they brought the war to an end.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: Ariston tells the jurors that when Conon, Bacchius, Aristocrates and others of that sort were youths, they had the nickname "Triballoi". He claims that they used to steal the offerings to Hecate and the pig testicles used for purification when there is going to be a public meeting and eat them, and "swore oaths and perjured themselves as casually as can be".

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Xanthias is refused passage onto the boat
statement:
[That he did not fight in the naval battle (at Arginusae) owing to eye trouble]
 ΧΑ.  Δοῦλον οὐκ ἄγω,  
 εἰ μὴ νεναυμάχηκε τὴν περὶ τῶν κρεῶν. 
ΞΑ. Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ γὰρ ἀλλ’ ἔτυχον ὀφθαλμιῶν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: None- Cineisas continues to question him
statement:
[That Cinesias is mad]
  Ἀλεός γα ναὶ τὸν Κάστορα 
  ὥνθρωπος.
remarks: Swearing by Castor and Pollux is a particularly Spartan practice; cf. oath id 1216 with cross references for other invocations of the Dioscuri in this play.

author: Plato
title: Letter VII
statement: n/a
remarks: Plato argues that a man does not benefit the common good by forming (sworn) conspiracies to kill the rich and plunder their wealth.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: During civil strife when people fled to Peiraeus (404 to 403)
statement:
[That the reason why Ceramon can feed all his dependants and still save money while Aristarchus struggles to feed his own dependants is that Ceramon's dependants are slaves, while Aristarchus' are free]
 Τί ποτέ ἐστιν, ἔφη, ὅτι Κεράμων μὲν πολλοὺς τρέφων οὐ μόνον ἑαυτῷ τε καὶ τούτοις τὰ ἐπιτήδεια δύναται παρέχειν, ἀλλὰ καὶ περιποιεῖται τοσαῦτα ὥστε καὶ πλουτεῖν, σὺ δὲ πολλοὺς τρέφων δέδοικας μὴ δι’ ἔνδειαν τῶν ἐπιτηδείων ἅπαντες ἀπόλησθε; Ὅτι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ὁ μὲν δούλους τρέφει, ἐγὼ δ’ ἐλευθέρους.
remarks: For a similar sentiment see oath id 2140.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians withdrew from the garrison
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians in the garrison when they withdrew]
remarks:
Thucydides states that when the Four Hundred were ousted, the general Aristarchus took a force of archers to the Athenian fortress at Oenoe which the Corinthians and Boeotians were besieging. 
Aristarchus, after making his plans known to the besiegers, deceived the garrison at Oenoe by telling them that the men in the city had made terms with the Spartans. Aristarchus told the men at Oenoe that it was included in the terms that Oenoe must surrender to the Boeotians. The garrison trusted him because he was a general, and evacuated the fort under a truce (ὑπόσπονδοι).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That Phalaecus and his men would be allowed to depart in safety wherever they pleased if the Phocians agreed to demolish their city walls]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the Phocians made peace with Philip because they put their trust in Aeschines (when he told the Athenians that Philip would spare the Phocians). 
See also oath id 2624.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That it was not the Assembly that gave birth to a boy]
 μὴ φροντίσῃς· ἄρρεν γὰρ ἔτεκε παιδίον. 
 {Βλ.}  ἡκκλησία; {Πρ.} μὰ Δί’
remarks: The joke here is based on the fact that "the Assemby" in Greek is a feminine noun.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
When the Plataeans sent messengers to the Athenians in 429 asking whether it would be acceptable to agree to the terms suggested by the Spartans i.e. to join in the war against Athens or do nothing, the Athenians assured the Plataeans that they had never abandoned them since they had been allies and they would help them to the best of their ability. 
The Athenians adjured the Plataeans by the oaths which their fathers' swore not to break off the alliance. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1561.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: None: Eumaeus does not believe his oath
statement:
[That Odysseus is coming home, and will be back some time during that same year and take his vengeance upon any who dishonours his wife and son]
 ἀλλ’ ἐγὼ οὐκ αὔτως μυθήσομαι, ἀλλὰ σὺν ὅρκῳ, 
ὡς νεῖται Ὀδυσεύς· εὐαγγέλιον δέ μοι ἔστω 
αὐτίκ’, ἐπεί κεν κεῖνος ἰὼν τὰ ἃ δώμαθ’ ἵκηται·
[ἕσσαι με χλαῖνάν τε χιτῶνά τε, εἵματα καλά·]
πρὶν δέ κε, καὶ μάλα περ κεχρημένος, οὔ τι δεχοίμην. 
ἐχθρὸς γάρ μοι κεῖνος ὁμῶς Ἀΐδαο πύλῃσι 
γίνεται, ὃς πενίῃ εἴκων ἀπατήλια βάζει. 
ἴστω νῦν Ζεὺς πρῶτα θεῶν ξενίη τε τράπεζα 
ἱστίη τ’ Ὀδυσῆος ἀμύμονος, ἣν ἀφικάνω· 
ἦ μέν τοι τάδε πάντα τελείεται ὡς ἀγορεύω.  
τοῦδ’ αὐτοῦ λυκάβαντος ἐλεύσεται ἐνθάδ’ Ὀδυσσεύς,
τοῦ μὲν φθίνοντος μηνός, τοῦ δ’ ἱσταμένοιο,
οἴκαδε νοστήσας, καὶ τείσεται, ὅς τις ἐκείνου
ἐνθάδ’ ἀτιμάζει ἄλοχον καὶ φαίδιμον υἱόν.”
τὸν δ’ ἀπαμειβόμενος προσέφης, Εὔμαιε συβῶτα· 
“ὦ γέρον, οὔτ’ ἄρ’ ἐγὼν εὐαγγέλιον τόδε τείσω
οὔτ’ Ὀδυσεὺς ἔτι οἶκον ἐλεύσεται· ἀλλὰ ἕκηλος
πῖνε, καὶ ἄλλα παρὲξ μεμνώμεθα, μηδέ με τούτων
μίμνῃσκ’· ἦ γὰρ θυμὸς ἐνὶ στήθεσσιν ἐμοῖσιν
ἄχνυται, ὁππότε τις μνήσῃ κεδνοῖο ἄνακτος.  
ἀλλ’ ἦ τοι ὅρκον μὲν ἐάσομεν, αὐτὰρ Ὀδυσσεὺς 
ἔλθοι, ὅπως μιν ἐγώ γ’ ἐθέλω καὶ Πηνελόπεια
Λαέρτης θ’ ὁ γέρων καὶ Τηλέμαχος θεοειδής.
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)first among gods; Table of xenia; Hearth of blameless Odysseus
remarks: Odysseus swears the oath but is in disguise as a Cretan beggar. He demands a cloak and a tunic as a reward when the truth of his statement is revealed, but the reward specified is not part of the terms and conditions of the oath proper, since Odysseus, the swearer himself, demands it. In any case, Eumaeus rejects the oath. This is the first of many oaths volunteered by the "Cretan" stating that Odysseus is returning. Odysseus swears, in these or similar terms, to everyone in Ithaca whom he wishes to have as an ally, except for those (Telemachus, Eurycleia) who know his real identity.  To these he has no need to swear:  his word is enough.  See also oath ids 545, 559, 561.

title: IC IV
statement: [That they had brought the child to the husband's master, and that he rejected it]
remarks:
According to the text, if a serf woman who is divorced gives birth to a child it is to be brought to the master of her ex-husband in the presence of witnesses. If he doesn't receive it, the child will be in the mother's power. The text indicates that the witnesses are to be believed (horkioteroi) if they swear that the child was brought to the husband's master. 
See also oath id 3869. 
For the regulation concerning children of free people see oath id 1125.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
statement:
[That Medea is receiving an unfair return from Jason (for all the good she has done him)]
 καὶ θεοὺς μαρτύρεται
  οἵας ἀμοιβῆς ἐξ ᾿Ιάσονος κυρεῖ.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Dionysius of Syracuse. It is not entirely certain whether the alliance was made between Athens and Dionysius I or II. 
Lines 37-8 indicate that each party shall swear their own "lawful oath".  
For the corresponding oath of the Dionysius and the Syracusans see oath id 408.

author: Philetaerus
title: Achilleus
statement:
[That Peleus is not the sort of name a monarch would have]
 Πηλεύς· ὁ Πηλεὺς δ’ ἐστὶν ὄνομα κεραμέως, 
ξηροῦ λυχνοποιοῦ, Κανθάρου, πενιχροῦ πάνυ,
ἀλλ’ οὐ τυράννου νὴ Δία.
remarks: Either there was a well-known potter called Peleus in Athens in Philetaerus’ time, or (perhaps more likely) there is a pun on the literal meaning of the name (“Clay-man”).

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
statement: [That they would protect Plataea should anyone attack]
remarks:
The Plataeans recount how Pausanias called all the Greeks together, made a sacrifice to Zeus Eleutherius, and made them all swear that they would protect the Plataeans if anyone ever marched against them. They claim that the Spartans were obliged to defend them against the Thebans because of this oath sworn after the battle at Plataea.  
See also oath id 1606 and 1629.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Provokes Philocleon to threaten that he will gnaw his way out of the house
statement:
[That Xanthias will never let Philocleon out (of the house)]
 ἴθ’, ἀντιβολῶ σ’, ἔκφρες με, μὴ διαρραγῶ. 
{Ξα.}μὰ τὸν Ποσειδῶ, Φιλοκλέων, οὐδέποτέ γε.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
if_taken: Peace treaty formalised and Spartans and Athenians will rule Greece together
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: This is a reference made by Trygaeus to a potential peace treaty. As Sommerstein ad 1082 remarks: "many Greeks believed in 421 that the Peace of Nicias would indeed result in such a joint Athenian-Spartan dictatorship over Greece".

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Leontiades of Sparta observes that Thebes undertook to conclude an alliance with Olynthus. 
See also oath id 1960.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That wings will not make him summons people any more skillfully]
 Ὑπαὶ πτερύγων τι προσκαλεῖ σοφώτερον;
  {ΣΥ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: The Informer goes on to explain that he wants wings so that he can get quickly to the islands and back without being bothered by pirates at sea.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That the only people who will suffer will be those he mentioned earlier i.e. Leucon of Bosporus, Epicerdes of Cyrene, the exiled Corinthians]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’ οὗτοι μόνοι τοῦτο πείσονται, καὶ περὶ τούτων μόνων ποιοῦμαι λόγον τοσοῦτον.
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that Leptines will swear that the only people who will suffer from his law will be Leucon of Bosporus, Epicerdes of Cyrene, the exiled Corinthians.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Apollodorus tells the jurors to listen to the laws, which are the foundation of their civic life, and which they have sworn to follow when voting. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Lysias
title: Against Alcibiades 2
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker warns the jurors that Alcibiades has disregarded them, and that they ought to disregard him in voting what is best for the polis, especially since they have sworn oaths. He warns that if they allow Alcibiades to go free he will go away mocking the city. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That many times before now he has reflected on the good luck of the city, not least among many reasons, for the fact that during the time when Timarchus held his magistracy no buyer could be found for the city of Andros]
 ἤδη νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω πολλάκις ἐνεθυμήθην τὴν εὐτυχίαν τὴν τῆς ἡμετέρας πόλεως, κατὰ πολλὰ μὲν καὶ ἄλλα, οὐχ ἥκιστα δὲ καὶ κατὰ ταῦτα, ὅτι κατ’ ἐκείνους τοὺς χρόνους οὐδεὶς ἐγένετο τῆς Ἀνδρίων πόλεως ὠνητής.
remarks: Aeschines is alleging that if Timarchus had found anyone (including an enemy state) to whom he could have sold Andros while holding a magistracy there, he would have done so.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That beauty and strength and wealth and glory are to be included in the concept of happiness]
 Τί δ’ ἄν, ἔφη, τῶν εὐδαιμονικῶν ἀμφίλογον εἴη; Οὐδέν, ἔφη, εἴ γε μὴ προσθήσομεν αὐτῷ κάλλος ἢ ἰσχὺν ἢ πλοῦτον ἢ δόξαν ἢ καί τι ἄλλο τῶν τοιούτων. Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία προσθήσομεν, ἔφη·
remarks: Cf. oath id 2138 for response.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides contrasts the Athenian position in 392/1 when they are deliberating whether they should continue the war with the Spartans without the Boeotians who are (according to Andocides) making peace with the Spartans, with the Athenian position in 395 when they made an alliance with the Boeotians in the belief that this would strengthen them so much that they could defend themselves against the whole world. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That Dionysodorus did not explain how to use each formation of men in different strategic situations, when he was teaching the young man about generalship]
 Καὶ μὴν πολλά γ’ ἐστὶ πρὸς ἃ οὔτε τάττειν οὔτε ἄγειν ὡσαύτως προσήκει. Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ διεσαφήνιζε ταῦτα.
remarks: Cf. oath ids 2073 and 2074.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he does not admire those who get angry with one who speaks well (and tells them the truth)]
 Οὐκ ἐπαινέτης εἶ, ἔφην ἐγώ, ὡς ἔοικας, τῶν τοιούτων ἀνδρῶν. Οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that the other ambassadors who were sent to Pella to administer the oaths for the peace led the Athenians astray with regard to Philip's intentions. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he can see a great beast]
 ΞΑ. Καὶ μὴν ὁρῶ νὴ τὸν Δία θηρίον μέγα.
remarks: See also oath ids 392 and 393.  If these oaths are to be taken seriously, they indicate that Xanthias can really see the monster and is not just pretending to do so in order to frighten Dionysus.  It is perhaps significant that it seems that no commentator has ever drawn this inference to help decide what has been a much-vexed question (see for example Sommerstein on 285ff).  However, there is other evidence (viz. his cry of fear at 298, which sounds genuine; Dover also cites the last three words of 296) to indicate that Xanthias is not pretending, so his oaths can be taken at face value.  Otherwise id 392, invoking Poseidon, would be hard to discount.  There is, of course, not the slightest reason to suppose that the audience can see anything at all.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [? That Timotheus owes him 44 minas, 38 drachmas and 2 obols]
remarks: Apollodorus states that after he had put this oath in the evidence box (see oath id 3661), Timotheus thought he could resolve their dispute with an oath of his own (see oath id 3662).

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker asks the jurors to abide by the oaths and agreements i.e. the oaths of reconciliation. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That anger led him to punch Demosthenes] 
 ὀργὴ νὴ Δία
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that Meidias will defend himself in this way.

author: Euripides
title: Hercules
statement:
[That she is acting against her will]
 Λυ. ῞Ηλιον μαρτυρόμεσθα δρῶσ’ ἃ δρᾶν οὐ βούλομαι.
remarks: The reference is to Hera's command to drive Heracles mad, causing him to slaughter his children and wife.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the women will not mock them while they live]
  Οὐ γὰρ μὰ τὴν Δήμητρ’ ἐμοῦ ζῶντος ἐγχανοῦνται·
remarks: The sentiment behind the statement is real enough, but unfortunately for the men, the women will continue to mock them for most of the play.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Pluto providing hospitality for him before he sails off is a good idea]
 ΠΛ.  Ἵνα ξενίσω ’γώ σφω πρὶν ἀποπλεῖν. 
  ΔΙ.  Εὖ λέγεις 
  νὴ τὸν Δί’·

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Aristides; Representatives of various poleis allied to Athens
swearee: Aristides; Representatives of various poleis allied to Athens
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides refers to the alliances between Sparta and and Athens and various poleis after the defeat of the Persians. He states that after these alliances were made both sides were constantly making peace, or fighting with each other or with their own allies who had revolted. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That she is going to come in with him whether he likes it or not]
  ξυνεσπεσοῦμαι γὰρ μετὰ σοῦ.  {Επ.}  μὴ πρὸς θεῶν·  
  ἑνὶ γὰρ ξυνέχεσθαι κρεῖττον ἢ δυοῖν κακοῖν. 
 {Γρ. β} }  νὴ τὴν Ἑκάτην, ἐάν τε βούλῃ γ’ ἤν τε μή.
remarks: On oaths by Hecate, see oath id 777.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That when it is expedient to lie, he cannot make the weaker argument the better]
 ὅταν δὲ ψευδῆ, τὸν ἥττω  λόγον, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία οὐ δύναμαι κρείττω ποιεῖν.
remarks: As Pomeroy notes ad loc., Socrates complains of being accused of making the weaker argument the better in Plato (Apol. 18B, 19B, cf. 23D).

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he will only winnow the rest of the chaff after he has swept the clean grain into a heap]
 Ἐπειδὰν δὲ καθάρῃς, ἔφη, τὸν 
σῖτον μέχρι τοῦ ἡμίσεος τῆς ἅλω, πότερον εὐθὺς οὕτω κεχυ-
μένου τοῦ σίτου λικμήσεις τὰ ἄχυρα τὰ λοιπὰ ἢ συνώσας τὸν
καθαρὸν πρὸς τὸν πόλον ὡς εἰς στενότατον; Συνώσας νὴ
Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ, τὸν καθαρὸν σῖτον

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
When countering the charge that he was the ghost-writer of Philip's letter to the Athenians, Aeschines quotes a passage where Philip writes, "I have given my oaths to your ambassadors", and indicates that he has written the names of his allies who were present (both names and the states they represented) and a list of those who had not arrived in Pella on time. Aeschines asks whether there is anything in the passage which Philip would not have been able to write himself. Cf. Dem. 19.36-41. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Emphasises her conviction in the affections of her boyfriend
statement:
[That if her boyfriend sensed she was upset, he would call her pet names like "my little duck" and "my little dove"]
 Καί, νὴ Δί’, εἰ λυπουμένην γ’ αἴσθοιτό με, 
  νηττάριον ἂν καὶ φάβιον ὑπεκορίζετο.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That soldiers do eat and sleep with good courage because when they are on active duty they post sentries to guard them]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὦ Σιμωνίδη·
remarks:
Hiero is responding to Simonides' observation that even though war is a fearsome thing, "our way when we are on active duty is to post sentries to guard us, and to eat and sleep with good courage". 
Hiero agrees, but adds that military sentries themselves have sentries in front of them i.e. the laws, and so they fear for themselves and on behalf of the troops they are protecting, whereas a tyrant’s guards are serving him only for money, and may well be able to get more money by assassinating him.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he has also seen Athena pouring health and wealth over the Demos with a bathman's ladle]
 Ἀλλ’ ἐγὼ εἶδον ὄναρ, καί μοὐδόκει ἡ θεὸς αὐτὴ 
  τοῦ δήμου καταχεῖν ἀρυταίνῃ πλουθυγίειαν. 
  {ΑΛ.}  Νὴ Δία καὶ γὰρ ἐγώ·

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates argues that if they make peace with their allies - as their "common agreements" (i.e. the terms of the King's Peace) demand they do - they will enjoy peace, security and the financial rewards that peace offers. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Eubulus
title: Chrysilla
if_broken: May he perish if he speaks ill of women
statement:
[That he does not intend to speak ill of women]
 εἶτ’ ἐγὼ κακῶς ποτε 
ἐρῶ γυναῖκας; νὴ Δί’ ἀπολοίμην ἄρα
remarks: The statement is true in intention. Cf. also oath id 1466.

author: Callisthenes
title: Hellenica
if_taken: Alliance between Messene and Arcadia would be formed
if_refused: Alliance between Messene and Arcadia would not be formed
consequences_of_breach: He is stoned to death by his own people and flung beyond the borders of Arcadia without burial
statement: [That he would be a loyal ally of Messene]
remarks: The perjury mentioned here refers to the treachery of Aristocrates who betrayed his Messenian allies to the Spartans, in exchange for a bribe, at the Battle of the Great Trench in the First Messenian War (see Pausanias 4.17). It was only when Aristocrates tried to betray the Messenians to the Spartans for a second time that his original treachery was discovered. Pausanias (4.12) tells us that when this was revealed, the Arcadians themselves stoned Aristocrates to death and threw him out of their borders without burial. They had encouraged the Messenians to join in, but Aristomenes had reacted to the news with eyes fixed to the ground and weeping. So the Arcadians punished Aristocrates themselves. Pausanias says that it was they who set up a tablet in the precinct of Zeus Lycaeus which read: "Truly time has found justice for an unjust king and, with the help of Zeus, has easily found the betrayer of Messene. It is a difficult thing for a perjured man to escape the notice of god. Hail, king Zeus, and keep Arcadia safe". Polybius (4.33.3), however, who credits Callisthenes with reporting this inscription, says that the Messenians set it up on a pillar beside the altar of Zeus Lycaeus.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between  Athens, Arcadia, Achaea, Elis and Phlius. 
See oath id 446.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is not possible for a man to be wise in all things]
 Πάντα μὲν ἄρα σοφὸν οὐχ οἷόν τε ἄνθρωπον εἶναι; Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτα, ἔφη.
remarks: This conclusion follows from Euthydemus' previous agreement that (1) a man can only be wise about those things which he knows and (2) no one has knowledge of everything that exists in the universe (see oath id 2159).

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he wants nothing else than for Thrasymachus to answer his questions honestly]
 οὐκ ἐᾷς λέγειν. καίτοι τί ἄλλο βούλει; Οὐδὲν μὰ Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ
remarks: Thrasymachus’ complaint is essentially that Socrates wants him to answer his questions and not make speeches.  And that (as usual) is indeed what Socrates wants, provided that Thrasymachus gives his honest opinion (e5).  To that stipulation Th. agrees, though only “to please you”, and Socrates reaffirms that that is all he wants. He does not want to allow Th. to “speak” if “speak” is to mean what Th. means by it.

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
if_broken: The Greeks would never take Troy
statement:
[That he would send Philoctetes back to the Achaeans by persuasion]
 ἦ κεῖνος, ἡ πᾶσα βλάβη,
ἔμ’ εἰς ᾿Αχαιοὺς ὤμοσεν πείσας στελεῖν;
remarks: Unlike the oath described by the pseudo-merchant at id 282, in which Odysseus is said to have sworn to take Philoctetes by persuasion or by force, here, Philoctetes takes up the oath as being only concerned with persuasion. In fact this is Odysseus' true goal, but he will be ultimately unable to effect the persuasion himself.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that when they are in the ecclesia they all find fault with the consequences of the peace, and refuse to share in the activities of the Amphictyons, and regard Philip with annoyance and suspicion, believing his actions to be sacrilegious, shocking, unjust and contrary to Athenian interests.  
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: Against Diogeiton
if_taken: Her statement will have more impact
if_broken: Destruction of herself and all her children
statement:
[That Diogeiton had received five talents from Diodotus when he sailed]
 ὃς ἔλαβες μέν, ὅτ’ ἐκεῖνος ἐξέπλει, πέντε τάλαντα παρ’ αὐτοῦ παρακαταθήκην.
remarks:
According to the speaker, Diogeiton's daughter told her father that he ought to be ashamed to have treated her children as he did, and told the speaker and those with him that she was prepared to swear in whatever location her father might name, surrounding herself with her children by Diodotus, and calling down destruction on them, herself, and the children she has borne subsequent to them, that Diogeiton had received five talents from Diodotus when he sailed with Thrasyllus. 
She goes on to say that she is not so wretched, nor does she regard money so highly as to die having committed perjury in the name of her children and unjustly taken away her father's property. 
She then goes on to provide documents demonstrating that Diogeiton received other funds from Diodotus before his death. 
The speaker does not state that Diogeiton's daughter was ever asked to actually swear the oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
impact: Draws attention to the statement about to be made
statement:
[That if "Lamius" put on the leather coat of the All-seeing One, he, if anyone, would be provide fodder for the  public executioner]
  νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν σωτῆρ’ ἐπιτήδειός γ’ ἂν ἦν
  τὴν τοῦ πανόπτου διφθέραν ἐνημμένος 
  εἴπερ τις ἄλλος βουκολεῖν τὸν δήμιον.
remarks: On the complexities of the jokes and puns contained within this statement, see Sommerstein ad 77, 78, 80 and 81.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker quotes one of the clauses of the peace as "If any of the parties shall overthrow the constitution established in each of the states when they swore the oaths concerning the peace, they shall be treated as enemies by all parties to the peace". 
He then goes on to argue that Alexander has overthrown the democracy at Pellene in Achaea and set up Chaeron the wrestler as their tyrant. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus tells the jurors that he is so earnest in urging the agreement to be read to the jurors because Olympiodorus knows well that he has wronged him and the gods in whose name he swore, and that he is a perjurer (see oath id 3623).

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a general reference to oath challenges in trials.

author: Plato
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Socrates' words have always had an extraordinary effect on him]
 ἐγὼ γοῦν, ὦ ἄνδρες, εἰ μὴ ἔμελλον κομιδῇ δόξειν μεθύειν, εἶπον ὀμόσας ἂν ὑμῖν οἷα δὴ πέπονθα αὐτὸς ὑπὸ τῶν τούτου λόγων καὶ πάσχω ἔτι καὶ νυνί
remarks: Alcibiades, in his eulogy of Socrates, suggests that were he not afraid that the others would tell him he were drunk, he would swear an oath to the effect of the statement. However, the oath is never taken, and mention of it seems to serve a purely rhetorical purpose. The rhetorical purpose is presumably to affirm very strongly (i) that the statement is true and (ii) that the effect that Socrates has on Alcibiades is so extraordinary that if Alcibiades were to describe it in detail, no one would believe him even if he made his statement on oath. There may also  be, on Plato’s part, an allusion back to what Pausanias said about lovers’ oaths (see oath id 2925).  That Alcibiades is in fact very drunk will have been as obvious to those present as it is to the reader; it is not clear whether we are to take him as being unaware of this (as people in that state often are) or as only pretending to be unaware of it.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That he could not find his Laconian shoes either]
 μὰ τὸν Διόνυσον, οὐδ’ ἐγὼ γὰρ τὰς ἐμὰς 
  Λακωνικάς
remarks: As the Neighbour and Blepyrus come to the realization that neither of them can find their cloaks and shoes, there is an increase in the intensity of their informal oaths, swearing first by Zeus (the weakest form of oath), then by Poseidon, then by Dionysus. See oath ids 794 and 795.

author: Aristophanes
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment is a single line. Nothing is known about the context. The oath is sworn by "those at a distance", i.e. the gods in heaven.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks: When Agesilaus led a Peloponnesian League expedition against the Acarnanians in 389 he sent a message to the general assembly of the Acarnanians at Stratus that unless they discontinued their alliance with the Athenians and the Boeotians and chose the Spartans and Achaeans as their allies he would lay waste their whole territory.

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks:
Euxitheus, the defendant, argues that the laws, preliminary oaths (διωμοσίαι), cut-pieces and proclamations and all the other things that are done for homicide trials are very different from the proceedings in other trials, because it is imperative that the facts at issue can be verified because there is so much at stake. He argues that to find an innocent man guilty of murder is a mistake that offends both the gods and the laws. 
This passage is almost identical to Antiphon 6.6  (see oath id 2479).

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that Philocrates and Demosthenes wanted the demos to vote to conclude peace and an alliance with Philip and to exclude Cersobleptes from the oaths (and the alliance and peace). 
He argues that Philip was not wrong to want these things, for before the oaths had been taken and the agreements made he could not be blamed for negotiating to his own advantage.  
Aeschines argues that those who sold off and conspired against the city's power - i.e. Philocrates and Demosthenes - deserve bitter resentment. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: Cyrus will help him avenge the death of his son
if_refused: Cyrus will not help him avenge the death of his son
statement:
[That if Cyrus helps him avenge his son and lets him keep his castle and province and the power he had before, Gobryas will give Cyrus the castle as his headquarters when he comes and will pay him the tribute of the province. Gobryas, with the forces of his province, will follow Cyrus wherever he may march, and he gives Cyrus his daughter in marriage]
 Ἀλλ’ ἤνπερ, ὦ Γωβρύα, καὶ φρονῶν φαίνῃ ὅσαπερ λέγεις πρὸς ἡμᾶς, δέχομαί τε ἱκέτην σε καὶ τιμώρησίν σοι τοῦ παιδὸς σὺν θεοῖς ὑπισχνοῦμαι. λέξον δέ μοι, ἔφη, ἐάν σοι ταῦτα ποιῶμεν καὶ τὰ τείχη σε ἔχειν ἐῶμεν καὶ τὴν χώραν καὶ τὰ
ὅπλα καὶ τὴν δύναμιν ἥνπερ πρόσθεν εἶχες, σὺ ἡμῖν τί ἀντὶ  τούτων ὑπηρετήσεις; ὁ δὲ εἶπε· Τὰ μὲν τείχη, ὅταν ἔλθῃς, οἶκόν σοι παρέξω· δασμὸν δὲ τῆς χώρας ὅνπερ ἔφερον ἐκείνῳ σοὶ ἀποίσω, καὶ ὅποι ἂν στρατεύῃ συστρατεύσομαι τὴν ἐκ τῆς χώρας δύναμιν ἔχων. ἔστι δέ μοι, ἔφη, καὶ θυγάτηρ παρθένος ἀγαπητὴ γάμου ἤδη ὡραία, ἣν ἐγὼ πρόσθεν μὲν ᾤμην τῷ νῦν βασιλεύοντι γυναῖκα τρέφειν· νῦν δὲ αὐτή τέ με ἡ θυγάτηρ πολλὰ γοωμένη ἱκέτευσε μὴ δοῦναι αὐτὴν τῷ τοῦ ἀδελφοῦ φονεῖ, ἐγώ τε ὡσαύτως γιγνώσκω. νῦν δέ σοι δίδωμι βουλεύσασθαι καὶ περὶ ταύτης οὕτως ὥσπερ ἂν  καὶ ἐγὼ βουλεύων περὶ σοῦ φαίνωμαι. οὕτω δὴ ὁ Κῦρος εἶπεν· Ἐπὶ τούτοις, ἔφη, ἐγὼ ἀληθευομένοις δίδωμί σοι τὴν ἐμὴν καὶ λαμβάνω τὴν σὴν δεξιάν· θεοὶ δ’ ἡμῖν μάρτυρες ἔστων.
remarks: Cf. remarks on oath id 2397.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he is a thief]
 Ὁμολογῶ κλέπτειν· σὺ δ’ οὐχί.
  {ΑΛ.}  Νὴ τὸν Ἑρμῆν τὸν Ἀγοραῖον.
remarks: As Sommerstein remarks ad 297, Hermes was the god of trading, and a statue of him stood in the agora. Hermes was also the god of stealing and of deceptive swearing (cf. oath ids 1358, 1361, 1364).

author: Xenophon
title: Lacedaemonian Politeia (except ch.14)
date: During the experience of Xenophon (399 to 355)
swearee: The other members of the sworn band
if_taken: He could be part of a sworn band
if_refused: He could not be part of a sworn band
statement: [? That he would fight while he was alive, and would not regard being alive as more important than being free; that he would not leave his taxiarch or his enomotarch, whether he was alive or dead, and that he would bury the dead among his fellow-fighters, and that he would leave no-one unburied]
remarks:
Xenophon observes that orders to wheel from column into line of battle are given by the enomotarchs - "the commanders of the sworn band" acting as heralds. 
See also oath id 1272.

title: SEG
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That if anyone attacked Pisa (or overthrew the demos?) they would help with all their strength on land and sea]
remarks:
This inscription records and alliance between Pisa, Sicyon and Messene. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 49.466. For the corresponding oath of the Pisatans see oath id 583.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That his parents do rebuke him and that there are an awful lot of things they stop him from doing]
  Ἐῶσιν ἄρα σε ἃ βούλει ποιεῖν, καὶ οὐδὲν ἐπιπλήττουσιν οὐδὲ διακωλύουσι ποιεῖν ὧν ἂν ἐπιθυμῇς; Ναὶ μὰ Δία ἐμέ γε, ὦ Σώκρατες καὶ μάλα γε πολλὰ κωλύουσιν.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That Demosthenes should be of good cheer because he won't suffer any insolence in the future]
 θάρρει νὴ Δία, φήσειέ τις ἄν· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ οὐδὲν ὑβρισθήσει.
remarks: Demosthenes asks why he should overlook his mistreatment by Meidias, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his rhetorical question.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That Pericles has been shown to be no good statesman not only by Socrates' account, but also by what Callicles has agreed to]
 Οὐκ ἄρ’ ἀγαθὸς τὰ πολιτικὰ Περικλῆς ἦν ἐκ τούτου τοῦ λόγου.  {ΚΑΛ.} Οὐ σύ γε φῄς.  {ΣΩ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐδέ γε σὺ ἐξ ὧν ὡμολόγεις.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement:
[That everyone will know which of the two was fined]
 ὅτι νὴ Δί’ εἴσονται πάντες πότερός ποτ’ ὦφλεν.
remarks: Mantitheus asks what will happen if Boeotus is listed among those owing a fine to the state, and imagines that someone will respond in this way.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
date: Time of writing of Ath. Pol. (335 to 322)
statement: [? That they would give a just verdict]
remarks: Rhodes remarks ad loc.: "The oath was probably a promissory oath on accepting a case, rather than a confirmatory oath when pronouncing judgement".

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of various Greek poleis
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of various Greek poleis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that when the dispute arose between Chalcis and Eretria all the rest of the Greeks took sides in alliance with one side or the other (see also oath id 1518).  
For the involvement of Miletus and Samos in the so-called Lelantine war, see Herodotus 5.99 (oath id 1522 and 1523).

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: The speaker's case would be believed
if_refused: The speaker's case would not be believed
statement: [That what he is saying is true]
remarks: Here the Athenian admires Rhadamathys' way of judging legal cases. In that time when all believed in the gods, cases were dealt with simply and effectively by issuing oath challenges to those involved in a dispute. The implication is that no one at that time would have committed perjury for fear of divine retribution, so the truth became clear in each case very quickly.

title: IC IV
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: All that can be determined is that an oath was sworn regarding produce (καρπο̃ ο῏τί κα κατομόσαντι).

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: There will be peace between the Armenians and Chaldaeans
statement: [That they will be friends, be free from one another,  have the right of intermarriage and mutual tillage and pasturage in each other's territories, and have a defensive alliance in case any one should injure either party]
remarks: Cyrus also agrees to leave a garrison on the heights between both countries to ensure that the terms of the peace treaty are enforced. In the passage referred to in this entry, the Chaldaeans return after consultation with their people to accept the peace treaty, which is ratified in section 23- cf. oath ids 2376 and 2380.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That the birds were not aware that they were more ancient than the Earth]
 Τουτὶ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἐπεπύσμην.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 646.

author: Amphis
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a discussion about those who do not trust oaths. "Whoever does not trust in any way someone who swears an oath", we are told, “knows the easy ways to commit perjury himself”.  The point is, in effect, that one who is good at suspecting and detecting perjury will also be good at committing it:  very much the same point as that made by Socrates in his argument with Polemarchus in book I of Plato’s Republic, that one who is good at guarding property will also be good at stealing it and vice versa.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: The Acanthians will revolt from Athens
if_refused: They will not revolt from Athens
statement:
[That whoever he should win as allies should be autonomous]
 ἦ μὴν οὓς ἂν ἔγωγε προσαγάγωμαι ξυμμάχους ἔσεσθαι αὐτονόμους
remarks:
According to Thucydides, the Acanthians refused to revolt until Brasidas offered to swear the same oath that the Spartan magistrates had sworn i.e that whoever he should win as allies should be autonomous. 
See also oath id 1673.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That it was not bad of the women to put the men's tunics back on]
 Ἀλλὰ τὴν ἐξωμίδ’ ἐνδύσω σε προσιοῦσ’ ἐγώ.
{Χ. ΓΕ.} Τοῦτο μὲν μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ πονηρὸν ἐποήσατε·

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Aristotle quotes Gorgias fr. 15 (see oath id 1603) as an example of frigid style resulting from the use of compound words.

author: Lysias
title: Against Theomnestus 1
date: At the time of the speech i.e. 384/3 (384)
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement:
[That he knew well that the defendant had killed]
ἔκτεινε
remarks:
The speaker is prosecuting Theomnestus for slandering him by charging him with parricide. He suggests that Theomnestus will again argue that he has not said that he is a "murderer" (androphonos), but rather that "he killed his father". 
The speaker argues that the jurors all know that on the Areopagus they do not use the term "androphonos" in making sworn statements (diomosiai), but the words used by Theomnestus. 
He states that the prosecutor swears that the defendant "has killed", and the defendant swears that he "has not killed". 
He goes on to argue that it would be absurd to acquit a murderer when he declared that he was an "androphonos" on the ground that the prosecutor swore that the defendant "had killed".

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That Agathon means "get fucked" when he says "steal"]
 Ἰδού γε κλέπτειν· νὴ Δία, βινεῖσθαι μὲν οὖν.
remarks: This is with reference to the women's complaints about Agathon that, as Sommerstein ad 205 puts it: "he usurps sexual opportunities which "ought" to be available for women".

author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement: unknown
remarks: This is a discussion refering to someone who swears an oath for personal gain. The oath statement, whatever it is, may or may not be true, but the oath is taken against moral norms of justice and must be deceptive, at least, if not false. Such a person may seem to profit in the short term, but in the long run he will become wretched once more, for the gods' design prevails.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the alliance]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Chalcis. 
The terms of the alliance were that: Chalcis would be free, autonomous, ungarrisoned. Chalcis would pay no tribute, and would not receive a governor from the Athenians. The Athenians and Chalcidians would defend each other as far as they were able. 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 351.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
impact: Highlights Menelaus' emphatic change of mind
statement:
[That he will speak clearly from his heart with no ulterior motive, but as he really thinks]
 Πέλοπα κατόμνυμ’, ὃς πατὴρ τοὐμοῦ πατρὸς
  τοῦ σοῦ τ’ ἐκλήθη, τὸν τεκόντα τ’ ᾿Ατρέα,
  ἦ μὴν ἐρεῖν σοι τἀπὸ καρδίας σαφῶς 
  καὶ μὴ ’πίτηδες μηδέν, ἀλλ’ ὅσον φρονῶ.
gods_invoked: PelopsEpithet(s)father of their father; AtreusEpithet(s)their father
remarks: The use of an oath here by Menelaus may make his dramatic change of mind at this point in the play somewhat more credible.

author: Chionides
title: Heroes
statement:
[That the swearer thinks s/he is no different from an agnus castus growing in a gully]
 καὶ μὴν μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐδὲν ἔτι γέ μοι δοκῶ
ἄγνου διαφέρειν ἐν χαράδρᾳ πεφυκότος.
remarks: In comedy it is perhaps more likely that a man would find reason to say this than that a woman would; the next (lost) line might be something like “I’m a turn-off to every woman I meet”.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That is would not be a great shame for Androtion, Glaucetes or Melanopus to be sent to prison]
 οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’
remarks: Diodorus is responding to an imaginary sworn objection (see oath id 3479).

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_kept: That Paphlagon will continue to be able to dine in the Prytaneum... for having done nothing
if_broken: May he perish and be sawn in two and cut into yoke-straps
impact: Prompts the Sausage-seller to give his own oath
statement:
[That he does not hate Demos and that he is the only man who stands firm and fights for Demos]
 εἰ δέ σε μισῶ καὶ μὴ περί σου μάχομαι μόνος ἀντιβεβηκώς, 
  ἀπολοίμην καὶ διαπρισθείην κατατμηθείην τε λέπαδνα.
remarks: This is a conditional self-curse. See also the Sausage-seller's conditional self-curse at id 1020.

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians.
