But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates imagines that someone might object to his suggestion that the Greeks should unite in a war against the Persians on the grounds that some states have gained their freedom through the peace and may feel grateful to the King, because they believe it was through him that they gained their autonomy, and those states which were handed over to the King complain bitterly about the Spartans and the other Greeks who entered into the treaty and caused their slavery. 
He responds to this imaginary criticism by answering that it is the duty of the Greeks to undo the agreement. 
Isocrates also criticises the peace treaty because (in his opinion) the Greeks observe and defend only the worst and shameful terms of the peace, and that those which guarantee the freedom of the islands and cities of Europe have long since been broken and are dead letters on the stelae. 
He goes on to argue that the ambassadors who negotiated the peace, although sent from Greece, made the treaty in the interests of the Persians. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he was afraid the god might beat him to the broth-pot]
  Κἀγὼ νομίσας πολλὴν ὁσίαν τοῦ πράγματος 
  ἐπὶ τὴν χύτραν τὴν τῆς ἀθάρης ἀνίσταμαι.  Ταλάντατ’ ἀνδρῶν, οὐκ ἐδεδοίκεις τὸν θεόν; 
  {ΚΑ.}  Νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς ἔγωγε

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he is not proud of the boy (because the boy is a source of worry for him)]
 ὦ Συρακόσιε, ἐπὶ τῷ μέγα φρονεῖς; ἢ δῆλον ὅτι ἐπὶ τῷ παιδί; Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ μὲν δή·

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines states that his accusers say that Philip bought the peace, that he overreached the Athenians in all the articles of the agreement, and that he has breached the peace that he devised to his own advantage. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That their period of separation has been very short]
 ἀλλ’ ἥκω διὰ χρόνου. καὶ τὸν Κῦρον εἰπεῖν· Νὴ Δί’, ὦ σύγγενες, δι’ ὀλίγου γε.
remarks: Their period of separation has, in fact, only been a few lines of text. Cf. oath id 2319.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he hasn't grasped anything]
 ἔχεις τι;
 {Στ.}  μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’ ἔγωγ’.
remarks: The statement is ambiguous (as 734 comically reveals).

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Methymna under the auspices of the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
The text indicates that Aesimus (the Athenian strategos?) and the synedroi on the ships would take care that the Methymnaean archai swore like the other allies. 
For the oath sworn by the Methymnaean envoys see oath id 334. For the oath sworn by the Athenians see oath id 335. 
For other references to the Second Athenian Confederacy see oath id 2974.

author: Plato
title: Euthyphro
statement:
[That only a man far advanced in wisdom will know the right way to prosecute his father]
 οὐ γὰρ οἶμαί γε τοῦ ἐπιτυχόντος ὀρθῶς αὐτὸ πρᾶξαι ἀλλὰ πόρρω που ἤδη σοφίας ἐλαύνοντος.  {ΕΥΘ.} Πόρρω μέντοι νὴ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες.
remarks: Euthyphro is prosecuting his father on a charge of homicide and is convinced that he is exceedingly wise and pious. The new Oxford text (Duke et al.) retains ὀρθῶς, which Burnet had deleted.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
if_taken: Their statements will carry more weight
statement: [? That they would declare what they regarded as true from the statements]
remarks: Demosthenes tells the jurors that Aphobus dismissed the arbitrators he chose to resolve his dispute with Demosthenes when they told him that they would find him guilty for his guardianship if they gave their verdict under oath.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
statement:
[That she is not devising ill for Odysseus]
 εἰ μή μοι τλαίης γε, θεά, μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμόσσαι, 
μή τί μοι αὐτῷ πῆμα κακὸν βουλευσέμεν ἄλλο.’ 
  ὣς ἐφάμην, ἡ δ’ αὐτίκ’ ἀπώμνυεν, ὡς ἐκέλευον. 
αὐτὰρ ἐπεί ῥ’ ὄμοσέν τε τελεύτησέν τε τὸν ὅρκον
remarks: This oath is related by Odysseus in his narrative to Alcinous. It is reported as proposed by Odysseus and sworn by Circe and is first suggested to Odysseus by Hermes at oath id 537. Cf. also oath id 540.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That beauty is not good nor good beauty]
 Μὰ Δία, ὦ ἄριστε, οὐδὲ ἄρα τὸ καλὸν ἀγαθόν ἐστιν, οὐδὲ τὸ ἀγαθὸν καλόν·
remarks: Socrates' statement is based on what has been previously agreed: beauty is the cause of good, but the cause is not that which it brings into existence nor vice versa  (i.e. nothing is the cause of itself). Hence beauty is not good nor vice versa. But see also oath ids 3162-3164.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
[That if anyone went to war against the Athenian demos or the Athenian settlers in Potidaea they would help the Athenians in words and deeds]
 [ἐὰν τις ἴηι π]ο̣λ̣έ̣μ̣ι̣ος [ἐπὶ τὴν πό]λιν τὴν Ἀθη[ναίων ἢ ἐπὶ τὸς ἐποίκος τὸς Ἀθηναίων τ]ὸ[ς Ποτείδ]α̣ιαν ἔχοντ[ας, βοηθήσω Ἀθηναίοις κατὰ τὸ δυνατὸν καὶ λόγωι κ]αὶ ἔργωι [- - - - -]
remarks:
This inscriptions records an agreement between Athens and colonists from Aphytis. 
The oaths sworn by the colonists from Aphytis and the Athenians were to be inscribed on stone stelai in both cities. 
The Athenian demos resolved that the colonists from Aphytis would have to pay 500 drachmas to "the goddess". The corresponding oath of the Athenians has not survived.

author: Antiphon
title: Against the stepmother
if_taken: He will help establish the innocence of his mother
if_refused: He will not help establish the innocence of his mother
if_broken: Destruction of self, family and household (?)
statement: [That he knew well that his mother had not killed]
remarks: The prosecutor says, "I am ashamed by the shameless spirit shown by my brother. To think that he swore in his mother's defence that he was sure of her innocence!".

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, in 395 the leading men in Thebes were aware that unless someone began the war the Spartans would not break the treaty with their allies. They resolved to stir up trouble between Sparta's allies, which would then force the Spartans to intervene. 
Accordingly, they persuaded the Opuntian Locrians to levy money from territory which was in dispute between Phocis and Locris, for they thought that if this was done Phocis would invade Locris. This did happen, and the Thebans made a counter invasion of Phocis. When Phocis appealed to Sparta for assistance, war between Sparta and Thebes ensued. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That they should bring Diopeithes to trial]
 κρινοῦμεν Διοπείθη νὴ Δία.
remarks: Demosthenes is imagining how someone might respond to his question regarding what to do if Diopeithes marches on the Chersonese after his force is officially disbanded.

author: Sophocles
title: Electra
impact: Prompts Orestes to remind Electra of Clytemnestra's role in the killing of Agamemnon
statement:
[That Electra is not afraid of those in the house]
 Ηλ. μὰ τὰν ῎Αρτεμιν τὰν ἀεὶ ἀδμήταν,
τόδε μὲν οὔποτ’ ἀξιώσω τρέσαι, 
περισσὸν ἄχθος ἔνδον 
γυναικῶν ὃ ναίει.

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
statement: [That they would not attack each other]
remarks: Theopompus refers to a truce between the Egyptians and the Barcaeans.

author: Aristotle
title: Politics
date: Any time with oligarchs in office (400 to 330)
impact: This will give greater security to their rule
statement:
[That they will not wrong the people]
 οὐκ ἀδικήσω τὸν δῆμον
remarks: Aristotle here proposes that oligarchs should actually swear the opposite of what some swear, which is to be hostile to the people. See also oath id 1624 for further details.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That vying in being hungry is nice if there's a piper about]
See also remarks.
 {ΔΙ.}Πῶς ἔχετε; {ΜΕ.}  Διαπεινᾶμες ἀεὶ ποττὸ πῦρ.  
{ΔΙ.}  Ἀλλ’ ἡδύ τοι νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἢν αὐλὸς παρῇ.
remarks: Dicaeopolis here misunderstands the  Megarian's statement and answers as if he had spoken of "drinking bouts" (διαπίνομες) rather than "starvation bouts" (διαπεινᾶμες). See Sommerstein ad loc.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That if anyone goes against the Chians they would go in support as far as possible]
 ἐ[ά]ν τις ἴηι [ἐπὶ Χί]ος βοηθε̃ν Ἀθηναί[ος π]α̣ντὶ σθέ[νει κατὰ τ]ὸ δυνατόν
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Chios. 
The Athenian oath was sworn before the Chians who had come to Athens as presbeis. The terms of the alliance indicate that the Athenians and Chians would come to the aid of each other to the best of their ability if they were attacked by a third party. These oaths were stated to have been in addition to and not in violation of those sworn in the King's Peace (see oath id 328) which is described as a peace and oath and agreement.  
For the corresponding oath of the Chians see oath id 306. IG II(2) 35 is a copy of IG II(2) 34

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: When Herodotus was in Libya ca.465-444 (?) (465 to 444)
statement: n/a
remarks: Herodotus observes that when the Nasamones swear oaths they lay their hands on the graves of the men reputed to have been the most just and good among them, and swear by them.

title: IG XII 9
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Histiaea and Eretria. 
The text indicates that the oaths should be renewed each Olympiad. The text clearly stipulates that the current archai and all future archai will swear the oath. The text also indicates a penalty of ten talents for whichever party transgresses the alliance (a tithe from which will go to the shrine of Apollo).  
For the oath of the Histiaeans see oath id 757.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: The Epidaurians would be required to pay their debt
if_refused: The Epidaurians would be deemed not to owe anything
statement: [? That the Epidaurians were in debt to Apollo Pythaeus]
remarks:
Thucydides notes that one of the terms of the peace treaty between Argos and Sparta (see oath id 1746) included a clause regarding the offering to Apollo Pythaeus .  
Thucydides states at 5.53 that the Epidaurians were obliged to send a sacrifice to the Argive-controlled sanctuary of Apollo Pythaeus as payment for pasturage. The Argives accused the Epidaurians of not doing so, and war broke out.  
Thucydides adds that the Argives did so on the advice of Alcibiades. Both parties hoped to bring Epidaurus into the "Argive alliance" in order to keep Corinth quiet, and to reduce the time it would take to bring aid to Argos from Athens by sea.  
The clause in the treaty between Sparta and Argos stipulated that the Argives "if they wished, might tender an oath to the Epidaurians, or, if not, should swear one themselves".  This appears to mean that the dispute over the offering should be settled by the procedure of oath-challenge, with the Argives having the right to choose whether to demand an oath from the Epidaurians (presumably to the effect that they did not owe anything to the sanctuary) or to swear one themselves (presumably to the contrary effect); the side refusing to swear would be deemed to have accepted that it was in the wrong. 
See also oath id 1747.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines asks, "Was I the one who prevented the people from imitating their ancestors, or you and your fellow conspirators against the common good? Was it safer and more honourable for the Athenians to march out when the Phocians were at the height of their madness, when they were at war with Philip and were holding Halponus and Nicaea, and the people we were to support were rejecting the truce for the Mysteries, and we were leaving the Thebans in our rear; or when Philip invited us, when we were bound by oaths of alliance, and when the Thessalians and the rest of the Amphictyons were participating?". 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
impact: Leads Trygaeus to believe the Chorus
statement:
[That after kicking out their right leg, they will have finished dancing]
 Τουτογὶ νὴ τὸν Δία τὸ σκέλος ῥίψαντες ἤδη λήγομεν τὸ δεξιόν.
remarks: A.H. Sommerstein comments in a personal communication: "Trygaeus, apparently persuaded by the oath of their sincerity, grants them this one high kick – and then they say "But I can't avoid doing the same with the left as well, you know!" (334).  That, by itself, might be excused on the plea of force majeure; an oath, like a law, cannot compel one to do the impossible.  It will, however, be another matter if they then continue to dance on as if nothing had happened; and certainly their next few words might suggest that they do:  "I’m glad, I’m happy, I fart, I laugh, at having escaped from my shield, more than if I’d cast off my old age! (335-6)."  However, Trygaeus, though still annoyed with them, no longer complains that they are still dancing, and I think on the whole we are not here entitled to assume that they have violated their oath". On the fluctuating identity of the Chorus in this play, see Sommerstein (ed) xviii-xix.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he is no longer angry at the suggestion that he is a good go-between]
 σὺ δὲ ὡς κακῶς ἀκούσας ὅτι ἀγαθόν σε ἔφην προαγωγὸν εἶναι, ὠργίσθης. Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ νῦν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he was not one of the crooks and villains]
  Ἦ τῶν πονηρῶν ἦσθα καὶ τοιχωρύχων; 
  {ΣΥ.}  Μὰ Δί’

author: Plato
title: Crito
impact: Emphasises Crito's wish for Socrates to escape
statement:
[That if, when attempting to leave the city, Socrates were asked by the laws of Athens if he is rejecting the state verdict and penalty on him, he should reply that he is because the state has wronged him by passing a faulty judgment]
 εἰ μέλλουσιν ἡμῖν ἐνθένδε εἴτε 
ἀποδιδράσκειν, εἴθ’ ὅπως δεῖ ὀνομάσαι τοῦτο, ἐλθόντες οἱ 
νόμοι καὶ τὸ κοινὸν τῆς πόλεως ἐπιστάντες ἔροιντο· “Εἰπέ 
μοι, ὦ Σώκρατες, τί ἐν νῷ ἔχεις ποιεῖν; ἄλλο τι ἢ τούτῳ τῷ ἔργῳ ᾧ ἐπιχειρεῖς διανοῇ τούς τε νόμους ἡμᾶς ἀπολέσαι
καὶ σύμπασαν τὴν πόλιν τὸ σὸν μέρος; ἢ δοκεῖ σοι οἷόν τε 
ἔτι ἐκείνην τὴν πόλιν εἶναι καὶ μὴ ἀνατετράφθαι, ἐν ᾗ ἂν
αἱ γενόμεναι δίκαι μηδὲν ἰσχύωσιν ἀλλὰ ὑπὸ ἰδιωτῶν ἄκυροί
τε γίγνωνται καὶ διαφθείρωνται;” τί ἐροῦμεν, ὦ Κρίτων, 
πρὸς ταῦτα καὶ ἄλλα τοιαῦτα; πολλὰ γὰρ ἄν τις ἔχοι, 
ἄλλως τε καὶ ῥήτωρ, εἰπεῖν ὑπὲρ τούτου τοῦ νόμου ἀπολλυμένου ὃς τὰς δίκας τὰς δικασθείσας προστάττει κυρίας εἶναι. ἢ ἐροῦμεν πρὸς αὐτοὺς ὅτι “Ἠδίκει γὰρ ἡμᾶς ἡ πόλις καὶ
οὐκ ὀρθῶς τὴν δίκην ἔκρινεν;” ταῦτα ἢ τί ἐροῦμεν;
  {ΚΡ.} Ταῦτα νὴ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Menecles
swearer: The speaker and his party; Menecles' brother and his party
swearee: The speaker and his party; Menecles' brother and his party
statement: [That in future they would behave properly towards one another, both in words and deeds, as far as lay in their power]
remarks:
The speaker argues that the oath would not have been necessary if his adoption by Menecles had not been carried out legally, and had he not been recognised as Menecles' heir by his opponents. He asks the jurors why his opponents would have needed to be reconciled with him if he was not legally Menecles' heir. 
See also oath id 3027.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [? That he would use his forces in the interests of Memnon and Mentor]
remarks: Euthycles claims that Charidemus hired himself out to the sons-in-law of Artabazus - Memnon and Mentor - and after taking and receiving pledges, ignored and broke his oaths by seizing Scepsis, Cebren and Ilium. These cities were caught off guard because they thought they were dealing with a friend.

author: Euripides
title: Rhesus
swearee: Second Soldier (Chorus); Leader (Chorus); Third Soldier; Driver of Rhesus' Chariot
if_broken: They can regard Hector as a nobody and a coward
impact: Prompts the Chorus to argue in their defence
statement:
[That the lash and beheading are the fates awaiting soldiers who desert their post]
 εὖ νυν τόδ’ ἴστε—Ζεὺς ὀμώμοται πατήρ—
  ἤτοι μάραγνά γ’ ἢ καρανιστὴς μόρος
  μένει σε δρῶντα τοιάδ’, ἢ τὸν ῞Εκτορα
  τὸ μηδὲν εἶναι καὶ κακὸν νομίζετε.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Pyrrhus
statement:
[That Pyrrhus could have adopted another relative and given him the possession of his estate and his daughter]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία ἄλλον τινὰ ποιησάμενος τῶν συγγενῶν ἔδωκεν ἂν ἔχειν τὸν κλῆρον καὶ τὴν θυγατέρα τὴν ἑαυτοῦ·
remarks: In response to this imaginary objection, the speaker points out that Pyrrhus would never have needed to adopt an heir if he had really married the sister of Nicodemus because he could then have adopted one of her grandsons as his heir. The point is that he would not have needed to take the invidious step of choosing a relative to adopt (thus offending those who weren’t chosen), because, having a legitimate daughter with children, he would have had what all would have recognised as the next best thing to a direct male line heir, and could have adopted one of the children without anyone complaining.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Hagnias
statement:
[That the charges against him cannot be justified when they concern his own property]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἐπὶ τοῖς ἐμοῖς.
remarks: Theopompus argues that if he were holding property that belonged to the child the charges against him would be justified, but not when they concern his own property.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [That he had not acknowledged that Milyas was free and that he had not testified against Demon]
remarks: Demosthenes states that Aphobus refused to give the oath either to himself or the witnesses (see also oath id 3524).

author: Hypereides
title: In defence of Euxenippus
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Hypereides says to the jurors, "when you are on the point of voting, urge the clerk to read out the impeachment law and the Heliastic oath". He urges them to let the laws govern their decision, and to give their vote according to what seems just and in keeping with their oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Alexis
title: Mandragorizomene
if_broken: That the swearer may be turned into an eel and purchased by Callimedon "the Crayfish"
statement: That the speaker does not love any other foreigners more than he does the swearees
remarks: Callimedon (nicknamed after one of his favourite dishes) was a politician and a notorious glutton; so the self-curse here is in effect "May I be devoured".

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That he is not trying to discuss slaves with Socrates]
 Περὶ δούλων μοι, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης,
ἐπιχειρεῖς, ὦ Κριτόβουλε, διαλέγεσθαι;  Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη,
οὐκ ἔγωγε
remarks: Critobulus has just said that there are some people who are in a position, and have the necessary knowledge, to increase their property, but have no wish actually to do so.  Socrates asks him whether he is referring to slaves, and he says no – there are some people of very noble birth who have useful skills but don’t bother to put them to use “precisely because they have no master”.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That (he thinks) "alektruaina" is a nice neologism]
 ἀλεκτρύαιναν; εὖ γε νὴ τὸν Ἀέρα·

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he knows he has learned how to deceive and entrap animals when hunting, but he would be severely punished if he even thought of deceiving a fellow human]
 ἢ οὐ πάντα γιγνώσκεις ταῦτα ὅτι κακουργίαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ἀπάται καὶ δολώσεις καὶ πλεονεξίαι; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, θηρίων γε· ἀνθρώπων δὲ εἰ καὶ δόξαιμι βούλεσθαι ἐξαπατῆσαί τινα, πολλὰς πληγὰς οἶδα λαμβάνων.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2335.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Peloponnesians departed and were attacked by the Acarnanian soldiers
statement: [? That they would not molest the Peloponnesians while they withdrew]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, after being defeated in battle by the Athenians and Acarnanians, Menedaius the Spartan commander of the Peloponnesian and Ambraciot army approached Demosthenes the Athenian general regarding a truce for recovering the dead. 
Demosthenes agreed to a secret treaty (without the knowledge of his Acarnanian allies) whereby Menedaius, the Peloponnesian commanders and the Mantinean soldiers could return home. 
Thucydides explicitly states that Demosthenes and the Acarnanian leaders would not openly agree to the retreat of the whole army, but were content with this compromise. 
According to Thucydides, Demosthenes hoped to discredit the Peloponnesians in the region by allowing them to withdraw. 
See also oath id 1634.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
swearer: The Thirty and their followers; Athenians
swearee: The Thirty and their followers; Athenians
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
Here we are told of an unnamed citizen who began to ignore the terms of the reconciliation agreement (for which see oath id 1796). Archinus persuades the council to execute him without regular trial as an example to show their willingness to abide by their oaths. The man was executed and no one afterwards broke the terms of the reconciliation. 
See also oath id 1900-1902.

title: IG I(3)
swearer: Perdiccas; Alcetas, son of Alexander (Perdiccas's brother); Archelaus, son of Perdiccas; Alexander, son of Alcetas; Aeropus, son of Philip; Menelaus, son of Alexander; Agelaus, son of Alcetas; Byrginus, son of Craston; Agerrus, son of Philip; Alexander, son of Pantapon; Eurylochus; Neoptolemus; Eulander; Antigenes; Adimus; Cleander; Lycaeus; Nomenius; Craston; Stadmeas; Nicander; Gaeteas; Callias; Corratas; Meleager; Dirbeas; Arrhabaeus; Limnaeus; Autannius; Callimachus; Derdas of Elimea; Antiochus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they have the same friends and enemies as the Athenians, and would be allies to the Athenians forever, without guile and without injury]
 δράσο κα̣[ὶ ἐρο̃ - - - - ]
[- - - καὶ τὸ]ς̣ αὐτὸς φίλος νομιο̃ καὶ ἐχθρ̣[ὸς hόσπερ ἂν Ἀθεναῖοι - - - ]
[- - - πρὸς Ἀθε]ν̣αίος δικαίος καὶ ἀδόλος κα[ὶ ἀβλαβο̃ς - - -]
[- - - κ]ατὰ τὸ δυνατὸν το̃ι δέμοι το̃ι [Ἀθεναίον - - -]
[- - καὶ οὐδένα κο]πέας ἐχσάγεν ἐάσο ἐὰμ μὲ Ἀθενα̣ιον [- - -]
[- - - δ]υ̣ν̣ατὸν hόσοι ἂν ἐθέλοσι [- - -]
[- - -]ιας πρ̣ὸς Ἀθεναίος·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Perdiccas, King of Macedon and his allies, and Arrhabaeus the Lyncestian and his allies. 
The terms of the oath are very fragmentary, but it is clear that Perdiccas and the Athenians are to have the same friends and enemies, Athens will have exclusive rights to take timber for oars from Macedon, and the agreement includes peaceful relations between Perdiccas and Arrhabaeus the Lyncestian in its terms. 
It appears that the Athenians compelled the entire Macedonian nobility to swear the oath alongside Perdiccas to ensure his loyalty. Numerous others swore the oath, but their names are too fragmentary to be included in the database. This entry takes into account textual changes from SEG 25.18. 
For other references to alliances between Perdiccas and Athens see oath id 257, 1544, 1546, 1568, 1679, 1682, 1755.

author: Aristophanes
title: Geras
statement:
[That the swearer will follow the swearee for a few days]
 {Α.} σὺ δ’ οὐκ ἕπῃ μοι; {Β.} νὴ Δί’, ὀλίγας ἡμέρας.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That if he didn't think it was right and honourable to submit to whatever penalty his own polis imposed on him, he would long since have escaped to Megara or Boeotia]
 ἐπεὶ νὴ τὸν κύνα, ὡς ἐγᾦμαι, πάλαι ἂν  ταῦτα τὰ νεῦρα καὶ τὰ ὀστᾶ ἢ περὶ Μέγαρα ἢ Βοιωτοὺς ἦν, ὑπὸ δόξης φερόμενα τοῦ βελτίστου, εἰ μὴ δικαιότερον ᾤμην καὶ κάλλιον εἶναι πρὸ τοῦ φεύγειν τε καὶ ἀποδιδράσκειν ὑπέχειν τῇ πόλει δίκην ἥντιν’ ἂν τάττῃ
remarks: It is a Socratic mannerism to swear by "the dog"- see oath id 2548 with cross references.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would be not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest Hippias if he left the city]
remarks: Thucydides states that when Hippias was deposed as tyrant of Athens by the Spartans and the exiled Alcmaeonidae, he left Athens and retired under a truce to Sigeum.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That she has carried the child/wineskin for ten months]
 <Καὶ> δέκα μῆνας αὔτ’ ἐγὼ 
  ἤνεγκον. 
{ΚΗ.}  Ἤνεγκας σύ;  
  {ΜΙ.}  Νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν.
remarks: Mica is saved from perjury thanks to the ambiguity of  ἤνεγκον (either ‘was pregnant with’ or ‘carried about’).  Or it may be, as Sommerstein suggests, that ‘[the] Inlaw supposes, or pretends to suppose, that she meant the word in the sense in which people not easily overcome by alcohol are said to “carry their drink well” (cf. Diophantus com. fr. 1)’, and that Mica’s answer is to be taken in this sense too.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the lifetime of Herodotus ca.484 to ca.415 (484 to 415)
statement: n/a
remarks:
Herodotus observes that when the Scythians swear "the greatest oath" (τὸν μέγιστον ὅρκον) it is customary to swear by the king's hearth. 
When the king falls ill it is generally assumed to be because someone has sworn falsely. 
Thus, diviners are summoned and they denounce such and such a man who has sworn falsely by the king's hearth. 
When he is brought in, the diviners accuse him, saying that their divination shows him to have sworn falsely by the king's hearth, and because of this the king is ill. After this the man complains loudly. 
When he denies the charge, the king sends for twice as many diviners. If they prove by divination that he is guilty, he is beheaded and his property is divided amongst the first diviners. 
If the new diviners acquit him, then yet other diviners and yet again other diviners are all called in. If the greater number acquit him, the first diviners are put to death.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
statement:
[That they will abide by the terms of the truce]
 εἴ περ γάρ κ’ ἐθέλοιμεν ᾿Αχαιοί τε Τρῶές τε 
ὅρκια πιστὰ ταμόντες ἀριθμηθήμεναι ἄμφω,
Τρῶας μὲν λέξασθαι ἐφέστιοι ὅσσοι ἔασιν,
ἡμεῖς δ’ ἐς δεκάδας διακοσμηθεῖμεν ᾿Αχαιοί,
Τρώων δ’ ἄνδρα ἕκαστοι ἑλοίμεθα οἰνοχοεύειν,
πολλαί κεν δεκάδες δευοίατο οἰνοχόοιο.
remarks: Agamemnon here makes a playful proposal for an treaty to be sworn by the Achaeans and the Trojans, while a census is taken to show that the Greeks are ten times as numberous as the Trojans.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement:
[That Euthycles is quibbling]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία συκοφαντοῦμεν τὸ πρᾶγμα·
remarks: Euthycles complains that Aristocrates' proposal is contrary to the homicide law which allows homicide in immediate self-defence, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his complaint.

author: Antiphanes
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a general reflection on placing no trust in oaths. A person who asks someone to take an oath, and who as a result is cheated, is thereby shown to be stupid because he trusted someone. The speaker is apparently a misanthrope who believes one should never trust anybody. Cf. oath ids 1416, 1433, 1446.

author: Plato
title: Laches
statement:
[That he does not think they are right to say that foolish endurance is courage  (andreia)]
 Καλῶς οὖν σοι δοκοῦμεν λέγειν;  {ΛΑ.} Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἐμοὶ μὲν οὔ.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Bdelycleon's father is not a compulsive entertainer]
  μὰ τὸν κύν’, ὦ Νικόστρατ’, οὐ φιλόξενος
remarks: Sommerstein ad loc. comments that this is "a form of quasi-oath that allowed the speaker emotional release without actually invoking the name of a god". Cf. also Birds 521 and Frogs 1374. Sommerstein also notes that the "oath by the dog was a favourite with Socrates, at least the Platonic Socrates"; cf. oath id 2548 with references.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Xenophon
title: Lacedaemonian Politeia (except ch.14)
date: During the experience of Xenophon (399 to 355)
swearee: The other members of the sworn band
if_taken: He could be part of a sworn band
if_refused: He could not be part of a sworn band
statement: [? That he would fight while he was alive, and would not regard being alive as more important than being free; that he would not leave his taxiarch or his enomotarch, whether he was alive or dead, and that he would bury the dead among his fellow-fighters, and that he would leave no-one unburied]
remarks:
Xenophon describes the Spartan military organisation as comprising six morai of cavalry and infantry, which each of the morai commanded by one polemarch, four lochagoi, eight pentekonteres and sixteen enomotarchs i.e. "commanders of the sworn bands". 
Xenophon goes on to say (in a slightly corrupt passage) that the morai form with the enomotiai sometimes two, three or six abreast. 
See also oath id 1272.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement:
[That, as a result of his recent diplomatic activity, large Peloponnesian and Acarnanian forces would be ready to serve under Athenian leadership against Philip by the 16th of Anthesterion 341/0]
 Ἦν δ’ αὐτῷ κεφάλαιον τῶν λόγων πάντας μὲν Πελοποννησίους ὑπάρχειν, πάντας δ’ Ἀκαρνᾶνας συντεταγμένους ἐπὶ Φίλιππον ὑφ’ ἑαυτοῦ, εἶναι δὲ τὸ 
σύνταγμα χρημάτων μὲν εἰς ἑκατὸν νεῶν ταχυναυτουσῶν πληρώματα καὶ εἰς πεζοὺς στρατιώτας μυρίους καὶ ἱππέας χιλίους, ὑπάρξειν δὲ πρὸς τούτοις καὶ τὰς πολιτικὰς δυνάμεις, ἐκ Πελοποννήσου μὲν πλέον ἢ δισχιλίους ὁπλίτας, ἐξ Ἀκαρνανίας δὲ ἑτέρους τοσούτους· δεδόσθαι δὲ ἁπάντων τούτων τὴν ἡγεμονίαν ὑμῖν· πραχθήσεσθαι δὲ αὐτὰ οὐκ εἰς μακράν, ἀλλ’ εἰς τὴν ἕκτην ἐπὶ δέκα τοῦ ἀνθεστηριῶνος μηνός·
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that whereas all other braggarts try to make vague and imprecise statements when they tell lies because they fear refutation, Demosthenes, when making grandiose statements, first adds an oath to his lies, calling down destruction on himself, and secondly has the nerve to give a date for events he knows will never happen and provides the names of people he has not seen in person, deceiving all hearers and mimicking the manner of people telling the truth. 
This passage clearly refers specifically to Demosthenes' speech supporting the alliance with Callias. This was the occasion when D. allegedly gave the date of a future event he knew would never happen, saying that, as a result of his recent diplomatic activity, large Peloponnesian and Acarnanian forces would be ready to serve under Athenian leadership against Philip by the 16th of Anthesterion 341/0 (Aeschines 3.97-98).  Aeschines must be claiming that D. backed this statement (or some part of it) by an oath explicitly calling down destruction on himself.  In fact forces from some states in these areas (Corinth and Achaea - also Leucas and Corcyra from the north-west) did serve on the Athenian side in the ensuing war.  Aeschines may well be trying to give the impression that the claims Demosthenes made, and particularly those which he backed by oath, were more comprehensive than they actually were.  The 16th of Anthesterion was apparently the date envisaged for a congress of the new alliance at Athens, which does not in fact appear to have been held.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians]
remarks:
Andocides tells the jurors that when the King of Persia invaded Greece, their forefathers, realising the size of the King's army, decided to recall exiles, re-enfranchise the disfranchised, and make safety and dangers common to all. When they had done this, and exchanged pledges and great oaths, they resolved to meet the barbarians at Marathon. 
Andocides states that they fought and conquered, freed Greece and saved their own country. 
Andocides has combined the two Persian invasions of Greece in 490 and 480-479. There is no other evidence for an oath being sworn prior to Marathon, nor is there any evidence of a recall of exiles in 490. 
Andocides is intending the oath to be seen as an oath of reconciliation like that in 403/2. He emphasises the parallel between this fictitious oath of reconciliation and the oaths of 403/2 in section 107.

title: IC IV
if_refused: He is to pay the simple (amount)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that if someone does not swear an oath he will have to pay the simple amount (α[ἰ δέ] κα̣ μὴ ὀμόσει, τὸ ἀπλό<ο>ν καταστασεῖ.)

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: He will be allowed to vote
if_refused: He will not be allowed to vote
impact: New public officials are voted in fairly
statement: [That he will vote fairly and according to the laws]
remarks: Other types of judge are also to swear oaths- trial judges, judges of music and physical contests (see oath ids 2730, 2732, 2733) as well as anyone else who does not bring any gain to himself by committing perjury.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that Philip did not want to accept the Phocians as allies of Athens, for if he swore oaths of alliance to them along with the Athenians he would be immediately compelled to break his oaths to the Thessalians and Thebans (see oath id 3825-6). 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Mantitheus tells the jurors that they will be fulfilling their oaths if they vote as he asks. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

title: IvO
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the other state
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the other state
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: This is an agreement between Chalcis (or a colony) and another state which cannot be identified.  The text is very fragmentary, but it is clear from line 11 that someone had to swear an oath (ὀμνύτω), presumably in order to ratify the agreement. In line 12 the text also indicates that something had to be taken to the altar of Pythian Apollo, which may indicate the location of the swearing of the oath.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That not even he grasps what Socrates is saying]
 Μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἀλλ’ ἐγὼ οὐδὲ αὐτὸς συνίημι ὅτι λέγεις.
remarks: Gorgias is commenting on an exchange between Socrates and Polus, in which Socrates has just made the obscure statement that rhetoric is "the image of a branch of politics", a statement which Polus plainly does not understand but pretends he does. Gorgias, unlike Polus, is willing to admit his ignorance and ask the necessary questions.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
statement: n/a
remarks: In his rhetorical question, Theseus sees no oath that Hippolytus can swear which would outweigh the proof of Phaedra's letter and death. See oath id 129.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That they should conisder exactly how matters stand (concerning marching on Babylon)- i.e. that victory in battle is, and always has been, much more a matter of morale than of numbers]
 ἐκεῖνο μέντοι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, σκεψώμεθα ἀκριβῶς ὅπως ἔχει.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That the creators of living beings deserve greater admiration than those of witless images, if it is true that they make them by design and not by chance]
 Πότερά σοι δοκοῦσιν οἱ ἀπεργαζόμενοι εἴδωλα ἄφρονά τε καὶ ἀκίνητα ἀξιοθαυμαστότεροι εἶναι ἢ οἱ ζῷα ἔμφρονά τε καὶ ἐνεργά; Πολὺ νὴ Δία οἱ ζῷα
remarks: The creators of "witless images" are painters and sculptors (such as Zeuxis and Polycleitus), whom Aristodemus has just said he admires for their expertise (sophia).

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
if_taken: Their wives will have sex with them
if_refused: Their wives will refuse to have sex with them
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: Lysistrata suggests to the men that they exchange oaths and pledges with each other and then each can take his wife and go away. The treaty was discussed by the men at oath id 1220; cf. also ids 1238 and 1239.

author: Demosthenes
title: Olynthiac 1
statement:
[That he is not proposing that they divert funds to pay for his proposed expeditionary force] 
 μὰ  Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the Athenians that they have ample funds to pay for their military needs but appropriate the money for themselves. He imagines that someone might object that he is proposing that they divert these funds to the military, but then swears that he is not. 
He then complains that the Athenians take all the available money and spend it on festivals, and says the only remaining way to raise funds (though others may have other suggestions) is an eisphora.  It is true that he has not actually proposed that the money in the festival (theoric) fund should be diverted to military purposes, but he has made it clear enough that this is what he favours doing.

author: Aeschylus
title: Agamemnon
impact: Cassandra is shown to be a true prophet
statement:
[That the Chorus do not know the ancient wrongdoings of the house]
 ἐκμαρτύρησον προυμόσας τό μ’ εἰδέναι
λόγωι παλαιὰς τῶνδ’ ἁμαρτίας δόμων.
remarks: The chorus refuse to take the oath, see oath id 202. West prints M' EIDENAI with the mss., but many editors have preferred the anonymous conjecture MH EIDENAI. The emended text perfectly fits the language of the Athenian witness's exomosia (whereby he could excuse himself from testifying by swearing that he did not know the statement, to which he was being asked to testify, to be true) and it also explains, as the transmitted text does not, why the chorus-leader refuses to swear.  He is asked to swear that he does not know that Cassandra's statement (about the adultery of Thyestes with the wife of Atreus) is true, and replies, in effect, that he cannot truthfully so swear - in other words, that he does know the statement is true.  Cassandra uses the rejected oath-challenge, just as an Athenian litigant might, as persuasive evidence tending to show that she is a true prophet.  West, retaining the transmitted text, supposes that Cassandra is asking the Elders to swear in the future (after her death) that she knows about the past history of the house - and West then marks LOGWI as corrupt.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would obey the Syracusans]
remarks: Thucydides states that some of the Sicels had been unwilling subjects and allies of the Syracusans, and they revolted in 426 and joined the Athenians in attacking the Sicel town of Inessa.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Evergus and Mnesibulus
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed, and that he was a relative no more remote than a first-cousin-once-removed to the victim, or her owner]
remarks: The speaker states that in the oath it is precisely defined what 'relative' means, i.e. the prosecutor must swear in so many words (if the victim was a free person) that he is (not just vaguely "a relative" but) a relative no more remote than a first-cousin-once-removed. He tells the jurors that he did not dare to tell them something false and swear the diomosia with imprecations upon himself, his son and wife (see also oath id 3658).

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement: n/a
remarks: Peisetaerus here relates that in "the old days" no one would swear by a god, rather they all swore by birds. Even today (i.e. 414 BC), he says, Lampon swears by the goose, when he's up to something. As noted by Sommerstein ad 521, Lampon was "a distinguished diviner and expounder of religious law"; and "by Goose" (Νὴ τὸν χῆνα) is a deformation of "by Zeus" (Νὴ τὸν Ζῆνα) . See Sommerstein for further details.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
This text refers to the "peace and friendship and oaths" sworn by the Greeks and the Persian King i.e. the so-called King's Peace.  
This entry is based on the text in Rhodes and Osborne, GHI 22. This text is the charter of the so-called Second Athenian League. It states that the League will ensure that the peace and frienship and oaths sworn by the Greeks and the Persian king (the King's Peace of 387/6) will be in force and endure.  
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see also oath id 1956.

author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement: n/a
remarks: Here the poet asks how it is possible that a good man, someone who does not commit transgressions nor swear wicked oaths, can nevertheless suffer injustice. Cf. oath id 1298.

title: IG IX, 1(2)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This procedure is part of a new treaty between Chalium and Oeanthia in Locris. If a suit is brought against a citizen by another citizen with regard to the treaty, the damiourgoi shall select five jurors from the best citizens, "after swearing the five-fold oath (literally: τὰν πεντορκίαν)". 
For the oath sworn by the jurors see oath id 715.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Nicias proposed sending an embassy to Sparta to urge them to restore Panactum to the Athenians intact and to give up the alliance with the Boeotians unless they should accede to "the treaty" i.e. the peace of Nicias 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Andocides criticises the Athenians for having sworn oaths to observe a truce with the Spartans and then making an alliance with Boeotia and Corinth and detaching both poleis from the Spartans. 
See also oath id 2421.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That the tools with which animate beings are equipped satisfy him beyond doubt that they are the result of design rather than chance]
 ταῦτα οὕτω προνοητικῶς πεπραγμένα ἀπορεῖς πότερα τύχης ἢ γνώμης ἔργα ἐστίν;  Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Emphasises the urgency of his desire
statement:
[That Lysistrata should lead them into the Acropolis as fast as she can]
  Ἄγ’ ὅπα τυ λῇς. 
{ΑΘ. α} Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ὡς τάχιστ’ ἄγε.

author: Aeschylus
title: Agamemnon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Alliance between fire and sea, destruction of the Achaean fleet
statement:
[That they would destroy the ill-fated Argive host]  
 ξυνώμοσαν γάρ, ὄντες ἔχθιστοι τὸ πρίν, 
πῦρ καὶ θάλασσα, καὶ τὰ πίστ’ ἐδειξάτην
φθείροντε τὸν δύστηνον ᾿Αργείων στρατόν.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Evergus and Mnesibulus
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had killed, and that he was related to the victim or her owner]
remarks: The speaker states that he was told he could not prosecute anyone for the murder of the slave woman because he could not swear in the Palladium - while cursing himself and his household - that he was a relative or that he owned her, without being thought to have committed perjury (see also oath id 3659).

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[That they would bear no ill-will and would propose what was in the best interests of the city]
 μηδὲν μνησικακήσειν, βουλεύσειν δὲ τῇ πόλει τὰ ἄριστα.
remarks:
According to Thucydides, the Megarians in the city most implicated in negotiations with the Athenians knew that they had been detected and left. 
The rest of the Megarians negotiated with the friends of the exiles, and restored the party from Pegae, after binding them under solemn oaths and pledges "to bear no ill-will and to propose what was in the best interests of the city”. 
However, as soon as the anti-Athenian party were in office, they held a review of the hoplites, and picked out about one hundred of their enemies and those who were thought to be most involved in the negotiations with the Athenians, and compelled the demos to vote without secrecy and had them condemned and executed. 
After this they set up an extreme oligarchy in the city.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Zeus, who is king now, stands with an eagle on his head, his daughter with an owl, and Apollo, like a servant with a hawk]
 ὁ Ζεὺς γὰρ ὁ νῦν βασιλεύων
αἰετὸν ὄρνιν ἕστηκεν ἔχων ἐπὶ τῆς κεφαλῆς βασιλεὺς ὤν, 
ἡ δ’ αὖ θυγάτηρ γλαῦχ’, ὁ δ’ Ἀπόλλων ὥσπερ θεράπων ἱέρακα.
{ΠΙ.} Ἰκτῖνος δ’ οὖν τῶν Ἑλλήνων ἦρχεν τότε κἀβασίλευεν. 
 {ΧΟ.}Νὴ τὴν Δήμητρ’ εὖ ταῦτα λέγεις.
remarks: Sommerstein ad 515 explains this passage: "It appears… that the tradition of bird-crowned deities, known to us from Minoan and Mycenaean iconography, had not been entirely forgotten in sixth- and fifth-century Greece; cult-images, which were often of great antiquity, suggest themselves as possible vehicles for the preservation of the tradition".

author: Homer
title: Iliad
impact: Trojans are allowed to retrieve their dead
statement:
[That he will not hinder the Trojans from collecting their corpses for burning] 
 ἀμφὶ δὲ νεκροῖσιν κατακαιέμεν οὔ τι μεγαίρω·
οὐ γάρ τις φειδὼ νεκύων κατατεθνηώτων
γίγνετ’ ἐπεί κε θάνωσι πυρὸς μειλισσέμεν ὦκα. 
ὅρκια δὲ Ζεὺς ἴστω ἐρίγδουπος πόσις ῞Ηρης.
  ῝Ως εἰπὼν τὸ σκῆπτρον ἀνέσχεθε πᾶσι θεοῖσιν, 
ἄψορρον δ’ ̓Ιδαῖος ἔβη προτὶ ῎Ιλιον ἱρήν.
remarks: Agamemnon raises his sceptre to formalise the oath. Cf. Achilles at oath  id 312 and Hector at oath id 349.

author: Theognis
title: Book 1
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a piece of advice: one should not swear that something will never happen (because this is ultimately in the hands of the gods). Cf. oath id 1377.

title: IG IX, 1(2)
statement: [? That they would judge according to the laws]
remarks: The jurors for trials of citizens under the new agreement between Chalium and Oeanthia swore the same "five-fold" oath as that sworn by the damiourgoi who selected them. The jurors are described as having been chosen from "the best men". For the oath of the damiourgoi see oath id 714.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
Nicias proposed sending an embassy to Sparta to urge them to restore Panactum to the Athenians intact and to give up the alliance with the Boeotians unless they should accede to the treaty. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1708.

author: Antiphanes
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: n/a
remarks: Here a character addresses a "mistress" (possibly a divinity) and voices the opinion that: "When someone despises an oath-taker [i.e. refuses to accept a sworn statement as true] without knowing that the man had previously been guilty of perjury, I think that such a person is contemptuous of the gods and has previously been guilty of perjury himself.” This is, strikingly, almost the exact opposite of the position taken (obviously by another character, probably in another play) in oath id 1408.  For this speaker, the only valid reason for not accepting a sworn statement as true is if you know the swearer had sworn falsely on a previous occasion.  In comedy he appears to be in the minority, cf. remarks on oath id 1416.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement:
[That Aristocrates should not have added the clause  'he shall be liable to seizure' after naming an accusation]
 μὴ μὰ Δί’ αὐτὸ τὸ τῆς αἰτίας ὄνομ’ εἰπόντα ‘ἀγώγιμος ἔστω’ προσγράψαι.
remarks:
Euthycles directs his comments to Aristocrates himself rather than the jurors. 
The point being made is that if Aristocrates was going to create a power of summary arrest, he should not have attached to it the bare, unqualified condition "if anyone kills Charidemus" but should have specified e.g. whether the killing had to be intentional, whether it had to be unjustifiable, and whether the killer had to be a citizen.  The speaker goes on to argue (49-50) that the decree, as it stands, would in effect make it possible to get someone extradited for an act that wasn’t even a crime (e.g. a killing in self-defence).

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That if Bdelycleon's father sees scribbled on a door anywhere "Prylampes' son Demos is beautiful", he goes and writes close beside it "The voting urn's funnel is beautiful"]
  καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἢν ἴδῃ γέ που γεγραμμένον
  υἱὸν Πυριλάμπους ἐν θύρᾳ Δῆμον καλόν,
  ἰὼν παρέγραψε πλησίον “κημὸς καλός
remarks: Xanthias is arguing here that Philocleon is a compulsive juror.

author: Plato
title: Laches
statement:
[That he wouldn't call courageous (andreios) a man who shows the quality of endurance in spending his money wisely, knowing that by spending he will acquire more in the end]
 οἷον εἴ τις καρτερεῖ ἀναλίσκων ἀργύριον φρονίμως, εἰδὼς ὅτι ἀναλώσας πλέον ἐκτήσεται, τοῦτον ἀνδρεῖον καλοῖς ἄν;  {ΛΑ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.
remarks: This kind of "spending" would today be called investment, a concept for which ancient Greek did not have a word - hence the long-winded paraphrase.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he makes men more righteous by giving them money]
 δικαιοτέρους τοὺς ἀνθρώπους ποιῶ. καὶ ὁ Σωκράτης, Πῶς, ὦ λῷστε; ἔφη. Διδοὺς νὴ Δί’ ἀργύριον.
remarks: Callias “makes men more righteous” because by giving them money he makes it less likely that they will feel driven by poverty to steal.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes brought ruin upon the state by proposing the alliance with Thebes, an alliance he describes as unjust and completely unequal. 
See also oath id 2670.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
The text indicates that it was illegal to sell a fugitive slave until a certain time had elapsed. If someone sold a fugitive slave before the deadline "the judge shall decide upon swearing an oath" (ἀμπὶ δὲ τὸν κρόνον ὀμνύ[ντα κρίνεν τὸν δικαστὰν]). 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
swearer: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The followers of the Thirty; The rest of the Athenians
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
Andocides observes that some have come to his trial to see whether they can trust the laws and the oaths of reconcilation, and others have come to see whether they will be able to make false accusations and public prosecutions without fear. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: He will be allowed to judge the trial
if_refused: He will not be allowed to judge the trial
statement: [That he will judge fairly, according to the laws]
remarks: This is in contrast to the litigants and defendants who are prohibited from swearing oaths before or during trials- see oath ids 2728, 2734. Other types of judges are also to swear oaths- those voting for new public officials, judges of music and physical contests (see oath ids 2731, 2732, 2733) as well as anyone else who does not bring any gain to himself by committing perjury.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that Aeschines told the Athenians (on Elaphebolion 19, 347/6) that he was surprised that some orators advised them to consult with the other Greeks about the peace with Philip. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
statement: [That he was unable to attend]
remarks: Mantitheus claims that when he entered this lawsuit against Boeotus, he lodged a hypomosia in the name Boeotus, thus proving (in Mantitheus' opinion) that he should rightly bear the name Boeotus and not Mantitheus.

title: IvO
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: This is an agreement between Megara (see below) and Selinus.  This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 29.403. Fragment h, which has been placed at the top left of the text begins with the word hόρκια in larger script than the rest of the text. This is perhaps the heading of the text? Fragment def, lines 5-6 indicates that the agreement is to be ratified by oaths. It is a matter of debate as to whether this text is an agreement concerning the admittance of exiles from Megara Hyblaia to Selinus, or concerning exiles from Selinus in Megara Hyblaia (or perhaps even Megara Nicaea).

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That whenever Polus speaks, Socrates is puzzled as to whether he is speaking for himself and expressing his own views, or whether he is questioning Socrates]
 Νὴ τὸν κύνα, ἀμφιγνοῶ μέντοι, ὦ Πῶλε, ἐφ’ ἑκάστου ὧν λέγεις πότερον αὐτὸς ταῦτα λέγεις καὶ γνώμην σαυτοῦ ἀποφαίνῃ, ἢ ἐμὲ ἐρωτᾷς.
remarks: Swearing by "the dog" is typical of the character of Socrates. See oath id 2548 for references.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
if_broken: May Hippolytus perish unfamed and nameless, and may neither sea nor earth accept his body when he dies
statement:
[That Hippolytus never touched Theseus' wife, nor would he have wished to, nor further would the idea have even occurred to him]
 νῦν δ’ ὅρκιόν σοι Ζῆνα καὶ πέδον χθονὸς 
  ὄμνυμι τῶν σῶν μήποθ’ ἅψασθαι γάμων
  μηδ’ ἂν θελῆσαι μηδ’ ἂν ἔννοιαν λαβεῖν.
  ἦ τἄρ’ ὀλοίμην ἀκλεὴς ἀνώνυμος
  {ἄπολις ἄοικος, φυγὰς ἀλητεύων χθόνα,}
  καὶ μήτε πόντος μήτε γῆ δέξαιτό μου 
  σάρκας θανόντος, εἰ κακὸς πέφυκ’ ἀνήρ.
remarks: Just as Theseus predicted at 960 (id 128), Hippolytus' oath fails, and Theseus does not believe him.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That Thucydides, when he was himself, would not even have put up with Achaea herself]
 ὃς μὰ τὴν Δήμητρ’, ἐκεῖνος ἡνίκ’ ἦν Θουκυδίδης,
οὐδ’ ἂν αὐτὴν τὴν Ἀχαίαν ῥᾳδίως ἠνέσχετο
remarks: Achaea was a cult-title of Demeter, though the meaning of 709 has not been satisfactorily explained by editors; see Sommerstein, and Olson, ad loc.  The Thucydides referred to is Pericles' former rival, now an old man, Thucydides son of Melesias, who apparently on a recent occasion, when he was prosecuted on some charge, broke down and was unable to make, or complete, his defence speech.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians were able to collect their dead from the battlefield
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Athenians lost about one hundred and twenty hoplites and two generals as well as numerous allies in the battle. After collecting their dead the Athenians withdrew to Naupactus.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they have the same friends and enemies as the Macedonians, and would be allies to the Macedonians forever, without guile and without injury]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Perdiccas, King of Macedon and his allies, and Arrhabaeus the Lyncestian and his allies. 
For other references to alliances between Perdiccas and Athens see oath id 256.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians while they collected their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that after the Syracusans repelled an Athenian attack in 413 they set up trophies, and the Athenians collected their dead under a truce.

author: Aristophanes
title: Amphiaraus
statement:
[That the swearer wants the swearee to bring a cushion and a linen pillow from the house]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἐκ τοῦ δωματίου γε νῷν φέρε
κνέφαλλον ἅμα καὶ προσκεφάλαιον τῶν λινῶν.
remarks: This scene not too dissimilar to that between Cinesias and Myrrhine in Lysistrata (though K-A are cautious). The only uncertainty is which of the two is the speaker. Sommerstein is inclined to agree with Bergk, Kock and Kaibel that it is the man who gives the order and the woman who is expected to obey it (similarly in Lysistrata it is Myrrhine who does all the fetching and carrying, even though she is the one who also does all the complaining about the absence of pillows and other comforts).

author: Lysias
title: Against Philon
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
if_refused: They cannot take office in the boule
remarks:
The speaker states that he is not pursuing a private hatred, nor is he stirred to action by speaking skill, or the habit of addressing the demos. Rather, he is relying on the multitude of Philon's crimes, and the need to abide by the oaths he has sworn. 
See also oath id 1775.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
if_refused: They would not be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
The mention here of the 'Spartan alliance' refers to the alliance made between the Greeks against the Persians.  
See also oath id 1501.

title: IG XII 5
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That they would deliberate as well as they were able concerning the Ceans]
 [καὶ περὶ] Κείωμ βουλεύσειν ἀγαθ̣[ὸν ὅ, τι ἂν δύνωνται]
remarks:
This oath is attached to a treaty between Ceos and Histiaea.   
For the corresponding oath of the Ceans see oath id 741.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the lifetime of Herodotus ca.484 to ca.415 (484 to 415)
statement: n/a
remarks:
Herodotus observes that when Scythians make oaths they take blood from the parties involved by making a small hole or cut in the body with an awl or knife and pour it mixed with wine into a great ceramic bowl; they then dip into the kylix a sword (ἀκινάκης), arrows, a sagaris (axe) and a javelin. 
When this is done, those swearing the agreement and the most honourable of their followers drink the blood after solemn curses. 
Lucian, Toxaris. 38 depicts the Scythian Toxaris claiming that Scythians swear by the sword because it represents death. 
Aristophanes, Lysistrata ll 195ff shows a similar oath ritual (see oath id 1164). 
See also oath id 198.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
statement:
[That the Achaeans will long for Achilles some day (i.e. because he will not fight for them)] 
 ἀλλ’ ἔκ τοι ἐρέω καὶ ἐπὶ μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμοῦμαι·
ναὶ μὰ τόδε σκῆπτρον, τὸ μὲν οὔ ποτε φύλλα καὶ ὄζους
φύσει, ἐπεὶ δὴ πρῶτα τομὴν ἐν ὄρεσσι λέλοιπεν,  
οὐδ’ ἀναθηλήσει· περὶ γάρ ῥά ἑ χαλκὸς ἔλεψε
φύλλά τε καὶ φλοιόν· νῦν αὖτέ μιν υἷες ᾿Αχαιῶν
ἐν παλάμῃς φορέουσι δικασπόλοι, οἵ τε θέμιστας
πρὸς Διὸς εἰρύαται· ὃ δέ τοι μέγας ἔσσεται ὅρκος·
ἦ ποτ’ ᾿Αχιλλῆος ποθὴ ἵξεται υἷας ᾿Αχαιῶν 
σύμπαντας· τότε δ’ οὔ τι δυνήσεαι ἀχνύμενός περ 
χραισμεῖν, εὖτ’ ἂν πολλοὶ ὑφ’ ῞Εκτορος ἀνδροφόνοιο
θνήσκοντες πίπτωσι· σὺ δ’ ἔνδοθι θυμὸν ἀμύξεις
χωόμενος ὅ τ’ ἄριστον ᾿Αχαιῶν οὐδὲν ἔτισας.
  ῝Ως φάτο Πηλεΐδης, ποτὶ δὲ σκῆπτρον βάλε γαίῃ
χρυσείοις ἥλοισι πεπαρμένον, ἕζετο δ’ αὐτός·
remarks: In this oath, Achilles swears by Agamemnon's sceptre thus indicating his subversion of Agamemnon's power. Achilles is the only man to volunteer oaths in the Iliad, see also oath id 420. For the use of the sceptre to formalise an oath, cf. Agamemnon at oath id 345 and Hector at oath id 349.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines asks, "Was it not the people who are now set on war and call peace cowardice who prevented you from taking the field [against the Phocians] after peace and alliance had been concluded, claiming that they were afraid that Philip would seize our troops as hostages?". 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he will run and get a pestle (i.e. Cleon) from Athens]
 Οἴσεις ἀλετρίβανον τρέχων;
  {ΚΥ.}  Ἀλλ’, ὦ μέλε, 
  οὐκ ἔστιν ἡμῖν· ἐχθὲς εἰσῳκίσμεθα. 
  {ΠΟ.}  Οὔκουν παρ’ Ἀθηναίων μεταθρέξει ταχὺ <πάνυ>; 
  {ΚΥ.}  Ἔγωγε νὴ Δί’·
remarks: The oath will remain ultimately unfulfilled due to the fact that the Athenians have lost their pestle (i.e. Cleon).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That it’s a good thing that the man is ruined, since he seems like a piece of bad coinage]
 ἔοικε δ’ εἶναι τοῦ πονηροῦ κόμματος.
 {ΚΑ.} Νὴ Δία καλῶς τοίνυν ποιῶν ἀπόλλυται.
remarks: This is said about the Informer who has just appeared.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he is handing over to Antisthenes the skill of being a procurer]
 καὶ ὁ Ἀντισθένης, Ἐμοί, ἔφη, παραδίδως, ὦ Σώκρατες, τὴν τέχνην; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη.

author: Plato
title: Crito
statement:
[That he wouldn't have wished to be in his present state of sleeplessness and grief]
 Εἶτα πῶς οὐκ εὐθὺς ἐπήγειράς με, ἀλλὰ σιγῇ παρακάθησαι; {ΚΡ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐδ' ἂν αὐτὸς ἤθελον ἐν τοσαύτῃ τε ἀγρυπνίᾳ καὶ λύπῃ εἶνα&iota

author: Plato
title: Theages
statement:
[That, when he says he would like to govern with the support of the people, he means like Themistocles and Pericles and Cimon <and the other expert politicians>]
 Ἆρά γε λέγεις ὥσπερ Θεμιστοκλῆς καὶ Περικλῆς καὶ Κίμων καὶ ὅσοι τὰ πολιτικὰ δεινοὶ γεγόνασιν; {ΘΕ.} Νὴ Δία τούτους λέγω.

author: Plato
title: Ion
statement:
[That a man who weeps though he has lost nothing and is fearful though among friendly people is not within his senses]
  Τί οὖν; φῶμεν, ὦ Ἴων, ἔμφρονα εἶναι τότε τοῦτον τὸν ἄνθρωπον, ὃς ἂν κεκοσμημένος ἐσθῆτι ποικίλῃ καὶ χρυσοῖσι στεφάνοις κλάῃ τ’ ἐν θυσίαις καὶ ἑορταῖς, μηδὲν ἀπολωλεκὼς τούτων, ἢ φοβῆται πλέον ἢ ἐν δισμυρίοις ἀνθρώποις ἑστηκὼς φιλίοις, μηδενὸς ἀποδύοντος μηδὲ ἀδικοῦντος;  {ΙΩΝ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, οὐ πάνυ, ὦ Σώκρατες, ὥς γε τἀληθὲς εἰρῆσθαι.
remarks: This follows on from Socrates' argument that a poet is not in his own senses when reciting poetry but is possessed by a divine power.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Hagnias
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Theopompus states that he was awarded the estate of Hagnias by those judging the case because they attached such importance to their oaths, and his claim was in conformity with the law. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
if_taken: Their statements will carry more weight
statement: [That Aphobus acknowledged that Milyas was free and that he testified against Demon]
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that the witnesses were also willing to set their children beside them and give a pledge by them to confirm the testimony they gave, but that Aphobus refused to give an oath either to them or to Demosthenes himself (see also oath id 3524). 
Although it is not made clear here, Demosthenes states at 57 that he and the witnesses did swear the oath (see also oath id 3523)

author: Hypereides
title: Epitaphios
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other and to make war in common against the Macedonians]
remarks: Hypereides states that Leosthenes made the Thessalians, Phocians and Aetolians his allies, bringing under his control by their consent the men Philip and Alexander gloried in controlling against their wishes.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That if something is bad, he does not call it a possession]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ εἴ τι κακόν, τοῦτο 
κτῆμα ἐγὼ καλῶ.
remarks: Cf. oath id 1847.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_broken: That the swearers may become a blanket in the house of Cratinus, and be trained to sing the odes in a tragedy by Morsimus
statement: That they hate Paphlagon
remarks: Cratinus (the comic dramatist) is presented in Aristophanes' early plays as a senile drunkard, and the implication here is that he was incontinent and liable to wet his bed.  With the second imprecation, cf. oath id 3873.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he does use the same word for male and female fowl]
 ἀλεκτρυὼν κἀλεκτρυών. 
 {Στ.}  νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That just as the Persians do not give boys sexual information until they are old enough to have learned self-control, so they do not teach them military skills until they are old enough to know that they should only use these against an enemy]
 οὐ γὰρ ἂν ἔτι ἐξενεχθῆναι δοκεῖτε πρὸς τὸ ἄγριοι πολῖται γενέσθαι ἐν τῷ αἰδεῖσθαι ἀλλήλους συντεθραμμένοι· ὥσπερ γε καὶ περὶ ἀφροδισίων οὐ διελεγόμεθα πρὸς τοὺς ἄγαν νέους, ἵνα μὴ πρὸς τὴν ἰσχυρὰν ἐπιθυμίαν αὐτοῖς ῥᾳδιουργίας προσγενομένης ἀμέτρως αὐτῇ χρῷντο οἱ νέοι. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη·

author: Antiphon
title: Against the stepmother
if_taken: He will help establish the innocence of his mother
if_refused: He will not help establish the innocence of his mother
if_broken: Destruction of self, family and household (?)
statement: [That he knew well that his mother had not killed]
remarks:
The prosecutor asks how his half-brother is going to remain true to his oath as a defendant i.e. that his mother is innocent of the crime if he does not allow the slaves to be tortured and therefore gain full possession of the facts of the case. 
 ἀντόμνυμι can be used of any oath sworn by a litigant, though strictly speaking διόμνυμι should be used in homicide cases. 
It is, to say the least, not certain that the half-brothers are "mature", since the speaker himself is very young indeed (probably only 18).  The way in which the phrase εὖ εἰδέναι is introduced strongly suggests (and §29 of this speech pretty much conclusively proves) that the oath formula for this type of case ran "I know well that X has (not) killed". 
It would not, though, be a breach of such an oath to refuse a torture challenge, even on the assumption (always made by challengers in such cases!) that torture was guaranteed to reveal the truth.  That I refuse to take a lie-detector test may throw doubt on the veracity of my sworn assertion of innocence, but it is not an act, or even an admission, of perjury!

author: Aristotle
title: Locron epizephurion politeia
statement:
[That they would not return to their own country until they had subdued the Messenians]
 διόπερ οἱ Λοκροὶ μήτε ταῖς ἀραῖς ὄντες ἔνοχοι μήτε τοῖς ὅρκοις οἷς ὤμοσαν οἱ Λακεδαιμόνιοι μὴ πρότερον εἰς τὴν οἰκείαν ἐπανήξειν πρὶν ἢ τὴν Μεσσήνην κατὰ κράτος ἑλεῖν
remarks: We do not know whether this oath was taken before the first or second Messenian War.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That Philip will not attack]
 ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ οὐχ ἥξει.
remarks: Demosthenes is imagining how someone might respond to his argument that the winds might prevent the Athenians from sending an expeditionary force to the Chersonese. He rejoins "And who's going to guarantee that?"

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Tyrannus
if_broken: May he not be blessed but die accursed
impact: Prompts Jocasta to plead with Oedipus to be reasonable
statement:
[That he has not been plotting against Oedipus]
 δρῶντα γάρ νιν, ὦ γύναι, κακῶς 
εἴληφα τοὐμὸν σῶμα σὺν τέχνῃ κακῇ.
Κρ. μή νυν ὀναίμην, ἀλλ’ ἀραῖος, εἴ σέ τι
δέδρακ’, ὀλοίμην, ὧν ἐπαιτιᾷ με δρᾶν.
remarks: This oath is referred to again at ids 242 and 243. All but one of the oaths referred to in this play (id 1979) have to do with persuading Oedipus against thinking or acting irrationally.

author: Aristotle
title: Politics
date: Any time with oligarchs in office (400 to 330)
impact: Hostility to the people is made clear
statement:
[That they will be hostile to the demos and plan whatever evil they can against them]
 νῦν μὲν γὰρ ἐν 
ἐνίαις ὀμνύουσι “καὶ τῷ δήμῳ κακόνους ἔσομαι καὶ βουλεύσω 
ὅ τι ἂν ἔχω κακόν”
remarks: It is hard to believe that this oath was ever taken publicly; it is more likely to be a pledge made by oligarchs to each other (annually?) at private meetings of their own faction.  Aristotle disapproves of this oath and suggests that the oligarchs should in fact swear the opposite- see remarks on second entry for 1310a7-11 (oath id 1625).

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Various parties later accuse each other of breaking this peace. 
For the other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That the item in question is a "porker"]
See also remarks.
  Τουτὶ τί ἦν τὸ πρᾶγμα; 
  {ΜΕ.}  Χοῖρος ναὶ Δία.
remarks: The Megarian is trying to pass the girls off as pigs. The oath is true because of the double meaning of Χοῖρος as both "pig" and "cunt". Sommerstein attempts to capture this pun by using the translation "porker". See further Sommerstein ad 739. Cf. also the double-entendre potential of πρᾶγμα (Henderson, The Maculate Muse 133-4, citing Ar. fr. 63 Kock = fr. dub. 926 K-A).

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Locris. 
The identity of the swearers and the nature of their oath are unknown. The terms of the alliance were as follows: "If anyone goes against the Athenians for war either by land or sea the Locrians shall, in all their strength, as the Athenians call on them; and if anyone goes against the Locrians for war, either by land or sea, the Athenians shall go in support with all their strength, as the Boeotians call on them, as far as possible..."

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of Darius ca.520-510 (520 to 510)
impact: The Barcaeans opened their gates and allowed the Persians to enter their city
statement:
[That their treaty should hold good while the ground where they stood was unchanged]
 ἔστ’ ἂν ἡ γῆ αὕτη οὕτω ἔχῃ μένειν τὸ ὅρκιον κατὰ χώρην
remarks:
Herodotus states that one night when he was besieging Barca, Amasis the Persian general dug a wide trench and laid frail planks across it, which he then covered over with a layer of earth.  
When day came, Amasis invited the Barcaeans to meet with him, and they agreed to a peace treaty. This was done while standing on the hidden trench. The two parties gave and accepted a sworn assurance that their treaty would hold good while the ground where they stood was unchanged. 
When the sworn agreement was made, the Barcaeans opened their gates and came out of the city.  
After this the Persians broke down the hidden bridge and ran into the city.  
Herodotus states that they broke down the bridge in order that that they might keep the oath which they had sworn to the Barcaeans: namely, that this treaty would hold good for as long as the ground remained as it was; but if they broke the bridge the treaty no longer held good.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he is not making fun of the archer]
  {ΤΟ.}  Κἀγκάσκι μοι;
  {ΗΧ.}  Κἀγκάσκι μοι;  
 {ΚΗ.}  Μὰ Δί’, ἀλλὰ γυνὴ πλησίον αὕτη.
remarks: Because Echo is repeating everything that is being said, the Archer thinks that the Inlaw is making fun of him, since he hasn't noticed Echo.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement: [? That they would not attack the territory of each other for thirty years]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Mantineans found themselves unable to hold out against the Spartans without the Argives and made an agreement with the Spartans.  
Xenophon states that a thirty year peace treaty was concluded after the battle of Mantinea (see oath id 1957).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That they will say to the Greeks that they should wait to the ninth prytany because of Timocrates' law, and after that they will start]
 ἐροῦμεν νὴ Δία τοῖς Ἕλλησιν ‘Τιμοκράτους νόμος ἐστὶ παρ’ ἡμῖν· ἀναμείνατ’ οὖν τὴν ἐνάτην πρυτανείαν· εἶτα τότ’ ἔξιμεν·’
remarks: Diodorus wonders how the Athenians will be able to raise revenue and mount military expeditions. He imagines that the Athenians will have to tell the other Greeks that they will be unable to take any actions until the debts have been collected in the ninth prytany.

author: Xenarchus
title: Priapos
statement:
[That the young slave should fill the drinking-cup]
 εἰς τὸν κάνθαρον,
παιδάριον, ἔγχει. {Β.} νὴ Δία, εἰς τὸν κάνθαρον.
remarks: One diner tells the slave to fill the (large, earthenware) kantharos rather than the silver goblet, and another chimes in to agree.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia Aulidensis
statement:
[That she will not be persuaded to go home (and not attend her daughter's wedding)]
 Αγ. πιθοῦ. Κλ. μὰ τὴν ἄνασσαν ᾿Αργείαν θεάν.
