remarks: Clytemnestra here appropriately swears by the goddess of marriage that she will not abandon her daughter on her wedding day.

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
statement: n/a
remarks: Isocrates remarks that the Athenians and Spartans of the past won other Greek cities to themselves by acts of kindness rather than force, by keeping their word more faithfully than they now keep their oaths, and thinking it right to abide by their agreements as by decrees of necessity.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That (he thinks) Demos should come out]
 Ὦ Δῆμε, δεῦρ’ ἔξελθε—  
  {ΑΛ.}  Νὴ Δί’, ὦ πάτερ, 
  ἔξελθε δῆτ’
remarks: This is a weak oath form asserting agreement to an imperative.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Philip is right to be proud of being a jester]
 Νὴ Δία, σὺ τοίνυν δικαίως μέγα φρονεῖς.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That being washed in the cold sea water will have made the old man happy]
 Νὴ Δί’ εὐδαίμων ἄρ’ ἦν  
  ἀνὴρ γέρων ψυχρᾷ θαλάττῃ λούμενος.
remarks: This is another sarcastic statement emphasised by the informal invocation of Zeus, the weakest form of oath; cf. oath ids 873 and 900.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
swearer: The Thirty and their followers; The rest of the Athenians
swearee: The Thirty and their followers; The rest of the Athenians
statement:
[That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted] 
 μὴ μνησικακεῖν πρὸς ἀλλήλους
remarks:
Aeschines states that the reconciliation won for the state the reputation for the highest wisdom. 
For other references to the reconciliation between the Thirty and the rest of the Athenian see also oath id 1796.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Andocides says to the jurors, "I believe that you will decide my case impartially, and rather than allow my enemies to defy justice by taking my life, will uphold justice by protecting me, as the laws and the oaths you swore require you to do. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he is not asleep]
  οὗτος, καθεύδεις;
 {Στ.}  μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω ’γὼ μὲν οὔ.
remarks: He isn't asleep - but was he?

author: Plato
title: Euthyphro
statement:
[That if Meletus ever tried to bring Euthyphro to court, he thinks he would soon find out Meletus' weak spot, and much more would be heard in court about Meletus than about himself]  
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, εἰ ἄρα ἐμὲ ἐπιχειρήσειε γράφεσθαι, εὕροιμ’ ἄν, ὡς οἶμαι, ὅπῃ σαθρός ἐστιν, καὶ πολὺ ἂν ἡμῖν πρότερον περὶ ἐκείνου λόγος ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ δικαστηρίῳ ἢ περὶ ἐμοῦ.
remarks: After that, Euth. continues:  "and we’d be talking a lot more about him in court than we would about me", i.e. "I'd thoroughly turn the tables on him".

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
statement:
[That he could not prove his case more thoroughly in any other way (than to describe how Aphobus refused to examine the slave by torture, and refused to examine Demosthenes' female servants regarding Milyas' status as a freedman, and how Demosthenes' mother was ready to swear that Milyas was free, and how Aphobus refused to accept for examination any slaves who might have known more than Milyas, and how he has not brought a charge of false witness against any of those who testified that he had had the money, that he did not give over the will, nor let the house, although the laws so bade; and finally that he refused to take the oath)]
 μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ἐγὼ μὲν οὐκ ἂν ἔχοιμ’ ἐπιδεῖξαι ταῦτ’ ἀκριβέστερον ἢ τοῦτον τὸν τρόπον.

title: IG II(2)
date: Third quarter of the 4th century (349 to 325)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text indicates that if an official undergoing scrutiny appeals the demarch shall exact an oath from the demesmen and give out the ballot.  
For the oaths of the other officials involved in the scrutiny see oath id 531, 535 and 536.

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That it seems very strange to him that what they thought to be beautiful has proved other than beautiful]
 Βαβαῖ, οἴχεται ἄρ’ ἡμᾶς διαπεφευγός, ὦ Ἱππία, τὸ καλὸν γνῶναι ὅτι ποτέ ἐστιν, ἐπειδή γε τὸ πρέπον ἄλλο τι ἐφάνη ὂν ἢ καλόν.  {ΙΠ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, καὶ μάλα ἔμοιγε ἀτόπως.

author: Euripides
title: Phoenissae
statement:
[That he would restore both his sons-in-law to their kingdoms, but Polyneices first]
 Πο. δισσοῖς ῎Αδραστος ὤμοσεν γαμβροῖς τόδε,
{Τυδεῖ τε κἀμοί, σύγγαμος γάρ ἐστ’ ἐμός,}
 ἄμφω κατάξειν ἐς πάτραν, πρόσθεν δ’ ἐμέ.

author: Anaxandrides
title: Agroikoi
statement:
[That the table which was brought in was laden with an amount food that the swearer did not know to be in the house]
 ἡ τράπεζ’ ἐσῄρετο, 
τοσαῦτ’ ἔχουσα βρώμαθ’, ὅσα μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς
καὶ τὰς θεὰς οὐδ’ ἔνδον ὄντ’ ᾔδειν ἐγώ·
remarks: What is being sworn here is that the swearer had not known the house contained the amount of food that was now being served.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
impact: Convinces the birds of the truth of P.'s statement
statement:
[That the birds are more ancient than Earth]
  πάντων ὁπόσ’ ἔστιν, ἐμοῦ πρῶτον, τουδί, καὶ τοῦ Διὸς αὐτοῦ, 
  ἀρχαιότεροι πρότεροί τε Κρόνου καὶ Τιτάνων ἐγένεσθε,
  καὶ Γῆς. 
 {ΧΟ.}  Καὶ Γῆς;  
 {ΠΙ.}  Νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω.
remarks: The birds query Peisetaerus' statement that they are more ancient than the Earth. P. explains the primal seniority of birds with an Aesopic fable which is not attested elsewhere, but is thought to derive from some version of a legend told much later by Aelian about the Indians (see Sommerstein and Dunbar ad loc.). The fact adduced in this story that "there was no earth" when birds first existed clearly seems to suit P.'s purpose and there may have been such a story available to Aristophanes (see Sommestein's addendum on 471 in his edition of Wealth p. 293).  Later on, in the parabasis, the birds themselves will give us a revised Theogony (or Ornithogony, as various critics have called it) in which they are indeed older than Earth:  the primal beings are Chaos, Night, Erebus, Tartarus, and Night's son Eros, which between them engender the birds, after which Eros "mingles all things together" and brings into being Heaven, Ocean, Earth and the gods.  Thus, as Sommerstein notes, the birds, unlike the gods, were "begotten ... before all worlds".  It is crucial (as it often is) that these controversial claims are not denied or challenged by the adversaries of those who advance them.  In the peace negotiations, Peisetaerus demands (1600-1) that Zeus should give the sceptre back again (palin ... apodounai) to the birds; not only do the divine ambassadors not challenge the presupposition of this demand (that rulership belongs to the birds by right), but one of them, Heracles, in agreeing to it, uses exactly the same language (1626).  So, while we may think when we hear 468-470 that Peis. is telling a tall story, that story turns out to be true!

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: The Spartans will be absolved of blame
statement:
[That he came for their good but could not persuade them]
 ὡς ἐπ’ ἀγαθῷ ἥκων οὐ πείθω
gods_invoked: The gods and heroes of the Acanthian country
remarks:
Brasidas states that if the Acanthians do not agree to revolt from Athens he will swear this oath with the gods and heroes of the Acanthian land as his witnesses and then ravage their land safe in the knowledge that he has done nothing wrong. 
Thucydides adds that the Acanthians were persuaded by the impassioned words of Brasidas and agreed to revolt after making him swear the same oath sworn by the Spartan magistrates. 
See also oath id 1672.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
if_taken: They will be permitted to act as judges
if_refused: They will not be permitted to act as judges
impact: Case will be judged by both Athena and her people
statement: [That they will judge according to the laws]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 214.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That some insect has been biting him in the eye for quite a time]
  ὡς τὸν ὀφθαλμόν γέ μου νὴ τὸν Δία πάλαι δάκνει.

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
statement: [That he would be loyal to the Thirty in the overthrow of the democracy]
remarks: An imaginary speaker, either in the Assembly or in the courts, some time in the 390s or 380s, attacks a politician who says he loves the people, but who had conspired (sc. against the people) with the Thirty.  This is given as an example of the rhetorical topos of demonstrating a contradiction between an opponent's statement and some establishable fact.

author: Lysias
title: Against Theomnestus 1
date: At the time of the speech i.e. 384/3 (384)
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement:
[That he has not killed]
 οὐκ ἔκτεινεν
remarks:
The speaker is prosecuting Theomnestus for slandering him by charging him with parricide. He suggests that Theomnestus will again argue that he has not said that he is a "murderer" (androphonos), but rather that "he killed his father". 
The speaker argues that the jurors all know that on the Areopagus they do not use the term "androphonos" in making sworn statements (diomosiai), but the words used by Theomnestus. 
He states that the prosecutor swears that the defendant "has killed", and the defendant swears that he "has not killed".

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That Agathon's excuse is reasonable]
 Ἀτὰρ ἡ πρόφασίς γε νὴ Δί’ εἰκότως ἔχει.
remarks: The Inlaw refers here to Agathon's excuse not to go to the Thesmophoria incognito and speak on Euripides' behalf. Agathon claims he is more hated by women than Euripides; see also remarks on oath id 702.

author: Anonymus Lyricus
title: Lyric Fragment
statement:
[S/he has a true treasure-house on his/her tongue]
 ναὶ τὰν Ὄλυμπον καταδερκομέναν σκηπτοῦχον Ἥραν, 
ἐστί μοι πιστὸν ταμιεῖον ἐπὶ γλώσσας
remarks: Oaths by Hera are very unusual in poetry; cf. oath ids 135 and 187 in Euripides, though both these oaths are 'by the queen'- Hera's name is not invoked directly.  Presumably the speaker (whether it’s the poetic I, or someone else) is really saying that they’ve got a reliable lock on their tongue, since a lock is what a treasure-house needs if it’s to be a trustworthy place to put treasure. A. H. Sommerstein, in correspondence, suggests that the fragment must be tragic for the following reasons: " it's dactylo-epitrite - which probably means it's Bacchylides, Pindar, or tragedy - and since SKHPTOUXON is an Ionic-Attic form, not choral Doric, tragedy is more likely (cf. Eur. IT 235).  Another reason for suspecting it's tragedy, if any were needed, is that it's hard to imagine Pindar or Bacchylides proclaiming that they can be trusted to keep their mouths shut. This is surely a chorus, probably of women and probably Euripidean, swearing itself to secrecy in the way so many tragic choruses (mostly of women and mostly Euripidean) do; their choice of Hera to swear by may indicate that they are married, or that they are Argive, or (quite likely) both.  For NAI (without  MA) introducing an affirmative oath in Euripidean lyrics cf. Bacchae 534" - id 181.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens, Corcyra, Cephallenia and Acarnania under the auspices of the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
For the corresponding oath of the existing allies see oath id 354, and for the oaths of the new allied poleis see oath id 355, 356 and 357. 
For other references to the Second Athenian Confederacy see oath id 2974.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
remarks:
Aeschines states that Demosthenes proposed that the prytaneis call an assembly on Elaphebolion 8 (unprecedented, he says, for a day of a sacrifice to Asclepius and the proagon to the City Dionysia) in order that the people might deal with Philip's ambassadors speedily. 
Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes did so in order that they might make peace not in cooperation with the other Greeks after the return of the ambassadors they had sent out, but alone. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_taken: He will not be charged with theft
if_refused: He will be charged with theft
statement: [That he has not stolen]
remarks: Here the sausage-seller explains that he is willing to deny on oath that he has not stolen even though he is, in fact, a thief. He will give an example of a time he did this at oath id 1000. See also oath id 1038.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: King of Bactria; King of Assyria
swearee: King of Bactria; King of Assyria
statement: [That they would fight alongside each other]
remarks: This is a reference to an attempt on the part of the Assyrian king to enlist Bactria as an ally to help defend themselves against the Persians. The Assyrian king is killed when the Assyrian camp is taken before any alliance with Bactria can be made.

author: Xenophon
title: Lacedaemonian Politeia (except ch.14)
date: During the experience of Xenophon (399 to 355)
swearee: The other members of the sworn band
if_taken: He could be part of a sworn band
if_refused: He could not be part of a sworn band
statement: [? That he would fight while he was alive, and would not regard being alive as more important than being free; that he would not leave his taxiarch or his enomotarch, whether he was alive or dead, and that he would bury the dead among his fellow-fighters, and that he would leave no-one unburied]
remarks:
Xenophon states that when the Spartan army is on the march, they march in columns with every enomotia or "sworn band" in the rear of the enomotia in front of it. 
See also oath id 1272.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he does not think a man happy if he is a slave and cannot do anything he desires]
 Δοκεῖ δέ σοι εὐδαίμων εἶναι ἄνθρωπος δουλεύων τε καὶ ᾧ μηδὲν ἐξείη ποιεῖν ὧν ἐπιθυμοῖ;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔμοιγε, ἔφη.
remarks: Lysis is assenting to a proposition put to him by Socrates. The proposition, like the English translation of it adopted here, is ambiguous (is it that the man is allowed to do none of the things he desires, or that there are some things which he desires to do and is not allowed to?) and Socrates will take advantage of this ambiguity.

title: SEG
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That if anyone attacked the Pisatans or Acroreans, or overthrew the demos in either polis, they would help with all their strength]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Arcadia, Pisa and Acrorea. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 49.466.  
The fact that the peltasts are listed as swearing the oath suggests that the entire army swore the oath.  
For the corresponding oath of the Pisatans and Acroreans see oath id 582.

author: Ephorus
title: Histories
statement: [That they would be loyal to each other and fight alongside each other]

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes imagines that Meidias' friends will try to convince the jurors to cast their votes contrary to the laws, and to break their oaths. 
He argues that if Meidias' friends think it is a dreadful thing that he won't be rich, they should give Meidias money from their own pockets and allow the jurors to give the just verdict they have sworn to do. He asks the jurors how it can be right for them to sacrifice their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Socrates tells the story of the judgement of souls in the Underworld, where Rhadamanthys judges incoming souls from Asia to see whether they should be sent to the Isles of the Blessed or to Tartuarus. It is said to be clear which souls had committed perjury or other crimes because these are full of scars as a result. It is striking that perjury is mentioned first here.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
statement: [That Boeotus and Pamphilus were sons of Mantias]
remarks: Mantitheus complains that Plangon's oath and Mantias' simplicity has allowed Boeotus to obtain a father and a place in the tribe Acamantis instead of Hippothontis (see also oath id 3562).

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
date: Time of writing of Ath. Pol. (335 to 322)
if_taken: They will be exempt from testifying
if_refused: They will not be exempt from testifying
statement: [That they do not know that the statement they are being asked to make is true]
remarks: This 'exomosia' is  where a witness in a court case can claim exemption from testifying by swearing that they do not know that what they are being asked to say is true. See further Carey, CQ 45 (1995) 114-9.

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: His statement of denying knowledge will be believed
if_refused: His statement of denying knowledge will not be believed
impact: The witness is dismissed from proceedings
statement:
[That he does not know the statement prepared for him to be true]
 Ἐάν τις ἑκὼν μὴ ’θέλῃ μαρτυρεῖν, προκαλεῖσθαι τὸν δεόμενον, ὁ δὲ κληθεὶς ἀπαντάτω πρὸς τὴν δίκην, καὶ ἐὰν μὲν εἰδῇ καὶ ἐθέλῃ μαρτυρεῖν, μαρτυρείτω, ἐὰν δὲ εἰδέναι μὴ φῇ, τοὺς τρεῖς θεοὺς Δία καὶ Ἀπόλλωνα καὶ Θέμιν ἀπομόσας ἦ μὴν μὴ εἰδέναι ἀπαλλαττέσθω τῆς δίκης·
remarks: There is a similar practice of exomosia in the real Athenian courts, exemplified at Aeschines 1.67-69; see oath id 2558.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: There will be peace between the Armenians and Chaldaeans
statement: [That they will be friends, be free from one another, have the right of intermarriage and mutual tillage and pasturage in each other's territories, and have a defensive alliance in case any one should injure either party]
remarks: Cyrus also agrees to leave a garrison on the heights between both countries to ensure that the terms of the peace treaty are enforced. The passage referred to in this entry is the first proposal of the peace by Cyrus, which is ratified in section 23. Cf. also oath ids 2377 and 2380.

title: IC IV
if_taken: If believed he can keep the land
statement: [That the land in question is the property of the pledger and not that of the pledgee]
remarks:
The text indicates that during disputes over pledged property, the person to whom property was pledged should summon the pledger in order to mark off the land (i.e. measure it), and if the one summoned does not appear the pledgee should mark off the property himself, and warn the pledger to appear in the agora in four days time before two witnesses. They are to swear that the land in question is the property of the pledgee and not that of the pledger. 
For the oath of the pledgee see oath id 994. For an almost identical text see oath id 984 and 986.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is not possible to name one thing which is fine for all purposes]
  Τὸ δὲ καλὸν ἔχοιμεν ἄν πως ἄλλως εἰπεῖν; ἤ ὀνομάζεις καλὸν ἢ σῶμα ἢ σκεῦος ἢ ἄλλ’ ὁτιοῦν, ὃ οἶσθα πρὸς πάντα καλὸν ὄν; Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’, ἔφη.
remarks: The adjective καλός "beautiful, noble, fine" has several shades of meaning; Socrates, by a series of questions, steers Euthydemus towards taking it to mean "beautifully adapted for a particular function".

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The prosecutor urges the jurors to condemn Demosthenes now that he has fallen into their hands. The prosecutor reminds the jurors that they have sworn to obey the laws and decrees of the demos, and asks (rhetorically) what they shall do about Demosthenes. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: He will not have to serve as ambassador
if_refused: He will have to serve as ambassador
impact: Demosthenes did not go on the embassy
statement: [? That he was unwell and could not serve as an ambassador]
remarks: Demosthenes repeats that he did not go on the embassy to Philip because he took the exomosia (see oath id 3765).

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That it was reasonable for Simmias and Cebes to agree wholeheartedly with Socrates]
 Νὴ Δία, ὦ Φαίδων, εἰκότως γε
remarks: The reason given is that Socrates had made his meaning exceptionally clear "to anyone who has even a little intelligence". However, few modern readers would agree here; indeed Rowe’s note on the passage begins “Hardly any two scholars agree completely about most aspects of this passage”!

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
statement:
[That they will bring Philoctetes either by persuasion or by brute force]
ὁ Τυδέως παῖς ἥ τ’ ᾿Οδυσσέως βία,
διώμοτοι πλέουσιν ἦ μὴν ἢ λόγῳ
πείσαντες ἄξειν, ἢ πρὸς ἰσχύος κράτος.
remarks: The oath reported cannot be completely true  since it is imperative to the success of the mission that Philoctetes' co-operation be secured by persuasion alone. Ultimately Philoctetes is persuaded to come to Troy but not by Odysseus, let alone Diomedes.

title: IG XII 2
date: 336 and after (during the reign of Alexander) (336 to 324)
statement: [? That they would judge in accordance with the laws]
remarks:
The trials of the former tyrants of Eresus - Eurysilaus and Agonippus - were ordered by Alexander the Great. The text indicates that "men on oath shall try him on a secret ballot for death" (κρῖνα[ι μ]ὲν αὖτον κρύπται ψάφιγγι ὀμόσαντας περ[ὶ θ]ανάτω·). 
For the oath sworn at the trial of Eurysilaus see oath 776.   
The oath mentioned here is for the trial of Agonippus.  For the oath sworn at the trial of the descendants of the first tyrants of Eresus see oath 780.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker argues that if the Athenians are going to abide by their oaths and agreements they must seize their arms and take the field against the transgressors (i.e. Alexander) with all those who will join them. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
This inscription refers to the so-called King's Peace. 
The oath is stated to have been sworn by the Persian king, the Athenians, the Spartans and the other Greeks.  
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see also oath id 1956.

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
statement: [That they would count the votes fairly]
remarks: This is a general discussion of oaths in the context of re-electing magistrates in oligarchies, where the votes must be counted with oaths and great accuracy. Presumably the "oaths" are to be sworn by those counting the votes, to the effect that they will count the votes fairly.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus argues that the fact that Olympiodorus refuses to do anything that was stipulated in the agreement which was entered into with their full consent and confirmed by oath is proof of his madness - especially since Callistratus is acting in the interest of his wife, Olympiodorus' own sister (see also oath id 3623).

author: Plato
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he had ‘slept with’ Socrates only in the sense in which one might sleep with one’s father or elder brother]
 εὖ γὰρ ἴστε μὰ θεούς, μὰ θεάς, οὐδὲν περιττότερον καταδεδαρθηκὼς ἀνέστην μετὰ Σωκράτους, ἢ εἰ μετὰ πατρὸς καθηῦδον ἢ ἀδελφοῦ πρεσβυτέρου.
remarks: Presumably we’re invited to consider whether anyone is going to believe Alc. this time; the answer we’re expected to give is probably “well, they wouldn’t normally, but since it’s Socrates we’re talking about …”

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae B
impact: None- swearee continues in the same vein
statement:
[That no one has bought any of the fish mentioned]
  {Α.} ἰχθὺς ἐώνηταί τις ἢ σηπίδιον
ἢ τῶν πλατειῶν καρίδων ἢ πουλύπους; 
ἢ νῆστις ὀπτᾶτ’, ἢ γαλεός, ἢ τευθίδες; 
{Β.} μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’.
remarks: Since this fr. comes from Thesmophoriazusae II, it is likely that the swearee (the person asking the questions) is a woman.  The play was set on the day of the Calligeneia (see fr. 331), which was the day after the Thesmophorian fast, and the women were evidently hoping for a blowout (see lines 7-8 of fr. 333).  The location is presumably the Thesmophorion.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
statement:
[That the Athenians will not be able and do not want to punish Athenians who are aiding the enemy - on the contrary they are eager to hear such people speak, and it is now more dangerous for a politician to be a patriot than a traitor]
 ὃ μὰ τὸν Δία καὶ τοὺς ἄλλους θεοὺς οὐ δυνήσεσθ’ὑμεῖς ποιῆσαι,

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the wild pear that is keeping his food locked inside him is the one that Thrasybulus told the Spartans about]
 ἀχράς τις ἐγκλῄσασ’ ἔχει τὰ σιτία. 
 {Γε.}  μῶν ἣν Θρασύβουλος εἶπε τοῖς Λακωνικοῖς;
 {Βλ.}  νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον
remarks: The nature of the joke contained in this statement is not clear. Wild pears were thought to cause constipation, but how this ties in with Thrasybulus was a cause for confusion even in antiquity. Sommerstein ad 356 discusses this in some detail and concludes that "Blepyrus will be saying (1) that his constipation is giving him great trouble and (2) that Thrasybulus delivered a violent invective against the Spartans…. Probably this was an earthy metaphor or simile to emphasize an important point (perhaps e.g. Thrasybulus asserted that one or another Spartan or Persian demand was blocking the path to peace as firmly as a wild pear blocks up the bowels…)". See Sommerstein ad loc. for further details.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Achaeans asked the Spartans to help Calydon after it was attacked by the Acarnanians (and Athenians and Thebans) because the Calydonians were Achaean citizens. 
The Achaeans said threatened to make peace on whatever terms they could if the Spartans did not lead an expedition to Calydon. 
Xenophon states that by doing so they covertly threatened to withdraw from their alliance with Sparta unless they agreed to help the Calydonians. In view of this the ephors and the Spartan assembly then decided to make an expedition against the Acarnanians. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Euxitheus, the defendant, argues that only a verdict saving his life will enable the jurors to comply with the law and their oath to return a lawful verdict (κατὰ γὰρ τοὺς νόμους ὠμόσατε δικάσειν). 
He again complains that he ought to be undergoing trial before the Areopagus, because the laws under which he has been arrested do not concern his case. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Emphasises the men's frustration with the women
statement:
[That if someone had given the women a sock in the jaw two or three times, like Bupalus got, they wouldn't have a voice to speak now]
Εἰ νὴ Δί’ ἤδη τὰς γνάθους τούτων τις ἢ δὶς ἢ τρὶς
ἔκοψεν ὥσπερ Βουπάλου, φωνὴν ἂν οὐκ ἂν εἶχον.
remarks: For details on the reference to Bupalus, see Sommerstein ad 361.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement: [That he would take Euripides home]
remarks: The “oath” referred to here is the same one as at id 513.  Dionysus accepts (inaccurately) that he swore to take Euripides home, but then says, like Hippolytus, that it was only his tongue that did so.  Like everyone else who quotes Hipp. 612, Dionysus is assuming (inaccurately) that the line is a perjurers’ charter:  Hippolytus was saying in effect “yes, I did swear, but you deceived me into doing so” , whereas Dionysus is saying something very different – “yes, I did swear, but I didn’t mean it”. Cf. oath id 513 with cross references.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Thucydides refers to the alliances between Sparta and and Athens and various poleis after the defeat of the Persians. He states that after these alliances were made both sides were constantly making peace, or fighting with each other or with their own allies who had revolted. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517, 1590, 1592, 1593, 1594, 1595, 1596, 1657, 1694 and 1707.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That he is accursed and wretched to be shut up with such beasts]
 βαρυδαίμων μὲν οὖν,
  νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν σωτῆρ’, ἀνὴρ καὶ δυστυχής,
  ὅστις τοιούτοις θηρίοις συνείρξομαι.
remarks: The "beasts" in question are the two old women.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That Socrates very much approves of Ischomachus' way of life]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφην ἐγώ, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, ἀρεσκόντως γέ μοι ταῦτα ποιεῖς.
remarks: For Socrates invoking Hera in an informal oath cf. oath ids 1870, 2102, 2106, 2122, 2144 and 2268.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he has never seen the type of trench that is dug for plants dug more than three feet deep (nor even more than two and a half feet deep)]
 Ἤδη τινὰ οὖν αὐτῶν εἶδες βαθύτερον τριπόδου; Οὐδὲ μὰ Δί’ ἔγωγ’, ἔφην, πενθημιποδίου

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines states that Demosthenes is directing his accusations against the embassy that was sent to take the oaths from Philip. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Emphasises her indignation at the suggestion
statement:
[That her boyfriend did not call around for her funeral]
  Ἐπ’ ἐκφοράν;
  {ΓΡ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: The joke is a reference to the Old Woman's advanced age.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
statement: [? That they would abide by the peace, on condition that Chios, Cos and Rhodes were able to withdraw from the Second Athenian Confederacy, and the independence of Byzantium was recognised]
remarks:
Isocrates argues that the Athenians should not accept the terms of the peace without first taking counsel about how they should keep the peace once it has been made. 
See also oath id 3005.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
impact: Prompts Paphlagon to explain his meaning
statement:
[That Demos doesn't know what Paphlagon means]
 Ταῦτ’ οἶσθ’ ὅ τι λέγει; 
 {ΔΗ.}  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω ’γὼ μὲν οὔ.
remarks: Paphlagon has been trying to argue that he is needed to safeguard Demos.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
if_taken: The Egyptian revolt against Persia would come to an end
if_refused: The Egyptian revolt against Persia would not come to an end
statement: [That Inaros and the Greeks would suffer no harm from the king]
remarks: Five years later, Artaxerxes finally gives in to his mother's pestering. She had been eager to get revenge on Inaros since he had killed her son Achaemenides. Inaros and some Greeks are brought to the king's court and she has Inaros crucified and fifty Greeks decapitated (cf. oath id 3466 for a woman's interference). Technically, the oath is broken, but Megabyzus is not to blame. In fact he had worked hard to maintain security for the Greeks and was greatly grieved by events. See also oath id 3460.

author: Eubulus
title: Sphingokarion
statement:
[That she became ill after eating figs at midday the day before yesterday]
 νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἠσθένουν γάρ, ὦ βέλτιστε σύ,
φαγοῦσα πρῴην σῦκα τῆς μεσημβρίας.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would go in support with all their strength as far as possible, if anyone went against the koinon of the Thessalians for war, or overthrew the archon whom the Thessalians had appointed, or set up a tyrant in Thessaly]
 βοηθήσω π[α]ντὶ σθένει κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν, ἐὰν τι[ς] ἴηι ἐπὶ τὸ κοινὸν τὸ Θετταλῶν ἐπὶ πόλ[έμ]ωι ἢ τὸν ἄρχοντα καταλύει, ὃν εἵλοντο Θετταλοί, ἢ [τ]ύραννον καθ[ι]στῆι ἐν Θετταλίαι·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Thessaly. 
The text indicates that each party will swear their "lawful oath".  
For the corresponding oath of the Thessalians in Thessaly see oath id 452.  
For the oath of the Thessalian envoys in Athens see oath id 453.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That there are decent occupations other than being an informer]
 Ἀλλ’ ἔστιν ἕτερα νὴ Δί’ ἔργα σώφρονα

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
if_taken: He could introduce his son to the genos
if_refused: He could not introduce his son to the genos
statement:
[That he believed the boy to be his own son, by an Athenian woman, betrothed to him according to the law]
 ἦ μὴν νομίζειν εἶναι αὑτοῦ υἱὸν ἐξ ἀστῆς γυναικὸς καὶ ἐγγυητῆς κατὰ τὸν νόμον.
remarks: Apollodorus states that Phrastor brought a suit against the gennetae for refusing to register his son by Phano, but they challenged him to swear before the arbitrator that he believed the boy to be his legitimate son by an Athenian woman (aste). Phrastor refused to take the oath, and did not swear. Apollodorus then calls witnesses to verify his story (see also oath id 3728).

author: Lysias
title: In defence of Mantitheos
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Mantitheos claims that at the time the Athenians made their alliance with the Boeotians (395), he was called up to serve in the cavalry, but enrolled in the infantry instead. 
See also oath id 2019.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That he will provide the jurors with clear and explicit testimony from the witnesses to prove that he is speaking the truth]
 Ὅτι δὲ  ταῦτ’ ἀληθῆ λέγω, ἐνταῦθα μέντοι νὴ Δία σαφῶς πάνυ καὶ διαρρήδην ἐγὼ μαρτυροῦντας ὑμῖν τοὺς μάρτυρας παρέξομαι·

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it is said that Daedalus was taken captive by Minos because of his wisdom and was forced to be his slave, and was deprived of his fatherland and freedom and when he tried to run away with his son, he lost the boy and was unable to save himself but was carried off to the barbarians where he was once again a slave]
 τὸν Δαίδαλον, ἔφη, οὐκ ἀκήκοας ὅτι ληφθεὶς ὑπὸ Μίνω διὰ τὴν σοφίαν ἠναγκάζετο ἐκείνῳ δουλεύειν καὶ τῆς τε πατρίδος ἅμα καὶ τῆς ἐλευθερίας ἐστερήθη καὶ ἐπιχειρῶν ἀποδιδράσκειν μετὰ τοῦ υἱοῦ τόν τε παῖδα ἀπώλεσε καὶ αὐτὸς οὐκ ἐδυνήθη σωθῆναι, ἀλλ’ ἀπενεχθεὶς εἰς τοὺς βαρβάρους πάλιν ἐκεῖ ἐδούλευε; Λέγεται νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ταῦτα.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides argues that the Athenians must choose between war with the Argives against Sparta or to make peace in common with the Boeotians. 
He observes that it is the customary error of the Athenians to make war for the sake of others when it is possible for them to make peace for their own sake. 
Andocides goes on to provide historical examples (some of doubtful validity) - see oath id 2424-2428. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That Dionysodorus did not teach him how to distinguish between good and bad men]
 Εἰ μὲν τοίνυν, ἔφη, καὶ διαγιγνώσκειν σε τοὺς ἀγαθοὺς καὶ τοὺς κακοὺς ἐδίδαξεν· εἰ δὲ μή, τί σοι ὄφελος ὧν ἔμαθες; οὐδὲ γὰρ εἴ σε ἀργύριον ἐκέλευσε πρῶτον μὲν καὶ τελευταῖον τὸ κάλλιστον τάττειν, ἐν μέσῳ δὲ τὸ χείριστον, μὴ διδάξας διαγιγνώσκειν τό τε καλὸν καὶ τὸ κίβδηλον, οὐδὲν ἄν σοι ὄφελος ἦν. Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἐδίδαξεν·
remarks: Cf. oath ids 2072 and 2074.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he has not perceived in himself nor in anyone else emotion making common cause with desires against the active opposition of reason]
 ταῖς δ’ ἐπιθυμίαις αὐτὸν κοινωνήσαντα, 
αἱροῦντος λόγου μὴ δεῖν ἀντιπράττειν, οἶμαί σε οὐκ ἂν φάναι γενομένου ποτὲ ἐν σαυτῷ τοῦ τοιούτου αἰσθέσθαι, οἶμαι δ’ οὐδ’ ἐν ἄλλῳ.  Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἔφη.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes observes that the Athenians were induced to make peace by Philip's promises, and goes on to claim that he would never have consented to serve on the embassy to Philip had he known that Philip would act as he has done after peace was secured. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [? That he does not owe Apollodorus 44 minas, 38 drachmas and 2 obols]
remarks:
Apollodorus states that after he (Apollodorus) put his oath in the evidence box (see oath id 3661), Timotheus thought he could resolve matters by an oath of his own. 
Apollodorus tells the jurors that if he did not know that Timotheus has perjured himself in many solemn oaths to states and individuals (see oath id 3664, 3666) he would have allowed Timotheus to take the oath. 
Apollodorus argues that because he had witnesses to prove that the persons appointed by Timotheus had received the money from the bank (and other circumstantial evidence) it seemed a terrible thing to give an oath to one who would not care to swear honestly, and one who - when it was a question of gain - had not even spared temples.

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker asks the jurors to consider whether they ought to fear that once their oaths (of reconcilation) have been violated they may again be brought to the same state of affairs that compelled them to declare the Amnesty in the first place. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he is sure Dionysus would like to meet a terrifying beast and have a contest worthy of the journey]
 ᾿Εγὼ δέ γ’ εὐξαίμην ἂν ἐντυχεῖν τινι
  λαβεῖν τ’ ἀγώνισμ’ ἄξιόν τι τῆς ὁδοῦ. 
  ΞΑ.  Νὴ τὸν Δία·
remarks: Xanthias cannot swear to Dionysus' state of mind. So the statement cannot be "That Dionysus would like to meet one of the terrifying beasts and have a contest worthy of the journey". This isn't really an oath but just a strong (and probably ironic) assertion - "I'm sure you would (like to meet one of the beasts...)!!?".

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That Demosthenes should not subject him to a public prosecution and assessment of the penalty which he should suffer or pay] 
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχὶ δημοσίᾳ κρίνειν αὐτὸν καὶ τίμημα ἐπάγειν ὅ τι χρὴ παθεῖν ἢ ἀποτεῖσαι.
remarks: Demosthenes tells the jurors that it has been reported to him that Meidias is telling "some people" in private that if Demosthenes really suffered the treatment he alleges, he ought to have brought private cases against Meidias for the destruction of the cloaks and the gold crowns, and for the obstruction concerning the chorus, and for the insolent treatment of his person, and not (by Zeus) subject him to public prosecution.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes reports how Aeschines addressed the ecclesia and said to the Athenians, "As far as I'm concerned, as long as there's a single Athenian left alive, I would never advise the city to make this particular peace treaty. Yet I do say that a peace ought to be made". Demosthenes complains that the next day, when the peace was to be ratified, Aeschines stood up and spoke in support of Philocrates.  
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristotle
title: Sophistici Elenchi
statement: n/a
remarks:
It is discussed here whether or not the same person can both keep and break an oath. A case is imagined where a man swears that he will commit perjury. He can only then break one oath to keep the other. He swears oath A, and then oath B (to break oath B). When he acts according oath B is he 'euorkos' or 'epiorkos'? The answer recommended by Aristotle is that he is keeping oath B (so he is not 'epiorkos') but he is not an 'euorkos' individual. Compare Tennyson’s couplet on Lancelot: “His honour rooted in dishonour stood, 
And faith unfaithful kept him falsely true.” (Meaning that Lancelot would not become the lover of Elaine because that would have meant disloyalty to his love for Guinevere – which itself was, of course, adulterous, treasonable, and a breach of his oath of allegiance to Arthur.)

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That there is nothing suspicious going on]
 ἀλλ’ ἔστιν ἐνταῦθά τι κακόν. {Πρ.} μὰ τὼ θεὼ
remarks: The statement is clearly true from Praxagora's subjective point of view, and  also in the sense that Blepyrus had in mind (he still suspects that she’s been seeing a lover).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Plataeans sent envoys to the Athenians to put the proposals of Archidamus to them
statement: [? That he would not lay waste the land of the Plataeans for a certain number of days within which the representatives of Plataea could be expected to go to Athens and return with an answer]
remarks:
Archidamus suggested to the Plataeans that they should either join the Peloponnesians or do nothing against them. 
The Plataeans requested a truce in order to consult the Athenians about these proposals. 
Accordingly, Archidamus made a truce for the number of days within which the representatives of Plataea could be expected to go to Athens and return, and did not lay waste their land. 
The Athenians promised to help the Plataeans in accordance with their alliance.

title: IG II(2)
if_taken: They can submit to arbitration before the demesmen
if_refused: They cannot submit to arbitration before the demesmen
statement:
[That they would redeem none of these (things seized in pledge), not themselves nor anyone with their knowledge, unless the demesmen vote to sell the right to collect pasturage dues; and in the future they would inform the demesmen of anyone doing these things in the countryside]
 [- - - ] καὶ λύ[σομαι οὐδὲν] τούτω[ν οὔτ’ ἐγὼ οὔτ]ε τῶν ἐμ[ῶν οὐδεὶς εἰ]δότος ἐμ[οῦ, ἐὰν μὴ ψή]φίσωνται οἱ [δ]ημόται ἀποδόσθαι τὰ ἐννόμια. καὶ ἐς τὸν λοιπὸν χρόνον ἀποφανῶ τοῖς δημόταις, ἐὰν τινά τι εἰδῶ̣ ποιοῦντα τούτων ἐν τοῖς [ἀ]γροῖς. ἀληθῆ ταῦτα [ν]ὴ τὸν Δία, νὴ τὸν Πο[σε]ιδῶ, νὴ τὴν Δήμητ[ρα] εὐορκοῦντι μέμ [μοι] εἶναι πολλὰ καὶ [ἀγαθ]ά, εἰ δ’ ἐπιορκοί[ην, τὰ ἐν]αντία.
remarks:
The date is confirmed by the presence of Dor[otheus] as demarch in line 4. Dorotheus is known to have been demarch in 326/5 from IG II(2) 1198. 
Fragment a indicates that those lessees who claimed to have reason to not pay their rent (and had thus become debtors) could submit to arbitration by the demesmen. They would swear an oath before entering the dikasterion to submit their case for arbitration and defer payment until the demesmen might be in position to make a judgement. They were also to swear when they submitted their case to abide by whatever decision the demesmen might make and to pay back the money if required, or provide a guarantor. 
The oath itself is referred to in fragment a lines 8-13 and survives in fragmentary form in fragment b.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That she doesn't want Philocleon to tell her an amusing story]
 λόγον σοι βούλομαι λέξαι χαρίεντα. 
 {Μυ.}  μὰ Δία μὴ ’μοιγ’, ὦ μέλε.
remarks: Myrtia is warning Philocleon here that she will not be receptive to his "amusing stories".

author: Euripides
title: Medea
impact: Medea comes to Greece with Jason
consequences_of_breach: Causes Medea's fury and revenge plan
statement: [That he would be faithful to Medea]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 111.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Leucas. 
In lines 11-12 there is a further reference to τὸς ὅρ[κος]. The Athenian strategoi Phormion and Spudias are also mentioned in lines 2-3.

author: Philonides
title: Unidentified drama
statement: n/a
remarks: The speaker here is presumably female- what man would care whether an adulterer kept his oath or not? She reflects on the worthlessness of an adulterer's oath; cf. oath id 1307.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
if_refused: They would not be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
King Archidamus argued that the Plataeans should join in freeing states that were subject to Athens because they had all sworn an oath to protect Greek freedom. He is referring here to the alliance of the Greeks against the Persians. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1501.

title: Syll (3)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This inscription is a first century copy of a sixth century document. The last line of the original text survives in text A. 
The inscription records honours awarded to Medikes and the sons of Aesop and their descendants. The text indicates that the demos formalised these honours by swearing oaths. The text reads. "with regard to these things the demos cut oaths" (καὶ ἐπὶ τούτοισιν δῆμος ὅρκιον ἔταμον).

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That Homer was wise to say that someone who lusts after intestine war should be treated as an outcast]
  Ἀλλ’ ὁ σοφός τοι νὴ Δί’ Ὅμηρος δεξιὸν εἶπεν· «Ἀφρήτωρ, ἀθέμιστος, ἀνέστιός ἐστιν ἐκεῖνος, 
  ὃς πολέμου ἔραται ἐπιδημίου ὀκρυόεντος.»
remarks: The apparent implication is that wars among Greeks are tantamount to civil wars (see Sommerstein ad loc.).

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Envoys sent to Sparta from Acanthus and Apollonia warned the Spartans that they had heard that the Olynthians had voted to send envoys to Athens and Thebes to conclude an alliance. 
See also oath id 1959 and 1961.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he thinks he would have felt badly if he had had to carry his attendant's load]
 ἔφη, εἰ τὸ ἐκείνου φορτίον ἔδει σε φέρειν, πῶς ἂν οἴει διατεθῆναι; Κακῶς νὴ Δί’, ἔφη·
remarks: For the background to this statement compare oath ids 2118 and 2119.  Socrates comments that if the man has so much less stamina than his slave, he can't have taken much care of his fitness.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines tells the jurors that, "In general, men of Athens, you should not admit lines of defence not relevant to the main issue, first of all because of the oaths you have sworn, and secondly to avoid being misled by a man who is a master of the art of speaking". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Lysias
title: Against Eratosthenes
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal, maintain secrecy, and overthrow the democracy]
remarks:
Lysias states that Eratosthenes' accomplices in the anti-democratic conspiracy would act as witnesses against him if they were wise, and "would not regard as trustworthy the oaths that were designed to harm the citizens, and they would willingly break them for the good of the city". 
See also oath id 2824 and 2826.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Apollodorus describes how the Spartans attacked Plataea in violation of the peace. 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the Inlaw has no breasts like the other women]
 καὶ νὴ Δία τιτθούς γ’ ὥσπερ ἡμεῖς οὐκ ἔχει.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Heracles will not have any share in his father's property]
 Ἐμοὶ δ’ ἄρ’ οὐδὲν τῶν πατρῴων χρημάτων  
  μέτεστιν; 
 {ΠΕ.}  Οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία
remarks: See remarks on oath id 692.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that it is shameful and sacrilegious for Aeschines to have called the gods to witness that certain measures were very good, and to ask the jurors now to vote that they were very bad, when the jurors have sworn by the gods. 
The logic of Demosthenes' argument is somewhat underwhelming.  To be sure, Aeschines is putting himself in danger of divine retribution by denying a proposition that he once called the gods to witness; but the jurors aren’t bound by what he may have said or done eight years ago.  The argument, however, gains its persuasive power from the fact that virtually all the jurors must have taken part themselves in the celebrations referred to. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would join the Spartans in attacking the Athenians]
 ὥστ’ ὤμοσαν ἦ μὴν ἀκολουθήσειν μετ’ ἐκείνων  ἐφ’ ὑμᾶς τοὺς διασώσαντας τὴν πόλιν αὐτῶν·
remarks:
The Plataean speaker states that even though the Athenians saved the Thebans in the Corinthian War, as soon as the war was over the Thebans abandoned them and made an alliance with the Spartans. 
He contrasts the behaviour of the Thebans with that of the citizens of Chios, Mytilene and Byzantium, arguing that whereas they remained loyal, the Thebans did not even have the courage to remain neutral, but rather showed such cowardice and baseness that they swore to join the Spartans in attacking the Athenians, the saviour of their city. 
This is not as clear as the speaker implies. What he actually means is that "after" the seizure of the Cadmeia, the pro-Spartan (if you like, puppet) regime did so.  Isocrates' Plataeans are playing the classic (and not yet obsolete) rhetorical tricks of (a) putting events in the wrong order and/or (b) using the term "the Thebans" to refer now to one faction, now to the other, as convenient (the Thebans who were forced to flee to Athens were not the same as - indeed were the enemies of - the Thebans who made the alliance with Sparta; on the other hand each side claimed to be the sole legitimate representatives of "the Thebans").   
So the alliance was made by Leontiades and his supporters shortly after the seizure of the Cadmeia, and it was the action of what then officially counted as the Theban state.  And the Plataeans are falsifying (quite recent) history.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Encourages Xanthias to say something funny

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
if_broken: He will come back to life
impact: Xanthias relents and agrees to go to Hades with Dionysus
statement:
[That he will not accept nine obols for agreeing to carry the luggage]
 ΔΙ.  Λάβ’ ἐννέ’ ὀβολούς. 
ΝΕ.  ᾿Αναβιοίην νυν πάλιν.
remarks: This is a conditional self-curse, unique in that it is uttered by a corpse, and is the antithesis of what a living person would say (i.e. "May I not live if I do X" vel sim.).

author: Isocrates
title: Against Callimachus
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker argues that he cannot be prosecuted for confiscating Callimachus' money (aside from the fact that he has proved that he was not responsible) because the terms of the Amnesty explicitly exculpate "anyone who has provided information or denounced anyone, or has done anything similar". He asks for the oaths to be read to the jurors to confirm his statement. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [? That he did not assault Ariston]
remarks:
Ariston tells the jurors that Conon intends to bring in his children and swear by them, calling down "dreadful, cruel curses, so awful that the man who heard them and reported them was amazed" (see also oath id 3678). 
He goes on to describe Conon's shameless behaviour as a youth, and argues that he is not to be believed under oath (see oath id 3675).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: Sixty ships were delivered up and the Spartan envoys went to Athens
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Spartans sent magistrates to Pylos to examine the situation. These magistrates decided that the situation was so perilous that they ought to conclude a truce. 
Accordingly they proposed a truce with the Athenian generals so that they could send envoys to Athens to propose an agreement. The Athenian generals accepted their proposal and concluded a truce on the terms described in the statement. 
See also oath id 1650.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Peace
remarks:
Demosthenes comments that when he and the other ambassadors returned from administering the oaths for the peace there were some who assured them that Thespiae and Plataea would be rebuilt, and that if Philip gained mastery he would protect the Phocians, break up Thebes into villages, allow the Athenians to retain Oropus, and return Amphipolis to them. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: None- Cinesias does not believe him
statement:
[That he is not "at full cock"]
  Ἀλλ’ ἔστυκας, ὦ μιαρώτατε.  
  {ΚΗ.}  Οὐ τὸν Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωνγα·

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: During civil strife when people fled to Peiraeus (404 to 403)
statement:
[That it is indeed disgraceful that Ceramon, with a house full of inferior people, is prospering, while Aristarchus, despite having superior people in his house, is in dire straits]
 Οὐκοῦν, ἔφη, αἰσχρὸν τὸν μὲν ἀπὸ τῶν πονηροτέρων εὐπορεῖν, σὲ δὲ πολλῷ βελτίους ἔχοντα ἐν ἀπορίᾳ εἶναι; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη
remarks: See oath id 2064.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he was coming to gaze on Cyrus again to see what the man who possessed such a soul looked like]
 Ἐγὼ δέ γ’, ἔφη ὁ Γαδάτας, ναὶ μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς σὲ ἐπαναθεασόμενος ᾖα ὁποῖός τίς ποτε φαίνῃ ἰδεῖν ὁ 
τοιαύτην ψυχὴν ἔχων·
remarks: The name of the land is never specified. It is the land of Gadatas and borders on Assyria.

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[That they would not rebel against the Athenians or their allies, either by their own initiative or by the persuasion of others, and that they would obey the decisions of the Athenians]
 οὐκ ἀκο[στέ]σομα[ι] Ἀ[θεναίον το̃ πλέθος οὐδὲ τὸν χσυνμάχο]ν τὸν Ἀθεν[αίο]ν οὔτ᾿ αὐ[τὸς ἐγὸ οὔτ᾿ ἄλλοι πείσομαι, τε̃ι δὲ γνόμ]ει τε̃[ι] Ἀθ[ε]ναίον πείσ[ομαι·]
remarks:
This inscriptions records the regulations imposed on Erythrae by Athens. 
The Erythraeans swore before the boule and the Athenian garrison commander. It should be noted that each of the formulae for this entry is restored.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
date: Before the destruction of the city (ca. 510) (510)
impact: Gives added emphasis to the story
statement:
[That if the jar had forgotten about calling people to witness and hurried up and brought a bandage, it would have been more sensible]
 εἰ ναὶ τὰν Κόραν
  τὴν μαρτυρίαν ταύτην ἐάσας ἐν τάχει 
  ἐπίδεσμον ἐπρίω, νοῦν ἂν εἶχες πλείονα
remarks: Like Philocleon's story about Aesop which included an informal oath (see remarks on id 1128), this oath here is also entirely fictitious.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
if_broken: May his head be struck from his shoulders
statement:
[That the speaker will be a plague to all the suitors]
 αἲ γὰρ ἐγὼν οὕτω νέος εἴην τῷδ’ ἐπὶ θυμῷ, 
ἢ παῖς ἐξ Ὀδυσῆος ἀμύμονος ἠὲ καὶ αὐτὸς  
ἔλθοι ἀλητεύων· ἔτι γὰρ καὶ ἐλπίδος αἶσα· 
αὐτίκ’ ἔπειτ’ ἀπ’ ἐμεῖο κάρη τάμοι ἀλλότριος φῶς,
εἰ μὴ ἐγὼ κείνοισι κακὸν πάντεσσι γενοίμην
remarks: This oath contains no linguistic markers, and no gods are named, but it is a strong conditional self-curse and therefore an oath. There seems to be some confusion in this passage about who “I” is:  the speaker seems to have momentarily forgotten that he is not supposed to be Odysseus!  (Cf. also 106, where he speaks of preferring to be killed "in my own halls" rather than have to watch the suitors' disgraceful behaviour.  Are we to suppose that even he is finding it hard, in the presence of Telemachus, to keep up his pretence?  This is the only speech he makes between the arrival of Telemachus and the father-son reunion. One quite understands that Athena sets up the recognition scene the instant she sees Eumaeus leave the hut, 155ff.).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would hand over the dead from within their city walls and would not molest the Thebans while the latter were taking their dead away]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Plataeans handed over the Theban dead "under a truce" (ὑποσπόνδους).

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the speaker told no lie (when s/he said that women don't leak the secrets of the Thesmophoria, but men leak those of the Council]
 κοὔτε τἀπόρρητ’ ἔφη
  ἐκ Θεσμοφόροιν ἑκάστοτ’ αὐτὰς ἐκφέρειν, 
  σὲ δὲ κἀμὲ βουλεύοντε τοῦτο δρᾶν ἀεί. 
 {Βλ.}  καὶ νὴ τὸν Ἑρμῆν τοῦτό γ’ οὐκ ἐψεύσατο. (445)
remarks: On the Council's secret sessions and the probable difficulty in maintaining its secrets, see Sommerstein ad 444.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies (as the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Corcyraeans as allies, observing that they were autonomous but claimed that they had been compelled to assist the Athenians. 
Thucydides states at 3.75.1 that Nicostratus persuaded the Corcyraeans to agree to have the same friends and enemies as the Athenians (see also oath id 1631).

author: Aristotle
title: Aporemata Homerica
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Helios; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Here Aristotle discusses the oath of truce between the Trojans and Greeks recounted in books 3 and 4 of the Iliad (see oath id 318 with cross references). The oaths are broken by the Trojans when Pandarus, under the influence of Athena, shoots an arrow at Menelaus, thus causing the conflict to resume. Aristotle says that the poet does not say that they perjured themselves … but that they were accursed, having cursed themselves by saying [Il. 3.298-300].  That is, they did not commit perjury, but committed the crime of damaging (ἔβλαψα&nu) their oaths [cf. the phrase in 3.299 ὑπέρ ὅρκια πημήνεια&nu] and thus brought a curse on themselves.  Hence Hera tries to ensure that harm comes to them from their own curse; for after they have prayed [3.298-300] Hera makes this suggestion to Athena (see oath id 322).  And damaging is not the same thing as perjuring oneself. It is, of course, a total quibble; if 3.298-300 is indeed an oath, and the Trojans have acted contrary to it, then they have committed perjury, and there’s an end of it. Cf. also oath ids 2000 and 2002.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
remarks:
Aeschines says that he will address the periods when Demosthenes intervened in politics in turn (see oath id 2658), and begin with the peace which Demosthenes and Philocrates proposed. 
Aeschines argues that they could have made a peace supported by a common synedrion of the Greeks if certain men i.e. Demosthenes and Philocrates had allowed them to wait for the return of the embassies sent out to the rest of the Greeks, calling them to unite against Philip. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: Representatives; Envoys; Envoys of the allies of Athens; Envoys
swearee: Representatives; Envoys; Envoys of the allies of Athens; Envoys
remarks:
Xenophon contrasts the behaviour of the Athenians and the Spartans after the truce was formalised. 
Whereas the Athenians withdrew their garrisons and recalled the forces led by Iphicrates (see oath id 1975), the Spartans withdrew their harmosts and garrisons, but did not send out orders to King Cleombrotus who was at the head of the army in Phocis. Cleombrotus asked the authorities at home for instructions, and the matter was debated at Sparta. 
Prothous addressed the assembly, saying that it seemed to him that they ought to disband the army in accordance with their oaths, and then send round word to the cities to make contributions to a war fund. Then, if anyone tried to prevent the cities from being autonomous, they should call together all who wished to support the cause of independence and lead them against those who opposed it. 
Prothous argued that this would ensure that the gods would be most favourably inclined towards them, and the cities least annoyed. 
The Spartan assembly, however, decided that he was talking nonsense, and sent orders to Cleombrotus not to disband his army, but to lead it against the Thebans if they did not leave the cities autonomous. 
When Cleombrotus learned that the Thebans had not disbanded their army but were planning to lead it against him, he led his troops into Boeotia. 
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That the Megarians are not managing to haul up Peace, in spite of their efforts, because they are perishing with hunger]
  {ΤΡ.}  Οὐδ’ οἱ Μεγαρῆς δρῶσ’ οὐδέν·  
  {ΕΡ.}  ἕλκουσιν δ’ ὅμως 
  γλισχρότατα σαρκάζοντες ὥσπερ κυνίδια—
 {ΤΡ.}  ὑπὸ τοῦ γε λιμοῦ νὴ Δί’ ἐξολωλότες.
remarks: The joke about Megarian hunger is a reference to the devastation suffered by the Megarid during the war.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That it seems to him that Heracleides is not caring for Seuthes' interests as he should]
 Δοκεῖς μοι, ὦ Ἡρακλείδη, οὐχ ὡς δεῖ κήδεσθαι Σεύθου·
remarks:
When Heracleides the Maronite, a key retainer of Seuthes, paid the wages of Xenophon's troops, it was for only twenty days of the preceding month. 
Heracleides claimed that he had not obtained more from the sale of the booty. 
Xenophon was angry, and swore that it seemed to him that Heracleides was not looking after Seuthes' interests as he should. For if he was he would have paid the Greeks in full, even if it meant borrowing the money or paying it out of his own pocket. 
Heracleides was angered by Xenophon's comment, and also afraid that he would lose Seuthes' favour. According to Xenophon, as a result he began to slander Xenophon before Seuthes.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he doesn't want his father to buy him knucklebones]
 τί βούλει με πρίασθαι
  καλόν; οἶμαι δέ σ’ ἐρεῖν ἀσ‐ 
 τραγάλους δήπουθεν, ὦ παῖ.
 {Πα.}  μὰ Δί’
remarks: As Sommerstein ad 295-6 explains, "knucklebones" describes "small bones from the feet of sheep or other animals, used by children as dice or for playing odd-and-even and other games".

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Dicaeogenes
swearer: Menexenus (III); The cousins of Menexenus; Dicaeogenes; Leochares
swearee: Menexenus (III); The cousins of Menexenus; Dicaeogenes; Leochares
if_refused: The agreement would not be formalised
statement:
[That they would abide by whatever the arbitrators decided]
 ἐμμενεῖν οἷς [ἂν] αὐτοὶ γνοῖεν
remarks:
Menexenus claims that the arbitrators nominated by his opponents refused to pronounce their decision even though they had made the disputing parties swear that they would abide by whatever they decided. 
See also oath id 3045.

author: Pherecrates
title: Korianno
statement:
[That the swearer does not want lentil seeds]
 μή μοι φακούς, μὰ τὸν Δί’, οὐ γὰρ ἥδομαι·
remarks: The " φακούς" seem to refer to  lentil seeds as a crudité rather than "lentil  soup". The verb for consuming soup is rhophein, whereas here we have (en)tragein which normally refers to things that one chews or nibbles.  In line 2, we see that this food is being served not as a meal, but as an accompaniment for drinks.  Cf. Solon fr. 38 where people are said to take bread, cakes or lentils with their wine.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That it was clear to him that - at the time when Meidias was going around alleging that Demosthenes had dropped the case - that some of those who are perfectly happy to talk to Meidias were sorry to hear it]
 ἐμοὶ μὲν νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω καὶ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν (εἰρήσεται γάρ, εἴτ’ ἄμεινον εἴτε μή,) ὅθ’ οὗτος ὡς ἀπήλλαγμαι περιιὼν ἐλογοποίει, ἔνδηλοί τινες ἦσαν ἀχθόμενοι τῶν πάνυ τούτῳ λαλούντων ἡδέως.
remarks: MacDowell, Demosthenes: Against Meidias, (Oxford 1990), p46, writes that "an oath with two or three accusatives is used by D. to introduce a statement cautiously or apologetically".  The context shows, at any rate, that the people he is talking about are people who are generally regarded as friends of Meidias, and that what he is claiming is that these people only act friendly towards him because he is influential.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
impact: Hera can continue with her plan to set Eurystheus up as ruler
statement:
[That whatever son of Zeus is born on that day will be lord over all his neighbours]
 ψευστής εἰς, οὐδ’ αὖτε τέλος μύθῳ ἐπιθήσεις. 
εἰ δ’ ἄγε νῦν μοι ὄμοσσον Ὀλύμπιε καρτερὸν ὅρκον, 
ἦ μὲν τὸν πάντεσσι περικτιόνεσσιν ἀνάξειν 
ὅς κεν ἐπ’ ἤματι τῷδε πέσῃ μετὰ ποσσὶ γυναικὸς
τῶν ἀνδρῶν οἳ σῆς ἐξ αἵματός εἰσι γενέθλης. 
ὣς ἔφατο· Ζεὺς δ’ οὔ τι δολοφροσύνην ἐνόησεν,
ἀλλ’ ὄμοσεν μέγαν ὅρκον, ἔπειτα δὲ πολλὸν ἀάσθη.
remarks: This oath is unusual in several ways. It is used by Agamemnon to justify his delusions about Briseis because even Zeus can be deceived, as Hera uses this oath to guarantee that her plans for Eurystheus will go ahead instead of Zeus' plans for Heracles. This speech is the only place where Zeus is reported to swear. Cf. also oath id 411. Aristotle discusses this oath in Aporemata Homerica, see oath id 2003.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that it was to Philip's advantage that the longest time possible should elapse before the ratification of the oaths, but to the advantage of the Athenians that it should be as short as possible. He claims that whereas the Athenians from the day the treaty was signed the Athenians hoped for peace, Philip was planning to seize as much as he could before the oaths were ratified. 
Demosthenes rejects Aeschines' criticism that he proposed a motion to send envoys to wherever Philip was and to receive the oaths from him with all speed, arguing that he did so in order that they might make peace with Philip before their allies in Thrace were lost. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Coloneus
statement:
[That he will never betray Oedipus' daughters willingly, and will always do whatever is to their advantage]
“ὦ φίλον κάρα,
δός μοι χερὸς σῆς πίστιν ἀρχαίαν τέκνοις,
ὑμεῖς τε, παῖδες, τῷδε· καὶ καταίνεσον
μήποτε προδώσειν τάσδ’ ἑκών, τελεῖν δ’ ὅσ’ ἂν
μέλλῃς φρονῶν εὖ ξυμφέροντ’ αὐταῖς ἀεί.”
ὁ δ’, ὡς ἀνὴρ γενναῖος, οὐκ οἴκτου μέτα
κατῄνεσεν τάδ’ ὅρκιος δράσειν ξένῳ.
remarks: We are given Oedipus' words in oratio recta. He asks Theseus only for a hand pledge, with no mention of swearing, but Theseus gives him an oath just the same. So the promise is proposed by Oedipus, but the oath seems to be volunteered by Theseus. Compare oath id 291 in this play and also id 284, where attention is drawn to the fact that an oath is not demanded (presumably because it would seem rude), and a hand pledge suffices in these cases.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That he thinks he did not do badly to surmise, what he has now perceived, that the ancients gave names in such a way as to indicate that everything was in motion and nothing was stable]
 Καὶ μήν, νὴ τὸν κύνα, δοκῶ γέ μοι οὐ κακῶς μαντεύεσθαι, ὃ καὶ νυνδὴ ἐνενόησα
remarks: Swearing by the "the dog" is a common Socratic oath formula- see oath id 2548 with cross-references.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
swearer: Aeschines' brother; Aeschines' nephew; Aeschines' physician
if_taken: Aeschines will not have to serve as ambassador
if_refused: Aeschines will have to serve as ambassador
statement: [? That Aeschines was unwell and could not serve as an ambassador]
remarks:
Aeschines states that when he was elected as an ambassador to Philip he was ill, so he sent his brother, his nephew and his physician (Execestus) to the boule to swear that he was ill. 
Aeschines stresses that he sent them not to decline the office (for the law forbids this) but merely to testify that he was ill. See also oath id 3767, 3768, 3769.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That Thrasymachus should not spoonfeed his argument into Socrates’ mind]
 ἢ εἰς τὴν ψυχὴν φέρων ἐνθῶ τὸν λόγον;  Μὰ Δί’, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, μὴ σύ γε·
remarks: Thrasymachus is worried that he will not be able to persuade Socrates and the other guests that they are ill-advised in preferring justice to injustice.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would be allies to the Greeks, would not betray them, and would lead them without treachery]
remarks:
When addressing the Greeks, Cleanor the Orchomenian observed that "Ariaeus, whom we were ready to make King (see 2.1.4), with whom we exchanged pledges not to betray one another, even he, showing neither fear of the gods nor honour for the memory of Cyrus..has gone over to the most bitter foes of Cyrus and is trying to work harm to us, the friends of Cyrus". 
See also oath id 2169.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Cyrus should no longer trouble himself over the matter of Croesus' happiness (he has just made Croesus very happy by restoring his family and household to him)]
 Μὰ Δία μηδὲν τοίνυν, ἔφη ὁ Κροῖσος, σὺ {ἐμοὶ} ἔτι βουλεύου {ἀποκρίνασθαι} περὶ τῆς ἐμῆς εὐδαιμονίας·

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he doesn't doubt that Callias knows how to shadow-box because his legs appear to be nearly equal in weight to his shoulders]
 ἐπεὶ δέ σου ἤκουσα ὅμοια οἷς νῦν λέγεις, καὶ αὐτὸς ἐλθὼν οἴκαδε ὠρχούμην μὲν οὔ, οὐ γὰρ πώποτε τοῦτ’ ἔμαθον, ἐχειρονόμουν δέ· ταῦτα γὰρ  ἠπιστάμην. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Φίλιππος, καὶ γὰρ οὖν οὕτω τὰ σκέλη τοῖς ὤμοις φαίνει ἰσοφόρα ἔχειν ὥστε δοκεῖς ἐμοί, κἂν εἰ τοῖς ἀγορανόμοις ἀφισταίης ὥσπερ ἄρτους τὰ κάτω πρὸς τὰ ἄνω, ἀζήμιος ἂν γενέσθαι.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the Assembly will take place at dawn]
 ἡκκλησία δ’, εἰς ἣν παρεσκευάσμεθα 
  ἡμεῖς βαδίζειν, ἐξ ἕω γενήσεται. 
 {Γυ. α}  νὴ τὸν Δί’

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
statement:
[That he does not believe that Philip himself would pray that the Athenians might act otherwise than they are acting]
καὶ Φίλιππον δ’ αὐτὸν οὐδὲν ἂν ἄλλ’ οἶμαι μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς εὔξασθαι ποιεῖν τὴν πόλιν ἢ ταῦθ’ ἃ νῦν ποιεῖτε·
remarks: Demosthenes is criticising the Athenians for wasting time, wasting money, looking for someone to pass the buck to, grumbling, blaming each other, and always reacting to events instead of making plans that will enable them to dictate events.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
impact: Gives added weight to his claim
statement:
[That he would not have gone as an ambassador with "these men" if it had not been for his wish to rescue the prisoners of war, even if he'd been paid a large sum of money for it]
 ἐπεὶ εἰ μὴ διὰ τὸ τούτους βούλεσθαι σῶσαι, ἐξώλης ἀπολοίμην καὶ προώλης, εἰ προσλαβών γ’ ἂν ἀργύριον πάνυ πολὺ μετὰ τούτων ἐπρέσβευσα.
remarks: Demosthenes is referring to Aeschines and Philocrates when he speaks of "these men".

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
impact: Socrates is compelled to give his speech
statement: [That unless Socrates delivers his speech in the very presence of the plane tree, Phaedrus will never again report any other speech by any other author]
