remarks: Here Socrates responds to Phaedrus' oath by giving in to Phaedrus' request because of the oath- see oath id 2930 for further details.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
[That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
 καὶ ὅρκους ἰσχυροὺς ὠμόσαμεν ἀλλήλοις, ἦ μὴν τά τε ὑπάρχοντα φανερὰ ὄντα καλῶς καὶ δικαίως διαιρήσεσθαι καὶ μηδ’ ὁτιοῦν πλεονεκτήσειν τὸν ἕτερον τοῦ ἑτέρου ὧν κατέλιπεν Κόμων, καὶ τἄλλα πάντα κοινῇ ζητήσειν, καὶ πράξειν μετ’ ἀλλήλων βουλευόμενοι ὅ τι ἂν ἀεὶ δέῃ.
remarks:
Callistratus tells the jurors that they swore this oath because they suspected that others would come to lay claim to the estate of Comon - as they did. 
Callistratus adds that they drew up their articles of agreement and swore their oaths in order that neither of them would have the opportunity of doing anything independently, whether he should wish to do so or not, and that they called to witness the agreement not only the gods, but also Androcleides of Acharnae with whom they deposited the articles. 
See also oath id 3624, 3625, 3626, 3627, 3629, 3630, 3631, 3632, 3633, 3634, 3635.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That Ischomachus did not train his wife to be competent in matters that concern her until he had sacrificed to the gods and prayed for success]
 αὐτὸς ἐπαίδευσας τὴν γυναῖκα ὥστε
ἱκανὴν εἶναι ὧν προσήκει ἐπιμελεῖσθαι; Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ
 Ἰσχόμαχος, οὐ πρίν γε καὶ ἔθυσα καὶ ηὐξάμην ἐμέ τε 
τυγχάνειν διδάσκοντα καὶ ἐκείνην μανθάνουσαν τὰ βέλτιστα
ἀμφοτέροις ἡμῖν

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks: Xenophon refers here to the so-called Argive alliance of ca. 420 (see also oath id 251). Describing events of 399 he states that the Spartan declaration of war against Elis in that year was partly due to long-standing resentment of the alliance they had made with the Athenians, Argives and Mantineans - even though this alliance had long lapsed, and Athenians actually took part in the Elean war as Allies of Sparta (3.2.25). The Spartans' more immediate grievances concerned the Eleans' actions in debarring them from the Games at Olympia in 400, and preventing King Agis from making a sacrifice there to Zeus.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Chremylus attempts to coax the blind man into revealing his identity "if [he] takes pleasure in the character of a man who keeps his word". Sommerstein comments ad 61: "it is not obvious from the context why Chremylus ahould here highlight this particular virtue; most likely the explanation is that the line is a tragic quotation… and that the keeping of oaths was significant in its original tragic context".

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, the Aeginetans sent delegates to Sparta who said that they were not autonomous as they were supposed to be "according to the treaty" (λέγοντες οὐκ εἶναι αὐτόνομοι κατὰ τὰς σπονδάς).  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Emphasises the excitement over the wine
statement:
[That the "blood" (i.e. wine) is sweet-smelling]
  Καὶ μὰν ποτόδδει γ’ ἁδὺ ναὶ τὸν Κάστορα.
remarks: This informal oath comes in the long formal oath sequence of id 1164. Once again, it is fitting for the Spartan to swear by Castor; cf. oath id 1216 with cross references.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia in Tauris
if_taken: Iphigenia will enable Pylades to escape
if_refused: Iphigenia will not enable Pylades to escape
statement: [That he will bring Iphigenia's letter back to Argos]
remarks: Same oath as id 149.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between  Athens, Arcadia, Achaea, Elis and Phlius. 
See also oath id 446.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That men growing old and women growing old are not the same thing]
 Οὔκουν χἄνδρες γηράσκουσιν;
 {ΛΥ.}  Μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ οὐκ εἶπας ὅμοιον.
remarks: Lysistrata's argument is that while a man can marry at any age, a woman's marrying prime is short.

author: Eupolis
title: Demoi
statement:
[That anyone who offends him will regret it]
 οὐ γὰρ μὰ τὴν Μαραθῶνι τὴν ἐμὴν μάχην 
χαίρων τις αὐτῶν τοὐμὸν ἀλγυνεῖ κέαρ.
remarks: The speaker here is Miltiades returned from the dead. His oath is unusual in that he evokes (literally) "my own battle at Marathon" as sanctifying witness.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he has done far more good for the city than Themistocles ever did]
 πεποηκότα πλείονα χρηστὰ 
  νὴ τὴν Δήμητρα Θεμιστοκλέους πολλῷ περὶ τὴν πόλιν ἤδη
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 812: "For Paphlagon-Cleon to claim that his achievements in general were greater than those of Themistocles would be an obvious absurdity; but the real Cleon may perhaps have made the claim (which he could make with perfect truth) that in defeating a Spartan force in a land battle he had done something which Themistocles had never done."

title: IPriene
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that individuals can deliver up unspecified offerings to the hieropoioi "upon swearing by Mykale", and deliver up unspecified offerings on the 13th of Taureon to Mykale and the nymphs, and offerings of cheese to Hermes Ktenites on the 8th of Targelion, and subsequently to Maiandros "upon swearing by Mykale".

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That Spithridates' daughter certainly is beautiful]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ὄτυς, καλὴ γάρ ἐστι
remarks:
Agesilaus asked Otys whether he had noticed how handsome Spithridates' son was, and observed that people said that Spithridates' daughter was even more handsome. 
Otys replied, "Yes, by Zeus, she certainly is beautiful."

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
statement:
[That, as long as the kings kept their oath, they would never attack the monarchy nor allow others to do so;  and that they would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
 βασιλεῖαι τρεῖς βασιλευομέναις πόλεσιν
τριτταῖς ὤμοσαν ἀλλήλαις ἑκάτεραι, κατὰ νόμους οὓς ἔθεντο
τοῦ τε ἄρχειν καὶ ἄρχεσθαι κοινούς, οἱ μὲν μὴ βιαιοτέραν 
τὴν ἀρχὴν ποιήσεσθαι προϊόντος τοῦ χρόνου καὶ γένους, 
οἱ δέ, ταῦτα ἐμπεδούντων τῶν ἀρχόντων, μήτε αὐτοὶ τὰς 
βασιλείας ποτὲ καταλύσειν μήτ’ ἐπιτρέψειν ἐπιχειροῦσιν ἑτέροις, βοηθήσειν δὲ βασιλῆς τε βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις
καὶ δήμοις, καὶ δῆμοι δήμοις καὶ βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις.
remarks: The discussion concerns the time in which Temenus was King of Argos, Cresphontes was king of Messene and Procles and Eurysthenes were kings of Sparta, when the area was first divided into the three states of Argos, Sparta and Messene. The king swears a reciprocal oath- see oath id 2678. The kings and people of Argos and Messene do the same- see oath ids 2680-3. The kings do not break their oath, but they subsequently disagree about it- see oath ids 2684-6. Compare also Xenophon, Lakedaimonion Politeia 15.7 (oath id 2236).

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Xenophon states that the envoys from all the Greek poleis swore that they would observe the provision laid down by the King. 
However, the Theban envoys claimed the right to swear on behalf of all the Boeotians. 
Agesilaus refused to accept the oaths unless they swore just as the King's letter directed: that every city whether small or great should be independent. 
When the Theban envoys refused, Agesilaus told them to go home and report to the people that they would be shut out of the treaty. 
Agesilaus then prepared a force to lead against Thebes and marched out to Tegea. But before he left Tegea the Theban envoys returned with word that the Thebans would leave the other Boeotian cities independent. Agesilaus then returned home and the Thebans were forced to accede to the treaty. 
The Argives also withdrew from Corinth and the Corinthians regained their independence. 
Xenophon states that when these things had been accomplished and the states had sworn that they would abide by the treaty the armies and navies were disbanded. 
See also oath id 328, 344, 413, 414, 1964, 1985, 2299, 2939, 2940, 2978, 2980, 2982, 2985, 2987, 2988, 2994, 2995, 3004, 3006, 3008, 3011, 3016, 3017, 3018, 3019, 3024, 3057, 3299, 3300, 3301, 3374, 3619, 3620.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he will not say what way there can be to safety]
 Οὐκ ἐχρῆν ζητεῖν τινα
  σωτηρίαν νῷν, ἀλλὰ μὴ κλάειν ἔτι; 
  {ΝΙ.}  Τίς οὖν γένοιτ’ ἄν;
  {ΔΗ. }  Λέγε σύ.
  {ΝΙ.}  Σὺ μὲν οὖν μοι λέγε,
  ἵνα μὴ μάχωμαι.
 {ΔΗ. }  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω ’γὼ μὲν οὔ.
remarks: The two slaves are never named in the actual text, but one of them identifies himself as the general Demosthenes by claiming (54-57) that Paphlagon/Cleon robbed him of credit for the victory of Pylos-Sphacteria, and some ancient scholars, cited in Hypothesis II, argued on grounds of symmetry that the other was meant to represent Nicias; for some evidence suggesting that they were right, and that the identities of these two characters were established in performance by portrait-masks, see D.M. MacDowell, Aristophanes and Athens (Oxford, 1995) 87-88. The statement is qualified by the following line in which Demosthenes tells Nicias that he will tell Nicias (what he is thinking) after the latter has spoken.

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: The text indicates that an agreement was made between Tylissos, Cnossus and Argos, and that "no new treaties should be made by either (party) unless it is agreed upon by the the (common) assembly".

author: Ephorus
title: Histories
impact: Boeotians encamp rather carelessly as they have no fear of attack from the Thracians
statement: [That they would not attack each other for a specified number of days]
remarks: In spite of swearing this truce, the Thracians attack the unsuspecting Boeotians during the night, which suggests that they proposed the truce in order to do this. When the Boeotians, who had thought that peace had been made, charge the Thracians with breaking the truce, the Thracians assert that they did not break it since the truce had referred to days, whereas they had made their attack by night. From this incident apparently arose the proverb of "Thracian pretense".

author: Hellanicus
title: The First Trojan War
if_taken: Apollo and Poseidon would build the walls of Troy
if_refused: Apollo and Poseidon would not build the walls of Troy
consequences_of_breach: Poseidon sends a sea monster which destroys both the people it met with and the crops
statement:
[That he would pay Apollo and Poseidon an agreed wage for building the walls of Troy]
 Λαομέδων δὲ παραβὰς τοὺς ὅρκους καὶ τὰς συνθήκας μὴ δοὺς τὸν μισθὸν ἀπήλασεν αὐτούς.
remarks: Laomedon was known for his treachery, but here the breaking of his agreement with Apollo and Poseidon is treated as the violation of an oath. This is also the case in Virgil Geogics 1.501-2 (satis iam pridem sanguine nostro/ Laomedonteae luimus periuria Troiae).  Cf. also Aeneid 4.541-2 (Dido speaking) nescis heu, perdita, necdum / Laomedonteae sentis periuria gentis?  In Ovid Met. 11.205-6 it is implied, rather than stated, that Laomedon's perjury consisted in swearing that he had never promised to pay the two gods; Hellanicus, however, clearly assumes that the initial promise was itself made on oath.

author: Antiphanes
title: Parasitos
statement:
[That dried pigs' legs are a charming meal]
 χοιρίων 
σκέλη καπύρ’. {Β.} ἀστεῖόν γε νὴ τὴν Ἑστίαν
ἄριστον.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he has not struck Xanthias yet]
  ἤδη ’πάταξας; 
ΑΙ.  Οὐ μὰ Δί! 
 ΞΑ. οὐδ’ ἐμοῖ δοκεῖς.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
if_taken: The Nurse will divulge her secret
if_refused: The Nurse will not divulge her secret
impact: Hippolytus is bound against his will and will later be unable to clear his name
statement: [That he will not reveal what he has been told]
remarks: Line 612, where Hippolytus states that his tongue has sworn but his heart isn't under oath, was famously parodied by Aristophanes- see oath ids 376, 514, 711. The oath is referred to several times during the play (see oath ids 126, 132, 133). Aristotle in his Rhetoric cites this passage with reference to Hygiaenon's accusation of Euripides' impiety (see oath id 1739). Socrates also refers to this passage during the Theaetetus when commenting on a seemingly paradoxical response (see oath id 2896). Compare also Bacchylides Pasiphae (?) 26.8 where Pasiphae makes Daedalus swear an oath of secrecy about her illness (i.e. lust for the bull)- see oath id 1342.

author: Aristophanes

[That Labes really was acquitted]
 ὄντως ἀπέφυγε; 
 {Βδ.}  νὴ Δί’.

title: IPArk
statement:
[That they would be guileless in the synoecism with the Orchomenioi with regard to the agreement, by Zeus Ares, by Athena Areia, by Enyalios Ares. That they would never move away from the Orchomenians, not by Zeus Ares, not by Athena Areia, not by Enyalios Ares]
 ἀψευ[δ]ήων ἂ<ν> τὰν συϜοι[κί]α̣ν τοῖς Ἐρχομινίο[ι]ς πὸς τὰς συνθέ[σι]ς, νεὶ τὸν Δία τὸν Ἄρ[η]α̣, νεὶ τὰν Ἀθάναν τ̣ὰν Ἄρειαν, νεὶ τὸν [Ἰ]νυάλιον τὸν Ἄρηα̣, [ο]ὐδ’ ἂν ἀνισταίμαν ἀπὺ τοῖς Ἐρχομιν[ί]οις οὔποτε, οὐ τὸν [Δ]ία τὸν Ἄρηα, οὐ τὰ̣ν Ἀθάναν τὰν Ἄρε̣[ι]α̣ν, οὐ τὸν Ἰνυάλιον τὸν Ἄρηα· κεὐορκέντι μὲν τἀγαθά̣, [ἐ]πιορκέντι δὲ ἐξο̣[λέ]σθαι αὐτὸγ καὶ γένος.
linguistic: nei tan, nei ton, ork, wmos
remarks:
This text refers to the synoecism of Orchomenos and Euaemon. 
The text was originally published as IG V, 2 343.  
The four swearers are presuambly representatives of the community of Euaemon.  
For the corresponding oath sworn by all the citizens of Orchomenos see oath id 576.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That good men do indeed speak ill of evil things – or at least of evil men]
 Κακῶς ἄρα, ἔφη, λέγουσιν, ὦ Κτήσιππε, οἱ ἀγαθοὶ τὰ κακά, εἴπερ ὡς ἔχει λέγουσιν.  Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, σφόδρα γε, τοὺς γοῦν κακοὺς ἀνθρώπους·

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
The Spartan assembly decided that the peace treaty had been broken.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That they are not preparing a display for Hieron the auctioneer]
 οὔ τι μὴν 
  Ἱέρωνι τῷ κήρυκι πομπὴν πέμπετε; 
 {Γε.}  μὰ Δί’
remarks: For the translation "preparing a display" see Sommerstein ad 757 who explains: "we should probably deduce that when goods were displayed for sale by public auction... they were often put out in a long row on a table or board, and that such a display was called a "procession" (pompe)".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the trierarchs at Samos and the most influential men were bent upon overthrowing the democracy. 
When Alcibiades who was in exile in Asia Minor claimed he could convince Tissaphernes to support Athens instead of Sparta if there were not a democracy at Athens the movement evolved into a conspiracy. The members of the conspiracy assembled and then agreed to send Peisander and others to Athens to negotiate the return of Alcibiades and the overthrow of the democracy.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement:
[That they would not neither work the land themselves, nor allow anyone else, but would aid the god and the consecrated land with hand and foot <and voice> and every means]
 μήτ’ αὐτοὶ τὴν ἱερὰν γῆν ἐργάσεσθαι μήτ’ ἄλλῳ ἐπιτρέψειν, ἀλλὰ βοηθήσειν τῷ θεῷ καὶ τῇ γῇ τῇ ἱερᾷ καὶ χειρὶ καὶ ποδὶ <καὶ φωνῇ> καὶ πάσῃ δυνάμει.
remarks:
Aeschines states that the after the Amphictyones defeated the Cirrhaeans (and Cragalidae) in the First Sacred War, they enslaved them, destroyed their city and consecrated their land as commanded by the oracle. 
They then swore a mighty oath that they would not neither work the land themselves, nor allow anyone else, but would aid the god and the consecrated land with hand and foot <and voice> and every means. 
Not content with this, they added a strong curse: "If anyone should violate this, city, individual or race, let them be cursed by Apollo, Artemis, Leto and Athena Pronaia. Their land should produce no crops, their wives bear children not like the parents, but monsters, their livestock not produce natural offspring; they should be defeated in war, lawsuits and debates, and they themselves, their households and their race should perish utterly; and they shall never offer pure sacrifice to Apollo, Artemis, Leto and Athena Pronaia, and may the gods not accept their offerings. 
Aeschines has the oath and curse read to the jurors, and goes on to say that "although this curse and oath and oracle are publicly inscribed today, the leaders of the Locrians of Amphissa - most lawless of men - tilled the plain, rebuilt the walls of the harbour that was consecrated and cursed, and were exacting duties from the people putting in there, and had bribed some of the delegates who came to Delphi - including Demosthenes".

author: Antiphanes
title: Aleiptria
statement:
[That if the swearees make the workshop a subject for gossip, the swearer will pour the greatest cupful of boiling water over them]
 ἐὰν δὲ τοὐργαστήριον ποιῆτε περιβόητον,
κατασκεδῶ, νὴ τὴν φίλην Δήμητρα, τὴν μεγίστην 
ἀρύταιναν ὑμῶν ἐκ μέσου βάψασα τοῦ λέβητος 
ζέοντος ὕδατος·
remarks: The “workshop” is probably a brothel.  Cf. [Dem.] 59.67 where ergasterion is clearly a term in regular use with this meaning.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That he doesn't think that the many agree with themselves or each other in the slightest about just and unjust men or things]
 νῦν περὶ τῶν δικαίων καὶ ἀδίκων ἀνθρώπων καὶ πραγμάτων οἱ πολλοὶ δοκοῦσί σοι ὁμολογεῖν αὐτοὶ ἑαυτοῖς ἢ ἀλλήλοις; {ΑΛ.} Ἥκιστα νὴ Δί’, ὦ Σώκρατες.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Sicyonians repelled an Athenian attack, and then set up a trophy and gave up the dead "under truce" (ὑποσπόνδους).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Stephanus 1
if_taken: He will not have to testify
statement: [That he did not know that the facts, to which he had been called to testify, were true]
remarks:
Apollodorus calls his father-in-law Deinias to testify that he gave his daughter to Apollodorus as his wife according to the laws, and that he was not present when Apollodorus released Phormion from all claims, and was not aware that he had done so. 
Apollodorus then states that Deinias refuses to testify against Stephanus on behalf of his daughter, his daughter's children, and his son-in-law. 
This must mean that Deinias took the exomosia to avoid testifying. 
The witness making an exomosia is swearing, not "that he knew nothing of the facts about which he had been called to testify", but that he did not know that the facts, to which he had been called to testify, were true.  See Carey, CQ 45 (1995) 114-9.  Otherwise a witness, called to confirm a deposition, written for him without his consent, which he knew to be untrue, would be forced to choose between giving false evidence and falsely swearing complete ignorance of the matter.  It is, of course, always the party calling the witness who talks about the exomosia, and he has a vested interest in throwing dust in the jurymen’s eyes.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
if_taken: Their wives will have sex with them
if_refused: Their wives will refuse to have sex with them
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
gods_invoked: Graces; Artemis; Apollo; Dionysus; Zeus; Hera; Daimones
remarks: Lysistrata here refers once more to the treaty of peace (for which she gives credit to Cypris Aphrodite) and invokes a long list of gods to witness it; cf. oath id 1238, and also ids 1220 and 1234. The invocation of daimones may refer to all the gods (so the scholia, and Sommerstein, and cf. E. Hel. 1678); but Halliwell renders “all the other gods”, Thiercy “les autres déités”.

author: Plato
title: Menexenus
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks: This is a reference to the Peace of Nicias. Plato describes how the peace was followed by "a third war" during which many brave men lost their lives. For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see also oath id 1681.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Thebans and Thessalians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Thebans and Thessalians while they collected their dead]
remarks: Xenophon says that the Athenian cavalry, after their victory, did not abandon their own dead, and gave up some of the enemy's dead under a truce.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he does know of others (apart from themselves) who are enemies of the Assyrians]
 ἐπίστασθε καὶ ἄλλον τινὰ αὐτῷ πολέμιον; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη
remarks: The enemies mentioned are the Cadusians and the Sacians.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That people's facial reaction to good or bad news about a friend differs according to whether they really care about the friend or not]
 Ἐπὶ δὲ τοῖς τῶν φίλων ἀγαθοῖς καὶ τοῖς κακοῖς ὁμοίως σοι δοκοῦσιν ἔχειν τὰ πρόσωπα οἵ τε φροντίζοντες καὶ οἱ μή; Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτα

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Philocles
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The prosecutor argues that the Athenian jurors did not allow the services Timotheus the son of Conon rendered to the state to outweigh their oaths, and that the jurors should not do so presently. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Lysias
title: Against Andocides
statement:
[That if the jurors show any unjust favouritism towards Andocides, it will be hard for them to escape the attention of the Greeks]
 ὥστε μὰ τὸν Δία οὐ ῥᾴδιόν ἐστιν ὑμῖν αὐτῷ οὐδὲν χαρισαμένοις παρὰ τὸ δίκαιον λαθεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας.
remarks: The speaker is envisaging the (highly unlikely) scenario of Andocides, at some future time, being chosen by lot as king-archon (basileus) and therefore being responsible for the supervision of public religious activities, including the Eleusinian Mysteries which he has allegedly profaned, something that would horrify the many who visit this festival from other parts of the Greek world.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
swearer: Euboulides the demarch; Supporters of Euboulides
if_taken: They will not have to give evidence
if_refused: They will have to give evidence
statement: [That they did not know that the facts, to which they had been called to testify, were true]
remarks:
Euxitheus states that the aliens Anaximenes and Nicostratus were enrolled as citizens at Halimus for a fee of five drachmas, and claims that Euboulides and those with him will not deny under oath that they have knowledge of this. 
While Euxitheus makes it sound as if he is going to call up Euboulides and those with him to confirm or deny his allegations under oath, he does not do so.

title: Rhodes and Osborne, GHI
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
consequences_of_breach: War with Philip and the ultimate destruction of Olynthus
statement:
[That they would be an ally in accordance with what has been agreed]
 συμμαχήσω κατ̣[ὰ τὰ ὡμολογημένα.]
remarks:
Philip II of Macedon and the Chalcidians (i.e. the cities of Chalcidice) consulted the oracle at Delphi before making this alliance. As a result of consulting Apollo, a copy of the alliance was set up at Delphi as well as at Olynthus and Dium.  
The alliance is said to have included a special clause stipulating that neither party could negotiate a separate alliance with Athens.  
For further details of the alliance see Diod. 16.8; Demosthenes. 23.207-8; 2.7, 14; 6.20; Libanius, Comment on Demosthenes 1.  
When the Chalcidians opened negotiations with Athens, they violated the terms of this agreement and their oaths. Hammond, Philip of Macedon, pp77-8,  argues that Philip used the violation of this oath as the pretext for the destruction of Olynthus. He writes, "In 348 Philip and his Macedonians felt that they were justified in the sight of Apollo and of Zeus, Earth, Sun and Poseidon in destroying Olynthus for its act of perjury". 
The text indicates that both parties should swear "without guile and without craft".  
For the corresponding oath of Philip and the Macedonians see oath id 720. 
For the oath sworn by the Chalcidian envoys to Philip, see oath id 3864.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes complains that Aeschines has reached such a pitch of shamelessness that he is saying not just that Demosthenes is responsible for the peace, but that he also prevented the Athenians from making peace together with a common council of the Greeks. 
Demosthenes goes on to defend himself, arguing that if he had intrigued with Philip to prevent the Greeks from coming together the Athenians themselves would have stopped him, and that the Athenians cannot have been summoning the Greeks to war at the same time as they were sending ambassadors to Philip to treat for peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Thucydides observes that both parties abstained from invading each other's territory for six years and ten months until the treaty was broken
statement:
[? That they would justly, zealously and guilelessly abide by the following terms of the alliance:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies, and neither could make peace with an enemy without the other
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Athenians were to assist the Spartans in the event of an uprising of the slave population
4. The same people who swore to the treaty should swear the oaths, and that the should be renewed each year – with the Spartans going to Athens at the Dionysia and the Athenians going to Sparta at the Hyacinthia.
5. Each party was to erect a stele to announce the agreement (the Athenians on the Acropolis and the Spartans at Amyclae)
6. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
 ταῦτα δ’ εἶναι δικαίως καὶ προθύμως καὶ ἀδόλως
remarks:
Thucydides describes here the fifty year alliance between Athens and Sparta. 
The same 34 statesmen who represented both states for the oath-swearing for the Peace of Nicias also swore the oath for the alliance. 
See also oath id 1690 and 1710.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
impact: Encourages Dolon to spy on the Achaeans for Hector
statement:
[That no other man of the Trojans will mount the horses, but that Dolon will be glorified thoroughly] 
 ἀλλ’ ἄγε μοι τὸ σκῆπτρον ἀνάσχεο, καί μοι ὄμοσσον 
ἦ μὲν τοὺς ἵππους τε καὶ ἅρματα ποικίλα χαλκῷ 
δωσέμεν, οἳ φορέουσιν ἀμύμονα Πηλεΐωνα, 
σοὶ δ’ ἐγὼ οὐχ ἅλιος σκοπὸς ἔσσομαι οὐδ’ ἀπὸ δόξης·
τόφρα γὰρ ἐς στρατὸν εἶμι διαμπερὲς ὄφρ’ ἂν ἵκωμαι  
νῆ’ ̓Αγαμεμνονέην, ὅθι που μέλλουσιν ἄριστοι
βουλὰς βουλεύειν ἢ φευγέμεν ἠὲ μάχεσθαι.
  ῝Ως φάθ’, ὃ δ’ ἐν χερσὶ σκῆπτρον λάβε καί οἱ ὄμοσσεν· 
ἴστω νῦν Ζεὺς αὐτὸς ἐρίγδουπος πόσις ῞Ηρης
μὴ μὲν τοῖς ἵπποισιν ἀνὴρ ἐποχήσεται ἄλλος
Τρώων, ἀλλά σέ φημι διαμπερὲς ἀγλαϊεῖσθαι. 
  ῝Ως φάτο καί ῥ’ ἐπίορκον ἐπώμοσε, τὸν δ’ ὀρόθυνεν·
remarks: Dolon effectively challenges Hector to swear to the promise he has made at 305-312, and to formalise it by raising his sceptre (oath ids 312 and 345). Some have interpreted this as a false oath, based on epiorkos, but this term does not necessarily imply intentional false swearing; the poet may merely be drawing attention to the fact that the oath proved impossible of fulfilment because (i) Achilles' horses never were captured and (ii) Dolon was dead before battle resumed in the morning - and drawing attention also, perhaps, to Hector's overconfidence (see Hainsworth ad loc.).

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: The text indicates that the general Phaedrus sent a message to Athens and envoys from Mytilene travelled to Athens to agree that "the friendship and alliance, the one that was mutually agreed," should continue to exist between Athens and Mytilene.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Pyrrhus
statement:
[That Nicodemus would have summoned all his relations as witnesses if his claim was true]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὡς ἔγωγε ᾤμην, εἴ γε ἦν ἀληθὲς τὸ πρᾶγμα.

author: Cratinus
title: Ploutoi
statement: unknown
remarks: This is an informal oath invoking Zeus. Unfortunately, this passage is too fragmentary to reconstruct further details.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he will not get away with all the talents he's stolen from the Athenian state]
 Οὔτοι μὰ τὴν Δήμητρα καταπροίξει τάλαντα πολλὰ 
  κλέψας Ἀθηναίων.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
statement:
[That they must not expect him to act in a manner which he considers unjust or unholy, especially when he is accused of impiety by Meletus]
 μὴ οὖν ἀξιοῦτέ με, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, τοιαῦτα δεῖν πρὸς ὑμᾶς πράττειν ἃ μήτε ἡγοῦμαι καλὰ εἶναι μήτε δίκαια μήτε ὅσια, ἄλλως τε μέντοι νὴ Δία πάντως καὶ ἀσεβείας φεύγοντα ὑπὸ Μελήτου τουτουΐ.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
impact: Provokes Trygaeus into finally revealing his name
statement:
[That Trygaeus will most certainly die if he doesn't tell Hermes what his name is]
 Οὔτοι μὰ τὴν Γῆν ἔσθ’ ὅπως οὐκ ἀποθανεῖ,
  εἰ μὴ κατερεῖς μοι τοὔνομ’ ὅ τι ποτ’ ἐστί σοι.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
After the oaths of reconciliation were exchanged, Thrasybulus addressed the men from the city (in the ecclesia?) and said, "it is not the case that I expect you to violate any of the oaths you have sworn. Instead, I expect you to demonstrate that you are respectful of oaths and pious in addition to your other good qualities". 
For other references to the oaths of reconciliation see also oath id 1796.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Hypereides asks whether, if anyone in 339 had promised in advance that he would persuade the Thebans to go to war with Philip and be allies of Athens, there would have been anyone who would not have praised him and thought him worthy of the greatest honours.
See also oath id 2670.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that Demosthenes and Eurymedon sailed along the coast to Thurii, and found that those hostile to Athens had recently been expelled as a result of civil strife; and, wishing to persuade the Thurians to join their expedition with the greatest possible enthusiasm and have the same friends and enemies as the Athenians, they stayed for a time in Thurii and worked towards this goal.  
The Thurians agreed to send 700 hoplites and 300 light-armed (7.35.1).  See also oath id 1836.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he thinks Blepsidemus is not in his right mind]
 Οὔ τοι μὰ τὴν Δήμητρ’ ὑγιαίνειν μοι δοκεῖς.
remarks: Cf. the similar statement at oath id 872.

author: Xenophon
title: Apology
statement:
[That the people elect others as generals, those whom they consider to have the best military brain, even in preference to themselves  ]
 οὐ γὰρ δὴ καὶ στρατηγοὺς αἱρεῖσθε καὶ πρὸ πατέρων καὶ πρὸ ἀδελφῶν καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία γε ὑμεῖς πρὸ ὑμῶν αὐτῶν;

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
According to de Ste Croix, the Origins of the Peloponnesian War, p106, based on Xenophon, Hellenica 2.2.20, 5.3.26, the members of the so-called Peloponnesian League swore "to have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and to follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead". 
In this passage the Corinthian envoy to Sparta warns the Spartans that spondai are not broken by those who join others when they have been left unsupported, but by those who fail to support those they have sworn to help i.e. the Corinthians will be forced to abandon the treaty because the Spartans are not supporting them. 
The Corinthian envoy goes on to say that if the Spartans mean to be zealous allies they will remain as allies, for if the Spartans fulfill their obligations it would be impious for the Corinthians to change their friends. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1521, 1590, 1592, 1593, 1594, 1595, 1596, 1657, 1694, 1707, 1734, 2009, 2010, 2014, 2018, 2024, 2033, 2034, 2039, 2040.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This entry, relating to an alliance between Athens and Thessaly, takes into account textual changes in SEG 45.51.  
The polemarchs are indicated by geographical location (Pelasgiotis, Phthitiotic Thebes, Megalos, Hestiotis, Eiron). The pezarchoi are mentioned by name: Philip, Polymides, Thibron, Cotimilas, Theodorus, Pame[.]os, Dra[...]s, Philolaus and Hippocrates.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will dye a gown with saffron]
 Κροκωτὸν ἄρα νὴ τὼ θεὼ ’γὼ βάψομαι.
remarks: Swearing by Demeter and Persephone is exclusively a woman's oath. See remarks on oath id 788.

author: Euripides
title: Phoenissae
statement:
[That he is acting justly and yet has been depived of his fatherland unjustly and most impiously]
 μάρτυρας δὲ τῶνδε δαίμονας καλῶ
  ὡς πάντα πράσσων σὺν δίκηι δίκης ἄτερ
  ἀποστεροῦμαι πατρίδος ἀνοσιώτατα.
remarks: Cf. oath id 173.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: Shows the strength of Gadatas' own feelings
statement:
[That Hystaspas had not influenced him to beg Cyrus to stay]
 καὶ ὁ Γαδάτας ἀνατείνας τὰς χεῖρας πρὸς τὸν οὐρανὸν ἀπώμοσεν ἦ μὴν μὴ ὑπὸ τοῦ Ὑστάσπου πεισθεὶς ταῦτα γιγνώσκειν·

author: Aristotle
title: Politeia 119 (Naxos)
if_refused: Her gift would not be secured
impact: The citizens are given back their land
statement:
[That she would come to him if she was given one gift]
 ὁ δ’ Ἀριστοτέλης (cf. Parthen. erot. 9) φησὶν οὐδ’ ἁλούσης τῆς Πολυκρίτης, ἄλλως δέ πως ἰδόντα τὸν Διόγνητον ἐρασθῆναι καὶ πάντα διδόναι καὶ ποιεῖν ἕτοιμον εἶναι· τὴν δὲ ὁμολογεῖν ἀφίξεσθαι πρὸς αὐτὸν ἑνὸς μόνου τυχοῦσαν, περὶ οὗ τὸν Διόγνητον, ὥς φησιν ὁ φιλόσοφος, ὅρκον ᾔτησεν. ἐπεὶ δ’ ὤμοσεν, ἠξίου τὸ Δήλιον αὐτῇ δοθῆναι, Δήλιον γὰρ ἐκαλεῖτο τὸ χωρίον, ἄλλως δ’ οὐκ ἂν ἔφη συνελθεῖν. ὁ δὲ καὶ διὰ τὴν ἐπιθυμίαν καὶ διὰ τὸν ὅρκον ἐξέστη καὶ παρέδωκε τῇ Πολυκρίτῃ τὸν τόπον, ἐκείνη δὲ τοῖς πολίταις.ἐκ δὲ τούτου πάλιν εἰς ἴσον καταστάντες ἐφ’ οἷς ἠβούλοντο πρὸς τοὺς Μιλησίους διελύθησαν
remarks: During a war between Naxos and Miletus (with Erythrae as their ally), the Erythraean commander Diognetus fell in love with a certain Polycrite who had been captured. She agreed to come to him only if she was given one gift. He demanded that she swear as much. She did and asked for Delion as a gift (the name of the area), and then gave it to the citizens.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the Athenians that if they levy the military force he is proposing and are vigilant over their expenditure, they will either compel Philip to keep the peace fairly and to remain within his own frontiers, or they will fight him on equal terms. See also Oath id 3276. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides states that in 414/3 the Spartans were now confident because they believed that the Athenians would be more easily overthrown because they were fighting a war on two fronts, and because they regarded the Athenians as being the first to break the treaty i.e. the Peace of Nicias. 
The Spartans considered the Athenians to have broken the treaty because they had ravaged parts of Epidaurus and Prasiae, were making raids out of Pylos and were refusing Spartan requests for arbitration. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Isocrates
title: For Demonicus
statement: n/a
remarks:
Isocrates urges Demonicus, the son of his Cypriot friend Hipponicus, to accept an imposed oath for two reasons: either to clear himself of disgraceful charges, or to save his friends from great danger. 
This strongly implies, though it does not explicitly state, that one should never accept a demand for an oath for any other reason, nor volunteer an oath for any reason at all.  Isocrates' own practice may well have conformed with his injunction.  In his surviving works he never once swears in his own name, even informally, or makes any reference to any oath he has taken previously; nor, we learn, did he ever initiate a lawsuit (cf. [Plutarch], Lives of the Ten Orators 839c), which would of course have required him to swear an antomosia.  Twice he was sued himself (with only money at issue - they were antidosis suits about liturgies), but on one of these occasions he was ill and his son acted for him (and presumably swore any necessary oaths) while on the other occasion he lost the case and may for all we know have let it go by default.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Macartatus
statement: n/a
remarks: Sositheus states that Phylomache won the right to inherit Hagnias' estate, not by wrongful trickery or conspiracy, but in the most just manner possible.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker begins by stating that it is right for the Athenians to agree with those who insist that they should abide by their oaths and agreements, provided they do so from conviction. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This alliance must have been concluded immediately after Cyrus conquered Lydia, since Herodotus maintains that Cyrus made a sworn agreement with Miletus on the same terms as the Milesians had with the Lydians. 
Herodotus refers to this alliance three times to explain why the Milesians did not fight against the Persians.  
For the other references see oath id 1280 and 1282.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That when Homer wrote the lines "[Odysseus] struck his chest and scolded his heart with the following words: Endure, my heart; you have endured worse before this" (Odyssey 20.17-18), Homer must have thought of the soul as a quasi-divine entity capable of influencing and controlling physical feelings, and not as a kind of attunement]
 ἆρ’ οἴει αὐτὸν ταῦτα ποιῆσαι διανοούμενον ὡς ἁρμονίας αὐτῆς οὔσης καὶ οἵας ἄγεσθαι ὑπὸ τῶν τοῦ σώματος παθημάτων, ἀλλ’ οὐχ οἵας ἄγειν τε ταῦτα καὶ δεσπόζειν, καὶ οὔσης αὐτῆς πολὺ θειοτέρου τινὸς πράγματος ἢ καθ’ἁρμονίαν; Νὴ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔμοιγε δοκεῖ.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes has the clerk read Philocrates' decree to the jurors, and draws their attention to the words "the peace and alliance are to be granted also to his descendants" and "Philip is to be praised because he offers to do what is right". He complains that Philip isn't offering anything, and is saying that he doesn't know what favour he can offer them. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had not killed]
remarks:
The defendant states that the witnesses are testifying that he is telling the truth, and that the prosecution is arguing that their evidence is untrustworthy. Antiphon argues that if the witnesses were testifying against him, the prosecution would be treating them as supremely important and calling their evidence conclusive proof. 
Antiphon goes on to say that if he were producing witnesses when there had been none, or producing false witnesses, there would be grounds for treating his witnesses as unreliable. However, he states that the prosecution admit that his witnesses were present. 
See oath id 2481.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That masters who prevent the best and enforce the worst are the worst possible kind of masters]
 Ποίους δέ τινας δεσπότας ἡγῇ τοὺς τὰ μὲν ἄριστα κωλύοντας, τὰ δὲ κάκιστα ἀναγκάζοντας; Ὡς δυνατὸν νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, κακίστους.
remarks: The "masters" are the pleasures of the body, which enslave those who are lacking in self-control (see oath id 2156).

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That if Tissaphernes fulfilled his oath, Agesilaus would observe the truce]
 ἦ μὴν ταῦτα πράττοντος αὐτοῦ ἐμπεδώσειν τὰς σπονδάς
remarks:
At Ephesus, Tissaphernes sent to Agesilaus and asked him with what intent he had come to Asia Minor. Agesilaus answered, "that the cities in Asia shall be independent, as are those in our part of Greece." Tissaphernes replied, "then if you are willing to make a truce until I can send to the King, I think you could accomplish this object and, if you should so desire, sail back home."  
Agesilaus responded, "indeed I should so desire, if I could but think that I was not being deceived by you."  
Tissaphernes reponded to this, "but it is possible for you to receive a guarantee on this point, that in very truth and guilelessly, if you follow this course, we will do no harm to any part of your domain during the truce."  
After this agreement had been reached, Tissaphernes swore an oath to the representatives who were sent to him (Herippidas, Dercylidas and Megillus), that in very truth and  guilelessly he would negotiate the peace (see oath id 1916), and they swore in turn on behalf of Agesilaus to Tissaphernes that in very truth, if he did this, Agesilaus would steadfastly observe the truce.  
Xenophon observes that Tissaphernes straightway violated the oaths which he had sworn; for instead of keeping peace he sent to the King for a large army in addition to that which he had before. But Agesilaus, though he was aware of this, nevertheless continued to abide by the truce.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That the man who is unable to define and distinguish the good will live his life on earth dreaming and dozing, and will arrive at the house of Hades and fall asleep forever, before he ever wakens on earth]
 Οὐκοῦν καὶ περὶ τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ ὡσαύτως· ὃς ἂν μὴ ἔχῃ διορίσασθαι τῷ λόγῳ ἀπὸ τῶν ἄλλων πάντων ἀφελὼν τὴν  τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ ἰδέαν, καὶ ὥσπερ ἐν μάχῃ διὰ πάντων ἐλέγχων διεξιών, μὴ κατὰ δόξαν ἀλλὰ κατ’ οὐσίαν προθυμούμενος ἐλέγχειν, ἐν πᾶσι τούτοις ἀπτῶτι τῷ λόγῳ διαπορεύηται, οὔτε αὐτὸ τὸ ἀγαθὸν φήσεις εἰδέναι τὸν οὕτως ἔχοντα οὔτε ἄλλο ἀγαθὸν οὐδέν, ἀλλ’ εἴ πῃ εἰδώλου τινὸς ἐφάπτεται, δόξῃ, οὐκ ἐπιστήμῃ ἐφάπτεσθαι, καὶ τὸν νῦν βίον ὀνειροπολοῦντα καὶ ὑπνώττοντα, πρὶν ἐνθάδ’ ἐξεγρέσθαι, εἰς Ἅιδου πρότερον ἀφικόμενον τελέως ἐπικαταδαρθεῖν; Νὴ τὸν Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, σφόδρα γε πάντα ταῦτα φήσω.
remarks: Of course he won’t “fall asleep forever” – not if you believe what Plato says elsewhere, including at the end of the Republic itself – but Plato has got carried away by his rhetoric! In Platonic thought, the life of an ordinary man was something between sleep and waking.

title: Syll (3)
statement:
[That they would find anyone occupying public land according to the decree and they shall impose a fine according to the value, rightly and justly, according to their own opinion]
 τοὺς δὲ αἱρεθ[έ]ντας ὀμόσαι τὴν Ἄρτεμιν, ἀνευρήσειν εἴ τίς [τι] τῶν δημοσίων χωρίων ἔχει κατὰ τ’ ψήφισμα, καὶ τιμήσειν τῆς ἀξίης ὀρθῶς καὶ δικαίως κ[α]τὰ γνώμην τὴν ἑαυτοῦ.
remarks: This decree was probably set up not long after Alexander the Great passed through the area. Nine citizens were elected to act as inspectors to find out whether any public land had been occupied illegally and to impose fines.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That the medicine chest is not made of stone]
  Λίθινον;
 {ΚΑ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’, οὐχὶ τό γε κιβώτιον.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
impact: Emphasises the irony of the Syracusan's previous statements
statement:
[That the Syracusan is lucky indeed to have such a skin as to be unique in not corrupting those he sleeps with]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, εὐτύχημά γέ σου μέγα τὸ τὸν χρῶτα τοιοῦτον φῦναι ἔχοντα ὥστε μόνον μὴ διαφθείρειν τοὺς συγκαθεύδοντας.
remarks: This is Socrates' response to the Syracusan's statements at oath id 2266 and 2267. Swearing by Hera is typical of Socrates, cf. oath id 1870 and cross references there. Note also oath id 2259 where Callias, who is from the same deme as Socrates, uses the same unusual oath formula.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Diondas
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Hypereides imagines the charges that might have been brought against him and Demosthenes if they had been arrested and put on trial before Philip; one of them is "that we destroyed his existing alliance with the Thebans".
See also oath id 3826.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That Socrates has made him laugh although he was not at all in the mood for it]
 Καὶ ὁ Σιμμίας γελάσας, Νὴ τὸν Δία, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐ πάνυ γέ με νυνδὴ γελασείοντα ἐποίησας γελάσαι.
remarks: What makes Simmias laugh is the fact that what Socrates has said about the true philosopher spending his life preparing for death surprisingly agrees with the plain man’s view of philosophers – which is that they talk and act as though they’d rather be dead than alive!

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he will never want to live if he doesn't eat the Sausage-seller up and rid the land of him]
 Οὔτοι μὰ τὴν Δήμητρ’ ἔτ’ εἰ μή σ’ ἐκφάγω 
  ἐκ τῆσδε τῆς γῆς, οὐδέποτε βιώσομαι.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Menecles
swearer: The speaker and his party; Menecles' brother and his party
swearee: The speaker and his party; Menecles' brother and his party
statement:
[That in future they would behave properly towards one another, both in words and deeds, as far as lay in their power]
 εὖ ποιήσειν ἀλλήλους ἐκ τοῦ ἐπιλοίπου χρόνου, κατὰ δύναμιν εἶναι, καὶ λόγῳ καὶ ἔργῳ.
remarks:
The speaker states that after the arbitrators decided that both parties should swear to behave properly to one another they did so. 
He goes on to say that he will produce the arbitrators or the witnesses to testify that the oath happened, and that his opponents are in possession of the property that was awarded to them, and that their notion of behaving well towards him and his party is to try to make Menecles childless, and drive himself away with insults. He adds that the arbitrators might not wish to testify because they are the friends of his opponents. 
See also oath id 3027.

author: Timocles
title: Marathonioi
statement:
[That it is sweeter to sleep with a maiden than with a prostitute]  
 ὅσον τὸ μεταξὺ μετὰ κορίσκης ἢ μετὰ
χαμαιτύπης τὴν νύκτα κοιμᾶσθαι, βαβαί. 
ἡ στιφρότης, τὸ χρῶμα, πνεῦμα, δαίμονες,
τὸ μὴ σφόδρ’ εἶναι πάνθ’ ἕτοιμα, δεῖν δέ τι 
ἀγωνιᾶσαι καὶ ῥαπισθῆναί τε καὶ 
πληγὰς λαβεῖν ἁπαλαῖσι χερσίν. {Β.} ἡδύ γε
νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν μέγιστον.
remarks: The swearer is almost certainly a young male.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That it would be a shame for Androtion, Glaucetes and Melanopus to be sent to prison]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δί’ αἰσχρὸν ἴσως ἦν Ἀνδροτίωνα δεθῆναι ἢ Γλαυκέτην ἢ Μελάνωπον.
remarks: Diodorus imagines that someone might object in this way. He answers this imaginary oath with one of his own (see oath id 3474).

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Ciron
statement:
[That he could not possibly give stronger proofs than he has given]
 Ἔγωγε μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς τοὺς Ὀλυμπίους οὐκ ἂν ἔχοιμι πίστεις μείζους τούτων εἰπεῖν,

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would abide by the alliance and arrangement with the Eretrian demos and the allies, justly and guilelessly; and if someone went against the land of the Eretrians or overthrew the Eretrian demos, they would help with all their strength as they were able]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Eretria. 
For the corresponding oath of the Eretrians see oath id 469.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus reminds the jurors that the laws forbid the introduction of a law that does not apply equally to every citizen, and that they have sworn to judge in accordance with the laws. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Euripides
title: Helena
statement: [That he will end his life if he is deprived of Helen]
remarks: Same oath as id 162.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she does think she could throttle a bull]
  Κἂν ταῦρον ἄγχοις. 
{ΛΑΜΠΙΤΩ}  Μάλα γ’, οἰῶ, ναὶ τὼ σιώ·
remarks: The twin gods are Castor and Pollux, the Dioscuri, who are special patrons of Sparta; cf. oath id 1216 with cross references for other invocations of the Dioscuri in this play.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: Odysseus feels able to leave in safety
statement:
[That she is not planning another painful trial for Odysseus]
 οὐδ’ ἂν ἐγώ γ’ ἀέκητι σέθεν σχεδίης ἐπιβαίην, εἰ μή μοι τλαίης γε, θεά, μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμόσσαι
μή τί μοι αὐτῷ πῆμα κακὸν βουλευσέμεν ἄλλο.”
  ὣς φάτο, μείδησεν δὲ Καλυψώ, δῖα θεάων,  
χειρί τέ μιν κατέρεξεν ἔπος τ’ ἔφατ’ ἔκ τ’ ὀνόμαζεν· 
  “ἦ δὴ ἀλιτρός γ’ ἐσσὶ καὶ οὐκ ἀποφώλια εἰδώς, 
οἷον δὴ τὸν μῦθον ἐπεφράσθης ἀγορεῦσαι.
ἴστω νῦν τόδε γαῖα καὶ οὐρανὸς εὐρὺς ὕπερθε 
καὶ τὸ κατειβόμενον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, ὅς τε μέγιστος  
ὅρκος δεινότατός τε πέλει μακάρεσσι θεοῖσι,
μή τί τοι αὐτῷ πῆμα κακὸν βουλευσέμεν ἄλλο.
gods_invoked: Gaia; OuranosEpithet(s)wide; Dripping water of the Styx
remarks: It is noteworthy that Calyspso has already promised to send Odysseus on his way with good will at 5.160-170, but Odysseus feels the need to request an oath nonetheless.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
if_refused: They would not be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
Herodotus refers to "the Greeks who swore against the Persians" (oἱ δὲ συνωμόται Ἑλλήνων ἐπὶ τῷ Πέρσῃ). 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1519, 1552, 1599, 1600, 1627, 1628, 1643, 1645, 1777. 
For a later oath to tithe the Greeks who surrendered to the Persians without having been compelled to do so see oath id 1500. 
See also the oath id 338 for the oath sworn prior to the battle of Plataea.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
impact: Emphasises how convincing the performance was
statement:
[That they would marry]
 οἱ μὲν ἄγαμοι γαμεῖν ἐπώμνυσαν
remarks: The men apprently swore to marry after seeing the love-scene between Ariadne and Dionysus; cf. oath ids 2285 and 2286.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That there was a lot of talk among those sitting in the barbers' shops that Chremylus had suddenly become wealthy]
 Καίτοι λόγος γ’ ἦν νὴ τὸν Ἡρακλέα πολὺς 
  ἐπὶ τοῖσι κουρείοισι τῶν καθημένων,
  ὡς ἐξαπίνης ἁνὴρ γεγένηται πλούσιος.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That there are times when Socrates greatly pities Critobulus (because he seems very poor to Socrates)]
 καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δί’ ἔστιν ὅτε καὶ πάνυ οἰκτίρω σε ἐγώ
remarks: Although Critobulus’ property is at least 100 times greater than that of Socrates, he is still the poorer man of the two because his property is insufficient to support his chosen lifestyle.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Stephanus 2
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Apollodorus asks the jurors to consider whether they have sworn to vote according to the laws of the state or the laws Phormion has enacted for himself. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
The Theban envoy again accuses the Plataeans of having betrayed the Greeks with whom they had sworn oaths against the Persians. 
The Theban envoy blurs the distinction between the oaths sworn against the Persians and the oaths sworn after the battle of Plataea (see oath id 1598), suggesting that the Plataeans are arguing that the oath sworn against the Persians should protect them now - which they are not. See also oath id 1501.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he doesn't know what they should say]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔγωγε οὐκ ἔχω τί χρὴ λέγειν.
remarks: Socrates has just presented Theaetetus with a list of possible objections to their conclusions on knowledge and ignorance.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Thucydides states, that after one of those accused of the mutilation of the Hermae [Andocides] confessed and denounced others, the agitation against Alcibiades by his political enemies over the profanations of the Mysteries, in which he was implicated, was stepped up, and the Athenians grew more and more convinced that both these acts of impiety had been part of one great conspiracy against the demos, with Alcibiades at its centre - even though Andocides had not mentioned Alcibiades in his denunciation. 
See also oath id 1771.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that if anyone objects that the peace should be maintained so long as Philip does not attack Attica or the Piraeus their argument is impious, intolerable and dangerous to Athens. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of King Croesus ca.560-546 (560 to 546)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Herodotus indicates that when Croesus was at war with Cyrus of Persia, he marched away to Sardis, intending to ask for help from the Egyptians "in accordance with the sworn agreement" (κατὰ τὸ ὅρκιον ). Herodotus goes on to add that Croesus had made an alliance with Amasis the king of Egypt before making an alliance with the Spartans.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That the outcome of the vote had been wrongly judged]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the assembly voted in favour of the resolution of Euryptolemus to try the generals separately, but a second vote was taken when Menecles lodged an objection under oath (a hypomosia). The Athenians then voted in favour of the proposal of the boule to try the generals together. 
When the assembly voted by show of hands, its presiding officers estimated which side had the majority and announced their decision to the meeting. If any citizen asserted on oath that the outcome had been wrongly judged, the vote was taken again.  
See M.H. Hansen, The Athenian Ecclesia (Copenhagen 1983), pp103-121 and oath id 1248.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he is acquainted not only with the numbers and battle-order of the enemy [as Cyrus had just said], but also with their tactical plans]
 Σὺ μὲν ἄρα, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, οὐ τὸ πλῆθος μόνον οἶσθα, ἀλλὰ καὶ τὴν τάξιν αὐτῶν. Ἐγὼ μὲν ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἀράσπας

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it has never occurred to him to consider how the gods have taken care to equip mankind with what he needs]
 Εἰπέ μοι, ἔφη, ὦ Εὐθύδημε, ἤδη ποτέ σοι ἐπῆλθεν ἐνθυμηθῆναι ὡς ἐπιμελῶς οἱ θεοὶ ὧν οἱ ἄνθρωποι δέονται κατεσκευάκασι; καὶ ὅς, Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἔμοιγε.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: Unity among Persians and fairness in Persian rule would be assured
if_refused: Unity among Persians and fairness in Persian rule would not be assured
impact: Unity among the Persians is formalised
statement: [That if anyone attempts to put a stop to Cyrus' rule or if any of his subjects revolt, they will come to assist both each other and Cyrus  in whatsoever he might call upon them to do]
remarks: Here, Xenophon explains how Cyrus and the Persians accepted the proposals of Cambyses for swearing a pact (see oath ids 2500 and 2501) and states that that the Persians and their king continue to act in accordance with this agreement.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes states that the peace was concluded on the 19th of Elaphebolion, and the ambassadors were away to administer the oaths for a full three months. He argues that throughout this time the Phocians were safe. 
He then states that the ambassadors returned on the 13th of Skirophorion, and that by then Philip was at Thermopylae making promises to the Phocians, but they had no confidence in those promises. 
According to Demosthenes' chronology, the Phocians then sent envoys to Athens, but on the 16th of Skirophorion, Aeschines ruined everything by telling lies and raising false expectations. On the 20th of Skirophorion, the Phocians heard the decision of the Athenians. He goes on to describe how the Phocians made a truce with Philip after these events took place from the 21st to the 23rd of Skirophorion (see oath id 2624), and on the 27th of the month the Athenians heard that Philip had put the Phocians' fate in the hands of the Thebans, some four days after the Phocians made the truce because of what Aeschines reported. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: On the property of Aristophanes
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement:
[That he could not loan Demus the required money because he had already been forced to borrow from elsewhere for the mercenaries he had funded]
 ἀλλ’ ὤμνυε καὶ προσδεδανεῖσθαι τοῖς ξένοις ἄλλοθεν,
remarks: The speaker states that he and Demus son of Pyrilampes went to see Aristophanes regarding a loan. Demus said that he had a gold cup as a pledge from the Great King, and that he would give it to Aristophanes as security for a loan of sixteen minas so that he would be able to pay for the trierarchy. He explained that Aristophanes would be in a position to redeem it for twenty minas when he arrived at Cyprus. Aristophanes listened to Demus' proposal, but swore that he could not provide the money because he had had to borrow money himself to pay for mercenaries.

title: IG XII 3
statement:
[That he inscribed this, and he danced] 
Ἐνπεδοκλῆς ἐνεϞόπτετο τάδε Ϟὠρκ<h>ε<ῖ>το μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλ<λ>ω.
remarks:
This text is an example of pederastic graffiti on stones that were later used in the gymnasium at Thera. 
The first line reads: "Pheidippides fucked. Timagoras and Empheres and me - we got fucked too" (Πhειδιπίδας ὦιπhε. Τιμαγόρας καὶ Ἐνπhέρες καὶ ἐγὄιπh[ομες]). 
A certain Empylos then wrote "Empylos [did?] this [too]" (Ἔνπυλος τάδε). 
This line was not completed, and someone else wrote "faggot" (πόρνος). 
Lastly, perhaps the in line one, Empedocles writes, "Empedocles wrote this. And he danced, by Apollo!" (Ἐνπεδοκλῆς ἐνεϞόπτετο τάδε Ϟὠρκ<h>ε<ῖ>το μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλ<λ>). 
It seems that the verb ὀρχέομαι means more than "dance" in this context. The verb certainly can have a sexual meaning; cf. Euripides, Cyclops 171 (which, if understood literally, would be sadly anticlimactic). B.B. Powell," Why was the Greek alphabet invented?", ClAnt 8, (1989), p345, writes, "This youthful pederastic boaster not only writes - he dances too!".

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_taken: Prexaspes will receive all things in great abundance
statement:
[That he would keep the truth about the death of Smerdis to himself and not reveal to any man the treachery done by the Magi to the Persians]
 Τούτων δή μιν εἵνεκεν καλέσαντες φίλον προσεκτῶντο πίστις τε λαβόντες καὶ ὁρκίοισι ἦ μὲν ἕξειν παρ’ ἑωυτῷ μηδ’ ἐξοίσειν μηδενὶ ἀνθρώπων τὴν ἀπὸ σφέων ἀπάτην ἐς Πέρσας γεγονυῖαν
remarks:
According to Herodotus, the Magi were ruling Persia in the name of Smerdis, the brother of Cambyses. Prexaspes had murdered Smerdis on secret orders of Cambyses, and was therefore the only person other than the Magi who knew that he was dead. The Magi hoped to keep Prexaspes silent, but after he swore the oath to keep their treachery secret he betrayed them.  
Prexaspes betrayed the Magi when they asked him to summon the Persians to a meeting before the palace wall and declare that the king was none other than Smerdis the son of Cyrus. Prexaspes climbed a tower and announced to the Persians that he had murdered Smerdis on the orders of Cambyses, but that he had not told the truth earlier because he could not safely tell it. After doing so he invoked a terrible curse on the Persians if they failed to win back their freedom and hurled himself headlong from the tower. Herodotus notes that Prexaspes ended his life honourably.

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Liberty of the Rhodians
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Demosthenes recalls that the Athenians once sent Timotheus to aid Ariobarzanes in his revolt against the Persian King with the clause "provided that he does not violate the treaty with the King" inserted in his instructions. 
He adds that when Timotheus saw that Ariobarzanes was in open revolt he abandoned any thought of assisting him because it would violate the treaty. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aeschylus
title: Dictyoulkoi
statement: [That he will support and protect Danae and not let her come to harm]
remarks: Radt prints the fourth word from the end of 772 (the first of which anything survives) as [.].[..] followed by a dotted sigma; H&N now read it as ORKOS with the first four letters (but not the last) dotted (see Henry, W. B., and Nünlist, René. - Aeschylus, Dictyulci (fr. 47 a Radt) und Isthmiastae (fr. 78 a-d). ZPE 2000 N° 129 : 13-16).  So the speaker is saying that his oath remains (or will remain, if we accent MENEI as a future) permanently valid. The oath is presumably the one for which the speaker "calls the gods to witness" at line 765, apparently (to judge from 767-9) that he will support and protect Danae and not let her come to harm; since the speaker is almost certainly Silenus, it is not surprising that Danae completely ignores this sworn pledge.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
if_broken: May he perish most wretchedly, and his wife and children too, and Archedemus
impact: Xanthias accepts and dons Heracles' gear
statement:
[That he will never take the gear back from Xanthias]
 Ἀλλ’ ἤν σε τοῦ λοιποῦ ποτ’ ἀφέλωμαι χρόνου, 
  πρόρριζος αὐτός, ἡ γυνή, τὰ παιδία, 
  κάκιστ’ ἀπολοίμην, κἀρχέδημος ὁ γλάμων.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad 587, "the apparent reinforcement of the oath [by including Dionysus' family in the scope of the curse] is illusory, since myth knows of no marriage for Dionysus, and in archaic and classical Greek sources, he usually has no children either".

author: Alexis
title: Theteuontes
statement: n/a
remarks: In this single-line fragment, someone says "the oath is secure if I just nod my head". Arnott ad loc. comments that the "unidentified speaker appears to be parodying, at least indirectly, the words and attitudes of Zeus in Hom. Il. 1.526f."

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Spudias
statement:
[That Spudias will be his strongest witness - but not by the words he utters now in arguing his case]
 οὐ λόγῳ μὰ Δί’ ὥσπερ νῦν ἀντιδικῶν
remarks: The speaker is arguing that Spudias will be a powerful witness against himself, because his actions speak against him far more strongly than any words of his could speak for him.

title: Lindos II
reference: 13, a I, ll 1-2, a II, line 3
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: This inscription records an agreement between Lindos and Lyttus.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That they all very much want to be trained as cavalry]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἔφασαν οἱ  ἄλλοι πάντες, καὶ ἡμᾶς γε.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_taken: They will be part of the conspiracy
if_refused: They will not be part of the conspiracy
statement: [That they will conspire against the people]
remarks: Nicias and Demosthenes are trying to get the sausage-seller to expel Paphlagon (who represents Cleon), when he comes out at 235. Sommerstein comments ad 236: "Cleon and his supporters seem often to have suggested that their political opponents, or men whom they prosecuted, were anti-democratic conspirators…. The term [conspiracy] covers both internal subversion and intrigues which actually or potentially hostile states". This is also mentioned at 452, where the Sausage-seller is deisgnated as one of the conspirators; see oath id 1004; cf. also id 1243.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he would dig a deep hole for a plant in dry soil rather than moist]
 Πότερα οὖν, ἔφη, ἐν τῇ ξηρᾷ ἂν βαθὺν ὀρύττοις βόθρον τῷ φυτῷ ἢ ἐν τῇ ὑγρᾷ; Ἐν τῇ ξηρᾷ νὴ Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ·
remarks: The logic behind this statement is that if one digs a very deep hole in moist soil one finds water where one cannot plant, therefore dry soil is more appropriate.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement:
[That he would rule according to the established nomoi; and that he would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
 βασιλεῖαι τρεῖς βασιλευομέναις πόλεσιν τριτταῖς ὤμοσαν ἀλλήλαις ἑκάτεραι, κατὰ νόμους οὓς ἔθεντο τοῦ τε ἄρχειν καὶ ἄρχεσθαι κοινούς, οἱ μὲν μὴ βιαιοτέραν τὴν ἀρχὴν ποιήσεσθαι προϊόντος τοῦ χρόνου καὶ γένους, οἱ δέ, ταῦτα ἐμπεδούντων τῶν ἀρχόντων, μήτε αὐτοὶ τὰς βασιλείας ποτὲ καταλύσειν μήτ’ ἐπιτρέψειν ἐπιχειροῦσιν ἑτέροις, βοηθήσειν δὲ βασιλῆς τε βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις καὶ δήμοις, καὶ δῆμοι δήμοις καὶ βασιλεῦσιν ἀδικουμένοις.
remarks: The discussion concerns the time in which Temenus was King of Argos, Cresphontes was king of Messene and Procles and Eurysthenes were kings of Sparta, when the area was first divided into the three states of Argos, Sparta and Messene. The people swear a reciprocal oath- see oath id 2681. The kings and people of Sparta and Messene do the same- see oath ids 2678-9 and 2682-3.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: Thucydides states that after Tissaphernes destroyed the fortifications at Teos and withdrew, the Athenian admiral Diomedon sailed up with ten ships and made an agreement with the Teians to receive them.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
