 ἐμμενῶ τῇ ξυμμαχίᾳ κατὰ τὰ ξυγκείμενα δικαίως καὶ ἀβλαβῶς καὶ ἀδόλως, καὶ οὐ παραβήσομαι τέχνῃ οὐδὲ μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ.
remarks:
This inscription records the so-called Argive alliance. See Thucydides 5.47.1-12 for full details.  
The text indicates that each city will swear the oath that is most binding in their land. The Athenians were to swear on behalf of their allies, whereas the Argives, Mantineans, Eleans, and their allies were to swear individually by state. 
It is stipulated that for the renewal of the oath the Athenians will travel to Elis, Mantinea, and Argos, thirty days before the Olympic games, and the Argives, Eleans and Mantineans will travel to Athens ten days before the Great Panathenaea. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the City would receive 500 talents from the two-and-a-half percent tax that Heurippides had devised]
 τὸ δ’ ἔναγχος οὐχ ἅπαντες ἡμεῖς ὤμνυμεν 
  τάλαντ’ ἔσεσθαι πεντακόσια τῇ πόλει 
  τῆς τετταρακοστῆς, ἣν ἐπόρισ’ Εὑριππίδης;
remarks: The whole point of the passage is that it didn't come true. Presumably this is a loose use of OMNUMI like those found in Sophocles, since the speaker - like the Guard in Antigone - can hardly be accusing himself of perjury. Another possibility is that the imperfect tense may indicate that we should understand the verb to mean "were ready to swear". See also oath id 774.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Samian rebels; The most influential Samians; Pissuthnes
swearee: Samian rebels; The most influential Samians; Pissuthnes
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Pissuthnes the satrap of Sardis attacked Samos
statement: [? That they would fight together against the democratic regime imposed by the Athenians]
remarks: Thucydides indicates that after the Athenians imposed a democracy on Samos numerous Samians fled to the mainland and made an alliance with the most influential men in the city and with Pissuthnes the satrap of Sardis.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That it is very likely that some higher power has uttered the words Socrates ascribed to Clinias]
 ἀλλ’, ὦ δαιμόνιε Κρίτων, μή τις τῶν κρειττόνων παρὼν αὐτὰ ἐφθέγξατο; ὅτι γὰρ ἤκουσά γε ταῦτα, εὖ οἶδα. {ΚΡ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες· τῶν κρειττόνων μέντοι τις ἐμοὶ δοκεῖ, καὶ πολύ γε.
remarks: The joke is that Crito is suggesting that Socrates himself is the higher power (not a divinity as Socrates had meant). Cf. oath id 3090.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
if_taken: Odysseus and the suitors will be at peace
if_kept: They will have prosperity and peace in abundance
impact: Peace in Ithaca and the restoration of Odysseus to the kingship
statement:
[That Odysseus will be accepted as king “for ever” (which probably implies accepting Telemachus as his heir) and will not be pursued over the deaths of the suitors, and that they will be friends to each other as formerly] 
 ἐπεὶ δὴ μνηστῆρας ἐτείσατο δῖος Ὀδυσσεύς, 
ὅρκια πιστὰ ταμόντες ὁ μὲν βασιλευέτω αἰεί,
ἡμεῖς δ’ αὖ παίδων τε κασιγνήτων τε φόνοιο 
ἔκλησιν θέωμεν· τοὶ δ’ ἀλλήλους φιλεόντων 
ὡς τὸ πάρος, πλοῦτος δὲ καὶ εἰρήνη ἅλις ἔστω.”
remarks: The oath is proposed here by Zeus, and it is reported as sworn (with Athene, in the guise of Mentor, administering it) at oath id 564. The phrase "cut trustworthy oaths" is unique here in the Odyssey but is common in the Iliad (cf. e.g. oath ids 316, 317, 318) because it is used in oaths between factions.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That the cock agrees that Labes is a thieving sort of man]
 κλέπτον τὸ χρῆμα τἀνδρός. οὐ καὶ σοὶ δοκεῖ, 
  ὦ ’λεκτρυών; νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἐπιμύει γέ τοι.
remarks: The statement is qualified by the additional information that the cock is winking in agreement.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
if_taken: The Nurse will divulge her secret
if_refused: The Nurse will not divulge her secret
impact: Hippolytus is bound against his will and will later be unable to clear his name
statement: [That he will not reveal what he has been told]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 125.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That the boy being trained as a ruler must be given  the knowledge needed for overcoming enemies]
 Τί δέ, τὸ μαθεῖν εἴ τι ἐπιτήδειόν ἐστι μάθημα πρὸς τὸ κρατεῖν τῶν ἀντιπάλων, ποτέρῳ ἂν προσθεῖναι μᾶλλον πρέποι; Πολὺ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, τῷ ἄρχειν παιδευομένῳ·
remarks: Cf. oath id 2052.

author: Demosthenes
title: Olynthiac 2
statement: n/a
remarks: Demosthenes tells his fellow citizens that it is impossible to gain permanent power through injustice, perjury and lies.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
statement:
[That Callippus initiated a suit against Pasion not for debt (but for damages)]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχ ὥσπερ νῦν ἀργυρίου,

author: Isocrates
title: To Philip
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Isocrates argues that the Athenians can be convinced to join Philip against the Persians now that they have come to their senses and made peace. 
See also oath id 2517.

author: Anonymus Epicus
title: Titanomachy
statement: n/a
remarks: This fragment refers to the wise centaur Chiron as the first to instruct humans in oath-taking.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would justly, zealously and guilelessly abide by the following terms of the alliance:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies, and neither could make peace with an enemy without the other
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Athenians were to assist the Spartans in the event of an uprising of the slave population
4. The same people who swore to the treaty should swear the oaths, and that the should be renewed each year – with the Spartans going to Athens at the Dionysia and the Athenians going to Sparta at the Hyacinthia.
5. Each party was to erect a stele to announce the agreement (the Athenians on the Acropolis and the Spartans at Amyclae)
6. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
 ταῦτα δ’ εἶναι δικαίως καὶ προθύμως καὶ ἀδόλως
remarks:
Thucydides refers to the fifty year alliance between Athens and Sparta, and commences describing the events that followed. 
See also oath id 1686.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes accuses Aeschines of feeling no shame about bringing a charge prompted by envy, based on no wrong committed, altering laws and removing parts from them when they should be read whole to a jury that has sworn to vote according to the laws (ὀμωμοκόσιν κατὰ τοὺς νόμους ψηφιεῖσθαι). 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
statement: [That Euxitheus' mother Nicarete was an Athenian]
remarks: Euxitheus points out that the witnesses who testified on his behalf could inherit his property if he was illegitimate or an alien. He asks why they would have chosen to run the risk of a suit for false witness and to perjure themselves for a small payment, rather than to take everything, risk free, and without calling down destruction upon themselves.

author: Lysias
title: On a wound by premeditation
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had not wounded with the intent to kill]
remarks:
The defendant states that there has been no wrong doing, and that this has been made clear by the evidence and testimony from witnesses. 
Presumably these witnesses were called during the lost narrative portion of the speech.  The witnesses are on oath because the trial was held before the Areopagus Council.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Philocles
statement:
[That he is ashamed that the Athenians should need him and his fellow prosecutors to encourage them and goad them on before they proceed to punish the defendant now on trial]
 Ἀλλ’ ἔγωγε νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν σωτῆρα αἰσχύνομαι, εἰ προτραπέντας ὑμᾶς δεῖ καὶ παροξυνθέντας ὑφ’ ἡμῶν ἐπὶ τὴν τοῦ νῦν ⌈εἰσεληλυθ⌉ότος τὴν κρίσιν τιμωρίαν ἐλθεῖν.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he does not want to be drawn to Theodote himself (rather he wants her to come to him)]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ αὐτὸς ἕλκεσθαι πρὸς σὲ βούλομαι, ἀλλὰ σὲ πρὸς ἐμὲ πορεύεσθαι.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that Agesilaus induced the Acarnanians, Aetolians and [Amphilochian] Argives to enter into friendship with the Achaeans (see oath id 2302) and alliance with himself. 
See also oath id 1951.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he wants to know the truth about the gods, if possible] 
 βούλει τὰ θεῖα πράγματ’ εἰδέναι σαφῶς 
  ἅττ’ ἐστὶν ὀρθῶς;
 {Στ.}  νὴ Δί’, εἴπερ ἐστί γε.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the same party at Argos which had brought about the peace treaty with Sparta then brought about the renunciation of the alliance with the Mantineans, Eleans and Athenians. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Lycurgus mentions the 'execution' of the Spartan regent Pausanias as an example of how the Spartans dealt with their traitors, and expresses the hope that this story will encourage the jurors to vote in keeping with their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That Aristogeiton will defend himself by pointing out something his father did]
 ὧν ὁ πατήρ τι πεποίηκε νὴ Δία
remarks: The speaker asks how Aristogeiton will defend himself, and imagines that someone will respond in this way.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Members of the koine of Eikadeus
if_broken: The curse called down by Eikadeus
statement: [? To be a loyal member of the Eikadeis]
remarks:
The text indicates that some members of the koine of Eikadeus have been violating an oath they swore by acting as false witnesses in the dikasterion to the detriment of the koine.  
It is not clear what sort of assocation the koine of Eikadeus was. It may have been a genos, a hetaireia, or a thiasos. 
It is claimed here that their perjury has affected the property of the koine which is used to provide for sacrifices to the gods. The decree praises a certain Polyxenus son of Diodorus for prosecuting these false witnesses, and calls for the election of three men to assist him in the prosecution. The text of lines 2-12 read as follows (ἐπειδή τι[ν]ες ἐναντία τῶι ὅρκωι ὃν ὤμοσαν καὶ τε[ῖ] ἀρᾶι ἣν Εἰκαδεὺς ἐπηράσατο διατελοῦσι πράττοντες καὶ λέγοντες κατὰ Εἰκαδέων ἐπὶ βλάβει τῶν κοινῶν τῶν Εἰκαδέων, ἀφ’ ὧν τὰ ἱερὰ τοῖς θεοῖς θύουσιν Εἰκαδέες καὶ τοῖς δικαζομένοις Εἰκαδεῦσιν συνδικοῦσιν ὑπεναντία τοῖς Εἰκαδεῦσιν καὶ μεμαρτυρήκασιν ἐπὶ τοῦ δικαστηρίου ἐπὶ βλάβει τοῦ κοινοῦ τοῦ Εἰκαδέων ψευδεῖς μαρτυρίας).

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That he was not trying to make Socrates contradict himself]
 νῦν ἐρωτᾷς εἰ ἔχω σε διδάξαι, ὃς οὔ φημι διδαχὴν εἶναι ἀλλ’ ἀνάμνησιν, ἵνα δὴ εὐθὺς φαίνωμαι αὐτὸς ἐμαυτῷ τἀναντία λέγων.  {ΜΕΝ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐ πρὸς τοῦτο βλέψας εἶπον

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[That they would not deport Chalcidians from Chalcis or devastate the polis or deprive any individual of his rights or punish him with exile or imprison him or kill him or take property from anyone unheard in trial without the agreement of the Athenian demos. That they would not put any motion to the vote, without summons to attend trial, against either the state or any private individual. When an embassy arrived they would introduce it to the boule and the demos within ten days when they held the prytany, to the best of their power. This they would guarantee to the Chalcidians if they obeyed the Athenian demos]
 οὐκ ἐχσελο̃ Χαλκιδέας ἐχ Χαλκίδος οὐδὲ τὲν πόλιν ἀνάστατον ποέσο οὐδὲ ἰδιότεν οὐδένα ἀτιμόσο οὐδὲ φυγε̃ι ζεμιόσο οὐδὲ χσuλλέφσομαι οὐδὲ ἀποκτενο̃ οὐδὲ χρέματα ἀφαιρέσομαι ἀκρ̣ίτο οὐδενὸς ἄνευ το̃ δέμο το̃ Ἀθεναίον, οὐδ’ ἐπισφεφιο̃ κατὰ ἀπροσκλέτο οὔτε κατὰ το̃ κοινο̃ οὔτε κατὰ ἰδιότο οὐδὲ ἑνός, καὶ πρεσβείαν ἐλθο̃σαν προςάχσο πρὸς βολὲν καὶ δε̃μον δέκα ἑμερο̃ν hόταν πρυτανεύο κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν. ταῦτα δὲ ἐμπ̣[ε]δόσο Χαλκιδεῦσιν πειθομένοις το̃ι δέ[μ]οι το̃ι Ἀθεναίον.
remarks:
This inscription records the regulations imposed on Chalcis by Athens. 
The text indicates that the oath was to be administered by the embassy arriving from Chalcis, together with the oath-commissioners, and that the names of the Athenians who swore the oath would be inscribed on the stele. The generals were to ensure that everyone swore the oath. 
This oath is described in lines 40ff as being exchanged just as it was with the Eretrians (see oath id 146 and 147).  
For the corresponding oath of the Chalcidians see oath id 150.

author: Epicharmus
title: Pyrra kai Promatheus
statement: unknown
remarks: The passage is too fragmentary to reveal the oath statement.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will strip "it" bare and come straight back]
  Ἀλλὰ νὴ τὴν Φωσφόρον
 ἔγωγ’ ἀποδείρασ’ αὐτίκα μάλ’ ἀνέρχομαι.
remarks: As at oath id 1191, there is an intentional double meaning in the statement. "it" may refer to the flax, which has been mentioned just previously or to sexual stimulation. As Sommerstein remarks ad 739-740: "Greek apoderein… can mean either (i) to remove the skin of an animal or the bark of a plant (properly by beating or flaying) or (ii) to cause the retraction of a man's foreskin by sexual stimulation". For Hecate as the "light-bringing" goddess, see remarks on oath id 1176.

author: Eupolis
title: Baptai
statement:
[That the addressee will be the death of the swearer]
 ἀλλ’ ἐξαπολεῖς με ναὶ μὰ τὴν ἀμυγδαλῆν.
remarks: Swearing by plants is quite common in comic oaths; see further remarks on oath id 1438.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and that they would respect the division of Cotys' former kingdom and not attempt to change the settlement by force, and that the Athenians would receive back their possessions ]
remarks:
Euthycles asks for a letter from Berisades to be read to the jurors, and then comments that the alliance between Athens and the Thracian kings was concluded after fraudulent convention made by Cephisodotus. 
See also oath id 458.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_taken: He will be able to conceal his theft
if_refused: He will be charged with theft
statement: [That he has not stolen]
remarks: This is a reference to the Sausage-seller's habit of lying under oath when he has stolen; see also remarks at oath ids 979 and 1038.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
statement: [? That they would abide by the peace, on condition that Chios, Cos and Rhodes were able to withdraw from the Second Athenian Confederacy, and the independence of Byzantium was recognised]
remarks:
Isocrates argues that the Athenians should not only make peace with the Chians, Rhodians and Byzantines in 355, but also with all men, and not only accept the terms of the peace drawn up by "certain men" (i.e. Eubulus), but also the terms entered into with the King of Persia (i.e. the so-called King's Peace). 
See also oath id 3007, 3009.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians as they left the city]
remarks:
Xenophon states that when Lysander sailed against Byzantium and Calchedon the inhabitants of both cities admitted him and allowed the Athenians to withdraw under a truce. 
See also oath id 1892.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That he agrees with Hiero that praise from the most free is the sweetest]
 Τοῦτο μὲν δὴ ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δία ἔγωγέ σοι, Ἱέρων, πάνυ συγχωρῶ, τοὺς ἐπαίνους παρὰ τῶν ἐλευθερωτάτων ἡδίστους εἶναι
remarks: This oath is Simonides' response to Hiero's question, "What pleasure comes of this praise, do you think, when praise sounds suspiciously like flattery?".

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That if the imaginary fettered prisoners heard an echo when a passer-by made a sound, they would assume the passing shadow cast from the fire onto the wall of the cave to be the speaker]
 ὁπότε τις τῶν παριόντων φθέγξαιτο, οἴει ἂν ἄλλο τι αὐτοὺς ἡγεῖσθαι τὸ φθεγγόμενον ἢ τὴν παριοῦσαν σκιάν; Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’, ἔφη.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_refused: War will continue as it is
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Agamemnon tells Menelaus that he feels he swore to Menelaus's death by swearing the oath at id 318. He also says that the Trojans have trampled on their oaths but that the oath was not fruitless, i.e. that  Zeus will assuredly fulfil the oath's curse by destroying the Trojans and their city (explained at oath id 325).

author: Pindar
title: Olympian 2
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a general reference to the benefits reaped by good men who kept their oaths in contrast to others (presumably oath-breakers) who "endure a pain too terrible to behold" (trans. Race). Pindar himself takes an oath later on in the victory ode (see oath id 1312).

author: Philip of Macedon
title: Letter to the Athenians
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Philip begins by indicating that he is writing because the Athenians have ignored the embassies he sent to ensure that they would abide by their oaths and agreements. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the last of the women to arrive would have to pay three choes of wine and a quart of chickpeas]
 ὡς Γλύκη κατώμοσεν 
  τὴν ὑστάτην ἥκουσαν οἴνου τρεῖς χοᾶς
  ἡμῶν ἀποτείσειν κἀρεβίνθων χοίνικα.
remarks: Sommerstein notes ad loc.: "We are probably meant to assume that Glyce was one of the group who arrived first, with the chorus-leader"; he also comments that we should understand the oath as a threat rather than a promise. It's a somewhat odd oath, because Glyke on her own would not be in a position to fulfil it; she would need to persuade (a majority of) the other women first.  And we may take it as axiomatic that no one would deliberately take on herself a sworn obligation whose assumption brought her no benefit and whose fulfilment she knew to be beyond her power.  So perhaps we are to understand "so far as in her lay" (KATA TO DUNATON vel sim.); i.e. what she swore was that she would do her best to ensure that the last comer was fined. Another possibility is that this is a loose use of OMNUMI like those found in Sophocles (see oath ids 236, 263, 270, 285, 289, 292).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would abide by the truce for four months, during which time they would settle their dispute by arbitration]
remarks:
King Agis made a truce with the Argives for four months, within which time they would fulfil their agreement i.e. to settle their dispute by arbitration and make a treaty for peace. 
Agis was persuaded by Thrasyllus, one of the five generals, and Alciphron the Argive proxenos for Sparta. Thucydides states that these men were acting on their own initiative rather than at the behest of the Argive people. 
Thucydides observes that the allies were angry with Agis and the Argives were angry with those who had made the truce without consulting them. They tried to stone Thrasyllus to death, but he escaped to a nearby sanctuary. 
However, when an Athenian infantry and cavalry force arrived the Argives told them to go away, because they were afraid to break the truce with the Spartans. 
The Athenians protested that it was not right to have made a truce without the consent of the rest of the allies. 
For other references to this truce and its impact see oath id 1743.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That a supperless wife would suit him who has dined well]
 Λέγεις σύ, ἔφη, ὡς καὶ τῷ εὖ δεδειπνηκότι ὥσπερ καὶ ἐγὼ νῦν ἄδειπνος ἂν συναρμόττοι. Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος·
remarks: Cyrus' reasoning is that the stomach of one who has eaten becomes curved outwards, and that of one who has not dined curves inwards. The idea is that they would make an ideal shape between them for embracing, as was already implied by Cyrus' suggestion that a snub-nosed wife would suit Chrysantas because he himself was hook-nosed. Chrysantas retorts:  “Could you say what kind of wife was most suitable for a King who makes bad jokes?”.

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Euxitheus asks the jurors to acquit him, and observes that in making this request he is not forgetting their duty as pious men, or depriving himself of justice for his own safety is bound up with their oath. The last sentence of the speech is a request, not an assertion:  "Be persuaded by whichever of these considerations [justice and your oath] you prefer, and acquit me." 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1a
date: During Critias' friendship with Socrates (440 to 403)
statement:
[That Socrates must avoid his favourite subjects- Justice, Holiness and so on (because Critias thinks them over-used)]
 ὁ δὲ Κριτίας, Ἀλλὰ τῶνδέ τοί σε ἀπέχεσθαι, ἔφη, δεήσει, ὦ Σώκρατες, τῶν σκυτέων καὶ τῶν τεκτόνων καὶ τῶν χαλκέων· καὶ γὰρ οἶμαι αὐτοὺς ἤδη κατατετρῖφθαι διαθρυλουμένους ὑπὸ σοῦ. Οὐκοῦν, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, καὶ τῶν ἑπομένων τούτοις, τοῦ τε δικαίου καὶ τοῦ ὁσίου καὶ τῶν ἄλλων τῶν τοιούτων; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
statement:
[That he has no ambition to incur the hostilty of his audience]
 οὐ γὰρ ἀπεχθάνεσθαι μὰ τὸν Δία καὶ πάντας θεοὺς προαιροῦμαι.

author: Aristophanes
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: unknown
remarks: This single line refers to the dictation of an oath. Cf. Lysistrata id 1164.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds the jurors that they have sworn to vote in accordance with the laws, and the decrees of the demos and the boule of five hundred. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
impact: Emphasises the magnitude of the subject
statement:
[That he doesn't think it an easy thing for him to learn (or for Cratylus explain) a subject of the importance of language all in a moment]
 Τί δέ, ὦ Ἑρμόγενες; δοκεῖ σοι ῥᾴδιον εἶναι οὕτω ταχὺ μαθεῖν τε καὶ διδάξαι ὁτιοῦν πρᾶγμα, μὴ ὅτι τοσοῦτον, ὃ δὴ δοκεῖ ἐν τοῖς [μεγίστοις] μέγιστον εἶναι;  {ΕΡΜ.} Μὰ Δί’, οὐκ ἔμοιγε.

author: Sophocles
title: Antigone
statement: n/a
remarks: The guard remarks that there is nothing that men should abjure on oath, since second thoughts make liars of them. He makes his reasons clearer through reference to his "oath" at 394 (see oath id 263).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
statement:
[That Pasion ought to have demanded the return of the bowls from him]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία,φήσει ἴσως, ἔδει τὸν πατέρα τὸν ἐμὸν ἀπαιτεῖν αὐτὸν τὰς φιάλας.
remarks:
Apollodorus describes what happened in 373/2 when Timotheus' servant Aeschrion was sent to Pasion to acquire bedding, cloaks and bowls when Timotheus was entertaining Alcetas of Epirus and Jason of Pherae. According to Apollodorus, Lycian bowls belonging to a certain Timosthenes were accidentally given to Timotheus, who left Athens without returning the bowls. When Timosthenes demanded the return of his bowls, Pasion persuaded him to accept the value of the bowls (237 drachmas), and recorded Timotheus as owing the money to him.  
Apollodorus suggests that Timotheus will object that Pasion ought to have demanded the return of the bowls from him, and argues that Pasion did not ask for their return because he saw what straits Timotheus was in.

author: Hesiod
title: Catalogue of Women
statement: [That Theseus would be faithful to Ariadne]
remarks: This is a reference attributed to Hesiod naming Aigle as the women because of whom Theseus broke his oaths to Ariadne; according to Plutarch, Theseus 20.1 (= Hesiod fr. 298), Theseus abandoned Ariadne (apparently at sea, not on Naxos) because he had fallen in love with Aigle, who must in that case have been one of the seven Athenian maidens who had been sent as tribute to Minos.  Theseus' objective in swearing fidelity to Ariadne can only have been to secure her assistance against her father and the Minotaur.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That Peisetaerus loves a toilsome life]
  Νὴ Δία ταλαιπώρων γε πραγμάτων ἐρᾷς.
remarks: The scholiast sees this line as ironic.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That physical trainers should not be banished from cities if their pupils use their skill against their kin (since the instruction was imparted for use against enemies and the pupils are the ones who have been guilty of misusing their skill)]
 οὐδέ γε μὰ Δία ἐάν τις εἰς παλαίστραν φοιτήσας εὖ ἔχων τὸ σῶμα καὶ πυκτικὸς γενόμενος, ἔπειτα τὸν πατέρα τύπτῃ καὶ τὴν μητέρα ἢ ἄλλοντινὰ τῶν οἰκείων ἢ τῶν φίλων, οὐ τούτου ἕνεκα δεῖ τοὺς  παιδοτρίβας καὶ τοὺς ἐν τοῖς ὅπλοις διδάσκοντας μάχεσθαι μισεῖν τε καὶ ἐκβάλλειν ἐκ τῶν πόλεων.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Philocleon is not slipping through again some way]
  μῶν ὁ γέρων πῃ διαδύεται αὖ;
 {Ξα.}  μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’
remarks: In fact, Philocleon is trying to lower himself out of the house with a rope (rather than slipping through), as Xanthias subsequently remarks.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Lacritus
statement:
[That he has never made any objection or criticism if anyone wants to be a sophist and pay cash to Isocrates]
 ἐγὼ δέ, μὰ τὸν Δία τὸν ἄνακτα καὶ τοὺς θεοὺς ἅπαντας, οὐδενὶ πώποτε ἐφθόνησα οὐδ’ ἐπετίμησα, ὦ ἄνδρες δικασταί, εἴ τις βούλεται σοφιστὴς εἶναι καὶ Ἰσοκράτει ἀργύριον ἀναλίσκειν·

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Methymnaeans as allies, observing that they were autonomous and contributed ships. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1520, 1562, 1563, 1584, 1588, 1638, 1639, 1828, 1831, 1832 and 1834.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes compares the results of the Peace of Callias (see oath id 3813) to those of the Peace of Philocrates and argues that they need a prosecutor, and to try the men whose crimes are obvious (i.e. Aeschines and Philocrates). 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes betrayed all Boeotia to Thebes by writing a clause in their alliance with Thebes that if any Boeotian polis seceded they were to help the Thebans. 
See also oath id 2670.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that after the battle of Leuctra, Jason of Pherae urged both the Thebans and the Spartans to seek a truce with each other.  The Spartans accordingly asked him to negotiate a truce.  
As soon as the polemarchs learned that the truce had been made they gave orders to the men to dine and pack so they could withdraw that night and cross Mount Cithaeron next morning; in fact, however, "trusting to secrecy more than to the truce", they made the army set off directly after their meal and made the difficult crossing of the mountain during the night.

author: Andocides
title: On the Mysteries
if_taken: They can take office in the boule
remarks:
Andocides cites the oaths of reconciliation (see oath id 2355) as well as the oath of the bouleutai and the Heliastic oath (see oath id 2357) as evidence that the Athenians should not remember past grievances with regard to his own case. 
According to Andocides, each of the bouleutai swore, "I will not allow any denunciation or summary arrest arising out of past events, except in the case of those who fled". 
For other references to the bouleutic oath see also oath id 1775.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he will sue Strepsiades]
 θήσω πρυτανεῖ’, ἢ μηκέτι ζῴην ἐγώ.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement: n/a
remarks: This is an abstract discussion of an alliance made, in a time of stasis, between an oligarchic or democratic faction and an external state of the same political type. In the circumstances imagined, such an alliance would almost certainly need to be buttressed by oaths.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That the Arms-Dealer and his companions should leave]
 Χωρῶμεν, ὦ τᾶν, ἐκποδών.
  {ΤΡ.}  Νὴ τὸν Δί’

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he should be ashamed if he had been deceived by one who was an enemy]
 ναὶ μὰ Δία ᾐσχυνόμην μέντἄν, εἰ ὑπὸ πολεμίου γε ὄντος ἐξηπατήθην·
remarks: Xenophon anticipates that he will be asked whether he is ashamed to be deceived by Seuthes. He swears that he would be ashamed to be deceived by an enemy, but says that in dealings between friends he thinks that deceiving, not being deceived, is what one should be ashamed of.

author: Plato
title: Charmides
statement:
[That he does not know what is meant by a man doing his own business]
 Τί οὖν ἂν εἴη ποτὲ τὸ τὰ αὑτοῦ πράττειν; ἔχεις εἰπεῖν;  Οὐκ οἶδα μὰ Δία ἔγωγε, ἦ δ’ ὅς·

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Sparta at the start of the war in 431 as all of the Peloponnesians within the Isthmus except for Argos and Achaea (Pellene was the only Achaean city allied to Sparta), Megara, the Locrians (the Opuntian and Epicnemidian), the Boeotians, Locrians, the Ambraciots, the Leucadians and Anactorians. 
de Ste Croix, Origins of the Peloponnesian War, pp123-4, speculates that the Phocians joined the Peloponnesian League between 446 and 431. The former date is speculative. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement: [That they will judge the choruses fairly]
remarks:
Demosthenes states that he is sure that none of the jurors could remember a time when a political adversary displayed his hostility by standing by while the judges were being called up, or by dictating an oath to them. 
For further details see also oath id 3396. 
For other references to the judges' oath see oath id 1247.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he cannot tell Socrates, off the top of his head, the naval and military strength of Athens, nor that of her enemies]
 Πρῶτον μὲν τοίνυν, ἔφη, λέξον ἡμῖν τῆς πόλεως τήν τε πεζικὴν καὶ τὴν ναυτικὴν δύναμιν, εἶτα τὴν τῶν ἐναντίων. Ἀλλὰ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἂν ἔχοιμί σοι οὕτω γε ἀπὸ στόματος εἰπεῖν.
remarks: See remarks on oath id 2085 for context and cf. other entries for 3.6 (esp. oath id 2091).

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Athenians were angry that the Spartans had made a separate alliance with the Boeotians (see oath id 1708)  because they had said that they would join in coercing any state that did not accept the treaty. 
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1681.

author: Lysias
title: On the Property of Eraton
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
The speaker claims that during the war there were no lawsuits, but that once peace was made (presumably the peace of 404) civil suits began to be tried. Thus, they were able to prosecute the sons of Eraton to make them pay what they owed. 
See also oath id 1893.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he has not said everything he knows yet]
  Καὶ νὴ Δί’ οὐδέπω γε 
  εἴρηχ’ ὅσα ξύνοιδ’·
remarks: Inlaw is masquerading as a woman; cf. oath id 721.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement: n/a
remarks: Here, Peisetaerus tries to persuade Poseidon that if the gods have the birds as allies, mortals will no longer be able to perjure themselves and get away with it, essentially because the birds will be able to see the perjury and effect a punishment with all speed. Sommerstein explains 1609 (which refers to the bowed heads of the perjurers) as follows: "the perjurer is unable to look the person he is deceiving in the eye; the clouds prevent the gods from seeing him thus betray himself". Poseidon is convinced and replies with an informal oath invoking himself- see oath id 690.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of King Ariston ca. 545-530 (545 to 530)
if_taken: Each will receive a gift from the other
statement:
[That they would give each other one of their possessions]
 ὑποδέκεται δωτίνην δώσειν τῶν ἑωυτοῦ πάντων ἕν, τὸ ἂν αὐτὸς ἐκεῖνος ἕληται, καὶ τὸν ἑταῖρον ἑωυτῷ ἐκέλευε ὡσαύτως τὴν ὁμοίην διδόναι·
remarks:
Herodotus states that Ariston conceived a passion for the wife of his friend Agetus. 
He then promised to give Agetus a gift if he promised to give one in return. 
When Agetus agreed they swore an oath to confirm the agreement. 
After giving Agetus what he requested, Ariston then demanded Agetus's wife. 
Agetus said that he would have given anything other than that, but that he was compelled by his oath (ἀναγκαζόμενος μέντοι τῷ τε ὅρκῳ ) and the trick by which he was deceived.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callicles
statement:
[That the jurors are not accustomed to let water from the road flow onto their property]
 ἀλλ’ οὐ μὰ Δί’ εἴσω τὸ ἐκ τῆς ὁδοῦ δέχεσθαι,
remarks: The speaker asks why he should say anything more to support his case when he has shown that his father did nothing wrong in enclosing his property, the other neighbours did not complain, and when the jurors are all accustomed to direct water from their properties onto the road, and not the opposite.

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
swearee: Representatives of the allies of Athens
statement:
[That they would liberate the allies of Athens]
 ἐλευθερώσειν
remarks:
At 103, Isocrates describes how the Spartans were so avid to gain mastery of the sea that they were (a) negotiating a treaty of friendship and alliance with the Persian king, and promising to give over to him all the Greeks of Asia, and (b) promising to liberate Athens' [Asian] allies if they revolted. 
At 104, he claims that after they had given these pledges to the allies of Athens and the King, and had conquered Athens in war, they reduced those who they had sworn to set free to a state of slavery worse than that of Helots, and they returned the favour to the King by persuading his brother Cyrus to dispute his throne and sent an army to support Cyrus in his endeavour.  (This is massively misleading:  Cyrus needed no Spartan persuasion to dispute his brother's throne; his brother wsa not the King [Darius II] with whom Sparta had made the alliance, but his successor [Artaxerxes II]; and the Greek army that supported him was neither despatched nor financed by Sparta.) 
One can only speculate regarding the occasion on which the Spartans can have sworn to liberate the allies of Athens. This is perhaps to be regarded as a "Sophoclean oath" where what is called a "promise" in 103 has become an oath in 104.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he and Cleisthenes sank twelve or thirteen enemy ships in a naval battle]
  ΗΡ.  Κἀναυμάχησας;
  ΔΙ.  Καὶ κατεδύσαμέν γε ναῦς 
  τῶν πολεμίων ἢ δώδεκ’ ἢ τρεισκαίδεκα. 
  ΗΡ.  Σφώ;
  ΔΙ.  Νὴ τὸν ᾿Απόλλω. 
  ΞΑ.  Κᾆτ’ ἔγωγ’ ἐξηγρόμην.
remarks: Xanthias' response to Dionysus' oath ("And then I woke up") indicates, as Sommerstein ad loc. comments, that the statement would only be true were Dionysus relating a dream.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That he has had to endure many threats] 
 νὴ Δί’ ἀπειλὰς ὑπομείνας
remarks: Demosthenes claims that a great deal of money was offered to convince him to refrain from prosecuting, but he did not accept it, and held out against many requests and favours, and threats too.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would conduct the oligarchs to Athens for trial and safeguard them until the Athenian demos had decided their fate]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Athenians and Corcyraeans mounted an expedition against the oligarchs who had established themselves on Mt Istone. 
The combined forces captured the stronghold, but the oligarchs fled to higher ground. 
These soon capitulated on condition that they should surrender their mercenary troops, give up their arms, and leave it to the Athenian demos to decide their fate. 
Thucydides states that the Athenian generals conveyed the men under truce (ὑποσπόνδους) to the island of Ptychia to be kept under custody until they should be sent to Athens. However, the understanding was that if any oligarch should be caught trying to escape the truce should be regarded as broken by all. 
The leaders of the Corcyraean demos feared that the oligarchs would not be put to death, and sent men to tell them that they ought to escape because the Athenian generals were intending to hand them over to the Corcyraean demos. When they were persuaded and caught sailing away the truce was broken and the whole party was handed over to the Corcyraean demos. They were brutally slain. The details of their deaths can be found in 4.47.2-48.5.

author: Sophocles
title: Ajax
statement:
[That Agamemnon and Menelaus did not come as his or the Achaeans' generals or admirals, but that Ajax sailed as his own commander]
 κοὔτε στρατηγοὺς οὔτε ναυάρχους μολεῖν 
ἡμᾶς ᾿Αχαιῶν οὔτε σοῦ διωμόσω,
ἀλλ’ αὐτὸς ἄρχων, ὡς σὺ φής, Αἴας ἔπλει.
remarks: Agamemnon is referring to Teucer's speech at 1097-1110 which was NOT in fact a sworn statement. However, when Agamemnon puts it to Teucer that he has "sworn" such things, Teucer does not take issue with this. This seems to be a particular feature of Sophocles, see oath ids 263, 270, 285, 289, 292.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
swearer: Lampito; Calonice; Myrrhine; All women present; Lysistrata
swearee: Lampito; Calonice; Myrrhine; All women present; Lysistrata
if_taken: The sex strike will be ensured; peace will be enabled
if_refused: The sex strike will not be ensured; war will continue
if_kept: May she drink from the wine-cup
if_broken: May the wine-cup be filled with water
impact: The sex strike is ensured and peace is enabled
statement: [That no man whatever, neither lover nor husband shall come near her with his cock up, and that she will pass her life at home, pure and chaste in make-up and saffron gown so that her husband may be greatly inflamed with desire for her, and that she will never yield herself to her husband of her own free will. And if he should force her against her will, she will submit grudgingly and not thrust back. She will not raise her Persian slippers ceilingwards. She will not stand in the lioness-on-a-cheesegrater position]
remarks: Myrrhine here make a reference to the oath she and the other women had sworn at 181-238. See further remarks at oath id 1164.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
if_taken: Cersobleptes would be included in the peace
if_refused: He would not be included in the peace
remarks:
Aeschines asks (rhetorically), "Are we to believe, Demosthenes, that after trying to exclude Cersobleptes from the treaty at Athens, you pitied him when you got to Oreus?". 
See also oath id 2583. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he will prove he was right to hit Strepsiades]
 τὸν πατέρα τύπτεις;
 {Φε.}  κἀποφανῶ γε νὴ Δία 
  ὡς ἐν δίκῃ σ’ ἔτυπτον.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the shares of meat will not be distributed equally if they start serving from one side, then another, but never from the middle]
 Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, τῶνδε μὲν οὐδὲν ἴσον ἐστίν, εἴγε ἀφ’ ἡμῶν γε τῶν ἐν μέσῳ οὐδεὶς οὐδέποτε ἄρξεται.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2339.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Thebans called for representatives from all the Greek cities to come to Thebes to hear the King's letter. 
When they had read the letter to the representatives of the other Greeks, the Thebans directed those who wished to be friends of the Thebans and the King to swear to these provisions. 
The envoys replied that they had not been sent to swear oaths, but to listen. They told the Thebans that if they desired oaths, they should send to the cities.  
See also oath id 1996.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines claims that "anyone who begs for your vote in the first speech is asking you to make a gift of your oath, of the law, of democracy". He argues that none of these things can rightly be asked by anyone, nor can they rightly be given to another when asked. 
Since every speaker in the courts asked for the jury to vote his way, we must suppose that what Aeschines is saying is that every speaker who asked for the jury’s vote as a favour in his first speech was asking for them to disregard oath, law and democracy.  His point is that when arguing for acquittal and against conviction, the defendant should stick to trying to prove that he is not legally guilty; the time for asking favours is when he is arguing about what penalty should be imposed. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That Timarchus' trial improved the morals of the young men of Athens]
 νὴ Δί’, οἱ νέοι γὰρ ἡμῖν δι’ ἐκεῖνον ἔσονται τὸν ἀγῶνα βελτίους.
remarks: Demosthenes contrasts the trial of Timarchus with that of Aeschines, and asks the jurors how great a penalty they will impose on Aeschines given the magnitude of his crimes compared to those of Timarchus. He imagines that someone will respond in this way to his comments about Timarchus' trial.

author: Demosthenes
title: For Phormion
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that if they ignore Apollodorus' shameless bawling, and remember what he has told them, they will be keeping their oaths and justly acquitting Phormion. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That the accused was guilty]
remarks:
According to the text if someone rapes a slave woman he shall pay a fine, "and the oath of the slave-woman shall prevail" (ὀρκιοτέραν δ' ἔμεν τὰν δόλαν). 
We can be sure that this provision is not meant to apply 'only' to slaves; it is to be understood as applying, a fortiori, to other rape complainants too.  And in view of the comparative, the situation envisaged must be that in which 'both' the accuser and the defendant are swearing, and the rule is that in that situation the accuser is to be believed.  Evidently both parties were challenged to swear to the truth of their respective contentions; whoever refused to swear ipso facto lost the case; and if both swore, the man was deemed guilty. 
See also oath id 3867.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: None: Penelope does not believe him
statement:
[That Odysseus will come home within the year]
 ἴστω νῦν Ζεὺς πρῶτα, θεῶν ὕπατος καὶ ἄριστος, 
ἱστίη τ’ Ὀδυσῆος ἀμύμονος, ἣν ἀφικάνω· 
ἦ μέν τοι τάδε πάντα τελείεται ὡς ἀγορεύω.  
τοῦδ’ αὐτοῦ λυκάβαντος ἐλεύσεται ἐνθάδ’ Ὀδυσσεύς,
τοῦ μὲν φθίνοντος μηνός, τοῦ δ’ἱσταμένοιο.”
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)first among the gods, loftiest, most noble; Hearth of blameless Odysseus
remarks: Cf. oath ids 542, 545, 561.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he is not listening to Euthydemus and Dionysodorus (because he could not hear for the crowd)]
 Ὦ Κρίτων, ἔφη, οὐδὲν ἀκροᾷ τῶνδε τῶν σοφῶν;  Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ· οὐ γὰρ οἷός τ’ ἦ προσστὰς κατακούειν ὑπὸ τοῦ ὄχλου.
remarks: We can say (from 305c) that the man was a professional speechwriter.  We can’t put a name to him (Antiphon was probably dead, and Lysias and Isocrates were not yet practising the profession), and are probably not meant to try, but such people certainly existed at the time (we even have one of their products – [Lysias] 20, which probably belongs to 410).  Socrates’ excursus on the men of this type strongly suggests that Plato has Isocrates in his sights, as indeed is the view of most scholars.

author: Euripides
title: Alcestis
statement:
[That a woman by far the best of all is being ferried across the Acherontian mere in the two-oared pine boat]
 ἴστω δ’ ᾿Αίδας ὁ μελαγχαί-
  τας θεὸς ὅς τ’ ἐπὶ κώπαι
  πηδαλίωι τε γέρων 
  νεκροπομπὸς ἵζει
  πολὺ δὴ πολὺ δὴ γυναῖκ’ ἀρίσταν
  λίμναν ᾿Αχεροντίαν πορεύ-
  σας ἐλάται δικώπωι.
remarks: Lines 473-5 suggest that the citizens of the Chorus are unmarried but their age is difficult to determine. They are either adolescent or mature.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That the Athenians would not molest the Thebans as they departed the island]
remarks:
The actual oath statement is unknown. 
Demosthenes criticises Meidias for failing to arrive in Euboea until after Diocles had made the truce with the Thebans. 
See also oath id 2671.

author: Pherecrates
title: Myrmekanthropoi
statement:
[That the bogue is the only fish that has a voice]
 τί ληρεῖς; ἀλλὰ φωνὴν οὐκ ἔχειν
ἰχθύν γέ φασι τὸ παράπαν. {Β.} νὴ τὼ θεώ,
κοὐκ ἔστιν ἰχθὺς ἄλλος οὐδεὶς ἢ βόαξ.
remarks: This sentence must be either corrupt or incomplete, since the speaker seems to be saying that the bogue (Boops boops; Greek boax or bτx) is the only fish there is, which makes neither sense nor a joke. The statement is most likely to have been “That the bogue is the only fish that has a voice”. Swearing by Demeter and Persephone is a female oath; see on oath id 788.

author: Thucydides
title: History
date: During the reign of Alexander I of Macedon? (498 to 454)
swearer: King of Macedon; King of Lyncestis; King of Elimea; Kings of other tribes
swearee: King of Macedon; King of Lyncestis; King of Elimea; Kings of other tribes
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would be loyal to the Macedonian king and to support each other in war]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Macedonian race includes also the Lyncestians, Elimiotes and other tribes of the upper country, which, though in alliance with the nearer Macedonians and subject to them, have kings of their own. 
These tribes were not always unified. See oath id 1545. 
Hammond, A History of Macedonia Vol 1, p439 suggests that the tribes were first unified during the reign of Alexander I ca.498-454.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Dicaeogenes
if_taken: He can proceed with his case
if_refused: He cannot proceed with his case
statement: [That the facts in his written statement were true]
remarks: Menexenus states that when he was about to make his antomosia against Dicaeogenes (III) - i.e. that Dicaeogenes had transgressed the terms of the agreement with his father and uncles - Leochares produced evidence that Dicaeogenes had been adopted as the sole heir of Dicaeogenes (II), so Menexenus did not proceed with the case.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
if_taken: He will be part of a conspiracy
if_refused: He will not be part of a conspiracy
statement: [That he will be party to the conspiracy]
remarks: The Chorus here suggest that Bdelycleon is part of a sworn conspiracy, which as Sommerstein remarks "covers both subversion of democracy at Athens and intrigues with actually or potentially hostile states like Sparta". They cannot otherwise understand why he is not letting his father out of the house to perform his juror's duties. Cf. oath ids 1087, 1089, 1090, 1107.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That neither Xenophon nor anyone else directed him to rescue the man who was arrested for stealing sheep]
 Ἐγώ, ὦ ἄνδρες, ὄμνυμι θεοὺς καὶ θεὰς ἦ μὴν μήτε με Ξενοφῶντα κελεῦσαι ἀφελέσθαι τὸν ἄνδρα μήτε ἄλλον ὑμῶν μηδένα·
remarks:
This oath was taken at the time when Cleander, the Spartan harmost of Byzantium, had arrived in Bithynia with ships to transport the Greeks to the Hellespont. 
Because Cleander arrived with only two triremes the Greeks feared that they would lose the many sheep that they had acquired in the mountain. As a result, they made an agreement with Dexippus one of the perioeci who was serving with Cleander that was intended to safeguard the livestock. 
Dexippus then broke his agreement with the Greeks, and arrested one of them for stealing sheep. 
When Dexippus was taking the man to Cleander, Agasias rescued him because he was a member of his lochos. The other soldiers of the lochos then set about stoning Dexippus, calling him a traitor. 
When the fighting was stopped, Dexippus accused Xenophon of ordering Agasias to attack him. 
Agasias then swore that no one had ordered him to do so, and offered to go to Cleander for trial.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines states that the lawgiver i.e. Solon placed the words, "I shall vote according to the laws" first in the dikastic oath, for he knew well that if the laws were upheld faithfully for the state, the democracy would be preserved. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Sophocles
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: n/a
remarks: Here a character remarks that no oath is a burden for a thief.  Cf. oath ids 979, 1000, 1038.

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The Plataean speaker asks if it will become the Athenians to have greater regard for the city of the Thebans than for their own oaths and agreements, when it is their ancient tradition to fear acts of infamy and dishonour rather than to fear danger. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callicles
if_taken: Callicles would not lose the case if his opponent's mother swore
if_refused: He would lose the case if his opponent's mother swore
statement: [That Callicles did not throw rubble on the road, and did not narrow the road by bringing the wall forward]
remarks:
The speaker states that he offered Callicles' mother the chance to swear to her son's versions of the fact, and declared that he was ready to summon his own mother to swear to his version (see also oath id 3682). 
Presumably the challenge (actually delivered to Callicles himself, not directly to his mother) will have specified that if the oath was tendered to her and she refused it, Callicles would lose his case; more precisely, since the speaker asks for only one challenge (not two) to be read to the jury, Callicles would lose his case if his mother refused to swear while the speaker’s own mother did not refuse.  Callicles either rejected the challenge outright or (perhaps more likely) haggled over the terms so that no agreement was reached.

author: Ibycus
title: Fragments
statement: unknown
remarks: This is a reference to an oath. Nothing more can be deduced from the fragment.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the woman is Mica's nurse]
 Ἡδὶ δὲ δὴ τίς ἐστιν, ἡ τὸ παιδίον 
  ἔχουσα;  
{ΜΙ.}  Τίτθη νὴ Δί’ ἐμή.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that the Argives and Corinthians, being now allies, marched to Tegea hoping to induce it to revolt from Sparta. 
For other references to this alliance and its impact see oath id 1698.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he has not considered the matter of the city's revenues nor considered how to raise any funds that are lacking]
 δῆλον γὰρ ὅτι ἔσκεψαι, ἵνα, εἰ μέν τινες αὐτῶν ἐνδεῶς ἔχουσιν, ἐκπληρώσῃς, εἰ δὲ παραλείπονται, προσπορίσῃς. Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Γλαύκων
remarks: See remarks on oath id 2085 for context, and cf. other entires for 3.6.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: Emphasises that the Persians will wait for Gadatas
statement:
[That Gadatas will have time to get himself ready before they set off]
 Ἆρ’ οὖν, ἔφη, δυναίμην ἂν συσκευασάμενος φθάσαι πρίν σε ἐξιέναι; βούλομαι γάρ τοι, ἔφη, καὶ τὴν μητέρα ἄγειν μετ’ ἐμαυτοῦ. Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, φθάσεις μέντοι.
remarks: Gadatas wishes to bring his mother along on the expedition. Greeks thought it typical of barbarians (some of whom were nomadic) to bring their families with them on campaigns (see 4.2.2 on this generalisation made in the context of the Hyrcanians). The name of the land is never specified. It is the land of Gadatas and borders on Assyria.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: Shortly after the end of the war (404 to 401)
statement:
[That he will not have bodily strength to work for a living for much longer]
 Καὶ πόσον χρόνον οἴει σοι, ἔφη, τὸ σῶμα ἱκανὸν εἶναι μισθοῦ τὰ ἐπιτήδεια ἐργάζεσθαι; Μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ πολὺν χρόνον.
remarks: Despite what Eutherus says here, he does not regard himself, nor does Socrates regard him, as being an old man as yet, since Socrates, in his next reply, speaks of what is likely to happen to Eutherus "when [he] become[s] an old man".  Thus although he is described as an old friend of Socrates (2.8.1), he should be assumed to be several years younger than Socrates (who must be at least 65).

author: Plato
title: Republic
impact: Emphasises the success of their endeavour
statement:
[That they would not be lying if they asserted that they had discovered the just man, the just state, and what justice really is in them]
 Εἶεν, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ· τὸν μὲν δίκαιον καὶ ἄνδρα καὶ πόλιν καὶ δικαιοσύνην, ὃ τυγχάνει ἐν αὐτοῖς ὄν, εἰ φαῖμεν ηὑρηκέναι, οὐκ ἂν πάνυ τι οἶμαι δόξαιμεν ψεύδεσθαι. Μὰ Δία οὐ μέντοι, ἔφη.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That Myrrhine is not utterly loathsome and disgusting]
  ἡ παμβδελύρα καὶ παμμυσάρα.
  {Χ. ΓΡ.}  Μὰ Δί’

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes criticises Philip for rejecting the friendship of Athens and for favouring Thebes and Argos, arguing that he cannot have done so because he regards their fleets as superior to that of Athens, or because he has forgotten the speeches and promises that gained him the peace with Athens. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
statement: [That Argos will be Athens' ally if Athena comes to his assistance]
remarks: This is the same alliance propsed by Orestes at oath id 211. See remarks there. This will be formally sworn by Orestes at id 222.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Spartans; The other Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: Spartans; The other Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
if_refused: They would not be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
The Theban envoy refers to the Plataeans' "alliance with the Spartans against the Medes", and argues that this should have been sufficient to protect them against Thebes, without their needing to become collaborators with Athenian imperialism. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1501.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [? That he did not assault Ariston]
remarks: Ariston says that he will swear his oath now (see oath id 3677), because he does not wish to lose the case because of Conon's perjury (see also oath id).

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That there were ducks "with aprons on" laying the bricks (of the city wall)]
 Καὶ νὴ Δί’ αἱ νῆτταί γε περιεζωσμέναι
  ἐπλινθοβόλουν·
remarks: As with the sworn statement that the birds are older than the Earth (see oath id 646), the truth of the present statement relies on the fact that this is set in a fantastical world, where these sorts of things are, in fact, true. Sommerstein qualifies "with aprons on" as "possibly alluding to the white collar of the mallard, which might suggest an apron tied at the neck"; Dunbar, following W.G. Arnott, renders the Greek word as "with tunic secured by waist-belt", and suggests several duck species whose colouring gives them a clearly marked waistline.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the Opuntian Locrians
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the Opuntian Locrians
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the Athenians need to take care that they do not wrong men who once drew whole states into alliance with Athens against the Spartans i.e. the alliance in 395. 
See also oath id 2019.

author: Anonymus Comicus
title: Pseudepicharmea
statement:
[That nothing came into existence ‘first’ or ‘second’, but on the contrary everything has existed from eternity]
 οὐκ ἄρ’ ἔμολε πρᾶτον οὐδέν; {A.} οὐδὲ μὰ Δία

author: Plato
title: Hippias Major
statement:
[That the knowledge of what beauty is by itself is but a small part of Hippias' knowledge]
 οἶσθα γὰρ δήπου σαφῶς, καὶ σμικρόν που τοῦτ’ ἂν εἴη μάθημα ὧν σὺ τῶν πολλῶν ἐπίστασαι.  {ΙΠ.} Σμικρὸν μέντοι νὴ Δί’, ὦ Σώκρατες
remarks: Hippias then adds that this knowledge is also of no value.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That all the citizens frequent the agora on either public or private business]
 τούτων ἕκαστος ἕν γέ τι πράττων κατὰ τὴν ἀγορὰν περιέρχεται, ἤτοι νὴ τὸν Ἡρακλέα τῶν κοινῶν ἢ τῶν ἰδίων

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
if_kept: Polis free from sickness; polis unsacked; (land) bear (fruit); women bear children like to their parents; cattle bear young like to cattle (?)
if_broken: Polis afflicted with sickness; polis sacked; land barren; women bear monsters; cattle bear monsters (?)
statement:
[That they will not hold life dearer than freedom, nor will they abandon their leaders whether they are alive or dead. That they will bury all allies killed in the battle. If they conquer the barbarians in war, they will not destroy any of the cities which have fought for Greece, but will consecrate a tenth of all those who sided with the barbarian. They will not rebuild a single one of the shrines which the barbarians have burnt and razed, but will allow them to remain for future generations as a memorial of the barbarians' impiety]
 Οὐ ποιήσομαι περὶ πλείονος τὸ ζῆν τῆς ἐλευθερίας, οὐδ’ ἐγκαταλείψω τοὺς ἡγεμόνας οὔτε ζῶντας οὔτε ἀποθανόντας, ἀλλὰ τοὺς ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τελευτήσαντας τῶν συμμάχων ἅπαντας θάψω. καὶ κρατήσας τῷ πολέμῳ τοὺς βαρβάρους, τῶν μὲν μαχεσαμένων ὑπὲρ τῆς Ἑλλάδος πόλεων οὐδεμίαν ἀνάστατον ποιήσω, τὰς δὲ τὰ τοῦ βαρβάρου προελομένας ἁπάσας δεκατεύσω. καὶ τῶν ἱερῶν τῶν ἐμπρησθέντων καὶ καταβληθέντων ὑπὸ τῶν βαρβάρων οὐδὲν ἀνοικοδομήσω παντάπασιν, ἀλλ’ ὑπόμνημα τοῖς ἐπιγιγνομένοις ἐάσω καταλείπεσθαι τῆς τῶν βαρβάρων ἀσεβείας.
remarks:
Lycurgus states that because no one who has who has broken his oath can deceive the gods, and if the perjurer does not suffer himself, his children and his family will suffer great misfortune (see oath id 2746), the Greeks exchanged a pledge at Plataea before taking their posts to fight against the power of Xerxes. He argues that the formula was not their own, but borrowed from the oath that is traditional among the Athenians. 
Lycurgus then has the Plataea oath read to the jurors, and goes on to say that the Greeks "stood by this so strongly that they had the favour of the gods on their side to help them". He also (curiously) argues that the Athenians won the most renown at Plataea as a result.  
It is remarkable that Lyc. should cite the oath in this form, and say the Athenians faithfully observed it, when he and all his audience know perfectly well that the Athenians had in fact rebuilt most of the destroyed sanctuaries, generally on the same site.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
After Xenophon advocated preparing for war, a certain Apollonides addressed the lochagoi of Proxenus the Boeotian, saying that Xenophon was speaking nonsense in suggesting that they could gain safety by any means other than by winning the King's consent. 
Xenophon interrupted him saying, "You amazing fellow, you have eyes but still do not perceive, and you have ears but still do not remember. You were present, surely, with the rest of these officers at the time when the King, after the death of Cyrus and in his elation over that event, sent and ordered us to give up our arms. But when, instead of giving them up, we equipped ourselves with them, and went and encamped beside him, what means did he leave untried - sending ambassadors, begging for a truce, offering us provisions - until in the end he obtained a truce? When, however, our generals and captains, following precisely the plan that you are now urging, went unarmed to a conference with them, relying upon the truce, what happened in that case? Are they not at this moment being beaten, tortured, insulted, unable even to die, hapless men that they are, even though they earnestly long, I imagine, for death? And do you, knowing all these things, say that those who urge self-defence are talking nonsense, and do you propose that we should again go and try persuasion? In my opinion, gentlemen, we should not simply refuse to admit this fellow to companionship with us, but should deprive him of his captaincy, lay packs on his back, and treat him as that sort of a creature. For the fellow is a disgrace both to his native state and to the whole of Greece, since, being a Greek, he is still a man of this kind." 
Apollonides was then driven off. 
See also oath id 2105.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That those who draw water in a leaky jar are to be pitied because they seem to toil in vain]
 οὐχ ὁρᾷς, ἔφην ἐγώ, οἱ εἰς τὸν τετρημένον πίθον ἀντλεῖν λεγόμενοι ὡς οἰκτίρονται, ὅτι μάτην πονεῖν δοκοῦσι; Νὴ Δί’
remarks: As Pomeroy notes ad loc., drawing water with a leaky vessel was proverbial for wasted labour.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the men who are raiding their belongings look worthless, as do their horses]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ πάππε, ἀλλ’ οὖν πονηροί γε φαινόμενοι καὶ ἐπὶ πονηρῶν ἱππαρίων ἄγουσιν ἡμῶν τὰ χρήματα·

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
When defending himself against Demosthenes' allegations that he is responsible for King Cersobleptes losing his kingdom, Aeschines states that the Athenians delayed sending out the ambassadors a month, and they did not set out until the month of Mounichion. Aeschines cites a decree dated Mounchion 3, and reminds the jurors that Cersobleptes lost his kingdom in Elaphebolion - the month before Mounchion. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

title: CID I
if_taken: He can consult the oracle or make a sacrifice
if_refused: He cannot consult the oracle or make a sacrifice
statement:
[That he is an Asclepiad of the male line]
 ὀμόσαντα χρῆσθαι ἔμεν Ἀσκλαπ[ιά]δας κατὰ ἀνδρο[γέν]ειαν
remarks:
This text is a decree of the koinon of the Asclepiads of Cos and Cnidus. 
The text indicates that any Asclepiad who comes to Delphi and wishes to consult the oracle or make a sacrifice "must do so only after swearing that he is an Asclepiad of the male line".

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he does not pray never to be rich and does not sacrifice to deities who avert disaster when he has a good dream] 
 Οὐκοῦν, ἔφη ὁ Καλλίας, καὶ εὔχῃ μηδέποτε πλουτεῖν, καὶ ἐάν τι ὄναρ ἀγαθὸν ἴδῃς, τοῖς ἀποτροπαίοις θύεις;  Μὰ Δία τοῦτο μέντοι, ἔφη, ἐγὼ οὐ ποιῶ
remarks: Normally it would be after a dream of evil omen that one would make apotropaic offerings, as Xerxes' mother does in Aeschylus' Persians (200-4, 216-223) and Clytaemestra in his Choephoroi.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That he would conduct the envoys back to the coast if he could not take them to the King]
 φάσκων ὀμωμοκέναι καὶ ἀπάξειν ἐπὶ θάλατταν, ἐπειδὴ οὐ παρὰ βασιλέ&alpha
remarks:
When Cyrus was sent to take control of Persian affairs in the west, he came upon Pharnabazus conducting Athenian envoys to the King. These envoys had been sent during the aborted siege of Calchedon, and wished either to be allowed to see the King or to return home. 
Cyrus ordered Pharnabazus to hand them over or not to send them home yet, because he did not wish the Athenians to know what was going on. 
Pharnabazus then detained them for three years (or three months) to ensure that Cyrus did not have cause to censure him, but later asked Cyrus to allow him to send them home, claiming that he had given them his oath to conduct them back to the coast if he could not conduct them to the King. (Perhaps significantly, there is no mention of this part of the oath sworn by Pharnabazus in 1.3.9-10: see oath id 1883 and 1885). 
The envoys were then sent to Ariobarzanes who escorted them to Kios in Mysia, and from there they sailed to join the Athenian army.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The King's country in Asia is to remain his possession and to be governed as he pleases
2. The Spartans and their allies shall not go against the country of the King, nor the King against the Spartans and their allies.
3. If any of the Spartans and their allies go against the King's territory, the Spartans and their allies shall stop them, and if any of the King's subjects go against the Spartans and their allies the King shall stop them
4. Tissaphernes shall pay for the ships now present until the arrival of the King's ships. After these arrive, the Spartans can then pay for their own ships if they wish. If not, Tissaphernes will provide money, but the Spartans will repay the money at the end of the war
5. When the King's ships arrive, the ships of the Spartans and their allies and those of the King shall wage war together, according to what seems best to Tissaphernes and the Spartans and their allies. If they wish to end the war with the Athenians, they will do so jointly]
remarks:
Isocrates criticises the Spartans for attacking their own allies and benefactors. 
He claims that after the Persian King had furnished the Spartans with more than five thousand talents for the war they sent Clearchus with an army against him.  (In fact the Ten Thousand were neither despatched nor financed by the Spartan state, and Clearchus was an exile when he joined Cyrus; what is more, the army regarded itself as fighting for, not against, the man who was rightfully King of Persia.) 
He also criticises the Spartans for turning on their allies from Chios and Thebes (see also oath id 3012 and 3014). 
For the treaty between Sparta and Persia see also oath id 1818.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
statement:
[That he would defeat Semiramis and crucify her]
 θεοὺς ἐπιμαρτυράμενος, ἠπείλει καταπολεμήσας αὐτὴν σταυρῶι προσηλώσειν.
remarks: It is impossible to pinpoint the reign of this queen Semiramis, largely a figure of legend in Greek literature. The oath of Stabrobates is clearly taken in earnest although it remains unfulfilled since Semiramis is victorious in the battle.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That they'll stop the men (?)- see remarks]
 οἶμαί ποτε Λυσιμάχας ἡμᾶς ἐν τοῖς Ἕλλησι καλεῖσθαι. 
{ΠΡ.} Τί ποησάσας; 
{ΛΥ.} Ἢν παύσωμεν πρώτιστον μὲν ξὺν ὅπλοισιν 
  ἀγοράζοντας καὶ μαινομένους. 
{ΓΡ. α}  Νὴ τὴν Παφίαν Ἀφροδίτην.
remarks: It is difficult to pinpoint exactly what the statement is here. Possibly the speaker is assenting to what is contained in mainomenous and, formally expressed, the statement would be “That the men who do shopping in the Agora in armour are behaving like lunatics”.  Alternatively, she may be treating Lysistrata’s words “if we stop the men doing so-and-so” as a statement of intent (“we’ll stop the men doing so-and-so”) and saying “yes, we will” (so in effect two recent scholar-translators, Halliwell and Thiercy).

author: Antiphon
title: On the choreutes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had not killed]
remarks:
The defendant states that he did not tell the boy to drink the medicine that caused his death, nor compel him to drink it, nor give it to him, nor even see him drink it. He then calls witnesses who verify his statement. As usual, we don't know exactly what these witnesses said, but almost certainly the defendant would make sure (at this period, by framing his questions to them appropriately) that they would do no more than confirm his negative statements, since otherwise they risked getting one or more of his associates into trouble.  Note that his denials leave open the possibility that he ordered a subordinate to give the drug to the boy and that it was duly given at a time when he himself was not present.  
See oath id 2507.

author: Lysias
title: On the Scrutiny of Euandros
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The speaker blames Thrasybulus of Collytus for the Thebans accepting the King's Peace, which "changed the Boeotian constitution" (i.e. ended Theban control of the other Boeotian cities) and deprived the Athenians of the alliance with Thebes. 
See also oath id 2019.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
impact: New legal system formally accepted by the people
statement:
[To observe the laws established by Solon]
