 ἀναγράψαντες δὲ τοὺς νόμους εἰς τοὺς κύρβεις ἔστησαν ἐν τῇ στοᾷ τῇ βασιλείῳ καὶ ὤμοσαν χρήσεσθαι πάντες

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Egesta. 
The swearing of the oath by the Athenian bouleutai and dikastai is not included in the text of IG I(3), but was restored in lines 6-7 by Bradeen and McGregor.  
For the corresponding oath of the Egestans see oath id 87. See also oath id 1841.

title: IDidyma
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
All that can be determined is that someone had to swear an oath to pay or restore something. 
The text is inscribed boustrophedon.

author: Philip of Macedon
title: Letter to the Athenians
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
Philip counters the Athenian demand that he should leave Teres and Cersobleptes to rule in Thrace because they are Athenians by arguing that Teres fought with him against Athens, and that Cersobleptes was ready to take oaths with his ambassadors in private, but that he was denounced as an enemy of Athens. This presumably took place during the negotiation of the Peace of Philocrates at Athens in 346. 
See also oath id 2583. 
Philip's point (made in the next section) is that the Athenians are being hypocritical in claiming Cersobleptes as a citizen when earlier, when it had served their turn, they had denounced him as an enemy.  It is entirely unclear who is supposed to have made this denunciation and on what occasion, and it seems likely that Philip is simply lying. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Hesiod
title: Catalogue of Women
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a discussion concerning the notion that the lover (under the influence of Aphrodite) who breaks an oath will not be punished. Cf. oath ids 1433, 2921, 2925, 2932, 2933.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That if anyone goes against the Byzantines they would go in support as far as possible]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Byzantium. This alliance is explicitly said to be on the same terms as that between Athens and Chios. 
The decree indicates that Orthoboulus of Cerameis, Execestides of Pallene, Xenodocus of Acharnae, Pyrrhandrus of Anaphlystus and Alcimachus of Angele were chosen as ambassadors to Byzantium. Presumably these ambassadors swore the oath on behalf of Athens at Byzantium. 
For the corresponding oath of the Byzantines see oath id 333.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That there is no path]
 Οὐδὲ μὰ Δί’ ἐνταῦθά γ’ ἀτραπὸς οὐδαμοῦ.

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a definition of an oath. It is an unproven statement with divine involvement. A speaker who wishes to stress the importance of an oath which he himself has taken, or is willing to take, should say that "no one would want to perjure themselves if they feared divine retribution and the censure of their peers"; one who wishes to disparage an opponent's oath should say that "the kind of people who commit crimes are also those who are not concerned about perjury".

author: Sophocles
title: Trachiniae
impact: Makes Hyllus agree to Heracles' demands
statement:
[That it is Heracles' order for Hyllus to carry out his father's wishes]
Υλ. πράσσειν ἄνωγας οὖν με πανδίκως τάδε;
Ηρ. ἔγωγε· τούτων μάρτυρας καλῶ θεούς.
remarks: See also oath id 275.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That the puzzles which Socrates has posed (regarding the way something can remain the same yet simultaneously grow or decrease in size in its relation to something else) make Theatetus wonder what they can mean]
 Καὶ νὴ τοὺς θεούς γε, ὦ Σώκρατες, ὑπερφυῶς ὡς θαυμάζω τί ποτ’ ἐστὶ ταῦτα

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes asks the jurors how it would be possible for a sensible juror who wishes to avoid perjury to acquit Aeschines. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That they will abide by the terms of the agreement] 
See also remarks.
remarks: The peace treaty referred to here by the Chorus was originally proposed by Amphitheos at 51-52, envisaged as being between the Athenians and the Spartans. Dicaeopolis subsequently undertakes to make a thirty-year peace treaty with the Spartans alone (see oath id 596). Although a real peace treaty necessarily entails the swearing of an oath, Dicaeopolis never actually swears one in the context of this treaty. However, we must bear in mind that this is a comic treaty of a fantastical nature, exemplified by the fact that it is characterized by physical smells and flavours. But, we should also note that at, oath id 600, the Acharnians assume that the Spartans have sworn the treaty and that their oaths cannot be trusted. This treaty is referred to multiple times throughout the play.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he would gladly watch Peisander the demagogue learning to somersault among knives]
 καὶ ὁ Φίλιππος, Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, καὶ μὴν ἔγωγε ἡδέως ἂν θεῴμην Πείσανδρον τὸν δημηγόρον μανθάνοντα κυβιστᾶν εἰς τὰς μαχαίρας
remarks: Antisthenes has suggested that the Syracusan showman might be paid by the Athenian state to give every Athenian citizen the courage to charge a line of enemy spears, and this is Philip’s humorous cap on the suggestion. The joke is that Peisander, in spite of his position of power, had a bad military record, and was regularly the butt of jokes among the comic poets.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Orestes did not "remigrate" home because he came secretly, without the consent of those in charge]
  ΕΥ. Οὔ φημι τὸν Ὀρέστην κατελθεῖν οἴκαδε· 
  λάθρᾳ γὰρ ἦλθεν οὐ πιθὼν τοὺς κυρίους.
  ΔΙ.  Εὖ νὴ τὸν Ἑρμῆν·
remarks: The invocation of Hermes here shows that Euripides has won the argument. Dionysus has invoked Zeus (at oath id 494), then Apollo (at oath id 496) and now invokes Hermes. But Dionysus remains desperately confused as evidenced by his words uttered immediately after this third oath: ὅ τι λέγεις δ’ οὐ μανθάνω. He has sworn to the correctness of a statement whose meaning he does not understand.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, when the Athenians arrived at Corcyra to assist them against the Corinthians, the generals gave orders to their ships not to engage with the Corinthians unless they sailed against Corcyra or attempted to land there to avoid breaking the Thirty Years' Peace.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Euripides
title: Ion
impact: Ion learns that his father is Apollo
statement:
[That Creusa lay with Apollo and bore him a son (Ion)]
 Κρ. ἴστω Γοργοφόνα Ιων τί τοῦτ’ ἔλεξας;
Κρ. ἃ σκοπέλοις ἐπ’ ἐμοῖς
  τὸν ἐλαιοφυῆ πάγον 
  θάσσει Ιων λέγεις μοι σκολιὰ κοὐ σαφῆ τάδε.
Κρ. παρ’ ἀηδόνιον πέτραν
  Φοίβωι Ιων τί Φοῖβον αὐδᾶις;
Κρ. κρυπτόμενον λέχος ηὐνάσθην
Ιων λέγ’· ὡς ἐρεῖς τι κεδνὸν εὐτυχές τέ μοι. 
Κρ. δεκάτωι δέ σε μηνὸς ἐν
  κύκλωι κρύφιον ὠδῖν’ ἔτεκον Φοίβωι.
remarks: Cf. oath id 156 where a second oath, again in the name of Athena, is needed to reassert the same facts.

title: Syll (3)
statement: [? That they would recognise the title of the owners and to not interfere with their title]
remarks: This text relates to the confiscation and re-sale of property and person of the debtors of Apollo, Athenaia and Parthenos. The text indicates that the gods are to confirm the purchase forever, and the neopoiai (officials in charge of the temple fabric) are to join in confirming, and they are to be made to swear an oath in these terms - to recognise the title of the owners and to not interfere with their title.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That there is no man with a better character than Chremylus (except Carion)]
 οὐ γὰρ εὑρήσεις ἐμοῦ
  ζητῶν ἔτ’ ἄνδρα τοὺς τρόπους βελτίονα. 
 {ΚΑ.}  Μὰ τὸν Δί’, οὐ γὰρ ἔστιν ἄλλος πλὴν ἐγώ.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That whenever he's in good health, he never dines before working up a sweat]
 ὄμνυμί σοι τὸν Μίθρην, 
ὅτανπερ ὑγιαίνω, μηπώποτε δειπνῆσαι πρὶν ἱδρῶσαι
remarks: Xenophon is the first Greek to refer to the god Mithra(s). Cf. oath id 2469.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he envies Antisthenes his wealth because the city does not use him as a slave while people do not resent him for not giving them a loan]
 ὁ δὲ Καλλίας, Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφη, τά τε ἄλλα ζηλῶ σε τοῦ πλούτου καὶ ὅτι οὔτε ἡ πόλις σοι ἐπιτάττουσα ὡς δούλῳ χρῆται οὔτε οἱ ἄνθρωποι, ἂν μὴ δανείσῃς, ὀργίζονται.
remarks: Antisthenes' "wealth" is spiritual rather than material; that is why the state does not harass him with demands for taxes and liturgies, nor individuals with requests for loans.  It is striking that Callias here uses the unusual oath invocation of Hera, otherwise only found (with a few exceptions- see oath id 2281) in informal oaths of Socrates (see oath id 1870 with cross references). However, it is noteworthy that Callias is actually from the same deme as Socrates: Alopeke.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That they must now turn their attention to the question of whether or not their chosen method of community of wives and children among the guardians is consistent with the rest of their state, and is the best method by far]
 Ἡ μὲν δὴ κοινωνία, ὦ Γλαύκων, αὕτη τε καὶ τοιαύτη γυναικῶν τε καὶ παίδων τοῖς φύλαξί σοι τῆς πόλεως· ὡς δὲ ἑπομένη τε τῇ ἄλλῃ πολιτείᾳ καὶ μακρῷ βελτίστη, δεῖ δὴ τὸ μετὰ τοῦτο βεβαιώσασθαι παρὰ τοῦ λόγου. ἢ πῶς ποιῶμεν; Οὕτω νὴ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That it is not possible for a person who lacks concern to make others show concern]
 εἰ οἷόν τέ ἐστιν ἀμελῆ αὐτὸν ὄντα ἄλλους ποιεῖν ἐπιμελεῖς. Οὐ μὰ Δί’

title: IG XII 5
if_taken: The agreement and reconciliation will be formalised
statement:
[That they would not be persuaded by anyone transgressing the agreement, but help with all their strength to abide by the agreements; and they would not assist..] 
 οὐ πείσομ[αι τῶι  παραβάντι ἀλλὰ βοηθήσω παντὶ σ]θένει̣ τ̣οῖς ἐμμέν[οσι τῆις συνθήκαις - - - - ]σιν ο[ὐδὲ ἐπ]ιτ̣ρ̣ε̣ψω̣ τ[- - -]
remarks:
This inscription records the agreement and reconciliation between Thasos and the Neapolitans in Thrace. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 38.852.  
For the oath of the Thasians see oath id 912.

author: Eupolis
title: Poleis
statement: n/a
remarks: Someone here asks what matter is declared impossible on oath by the Athenians, i.e. that Athenians never swear that anything is impossible.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Euthycles warns the jurors that even if the decree is advantageous, it is disadvantageous to them if they vote to ratify a decree which Aristocrates cannot prove to have been drawn up justly, when they have sworn "to judge according to the law" (κατὰ τοὺς νόμους δικάσειν), and they are all bound to place the greatest value on keeping the oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Shows Sophocles supporting Aeschylus against Euripides
statement:
[That Sophocles did not seize Aeschylus' throne of tragedy]
  ΞΑ.  Κἄπειτα πῶς 
  οὐ καὶ Σοφοκλέης ἀντελάβετο τοῦ θρόνου;
  ΟΙ.  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἐκεῖνος
remarks: See Sommerstein ad 738 on the identity of the slave.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement: [That they will conspire against the people]
remarks: Here Paphlagon claims that he has put a stop to the conspirators himself. The (alleged) conspirators referred to here are not necessarily, or even probably, those of 236 etc. (see oath id 975); a claim to have “put a stop” to them would not have much plausibility, when their leader is still fighting, on at least level terms, to overthrow Paphlagon. Wasps 488ff. suggests that Cleon “detected” a new “subversive ring” roughly every week or so …

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates catalogues the crimes of the Spartans. He notes that they sacked and razed Mantinea "after the peace was made", and they have occupied the Cadmea at Thebes, and now are laying siege to Olynthus and Phlius. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The prosecutor argues that the Athenian jurors did not allow the services Timotheus the son of Conon rendered to the state to outweigh their oaths, and that the jurors should not do so presently. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: The brother of the King's wife; Tissaphernes
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
Xenophon describes how he responded to the comments of Ariaeus, saying that "if Clearchus really was transgressing the truce in violation of his oath, he has his deserts, for it is right that perjurers should perish". 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2105.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes begins by urging the jurors to pay heed to their oath "to give an equal hearing to both sides" (τὸ ὁμοίως ἀμφοῖν ἀκροάσασθαι). 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_broken: Let some stranger cut his head from his shoulders
statement:
[That if Pandarus ever gets home, he will break his bow and throw it into the shining fire]
  εἰ δέ κε νοστήσω καὶ ἐσόψομαι ὀφθαλμοῖσιν
πατρίδ’ ἐμὴν ἄλοχόν τε καὶ ὑψερεφὲς μέγα δῶμα, 
αὐτίκ’ ἔπειτ’ ἀπ’ ἐμεῖο κάρη τάμοι ἀλλότριος φὼς
εἰ μὴ ἐγὼ τάδε τόξα φαεινῷ ἐν πυρὶ θείην 
χερσὶ διακλάσσας· ἀνεμώλια γάρ μοι ὀπηδεῖ.
remarks: Pandarus' statement is uttered in frustration at his bow missing Diomedes. Cf. oath id 321 for similar self-curse as oath.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That he cannot say why 'fire' is called the way it is]
 ἀπόκριναι γάρ μοι· ἔχοις ἂν εἰπεῖν πῦρ κατὰ τίνα τρόπον καλεῖται; {ΕΡΜ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Coloneus
swearer: Amphiaraus; Tydeus; Eteoclus; Hippomedon; Capaneus; Parthenopaeus; Polynices
swearee: Amphiaraus; Tydeus; Eteoclus; Hippomedon; Capaneus; Parthenopaeus; Polynices
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would take Thebes or die]
remarks: Cf. oath id 198.

title: IG XII 8
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text indicates that on the re-establishment of democracy at Thasos, all the Athenians and Thasians (except those who established the oligarchy) are to swear an oath. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 38.851.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
statement:
[That the Athenians must not call on a politician who is trying to give them the best advice to move a decree declaring war]
 ταῦτα τοίνυν ἕκαστον εἰδότα καὶ γιγνώσκοντα παρ’ αὑτῷ δεῖ μὰ Δί’ οὐ γράψαι κελεύειν πόλεμον τὸν τὰ βέλτιστ’ ἐπὶ πᾶσι δικαίοις συμβουλεύοντα·
remarks: The point seems to be that it is pointless arguing whether to make a formal declaration of war when Athens is de facto at war already; practical measures are what matters.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
The Peace of Nicias was only partially successful in that many of the allies in the Peloponnesian league refused to accept it. As Sommerstein explains, the reference here is to "a decision taken during the winter of 419/8. The Spartans had put a garrison into Epidaurus, Epidaurus then being at war with Argos, and ally of Athens since 420. Argos demanded Athenian retaliation against Sparta notwithstanding the Athenian-Sparta peace treaty of 421, and on the proposal of Alcibiades..the Athenian Assembly voted..to inscribe upon the stone slab (stele) recording the treaty of 421 the words "The Spartans have not kept their oaths". The proper Athenian course, if they considered Sparta had broken the treaty of 421, should have been to demand arbitration".  
See oath id 1681 for further details on the Peace of Nicias.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That men make libations in the Assembly]
 καὶ νὴ Δία σπένδουσί γ’·
remarks: Men did not pour libations in the Assembly (neither did they drink- cf. remarks on oath id 785), but it is evident that the speaker sincerely believes they do; they utter long prayers [before the proceedings begin], therefore there must be libations too; they revile each other, etc.  So this oath is not true, but the speaker is not lying either.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
statement:
[That what he has heard about rhetoric is not exactly what Socrates says]
 ἢ πῶς σὺ ταῦτ’ ἀκήκοας;  {ΦΑΙ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ παντάπασιν οὕτως
remarks: Socrates has suggested that the art of rhetoric is concerned with great issues and small issues, with its correct employment deserving no more respect when dealing with important matters than with unimportant. Phaedrus suggests that it is only with lawsuits and public speaking that the art of rhetoric is concerned.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus tells the jurors that when they had exchanged the oaths (see oath id 3623), and the agreement had been deposited with Androcleides, he divided the property of Comon into two shares: the first consisted of Comon's house and the slaves engaged in weaving sack-cloth; the second comprised another house and the slaves engaged in making dyes.

author: Aristotle
title: Politics
statement: n/a
remarks: This is Aristotle's response to Hippodamus' proposals for jurors to avoid the possibility of being forced to commit perjury (see remarks on id 1618). He gives an example based on Hippodamus' principles. If a man is sued for twenty mnai, and each jury member gives a verdict of what he actually thinks the man owes, one juror may judge he owes ten mnai, another five, another four and so on. The verdict will be confused. But, Aristotle argues, the juror who believes the man owes some money but not twenty mnai is NOT in fact committing perjury if he acquits the man, since he is not giving a judgement that the defendant owes nothing, simply that he does not owe twenty mnai. It is only a juror who gives a verdict condemning the defendant when he does not think he owes twenty mnai who is committing perjury.

author: Antiphon
title: Proems and Perorations
statement:
[That he brought this indictment because he had been much wronged by the defendant]
Ἐγραψάμην ταύτην τὴν γραφὴν ἠδικημένος ὑπὸ τούτου νὴ Δία πολλά, ἔτι δὲ καὶ πλείω ὑμᾶς ᾐσθημένος ἠδικημένους καὶ τοὺς ἄλλους πολίτας
remarks: For all we know, the speaker may be of any adult age, from a young sykophant to an elderly personal enemy of the defendant.  The position of the swearing formula strongly suggests that he is swearing only to the statement that he has himself been greatly wronged by the defendant (something that should if possible be emphasized by the prosecutor in a graphe, as a protection against the suspicion of sykophancy), not to the further statement that the defendant had wronged the jurors and their fellow citizens even more.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That he came to Thebes of his own free will]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία, εἴποι ἄν τις, ἑκὼν ἦλθε.
remarks:
Euphron was driven from power in Sicyon in 366, but was restored with the help of Athenian mercenaries.  
Because the acropolis at Sicyon was held by Theban troops, Euphron travelled to Thebes with the intention of persuading the Thebans to banish the aristocrats and hand the city over to him. He was slain in front of the Theban boule in the Cadmea by two Sicyonian exiles who feared that he would persuade the Thebans to assist him. 
His assassins were put on trial at Thebes. This hypothetical oath is included in the speech of the defence. 
The defence raises an imaginary objection to their assertion that Euphron was an enemy of Thebes i.e. that Euphron came to Thebes of his own free will, and therefore ought to have been protected. The defence goes on to refute this imaginary objection by arguing that Euphron had come to Thebes to do further harm to Sicyon.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Messenians at Naupactus as allies. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That he would welcome Philip's death]
 ὤμνυες ἦ μὴν ἀπολωλέναι Φίλιππον ἂν βούλεσθαι·
remarks: Demosthenes addresses Eubulus, and asks how he can defend Aeschines given that he swore an oath by his children in the ecclesia that he would welcome Philip's death.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Blepyrus would not even had got anything if he had come at the second cock-crow]
 οὐδ’ εἰ μὰ Δία τότ’ ἦλθες ὅτε τὸ δεύτερον
  ἁλεκτρυὼν ἐφθέγγετ’.
remarks: This is an even grosser exaggeration than the informal oath at 377, since, as Sommerstein notes, the women had not even gathered for their practice session at the second cock-crow. Cf. also 553.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
According to the text, if anyone pays to ransom a prisoner, the prisoner shall then be in the power of the one who freed him until he repays the ransom fee. But if they disagree on the amount, or on the ground that he did not request to be ransomed, the judge will decide under oath (ὀμνύντα), with reference to the pleas. 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
statement:
[That Silenus will not weep (at the Cyclops' suggestion) since he loves the wine which does not love him] 
 Κυ. κλαύσηι, φιλῶν τὸν οἶνον οὐ φιλοῦντα σέ.
Σι.  οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἐπεί μού φησ’ ἐρᾶν ὄντος καλοῦ.
remarks: οὐ at the start of Silenus' reply is an emendation by Diggle, and Seaford (1984) ad loc. comments: 'L's ναὶ may be right: Sil. affirms what he implies in 553, and contradicts Od.: 'Yes, by Jove, (he does love me) since he says he is in love with me for my good looks'.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides refers here to the alliance between Athens and King Sitalces of Thrace. 
For other references to this oath see oath id 1570 and 1571.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: The relief of this inscription shows Athena clasping the hand of another goddess. The word Κίος also appears in the relief. This implies that this decree referred to an alliance between Athens and Cios.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Athens at the outbreak of the war in 431 as: 
Chios, Lesbos, Plataea (allied since 519), the Messenians in Naupactus (allied since ca.461), the Acarnanians (allied since 431), Corcyra (allied since 434/3), Zacynthus, some cities in Caria, the Dorians adjacent to Caria, Ionia, the Hellespont, the coast of Thrace and the Cyclades except Melos and Thera (each of these poleis presumably became allies at the same time as Chios and Lesbos). 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That the jurors got up late that day (because they haven't yet called for Philocleon)]
  νὴ τὸν Δί’, ὀψὲ γοῦν ἀνεστήκασι νῦν.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: The fire in Xanthos may be quenched
impact: Xanthos leaves Achilles alone and Hera in turn stops Hephaestus from boiling Xanthos
statement:
[That he will not intervene on behalf on the Trojans even if Troy is sacked]
 ἐγὼ δ’ ἐπὶ καὶ τόδ’ ὀμοῦμαι, 
μή ποτ’ ἐπὶ Τρώεσσιν ἀλεξήσειν κακὸν ἦμαρ,
μὴ δ’ ὁπότ’ ἂν Τροίη μαλερῷ πυρὶ πᾶσα δάηται 
καιομένη, καίωσι δ’ ἀρήϊοι υἷες Ἀχαιῶν.
remarks: The text of this oath is identical to Hera's oath referenced at oath id 415. Here the oath is volunteered under duress, however.

author: Alexis
title: Phaidros
statement:
[That he does not know what love is]
 καὶ ταῦτ’ ἐγώ, μὰ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν καὶ θεούς,
οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅ τι ἐστίν
remarks:
The implication is that the speaker is involved in an unhappy love affair, following from lines 1-2, where he says that he fell to philosophizing about love “because of my troubles and my despair” while walking to town from Peiraeus. 
 On possible Platonic allusions, see Arnott's introduction to Alexis' Phaidros.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
impact: Stresses the effort that is being put in
statement:
[That they are heaving]
  Εἶα, νὴ Δία.
remarks: On the fluctuating identity of the Chorus in this play, see Sommerstein (ed) xviii-xix.

author: Lysias
title: Against Eratosthenes
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal, maintain secrecy, and overthrow the democracy]
remarks:
Lysias states that after the battle of Aegospotami, while there was still democracy at Athens, five men were appointed as ephors by the so-called 'hetairoi' to be organisers of the citizens and leaders of the sworn conspirators, and to oppose democracy. He states that Eratosthenes and Critias were among these five. 
See also oath id 2823.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_taken: They would prevent the case from being postponed
if_refused: They would not prevent the case from being postponed
statement: [That Olympiodorus was not unable to attend due to military service]
remarks:
Callistratus tells the jurors that when the Archon summoned into court all those who were filing claims according to the law, he entered a sworn statement (see oath id 3628), asking for a postponement on the ground that Olympiodorus was abroad on military service. However, their opponents swore a counter-hypomosia, and convinced the jurors that Olympiodorus had left Athens on account of the trial. 
The exact mechanics of this procedure are unclear. If a hypomosia is submitted on behalf of one party, justice might seem obviously to demand that the presiding magistrate should then turn to the other party and ask him "Have you got anyone who is willing to swear the contrary?"  If both parties swore, the jury had to vote, after hearing speeches, on the question which of them was telling the truth, and according to how they voted, either a postponement was allowed, or the case was decided against the absent party by default  (see also oath id 3720).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement:
[That a patriotic citizen should never abandon his city's interests, hire himself out to her adversaries and watch out for opportunities favourable to her enemies rather than to his own country]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’οὐκ ἀποστάντα τῶν συμφερόντων τῇ πόλει, μισθώσαντα δ’αὑτὸν τοῖς ἐναντίοις, τοὺς ὑπὲρ τῶν ἐχθρῶν καιροὺς ἀντὶ τῶν τῆς πατρίδος θεραπεύειν,

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That the Triballian is not saying that they should hand over the girl to Peisetaerus]
 Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐχ οὗτός γε παραδοῦναι λέγει
remarks: Although, as Sommerstein notes, the word παραδίδωμι "hand over" is the only clear Greek word in the Triballian's statement, and the Triballian does indeed seem to be advocating the handover of the girl, Poseidon's suggestion that the Triballian is not speaking Greek but "twittering like the swallows" would imply that the Triballian's words cannot be understood as clear Greek. Poseidon's statement seems false, but we may be meant to understand that he is deceiving himself.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That taking a friend's sword for fear that he will do himself harm is not an unjust act]
 ἐάν τις, ἐν ἀθυμίᾳ ὄντος φίλου, δείσας μὴ διαχρήσηται ἑαυτόν, κλέψῃ ἢ ἁρπάσῃ ἢ ξίφος ἢ ἄλλο τι τοιοῦτον, τοῦτο αὖ ποτέρωσε θετέον; Καὶ τοῦτο νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, πρὸς τὴν δικαιοσύνην.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he cannot tell which rhythms are appropriate to an orderly and courageous man]
 οἵτινες δ’ ἂν εἶεν οὗτοι οἱ ῥυθμοί, σὸν ἔργον, ὥσπερ τὰς ἁρμονίας, φράσαι.  Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ ἔχω λέγειν.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That useless persons are incapable of forming friendships with useful ones]
 οἶσθά τινας οἳ ἀνωφελεῖς ὄντες ὠφελίμους δύνανται φίλους ποιεῖσθαι; Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’, ἔφη·

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines reminds the jurors of the plight of Athens prior to the concluding of the peace and cites a decree proposed by Cephisophon of Paeania, a friend of Chares, that stipulated that Antiochus, the commander of the supply boats, should sail immediately to find Chares, and tell him that the Athenians did not know where he was and were amazed that while Philip was making for the Chersonese [against Athenian interests there] they did not even know the location of the general and the force they had sent out. 
Aeschines goes on to say, "blame the peace on your commanders, not on your ambassadors". 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides observes that even though the Athenians possess the same foundation for success as their ancestors (viz. their walls and fleet - or at least the right to build them, taken away by the peace of 404 but implicitly recognized in the draft treaty under discussion), some say that the peace must not be made. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That he does not know how to ascend to heaven]
 οἶσθα ὅντινα τρόπον ἀναβήσῃ εἰς τὸν οὐρανόν;  {ΑΛ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
if_taken: Their statements will carry more weight
statement: [? That their statements were true]
remarks: Ariston describes how Conon's supporters stretched out the proceedings past midnight by refusing to read their depositions, bringing Ariston's witnesses to the stone one by one and putting them under oath.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he wishes Heracles good health]
  Νὴ Δία καὶ σύ γε  
  ὑγίαινε
remarks: This is a wish reciprocating Heracles' bid of faring well to Dionysus.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds Aeschines and the jurors that they chose him to give the funeral oration, not Aeschines, or even Demades who had "just negotiated the peace" i.e. the League of Corinth. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Plato
title: Letter VII
statement:
[That he is determined to take revenge on Dionysius]
 ὁ δὲ τὸν Δία ἐπιμαρτυράμενος εὐθὺς παρήγγελλεν ἐμοὶ καὶ τοῖς ἐμοῖς οἰκείοις καὶ φίλοις παρασκευάζεσθαι τιμωρεῖσθαι Διονύσιον, ἡμᾶς μὲν ξεναπατίας χάριν—οὕτω γὰρ ἔλεγέν τε καὶ ἐνόει— αὐτὸν δ’ ἐκβολῆς ἀδίκου καὶ φυγῆς.
remarks: Although Plato urges him towards moderation, his advice goes unheeded, but Plato nevertheless presents Dion in a favourable light, arguing that he did not seek power for his own sake but for the sake of public good.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
statement:
[That Odysseus' ship was ready and crewed to take him back to his fatherland]
 ὤμοσε δὲ πρὸς ἔμ’ αὐτόν, ἀποσπένδων ἐνὶ οἴκῳ,
νῆα κατειρύσθαι καὶ ἐπαρτέας ἔμμεν ἑταίρους, 
οἳ δή μιν πέμψουσι φίλην ἐς πατρίδα γαῖαν.
remarks: The oath related here by Odysseus in disguise as the Cretan is entirely fictitious. He tells Penelope the same story at oath id 558, still in disguise.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that a rumour spread even to the Greeks hostile to Athens that Sitalces would lend assistance to the Athenians against them in accordance with the terms of his alliance with Athens. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id. 1567.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
statement: n/a
remarks: The Nurse relates how Zeus is invoked by Medea as protector of oaths. See also oath id 115.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he will not get away with stealing the flute-girl from the party]
 οὔτοι καταπροίξει μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω τοῦτο δρῶν.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That they will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, they shall help with all their strength]
remarks:
When the Thebans invaded Laconia in 370, the Spartans sent envoys to Athens who told the Athenians that they were required by their oaths to come to the aid of the Spartans. 
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That they are not going to share the shit]
  καὶ τῶν πελέθων κοινωνοῦμεν; {Πρ.} μὰ Δί’

author: Aristotle
title: Metaphysics
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a fragment of Empedocles where Strife appoints the members of the Sphere in turn with an oath. Aristotle states that this is the only explanation Empedocles gives concerning the process of change, i.e. that it is so by nature. Empedocles seems to mean – and Aristotle takes him to mean – that there is a sort of treaty between Love and Strife (rather like the one between Eteocles and Polyneices in some versions of the Theban saga) that they should rule the universe in alternation.  As Aristotle says, this is a non-explanation.  The passage, together with references to the foedera naturai in Lucretius, is discussed by Myrto Garani in Sommerstein and Fletcher ed. Horkos (Exeter, 2007) 189-202. Cf. oath id 3342 for Empedocles entry.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he knows no other race of men more stupid than rhapsodes]
  Οἶσθά τι οὖν ἔθνος, ἔφη, ἠλιθιώτερον ῥαψῳδῶν; Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Νικήρατος, οὔκουν ἔμοιγε δοκῶ.
remarks: Niceratus is presumably the son of Nicias, who has a walk-on part in the Republic and is mentioned in the Laches.  His eldest son, another Nicias, was very young in 403 (Lysias 18.10), so he himself must, one would have thought, have been well under thirty in 422.  He is spoken of in 2.3 (cf. 4.8) as recently married; this may be an error by Xenophon, but it is also possible that Niceratus married early (as some men did), that his wife died young, and that the younger Nicias (who himself married early; see D.M. Lewis, ABSA 50 [1955] 30) was born from a second marriage.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
Xenophon states that Olynthian horsemen served with the Spartans during Agesilaus' campaign in Boeotia in 377, "in accordance with their oaths". 
See also oath id 1963.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he thinks a person raised from a low to a middle level, and unaware that there was a top level above it, would inevitably suppose that he had reached the top]
  Οἴει οὖν ἄν τινα ἐκ τοῦ κάτω φερόμενον πρὸς μέσον ἄλλο τι οἴεσθαι ἢ ἄνω φέρεσθαι; καὶ ἐν μέσῳ στάντα, ἀφορῶντα ὅθεν ἐνήνεκται, ἄλλοθί που ἂν ἡγεῖσθαι εἶναι ἢ ἐν τῷ ἄνω, μὴ ἑωρακότα τὸ ἀληθῶς ἄνω;  Μὰ Δί’, οὐκ ἔγωγε, ἔφη, ἄλλως οἶμαι οἰηθῆναι ἂν τὸν τοιοῦτον.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That the man approaching is not a diviner]
  Μάντις τίς ἐστιν; 
  {ΤΡ.}  Οὐ μὰ Δί’
remarks: Hierocles, the man who is approaching, is not just any diviner, but as Trygaeus qualifies: "the oracle-monger from Oreus". See further Sommerstein ad 1046 and 1047.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement:
[Τhat he had made no allegation against Aristarchus]
 μηδὲν εἰρηκέναι κατ’ αὐτοῦ φλαῦρον
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that Meidias denounced Aristarchus in the boule as a murderer, and subsequently swore that he had made no such allegation, and then asked Aristarchus to help settle his dispute with Demosthenes. 
Demosthenes states that Meidias "did not care that he was committing perjury". 
He then calls witnesses to confirm what Meidias did (see oath id 3410).

author: Plato (com.)
title: Hai aph' Hieron
statement:
[That <the swearer would> even <believe the addressee> if s/he were to say that Pamphilus was an embezzler and sykophant]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ εἰ Πάμφιλόν γε φαίης
κλέπτειν τὰ κοίν’ ἅμα τε συκοφαντεῖν.
remarks: The oath statement is based on A. H. Sommerstein's interpretation of the fragment. The statement is, of course, ironic, because the point is that this is NOT at all hard to believe.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would give assistance to the demos of Corcyra in full strength, to the best of their ability, if anyone comes for the purpose of making war either by land or sea, against the land of the Corcyreans, in accordance with the demands of the Corcyreans. Concerning war and peace they would act in accordance with whatever the majority of the allies resolve, and in other respects they would act in accordance with the resolutions of the allies. That this is true they would swear by Zeus and Apollo and Demeter]
 βοηθήσω Κορκυραίων τῶι δήμωι παντὶ σθένει κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν, ἐὰν τις ἴηι ἐπὶ πολέμωι ἤ κατὰ γῆν ἤ κατὰ θάλατταν ἐπὶ τὴγ χώραν τὴγ Κορκυραίων καθ’ [ὅ]τι ἂν ἐπαγγέλλωσι Κορκυραῖοι, καὶ περὶ πολέμου καὶ  εἰρήνης πράξω καθότι ἂν τῶι  πλήθει τῶν συμμάχων δοκῆι, καὶ  τἆλλα ποιήσω κατὰ [τ]ὰ [δ]όγματα τῶν συμμάχων· ἀ̣λ̣ηθ̣ῆ̣ ταῦτα νὴ τὸ[ν] Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω καὶ τὴν Δήμητρα· [ε]ὐο[ρ]κο̃ντι μέμ μοι εἴη πολ[λ]ὰ καὶ  ἀγαθά, εἰ δὲ [μή], τἀναντία.
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Corcyra. 
This oath and alliance are presumably a follow-up alliance to that in oath id 353-357. For the corresponding oath of the Corcyreans see oath id 402.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Philoctemon
statement:
[That no grudge ought to be held against Phanostratus and Chaerestratus because they are rich, but against his opponents if they obtain what does not belong to them]
 Ὥστ’ οὐ φθονεῖσθαί εἰσιν ἄξιοι, ἀλλὰ πολὺ μᾶλλον, νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω, οὗτοι, εἰ λήψονται ἃ μὴ προσήκει αὐτοῖς.
remarks: The speaker argues that Phanostratus and Chaerestratus have benefited the state through liturgies, and will do so again if they are allowed to inherit the estate of Philoctemon, whereas their opponents will squander the money and offer no benefit to the state.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he is not up to any mischief]
 ἅνθρωπος οὗτος μέγα τι δρασείει κακόν. 
 {Φι.}  μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’
remarks: As Sommerstein ad 168 remarks: "mischief or harm (kakon) is indeed exactly what Philocleon wants to do and complains his son is preventing him from doing (322, 340)". It may depend on what we mean by "harm".  He might be assuming (or pretending to assume) that his son is accusing him of wanting to do something detrimental to his own or his son’s interests; whereas in fact Bdel.’s words mean either “he’s wanting to harm other people” (viz. defendants) or just “he’s being naughty/disobedient” (as a parent might say of a child).

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That he can find no more decorous way of referring to the grotesque acts that Timarchus has practised]
 οὐ γὰρ ἔχω μὰ τὸν Δία τὸν Ὀλύμπιον τίνα τρόπον εὐφημότερον μνησθῶ τῶν σοὶ καταγελάστως πεπραγμένων ἔργων.
remarks: Aeschines is explaining his use of the term "furnishing pleasures" to describe the activities of Timarchus.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he has been to Delphi twice]
 καὶ ὁ Σωκράτης, Εἰπέ μοι, ἔφη, ὦ Εὐθύδημε· εἰς Δελφοὺς δὲ ἤδη πώποτε ἀφίκου; Καὶ δίς γε νὴ Δί’, ἔφη.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2132.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he will put a stop to Cinesias' blasts (of poetry)]
  Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἦ ’γώ σου καταπαύσω τὰς πνοὰς.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That he does not believe there are five metics who are currently exempt from performing liturgies]
 καὶ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ὅπερ εἶπον ἀρτίως, οὐκ οἶμαι πέντε εἶναι.

author: Plato
title: Hipparchus
statement:
[That there is nothing good that he does not love]
 Ἔστι δέ τι ἀγαθόν, ὃ οὐ φιλεῖς, ἀλλὰ κακόν; {ΕΤ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement: n/a
remarks: Here, those who have sworn a perjured oath are listed among the criminals who lie in the Underworld's sea of mud and ever-flowing dung.  Cf. oath id 388.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Theocrines
if_taken: He would prevent the case from being postponed
if_refused: He would not prevent the case from being postponed
statement: [? That Demosthenes was not unwell, and could attend]
remarks:
Epichares claims that when Theocrines once launched a graphe paranomon against Demosthenes, and the latter sent someone to swear that he was unable to attend the trial due to illness (see oath id 3719), Theocrines did not swear a counter-hypomosia even though Demosthenes was going around abusing Aeschines. 
The exact mechanics of this procedure are unclear. If a hypomosia is submitted on behalf of one party, justice might seem obviously to demand that the presiding magistrate should then turn to the other party and ask him "Have you got anyone who is willing to swear the contrary?"  If both parties swore, the jury had to vote, after hearing speeches, on the question which of them was telling the truth (Dem. 48.25), and according to how they voted, either a postponement was allowed, or the case was decided against the absent party by default (see also oath id 3628 and 3736).

author: Lysias
title: Against Alcibiades 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker concludes by asking that the laws, oaths and indictment be read to the jurors. He urges the jurors to bear these in mind and vote what is just. 
The laws, oaths and indictment are then read to the jurors. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

title: IG XII Supplement
swearer: The father of the young man
if_taken: He can introduce his son to the phratry
if_refused: He cannot introduce his son to the phratry
statement:
[That he believes he is the father of the young man]
 ἐπὶ τὴν ἱστίην ὀμνύτω [καὶ μάρτυρας δ]ύ[ο] παρεχέτω ὀμνύντας οἰόμενον·
remarks:
The text indicates that any man introducing a son has to provide two witnesses who will swear that he believes he is the father of the young man. For the oath sworn by the witnesses see oath id 729.  
For the oath sworn by the mother see oath id 730.  
For oaths sworn when an elder brother or an uncle introduced a young man to the phratry see oath id 731 and 732.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she wants a pillow]
 προσκεφάλαιον οὐκ ἔχεις. 
{ΚΙ.}  Ἀλλ’ οὐ δέομ’ οὐδὲν ἔγωγε.
{ΜΥ.}  Νὴ Δί’ ἀλλ’ ἐγώ.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
statement:
[That he will boldly tell the Athenians the whole truth and hold nothing back]
 ἐγὼ νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς τἀληθῆ μετὰ παρρησίας ἐρῶ πρὸς ὑμᾶς καὶ οὐκ ἀποκρύψομαι·
remarks: The "whole truth" (or what D. claims to be such) in this case is that his reason for denouncing those who misled the Athenians into agreeing to the Peace is his fear that when the people fully perceive how dangerous it has made Philip, they will not direct their anger at the people responsible but will lash out wildly at any target in range including himself.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That she will not tolerate Xanthias' refusal to come in and dine with Persephone]
  ΞΑ.  Κάλλιστ’, ἐπαινῶ. 
  ΘΕ.  Μὰ τὸν ᾿Απόλλω οὐ μή σ’ ἐγὼ 
  περιόψομἀπελθόντ’
remarks: It is unclear why Xanthias at first refuses the invitation to come in; see Sommerstein ad 508, who suggests that it may be because the Maid "is somewhat elderly or at any rate not outstandingly attractive".  The Maid believes him to be Heracles, whose garb and attributes he is at this moment wearing.  On the gender of the speaker, see A.H. Sommerstein in De Martino & Sommerstein ed. Lo spettacolo delle voci (Bari, 1995) ii 72-73; it is usually males who swear by Apollo, but this is not an invariable rule, as is shown by Lysistrata 917 (oath id 1206).  This speaker is a servant of Persephone, and in drama and real life alike the personal servants of women were nearly always female.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the other Dorians of Sicily
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the other Dorians of Sicily
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: These cities became involved in warfare against the other Greeks in Sicily and the Athenians
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides states that at the time of the outbreak of war in Sicily in 427, all the Dorian cities except for Camarina were allies to Syracuse.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [? That he does not owe Apollodorus 44 minas, 38 drachmas and 2 obols]
remarks:
Apollodorus relates how Timotheus has committed perjury in the past (see oath id 3664), and asks the jurors whether it was strange that he refused to allow Timotheus to swear an oath to him when he was not ashamed to deceive the demos, and does not fear the gods in whose name he has perjured himself. 
See also oath id 3662.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades II
statement:
[That if, under the misguided  delusion that he should kill Pericles, he went to the house of Pericles and saw him but thought he was someone else, he would not venture to kill him]
 Εἰ οὖν παρελθὼν εἴσω καὶ ἰδὼν αὐτὸν ἐκεῖνον ἀγνοήσαις τε καὶ οἰηθείης ἂν ἄλλον εἶναί τινα, ἆρ’ ἔτι ἂν αὐτὸν τολμήσαις ἀποκτεῖναι;  {ΑΛ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, οὐκ ἄν μοι δοκῶ.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
Andocides cites the truce between the Athenians and the Persians in 424/3 (negotiated, he claims, by his uncle Epilycus) as an example of how the Athenians traditionally make war for the sake of others when it is possible for them to make peace for their own sake. He states that after the Athenians made peace with the Great King they chose the friendship of Amorges, the bastard son of Pissuthnes the satrap of Sardis (Andocides describes him as a runaway slave) who revolted from the Great King. 
Andocides claims the Great King consequently became an ally of Sparta  and provided them with five thousand talents to prosecute the war until he had overthrown the power of the Athenians. 
See also oath id 519.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That the young man should go back to Dionysodorus and ask him how to use each formation of men in different strategic situations]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, πάλιν τοίνυν ἐλθὼν ἐπανερώτα·
remarks: Cf. oath ids 2072 and 2073. All the informal oaths in this section have to do with Dionysodorus' failure to teach the art of generalship appropriately.

author: Isocrates
title: Concerning the team of horses
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
The speaker - Alcibiades the younger - reminds the jurors that his father caused the most powerful cities in the Peloponnese to revolt from the Spartans and brought them into alliance with Athens. 
This must be a reference to the alliance between Athens, Argos, Mantinea and Elis ca.420 (see also oath id 251).

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That Ischomachus is taking strong precautions not to lose the name 'gentleman' that he has been called]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ, φυλάττῃ γὰρ ἰσχυρῶς μὴ ἀποβάλῃς τὴν ἐπωνυμίαν, τὸ ἀνὴρ καλὸς κἀγαθὸς κεκλῆσθαι.
remarks: Ischomachus is staying in the Agora to wait for his guests, as he has promised, even at the cost of neglecting his own business.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the scroll she has (which explains the new law) will make Epigenes do what the old woman wants]
 κοὐκ ἂν πιθοίμην οὐδέποτ’. {Γρ. α} ἀλλά, νὴ Δία,
  ἀναγκάσει τουτί σε.
remarks: According to the new rules, the young man must first "screw" an old or ugly woman before he can "screw" his young girlfriend. The old woman will now read him out this new law; cf. oath id 839.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That if the archer touches her even with the tip of his finger, he will soon he begging for a cupping-vessel]
 Εἰ τἄρα νὴ τὴν Φωσφόρον τὴν χεῖρ’ ἄκραν 
  ταύτῃ προσοίσεις, κύαθον αἰτήσεις τάχα.
remarks: The second old woman here reinforces the oaths sworn by both Lysistrata and the the first old woman (see ids 1174 and 1175) that whoever lays a finger on Lysistrata will regret it. Hecate is also called 'Light-Bringer' in Aristophanes at Thesm. 858 and fr. 608 K-A. Sommerstein ad 444 explains the phrase "you'll soon be begging for a cupping vessel" as follows: "i.e. [he] will get a black eye… and want to use a kyathos, a bronze vessel that could be applied to the skin for the relief of bruises and swellings".

author: Euripides
title: Electra
statement: n/a
remarks: The Dioscuri remark on the dangers of sharing a voyage with perjured men, in that such men incur divine punishment.

author: Hippocrates
title: Oath
if_taken: Student will be allowed to learn medicine
if_refused: Student will not be allowed to learn medicine
if_kept: He will enjoy the benefits both of his life and his skill and be held in good repute among all forever
if_broken: He will not enjoy the benefits of his life and his skill and will not be held in good repute
impact: Protects the interests of the patient
statement:
[That the swearer will regard his teacher as equal to his parents, and share his livelihood with the teacher and give him a share when he is in need of necessities, and that he will judge his teacher's offspring as equal to his siblings and that he will teach them his skill should they desire to learn it, without fee and written covenant, and that he will give a share of all his learning to his own sons and the sons of his teacher and to the pupils who have made a written contract with him and sworn the medic's oath, but will not teach his skill to any other. He will use regimens for the benefit of the ill in accordance with his ability and judgement and will keep the ill from harm or injustice. He will not give a drug that is deadly to anyone if asked for it, nor will he suggest any such thing, nor give a woman a destructive pessary. He will guard his life and his skill in a pure and holy manner. He will not cut patients, not even those suffering from stone, but will cede this to men who are practitioners of this activity. Into as many houses as he enters, he will go for the benefit of the ill, while being far from all voluntary and destructive injustice, especially from sexual acts both upon women's bodies and upon men's, both of the free and of slaves. About whatever he may see or hear in treatment, or even without treatment, in the life of human beings, he will remain silent, holding such things unutterable (sacred, not to be divulged)]
  Ὄμνυμι Ἀπόλλωνα ἰητρὸν, καὶ Ἀσκληπιὸν, καὶ Ὑγείαν, καὶ 
Πανάκειαν, καὶ θεοὺς πάντας τε καὶ πάσας, ἵστορας ποιεύμενος, 
ἐπιτελέα ποιήσειν κατὰ δύναμιν καὶ κρίσιν ἐμὴν ὅρκον τόνδε καὶ 
ξυγγραφὴν τήνδε· ἡγήσασθαι μὲν τὸν διδάξαντά με τὴν τέχνην
ταύτην ἴσα γενέτῃσιν ἐμοῖσι, καὶ βίου κοινώσασθαι, καὶ χρεῶν 
χρηΐζοντι μετάδοσιν ποιήσασθαι, καὶ γένος τὸ ἐξ ωὐτέου ἀδελφοῖς
 ἴσον ἐπικρινέειν ἄῤῥεσι, καὶ διδάξειν τὴν τέχνην ταύτην, ἢν χρηΐ-
ζωσι μανθάνειν, ἄνευ μισθοῦ καὶ ξυγγραφῆς, παραγγελίης τε καὶ 
ἀκροήσιος καὶ τῆς λοιπῆς ἁπάσης μαθήσιος μετάδοσιν ποιήσα-
σθαι υἱοῖσί τε ἐμοῖσι, καὶ τοῖσι τοῦ ἐμὲ διδάξαντος, καὶ μαθηταῖσι 
συγγεγραμμένοισί τε καὶ ὡρκισμένοις νόμῳ ἰητρικῷ, ἄλλῳ δὲ 
οὐδενί. Διαιτήμασί τε χρήσομαι ἐπ’ ὠφελείῃ καμνόντων κατὰ δύ-
ναμιν καὶ κρίσιν ἐμὴν, ἐπὶ δηλήσει δὲ καὶ ἀδικίῃ εἴρξειν. Οὐ
δώσω δὲ οὐδὲ φάρμακον οὐδενὶ αἰτηθεὶς θανάσιμον, οὐδὲ ὑφηγήσο-
μαι ξυμβουλίην τοιήνδε· ὁμοίως δὲ οὐδὲ γυναικὶ πεσσὸν φθόριον 
δώσω. Ἁγνῶς δὲ καὶ ὁσίως διατηρήσω βίον τὸν ἐμὸν καὶ τέχνην
τὴν ἐμήν. Οὐ τεμέω δὲ οὐδὲ μὴν λιθιῶντας, ἐκχωρήσω δὲ ἐργά- 
τῃσιν ἀνδράσι πρήξιος τῆσδε. Ἐς οἰκίας δὲ ὁκόσας ἂν ἐσίω, ἐσελεύ- 
σομαι ἐπ’ ὠφελείῃ καμνόντων, ἐκτὸς ἐὼν πάσης ἀδικίης ἑκουσίης 
καὶ φθορίης, τῆς τε ἄλλης καὶ ἀφροδισίων ἔργων ἐπί τε γυναι- 
κείων σωμάτων καὶ ἀνδρῴων, ἐλευθέρων τε καὶ δούλων. Ἃ δ’ ἂν ἐν
θεραπείῃ ἢ ἴδω, ἢ ἀκούσω, ἢ καὶ ἄνευ θεραπηΐης κατὰ βίον ἀνθρώ-
πων, ἃ μὴ χρή ποτε ἐκλαλέεσθαι ἔξω, σιγήσομαι, ἄῤῥητα ἡγεύμενος 
εἶναι τὰ τοιαῦτα. Ὅρκον μὲν οὖν μοι τόνδε ἐπιτελέα ποιέοντι,
καὶ μὴ ξυγχέοντι, εἴη ἐπαύρασθαι καὶ βίου καὶ τέχνης δοξαζομένῳ 
παρὰ πᾶσιν ἀνθρώποις ἐς τὸν αἰεὶ χρόνον· παραβαίνοντι δὲ καὶ
ἐπιορκοῦντι, τἀναντία τουτέων.
gods_invoked: Apollo; Asclepius; Health; Panacea; All the gods and goddesses
remarks: This oath was taken by those registering as medical students, and itself contains a reference to those who have sworn it (15). The oath statement is based on the translation of H. Von Staden in "In a pure and holy way': Personal and Professional Conduct in the Hippocratic Oath' in the 'Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Sciences' 51, 404-37.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement: [That he would take Euripides home]
remarks: There is no point in the play where Dionysus swears such an oath; he did make a very strong statement of intent at 66-70, which might (as often in Sophocles, cf. oath ids 236, 263, 270, 285, 289, 292 ) be referred to retrospectively as an oath, but there is no indication that Euripides has been made aware of this. Euripides' words here are the perfect dramatic feed for Dionysus' response (parodying line 612 from the Hippolytus- oath id 125). See also oath ids 376, 711 and 1739.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That what the Sausage-seller has said is much better than what Paphlagon said]
 Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ πολύ γ’ ἄμεινον, ὦ Γλάνι.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Thracian kings
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Thracian kings
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the treaty]
remarks:
This decree records a treaty between Athens and the Thracian kings Berisades, Amadocus and Cersebleptes.  
The text indicates that the poleis in the Chersonese who pay tribute to the Thracian kings and syntaxis to Athens are to be free and autonomous, being allies to the Athenians "in accordance with their oaths", and to be allies with the three kings.  
Cf. Dem. 23.173.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That he does indeed have something to give Lysistrata]
 Δώσεις τί μοι; 
 {ΚΙ.} Ἔγωγε <σοι> νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἢν βούλῃ γε σύ.
remarks: Cinesias initally "indicates his phallus" as Sommerstein has in his stage directions, but then gives in and throws Lysistrata his purse.

author: Eubulus
title: Stephanopolides
statement:
[That the women should not be wandering about with their faces made up]
 μὰ Δί’ οὐχὶ περιπεπλασμέναι ψιμυθίοις
remarks: The speaker is probably female, like those she is criticizing.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Wealth should force the man she has treated well to treat her well in return]
 Ἀναγκάσαι δίκαιόν ἐστι, νὴ Δία,
 τὸν εὖ παθόνθ’ ὑπ’ ἐμοῦ πάλιν μ’ ἀντευποιεῖν.
remarks: The statement expresses the Old Woman's opinion here.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearee: Some Corinthians opposed to the regime
if_taken: The exiles might return to Corinth
statement:
[That they should suffer no harm if they returned home]
 οἳ ὀμνύοντες ὑπισχνοῦντο μηδὲν χαλεπὸν αὐτοὺς πείσεσθαι
remarks:
According to Xenophon (who is more than usually biased in this part of his narrative) "most, and the best" of the Corinthians came to wish for peace, but their allies and those Corinthians who were in Persian pay or had been foremost in promoting the war perpetrated a large-scale massacre of the peace party, marked by many acts of sacrilege. 
After the massacre, many Corinthians fled from the city intending to leave Corinthian territory; some of them were persuaded to return after a group of the ruling faction swore that they would not be harmed if they returned.  And they did indeed live unharmed in Corinth, at least until two of them attempted to betray it to the Spartans (4.4.6-13).

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
statement: [That he will take Philoctetes home]
remarks: Philoctetes has understood that Neoptolemus will bring him home, when in fact the plan is to bring him to Troy. Neoptolemus had never "sworn" to bring Philoctetes home as Philoctetes claims here (and at oath id 289), but swearing words are sometimes used in Sophocles to convey strong affirmation. Cf. oath ids 236, 263, 270, 289, 292.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes complains that Athens has relinquished "all its possessions and allies" and sworn to Philip that if anyone else ever attempts to recover Athens' former possessions and allies they will prevent it, and that they will regard anyone intending to hand them over to them as an opponent and enemy, and anyone who keeps them as a friend. He argues that this is what the Athenians have gained from the peace. 
He also complains that Philocrates and Aeschines have personally profited from the peace at the expense of Athens' former allies. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That all men will agree, and to his mind the gods even more so, that God, and the form of life, and anything else that is immortal can never cease to exist]
 Ὁ δέ γε θεὸς οἶμαι, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, καὶ αὐτὸ τὸ τῆς ζωῆς εἶδος καὶ εἴ τι ἄλλο ἀθάνατόν ἐστιν, παρὰ πάντων ἂν ὁμολογηθείη μηδέποτε ἀπόλλυσθαι. Παρὰ πάντων μέντοι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ἀνθρώπων τέ γε καὶ ἔτι μᾶλλον, ὡς ἐγᾦμαι, παρὰ θεῶν.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker argues that if those who are subservient to the Macedonian king keep insisting that they should abide by the agreement, they should take them at their word since their contention is just, and exclude the guilty parties from the treaty, "as the oath commands". 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement: n/a
remarks: In summing up Menon's character, Xenophon observes that Menon imagined the quickest way to achieve whatever he desired was through perjury, lies and deception.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That it is no trivial task that they have set themselves (i.e. selecting what kind of natures are suited to the guardianship of the state)]
  Μὰ Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, οὐκ ἄρα φαῦλον πρᾶγμα ἠράμεθα·

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks: Xenophon states that the Acarnanians made an expedition against Calydon in 389 and were joined by some Athenians and Boeotians because the Acarnanians were their allies. The Athenian alliance with the Acarnanians must be that of 431. The Thebans presumably assisted because they had become allies of Athens ca.395.

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks: Euxitheus, the defendant, argues that the prosecutor knew that he would find no one to testify against him after taking the oath (διωμοσία) which witnesses were required to take in trials following the traditional homicide procedure; this is why he has chosen instead - improperly, as Euxitheus claims - to use the procedure of endeixis, in which witnesses were not required to swear.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That a great pain has seized him (because no one will laugh at his jokes)]
 Τί τοῦτ’, ἔφη, ὦ Φίλιππε; ἀλλ’ ἢ ὀδύνη σε εἴληφε; καὶ ὃς ἀναστενάξας εἶπε· Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Καλλία, μεγάλη γε·

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus addresses Olympiodorus in court, and tells him (and the jurors) that the fact that he voluntarily withdrew his suit while Olympiodorus was abroad is not consistent with Olympiodorus' allegations that Callistratus has been acting against him all the time (see oath id 3631). Callistratus states that he could have entered his own suit while Olympiodorus was abroad, but did not do so because he would have perjured himself, because he had sworn to do in concert with Olympiodorus whatever he thought best (see oath id 3623).

author: Plato
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he had not heard about the symposium from Socrates himself (but from Aristodemus of Cydathenaeum)]
 ἀλλὰ τίς σοι διηγεῖτο; ἢ αὐτὸς Σωκράτης;”  “Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία,” ἦν δ’ ἐγώ ἀλλ’ ὅσπερ Φοίνικι. Ἀριστόδημος ἦν τις, Κυδαθηναιεύς

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
impact: Shows the woman admitting her mistake
statement:
[That she was wrong to swear by the two goddesses]
 καίτοι τά γ’ ἄλλ’ εἰποῦσα δεξιώτατα.
 {Γυ. α}  ὢ νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω.
remarks: The woman swears here by Apollo, which is normally, but not exclusively (see oath id 1206), a man's oath. The speaker is interrupted by Praxagora before she can make it clear precisely what her oath statement is, but she appears to be admitting her mistake (cf. oath ids 788 and 789) and perhaps was about to offer an excuse or explanation. See Sommerstein ad 160 for further details.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That he would give Naupactus to the Aetolians]
 Ναύπακτον ὀμώμοκεν Αἰτωλοῖς παραδώσειν
remarks: Demosthenes states that the Achaeans are suffering from Philip's oath to hand over Naupactus to the Aetolians.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That Demosthenes is prosecuting him in the manner of a sykophantes in order to get money from him]
 συκοφαντῶ νὴ Δία, ἵν’ ἀργύριον λάβω παρὰ σοῦ.
remarks: Demosthenes asks Aeschines (rhetorically) why he is prosecuting him, and imagines that Aeschines will respond in this way.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That he will not sit down and be quiet unless the Prytaneis raise a motion for peace]
  {ΚΗ.}  Κάθησο, σῖγα.
  {ΔΙ.}  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω ’γὼ μὲν οὔ, 
  ἢν μὴ περὶ εἰρήνης γε πρυτανεύσητέ μοι.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That his mother does not only hinder him from touching her spinning instruments, but he would be hit if he touched them]
 Μὰ Δία, ἔφη, ὦ  Σώκρατες, οὐ μόνον γε διακωλύει, ἀλλὰ καὶ τυπτοίμην ἂν εἰ ἁπτοίμην.

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
statement:
[That what the mnemones know shall be binding]
 ὅ τ[ι] ἂν οἱ μνήμονες εἰδέωσιν, τοῦτο καρτερὸν ε῏ναι.
remarks:
This law provided that no land or houses could be handed over to a board of mnemones in the year of Apollonides (which was either about to start, or had started recently). If anyone wished to bring a suit about land or houses within a period of 18 months, existing procedures would apply whereby the jurors would swear that "what the mnemones know shall be binding". After this period of 18 months has expired, those who held property in the year of Apollonides are to be regarded as the legal owners, and if their title is disputed they are only required to substantiate their claim by an oath.  
For this oath see oath id 1049. The text also stipulates that any Halicarnassian who abides by this law may bring a case, according to the oath taken and agreements recorded in the temple of Apollo.  
For this oath see oath id 1050.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Androtion
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That the Athenians would not molest the Thebans as they departed the island]
remarks:
Diodorus reminds the jurors that they recently sent help to the Euboeans, and within three days got rid of the Thebans under a truce. 
See also oath id 2671.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the allies; Envoys
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the allies; Envoys
remarks:
Aeschines reports that a clause was added at the meeting of the synod of allies which stipulated that any Greek polis that wished should be permitted within the space of three months to have its name inscribed with the Athenians on the same stele, and to share the oaths and agreements. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Lacedaemonian Politeia (except ch.14)
date: During the experience of Xenophon (399 to 355)
swearee: The other members of the sworn band
if_taken: He could be part of a sworn band
if_refused: He could not be part of a sworn band
statement: [? That he would fight while he was alive, and would not regard being alive as more important than being free; that he would not leave his taxiarch or his enomotarch, whether he was alive or dead, and that he would bury the dead among his fellow-fighters, and that he would leave no-one unburied]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the men shout encouragement to the enomotarch or "commander of the sworn band", for it is impossible for each to make his voice travel along the whole enomotia or "sworn band" to the far end. 
See also oath id 1272.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines tells the jurors that they can see Solon, who equipped the democracy with the most noble laws, arrayed against these lawless men (i.e. Ctesiphon and Demosthenes) urging them under no circumstances to set more value on Demosthenes' arguments than on their oaths and the laws. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That if Paphlagon drags the sausage-seller out, he'll have to drag Demosthenes out too]
  Νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ κἀμὲ τἄρ’, ἤνπερ γε τοῦτον ἕλκῃς.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he would not like to employ subjects who he knew served him only by compulsion]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη, τοιούτοις μὲν ἔγωγε ὑπηρέταις, οὓς εἰδείην ἀνάγκῃ ὑπηρετοῦντας, ἀηδῶς ἄν μοι δοκῶ χρῆσθαι·

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That Socrates never stops talking about cobblers and fullers and cooks and doctors (as if they were relevant)]
 Νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ἀτεχνῶς γε ἀεὶ σκυτέας τε καὶ κναφέας καὶ μαγείρους λέγων καὶ ἰατροὺς οὐδὲν παύῃ, ὡς περὶ τούτων ἡμῖν ὄντα τὸν λόγον.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That a man who is slave to eating and drinking, lust, sleep and idleness cannot do his duty to himself or his friends]
 ὁ γὰρ ὑπὸ τούτων κρατούμενος οὔτ’ αὐτὸς ἑαυτῷ δύναιτ’ ἂν οὔτε φίλῳ τὰ δέοντα πράττειν. Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτα, ἔφη.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides observes that the Boeotians are making peace and allowing Orchomenos to be autonomous even though they went to war to prevent this from happening. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians requested a truce to collect their dead
statement: [? That he would not molest the Athenians if they withdrew from the city]
remarks:
When about to besiege the Athenians and the Toronaeans who were occupying the acropolis at Torone, Brasidas proclaimed that the Toronaeans could return to their city if they wished, but sent a herald to the Athenians ordering them to come out under a truce because the land belonged to the Chalcidians. 
The Athenians refused, but requested a truce for the duration of one day so that they might collect their dead. 
See oath id 1675.

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
if_kept: May their polis be free from sickness, and remain unsacked; may the land bear fruit; may women bear children like to their parents; may cattle bear young like to cattle
if_broken: May their polis be afflicted with sickness and be sacked; may the land be barren; may the women and the cattle bear monsters
