statement: [That they would fight while they lived, and not put life before being free, and not desert the taxiarch nor the enomotarch, neither while they live nor when they are dead, and that they would not depart unless the leaders led the way, and they would do whatever the generals command, and they would bury in the same place the dead of those who were allied, and they would leave no one unburied, and when they had been victorious fighting against the barbarians they would (totally destroy and) dedicate a tenth of the city of the Thebans, and that they would not raze Athens or Sparta or Plataea or any of the other poleis that were allied, and not keep them from running water, whether they were friends or enemies]
remarks: Here Theopompus claims that the so-called oath of Plataea is, in fact, spurious. This text was set up in the mid-fourth century. See oath id 338 for further details.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
impact: Induces the birds to make a pact with Peisetaerus
statement:
[That he will not explain his plan to the birds unless they make a pact with him]
  σὺ δὲ τούσδ’ ἐφ’ οἷσπερ τοῖς λόγοις ξυνέλεξ’ ἐγὼ
  φράσον, δίδαξον. 
{ΠΙ.}  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω ’γὼ μὲν οὔ, 
  ἢν μὴ διάθωνταί γ’ οἵδε διαθήκην ἐμοὶ
remarks: The birds immediately agree to this pact, but Peisetaerus makes them swear to it, on which see oath id 642. The plan which Peisetaerus will reveal is for the creation of a bird city in the sky, endorsed by Tereus at 194-195; cf. oath id 635.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the women's leader has done him a real service (by removing the insect that was biting his eye)]
 Νὴ Δί’ ὤνησάς γέ μ’

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 1
statement:
[That he cannot believe that Philip is deliberately acting in such a way that all the fools in Athens know what he is going to do next]
 οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δί’ οὕτω γε προαιρεῖσθαι πράττειν ὥστε τοὺς ἀνοητοτάτους τῶν παρ’ ἡμῖν εἰδέναι τί μέλλει ποιεῖν ἐκεῖνος·

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
impact: Alliance will be formed between Athens and Argos
statement:
[That Argos will be Athens' ally if Athena comes to his assistance]
  καὶ νῦν ἀφ’ ἁγνοῦ στόματος εὐφήμως καλῶ
χώρας ἄνασσαν τῆσδ’ ᾿Αθηναίαν ἐμοὶ
μολεῖν ἀρωγόν· κτήσεται δ’ ἄνευ δορὸς
αὐτόν τε καὶ γῆν καὶ τὸν ᾿Αργεῖον λεὼν 
πιστὸν δικαίως ἐς τὸ πᾶν τε σύμμαχον.
remarks: Orestes' proposition that Argos will be Athens' ally if Athena rescues him will be formally sworn by Orestes only at oath id 222. Alliances between states normally involve an oath in any case, and it is thus reasonable to assume that the present passage implies that an oath will eventually be taken. However, this alliance is unusual in that it is effectively only sworn by one side- Orestes for Argos. Athena's help is seemingly proof enough of Athens' commitment to the agreement.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he is not going to stay there to be cut to pieces]
 οὐ γὰρ μὰ τὴν Δήμητρ’ ἔτ’ ἐνταυθοῖ μενῶ  
  τεμνόμενος.
remarks: Euripides has been trying to shave the Inlaw and, as Sommerstein puts it, "Euripides is not a skilful barber". As line 224 shows, the Inlaw has run away from Euripides, and only returns when Euripides beseeches him "in the gods' name, don't desert me" (228-9).  Thus at the moment when he speaks, the Inlaw fully intends to leave.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that Alcibiades led a force to the Peloponnese to assist the Argives and their allies in settling matters "concerning the alliance" (περὶ τὴν ξυμμαχίαν). 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

title: IG II(2)
swearer: Representatives of the existing allies of Athens
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens, Corcyra, Cephallenia and Acarnania under the auspices of the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 353. For the oaths of the new allied poleis see oath id 355, 356 and 357. 
For other references to the Second Athenian Confederacy see oath id 2974.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Hermes
if_refused: Apollo will only be pleased if Hermes makes the promise
statement:
[That he will not steal Apollo's lyre or bow]
 Δείδια Μαιάδος υἱὲ διάκτορε ποικιλομῆτα 
μή μοι ἀνακλέψῃς κίθαριν καὶ καμπύλα τόξα· 
τιμὴν γὰρ πὰρ Ζηνὸς ἔχεις ἐπαμοίβιμα ἔργα
θήσειν ἀνθρώποισι κατὰ χθόνα πουλυβότειραν.  
ἀλλ’ εἴ μοι τλαίης γε θεῶν μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμόσσαι, 
ἢ κεφαλῇ νεύσας ἢ ἐπὶ Στυγὸς ὄβριμον ὕδωρ, 
πάντ’ ἂν ἐμῷ θυμῷ κεχαρισμένα καὶ φίλα ἔρδοις. 
  Καὶ τότε Μαιάδος υἱὸς ὑποσχόμενος κατένευσε 
μή ποτ’ ἀποκλέψειν ὅσ’ Ἑκηβόλος ἐκτεάτισται,
μηδέ ποτ’ ἐμπελάσειν πυκινῷ δόμῳ·
remarks: Apollo proposes that Hermes should swear "the great oath of the gods, either by nodding his head, or upon the dread water of the Styx" that he will not steal Apollo's lyre or bow. It seems that since Hermes and Apollo are now friends (cf. 507), Apollo feels he cannot really demand an oath, although he would like to, and so gives Hermes the alternative of nodding in assent.  Hermes once more PROMISES rather than swears (cf. oath id 1358) and chooses to nod his head, a much weaker sign of confirmation than the god's oath on Styx. But, he promises more than Apollo had asked for by agreeing never to steal Apollo's property nor to come near his strong room. In return for this promise, Apollo agrees that Hermes will be his greatest friend among both gods and mortals. Furthermore, he rewards Hermes with a gold wand of wealth and fortune to keep him safe.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he wants to be rich]
  Νὴ Δί’ ἐγὼ γοῦν ἐθέλω πλουτῶν

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That if conduct such as Hermogenes describes makes the gods his friends, then they too must take delight in nobility]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, εἰ ἄρα τοιοῦτος ὢν φίλους αὐτοὺς ἔχεις, καὶ οἱ θεοί, ὡς ἔοικε,  καλοκἀγαθίᾳ ἥδονται.
remarks: See oath ids 2261 and 2262 for context.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That those present at the discussion before Socrates' death have his sympathy]
 Νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ὦ Φαίδων, συγγνώμην γε ἔχω ὑμῖν.
remarks: Echecrates expresses sympathy for those present  because at this stage in the narrative Simmias and Cebes seem to have upset all the previous arguments concerning the life of the soul after death, which Phaedo had found so convincing.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
impact: Emphasises the statement; see also remarks
statement:
[That the beetle did not eat the dung-cake]
 Οὐ κατέφαγεν; 
  {ΟΙ. Αʹ}  Μὰ τὸν Δί’
remarks: The beetle technically did eat the dung-cake, but as line 7 makes clear, the slave feels that "eat" is too weak an expression to describe what the beetle did: he seized it, rolled into place with his feet, and guzzled the whole thing. The particle-combination MEN OUN “on the contrary” is used in the same way where “the second speaker … shows that he regards [what the first speaker has said] as inadequate by substituting a stronger form of expression” (Denniston GP 475).

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: The statement has not survived.
remarks:
This inscription records an agreement between Athens and Thespiae. 
The only secure reference to an oath on this very fragmentary decree is line 29 where the text reads: [οἱ δὲ στρ]ατεγοὶ ἐχ[σ]ορκ[όντον]. 
See also Thucydides 6.95.2.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That it is possible for anyone to indict a law]
 ἀλλὰ γράψασθαι νὴ Δί’ ἕκαστον ἔστιν
remarks: Diodorus imagines that someone might object in this way.

author: Plato
title: Ion
statement:
[That he would indeed like to hear what Socrates means (when he says that the same method of inquiry holds for all teachable skills)]
 Οὐκοῦν ἐπειδὰν λάβῃ τις καὶ ἄλλην τέχνην ἡντινοῦν ὅλην, ὁ αὐτὸς τρόπος τῆς σκέψεως ἔσται περὶ ἁπασῶν τῶν τεχνῶν; πῶς τοῦτο λέγω, δέῃ τί μου ἀκοῦσαι, ὦ Ἴων;  {ΙΩΝ.} Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἔγωγε·

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
statement: n/a
remarks: Isocrates argues that the Greeks make peace in vain, for they do not settle their wars, but merely postpone them and wait for the opportune moment when they will have the power to inflict some irreparable disaster upon each other.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Zenothemis
statement:
[That Protus has gone away]
 νὴ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἐκποδών ἐστιν ἅνθρωπος.
remarks: Demon states that Zenothemis was awarded some sort of compensation from Protus as a result of his case against him, and says that he is not pleading for Protus, nor does he care whether Zenothemis accused Protus maliciously. He imagines that someone will respond to his comments in this way, and answers that Zenothemis is responsible for Protus disappearing.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Astyphilus
if_taken: He will not have to give evidence
if_refused: He will have to give evidence
statement: [That he did not know that Thudippus assaulted Euthycrates]
remarks:
The speaker alleges that Hierocles saw Thudippus strike Euthycrates, who died of his injuries a few days later, and calls for him to be summoned to give evidence or swear the oath of ignorance (the exomosia).  
Hierocles swears the exomosia, after which the speaker goes on to say that it is in keeping with Hierocles' character to swear that he is ignorant of facts he knows, yet give his (sworn) pledge to the truth of what did not really happen (i.e. that Astyphilus adopted Cleon as his heir and deposited a will with Hierocles). 
See also oath id 3170.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
swearee: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
statement:
[That they would fight together in attacking the Medes and Persians]
 οὕτω δὴ διαπέμπει πρός τε τοὺς ὑπ’ αὐτὸν πάντας καὶ πρὸς Κροῖσον τὸν Λυδῶν βασιλέα καὶ πρὸς τὸν Καππαδοκῶν καὶ πρὸς Φρύγας ἀμφοτέρους καὶ πρὸς Παφλαγόνας καὶ Ἰνδοὺς καὶ πρὸς Κᾶρας καὶ Κίλικας, τὰ μὲν καὶ διαβάλλων τοὺς Μήδους καὶ Πέρσας, λέγων ὡς μεγάλα τ’ εἴη ταῦτα ἔθνη καὶ ἰσχυρὰ καὶ συνεστηκότα εἰς ταὐτό, καὶ ἐπιγαμίας ἀλλήλοις πεποιημένοι εἶεν, καὶ κινδυνεύσοιεν, εἰ μή τις αὐτοὺς φθάσας ἀσθενώσοι, ἐπὶ ἓν ἕκαστον τῶν ἐθνῶν ἰόντες καταστρέψασθαι. οἱ μὲν δὴ καὶ τοῖς λόγοις τούτοις πειθόμενοι συμμαχίαν αὐτῷ ἐποιοῦντο, οἱ δὲ καὶ δώροις καὶ χρήμασιν ἀναπειθόμενοι· πολλὰ γὰρ καὶ τοιαῦτα ἦν αὐτῷ.
remarks: Apparently the allies were convinced of the need for the alliance by the Assyrian king's suggestions that the Medes and the Persians, who had intermarried, and were powerful nations, would be likely to make war on each of the other nations and subjugate them. Those who were unconvinced by such arguments were apparently bribed to join the alliance. Cf. oath ids 2381, 2385 and 2389. The allies reportedly begin to desert, when the Assyrians are defeated in battle- see oath id 2387; but most of the allies are present for the siege of Babylon- see oath id 2449.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That following the Better Argument's advice will make Pheidippides an imbecile]
  εἰ ταῦτ’, ὦ μειράκιον, πείσει τούτῳ, νὴ τὸν Διόνυσον 
  τοῖς Ἱπποκράτους υἱέσιν εἴξεις καί σε καλοῦσι βλιτομάμμαν.
remarks: Circumstances for verifying the oath do not arise.

title: Rhodes and Osborne, GHI
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Others as ordered by the Chalcidians
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
consequences_of_breach: War with Philip and the ultimate destruction of Olynthus
statement:
[That they would be an ally in accordance with what has been agreed]
 συμμαχήσω κατ̣[ὰ τὰ ὡμολογημένα.]
remarks:
This alliance between Philip II and the cities of Chalcidice is said to have included a special clause stipulating that neither party could negotiate a separate alliance with Athens. 
The text indicates that both parties should swear "without guile and without craft". 
See also oath id 719.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That Critobulus must think himself an even greater fool than Socrates thinks him]
 Οὐκοῦν γελοῖός σοι φαίνομαι εἶναι, ὦ Σώκρατες. Σαυτῷ δὲ πολὺ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, 
γελοιότερος

author: Plato
title: Apologia
statement:
[That he found that those who had the best reputations for wisdom were practically the most deficient, but men who thought themselves inferior were in fact more sensible]
 καὶ νὴ τὸν κύνα, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι— δεῖ γὰρ πρὸς ὑμᾶς τἀληθῆ λέγειν—ἦ μὴν ἐγὼ ἔπαθόν τι τοιοῦτον· οἱ μὲν μάλιστα εὐδοκιμοῦντες ἔδοξάν μοι ὀλίγου δεῖν τοῦ πλείστου ἐνδεεῖς εἶναι ζητοῦντι κατὰ τὸν θεόν, ἄλλοι δὲ δοκοῦντες φαυλότεροι ἐπιεικέστεροι εἶναι ἄνδρες πρὸς τὸ φρονίμως ἔχειν
remarks: Swearing by the "dog" is a favourite expression of the Platonic Socrates. Cf. oath id 2548 with further references.

author: Sophocles
title: Antigone
statement:
[That they had not covered the corpse with dust themselves nor had any knowledge of who had contrived or done so]
 καὶ πῦρ διέρπειν, καὶ θεοὺς ὁρκωμοτεῖν 
τὸ μήτε δρᾶσαι μήτε τῳ ξυνειδέναι
τὸ πρᾶγμα βουλεύσαντι μήτ’ εἰργασμένῳ.
remarks: The guards are "ready" to take the oath (as also to walk through fire or lift lumps of red-hot iron), but this is superseded by the realization that they must tell Creon the news, and the oath is never actually taken.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would defend each other in the event of their being wronged by their enemies, but that the Camarinaeans would receive the Athenians only if they put in with a single ship, unless they themselves sent for more]
remarks:
The Athenians sent an embassy to Camarina in 415. The opening line of the speech of the Athenian envoy is "we had come here for the renewal of the alliance". 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1774, 1788, 1790 and 1791.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of King Croesus but before 550/49 (560 to 550)
proposed_by: Croesus (through his envoys) (male, unknown, unknown, unknown)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be friends and allies without deceit or guile]
 ἄνευ τε δόλου καὶ ἀπάτης
remarks:
Herodotus notes, that when Croesus sent envoys to Sparta seeking an alliance, the Spartans were obliged to make an alliance with Croesus because of certain benefits they had already received from the Lydian king. 
He also described in 82 how the Spartans planned to come to the aid of Croesus in fulfilment of their obligation to him, but ceased their preparations once they learned that he had been defeated by Cyrus.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That his shoulder is hurting]
 Ἴττω Ἡρακλεῖς, ἔκαμόν γα τὰν τύλαν κακῶς.
remarks: The Theban swears in his native dialect by Heracles, who was a favourite Theban deity as Thebes was his birthplace; see also Sommerstein ad loc..

author: Aristotle
title: Politics
if_taken: The man would be excused from office
if_refused: The man would be bound to fufill the duites of a magistrate
impact: Only those wealthy enough hold office
statement: [That he is unable to serve as magistrate]
remarks: This is part of a discussion of ways to ensure that the right people hold office. Here we are told that those who lack the means (i.e. wealth) to hold office (effectively) are permitted to take an oath to decline office. Those who have property are not permitted to take such an oath. This device (and the others discussed in the passage) are used by (some) oligarchic regimes to make them appear more democratic than they really are.  Since these are oligarchies, the offices are, of course, unpaid.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [That they would release Cleomenes and all the men with him]
remarks:
According to Herodotus, after Cleomenes led a Spartan force into Athens and expelled Cleisthenes, he attempted to install Isagoras as tyrant. When the Athenians resisted he seized the Acropolis.  
The Athenians then besieged Cleomenes for two days before he agreed to leave "under a truce" (ὑπόσπονδοι). Details of the statement are found in Aristotle, Ath. Pol. 20.3.10 (oath id 1772).

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Boeotia. 
The identity of the swearers and the nature of their oath are unknown. The terms of the alliance were as follows: "If anyone goes against the Athenians for war either by land or sea the Boeotians shall, in all their strength, as the Athenians call on them; and if anyone goes against the Boeotians for war, either by land or sea, the Athenians shall go in support with all their strength, as the Boeotians call on them, as far as possible..." This entry takes into account the revised text in Athenian Agora 16.34.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That as allies they would be forever guileless and reliable to each other]
remarks:
In 415 Alcibiades advocated going to war in Sicily on the grounds that they had to support their allies. 
Alcibiades asked, "What excuse can we offer to our allies in Sicily for not helping them? This we must do since we swore oaths with them, and we cannot object that they did not help us either". 
After Alcibiades spoke, Egestan and Leontine exiles came forward an encouraged the Athenians to remember their oaths.  
These oaths are presumably a renewal of the alliance from 433 preserved in IG I(3) 54 (see oath id 166-7) and mentioned by Thucydides (see oath id 1662). 
For other references to the alliances between Athens and Leontini see oath id 1765 and 1770.

author: Lysias
title: On overthrowing democracy
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors to bear in mind that those members of the Piraeus party who have the highest reputation, have faced the greatest danger, and have done the demos the most good, have frequently advised them "to abide by the oaths and agreements" i.e. the oaths of reconciliation. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That Echo's intrusion is very irritating indeed]
 Νὴ Δί’ ὀχληρά γ’ εἰσήρρηκας  
  λίαν.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That the pledger had forfeited the pledge]
remarks:
This text concerns disputes over pledged property. If both swear, the pledgee (i.e. the debtor) wins the case. To win his case, the pledgee would have to swear that the pledger had forfeited the pledge (e.g. by not paying his debt, or the interest on it, when due).   
See also oath id 3870.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Menecles
swearer: The speaker and his party; Menecles' brother and his party
swearee: The speaker and his party; Menecles' brother and his party
statement: [That in future they would behave properly towards one another, both in words and deeds, as far as lay in their power]
remarks:
The speaker argues that his opponent must be insane, for after bringing about a settlement of the quarrel, and having sworn oaths, he has now come forward in violation of his acknowledgement and his oaths, and demands that the speaker should be deprived of the remnants of his estate. 
See also oath id 3027.

author: Eriphus
title: Meliboia
statement:
[That they say that the golden apples are those of the Hesperides]
  παρ’ Ἑσπερίδων, ᾤμην γε. {Α.} νὴ τὴν Ἄρτεμιν, 
φασὶν τὰ χρυσᾶ μῆλα ταῦτ’ εἶναι. {Β.} τρία 
μόνον ἐστίν.
remarks: This passage is, according to Athenaeus, plagiarized from id 1395 (see further remarks there). The "golden applens" are apparently citrons.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
if_taken: Secyndianus would entrust himself to him
if_refused: Secyndianus would not entrust himself to him
statement: [That he would not harm Secyndianus]
remarks: Secyndianus is entreated by Menostanes not to trust the oaths of Darius and not to make bargains with deceivers, but Secyndianus does not listen. He trusts in the oaths and is captured as a result, thrown down in the dust, and killed, having reigned for just six months and fifteen days.

author: Euripides
title: Phrixos A-B
impact: Athamas is unsure who to believe
statement:
[That the servant did not receive the seed from Ino's hand]
 ἀπώμοσ]α ὅρκου τ’ ἐκτὸς οὐ ψευδῆ λέγω
μὴ τῆς γ’] ἐ̣μῆς τόνδ’ ὠλένης λαβεῖν <ποτε>.
remarks:
ἀπώμοσ]α Schadewaldt 
μὴ τῆς γ’]  Schadewaldt 
ὠλένης λαβεῖν <ποτε> Sommerstein (cf. Dodds ad Eur. Ba. 1125): ὠλένης χερὸς λαβεῖν Π. It is unclear from the fragmentary evidence whether or not the oath is false. It is at the very least misleading since Ino had, in fact, been responsible for the plan to sow burnt seeds. However, it may be the case that e.g. the slave did not receive the seed "from her hand" because it was sent to him through an agent (possibly one of tragedy's indispensable nurses?).

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
statement: [? That he would not molest the Orchomenians as they withdrew from Boeotia]
remarks: Aeschines states that the Orchomenians begged Philip for a truce guaranteeing their physical safety on condition that they left Boeotia.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That beauty is to be found not only in human beings, but also in horses and oxen and in many inanimate objects]
 Πότερον οὖν ἐν ἀνθρώπῳ μόνον νομίζεις τὸ καλὸν εἶναι ἢ καὶ ἐν ἄλλῳ τινί; Ἐγὼ μὲν ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, καὶ ἐν ἵππῳ καὶ βοῒ καὶ ἐν ἀψύχοις πολλοῖς.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That Carion and the Honest Man are not there for the good of the Informer]
 Οὐκ ἐπ’ ἀγαθῷ γὰρ ἐνθάδ’ ἐστὸν οὐδενί.
  {ΚΑ.}  Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὔκουν τῷ γε σῷ, σάφ’ ἴσθ’ ὅτι.
remarks: The Informer responds with his own emphatic invocation of Zeus at 890- see oath id 896.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Philippides
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Hypereides reminds the jurors that they have sworn to vote according to the laws (κατὰ τοὺς νόμους ψηφιεῖσθ̣αι). 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
impact: Emphasises Theseus' unjust treatment of him
statement:
[That he is not an evil man]
 Ζεῦ, μηκέτ’ εἴην εἰ κακὸς πέφυκ’ ἀνήρ·

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he has a selectively good memory]
  εἰ μνημονικὸς εἶ.
{Στ.}  δύο τρόπω, νὴ τὸν Δία.
remarks: Strepsiades explains that his memory is good when he is owed money and bad when he is in debt to others.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That , in order to keep himself healthy, he tries never to eat too much, in the first instance]
 Πρῶτον μὲν νὴ Δία πειρῶμαι μηδέποτε ὑπερπίμπλασθαι·

author: Plato
title: Hippias Minor
statement:
[That deceitful men are very intelligent]
 Φρόνιμοι μὲν ἄρα εἰσίν, ὡς ἔοικεν. {—ΙΠ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία, λίαν γε.
remarks: Hippias agrees to this when a kind of prudence is presented to him as the opposite of folly.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That the rich man, when designated as a trierarch, wraps himself in rags and wails and claims to be poor]
 ΑΙ. Οὔκουν ἐθέλει γε τριηραρχεῖν πλουτῶν οὐδεὶς διὰ ταῦτα, 
ἀλλὰ ῥακίοις περιειλάμενος κλάει καὶ φησὶ πένεσθαι. 
  ΔΙ.  Νὴ τὴν Δήμητρα
remarks: This imaginary rich man is trying to avoid the expensive public service of trierarchy by the antidosis procedure (challenging someone else either to take on the service or to exchange property with him). See Sommerstein ad 1065 and 1066.

author: Euripides
title: Orestes
statement:
[That his statement that Helen is justly dead was not made merely to placate Orestes]
 Ορ. ἐνδίκως ἡ Τυνδάρειος ἆρα παῖς διώλλυτο; 
Φρ. ἐνδικώτατ’, εἴ γε λαιμοὺς εἶχε τριπτύχους θενεῖν
Ορ. δειλίαι γλώσσηι χαρίζηι, τἄνδον οὐχ οὕτω φρονῶν.
Φρ. οὐ γάρ, ἥτις ῾Ελλάδ’ αὐτοῖς Φρυξὶ διελυμήνατο;
Ορ. ὄμοσον (εἰ δὲ μή, κτενῶ σε) μὴ λέγειν ἐμὴν χάριν.
Φρ. τὴν ἐμὴν ψυχὴν κατώμοσ’, ἣν ἂν εὐορκοῖμ’ ἐγώ.
remarks: In spite of the Phrygian's terror, it is clear that his sworn statement is true. This is evident from 1381-8 (which Orestes did not hear) that "Dyshelena" caused the lamentable destruction of Troy, confirming 1515. The Phrygian swears truly concerning what he has seen, and the subsequent salvation of Helen is miraculous. The "if broken" condition of the oath is indicated by the slave swearing on his soul, representing an invitation to unspecified gods to destroy him if he is lying.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
if_taken: He will not have to testify
statement: [That it was not true that Milyas was not a slave and that Aphobus had acknowledged that fact]
remarks:
Demosthenes tells the jurors that when he summoned Aphobus to testify against Demon he drafted a witness statement and told Aphobus to testify to the same evidence which by his present prosecution he is alleging to be false. 
Aphobus initially refused, but when the arbitrator ordered him to attest to it or to take the oath of denial, he attested with reluctance. 
Demosthenes goes on to ask that if Milyas was a slave and Aphobus had not already acknowledged that he was free, why did he attest to it rather than take the oath and thus escape the matter?

title: IG II(2)
swearee: Representatives of the newly allied state
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and another state. The other party to this alliance cannot be identified. 
The statement is almost entirely lost, but begins "and they are to swear by Zeus, Gaia, Helios" (ὀμνύναι δὲ Δία Γ[ῆν Ἥλιον ? - - -])

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the Opuntian Locrians
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the Opuntian Locrians
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
The statement is unknown.
Presumably the parties involved swore to defend each other.
remarks:
Xenophon lists the Athenians, Argives, Boeotians (except Orchomenos), Corinthians and Opuntian Locrians as allies against the Spartans at the battle of Nemea. 
See also oath id 2835, 2878, 3010.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Cilicians; King of Assyria; Lycaonians; Arabians; Phoenicians; Ionians; Aeolians; Most Greeks in Asia
swearee: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Cilicians; King of Assyria; Lycaonians; Arabians; Phoenicians; Ionians; Aeolians; Most Greeks in Asia
statement: [That they would fight together in attacking the Medes and Persians]
remarks: Apparently the allies were convinced of the need for the alliance by the Assyrian king's suggestions that the Medes and the Persians, who had intermarried, and were powerful nations, would be likely to make war on each of the other nations and subjugate them. Those who were unconvinced by such arguments were apparently bribed to join the alliance.  Cf. oath ids 2326, 2385 and 2389. The allies subsequently begin to desert- see oath id 2387.   Here, the Indian spies report to Cyrus that Croesus has been made leader and general over all the allied kings. They also report that Thracian swordsmen had been hired and 120,000 armed Egyptians were sailing to join them. Indians were listed amongst the original allies (see oath id references above) but are not mentioned here for obvious reasons, and the Carians are also absent, though Lycaonians, Arabians, Phoenicians, Ionians, Aeolians and almost all the Greek colonists in Asia have now seemingly joined the alliance. In this passage also, the Assyrian king, whose father had originally proposed the alliance has fled and left his troops under the king of Babylon. The Hyrcanians, subjects of Assyria, had previously deserted- see oath id 2387.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leochares
statement:
[That Leochares' status as the adopted son of Archiades can be 'rightfully established according to the statute' because he  was registered as the son of Archiades]
 ὅτι νὴ Δία ἐγγέγραπται Ἀρχιάδῃ υἱός.
remarks: The speaker asks how Leochares' status as the adopted son of Archiades can be "rightfully established according to the statute" when it is clear that he was not adopted by Archiades himself, and imagines that Leochares will respond in this way.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement: n/a
remarks:
Thucydides states that during the period of stasis that afflicted the Greek world, "oaths of reconciliation, being only proffered on either side to meet an immediate difficulty, only held good so long as no other weapon was at hand; but when opportunity offered, he who first ventured to seize it and to take his enemy off his guard, thought this perfidious vengeance sweeter than an open one, since, considerations of safety apart, success by treachery won him the palm of superior intelligence". 
At this point Thucydides is referring in particular to Corcyra. For the oath of reconciliation between the oligarchs and the democrats at Corcyra see oath id 1630.  
For another discussion of oaths in the time of stasis see oath id 1636.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: See oath id 590 for remarks and cross references.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that if the Athenians were all agreed that Philip is at war with Athens and violating the peace the only task of an orator would be to come forward and recommend the easiest method of defence. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Georgoi
statement:
[That they did plead their lawsuits in song in previous times]
 καὶ τὰς δίκας οὖν ἔλεγον ᾄδοντες τότε;
{2{Β.} νὴ Δία ·
remarks: Swearer proceeds to offer proof of his statement.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he will not hand over the wineskin]
 Ἀλλ’ ἀπόδος αὐτό.
{ΚΗ.}  Μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω τουτονί.
remarks: Sommerstein remarks on the invocation of "Apollo who dwells here" as follows: "Apollo has no place in a sanctuary of Demeter and Kore; but in several tragedies… there is evidence that a pillar of Apollo Agyieus … stood in front of the stage-house, and our passage shows that this was a permanent fixture…The reference cannot be to the altar in the orchestra where Inlaw now is: in the dramatic fiction that was an altar of Demeter and Kore, in theatrical fact it was an altar of Dionysus". For further references see Sommerstein ad 748.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That as allies they would be forever guileless and reliable to each other]
remarks:
In 415 the Athenians sailed past Syracuse and announced that they had come to reinstate the Leontines in their own country on the ground of alliance and kinship. 
This alliance is presumably a renewal of the alliance from 433 preserved in IG I(3) 54 (see oath id 166-7) and mentioned by Thucydides (see oath id 1662). 
For other references to the alliances between Athens and Leontini see oath id 1765 and 1766.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
statement: n/a
remarks: Here the river Styx is called the oath river, but it is only invoked as such by gods, see e.g. oath id 350. On the origins of the Styx as the oath river, see oath id 1291.

author: Pindar
title: Nemean 9
statement: see remarks
remarks: Like oath id 1315 this is a metaphorical oath (cf. also id 23). Adrastus gives Eriphyle to Amphiaraus as wife "like a reliable oath", thus securing Amphiaraus' support for the attack against Thebes. The oath is, in effect, an oath of alliance.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he does not know that he is the richest man in the world]
 καὶ ὁ Καλλίας ἰδών, Ἆρ’ οἶσθα, ἔφη, ὦ Λύκων, ὅτι πλουσιώτατος εἶ ἀνθρώπων; Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, τοῦτο μέντοι ἐγὼ οὐκ οἶδα.
remarks: Callias was actually far richer than Lycon (having not yet had time to squander his inherited wealth). What Callias means here, as he proceeds to explain, is that Lycon would not exchange his son for all the wealth of the King of Persia.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest the mercenaries as they departed the island]
remarks:
Aeschines reminds the jurors that they defeated the Chalcidians and then let "the enemy" depart under a truce. 
The latter statement can hardly refer to the Chalcidians themselves (it would imply either, incredibly, that their whole army was taken prisoner or, falsely, that they were required to leave their own city's territory) and probably refers only to the Phocian mercenaries who had aided them.

title: IC IV
work_date: mid-seventh century - end of sixth century
date: Mid-seventh century - end of the sixth century (650 to 500)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
All that can be determined is that this text refers to an oath of some kind. The only line of this text reads:  
[- - - ]ς ὀμν[υ - - -]

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
if_broken: May Silenus' wicked sons, whom he loves dearly, perish miserably
statement:
[That Silenus is not selling the Cyclops' property to the strangers]
 μὰ τὸν Ποσειδῶ τὸν τεκόντα σ’, ὦ Κύκλωψ,
  μὰ τὸν μέγαν Τρίτωνα καὶ τὸν Νηρέα,
  μὰ τὴν Καλυψὼ τάς τε Νηρέως κόρας,
  μὰ θαἰερὰ κύματ’ ἰχθύων τε πᾶν γένος, 
  ἀπώμοσ’, ὦ κάλλιστον ὦ Κυκλώπιον,
  ὦ δεσποτίσκε, μὴ τὰ σ’ ἐξοδᾶν ἐγὼ
  ξένοισι χρήματ’. ἢ κακῶς οὗτοι κακοὶ
  οἱ παῖδες ἀπόλοινθ’, οὓς μάλιστ’ ἐγὼ φιλῶ.
gods_invoked: PoseidonEpithet(s)Cyclops' father; TritonEpithet(s)Great; Nereus; Calypso; Nereids; Sacred waves; All species of fish
remarks: Silenus' oath is probably to be treated as true. The present infinitive could be equivalent either to a present or to an imperfect tense (since both derive from the present stem).  If it stands for an imperfect, Silenus is lying. If it stands for a present, however, he is telling the truth, since he is not now engaged in selling anything to the newcomers. See also oath ids 98 an 101. Cf. oath id 1484 for the invocation of Poseidon in the context of the Cyclops.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Euthycles begs the jurors not to give him an unfriendly hearing because they look on Charidemus as a benefactor and thus deprive themselves of the power to give their vote in keeping with their oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Laches
statement:
[That it is not a difficult thing to explain what courage is (andreia)]
 Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐ χαλεπὸν εἰπεῖν
remarks: Clearly, as the dialogue progresses, Socrates will show that the concept of andreia in fact very difficult to define, but at the moment of swearing, Laches believes his statement to be true. In fact, Laches’ answer to the request for a definition of courage is a poor one, since he gives not a definition but an example – “if someone is willing to stay in the ranks, defend himself against the enemy, and not run away” – evidently because, like many of Socrates’ interlocutors, he doesn’t realize that it was for a definition that Socrates was asking.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That Theorus would not have been so long in Thrace had he not had such a good wage]
 {ΘΕ.} Χρόνον μὲν οὐκ ἂν ἦμεν ἐν Θρᾴκῃ πολύν, —
{ΔΙ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἄν, εἰ μισθόν γε μὴ ’φερες πολύν.
remarks: Dicaeopolis' remark here is an aside and has no effect on the swearee.

author: Ephorus
title: Histories
if_taken: They will prove their dedication to fighting Messene
if_refused: They will not prove their dedication to fighting Messene
impact: Dedication to the war with Messene is assured
statement:
[That they would not return home again until they had either destroyed Messene or were all killed]
 ὀμόσαντες μὴ πρότερον ἐπανήξειν οἴκαδε πρὶν ἢ Μεσσήνην ἀνελεῖν ἢ πάντας ἀποθανεῖν
remarks: The oath sworn here causes a problem among the women in Sparta who, after ten years, complain about the length of time that their husbands have been away. In order to keep their oath but also keep their women having children, they send back the youngest men among them, since these would have been too young at the time of the initial expedition to have taken part in the oaths themselves. The oath statement itself is remarkably similar to that sworn by the Seven before they attack Thebes, see oath id 198. Cf. oath id 2883 where the Argives swear that no Argive man will grow his hair long, and none of their women will wear gold jewellery, until they recover Thyrea.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 2
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
statement: [That Boeotus and Pamphilus were sons of Mantias]
remarks: Mantitheus states that when Mantias proposed the oath, Plangon, contrary to all that she had agreed to do, swore the opposite of what she had promised to swear (see oath id 3561), and that as a result Mantias was compelled to abide by the arbitrator's award, and thus enrolled Boeotus and Pamphilus in his phratry (see oath id 3562).

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That if Callicles leaves philosophy's arguments unchecked, then Callicles will not be in agreement with Callicles, but at variance with him in every aspect of his life]
 ἢ εἰ τοῦτο ἐάσεις ἀνέλεγκτον, μὰ τὸν κύνα τὸν Αἰγυπτίων θεόν, οὔ σοι ὁμολογήσει Καλλικλῆς, ὦ Καλλίκλεις, ἀλλὰ διαφωνήσει ἐν ἅπαντι τῷ βίῳ.
remarks: This oath presents us with an interesting qualification to the invocation of "the dog" which is typical only of Socrates' character in Greek literature (see oath id 2548 for references). Here it is qualified by the phrase "god of the Egyptians" (presumably referring to Anubis), showing that Socrates' invocation of "the dog" is meant to be taken as a serious divine force.

author: Andocides
title: Against Alcibiades
date: At the time of the speech ca.417-415 (417 to 415)
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the Athenians that the laws forbid the possibility of the same man being tried twice on the same charge, "and you have sworn to employ the laws".  This statement is irrelevant to the situation he is in, since an ostracism vote was not a judicial trial and the voters were not on oath at all; many of them, moreover, will never have taken the Heliastic oath, including all those who were under thirty and therefore not yet eligible to be jurors. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he will not let Paphlagon speak (before him)]
  Οὐκ αὖ μ’ ἐάσεις; 
  {ΑΛ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: This oath is repeated in the following sequence. See also oath ids 988, 989, 990.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
if_taken: They will not have to give evidence
if_refused: They will have to give evidence
statement: [That they did not know that the defendant had committed the crime]
remarks: Lycurgus urges the jurors to ask the witnesses to come forward to fulfil their duty (and not follow the negative example set by the defendant Leocrates), or let them take the exomosia holding the cut-pieces, according to the law.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The King's country in Asia is to remain his possession and to be governed as he pleases
2. The Spartans and their allies shall not go against the country of the King, nor the King against the Spartans and their allies.
3. If any of the Spartans and their allies go against the King's territory, the Spartans and their allies shall stop them, and if any of the King's subjects go against the Spartans and their allies the King shall stop them
4. Tissaphernes shall pay for the ships now present until the arrival of the King's ships. After these arrive, the Spartans can then pay for their own ships if they wish. If not, Tissaphernes will provide money, but the Spartans will repay the money at the end of the war
5. When the King's ships arrive, the ships of the Spartans and their allies and those of the King shall wage war together, according to what seems best to Tissaphernes and the Spartans and their allies. If they wish to end the war with the Athenians, they will do so jointly]
remarks:
Thucydides states that after this agreement was made Tissaphernes set about preparing to bring Phoenician ships as had been agreed. 
The role played by Hieramenes and the sons of Pharnaces who are named in the agreement is unclear. Gomme, Andrewes and Dover, A Historical Commentary on Thucydides, Volume V, p139, argue that Krumbholz was correct to see Hieramenes (also mention in Xen. Hell. 2.1.9) and "the sons of Pharnaces" as witnesses to the treaty rather than the highest Persian officers in the area. This seems plausible since it is unlikely that the term "the sons of Pharnaces" is intended to include Pharnabazus who was a satrap in his own right. 
For references to the other agreements between the Persians and the Spartans see also oath id 1806.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that if Philip accepted the Phocians as allies of Athens and swore oaths to them (see oath id 3823), he would have violated his oaths to the Thessalians and the Thebans (see oath id 3826). 
Demosthenes claims that Philip swore to assist the Thessalians "in establishing the Pylaea".  
During the Sacred War the Phocians had made it impossible for the regular meetings of the Amphictyonic Council to be held at Thermopylae, and that the Thessalians made their alliance with Philip partly in order to get these meetings restarted. Demosthenes' claim that the terms of the alliance made explicit reference to the Pylaea is presumably rhetorical exaggeration. Cf. MacDowell, p345. 
See also oath id 2951.

author: Aeschylus
title: Choephoroi
statement:
[That Clytemnestra and Aegisthus would kill Agamemnon together and die together themselves]
 ὡς ἐπεικάσαι πάθη
πάρεστιν, ὅρκος τ’ ἐμμένει πιστώμασιν·
ξυνώμοσαν μὲν θάνατον ἀθλίωι πατρὶ
καὶ ξυνθανεῖσθαι· καὶ τάδ’ εὐόρκως ἔχει.
remarks: This oath between Clytemnestra and Aegisthus is reported by Orestes, but it is not actually referred to in the trilogy by the swearers themselves. However, see also oath ids 204 and 205 which may support the oath referred to here, and see Apollo's arguments at Eum. 218 with Sommerstein ad loc..

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the Spartan's allies will certainly be in favour of a "fucking policy" (i.e. a peace policy)]
 Οὐ ταὐτὰ δόξει τοῖσι συμμάχοισι νῷν,
  βινεῖν, ἅπασιν;  
{ΛΑ.}  Τοῖσι γῶν ναὶ τὼ σιὼ 
  ἁμοῖσι.
remarks: Swearing by the Dioscuri is typically Spartan, cf. oath id 1216 with cross references.

author: Antiphanes
title: Knoithideus or Gastron
statement:
[That Phillip was a very lucky man]
  ὡς σφόδρα
ὁ Φίλιππος ἆρ’ ἦν εὐτυχής τις, νὴ Δία
remarks: The speaker is clearly male (cf. lines 8-9).

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That it is not time for nodding off or delaying victory, but time for action as soon as possible]
 Καὶ μὴν μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐχὶ νυστάζειν ἔτι 
  ὥρα ’στὶν ἡμῖν οὐδὲ μελλονικιᾶν,  
  ἀλλ’ ὡς τάχιστα δεῖ τι δρᾶν
remarks: Most editors, including Dunbar, assign these lines to Tereus; see her note, and Sommerstein's, for arguments for and against this.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That as allies they would be forever guileless and reliable to each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Leontines and their allies sent an embassy to Athens in 427 and urged them to help "because of an earlier alliance". This alliance is preserved in IG I(3) 54 (see oath id 166-7). 
As a result of this, the Athenians sent ships to assist the Leontines against the Syracusans and their allies.

author: Archilochus
title: Fragments
date: After the solar eclipse of 648 (648 to 647)
statement: n/a
remarks: This is general piece of advice that nothing should be sworn impossible, now that Zeus has made day into night (a reference to the solar eclipse of 648 BC). This fragment is quoted in Aristotle's Rhetoric 1418b29 (oath id 1740). For a similar sentiment, see oath id 1370.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
statement:
[That he will give his opponent's body back for burial should he win in single combat provided his opponent is willing to do the same] 
 ὧδε δὲ μυθέομαι, Ζεὺς δ’ ἄμμ’ ἐπὶ μάρτυρος ἔστω· 
εἰ μέν κεν ἐμὲ κεῖνος ἕλῃ ταναήκεϊ χαλκῷ, 
τεύχεα συλήσας φερέτω κοίλας ἐπὶ νῆας, 
σῶμα δὲ οἴκαδ’ ἐμὸν δόμεναι πάλιν, ὄφρα πυρός με 
Τρῶες καὶ Τρώων ἄλοχοι λελάχωσι θανόντα.  
εἰ δέ κ’ ἐγὼ τὸν ἕλω, δώῃ δέ μοι εὖχος ̓Απόλλων,
τεύχεα σύλησας οἴσω προτὶ ῎Ιλιον ἱρήν, 
καὶ κρεμόω προτὶ νηὸν ̓Απόλλωνος ἑκάτοιο, 
τὸν δὲ νέκυν ἐπὶ νῆας ἐϋσσέλμους ἀποδώσω,
ὄφρά ἑ ταρχύσωσι κάρη κομόωντες ̓Αχαιοί, 
σῆμά τέ οἱ χεύωσιν ἐπὶ πλατεῖ ̔Ελλησπόντῳ.
remarks: Ajax accepts Hector's challenge of single combat but no oath is formally sworn by either side. In the event, the battle between Ajax and Hector is deemed a draw, and the occasion for the oath's fulfilment does not arise. This oath proposal is significant in that it foreshadows Achilles' refusal of the same terms proposed by Hector at oath id 419.

author: Lysias
title: Against Simon
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That he knew well that the defendant had wounded with the intent to kill]
remarks:
The defendant argues that he would never have imagined that Simon would have been so audacious as to appear before the council of the Areopagus upon swearing the great and solemn diomosia. 
See also oath id 2809 and 2810.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: The Spartans will be able to make the sacrifice at Olympia
if_refused: They will not be able to make the sacrifice
statement:
[That they would pay the fine for violating the Olympic truce later]
 ἦ μὴν ἀποδώσειν ὕστερον τὴν καταδίκην.
remarks:
The Spartans were excluded from Olympia in 420 for breaking the sacred truce.  
Because they desired access to the sanctuary, the Eleans offered the Spartans the alternative that they could go up to the altar of Zeus Olympios and swear in the presence of the Greeks that they would pay the fine later. 
The Spartans refused to do so and were excluded from the temple, the sacrifice and the contests.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement: see remarks
remarks:
Here the Chorus discuss women who break the "customary oaths", among other deceptions and transgressions, as being impious and doing wrong against the city. Olson & Austin take the reference to be to "oaths of office" - but Sommerstein has suggested in discussion that ἐξαπατῶσιν, immediately before, points rather to assembly speakers, who would not usually be office-holders at all. (Though he admits he had once taken a similar view, in JHS 97 [1977] 123, speaking of "councillors, magistrates and perhaps jurors who violate the law.")   He would now prefer to see a reference to the only oath which every citizen had to have taken, the so-called ephebic oath (see Oath id 340), which included the following clauses: 
"I shall hand over the fatherland <to the next generation> not smaller, but greater and better <than I received it>, to the best of my ability and with the aid of all; and I shall obey those who at any time exercise authority reasonably, and the established laws, and those which they may establish reasonably in the future; and if anyone tries to destroy them, I shall not permit it, to the best of my ability and with the aid of all." 
Anyone who, as stated in this passage of the Thesm., "[a] seek[s] to invert decrees and laws, or [b] disclose[s] secrets to our enemies, or [c] invite[s] the Medes to intervene" would certainly be breaking the above oath - in case [a] by not obeying the "established laws", in cases [b] and [c] by acting in a way calculated to make "the fatherland ... smaller" (or even to destroy it altogether as an independent community).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Navy-Boards
statement:
[That the Greeks will respond to the Athenians' call because the Athenians will warn them that the Persian King is plotting against them]
 ὅτι νὴ Δί’ ἀκούσονται παρ’ ἡμῶν ὡς ἐπιβουλεύει βασιλεὺς αὐτοῖς.
remarks: Demosthenes asks the Athenians how they will convince the other Greeks to join them in fighting against the Persian King when relations with some of them are not cordial.

title: IErythrae
swearer: Men with property of more than 30 staters
statement:
That they would give judgement according to the laws and decrees]
 ὀμόσαντας τὸν αὐτὸν ὅρκον τῆι βουλῆι δικᾶν κατὰ νόμος καὶ ψηφίσματα
remarks:
These laws state that when archai are prosecuted, the judgement shall be given by nine men from each tribe who have property of not less than thirty staters, after they have sworn to give judgement according to the laws and decrees. 
It is thought that these laws were associated with a democratic politeia imposed by Athens.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
if_taken: They will be allowed to serve as judges
if_refused: They will not be allowed to serve as judges
statement: [That they will judge fairly]
remarks: This is the fragmentary opening of the Ath. Pol. which refers to the curse of the Alcmaeonidae. Cylon and his supporters had attempted to seize the Acropolis. When this failed they took refuge as suppliants and were assured that their lives would be spared, but the promise was broken. Megacles the Alcmaeonid was held to blame for this which led to war between Athens and Megara. Eventually the Alcmaeonids were made to stand trial and condemned (with our reference here to the judges' oaths at the trial).

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Methymna under the auspices of the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
For the corresponding oaths of the Methymnaens see oath id 334, 3862. 
For other references to the Second Athenian Confederacy see oath id 2974.

author: Hesiod
title: Works and Days
impact: Testimony believed or judgement deemed fair
statement: n/a
remarks: Here, Hesiod refers to Oath who runs beside crooked judgements. West comments ad loc.: "Divine sanctions affect those responsible for the miscarriage of justice, both the litigant whose sworn deposition is false .. and the judges who are corrupt". Cf. Theognis (oath id 1374).

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the Sacian had hit someone who was no longer present (because he had ridden away at high speed)]
 Ἀλλ’ οὐ μέντοι, ἔφη ὁ νεανίσκος, τῶν γε ἀπόντων. Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, σύγε ἐκείνου τοῦ παρὰ τὰ ἅρματα ταχὺ ἐλαύνοντος τὸν ἵππον.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2485.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Pellenaeans had come back into their alliance with the Spartans. For the earlier alliance between Sparta and Pellene, see oath id 2018. 
At 7.2.12-16 the Pellenaeans are found fighting against the Spartans and their allies in 366. By 7.2.18 Pellene has returned to the Spartan side. It is presumably not a coincidence that at 7.2.16 Xenophon describes how the Phliasians allowed one of their prisoners, a certain Proxenus of Pellene, to go without a ransom. It seems likely that when Proxenus returned home he brought about a change of heart at Pellene. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That if he had not fought his way through the crowd with his fists the previous day, he would not have been able to get near Cyrus]
 καὶ μὰ τὸν Μίθρην ἐγώ τοι ἐχθές, εἰ μὴ πολλοῖς διεπύκτευσα, οὐκ ἂν ἐδυνάμην σοι προσελθεῖν.
remarks: Artabazus is seeking more time with the increasingly busy Cyrus. Xenophon is the first Greek writer to refer to the god Mithras- see oath id 1863.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Lycon's son has not only heard what was said (about the importance of associating with virtuous people) but practices it]
 καὶ ὁ Λύκων εἶπεν· Ἀκούεις ταῦτα, ὦ υἱέ; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, καὶ χρῆταί γε.

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the alliance]
remarks: This is a reference to an imaginary but specific alliance between Athens and an imaginary state some time before 404.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
statement:
[That Olympiodorus was unable to attend due to military service]
 ὑπωμοσάμεθα ἡμεῖς τουτονὶ Ὀλυμπιόδωρον δημοσίᾳ ἀπεῖναι στρατευόμενον.
remarks: Callistratus tells the jurors that when the Archon summoned into court all those who were filing claims according to the law, he entered a sworn statement (the hypomosia), asking for a postponement on the ground that Olympiodorus was abroad on military service. However, their opponents lodged a counter-hypomosia (see oath id 3736) and convinced the jurors that Olympiodorus had left Athens on account of the trial.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Gives validity to the Theban's claim
statement:
[That the goods in his bag are his own]
 Ταυτὶ τίνος τὰ φορτί’ ἐστί;
{ΘΗ.}  Τῶδ’ ἐμὰ  
  Θείβαθεν, ἴττω Δεύς.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Strepsiades will not get away with treating him like this]
 οὔτοι μὰ τὸν Δία τὸν μέγαν καὶ τοὺς θεοὺς
  ἐμοῦ καταπροίξει.
remarks: Cf. oath id 45.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
statement:
[That it would be disgraceful and unworthy of the Athenians, the resources of their city, and the record of their ancestors, if they were to abandon the other Greeks to enslavement for the sake of their own ease]
 αἰσχρὸν μὲν νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ πάντας θεοὺς καὶ ἀνάξιον ὑμῶν καὶ τῶν ὑπαρχόντων τῇ πόλει καὶ πεπραγμένων τοῖς προγόνοις, τῆς ἰδίας ῥᾳθυμίας ἕνεκα τοὺς ἄλλους ἅπαντας Ἕλληνας εἰς δουλείαν προέσθαι,
remarks: See also oath id 3254.

author: Isocrates
title: For Demonicus
statement: n/a
remarks:
Isocrates urges Demonicus, the son of his Cypriot friend Hipponicus, to show his devotion to the gods by not only making sacrifices, but also by keeping his oaths.  
He describes the former as evidence of material prosperity, and the latter as proof of a noble character.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Envoys; Representatives of the allies of King Philip
swearee: Envoys; Representatives of the allies of King Philip
remarks:
Demosthenes complains that the envoys were idle in Pella for three months. He imagines that someone will object that during this time they administered the oaths to the allies, and responds to this imaginary objection by reporting that the ambassadors drew one thousand drachmas in travel expenses, yet did not administer the oaths to a single city either on the way there or the way back. 
Rather, the oaths were sworn in the inn in front of the Dioskoureion at Pherae, at a time when Philip was already moving towards Athens with his army. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Sophocles
title: Trachiniae
statement: [That Iole's identity is unknown]
remarks: Deianeira, distraught and confused to find out that Heracles is in love with this beautiful girl, suspects that Lichas may have been lying when he told her he did not know the girl's name (at 318-319). In fact, Lichas never "swore", as Deianeira claims, that the girl was nameless or unknown. This seems to be a particular feature of Sophocles, that strong affirmations can be treated as sworn statements. Cf. oath ids 236, 263, 285, 289, 292.

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
if_taken: They will be eligible to be citizens
if_refused: They will not be eligible to be citizens
statement: [That they shall not bring shame upon the sacred weapons nor shall they desert the man beside them, wherever they stand in the line. They shall fight in defence of things sacred and profane and shall not hand the fatherland on lessened, but greater and better both as far as they are able and with all. And they shall be obedient to whoever exercises power reasonably on any occasion and to the laws currently in force and any reasonably put into force in the future. If anyone attempts to destroy these, they shall refuse to allow him both as far as is in their power and in union with all, and they shall honour the ancestral religion]
gods_invoked: Aglaurus; Hestia; Enyo; Enyalios; Ares; Athena; Zeus; Thallo; Auxo; Hegemone; Heracles; The boundaries of my fatherland; Wheat; Barley; Vines; Olives; Figs
remarks:
Lycurgus says that there is an oath sworn by all citizens when they are epheboi and are being enrolled on the deme register. He reminds the jurors that they swore when they were ephebes "not to disgrace your sacred arms, not to desert your post in the ranks, but to defend your country and to hand it on better than you found it" (μήτε τὰ ἱερὰ ὅπλα καταισχυνεῖν μήτε τὴν τάξιν λείψειν, ἀμυνεῖν δὲ τῇ πατρίδι καὶ ἀμείνω παραδώσειν). 
If the oath was taken at the time of deme registration (which is what is stated here), it was presumably taken in the demes themselves, and most likely administered by the demarch (who had custody of the register; see Demosthenes. 57.60, where Eubulides' father, when demarch of Halimous, is said to have claimed that he had lost it). 
See also oath id 340.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be allies to the Greeks, would not betray them, and would lead them without treachery]
 μήτε προδώσειν ἀλλήλους σύμμαχοί τε ἔσεσθαι· [and] ἡγήσεσθαι ἀδόλως
remarks:
Xenophon refers here to the alliance between the Ten Thousand and the Persians who fought with Cyrus. 
According to Xenophon, the Greeks met with Cyrus' Persian troops led by Ariaeus at "the first stopping place" (see 2.1.3). 
The Greek generals and lochagoi and Ariaeus and his highest officers exchanged oaths that they would not betray each other and they would be allies. The Persians also swore to lead the Greeks out of the area without treachery. 
After this exchange of oaths the Greeks and the Persians made their escape. 
For the oaths sworn by the Greeks see oath id 2078.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he does intend to give Cyrus all the meat to use as he pleases]
 Ἦ καὶ δίδως, φάναι, ὦ πάππε, πάντα ταῦτά μοι τὰ κρέα ὅ τι ἂν βούλωμαι αὐτοῖς  χρῆσθαι; Νὴ Δία, φάναι, ὦ παῖ, ἔγωγέ σοι.
remarks: The young Cyrus proceeds to distribute the meat among the servants as a reward for all their good work.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Nicostratus
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker concludes by asking the jurors to remember the laws and the oaths which they swore, and to vote according to justice. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Euripides
title: Helena
statement:
[That if Menelaus is dead, she will kill herself]
 Ελ. σὲ γὰρ ἐκάλεσα, σὲ δὲ κατόμοσα
  τὸν ὑδρόεντι δόνακι χλωρὸν
  Εὐρώταν, θανόντος 
  εἰ βάξις ἔτυμος ἀνδρὸς
  ἅδε μοι τί τάδ’ ἀσύνετα,
  φόνιον αἰώρημα 
  διὰ δέρας ὀρέξομαι, 
  ἢ ξιφοκτόνον διωγμὸν 
  αἱμορρύτου σφαγᾶς 
  αὐτοσίδαρον ἔσω πελάσω διὰ σαρκὸς ἅμιλλαν,
  θῦμα τριζύγοις θεαῖσι αὐτοσίδαρον ἔσω πελάσω διὰ σαρκὸς ἅμιλλαν,
  θῦμα τριζύγοις θεαῖσι 
  τῶι τε σήραγγας ῎Ι- 
  δας ἐνίζοντι Πριαμί- 
  δαι ποτ’ ἀμφὶ βουστάθμους.
remarks: Given the portrayal of Helen in this play, the oath she swears must be genuine. However, it is conditional and as events unfold, she will not be required to fulfill the oath.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement: n/a
remarks:
According to Herodotus, when King Leotychides went to Athens to organise the release of Aeginetan hostages left there on trust by Cleomenes, the Athenians refused to hand them over. 
Leotychides then warned them about the fate of a certain Spartan, Glaucus son of Epicydes, who lived three generations earlier. 
Glaucus had a reputation for justice such that a man from Miletus came to give him half his property (recently converted into silver) for safe-keeping. If Glaucus received the money he would take and keep tokens, and restore the money to any person who came with like tokens and demanded the money back.  
Glaucus received the trust, and after a long time the sons of the Milesian came to Sparta, showed Glaucus the tokens, and demanded the money back. Glaucus claimed that he could not yet remember the matter, and promised that if they returned in four months he would settle the matter one way or another. 
Glaucus then travelled to Delphi to consult the oracle and asked whether he should steal the money "by an oath" (ὅρκῳ). 
The priestess threatened him with the following verses: 
"For now, Glaucus son of Epicydes, you have an immediate profit; to win by oath (ὅρκῳ νικῆσαι) and to steal the money; swear (ὄμνυ), since death awaits even the man who swears well (εὔορκον μένει ἄνδρα); but Horkos has a child with no name, nor hands, nor feet, but swift in pursuit, until he has in his grasp all a man's offspring and household, which he destroys. But the offspring of the man who swears well shall afterwards be better". 
When Glaucus heard this, he asked the god to forgive him for what he had suggested. But the Pythia responded that to tempt the god and to do the deed were the same thing. 
Glaucus then sent for the Milesians and returned the money to them. 
Leotychides then goes on to warn the Athenians that there are no descendants of Glaucus, nor any household that bears his name at Sparta, and warns them that the only good thing to do concerning a trust is to restore it on demand.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement: n/a
remarks: The speaker tells the jurors that there are not shrines dedicated to Shamelessness, Chicanery, Perjury or Ingratitude.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That they would never have believed it (i.e. the weighing of words in a scale) even if someone they had bumped into had told them]
  Μὰ τόν, ἐγὼ μὲν οὐκ ἂν εἴ τις 
  ἔλεγέ μοι τῶν ἐπιτυχόντων,  
  ἐπιθόμην
remarks: Sommerstein ad 1374 remarks that this is "an abortive oath which is broken off without any god's name being mentioned (cf. Pl. Gorg. 466e), thus adding to the speaker's words most of the emphasis that an oath would have conferred while avoiding any risk of perjury". See also Sommerstein ad 1374-5 on the joke in the Chorus' statement here (i.e. that we expect mention of some very strong reason for belief; what the chorus actually say presupposes that the strongest possible reason for believing something is to have heard it from some Tom, Dick or Harry!). On the identity of the Chorus, see Sommerstein ad 323-459.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
Isocrates criticises the Spartans for attacking their own allies and benefactors. 
He claims that even though the Thebans had contributed the greatest number of troops to their forces against Athens during the Peloponnesian war, when the war was over they straightaway plotted against the Thebans. 
He also criticises the Spartans for turning on the Persian King and the Chians (see oath id 3012 and 3013). 
For the alliance between Sparta and Thebes see also oath id 1708.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
impact: Emphasises the support of the Chorus
statement:
[That the Sausage-seller has spoken well]
 Εὖ γε νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ τὸν Ἀπόλλω καὶ τὴν Δήμητρα.
remarks: The Chorus are responding here to the Sausage-seller's extended curse of Paphlagon (at 929-940), which is basically a curse that he may end up choking because of his greed. Zeus, Apollo and Demeter were the "Oath-Gods" (horkioi theoi) by whom were sworn oaths of particular solemnity (Deinarchus fr. 29 Conomis) including that of the jurors (Pollux 8.122); see Fisher on Aeschines 1.114. It is not exactly clear why this oath is particularly appropriate in the mouth of the chorus at this moment.  Perhaps it's just very, very emphatic; cf. [Dem.] 52.9.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That there isn't a man in the country (because of the war)]
 «Οὐκ ἔστιν ἀνὴρ ἐν τῇ χώρᾳ.» — «Μὰ Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’,» εἶφ’ ἕτερός τις, —
remarks: Here Lysistrata reports that hearing such a statement prompted the women to band together to save Greece.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
statement:
[That the Parthians (who had previously revolted from the Medes and given themselves over to the Sacae) would be subject to the Medes, but that both peoples should retain their former possessions and be friends and allies forever]
 τὸ τελευταῖον εἰρήνην αὐτοὺς ἐπὶ τοῖσδε συνθέσθαι· Πάρθους μὲν ὑπὸ Μήδους τετάχθαι, τῶν δὲ προυπαρχόντων ἑκατέρους κυριεύσαντας φίλους εἶναι καὶ συμμάχους ἀλλήλοις εἰς τὸν ἅπαντα χρόνον.

author: Eupolis
title: Philoi
statement:
[That someone’s door is never closed to visitors]
 νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ, οὐδέποτ'  ἴσχει ἡ θύρα
remarks: For this meaning, cf.  Ar. Ach. 127.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
As part of his defence, Aeschines recounts the other matters dealt with by the embassy to Philip, as well as the receiving of the oaths. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That they would bring their generals back from exile when they returned to Syracuse]
 ὀμόσαντες ... κατάξειν αὐτούς, ἐπὰν εἰς Συρακούσας  
ἀφίκωντα&iota
remarks:
When the new democratic regime at Syracuse deposed the generals (including Hermocrates) and replaced them with Demarchus, Myscon and Potamis, most of the trierarchs took an oath to bring their generals back from exile when they returned to Syracuse. 
Xenophon adds that the trierarchs commended all the generals before they left, but those associated with Hermocrates were particularly despondent because of the loss of his leadership qualities.  
Hermocrates did in fact return to Sicily in 408/7, being killed in an attempt to enter Syracuse (Diodorus Siculus 13.63, 75); we do not know whether any of these trierarchs were with him.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement:
[That if Agesilaus arranged a truce to last until the return of the messengers whom he would send to the King, he would do his utmost to obtain autonomy for the Greek cities in Asia]
 εἰ σπείσαιτο ἕως ἔλθοιεν οὓς πέμψειε πρὸς βασιλέα ἀγγέλους, διαπράξεσθαι αὐτῷ ἀφεθῆναι αὐτονόμους τὰς ἐν τῇ Ἀσίᾳ πόλεις Ἑλληνίδας,
remarks:
Tissaphernes approached Agesilaus regarding a truce. He swore that he would do his best to convince King Artaxerxes II to guarantee the autonomy of the Greeks in Asia if Agesilaus agreed to halt hostilities. 
Agesilaus swore to abide by the truce for three months (see oath id 2256). 
Xenophon states that Tissaphernes broke his oath at once, and instead of arranging a peace applied to the King for a large army in addition to the one which he had before. 
Xenophon observes that Agesilaus continued to keep the truce even though he was aware that Tissaphernes had broken his oath, and that by showing Tissaphernes to be a perjurer Agesilaus made him distrusted everywhere. 
Xenophon also describes this oath exchange in the Hellenica (see oath id 1916-7).

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he will try to encourage an eagerness among his men to excel by winning glory and honour]
 Μὴ τοίνυν ὄκνει, ἔφη, ἀλλὰ πειρῶ τοὺς ἄνδρας ἐπὶ ταῦτα προτρέπειν, ἀφ’ ὧν αὐτός τε ὠφελήσῃ καὶ οἱ ἄλλοι πολῖται διὰ σέ. Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία πειράσομαι, ἔφη.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he has never to his knowledge seen Agathon]
 {ΕΥ.}  Οὐχ ἑόρακας πώποτε; 
 {ΚΗ.}  Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὔπω γ’ ὥστε κἀμέ γ’ εἰδέναι.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Apollo
if_taken: Delos will accept the birth of Apollo without reservation
if_refused: Delos will have reservations about accepting the birth of Apollo
impact: Delos is pleased to be the birth-place of Apollo
statement:
[That Apollo's altar and precinct will be in Delos forever and that he will honour Delos above all others]
 ἀλλ’ εἴ μοι τλαίης γε θεὰ μέγαν ὅρκον ὀμόσσαι,
  ἐνθάδε μιν πρῶτον τεύξειν περικαλλέα νηὸν  
  ἔμμεναι ἀνθρώπων χρηστήριον, αὐτὰρ ἔπειτα
  πάντας ἐπ’ ἀνθρώπους, ἐπεὶ ἦ πολυώνυμος ἔσται. 
  Ὣς ἄρ’ ἔφη· Λητὼ δὲ θεῶν μέγαν ὅρκον ὄμοσσεν·
  ἴστω νῦν τάδε γαῖα καὶ οὐρανὸς εὐρὺς ὕπερθεν
  καὶ τὸ κατειβόμενον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, ὅς τε μέγιστος 
  ὅρκος δεινότατός τε πέλει μακάρεσσι θεοῖσιν· 
  ἦ μὴν Φοίβου τῇδε θυώδης ἔσσεται αἰεὶ 
  βωμὸς καὶ τέμενος, τίσει δέ σέ γ’ ἔξοχα πάντων.
  Αὐτὰρ ἐπεί ῥ’ ὄμοσέν τε τελεύτησέν τε τὸν ὅρκον, 
  Δῆλος μὲν μάλα χαῖρε γόνῳ ἑκάτοιο ἄνακτος

author: Isocrates
title: Plataicus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The Plataean speaker states, "I presume that it is clear to all that it is incumbent upon the wise to strive to get the better of the enemy in war, but to regard nothing as of greater importance than their oaths and agreements". This serves as an implicit reference to the King's Peace. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Demosthenes
title: Exordia
statement:
[That previously, he did not know what was the point of saying "office-holding reveals the man"]
 πρότερον μὲν οὖν ἔγωγε μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐκ ᾔδειν πρὸς τί ποτ’ εἴη τοῦτ’ εἰρημένον «ἀρχὴ ἄνδρα δείκνυσιν»
remarks: The point of the proverb, at least in this context, is similar to that of Lord Acton's "All power tends to corrupt", but it is a bit more specific; give a person power, and you will discover whether or not he is corruptible – for if he is, he’s sure to act corruptly.  In another context, it might be differently interpreted, e.g. as saying that the only way to know whether a man is competent to hold a responsible position is to appoint him to it (cf. Tacitus (Histories 1.49) on the emperor Galba, 'omnium consensu capax imperii, nisi imperasset', and the Peter Principle "In a hierarchy, everyone tends to rise to his level of incompetence").

author: Sophocles
title: Oenomaus
statement: see remarks
remarks: A character remarks that because an oath has been added they remain very careful. Someone who has made a promise and backed it by an oath is thenceforward deterred from breaking it by two factors instead of one - not only damage to reputation among the "friends" to whom (s)he has made the commitment, but also the fear of offending the gods. The most common view (Welcker, Pearson) is that the sworn promise was made by Myrtilus to the lovestruck Hippodameia, and the promise was to sabotage Oenomaus' chariot.  Calder (Philologus 118, 1974, 205ff) prefers to see the statement as a generalization, used by Hippodameia to persuade Myrtilus, with particular reference to a sworn promise which had been made by Pelops to her:  she's saying, in effect, "Pelops has taken an oath, so you can trust him".  A further alternative might be Hippodameia using a generalisation about oaths to explain to Pelops (or Myrtilus) why she wants him to swear to fulfil his promises to her.

author: Lysias
title: Concerning the Olive Stump
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that that the defendant had not committed the crime]
