remarks: At the conclusion of his speech, the defendant reminds the jurors that he has produced (sworn) witnesses to prove to them that there was no stump on the plot of land.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Boeotian councillors feared that the Spartans would be offended if they swore oaths (see oath id) with the Corinthians because the Spartans believed that the Corinthians had broken off their alliance with them. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

title: IG XII Supplement
swearer: The uncle of the young man
if_taken: He can introduce his nephew to the phratry
if_refused: He cannot introduce his nephew to the phratry
statement:
[That the young man was the son of his brother]
 ὁ δὲ ἐσάγωγ [καὶ ὀμνύτω] ἀδελφο̃ παῖδα·
remarks:
For the oath sworn by the father (if he was still alive) see oath id 728.  
For the oath sworn by the witnesses see oath id 729.  
For the oath sworn by the mother see oath id 730.  
For oath sworn when an elder brother introduced a young man to the phratry see oath id 731.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would be allies and friends of the Athenians and to be ready to hand over their harbours to the Athenians and to be ready to assist the Athenians to the best of their ability and to abide by their agreements with the Athenians faithfully and guilelessly]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Halieis. 
After the entire citizen body of Halieis swore the oath, these presbeis from Halieis reported proceedings to the Athenians and swore destruction upon themselves if they did not abide by the oaths which the other citizens swore.  
For the oath sworn by the citizens of Halieis see oath id 228.  
For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 229.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will put scent on him whether he likes it or not]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην, ἤν τε βούλῃ γ’ ἤν τε μή.
remarks: Cf. oath id 1211.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That there will be no need for honours like those awarded to Harmodius and Aristogeiton in the future]
 ὅτι νὴ Δία πόρρω τοῦ τι τοιοῦτον νῦν ἐλπίζειν ἐσμέν.
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that Leptines will object in this way to his criticism of Leptines' law, which would forbid any future grant of exemption from liturgies, even to men whose achievements matched those of Harmodius and Aristogeiton.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
impact: Encourages the young man to want to migrate there
statement:
[That the Nephelokokkugians consider it very manly when a bird who is still a chick beats up his father]
 Καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἀνδρεῖόν γε πάνυ νομίζομεν,
  ὃς ἂν πεπλήγῃ τὸν πατέρα νεοττὸς ὤν.
remarks: It seems that this law is true to an extent, but it is also true as is related subsequently at 1354-1357 that birds must also care for their fathers in old age. Dunbar comments ad loc. that "the two [laws] that Peis. adduces are compatible as referring to two different types of behaviour, striking one's father when he is stronger, which needs courage… and feeding him when he is weaker, which shows piety".  They are also compatible as referring to two different species (respectively, cockerels and storks).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Prior to the destruction of Plataea, the Athenians and Plataeans assisted each other when they were threatened
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The Plataean envoys remind Archidamus that the Athenians assisted them against the Thebans when the Spartans refused to help them. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1561.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That they should not give up the discussion before they have seen clearly that it is beneficial in all circumstances to live justly]
 ἀλλ’ ὅμως ἐπείπερ ἐνταῦθα ἐληλύθαμεν, ὅσον οἷόν τε σαφέστατα κατιδεῖν ὅτι ταῦτα οὕτως ἔχει οὐ χρὴ ἀποκάμνειν.  Ἥκιστα, νὴ τὸν Δία, ἔφη, πάντων ἀποκμητέον.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That Bdelycleon deserves to be accused of being a conpirator with dictatorial ambitions]
 αἰτίαν ἔχω 
 ταῦτα δρᾶν ξυνωμότης ὢν καὶ φρονῶν τυραννικά.
 {Φι.}  νὴ Δί’, ἐν δίκῃ γ’·
remarks: For further context, see remarks on id 1090.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Pantaenetus
statement:
[That although some money-lenders are rightly hated because they have no thought for human feelings or anything else except profit, he does not defraud them or accuse them maliciously]
 οὐδὲ φιλῶ, οὐ μέντοι γ’ ἀποστερῶ μὰ Δία, οὐδὲ συκοφαντῶ.

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
statement:
[That what Protagoras does to wrong Hippocrates is to be wise himself without making Hippocrates wise]
 μῶν τί σε ἀδικεῖ Πρωταγόρας;” Καὶ ὃς γελάσας, “Νὴ τοὺς θεούς,” ἔφη, “ὦ Σώκρατες, ὅτι γε μόνος ἐστὶ  σοφός, ἐμὲ δὲ οὐ ποιεῖ.”
remarks: Socrates responds directly with an informal oath of his own. See oath id 3107.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That they will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, they shall help with all their strength]
remarks:
Cleiteles the Corinthian envoy to Athens in 370 warns the Athenians that they will be violating their own oaths if they do not aid the Corinthians against the Thebans. 
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he will tell them why he enjoys the company of the ugly man so much]
 Ἐγὼ ὑμῖν νὴ τὸν Δία, ὦ ἄνδρες, ἐρῶ.
remarks: He explains that the man is happy to be at his beck and call, he works hard and inspires others to do the same. Cf. oath id 2346.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
Aeschines tells the jurors that when they give Demosthenes credit for the alliance with Thebes they deceive the ignorant and insult the sensible and well informed. 
See also oath id 2670.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That Creon would not keep his peace if he saw destruction threatening his citizens nor would he count as a friend someone who was an enemy of the land]
 ἐγὼ γάρ, ἴστω Ζεὺς ὁ πάνθ’ ὁρῶν ἀεί,  οὔτ’ ἂν σιωπήσαιμι τὴν ἄτην ὁρῶν στείχουσαν ἀστοῖς ἀντὶ τῆς σωτηρίας,
  οὔτ’ ἂν φίλον ποτ’ ἄνδρα δυσμενῆ χθονὸς  θείμην ἐμαυτῷ,
remarks: Demosthenes quotes these lines from Sophocles' Antigone. See oath id 245.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Sicilian Naxians as allies.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he is the soldier who carried the sick man]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δί’
remarks:
At the scrutiny of his time in office, Xenophon is accused by several men of beating them because of his arrogance. 
The first says that he was assigned to the post of driving a mule even though he was a free man. 
Xenophon recognises him and asks whether he is the fellow who carried off the sick man. The man replies, "yes by Zeus", adding that Xenophon forced him to do so. 
Xenophon then explains that he beat this man because he tried to bury the sick man even though he was not dead.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That it does not seem reasonable to take pleasure in watching a dramatic character acting in a way which would be unacceptable in reality]
 Ἦ καλῶς οὖν, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, οὗτος ὁ ἔπαινος ἔχει, τὸ ὁρῶντα τοιοῦτον ἄνδρα, οἷον ἑαυτόν τις μὴ ἀξιοῖ εἶναι ἀλλ’ αἰσχύνοιτο ἄν, μὴ βδελύττεσθαι ἀλλὰ χαίρειν τε καὶ ἐπαινεῖν; Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, οὐκ εὐλόγῳ ἔοικεν.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That they should offer the goddess a sheep]
  Ὀί; 
  {ΟΙ.}  Ναὶ μὰ Δί’.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That he donated a trireme] 
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία τριήρη ἐπέδωκεν
remarks: Demosthenes asks what liturgies Meidias has performed, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his rhetorical question.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Dicaeogenes
swearer: The husbands of the sisters of Dicaeogenes (II); Dicaeogenes (III)
swearee: The husbands of the sisters of Dicaeogenes (II); Dicaeogenes (III)
statement:
[That they would not transgress the agreed terms]
 ὀμόσαντες μὴ παραβήσεσθαι τὰ ὡμολογημένα
remarks:
According to Menexenus, when Dicaeogenes (II) died, his uncle Proxenus (the father of Dicaeogenes III) produced a will which stipulated that Dicaeogenes (III) was to be recognised as the adopted son of Dicaeogenes (II), and heir to one third of his estate. The rest of the estate was to be divided equally among his sisters i.e. Menexenus' mother and her sisters. 
Menexenus states that "our fathers" i.e. the husbands of the sisters of Dicaeogenes (II) agreed to this, and that when they had divided up the inheritance, they swore not to transgress the agreed terms, and each remained in possession of his share for twelve years. 
At this time Dicaeogenes (III) brought a suit claiming that he had been adopted as the sole heir of Dicaeogenes (II), and thus deprived the sisters of Dicaeogenes (II) of their inheritance. 
Dicaeogenes II died in a sea-battle off Cnidus, probably that of Syme in early 411 (Thuc. 8.42), and the division of the inheritance remained in effect for twelve years, i.e. from 412/1 until 401/0.  Dicaeogenes III therefore advanced his claim in 401/0; the reference to stasis does not require us to assume an earlier date, since 401/0 was the year in which the democrats reconquered the mini-state of Eleusis which had been granted to the oligarchs in 403. The date of the oath, therefore, is 411.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Aristides; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of various poleis
swearee: Aristides; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of various poleis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Athens at the outbreak of the war in 431 as: 
Chios, Lesbos, Plataea (allied since 519), the Messenians in Naupactus (allied since ca.461), the Acarnanians (allied since 431), Corcyra (allied since 434/3), Zacynthus, some cities in Caria, the Dorians adjacent to Caria, Ionia, the Hellespont, the coast of Thrace and the Cyclades except Melos and Thera (each of these poleis presumably became allies at the same time as Chios and Lesbos). 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he has not even said the ten-thousandth part of the things "we" (i.e. women) do]
 Ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἂν ἔτ’ ἔχοις· ὅσα γὰρ ᾔδησθ’ ἐξέχεας ἅπαντα. 
  {ΚΗ.}  Μὰ Δί’ οὐδέπω τὴν μυριοστὴν μοῖραν ὧν ποιοῦμεν.
remarks: Once again, the Inlaw is speaking through his disguise as a woman; cf. oath id 721.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Argives believed that because Sparta had made an alliance with Boeotia the Spartans had persuaded the Boeotians to accede to the treaty with Athens, and thus feared that their whole confederacy would go over to the Spartans. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 233.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs

author: Demosthenes
title: Exordia
statement:
[That the Spartans, who take every opportunity to seize political and strategic advantages, are very unlike the Athenians who, thanks to the speaker's opponents and those like them, are more concerned to take advantage of each other than of their enemies]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχ ὥσπερ ἡμεῖς καὶ διὰ τούτους καὶ τοὺς ὁμοίους τούτοις

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates describes the King's Peace as "of such a character that no one can point out in all history one more shameful, more reprehensible or more derogatory to the Greeks". 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Stesichorus
title: Fragment
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment refers to someone swearing, but we cannot tell what they swore.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That a dung basket is beautiful]
 Ἆρ’ οὖν, ἔφη, καὶ κόφινος κοπροφόρος καλόν ἐστι; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη
remarks: The argument is that something which is well made for its particular purpose is beautiful; cf. oath id 2099.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would be allies to the Persians and would not betray them]
 μήτε προδώσειν ἀλλήλους σύμμαχοί τε ἔσεσθαι·
remarks:
According to Xenophon, the Greeks met with Cyrus' Persian troops led by Ariaeus at "the first stopping place" (see 2.1.3). 
The Greek generals and lochagoi and Ariaeus and his highest officers exchanged oaths that they would not betray each other and they would be allies. The Persians also swore to lead the Greeks out of the area without treachery (see oath id 2169). 
The oaths were sealed by sacrificing a bull, a wolf, and a ram over a shield, with the Greeks dipping swords into the blood and the Persians dipping spears. 
After this exchange of oaths the Greeks and the Persians made their escape. 
See also oath id 2175. 
For sacrificing over a shield during the exchanging of oaths see Aeschylus, Seven Against Thebes (oath id 198). For dipping weapons in the blood see Herodotus (oath id 1327) and Aristophanes, Lysistrata (oath id 1164).

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That those who love in the right way should not have anything to do with extravagant and licentious pleasure]
 Οὐ προσοιστέον ἄρα αὕτη ἡ ἡδονή, οὐδὲ κοινωνητέον αὐτῆς ἐραστῇ τε καὶ παιδικοῖς ὀρθῶς ἐρῶσί τε καὶ ἐρωμένοις; Οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, προσοιστέον.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Andocides states that the Athenians rejected an offer of an alliance with Syracuse (see oath id 2426) in favour of their existing alliances with Egesta and Catana.  
Andocides states that instead of choosing peace with the Syracusans they chose to go to Sicily for the Egestans and Catanians, losing many Athenians and allies, the best before the rest, and throwing away many ships and much money in the process. 
See also oath id 1839.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
statement:
[That the course of action taken by Conon's supporters at the arbitration was found disgusting by everyone present, and in the end they disgusted even themselves]
 ἃ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ἄνδρες δικασταί, οὐδεὶς ὅστις οὐκ ἐπετίμα τῶν παρόντων καὶ ἐμίσει, τελευτῶντες δὲ καὶ αὐτοὶ οὗτοι ἑαυτούς.
remarks: Ariston describes how Conon's supporters stretched out the proceedings past midnight by refusing to read their depositions, bringing Ariston's witnesses to the stone one by one and putting them under oath (see oath id 3673), and writing out irrelevant depostions. Ariston claims that these actions disgusted all of those present.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the Sicilian allies of Syracuse; Representatives of the Sicilian allies of Athens; Generals
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the Sicilian allies of Syracuse; Representatives of the Sicilian allies of Athens; Generals
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms that each city would keep what possessions it had at that time, except that the Camarinaeans were to have Morgantina upon payment of a stated sum of money to the Syracusans]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Sicilians agreed to make peace.  
When they did so, the Sicilian allies of Athens summoned the Athenian generals and informed them that they proposed to make peace and that the treaty would include the Athenians. When the generals agreed the treaty was formalised. 
Thucydides adds that when the Athenian generals returned home they were prosecuted for bribery because they had failed to subdue Sicily when it was in their power to do so. Pythodorus and Sophocles were sentenced to exile and Eurymedon was fined.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he has never seen anything funnier]
 Μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ μὲν πρᾶγμά πω 
 γελοιότερον οὐκ εἶδον οὐδεπώποτε.
remarks: Euelpides is laughing at Peisetaerus' bird costume, though he himself is also dressed as a bird.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That he believes that there were two reasons, not just one,  why many citizens urged him to prosecute Meidias i.e. that it wasn't only sympathy for Demosthenes, but also because they wanted an opportunity to punish Meidias for his treatment of other people]
 ὡς μὲν ἐμοὶ δοκεῖ, δι’ ἀμφότερ’, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, νὴ τοὺς θεούς,
remarks: Demosthenes argues that those who urged him to prosecute Meidias thought that he had been treated shockingly by Meidias, and they wished to punish Meidias for other cases in which they had observed that he was audacious, disgusting, and out of control.

author: Demosthenes
title: On Halonnesus
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Hegesippus claims that his draft amendment to the peace treaty, providing "that each side should hold what belonged to it" (instead of "what it held"), proved that Philip did not wish to amend the peace, but to bring discredit upon those who were arguing in Athenian interests. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That Myrrhine should not lie down with him in front of the baby]
 Τί οὖν οὐ κατεκλίνης, ὦ Μύρριον;
 {ΜΥ.}  Ὦ καταγέλαστ’, ἐναντίον τοῦ παιδίου;
 {ΚΙ.}  Μὰ Δί’

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would defend the Bottiaeans in the alliance without guile and zealously according to the agreed terms and to bear no malice on account of the past]
 [ἀμυνο̃ τοῖς] Βοττια[ίοις τοῖς] χσυντιθεμέ[νοι]ς [τὲν συμμαχίαν, κ]αὶ τὲν χσ[υμμαχία]ν πιστο̃ς καὶ [ἀδ]όλο[ς φυλάχσο Βοττι]αίοις προ[θυμόμεν]ος κατὰ τὰ χ[συ]νκε[ίμενα· καὶ οὐ μνε]σικακέσο το̃[ν παρ]οιχομένον ἕ[νε]κα·
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and poleis in the Bottiae. 
This entry takes into account textual changes suggested in Agora 16.16. 
For the corresponding oath of the Bottiaeans, see oath id 232.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Representatives of the Persian King; Envoys
swearee: Representatives of the Persian King; Envoys
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds the jurors of what is said to have happened to Callias after he negotiated the peace that bore his name: it was the best peace that Athens ever made, yet Callias was judged to have accepted bribes on the embassy, and forced to pay a fine of fifty talents. He compares the results of the peace of Callias to those of the peace of Philocrates (see oath id 3814) and argues that they need a prosecutor, and to try the men whose crimes are obvious (i.e. Aeschines and Philocrates). 
See also oath id 3003.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: [That they would not neither work the land themselves, nor allow anyone else, but would aid the god and the consecrated land with hand and foot <and voice> and every means]
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes contrived to pass a decree that the Athenian sacred envoy and the delegates to the Amphictyones should go to Thermopylae and Delphi at the times appointed by their ancestors i.e. to prevent the Athenians from taking part in the extraordinary conference at Thermopylae to determine the punishment of Amphissa for violating the oath. He alleges that this meant that the Athenians were forbidden to remember the oaths that their ancestors swore, or the curse, or the god's oracle. 
He states that only one other city stayed away from the special meeting, and that this city (Thebes) has since suffered terrible disasters.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he always arranges his troops in the complicated manner he describes when they go to dinner]
 καὶ ὅταν τέλος ἡ σκηνὴ ἔχῃ, ἐξάγει μὲν ὁ οὐραγός, ἔφη, ὁ τοῦ τελευταίου λόχου τὸν λόχον, ὑστάτους ἔχων τοὺς πρώτους τεταγμένους εἰς μάχην· ἔπειτα ὁ δεύτερος τοὺς τοῦ ἑτέρου λόχου ἐπὶ τούτοις, καὶ ὁ τρίτος καὶ ὁ τέταρτος ὡσαύτως, ὅπως, ἔφη, καὶ ὅταν ἀπάγειν δέῃ ἀπὸ πολεμίων, ἐπίστωνται ὡς δεῖ ἀπιέναι. ἐπειδὰν δέ, ἔφη, καταστῶμεν ἐπὶ τὸν δρόμον ἔνθα περιπατοῦμεν, ὅταν μὲν πρὸς ἕω ἴωμεν, ἐγὼ μὲν ἡγοῦμαι, καὶ ὁ πρῶτος λόχος πρῶτος, καὶ ὁ δεύτερος ὡς δεῖ, καὶ ὁ τρίτος καὶ ὁ τέταρτος, καὶ αἱ τῶν λόχων δεκάδες καὶ πεμπάδες, ἕως ἂν παραγγέλλω ἐγώ· ὅταν δ’, ἔφη, πρὸς ἑσπέραν ἴωμεν, ὁ οὐραγός τε καὶοἱ τελευταῖοι πρῶτοι ἀφηγοῦνται· ἐμοὶ μέντοι οὕτω πείθονται ὑστέρῳ ἰόντι, ἵνα ἐθίζωνται καὶ ἕπεσθαι καὶ ἡγεῖσθαι ὁμοίως πειθόμενοι. καὶ ὁ Κῦρος ἔφη· Ἦ καὶ ἀεὶ τοῦτο 
ποιεῖτε; Ὁποσάκις γε, ἔφη, καὶ δειπνοποιούμεθα νὴ Δία.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That they'll sue if he doesn't pay by end of month]
  πᾶς γάρ τις ὀμνύς, οἷς ὀφείλων τυγχάνω, 
  θείς μοι πρυτανεῖ’ ἀπολεῖν μέ φησι κἀξολεῖν.
  κἀμοῦ μέτριά τε καὶ δίκαι’ αἰτουμένου,
  “ὦ δαιμόνιε, τὸ μέν τι νυνὶ μὴ λάβῃς,
 τὸ δ’ ἀναβαλοῦ μοι, τὸ δ’ ἄφες”, οὔ φασίν ποτε
  οὕτως ἀπολήψεσθ’, ἀλλὰ λοιδοροῦσί με 
  ὡς ἄδικός εἰμι, καὶ δικάσεσθαί φασί μοι.
remarks: Cf. oath id 47.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: Athenian officials; Highest officials of the allies of Athens; Highest officials of the Mantineans; Highest officials of the other Greeks
statement:
[That they will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, they shall help with all their strength]
 Ἐμμενῶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ἃς βασιλεὺς κατέπεμψε καὶ τοῖς ψηφίσμασι τοῖς Ἀθηναίων καὶ τῶν συμμάχων. ἐὰν δέ τις στρατεύῃ ἐπί τινα πόλιν τῶν ὀμοσασῶν τόνδε τὸν ὅρκον, βοηθήσω παντὶ σθένει
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Athenians invited to Athens all the poleis which wished to participate in the peace which the King had sent down i.e. the King's Peace of 387/6. 
When they came the Athenians passed a decree to take the following oath: "I will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, I shall help with all my strength". 
Xenophon states that all the others were pleased with the oath except for the Eleans, who said that it was not right to make the Marganians, Scilluntians or Triphylians autonomous, because these cities belonged to them. 
Despite their objections, the Athenians and their allies, after voting that both small and great cities should be autonomous alike, just as the King wrote, sent out the oath-commisioners (horkotai) and directed them to administer the oath to the highest officials in each city. 
Xenophon observes that they all took the oath except for the Eleans. 
The Mantineans now felt that they were entirely independent, and voted to make Mantinea a single city and to build a wall around it. 
For references to the original King's Peace see oath id 328. 
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1974, 1975, 1976, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1989, 1991, 1992, 3426, 3716.

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
if_taken: The student can pay Protagoras the sum of X in full settlement
if_refused: The student must pay the fee Protagoras has specified
impact: Intended impact- Protagoras is paid what it is thought he deserves
statement:
[That the value of Protagoras' teachings is X amount]
 ἐὰν δὲ μή, ἐλθὼν εἰς ἱερόν, ὀμόσας ὅσου ἂν φῇ ἄξια εἶναι τὰ μαθήματα, τοσοῦτον κατέθηκε.
remarks: This is a general proposition that Protagoras says he offers all his students if they do not want to pay the fee he asks for.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
impact: Medea comes to Greece with Jason
consequences_of_breach: Causes Medea's fury and revenge plan
statement: [That he would be faithful to Medea]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 111.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Apaturius
statement:
[That Apaturius was well off, so that he was in a position to leave his proceedings against the speaker until later]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία εὐπόρως διέκειτο, ὥστ’ ἐνεδέχετο αὐτῷ καὶ ὕστερον ἐπ’ ἐμὲ ἐλθεῖν,
remarks: The speaker wonders why Apaturius has waited three years to bring the case against him, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his question.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
if_taken: He will be part of a conspiracy
if_refused: He will not be part of a conspiracy
statement: [That he will be party to the conspiracy]
remarks: The chorus here suggest that Bdelycleon is a conspirator, much as they do at id 1079. See remarks there; cf. oath id 1107.

title: SEG
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text indicates that in the month of Metageitnion an "oath-victim" (ὁρκωμόσιον) was to be provided for the scrutinies.  
See also oath id 549.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Sparta at the start of the war in 431 as all of the Peloponnesians within the Isthmus except for Argos and Achaea (Pellene was the only Achaean city allied to Sparta), Megara, the Locrians (the Opuntian and Epicnemidian), the Boeotians, Phocians, the Ambraciots, the Leucadians and Anactorians. 
Megara had revolted from Sparta, but rejoined the League in 446. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That "Nobody" (i.e. Philocleon) will have "no bloody joy" from his trick]
 Οὖτις μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὔτι χαιρήσων γε σύ.
remarks: Sommerstein's translation here captures the Greek pun on "Nobody" (Outis) and "going to have no joy" (outi khaireson). See also remarks on oath id 1067 for further context.

author: Plato
title: Charmides
statement:
[That when he speaks of "knowledge", he does not mean "knowledge of shoemaking"]
 τίνος ἐπιστημόνως λέγεις; ἦ σκυτῶν τομῆς;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Telecleides
title: Prytaneis
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment contains an informal oath invoking cabbages as sanctifying oath objects. Cf. oath ids 1380, 1470, 1483 and also id 1382 "by the poppy leaf" and id 1468 “ by the Almond Tree”. For further remarks, see id 1380.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That Meidias is a loathsome bully]
 ὅτι νὴ Δί’ ἀσελγής ἐστι καὶ βδελυρός
remarks: Demosthenes asks the jurors what excuse they could give for Meidias' behaviour. He then sarcastically suggests that someone might respond that Meidias is a loathsome bully.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That a good lawgiver must be on his guard from afar against idle and spendthrift men, to prevent them springing up, and if they do, to get rid of them]
 ὣ δὴ καὶ  δεῖ τὸν ἀγαθὸν ἰατρόν τε καὶ νομοθέτην πόλεως μὴ ἧττον ἢ σοφὸν μελιττουργὸν πόρρωθεν εὐλαβεῖσθαι, μάλιστα μὲν ὅπως μὴ ἐγγενήσεσθον, ἂν δὲ ἐγγένησθον, ὅπως ὅτι τάχιστα σὺν αὐτοῖσι τοῖς κηρίοις ἐκτετμήσεσθον. Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, παντάπασί γε.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That it seems to him that the men are not just in being angry with Xenophon]
 Οὐ τὼ σιώ, ἀλλ’ ἐμοὶ μέντοι οὐ δικαίως δοκεῖτε τῷ ἀνδρὶ τούτῳ χαλεπαίνειν·
gods_invoked: The twin gods i.e. Castor and Pollux
remarks: After making this oath, Charminus adds that he can bear witness for Xenophon himself.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he was in earnest about what he was proposing (to give the Sacian all his wealth to deal with as he wished, so long as he provided for Pheraulas as a modest guest)]
 καὶ ὁ Φεραύλας ὀμόσας εἶπεν ἦ μὴν σπουδῇ λέγειν.
remarks: The Sacian and Pheraulas have been arguing over the joy which wealth brings. Pheraulas maintains that it is a burden, the Sacian thinks it will bring joy, so Pheraulas makes a proposition which should make them both happy. Cf. oath ids 2487-2489.

author: Pindar
title: Olympian 13
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a reference to the fact that the power of the gods can bring to pass even what one would swear impossible.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_refused: War will continue as it is
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Zeus orders Athena to make the Trojans break the truce. This is the same oath referred to throughout books 3 and 4, in most detail at oath id 318.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Argives would restore to the Orchomenians their children, to the Maenalians their men and to the Spartans the men they had installed at Mantinea
2. The Argives were to evacuate Epidaurus and demolish the fortifications they had built there
3. If the Athenians did not withdraw from Epidaurus they were to be enemies of both Sparta and Argos (and the allies of both)
4. The Spartans were to restore any children to their homelands
5. Concerning the offering to Apollo Pythaeus (which the Epidaurians had been accused of not making cf. Thucydides 5.53.1), the Argives could impose an oath upon the Epidaurians, or alternatively could swear it themselves (see oath id 1747 and 1760)
6. If anyone from outside the Peloponnese should invade the Peloponnese they shuld repel the invader, taking counsel with the other Peloponnesians
7. They should convey this agreement to their other allies and make terms with them as seemed best, but if the allies preferred they were to be allowed to send the treaty home for consideration.]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Spartans marched out to Tegea and then sent envoys to Argos regarding a peace treaty. According to Thucydides a faction opposed to democracy convinced the Argives to make peace, after which the Spartans returned home.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That there is one excellent principle which they must acknowledge, as men of sense, that they know nothing about the gods or about their real names, i.e. those by which they call themselves]
 Ναὶ μὰ Δία ἡμεῖς γε, ὦ Ἑρμόγενες, εἴπερ γε νοῦν ἔχοιμεν, ἕνα μὲν τὸν κάλλιστον τρόπον, ὅτι περὶ θεῶν οὐδὲν ἴσμεν, οὔτε περὶ αὐτῶν οὔτε περὶ τῶν ὀνομάτων, ἅττα ποτὲ ἑαυτοὺς καλοῦσιν· δῆλον γὰρ ὅτι ἐκεῖνοί γε τἀληθῆ καλοῦσι.

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
statement: [That he will take Philoctetes home]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 285.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
statement:
[That you have the honour of your grandfather and father to uphold and it would be scandalous to subvert it in your person]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία παππῴα σοι καὶ πατρῴα δόξ’ ὑπάρχει, ἣν αἰσχρόν ἐστιν ἐν σοὶ καταλῦσαι·
remarks: Presumably the objector is actually meant to be Aristomedes (70), talking about himself, and Dem. is being sarcastic:  his father and grandfather have no reputation to maintain ("you had a thief for a father - at least if he was anything like you") while Athens has a reputation "known by all the Greeks whom she saved from the greatest dangers".

title: IG I(3)
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of an unknown state
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of an unknown state
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and an unidentified polis. 
The terms ὀμνύτ[ο] and hορκοσ are included in lines 5 and 10. However, this inscription is too fragmentary to make any further comments.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_taken: Cersobleptes would be a party to the peace
if_refused: Cersobleptes would not be a party to the peace
remarks:
Demosthenes complains that the Athenians overlook anything that does not immediately cause them trouble and annoyance, and pass pointless decrees such as "Philip is to swear oaths also to Cersobleptes". 
This is probably a reference to the decree proposed by Aleximachus of Pelece to the effect that the representative of Cersobleptes should be permitted to join the other allies in giving the oath to Philip, but Demosthenes (in his capacity as one of the proedroi) refused to put the motion to the vote (see also oath id 2583). 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Isocrates
title: Concerning the team of horses
if_taken: Their alliance with Argos, Mantinea and Elis would be formalised
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
The speaker - Alcibiades the younger - reminds the jurors that his father caused the most powerful cities in the Peloponnese to revolt from the Spartans and brought them into alliance with Athens. 
This must be a reference to the alliance between Athens, Argos, Mantinea and Elis ca.420 (see also oath id 251).  This alliance was to be sworn separately in each of the contracting cities (the details given above are for the Athenian ceremony), and re-sworn at four-year intervals by Athenian representatives visiting the three Peloponnesian cities and vice versa.

author: Aristophanes
title: Horai
statement: unknown
remarks: This single line refers to the breaking of an oath by someone.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds

author: Gorgias
title: Fragment 15
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a reference to Gorgias describing the same people as both breaking and keeping their oaths. Cf. oath id 1737.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Greeks were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Greeks while they collected their dead]
remarks:
A detachment of Greeks who had been occupying a hill were dislodged by the Carduchians. 
Xenophon led a force to rescue them, and concluded a truce for collecting the dead. 
However, his truce (which also included a provision that the Greeks would not burn the Carduchians' houses) never took effect, since while the negotiations were still going on, many other Carduchians attacked Xenophon's detachment; but after they had escaped, a truce for the return of bodies was in the end concluded (4.2.23), on condition that a Carduchian whom they had captured, and whom they had forced on pain of death to serve as their guide (4.1.22-25), should be released.  It is not clear whether his release was part of the sworn terms, or whether it was a precondition for the truce.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 2
statement:
[That what happens on the bema is a disgrace to the city]
 ἀλλὰ ταῦτά γε νὴ τὴν Ἀθηνᾶν ὄνειδός ἐστιν, ἄνδρες δικασταί, τῇ πόλει γιγνόμεν’ ἐπὶ τοῦ βήματος,
remarks: The speaker has just described how Aristogeiton rails at everyone and shouts people down.

author: Heniochus
title: Trochilos
statement:
[That his is thinking to himself how much figs differ from cress]
 πρὸς ἐμαυτὸν ἐνθυμούμενος, νὴ τοὺς θεούς, 
ὅσῳ διαφέρει σῦκα καρδάμων
remarks: The point is, presumably, that the former can satisfy hunger, the latter not.

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That Thessalian gentlemen do not profess themselves to be teachers of virtue]
 καὶ ὁμολογεῖν διδάσκαλοί τε εἶναι καὶ διδακτὸν ἀρετήν;  {ΜΕΝ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That he would grant safe conduct to Pharnabazus and his escort to and from the meeting with him]
remarks:
Xenophon states that Pharnabazus made an agreement with Agesilaus that he would revolt from the Great King if he were not appointed general of the Persian forces, but also warned Agesilaus that if he were apppinted to the generalship he would make war on him with all his might, and did so in full confidence that nothing contrary to the terms of the treaty would happen to him. 
See also oath id 1927.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That (he thinks) Socrates' argument coheres well]
  νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω, τοῦτό γε τοι τῷ νυνὶ λόγῳ εὖ προσέφυσας.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That when he appoints foremen he also teaches them to be concerned about acquiring the good things they want for themselves]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος, τοιούτους ὅταν ἐπιτρόπους βούλωμαι καθιστάναι, καὶ ἐπιμελεῖσθαι διδάσκω.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the same party at Argos which had brought about the peace treaty with Sparta then brought about the renunciation of the alliance with the Mantineans, Eleans and Athenians. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Demosthenes
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Hypereides reminds the jurors that they have sworn to observe the laws when voting. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That tyrants get to see only a few spectacles, and for these they have to pay exorbitantly]
 ναὶ μὰ Δία, ὦ Σιμωνίδη, ὀλίγα γε τῶν πολλῶν καὶ ταῦτα τοιαῦτα ὄντα οὕτω τίμια πωλεῖται τοῖς τυράννοις ὥστε οἱ ἐπιδεικνύμενοι καὶ ὁτιοῦν ἀξιοῦσι πολλαπλάσια λαβόντες ἐν ὀλίγῳ χρόνῳ ἀπιέναι παρὰ τοῦ τυράννου ἢ ὅσα ἐν παντὶ τῷ βίῳ παρὰ πάντων τῶν ἄλλων ἀνθρώπων κτῶνται.
remarks: Hiero observes that tyrants are often afraid to attend festivals abroad. He then speculates that Simonides might argue that such spectacles might come to them even if they stayed at home. His oath is a response to this hypothetical objection.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That he knows only too well that this altar will not help him at all]
καὶ τοῦτο μέν, ἔφη, μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐκ ἀγνοῶ, ὅτι οὐδέν μοι ἀρκέσει ὅδε ὁ βωμός
remarks:
After Critias denounced Theramenes before the boule, the latter leapt onto the hearth (ἐπὶ τὴν ἑστίαν) and begged to be judged according to the law. He swore that he knew that the altar would not help him, but he wanted to show the boule that the Thirty were not only unjust toward men, but also impious to the gods. 
When Theramenes was then dragged from the altar by the Eleven he called upon the gods and men to witness what was happening, which was "natural" in the opinion of Xenophon. Theramenes was then forced to drink hemlock.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he thinks there is no profit in possessing or understanding all things apart from that which is good]
 ἢ οἴει τι πλέον εἶναι πᾶσαν κτῆσιν ἐκτῆσθαι, μὴ μέντοι ἀγαθήν; ἢ πάντα τἆλλα φρονεῖν ἄνευ τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ, καλὸν δὲ καὶ ἀγαθὸν μηδὲν φρονεῖν;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’, ἔφη.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he was not knocking so hard on the door]
  σὺ τὴν θύραν ἔκοπτες οὑτωσὶ σφόδρα;
  {ΕΡ.}  Μὰ Δί’
remarks: As Sommerstein ad 1102 remarks: "Hermes..may be lying outright, but more probably he is to be understood as equivocating. His words can be taken to mean either "I didn't knock hard" or "I didn't knock"; they are at least arguably true in the former sense, but he expects them to be understood in the latter".

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement:
[That it never came into his mind to grudge Charidemus the favours he received from the Athenians]
 μὰ τὸν Δία καὶ θεοὺς πάντας οὐδενὸς εἰσῄει μοι φθονεῖν

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the oracle Lysistrata has read out is clear]
 Σαφής γ’ ὁ χρησμὸς νὴ Δί’. Ὦ πάντες θεοί.

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The King's country in Asia is to remain his possession and to be governed as he pleases
2. The Spartans and their allies shall not go against the country of the King, nor the King against the Spartans and their allies.
3. If any of the Spartans and their allies go against the King's territory, the Spartans and their allies shall stop them, and if any of the King's subjects go against the Spartans and their allies the King shall stop them
4. Tissaphernes shall pay for the ships now present until the arrival of the King's ships. After these arrive, the Spartans can then pay for their own ships if they wish. If not, Tissaphernes will provide money, but the Spartans will repay the money at the end of the war
5. When the King's ships arrive, the ships of the Spartans and their allies and those of the King shall wage war together, according to what seems best to Tissaphernes and the Spartans and their allies. If they wish to end the war with the Athenians, they will do so jointly]
remarks:
Isocrates observes that the Athenians and Spartans both made peace with the Persians in the years that followed Xerxes' invasion.  The first such agreement made by Sparta was that of 412/1, some 67 years after the defeat of Xerxes' invasion and 37 years after the Peace of Callias (see oath id 3003), but it suits Isocrates to put no less blame on Sparta than on Athens. 
See also oath id 1818.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 1
statement:
[That they will you do what needs doing when they have no alternative]
 ἐπειδὰν νὴ Δί’ ἀνάγκη τις ᾖ.
remarks:
Demosthenes asks, "When will you do what needs doing?", and imagines that someone will respond, "Why, by Zeus, when we have no alternative." 
Demosthenes then goes on to argue that there now is no alternative. 
See also oath id 3255 and 3279.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the Spartans are in the wrong]
  Ἀδικοῦσιν οὗτοι νὴ Δί’, ὦ Λυσιστράτη.
remarks: The truth of the statement is admitted in the next line by a Spartan.

author: Anonymus Iambicus
title: Fragment
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment contains someone swearing affirmatively by the poppy leaf; there follows the comment that it is a mocking oath. Cf. swearing by cabbage at oath id 1380 with cross references there.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
if_taken: His statement will carry more weight
statement: [That he had not injured Callippus when he gave Cephisiades the money Lycon had deposited with him, after he had promised that he would not pay it out without Callippus' consent]
remarks:
Apollodorus asks why Callippus offered an oath to Pasion (see oath id 3643) - thus presuming him to be an honest man who told no lies - when he now speaks of Pasion as a man who erases entries from a deposit ledger. 
He also asks why Pasion was not condemned if he refused to take the oath and did not give the money back

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Aeneas son of Ocytus; Amphias son of Eupalidas; Athenaeus, son of Pericleidas; Autocles, son of Tolmaeus; Damotimus son of Naucrates; Euphamidas son of Aristonymus; Menecrates son of Amphidorus; Nicasus, son of Cecalus; Nicias; Nicostratus; Onasimus, son of Megacles; Philocharidas; Taurus son of Echetimidas
swearee: Aeneas son of Ocytus; Amphias son of Eupalidas; Athenaeus, son of Pericleidas; Autocles, son of Tolmaeus; Damotimus son of Naucrates; Euphamidas son of Aristonymus; Menecrates son of Amphidorus; Nicasus, son of Cecalus; Nicias; Nicostratus; Onasimus, son of Megacles; Philocharidas; Taurus son of Echetimidas
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Free access to the oracle at Delphi (the Spartans promised to try to persuade the Boeotians and Phocians about this)
2. Those who had misused the treasures at Delphi were to be sought out
3. Each side should retain what territory it currently possessed (the Athenian garrison at Pylos should keep within the coastal high points Buphras and Tomaeus; the Athenian garrison in Cythera should have no communication with the territory of the Spartan allies; the Athenian garrison in Nisaea and Minoa should not cross the roads leading to the mainland and the Megarians should not cross it either; the Athenians should retain the island [Atalante?] which they took and neither side shall communicate with the other; the Athenians should retain whatever territory they possessed in Troezen in accordance with the agreements which the Troezenians had made with the Athenians)
4. The Spartans and their allies were not permitted to sail in oared ships except along their own coasts, and then only in vessels of less than 500 metra capacity not designed for use in war 
5. Deserters should not be received
6. Any disputes should be resolved by arbitration]
remarks:
The city of Mende in Pallene revolted from Athens, and Brasidas received them.  
Thucydides states that Brasidas believed that they were not wrong to come over to him despite the fact that it was during an armistice because he was charging the Athenians with breaking some points of the truce.  
For other references to the one-year armistice and its impact, see oath id 1676.

author: Isocrates
title: Antidosis
swearer: Representatives; Envoys; Envoys of the allies of Athens; Envoys
swearee: Representatives; Envoys; Envoys of the allies of Athens; Envoys
remarks:
Isocrates states that by capturing Corcyra and defeating the Spartans at sea, Timotheus forced the Spartans to make peace. According to Isocrates, this peace (the common peace of 371) changed the relative positions of Athens and Sparta, and since that day the Athenians have celebrated the peace with sacrifices each year because no other treaty was so advantageous to the city. 
See also oath id 1972.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides points out that the Athenians should have no reason to object to the peace now that Sparta has agreed to cease "wronging" Athens and the Boeotians have decided to make peace by allowing Orchomenos to be autonomous. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: When Lamprocles was a young man (405 to 399)
statement:
[That his mother says things that no one would be willing to listen to even if his life were at stake]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία, ἔφη, λέγει ἃ οὐκ ἄν τις ἐπὶ τῷ βίῳ παντὶ βούλοιτο ἀκοῦσαι.
remarks: In this exchange between the fictional Socrates and his son, it is noteworthy that he reprimands Lamprocles for not respecting his mother (Xanthippe),  although apparently Socrates respected her little himself. See also oath ids 2055 and 2056.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That a man who believes in the Underworld and its terrors will not be fearless in battle nor prefer death to defeat and slavery]
 Τί δὲ δὴ εἰ μέλλουσιν εἶναι ἀνδρεῖοι; ἆρα οὐ ταῦτά τε λεκτέον καὶ οἷα αὐτοὺς ποιῆσαι ἥκιστα τὸν θάνατον δεδιέναι;  ἢ ἡγῇ τινά ποτ’ ἂν γενέσθαι ἀνδρεῖον ἔχοντα ἐν αὑτῷ τοῦτο τὸ δεῖμα;  Μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That they would not injure one another]
 μὴ ἀδικήσειν ἀλλήλους·
remarks:
Xenophon states that when the two forces reached the junction of the Tigris and Zapatas rivers, suspicion was rife, although no plot came to light. 
When Clearchus next saw Tissaphernes, he addressed the issue, saying, "I know, Tissaphernes, that both of us have sworn oaths and given our right hands, not to injure one another, yet I see you are on your guard against us, and we, observing this, are keeping guard on our side". 
Clearchus goes on to tell Tissaphernes that he is mistaken to mistrust the Greeks for two reasons: 
Firstly, because they have consigned their friendship to the keeping of the gods. Clearchus says, "the oaths sworn by the gods stop us from being at war with each other, and the man who is conscious that he has disregarded such oaths I should never account happy." 
He goes on to add, "if one is at war with the gods [for violating their oaths], I do not know by what swiftness of foot in trying to flee one could make his escape, or into what darkness he could stead away, or how he could withdraw himself into a secure fortress, for all places are subject to the gods." 
Secondly, Clearchus says that on the human level (as opposed to that of the gods) he would not violate his oaths because Tissaphernes is the greatest good that they possess. 
Ctesias refers to the breaking of this oath by Tissaphernes (see oath id 3485).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes cites a decree concerning the seizure of Athenian grain ships, and tells the jurors (and Aeschines) that it was Philip who violated the peace when he seized the Athenian ships, not Athens. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, after concluding an alliance with Corinth, the embassy from Elis then went on to Argos and concluded an alliance with the Argives. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id  251.

author: Sophocles
title: Atreus
statement: unknown
remarks: Here a character complains about another character's cowardice, and says that although that person himself is feminine, he has male enemies. The oath-formula might be taken as roughly equivalent to 'As surely as it is true that he is a coward...'.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
if_taken: They will be able to judge
if_refused: They will not be able to judge
statement: [That they would decide justly whether each deme member was entitled to remain on the deme register]
remarks: Euxitheus states that the demesmen had an opportunity to remove his father Thucritus from the deme register had he been an alien and non-citizen when the voting register was lost at the time when Antiphilus (Euboulides' father) was demarch. Euxitheus states that when the demesmen had the necessity to vote on another, after binding themselves by solemn oaths, they expelled some of the members, but no one attacked his father.

author: Lysias
title: Against Simon
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had not wounded with the intent to kill]
remarks:
The defendant summons witnesses to testify to his version of the fight outside Lampon's house - i.e. that he defended the Plataean boy Theodotus who was being attacked, and that he was attacked himself by Simon. These witnesses would have sworn the diomosia prior to giving evidence, as was necessary in trials held before the Areopagus Council. 
See also oath id 2813.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the headpiece provided by Agathon is most suitable for the Inlaw's disguise]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἀλλὰ κἀπιτηδεία πάνυ.

author: Xenophon
title: Hiero
statement:
[That people compare the tyrant's lot with their own without having actually experienced both]
 Ὅτι ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἱέρων, ἄπειροι ὄντες ἀμφοτέρων τῶν ἔργων σκοποῦνται περὶ αὐτοῦ.
remarks: Hiero is responding to Simonides asking why all the people in the world envy tyrants.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That the most powerful commander is not the commander whose soldiers are fittest or best trained, but the commander who can inspire his men with “a love of work and a desire that he should see them doing something noble” so that they are willing to follow him “through fire and through every danger”]
 πρὸς ὅντινα δ’ ἂν ἄρχοντα διατεθῶσιν οὕτως οἱ ἑπόμενοι, οὗτοι δὴ ἐρρωμένοι γε ἄρχοντες γίγνονται, οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχ οἳ ἂν αὐτῶν ἄριστα τὸ σῶμα τῶν στρατιωτῶν ἔχωσι καὶ ἀκοντίζωσι καὶ τοξεύουσιν ἄριστα ...
remarks: Here, more than ever, we can hear Xenophon talking through Ischomachus; cf. oath id 1954.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
remarks:
Aeschines alleges that Demosthenes violated the peace by bestowing crowns of honour on the embassy which Aristodemus led to Thessaly and Magnesia in 343/2, contrary to the provisions of the peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
impact: Emphasises the sausage-seller's horror at the suggestion that he is of noble stock
statement:
[That he does not come from good or upright stock]
  Μῶν ἐκ καλῶν εἶ κἀγαθῶν;  
  {ΑΛ.}  Μὰ τοὺς θεούς

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he will make the students suffer] 
  νὴ Δί’, οἰμώξεσθ’ ἄρα.
remarks: The oath is fulfilled in an unexpected way when Strepsiades burns down the school at the end of the play.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the foreign horsemen who are now with them consider that everything that has fallen into the Persians' hands belongs not only no less, but perhaps even more, to them than to the Persians]
 εἰ δ’ οὕτω ταῦτ’ ἔχει, οὐκ εὔδηλον ὅτι οἱ νῦν παρόντες ἡμῖν ἱππεῖς νομίζουσι πάντα τὰ ὑποχείρια γιγνόμενα ἑαυτῶν εἶναι οὐχ ἧττον ἢ ἡμέτερα,  ἴσως δὲ νὴ Δία καὶ μᾶλλον;
remarks: Cyrus has just argued that without cavalry the Persians would be unable to kill or capture enemy cavalry, archers or light troops who had been put to flight or were retreating after an attack.

author: Alexis
title: Lampas
statement:
[That not even if he'd got hare's milk and been eating peacocks (could he) gobble up so much money on his own]
  καταφαγεῖν 
αὐτὸς τοσοῦτ’ ἀργύριον; οὐδ’ εἰ γάλα λαγοῦ 
εἶχον, μὰ τὴν γῆν, καὶ ταὧς, κατήσθιον
remarks: The translation is based on Arnott's suggestion (ad loc.), with autos interpreted as “on his own”, i.e. without the assistance of an extravagant mistress. He further comments ad loc. that the fragment "could be spoken by an angry father (or paedagogus or friend) claiming that he himself would never have been so extravagant, or by the infatuated lover picking up his accuser's words and trying to refute them". He also notes (ad 3) that the oath μὰ τὴν γῆν (and μὰ γῆν) is used in comedy only by male speakers (where the sex is identifiable).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Androtion
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus reminds the jurors that the question they are sworn to decide is not the one posed by the defendant - that the charges against him are the result of his successful collection of unpaid property taxes - but whether Androtion's proposal was in accordance with the laws. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_refused: Antilochus will not get the prize
statement: [That he did not cheat in the chariot race]
remarks: This oath is mentioned here during the chariot race at Patroclus' funeral games. It is proposed again in earnest after the race but is never taken, see oath id 423.

title: Hicks, Inscriptions of Cos
if_taken: They can become priestesses of Demeter
if_refused: They cannot become priestesses of Demeter
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that those chosen by lot shall become priestesses of Demeter upon swearing an oath (τὰς δὲ λαχούσας ὁμοσάσας ἱερῶσθαι·).

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he does not want Socrates to converse with Menexenus in order that Socrates might ridicule himself (but in order that he might put Menexenus down)]
 Ἵνα, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, καταγέλαστος γένωμαι;  Οὐ μὰ Δία, ἔφη, ἀλλ’ ἵνα αὐτὸν κολάσῃς.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Spudias
statement:
[That he is being greatly injured in many other respects]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἕτερα πολλὰ καὶ μεγάλα βλάπτεσθαι,
remarks: The speaker is imagining the arguments that Spudias will use to defend himself.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
if_taken: Odysseus and the suitors will be at peace
if_kept: They will have prosperity and peace in abundance
impact: Peace in Ithaca and the restoration of Odysseus to the kingship
statement: [That Odysseus will be accepted as king “for ever” (which probably implies accepting Telemachus as his heir) and will not be pursued over the deaths of the suitors, and that they will be friends to each other as formerly]
remarks: The oath related at oath id 563 is reported as being sworn here. Athena settles the oaths disguised as Mentor.

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
impact: Emphasises the denial of the claim
statement:
[That from the fact that he is knowledgeable it does not necessarily follow that he knows everything]
 οὐκ ἀνάγκη σε ἔχει πάντα ἐπίστασθαι ἐπιστήμονά γε ὄντα; Μὰ Δί’, ἔφην ἐγώ·

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Thucydides observes that throughout the diplomatic exchanges between the Athenians and the Peloponnesians both sides continued to have intercourse without heralds. 
Thucydides observes that despite this, the events taking place constituted the annulment of the treaty.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytus
impact: Theseus realizes how noble his son is
statement:
[That he releases Theseus from bloodguilt]
 Θη. τί φήις; ἀφίης αἵματός μ’ ἐλεύθερον; 
Ιπ. τὴν τοξόδαμνον ῎Αρτεμιν μαρτύρομαι.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That none of the people that he got to rule "by dint of much toil on land and much oar-work on the waters" gives so much as a head of garlic for his boiled fish]
 σοὶ δ’, ὧν ἄρχεις πολλὰ μὲν ἐν γῇ, πολλὰ δ’ ἐφ’ ὑγρᾷ 
  πιτυλεύσας, 
  οὐδεὶς οὐδὲ σκορόδου κεφαλὴν τοῖς ἑψητοῖσι δίδωσιν.
 {Φι.}  μὰ Δί’
remarks: Sommerstein explains that 678 is "a poetic quotation or adaptation from an unknown source" and also remarks that "the point that the profits of the empire should go to those who fought to create the empire is repeated in 684-5, 711, 1075-1121."

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement: [That they would rule according to the established nomoi; and that they would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
remarks: The Athenian here reaches the conclusion that the lawgivers in the time of Cresphontes and Temenus were not fully expert in the art of legislation, since otherwise they would hardly have deemed it sufficient to moderate by means of oaths a youthful soul endowed with power such as might develop into a tyranny. Cf. oath ids 2678-86.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That he knows what the old woman wants]
 {Γρ. α}  οἶδ’, οἶδ’ ὅ τι βούλει. {Επ.} καὶ γὰρ ἐγώ σε, νὴ Δία.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
if_taken: They will be exempted from cavalry duty
if_refused: They will not be exempted from cavalry duty
statement:
[That they are physically or financially unable to serve]
 καὶ τὸν πίνακ’ἀνοίξαντες, ἐν ᾧ κατασεσημασμένα τὰ ὀνόματα τῶν ἱππέων ἐστί, τοὺς μὲν ἐξομνυμένους τῶν πρότερον ἐγγεγραμμένων μὴ δυνατοὺς εἶναι τοῖς σώμασιν ἱππεύειν ἐξαλείφουσι, τοὺς δὲ κατειλεγμένους καλοῦσι, κἂν μέν τις ἐξομόσηται μὴ δύνασθαι τῷ σώματι ἱππεύειν ἢ τῇ οὐσίᾳ, τοῦτον ἀφιᾶσιν, τὸν δὲ μὴ ἐξομνύμενον διαχειροτονοῦσιν οἱ βουλευταί, πότερον ἐπιτήδειός ἐστιν ἱππεύειν ἢ οὔ
remarks:
Currently-serving cavalrymen or new deme members up for cavalry service were both able to decline duty by swearing to physical or financial incapacity. The procedure, as carefully described, is: 
(a) The katalogeis draw up the provisional list of cavalrymen. 
(b) They pass it to the hipparchs and phylarchs who … 
(c)… bring it before the council, who open the sealed document. 
(d) The council erase the names of those who swear that they are not physically fit to serve. 
(e) Those remaining on the list are then summoned before the council. 
(f) Anyone who then swears that he is physically or financially unable to serve is exempted. 
(g) For each man still regarded as liable, the council vote on whether he is a suitable person to serve on horseback. 
It thus looks as though a claim of physical unfitness, once entered, remained on the record, and anyone who had made such a claim in one year would automatically be exempted in future years, without having to appear before the council.  Claims of financial incapacity, on the other hand, had to be publicly renewed each year:  a man’s material fortunes could recover, whereas his physical fitness was less likely to improve with the years (especially when it came to cavalry service, which was very much a young man’s game).

author: Aristotle
title: Aporemata Homerica
impact: Hera can continue with her plan to set Eurystheus up as ruler
statement: [That whatever son of Zeus is born on that day will be lord over all his neighbours]
remarks: Aristotle discusses here the oath which Hera asks Zeus to swear as reported by Agamemnon in Iliad 19 (see oath id 410). Why does Hera ask for this oath? Aristotle explains as follows: the whole thing is part of a story, Homer is not telling it in his own name, and in any case it is reasonable because Hera is afraid that things will not go as she wishes, hence she asks for an oath. For other Aristotelian comments on oaths in the Iliad, see oath ids 1999, 2000 and 2002.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the Babylonians and their allied troops were not at all pleased at the news of the Persians' advance]
 Τί οὖν; ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, ἦ καὶ ἔχαιρον ἀκούοντες ἰόντας; τοῦτο δὲ ἐπήρετο τῶν παρόντων ἕνεκα. Οὐ μὰ Δί’, εἶπον ἐκεῖνοι, οὐ μὲν δὴ ἔχαιρον, ἀλλὰ καὶ μάλα ἠνιῶντο.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Stephanus 1
statement:
[That Apollodorus would have refused to have the will opened in order that it might not be shown to the jurors]
 ἵν’ ἡ διαθήκη νὴ Δία μὴ φανερὰ  γένοιτο τοῖς δικασταῖς.
remarks: Apollodorus asks why he would have refused to open the will, and imagines that someone will respond in this way.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That he does find a multitude of people who pit their opinion against his own, once he has formed a judgement]
 ἢ μυρίοι ἑκάστοτέ σοι μάχονται ἀντιδοξάζοντες, ἡγούμενοι ψευδῆ κρίνειν τε καὶ οἴεσθαι; {ΘΕΟ.} Νὴ τὸν Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες, μάλα μυρίοι δῆτα

author: Demosthenes
title: On Halonnesus
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Hegesippus argues that Philip has violated the peace by taking places that belonged to Athens from them - Serreion Teichos, Ergisce and the Sacred Mount - after the peace was formalised at Athens. He tells the Athenians that anyone can find out which came first, the month in which peace was made, or the month in which the places were taken. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
if_refused: Hostilities continue (and the Athenians go on slowly starving)
statement: [That they would abide by the terms of the peace]
remarks: This is a reference to the peace treaty of 404 and the condition that the Athenians should live under their ancestral constitution. Other terms included the destruction of the Long Walls and fortifications of the Piraeus, the loss of foreign possessions for the Athenians (though they remained independent), the surrender of the whole Athenian fleet with the exception of 12 triremes, and the return of all exiles; in addition, Athens became the ally of Sparta and pledged to follow her leadership.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the reign of Amasis 570-525 (570 to 525)
impact: Safe passage to the Canobic mouth ensured
statement:
[That he had not come to the port of his own free will]
 μὴ μὲν ἑκόντα ἐλθεῖν
remarks: Herodotus states that Naucratis was the only emporium in Egypt in "ancient times" (τὸ παλαιὸν), and that anyone who came to any other mouth of the Nile had to swear that he had not come there of his own will. Upon swearing they were then to sail to the Canobic mouth. If they could not sail because of the wind they had to carry their cargo to Naucratis in barges.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes refers to the ambassadors who brought Philip's representatives to make peace, and says that no one blames Aeschines for doing this, but only for working to ensure that the peace was made in a way, and on terms, that were bad for Athens.  
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: Against the corn-dealers
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other while the negotiations were taking place]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that the metics are delighted to hear bad news about Athens, such as the loss of the Athenian ships in the Black Sea, the capture of vessels on the outward journey by the Spartans, the blockade of their trading ports, or "the impending rupture of the truce". 
[Edwards and] Usher ad loc. argues that this truce is a temporary cease-fire while ambassadors were gathering to consider the terms of the King's Peace".

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Megalopolitans
statement:
[That he cannot see how the Spartans can refuse to help them at Oropus without proving themselves to be the worst of men]
 μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς ἔγωγ’ οὐχ ὁρῶ.
remarks: Demosthenes poses this as a question, and then provides the answer with an oath.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he thinks deeds are better evidence than words]
 ἢ οὐ δοκεῖ σοι ἀξιοτεκμαρτότερον τοῦ λόγου τὸ ἔργον εἶναι; Πολύ γε νὴ Δί’, ἔφη·

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and make war in common against Philip]
remarks:
The prosecutor attacks Demosthenes for showing no compassion after the destruction of Thebes even though he visited Thebes as an envoy, shared food and drink with its citizens, and claims that he made Thebes the ally of Athens. 
See also oath id 2670.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_broken: May he fall apart and be scattered everywhere in pieces
statement:
[That he will destroy the Sausage-seller]
  Εἰ μή σ’ ἀπολέσαιμ’, εἴ τι τῶν αὐτῶν ἐμοὶ 
  ψευδῶν ἐνείη, διαπέσοιμι πανταχῇ.
remarks: This is a self-curse, implying an oath. There is no linguistic marker, though Paphlagon's self-curse is essentially "may I die if…". Paphlagon qualifies his statement by saying "if any of my old lies are left in me".

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That the Athenians (influenced by Euripides) now check up on everything that goes on in the house]
  Τοιαῦτα μέντοὐγὼ φρονεῖν
  τούτοισιν εἰσηγησάμην,
  λογισμὸν ἐνθεὶς τῇ τέχνῃ
  καὶ σκέψιν, ὥστ’ ἤδη νοεῖν
  ἅπαντα καὶ διειδέναι 
  τά τ’ ἄλλα καὶ τὰς οἰκίας 
  οἰκεῖν ἄμεινον ἢ πρὸ τοῦ 
  κἀνασκοπεῖν· «Πῶς τοῦτ’ ἔχει;
  Ποῦ μοι τοδί; Τίς τοῦτ’ ἔλαβε;» 
  ΔΙ.  Νὴ τοὺς θεούς
remarks: Sommerstein ad 983-8 remarks: "The Athenians, it seems, have become so critical and inquisitive that they check up minutely on the most trivial household losses, down to a small nibble at a single olive or the breaking of an old plate".

author: Isaeus
title: On Behalf of Euphiletus
statement:
[That Euphiletus was the son of herself and Hegesippus]
 ἦ μὴν τουτονὶ Εὐφίλητον εἶναι ἐξ αὑτῆς καὶ τοῦ ἡμετέρου πατρός.
remarks:
The speaker states that Euphiletus' mother (admitted by their opponents to be a citizen) expressed before the arbitrators her willingness to swear that Euphiletus was the son of herself and Hegesippus. 
He also tells the jurors that both he and Hegesippus are willing to swear as well (see oath id 3185, 3186). 
The speaker goes on to stress that the jurors would be justified in regarding their oaths as more worthy of credence than the statements of their opponents, because whereas they are willing to swear oaths concerning Euphiletus, their opponents are repeating statements which they heard from Euphiletus' enemies or are uttering their own lies.

author: Timocles
title: Heroes
statement:
[That what the swearee has said is long-winded]
 περιέργως γε νὴ τὸν οὐρανόν

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that if anyone plotting against the state reveals the plot he will receive a reward of 1000 staters, "and there is to be no sworn denunciation against him".

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, Dercylidas sent to Pharnabazus and asked whether he preferred to have a truce as in the winter, or war. 
Pharnabazus chose to have another truce, and Dercylidas crossed back into Europe.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That there are innumerable other examples which illustrate what recollection is (apart from those mentioned by Socrates)]
 Μυρία μέντοι νὴ Δία, ἔφη ὁ Σιμμίας

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That some people arrange everything in its designated place]
 τοῖς δὲ ἐν χώρᾳ ἕκαστα τεταγμένα κεῖται; Ναὶ
μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης·
remarks: These people are contrasted with others who "throw things down in any old place".

title: IC IV
statement: [That the child had not been brought to him]
remarks:
What's happening is apparently that the ex-husband is claiming custody of the child, and the ex-wife's family is arguing that he has no right to do so because he'd been offered the child and had rejected it. 
See also oath id 1125.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That whatever  is splendid and fine or is charming in human life, is there because of Wealth]
 Καὶ νὴ Δί’ εἴ τί γ’ ἐστὶ λαμπρὸν καὶ καλὸν
  ἢ χαρίεν ἀνθρώποισι, διὰ σὲ γίγνεται.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he is very much in love with Socrates]
 σὺ δὲ μόνος, ὦ Ἀντίσθενες, οὐδενὸς ἐρᾷς; Ναὶ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, εἶπεν ἐκεῖνος, καὶ σφόδρα γε σοῦ.
remarks: This is paradoxical, since Socrates is middle-aged and ugly; cf. Alcibiades in Plato’s Symposium.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Draws attention to the Corinthian woman's figure
statement:
[That the Corinthian woman certainly does have noble lines]
 Χαΐα νὴ τὸν Δία
remarks: The term Calonice uses Χαΐα “admirable”, already used by Lampito (cf. id 1155) to mean  “of noble birth”, but by which Calonice means “physically well endowed".

title: IG I(3)
swearer: Cleander; Unknown envoy; Silenus, son of Phocus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That as allies they would be trustworthy and just and steadfast and reliable to the Athenians]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Rhegium. 
The prescript was erased and reinscribed in antiquity. Each line is longer than the original text. The reason for the erasure is unknown. The oath sworn by the presbeis from Rhegium has not survived. The name of the second ambassador is also lost.  
For the corresponding oath sworn by the Athenians see oath id 165.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus argues that while the laws instruct sworn jurors to inflict penalties, Timocrates' law renders those penalties inoperative. He also complains that the law enfranchises state-debtors who do not pay back what they owe, and in all shows that the oaths, penalties and verdicts of the jurors are futile. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would remain faithful and would not desert]
remarks:
According to Herodotus, King Leotychides aksed for pledges from the messengers that the Samians would be allies.  
For another reference to the alliance between the Greek league and the Samians see oath id 1507.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: Penelope doesn't know that Telemachus is leaving and therefore does not try to stop him
statement: [That she will not tell Penelope that Telemachus is leaving for eleven or twelve days or until she misses him]
remarks: Here, Eurycleia relates to Penelope the oath she swore to Telemachus at oath id 530. See this entry for further remarks.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Syracusans were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Syracusans while they collected their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that after the Athenians defeated the Syracusans in battle they set up a trophy and gave up the dead under a truce (ὑποσπόνδους).

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: Five years into the reign of King Alyattes ca.605 (610 to 560)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: The details are limited. Herodotus indicates that twelve years into the war between the Lydians and the Milesians, King Alyattes was warned by the oracle at Delphi that he would receive no oracles until he made peace with Miletus. Herodotus notes that Alyattes offered to make a truce (σπονδὰς ποιήσασθαι) and that the two parties ended their war and agreed to be friends and allies (Μετὰ δὲ ἥ τε διαλλαγή σφι ἐγένετο ἐπ’ ᾧ τε ξείνους ἀλλήλοισι εἶναι καὶ συμμάχους).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That it would be disgraceful and unworthy of the Athenians, their resources, and the record of their ancestors to abandon all the other Greeks to enslavement for the sake of their own ease]
 αἰσχρὸν μὲν νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ πάντας θεοὺς καὶ ἀνάξιον ὑμῶν καὶ τῶν ὑπαρχόντων τῇ πόλει καὶ πεπραγμένων τοῖς προγόνοις, τῆς ἰδίας ἕνεκα ῥᾳθυμίας τοὺς ἄλλους πάντας Ἕλληνας εἰς δουλείαν προέσθαι,
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that it would be disgraceful for the Athenians to abandon the other Greeks to Philip even if they were certain that he would not attack them. 
See also oath id 3278.

author: Plato
title: Philebus
statement:
[That he washes his hands of the discussion]
 ἀλλὰ γὰρ ἀφοσιοῦμαι καὶ μαρτύρομαι νῦν αὐτὴν τὴν θεόν.
remarks: Philebus swears by the personification of pleasure, the very concept which he is arguing is a greater good than wisdom. “The goddess”, according to Philebus, is properly to be called Pleasure, but she is the same who is commonly called Aphrodite (12b7-9) – an identification that Socrates clearly dislikes (12c).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
