statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
When the Lesbians revolted from Athens, the Mytilenaeans sent envoys to Olympia to address the Spartans and their allies. These envoys told the Spartans that they became allies not to the Athenians for the enslavement of the Greeks, but to the Greeks for their liberation from the Medes. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Macartatus
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Sositheus again accuses Theopompus, Glaucon, Glaucus and Eupolemus of forming a conspiracy against Phylomache. 
See also oath id 3602.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he does not want to go home (he wants to continue the campaign)]
 ὁ δὲ Κῦρος ἔφη· Σὺ δ’ οὐκ ἐπιθυμεῖς οἴκαδε ἀπελθεῖν; Οὐ μὰ Δι’, ἔφη, ὁ Ὑστάσπας

author: Aristotle
title: Politeia 129 (Samos)
impact: The massacre by the Milesians is remembered
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a report of a battle where many Prienians were killed by the Milesians at a place called the Oak, in the time of Bias. Prienian women now swear by the darkness of the Oak. Plutarch says that the Darkness of the Oak became “a curse and an oath in the greatest matters”; which suggests that its role in oaths was precisely as a curse/sanction (as it were, “if I do not speak truth, may the Darkness of the Oak come upon me and mine”).  Its object was thus not, or not primarily, to memorialize the deaths, but to add solemnity to the oath.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: Unity among Persians and fairness in Persian rule would be assured
if_refused: Unity among Persians and fairness in Persian rule would not be assured
impact: Unity among the Persians is formalised
statement:
[That if anyone attacks Persia or attempts to break Persian laws, he will come to assist Persia with all his might]
 ἤν τις ἐπιστρατεύηται χώρᾳ Περσίδι ἢ Περσῶν νόμους διασπᾶν πειρᾶται, βοηθήσειν παντὶ σθένει
remarks: The Persian people  swear a reciprocal oath- see oath id 2501. Xenophon then states that both the Persian people and their king still act according to this agreement (see oath id 2502).

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That parents and children who have intercourse with one another cannot avoid the greatest penalty]
 Καὶ ποίαν, ἔφη, δίκην, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐ δύνανται διαφεύγειν γονεῖς τε παισὶκαὶ παῖδες γονεῦσι μιγνύμενοι; Τὴν μεγίστην νὴ Δί’, ἔφη· τί γὰρ ἂν μεῖζον πάθοιεν ἄνθρωποι τεκνοποιούμενοι τοῦ κακῶς τεκνοποιεῖσθαι;
remarks: The penalty referred to here is the kind imposed by the gods, which is inescapable, in contrast with the laws of men, violators of which can sometimes avoid punishment.

author: Anonymus Oxyrhynchicus
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
The text indicates that Agesilaus wanted safe passage through the middle of Mysian Olympus and made a truce with the Mysians. 
When he led his army through the region they Mysians attacked them. 
The Mysian ambush failed and they were forced to make a truce to collect their dead.  
At Col.21.25.743-747, the text indicates that Agesilaus ravaged Mysian territory for ten days in retaliation for their treachery. 
See oath id 3312.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That it would be lamentable if someone, through lack of technical ability, came to blame the arguments for seeming to be sometimes true and sometimes false rather than blaming himself, and thus missed his chance of learning the truth about reality]
  Οὐκοῦν, ὦ Φαίδων, ἔφη, οἰκτρὸν ἂν εἴη τὸ πάθος, εἰ ὄντος δή τινος ἀληθοῦς καὶ βεβαίου λόγου καὶ δυνατοῦ κατανοῆσαι, ἔπειτα διὰ τὸ παραγίγνεσθαι τοιούτοις τισὶ λόγοις, τοῖς αὐτοῖς τοτὲ μὲν δοκοῦσιν ἀληθέσιν εἶναι, τοτὲ δὲ μή, μὴ ἑαυτόν τις αἰτιῷτο μηδὲ τὴν ἑαυτοῦ ἀτεχνίαν, ἀλλὰ τελευτῶν διὰ τὸ ἀλγεῖν ἅσμενος ἐπὶ τοὺς λόγους ἀφ’ἑαυτοῦ τὴν αἰτίαν ἀπώσαιτο καὶ ἤδη τὸν λοιπὸν βίον μισῶν τε καὶ λοιδορῶν τοὺς λόγους διατελοῖ, τῶν δὲ ὄντων τῆς ἀληθείας τε καὶ ἐπιστήμης στερηθείη.
  Νὴ τὸν Δία, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, οἰκτρὸν δῆτα.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
remarks:
Demosthenes refers to the time when the Athenians re-elected Aeschines to administer the oaths. He says that he will tell the jurors about Aeschines' procrastination, the damage he did to the city's affairs, and the quarrels that arose about this between him and Aeschines when he tried to stop Aeschines. 
Demosthenes says that when they got back from the embassy to Philip - having gained none of the advantages talked about and expected at the time when the peace was made - he accused his fellow ambassadors before the boule. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

title: IG IX, 1(2)
statement: [That they would not deliberately distance themselves from the Naupactians with any pretext or device of their own free will]
remarks: For the corresponding oath sworn by the Naupactans see oath id 746. For the oath sworn thirty years earlier by the Naupactans see oath id 716.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
statement: [? That they would defend each other in battle]
remarks: Herodotus states that the people of Xanthus tried to repel the Persian army led by Harpagus, but were driven back into the city. They then gathered together their wives, children, property and slaves on the acropolis and set the whole acropolis on fire. After doing this they swore their terrible oaths (ταῦτα δὲ ποιήσαντες καὶ συνομόσαντες ὅρκους δεινούς), sallied out and fell fighting the Persians.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Highlights her indignation at the suggestion
statement:
[That she was not an informeress among the women]
  Τί δ’ ἐστίν; ἦ που καὶ σὺ συκοφάντρια 
  ἐν ταῖς γυναιξὶν ἦσθα;
  {ΓΡ.}  Μὰ Δί’ ἐγὼ μὲν οὔ.
remarks: Sommerstein ad 970 notes: "No woman, of course, could bring a prosecution in the Athenian courts; Chremylus (or Ar.) is humourously assuming that the women have a parallel court system of their own".

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That Socrates is quite right to say that the banquet would be much more charming if the young people were to perform dances representing the Graces, Seasons and Nymphs]
 εἰ δὲ ὀρχοῖντο πρὸς τὸν αὐλὸν σχήματα ἐν οἷς Χάριτές τε καὶ Ὧραι καὶ Νύμφαι γράφονται, πολὺ ἂν οἶμαι αὐτούς γε ῥᾷον διάγειν καὶ τὸ συμπόσιον πολὺ ἐπιχαριτώτερον εἶναι. ὁ οὖν Συρακόσιος, Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, καλῶς τε λέγεις καὶ ἐγὼ εἰσάξω θεάματα ἐφ’ οἷς ὑμεῖς εὐφρανεῖσθε.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Having reminded the jury of their dikastic oath (see oath id 2782), Socrates warns that they should not be influenced nor allow themselves to perjure themselves in respect of this oath. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines asks what crime he has committed. He goes on to say that "the peace" has failed to please some of the rhetores, but argues that they ought to have opposed it at the time instead of putting him on trial now. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that Dercylidas sent to the cities of Aeolis and requested that they free themselves, admit him inside their walls, and become his allies. 
Those in Neandria, Ilium and Cocylium obeyed. The citizens of Cebren also later complied.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
impact: Emphasises the Slave's horror at his master's suggestion
statement:
[That Trygaeus will never indict Zeus for betraying Greece to the Medes as long as the Second Slave lives]
  Γράψομαι  
  Μήδοισιν αὐτὸν προδιδόναι τὴν Ἑλλάδα. 
 {ΟΙ. Βʹ}  Μὰ τὸν Διόνυσον οὐδέποτε ζῶντος γ’ ἐμοῦ—
remarks: The statement "betraying Greece to the Medes" (as Sommerstein notes ad 107) refers to the fact that if Greeks continue to fight each other, they will not be able to fend off any new attack from the Persians (or Medes). The slave here is concerned for his master's safety, since challenging the gods in such a way is very dangerous for mortals (see further Sommerstein ad 109).

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That he would not attack Charidemus as he withdrew]
remarks:
Euthycles has two letters from Charidemus read to the jurors. The first was written before his truce with Artabazus, the second was written afterwards. 
See also oath id 3465.

author: Crobylus
title: Pseudupobolimaios
statement:
[That the swearer did not leave any of the pig's half-brain remaining]
 εἰσῆλθεν ἡμίκραιρα τακερὰ δέλφακος· 
ταύτης μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐχὶ κατέλιπον δ’ ἐγὼ 
οὐδέν.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Pyrrhus
if_taken: He can proceed with his case
if_refused: He cannot proceed with his case
statement: [That the facts in his written statement were true i.e. that Nicodemus had borne false witness]
remarks:
The speaker argues that since it has been proved that Xenocles gave false evidence [that he gave his sister in legal marriage to Pyrrhus] it follows that Nicodemus also gave false evidence when he testified in support of Xenocles. He tells the jurors that they will realise this when they hear his antomosia. 
After this the antomosia is read to the jurors along with the evidence and the diamarturia.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would be a friend and ally to Cetriporis, and would wage the war with Cetriporis against Philip without deceit and with all their strength as far as possible, and would not put an end in advance to the war against Philip without the consent of Cetriporis and his brothers; and they would join with Cetriporis and his brothers in subduing the other places that Philip holds, and they would join in taking Crenides with Cetriporis and his brothers, and they would give back - - -]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares
remarks:
The text records the alliance between Athens and Cetriporis of Thrace, Lyppeus of Paeonia and Grabus of Illyria. 
The name of the swearee has been restored as [Mon]unius. 
For the oath sworn by the Athenian envoys to Cetriporis see oath id 459.  
See also oath id 461 and 462.

author: Plato
title: Theages
statement:
[That he knows what it is that made those who kept company with Socrates superior to all whose inferiors they were before]
 Οἶσθα οὖν οἷον τοῦτό ἐστιν, ὦ παῖ Δημοδόκου;  {ΘΕ.} Ναὶ μὰ Δία ἔγωγε
remarks: Theages seems to think that learning from Socrates will make him a superior person, but Socrates disagrees and claims that a divine voice guides him. The good or bad success of a pupil thus depends entirely on decisions of an inscrutable will which presides over both Socrates and his mission.

title: IC IV
swearer: Plaintiff?; Sons of age with citizen rights; Grandsons of age; Witnesses; Brothers from the same father; Brothers from the same mother; Any free man who will testify
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that the swearer would swear by Zeus, Apollo, Athena, Hermes, but could not make the oath more formal by swearing by any other gods.

author: Anonymus Tragicus
title: Fragment 123a
statement: unknown
remarks: This Demosthenic line is credible as a tragic line, and may have been parodied by Aristophanes at Birds 194 (see oath id 635). The same line also appears in ids 1410 and 1445.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
if_taken: The safety of Clearchus would be assured
if_refused: The safety of Clearchus would not be assured
statement:
[That he would not kill Clearchus]
 βασιλέα δὲ τῆι μὲν μητρὶ παραιτουμένηι μὴ κτεῖναι τὸν Κλέαρχον ὁμολογῆσαι, καὶ ὀμόσαι
remarks: Artaxerxes' mother here requests an oath from her son not to kill Clearchus, but Artaxerxes' wife Stateira has other ideas and persuades him to dispatch Clearchus in spite of his oath, along with all the other Greek generals apart from Menon. This provokes Parysatis into contriving the death of Stateira by poison.

title: IG I(3)
statement: The statement has not survived.
remarks:
This inscription records the reassessment of the tribute of the Athenian empire. These lines refer to the duties of the ten taktai (tribute assessors). 
The oaths sworn by the taktai  were to be overseen by the horkotai (oath commissioners). If the oaths were not taken on the day that the taktai took office, the oath commissioners would be penalised. Lines 41ff indicate that the oath sworn by the taktai stipulated that the routes that the heralds were to travel would be set out within a specified time period.

title: IC IV
if_taken: He does not owe the money
statement: [? That he did not owe the money]
remarks: This part of the text is fragmentary. It indicates that in cases where a debt is being reclaimed it is possible to deny the debt by swearing an oath of denial.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Xenophon observes that when Agesilaus found the Thebans, Athenians, Argives, Corinthians, Aenianians, Euboeans and Locrians arrayed against him at Coronea in 394, he drew up his army which included also one and a half morai and, of the local allies, only the Phocians and the Orchomenians. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That he thinks the old man (i.e. Wealth) is without a foreskin]
 οἶμαι δὲ νὴ τὸν οὐρανὸν καὶ ψωλὸν αὐτὸν εἶναι.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes, the statement is clearly conjecture indicating that the phallus was not visible on this character. See further Sommerstein ad 267.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Herodotus states that the Plataeans placed themselves under the protection of the Athenians when they were being pressed hard by the Thebans. 
The Plataeans appealed to the Spartans for help, but King Cleomenes suggested that they choose the Athenians because they were much closer to Plataea. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1561.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
The Thebans were eager to continue the war against Elis, but according to Xenophon, those who sought the best interests of the Peloponnese persuaded the assembly of the Arcadians to send envoys to tell the Thebans not to come under arms to Arcadia unless they were summoned. Since both the Eleans and the Arcadians desired peace, a truce was concluded on condition that the Eleans relinquished their claims to the presidency of the shrine of Zeus at Olympia. 
After the oaths had been taken, feasts and celebrations were held at Tegea. The Arcadian aristocrats who were opposed to the peace tried to seize their opponents with the support of the Theban commander and his troops, but were ultimately unsuccessful. 
See also oath id 2043.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the alliance]
remarks: Here Cyrus declares forcefully that he will be true to the oaths and the right-hand pledges which he gave the Hyrcanians and he will never be caught playing them false. This is part of a speech aimed at encouraging the Medes to stay voluntarily as his allies.

author: Isocrates
title: Archidamus
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly]
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. free access to common sanctuaries
2. the independence of Delphi
3. peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. it was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. the Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. the Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to  their homelands
9. the fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.]
remarks: Archidamus tells the Spartans that in the past they have been forced to make peace when they were in a worse position than their foes, but that when this happened neither the Great King (when they agreed to the King's Peace in 387/6: see also oath id 307) or the Athenians (when they agreed to the Peace of Nicias in 422/1: see also oath id 1681) charged them with having acquired Messenia unjustly.

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [That they would not attack each other]
remarks: This doubtful fragment of Theopompus refers to Alexander of Pherae trampling down the sworn truce and valuing oaths at nothing, suggesting that Pelopidas and the Pharsalians had made a truce for negotiations with Alexander which he then violated. However, it is strange that Plutarch, in his Life of Pelopidas (26-32), makes no mention of any sworn truce, although he is eager to present Alexander in a bad light. He simply says that Pelopidas and the Pharsalians trusted in their own reputation and the power of Thebes in their dealings with Alexander. This suggests that the truce is spurious.

author: Antiphanes
title: Halieuomene
statement:
[That the crayfish is good and fat]
 τὸν κάραβον δὲ τόνδε πρὸς τὰς μαινίδας  
ἀπόθες· παχύς γε, νὴ Δί’.
remarks: The speaker seems to be a fishmonger- one of the few trades in Athens which was not exclusive to one gender.

author: Plato
title: Menexenus
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks: This is a reference to the Peace of Nicias during the synopsis (and glorification) of Athenian history given by Socrates in what is allegedly a funeral speech by Aspasia the Milesian. When the Athenians captured Torone they set the Peloponnesians free "in the treaty that was made". After this they handed the Toronaeans over to the Olynthians. For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see also oath id 1681.

author: Lysias
title: Against Andocides
statement:
[That there is no need for any of the jurors, young or old, to lose faith in the gods, through seeing Andocides saved from dangers]
 οὔκουν χρὴ μὰ τὸν Δία οὔτε πρεσβύτερον ὄντα οὔτε νεώτερον, ὁρῶντας Ἀνδοκίδην ἐκ τῶν κινδύνων σῳζόμενον,
remarks: The speaker's point seems to be that it would be wrong to take the risk that anyone, seeing Andocides saved from his dangers (in this trial) despite his notorious impieties, might lose faith in the gods; i.e. he is claiming that a vote for Andocides' acquittal will help to promote religious scepticism, with (it is assumed) disastrous consequences.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Neaera
remarks:
Apollodorus states that Stephanus stayed at Megara (where Neaera was a hetaera) at the time when peace was made and the battle was fought at Leuctra. 
For other references to this peace treaty see oath id 1984.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes; Representatives of Peloponnesian League members
impact: War between the Athenians and the Spartans (temporarily) ceased
statement:
[That they would abide by this agreement and this treaty, justly and guilelessly] 
 ἐμμενῶ ταῖς ξυνθήκαις καὶ ταῖς σπονδαῖς ταῖσδε δικαίως καὶ ἀδόλως 
The terms of the agreement can be summarised as follows:
1. Free access to common sanctuaries
2. The independence of Delphi
3. Peace to last on land and sea for fifty years
4. It was to be unlawful for either the Spartans and their allies or the Athenians and their allies to bear arms against each other (they were to have recourse to courts and oaths if either party violated this rule)
5. Amphipolis was to be restored to Athens
6. In the case of other cities delivered to Athens by the Spartans (Argilus, Stagirus, Acanthus, Stolus, Olynthus and Spartolus) were to be safeguarded if they paid the tribute fixed in the time of Aristeides
7. The Mecybernaeans and Sanaeans and Singians should dwell in their own towns on the same terms as the Olynthians and Acanthians
8. The Spartans were to restore Panactum to the Athenians and the Athenians were to restore Coryphasium, Cythera, Methana, Pteleum and Atalante and any Spartan captives to the Spartans, and any captured Peloponnesians to their homelands
9. The fate of Scione, Torone, Sermyle and any other city held by the Athenians was to be decided by the Athenians as they saw fit.
remarks:
When the Athenians captured Torone they set the Peloponnesians free "in the treaty that was made". After this they handed the Toronaeans over to the Olynthians.  
For other references to the Peace of Nicias and its impact see oath id 1249, 1684, 1685, 1688, 1689, 1693, 1702, 1703, 1704, 1709, 1716, 1717, 1721, 1722, 1723, 1733, 1763, 1768, 1794, 2388, 2633, 2941, 3203, 3204.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes has the clerk read a decree ordering the withdrawal from the Attic countryside to the city of all persons not manning the border fortresses to the jurors, and asks whether this was what they expected when they made peace with Philip. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it would be much more appropriate for Theodote than for a spider to discover a device with which to ensnare her source of sustenance]
 Πῶς δ’ ἄν, ἔφη, ἐγὼ τούτου μηχανὴν εὕροιμι; Πολὺ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, προσηκόντως μᾶλλον ἢ αἱ φάλαγγες·
remarks: Cf. oath id 2110.  Theodote's source of sustenance is her male "friends", as she calls them (see oath id 2106).

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That at the time Timarchus was not yet as ugly as now, but still usable]
 οὔπω μὰ Δία ὥσπερ νῦν ἀργαλέος ὢν τὴν ὄψιν, ἀλλ’ ἔτι χρήσιμος
remarks: Aeschines states that after Timarchus and his friends physically abused Pittalacus and he went as a suppliant to the altar of the Mother of the Gods in the agora, Timarchus went to Pittalacus and touched his chin in supplication, and said that he would comply with all of Pittalacus' wishes. Aeschines' oath is part of his explanation as to why Pittalacus was won over by Timarchus; by "usable" he means, of course, "tolerable as a sexual partner", and Timarchus' promise to do whatever Pittalacus wanted is meant to be interpreted in the light of that.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Phaenippus
if_taken: He will be able to proceed with the antidosis
if_refused: He will not be able to proceed with the antidosis
statement: [That he will give a true and honest inventory of his property, except that in the silver mines, all of which the laws have made exempt from taxes]
remarks:
The speaker states that even though Phaenippus had sworn on the eleventh day of Boedromion "to give a true and just inventory of his property", and the law explicitly states that the inventory shall be given within three days after the oath has been taken, Phaenippus approached him in front of the dikasteria accompanied by Polyeuctus of Crioa and some others, requesting that he put off the declaration regarding the property for a few days. The speaker agreed that they should meet regarding a settlement on the 23rd of Boedromion, and the declaration should be given on the 25th. However, Phaenippus did not appear on either of these days, and according to the speaker, thus has violated two laws - namely that the inventory should be presented within three days, and that mutual covenants agreed upon before witnesses shall be binding. 
See also oath id 3594.

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
swearer: All the Theran men living in Cyrene; All the Theran women living in Cyrene; All the Theran boys; All the Theran girls
if_taken: The Therans will be awarded Cyrenian citizenship
if_refused: They will not be awarded Cyrenian citizenship
if_kept: An abundance of good things to him and his descendants
if_broken: He shall melt away and dissolve, as will his descendants and property
statement:
[The sworn statement of colonists: Resolved by the assembly. Since Apollo spontaneously told Battus and the Therans to colonise Cyrene, it has been decided by the Therans to send Battus off to Libya, as Archagetes and as King, with the Therans to sail as his hetairoi. On equal and fair terms they shall sail according to family (?), with one son to be conscripted [- - -] adults and from the other Therans those who are free-born [- - -] shall sail. If they establish the settlement, kinsmen who sail later to Libya shall be entitled to citizenship and offices and shall be allotted portions of the land which has no owner. But if they do not successfully establish the settlement and the Therans are incapable of giving it assistance, and they are pressed by hardship for five years, from that land shall they depart, without fear, to Thera, to their own property, and they shall be citizens. Any man who, if the city send him, refuses to sail, will be liable to the death-penalty and his property shall be confiscated. The man harbouring him or concealing him, whether he be a father (aiding his) son, or a brother his brother, is to suffer the same penalty as the man who refuses to sail. On these conditions a sworn agreement was made by those who stayed there and by those who sailed to found the colony, and they invoked curses against those transgressors who would not abide by it, whether they were those settling in Libya or those who remained. They made waxen images and burnt them, calling down the following curse, everyone having assembled together, men, women, boys, girls: 'The person who does not abide by this sworn agreement but transgresses it shall melt away and dissolve like the images - himself, his descendants and his property; but those who abide by the sworn agreement - those sailing to Libya and those staying in Thera - shall have an abundance of good things, both themselves and their descendants']
 ὅρκιον τῶν οἰκιστήρων· [ἔ]δοξε τᾶι ἐκκλησίαι· ἐπεὶ Ἀπόλλων αὐτομάτιξεν Β[άτ]τωι καὶ Θηραίοις ἀποι[κίξαι] Κυράναν, ὁριστὸν δοκεῖ Θη[ραίο]ις ἀποπέμπεν ἐς τὰν [Λιβ]ύαν Βάττομ μὲν ἀρχαγέτα[ν τ]ε καὶ βασιλῆα, ἑταίρους δὲ τοὺς Θηραίους πλέν· ἐπὶ τᾶι ἴσα[ι κ]αὶ τᾶι ὁμοίαι πλ̣έν κατὰ τὸν ο̣ἶκον, υἱὸν δὲ ἕνα καταλ[έ]γεσθαί ΤΟΣ̣Δ̣ΕΕΛ̣Ο̣ - - - - κ̣α̣ὶ̣ τοὺς ἡβῶντας καὶ τῶν [ἄλλ]ων Θηραίων ἐλευθέρος - - - πλέν. αἰ μὲν δέ κα κατέχ[ων]τι τὰν οἰκισίαν οἱ ἄποικοι, τῶν οἰκείων τὸγ καταπλέον[τα] ὕστερον εἰς Λ̣ιβύ̣αν καὶ πολιτήιας καὶ τιμᾶμ πεδέχ[εν] καὶ γᾶς τᾶς ἀδεσπότω ἀπολαγχάν̣ε̣ν. αἰ μὲν δέ κα μὴ κατ[έχ]ωντι τὰν οἰκισίαν μηδὲ οἱ Θηραῖοί μ̣ιν δυνῶνται ἐπικου̣[ρέ]ν, ἀλλὰ ἀνάγκαι ἀχθῶντι ἔτη ἐπὶ πέντε, ἐκ τᾶς γᾶς ἀτίμ[εν] ἀδιέως Θήρανδε ἐπὶ τὰ αὐτῶγ χρήματα καὶ ἦμεμ πολιάτας· ὁ δέ κα μὴ λῆι πλέν ἀποστελλοίσας τᾶς πόλιος, θανά[σι]μος τένται καὶ τὰ χρήματα ἔστω αὐτοῦ δαμόσια. ὁ δὲ ἀποδεκόμενος ἢ ἀδήιζων ἢ πατὴρ υἱὸν ἢ ἀδελφεὸς ἀδελφεὸν παισεῖται ἅπερ ὁ μὴ λέων πλέν. ἐπὶ τούτοις ὅρκια ἐποιήσατο οἵ τε αὐτεῖ μένοντες καὶ οἱ πλέοντες οἰκίξοντες καὶ ἀρὰς ἐποιήσαντο τὸς ταῦτα παρβεῶντας καὶ μὴ ἐμμένοντας ἢ τῶν ἐλ Λιβύαι οἰκεόντων ἢ τῶν αὐτεῖ μενόντων. κηρίνος πλάσσαντες κολοσὸς κατέκαιον ἐπαρεώμενοι πάντες συνενθόντες καὶ ἄνδρες καὶ γυναῖκες καὶ παῖδες καὶ παιδίσκαι· τὸμ μὴ ἐμμένοντα τούτοις τοῖς ὁρκίοις ἀλλὰ παρβεῶντα καταλείβεσθαί νιν καὶ καταρρὲν ὥσπερ τὸς κολοσός, καὶ αὐτὸν καὶ γόνον καὶ χρήματα, τοῖς δὲ ἐμμένοισιν τούτοις τοῖς ὁρκίοις καὶ τοῖς πλέοισι ἐλ Λιβύαν κ[αὶ] τ[οῖς μέ]νοισι ἐν Θήραι ἦμεν πολλὰ καὶ ἀγαθὰ καὶ αὐ[τοῖς καὶ γό]νοις.
remarks: For the oath sworn at the time of the foundation of the colony see oath id 1051.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Xanthias is moved by the evident kindred spirit of the slave
remarks: This is clearly meant to emphasise how much the slave enjoys spreading gossip.  See Sommerstein ad 738 on the identity of the slave.

author: Antiphanes
title: Misoponeros
statement:
[That the foster-mothers excel (in villainy)]
 αὗται δ’ ὑπερβάλλουσι, μετά γε νὴ Δία 
τοὺς μητραγυρτοῦντάς γε·
remarks: There are four informal oaths in this short fragment. See oath ids 1400-1403.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That having a wank/ escaping is delightful]
  Μολωμεν αὐτο μολωμεν αὐτομολῶμεν. 
  {ΝΙ.}  Ἤν,  
  οὐχ ἡδύ;
  {ΔΗ. }  Νὴ Δία·
remarks: Demosthenes has tricked Nicias into saying "let's escape" while acting as if he is masturbating. The oath of assent must have a double meaning.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The war between the Peloponnesians and the Acarnanians ended
statement: [? That they would follow the Spartans wherever they might lead]
remarks: Xenophon states that when Agesilaus announced there would be a second year of campaigning against the Acarnanians they sent envoys to Sparta who concluded a peace with the Achaeans (see oath id 1950 and 2302) and an alliance with the Spartans (see also oath id 2301).

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
date: Time of writing of Ath. Pol. (340 to 330)
if_taken: They will be allowed to proceed with their case
if_refused: They will not be allowed to proceed with their case
impact: Focus on the matter in hand
statement:
[That they will speak only about the matter in dispute]
 κ[α]ὶ δ[ιο]μνύ[ουσι]ν οἱ ἀντίδικοι εἰς αὐτὸ τὸ πρᾶγμ[α] ἐρεῖν·
remarks: This is part of the litigant's oath discussed in full by Gagarin in Sommerstein and Fletcher ed. Horkos (Exeter, 2007) 39-47. Of course, what is relevant to the matter in dispute is highly subjective. The relevancy oath, and the extent to which and ways in which it was (shall we say) stretched in practice in various types of trial, are discussed by Rhodes in Harris & Rubinstein ed. The Law and the Courts in Ancient Greece (2004) 137-158. See also id 2470 and argumentation in Antiphon 6.9.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Praxagora's ideas, for honouring those who are brave in war, and shaming those who have been cowards, are admirable]
 καὶ ῥαψῳδεῖν ἔσται τοῖς παιδαρίοισιν 
  τοὺς ἀνδρείους ἐν τῷ πολέμῳ, κεἴ τις δειλὸς γεγένηται, 
  ἵνα μὴ δειπνῶσ’ αἰσχυνόμενοι. {Γε.} νὴ τὸν Ἀπόλλω (680)
  χάριέν γε.  (680)

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: Their choice for nomination will be accepted
if_refused: Their choice for nomination will not be accepted
impact: Their nominee will stand among those to be selected
statement: [That the person swearing thinks the man he is nominating as strategos is better than one of the current nominees]
remarks: The Athenian describes here the procedure in Magnesia for selecting new strategoi. They are to be nominated by the law-guardians from among the members of the city-state. From those nominated, the selection is to be made by all those who are serving or have served in war. If anyone deems that someone of the men not nominated is better than one of those nominated, he will state the name of his nominee and of the man he is to replace. He must then take an oath about the matter and propose his substitute. Whichever of the two is decided on by vote will be included in the list for selection. This passage refers to a generic oath, not a specific one.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he does not recognise the type of cloak which Bdelycleon has given him]
 νῦν δ’ οὐχὶ γιγνώσκεις. 
 {Φι.}  ἐγὼ 
  μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ τοίνυν

author: Euripides
title: Medea
impact: Medea comes to Greece with Jason
statement: [That he would be faithful to Medea]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 111.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Thucydides indicates that the Athenians returned Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea in accordance with the treaty.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he would by far prefer a good friend to the best horse or dog in the world]
 καὶ βουλοίμην ἄν μοι φίλον ἀγαθὸν γενέσθαι μᾶλλον ἢ τὸν ἄριστον ἐν ἀνθρώποις ὄρτυγα ἢ ἀλεκτρυόνα, καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία ἔγωγε μᾶλλον ἢ ἵππον τε καὶ κύνα
remarks: Ironically, after saying that he would rather have a friend than a dog, Socrates immediately invokes 'the dog' in an even more emphatic statement, ultimately to the same effect. See oath id 3081.

title: IPArk
statement:
[That they would bear goodwill towards the returned exiles whom the polis had agreed to receive back, and would bear no malice against any of them for the things they may have plotted (?) after the day on which they swore the oath, nor would they stand in the way of the safety of those who have returned, neither in [- - -] nor in the public affairs of the polis [- - -] against the returned exiles [- - -] to the polis [- - -] what is written in the diagramma about [- - -] nor would they give counsel against anyone]
 ὀμνύω Δία Ἀθάναν Ἀπόλλωνα Ποσειδᾶνα, εὐνοήσω τοῖς κατηνθηκόσι τοῖς ἔδοξε τᾶι πόλι κατυδέχεσθαι, καὶ οὐ μνασικακήσω τῶννυ οὐ̣δε̣ν[ὶ] τ[ὰ] ἂν̣ ἀμ̣π̣[ε]ίση ἀπὺ τᾶι ἁμέραι τᾶι τὸν ὅρκον ὤμοσα, οὐδὲ διακωλύσω τὰν τῶν κατηνθηκότων σωτηρίαν, οὔτε ἐν τᾶι - - - - οὔτε ἰν τοῖ κοινοῖ τᾶς πόλιος - - - δ̣ι̣ά̣γ̣ραμ̣μ̣α - - - πὸς τὸς κατηνθηκό[τ]ας - - - - - τᾶι πόλι - - - - - [τ]ὰ ἰν τοῖ διαγρά[μμ]ατι γεγραμμένα - - - - [ο]ὐδὲ βωλεύσω πὸς οὐδένα.
remarks: This oath was taken on the occasion of the restoration of exiles ordered by Alexander the Great in 324.  There is a slight chance that the oath was proposed not by Alexander but by Cassander:  in line 2 one might possibly restore [Kass]andros rather than [Alex]andros. This is, however, unlikely.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Phaenippus
if_taken: He will be able to proceed with the antidosis
if_refused: He will not be able to proceed with the antidosis
statement: [That he will give a true and honest inventory of his property, except that in the silver mines, all of which the laws have made exempt from taxes]
remarks:
The speaker complains that although Phaenippus had sworn to do so, he had not given him an inventory of his property even though the law states that he has to do so within three days after he took the oath. 
Phaenippus has in fact delivered the inventory a whole month late, thus delivering it only two or three days before the case was to come to court. 
See also oath id 3595, 3597.

title: TAM II, 1-3
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
[That they would abide by the agreements with the Phaselites, guilelessly and innocently]
[ἐμμεν]εῖν τοῖς ὡμολογημένοις ποτὶ [Φασηλίτας ἀδόλως καὶ ἀβ]λαβέως·
remarks:
This inscription records an agreement between Mausollus and Phaselis. 
The text followed for this entry is the original text of Wilhelm reproduced by Hornblower, Mausolus, p367, as M10.  
For the oath of the Phaselites see oath id 1054.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Xanthias feels a close bond with this slave
remarks: The statement, of course, means that the slave enjoys nothing more than being meddlesome. See Sommerstein ad 738 on the identity of the slave.

author: Antiphanes
title: Misoponeros
statement:
[That begging priests are the filthiest race on earth except for fishmongers]
 πολὺ γὰρ αὖ γένος
μιαρώτατον τοῦτ’ ἔστιν, εἰ μὴ νὴ Δία 
τοὺς ἰχθυοπώλας  βούλεταί τις λέγειν
remarks: There are four informal oaths in this short fragment.  See oath ids 1400-1403.

title: IC I
statement: [? That they would judge according to the laws]
remarks:
The text indicates that the kosmoi are to swear before giving a judgement (κόσμος γ[ι]γνόσκεν ὀμνύντας τὸν ἐπὶ πόλεος τὸν τ’ ἀν). 
The text seems to show that there were two kosmoi, one who is described as "in the city" (ἐπὶ πόλεος) and one whose designation is lost. All that can be read is τ’ ἀν̣.  
AHS tentatively suggests that the last word may have been a derivative or agros and referred to a second kosmos with "rural" responsibilities complementary to those of the kosmos in the city.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
swearee: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
statement: [That they would fight together in attacking the Medes and Persians]
remarks: Apparently the allies were convinced of the need for the alliance by the Assyrian king's suggestions that the Medes and the Persians, who had intermarried, and were powerful nations, would be likely to make war on each of the other nations and subjugate them. Those who were unconvinced by such arguments were apparently bribed to join the alliance. In the passage referred to in this oath entry, the Assyrians, disheartened by the success of the Persian campaigns, abandon camp, causing their allies, including Croesus, to lose heart also.  Cf. oath ids 2326, 2381, and 2389. The allies subsequently begin to desert- see oath id 2387.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks: Xenophon states that when Agesilaus announced there would be a second year of campaigning against the Acarnanians they sent envoys to Sparta who concluded a peace with the Achaeans (see also oath id 2302) and an alliance with the Spartans (see oath id 1951 and 2301).

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Spartans or their allies should not go against or raise revenue from whatever lands and cities belong to King Darius or belonged to his ancestors.
2. King Darius and his subjects shall not go against the territory of the Spartans
3. They shall fight against the Athenians and if they make peace they shall do so together
4. Whatever forces are in the territory of the King shall be paid for by the King
5. If any of the cities that have entered into the agreement with the King go against the territory of the King, the rest shall prevent this; and if any of those who inhabit the King's territory go against the territory of the Spartans or their allies, the King shall strive to prevent this and gave aid to the extent of his power]
remarks:
Thucydides states that Alcibiades kept trying to turn Tissaphernes towards the Athenians, playing upon the fears of Tissaphernes who feared the size of the Spartan fleet given the objections of Lichas to the treaty and the Spartan policy to liberate the Greek cities.  
For references to all these agreements see also oath id 1806.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Praxagora explains things well]
  νὴ τὴν Δήμητρ’ εὖ γε διδάσκεις.
remarks: This is with reference to the fact that no law suits will be necessary in the new society; cf. oath id 819.

author: Plato
title: Laws
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a discussion of the rights of a suppliant and the sanctity of oaths. The Athenian explains that if a suppliant is cheated out of an agreement, after having invoked a god as a witness, that god becomes his guardian and avenger. The man will never be wronged without vengeance being taken for his wrongs. The suppliant is assumed to have invoked a god as a witness to an agreement (homologia). That is, the person supplicated has sworn to protect the suppliant, and the suppliant has accepted this guarantee and has risen from his suppliant posture, thereby passing from the protection of Zeus Hikesios into that of the god(s) named in the oath.  A neat example of such a sequence is that between Medea and Aegeus in Eur. Med. 709ff:  Medea makes herself a suppliant (709-713); Aegeus promises to protect her, and backs up this promise with an oath dictated by Medea (719-755- see oath id 120); Medea releases him from her suppliant’s hold (756). See also oath id 2700.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he doesn't want any kindness done to him (because it is never to his advantage)]
  ἀγαθὸν ἔοικας οὐδὲν ἐπιθυμεῖν παθεῖν. 
{Φι.} μὰ τὸν Δί’, οὐ γὰρ οὐδαμῶς μοι ξύμφορον.
remarks: This statement is paradoxical. How can something be agathon and yet never sumphoron?  The example he proceeds to give provides a solution for the paradox:  something that was good for him in the short term (eating his fill of sprats) proved costly in the slightly longer run (he had an attack of diarrhoea and had to pay three obols to get his clothes cleaned).

author: Euripides
title: Medea
statement:
[That Medea is preventing Jason from burying his dead children]
 ἀλλ’ ὁπόσον γοῦν πάρα καὶ δύναμαι
  τάδε καὶ θρηνῶ κἀπιθεάζω,
  μαρτυρόμενος δαίμονας ὥς μοι 
  τέκνα κτείνασ’ ἀποκωλύεις
  ψαῦσαί τε χεροῖν θάψαι τε νεκρούς,
  οὓς μήποτ’ ἐγὼ φύσας ὄφελον
  πρὸς σοῦ φθιμένους ἐπιδέσθαι.
remarks: Jason only invokes the gods in general (daimones) to witness, rather than specific deities in this play. See also oath id 119.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, Perdiccas again deserted the Athenians after making this alliance with them. 
For other references to the various alliances between Athens and Perdiccas see oath id 256.  
See also oath id 1545 and 1751.

title: IG IV
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace]
remarks:
The statement is unknown. The decree indicates that various Greek states are at peace with "the King", but also indicates that if the king attacks those who have sworn an oath for peace they will defend themselves. The text reads, "But if he makes war on any of those who have sworn the oath of peace" (ἐὰν δὲ πολεμῆι πρὸς τινας τῶν [ὁμοσασῶν τὸν ὅρκον). 
The decree most likely dates from 362/1, and is a collective declaration by various poleis in reply to an embassy from the Persian satraps who had revolted from Artaxerxes II. The common peace mentioned is presumably that sworn after the battle of Mantinea in 362. The Greek poleis thus made it clear that they were not going to join in the war against Artaxerxes, but would do so if their interests were affected. However, other occasions for the swearing of the oaths cannot be ruled out.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he believes he would much rather acquire a companion than all the gold of Darius or Darius himself]
 οἶμαι δέ, νὴ τὸν κύνα, μᾶλλον ἢ τὸ Δαρείου χρυσίον κτήσασθαι δεξαίμην πολὺ πρότερον ἑταῖρον, μᾶλλον <δὲ> ἢ αὐτὸν Δαρεῖον
remarks: Cf. oath id 3080. Swearing by 'the dog' is typical of Socrates' literary character. See oath id 2548 with cross references.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, Epaminondas complained to envoys from Arcadia that they had concluded peace without Theban approval. 
He then threatened to invade Arcadia and make war with those Arcadians who remained loyal to Thebes. 
See also oath id 2042.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
impact: Influences the Medes to stay with Cyrus
statement:
[That Cyrus seems to enjoy treating his men well more than enriching himself]
 ὄμνυμι ὑμῖν πάντας τοὺς θεούς, εὖ ποιῶν ἡμᾶς μᾶλλον ἥδεσθαι ἢ ἑαυτὸν πλουτίζων.

author: Isocrates
title: Archidamus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Archidamus tells the Spartans that in the past they have been forced to make peace when they were in a worse position than their foes, but that when this happened neither the Great King (when they agreed to the King's Peace in 387/6) or the Athenians (when they agreed to the Peace of Nicias in 422/1) charged them with having acquired Messenia unjustly. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956. 
It is possible that this is a reference to the peace of 374 (see oath id 1972).

author: Theopompus
title: Philippica
statement: [That they would be loyal to each other and fight alongside each other]
remarks: Archidamus died fighting with the Tarentines.

author: Antiphanes
title: Boiotia
statement:
[That they say that the golden apples are those of the Hesperides]
 παρ’ Ἑσπερίδων, ᾤμην γε. {Α.} νὴ τὴν Φωσφόρον, 
φησὶν τὰ χρυσᾶ μῆλα ταῦτ’ εἶναι.
remarks: Swearing by "the light-bringer" is a feminine oath (cf. oath ids 1176 and 1192). The speaker is presumably mature since she addresses the other person as "parthene". The "golden apples" are apparently citrons.

author: Plato
title: Menexenus
statement:
[That he thinks there is no difficulty for a man to win good repute when he is performing among the persons whom he is praising]
 ὅταν δέ τις ἐν τούτοις ἀγωνίζηται οὕσπερ καὶ ἐπαινεῖ, οὐδὲν μέγα δοκεῖν εὖ λέγειν.  {ΜΕΝ.} Οὐκ οἴει, ὦ Σώκρατες;  {ΣΩ.} Οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία.

author: Lysias
title: Against Andocides
statement:
[That Andocides has had nothing to do with any of the peace agreements the Athenians arranged with the Spartans, nor the ones that those from Piraeus made with those in town]
 οὔτε μὰ τὸν Δία τῶν πρὸς Λακεδαιμονίους, ἃς ὑμεῖς συνέθεσθε, οὔτε ὧν πρὸς τοὺς ἐν [τῷ] ἄστει οἱ ἐκ Πειραιῶς.
remarks: This is a typically far-fetched attempt to exclude Andocides from the benefits of the amnesty:  the agreements, the speaker claims, were between the two sides in the civil war, and therefore cannot be invoked by Andocides who was on neither side.  A different but cognate line is taken in the Agoratus case (13.89-90; see oath id 2829), where it is argued that the amnesty doesn’t apply to that case because the prosecutor and the defendant were on the same side in the civil war.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Theocrines
if_taken: They will be excused from testifying
if_refused: They must testify as requested, or else submit to punishment
statement: [That they did not know that the facts, to which they had been called to testify, were true]
remarks: The speaker, Epichares, asks the jurors to join him in forcing Theocrines and his supporters to testify or swear that they know nothing about Theocrines bringing two prosecutions despite being a state debtor. Epichares does not call either Theocrines or his supporters to testify.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Aeneas son of Ocytus; Amphias son of Eupalidas; Athenaeus, son of Pericleidas; Autocles, son of Tolmaeus; Damotimus son of Naucrates; Euphamidas son of Aristonymus; Menecrates son of Amphidorus; Nicasus, son of Cecalus; Nicias; Nicostratus; Onasimus, son of Megacles; Philocharidas; Taurus son of Echetimidas
swearee: Aeneas son of Ocytus; Amphias son of Eupalidas; Athenaeus, son of Pericleidas; Autocles, son of Tolmaeus; Damotimus son of Naucrates; Euphamidas son of Aristonymus; Menecrates son of Amphidorus; Nicasus, son of Cecalus; Nicias; Nicostratus; Onasimus, son of Megacles; Philocharidas; Taurus son of Echetimidas
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Free access to the oracle at Delphi (the Spartans promised to try to persuade the Boeotians and Phocians about this)
2. Those who had misused the treasures at Delphi were to be sought out
3. Each side should retain what territory it currently possessed (the Athenian garrison at Pylos should keep within the coastal high points Buphras and Tomaeus; the Athenian garrison in Cythera should have no communication with the territory of the Spartan allies; the Athenian garrison in Nisaea and Minoa should not cross the roads leading to the mainland and the Megarians should not cross it either; the Athenians should retain the island [Atalante?] which they took and neither side shall communicate with the other; the Athenians should retain whatever territory they possessed in Troezen in accordance with the agreements which the Troezenians had made with the Athenians)
4. The Spartans and their allies were not permitted to sail in oared ships except along their own coasts, and then only in vessels of less than 500 metra capacity not designed for use in war 
5. Deserters should not be received
6. Any disputes should be resolved by arbitration]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the one year armistice continued until and ended at the time of the Pythian games. 
For other references to this oath and its impact, see oath id 1676.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That being able to live off friends is a fine acquisition to have]
 Ἐάν τις, ἔφη, φίλος μοι γενόμενος εὖ ποιεῖν  ἐθέλῃ, οὗτός μοι βίος ἐστί. Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφη, ὦ Θεοδότη, καλόν γε τὸ κτῆμα
remarks: Swearing by Hera is typical of Socrates; see oath id 1870 with cross references.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That the abuses and outrages that he has heard were committed on Timarchus by Pittalacus were worse than he would dare speak of to the jury]
 καὶ τοιαῦτα πράγματα καὶ τοιαύτας ὕβρεις ἐγὼ ἀκήκοα γεγονέναι ὑπὸ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου τούτου εἰς τὸ σῶμα τοῦ Τιμάρχου οἵας ἐγὼ μὰ τὸν Δία τὸν Ὀλύμπιον οὐκ ἂν τολμήσαιμι πρὸς ὑμᾶς εἰπεῖν

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That the Syracusan showman gives the impression of being a person who likes to abuse people]
 Σὺ μέντοι δεινὸς εἶ, ὦ Φίλιππε, εἰκάζειν· οὐ δοκεῖ σοι ὁ ἀνὴρ οὗτος λοιδορεῖσθαι βουλομένῳ ἐοικέναι; Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη,

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That the city has a pretty miserable champion (in the Informer)]
  Νὴ Δία, πονηρόν γ’ ἆρα προστάτην ἔχει.

author: Plato
title: Apologia
if_broken: Utter destruction of self and household
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Socrates reminds the jury of their dikastic oath; cf. oath ids 2783 and 2785. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
swearer: Aristophanes; Dercylus, son of Autocles, of Hagnous; Aristides, son of Euphiletus, of Cephisia
if_taken: His evidence will carry more weight
statement: The exact statement is unknown.
remarks:
Aeschines calls Aristophanes of Olynthus to testify that Demosthenes had tried to bribe him to give false evidence against Aeschines - namely that he had committed a drunken assault on one of Aristophanes' female relatives (see Demosthenes, On the False Embassy 196-8); in addition Dercylus and Aristeides testify that they had heard this story from Aristophanes and reported it to Aeschines. 
After they give evidence, Aeschines says to the jurors, "You have heard the witnesses swearing solemnly and testifying". 
Perhaps one of the witnesses (Aristophanes?) volunteered an oath (to make his testimony more impressive - or maybe merely because it was the normal practice at Olynthus where he came from?)

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
When Dercylidas moved against the cities of Skepsis and Gergis (which were ruled by Meidias), he told Meidias that he could become his ally if he allowed the citizens of Skepsis to be free and automonous. 
Meidias then allowed him to enter the city and remove the garrison he had there.

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he wants the First Slave to take the bilge to hell, and himself along with it]
 Αὐτὴν ἄρ’ οἴσω συλλαβὼν τὴν ἀντλίαν. 
 {ΟΙ. Βʹ}  Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἐς κόρακάς γε, καὶ σαυτόν γε πρός.
remarks: This oath emphasises an implicit imperative (cf. oath id 950). On the double meaning of "bilge" and the joke developed here, see Sommerstein ad 17-18.

author: Cratinus
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: unknown
remarks: This is a reference to someone (male) who administers an oath sworn by someone.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement:
[That Charidemus only wants to do us good]
 νὴ Δία πάντ’ ἀγάθ’ ἔμελλεν ἡμᾶς ποιήσειν
remarks: Demosthenes imagines that someone will say that Charidemus only wants to do good for the Athenians, but he argues that even if this were the case the decree would not be justified.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The text records the alliance between Athens and Cetriporis of Thrace, Lyppeus of Paeonia and Grabus of Illyria. 
See also oath id 459, 460, 462, all relating to the same alliance.

author: Plato
title: Ion
statement:
[That he thinks Socrates is right (when he argues that Ion's gift of speaking well on Homer is not a teachable skill (techne), but a divine power)]
 ἢ οὐ δοκῶ σοι ἀληθῆ λέγειν, ὦ Ἴων; {ΙΩΝ.} Ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἔμοιγε·

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_taken: They will be part of the conspiracy
if_refused: They will not be part of the conspiracy
statement: [That they will conspire against the people]
remarks: In the original reference to this conspiracy, necessarily involving an oath, the conspirators are Nicias and Demosthenes. Here they are designated as the Sausage-seller and Demosthenes. See also remarks on oath ids 975 and 1243.

author: Plato
title: Theages
statement:
[That it doesn't seem that Thucydides knows what a slave he was before he associated with Socrates]
 “Τί δέ, οὐκ οἶδεν,” ἔφη, “πρὶν σοὶ συγγενέσθαι οἷον ἦν τὸ ἀνδράποδον;” “Οὐκ ἔοικέν γε,” ἔφην ἐγώ, “νὴ τοὺς θεούς.”
remarks: Thucydides and Aristeides here are the grandsons respectively of Thucydides the aristocratic opponent of Pericles, and Aristeides the Athenian statesman of the time of the Persian wars. Cf. Plato's Laches.

title: SEG
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This text was written on a jar which contained the documents relating to a legal case. The jar contained the diamartyria, the law on abuse of heiresses, challenge of testimony, oaths of litigants, and names a certain Antenor as sealing the lid. The diamartyria was sworn testimony to a fact that affected the admissibility of an action at law. It preceded the oaths of the prosecutor and defendant.  
For the oath sworn by the litigants see oath id 523.   
All these oaths will have been taken at the preliminary hearing (anakrisis).

author: Anonymus Tragicus
title: Fragment 145b
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment refers to the 'great oath' the gods have sworn which is fixed, i.e. will be fulfilled. Cf. oath id 203.

author: Euripides
title: Phoenissae
impact: Strengthens Menoceus' resolve to sacrifice himself for the city
statement:
[That he shall not betray his father, brother and city and leave the land like a coward]
 ἐγὼ δέ, πατέρα καὶ κασίγνητον προδοὺς
  πόλιν τ’ ἐμαυτοῦ, δειλὸς ὣς ἔξω χθονὸς
  ἄπειμ’, ὅπου δ’ ἂν ζῶ κακὸς φανήσομαι; 
  μὰ τὸν μετ’ ἄστρων Ζῆν’ ῎Αρη τε φοίνιον,
  ὃς τοὺς ὑπερτείλαντας ἐκ γαίας ποτὲ
  Σπαρτοὺς ἄνακτας τῆσδε γῆς ἱδρύσατο.
remarks: This oath marks Menoeceus' decision to sacrifice himself for Thebes, the sacrifice of a male in this way being a unique moment in tragedy.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement:
[That while the public conduct of Androtion, Glaucetes and Melanopus  has been discreditable, they have carried out other business well]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία ταῦτα μὲν τοιοῦτοι γεγόνασιν ἐν οἷς πεπολίτευνται, ἄλλα δ’ ἔσθ’ ἃ καλῶς διῳκήκασιν.
remarks: Diodorus imagines that someone might object in this way to his description of the public conduct of Androtion, Glaucetes and Melanopus.

title: IC IV
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: According to the text the judges shall decide cases according to the rules inscribed according to the declarations of witnesses or under an oath of denial.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Emphasises the truth of the statement
statement:
[That things are not at the stage of sharing wealth]
  Οὐ τῷ μεταδοῦναι;  
  {ΧΡ.}  Μὰ Δία· δεῖ γὰρ πρῶτα—

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
Xenophon observes that when Agesilaus found the Thebans, Athenians, Argives, Corinthians, Aenianians, Euboeans and Locrians arrayed against him at Coronea in 394, he drew up his army which included also one and a half morai and, of the local allies, only the Phocians and the Orchomenians. 
The most recent alliance we know of between Sparta and Orchomenus is that made with the Boeotians as a whole in 421 (see oath id 1708), which all Boeotia except Orchomenus had now abandoned to make a new alliance with Athens and others.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Acarnanians as allies, observing that some of them served for gain, but the majority were moved by friendship for Demosthenes and goodwill toward the Athenians "whose allies they were". 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1569. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see oath id 1778.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that after the envoys from Syracuse and Athens put to the Camarinaeans their arguments as to why they should support them in the war, the Camarianeans resolved to help neither the Athenians nor the Syracusans, as they were allies of both parties, and it seemed consistent with their oaths to aid neither party. 
Thucydides does not state when this alliance took place. The relationship between Syracuse and Camarina during this period can be summarised as follows: 
1. In 427 Camarina was hostile to Syracuse and made an alliance with Athens  
2. In 425 (see 4.25) Camarina was betrayed to Syracuse by a certain Archias 
3. In 424 the Sicilians agreed to make peace with each other (see oath id 1654)  
4. In 422 Camarina was again hostile to Syracuse 
5. In 415 (see 6.52) the Camarinaeans warned the Athenians that Syracuse was manning a fleet and told the Athenians that they would help them if they came (and then rebuffed them) 
6. In 415 (see 6.67.2) cavalrymen and archers from Camarina served alongside the Syracusans against the Athenians 
7. In 415 (6.88.2) the Camarinaeans claimed to be allies of both the Syracusans and Athenians and to have exchanged oaths with both.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
statement:
[That the Athenians will do their duty whenever it is necessary]
 ὅταν νὴ Δί’ ἀναγκαῖον ᾖ.
remarks:
Demosthenes is imagining how someone might respond to his question regarding when the Athenians will do their duty and oppose Philip. He rejoins that the time when this is "necessary" has arrived long since. 

This is almost identical to oath id 3215 from ten years earlier. See also oath id 3279.

author: Aristophanes
title: Poiesis
statement: unknown
remarks: This passage is too fragmentary to supply the statement of the oath. It is also unclear whether the oath formula here is "ma ton" or "nh ton".

author: Plato
title: Philebus
statement:
[That the question asked may not be easy to answer, but it must be answered]
 Μὰ Δί’ οὐ ῥᾴδιον ἴσως εἰπεῖν, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἀλλ’ὅμως λεκτέον.
remarks: The question was: what was the identical feature they had in mind when they called hunger and thirst, which are so different, by the same name- desires?

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Macartatus
statement:
[That the inheritance should not go to Theopompus or Macartatus his son]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐ Θεοπόμπῳ οὐδὲ Μακαρτάτῳ τῷ Θεοπόμπου υἱεῖ,

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would have the same enemies and friends, and they would remain loyal and not desert (the Athenian masses or the allies of the Athenians)]
remarks:
Thucydides states that in 428 ten Mytilenaean triremes were serving with the Athenians in accordance with the alliance. 
For other references to the so-called Delian League see also oath id 1778.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he dared to let it get out, without seeking Cyrus’ consent, that Cyrus' father had called him back]
 καὶ σὺ τοῦτο ἐτόλμησας ἐξενεγκεῖν, εἴτ’ ἐγὼ ἐβουλόμην εἴτε μή; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη·
remarks: Hystaspas suggests that Cyrus is keen on going home to report to his father on his successful campaigns.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Xenophon lists these poleis as allies of Sparta at the battle of Nemea in 394. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: Unity among Persians and fairness in Persian rule would be assured
if_refused: Unity among Persians and fairness in Persian rule would not be assured
impact: Unity among the Persians is formalised
statement:
[That if anyone attempts to put a stop to Cyrus' rule or if any of his subjects revolt, they will come to assist both each other and Cyrus  in whatsoever he might call upon them to do]
 ὑμᾶς δέ, ὦ Πέρσαι, ἤν τις ἢ ἀρχῆς Κῦρον ἐπιχειρῇ καταπαύειν ἢ ἀφίστασθαί τις τῶν ὑποχειρίων, βοηθήσειν καὶ ὑμῖν αὐτοῖς καὶ Κύρῳ καθ ὅ τι ἂν οὗτος ἐπαγγέλλῃ
remarks: Cyrus swears a reciprocal oath- see oath id 2500. Xenophon states that both the Persian people and their king still act according to this agreement (see oath id 2502).

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That parents who have intercourse with their children and beget children will beget them badly, even if the fathers are good men and the mothers good women, because it is not enough that the parents should be good (they must also be in peak bodily condition)]
 Πῶς οὖν, ἔφη, κακῶς οὗτοι τεκνοποιοῦνται, οὕς γε οὐδὲν κωλύει ἀγαθοὺς αὐτοὺς ὄντας ἐξ ἀγαθῶν παιδοποιεῖσθαι; Ὅτι νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ μόνον ἀγαθοὺς δεῖ τοὺς ἐξ ἀλλήλων παιδοποιουμένους εἶναι, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἀκμάζοντας τοῖς σώμασιν.
remarks: This is not, in fact, a good argument, since if it proves anything it proves too much:  if this were a reason for avoiding parent-child incest, it would also be a reason for avoiding marriage with any woman young enough to be one's daughter, and such marriages, whether to a relative (e.g. niece) or a non-relative, were both legal and frequent in all Greek communities of which we have any relevant knowledge.

author: Anonymus Oxyrhynchicus
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not to attack each other for six month]
remarks:
The text states that Agesilaus advanced to the Hellespont with his army, and as long as he was going through Lydia, he caused no harm to the inhabitants since he wished to abide by the truce with Tithraustes. 
Diodorus 14.80.8 makes it clear that the truce was to last for six months. 
See also Xenophon, Hellenica 3.4.25-6.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement:
[That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
 Κήρυκες δ’ ἀνὰ ἄστυ θεῶν φέρον ὅρκια πιστὰ 
ἄρνε δύω καὶ οἶνον ἐΰφρονα καρπὸν ἀρούρης 
ἀσκῷ ἐν αἰγείῳ· φέρε δὲ κρητῆρα φαεινὸν
κῆρυξ ᾿Ιδαῖος ἠδὲ χρύσεια κύπελλα· 
ὤτρυνεν δὲ γέροντα παριστάμενος ἐπέεσσιν·
ὄρσεο Λαομεδοντιάδη, καλέουσιν ἄριστοι 
Τρώων θ’ ἱπποδάμων καὶ ᾿Αχαιῶν χαλκοχιτώνων 
ἐς πεδίον καταβῆναι ἵν’ ὅρκια πιστὰ τάμητε·
αὐτὰρ ᾿Αλέξανδρος καὶ ἀρηΐφιλος Μενέλαος
μακρῇς ἐγχείῃσι μαχήσοντ’ ἀμφὶ γυναικί·
 τῷ δέ κε νικήσαντι γυνὴ καὶ κτήμαθ’ ἕποιτο· 
οἳ δ’ ἄλλοι φιλότητα καὶ ὅρκια πιστὰ ταμόντες 
ναίοιμεν Τροίην ἐριβώλακα, τοὶ δὲ νέονται
῎Αργος ἐς ἱππόβοτον καὶ ᾿Αχαιΐδα καλλιγύναικα.
῝Ως φάτο ῥίγησεν δ’ ὃ γέρων, ἐκέλευσε δ’ ἑταίρους
ἵππους ζευγνύμεναι· τοὶ δ’ ὀτραλέως ἐπίθοντο. 
ἂν δ’ ἄρ’ ἔβη Πρίαμος, κατὰ δ’ ἡνία τεῖνεν ὀπίσσω·
πὰρ δέ οἱ ᾿Αντήνωρ περικαλλέα βήσετο δίφρον·
τὼ δὲ διὰ Σκαιῶν πεδίον δ’ ἔχον ὠκέας ἵππους. 
  ᾿Αλλ’ ὅτε δή ῥ’ ἵκοντο μετὰ Τρῶας καὶ ᾿Αχαιούς, 
ἐξ ἵππων ἀποβάντες ἐπὶ χθόνα πουλυβότειραν  
ἐς μέσσον Τρώων καὶ ᾿Αχαιῶν ἐστιχόωντο.
ὤρνυτο δ’ αὐτίκ’ ἔπειτα ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν ᾿Αγαμέμνων, 
ἂν δ’ ᾿Οδυσεὺς πολύμητις· ἀτὰρ κήρυκες ἀγαυοὶ 
ὅρκια πιστὰ θεῶν σύναγον, κρητῆρι δὲ οἶνον 
μίσγον, ἀτὰρ βασιλεῦσιν ὕδωρ ἐπὶ χεῖρας ἔχευαν.
᾿Ατρεΐδης δὲ ἐρυσσάμενος χείρεσσι μάχαιραν, 
ἥ οἱ πὰρ ξίφεος μέγα κουλεὸν αἰὲν ἄωρτο, 
ἀρνῶν ἐκ κεφαλέων τάμνε τρίχας· αὐτὰρ ἔπειτα
κήρυκες Τρώων καὶ ᾿Αχαιῶν νεῖμαν ἀρίστοις.
τοῖσιν δ’ ᾿Ατρεΐδης μεγάλ’ εὔχετο χεῖρας ἀνασχών·  
Ζεῦ πάτερ ῎Ιδηθεν μεδέων κύδιστε μέγιστε, 
᾿Ηέλιός θ’, ὃς πάντ’ ἐφορᾷς καὶ πάντ’ ἐπακούεις, 
καὶ ποταμοὶ καὶ γαῖα, καὶ οἳ ὑπένερθε καμόντας
ἀνθρώπους τίνυσθον ὅτις κ’ ἐπίορκον ὀμόσσῃ, 
ὑμεῖς μάρτυροι ἔστε, φυλάσσετε δ’ ὅρκια πιστά·  
εἰ μέν κεν Μενέλαον ᾿Αλέξανδρος καταπέφνῃ 
αὐτὸς ἔπειθ’ ῾Ελένην ἐχέτω καὶ κτήματα πάντα,
ἡμεῖς δ’ ἐν νήεσσι νεώμεθα ποντοπόροισιν· 
εἰ δέ κ’ ᾿Αλέξανδρον κτείνῃ ξανθὸς Μενέλαος, 
Τρῶας ἔπειθ’ ῾Ελένην καὶ κτήματα πάντ’ ἀποδοῦναι, 
 τιμὴν δ’ ᾿Αργείοις ἀποτινέμεν ἥν τιν’ ἔοικεν,
ἥ τε καὶ ἐσσομένοισι μετ’ ἀνθρώποισι πέληται. 
εἰ δ’ ἂν ἐμοὶ τιμὴν Πρίαμος Πριάμοιό τε παῖδες
τίνειν οὐκ ἐθέλωσιν ᾿Αλεξάνδροιο πεσόντος, 
αὐτὰρ ἐγὼ καὶ ἔπειτα μαχήσομαι εἵνεκα ποινῆς 
αὖθι μένων, εἵως κε τέλος πολέμοιο κιχείω.
  ῏Η, καὶ ἀπὸ στομάχους ἀρνῶν τάμε νηλέϊ χαλκῷ· 
καὶ τοὺς μὲν κατέθηκεν ἐπὶ χθονὸς ἀσπαίροντας
θυμοῦ δευομένους· ἀπὸ γὰρ μένος εἵλετο χαλκός.
οἶνον δ’ ἐκ κρητῆρος ἀφυσσόμενοι δεπάεσσιν 
ἔκχεον, ἠδ’ εὔχοντο θεοῖς αἰειγενέτῃσιν. 
ὧδε δέ τις εἴπεσκεν ᾿Αχαιῶν τε Τρώων τε· 
Ζεῦ κύδιστε μέγιστε καὶ ἀθάνατοι θεοὶ ἄλλοι 
ὁππότεροι πρότεροι ὑπὲρ ὅρκια πημήνειαν 
ὧδέ σφ’ ἐγκέφαλος χαμάδις ῥέοι ὡς ὅδε οἶνος 
αὐτῶν καὶ τεκέων, ἄλοχοι δ’ ἄλλοισι δαμεῖεν.
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: It is Agmamenon who makes the prayer which seals the oath, but the Achaeans and the Trojans who state the punishments for breaking the oath. The oath is mentioned several times in the Iliad- see oath ids 316, 317, 320, 322-326, 341, 343. Aristotle discusses this oath and issues of perjury- see oath ids 1999, 2000, 2002.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
if_taken: He may be more determined to defeat the argument of Simmias and Cebes
statement:
[That he will not let his hair grow again until he has defeated the argument of Simmias and Cebes]
 καὶ ἔγωγ’ ἄν, εἰ σὺ εἴην καί με διαφεύγοι ὁ λόγος, ἔνορκον ἂν ποιησαίμην ὥσπερ Ἀργεῖοι, μὴ πρότερον κομήσειν, πρὶν ἂν νικήσω ἀναμαχόμενος τὸν Σιμμίου τε καὶ Κέβητος λόγον.
remarks: This is an oath proposed by Socrates to Phaedo, but rejected by Phaedo on the grounds that not even Heracles would take on two opponents at once. To take such an oath is said to be 'like the Argives'- see oath id 2883.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That he really cannot name anyone else who has been fortunate in his time in the way that Philip has been (in that he has found bigger scoundrels than he needed to help him)]
 ὃ μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς καὶ τὰς θεὰς οὐκ ἔχω λέγειν ἔγωγ’ ἄλλον ὅστις ηὐτύχηκεν ἐφ’ ἡμῶν.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_taken: Their statement will carry greater weight
impact: The Greeks did not believe them
statement:
[That neither Helen, nor the goods claimed were with them, but were instead in Egypt with King Proteus]
 μὴ μὲν ἔχειν Ἑλένην μηδὲ τὰ ἐπικαλεόμενα χρήματα, ἀλλ’ εἶναι αὐτὰ πάντα ἐν Αἰγύπτῳ
remarks:
Herodotus claims that when the Greeks demanded that the Trojans hand over Helen and the goods taken by Paris, the Trojans (referred to as the Teucrians) denied that Helen was in Troy both with oaths and without oaths. Despite their swearing this oath, the Greeks believed the Trojans were mocking them.  
Herodotus also claims that the Trojans denied that Helen was in Troy after the Greeks had captured the city. For this oath see oath id 1288.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the Inlaw is lying, since Proteas has been dead for ten years]
 Ψεύδεται νὴ τὼ θεώ,
  ἐπεὶ τέθνηκε Πρωτέας ἔτη δέκα.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad loc., Critylla here fails to understand that Euripides and the Inlaw are re-creating Euripides' tragedy 'Helen'. This leads her to suppose that the person mentioned is Proteas (not Proteus, whose tomb figures in 'Helen'). This Proteas is probably Proteas son of Epicles, of the deme of Aexone, who had been a general in the time of Pericles (see Sommerstein for further details). On swearing by the two goddesses, see remarks on oath id 713.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_taken: They will be part of the conspiracy
if_refused: They will not be part of the conspiracy
statement: [That they would conspire against the people]
remarks: This is a report of how Paphlagon lies to the council calling the Knights conspirators. On the sworn conspirarcy between Nicias, Demosthenes and the sausage-seller, see remarks at id 975.

author: Isaeus
title: On Behalf of Euphiletus
statement:
[That Euphiletus is his son by a mother who is a citizen and legally married]
 ἦ μὴν Εὐφίλητον τουτονὶ ὑὸν εἶναι αὑτοῦ ἐξ ἀστῆς καὶ γαμετῆς γυναικός.
remarks:
The speaker (Euphiletus' half-brother) states that he, his father Hegesippus, and Euphiletus' mother are all willing to swear that Euphiletus is legitimate (see also oath id 3184, 3186).  
The speaker goes on to stress that the jurors would be justified in regarding their oaths as more worthy of credence than the statements of their opponents, because whereas they are willing to swear oaths concerning Euphiletus, their opponents are repeating statements which they heard from Euphiletus' enemies or are uttering their own lies.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he never created trollops like Phaedra or Stheneboea in his dramas]
  Ἀλλ’ οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐ Φαίδρας ἐποίουν πόρνας οὐδὲ Σθενεβοίας
remarks: See also Euripides' counter-oath at id 477.  Regarding the truthfulness of Aeschylus' statement, Dover comments:  "The modern reader thinks of Klytaimestra and Aigisthos, but Klytaimestra in the Oresteia is motivated primarily by desire for revenge, and enjoyment of Aigisthos is supplementary"; Sommerstein adds that "neither Clytaemestra nor, so far as our knowledge goes, any other Aeschylean woman character was portrayed in the throes of unsatisfied passion as Stheneboea ... and ... Phaedra [were by Euripides]".

author: Timocles
title: Epistolai
statement:
[That Spurge has never yet desired to eat so much, nor Tree-trunk  to wear a cloak, nor has Nile ever desired barley-groats so much, nor has Lark ever desired so much to eat for free]
 μὰ τοὺς θεούς, 
Τιθύμαλλος οὐδεπώποτ’ ἠράσθη φαγεῖν
οὕτω σφόδρ’, οὐδὲ Κόρμος ἱμάτιον λαβεῖν,
οὐ Νεῖλος ἄλφιτ’, οὐ Κόρυδος ἀσύμβολος
κινεῖν ὀδόντας.
remarks: Spurge, Treetrunk, Nile and Lark are all nicknames.  The speaker is apparently in love (line 1), and he (it must be he) is saying that the four persons he names have never desired their respective greatest pleasures as much as he desires … whoever she is.  Spurge is a glutton, Treetrunk and Nile are both very poor, and Lark is a parasite (mentioned frequently in other comedy and elsewhere).  We do not know the real names of any of the four; three of the nicknames are fairly obviously related to physical peculiarities (Lark to shape of head) and “Nile” to a real or alleged Egyptian connection of some sort.

title: Syll (3)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
This decree was probably set up not long after Alexander the Great passed through the area. Nine citizens were elected to act as inspectors to find out whether any public land had been occupied illegally and to impose fines. After the inspection was carried out, eleven citizens were to be elected from among the citizens who did not possess any public land. Eight of the eleven would serve as judges of those accused of owning public land illegally, and the remaining three would serve as advocates.
