The text indicates that "that judges and advocates were to swear by Artemis according to the law" (ὀμόσαι δὲ τοὺς δικαστὰς κ̣αὶ τοὺς συνηγόρους τὴν Ἄρτεμιν κατὰ τὸν νόμον). 
For the oath of the judges see oath id 923.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That it would be quite unreasonable for a philosopher to be afraid of death (since what he longs for, among other things, is for his soul to be independent from his body)]
 εἰ δὲ τοῦτο οὕτως ἔχει, ὅπερ ἄρτι ἔλεγον, οὐ πολλὴ ἂν ἀλογία εἴη εἰ φοβοῖτο τὸν θάνατον ὁ τοιοῦτος; Πολλὴ μέντοι νὴ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς.

title: IC IV
statement: [That the child had not been brought to him]
remarks:
According to the text, if a serf woman who is divorced gives birth to a child it is to be brought to the master of her ex-husband in the presence of witnesses. If he doesn't receive it, the child will be in the mother's power. The text indicates that the witnesses are to be believed (horkioteroi) if they swear that the child was brought to the husband's master. 
See also oath id 1127.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That he is not trying to avoid helping Critoboulos bear his unavoidable burdens]
 Προθύμως γε, ὦ 
Σώκρατες, ἀποφεύγειν μοι πειρᾷ μηδέν με συνωφελῆσαι εἰς
τὸ ῥᾷον ὑποφέρειν τὰ ἐμοὶ ἀναγκαῖα πράγματα. Οὐ μὰ Δί’,
ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, οὐκ ἔγωγε

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he admires Socrates in many ways, not least because now he is educating Callias while flattering him]
 Νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἄλλα τέ σου πολλὰ ἄγαμαι καὶ ὅτι νῦν ἅμα χαριζόμενος Καλλίᾳ καὶ παιδεύεις αὐτὸν οἷόνπερ χρὴ εἶναι.
remarks: Hermogenes here swears by Hera, as did his older brother (Callias) earlier in this dialogue. Swearing by Hera is highly unusual and it is only Socrates who invokes Hera with any frequency. However Callias and Hermogenes are from the same deme as Socrates: Alopeke (cf. Sommerstein, CQ 58 [2008], forthcoming). See further oath id 2259.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Emphasises the criminal profession rather than the legitimate ones
statement:
[That one of the occupations that man has invented because of Wealth is clothes-stealing]
  ὁ δὲ λωποδυτεῖ γε νὴ Δί’

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That Lysistrata should tell them what she wishes them to do]
  ὅ τι λῇς ποθ’ ἁμέ.  
 {ΚΛ.}  Νὴ Δί’, ὦ φίλη γύναι

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: n/a
remarks: Diodorus asks the jurors whether they can see any advantage to the polis in a law that overrides the decisions of the courts and requires unsworn people to cancel the judgements of sworn juries.

author: Euripides
title: Helena
statement:
[That he will end his life if he is deprived of Helen]
 Με. κἀγὼ στερηθεὶς σοῦ τελευτήσειν βίον. 
Ελ. πῶς οὖν θανούμεθ’ ὥστε καὶ δόξαν λαβεῖν;
Με. τύμβου ’πὶ νώτοις σὲ κτανὼν ἐμὲ κτενῶ.
  πρῶτον δ’ ἀγῶνα μέγαν ἀγωνιούμεθα
  λέκτρων ὑπὲρ σῶν· ὁ δὲ θέλων ἴτω πέλας.
remarks: There is no oath formula in the passage stated, but a verb of swearing has to be understood (from 835) to govern the infinitive τελευτήσειν.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other islanders
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would remain faithful and would not desert]
 ἐμμενεῖν τε καὶ μὴ ἀποστήσεσθαι
remarks:
Herodotus states that the Greek league admitted into their alliance the Samians, Chians, Lesbians and all the other islanders who had fought with them, after making them give pledges and swear oaths to remain faithful and not to desert. 
For another reference to the alliance between the Greek league and the Samians see oath id 1506.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
impact: Odysseus is not exposed and Helen learns the purpose of the Achaeans
statement:
[That she will not reveal Odysseus to the Trojans until he gets back to his tent and the fast ships]
 ἀλλ’ ὅτε δή μιν ἐγὼ λόεον καὶ χρῖον ἐλαίῳ,
ἀμφὶ δὲ εἵματα ἕσσα καὶ ὤμοσα καρτερὸν ὅρκον,
μή με πρὶν Ὀδυσῆα μετὰ Τρώεσσ’ ἀναφῆναι,
πρίν γε τὸν ἐς νῆάς τε θοὰς κλισίας τ’ ἀφικέσθαι,
καὶ τότε δή μοι πάντα νόον κατέλεξεν Ἀχαιῶν.
remarks: This oath is related in Helen's narrative to Telemachus in Sparta. The oath itself may have been proposed by Odysseus to guarantee his safety, or volunteered by Helen to make Odysseus reveal himself. The narrative in which the oath features is noteworthy in that the story is not requested (which breaks a general pattern), and follows Helen drugging Menelaus and Telemachus.

author: Aristotle
title: Aporemata Homerica
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Helios; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Once again Aristotle discusses this oath (cf. oath ids 1999 and 2000), specifically the breaking of it in Iliad book 4- see oath id 322. Here the question is: why does Athena influence Pandarus to break the truce rather than speak directly to one of the Trojans (Pandarus is technically one of the Trojan allies). The answer given is that Pandarus was born a perjurer because he belongs to a people who are still perjurers (Dardanians).

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That there was much talk in the enemy camp of the Persians' advance]
 Ἡμῶν δ’, ἔφη, λόγος τις ἦν παρ’ αὐτοῖς; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφασαν, καὶ πολύς γε ὡς ἐγγὺς ἤδη εἶτε προσιόντες.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Stephanus 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Apollodorus reminds the jurors that they have sworn to judge not concerning matters upon which the defendant asks their decision, but concerning only the very things about which the prosecution is. 
Apollodorus is putting quite a bit of spin on the wording of the oath, making it seem as though the jurors have sworn to accept the prosecutor’s view of what is and is not relevant! 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Plato
title: Theaetetus
statement:
[That Protagoras did profess emphatically to be superior to everyone in the matter of foretelling the future]
 Καὶ μάλα, ὦ Σώκρατες, τοῦτό γε σφόδρα ὑπισχνεῖτο πάντων διαφέρειν αὐτός. {ΣΩ.} Νὴ Δία, ὦ μέλε·

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Chersonese
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes expresses his surprise that members of the boule have been proposing putting before the Athenians the alternative of fighting Philip or observing the peace. 
He observes that if Philip keeps quiet, does not retain any Athenian possessions contrary to the terms of the peace, and does not form a coaltition against Athens, they will have no alternative but to adhere to the peace. 
He goes on to say that if the oath the Athenians took, and the terms of the peace are published, and if it can be proved that Philip has unfairly taken much that belongs to Athens (before Diopeithes was sent to the Chersonese) then the Athenians will have no alternative but to go to war. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristotle
title: Athenaion Politeia
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a reference to the temporary constitution of the 400. The council was to appoint the officials and draw up the oath which they were to swear [the statement was presumably to act in the interest of the city (cf. oath id 1779)], but this never actually took place.  What is said about the drafting of the oath is ambiguous. Were the 400 to draw up an oath for the magistrates, or an oath for themselves?  (Or indeed for the magistrates including themselves?). On this ambiguity, see Gomme, Andrewes and Dover on Thucydides Book VIII (pp. 228-9).

author: Hesiod
title: Theogony
statement: n/a
remarks: Here, Hesiod explains how Zeus made Styx (the river) "the great oath of the gods", i.e. she became the deity to be invoked in oaths made by gods; cf. oath ids 350 and 409. By 'oath' (horkos) is here meant 'the divinity to be invoked when swearing'. The circumstances for taking this oath are defined, not by the content of what was being asserted, but by the identity of the swearer (a divinity) and the perceived need for special solemnity. West comments ad loc.: "Styx is to the gods much as Horkos is to men… A god takes an oath by Styx, not merely mentioning her name, but by making a libation of water… This constitutes an effective curse on the perjurer". Cf. also oath ids 1289 and 1295.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes warns the jurors not to let Aeschines mix up the transgressions of the generals, the war against Philip, and the benefits of peace, but to consider each item separately. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Lysias
title: Against the corn-dealers
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker reminds the jurors that they have sworn to decide according to the laws (κατὰ τοὺς νόμους ὀμωμόκατε ψηφιεῖσθαι·). 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Demosthenes
title: For the Megalopolitans
swearer: Representatives of the Greeks except the Spartans
swearee: Representatives of the Greeks except the Spartans
remarks:
The exact oath statement is unknown. 
Demosthenes reminds the Athenians that they are bound to help the Messenians because of the oaths they swore to them, and because of the advantages they will derive from preserving Messenia. 
This is presumably a reference to the common peace treaty made after the battle of Mantinea in 362. For the details of this treaty see Diodorus 15.89.1-2, Plutarch, Agesilaus 35, Polybius 4.33.8-9. See also Ryder, Koine Eirene, Appendix VIII, pp140-144.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he does not find fault with those who eagerly help their fatherland in wars]
 ἢ καὶ τοὺς ἐν τοῖς πολέμοις ταῖς πατρίσι προθύμως βοηθοῦντας μέμφῃ; Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγ’
remarks: Hippias has argued that laws and obedience to law cannot be very important things because laws are often changed and repealed, sometimes by the very men who made them in the first place; Socrates has pointed out that by parity of reasoning he should then hold that discipline and courage in war are trivial matters because many states begin wars and then subsequently make peace.

author: Deinarchus
title: Against Demosthenes
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
impact: Emphasises his own admiration of beauty
statement:
[That if he really is handsome and that they feel the same towards him as he does towards those he finds handsome, then he would not give up his looks even if he were offered the whole Persian empire in exchange]
 εἰ δ’ εἰμί τε τῷ ὄντι καλὸς καὶ ὑμεῖς τὰ αὐτὰ πρὸς ἐμὲ πάσχετε οἷάπερ ἐγὼ πρὸς τὸν ἐμοὶ δοκοῦντα καλὸν εἶναι, ὄμνυμι πάντας θεοὺς μὴ ἑλέσθαι ἂν τὴν βασιλέως ἀρχὴν ἀντὶ τοῦ καλὸς εἶναι.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That farming is the easiest of all occupations to learn]
  ὑπέθου γὰρ τὴν γεωργικὴν τέχνην πασῶν εἶναι εὐμαθεστάτην, καὶ νῦν ἐγὼ ἐκ πάντων ὧν εἴρηκας τοῦθ’ οὕτως ἔχειν παντάπασιν ὑπὸ σοῦ ἀναπέπεισμαι. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Aeschines mentions the alliance between Athens and Chalcis (341/0) and the one between Athens and Thebes (339/8) and says that he will refer to both later. 
See also oath id 2673, 3391.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
In this section Andocides stresses that the proposed peace would allow the Athenians to build new walls, as many ships as they wish and they would be allowed to keep possession of Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros. 
He argues that the peace will mean safety and power for the democracy, whereas war will lead to the overthrow of the demos. 
The peace was rejected by the Athenians, Corinthians and Argives. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393, 2404, 2405, 2407, 2408, 2420, 2422, 2423, 2429, 2430, 2432, 2433, 3206.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That (he thinks) Strepsiades is stupid]
 ἀμαθής γε νὴ Δί’

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That the oracle speaks good]
  Πῶς δῆτά φησ’ ὁ χρησμός; 
  {ΔΗ. }  Εὖ νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Androtion
statement:
[That they will not presently provide information against Androtion concerning the law which forbids him to speak or propose motions because his father owed money to the demos]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐχὶ νῦν
remarks: Diodorus is answering the suggestion that if he and Euctemon really believe that Androtion is under atimia because of his father’s unpaid debts to the state, they ought to proceed against him by endeixis.  He replies that they will do this in due course, but that there is no reason why they should not now point out, when prosecuting him for moving an illegal decree, that he actually has no right to move even a legal one.

author: Alexis
title: Mandragorizomene
statement:
[That the addressee is a tiny sparrow (i.e. very thin)]
 στρουθὶς ἀκαρὴς νὴ Δί’ εἶ·

author: Homer
title: Iliad
statement:
[That he will not wash until he burns the body of Patroclus and buries him and cuts hair for him]
 αὐτὰρ ὅ γ’ ἠρνεῖτο στερεῶς, ἐπὶ δ’ ὅρκον ὄμοσσεν·
οὐ μὰ Ζῆν’, ὅς τίς τε θεῶν ὕπατος καὶ ἄριστος, 
οὐ θέμις ἐστὶ λοετρὰ καρήατος ἆσσον ἱκέσθαι 
πρίν γ’ ἐνὶ Πάτροκλον θέμεναι πυρὶ σῆμά τε χεῦαι 
κείρασθαί τε κόμην, ἐπεὶ οὔ μ’ ἔτι δεύτερον ὧδε 
ἵξετ’ ἄχος κραδίην ὄφρα ζωοῖσι μετείω.
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)loftiest, most noble of the gods
remarks: Achilles is the only person in the Iliad to use the oath formula "ma"; cf. also oath ids 311 and 312. Achilles is the only person in the Iliad to volunteer an oath solely for emphasis (here and at id 312). See also Aeschines 1.145 (oath id 2596).

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That he knows that Menexenus is very fond of dispute]
 ἢ οὐκ οἶσθα ὅτι ἐριστικός ἐστιν; Ναὶ μὰ Δία, ἔφη, σφόδρα γε·

title: Pouilloux, Recherches
statement: [? That they did not knowingly commit an offence]
remarks:
This decree indicates that in cases involving the adulterating of wine neither citizens nor aliens could plead ignorance under oath.  
This indicates that under other circumstances one could plead one's innocence by swearing an oath that one did not knowingly commit an offence.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 2
statement:
[That he does not think it is safe to live in the same house with Boeotus and Pamphilus]
οὔτε μὰ τὸν Δία ἀσφαλὲς εἶναί μοι νομίζω συζῆν τούτοις ἐν τῷ αὐτῷ·
remarks: Mantitheus reminds the jury that Boeotus has charged him with malicious wounding in an attempt to get him exiled, and asks them, in view of that, "what do you think they would shrink from, in terms of poisoning or other kinds of criminality?".

author: Plato
title: Euthydemus
statement:
[That he and Euthydemus know how to do cobbling (as well as how to stitch leather)]
 Ἦ καὶ νευρορραφεῖν δυνατώ ἐστον;  Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία καττύειν, ἔφη.
remarks: Having asserted that if one knows something, and has knowledge, then one must know everything, Dionysodorus and Euthydemus are being led into more and more implausible statements by the fear of self-contradiction. Cf. oath id 3099.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
The Athenian envoy to Sparta argues that the exclusion of Megarians from the Athenian empire does not violate the treaty.  
He also states that the Spartan expulsion of foreigners does not violate the treaty. 
In order to avoid a war (and the resulting breach of the treaty) the Athenian envoy suggests that the Athenians and Spartans could agree to stop both practices.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Euripides
title: Andromache
statement:
[That Andromache would not have enjoyed their bed and lived to see the light of day]
 μὰ τὴν ἄνασσαν, οὐκ ἂν ἔν γ’ ἐμοῖς δόμοις
  βλέπουσ’ ἂν αὐγὰς τἄμ’ ἐκαρποῦτ’ ἂν λέχη.
remarks: Hermione is explaining to Orestes how bad women filled her with vanity with such words, causing her angry victimization of Andromache. This is part of her rhetoric in persuading Orestes to rescue her (and we remember that Orestes is a potential husband for Hermione, who might himself have expected to enjoy a concubine).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That their pay doesn't even come to one tenth of the revenue]
 οὐδ’ ἡ δεκάτη τῶν προσιόντων ἡμῖν ἄρ’ ἐγίγνεθ’ ὁ μισθός. 
 {Βδ.}  μὰ Δί’ οὐ μέντοι.

author: Plato
title: Laws
impact: Assistance assured for both parties in case of trouble
consequences_of_breach: The people might attack the monarchy
statement: [That he would rule according to the established nomoi; and that he would come to the aid of the king(s) and people of any of the three states swearing the oath (Sparta, Argos, Messene) if the king(s) wronged the people or vice versa]
remarks: The Athenian here blames the kings of Argos, Messene and Sparta for ultimately bringing ruin on themselves because they were not in agreement about their oath (see oath ids 2678-83).

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That the old woman is expecting "Shagathon"]
 οὐ τὸν Σεβῖνον, ὃν σὺ προσδοκᾷς ἴσως.  
 {Γρ. α}  νὴ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην
remarks: The speaker’s point  is “Yes, I was expecting Shagathon, and you’re him!”. On the punned name translated here as "Shagathon", see Sommerstein ad 980.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: Nicias was able to verify that Demosthenes had surrendered
statement:
[That Nicias could send a horseman and find out what had happened to Demosthenes' forces] 
 ὁ δ’ ἀπιστῶν σπένδεται ἱππέα πέμψαι σκεψόμενον
remarks: Nicias did not believe the Syracusans when they told him that Demosthenes had surrendered, so he obtained a truce so that he might send a horseman and find out.  On learning that the statement was true, he proposed terms for peace (Athens to pay the whole cost of the war, and hostages to be given pending payment), but these were rejected.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the Spartans shall not get Pylos]
 Μὰ τὸν Ποσειδῶ τοῦτο μέν γ’ οὐ δράσετε.

author: Demosthenes
title: Olynthiac 3
statement:
[That he should not wonder if he got rougher treatment from the Athenians for pointing out the faults of these men (the politicians who keep the demos subservient with financial handouts) than the men who are responsible for them]
 ταῦτα μὰ τὴν Δήμητρ’ οὐκ ἂν θαυμάσαιμ’ εἰ μείζων εἰπόντι ἐμοὶ γένοιτο παρ’ ὑμῶν βλάβη τῶν πεποιηκότων αὐτὰ γενέσθαι·

author: Anonymus Iambicus
title: Fragment
statement: unknown
remarks: This fragment contains someone swearing a negation, but nothing further can be deduced. Gerber notes (ad Hipponax fr. 155b) that the figure Kadmilos "is often identified with Hermes and associated with the mysteries at Samothrace".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that Perdiccas sent a herald to the Athenian generals and made an agreement with them. He later adds the detail that Perdiccas had made an alliance with the Athenians. 
For other references to alliances between Athens and Perdiccas see oath id 256.  
See also oath id 1545 and 1751.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
statement:
[That Pasion got more profit from the money and for that reason he sided more with Cephisiades than with Callippus]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία, ἴσως ἂν εἴποι, κερδαίνων τι ἰδίᾳ ὁ πατὴρ ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀργυρίου ἐκείνῳ μᾶλλον προσετίθετο τὴν γνώμην ἢ τούτῳ.
remarks:
Apollodorus argues that because Callippus was a citizen capable of doing either harm or good, and Cephisiades was a powerless metic, Pasion would not have sided with Cephisiades contrary to justice. 
He imagines that Callippus will respond in this way.

author: Isocrates
title: Antidosis
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Isocrates urges his 'audience' to examine each point thoroughly and search for the truth, remembering their oaths and the laws under which they have come together to dispense justice. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides stresses that the peace will guarantee the autonomy of Athens and thus allow them to build more triremes and repair the ones they already possess. He also stresses that the Athenians do not need to fight to recover Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros, because these islands are explicitly said to be Athenian in the terms of the peace. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
date: When Lamprocles was a young man (405 to 399)
statement:
[That there are some people he thinks he should please]
 ἢ παρεσκεύασαι μηδενὶ ἀνθρώπων πειρᾶσθαι ἀρέσκειν μηδὲ πείθεσθαι μήτε στρατηγῷ μήτε ἄλλῳ ἄρχοντι; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’ ἔγωγε, ἔφη
remarks: Cf. remarks on oath id 2054.

author: Plato
title: Republic
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Helios; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: This is a reference to the oaths of truce sworn between the Greeks and the Trojans as recounted in Homer (see oath id 316 with further references). In the Republic, the fact that the violation is presented as being brought about by Athena and Zeus makes the story unacceptable material for the members of the ideal state.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That Theodote can adapt the efficiency of hounds for catching hares to her own needs of snaring rich men]
 Τίνι οὖν, ἔφη, τοιούτῳ φίλους ἂν ἐγὼ θηρῴην; Ἐὰν νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ἀντὶ κυνὸς κτήσῃ, ὅστις σοι ἰχνεύων μὲν τοὺς φιλοκάλους καὶ πλουσίους εὑρήσει, εὑρὼν δὲ μηχανήσεται ὅπως ἐμβάλῃ  αὐτοὺς εἰς τὰ σὰ δίκτυα.
remarks: Cf oath id 2107.

author: Sophocles
title: Assembly of the Achaeans
statement: see remarks
remarks: The verb used "ξυνώμοσεν" (lit. "swore together") may suggest an oath sworn by a group of Achaeans. It may possibly refer to the oath sworn by Helen's suitors to join forces to retrieve her should she ever be abducted. This oath is mentioned very frequently in tragedies which deal with aspects of the Trojan war (see e.g. Ajax, Philoctetes, Iphigenia Aulidensis). In 'Sophocles: Selected Fragmentary Plays I' Sommerstein argues that this is indeed the oath of Helen's suitors and that the object of using for the roll-call the list of those who swore that oath is to avoid naming Achilles as a defaulter if, as expected, he failed to turn up. Such a public shaming of Achilles would almost certainly have provoked Achilles into quitting the expedition, especially seeing that he is not bound to it by oath.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: According to Thucydides, an embassy from Elis concluded an alliance with Corinth.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Euboulides
if_taken: Their statement will carry more weight
statement: [That Euxitheus' mother Nicarete was an Athenian]
remarks:
Euxitheus tells the jurors to cast their votes for justice if he proves that his mother's relatives are the sort of people that free men should be, and they deny under oath "the slanders cast upon her", and they testify that she is an Athenian (aste). 
Euxitheus then calls Damostratus (his mother's nephew), and Apollodorus (the grandson of his grandmother's sister) to testify that his mother Nicarete was an Athenian (see oath id 3702).

author: Lysias
title: Against Simon
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had not wounded with the intent to kill]
remarks: The defendant reiterates that witnesses have corroborated his version of the events (see oath id 2812) - that he did not fight against Simon and his colleagues, but simply grabbed hold of Theodotus, whereas they continued dragging him off by force and began beating him up as well.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the headpiece is excellent]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἄριστ’ ἔχει.  (260)
remarks: See also oath id 708 for context.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker asks the jurors how they will be able to climb the Acropolis on the first of each month and pray for blessings on the state and on themselves, when the defendant and his father are registered there (as state debtors), and if they acquit Aristogeiton and thus give their verdict against their oaths and the documents preserved there. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Hermippus
title: Unidentified Drama
statement:
[That a good man should not get drunk nor use hot baths]
 μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ μέντοι μεθύειν τὸν ἄνδρα χρὴ 
τὸν ἀγαθὸν οὐδὲ θερμολουτεῖν, ἃ σὺ ποιεῖς
remarks: The speaker is probably an old man; cf. Aristophanes' Clouds 1045-6.

author: Plato
title: Meno
statement:
[That it is probably not true that Themistocles chose not to educate his son in the kind of wisdom in which he himself was wise]
  Ἆρ’ οὖν ταῦτα μὲν οἰόμεθα βούλεσθαι αὐτὸν τὸν αὑτοῦ ὑὸν παιδεῦσαι, ἣν δὲ αὐτὸς σοφίαν ἦν σοφός, οὐδὲν τῶν γειτόνων βελτίω ποιῆσαι, εἴπερ ἦν γε διδακτὸν ἡ ἀρετή;  {ΑΝ.} Ἴσως μὰ Δί’ οὔ.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
statement:
[That he would not kiss Megabates even if he were to become the fairest, strongest and swiftest man]
 Οὐ τὼ σιώ, οὐδ’ εἰ μέλλοιμί γε αὐτίκα μάλα κάλλιστός τε καὶ ἰσχυρότατος καὶ τάχιστος ἀνθρώπων ἔσεσθαι·
gods_invoked: The twin gods i.e. Castor and Pollux
remarks:
According to Xenophon, Agesilaus loved Megabates the son of Spithridates, yet when Megabates tried to kiss Agesilaus (as Persians do to those they honour), he resisted. 
Megabates felt slighted, and ceased to try to kiss Agesilaus. 
When Agesilaus approached one of Megabates' companions to ask whether he could persuade Megabates to show him honour once again, the companion asked whether Agesilaus would kiss Megabates if he yielded. This oath is Agesilaus' response. 
Agesilaus then goes on to swear by all the gods that he would rather fight the same battle over again than that everything I see should turn into gold (see oath id 2308). 
Roughly, Agesilaus says, "I wouldn't kiss him for all the tea in China; but I'd sooner have the chance to fight him off again, like I did before, than have all the gold in Peru!" i.e. in other words: "I fancy him rotten, but I don't kiss boys in public".

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That he has seen clouds shaped like animals]  
 ἤδη ποτ’ ἀναβλέψας εἶδες νεφέλην κενταύρῳ ὁμοίαν
  ἢ παρδάλει ἢ λύκῳ ἢ ταύρῳ;
 {Στ.}  νὴ Δί’ ἔγωγ’.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and would not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the same party at Argos which had brought about the peace treaty with Sparta then brought about the renunciation of the alliance with the Mantineans, Eleans and Athenians. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 251.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That he teaches loyalty by rewarding his foreman whenever the gods grant abundance of some good thing]
 Εὐεργετῶν νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Ἰσχόμαχος, ὅταν τινὸς ἀγαθοῦ οἱ θεοὶ ἀφθονίαν διδῶσιν ἡμῖν.

author: Hypereides
title: Against Demosthenes
swearer: Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and the alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace (?) and would neither break the agreement with Philip (?) nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?) neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they themselves do anything contrary to these agreements, nor would they allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone does commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?) and they would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?) as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon...]
remarks:
Hypereides observes that they made peace (in 338/7) "on behalf of them". It is not clear to whom he is referring. 
For other references to the so-called League of Corinth see also oath id 479.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he has seen Socrates with his bare shoulder pressing against Critobulus' bare shoulder when the two were reading]
 Ἀλλὰ τί δή ποτε, ὦ Σώκρατες, ἡμᾶς μὲν οὕτω τοὺς φίλους μορμολύττῃ ἀπὸ τῶν καλῶν, αὐτὸν δέ σε, ἔφη, ἐγὼ εἶδον ναὶ μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω, ὅτε παρὰ τῷ γραμματιστῇ ἐν τῷ αὐτῷ βιβλίῳ ἀμφότεροι ἐμαστεύετέ τι, τὴν κεφαλὴν πρὸς τῇ κεφαλῇ καὶ τὸν ὦμον γυμνὸν πρὸς γυμνῷ τῷ Κριτοβούλου ὤμῳ ἔχοντα.
remarks: This is a response to Socrates saying that one must refrain from kissing those in their bloom of beauty if one wishes to possess the power of self-control.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: Leaders of the men of Phyle; Leaders of their supporters from the Piraeus
swearee: Leaders of the men of the city
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The men of the city were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the men of the city while they collected their dead]
remarks: Xenophon states that the victorious men of Phyle and their supporters from the Piraeus (i.e. the democrats) took the arms of those of the men from the city (i.e. the supporters of the Thirty) who had been killed but did not take their chitons. These included Critias and Hippomachus. After taking their arms they gave up the dead under a truce.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That those who have no knowledge of truth are not much better off than those who are physically blind]
 Ἦ οὖν δοκοῦσί τι τυφλῶν διαφέρειν οἱ τῷ ὄντι τοῦ ὄντος ἑκάστου ἐστερημένοι τῆς γνώσεως, καὶ μηδὲν ἐναργὲς ἐν τῇ ψυχῇ ἔχοντες παράδειγμα, μηδὲ δυνάμενοι ὥσπερ γραφῆς εἰς τὸ ἀληθέστατον ἀποβλέποντες κἀκεῖσε ἀεὶ ἀναφέροντές τε καὶ θεώμενοι ὡς οἷόν τε ἀκριβέστατα, οὕτω δὴ καὶ τὰ ἐνθάδε νόμιμα καλῶν τε πέρι καὶ δικαίων καὶ ἀγαθῶν τίθεσθαί τε, ἐὰν δέῃ τίθεσθαι, καὶ τὰ κείμενα φυλάττοντες σῴζειν; Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὐ πολύ τι διαφέρει.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: Highlights' Chremylus' indignation at the suggestion
statement:
[That he's not trying to make a pass at the Old Woman]
 Μὰ τὴν Ἑκάτην, οὐ δῆτα·
remarks: Here Chremylus agrees with the Old Woman's oath at id 907. Swearing by Hecate is a common oath for women (cf. oath id 890) but can also be used by men, as here.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Euthycles tells the jurors that no man could possibly do them so much service that for his sake they ought to vote against justice and break their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: None- the statement is not believed
statement:
[That she really is pregnant]
 Καὶ κυῶ γε νὴ Δία.

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
remarks:
Isocrates observes that the Athenians and Spartans both made peace with the Persians in the years that followed Xerxes' invasion.  
For the so-called Peace of Callias cf. Lycurgus, Against Leocrates 73; Diodorus 12.4.4-6, Demosthenes. 19.273. 
See also oath id 3813.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That Cyrus seems to excel even more in kindness than in generalship (although Gobryas had thought him the greatest general)]
 νῦν δὲ θεοὺς ὄμνυμι ἦ μὴν ἐμοὶ δοκεῖν πλέον σε διαφέρειν φιλανθρωπίᾳ ἢ στρατηγίᾳ.

author: Pindar
title: Olympian 13
impact: Validates Pindar's praise of the Oligaithidai
statement:
[That the number of victories for Xenophon's family in the Isthmian and Nemean games comes to 60]
 Ἰσθμοῖ τά τ’ ἐν Νεμέᾳ παύρῳ ἔπει
  θήσω φανέρ’ ἀθρό’, ἀλαθής τέ μοι  
ἔξορκος ἐπέσσεται ἑξηκοντάκι δὴ ἀμφοτέρωθεν
ἁδύγλωσσος βοὰ κάρυκος ἐ<σλ>οῦ.
remarks: The voice of the herald mentioned here is equivalent to Pindar himself swearing (cf. oath ids 1312, 1313, 1315, 1319, 1321).

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_refused: War will continue as it is
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: Hera here asks Zeus to send Athena to cause the Trojans to break the truce. This is the same oath as id 318. Aristotle discusses the reasons for Athena approaching Pandarus (a Trojan ally) rather than the Trojans themselves at oath id 2002.

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
impact: Helps to convince Philoctetes to go back to Troy
statement:
[That Philoctetes is ailing by divine fortune because he approached the snake guardian of Chryse, and that he will never be free from the affliction until he goes willingly to the plains of Troy with the bow and joins Neoptolemus in capturing and sacking the city]
 ὅμως δὲ λέξω· Ζῆνα δ’ ὅρκιον καλῶ·
καὶ ταῦτ’ ἐπίστω, καὶ γράφου φρενῶν ἔσω. 
σὺ γὰρ νοσεῖς τόδ’ ἄλγος ἐκ θείας τύχης,
Χρύσης πελασθεὶς φύλακος, ὃς τὸν ἀκαλυφῆ
σηκὸν φυλάσσει κρύφιος οἰκουρῶν ὄφις·
καὶ παῦλαν ἴσθι τῆσδε μή ποτ’ ἂν τυχεῖν
νόσου βαρείας, ἕως ἂν αὑτὸς ἥλιος 
ταύτῃ μὲν αἴρῃ, τῇδε δ’ αὖ δύνῃ πάλιν,
πρὶν ἂν τὰ Τροίας πεδί’ ἑκὼν αὐτὸς μόλῃς,
καὶ τῶν παρ’ ἡμῖν ἐντυχὼν ᾿Ασκληπιδῶν  νόσου μαλαχθῇς τῆσδε, καὶ τὰ πέργαμα
ξὺν τοῖσδε τόξοις ξύν τ’ ἐμοὶ πέρσας φανῇς.
remarks: Neoptolemus also swears by Zeus at oath id 286.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_taken: The Epidaurians would be deemed not to owe anything
if_refused: The Epidaurians would be required to pay their debt
statement: [? That they did not owe anything to the sanctuary]
remarks:
Thucydides notes that one of the terms of the peace treaty between Argos and Sparta (see oath id 1746) included a clause regarding the offering to Apollo Pythaeus.  
Thucydides states at 5.53 that the Epidaurians were obliged to send a sacrifice to the Argive-controlled sanctuary of Apollo Pythaeus as payment for pasturage. The Argives accused the Epidaurians of not doing so, and war broke out.  
Thucydides adds that the Argives did so on the advice of Alcibiades. Both parties hoped to bring Epidaurus into the "Argive alliance" in order to keep Corinth quiet, and to reduce the time it would take to bring aid to Argos from Athens by sea.  
The clause in the treaty between Sparta and Argos stipulated that the Argives "if they wished, might tender an oath to the Epidaurians, or, if not, should swear one themselves".  This appears to mean that the dispute over the offering should be settled by the procedure of oath-challenge, with the Argives having the right to choose whether to demand an oath from the Epidaurians (presumably to the effect that they did not owe anything to the sanctuary) or to swear one themselves (presumably to the contrary effect); the side refusing to swear would be deemed to have accepted that it was in the wrong. 
See also oath id 1760.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That he doesn't think Socrates is talking nonsense]
 ἢ οὐδέν σοι δοκῶ λέγειν, ἀλλὰ λανθάνω καὶ ἐμαυτὸν οἰόμενός τινος ὥσπερ ἴχνους ἐφάπτεσθαι τῆς Ὁμήρου δόξης περὶ ὀνομάτων ὀρθότητος;  {ΕΡΜ.} Μὰ Δί’ οὐ σύ γε
remarks: Socrates has argued that Homer thought that "Hector" and "Astyanax" were names highly appropriate to their bearers.  (But his argument is based on a premise that Plato, and many of his readers, must know to be false:  Socrates has said, 392c-d, that it was the women who called Hector's son Scamandrius rather than Astyanax, whereas in Iliad 6.402 we are told it was Hector himself who used the name Scamandrius, and the only woman to mention the boy by name - his mother, in 22.500, 506 - names him as Astyanax!

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
statement:
[That in the case of a city which is expected to stand alone against an attempt to dominate Greece, its worth is not to be assessed by the quality of its market goods but by such tests as the reliability of its allies and the strength of its armaments]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ ἐκ τῶν ὠνίων

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
date: First half of the sixth century (599 to 550)
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that an official is to cut and swear an oath before the basileis ([- - -]ων  ὅρκια ἐπιταμνέτω Ϟὠ[μνύτω ἐν τοῖς β]ασιλεῦσιν). 'Cut' has either the same meaning as Iliad 3.292, or else is a metaphor based on the procedure there described.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That he is prosecuting his fellow ambassadors because he has no alternative]
 νὴ Δί’, εἴτε βούλομαί γ’ εἴτε μή,
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that Aeschines is going about asking people what they think of Demosthenes, who is prosecuting his fellow ambassadors. 
Demosthenes counters that he is, and argues that he is doing so because he was the victim of Aeschines' plots throughout the journey, and now has the choice either to be considered the partner in [their] dishonest actions, or to prosecute.

author: Isocrates
title: Busiris
date: At the time of writing ca. 390-385 (390 to 385)
statement: n/a
remarks: Isocrates observes that oaths taken in Egyptian sanctuaries are more to be trusted than those in use in other countries, and that each Egyptian believes that he will pay the penalty for his misdeeds immediately, and that he will neither escape detection at the present time, nor will the punishment be deferred to his children's time.

title: IG I(3)
statement: [? That they would safeguard the honorands from harm]
remarks:
This text is a fragmentary decree conferring the title of proxenus on a certain Crison, and several others who are thought to be Macedonian. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in Athenian Agora 16.11.

author: Aristophanes
title: Babylonians
statement: unknown
remarks: This single word referring to the taking of an oath (horkwmotein) may have been a reference to a specific oath, or to a more general discussion.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
remarks: The oath here serves to reinforce the previous speaker's words.

author: Gorgias
title: Defence of Palamedes
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a discussion concerning whether or not Palamedes is guilty of treason. The question is raised of a pledge between the Trojans and Palamedes, but it is suggested that no Trojans would have accepted the oath of Palamedes, a traitor. The argument develops thus: a pledge or oath between Palamedes and the Trojans would prove his treason, but if he is a traitor there would be no such oath, as the oath of a traitor would not be trusted by the Trojans. For oaths in the context of Palamedes, cf. oath id 1607.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearee: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
[That they would proceed as they would through a friendly country, doing no damage and taking no food and drink from the land unless the Persians did not provide them with a market, and if they did provide a market to obtain provisions by purchase]
remarks:
Book 4 begins with a summary of the previous book. Xenophon mentions the treaty between the Greeks and the Persians, and the warfare after Tissaphernes broke the truce. 
See also oath id 2098.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes reminds the jurors that he is not blaming Aeschines for the fact that peace was made, but because he created false expectations at Athens about the peace. He repeats his argument that Aeschines was bribed, and thus destroyed Halus, the Phocians, Doriscus, Cersobleptes, Hieron Oros and Thermopylae. He also argues that Aeschines opened up for Philip a path all the way to Attica through allies and friends, put Coronea, Orchomenus and Euboea into the hands of others and made the Thebans strong. 
He repeats his claim that he is not blaming Aeschines for the fact that Athens made peace, and calls on Aeschines to prove that the peace is not disgraceful and reprehensible. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Euripides
title: Hippolytos Kalyptomenos
if_broken: He will suffer whatever he specifies in the next line [unknown]
impact: Hippolytus is sworn to silence and unable to defend himself by revealing the truth
statement: [That he will not inform against Phaedra]
remarks: This oath has been reconstructed from the implication of fr. 435 where it seems most probable that Phaedra asks Hippolytus what he should suffer if he informs against her (i.e. if he breaks his oath). See Barrett p. 19 who cites three parallels. On the dating of the play, see Talboy & Sommerstein, in Sommerstein et al. ed. Sophocles: Selected Fragmentary Plays I (Oxford, 2006) 266-272, who argue for a date of 436-433 and give references to other recent discussions.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he thinks that Cyrus loves valiant men no less than he loves himself]
 ἀλλὰ σὺν θεῶν ὅρκῳ λέγω ἦ μὴν ἐμοὶ δοκεῖ Κῦρος οὕστινας ἂν ὁρᾷ ἀγαθοὺς φιλεῖν οὐδὲν ἧττον ἑαυτοῦ·

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That Strepsiades swore to repay what the First Creditor lent him]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἀποδώσειν γ’ ἐπώμνυς τοὺς θεούς

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearer: Envoys; Envoys from the other Boeotian poleis
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
The Boeotians swore to abide by the terms of the peace after the other Greeks. 
At the time when the other envoys swore the oath, the Theban envoys claimed the right to swear on behalf of all the Boeotians. 
Agesilaus refused to accept the oaths unless they swore just as the King's letter directed: that every city - i.e. including all the Boeotian cities - whether small or great should be independent. 
When the Theban envoys refused, Agesilaus told them to go home and report to the people that they would be shut out of the treaty. 
Agesilaus then prepared a force to lead against Thebes and marched out to Tegea. But before he left Tegea the Theban envoys returned with word that the Thebans would leave the other Boeotian cities independent. Agesilaus then returned home and the Thebans were forced to accede to the treaty. 
For the other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
statement:
[That he calls some things good even if they are not beneficial to men]
 Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, κἂν μὴ τοῖς ἀνθρώποις ὠφέλιμα ᾖ, ἔγωγε καλῶ ἀγαθά

author: Euripides
title: Medea
statement:
[That Jason wishes to help Medea and the children in any way]
 Ια. ἀλλ’ οὖν ἐγὼ μὲν δαίμονας μαρτύρομαι
  ὡς πάνθ’ ὑπουργεῖν σοί τε καὶ τέκνοις θέλω·
remarks: Jason's understanding of 'willing to do anything to help' is clearly at odds with Medea's view, but this does not make his oath untrue. Jason only invokes the gods in general (daimones) to witness, rather than specific deities in this play. See also oath id 123.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Apaturius
statement:
[That some witness will testify against him on Apaturius' behalf]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία (τὸ ῥᾷστον τοῖς ἀδικεῖν καὶ συκοφαντεῖν προῃρημένοις) μαρτυρήσει τις αὐτῷκατ’ ἐμοῦ.

title: SEG
if_taken: They will be eligible to act as scrutineers
if_refused: They will not be eligible to act as scrutineers
statement:
[That they would discharge the office of scrutineer for which they had been chosen by lot in accordance with the decrees establishing (?) the office]
 εὐθυνῶ τὴν ἀρχὴν ἣν ἔλαχ[ον εὐθύν]εν κατὰ τὰ ψηφίσματα ἐφ’ οἷς ἐ[γκαθέστ]η̣κ̣εν ἡ ἀρχή
remarks:
The text indicates that in the month of Skirophorion an "oath-victim" (ὁρκωμόσιον) was to be provided for the scrutinies.The text indicates that the scrutineers and assessors swore the same oath. The oath was to be inscribed on a stele and set up beside the [Delphin]ion.  
For a reference to the oath victim during the month of Metageitnion, see oath 548.

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
The text indicates that if someone seizes a slave or a free man with whom he is in legal dispute before the trial, he is to pay a fine each day until he releases him. The judge is to decide "on oath" (ὀμνύντα) as to the time involved.  
See also oath id 1115.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans, and follow the Spartans whithersoever they may lead]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Sparta at the start of the war in 431 as all of the Peloponnesians within the Isthmus except for Argos and Achaea (Pellene was the only Achaean city allied to Sparta), Megara, the Locrians (the Opuntian and Epicnemidian), the Boeotians, Phocians, the Ambraciots, the Leucadians and Anactorians. 
de Ste Croix, Origins of the Peloponnesian War, pp123-4, speculates that the Locrians joined the Peloponnesian League between 446 and 431. The former date is speculative. 
For other references to the so-called Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Plato
title: Charmides
statement:
[That he too finds it strange that they were wrong to agree that it would be very good for mankind if each person was to confine his activities to matters he knew about, and leave the matters he didn’t know about to be dealt with by those who did know about them]
  Ὅτι, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, ῥᾳδίως ὡμολογήσαμεν μέγα τι ἀγαθὸν εἶναι τοῖς ἀνθρώποις εἰ ἕκαστοι ἡμῶν, ἃ μὲν ἴσασιν, πράττοιεν ταῦτα, ἃ δὲ μὴ ἐπίσταιντο, ἄλλοις παραδιδοῖεν τοῖς ἐπισταμένοις. Οὐκ οὖν, ἔφη, καλῶς ὡμολογήσαμεν;  Οὔ μοι δοκοῦμεν, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ.  Ἄτοπα λέγεις ὡς ἀληθῶς, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες.  Νὴ τὸν κύνα, ἔφην, καὶ ἐμοί τοι δοκεῖ οὕτω
remarks: Swearing by the "dog" is typical of Socrates. Cf. oath id 2548 with cross references.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he is not bad]
 ἐγὼ πονηρός; οὐ μὰ Δί’
remarks: Sommerstein remarks ad 193: "Bdelycleon meant that Philocleon was wicked; but Philocleon, still pretending to be Odysseus escaping from the man-eating Cyclops, affects to understand his "bad" as meaning "bad to eat" and indignantly defends his foodworthiness."

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That Meidias has incurred a fine large enough to deprive him of all his property]
 μεγάλην νὴ Δί’ ὦφλε δίκην καὶ τοσαύτην ὥστ’ ἀποστερεῖσθαι τῶν ὄντων.
remarks:
Demosthenes describes how Meidias contrived to have Straton of Phalerum deprived of his citizen rights, and asks the jurors what losses Meidias would have had to suffer in order to be driven to such lengths.  
He imagines that someone will respond that Meidias lost all his property, and answers that Meidias lost only one thousand drachmas.

author: Telecleides
title: Unidentified Drama
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos)could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
Telecleides says that the Athenians had handed over to Pericles the power over truce and peace. This is probably a reference to the Thirty Years' Peace of 446/5. The mention of building walls is probably a reference to building the middle wall, with the abandonment of the Phaleric. This passage probably dates before the Samian war of 440, since there is no reference to war, only to peace.  
For other references to the thirty years' peace see oath id 1524.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he thinks the tyrant’s paid bodyguards, of whom Adeimantus is speaking, will be foreign ‘drones’ coming from far and wide]
 Κηφῆνας, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, νὴ τὸν κύνα, δοκεῖς αὖ τινάς μοι  λέγειν ξενικούς τε καὶ παντοδαπούς.
remarks: Swearing "by the dog" is a common habit only of Socrates (see oath id 2548 with cross references), though other characters do occasionally use this oath formula- see oath id 1058 from Aristophanes' Wasps.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he had neither received anything from Seuthes that was intended for the soldiers, nor asked to have for his private use anything that belonged to them, nor demanded from Seuthes what he had promised]
 καίτοι αὐτόν σε μάρτυρα σὺν θεοῖς εἰδόσι ποιοῦμαι ὅτι οὔτε ἔχω παρὰ σοῦ ἐπὶ τοῖς στρατιώταις οὐδὲν οὔτε ᾔτησα πώποτε εἰς τὸ ἴδιον τὰ ἐκείνων οὔτε ἃ ὑπέσχου μοι ἀπῄτησα·
remarks:
Xenophon says to Seuthes, "I make you my witness, along with the gods who know, that I have neither received anything from you that was intended for the soldiers, nor asked to have for my private use anything that belonged to them, nor demanded from you what you had promised me". 
See also oath id 2216.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the Inlaw will not escape unpunished for what he has said]
  Οὔ τοι μὰ τὼ θεὼ σὺ καταπροίξει λέγουσα ταυτί
remarks: Mica's statement relates to the Inlaw's suggestion that she passed off a slave-girl's child as her own. The "two goddesses" are Persephone and Demeter; cf. oath id 713.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes
swearee: Pleistoanax; Agis; Pleistolas; Damagetus; Chionis; Metagenes; Acanthus; Daithus; Ischagoras; Philocharidas; Zeuxidas; Antippus; Tellis; Alcinadas; Empedias; Menas; Laphilus; Lampon; Isthmionicus; Nicias; Laches; Euthydemus; Procles; Pythodorus; Hagnon; Myrtilus; Thrasycles; Theagenes; Aristocrates; Iolcius; Timocrates; Leon; Lamachus; Demosthenes
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would justly, zealously and guilelessly abide by the following terms of the alliance:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies, and neither could make peace with an enemy without the other
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Athenians were to assist the Spartans in the event of an uprising of the slave population
4. The same people who swore to the treaty should swear the oaths, and that the should be renewed each year – with the Spartans going to Athens at the Dionysia and the Athenians going to Sparta at the Hyacinthia.
5. Each party was to erect a stele to announce the agreement (the Athenians on the Acropolis and the Spartans at Amyclae)
6. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
 ταῦτα δ’ εἶναι δικαίως καὶ προθύμως καὶ ἀδόλως
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Spartans realised that by making an alliance with Boeotia (see oath id 1708) they would be wronging the Athenians because it had been agreed that neither should make peace nor war without the agreement of the other. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1686.

author: Demosthenes
title: Exordia
statement:
[That he will tell the Athenians what course of action he recommends]
 ἐγὼ νὴ Δί’ ἐρῶ.

author: Isocrates
title: Panathenaicus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates argues that the Spartans made a peace (i.e. the King's Peace) with a man (i.e. the Great King) who had led an army against them, and who had proposed to destroy both Athens and Sparta, and to enslave the rest of the Greeks, even though they could have conquered him on both land and sea. 
He then repeats that they drew up a peace for all time, as though the King had been their benefactor.  In fact, of course, neither Athens nor Sparta ever made peace with "[the] man who had ... proposed to destroy them" (Xerxes), but only with his successors. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
remarks: As Sommerstein remarks ad loc., Xenocles was a member of a noted theatrical family, though also widely regarded as a bad poet (Thesmophoriazusae 169). The contempt shown for him here highlights Dionysus' desire for Euripides above all other tragic poets at this point in the play.

author: Alcaeus
title: Fragments
date: Before Myrsilus came to power (612 to 608)
if_broken: May an Erinys pursue the man
statement: [That they would never (abandon?) any of their comrades, but either die at the hands of men who came against them or kill them and rescue the people from their oaths]
remarks: This is (presumably) another reference to the oath broken by Pittacus. See remarks on oath id 1338.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That he thinks Artaxerxes will fight]
 Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, εἴπερ γε Δαρείου καὶ Παρυσάτιδός ἐστι παῖς, ἐμὸς δὲ ἀδελφός, οὐκ ἀμαχεὶ ταῦτ’ ἐγὼ λήψομαι.
remarks: When Clearchus asks Cyrus whether he thinks Artaxerxes will fight him, Cyrus responds with an oath that he will have to fight Artaxerxes.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it would be a fine thing if the hipparch were able to use his position to do something good for the state]
 Καὶ ἔστι γε νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, καλόν, ἐὰν δύνῃ ταῦτα ποιῆσαι.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
if_taken: Cersobleptes would be included in the peace
if_refused: He would not be included in the peace
remarks:
When defending himself against Demosthenes' allegations that he is responsible for King Cersobleptes losing his kingdom, Aeschines states that on the day the Athenians voted to conclude the peace Demosthenes did not mention Cersobleptes. He states that when the ambassadors had been elected to receive the oaths from Philip but had not yet set out, there was an assembly at which Demosthenes was one of the proedroi. Critobulus of Lampsacus addressed this assembly and said that Cersobleptes had sent him, and demanded that he should be allowed to give his oath to Philip's ambassadors, and that Cersobleptes' name should be written down in the list of the allies of Athens. 
Aleximachus of Peleces submitted a motion to the proedroi to the effect that the representative of Cersobleptes should be permitted to join the other allies in giving the oath to Philip, but Demosthenes (in his capacity as one of the proedroi) refused to put the motion to the vote. 
Demosthenes argued that he would not destroy the peace with Philip, and that he did not recognise allies who joined only in time to pour the peace libations. 
See also oath id 2585. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides observes that whereas a general in wartime should practice secrecy and deception when leading many men into dangers, those serving as envoys about a common peace for the Greeks (i.e. he and his colleagues who have been negotiating the peace with Sparta) on matters about which oaths will be sworn, and inscribed stelae set up, should practice neither secrecy nor deception. Andocides adds that envoys in these circumstances deserve praise more than blame if they refer peace terms to the demos for consideration even though they have been sent out with full powers. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Boeotians were able to collect their dead
statement: [? That they would not molest the Boeotians while the latter were collecting their dead]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Athenians captured and despoiled the bodies of the Boeotian cavalrymen who had charged the walls of Nisaea, but returned them under a truce (ὑποσπόνδους) and set up a trophy.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Conon
statement:
[That he did not think he should bring a suit against Conon's sons or pay attention to the incidents]
 μὰ τοὺς θεοὺς οὐ μὴν ἔγωγ’ ᾠόμην δεῖν οὔτε δίκην λαχεῖν αὐτοῖς οὔτε λόγον ποιεῖσθαι τῶν συμβάντων οὐδένα,
remarks: Ariston describes how Conon's sons attacked both him and his slaves during their service at Panactum, but that when they returned to Athens he did not think he should bring a suit against them, until they assaulted him again at Athens.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Demosthenes reminds that jurors that he brought about the alliance with the Achaeans, Corinthians, Megarans, Leucadians and Corcyraeans, as well as the Euboeans (see oath id 3391), and the Thebans (see oath id 3390).

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement: [That they would not surrender to the sexual entreaties of their male lovers]
remarks: The Chorus-leader here explains how birds are used by the older male partner in a relationship to convince the younger male partner to surrender to his sexual desires, although the younger partner has sworn not to.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
swearer: Lampito; Calonice; Myrrhine; All women present
swearee: Lampito; Calonice; Myrrhine; All women present
if_taken: The sex strike will be ensured; peace will be enabled
if_refused: The sex strike will not be ensured; war will continue
if_kept: May she drink from the wine-cup
if_broken: May the wine-cup be filled with water
impact: The sex strike is ensured and peace is enabled
statement: [That no man whatever, neither lover nor husband shall come near her with his cock up, and that she will pass her life at home, pure and chaste in make-up and saffron gown so that her husband may be greatly inflamed with desire for her, and that she will never yield herself to her husband of her own free will. And if he should force her against her will, she will submit grudgingly and not thrust back. She will not raise her Persian slippers ceilingwards. She will not stand in the lioness-on-a-cheesegrater position]
remarks: Myrrhine refers once more to the oath she has taken to refrain from sex with her husband (cf. id 1203). Cinesias tells her not to worry about any oath, and while Myrrhine seems to take his advice, she only inflames him further and never actually yields to him. For further information on this oath, see remarks on id 1164.

author: Demosthenes
title: On Halonnesus
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Hegesippus recalls how Python (one of the Philip's ambassadors) urged the other public speakers not to attack the peace, but to propose amendments to any unsatisfactory clauses. Python also urged the Athenians to ignore speakers who confined themselves to abusing Philip without drafting any proposals which might clear Philip of suspicion while preserving the terms of the peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
if_taken: He will be part of a conspiracy
if_refused: He will not be part of a conspiracy
statement: [That he will be party to the conspiracy]
remarks: Bdelycleon complains here that he is being accused of being a conspirator just because he is wants his father to abandon the jury service to which he is addicted. See remarks on ids 1079, 1087, 1089; cf. id 1107.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Nausimachus and Xenopeithes
statement:
[That Demaretus sent someone to Bosporus to recover the debt]
 ἔπεμψεν νὴ Δί’, εἴποι τις ἄν, τὸν κομιούμενον.
remarks: The speaker (one of the sons of Aristaechmus) argues that Demaretus could never have recovered money owed to him in Bosporus because he never went there. He imagines that someone will respond in this way to his argument.

author: Plato
title: Protagoras
statement:
[That if Hippocrates gives Protagoras money and persuades him, he will make Hippocrates wise]
 “Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δία,” ἔφην ἐγώ, “ἂν αὐτῷ διδῷς ἀργύριον καὶ πείθῃς ἐκεῖνον, ποιήσει καὶ σὲ σοφόν.”
remarks: This statement must be to some extent ironic. Protagoras, if he agrees to teach Hippocrates, will endow him with the kind of wisdom that he himself possesses - but whether that is true wisdom, or whether Socrates believes it to be so, is quite another matter.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
After making a truce in 369 the Spartans led their troops away from Corinth. 
Xenophon observes that most people thought that the Spartan polemarch had made a truce that was more to the advantage of the Thebans than his own side. 
The Thebans and their allies went on to attack Sicyon, Pellene, Epidaurus and then Corinth.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he enjoys both being with the man who is by his side and gazing upon him]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σαμβαύλας, ἥδομαι γοῦν καὶ ἐγὼ συνών τε καὶ θεώμενος τοῦτον.
remarks: The man in question is exceedingly ugly, but Sambaulas explains why he enjoys his company so in what follows- see oath id 2347.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Aeschines warns the jurors that if a juror votes for the cleverest schemer rather than according to the laws, "the oath he swore when he became a juror pursues and torments him; for this (oath) I think, is what makes his act wrong". 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Catanaeans allies.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes asks the jurors how a great a fine they should impose on Aeschines compared to the fine imposed on Timarchus, given that Aeschines' crimes were greater. He asks what retribution a legal jury, bound by oath, should exact from men who have grievously transgressed against the state if Aeschines himself demanded such severity of retribution from men who had transgressed only against himself and his friends? 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement:
[That the troops were not prepared either to come to the aid of breakers of discipline or to join with Xenophon in chastising them]
 ἀλλὰ μὰ Δία οὔτε τούτοις ἐπεκουρεῖτε οὔτε σὺν ἐμοὶ τὸν ἀτακτοῦντα ἐπαίετε.
remarks:
In defending himself against the charge that he had unfairly beaten his men, Xenophon argues that no one stopped him beating those who were shirking their duty or acting in a cowardly manner, and therefore judged that he was justified in doing so. 
He adds that by not joining him in disciplining the men they gave the vicious among them freedom to act wantonly.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he is not aware that the soul is immortal and never perishes]
 Οὐκ ᾔσθησαι, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, ὅτι ἀθάνατος ἡμῶν ἡ ψυχὴ καὶ οὐδέποτε ἀπόλλυται;  Καὶ ὃς ἐμβλέψας μοι καὶ θαυμάσας εἶπε· Μὰ Δί’, οὐκ ἔγωγε·

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That he has already thrown some barley seeds to the spectators]
  καὶ τοῖς θεαταῖς ῥῖπτε τῶν κριθῶν.
  {ΟΙ.}  Ἰδού. 
  {ΤΡ.}  Ἔδωκας ἤδη;
  {ΟΙ.}  Νὴ τὸν Ἑρμῆν

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[Τhat Meidias should be pardoned because of his high birth]
 γένους εἵνεκα νὴ Δία
remarks: Demosthenes asks why Meidias should be pardoned, and imagines that someone will respond in this way to his rhetorical question.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Dicaeogenes
if_taken: He can proceed with his case
if_refused: He cannot proceed with his case
statement: [That the facts in his written statement were true]
remarks:
Menexenus tells the jurors that he is going to produce witnesses to prove that Dicaeogenes (III) agreed to hand over two-thirds of the property which Dicaeogenes (II) left, and that Leochares acted as his surety for his doing so. 
Menexenus then has the antomosia read to the jurors for a second time. 
See also oath id 3041.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Prior to the destruction of Plataea, the Athenians and Plataeans assisted each other when they were threatened
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the allies of Athens at the outbreak of the war in 431 as: 
Chios, Lesbos, Plataea (allied since 519), the Messenians in Naupactus (allied since ca.461), the Acarnanians (allied since 431), Corcyra (allied since 434/3), Zacynthus, some cities in Caria, the Dorians adjacent to Caria, Ionia, the Hellespont, the coast of Thrace and the Cyclades except Melos and Thera (each of these poleis presumably became allies at the same time as Chios and Lesbos). 
See also oath id 1561, 1577, 1581, 1642, 1644, 1646, 1830 and 1843.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That it will be much easier for the hipparch to teach his men that it is safe and honourable for them to obey him than if he had to teach them that evils are better and more profitable than good things]
 Πῶς οὖν, ἔφη, τοῦτο διδάξω; Πολὺ νὴ Δί’, ἔφη, ῥᾷον ἢ εἴ σοι δέοι διδά-
σκειν ὡς τὰ κακὰ τῶν ἀγαθῶν ἀμείνω καὶ λυσιτελέστερά ἐστι.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Demeter
impact: Highlights human foolishness and lack of foresight
statement:
[That she would have made Metanira's son deathless and ageless forever (had Metanira not spied her putting the child in the fire and become alarmed)]
 ἴστω γὰρ θεῶν ὅρκος ἀμείλικτον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ
ἀθάνατόν κέν τοι καὶ ἀγήραον ἤματα πάντα 
παῖδα φίλον ποίησα καὶ ἄφθιτον ὤπασα τιμήν·
remarks: Demeter swears the "gods' oath" as she calls it, but a counter-factual oath, which invokes the river Styx as witness. See further remarks on oath id 1291.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he is going to find out what this business is about]
 Νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς ἐγὼ πυθέσθαι βούλομαι τί τὸ πρᾶγμα τουτί.
remarks: The Inlaw seems to be saying this to himself; he does indeed proceed to question Euripides about what is going on.

author: Sophocles
title: Unidentified Drama
statement: n/a
remarks: Here, a character comments on the untrustworthiness of a woman's oath (literally "I write the oaths of a woman in water"). Cf. oath ids 1307, 1433, 1446. This poetic concept  is found elsewhere in later poets, like Callimachus (epigram 25.3-4) and Catullus (70).

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades II
statement:
[That he does not know how to answer Socrates' question]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ἐγὼ μὲν οὐθὲν ἂν ἔχοιμί σοι εἰπεῖν, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὕτως·

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Theocrines
statement:
[That he will show that the city is not at all damaged whether Thucydides' decree is valid or annulled]
 καὶ δείξομεν ὑμῖν οὐδὲν τὴν πόλιν βλαπτομένην, οὔτε μὰ τὸν Δία ἐὰν κύριον γένηται τὸ ψήφισμα τὸ Θουκυδίδου οὔτ’ ἂν ἄκυρον.

author: Lysias
title: Against Agoratus
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The prosecutor tells the jurors that Agoratus will try to argue that he cannot be prosecuted because of "the oaths and agreements" i.e. the amnesty of 403/2 agreed by "those in the Piraeus" and "those in the city". 
He argues that if Agoratus does make this objection he is practically admitting that he is a murderer. 
The prosecutor also argues (unconvincingly) that the oaths and agreements do not apply to Agoratus because he was in the Piraeus at the time the oaths were sworn, and "there was no oath taken between the men in Piraeus and the men in Piraeus".  
See also oath id 1796.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would come to the defence of whoever needed it, as circumstances required, and not go to war or reach any agreements without common consent]
 ἦ μὴν ἔν τε τῷ παρατυχόντι ἀμυνεῖν τῷ δεομένῳ καὶ μὴ πολεμήσειν τῳ μηδὲ ξυμβήσεσθαι ἄνευ κοινῆς γνώμης
remarks:
Thucydides states that the boeotarchs, the Corinthians, the Megarians and envoys from (the Chalcidians in) Thrace decided to swear oaths with each other to come to the defence of whoever needed it, as circumstances required, and not to go to war or reach any agreements without common consent. 
After this the Boeotians and the Megarians would make a treaty (σπένδεσθαι) with Argos. 
But before the oaths were sworn, the boeotarchs brought the matter before the four Boeotian councils, which had the supreme authority in the state. The boeotarchs recommended taking oaths with such cities as wished to take oaths with them (ξυνομνύναι) for mutual defence.  But the councillors did not accept the proposal, fearing that the Spartans might be offended if they swore oaths with the Corinthians who had broken away from the Spartans.

title: IG XII 9
date: Second half of the sixth century (549 to 500)
if_taken: He can pass judgement and award the penalty
if_refused: He cannot judgement and award the penalty
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text indicates that the judge (or arbiter) shall award a penalty after he has taken an oath (δίκεν…  ἐπεὰν… κατομόσει…) 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 41.725.

title: IG I(3)
statement:
[The statement is unknown]
 [- - - νὲ τὸν] Δία καὶ τὸ[ν - - -]
[- - - καὶ τὸν] Δία τὸν Ἀγο[ραῖον - - -]
[- - -] ἐ̣ὰν εὐhορκο̃ [- - -]
remarks:
The oath was sworn by Zeus and mentions Zeus Agoraios, but the text is too fragmentary for further speculation. 
An alternative restoration by Hiller reads:
