[ὀμνύο νὲ τὸν] Δία καὶ τὸ[ν (e.g.) Ἀπόλλονα καὶ τὲν Ἄρτ[εμιν καὶ τὸν] Δία τὸν Ἀγο[ραῖον ἐμμένεν τοῖς hόρκοις· καὶ] ἐ̣ὰν εὐhορκο̃, [εὖ πράττοιμι, ἐὰν δὲ μέ, τὀναντίον·] τὰ δὲ ἄλλα [πιστο̃ς καὶ ἀδόλος δ]ράσο hος ἂν h]α̣ι συνθε̃κα[ι τάττοσι·]

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the scent isn't a nice one]
 Οὐχ ἡδὺ τὸ μύρον μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω τουτογί
remarks: Cf.oath id 1212. As Sommerstein remarks ad loc. "Cinesias wants to avoid the delay involved in anointing himself; but all he gets is further delay as Myrrhine pretends to suppose he would prefer a different kind of scent".

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he will not keep his hands off Manes any longer, when he sees him so miserable and slow]
 Οὔ τοι μὰ τὰς κερχνῇδας ἔτι σου σχήσομαι,  
  οὕτως ὁρῶν σε δειλὸν ὄντα καὶ βραδύν.
remarks: Because the birds are now gods in this land of dream-fantasy, swearing by the kestrels constitutes a bona fide oath.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes cites the law proposed by Demophantus which stipulates that anyone who suffers in defence of democracy will receive the same award as Harmodius and Aristogeiton, and warns the jurors that they must vote to repeal Leptines' law, for if they do not it will be impossible for them to fulfil their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
swearer: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
swearee: The Greeks who fought against the Persians
if_taken: They would be included in the alliance
if_refused: They would not be included in the alliance
statement: [? That they would fight together against the Persians to maintain Greek liberty]
remarks:
The Plataeans beg the Spartans not to destroy them, invoking the names of the gods who sanctioned the alliance against the Persians. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1501.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That the funniest thing about a gender-blind society would be that women, including old women, would exercise naked together with men]
 Τί, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, γελοιότατον αὐτῶν ὁρᾷς; ἢ δῆλα δὴ ὅτι  γυμνὰς τὰς γυναῖκας ἐν ταῖς παλαίστραις γυμναζομένας μετὰ  τῶν ἀνδρῶν, οὐ μόνον τὰς νέας, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἤδη τὰς πρεσβυτέρας, ὥσπερ τοὺς γέροντας ἐν τοῖς γυμνασίοις, ὅταν ῥυσοὶ καὶ μὴ ἡδεῖς τὴν ὄψιν ὅμως φιλογυμναστῶσιν; Νὴ τὸν Δία, ἔφη·

author: Lycurgus
title: Against Leocrates
if_taken: He will be eligible to be a citizen
if_refused: He will not be eligible to be citizens
statement: [That they shall not bring shame upon the sacred weapons nor shall they desert the man beside them, wherever they stand in the line. They shall fight in defence of things sacred and profane and shall not hand the fatherland on lessened, but greater and better both as far as they are able and with all. And they shall be obedient to whoever exercises power reasonably on any occasion and to the laws currently in force and any reasonably put into force in the future. If anyone attempts to destroy these, they shall refuse to allow him both as far as is in their power and in union with all, and they shall honour the ancestral religion]
gods_invoked: Aglaurus; Hestia; Enyo; Enyalios; Ares; Athena; Zeus; Thallo; Auxo; Hegemone; Heracles; The boundaries of my fatherland; Wheat; Barley; Vines; Olives; Figs
remarks:
Lycurgus says that if Leocrates has sworn the ephebic oath he has clearly perjured himself (taking his flight from Athens, at a time of danger, as equivalent to desertion from the ranks), and if he has not he has been evading his duty as a citizen. 
See also oath id 340.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would be allies to the Greeks, would not betray them, and would lead them without treachery]
remarks:
Xenophon refers here to the alliance between the Ten Thousand and the Persians who fought with Cyrus. 
After the Greeks elected new leaders, Cheirisophus the Spartan addressed the Greek mercenaries saying that their present situation was particularly painful because they had been robbed of their generals and been betrayed by Ariaeus and his men, "who were formerly allies". 
See also oath id 2169.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he did not sip any of the wine because he was afraid that poison had been mixed in the bowl]
 Καὶ τί δή, ἔφη, ὦ Κῦρε, τἆλλα μιμούμενος τὸν Σάκαν οὐ κατερρόφησας τοῦ οἴνου; Ὅτι, ἔφη, νὴ Δία ἐδεδοίκειν μὴ ἐν τῷ κρατῆρι φάρμακα μεμιγμένα εἴη.
remarks: It turns out that his fear is based on witnessing a previous drinking session where Astyages and his company got terribly drunk. Cf. oath ids 2312-2315.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Nicostratus
statement:
[That according to our opponents, Hagnon and Hagnotheus are not Nicostratus' kinsmen, but other people are]
 Μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ οὐκ ἔστιν ὁ Ἅγνων οὐδ’ ὁ Ἁγνόθεος τοῦ Νικοστράτου συγγενής, ὡς οἱ ἀντίδικοί φασιν, ἀλλ’ ἕτεροι.
remarks: The speaker pretends to have just remembered that his opponents are alleging that Nicostratus was not the son of Thrasymachus but of another man named Smicrus, so that Thrasymachus' nephews, Hagnon and Hagnotheus, are no relation to Nicostratus

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That he would not attack Peisistratus]
remarks: According to Herodotus, Cimon son of Stesagoras was allowed to return to Athens "under treaty" (ὑπόσπονδος) after he won the four-horse chariot race and allowed his victory to be awarded to Peisistratus.

title: IG I(3)
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
That they would act, speak and counsel in the interests of the Athenian demos to the best of their ability and that they would not rebel against the Athenian demos or its allies by word or deed,  and would be loyal to the Athenian demos 
 [δράσο καὶ ἐρο̃ καὶ βολεύσο το̃ι δέμοι το̃ι Ἀθεναίον hό τι ἂν δύνομαι καλὸν κ]αὶ ἀγαθόν, [οὐδὲ ἀποστέσομαι ἀπὸ το̃ δέμο το̃ Ἀ]θεναίον οὔτε λ[όγοι οὔτε ἔργοι οὐδὲ ἀπὸ τον] χσυμμάχον το̃ν Ἀ[θεναίον, καὶ ἔσομαι πιστὸς τ]ο̃ι δέμοι το̃ι Ἀθ[εναίον·]
remarks:
This inscription records a treaty between Athens and Samos. 
For the corresponding oath sworn by the Athenians see oath id 161.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristogeiton 1
statement:
[That he did not wish to prosecute Aristogeiton]
 Πάνυ δ’, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, μετὰ πάσης οἰκειότητος ἐρῶ τἀληθῆ πρὸς ὑμᾶς. ἐγὼ γὰρ ἐν ταῖς ἐκκλησίαις ὁρῶν ὑμᾶς κατατάττοντάς με καὶ προχειριζομένους ἐπὶ τὴν τούτου κατηγορίαν, ἠχθόμην καὶ μὰ τὸν Δία καὶ πάντας θεοὺς οὐκ 
ἐβουλόμην.
remarks: The speaker tells the jurors that when he saw the Athenians in the ecclesia proposing him as the prosecutor of Aristogeiton, he was troubled, and swears that he did not relish the task.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he will not yet pay for the oil-flask]
 Ἀλλ’, ὦγάθ’, ἔτι καὶ νῦν ἀπόδος πάσῃ τέχνῃ·
λήψει γὰρ ὀβολοῦ πάνυ καλήν τε κἀγαθήν.
ΕΥ.  Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὔπω γ’·
remarks: See Sommerstein ad 1235 on the complexity of meaning here.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That the fact that all the jurors turned yellow (when they were being farted on) was "a solid gold piece of knavery"]
  Καὶ νὴ Δί’ἦν γε τοῦτο Πυρράνδρου τὸ μηχάνημα.
remarks: On the pun in the last part of the statement, see Sommerstein ad 901.

author: Isocrates
title: On the Peace
statement: n/a
remarks: Isocrates claims that empire brought misfortune to both Athens and Sparta, and that it filled Sparta with injustice, indolence, lawlessness, avarice, contempt for the allies, covetousness of the possessions of other states, and indifference to oaths and agreements.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the husband was right to say that war is for men to take care of]
 «πόλεμος δ’ ἄνδρεσσι μελήσει.» 
 {ΠΡ.}  Ὀρθῶς γε λέγων νὴ Δί’ ἐκεῖνος.

author: Eupolis
title: Taxiarchoi
statement:
[That when the garment was newer, it contained five staters worth of thread (but now it contains easily two talents worth of filth)]
  ὅτ’ ἦν μέντοι νεώτερος, κρόκης
πέντε στατῆρας εἶχε, ναὶ μὰ τὸν Δία. 
{Β.} νῦν δὲ ῥύπου γε δύο τάλαντα ῥᾳδίως.
remarks: The swearer clearly believes the statement to be true.The owner of the five staters is likely to be a garment (so Grotius and Kaibel), which, when new, contained 10 lb. of wool (cf. Ar. Eccl. 413, with Sommerstein ad loc.) but which now contains at least 120 lb. of dirt.

author: Ctesias
title: Persika
statement: [That the Parthians (who had previously revolted from the Medes and given themselves over to the Sacae) would be subject to the Medes, but that both peoples should retain their former possessions and be friends and allies forever]
remarks: Same as oath id 3445.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
remarks:
Aeschines states that there was no mention of a possible journey to Thrace, because it was not in the instructions in the decree of the demos, which were simply to receive the oaths from Philip and to carry out certain other business. 
He again stresses that nothing could have been done about Cersobleptes because he had already lost his kingdom. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Athenians collected their dead and sailed back to Notium
statement: [? That they would not molest the Athenians while they collected their dead]
remarks:
Xenophon states that after the Athenians were defeated by the Syracusans and Selinuntines at Ephesus they recovered their dead under a truce. 
They then sailed back to Notium, buried their dead, before sailing on towards Lesbos and the Hellespont.

author: Xenophon
title: Athenaion Politeia
statement: n/a
remarks:
According to the author, it is necessary for oligarchic poleis to keep alliances and oaths. For if they do not abide by the agreements, or if injustice is done, there are the names of the few who made the agreement written down. 
But whatever agreements the demos makes can be repudiated by referring the blame to the one who spoke or took the vote, while the others can declare that they were absent or did not approve of the agreement made by the whole demos. 
I wonder if the author, if challenged, could point to one single instance of democratic Athens behaving in the manner here described?  It is true that the ordinary citizen was very good at blaming his leaders for anything that went wrong (and there were always rival politicians to encourage him to do so), but that is not at all the same thing as breaking a sworn interstate agreement on the plea that only the leaders, not the people, had made it.

title: IErythrae
swearer: Messengers (angeloi) from Hermias and his hetairoi
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement:
[That they would help the Eyrthraeans by land and by sea, with all their strength, as far as possible, and to accomplish the other things in accordance with the agreement]
 ὁμ[οίως δὲ καὶ Ἑ]ρ̣μίαν καὶ τοὺς ἑταίρ[ους ὀμόσαι δ]ι’ ἀγγέλων βοηθήσειν [Ἐρυθραίοις κ]αὶ κατὰ γῆν καὶ κατὰ [θάλασσαν παν]τὶ σθένει κατὰ τὸ δυ[νατόν καὶ τὰ ἄ]λλα ἐπιτελεῖν κατὰ [τὰ ὡμολογη]μ̣ένα·
remarks:
This oath is attached to an agreement between Erythrae and Hermias, the ruler of Atarneus.   
The text indicates that Hermias and his hetairoi will swear "through messengers". 
For the corresponding oath of the Erythraeans see oath id 763.

author: Demosthenes
title: On Organisation
statement:
[That while in a few respects (see Remarks) things were better in the days of the Athenian Empire than now, in most they were worse]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δία ταῦτα μόνον τότ’ εἶχε βέλτιον ἢ νῦν, τὰ δ’ ἄλλα χεῖρον.
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the Athenians have squandered more than 1500 talents on the needy communities of Greece (cf. Olynthiac 3. 28), and have squandered their private estates, public funds and the contributions of the allies, and that allies gained in war have been lost in peace. He then suggests that someone might object (under oath) that in these respects alone things were better than they are now, but in other respects they were worse. 
He goes on to catalogue the other spleandours of the past i.e. the magnificent architecture that they can no longer afford to build such as the Propylaea, dockyards and stoas. He says that now the Athenians can only afford to build spend money on roads, fountains, whitewashing and other trivia.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The Argives and the Spartans sent envoys to Thrace and Macedon and persuaded Perdiccas to swear an oath (of alliance) with them. 
Thucydides states that Perdiccas did not desert the Athenians at once, but had been thinking about it because he saw that the Argives had done so, and he was of Argive descent. See also oath id 1754. 
For references to the alliance between Perdiccas and Athens see oath id 256.  
By 414 Perdiccas was again on the Athenian side (Thuc. 7.9).

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Methymna under the auspices of the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
The decree states that Aesimus (presumably one of the generals) and the synedroi on the ships shall ensure that the Methymnaean archai swear just as the other allies have done. For the corresponding oath of the Athenians see oath id 335, and the oath at Methymna see oath id 3862. 
For other references to the Second Athenian Confederacy see oath id 2974.

author: Hesiod
title: Works and Days
impact: Becomes subject to divine punishment or reward
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a general discussion of oath-taking in which we are told that if a man knowingly tells lies and swears an oath on it, offending Justice, this man is left with an enfeebled progeny thereafter, but the progeny of the true-sworn man grows stronger.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he thinks that when Pheraulas’ property is safe, he must be many times happier than the Sacian at the sight of so many blessings]
 καὶ ὁ Σάκας, Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ὅταν σῶα ᾖ, πολλὰ ὁρῶν πολλαπλάσια ἐμοῦ εὐφραίνῃ.
remarks: The Sacian and Pheraulas fundamentally disagree about the effect that wealth has on one's happiness. Cf. oath ids 2488-2490.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
The Thebans tried to force the Corinthian envoys sent to Thebes to negotiate a peace treaty (see oath id 2037) to swear an oath of alliance with them, but the Corinthians refused. They refused on the grounds that they would be exchanging one war for another rather than acquiring peace i.e. they would be fighting the Spartans alongside the Thebans instead of fighting the Thebans alongside the Spartans. 
Xenophon says that the Thebans were seized with admiration for the Corinthians "because, even when they were in danger, they were not prepared to go to war against their former benefactors", and agreed to make peace without an alliance.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Cilicians; King of Assyria; Lycaonians; Arabians; Phoenicians; Ionians; Aeolians; Most Greeks in Asia
swearee: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Cilicians; King of Assyria; Lycaonians; Arabians; Phoenicians; Ionians; Aeolians; Most Greeks in Asia
statement: [That they would fight together in attacking the Medes and Persians]
remarks: Apparently the allies were convinced of the need for the alliance by the Assyrian king's suggestions that the Medes and the Persians, who had intermarried, and were powerful nations, would be likely to make war on each of the other nations and subjugate them. Those who were unconvinced by such arguments were apparently bribed to join the alliance. Cf. oath ids 2326, 2385 and 2389. The allies subsequently begin to desert- see oath id 2387.   Later, in book 6, the Indian spies report to Cyrus that Croesus has been made leader and general over all the allied kings. They also report that Thracian swordsmen had been hired and 120,000 armed Egyptians were sailing to join them (see oath id 2451). Indians were listed amongst the original allies (see oath id references above) but are not mentioned later for obvious reasons, and the Carians are also absent, though Lycaonians, Arabians, Phoenicians, Ionians, Aeolians and almost all the Greek colonists in Asia have now seemingly joined the alliance. The Assyrian king, whose father had originally proposed the alliance apparently flees and leaves his troops under the king of Babylon. The Hyrcanians, subjects of Assyria, had previously deserted- see oath id 2387. Here, Cyrus reminds his troops as they are about to enter Babylon under the cover of darkness, that even when the Babylonians and their allies were wide awake and fully armed, Persian troops had defeated them.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That one cannot get "a gentleman's scent" from the perfume shop]
 Καὶ πόθεν ἄν τις τοῦτο τὸ χρῖμα λάβοι; Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, οὐ παρὰ τῶν μυροπωλῶν
remarks: Cf. oath id 2191.  Asked where then this scent can be procured, Socrates quotes Theognis (35-36) to the effect that one will learn to be good by associating with good men.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus tells the jurors that he and Olympiodorus agreed not to risk a joint suit against those who had been awarded Comon's estate. Olympiodorus would enter a suit for the whole estate and conduct his case himself, buh split the proceeds with Callistratus if he won "in accordance with the agreement and the oaths". Callistratus would bring suit for one half of the estate, and if he won he would split the proceeds with Olympiodorus just as they had sworn (see oath id 3623).

author: Anaximenes
title: Ars Rhetorica
if_taken: They will be allowed to judge
if_refused: They will not be allowed to judge
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Anaximenes refers to the Heliastic oath, and states that the judges swore that they would listen to everything that is said (ὅπως ἀκούσαντες πάντων τῶν λεγομένων εὐόρκως θῆσθε τὴν ψῆφον). 
This is a reference to the dikasts' oath, which included the clause "I will listen to the accuser and the defendant, both of them equally". See also oath id 1610 and 1613 for Anaximenes' comments regarding the jurors swearing to judge according to the laws. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Emphatically negative response; causes the slave to leave
statement:
[That he will not sell his thrushes or eels to Lamachus]
 {ΑΓ.}  Ὅ τι;  
 ἐκέλευε Λάμαχός σε ταυτησὶ δραχμῆς 
 εἰς τοὺς Χοᾶς αὑτῷ μεταδοῦναι τῶν κιχλῶν,
 τριῶν δραχμῶν δ’ ἐκέλευε Κωπᾷδ’ ἔγχελυν.
 {ΔΙ.} Ὁ ποῖος οὗτος Λάμαχος τὴν ἔγχελυν;
 {ΑΓ.} Ὁ δεινός, ὁ ταλαύρινος, ὃς τὴν Γοργόνα
  πάλλει κραδαίνων τρεῖς κατασκίους λόφους. 
 {ΔΙ.} Οὐκ ἂν μὰ Δί’, εἰ δοίη γέ μοι τὴν ἀσπίδα·

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
statement:
[That the Athenians will do their duty whenever it is necessary]
 ὅταν νὴ Δί’ ἀναγκαῖον ᾖ.
remarks:
Demosthenes asks when the Athenians will do their duty, and imagines that they will respond that they will do so whenever it is necessary. He then says that that time has long since arrived. 
See also oath id 3215 and 3255.

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
impact: Provokes the First Creditor to curse him
statement:
[That he agrees to swear the oath proposed by the First Creditor at 1232-1234]
{Στ.}  νὴ Δία,
 κἂν προσκαταθείην γ’, ὥστ’ ὀμόσαι, τριώβολον.
remarks: See also remarks on oath id 44.

title: IG I(3)
if_taken: He could hold office as choregus
if_refused: He could not hold office as choregus
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks: The text indicates that the choregoi at the deme Icaria would swear their oaths whilst placing their hand on the cult statue of Dionysus.

author: Isocrates
title: For Demonicus
statement: n/a
remarks: Isocrates urges Demonicus, the son of his Cypriot friend Hipponicus, to guard secrets more carefully than money which is entrusted to him, "for good men ought to show that they hold their honour more trustworthy than an oath".

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that if the Athenians had perceived Philip's aggression straight away they would not have neglected Phocis or Thermopylae, Philip would have had no threat over them, and he, not Athens, would have had his hands tied by the advantages arising from the peace. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Aeschylus
title: Choephoroi
statement: n/a
remarks: Garvie ad loc. remarks: 'The reference is not to a compact sworn between Orestes and Pylades…, but to 'faithful oaths' taken either by Apollo to the human questioners or vice versa. The former is easier [for grammatical reasons]… Apollo promises to support those who obey him…The oracle itself is equivalent to an oath in which Orestes can put his trust'.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That the Carystians will also be in a favour of a "fucking policy" (i.e. peace policy)]
  Καὶ γὰρ ναὶ μὰ Δία Καρυστίοις.
remarks: Carystian troops then in Athens had got themselves a reputation for being, in the WW2 phrase, "oversexed and over here". Cf. oath id 1232.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
if_kept: No longer will the gods abuse the birds' sceptre
statement:
[That if Peisetaerus "joins thoughts" with the birds, justly, sincerely, piously to attack the gods, in harmony of thought with the birds, that the gods will not be abusing their sceptre for much longer]
 κατώμοσα,  
 ἢν σὺ παρ’ ἐμὲ θέμενος ὁμόφρο- 
 νας λόγους δίκαιος ἄδολος
 ὅσιος ἐπὶ θεοὺς ἴῃς, 
 ἐμοὶ φρονῶν ξυνῳδά, μὴ 
 πολὺν χρόνον θεοὺς ἔτι 
 σκῆπτρα τἀμὰ τρίψειν.
remarks: This is a parody of a real oath. Line 631 is a comic adaptation of a military phrase meaning to join forces with someone, hence Sommerstein's translation "join thoughts with me". As Sommerstein notes ad 632, of the terms used the first two appear in treaties and oaths of peace. The third term chosen here "results in an attack on the gods being paradoxically described as "pious"."; see the commentaries of both Sommerstein and Dunbar for further detail.

author: Antiphanes
title: Korukos
impact: None- the swearee doesn't agree that it is a pleasure
statement:
[That the Cynics do not drink “a little wine” – what they drink is more like vinegar]
 ἐπὶ δὲ τούτοις πίνομεν
οἰνάριον. {B.}ἧδος, νὴ Δί’, οἰκίας τρόπον

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: The Athenians laid waste their land
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides states that the Aeolian islanders i.e. the Liparaeans were allied to the Syracusans, and the Athenians laid waste their land because of this.

author: Archilochus
title: Fragments
statement: unknown
remarks: This is a fragmentary reference to someone swearing. Nothing further can be deduced.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
if_taken: War will be determined by single combat between Paris and Menelaus
if_refused: War will continue as it is
if_broken: Let their brains be spilled on the ground and those of their sons, and let their wives be the spoils of others
statement: [That the Greeks and the Trojans will stop fighting, and that Menelaus and Paris will engage in single combat over Helen and her possessions]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)father, most honoured, greatest; HeliosEpithet(s)all-seeing, all-hearing; Rivers; Gaia; Nether Avengers against dead perjurers; All the immortal gods
remarks: This is the same oath which is referred to throughout books 3 and 4, and is recounted in most detail at oath id 318. Here Antenor urges the Trojans to give Helen back to the Greeks and end the war because the Trojans are fighting in contempt of their oaths.

author: Lysias
title: Against Simon
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house (?)
statement: [? That he knew well that the defendant had wounded with the intent to kill]
remarks:
The defendant asks the jurors to indulge his passion for the boy Theodotus (who was the cause of the dispute between the defendant and Simon) if he proves his innocence with regard to Simon's sworn statement. 
See also oath id 2808.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would defend each other]
 ἀλλήλοις βοηθεῖν
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Corinthians did not join the offensive and defensive alliance (see oath id 251), but were content with their first defensive alliance with Argos which obliged them to aid one another but not to join in attacking any other party. 
See also oath id 1698.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That it is not because of ambition that she is getting up to speak]
  Φιλοτιμίᾳ μὲν οὐδεμιᾷ μὰ τὼ θεὼ 
  λέξουσ’ ἀνέστην, ὦ γυναῖκες·
remarks: The two goddesses are Demeter and Persephone. As noted by Sommerstein ad loc: "this oath by Demeter and Persephone had no special connection with the Thesmophoria but was frequently used by women (and only women) at all times". Cf. oath ids 725, 740, 748, 750, 751, 788, 1124 and 1147.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement: n/a
remarks:
In 399, the Spartans tell Xenophon that if his men do not receive their pay from Seuthes they will lend their assistance and punish the men who have done wrong in violation of their oaths. 
However, the alliance between the Ten Thousand and Seuthes was not sworn (see 7.2.35-7.3.1 and 7.3.10 and 7.3.30-2). The alliance was in fact concluded only by the giving and receiving of right hands (see 7.3.1) presumably by Xenophon and Seuthes, although this is not explicit. 
Under these circumstances, we can only assume that the Spartans believed that the alliance between the Ten Thousand and Seuthes had been sworn as alliances commonly were.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Aeschines describes to the jurors how the alliance with Chalcis came about. 
He recalls that Callias of Chalcis fled to Philip after being defeated by the Athenians, and became one of his hetairoi. Callias then offended Philip and fled to Thebes. Callias later abandoned the Thebans, and "found himself caught between the hatred of the Thebans and Philip". 
Aeschines alleges that Callias, at a loss what to do with himself, thought that his sole remaining hope of survival was to bind the Athenian demos with an oath, to come to his aid under the title of ally, if anyone attacked him (σύμμαχον ὀνομασθέντα, βοηθήσειν, εἴ τις ἐπ’ αὐτὸν ἴοι·). 
Accordingly, Callias sent three envoys - Glaucetes, Empedon and Diodorus - to negotiate an alliance. 
Demosthenes then proposed the motion in the assembly. 
See also oath id 2669.

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
impact: Provokes Silenus to swear a formal oath
statement:
[That Odysseus and his men came from the ship wishing to buy food, and that Silenus was selling them sheep in exchange for a cup of wine, and that there was no violence involved]
 Κύκλωψ, ἄκουσον ἐν μέρει καὶ τῶν ξένων.
  ἡμεῖς βορᾶς χρήιζοντες ἐμπολὴν λαβεῖν
  σῶν ἆσσον ἄντρων ἤλθομεν νεὼς ἄπο. 
  τοὺς δ’ ἄρνας ἡμῖν οὖτος ἀντ’ οἴνου σκύφου
  ἀπημπόλα τε κἀδίδου πιεῖν λαβὼν
  ἑκὼν ἑκοῦσι, κοὐδὲν ἦν τούτων βίαι.
  ἀλλ’ οὗτος ὑγιὲς οὐδὲν ὧν φησιν λέγει,
  ἐπεὶ κατελήφθη σοῦ λάθραι πωλῶν τὰ σά. 
Σι. ἐγώ; κακῶς γ’ ἄρ’ ἐξόλοι’. Οδ. εἰ ψεύδομαι.
remarks: The use of the imperfect is important here. Silenus was "in the process of selling" but the exchange had not been completed. See also oath ids 99 and 101.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
swearer: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
swearee: Croesus; King of Cappadocia; Phrygians; Paphlagonians; Indians; Carians; Cilicians; King of Assyria
statement: [That they would fight together in attacking the Medes and Persians]
remarks: Apparently the allies were convinced of the need for the alliance by the Assyrian king's suggestions that the Medes and the Persians, who had intermarried, and were powerful nations, would be likely to make war on each of the other nations and subjugate them. Those who were unconvinced by such arguments were apparently bribed to join the alliance. The Hycarnians had not been mentioned as original swearers of the alliance, presumably because they are Assyrian subjects in any case. Here, the Hyrcanians, having volunteered themselves as Cyrus' allies are no longer afraid of the Assyrians or the Lydians or their allies. Cf. oath ids 2326, 2381, 2385 and 2387.

title: IC IV
work_date: mid-seventh century - end of sixth century
date: Mid-seventh century - end of the sixth century (650 to 500)
if_taken: He would be free to take action
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The text indicates that no oath can override the rules of the prothesis, whatever that prothesis might be. (πρόθεσιν μήτ’ ἀ[πο]δ̣ικάζαι μήτ’ ἀπομ̣[όσαι])  
AHS suggests that the term "prothesis" is roughly equivalent to Attic "prothesmia", and that this text is indicating that no one could use an oath to override time limitations for some kind of action e.g. for launching a prosecution.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and that they would respect the division of Cotys' former kingdom and not attempt to change the settlement by force, and that the Athenians would receive back their possessions ]
remarks:
Euthycles claims that upon the death of Berisades, one of the three kings, Cersobleptes, in violation of the oaths and agreements, began to levy war upon the sons of Berisades and upon Amadocus. 
See also oath id 458.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
statement:
[That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
See also remarks.
remarks: The peace treaty referred to here was originally proposed by Amphitheos at 51-52, envisaged as being between the Athenians and the Spartans. Dicaeopolis subsequently undertakes to make a thirty-year peace treaty with the Spartans alone (see oath id 596). Although a real peace treaty necessarily entails the swearing of an oath, Dicaeopolis never actually swears one in the context of this treaty. However, we must bear in mind that this is a comic treaty of a fantastical nature, embodied in wine that can be smelled and drunk. But we should also note that at oath id 600 the Acharnians assume that the Spartans have sworn the treaty and that their oaths cannot be trusted.  It would certainly be agreeably utopian, and therefore in the spirit of comedy, to have a treaty to which only the other party had sworn!  This treaty is referred to multiple times throughout the play: see oath ids 593, 595, 596, 597, 598, 599, 600, 606, 608, 622, 623, 625.

author: Plato
title: Laches
statement:
[That it is a good thing that Socrates upholds his father's name]
 Εὖ γε νὴ τὴν Ἥραν, ὦ Σώκρατες, ὅτι ὀρθοῖς τὸν πατέρα
remarks: Socrates is the character generally associated with informal invocations of Hera, but Lysimachus is a fellow-demesman of Socrates (180d). A. H. Sommerstein will suggest in an article to appear in CQ 58 (2008) that swearing by Hera was actually a local rather than a personal peculiarity, originating in Socrates’ deme of Alopeke. See oath id 1870 for references to Socrates' invocation of Hera.

author: Ephorus
title: Histories
if_taken: They would be allowed to join the conspiracy
if_refused: They would not be allowed to join the conspiracy
statement: [That they would be loyal to each other and maintain the secrecy of their conspiracy]
remarks: This is a reference to the assassination of Jason of Pherae, who had been chosen as ruler of Thessaly and was allegedly governing his subjects with moderation. Ephorus says he was murdered by seven young men who conspired together for the repute it would bring (cf. Xen. Hell. 6.4.31-2). Diodorus, in whom the fragment is preserved, says that other historians said that he was assassinated by his brother Polydorus (15.60.5). The two accounts are, of course, not incompatible, if e.g. it was suspected that the seven young men were in cahoots with Polydorus.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 2
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
statement:
[That if she were paid thirty minas, she would get her brothers to adopt Boeotus and Pamphilus, and that if Mantias challenged her before the arbitrator to swear that the children were in very truth his sons, she would decline the challenge]
 ὡμολόγησεν τριάκοντα μνᾶς λαβοῦσα τούτους μὲν τοῖς αὑτῆς ἀδελφοῖς εἰσποιήσειν υἱεῖς, αὐτὴ δέ, ἂν πρὸς τῷ διαιτητῇ προκαλῆται αὐτὴν ὁ πατήρ μου ὀμόσαι ἦ μὴν τοὺς παῖδας ἐξ αὑτοῦ γεγονέναι, οὐ δέξεσθαι τὴν πρόκλησιν·
remarks:
Mantitheus claims that Plangon deceived his father "by an oath that among all mankind is held to be the greatest and most awful". Mantitheus is highlighting the severity of swearing a false oath  by quoting the Iliadic phrase which calls the water of the Styx "the greatest and most awful oath among the blessed gods" (see oath id 409). 
Mantitheus states that his father agreed to the plan, because he believed that if Plangon declined to swear that Boeotus and Pamphilus were his sons, they would no longer be able to cause him problems. 
What is this "greatest and most formidable" oath - in the human world, of course, not the divine?  We are given no details in either of the speeches (here and in 39.3).  Are we meant to infer that Plangon called down destruction on herself and her offspring?  Perhaps - but if so, it is fairly certain that we are meant to infer a falsehood, since if Plangon had broken an oath taken in such terms, Mantitheus, suing her son, could not have failed to mention it explicitly. 
For other references to this oath see oath id 3561.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he believes that powerful men, such as Darius and Xerxes, act according to a law, but that law is the law of nature, not the legislation of ordinary humans]
 ἀλλ’ οἶμαι οὗτοι κατὰ φύσιν τὴν τοῦ δικαίου ταῦτα πράττουσιν, καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δία κατὰ νόμον γε τὸν τῆς φύσεως

title: IC IV
if_taken: If believed he can keep the land
statement: [That the land in question is the property of the pledger and not that of the pledgee]
remarks:
The text indicates that during disputes over pledged property, the person to whom property was pledged should summon the pledger in order to mark off the land (i.e. measure it), and if the one summoned does not appear the pledgee should mark off the property himself, and warn the pledger to appear in the agora in four days time before two witnesses. They are to swear that the land in question is the property of the pledgee and not that of the pledger. Whoever has the most witnesses to swear on his behalf is to win the case. 
For the oath of the pledgee see oath id 984. 
For an almost identical text see oath id 996.

author: Andocides
title: Against Alcibiades
date: At the time of the speech ca.417-415 (417 to 415)
swearer: The new member of a sworn political group
if_taken: He could be a member of the sworn political group
if_refused: He could not become a member of the sworn political group
statement: [? That he would maintain secrecy]
remarks: [Andocides] states that when there is an ostracism, those in the hetaireiai and synomosiai (sworn political groups) have an advantage.

author: Plato
title: Laws
if_taken: He must be allowed to search the premises
if_refused: He will not be allowed to search the premises
statement:
[That he expects to find the object he is searching for]
 Φωρᾶν δὲ ἂν ἐθέλῃ τις παρ’ ὁτῳοῦν, γυμνὸς ἢ χιτωνίσκον ἔχων ἄζωστος, προομόσας τοὺς νομίμους θεοὺς ἦ μὴν ἐλπίζειν εὑρήσειν, οὕτω φωρᾶν·
remarks: It is stated here that a man can search the premises of another man provided that he strips to his chiton and removes his girdle and then takes this oath by the "appointed gods". If, having done this, he is denied access to the house, including things "both sealed and unsealed", he should take legal proceedings against the man who obstructed him. Should this man be found guilty, he is liable to pay the double value of the item originally sought. The law that one could search another’s house for stolen goods, but only if one first removed one’s outer garment, also existed at Athens, cf. Ar. Clouds 498-9.  The object of the divestment rule was to prevent not only theft but also the smuggling in and planting of articles on the premises in order to then make false allegations.  We do not know whether Athenian law prescribed an oath to be taken before making such a search.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
if_refused: The old peace treaty will remain valid
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that Aeschines cannot say that it is advantageous that the Phocians have been destroyed, and Philip holds Thermopylae, and the Thebans are in power, and there are soldiers in Euboea, and there's a plot against Megara, and the peace is unsworn. 
This cannot be a reference to the Peace of Philocrates. Cawkwell, CQ 13, (1963), pp133-4, argues that Demosthenes is referring to an amendment to the Peace of Philocrates proposed in 344/3, which would have guaranteed freedom and autonomy to all Greek states. This would effectively turn the Peace of Philocrates into a Common Peace, but with Philip and Athens (rather than Persia) as its guarantors.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Thucydides states that on account of the enemy being at Decelea, all the Athenians were constantly on the wall or in the ranks at the various military posts. On the day that the Four Hundred seized control, those persons not in the secret were allowed to go home as usual, while orders were given to those in the conspiracy to remain quietly, at some little distance from the posts, and in case anyone attempted to resist what was being done, to seize their arms and prevent them from interfering.  
The Four Hundred, each bearing a concealed dagger, along with one hundred and twenty youths, whom they employed wherever violence was needed, appeared before the bouleutai in the bouleuterion, and told them to take their pay and be gone.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
Xenophon names the Pellenaeans as allies of Sparta at the battle of Nemea in 394. 
See also oath id 2039. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would fight for each other]
remarks: Cyrus sends some of the Indian envoys into Babylon on the pretext of proposing an alliance between India and Babylon, but with the real purpose of spying on the enemy and reporting back to Cyrus. They are successful in their mission.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not molest the Peloponnesians while they withdrew]
remarks:
Thucydides states that when the Mantinean soldiers departed they were attacked by the Acarnanian soldiers who were unaware of the treaty. 
When some of the Acarnanian generals tried to prevent them from attacking the Peloponnesians by warning them that a treaty had been made someone hurled javelins at them believing that they had been betrayed. 
Afterwards they let them go and attacked the Ambraciots instead, but according to Thucydides there was confusion about which troops were Ambraciots and which troops were not. 
Thucydides observes that numerous fugitives were received at Oeniadae by Salynthius the king of the Agraeans. For their fate see oath id 1637. 
See also oath id 1633.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leochares
statement:
[That he heard the facts he has presented from his father]
 νὴ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἀκηκοὼς τοῦ αὑτοῦ πατρὸς διαμεμαρτύρηκεν.
remarks: The speaker asks how Leochares' version of the facts can be trusted, and imagines that he will respond in this way.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Dicaeopolis tries to appease the Chorus
statement:
[That he will not listen to Dicaeopolis]
  Ἐξολοίμην, ἢν ἀκούσω.

author: Aristophanes
title: Gerytades
statement:
[That they do have men who are frequent visitors to Hades (i.e. they are emaciated and look half dead)]
  {Α.} εἰσὶ γάρ τινες 
ἄνδρες παρ’ ὑμῖν ᾁδοφοῖται; {Β.} νὴ Δία
μάλιστά γ’.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes alleges that Philip has seized the city of Pherae despite entering Thessaly as a friend and ally. 
Diod. 16.14.2 states when the Aleuadae fought against the tyrants in Thessaly they gained Philip as an ally, and that Philip entered Thessaly and overthrew the tyrants. Diodorus states that because Philip showed such goodwill to the Thessalians they became not only his allies, but also allies to his son Alexander. 
See also oath id 2951.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: Corinth began to think about returning to the Peloponnesian League
statement:
[That they will stand by this alliance according to its terms, justly, innocently, and guilelessly, and will not transgress it in any way or by any means whatsoever]
 ἐμμενῶ τῇ ξυμμαχίᾳ κατὰ τὰ ξυγκείμενα δικαίως καὶ ἀβλαβῶς καὶ ἀδόλως, καὶ οὐ παραβήσομαι τέχνῃ οὐδὲ μηχανῇ οὐδεμιᾷ.
remarks:
This text records the so-called Argive alliance. 
Thucydides indicates that each city will swear the oath that is most binding in their land. The Athenians were to swear on behalf of their allies, whereas the Argives, Mantineans, Eleans, and their allies were to swear individually by state. 
It is stipulated that for the renewal of the oath the Athenians will travel to Elis, Mantinea, and Argos, thirty days before the Olympic games, and the Argives, Eleans and Mantineans will travel to Athens ten days before the Great Panathenaea. 
Thucydides states that the Corinthians did not join (literally ξυνώμοσαν) this offensive and defensive alliance, but were content with their first alliance with Argos (see oath id 1698) which was defensive only. This makes it clear that the parties involved in this alliance agreed to aid one another and to join in each other's wars whether such wars were defensive or not. 
For this system of alliances, which Thucydides describes as the "Argive alliance," see also oath id 233, 1692, 1697, 1705, 1711, 1724, 1731, 1732, 1742, 1748, 1913, 2886, 3836, 3837, 3838, 3839, 3840, 3841, 3842, 3843, 3844, 3845, 3846, 3847, 3848, 3858, 3859, 3860.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the child/wineskin is very small]
 Μικρὸν νὴ Δία.
remarks: As Sommerstein notes ad loc., this statement is spoken sarcastically. One could say, with Austin & Olson, that “what is ‘small’ for a child is not so small for a wineskin”; i.e. Inlaw would be saying “yes, it certainly is small – for a child!”.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the mutilation of the Hermae was thought to have been part of a conspiracy (i.e. a swearing together) to bring about a revolution and to overthrow the democracy.  There certainly must have been a conspiracy behind this systematic attack on one particular kind of sacred objects all over the city, but there is no good reason to believe that the contemporary public perception of the conspirators' motives was accurate. 
See also oath id 1780, 1782, and Andocides 1.34-68.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
statement: [That the Greeks would not leave until they had sacked Troy]
remarks: There is no specific oath sworn to this effect within the Iliad, nor any specific reference to such an oath. Here Nestor mentions oaths in general in response to the Achaeans threatening to leave Troy, but earlier in the same book at 2.284-288 Odysseus has referred to a promise made by the Achaeans in Greece not to leave Troy until it was sacked. This promise was made presumably in Aulis, since this was the only place in which all the Greeks were gathered together. The "oath" then seems to be an oath in a loose "Sophoclean" sense where a promise is retrospectively upgraded to an oath for rhetorical purposes. For the "Sophoclean oath" phenomenon, cf. oath ids 236, 263, 270, 285, 289, 292.

author: Pindar
title: Nemean 11
statement:
[That Aristagoras would have been victorious in wrestling also at the Pythian or Olympian games]
 ναὶ μὰ γὰρ ὅρκον, ἐμὰν δόξαν παρὰ Κασταλίᾳ
καὶ παρ’ εὐδένδρῳ μολὼν ὄχθῳ Κρόνου  
κάλλιον ἂν δηρῐώντων ἐνόστησ’ ἀντιπάλων
remarks: Pindar swears here literally "by his oath", but this may also be an invocation of Horkos, the oath god. Pindar also swears in his authorial persona at ids 1312, 1313, 1315, 1317, 1319.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Menecles
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker concludes by asking the jurors to remember the law and the oath they have sworn, and the arguments, and to give a decision which is just and consistent with their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
if_taken: They will be part of the conspiracy
if_refused: They will not be part of the conspiracy
statement: [That they would conspire against Athens]
remarks: Here Paphlagon threatens to go to the Council and expose the conspiracies that have been hatched by the Sausage-seller and Demosthenes, including a specific reference to a conspiracy with the Medes (i.e. Persians) and their king. Although  a conspiracy against the people has been mentioned (see oath id 975), there is no reason to suppose that the characters are to be thought of as having entered into a sworn conspiracy with the Persians. As Sommerstein ad 478 comments: "In point of fact, contact with Persia, far from being evidence of "conspiracy", was in 425/4 the policy of the Athenian state (Thuc. 4. 50. 3), and in view of the strength of Cleon's influence at the time this policy would hardly have been started or continued against his advice; but Athenian hatred of "medism" was so ingrained that an accusation of it might inflame popular prejudice against those accused even when Athens was hoping to make Persia her ally".

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That he would not attack Charidemus as he withdrew]
remarks:
Euthycles states that Memnon and Mentor persuaded their father-in-law Artabazus to allow Charidemus to leave his strongholds (Scepsis, Cebren and Ilium) under a truce. 
See also oath id 3467, 3468.

author: Epicrates
title: Choros
statement:
[That the girl being offered was a young like a heifer, a virgin, and an untamed filly]
 τελέως μ’ ὑπῆλθεν ἡ κατάρατος μαστροπός,
ἐπομνύουσα τὰν Κόραν, τὰν Ἄρτεμιν, 
τὰν Φερρέφατταν, ὡς δάμαλις, ὡς παρθένος,
ὡς πῶλος ἀδμής· ἡ δ’ ἄρ’ ἦν μυωνιὰ
remarks: The girl being offered turns out, in fact, to be a “mousehole”! The swearer is a Doric speaker – and nevertheless, when swearing by the same goddess for the second time under a different name, she pronounces that name in the Attic way.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
impact: Phalaecus and his men withdrew to the Peloponnese
statement: [That Phalaecus and his men would be allowed to depart in safety wherever they pleased if the Phocians agreed to demolish their city walls]
remarks:
Aeschines refers to the truce between Philip and Phalaecus. 
See also Diod. 16.59.3, and oath id 2626, 3749.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That the god will be doing something of great value for the whole Greek people if he brings evil destruction on informers]
 Νὴ τὸν Δία τὸν σωτῆρα, πολλοῦ γ’ ἄξιος 
  ἅπασι τοῖς Ἕλλησιν ὁ θεὸς οὗτος, εἰ 
  τοὺς συκοφάντας ἐξολεῖ κακοὺς κακῶς.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That (Socrates thinks) Critobulus will not enter the beauty contest because he probably notices that the procurer (i.e. Socrates) is favoured by the judges]
 Ὁ δὲ Καλλίας ἔφη· Σὺ δὲ δή, ὦ Κριτόβουλε, εἰς τὸν περὶ τοῦ κάλλους ἀγῶνα πρὸς Σωκράτην οὐκ ἀνθίστασαι; Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, ἴσως γὰρ εὐδοκιμοῦντα τὸν μαστροπὸν παρὰ τοῖς κριταῖς ὁρᾷ.
remarks: In fact, Socrates is wrong. Critobulus replies that, in spite of this, he does not avoid the contest.

author: Hypereides
title: In defence of Euxenippus
statement:
[That it is wrong to maintain, as Polyeuctus did in his prosecution speech, that defendants ought not to rely on the eisangelia law]
 οὐ μὰ Δία οὐχ ὥσπερ ἐν τῇ κατηγορίᾳ Πολύευκτος ἔλεγεν, οὐ̣ φάσκων δεῖν τοὺς ἀπολογουμένους ἰσχυρίζεσθαι τῷ εἰσαγγελτικῷ νόμωι,
remarks: Polyeuctus had evidently anticipated that the defence would use the argument that the clause of the eisangelia law which he had used to prosecute Euxenippus - that concerned with "taking bribes to speak against the best interests of the Athenian people" - applied only to political speakers, as indeed its language made clear.

author: Ephippus
title: Homoioi or Obeliaphoroi
if_broken: That the swearer may be forced to learn by heart dramas by Dionysius and Demophon's poem about Cotys; that Theodorus may recite speeches to him over dinner; that he may live next door to Laches; and that he may have Euripides as a dinner guest and supply him with cups.  (There may have been some further self-curses preceding and/or following this list.)
impact: strongly emphasizes whatever statement was being made
statement: unknown
remarks: From this oath there survive only the curses (or some of them) which the swearer imprecates on himself if the oath is false/broken.  Dionysius is Dionysius I, tyrant of Syracuse, who dabbled in dramatic composition and won a first prize at Athens in 367; see R.L. Hunter, Eubulus: The Fragments (Cambridge, 1983) 116-7.  Cotys ruled the Odrysian kingdom in Thrace from about 384 to 358.  Theodorus was a famous actor; the point of this curse may be that in the confined space of a dining-room his voice would be too powerful for comfort.  The same may be implied by the reference to Laches, who was a politician (still active in the 320s).  Euripides is not the poet, but a contemporary, well known at symposia, who is described in Ephippus fr. 9 (cf. Anaxandrides fr. 33) as being "at war with cups" (because he stole them? because he broke them?)

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement:
[That if he learns rhetoric, he's willing to be disembowelled]
 κεἰ βούλονται,
  νὴ τὴν Δήμητρ’ ἔκ μου χορδὴν 
  τοῖς φροντισταῖς παραθέντων.
remarks: Circumstances for keeping the oath do not arise.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the soldiers do not just have leisure to do exercise, they are obliged to exercise]
 Ἦ καὶ σχολή, ἔφη, ὦ πάτερ, ἔσται, σωμασκεῖν τοῖς στρατιώταις; Οὐ μὰ Δι’, ἔφη ὁ πατήρ, οὐ μόνον γε, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἀνάγκη.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Astyphilus
statement: [That he is telling the truth i.e. that the will was deposited with him]
remarks:
The speaker alleges that Hierocles saw Thudippus strike Euthycrates, and calls for him to be summoned to give evidence or swear the oath of ignorance (the exomosia).  
Hierocles swears the exomosia, after which the speaker goes on to say that it is in keeping with Hierocles' character to swear that he is ignorant of facts he knows, yet give his (sworn) pledge to the truth of what did not really happen (i.e. that Astyphilus adopted Cleon as his heir and deposited a will with Hierocles). 
See also oath id 3167 and 3168.

author: Euripides
title: Orestes
impact: Proves Pylades' conviction in his plan to kill Helen
statement:
[That he will draw his dark sword against Helen]
 μὴ γὰρ οὖν ζώιην ἔτι,
  εἰ μὴ ’π’ ἐκείνηι φάσγανον σπάσω μέλαν.
remarks: Unlike the other plays which deal with the saga of Orestes, here Pylades is very active in word and deed, more so, in fact, than Orestes.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aphobus 3
statement: [That it was not true that Milyas was not a slave and that Aphobus had acknowledged that fact]
remarks:
Demosthenes states that Aesius, the brother of Aphobus, was the first witness to testify that Milyas was not a slave and that Aphobus had acknowledged this fact. He argues that even though Aesius now denies it because he is supporting Aphobus in the current trial, he gave his evidence at the previous trial because he did not wish to perjure himself or immediately incur a penalty. 
Why would Aesius have been at risk of perjuring himself if he did not give the evidence in question?  Presumably because he would have had to swear an exomosia that he did not know the evidence to be true (as in oath id 3521)?

title: IG II(2)
swearer: [---] of Coile; Sopolis, son of Kephisodoros, of Cydanthenaeon; [---] of Anaphlystus; [---] of Kephisia
swearee: Representatives of the newly allied state
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[That they would assist their new allies with all their strength]
 [- - - - β]οηθ[ήσω - - - -]
[- - - -]σι παν[τὶ σθένει - - -]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and another state. The other party to this alliance cannot be identified. 
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 39.79 and 45.68. This text has been assigned to the "Cutter of IG II(2) 105" by Steven Tracy. This mason was active from 368 to 339. Kirchner dated this text as "ante 336/5".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would defend each other in the event of their being wronged by their enemies, but that the Camarinaeans would receive the Athenians only if they put in with a single ship, unless they themselves sent for more]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Athenians sent an embassy to Camarina in 415 in the hope of winning them over to their cause on the strength of the alliance made "in the time of Laches" i.e. in 427. 
The Syracusans sent a counter embassy to convince the Camarinaeans to continue to support them. 
For other references to the alliance between Athens and Camarina see oath id 1774, 1789, 1790 and 1791.

author: Sophocles
title: Antigone
impact: Prompts the guard to defend himself
statement:
[That if the guard and his colleagues do not find the perpetrator of the burial rite and bring him before Creon, they will be hung up alive until they disclose the crime]
 ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ἴσχει Ζεὺς ἔτ’ ἐξ ἐμοῦ σέβας,
εὖ τοῦτ’ ἐπίστασ’, ὅρκιος δέ σοι λέγω, 
εἰ μὴ τὸν αὐτόχειρα τοῦδε τοῦ τάφου
εὑρόντες ἐκφανεῖτ’ ἐς ὀφθαλμοὺς ἐμούς,
οὐχ ὑμὶν ῞Αιδης μοῦνος ἀρκέσει, πρὶν ἂν
ζῶντες κρεμαστοὶ τήνδε δηλώσηθ’ ὕβριν,
ἵν’ εἰδότες τὸ κέρδος ἔνθεν οἰστέον 
τὸ λοιπὸν ἁρπάζητε, καὶ μάθηθ’ ὅτι
οὐκ ἐξ ἅπαντος δεῖ τὸ κερδαίνειν φιλεῖν.
remarks: In fact the guard does bring the perpetrator of the deed before Creon, so there is no need for the fulfilment of the threat.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
date: During the lifetime of Lycurgus (900 to 775)
swearee: Other members of the sworn band
if_taken: He could be part of a sworn band
if_refused: He could not be part of a sworn band
statement: [? That he would fight while he was alive, and would not regard being alive as more important than being free; that he would not leave his taxiarch or his enomotarch, whether he was alive or dead, and that he would bury the dead among his fellow-fighters, and that he would leave no-one unburied]
remarks:
Herodotus states that Lycurgus established all that related to war at Sparta: the "sworn companies" (the enomotiai), the bands of thirty, and the common messes. 
The date (and the very existence) of Lycurgus is open to debate. Herodotus names Lycurgus as the guardian of the Agiad king Leobotes (ca.900), but most later writers associate him with the Eurypontid king Charillos (ca.775). 
However, it seems most likely that the reforms to the Spartan constitution took place much later during the sixth century. 
For this oath see Hans van Wees, "The Oath of the Sworn Bands, the Acharnae stele, the Oath of Plataea and archaic Spartan warfare", in A. Luther. M. Meier, & L. Thommen (eds.), Das Fruhe Sparta, Franz Steiner, Stuttgart 2006, pp.125-64. 
See also oath id 1744, 1977, 2224, 2232, 2233, 2234, 3650.

author: Aristophanes
title: Acharnians
impact: Leads to the sale of the "pigs"
statement:
[That the "porkers" are a nice pair of beasts]
 Νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἀστείω γε τὼ βοσκήματε.
remarks: On the pun "porker", see also oath ids 611-615.

author: Aristotle
title: Politics
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Aristotle discusses monarchy in the heroic age and explains how kings gave judgements sometimes on oath and sometimes not, and that the oath was taken by raising up the sceptre. Aristotle is doubtless thinking of such passages in the Iliad- see oath ids 312, 345 and 349.

author: Herodotus
title: The Histories
impact: Darius agreed to send Histiaeus to Ionia
statement:
[That he would not take off the tunic he was wearing until he had made Sardo (Sardinia) the largest of the islands tributary to Darius]
μὴ μὲν πρότερον ἐκδύσεσθαι τὸν ἔχων κιθῶνα καταβήσομαι ἐς Ἰωνίην πρὶν ἄν τοι Σαρδὼ νῆσον τὴν μεγίστην δασμοφόρον ποιήσω.
remarks:
Histiaeus swears by the kingly gods (θεοὺς ἐπόμνυμι τοὺς βασιληίους ) i.e. the gods of Darius. 
Darius had previously summoned Histiaeus to Susa. Histiaeus left Aristagoras to rule Miletus in his absence, but wished to return to Ionia.  
When Darius learned that Aristagoras had led the Ionians to revolt and had sacked Sardis, he complained to Histiaeus about the fact that the man he had placed in charge in Miletus was leading the revolt. 
Histiaeus asked to be sent to Ionia so that he might restore the country to peace and deliver Aristagoras into the hands of Darius. His oath followed this request. 
Herodotus goes on to say that Histiaeus was deceiving Darius. His oath only applied when (or if) he had settled the affairs of Ionia in the manner in which the king wished and handed Aristagoras over to Darius as a prisoner; he did not in fact do these things (and had not sworn to do them!), so his oath never became effective.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Seuthes of Thrace. 
For details of this alliance brought about by Thrasybulus, see also Xenophon, Hellenica 4.8.26 (oath id 1953) and Diodorus 14.94.2.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
impact: The Spartans and their allies returned home
statement:
[That they would remain at peace for a certain time, provided neither the Orneates nor the Argives would injure each other's territory]
 σπεισάμενοί τινα χρόνον ὥστε μὴ ἀδικεῖν Ὀρνεάτας καὶ Ἀργείους τὴν ἀλλήλων
remarks: Thucydides states that the Spartans and their allies (except the Corinthians) invaded Argive territory, ravaged the land, and settled the oligarchic exiles at Orneae. They left a small body of troops with them, and made a truce for a certain time, on condition that neither the Orneates nor the Argives were to injure each other's territory.  It is not clear whether this truce was still in force when, "not long afterwards", an Argive-Athenian expedition laid siege to Orneae and, finding on the second day that the garrison and inhabitants had fled during the night, proceeded to demolish the place (Thuc. 6.7.2).

author: Lysias
title: On overthrowing democracy
swearer: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
swearee: The men of the Piraeus; The men of the asty
statement: [That they would not recall grievances against any citizens except the Thirty <and the Ten> and the Eleven, and not even against any of these who is willing to render account of the office he conducted]
remarks:
The speaker reminds the jurors that they decided to receive back exiles, restored citizen rights to those who lost them, and swore oaths about homonoia with the rest. 
See also oath id 1796.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That the archer ought to use his whip on anyone who approaches]
 ἀλλὰ τὴν μάστιγ’ ἔχων
  παῖ’, ἢν προσίῃ τις.
  {ΚΡ.}  Νὴ Δί’

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement: n/a
remarks: Here Hermogenes explains that he keeps the gods on his side by never lying when he invokes them as witnesses; cf. oath id 2261.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That her way of life does not involve the privations described in lines 535-546]
  Ἀλλ’ οὐχ οὑμὸς τοῦτο πέπονθεν βίος οὐ μὰ Δί’, οὐδέ γε μέλλει.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That fear of financial loss or poverty or fear of dishonour and a bad reputation would not be worthy motives for a philosopher to abstain from bodily desires (unlike the desire for the soul to be pure)]
 οὔ τι οἰκοφθορίαν τε καὶ πενίαν φοβούμενοι, ὥσπερ οἱ πολλοὶ καὶ φιλοχρήματοι· οὐδὲ αὖ ἀτιμίαν τε καὶ ἀδοξίαν μοχθηρίας δεδιότες, ὥσπερ οἱ φίλαρχοί τε καὶ φιλότιμοι, ἔπειτα ἀπέχονται αὐτῶν. Οὐ γὰρ ἂν πρέποι, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, ὁ Κέβης. Οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς.

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]

title: CID I
statement:
[That they would judge the cases so that they might make just decision - - - - - concerning judgements cancelled by themselves and they would not profit unfairly from the cases in any way - - - - - they would pass sentences within  their power - - - - - to/by the one chosen, and not from the money of the Amphyctiones - - - - - not themselves, nor combined with others, and they would not give the public money to others - - - - - ]
 Δικα̣[ξῶ τ]ὰς δ[ίκ]ας ὥς κα̣ δ[ικ]αιοτά̣τα̣[ι γ]νώμα[ι, τ]ὰ̣ μὲγ γε[γρ]αμμ[ένα - - - - - e.g. τὰ δὲ ἄ]γρα[πτα? κ]α̣τὰ(γ) γνώμαν τὰν αὑτο̣ῦ̣ καὶ [ο]ὐ̣ κ̣ερδ̣α̣ν̣ῶ τᾶν δ[ικ]ᾶν οὐ[δεμιᾶι ? - - - - - τὰ καταδικασθέντα ἐκπραξέω ἐν δύνασιν - - - - - τῶι  ἑ[λ]όντ[ι] οὐδὲ τῶν [χ]ρημάτων τῶ[ν] Ἀμφικτιονικῶν - - [- - - οὔτ’ αὐτὸς ἐγὼ οὔτ’ ἄλλος] ἐμίγγα οὐδ’ ἄλλωι δωσ[ῶ] τῶγ κοινῶν χρημάτων - - [- - - οὕτως ποὶ] τ[ο̃] Ἀπόλλωνος τοῦ Π[υ]θίου καὶ τᾶς Λατο̃ς καὶ τᾶς Ἀρτά̣[μιτος ὑπίσχομαι καὶ εὐορκέοντι μέμ μοι πολ]λὰ καὶ τἀγαθά, αἰ δ’ ἐφιορκέ(οιμι), τὰ κακὰ ἀντί τῶν ἀγαθῶν
remarks:
This text was previously published as IG II(2) 1126. 
 For the oath of the secretary see oath id 930.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timocrates
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus asks what the Athenians will say for themselves if they allow Timocrates' law to be confirmed. He asks if they will say that their juries, composed under democracy of men who have sworn the oath, are guilty of the same crimes as courts under the Thirty Tyrants. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Euripides
title: Bacchae
statement:
[That Dionysus will be a concern for Dirce (i.e. Thebes) in the future] 
  ἔτι ναὶ τὰν βοτρυώδη
  Διονύσου χάριν οἴνας 
  ἔτι σοι τοῦ Βρομίου μελήσει.
remarks: Literally, the oath is sworn "by the grape-clustered joy of Dionysus' vine". This oath shows that the whole of Thebes will suffer as a result of Pentheus' actions.

author: Plato
title: Ion
statement:
[That he has never seen anyone who can only express judgement and be attentive to the work of a single painter but dozes off when anyone shows the work of other painters]
 Ἤδη οὖν τινα εἶδες ὅστις περὶ μὲν Πολυγνώτου τοῦ Ἀγλαοφῶντος δεινός ἐστιν ἀποφαίνειν ἃ εὖ τε γράφει καὶ ἃ μή, περὶ δὲ τῶν ἄλλων γραφέων ἀδύνατος; καὶ ἐπειδὰν μέν τις τὰ τῶν ἄλλων ζωγράφων ἔργα ἐπιδεικνύῃ, νυστάζει τε καὶ ἀπορεῖ καὶ οὐκ ἔχει ὅτι συμβάληται, ἐπειδὰν δὲ περὶ Πολυγνώτου ἢ ἄλλου ὅτου βούλει τῶν γραφέων ἑνὸς μόνου δέῃ ἀποφήνασθαι γνώμην, ἐγρήγορέν τε καὶ προσέχει τὸν νοῦν καὶ εὐπορεῖ ὅτι εἴπῃ; {ΙΩΝ.} Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, οὐ δῆτα.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Zenothemis
statement:
[That it pains him to bring the suit against Zenothemis]
 ἀχθόμενος μὲν νὴ τὸν Δία καὶ θεούς
remarks: Demon imagines that the jurors will wonder why he is bringing the suit against Zenothemis, and explains that it pains him to do so, but he must do so.

author: Isaeus
title: On the estate of Astyphilus
if_taken: He can proceed with his case
if_refused: He cannot proceed with his case
statement: [That the facts in his written statement were true]
remarks: The speaker begins by referring to his antomosia which stated that the deceased did not adopt a son, did not bequeath his property, and left no will.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Swings the argument in Euripides' favour
statement:
[That returning is the same thing as remigrating]
 ἥκειν δὲ ταὐτόν ἐστι τῷ κατέρχομαι. 
  ΔΙ.  Νὴ τὸν Δί’,
remarks: Euripides is taking issue here with the phrasing of the opening lines of Aeschylus' Choephoroi. See also oath ids 496 and 505. Aeschylus explains that the two words are different because the second, but not the first, can refer only to a person returning from exile - and changes Dionysus' mind so completely that Dionysus swears an oath (oath id 496) which contradicts the one he swears here.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That he remembers hearing his father say that only those who had made the best of themselves should ask for blessings from the gods]
 παρέχοντας οὖν τοιούτους ἑαυτοὺς οἵους δεῖ, οὕτως ἡμῖν ἐδόκει δεῖν καὶ αἰτεῖσθαι τἀγαθὰ παρὰ τῶν θεῶν; Ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Κῦρος, μέμνημαι μέντοι τοιαῦτα ἀκούσας σου·

author: Aristophanes
title: Clouds
statement: [That (he thinks) Strepsiades is out of his mind]
remarks: Strepsiades here refers to the oath sworn by Pheidippides at 817, and ridicules his invocation of Zeus.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That he will do his best to understand why some people are hopeless at farming]
 Ἐγώ σε ἄξω καὶ ἐπὶ τούτους, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης·
σὺ δὲ θεώμενος δήπου καταμαθήσῃ. Νὴ Δί’, ἔφη

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Tyrannus
statement:
[That the killer of Laius is not living in his house with his knowledge]
 ἐπεύχομαι δ’, οἴκοισιν εἰ ξυνέστιος
ἐν τοῖς ἐμοῖς γένοιτ’ ἐμοῦ ξυνειδότος,
παθεῖν ἅπερ τοῖσδ’ ἀρτίως ἠρασάμην
remarks: Lines 246-51 are deleted in the OCT, but if the lines are not by Sophocles, it's likely that they are the work of a fourth century producer. If 246-251 is indeed to be deleted, then Oedipus nowhere in this speech curses himself, not even unintentionally.  He does curse anyone who fails to cooperate in the search for the killer (269-272), having already decreed that anyone (whether the killer himself, or another) who knows the killer's identity and fails to reveal it shall be banished and outlawed (presumably we are to understand "if and when the truth is discovered", otherwise how will anyone know who has violated the decree?).  That decree is, of course, the background to his bullying of Teiresias in 316-349; he forgets it with remarkable speed when Teiresias does tell him who the killer is!

author: Plato
title: Apologia
if_taken: He will be allowed to proceed with charges
if_refused: He will not be allowed to proceed with charges
statement:
[That Socrates is guilty of corrupting the young, and of not acknowledging the god the city acknowledges, but new divinities instead]
 λάβωμεν αὖ τὴν τούτων ἀντωμοσίαν. ἔχει δέ πως ὧδε· Σωκράτη φησὶν ἀδικεῖν τούς τε νέους διαφθείροντα καὶ θεοὺς οὓς ἡ πόλις  νομίζει οὐ νομίζοντα, ἕτερα δὲ δαιμόνια καινά.
remarks: Meletus certainly believes his statement to be true. Cf. oath id 2775.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That the kind of person who causes strife and wishes to provide his friends with many enemies must be avoided]
 ὅστις στασιώδης τέ ἐστι καὶ θέλων πολλοὺς τοῖς φίλοις ἐχθροὺς παρέχειν; Φευκτέον νὴ Δία καὶ τοῦτον.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
Andocides observes that the Athenians swore oaths to the Spartans (i.e. the peace treaty and alliance of 404), and got them to agree to a stone inscription of the terms, which, he argues, was the least infliction they could have expected in the circumstances.  
Andocides observes that the Athenians initially observed the treaty on the specified terms, but later made an alliance with Boeotia and Corinth, detaching these from the Spartans, and resumed their friendship with Argos. 
See also oath id 1893.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Callippus
if_taken: He can give a valid verdict
if_refused: His verdict will be a nullity
statement: [? That they would give a true verdict]
remarks: Apollodorus complains that when Lysitheides was chosen to arbitrate their dispute, Callippus persuaded him to render his decision without swearing an oath, despite his protest that he must give his decision in accordance with the laws. He goes on to argue that Lysitheides' decision would have been different if he had been deciding the dispute between Callippus and his father Pasion, for Lysitheides liked Pasion, but dislikes Apollodorus. He states that Lysitheides would not have wronged Pasion, "with or without an oath", and suggests that while he was happy to wrong Apollodorus without an oath, he would not have been happy to do so had he been forced to swear an oath. He concludes by arguing that this is why Lysitheides made his decision without taking an oath.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That he would not molest the Athenians while they collected their dead]
remarks:
Brasidas granted the Athenians a truce for two days, during which time he fortified the houses nearby and the Athenians strengthened their defences. As soon as the truce had expired Brasidas began assaulting the Athenian position. 
See also oath id 1674.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement: [That they would act in the best way possible for the bird community]
remarks: Here the Chorus of birds are horrified by Tereus' acceptance of the two humans into his domain. In response, they accuse him of having broken the sworn oath of birds. Dunbar ad loc. suggests that 332 "might well suggest the ephebic oath of loyalty to the city taken by all male Athenians on reaching the age of 18".

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 1
statement:
[That he believes that Philip is drunk with the magnitude of his own achievements and dreams of further triumphs since he finds that no one is barring his way]
 ἐγὼ δ’ οἶμαι μέν, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς ἐκεῖνον μεθύειν τῷ μεγέθει τῶν πεπραγμένων καὶ πολλὰ τοιαῦτ’ ὀνειροπολεῖν ἐν τῇ γνώμῃ, τήν τ’ ἐρημίαν τῶν κωλυσόντων ὁρῶντα καὶ τοῖς πεπραγμένοις ἐπῃρμένον,

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That their affliction (i.e. being ithyphallic) is worse than being seized with cramp in the early hours (rather they are absolutely done for)]
 Ἦ που πρὸς ὄρθρον σπασμὸς ὑμᾶς λαμβάνει; 
{ΑΘ. α} Μὰ Δί’ ἀλλὰ ταυτὶ δρῶντες ἐπιτετρίμμεθα.

author: Aeschylus
title: Eumenides
statement: n/a
remarks: Apollo argues that appointed marriage between a man and a woman is greater than oaths and is guarded by divine justice.

author: Aristophanes
title: Thesmophoriazusae
statement:
[That he does not see himself (in the mirror), he sees Cleisthenes]
  Ὁρᾷς σεαυτόν; 
  {ΚΗ.}  Οὐ μὰ Δί’, ἀλλὰ Κλεισθένη.
remarks: He sees Cleisthenes, as he says, because his beard had been shaved off. Cleisthenes was noted for not having a beard, when most Athenian men had one.

author: Aristotle
title: Rhetoric
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a complex discussion concerning oath challenges (cf. oath id 1728) and how to manipulate them. There are four possibilities. 1) to tender an oath and take one. 2) to do neither of these things. 3) to tender an oath and not take one, or 4) to take but not tender. In fact there are two kinds of oath challenges- those volunteered, and those tendered. There are real reasons for not wanting the other side to swear- men are too ready to commit perjury, and if the opponent does not swear, the jury will probably condemn him. One can trust jurors more than opponents. Aristotle tries to find valid arguments for refusing an opponent's oath-challenge (e.g. that the oath is only to be taken with a view to money), but in reality no one could do this convincingly, and litigants who have refused such a challenge normally avoid discussing the matter in their speeches. There follows advice regarding what to say when taking an oath or issuing an oath challenge. Taking an oath, one may claim confidence in oneself, but not in one's opponent, and one may argue that the only fair thing is for the impious man to tender the oath and the pious man to take it, and that it would be terrible to refuse an oath, while demanding that the judges take one before giving their verdict. This last point should also be mentioned on tendering oaths, along with a declaration of faith in the gods as judges. Aristotle also argues that if one has already taken an oath which contradicts the present one, it can be argued that the previous oath was taken by error or under compulsion; whereas if it is the opponent who has taken an oath which he now contradicts, it can be said that one who does not abide by what he swore subverts everything, for this is the reason the dikasts take an oath before applying the laws, and the opponent can be accused of demanding the judges' adherence to their oaths while himself not abiding by his.

title: IG II(2)
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
remarks:
This inscription records an alliance between Athens and Corcyra under the auspices of the so-called Second Athenian Confederacy. 
The decree indicates that three or five Athenians were to be chosen to receive the oaths of the new allies (see also oath id 356 and 357). For the oath of the Athenians see oath id 353. For the oath of the existing allies of Athens see oath id 354. 
For other references to the Second Athenian Confederacy see oath id 2974.

author: Anonymus Homericus
title: Hymn to Hermes
statement:
[That he will introduce Hermes to the immortals to enjoy prestige and fortune, he will give him fine gifts and never deceive him]
 ναὶ μὰ τόδε κρανέϊνον ἀκόντιον ἦ μὲν ἐγώ σε 
κυδρὸν ἐν ἀθανάτοισι καὶ ὄλβιον ἡγεμονεύσω,
δώσω τ’ ἀγλαὰ δῶρα καὶ ἐς τέλος οὐκ ἀπατήσω.
remarks: Apollo swears this oath to encourage Hermes to divulge from where he received his divine gifts. There is a significant contrast between the deceptive Hermes and Apollo who will never deceive.

title: Meiggs and Lewis, GHI
statement: [? That the land belonged to him]
remarks:
This law provided that no land or houses could be handed over to a board of mnemones in the year of Apollonides (which was either about to start, or had started recently). If anyone wished to bring a suit about land or houses within a period of 18 months, existing procedures would apply whereby the jurors would swear that "what the mnemones know shall be binding". (see oath id 1048). After this period of 18 months has expired, those who held property in the year of Apollonides are to be regarded as the legal owners, and if their title is disputed they are only required to substantiate their claim by an oath. This oath was to be administered by the jurors in the presence of the adversary.  
The text also stipulates that any Halicarnassian who abides by this law may bring a case, according to the oath taken and agreements recorded in the temple of Apollo. For this oath see oath id 1050.

author: Plato
title: Lysis
statement:
[That his parents would not allow him to drive one of his father's chariots in a race, if he wished to do so]
 ἢν ἐπιθυμήσῃς ἐπί τινος τῶν τοῦ πατρὸς ἁρμάτων ὀχεῖσθαι λαβὼν τὰς ἡνίας, ὅταν ἁμιλλᾶται, οὐκ ἂν ἐῷέν σε ἀλλὰ διακωλύοιεν;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐ μέντοι ἄν, ἔφη, ἐῷεν.

author: Alexis
title: Protochoros
statement:
[That he has never undertaken a more toilsome task in all his days as a parasite]
 ἐπιπονώτερον
ἔργον μὰ τὸν Διόνυσον οὐκ εἴληφ’ ἐγώ,
ἀφ’ οὗ παρασιτῶ.
