remarks: Apparently the "toilsome task" is having to dine with someone who couldn’t speak Attic! – the assumption no doubt being that only Athenians can make witty conversation over food and drink.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Androtion
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Diodorus asks the jurors to listen carefully to what he says to make sure they are not deceived by the rhetorical skills of Androtion and persuaded to vote contrary to their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of the allies; Envoys
swearee: Representatives; Representatives of the allies; Envoys

author: Xenophon
title: Lacedaemonian Politeia (except ch.14)
date: During the experience of Xenophon (399 to 355)
statement:
[That he will reign according to the established laws of the polis]
 κατὰ τοὺς τῆς πόλεως κειμένους νόμους βασιλεύσειν
remarks:
Xenophon states that every month the Spartan kings and Ephors exchange oaths. 
The kings swear to rule according to the laws of the polis, and the Ephors swear on behalf of the polis that while the kings abide by their oaths they will keep the kingship unshaken. 
For the corresponding oath sworn by the ephors on behalf of the polis see oath id 2236; and cf. Plato's Laws- oath id 2678.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Ctesiphon
statement:
[That Demosthenes passed his time not in hunting wild boar, nor in tending to his physical fitness, but in practising verbal techniques for use against men with property]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ τὸν Δία τὸν Ὀλύμπιον οὐχ ὗς ἀγρίους κυνηγετῶν, οὐδὲ τῆς τοῦ σώματος εὐεξίας ἐπιμελόμενος, ἀλλ’ ἐπασκῶν τέχνας ἐπὶ τοὺς τὰς οὐσίας κεκτημένους διαγεγένηται.
remarks:
Aeschines asks the jurors to think about those who will support Demosthenes. He asks if they are his companions in hunting or the gymnasium when he was young, and answers his question with this oath. 
The "men of property" against whom he was then practising "verbal techniques" were, of course, the guardians who had cheated him out of most of his father's estate.

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
statement:
[That the wrong-doings of the Armenians give Cyrus reason to distust them]
 Ἀλλὰ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Κῦρε, ἔχει μὲν προφάσεις τὰ ἡμέτερα ἁμαρτήματα ὥστ’ ἀπιστεῖν ἡμῖν·
remarks: Tigranes goes on to invite Cyrus to build forts in Armenia and occupy those strongholds already in place as he sees fit, and to take whatever else he wishes as security.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he will not let Paphlagon speak first]
  Μὰ τὸν Ποσειδῶ
remarks: Swearing by Poseidon is a stronger informal oath than swearing by Zeus. Here the Sausage-seller invokes Poseidon to emphasise the statement (over Paphlagon's invocation of Zeus). See also oath ids 987, 988, 989.

author: Plato
title: Gorgias
statement:
[That he does not know what Socrates means]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ Δί’ οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅτι λέγεις.

author: Euripides
title: Supplices
statement:
[That he would sack Thebes whether god willed it or not]
 οὔ τἄρ’ ἔτ’ ὀρθῶς Καπανέως κεραύνιον
  δέμας καπνοῦται, κλιμάκων ὀρθοστάτας
  ὃς προσβαλὼν πύλαισιν ὤμοσεν πόλιν
  πέρσειν θεοῦ θέλοντος ἤν τε μὴ θέληι
remarks: No person of sound mind could seriously believe in the validity of an oath sworn in defiance of the gods' will, self-contradictorily praying to the gods to punish him if he does NOT defy them! The language is similar to that ascribed to Capaneus in Aeschylus, Seven against Thebes 427-9, but his boast is not there expressed as an oath. There it is Parthenopaeus who swears in defiance of the gods- see oath id 199.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Boeotus 1
if_taken: Her statement will carry more weight
statement:
[That if Mantias should propose an oath regarding the paternity of Boeotus, she would refuse it, and that, when this had been done, all relations between them would be at an end]
 ἐὰν ὅρκον αὐτῇ διδῷ περὶ τούτων, μὴ ὀμεῖσθαι, τούτων δὲ πραχθέντων οὐδὲν ἔτ’ ἔσεσθαι αὐτοῖς
remarks: Mantitheus alleges that Plangon swore this oath to Mantias on the understanding that she would receive a sum of money (thirty minas) lodged with a third party if she refused the oath when he offered it to her (see oath id 3575). However, when Mantias offered Plangon the oath, she accepted it and swore that Boeotus and Pamphilos were her sons by Mantias (see also oath id 3562).

title: IG IV
statement: The statement is unknown.
remarks:
The statement is unknown. Although this decree is very fragmentary it is clear that four lines (2, 4-6) refer to oaths. Line 4 indicates that an official would receive oaths, line 5 seems to be what remains of the statement of a penalty for violating an oath, and line 6 seems to indicate that the oath shall be binding if someone desires or is willing to do something. These four lines are as follows: <o> 
2) [ὑ]πὸ τοῖν hόρϞια 
4) δέξεται τὸς hόρϞος 
5) αἴτ’ hόρϞον ὅτι ἁ ὠφέλε[ια - - - αἴτ’ hόρϞον ὅτι] 
6) - - hόρϞος ἐνδέτο, αἰ λο̃(ο)ι τὸν το - - - </o> 
This reference takes into account textual changes in SEG 27.38.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes catalogues what the Thebans have gained from the peace in order to highlight what the peace has cost Athens. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see also oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Phaedo
statement:
[That he does not think heat and cold are the same as snow and fire]
 θερμόν τι καλεῖς καὶ ψυχρόν;  Ἔγωγε.  Ἆρ’ ὅπερ χιόνα καὶ πῦρ;  Μὰ Δί’ οὐκ ἔγωγε.

author: Sophocles
title: Philoctetes
statement: [That he will not leave Philoctetes alone]
remarks: Philoctetes says to Neoptolemus that he will not ask for an oath, but asks instead for his hand in pledge. Cf. oath id 291.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker states that the peace stipulated that it shall not be lawful for exiles to set out under arms from states which are parties to the peace, with hostile intent against any other states included in the peace, and that if they do, those states shall be excluded from the terms of the treaty. 
He then goes on to argue that Alexander has never even put down his arms, and has restored exiles to various places, including "the paidotribes" at Sicyon. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement: n/a
remarks: In summing up Menon's character, Xenophon observes that Menon feared all whom he found to be perjurers and wrongdoers because he felt they would be well-armed against him. On the other hand Menon regarded those who were pious and truthful as weak and tried to exploit them.  The implication is that he took no account of the attitude of the gods, who could be expected to favour the latter type of person and punish the former.  Cf. oath id 2166.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That it will not be easy for brave and high-spirited guardians to refrain from being savage to each other and to the citizens, if this is their nature]
 Πῶς οὖν, ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, ὦ Γλαύκων, οὐκ ἄγριοι ἀλλήλοις τε ἔσονται καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις πολίταις, ὄντες τοιοῦτοι τὰς φύσεις;  Μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὐ ῥᾳδίως.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. Both parties were to have the same enemies
2. Both parties would defend each other in the event of an attack 
3. The Boeotians would assist the Spartans in the event of a helot revolt 
4. The oaths should be renewed each year
5. Any changes agreed to by both parties would not violate the oaths]
remarks:
According to Xenophon, in 395 the leading men in Thebes were aware that unless someone began the war the Spartans would not break the treaty with their allies. They resolved to stir up trouble between Sparta's allies, which would then force the Spartans to intervene. 
Accordingly, they persuaded the Opuntian Locrians to levy money from territory which was in dispute between Phocis and Locris, for they thought that if this was done Phocis would invade Locris. This did happen, whereupon Androcleides persuaded his fellow Thebans to make a counter invasion of Phocis on the grounds that the Locrians were their friends and allies. This alliance must have come about when the Thebans resumed their alliance with the Spartans in 421/0. Both the Thebans and the Locrians were members of the Peloponnesian League and were thus allied to each other. 
When Phocis appealed to Sparta for assistance, war between Sparta and Thebes ensued. 
See also oath id 1708.

author: Antiphon
title: On the murder of Herodes
if_broken: Destruction of self, kin and house
statement: [That they knew well that the defendant had killed]
remarks: Euxitheus, the defendant, again complains that witnesses are not under oath as they would be in a normal homicide trial. He observes, "you bid the court to believe your witnesses, in spite of their not being on oath, and pass sentence for murder".

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a reference to peace treaties as being trusted by enemies.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks:
Callistratus tells the jurors that Androcleides is present with the articles of the sworn agreement. He says that he gives consent for them to be opened during the defendant's speeches, and tells the jurors that he wishes for them to hear the agreement and the oaths that he and Olympiodorus swore to each other (see oath id 3623). He argues that if Olympiodorus refuses to read the oaths and agreements to the jurors it will be clear that he is the most shameless of men, and the jurors will be thus correct to refuse to accept anything that he says as true. 
There’s something a trifle fishy about this whole story, if we apply the regular principle that if two people confirm a business deal by oaths that means that they don’t fully trust each other; and it’s all the more remarkable in view of the fact that they were brothers-in-law.

author: Plato
title: Symposium
statement: n/a
remarks: Pausanias here explains how lovers act in ways which others would find unendurable. They will abase themselves in intolerable ways, including swearing oaths to obtain their goal, and be willing to subject themselves to servitudes such as not even a slave would endure. Anyone else behaving like that would be despised by both his enemies and his friends. Cf. oath ids 2925 and 2932.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 3
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that Philip is marching against "his allies", the Byzantines. 
See also oath id 3352 and 3353.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Praxagora has spoken well]
 νὴ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην εὖ γε ταυταγὶ λέγεις.
{Πρ.} τάλαιν’ Ἀφροδίτην ὤμοσας; χαρίεντά γ’ ἂν 
  ἔδρασας, εἰ τοῦτ’ εἶπας ἐν τἠκκλησίᾳ.
remarks: As with oath id 788, the woman, disguised as a man, gives herself away by invoking Aphrodite in her oath, as Praxagora is quick to point out. As Sommerstein notes ad 189, this is "nearly always a woman's oath, though it is used by a male character in Thesm. 254 [see oath id 707]- significantly just when he is putting on a woman's garments".

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That he entertained the ambassadors from Philip lavishly]
 καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἔγωγε καὶ τοὺς παρὰ τοῦ Φιλίππου πρέσβεις ἐξένισα, καὶ πάνυ γ’, ὦ ἄνδρες Ἀθηναῖοι, λαμπρῶς·

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
statement:
[That Socrates is not detaining him]
 Ἀλλὰ γάρ, ἔφην ἐγώ, μή σε κατακωλύω, ὦ Ἰσχόμαχε, ἀπιέναι ἤδη βουλόμενον. Μὰ Δί’, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες·

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
if_taken: Epigenes would not have to sleep with the old woman
if_refused: Epigenes will have to sleep with the old woman
statement: [That Epigenes has a legitimate reason for not sleeping with the old woman]
remarks: In an attempt to get out of having to sleep with the old woman, Epigenes suggests exwmosia, which is refused. This, as Sommerstein explains ad 1026, was "an oath declaring that one had a proper reason for failing to perform what would otherwise be one's legal duty; normally applied (1) to a witness swearing that he knew nothing of the facts about which he had been called to testify…. or (2) to a man elected to public office claiming that illness, pressures of work, etc., made it impossible for him to take the position… The allusion here is probably to (2)", though sources show (see Sommerstein ad loc. for references) that "to decline office in this way on any but medical grounds… was offensive to public sentiment, and the old woman's retort is in line with this attitude".

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That if the archer comes near Lysistrata, the third old woman will tear out his hair]
 Εἰ τἄρα νὴ τὴν Ταυροπόλον ταύτῃ πρόσει,
 ἐγὼ ’κποκιῶ σου τὰς στενοκωκύτους τρίχας.
remarks: See also 435-436, 439-440, 433-444 all of which contain similar oaths threatening the archers if they so much as touch Lysistrata. As Sommerstein notes ad 447, Tauropolos is "the title under which Artemis was worshipped at Halae Araphenides on the east coast of Attica". He also remarks on the aetiology of the title given in Euripides' IT "derived from the adventures of Orestes and Iphigeneia in the land of the Scythian Tauri" and suggests that invoking Artemis Tauropolos is thus appropriate in threatening a Scythian.

author: Euripides
title: Supplices
if_broken: The Argive land should be wretchedly destroyed
statement: [That Argives will never bring force of arms against Athens, and if others do, Argos will impede them with her spear]
remarks: See remarks on oath id 140.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
In this passage the Corinthian envoy to the Athenians argues that the Athenians will be breaking the treaty if they make an alliance with Corcyra. 
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see oath id 1524.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That if Aeschylus doesn't find a solution to Athens' problems, he will not return to earth]
  Εὕρισκε νὴ Δί’, εἴπερ ἀναδύσει πάλιν.
remarks: Dionysus' oath appears to be an imperative oath, which is, of course, logically impossible. In fact, this is a disguised conditional oath and not a true imperative. Compare the expression "laugh and the world laughs with you", which means if you laugh, the world laughs with you.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That he doesn't know what Paphlagon means (i.e. he doesn't know what Erectheus has to do with jackdaws and a dog)]
  Ταυτὶ μὰ τὴν Δήμητρ’ ἐγὼ οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅ τι λέγει.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Increases Cinesias' desire for his wife
statement:
[That his wife Myrrhine always has him on her lips; and if she's having an egg or an apple, she says "Let this be for Cinesias"]
 Ἀεὶ γὰρ ἡ γυνή σ’ ἔχει διὰ στόμα.
  Κἂν ᾠὸν ἢ μῆλον λάβῃ, «Κινησίᾳ
  τουτὶ γένοιτο,» φησίν. 
{ΚΙ.}  Ὢ πρὸς τῶν θεῶν.  
{ΛΥ.}  Νὴ τὴν Ἀφροδίτην·
remarks: There is no real way of telling whether or not this statement is true, but we would probably be right to understand it as false since Lysistrata is attempting to inflame Cinesias deceitfully at this point.

author: Eubulus
title: Mylothris
statement:
[That he is Wine (and not Vinegar/ Cheap wine)]
 τὸ δ’ ὄξος οἶνον αὑτὸ μᾶλλον θατέρου.
remarks: Presumably during some official proceedings, Vinegar swears a hupomosia that he is not who he is seemingly in an attempt not to be drunk. Cf. Wine's similar statement at oath id 1461.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
impact: None - the Old Woman does not respond
statement:
[That her boyfriend probably did say her skin smelled sweet if she was pouring out Thasian wine]
  ὄζειν τε τῆς χροιᾶς ἔφασκεν ἡδύ μου, —
 {ΧΡ.}  εἰ Θάσιον ἐνέχεις, εἰκότως γε, νὴ Δία.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That the sigmas on their shields would deceive the Argives]
 Ναὶ τὼ σιώ, ὦ Ἀργεῖοι, ψευσεῖ ὑμὲ τὰ σίγμα ταῦτα
gods_invoked: The twin gods i.e. Castor and Pollux
remarks:
Xenophon states that Pasimachus the Spartan commander took from the Sicyonians some of their shields which bore sigmas and advanced with a volunteer force against the Argives. 
The Argives were tricked into thinking that the force was made up of Sicyonians rather than Spartans and eagerly joined the battle. 
Pasimachus and many of his party were slain in the fighting.

author: Aeschines
title: Against Timarchus
statement:
[That we shall manage the polis well, if when we know that acts are taking place, we are to ignore them simply because someone does not come forward in court and testify explicitly without shame]
 νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ καλῶς ἄρα τὴν πόλιν οἰκήσομεν, εἰ ἃ αὐτοὶ ἔργῳ ἴσμεν γιγνόμενα, ταῦτα ἐὰν μή τις δεῦρο παρελθὼν σαφῶς ἅμα καὶ ἀναισχύντως μαρτυρήσῃ, διὰ τοῦτο ἐπιλησόμεθα.
remarks:
An interesting and important one, this, because it must be ironic; Aeschines clearly means the opposite of what he says (but expects to be understood as meaning the opposite of what he says, so there is no intent to deceive).  Fisher ad loc. notes that this is the only oath by Poseidon in the orators.  
With this indignant expression of disgust Aeschines is trying to distract the jurors' attention from the fact that he is asking them to accept as true a story for which he has produced no evidence whatever - indeed Hegesandrus, the alleged lover of the accused, has sworn that he does not know the statement drafted for him by Aeschines to be true, and Aeschines has said he expects Hegesandrus will be testifying for the defence.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That he thought he was studying a philosophy that would teach him all things appropriate for being a good man (but he now realises that he cannot answer Socrates' questions)]
 Ἀλλὰ νὴ τοὺς θεούς, ἔφη, ὦ Σώκρατες, πάνυ ᾤμην φιλοσοφεῖν φιλοσοφίαν δι’ ἧς ἂν μάλιστα ἐνόμιζον παιδευθῆναι τὰ προσήκοντα ἀνδρὶ καλοκαγαθίας ὀρεγομένῳ· νῦν δὲ πῶς οἴει με ἀθύμως ἔχειν, ὁρῶντα ἐμαυτὸν διὰ μὲν τὰ προπεπονημένα οὐδὲ τὸ ἐρωτώμενον ἀποκρίνεσθαι δυνάμενον ὑπὲρ ὧν μάλιστα χρὴ εἰδέναι, ἄλλην δὲ ὁδὸν οὐδεμίαν ἔχοντα ἣν ἂν πορευόμενος βελτίων γενοίμην;

author: Anonymus Philosophus
title: Dissoi Logoi
if_refused: The prisoner will not be released
statement:
[That he will betray his city]
 ὀμνύων ἦ μὰν ἀφεθεὶς τὰν πόλιν προδώσεν
remarks: Within a general discussion concerning just and unjust actions, this discussion is essentially concerned with justified oath-breaking. The author refers to a situation in which a prisoner of war swears to betray his city in exchange for release. The author then asks if such a man would be right to keep his oath and concludes that he would rather be right in breaking it and saving his city, his philoi and the ancestral temples.

author: Aristophanes
title: Birds
statement:
[That he is not thinking of flying straight to Pellene]
 Μῶν εὐθὺ Πελλήνης πέτεσθαι διανοεῖ; 
  {ΣΥ.}  Μὰ Δί’

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That anyone who's learnt the war-dance of Cinesias should be added to the list of criminals in the Underworld's sea of ever-flowing dung]
 ΔΙ. Νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς ἐχρῆν γε πρὸς τούτοισι κεἰ 
  τὴν πυρρίχην τις ἔμαθε τὴν Κινησίου
remarks: Cf. oath id 378. Cinesias was a much satirized dithyrambic poet; see further Sommerstein ad loc.

author: Plato
title: Hipparchus
statement:
[That he is not trying to deceive Socrates]
 Ὁρᾷς οὖν, ἐπιχειρεῖς με ἐξαπατᾶν, ἐπίτηδες ἐναντία λέγων οἷς ἄρτι ὡμολογήσαμεν.  {ΕΤ.} Οὐ μὰ Δία, ὦ Σώκρατες

author: Demosthenes
title: Funeral Oration
swearer: Representatives of the Greeks except the Spartans
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that the valour shown by the dead was the reason why Philip made peace with the Athenians. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

author: Lysias
title: Against Alcibiades 2
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker tells the jurors that if the generals were not entitled to enrol Alcibiades in the cavalry, they (the jurors) should reflect on their oath to decide according to justice (τὰ δίκαια γνώσεσθαι). Apparently fearing that the generals, who are acting as presiding magistrates at the trial, may themselves urge the jury to acquit Alcibiades, he argues that the jurors ought not to have more regard for these men than for themselves and their oaths. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

title: IG XII Supplement
statement: [? That the man introducing his son to the phratry believes that the young man is his son]
remarks: For the oath sworn by the father see oath id 728. For the oath sworn by the mother see oath id 730. For oaths sworn when an elder brother or an uncle introduced young man to the phratry see oath id 731 and 732.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 2
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that if the Athenians had not been hoodwinked by the other ambassadors Philip would have been forced to act fairly and observe the peace, or else he would have been engaged in a war similar to that which made him anxious for peace in the first place. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
impact: Gives added weight to his claim
statement:
[That he will not double-cross Myrrhine over their settlement ]
 μή μ’ ἐξαπατήσῃς τὰ περὶ τῶν διαλλαγῶν.  
  {ΚΙ.}  Νὴ Δί’ ἀπολοίμην.
remarks: The "settlement" refers to Myrrhine's oath at id 1202 that she will only sleep with him if he makes a settlement and stops the war.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Timotheus
if_broken: Destruction of self and dedication of property to sacred uses
statement:
[That he would indict Iphicrates as a usurper of citizen rights]
 εἰ μὴ γράψοιτο Ἰφικράτην ξενίας
remarks:
Apollodorus tells the jurors that it would be a long story to describe all the perjury of Timotheus, and relates one example, when Timotheus swore that he would indict Iphicrates as a usurper of citizen rights. According to Apollodorus, even though Timotheus swore this oath, and called down destruction upon himself if he failed to fulfil it, he later - to serve his own interests - gave his daugther in marriage to the son of Iphicrates. 
Apollodorus asks the jurors whether it was strange that he refused to allow Timotheus to swear an oath to him (see oath id 3662) when he was not ashamed to deceive the demos, and does not fear the gods in whose name he has perjured himself. 
It should be mentioned that no witnesses are called to prove that Timotheus ever said what is alleged; all we are given in the way of evidence is that old (un)reliable, "you all know".

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
impact: These cities became involved in warfare against the Dorian Greeks in Sicily and the Spartans
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks: Thucydides states that at the time of the outbreak of war in Sicily in 427, the Chalcidian cities and Camarina were allies of the Leontines.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades II
statement:
[That he does not believe there is any condition in which it would be better for anyone to be ignorant rather than knowledgeable]
 ἔστι γὰρ ὁτιοῦν πρᾶγμα ὅτῳ δὴ ὁπωσοῦν ἔχοντι ἄμεινον ἀγνοεῖν ἢ γιγνώσκειν;  {ΣΩ.} Ἔμοιγε δοκεῖ· σοὶ δ’ οὔ;  {ΑΛ.} Οὐ μέντοι μὰ Δία.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he thinks Xanthias will not be a coward]
 Καὶ βλέψον εἰς τὸν ῾Ηρακλειοξανθίαν,
  εἰ δειλὸς ἔσομαι καὶ κατὰ σὲ τὸ λῆμ’ ἔχων. 
ΔΙ.  Μὰ Δί’ ἀλλ’ ἀληθῶς οὑκ Μελίτης μαστιγίας.
remarks: Heracles had a sanctuary in the city deme of Melite, but  a designation of him as a "whipped rogue" (mastigias) would hardly be appropriate, and a scholiast suggests that Dionysus is really alluding to Callias (cf. lines 428-430) who was apparently fond of dressing up as Heracles as Xanthias has just done; if this is right, Dionysus' apparent compliment to Xanthias turns out to be no compliment at all.  See Sommerstein ad loc.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The King's country in Asia is to remain his possession and to be governed as he pleases
2. The Spartans and their allies shall not go against the country of the King, nor the King against the Spartans and their allies.
3. If any of the Spartans and their allies go against the King's territory, the Spartans and their allies shall stop them, and if any of the King's subjects go against the Spartans and their allies the King shall stop them
4. Tissaphernes shall pay for the ships now present until the arrival of the King's ships. After these arrive, the Spartans can then pay for their own ships if they wish. If not, Tissaphernes will provide money, but the Spartans will repay the money at the end of the war
5. When the King's ships arrive, the ships of the Spartans and their allies and those of the King shall wage war together, according to what seems best to Tissaphernes and the Spartans and their allies. If they wish to end the war with the Athenians, they will do so jointly.]
remarks:
Andocides states that when the Athenians abandoned their alliance with the Great King in favour of the friendship of Amorges, the bastard son of Pissuthnes the satrap of Sardis (Andocides describes him as a runaway slave) who revolted from the Great King, the Great King consequently became an ally of Sparta  and provided them with five thousand talents to prosecute the war until he had  overthrown the power of the Athenians. 
It is perhaps worth mentioning the now widespread view (much stressed e.g. by Hornblower) that this alliance with Amorges was the decisive error that lost the Peloponnesian War; for a sceptical view (of this analysis, and of And.’s evidence) see H.D. Westlake, Phoenix 31 (1977) 319-329.  (Hornblower on Thuc. 1.112.2-4 dismisses Westlake too easily; certainly Thuc. 8.5.5 shows that in 413/2 "the situation had [recently] changed in some respect", but it is by no means "obvious" that the change had to do with Athenian support for Amorges – Westlake’s case, ignored here by Hornblower, was that what had changed things was the annihilation of the Athenian fleet in Sicily.)  We should mention ML 70, which seems to support And.'s statement about an agreement in 424/3 (not mentioned by Thucydides).  Amorges was not, of course, really a "runaway slave", except in the sense in which every Persian subject was a slave of the King. 
See also oath id 1818.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
statement: n/a
remarks:
Xenophon observes that when Cyrus the younger was sent down to be satrap of Lydia, Greater Phrygia and Cappadocia and commander of all the troops in the plain of Castolus, he showed in the first place that he considered it of the utmost importance when he concluded a treaty or an agreement with anyone, or made a promise, to never be false to his word. 
See also oath id 2076.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
statement: [That Odysseus is coming home, and will be back some time during that same year and take his vengeance upon any who dishonours his wife and son]
gods_invoked: ZeusEpithet(s)first among gods; Table of xenia; Hearth of blameless Odysseus
remarks: Odysseus here refers back to the oath that Eumaeus rejected, sworn at oath id 542. See remarks there, and cf. oath ids 559 and 561.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides notes that Sitalces made an agreement and entered into an alliance with Athens to bring an end to their war with the Chalcidians in Thrace. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1567.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
statement: n/a
gods_invoked: ThemisEpithet(s)protectress of oaths, daughter of Zeus
remarks: The Chorus relate how Medea invokes Themis as protectress of oaths. See also oath id 114.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
impact: Suggests that the statement is true
statement:
[That his son, Ariphrades, without learning it from anyone "licked them up" every time he went into a brothel]
 εἶτ’ Ἀριφράδην πολύ τι θυμοσοφικώτατον,
  ὅντινά ποτ’ ὤμοσε μαθόντα παρὰ μηδενὸς 
  γλωττοποιεῖν εἰς τὰ πορνεῖ’ εἰσιόνθ’ ἑκάστοτε.
remarks: This is an alleged oath reported by the Chorus, and we have no reason to believe that it was ever actually taken. The suggestion that Ariphrades practised cunnilingus fits in well with other attacks on him for sexual perversion in Aristophanes; see Sommerstein ad 1280.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement: [That they will abide by the treaty which the King sent down, and by the decrees of the Athenians and their allies. And if anyone takes the field against any of the cities which have sworn this oath, they shall help with all their strength]
remarks:
When the Spartans sent envoys to Athens to appeal for aid against the Thebans they argued that they had done nothing wrong in attacking Mantinea because the Mantineans had violated their oaths. 
Xenophon states that most stress was placed upon the consideration that the oaths (of the Common Peace) bound Athens to help Sparta, because "the Arcadians and those with them were not attacking Sparta because Sparta had done any wrong, but because she had helped the Tegeates when the Mantineans had broken their oaths by attacking them".   
The real issue was, at one level, which of the two factions in the civil war actually counted as "the Tegeates"; at a quite different level, it was what to do about the emergence of Thebes as the leading and very nearly dominating power. 
For other references to the Common Peace of 371 see oath id 1984.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That what Praxagora is saying is great, provided she is telling the truth]
  νὴ τὸν Ποσειδῶ μεγάλα γ’, εἰ μὴ ψεύσεται.
remarks: This is with reference to Praxagora explaining that there will be no more clothes-snatching, jealousy, poverty, slander or seizures for debts.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: They could not join the conspiracy
statement: [? That they would be loyal and maintain secrecy]
remarks:
Alcibiades addressed the Athenians at Samos, and encouraged them to be hopeful about the future, exaggerating his influence over Tissaphernes.  
Thucydides states that his intention was to make the oligarchs at Athens fear him, and to destabilize the "clubs" (αἱ ξυνωμοσίαι, lit. "sworn conspiracies") at Athens which had intrigued against him, as well as to increase the fleet's confidence in itself and respect for him and to drive a wedge between the Spartans and Tissaphernes.

author: Xenophon
title: Symposium
statement:
[That he does not have even an obol]
 ὁ μὲν δὴ Ἑρμογένης ἀνήρετο εἰ πολὺ εἴη αὐτῷ ἀργύριον. ὁ δὲ ἀπώμοσε μηδὲ ὀβολόν.
remarks: This is an unusual example of a reported oath within the dialogue where one would expect direct speech with an informal oath.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
swearee: One of the friends of Sphodrias
statement:
[That they would not be following the same course as Agesilaus if they favoured putting Sphodrias to death]
 Μὰ Δία οὐκ ἄρα ταὔτ’, ἔφη, ποιήσομεν Ἀγησιλάῳ
remarks:
When one of the friends of Sphodrias said to Etymocles, "I suppose that you friends of Agesilaus are all for putting Sphodrias to death". Etymocles responded that if they wanted to put Sphodrias to death they would not be in agreement with Agesilaus, for he was constantly arguing that while Sphodrias was certainly guilty, it was very difficult to put to death a Spartan who had continually performed all the duties expected of him, because "Sparta had need of soldiers like that". 
Etymocles is thus implying that Agesilaus' friends do agree with him on this matter, and that Sphodrias' friends are wrong in their suspicions.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That it would not surprise him if men without experience of the truth believe that they are experiencing pleasure when they have merely returned to a neutral state after a spell of pain (and vice versa). In fact he would be surprised if this were not so]
 Θαυμάζοις ἂν οὖν εἰ καὶ οἱ ἄπειροι ἀληθείας περὶ πολλῶν τε ἄλλων μὴ ὑγιεῖς δόξας ἔχουσιν, πρός τε ἡδονὴν καὶ λύπην καὶ τὸ μεταξὺ τούτων οὕτω διάκεινται, ὥστε, ὅταν μὲν ἐπὶ τὸ  λυπηρὸν φέρωνται, ἀληθῆ τε οἴονται καὶ τῷ ὄντι λυποῦνται, ὅταν δὲ ἀπὸ λύπης ἐπὶ τὸ μεταξύ, σφόδρα μὲν οἴονται πρὸς πληρώσει τε καὶ ἡδονῇ γίγνεσθαι, ὥσπερ πρὸς μέλαν φαιὸν ἀποσκοποῦντες ἀπειρίᾳ λευκοῦ, καὶ πρὸς τὸ ἄλυπον οὕτω λύπην ἀφορῶντες ἀπειρίᾳ ἡδονῆς ἀπατῶνται;  Μὰ Δία, ἦ δ’ ὅς, οὐκ ἂν θαυμάσαιμι, ἀλλὰ πολὺ μᾶλλον, εἰ μὴ οὕτως ἔχει.
remarks: Plato was not to know that a couple of generations later Epicurus would maintain precisely this position!

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement: [That they will abide by the terms of the agreement]
remarks: Hierocles here explains why it is not yet right for peace to be made. This is a reference to a peace treaty (which would necessarily contain an oath), and not an offering to Peace which is in the process of taking place in the dramatic context.

author: Plato (com.)
title: Lakones or Poietai
statement: [That he is not dead]
remarks: This oath is proposed but not taken. A ghost is asked to swear that he is not dead, but does not actually swear to that or to anything at all.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Meidias
statement:
[That shamelessness, cruelty and insolence can go no farther than if a man who had done wrong to another quite terribly and repeatedly, instead of offering atonement and regret, were to go on and commit yet other worse crimes, and were to employ his wealth not to further his own interests without harming others, but for the opposite purpose of driving his victims into exile unjustly, and then congratulate himself on his own affluence] 
 ἄνθρωπος εἰ ποιήσας δεινὰ νὴ Δία καὶ πόλλα ἀδίκως τινά, ἀντὶ τοῦ ταῦτ’ ἀναλαμβάνειν καὶ μεταγιγνώσκειν, ἔτι πολλῷ δεινότερα ὕστερον ἄλλα προσεξεργάζοιτο, καὶ χρῷτο τῷ πλουτεῖν μὴ ἐπὶ ταῦτ’ ἐν οἷς μηδένα βλάπτων αὐτὸς ἄμεινόν τι τῶν ἰδίων θήσεται, ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ τἀναντία, ἐν οἷς ἀδίκως ἐκβάλων τινὰ καὶ προπηλακίσας αὑτὸν εὐδαιμονιεῖ τῆς περιουσίας;
remarks: Demosthenes asks what the limit of wickedness is, and what shamelessness, cruelty and insolence could one go beyond, if Meidias behaves as he has done.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
impact: Encourages the Innkeeper in telling her story
statement:
[That the Innkeeper thought the man drawing his sword had gone mad]
ΠΑ. Αʹ  καὶ τὸ ξίφος γ’ ἐσπᾶτο μαίνεσθαι δοκῶν.
  Πλ.  Νὴ Δία, τάλαινα.
remarks: See also oath ids 398 and 399.

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he could not sell the donkey as well as Philocleon, but better]
 οὔκουν κἂν ἐγὼ  
  αὐτὸν ἀποδοίμην δῆτ’ ἄν;
 {Φι.}  οὐχ ὥσπερ γ’ ἐγώ.  
 {Βδ.}  μὰ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἄμεινον.

author: Isaeus
title: On the Estate of Philoctemon
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
The speaker expresses hope that the jurors will vote according to their oaths, and that justice shall be done to his clients. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Lysias
title: Against Eratosthenes
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
According to Lysias, after Theramenes addressed the Athenians and proposed that they entrust the city to thirty men, Lysander also addressed the Athenians, informing them that they were guilty of breaking the truce, and that they would pay with their lives if they refused to do what Theramenes suggested. 
For another version of these events cf. Plut. Lysander 15. 
For other references to the peace treaty and alliance of 404, see also oath id 1893.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement:
[That he thinks the reaction of the Athenians was natural when they didn't listen to Demosthenes, and only wanted to listen to Aeschines]
 καὶ νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς εἰκός τι παθεῖν ἔμοιγε δοκεῖτε·
remarks: Demosthenes argues that the Athenians listened to Aeschines rather than himself because they were expecting success, and did not want to hear criticism.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Leptines
statement:
[That he framed his law in the way that he did because the demos is easily deceived]
 ἀλλὰ νὴ Δι’ ἐκεῖν’ ἂν ἴσως εἴποι πρὸς ταῦτα, ὅτι διὰ τὸ ῥᾳδίως ἐξαπατᾶσθαι τὸν δῆμον, διὰ τοῦθ’ οὕτως ἔθηκε τὸν νόμον.
remarks:
Demosthenes argues that by inserting a clause in his law that "none shall be exempt," Leptines has taken away the right of the demos to bestow privileges. 
He imagines that Leptines might object that the demos is easily fooled into bestowing privileges upon unworthy recipients.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 3-4
statement:
[That not only can he explain what actions exhibit justice, he can also explain which exhibit injustice]
 Μὴ οὖν, ἔφη ὁ Εὐθύδημος, οὐ δύναμαι ἐγὼ τὰ τῆς δικαιοσύνης ἔργα ἐξηγήσασθαι; καὶ νὴ Δί’ ἔγωγε τὰ τῆς ἀδικίας·

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other, and that they would respect the division of Cotys' former kingdom and not attempt to change the settlement by force, and that the Athenians would receive back their possessions ]
remarks:
Aeschines argues that Demosthenes is charging him with having destroyed the cities in Phocis, losing the territory in Thrace, and removing from power Cersobleptes, a friend and ally of Athens. 
For the decree announcing the alliance between Athens and Cersobleptes (and Berisades and Amadacous of thrace) see oath id 458.

author: Xenophon
title: Memorabilia 1b-2
statement:
[That he is not free to say what he chooses about Critobulus (because he will do Critobulus no good by praising him falsely)]
 Τί οὖν, ἔφη ὁ Κριτόβουλος, ἐμοὶ τοῦτο λέγεις, ὥσπερ οὐκ ἐπὶ σοὶ ὂν ὅ τι ἂν βούλῃ περὶ ἐμοῦ λέγειν; Μὰ Δί’ οὐχ

author: Aeschines
title: On the Embassy
swearee: Representatives of the Spartans and their allies
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The Athenians were to demolish the Long Walls and the Piraeus wall 
2. The Athenians were to surrender all but twelve of their ships
3. The Athenians were to receive back their exiles
4. The Athenians were to have the same enemies and friends as the Spartans
5. The Athenians were to follow the Spartans where they might lead on land and sea]
remarks:
Aeschines compares the Peace of Philocrates with the peace treaty between Athens and Sparta in 404. He highlights the fact that the Athenians were compelled to receive a garrison and a Spartan harmost, and the fact that they were forced to surrender the democracy to the Thirty who put 1500 citizens to death without trial. 
For other references to this treaty see oath id 1893.

author: Andocides
title: On the Peace with Sparta
swearer: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
swearee: Representatives; Representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the other Greeks
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the peace: i.e. that the Greek states were to be autonomous, with the exception of  those in Asia (which were to belong to the King) and Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros (which were to belong to Athens)]
remarks:
Andocides observes that the Argives and Corinthians are at hand to show the Athenians that it is better to make war, while the Spartans have come to persuade them to make peace. 
Andocides observes that soon each Athenian in the assembly will raise his hand in favour of war or peace and warns them to vote in such a way as will never cause regret. 
For other references to the proposed peace of 392/1 see also oath id 2393.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That he is celebrating  the Mysteries as a donkey (i.e. doing all the work and getting none of the benefits]
  Νὴ τὸν Δί’ ἐγὼ γοῦν ὄνος ἄγω μυστήρια.
remarks: Xanthias picks up Heracles' reference to mystic initiates at 158 and refers once more to the load he is carrying, as an aside to the spectators.

author: Plato
title: Alcibiades I
statement:
[That he doesn't know what he is saying]
 Ἀλλὰ μὰ τοὺς θεούς, ὦ Σώκρατες, οὐκ οἶδ’ ἔγωγε οὐδ’ ὅτι λέγω
remarks: Socrates has forced Alcibiades into recognising that his previous claims do not make sense. Cf. oath id 2963 where Aclibiades makes almost exactly the same oath statement.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Dionysodorus
statement:
[That the contract does not say what Dionysodorus says it does]
 οὐ μὰ Δί’ οὐ ταῦτα ἃ σὺ λέγεις, ὦ Διονυσόδωρε·

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Crown
statement: [That there was nothing between him and Philip]
remarks:
Demosthenes claims that when the city suffered a setback Aeschines admitted "to those connections" which he had denied under oath when the city was prospering. 
See also oath id 3387.

author: Plato
title: Letter VII
impact: Emphasises a tyrant's failure to keep to his agreements
statement:
[That Dionysius did indeed make an agreement not to harm Heracleides]
 καὶ ὃς ἐμβλέψας μοι καὶ μάλα τυραννικῶς, “Σοί,” ἔφη, “ἐγὼ οὔτε  τι σμικρὸν οὔτε μέγα ὡμολόγησα.” “Νὴ τοὺς θεούς,” ἦν δ’ ἐγώ, “σύ γε, ταῦτα ἃ σοῦ νῦν οὗτος δεῖται μὴ ποιεῖν·”
remarks: The exchange reported takes place during Plato's third Sicilian visit. Dionysius has just angrily denied making any such agreement with Plato (a denial which is technically, but only technically, true; he made the promise to Theodotes in Plato’s presence).

author: Demosthenes
title: On the False Embassy
statement: [That they will vote according to the laws and decrees of the Athenian people and the Council of Five Hundred; <and concerning matters about which there are no laws, they will judge according to their perfectly honest opinion, and not from favour nor from enmity>. Nor will they accept gifts for judging, nor will any other man or woman do so on their behalf with their knowledge. And they will give an equal hearing to the accuser and the defendant alike, and cast their vote in relation to the actual matter in issue.]
remarks:
Demosthenes warns the jurors not to listen to Aeschines' brothers who will speak on his behalf. He argues that while it is proper for Philochares and Aphobetus to be concerned for Aeschines, the jurors should be concerned for the laws, the whole city, and the oaths by virtue of which they sit as jurors. 
He argues that Aeschines and his supporters make a general request to acquit Aeschines (i.e. without proving that Aeschines is innocent) they are asking the jurors to commit perjury. 
For the details of the Heliastic oath see oath id 3494.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides lists the states that supported Athens against Syracuse at 7.57.1-11. He observes that some came as subjects, some as allies, and some as mercenaries. Thucydides includes the Argives as allies, observing that they were fighting out of hatred for Sparta. 
For other references to this alliance see oath id 1756 and 1797. See also oath id 255.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That Chremes is ashamed to face his bag]
 ἀλλ’ ὕστερος νῦν ἦλθον, ὥστ’ αἰσχύνομαι. 
 {Βλ.}  μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐδέν’ ἄλλον ἢ τὸν θύλακον.
remarks: The point is, as Sommerstein puts it ad 382, that "the (personified) bag, into which Chremes would have put the purchases he was going to make in the Agora with his three obols, has now been cheated of its expectations owing to his tardiness and is now having to go home empty".

title: IC IV
statement: [? That his verdict was true]
remarks:
According to the text if some of the next-of-kin wish to divide inherited property but others do not, the judge shall decide under oath (ὀμνύντα) with reference to the pleas. 
See also oath id 1115.

author: Euripides
title: Cyclops
statement:
[That Silenus will not hand over the wine until he sees the Cyclops taking the garland, and Silenus has a little taste]
 Κυ. ἀπολεῖς· δὸς οὕτως. 
  Σι. οὐ μὰ δί’, οὐ πρὶν ἄν γέ σε
  στέφανον ἴδω λαβόντα γεύσωμαί τ’ ἔτι.
remarks: L has ναὶ μὰ δί’ but Seaford (1984) ad loc. quotes Paley on this reading as being 'strangely combined with a following negation', and further remarks that it 'is defensible only as part of the slapstick: Sil. buys time by agreeing to Pol.'s request, but then immediately, in order to take another gulp, qualifies this agreement. But probably we should read οὐ [an emendation by Wecklein]'.

author: Thucydides
title: History
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Thucydides states that the Thessalians sent a force to assist the Athenians in a skirmish at Phrygia in 431, "in accordance with the old alliance" i.e. the alliance made in 462/1. 
See also oath id 1553.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
statement: see remarks
remarks: Athena here proposes to Telemachus that he should call the gods as witnesses when addressing the assembly.  He is to promise that if the suitors go back to their homes, he will let his mother, if she wishes, go to her father's house so that he (Icarius) can give her in second marriage.   In fact, Telemachus in his opening speech mentions this proposal only indirectly (2.50-54) and then breaks down without being able to complete his speech; the proposal comes instead from Antinous (2.113-4) - but without the crucial qualifier "if she wishes" - and Telemachus then refuses to drive his mother out against her will (2.130-7).  He does in the end say that he will give her to a new husband if he learns that Odysseus is dead, or (by implication) if Odysseus has still failed to return after another year (2.218-223), but he does not back this statement by an oath (it being quite clear by now that there is no prospect of the suitors leaving his house voluntarily).

author: Aristophanes
title: Wasps
statement:
[That he never used to be so slow]
 ὦ Κωμία, βραδύνεις. 
  μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ μέντοι πρὸ τοῦ γ’

title: IG II(2)
statement:
[That they would conduct the audit according to the decree inscribed in the agora]
 [εὐθύνεν κατ]ὰ τὸ ψήφισμα τὸ ἐ[ν τῆι ἀγορᾶι ἀναγεγ]ραμμένον
remarks:
This is a deme decree from Halai Aixonides outlining a new procedure for auditing the accounts of officials after they have left office. 
The text indicates that the demarch will administer an oath, and the paredroi shall then audit the accounts of the outgoing officials according to the decree set up in the agora (ἐξορκούτω [δὲ ὁ δήμαρχος τὸν εὔ]θυνον καὶ τὸς πα[ρέδος εὐθύνεν κατ]ὰ τὸ ψήφισμα τὸ ἐ[ν τῆι ἀγορᾶι ἀναγεγ]ραμμένον· ἐὰν δὲ [- - - -] καὶ μὴ ἐξέλωσι[ν τὴν εὔθυναν κατὰ τόδε] τὸ [ψ]ή[φι]σ[μα?]).

author: Alexis
title: Phaidros
statement:
[That a certain person [it may be the addressee or someone else] has been remarkably slow in squandering his property]
 σχολῇ γε, νὴ τὸν ἥλιον, σχολῇ λέγεις.
remarks: Arnott comments ad loc. that this line is "probably the opening… of one speaker's riposte to another's criticism of the speed with which some young man in the play has dissipated his fortune".

author: Aristophanes
title: Peace
statement:
[That the beetle-maul's a splendid thing when it's ready for action, and the three-pronged forks gleam brightly in the sun]
 Νὴ Δί’ἡ γοῦν σφῦρα λαμπρὸν ἦν ἄρ’ ἐξωπλισμένη, 
 αἵ τε θρίνακες διαστίλβουσι πρὸς τὸν ἥλιον.
remarks: Sommerstein comments ad 564-7: "it is as if the Greeks who have so long been waging war destructively upon each other are now turning to wage war constructively upon the devastation their countryside has suffered".

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
statement:
[That it seems to him to be better to bring Pharsalus over to his side willingly rather than unwillingly]
 ὅτι νὴ Δία τῷ παντὶ κρεῖττόν μοι δοκεῖ εἶναι ἑκόντας ὑμᾶς μᾶλλον ἢ ἄκοντας προσαγαγέσθαι.
remarks: Polydamas told the Spartans that when he asked Jason of Pherae why he did not attack Pharsalus at once because of his military resources, Jason replied that he hoped to bring Pharsalus over to him willingly rather than by force.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That he will tell Socrates what old age is like, in his opinion]
 Ἐγώ σοι, ἔφη, νὴ τὸν Δία ἐρῶ, ὦ Σώκρατες, οἷόν γέ μοι φαίνεται.
remarks: The dramatic date of the Republic is impossible to determine precisely. Some features, such as the first festival of the Bendideia, suggest a date in the early 420s. Others, such as the presence of Lysias and Polemarchus in Athens, and the great age of Sophocles, suggest a date around 410.

author: Xenophon
title: Anabasis
swearer: Tissaphernes; The brother of the King's wife
if_refused: There would not be a treaty
statement: [That the territory the Greeks pass through shall be friendly, and that they shall lead the Ten Thousand back to Greece without treachery, providing them with a market; and wherever they do not furnish the Ten Thousand with a market they will allow them to take provisions from the country]
remarks:
Book 3 begins with a summary of the previous book. Xenophon notes that the preceding chapter described "all that took place after the death of Cyrus while the Greeks were on the way back with Tissaphernes during the period of the truce". 
For other references to the treaty between the Ten Thousand and the Persians, see also oath id 2098.

author: Demosthenes
title: On the Treaty with Alexander
swearer: Representatives; Representatives of Greek states except Sparta
if_taken: They would be party to the peace and alliance
if_refused: They would not be party to the peace and alliance
statement: [That they would abide by the peace(?)and neither break the agreement with Philip (?)nor take up arms for harm against any of those who abide by the oaths (?)neither by land nor by sea; nor would they take any polis or guardpost nor harbour, for war, of any of those participating in the peace, by any craft or contrivance; nor would they overthrow the kingdom of Philip or his descendants, nor the constitutions existing in each state when they swore the oaths concerning the peace; nor would they do anything contrary to these agreements, nor allow anyone else as far as possible; if anyone did commit any breach of treaty concerning the agreements, they would go in support as called on by those who are wronged (?)and would make war against the one who transgresses the common peace (?)as decided by the common synedrion and the hegemon; and they would not abandon..]
gods_invoked: Zeus; Gaia; Helios; Poseidon; Athena; Ares; All the gods and goddesses
remarks:
The speaker cites a clause in the agreement which reads, "if we will be parties to the common peace". He apparently argues (the text is obscure, in part ungrammatical, and probably corrupt or defective) that "if we will" also means "if we ever ought to cease shamefully following others, and forgetting those honours, of which we, beyond all people, have won so many from the earliest time", and again argues that the Athenians should declare war because the agreement has been broken. 
For other references to the League of Corinth see oath id 479.

title: Rhodes and Osborne, GHI
if_kept: May their polis be free from sickness, and remain unsacked; may the land bear fruit; may women bear children like to their parents; may cattle bear young like to cattle
if_broken: May their polis be afflicted with sickness and be sacked; may the land be barren; may the women and the cattle bear monsters
statement:
[That they would fight while they lived, and not put life before being free, and not desert the taxiarch nor the enomotarch, neither while they (the officers) live nor when they are dead, and that they would not depart unless the leaders led the way, and they would do whatever the generals command, and they would bury in the same place the dead of those who were allied and leave none unburied, and when they had been victorious fighting against the barbarians they would (totally destroy and) dedicate a tenth of the city of the Thebans, and that they would not raze Athens or Sparta or Plataea or any of the other poleis that were allied, nor let them be coerced by hunger, nor keep them from running water, whether they were friends or enemies] 
 μαχοῦμαι ἕως ἂν ζῶ, καὶ οὐ περὶ πλέονος ποήσομαι τὸ ζῆν ἢ τὸ ἐλεύθερος εἶναι, καὶ οὐκ ἀπολείψω τὸν ταξίαρχον οὐδὲ τὸν ἐνωμοτάρχην οὔτε ζῶντα οὔτε ἀποθανόντα, καὶ οὐκ ἄπειμι ἐὰμ μὴ οἱ ἡγεμόνες ἀφηγῶνται, καὶ ποήσω ὅ τι ἂν οἱ στρατηγοὶ παραγγείλωσιν, καὶ τοὺς ἀποθανόντας τῶν συμμαχεσαμένων θάψω ἐν τῶι αὐτῶι καὶ ἄθαπτον οὐδένα καταλείψω· καὶ νικήσας μαχόμενος τοὺς βαρβάρους δεκατεύσω τὴν Θηβαίων πόλιν, καὶ οὐκ ἀναστήσω Ἀθήνας οὐδὲ Σπάρτην οὐδὲ Πλαταιὰς οὐδὲ τῶν ἄλλων πόλεων τῶν συμμαχεσαμένων οὐδεμίαν, οὐδὲ τῶν λιμῶι περιόψομαι ἐργομένους οὐδὲ ὑδάτων ναματιαίων εἴρξω οὔτε φίλους ὄντας οὔτε πολεμίους. καὶ εἰ μὲν ἐμπεδορκοίην τὰ ἐν τῶι  ὅρκωι γεγραμμένα, ἡ πόλις ἡμὴ ἄνοσος εἴη, εἰ δὲ μή, νοσοίη· καὶ πόλις ἡμὴ ἀπόρθητος εἴη, εἰ δὲ μή, πορθοῖτο· καὶ φέροι ἡμή, εἰ δὲ μή, ἄφορος εἴη· καὶ γυναῖκες τίκτοιεν ἐοικότα γονεῦσιν, εἰ δὲ μή, τέρατα· καὶ βοσκήματα τίκτοι ἐοικότα βοσκήμασι, εἰ δὲ μή, τέρατα.
remarks:
This text was set up in the mid-fourth century, and records the oath sworn prior to the battle of Plataea. 
Herodotus does not mention this oath, although he speaks of a similar oath being sworn at Thermopylae. 
Theopompus (fr. 153) dismissed the oath as ficticious (see oath id 3649), but Lycurgus quoted an almost identical oath (oath id 2747) and so did Diodorus (11.29.2f) presumably when using Ephorus. Both of these sources place the taking of the oath at the Isthmus. 
For a discussion which argues that this oath is an altered version of the oath of the sworn bands at Sparta (oath id 1272), see Hans van Wees, "The Oath of the Sworn Bands, the Acharnae stele, the Oath of Plataea and archaic Spartan warfare", in A. Luther. M. Meier, & L. Thommen (eds.), Das Fruhe Sparta, Franz Steiner, Stuttgart 2006, pp.125-64. 
This stone also records the ancestral oath sworn by the Athenian ephebes (see oath id 340).

author: Sophocles
title: Oedipus Coloneus
statement:
[That he will bring Oedipus' daughters back safely] 
 ὧν γὰρ ὤμοσ’ οὐκ ἐψευσάμην 
οὐδέν σε, πρέσβυ. τάσδε γὰρ πάρειμ’ ἄγων
ζώσας, ἀκραιφνεῖς τῶν κατηπειλημένων.
remarks: Theseus refers to his statement at 1040-1041 as an oath although he did not actually swear anything.  For another example in which a Sophoclean character says he has sworn to something when he has not, compare oath id 236. Cf. also oath ids 263, 270, 285, 289.

author: Plato
title: Cratylus
statement:
[That Cratylus was quite right to say that he (Hermogenes) was no true son of Hermes (since he is not skilled at making speeches)]
 Νὴ τὸν Δία, εὖ ἄρα μοι δοκεῖ Κρατύλος λέγειν τὸ ἐμὲ μὴ εἶναι Ἑρμογένη· οὔκουν εὐμήχανός γέ εἰμι λόγου.
remarks: Socrates has just provided an etymology for the name Hermes according to which its original meaning is "crafty speaker".

title: SEG
if_taken: They would be party to the treaty
statement: [? That they would abide by the terms of the treaty]
remarks:
This inscription records a treaty between Naupactus and Messene.  
The text is too fragmentary to be fully restored. It is clear that the Locrians, the Messenians and a group described as the "-atidae" (or "-atides") swore the oath before the oath officials known as the "horkisteroi". A group of officials known as the "iduoi" were to ensure that the oath was sworn or those not swearing were punished. If they failed to do so, they would pay a fine. 
Those who refused to swear the oath were to pay a fine. The staters were to be sacred to Athena i.e. paid into the treasury of Athena Polias. 
Those who break their oath were to be cursed by Athena Polias, their property confiscated, and to set up "hammered statues".

title: IG XII 8
statement: This decree covers all oaths sworn during the oligarchy, so no single oath-statement can be referred to.
remarks:
This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 38.851. 
This decree was passed upon the restoration of democracy at Thasos in 407, and concerns the repealing of motions passed during the oligarchy. 
In line 15 the text states "let all things he put to the vote or oath he swore(during the oligarchy) be invalid"[ἐπιψηφί]ζηι ἢ ὅρκον ὀμνύηι πάντα ἀκρα[τῆ ἔστω]. In line 13 the texts reads "neither decree, nor oath", which presumably also refers to the nullification of oaths and decrees from the period of the oligarchy.

author: Aristophanes
title: Ecclesiazusae
statement:
[That she would have been better off without a beard]
 νὴ τὸν Δί’, ἦ μοι μὴ γενειᾶν κρεῖττον ἦν·
remarks: The woman here is referring to her man's disguise. Her oath is followed by the complaint that she is thirsty, which, as Sommerstein explains is "not because the beard itself has made her thirsty…, but because she was led to expect a drink and then did not get it".

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
if_taken: The vote would be taken again
if_refused: The vote would not be taken again
statement: [That the outcome of the vote had been wrongly judged]
remarks: Sommerstein comments ad loc.: "The term hupomosia was applied to various procedures by which an objection could be raised on oath which would obstruct or delay an Assembly decision or court case, but the reference here is to one of these procedures in particular. When the Assembly voted, as it normally did, by show of hands, its presiding officers estimated which side had the majority and announced their decision to the meeting. If any citizen asserted on oath that the outcome had been wrongly judged, the vote was taken again…. It would appear that Neocleides had been in the habit of challenging vote declarations in this way: Asclepius, by making him totally blind, wishes to make it impossible for him to do so, since no one who had not seen the hands go up could possibly swear that the vote had been incorrectly assessed". One possible inference from Xen. Hell. 1.7.34 (our only other source for this particular variety of hypomosia; see oath id 2004) might be that on any given motion the vote could only be repeated once.

author: Demosthenes
title: Philippic 4
swearer: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
swearee: Philip of Macedon; Philip of Macedon's representatives; Representatives; Representatives of the allies of Athens
remarks:
Demosthenes alleges that Philip has violated the peace many times. 
For other references to the Peace of Philocrates see oath id 2517.

author: Plato
title: Phaedrus
statement:
[That (not only has he never heard of the rhetorical treatise of Palamedes), he has never heard of the rhetorical treatise of Nestor]
 Ἀλλ’ ἦ τὰς Νέστορος καὶ Ὀδυσσέως τέχνας μόνον περὶ λόγων ἀκήκοας, ἃς ἐν Ἰλίῳ σχολάζοντες συνεγραψάτην, τῶν δὲ Παλαμήδους ἀνήκοος γέγονας;  {ΦΑΙ.} Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δί’ ἔγωγε τῶν Νέστορος

author: Aristotle
title: Politics
statement: n/a
remarks: This is a discussion of how to avoid perjury in a jury system proposed by Hippodamus of Miletus. He proposed that each juryman could return verdicts of "guilty", "not guilty" or "guilty on some counts only". This was to avoid the established custom of giving simple "guilty" or "not guilty" verdicts, which forces jurors to commit perjury (if they believe that the accused is only partly guilty). See Aristotle's response to this at oath id 1619.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Olympiodorus
if_refused: There would not be an agreement
statement: [That they would in truth divide fairly and honestly all the visible property of Comon, and that neither would in any respect take advantage of the other in regard to Comon's estate, that they would make joint inquiry for the rest, and would act in common in forming whatever plans should from time to time be necessary]
remarks: Callistratus tells the jurors that when they found that one of Comon's slaves - a certain Moschion - had stolen 1000 drachmas from the estate of Comon - they made him hand over about 600 drachmas (he claimed he had spent the rest) and made a fair division, "in accordance with the oaths" they had sworn (see oath id 3623).

author: Xenophon
title: Cyropaedia
if_taken: He will gain the trust of the Carians
if_refused: He will not gain the trust of the Carians
statement:
[That he will enter the walls of the Carians without treachery and for the advantage of those who receive him]
 αὐτὸς δὲ ὀμόσαι θέλειν ἀδόλως εἰσιέναι εἰς τὰ τείχη καὶ ἐπ’ ἀγαθῷ τῶν δεχομένων.
remarks: Cf. oath id 2463.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [That they would have the same friends and enemies as the Spartans and would follow the Spartans whithersoever they might lead]
remarks:
Xenophon observes that he has already noted that the Phliasians remained steadfast in their alliance with the Spartans. 
See also oath id 2033. 
For other references to the Peloponnesian League see oath id 1517.

author: Aristophanes
title: Frogs
statement:
[That Oedipus did not "become" the most wretched of mortals (i.e. he already was)]
  ΕΥ. «εἶτ’ ἐγένετ’ αὖθις ἀθλιώτατος βροτῶν.»
  ΑΙ.  Μὰ τὸν Δί’ οὐ δῆτ’
remarks: Cf. oath id 503.

author: Thucydides
title: History
statement:
[? That they would abide by the following terms:
1. The peace was to last for thirty years
2. Athens was to give up Nisaea, Pagae, Troezen and Achaea
3. Neither side was to make an armed attack on the other
4. Disputes were to be submitted to arbitration
5. Each side was to keep what it possessed at the date of the conclusion of the treaty
6. Lists of the allies on each side were included
7. Any state not listed (except Argos) could ally itself with either side
8. Athens could establish friendly relations (but not an alliance) with Argos]
remarks:
According to Thucydides, the Corinthians were afraid that the Athenians would consider that the treaty had been broken because they had engaged them in battle at Corcyra.  
For other references to the Thirty Years' Peace see also oath id 1524.

author: Euripides
title: Iphigenia in Tauris
impact: Iphigenia is free to contrive her escape plan
statement:
[That the Chorus will keep silent about everything that Iphigenia has asked them to keep silent about (i.e. the escape plan)]
 ὡς ἔκ γ’ ἐμοῦ σοι πάντα σιγηθήσεται
  (ἴστω μέγας Ζεύς) ὧν ἐπισκήπτεις πέρι.

author: Aristophanes
title: Lysistrata
statement:
[That she will not abstain from sex]
  Μὰ Δί’ οὐδ’ ἔγωγ’ ἄν

author: Aristophanes
title: Wealth
statement:
[That everyone (who comes into possession of Wealth) becomes wicked]
  Ἔχει μὲν οὕτως, εἰσὶ δ’ οὐ πάντες κακοί.  
  {ΠΛ.}  Μὰ Δί’, ἀλλ’ ἁπαξάπαντες.

author: Xenophon
title: Oeconomicus
date: After the death of Cyrus (401) (401 to 399)
statement:
[That Cyrus would have proved himself an excellent leader had he lived]
  Καὶ ναὶ μὰ Δί’, ἔφη ὁ Σωκράτης, Κῦρός γε, εἰ ἐβίωσεν, ἄριστος ἂν
δοκεῖ ἄρχων γενέσθαι·
remarks: The Cyrus mentioned here is Cyrus the Younger, confusing after a mention of Cyrus the Great (in 4.16). Sommerstein (in correspondence) notes though that the particle-combination καὶ … γε “and also” shows that the two men are in fact clearly distinguished even though they are referred to by the same name.  There is a general tendency in antiquity, to us surprising, to refer casually to different persons of the same name in close proximity and rely on the context to distinguish between them; this tendency is particularly noticeable in speeches in inheritance lawsuits (such as those of Isaeus), where translators are forced to insert Roman numerals in brackets to make it clear whether the speaker is talking about (say) Dicaeogenes I, II or III when the speaker himself just says Dicaeogenes, every time.  Cf. also, for example, Ar. Acharnians 46-51 where a character gives his name as Amphitheus, then says “Amphitheus was the son of Demeter and Triptolemus”, and then gives a genealogy which makes him the great-grandson of this earlier Amphitheus – a passage which can’t be translated without amplification, e.g. speaking of “the first Amphitheus” or “the original Amphitheus.”  In our passage it would be easy for a listener or reader to distinguish between the Cyrus of 4.16, who is described as having (actually) been an excellent king, and the Cyrus of 4.18 of whom it can only be said that he would have been one had he lived to reign.

author: Xenophon
title: Agesilaus
swearer: Representatives; Pharsalian representatives; Crannonian representatives; Scotussian representatives; Larissan representatives
swearee: Representatives; Pharsalian representatives; Crannonian representatives; Scotussian representatives; Larissan representatives
if_refused: There would not be an alliance
statement: [? That they would defend each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that the Larissans, Crannonians, Scotussians and Pharsalians were allies of the Boeotians and molested Agesilaus when he returned from Asia in 394. 
See also oath id 2020.

author: Plato
title: Republic
statement:
[That settling the law concerning the possession of women and the rearing of children in the ideal state does not seem an easy thing]
 ὤκνουν ἅπτεσθαι τοῦ νόμου τοῦ περὶ τὴν τῶν γυναικῶν καὶ παίδων κτῆσιν καὶ τροφήν. Οὐ μὰ τὸν Δία, ἔφη· οὐ γὰρ εὐκόλῳ ἔοικεν.

author: Xenophon
title: Hellenica
if_refused: There would not be a truce
statement: [? That they would not attack each other]
remarks:
Xenophon states that a certain Apollophanes of Cyzicus who was a friend of both Pharnabazus and Agesilaus suggested to Agesilaus that he could persuade Pharnabazus to a conference with regard to establishing friendly relations. 
Agesilaus then obtained a truce and a pledge, and brought Pharnabazus to the place which had been agreed upon. 
See also oath id 2306.

title: IG XII 5
if_taken: The agreement and reconciliation will be formalised
statement:
[That they would remain guileless with regard to the agreements which Alcides made on behalf of the Thasians with the Neapolitans, and they would not transgress the agreement by any means, not by craft or by contrivance, or in words, or in actions; and they would not assist others to transgress the agreement to the best of their ability, neither citizens nor foreigners; and they would bear no malice for actions from before the agreement and the oath, neither for private citizens, nor magistrates, and they would not plan any evil?] 
 [ἐμ]μενέω ἀδόλως τῆις σ̣[υνθήκαις ἅς συνέθετο - - - ὑ]πὲρ Θασίων Ἀλκείδ̣η̣[ς - - - - - πρὸς τοὺς Νεο]π̣ο̣λ̣ί̣τ̣α̣ς καὶ οὐ παρα̣β̣[ήσομαι οὐδενὶ τρόπωι οὐδὲ τέχνηι οὐ]δὲ μηχανῆι οὔτε λό̣[γωι οὔτε ἔργωι - - - - τὰς συνθή]κας· οὐδὲ ἄλλωι ἐπιτρ[έψω παραβῆναι ἐς τὸ δυνατὸν οὔ]τε ἀστῶι οὔτε ξένω[ι· οὐδὲ μνησικακήσω - - - - τ]ῶμ παρικότων ὅσα [ἐγένετο πρὸ τῶν συνθηκῶν τῶνδε καὶ το̃ ὅρκο τοῦδε οὔτε ἰδ[ιώτης οὔτε ἄρχων· - - - - τ]όδε καὶ β̣ο̣λεύσω κα̣κ̣[ὸν οὐδὲν? - - - -]
remarks:
This inscription records the agreement and reconciliation between Thasos and the Neapolitans in Thrace. 
The text is very fragmentary. This entry takes into account textual changes in SEG 38.852.  
For the corresponding oath of the Neapolitans see oath id 913.

author: Demosthenes
title: Against Aristocrates
statement:
[That the Athenians were fairly tricked and misled]
 ὅτι νὴ Δί’ εἰκότως ἐφενακίσθητε καὶ παρεκρούσθητε
remarks: Euthycles argues that no one can object that it was reasonable for the Athenians to be tricked regarding affairs in northern Greece.

author: Eupolis
title: Marikas
statement: unknown
remarks: The passage is too fragmentary to reconstruct the oath statement. Diocles was a Megarian hero (see Olson on Ach. 774-5, and Gow on Theocritus 12.29), but the scholiast here seems to think that Διοκλέα in this passage is just a humorous extension of Δία – perhaps, one might suggest, with reference to some contemporary of the name.

title: Frogs

author: Isocrates
title: Panegyricus
if_refused: Artaxerxes would wage war on them by land and by sea, with ships and with money
statement:
[That they would abide by the peace which the King sent down]
 αἱ πόλεις ἐμμενεῖν ἐν τῇ εἰρήνῃ ἣν κατέπεμψε βασιλεύς 
Artaxerxes imposed his terms in the following letter:
"King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia should belong to him, as well as Clazomenae and Cyprus among the islands, and that the other Greek cities, both small and great, should be left independent, except Lemnos, Imbros, and Scyros; and these should belong, as of old, to the Athenians. But whichever of the two parties does not accept this peace, upon them I will make war, in company with those who desire this arrangement, both by land and by sea, with ships and with money".
remarks:
Isocrates argues that the most monstrous thing to see is the Spartans making an alliance for all time with the barbarians when they claim the right to lead the Greeks. 
This is presumably a reference to the fact that both Sparta and Persia have declared they were prepared to use force against any violator of the King's Peace, and have on one or more occasions actually done so. 
For other references to the King's Peace and its impact see oath id 1956.

author: Aristophanes
title: Knights
statement:
[That things aren't in such a state yet that the Sausage-seller will overcome him]
 κατεργάσει γὰρ ῥᾳδίως πλευρὰς ἔχων τοιαύτας.
 {ΠΑ.} Οὐκ, ὦγαθοί, ταῦτ’ ἐστί πω ταύτῃ μὰ τὸν Ποσειδῶ.
